Paid Notice: Deaths   JONES, ALBERTA CONWAY JONES
description: JONES -- Alberta Conway Jones. Age 87, passed away on February 27, 2006, at her Stamford home. Beloved wife of the late Edwin M. Jones. Cherished sister of Lois Conway Crabill of Rego Park, NY, and the late Elaine C. McLaughlin and Hewitt Conway. Loving mother of Michele Delmhorst of Stonington, CT, Karen Fronio of Kerhonkson, NY, Tina Will of Fredericksburg, VA, Edwin M. Jones, Jr., of Stamford, CT, and Marianne McNee of Westport, CT. Devoted grandmother to Ian, Ruth, Matthew, Sarah, Kate and Emily, and adored aunt of many nieces and nephews. Longtime resident of Belle Haven, Greenwich, CT, and Quonochontaug, Charles town, RI. We will all miss her gracious touch, her generous nature and good humor. Her sense of adventure will always be remembered, especially stories of Paris and London during WWII. She loved sports, and was devoted to the opera and the NY Times crossword puzzle. Friends and family will be received at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich, CT, from 2-6PM on Saturday, March 4, and from 1-5PM on Sunday, March 5. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at 10AM Monday, March 6, at St. Mary Church, 178 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, CT.

title: Heroin Intoxication Killed Bronx Girl, 2, Officials Say
description: The death of a 2-year-old girl found unconscious in a Bronx apartment where the police said they discovered evidence of drugs has been ruled a homicide after the city medical examiner determined that she died of acute heroin intoxication, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Arab-bashing: The peril of port polemics
World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Pemex to Increase Spending
description: Petrleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state-owned oil monopoly, plans to increase investment 21 percent in 2006, to $13.1 billion, to increase oil production and refining. Of the increase, 79 percent will go to exploration and production and 14 percent to refining, Juan Jos Surez, the chief financial officer, said on a conference call. Pemex, as the company is known, invested $10.8 billion last year, with 89 percent spent on exploration and production and 7 percent on refining. The spending plan will need approval from the Finance Ministry because it is higher than the $9 billion Pemex budget approved by Congress, Mr. Surez said. The plan to more than double spending on refineries, to $1.83 billion from $756 million last year, is intended to help Mexico reduce its need to import gasoline. In 2005, Mexico imported $7.8 billion of gasoline, diesel, propane and other refined fuels.

title: Corrections
description: Two articles on Saturday about the management deal for six American ports and its political fallout referred incorrectly to the role to be played by Dubai Ports World. It would run some of the terminal operations; it would not own the ports or take over all operations.

title: It's Official: Knicks at Bottom of N.B.A.
description: MEMPHIS, March 1 - A day after giving his beleaguered players a locker-room pep talk, James L. Dolan sat in the crowd Wednesday night with his arms crossed, waiting to see signs of life return from his significant investment.

title: Keeping Time With the Internet
description: Keeping Time With the Internet

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Militants Free 6 Of 9 Hostages
description: A militant group in the oil-producing delta region that has been demanding a greater share of the oil wealth said in an e-mail message that it had released an American hostage, Macon Hawkins, 68, from Kosciusko, Tex., an employee of a company hired by Royal Dutch Shell to lay oil pipelines, citing his age and health. Mr. Hawkins is diabetic. News services later reported that five oil workers from Egypt, the Philippines and Thailand who were kidnapped with Mr. Hawkins on Feb. 18 had also been freed. Three other foreign oil workers -- from the United States and Britain -- are still being held. The group, Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta, reiterated its demand that two leaders of the Ijaw ethnic group be released from prison and that a neutral third party mediate its dispute with the government. Over the past two months, the group has taken hostages and shut down 20 percent of Nigeria's daily output of 2.5 million barrels of crude oil. LYDIA POLGREEN (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRANICK, FRANCES ZUCKER
description: GRANICK--Frances Zucker. Mother of Dr. William H. Frishman and wife, Esther, and Randy Spiegel. Grandmother of Sheryl Frishman, Amy Frishman-Amir, Michael Frishman and Larry and Adam Spiegel. Greatgrandmother of Aaron, Rebekah, Zachary, Joshua and Mikayla. Services Monday, 1:30 PM, "Gutterman-Musicant," 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey. Contributions to JCC on the Hudson, C/O The Frishman Family Special Childrens Foundation.

title: Thousands in India Protest Bush's Visit
description: MUMBAI, March 2 A For the second day in a row, there were raucous protests across India today against President Bush's visit, with the most militant here in India's commercial capital.

title: Betraying Student Athletes
description: The national effort to raise educational standards -- especially for the inner-city poor -- is besieged by advocates of mediocrity and the bad old status quo. A vivid example of that can be found in the growing number of dubious "prep schools" where barely literate athletes earn bogus grades, often by taking no real courses to speak of. The athletes can then move on to universities that care nothing about them and value winning teams above all else. This deception exploits the athletes, who will probably end up back on the streets without degrees. It also encourages young people everywhere to ignore their studies in the belief that they will one day be rich professional athletes.

title: Beyond Data: Does Therapy Work?
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Opposition Eager to Pick a Presidential Candidate
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 24 - A year ago, President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva appeared unbeatable, and the opposition was having difficulty finding a candidate willing to offer himself as a sacrificial lamb. Now, though, with the president weakened by the worst corruption scandal in Brazil's modern history, the main opposition party has the opposite problem: two strong contenders for a nomination only one can win.

title: U.S. Stockpiles Antiviral Drugs, but Democrats Call Pace Too Slow
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - The Bush administration announced Tuesday that it was buying enough antiviral drugs to treat 14 million people in the event of a pandemic flu, but Democrats said that the administration had yet to spend all of the money that Congress appropriated in December to buy drugs, and that the delay was putting people at risk.

title: Philippines perseveres, with or without coup
Waters Accepts a Buyout From Rutgers
description: When he was hired as the men's basketball coach at Rutgers in 2001, Gary Waters promised to rescue the program from the mediocrity that had defined it for a decade. It was a pledge that he failed to deliver on, and that cost him his job.

title: Bombing kills U.S. diplomat in Karachi
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. and Ford Plan to Cut Output As Asian Carmakers Gain Market Share General Motors and Ford continued to lose market share in the American automobile market to Asian manufacturers in February and said they would reduce production in the second quarter. [Page C1.]

title: Senate Approves Renewal of Antiterrorism Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 A The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to extend the Patriot Act, clearing the way for the House to wrap up its work on the anti-terrorism bill and send it to President Bush before it expires on March 10.

title: Apple Laptop Has Looks and Brains
description: REMEMBER the famous five stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance? If you're a fan of the Macintosh computer, meet the five stages of switching to Apple's new laptop: lust, anticipation, delight, dismay and waiting.

title: With referendum date set, Montenegro looks ahead
World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Morgan Buys Real Estate Stake
description: Morgan Stanley's real estate investment arm said on Wednesday that it had agreed to take a minority stake in an Indian property company, Mantri Developers, for $68 million. Mantri, which is based in Bangalore, builds residential, office and retail projects. Sushil Mantri, its managing director, said the company would use the investment to expand into other types of assets and other Indian cities including New Delhi; Hyderabad; Chennai, formerly known as Madras; and Mumbai, formerly Bombay. The investment comes a year after India eased restrictions on the foreign ownership of real estate and construction companies, hoping to accelerate the development of housing and commercial projects. "We believe India presents an extremely compelling investment story," said Karamjit S. Kalsi, a senior Morgan Stanley real estate executive, "and expect to be a long-term investor in the real estate sector. The residential market is attractive because of rapid urbanization, the availability of housing finance and the strong growth of the consumer segment."

title: Other Views: Straits Times, Baltimore Sun, Gulf News
France finds 11 more infected birds
Impeach Bush: When the emperor has no clothes
De Beauvoir, Giving Into and Resisting Love
description: "I am nothing else now but that burning, proud, impatient longing for you." The "you" is Nelson Algren, the American author of "The Man With the Golden Arm." The surprising "I" is Simone de Beauvoir, the French philosopher, whose feminist classic, "The Second Sex," inspired generations of women to seek fulfillment independent of men.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'NEILL, MARGARET (NEE DELAHANTY)
description: O'NEILL--Margaret (nee Delahanty). On February 28, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Thomas P. Loving mother of Patrick J. and the late James Keating. Dear sister of Patricia, Thomas, Jimmy, and the late Brother David Delahanty F.S.C. Devoted grandmother of Megan. Former Secretary of Immaculate Conception School. Reposing at O'SheaHoey Funeral Home, Inc. 2913 Ditmars Blvd. Astoria Thursday & Friday 2-5 & 79:00 P.M. Funeral Mass Saturday at Immaculate Conception Church, 9:45 A.M. Interment St. John Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to The James Keating O'Neill Foundation, P.O. Box 5524, Astoria, NY 11105.

title: Shift urged in Ireland's labor force
At a Brooklyn Party, Angst and Velour Till the Wee Small Hours
description: You've probably been to parties like this, even if you wish you hadn't: languid all-nighters filled with vaguely recognizable music and vaguely employed artists. In "Home," the debut feature from the writer and director Matt Zoller Seitz, the gathering takes place in a charming Brooklyn brownstone where a bunch of well-fed, good-looking 20-somethings try desperately to get over themselves. Only a few succeed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about the spread of the refugee crisis in the Darfur region of Sudan referred incorrectly to the armed groups considered responsible for a campaign of terror that is a cause of the crisis, which the Bush administration has called genocide. Those groups are the government forces and allied Arab militias known as the janjaweed, not the rebels who are battling them.

title: EU to consider sharing some costs on defense
Paid Notice: Deaths   KERNAN, JOHN DEVEREUX III
description: KERNAN--John Devereux III. Of Hamden, CT. Died on February 22, 2006 at Connecticut Hospice. Born in New York City in 1911, he was the son of Dr. John Devereux Kernan, Jr. and Charlotte Sherrill, and husband of the late Una Greene Kernan. He graduated from Canterbury School (1930), Harvard College (1934) and Columbia Law School (1937). He served as a Lieutenant in the US Navy during WWII and later as a Lt. Commander in the US Naval Reserve. At his retirement he was General Counsel of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. Mr. Kernan was an expert on both American and Chinese export silver. He was a co-author of "Chinese Export Silver, 1785-1885," and author of "The Chait Collection of Chinese Export Silver," as well as numerous articles. He was also an avid amateur silversmith and gardener. He was a genealogist and co-author of "Francis Kernan," a history of his great-grandfather, who was the first Roman Catholic member of the US House of Representatives and Senate, serving from 1863-1882. Mr. Kernan served as President of the New Haven Colony Historical Society, the New Haven Chorale, the New Haven Opera Society, and the Englewood NJ Field Club. He was a member of the Society of the Cincinnati. He is survived by a son, John Devereux Kernan IV (Sean) of Stony Creek, CT; a daughter Brigid Devereux Kernan of Baltimore; his brother Henry S. Kernan of South Worcester, NY; and numerous nieces and nephews. There will be a Memorial Mass at 11 AM on March 11 at St. Thomas More, 100 Park St, New Haven, CT. Memorial donations may be sent to Connecticut Hospice, 100 Double Beach Road, Branford, CT. 06405.

title: Documenting a Family That Comes in 2 Sizes
description: Shopping for clothes with teenagers can be an experience loaded with emotional land mines. Viewers can peek at an unusually fraught expedition in the first few minutes of "Little People, Big World," a new series beginning Saturday on TLC. Amy Roloff, a dwarf, shops with her 15-year-old twin sons, one of whom is also a dwarf.

title: Physical Culture; Working Out While Baby Grows
description: AS pregnancies progress, women are vulnerable to back pain, and that may discourage them from doing 30 minutes of moderate exercise most, if not all, days of the week as the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends. So it helps to have workout clothes that not only accommodate mothers' ever-changing stomachs but also cradle them enough to alleviate pressure on their lower backs.

title: U.S. Is Reducing Safety Penalties for Mine Flaws
description: CRAIGSVILLE, W.Va. - In its drive to foster a more cooperative relationship with mining companies, the Bush administration has decreased major fines for safety violations since 2001, and in nearly half the cases, it has not collected the fines, according to a data analysis by The New York Times.

title: When the TV Picture Runs to Triple Digits
description: When it comes to watching television, it seems bigger is always better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWNE, MARTIN T.
description: BROWNE--Martin T. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Martin T. Browne, associated with The Times since January, 1976.

title: Taliban Rebels Still Menacing Afghan South
description: LOY KAREZ, Afghanistan - When Haji Lalai Mama, the 60-year-old tribal elder in these parts, gamely tried to organize a village defense force against the Taliban recently, he had to do it with a relative handful of men and just three rifles. "We were patrolling and ready," he recalled.

title: If You Like the Chandelier, You Should See the Table ... and the Server
description: From a distance, the fixture in question could almost pass for a grand chandelier, tiered and tapered and made of cut glass, and perfect for a Hollywood swashbuckler to swing from.

title: Also, They All Swirled Counterclockwise
description: Also, They All Swirled Counterclockwise

title: Briefing: European tour firms are raided in Belgium
National Briefing | Religion: Religious Leaders Take A Stand On Immigration
description: As Congress takes up immigration reform, Cardinal Theodore E. McCarrick of Washington; the Rev. Robert Edgar, general secretary of the National Council of Churches; and other Christian and Jewish religious leaders announced that they would support legislation to legalize illegal workers, institute a program for temporary workers and reunite families separated by immigration laws. The religious leaders said they were opposing a bill, H.R. 4437, the Border Protection, Antiterrorism and Illegal Immigration Act of 2005, that would stiffen enforcement and restrict immigration. LAURIE GOODSTEIN (NYT)

title: To Sing and Be Young at Heart (and in Years)
description: The optimism and ingenuousness of youth skipped into the staid Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Tuesday evening with the debut of Samantha Sidley, a 20-year-old jazz singer accompanied by three fellow students from the Berklee College of Music in Boston. Ms. Sidley recently won the first annual Oak Room Young Artist Competition, and the pleasure of hearing her at the opening-night show was akin to discovering signs of spring in the first crocuses poking their way up through the soil.

title: TechBrief: Telekom dividend gains as profit plunges 43%
Paid Notice: Deaths   DENT, ROSEMARY ''POSY'' ROMEYN
description: DENT -- Rosemary "Posy" Romeyn of Charlottesville, VA. died Monday, February 27, 2006 at her residence. A memorial service will be held 4:00 PM Friday, March 3, 2006 at St. Paul's Church, Ivy, VA.

title: A Ray of Hope for Diabetics
description: The users call the drug Lizzie, the Big Brother or sometimes Gilly. On blogs they rave over its uncanny ability to melt away pounds, although some are wary of its side effects, which can include nausea and strange welts.

title: Families of Victims Speak at Sentencing Hearing for Nurse
description: The sentencing hearing for Charles Cullen, a nurse who killed intensive care patients with fatal injections, began with a somber string of statements by relatives of the victims, who told the court of their loathing for Mr. Cullen and their anger at the hospitals that hired him.

title: If You've Got It, Do You Flaunt It?
description: WINNING an Academy Award is obviously a high point for most people, but what happens next? What happens after this particular happily ever after? Once you're home from the afterparties and it's just you and your little golden man, staring each other down in the front hall on Monday morning, where's he going to go? The two of you will be living together for a long time, and -- regardless of the fact that he's never going to smile, no matter where you put him -- you need to come to some sort of arrangement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MARKS, ELAINE MILLER
description: MARKS -- Elaine Miller. March 2, 2005. One more walk around the garden, One more stroll along the shore, One more memory we can dream of her before we dream no more. And One more time perhaps the dawn will wait and One more prayer it's not too late to gather one more rose and kiss goodbye before we close the garden gates. Alvin, Evan, Wendy, and Jeffrey

title: Bush Stops in Afghanistan in Surprise on Way to India
description: NEW DELHI, Thursday, March 2 - President Bush made a surprise five-hour visit to Afghanistan on Wednesday to meet with President Hamid Karzai and to see for the first time the country created after the United States went to war against the Taliban in retaliation for the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Beyond Data: Does Therapy Work?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, MAURICE MILTON (SHARKEY)
description: ROSENTHAL--Maurice Milton (Sharkey). WWII veteran, passed away peacefully on March 1, 2006. Former resident of Trenton, NJ and Boca Raton, FL. He is survived by his beloved wife, Beverly, sister, Dorothy Saaz, sons, Andrew and Robert, daughter, Jane Schorr, son-in-law, Marc Schorr, and cherished grandchildren, Seth and Courtney Schorr. Services will be held at Temple Beth El, Boca Raton, Friday, March 3, 12 noon.

title: Richard Meier Condos, Dressed Accordingly
description: Six apartments in the new condominium tower by Richard Meier, at 165 Charles Street in the West Village, will serve as a show house March 10 through March 13, with furniture from six New York dealers specializing in 20th-century design. Called Design and Architecture, the four-day event will showcase apartments with asking prices of $5.3 million to $7.1 million, along with suitably priced furnishings. A 1930's seating group by Axel Einar Hjorth ($85,000), above left, is from Antik; a 1971 Pratone lounge seat that looks like a chunk of lawn ($45,000), above right, is from R 20th Century. The other dealers are Barry Friedman, Cristina Grajales, Demisch Danant and Magen H Gallery. The show house will be open to the public but reservations are required; (212) 645-9700.

title: Doubts Back Home Fuel G.O.P. Worries Over Ports Deal
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - Senator Jon Kyl, a staunch supporter of President Bush who faces a potentially difficult re-election fight this year, is hearing a lot from constituents in Arizona about the plan to allow a Dubai company to operate shipping terminals at Eastern ports. Most think the deal should be stopped.

title: Offering vote delay, Thaksin opens re-election drive
Paid Notice: Deaths   BENTON, NICHOLAS
description: BENTON--Nicholas, 79, on February 26, 2006 in Manhattan. Time-Life Books and magazines executive for 33 years, Bwy and Off-Bwy producer, President of NYC Opera Guild, recipient of The Mayor's Volunteer Award Of The Year for his work with The Harvard/Radcliffe Tutoring Program. He was an avid New Yorker with an infectious enthusiasm. Survived by his wife, Kitty, of fifty-two years, four daughters, four grandsons, three step grandchildren, and two brothers. Service 11 A.M. March 4 at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to The New York City Opera, 20 Lincoln Center, NY, NY 10023.

title: Prisons Often Shackle Pregnant Inmates in Labor
description: Shawanna Nelson, a prisoner at the McPherson Unit in Newport, Ark., had been in labor for more than 12 hours when she arrived at Newport Hospital on Sept. 20, 2003. Ms. Nelson, whose legs were shackled together and who had been given nothing stronger than Tylenol all day, begged, according to court papers, to have the shackles removed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLATT, ALLAN H.
description: BLATT--Allan H. Age 53. Beloved son of Jeanne and Mortimer, brother of Ronald D. Blatt, M.D. and his wife, Elisa T. Blatt, passed away Monday, February 27, 2006. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. on March 3 at 11:45 A.M.

title: Calendar
description: Urban Preservation Altschul Auditorium at the International Affairs Building of Columbia University, Amsterdam Avenue at 118th Street; (212) 614-9107.

title: Human Rights Director Urges Europe to Improve Oversight
description: PARIS, March 1 - Frustrated by his failure to find clear evidence that European governments have taken part in the secret detention or transportation of American-held terrorism suspects, the chief of Europe's human rights agency called Wednesday for tougher oversight of European intelligence services and stricter controls over foreign agents operating in Europe.

title: Thrilling Action in Flawed Wrappers
description: MOST people, if trapped in a burning building, would call 911. But in Taito's puzzle game Exit, those in peril instead pick up their charred phone books and look under "escapologists" for the number of Mr. Escape, a zoot-suited hero-for-hire. Even if you've been snowed in by an avalanche or hit by a flood, Mr. Escape will be glad to help. Just make sure to have your credit card handy.

title: A Holocaust Contemplation, Inspired by a Hardy Poem
description: A big question looms over American Opera Projects' premiere presentation of "Darkling," which opened at the East 13th Street Theater on Tuesday night: What is it? The director Michael Comlish, who adapted the work from the book-length poem by Anna Rabinowitz, calls this 80-minute theater piece with music by Stefan Weisman an "operatic fantasia on themes of emotional fragmentation," and I'm not sure I can better that description of this brave and sensitive though ultimately frustrating work.

title: Making Winter Bloom
description: PHILADELPHIA - IT feels like Walt Disney World at the Pennsylvania Convention Center as Natura, a giant goddess draped in evergreens and vines, reclines in her gardens of fire, wind and water, and Floratopia, a life-size fake tree covered with fragrant flowers, comes to life at the nation's most prestigious flower show.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Political strife in Iraq as violence continues
Boone Says Thrill Is Gone and Retires
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Mar. 1 - Kazuo Matsui must have a voodoo doll, because his competition for the second-base job is dwindling. A few days after Jeff Keppinger was sidelined by back spasms, Bret Boone announced his retirement Wednesday morning, ending his 14-year major-league career.

title: Opposition Candidate in Belarus Is Arrested and Beaten
description: MOSCOW, March 2 A Security officers in Belarus today arrested and beat a candidate running against President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, raising tensions ahead of a disputed presidential election scheduled for March 19.

title: Could I Call You Later? My Trainer's on the Phone
description: If you have a cellphone with a Global Positioning System receiver, BiM Active, a new service from Bones in Motion, can turn the phone into a pocket-size personal trainer. BiM Active uses data from G.P.S. satellites and local cellphone towers to plot your location during a walk, jog or bicycle ride. With that data, it generates highly accurate route maps, speed calculations, changes in elevation and other information.

title: Europeans to Meet With Iran on Nuclear Impasse
description: PARIS, March 1 - In a surprise development, the foreign ministers of Britain, France and Germany have agreed to meet with Iran's top nuclear negotiator to discuss what Iran is describing as new ideas to break the impasse over its nuclear program, European officials said Wednesday.

title: News analysis: Military often the trigger in Philippines' politics
Budget Cuts Back Much-Promoted NASA Missions
description: Some of the most highly promoted missions on NASA's scientific agenda would be postponed indefinitely or perhaps even canceled under the agency's new budget, despite its administrator's vow to Congress six months ago that not "one thin dime" would be taken from space science to pay for President Bush's plan to send astronauts to the Moon and Mars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIELD, HENRY C., JR.
description: FIELD--Henry C., Jr. On February 28, 2006 in Hackensack, NJ. born in Glen Ridge and long time resident of Glen Ridge. Memorial service will be Saturday March 4, 2006 at 12:30-2:30 PM at Van Tassel Chickene - Brown Funeral Home, Bloomfield, NJ 973-743-1234.

title: Freedom for the thought we hate
Corrections
description: The Physical Culture column on Feb. 16, about treadmills, misstated the length of time that Brady Crain, a running coach, tested one model. Although he did use the four others for a few weeks, he tried the Precor M9.35i for three days.

title: Still Games to Coach, Players to Teach, Miles to Go
description: Kay Yow, the North Carolina State women's basketball coach, has had three bouts with breast cancer. Although she has undergone operations as well as hormone and radiation treatments, and changed her diet radically, Yow does not know if she is cancer free.

title: Under the Hood With the Salary Cap
description: Q. What happens now?

title: Salary Cap Chaos Looms as Talks Drag On in N.F.L.
description: National Football League owners will meet in New York this morning in a last-ditch attempt to forge labor peace before the start of the signing period for free agents tomorrow. If no deal is reached, the annual salary-cap-induced purge of players is expected to balloon as teams struggle to get under a cap that could be at least $10 million lower than it would have been under a new labor agreement.

title: News Analysis: India deal complicates U.S. stance on Iran
Alito's Note to Evangelist Is Called Just Thanks
description: Correction Appended

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Who's the Prettiest Of Them All?
description: The Pirouette mirror has seven rotating pillars, each with three sides. One side is plain mirror; another is etched mirror; the third, black wood veneer. You can rotate all seven to yield one continuous surface or mix them up.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Vapors Suspected In Plant Explosion
description: Chemical vapors leaking from a reactor used to make a paint additive are the likely cause of a Jan. 31 plant explosion in Morgantown that killed one man and injured 12 others, a federal investigator said. The explosion destroyed the plant, owned by Synthron Inc., and damaged nearby homes. The investigator, Jim Lay, who led the inquiry for the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, said the investigation was continuing. JOHN DeSANTIS (NYT)

title: Northwest Attendants Agree to Concessions as Pilots Continue Talks
description: CHICAGO, March 1 - Flight attendants at Northwest Airlines agreed on Wednesday to wage concessions of $195 million a year as the airline continued negotiating with its pilots to accept more cuts and avoid the possibility of having their contract voided by a bankruptcy court.

title: No Cinderella Story, No Ball, No Black Debutante
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 1 - Just before midnight on Tuesday, the young women of this city's most prominent white families waltzed and waved in flowing gowns and tiaras at the formal galas held by the oldest and most glittering krewes of the Carnival season, Comus and Rex.

title: In Brief: Curb on foreigners is weighed
Documenting a Family That Comes in 2 Sizes
description: Shopping for clothes with teenagers can be an experience loaded with emotional land mines. Viewers can peek at an unusually fraught expedition in the first few minutes of "Little People, Big World," a new series beginning Saturday on TLC. Amy Roloff, a dwarf, shops with her 15-year-old twin sons, one of whom is also a dwarf.

title: Bridge; An Early Decision by East Becomes the Deciding Factor
description: The best defensive play during the NEC Cup in Yokohama, Japan, last month occurred during the quarterfinal match between Australia and Italy.

title: Citigroup Paid Income Tax On Its Chairman's Salary
description: Correction Appended

title: New Greek law permits cremation
Documenting a Family That Comes in 2 Sizes
description: Shopping for clothes with teenagers can be an experience loaded with emotional land mines. Viewers can peek at an unusually fraught expedition in the first few minutes of "Little People, Big World," a new series beginning Saturday on TLC. Amy Roloff, a dwarf, shops with her 15-year-old twin sons, one of whom is also a dwarf.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Inquiry Into Leak Of 'Dirty War' Report
description: Attorney General Daniel Cabeza de Vaca announced that his office had begun an investigation into the leak last week of a secret report prepared by a special prosecutor's office that accused the armed forces of kidnapping, torturing and murdering hundreds of suspected subversives during the so-called dirty war of the late 1960's to the early 1980's. The government had withheld the report since December, saying that it placed too much blame for the abuses on the military. Its authors, worried their report would be censored, leaked it to several prominent writers, and it was posted on the Internet by the National Security Archives, a nonpartisan research group based in Washington. The special prosecutor, Ignacio Carrillo Prieto said an official version of the report would be released on April 15. ANTONIO BETANCOURT (NYT)

title: Room Dividers
description: Q. I would like to use a wall unit as a room divider. How can I improve the look of its unfinished back?

title: In Italy, fear of bird flu shows at checkout
Pakistan's progress
TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the appointment of Marc V. Shaw, the former first deputy mayor of New York, to a position at a real estate development company referred imprecisely to his successor, Patricia E. Harris. She will not in fact assume Mr. Shaw's other title, deputy mayor for operations. That title will be retired when Mr. Shaw leaves the government on March 17.

title: U.S. and India reach nuclear deal
U.S. diplomat among dead in Pakistan bombing
INSIDE
description: Ports Deal Irks Voters; In Dubai, Life Goes On It is not clear what kind of staying power the ports deal has as an issue, but Republicans have little choice but to acknowledge the objections they are hearing from voters, distancing themselves from President Bush on national security heading to the midterm elections. PAGE A22

title: Young, Inexpensive, Ready to Shine
description: TAMPA, Fla. - He is one of the most important pitchers on the Yankees and, presumably, will become even more valuable in the future. He shows as much emotion as someone who is napping. He produces grounders almost as steadily as a coach tapping them to infielders.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Storm Victims Leave Hotels And Cruise Ships
description: Thousands of Hurricane Katrina evacuees vacated hotel rooms and cruise ships as the Federal Emergency Management Agency reached another deadline in its short-term emergency housing programs. Authorization for 3,000 families in hotel rooms all over the country expired. However, the agency reserved 600 new hotel rooms in New Orleans for some of the police officers, firefighters and other public employees who had been living on two cruise ships, said David Passey, a spokesman for the agency. About 8,000 families will remain in the hotel program. SHAILA DEWAN (NYT)

title: Mets Have Young Arms, One Healthy, One Hurting
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 1 - In late January, Philip Humber and Mike Pelfrey shared a flight to Dallas from West Palm Beach, Fla.. They were traveling from the Mets' minicamp, where Pelfrey, the Mets' 2005 first-round draft pick, had been introduced after signing his first multimillion-dollar, major league contract, and was still coming off the high of putting on a Mets cap and jersey for the first time.

title: A Workaround for Internet Calling's Drawbacks
description: Internet calling -- using a technology called voice- over-Internet protocol, or VoIP -- promises unlimited low-cost phone time. But for all its benefits, VoIP has drawbacks: it requires a broadband connection and often a new phone number, and 911 calls do not automatically pinpoint a caller's location in emergencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, ROSE K.
description: GOLDBERG--Rose K. Park East Synagogue Men's Club regrets the passing of Rose K. Goldberg, mother of our Trustee and former President Dr. Allan Goldberg. Dr. Barry Zimmerman, President Herman Hochberg, Chairman

title: News Analysis: German divide: Moralism vs. realpolitik
A Sun That Always Arrives, a Storm That Doesn't Quit
description: Music can't describe the world it was born in, but it does let us know how we feel about it. Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony, as played by the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, is one of music's great happy endings. In five movements, troubles arrive, troubles go away, and we are left with joyous F-major singing high in the violin sections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILNE, MARGERY GREENE
description: MILNE--Margery Greene, 94. Internationally known naturalist, died peacefully in her Durham, NH, home February 28, 2006. She was the town's Swan Keeper. A spring memorial service is planned.

title: N.F.L. Owners Break Off Talks; Deadline Extended
description: National Football League owners voted unanimously today to break off talks with the league's players union after failing to reach agreement on a new collective bargaining contract. The deadlock leaves in place the current salary cap, and the league, concerned that there would be mass cuts by teams trying to get under the cap, extended its deadline for free agency by three days.

title: U.S. and India agree on nuclear deal
Devils End Olympic Sabbatical in Style
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 1 - The Devils resumed their season Wednesday after an 18-day Olympic break, and the Philadelphia Flyers often got in their way. Many Devils players ended shifts with snow on their pants and snarls on their faces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOSSETT, O. MILTON
description: GOSSETT--O. Milton, 80. Milt worked his way up the advertising industry ladder reaching Chairman and CEO of Compton Advertising and later CEO of Saatchi & Saatchi. While he was very successful in his career, his most favorite things to do were fishing and gardening. He leaves loving wife Anna, five children, Susanne, Michael, Thomas, Lorraine and James, and 11 grandchildren. Wake 2-4 and 6-8PM on March 3, at Kane Funeral Home, 25 Catoonah St., Ridgefield, CT, (203) 438 - 6597. Funeral 12PM March 4 at Jesse Lee Memorial United Methodist Church, 207 Main Street, Ridgefield, CT, 203-438-8791. Donations: The O. Milton Gossett Memorial Fund, Salish-Kootenai College, POB 70, Pablo, MT 59855. Visit: miltgossett.blogspot.com

title: Sneaky Poison Sumac
description: Sneaky Poison Sumac

title: Masked Officers Raid TV Station and Newspaper Plant in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 2 A Dozens of masked police officers knocked a television station off the air in an early morning raid in the Kenyan capital today before moving to a newspaper plant, where they disabled the printing press and torched thousands of papers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BERGER, SYLVIA JOSEPHS
description: BERGER--Sylvia Josephs. A woman of extraordinary intelligence and taste: character and grace. She had a life long passion for languages, learning and travel. With all her varied interests, her family always came first. We who knew you well-miss your counsel and compassion. Love, Joyce

title: Compliance spending is expected to rise
Works Well With Others
description: WHAT makes Rogan Gregory an interesting designer, apart from creating denim styles that are environmentally friendly and still wearable, is his collaborative approach to fashion.

title: Seoul picks winners in electronics
Emirate Wakes Up Famous. Thank You, America.
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, March 1 - As United States senators turned Dubai into a household word last week, life in this desert city hardly changed: skiers swooshed down a man-made snow park in the region's largest shopping mall, workers put the finishing touches on man-made islands under construction and men like Rashad Bukhash continued planning for the day when this city of one million would grow to three million.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a lawsuit against Arizona court programs for Spanish-speaking and Indian drunken-driving offenders misstated the given name of the court's lawyer, who declined to comment. He is Scot L. Claus, not Stan Claus.

title: Praise the Lord and Pass the Joystick
description: The battle is on for souls and Troy A. Lyndon refuses to lose. As non-Christians wander Manhattan in Mr. Lyndon's new video game, Left Behind: Eternal Forces, they are recruited to join the side of God or be judged following the rapture.

title: U.S. Lists Its Pluses and Minuses in Fighting Narcotics Worldwide
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - The Bush administration published an annual report Wednesday on international narcotics control, listing its accomplishments in disrupting the production and trafficking of cocaine, heroin, marijuana and other drugs to the United States.

title: Save Iraq One Switch at a Time
description: LAST fall I was allowed to sit in on a high-level meeting at Iraq's Electricity Ministry in Baghdad. The minister, Muhsin Shlash, arrived 20 minutes late. Around a big table, several small groups of officials -- from the ministry, the American State and Defense Departments, and the British Foreign Office -- sat in separate cliques, and gave essentially separate reports. Toward the end of the meeting, Mr. Shlash's deputy fulminated at the Westerners, accusing them of keeping ministry officials out of the loop: "Always we are getting this news, this is cancelled, there is no budget for this, the plan is changed."

title: Nearly 100% of Publicists Love Surveys
description: BET you didn't know: People who own hot tubs have better sex than people who don't.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Convicted Of Threats
description: A man described by federal prosecutors as a trafficker of tons of cocaine was convicted yesterday of threatening to kill federal drug agents and conspiring to ship cocaine into the United States. The man, Robert James Hertular, of Belize, is scheduled to be sentenced in June and faces up to life in prison, prosecutors said. Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney, said Mr. Hertular was arrested in Belize in 2001 after the authorities there seized a shipment of 1.1 tons of cocaine. After he learned that he faced indictment in the United States, Mr. Garcia said, Mr. Hertular threatened to kill Drug Enforcement Administration agents in Belize and offered a hand grenade to a federal informant to be used against the agents. After prolonged legal maneuvers in Belize, Mr. Hertular was extradited to New York in July 2004.

title: Corrections
description: Two articles on Saturday about the management deal for six American ports and its political fallout referred incorrectly to the role to be played by Dubai Ports World. It would run some of the terminal operations; it would not own the ports or take over all operations.

title: Elite Teams Are Spared New Sanctions by N.C.A.A.
description: The N.C.A.A.'s effort toward academic overhaul has resulted in penalties for the first time, but fewer than 2 percent of its teams and only a few high-profile colleges and universities were cited yesterday for failing to maintain the N.C.A.A.'s more rigorous standards.

title: Starting Up the Ladder, From Below the Bottom Rung
description: NEW DELHI - It's hard not to notice Abida Parvin as soon as you walk into the small room that serves as a computer training center for girls and women in an annex to, of all things, a madrasa in the heart of Jafrabad, one of this city's teeming Muslim neighborhoods.

title: Aged Wood Tells a Story, Then Takes A New Shape
description: Samuel Moyer, top right, a furniture maker in Los Angeles, has introduced the Hello collection, his first retail venture. The one-of-a-kind pieces are all made with reclaimed wood, some of it over 100 years old.

title: If Dolan Were in Charge . . . Oh, Wait. He Is.
description: MEMPHIS, March 1 - James L. Dolan, the chairman of Madison Square Garden, sat in a near-empty ballroom yesterday and said, half jokingly, that some people probably thought he was missing his mental faculties.

title: For Your Consideration: Sappy Hallmark Moments
description: Part of an enormous push to lure viewers to the Academy Awards show on Sunday, the annual Oscar trailer has been running in theaters for weeks, long enough to drive thousands of people away. That 30-second promo, online at www.oscars.org/78academyawards/trailer/, is a hokey and backward-looking affair, completely at odds with the idea that Jon Stewart and a crop of untraditional movies might lead to a newer, fresher Oscar show.

title: Please Don't Touch the Celebrities
description: Beverly Hills, Calif. - YOU'RE either on or you're off. In the intricate geography of celebrity known as the star maps, landmarks -- like people -- are evanescent. "Pitt, Brad" is indexed with "Aniston, Jennifer" (it's hard to keep up in Starland). "Cruise, Tom" and "DiCaprio, Leo" are on the map. Cher, who is as peripatetic as "Monroe, Marilyn," is listed twice, while "Grant, Cary," whose house was demolished for a gated community, is one of dozens of former icons now stricken from the map. But "Dietrich, Marlene," "Disney, Walt" and "Sinatra, Frank" are eternal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALVITO, ANNE NUMRICH
description: DALVITO--Anne Numrich, a long time resident of Mamaroneck, passed away March 1, 2006 at her home after a long battle with cancer, she was 75. Born October 26, 1930 in Lancaster, PA, she was the daughter of the late Miriam Book Numrich and George Robert Numrich. She was the sister of the late George Robert Numrich, Jr. Mrs. Dalvito was a 1946 graduate of Mamaroneck High School. She attended Emerson College, Carnegie-Mellon University and received her BA degree from SUNY Purchase in 1992. Mrs. Dalvito was an avid gardener and member of the Mamaroneck Garden Club, where she won numerous awards for her flower arranging. She loved to travel and before her illness visited much of the world. She was a member of The Brick Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. A beloved and devoted wife, mother and grandmother, Mrs. Dalvito is survived by her husband Rocco James Dalvito of Mamaroneck, NY, and her four children, Deborah Keats McCarter of Okatie, SC, William E. Keats of Bethelehem, PA, Lisa Britton of Darien, CT, and Gregory James Dalvito of New York, NY. She is also survived by six grandchildren; Tony, Alex, Emma, Daniel, Amelia and Jaime. A visitation will be held at Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home, 767 Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY from 6-9PM on Friday, March 3rd. A memorial service will be held at Larchmont Presbyterian Church at a later date. The Reverend Michael Lindvall from Brick Church will officiate. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Memorial SloanKettering Institute or the American Cancer Society.

title: Harvard-Bound? Chin Up
description: I've got great news! You're young and you're smart and next year you're beginning college. Unfortunately, I've also got bad news. The only school you got into is Harvard, where, as Peter Beinart of The New Republic notes, students often graduate "without the kind of core knowledge that you'd expect from a good high school student," and required courses can be "a hodgepodge of arbitrary, esoteric classes that cohere into nothing at all."

title: Owen Chamberlain, 85, Dies; Discovered Antiproton
description: Owen Chamberlain, who shared a Nobel Prize for discovering the antiproton, opening a glimpse into the strange world of antimatter, whose mysteries tantalize scientists to this day, died Tuesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORPHOS, DIANE BELOGIANIS
description: MORPHOS--Diane Belogianis. Beloved wife of the late Panos Paul Morphos & sister of the late William D. Belroy. Devoted mother of Paul Morphos and Evangeline Morphos. Born in Chicago, IL. in 1913, she graduated from the University of Chicago with a BA and an MA and taught there until her marriage. She was an active civic leader in New Orleans, LA. and her many activities included leadership of the Southeast Louisiana Girl Scout Council and the A.A. U.W. She ran for Congress in 1974 and moved to New York City in 1980. Survived by her grandchildren Peter Morphos and Elly Brinkley. Friends may call Thursday 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), 81st Street and Madison Ave. Funeral services Friday 2PM from the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral. Interment Elmwood Cemetery, River Grove, IL.

title: Youth Who Killed at 12 Will Return to Prison, but Not for Life
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1 - A teenager who was sentenced to life in prison five years ago for stomping a younger playmate to death when he was 12 pleaded guilty Wednesday to armed robbery, in a deal that spares him a life sentence for violating probation.

title: Lincoln Center's Summer Festival Has 2 Beowulfs
description: Correction Appended

title: To sleep,perchance to have a Gothic nightmare
How to Stuff a Wild Bikini Bottom
description: DR. CONSTANTINO MENDIETA, a plastic surgeon in Miami, has never seen a woman's backside that he didn't want to tweak with a little surgery.

title: TiVo to Offer Tighter Rein on Children's Viewing
description: In a new twist on helping parents control what children watch on television, TiVo will announce today a service that lets its video recorders limit children to watching shows approved by one of two groups promoting family programming.

title: Flea Market Flavor, Factory-Fresh
description: NOT everyone has room for extra seating. A new crop of dining chairs is versatile and attractive enough to double as side chairs. Their vintage forms will appeal to those who like the flea-market look, but want something more contemporary.

title: Stretched to Limit, Women Stall March to Work
description: For four decades, the number of women entering the workplace grew at a blistering pace, fostering a powerful cultural and economic transformation of American society. But since the mid-1990's, the growth in the percentage of adult women working outside the home has stalled, even slipping somewhat in the last five years and leaving it at a rate well below that of men.

title: Do You Need a License to Earn a Living? You Might Be Surprised at the Answer
description: IT is well known that doctors, dentists, and lawyers must be licensed to practice their professions. But what about occupational therapists, manicurists and barbers? How about fortune tellers, massage therapists, shampoo assistants, librarians, beekeepers, electrologists and movie projector operators? These are just a sampling of the hundreds of occupations that require a license in at least some states or counties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAAS, CHARLES WILLIAM
description: BAAS--Charles William. Of Easley, SC, formerly of Keowee Key, SC, East Hampton, NY and New Jersey; husband of Gertrude Rosenast, died Monday, February 27, 2006. He served 41 years as Treasurer of the American Bible Society; additionally he served as Treasurer of the United Bible Societies and was Director of the Astor Place Real Estate Co. Surviving in addition to his wife of 61 years are two sons: Charles W. Jr. and Bruce Warren. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to: Providence Presbyterian Church, 4000 Earle E. Morris Jr. Highway, Greenville, SC 29611.

title: Singapore levies fines after firm hides loss
Senate Bill to Address Fears of Blocked Access to Net
description: Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, will introduce new legislation today that would prohibit Internet network operators from charging companies for faster delivery of their content to consumers or favoring some content providers over others.

title: Russia economy chief warns of a stock crash
From China To Chairs
description: A confident new home collection comes from Sieger Design, a company in Sassenberg, Germany, owned by two brothers, Michael and Christian Sieger. This is the first signature collection from a company that has developed luxury goods for European manufacturers like Dornbracht and Duravit. It includes My China! porcelains with multitasking pieces (plates fit as lids on bowls, for example) made by Furstenberg, a German company founded in 1747. Plates and bowls will be $25 to $145, and a teapot (not shown), $240. A line called Objects to a Muse includes a gilded porcelain torso ($8,850), made in a limited edition of 25. Michael Sieger said that their chrome and steel Couture chair ($3,000), top, stemmed from his need for an elegant, comfortable chair. The fabric, by the Danish company Kvadrat, comes in 10 colors. The collection will be available in the United States in April. Store locations: (630) 853-1623. CURRENTS: COLLECTIONS

title: Chilly warm-ups kindle some hope
10th German state is hit by a walkout
Beyond Data: Does Therapy Work?
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Express Concern Over Aspects of Some Texas Redistricting
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Texas Democrats had their day in the Supreme Court on Wednesday to challenge the unusual middecade redistricting of the state's Congressional delegation that led to the loss of five Democratic seats and helped solidify Republican control of Congress.

title: Unaware as Levees Fell, Officials Expressed Relief
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - A newly released transcript of a government videoconference shows that hours after Hurricane Katrina made landfall, federal and state officials did not know that the levees in New Orleans were failing and were cautiously congratulating one another on the government response.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREIDES, JACK
description: FREIDES--Jack. Of Larchmont, NY. Died March 1, 2006 at age 82. Born January 21, 1924 in NYC to Harry and Esther (Horshovsky) Freides. Survived by his wife Barbara (Greene), sons Randall (Judy) and Drew, grandchildren Rebecca and Adam and a sister Shirley Lesser (Richard). Funeral Service Friday 12:30PM at Westchester Jewish Center, Rockland and Palmer Aves. Mamaroneck, NY 10543 followed by an interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Family requests donations to Westchester Jewish Center. For information Zion Memorial Chapel, 914-381-1809.

title: Opportunity Knocks, but the Nets Don't Answer
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 1 - The Nets seemed to have a perfect scenario as they prepared for their game Wednesday night at the Target Center. They had a night off here Tuesday as the struggling Timberwolves were losing in Chicago, where the Bulls scored 50 points in the paint.

title: Agreement Is Reached for Students From Somalia
description: An agreement intended to improve educational opportunities for Somali children enrolled in schools in Springfield, Mass., was reached by the federal Education Department and Springfield Public Schools late last month, representatives of both entities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUTLER, PETER
description: CUTLER--Peter. The Board of Governors and Membership of Ridgeway Country Club express their deepest sorrow in the passing of longstanding Members and friends, Mr. Peter Cutler, on Monday, February 27, 2006. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Meri and the Cutler family.

title: Spurt of Violence in Iraq Mutes Talk of U.S. Troop Cuts, but Decisions Loom
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - Senior Pentagon officials said Wednesday that in the aftermath of a burst of sectarian violence in Iraq, it was unlikely that a decision would be made on a reduction in troop levels when top Army commanders meet with President Bush next week.

title: Safety on the Slopes: Easy to Say, but Harder to Ensure
description: DAVID BLOOM, a 45-year-old skier, had stopped on a trail at Sunday River resort in Maine to give his 5-year-old daughter a rest. The next thing he knew, he was sprawled on the snow. A snowboarder hit him with enough force to shear the bindings off his skis. Luckily, Mr. Bloom absorbed the brunt of the blow and his daughter was unhurt.

title: State Bars a Bronx Lawyer From Receiving Court Appointments
description: Stanley K. Schlein, the politically influential Bronx lawyer who is the chairman of the city's Civil Service Commission, has been barred indefinitely by state court officials from accepting guardianships and other potentially lucrative judicial appointments.

title: Owen Chamberlain, 85, Dies; Discovered Antiproton
description: Owen Chamberlain, who shared a Nobel Prize for discovering the antiproton, opening a glimpse into the strange world of antimatter, whose mysteries tantalize scientists to this day, died Tuesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 85.

title: Lack of Food Not Main Cause of Child Malnutrition, Study Says
description: Rampant child malnutrition in poor countries is usually not caused principally by lack of food, nor are large, politically popular programs to feed schoolchildren the right way to tackle a problem stunting the intellectual and physical development of more than 100 million children worldwide, a new World Bank report says.

title: Video shows Bush knew power of storm
Human rights: A needed UN reform
Milestone Night for a 32-Year-Old Conductor, Another Ovation for a 97-Year-Old Composer
description: There had to have been a lot of pressure on the 32-year-old French conductor Ludovic Morlot, who made his unexpected subscription concert debut with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening. On a few days' notice, he stepped in for the formidable maestro Christoph von Dohnanyi, who withdrew because of illness (reportedly bronchitis).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, MARVIN
description: GREENFIELD--Marvin. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to Barbara, Felicia, Eric and the grandchildren. Marvin was a dear friend and will be sorely missed. The Stoppelmann Family

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Most of us thought we would work and have kids, at least that was what we were brought up thinking we would do -- no problem. But really we were kind of duped. None of us realized how hard it is."

title: Letter from India: India's activist author indignant at Bush visit
Crucial to the Close-Up: A Show-Biz Dermatologist
description: WHEN the Oscar-nominated film "The Constant Gardener" began shooting in Africa, Dr. David Colbert, a dermatologist in New York, was ready for anything. "We knew it was going to be hot," he said. "There were going to be all these weird insects. If Rachel Weisz or one of the other actors got a rash or an insect bite, it could cost a huge amount of money if they had to shut the production down."

title: Euro changeover often pushed up prices
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jets Settle Stadium Lawsuit
description: The New York Jets and Cablevision finally settled their bitter dispute over a proposed football stadium on the West Side on Monday, eight months after the $2.2 billion project died in Albany. The Jets spent five years and more than $65 million on the effort to build the stadium, but faced opposition from civic groups, residents, politicians and Cablevision, which spent more than $30 million on lobbyists and a television advertising campaign. That prompted the Jets to sue the cable giant, which owns Madison Square Garden. But in response to questions yesterday, both sides issued an identical statement saying that they had ended their legal battle without either of them admitting any fault or assuming any liability.

title: Pakistan Battles Militants; Bombs Explode Near U.S. Consulate
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Thursday, March 2 - Pakistan on Wednesday attacked a compound near the border with Afghanistan and killed at least 25 foreign militants in a fierce gun battle, security officials said. At least four civilians, including two children, were also killed.

title: At Manipulative Fingertips, 311 Can Be a Bludgeon
description: IT took George Schmidt at least six months and the services of a lawyer before he could prove he was innocent of anonymous charges that he had illegally divided his house in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Parts Supplier Says It Missed Bond Payments
description: DETROIT, March 1 - The Dana Corporation, the auto parts maker, said Wednesday that it missed two payments totaling $21 million that were due on its bonds, heightening speculation that it might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection.

title: ECB raises rates and promises future step
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Fashion Diary article on Feb. 9 about grunge and garage-rock influences on fall fashions misstated the name of a band that included the singer Holly Golightly. It is Thee Headcoatees, not Three Headcoatees.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about the spread of the refugee crisis in the Darfur region of Sudan referred incorrectly to the armed groups considered responsible for a campaign of terror that is a cause of the crisis, which the Bush administration has called genocide. Those groups are the government forces and allied Arab militias known as the janjaweed, not the rebels who are battling them.

title: Even From Hospital, Pataki Has Albany in Budget Distress
description: ALBANY, March 1 - With only a month until the state's budget deadline, Gov. George E. Pataki continues to negotiate with legislative leaders from his hospital bed. And despite his weakened condition and lame-duck status, his budgets continue to drive Albany crazy.

title: Oscar's message: Quality is now a niche market
Energy merger rushshakes Europe markets
Arts, Briefly; Fox Runs Away From Its Hounds
description: "American Idol," with Ryan Seacrest, right, as host, lifted Fox to another overall victory in Nielsen's overnight estimates of Tuesday's shows. Its 90-minute edition, in which the top 10 female contestants performed, drew 29.75 million viewers. But that total failed to buoy the Tuesday episode of "The War at Home," which followed "Idol"; the sitcom brought in 13.54 million viewers, a steep drop. CBS placed second for the night among total viewers and scraped by NBC in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Its two-hour premiere of "Amazing Race" attracted 10.27 million viewers. That total was down compared with the show's family edition in the fall. KATE AURTHUR

title: Critics Say Memorial Plan Imperils Towers' Remnants
description: To a growing chorus of criticism of the World Trade Center memorial and museum -- that it may be unsafe, that it will not properly honor the dead, that it is too much of a fund-raising challenge -- the National Trust for Historic Preservation has added its own concern: that it would cause the "substantial destruction" of the remaining foundations of the twin towers.

title: Reviled and exploited, they enrich Moscow
Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLNY, LIPSY, DENYSE
description: DOLNY-LIPSY--Denyse. It is with profound sadness that the Heschel School community mourns the untimely passing of Denyse, wife of Mark Lipsy, mother of Talia and our student Boaz, after a valiant struggle with her illness. May this brave, vibrant, sensitive, caring woman rest in peace. Our hearts go out to the entire Dolny-Lipsy family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alisa R. Doctoroff President Roanna Shorofsky Head of School

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Mexico City Backs Away From Order Closing Hotel
description: Mexico City officials announced that they would not immediately shut down the popular Sheraton Mara Isabel after its representatives provided documents indicating that the 755-room hotel had corrected most of a long list of code violations. Virginia Jaramillo Flores, the leading city official in the borough where the hotel stands, said the hotel was given 72 hours to come to full compliance with zoning laws. The hotel stirred outrage among the leftist leaders of the city government last month when, at the request of the United States, it forced out 16 Cuban officials meeting there with American oil executives. GINGER THOMPSON (NYT)

title: Iraqi Parties Want Jaafari Out of Prime Minister Race
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 1 - In a move that could redraw Iraq's political map, leaders of Iraq's Kurdish, Sunni and secular parties are considering a plan to ask the country's largest Shiite bloc to withdraw Ibrahim Jaafari as its candidate for prime minister in the new government.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about objections to plans by America Online and Yahoo to charge fees for sending some e-mail referred imprecisely to a protest effort. An alliance of nonprofit and public-interest groups is aiming a protest at America Online; while the groups also object to e-mail fees planned by Yahoo, they have not organized a protest against it.

title: GE unit in France must translate documents
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Rescue From Burning Building
description: Firefighters rescued a woman from the top floor of a burning 24-story building early yesterday morning, the Fire Department said. The woman climbed onto a window ledge at 1700 Bedford Avenue in Crown Heights about 3 a.m. to escape smoke, which had filled the building. A firefighter was lowered by a rope and carried the woman to safety, according to the Fire Department. The woman, whom fire officials did not identify, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, along with one firefighter and two other residents. Fire officials said that their injuries were not life-threatening. The fire, which was mainly confined to the trash compactor room in the basement, was brought under control at 4:13 a.m., officials reported.

title: Letter from India: Booker Prize winner takes to the streets
In Paris, Splashes of Black
description: PARIS, March 1 - When five designers from five countries, each working independently and each with a different point of view on style, can agree on the importance of a formal black coat, one gets a sense that there is at last some coherence between the extremes of the fall season.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (5) SKATING WITH CELEBRITIES -- Season finale. This ice-skating competition is down to the final two celebrities: Kristy Swanson, the original Buffy the Vampire Slayer, who is reportedly now romantically involved with her married skating partner, Lloyd Eisler (above, with Ms. Swanson); and Jillian Barberie, the television host, whose partner on the ice is John Zimmerman.

title: Budget Cuts Back Much-Promoted NASA Missions
description: Some of the most highly promoted missions on NASA's scientific agenda would be postponed indefinitely or perhaps even canceled under the agency's new budget, despite its administrator's vow to Congress six months ago that not "one thin dime" would be taken from space science to pay for President Bush's plan to send astronauts to the Moon and Mars.

title: Corrections
description: The Physical Culture column on Feb. 16, about treadmills, misstated the length of time that Brady Crain, a running coach, tested one model. Although he did use the four others for a few weeks, he tried the Precor M9.35i for three days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALLINGER, JERROLD M.
description: BALLINGER -- Jerrold M. Journalist and author, on Tuesday, February 28, 2006, of New York City. Beloved brother of Ruth and Larry Shavelson of Fort Lee, NJ. Dear uncle of Michael, Lynn, Robert and Marlene. Services will be 11AM today at Temple Sholom, 385 Howland Ave, River Edge, NJ.

title: It's Official: Mark Green Is Running for Attorney General
description: He began raising money for his statewide political campaign nearly two years ago. And he has spent more than a year traveling to every corner of New York in pursuit of votes. But it was not until yesterday that Mark Green, the former public advocate of New York City and onetime mayoral nominee, made official what has long been well known to anyone interested in state politics: He is running for attorney general.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Victims' Parents Protest Film About Suicide Bombers

title: Italy Concludes Soviets Were Behind 1981 Plot to Kill Pope
description: ROME, March 2 A Citing new photographic analysis, an Italian parliamentary commission has concluded that top Soviet leaders were behind the failed plot to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981.

title: Ex-Enron Official Insists Chief Knew of Wrongdoing
description: HOUSTON, March 1 - Despite intense questioning by a defense lawyer, the former head of Enron's Energy Services retail unit insisted Wednesday that Jeffrey K. Skilling should have known he was committing a crime by lying about a questionable accounting move.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAIG, SHIRLEY
description: BAIG--Shirley. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Shirley Baig, associated with The Times since November, 1946 until retiring in June, 1986.

title: Beyond Data: Does Therapy Work?
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Kids Rule
description: Move over, Barry Manilow and Andrea Bocelli. In an unusual convergence, the top three albums on the Billboard chart this week are aimed at young listeners. The soundtrack to "High School Musical" (Disney), the hit television movie for teenagers and 'tweens, reached No. 1 with 101,000 in sales in its seventh week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It is the first television soundtrack to reach the top slot since "Miami Vice" two decades ago. "Kidz Bop 9" (Razor & Tie), the latest in a steadily selling franchise of schoolyard-friendly versions of pop hits, reached No. 2 with 98,000 sales, and Jack Johnson's soundtrack to "Curious George" (Universal), above, was right behind with 89,000. In a slow week overall at record stores, "Kidz Bop" was the only new album to reach the Top 20, and only "High School Musical" had an increase over the week before. BEN SISARIO

title: Putting Order to Acts That Defy Order
description: WALID RAAD, an artist who carries with him lessons from Lebanon, spoke about the shocks that radiate from a single explosion.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,288 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: 2 Top Senators Seek an Agency Policing Ethics at the Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - The Republican and Democratic leaders of a Senate committee responsible for legislation on lobbying are expected to propose an independent office on Thursday that would investigate ethics abuses in either house of Congress.

title: Milton Katims, 96, Conductor Who Led Seattle Symphony, Dies
description: Milton Katims, an American conductor and noted violist who played under Toscanini and led the Seattle Symphony for more than two decades, died on Monday in Shoreline, Wash., a suburb of Seattle. He was 96.

title: Computing error
A Russian Night, Colored With a Sense of the Tragic
description: David Finckel, the cellist of the Emerson String Quartet, and his wife, Wu Han, a pianist who has long been a dedicated chamber music player, were appointed artistic directors of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in 2004, but they are only now settling into the job. This is a business, after all, that doesn't operate in real time: programming and administrative decisions are made years in advance. Having recently announced next season's programs, the first they had planned themselves, they spent Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, introducing themselves as musicians to the society's audience, or at least to listeners who have not been following their adventures through a series of exemplary recordings on their own ArtistLed label.

title: Reports Give Conflicting Views of Congestion Pricing in City
description: For an idea that barely exists on paper and has the support of neither the mayor nor the City Council, congestion pricing -- charging a fee for driving into the busiest areas of the city at the busiest times -- has attracted a striking amount of controversy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROH, THE HON. ROBERT THEODORE
description: GROH--The Hon. Robert Theodore. Of Quogue on February 27, 2006 in his 91st year. Loving grandfather of Anne Law (James) of East Moriches, NY. Devoted friend and companion of Thomas C. Feaster of Quogue, NY. Predeceased by his loving wife, Anne Marie Groh (nee Conlin), daughter Kathleen Marie Groh and son Robert Gerald Groh. Retired New York State Supreme Court Justice, Queens County, former Queens County Deputy Borough President, Commissioner of Sanitation for the City of New York, Civil Court Justice, State of New York, Queens County, Adjutant Justice Villages of Quogue and Westhampton Beach, Trustee and Past President of the Queens Borough Public Library, Member of Board of Directors and Past President of Queens Centers for Progress, former Trustee of Booth Memorial Hospital, Pride of Judea and Visions. A 2nd Lieutenant in the U.S. Army, bodyguard to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Legal Staff to General Douglas MacArthur for the Occupied Forces, Japan. Graduate of Xavier High School and Fordham School of Law. Member of the Knights of Malta, Knights of Columbus Council #

title: Iraqi Parties Ask Shiites to Drop Jaafari as Prime Minister
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 2 ALeaders of Iraq's Kurdish, secular and Sunni Arab parties asked the main Shiite alliance today to withdraw its support for Ibrahim al-Jaafari to remain as prime minister in the next government, saying Mr. Jaafari failed to control the sectarian violence that swept the country over the past week.

title: On The Street: Then
description: IN the winter of 1992 audacious New York women opted to put a little swagger in their step, dressing with a distinctly mannish flair. Their notion of style, built on classic haberdashery, was not so much adapted from a man's wardrobe as pilfered outright. It owed a debt to brazen, if sometimes unlikely, fashion plates like George Sand, a sensation in her day who flaunted mannish frock coats and cravats, and that hoyden Coco Chanel, who wore her boyfriend's sweaters with a near-fetishistic fidelity.

title: Yahoo Says It Is Backing Away From TV-Style Web Shows
description: After proclaiming grand plans to bring elaborately produced sitcoms, talk shows and other television-style programs to the Internet, the head of Yahoo's Media Group said yesterday that he was sharply scaling back those efforts. He said the group would shift its focus to content acquired from other media companies or submitted by users.

title: Arnold A. Rogow, 81, a Writer Who Put History on the Couch, Dies
description: Arnold A. Rogow, an author and political scientist who trained as a psychoanalyst to gain insight into historical figures like Alexander Hamilton, died on Feb. 14 at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: 4 to Plead Guilty on Chip Pricing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 - Four executives of Hynix Semiconductor, a South Korean supplier of memory chips, have agreed to plead guilty and serve prison time in the United States for their roles in a price-fixing conspiracy, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.

title: Microsoft accuses EU of working with rivals
Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, ABRAHAM
description: ZUCKERMAN - Abraham. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Abraham Zuckerman, associated with The Times since April, 1972 until retiring in October, 1976.

title: Political anger grows amid more Iraqi deaths
Generals from the 2 Koreas have rare meeting
For Instant Wit, Just Add Paint
description: An 8 1/2-by-11-inch Mylar stencil called Traffic, above, can be used to embellish a wall, lampshade or other surface. It is one of several patterns available from Stencil1, a Brooklyn company. Ed Roth, the company's owner, is a graphic designer who once owned a Brooklyn gallery dedicated to street art and graffiti. He said he thought it would be interesting to apply the medium's wit and humor to interiors. Other patterns include retro muscle cars and a go-go dancer; $10.50 each at stencil1.com. CURRENTS: STENCILS

title: Ramirez Turns Bumpy Trail Into a Happy Trail
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., March 1 - The saga of Manny Ramirez always seems to end the same way. No matter what happens, Ramirez shows up for work -- eventually -- and hits better than almost anyone alive.

title: Central American Trade Deal Is Being Delayed by Partners
description: MEXICO CITY, March 1 - Two months after the Central American Free Trade Agreement was supposed to go into effect, only El Salvador is ready to join, frustrating a hard-won victory for Washington in its push toward free trade.

title: To Dress Your Windows, Help Is at Your Fingertips
description: Choosing and installing window treatments can be daunting, but a new Web site, theshadestore.com, makes the task easier. It offers custom shades, blinds and draperies in a wide variety of fabrics and other materials, many of them exclusive to the site. Ian Gibbs, an owner of the company, said the prices are often 15 percent lower than those of comparable items sold elsewhere. Instructions online for both measuring and installation seem easy to follow, and help is available by phone. Glare-reducing solar shades, above, start at $134 for a 36-by-60-inch shade; (800) 754-1455.

title: Roundup: World Classic loses 4 more star players
The Abusive New Federalism
description: After a murky legislative process distinguished by a lack of any public hearing, the House is ready to rush to approve a special-interest measure for the food industry today. The bill would pre-empt all state food safety regulations that are more protective than federal standards. A bipartisan majority behind this clearly dangerous bill is echoing the industry's line that the goal is simply to end consumers' confusion about varying state regulations that govern warning labels and protective inspections.

title: Britain's Liberal Democrats choose veteran as leader
The War Machine Is Consuming Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Deal Faces Skepticism From Congress and Allies
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 A In concluding its nuclear deal with India, the Bush administration faces significant opposition in Congress and tough questions from its allies on whether the arrangement could set a precedent encouraging the spread of nuclear weapons to Iran and other potential foes of the United States.

title: To Bolster Audience, Soaps Turn to the Web
description: THE advertising giant that popularized the soap opera, first on radio and then on television, is going online with a multimillion-dollar promotional campaign to stimulate interest in its two remaining shows.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Officer's Death Called Strange
description: A state medical examiner performed an autopsy yesterday on Police Officer Kevin Jones, 42, who was found dead in his apartment on Tuesday evening, officials said. The results of the autopsy will not be known for up to two weeks, said the Jersey City police chief, Robert Troy, who called the death "strange, but not suspicious." Over the weekend Officer Jones complained of flulike symptoms, but did not go to the hospital, said his brother Robert Jones. Officer Jones was an Army veteran who returned from Iraq in November.

description: NEW YORK

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15
