Paid Notice: Deaths   KOHLOFF, ROLAND
description: KOHLOFF--Roland. The entire Juilliard community mourn the passing of Roland Kohloff, a member of the faculty since 1978 and Chairman of the Percussion Department. A brilliant performer, dedicated teacher, and compassionate human being, Roland was a passionate advocate also for his students and for his art. With enormous energy and a wonderful smile, Roland approached all endeavors with an enthusiasm that was contagious. His personal and artistic integrity made him a respected and trusted colleague. Our condolences go to his entire family. He will be deeply missed by us all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELSTEIN, SIDNEY
description: KELSTEIN--Sidney. On February 28, 2006. Loving life partner of Karen Eller. Beloved father of Madelyn and Richard. Cherished grandfather of Cecelia, Rose, Sean, Max, Sam and Anna. Services Thursday 11:15 AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Camera for Steady Images in an Unstable World
description: The new Canon Elph PowerShot, the SD700, is practically unshakable. Designed for rough roads and the high seas, the camera features improved optical image stabilization and a faster shutter speed to grab action shots and capture changing scenes.

title: Lifestyles of the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOULD, JACK U.
description: GOULD--Jack U. On March 1, 2006. Beloved husband of Esther. Loving father of Jessica Stuart Yudelson and fatherin-law of Jerry Yudelson. Also survived by many dear friends. Services Sunday 11:15 AM at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Cooper Union for the Advancemnent of Science and Art, Cooper Square, NY, NY 10003.

title: Kenyan police raid TV station and newspaper
A New Season Arrives With a Paul Taylor Premiere
description: Over the first 50 years of Paul Taylor's career, the choreographer has tried nearly everything, in all its dizzying variety of mood and style. Most of that everything was on display in last winter's 50th-anniversary season and will be on display again in the company's season that opened on Tuesday night at City Center.

title: Arts, Briefly; Coming Attractions At Kennedy Center
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington announced plans yesterday for a 2006-07 season that includes theater, dance, classical music, opera, jazz and children's productions. The season will include a new production of "Carnival!," a jazz festival celebrating that most American of musical forms, and the 10th anniversary of the Millennium Stage, which presents a free daily performance at the center. From Oct. 10 to Feb. 7, the center will offer a tribute honoring the centennial of Dmitri Shostakovich's birth. That event will include the National Symphony Orchestra, the violinist Maxim Vengerov, the pianist Martha Argerich, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the Emerson String Quartet, the pianist Joseph Kalichstein and the Kirov Opera. On Jan. 18, 20 and 22, the orchestra's music director, Leonard Slatkin, will lead a concert performance of Richard Strauss's opera "Salome," with Deborah Voigt in the title role. The theater season will include a Royal Shakespeare Company production of "Coriolanus," from April 14 to May 6, 2007. JOHN FILES

title: New York and in Boston, Copley Place
description: Barneys New York will open its first large store in 12 years next week, on March 10, at Copley Place in Boston. The two-story store will feature a 45-foot-wide octagonal skylight, a 30-foot-high glass facade and a fireplace in the women's shoe section (which might not actually warm all 4,000-square-feet of that department).

title: American Diplomat Is Killed in Blast Outside Karachi Consulate
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 2 A Four people, including a United States diplomat, were killed today when a powerful bomb triggered by a suicide bomber went off in the southern port city of Karachi, according to Pakistani officials. The attack came just two days before President Bush is to visit Pakistan, but Mr. Bush said in New Delhi today that he would continue with his trip nevertheless.

title: A Mirror That Will Inform You if the Weather Looks as Good as You
description: Getting ready in the morning may have become a little easier. With the Firenze Mirror Weather Forecaster from Oregon Scientific, you can coif your hair, smooth your lapels and get the day's weather report at once.

title: No, it's not Vietnam. This one's a civil war
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline President Is Removed
description: Japan Airlines removed its president, Toshiyuki Shinmachi, ending a boardroom feud that was started by the billionaire Eitaro Itoyama, left, the company's biggest individual shareholder and Japan's fourth-richest man. Mr. Shinmachi, who took over in April, will be succeeded by the 58-year-old finance director Haruka Nishimatsu, the airline said. Mr. Itoyama last month urged Mr. Shinmachi, 63, to quit to take the blame for repeated safety lapses and a failure to pay dividends. His successor must win union support to cut wages by 10 percent and regain customers lost to All Nippon Airways. Mr. Itoyama, a former member of Parliament, owns golf courses and resorts and has a personal fortune estimated at $4.9 billion, according to Forbes magazine. Mr. Itoyama owns 4 percent of Japan Airlines and his February demand that Mr. Shinmachi resign was supported four days later by four of Japan Airlines' directors. As many as 400 Japan Airlines managers signed petitions calling for a resignation.

title: A Little SoHo, a Little St.-Tropez, All Welcoming
description: WHEN Brad Zipper hired Robert and Cortney Novogratz to design the interior of his four-story town house in Little Italy two years ago, he had one firm requirement. "I wanted a place where I could entertain," said Mr. Zipper, 41, "whether for friends or business, or a little bit of both."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a plea deal by a military contractor, Mitchell Wade, in a $1 million bribery case misstated the political affiliation of Representative Virgil H. Goode Jr. of Virginia, who said he was surprised to learn that his campaign had received illegal contributions from Mr. Wade. He is a Republican.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEGAL, ARNOLD
description: SEGAL--Arnold. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of longtime friend and supporter, Arnold Segal. A member of the President's Circle, he advanced the Institute's interests in his New Jersey community and provided a major gift in support of research in cancer and multiple sclerosis. We salute his dedication to Jewish causes and his visionary philanthropy, and send our heartfelt condolences to his wife Hattie, sons Richard, Stephen and Kenneth, his family and wide circle of friends. Robert B. Machinist, Chair, American Committee Dr. Albert Willner, President, American Committee Martin S. Kraar, Exec. V.P., American Committee James Gurland, Director, New Jersey Region Mandy Moross, Chair, Weizmann Institute Prof. Ilan Chet, President Weizmann Institute

title: Governor, In High Spirits, Joins Briefing On His Illness
description: Seeking to allay concerns about his health after two operations for a ruptured appendix, Gov. George E. Pataki made a surprise appearance yesterday during a hospital news conference, joking with reporters and saying he was eager to go home.

School Builders Drop Plan to Demolish Nearby Sex Theater and Hotel
description: PASSAIC, N.J., March 1 - When the Passaic school district chose a home for a new $37 million elementary school, plans included the purchase and demolition of two nearby buildings deemed unsuitable for a school zone: the Montauk Theater, which specializes in pornography, and the Hotel Passaic, the site of prostitution arrests.

title: Brooding Intensity, Kept Just Below the Boiling Point
description: To the subculture that tracks the movements of the so-called punk-folk goddess Ani DiFranco, the bassist Todd Sickafoose is known for sensitivity and stamina; he has toured extensively with Ms. DiFranco in a duo, bearing the full weight of her accompaniment and absorbing the full voltage of her energies. Mr. Sickafoose has a life outside that orbit, as a prominent member of overlapping underground scenes in the Bay Area, Los Angeles and New York (mainly Brooklyn). It should come as no surprise that he's also a serious bandleader, as he confirmed at Barbs in Park Slope on Tuesday night.

description: Correction Appended

title: Always Having to Say He's Sorry
description: If there were a trapdoor that was somehow rigged to open beneath the U.S. senators we really don't need, Conrad Burns of Montana would surely fall right through it.

title: Something for Dancers Who Still Love the 80's
description: Getting into America is harder than ever. Everyone knows someone who has been pulled aside at J.F.K., interrogated at L.A.X., turned away at some embassy overseas. But apparently this increased vigilance hasn't been enough to repel James Blunt, the former British Army officer who has scored his first American hit with "You're Beautiful." The song gives him a chance to murmur that compliment in a breathy falsetto, and the video gives him a chance to show off the impressive results of military calisthenics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROOT, ALAN CHARLES
description: ROOT--Alan Charles. A resident of Las Vegas and formerly of New York, born April 11, 1925, passsed away February 24, 2006. Educated at Oxford, Cambridge and Stanford, Alan was retired from the American Standard Company, NJ. Service will be held 2PM Saturday, March 4, 2006 at Christ Church Episcopal, 2000 S. Maryland Parkway, Las Vegas, NV 89104.

National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Charity Board Members Quit Over Adoption Plan
description: Seven board members of Catholic Charities have resigned after the state's four Roman Catholic bishops announced that they planned to seek an exemption from state rules requiring the church to ease adoptions for same-sex couples. Catholic Charities manages adoptions for the Archdiocese of Boston, and has placed children with 13 same-sex couples. In a statement, the seven members said the bishop's proposal "undermines our priority" of placing children in homes, and seeking an exemption shows a "profound disrespect" for same-sex couples. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: The Dubai Ports Deal
description: President Bush is not doing any favors for America's Arab allies with his attitude toward the deal that would put a Dubai state-owned company in control of operations at terminals within six American ports. The administration initially stonewalled Congress when lawmakers demanded more information. Now that the company, Dubai Ports World, has wisely agreed to a 45-day review of potential security risks, the White House seems to feel that all it's required to do is lobby recalcitrant Republicans and "educate" the public about the rightness of the original decision.

title: Briefly: Soviet Union accused in attack on pope in '81
Corrections
description: A chart on Tuesday listing lobbyists who became politicians referred incorrectly to Representative Dan Lungren's election in 2004. Mr. Lungren, who represented Long Beach, Calif., from 1979 to 1989, was elected to represent the Sacramento area in 2004. He was not re-elected to his old seat.

title: Rebels With a Cross
description: BY phone from Nashville Bryan Norman was talking about rebellion, God and the mullet haircut. Mr. Norman, 26, is the editor of a gothic scripted, visually hyperactive book called "The New Rebellion Handbook," and he took a particular line on the romance of the rebel.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Picaresque Adventures of La Mancha Man and Sancho Panza
description: Impossible dreamers seeking windmills at which to tilt will need to look elsewhere than "El Quijote," Repertorio Espaol's cheerful but uneven Spanish-language dramatization of the Cervantes classic. (A simultaneous English translation is available.) This "Quijote," adapted by the renowned Colombian director Santiago Garca, omits the book's most familiar image, but there is an attack on a flour mill, not to mention the search for Dulcinea and the capture of Don Quixote, all staged with varying degrees of effectiveness.

title: Tourists are returning to Sri Lanka's beaches
Young, Inexpensive, Ready to Shine
description: TAMPA, Fla.  He is one of the most important pitchers on the Yankees and, presumably, will become even more valuable in the future. He shows as much emotion as someone who is napping. He produces grounders almost as steadily as a coach tapping them to infielders.

title: Wider Use of ImClone Drug
description: ImClone Systems has won federal approval to sell its Erbitux cancer medicine as a treatment for patients with head and neck tumors, the first such medicine in 45 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS BEIRNE, CAROL
description: PHILLIPS BEIRNE--Carol. Clinique Laboratories LLC and The Estee Lauder Companies, Inc., mourn the passing of Carol Phillips Beirne, Clinique's Founder and former Chairman, on March 1, 2006. Launched in 1968, Clinique became the first beauty brand to be guided by a dermatologist, as well as the first allergy-tested and fragrance free line ever marketed. Under Carol's guidance, it became the best-selling cosmetics brand in The United States, as well as in many of the approximately 130 countries around the world in which it is marketed. Carol retired in 1992. We extend our deepest sympathy to Carol's sister, Lucia Haile; her daughter Deirdre Beirne Brown; her granddaughter, Jennifer Morrell, and her two greatgranddaughters. Burial will be private. The family has requested that contributions in memory of Carol be made to: The Sag Harbor Historical Society, P.O. Box 1709, Sag Harbor, New York 11963; The John Jermain Memorial Library, P.O. Box 569, Sag Harbor, New York 11963, or The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, 60 East 56th Street, 8th Floor, New York, New York 10022.

title: Car Explosion in Gaza City Kills a Leader of Jihad Group
description: JERUSALEM, March 1 - A leader in the armed wing of the Palestinian faction Islamic Jihad was killed Wednesday when an explosion tore a car apart on a busy street in Gaza City.

title: Both Ford and G.M. to Scale Back Production
description: DETROIT, March 1 - Both General Motors and Ford said Wednesday they would scale back production in the second quarter, a move that reflects their falling sales and shrinking market share in the United States.

title: One Man, One Keyboard, Several Approaches
description: Playing the piano alone at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night, Fred Hersch turned songs into double exposures, or triple exposures if you want: melody, harmony and rhythm.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Shots Fired At Police Officers
description: Three police officers were fired upon while patrolling near the intersection of Bainbridge Street and Patchen Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant about 1:50 p.m. yesterday, the police said. The officers, who were not injured, encountered three arguing men and were shot at, the police said. The officers, who did not return fire, chased the men, captured two of them and recovered a handgun. The suspects were not identified by the police yesterday evening.

title: BERLIN FILE SAYS GERMANY'S SPIES AIDED U.S. IN IRAQ
description: BERLIN, March 1 - Starting in early 2003 and lasting through the American military invasion of Iraq, a German intelligence officer stationed in the office of Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the American commander of the invasion, passed on to the United States information being gathered in Baghdad by two German intelligence officers operating there, a classified German review has found.

description: LOS ANGELES is a place where people live in a world of fantasies, and earn their livings by promoting fantasies, and so all the world -- even the popular local clothing boutique -- becomes a place to satisfy the needs for props and equipment.

description: RAWITZ--Irwin. On February 28, 2006, at the age of 87. Loving husband of Ann for fifty years. Devoted father of Gary, Stella, Marcy, Mitchell, and Melissa. Proud grandfather of Andrew, Alexander, and Brittney. He was very wonderful.

title: Justices Express Concern Over Aspects of Some Texas Redistricting
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - Texas Democrats had their day in the Supreme Court on Wednesday to challenge the unusual middecade redistricting of the state's Congressional delegation that led to the loss of five Democratic seats and helped solidify Republican control of Congress.

title: N.J. Nurse Sentenced to Life for Killing 22
description: Charles Cullen, the nurse who admitted killing as many as 40 intensive-care patients with fatal injections, was sentenced today to life in prison without parole for the deaths of 22 victims in New Jersey.

title: Queens Day Care Worker Charged With Raping Boy, 4
description: A day care worker in Queens was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 4-year-old boy in her care, the authorities said.

title: Milosevic Team Seeks to Subpoena Bill Clinton
description: PARIS, March 1 - Lawyers for Slobodan Milosevic have asked the court trying him on war crimes charges to issue a subpoena for Bill Clinton to testify at the trial.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: For St. Patrick's New Rector, an Old Rite: Making Crosses of Ash
description: The Rev. Robert T. Ritchie, the freshly appointed rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, woke up at 3 a.m. in his old rectory in the Bronx yesterday to make sure he made it to Ash Wednesday services at his new church on time.

title: Insider Art
description: The Whitney Biennial remains an insider's affair: It will seem old hat to aficionados and inscrutable to many others.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "The Pajama Game," "Defiance" and "A Parsifal."

title: A Look at the Exhibits
Right About Now . . . and Then
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: British Pizza Entrepreneur Takes Stake in Fashion Chain
description: Luke Johnson, the restaurant entrepreneur and chairman of Channel 4, has moved into retail by taking a stake in East, the fashion chain. He is leading a consortium of 11 private businessmen taking a 50 percent stake in the company.

title: The Carpetbagger Handicaps the Field
description: David Carr offers his predictions in nine major categories for this year's Academy Awards.

title: Cramer Systems Picks Up T-Soft
description: Telecommunications software provider Cramer Systems Ltd. has revamped its market strategy under new CEO Guy Dubois, scrapping its IPO plans and focusing instead on expansion. That expansion started with the acquisition of Israeli firm T-Soft, a specialist in network discovery and data reconciliation that counts carriers such as Belgacom and Swisscom among its customers.

title: IXI Mobile Acquired in $42 Million Stock Deal
description: Israel Technology Acquisition said on Wednesday it has agreed to acquire IXI Mobile for about $42 million in stock. IXI is a privately held developer of mobile messaging products, based in Redwood City, Calif.

title: Wall Streets Spring Line-up: Taking Stock
description: This season brings a rebirth for the New York Stock Exchange, a fresh assault on regulation by the industrys biggest lobbying group, a new wardrobe for star dealmaker Bruce Wasserstein, big CEO bonuses and a new brokerage chief at Morgan Stanley.

title: Chipotle IPO Spiced Up February
description: Chipotle Mexican Grill, American Railcar Industries and NightHawk Radiology Services turned in the best year-to-date gains among the 32 initial public offerings so far as the first two months of 2006 came to a close.

title: Lasalle Outsources Chicago Jobs
description: LaSalle Bank on Tuesday told 160 Chicago workers that theyll be losing their jobs as part of its parents previously announced plans to slash about 3,500 information technology positions worldwide.

title: U.K. Hedge Fund Faces Deadline to Appeal Fine
description: Embattled hedge fund trader Philippe Jabre and the London hedge fund GLG Partners have 28 days to appeal against a Financial Services Authority decision to fine them each 750,000 pound for alleged insider dealing.

title: Analyst Unimpressed by Intrawest Move
description: Dont buy shares of ski-resort operator Intrawest based on the companys announcement it has hired an investment banker and is ready to entertain interesting ideas to fuel growth, advises National Bank Financial analyst Michael Smith.

title: Perot Systems Buys Outsourcing Firm eServ
description: Perot Systems has acquired eServ, a provider of high-end product engineering outsourcing services, for $21 million. The acquisition launches Perot Systems expansion into outsourced engineering services, broadening the companys suite of services for the automotive, manufacturing and industrial services segments.

title: Falconbridge Bid May End Union Rivalry
description: Bob Dickie, a retired worker at Inco Ltd., says the Canadian nickel producers $12.5 billion bid for Falconbridge Ltd. may finish a job he started almost 50 years ago: combining two unions that fought for a generation

title: Indonesia to Raise $2 Billion in Debt Sale
description: Indonesia plans to raise $2 billion in its biggest overseas debt sale as it takes advantage of a fall in borrowing costs to fund its budget deficit.

title: 3i Joins $2.5 Million Round for Carbonite
description: Carbonite has raised a $2.5 million Series A round with plans to begin selling its Internet-based consumer data-storage service in late April.

title: VCs Put More Money into Medical Devices
description: A healthy increase in venture-capital funding of medical-device companies has helped lift overall investments in life-sciences industries, even as biotechnology deals have tailed off.

title: Ex-Enron Official Insists Chief Knew of Wrongdoing
description: Despite intense questioning by a defense lawyer, the former head of Enrons Energy Services retail unit insisted Wednesday that Jeffrey K. Skilling should have known he was committing a crime by lying about a questionable accounting move.

title: Paris Collections
description: Women's wear from the fall 2006 fashion shows.

title: BEA Systems Buys Software Provider
description: BEA Systems said that it paid $87.5 million to acquire Fuego, a business process management software developer, in a move aimed at cementing its position in the market for service-oriented architecture software.

title: Tribe Looks for VCs, Twenty-Somethings
description: Tribe Networks is raising between $4 million and $8 million in Series C financing to help the social networking Web site capture the attention of post-college twenty-somethings, VentureWire reported. The three-year-old company previously sealed a $6.5 million Series A round in November 2003 from venture firm Mayfield, and publishers Knight Ridder and the Washington Post Co.

title: PE Firms Threaten U.K. Exodus
description: The private equity industry has warned the British chancellor that it will consider abandoning the United Kingdom if he clamps down on its profits. The Treasury is currently reviewing the way it taxes private equity deals and, while changes are not imminent, the industry fears that it has to emphasize the contribution it makes to the British economy ahead of Gordon Browns Budget on March 22.

title: Hicks Muse Changes Name, Adds Partners
description: Dallas buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst said Wednesday that it is changing its name to HM Capital Partners LLC and adding three new partners. The name change, effective immediately, reflects a generational shift.

title: Mittal Sends Project Plans to France
description: France said Wednesday it has received the outline of Mittal Steels industrial project for European rival Arcelor, for which it has made a $23 billion bid.

title: Crash Producers Clash Over Credit and Payment
description: On the eve of this weekends Academy Awards, a bare-knuckled fight has broken out among the producers of one of the leading Oscar-nominated movies, Crash, over two of the things Hollywood cares about most: money and credit.

title: ThyssenKrupp Favors Dofasco Deal
description: German steel maker ThyssenKrupp is examining all its options, including alternatives to its proposed acquisition of Canadian steel company Dofasco, as part of a new corporate strategy, a board member said Wednesday.

title: Fannie Mae Ex-Chief Sued Over Charity Gifts
description: Franklin Raines, the ousted chief of troubled mortgage giant Fannie Mae, is being accused of corrupting its directors by giving them $12 million in charity checks to ignore his scandals.

title: Danas Missed Payment Stokes Bankruptcy Fears
description: Dana, the worlds largest maker of axles for light trucks, added fuel to mounting speculation about a potential bankruptcy filing when it missed a semi-annual bond payment of $21 million due today. Failure to make the interest payments by March 31 would result in an eventual default.

title: More BofA Staffers Jump to Jefferies
description: Seven more employees of a Bank of America unit in New York that serves hedge-fund customers have jumped to rival Jefferies. The move follows last week announcement that a team of six BofA employees had joined Jefferies prime brokerage services division.

title: Sale of GMAC Stake May Have Stalled, Analyst Says
description: General Motors plan to sell off a majority stake in its GMAC finance unit to raise cash and cut its borrowing costs appears to have stalled, a Goldman Sachs analyst said on Wednesday. A sale is widely seen as a key step to raising credit ratings at the auto giants financing arm.

title: Xstrata to Pay $1.7 Billion for Coal Mining Stake
description: Xstrata, the London mining giant, has agreed to pay Glencore, its major shareholder, $1.7 billion for a stake in one of the worlds most valuable coal projects. The proposed deal, which will have to be approved by Xstratas other shareholders, will give the London-based company a one-third stake in the massive Cerrejn project in Colombia.

title: U.S. Investigates Another Dubai Deal Amid Ports Ruckus
description: Stung by the public outcry over the Dubai port deal, the Bush administration has begun a national security investigation of another Dubai-owned company set to take over plants in Georgia and Connecticut that make precision components used in engines for military aircraft and tanks.

title: Overstock Chief Says S.E.C. Investigated Journalists on Its Own
description: The chief executive of Overstock.com said on Wednesday that federal regulators, not his company, an online retailer, were behind the subpoenas of business journalists as part of an investigation into allegations that Overstock.coms stock was manipulated.

title: Goldman on Sidelines as NYSE Sets Banking Team
description: J.P. Morgan Chase, Lehman Brothers Holdings, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley will arrange a sale of New York Stock Exchange shares that may raise as much as $2 billion, three people briefed on the selection said.

title: Italy Steps Up Protest Over French Deal for Suez
description: Italy has filed a document with the European Commission that accuses the French government of flouting European law by engineering a merger between Gaz de France and Suez in order to derail a potential bid for Suez by Enel of Italy.

title: The Producers  Theyre Back and This Time Theyve Got Lawyers
description: Not everyone is spending the run-up to the Oscar picking out frocks and deciding what party to attend. Cathy Schulman mentioned greed and ego in her suit against Bob Yari, a fellow producer on Crash. Not all manners were thrown to the wind. At least they waited until the voting was closed to go at each others throats. As my colleague Sharon Waxman writes:

title: Clock Watchers
description: Academy Awards producer Gil Cates is serious about keeping the old gimlet eye on the clock, and as Defamer points out, has enlisted Tom Hanks, of all people, as his enforcer. Hanks is on a DVD given to potential winners, reminding them that hugging half the audience on the way to the podium is going to chew up precious seconds. And once there, he reminds everyone to keep it simple and keep it short. Defamer is having none of it, of course:

title: Numerology Squared
description: If youre the kind of Oscar fan who spends your afternoons sneaking a peek at your cubicle mates chart to see where she is headed, you might want to check in on the chart in process at OscarWatch.com, which aggregates choices from some of the smartest Oscar cogitators on the web.

title: As Weill Pulled in $21.5 Million, Citigroup Paid the Tax

Not only did Citigroups board hand Mr. Weill $21.5 million in pay; it also took care of the taxes on his benefits. The cost to Citigroup shareholders was hundreds of thousands of dollars, based on public filings disclosed yesterday.

title: Cross-Pond Frolic
description: Readers who have their own case of pre-Oscar ennui could do worse than read a journal put together by the folks from the BBC here to cover the proceedings. They are clearly having fun and dont have time for all the jaded, seen-it-all stuff you will be reading so much of in the coming days.

title: Therapy Born of the Calendar
description: The Bagger apparently had significant issues yesterday, but some concerned colleagues found some stout butterfly nets and took him straightaway to a mental health clinic for some much needed triage. The diagnosis? Level Four Oscar Fatigue, characterized by facial tics, endless ruminations over various categories, and nightmares involving being chased by little golden statues with no discernible legs. (Its the little hopping movement they make that really freaks him out.) He entered a day of deprogramming and talk therapy, with an emphasis on remembering the good things about the Oscars. Its a short list, but a good one.

title: Threats of a New Genocide
Morgan Stanley Creeps Into Indian Real Estate Market
description: Morgan Stanleys real estate investment arm has invested about $68 million in Indian property developer Mantri Developers Private in its first foray into the fast-growing market, the U.S. investment bank said Wednesday.

description: Eitaro Itoyama, the billionaire who forced out a Japan Airlines president for the second time on Wednesday, threatened to oust replacement Haruka Nishimatsu after a year unless he turns around the unprofitable carrier.

title: Gateway to Pay $47 Million in H-P Settlement
description: Gateway agreed Wednesday to pay $47 million to Hewlett-Packard to settle a series of patent lawsuits, and the rival computer makers entered into a seven-year cross-licensing deal.

title: Patent Ruling to Benefit Big Business

title: Memory Makers Plead Guilty to Price Fixing

Samsung, Hynix, Elpida and Infineon have all agreed, as corporations, to plead guilty and agreed to pay more than $731 million in collective fines.

title: Survey Says: Polling the Troops in Iraq
description: The new Zogby poll of U.S. soldiers in Iraq is being picked over by the blogosphere. According to the poll, An overwhelming majority of 72 percent of American troops serving in Iraq think the U.S. should exit the country within the next year: 29 percent say immediately, 22 percent say in the next six months, and 21 percent say between six and 12 months. Only 23 percent say American troops should stay as long as they are needed.

description: ANGELILLI--Josephine Danza. Beloved wife of Professor Frank J. Angell. Loving mother of Peter and Marietta, mother-in-law of Larry and Arlene. Adored grandmother of Bradley, James, Lauren, Elizabeth, Allison, Jon and Kristen, grandmother-in-law of Jen, Ron, Jeff and Evan, and great-grandmother of Josephine. The void that was created when you left us can never be filled. We love and miss you.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 3 A Before arriving in Pakistan today, President Bush finished his two-day visit to India with a speech praising the new warmth in Indian-American relations, and urged Americans to welcome rather than fear India as an economic competitor.

description: Medicare said yes, but many patients and their doctors ended up saying no.

description: Environmental cleanup workers entered two New York City buildings yesterday where anthrax spores were detected last Friday and began a painstaking decontamination process under close monitoring from federal and city officials.

title: BUDDY BOLDEN SUITE
description: Few musicians in modern history have inspired more apocryphal lore than the fin-de-sicle New Orleans cornetist Charles (Buddy) Bolden, who had a hand in shaping early jazz but was never caught on record, and barely on camera. (He stands second from the left at rear, above, in his only known photograph.) Before he entered a state insane asylum in 1907, Bolden brought New Orleans brass band traditions into contact with church music and the blues, by way of an outsize, swaggering style that influenced both Joe (King) Oliver and Louis Armstrong. He is also remembered, more dubiously, as a part-time barber and the publisher of a gossip broadside; Michael Ondaatje made those details an integral part of his portrayal of Bolden in the novel "Coming Through Slaughter" some 30 years ago. Popular perceptions of Bolden were shaped more than a little by Mr. Ondaatje's vivid fictionalization, which imagined life inside the humid atmosphere of E. J. Bellocq's Storyville photographs. A less fanciful depiction appeared in 1978 -- "In Search of Buddy Bolden," by the historian Donald M. Marquis -- and it was this account that eventually captured the imagination of an aspiring trumpeter named Charles Porter, who traced Bolden's steps in New Orleans and heard the inkling of a theme. Nine years later, Mr. Porter is a Juilliard graduate, a Fulbright scholar and a former student of Wynton Marsalis, and his theme has blossomed into a six-part suite for seven musicians. The clear perils of this undertaking could be a selling point; by most accounts, Bolden was usually up for an adventure. (Thursday at 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063; cover, $15.) NATE CHINEN THE LISTINGS: MARCH 3 - MARCH 9

title: Dissenting on Atomic Deal
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 - In concluding its nuclear deal with India, the Bush administration faces significant opposition in Congress and tough questions from its allies on whether the arrangement could set a precedent encouraging the spread of nuclear weapons to Iran and other potential foes of the United States.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New $10 Bills In Circulation
description: The government has begun circulating a redesigned $10 bill in an effort to make counterfeiting more difficult. The Federal Reserve has shipped the first of 800 million of the bills to commercial banks. The bills are the same size and still feature Alexander Hamilton. But the opening phrase of the Constitution, "We the people," is printed in red letters on the new ones and they now include orange, yellow and red elements. The bills also have embedded security threads and ink that changes from a copper color to green when they are tilted. JOHN FILES (NYT)

description: "Woman Is the Future of Man" was shown as part of the 2004 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Manohla Dargis's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 8, 2004; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The unrated film, in Korean with English subtitles, opens today at the Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Another Bid For Expatriate Tycoon's Return
description: The Prosecutor General's Office announced a new criminal investigation against Boris A. Berezovsky, the self-exiled tycoon and critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, and renewed a request for Britain to extradite him to face trial in Russia. The new investigation stemmed from interviews in January in which Mr. Berezovsky denounced Mr. Putin's government as unconstitutional and called for its forceful overthrow. Mr. Berezovksky received political asylum in Britain in 2003, but the British foreign minister, Jack Straw, publicly warned him earlier this week that his status could be reviewed. "Advocating the violent overthrow of a sovereign state is unacceptable and I condemn these comments unreservedly," Mr. Straw said. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   BENTON, NICHOLAS
description: BENTON--Nicholas, 79, on February 26, 2006 in Manhattan. Time-Life Books and magazines executive for 33 years, Bwy and Off-Bwy producer, President of NYC Opera Guild, recipient of The Mayor's Volunteer Award Of The Year for his work with The Harvard/Radcliffe Tutoring Program. He was an avid New Yorker with an infectious enthusiasm. Survived by his wife, Kitty, of fifty-two years, four daughters, four grandsons, three step grandchildren, and two brothers. Service 11 A.M. March 4 at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to The New York City Opera, 20 Lincoln Center, NY, NY 10023.

title: Hype-Week Patter as the Oscars Near
description: Hollywood's magical ball is Sunday night, and all week television personalities have been fretting and squealing about it, expecting us to watch in supportive awe, like Cinderella. It all seemed to go too far -- or farther than too far -- on Wednesday night, when the gangs at "Entertainment Tonight" and "The Insider" performed an inexplicable Broadway-like number in gowns and black tie against a white background, drumming up giddiness while frantically trying to brand their coverage of the Academy Awards ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDBERG, IRENE LISMAN
description: FREEDBERG--Irene Lisman, 72. Of NYC and Holderness, NH, formerly of Newton, MA. Wife for 51 years of the late Irwin M. Freedberg. Father of Marjorie F. Bogdanow and her husband Michael of Lexington, MA, Kenneth A. and his wife Joyce Jen of Weston, MA, and Deborah A. and her husband William Diebold of Portland, OR. Grandmother of Matthew, Daniel & Alyssa Bogdanow, Suzanne and Katherine Freedberg, and Joseph and Abigail Diebold. Identical twin sister of Adelle Fagelman, sister of Alvin Lisman and the late Beverly Lamm. Funeral service will be at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51st St., NY, on Sunday, March 5, at 9 AM. Burial at Lindwood Memorial Park in Randolph, MA, on Sunday, March 5, at 4:30PM. Donations in her memory may be made to the Bellevue Hospital Auxiliary, Room A100, 462 1st Ave., NY, 10016.

title: Lawyer Paid Mother for Sex With 2 Teenagers, D.A. Says
description: A tax lawyer who worked at a prominent Manhattan firm has been indicted on charges of paying two teenage girls for sex and paying their mother to allow it. He was arrested in Grimsby, Ontario, last week, but was released, for reasons that were not immediately clear, and is considered a fugitive, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney said.

The optimism has not always been shared in the Nascar garage, however, where many race-team owners have prayed that tomorrow would never come.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Veterans Health Program Unveiled
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the federal secretary of veterans affairs, R. James Nicholson, announced a program yesterday to educate veterans about obesity, nutrition and the risks of diabetes. The program is part of HealthierUS Veterans, a program of the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Health and Human Services. There are 312,000 veterans in the city. Nationally, two-thirds of veterans receiving health care from Veterans Affairs are overweight or obese and one-fifth have diabetes, compared with 7 percent of the general population. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: 'THE 25TH ANNUAL PUTNAM COUNTY SPELLING BEE'
description: As anyone who has snickered about Lake Titicaca from the back of a classroom knows, it is not difficult to make dirty jokes out of even the driest pedagogy, and in the hormonal cauldron of high school, it is all but inevitable. So the occasionally presented "adults only" variation on this musical about the agonies and ecstasies of a competitive provincial spelling contest -- with bawdy and otherwise rude dialogue substituted throughout -- is not simply a raunchy indulgence but also a riotously close look at the characters' most ticklish thoughts. Already fidgety, the teenage contestants (above, Jose Llana and cast members) are further tortured by peculiarly suggestive new words ("acouchi," "vas deferens") and definitions ("despite the excruciating pain, Frankie took some comfort in his suppedaneum"), and from their judges, they receive the academic equivalent of a pie in the face. (One of the students, Logainne, is said to be banned from her local movie house because of an indecent exposure during "Fahrenheit 9/11.") Jay Reiss, who played Vice Principal Douglas Panch until October and continues to write for the show, said the concept began as a way to entertain himself and the cast during rehearsals. "I would flip through the dictionary for words and see how fast I could make up a definition for them," he said. "They tended toward the risqu." The last of these shows this season -- which are prominently advertised as unsuitable for children -- will be presented on Sunday night, but since they have proved to be a smart marketing gimmick, bringing fans back to the theater, expect a return in the fall. (7:30, Circle in the Square, 254 West 50th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200.) BEN SISARIO THE LISTINGS: MARCH 3 - MARCH 9

title: Kenyan Police Deliver Blows to the Press
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 2 - Dozens of masked police officers forced a television station off the air in an early morning raid here in the Kenyan capital on Thursday before moving to a newspaper plant, where they disabled the printing press and burned thousands of papers, witnesses said.

He was a large and rotund man, instantly identifiable by his full walrus mustache, Harris Tweed trilby hat, thick glasses and high-pitched voice.

title: A Voyage From Australia to Nashville, in Their Dreams
description: Nine years after winning several awards from the Australian film industry, "Doing Time for Patsy Cline," a muddled cinematic ballad to American country music, has belatedly strummed and twanged its way north.

title: A Comedian's Ultimate Goal: Rock the Block
description: AFTER pulling a widely publicized Houdini last year, Dave Chappelle has been popping up all over the place recently: "Inside the Actors Studio," "Oprah," a theater in Seattle for a gig and, now, Brooklyn's own Bedford-Stuyvesant for an exhilarating new film. "Dave Chappelle's Block Party" was shot in 2004, about eight months before Mr. Chappelle, now 32, abruptly left the sketch-comedy show, walking away from a deal worth $50 million and into a storm of publicity and innuendo. "I wasn't crazy," Mr. Chappelle told Oprah Winfrey last month when he took the hot seat on her show. "But it's incredibly stressful." No kidding.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,289 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following American yesterday:

title: Yellowing Paper, Stiffening Glue and the Sudden Demise of a Library
description: Some days I suspect that the objects around me are aging faster than I am. I put on a jacket to do chores and realize that I bought it in 1987. Here is a fly rod I made in 1981. In the stairwell hangs a mounted deer head -- a mule deer my dad shot a couple of years before I was born. The ears are coming apart at the edges, though the glass eyes are as bright as ever. They have been looking at me since I was an infant. How did these things get to be so old?

title: Like Fathers, Like Sons Is Goal for Iona Pair
description: Steve Burtt and Gary Springer brought basketball glory to Iona College, helping the Gaels reach the N.C.A.A. tournament in 1984.

title: Riccardo Muti, Back on Top
description: To hear him tell it, less than a year after his unceremonious departure from La Scala Opera in Milan, the Italian maestro Riccardo Muti is free at last and living his dreams. Certainly, conducting the Vienna Philharmonic in three concerts at Carnegie Hall this weekend is not bad for starters.

description: Ivy Baldwin and Kate Weare make a well-matched pair, and their pairing has been taking place this week at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: Strange City. Thankless Job. Heartless Russian Winter.
description: MOSCOW, March 2 - The men and women who stack fruit and fish in the chill each day at the Dorogomilovsky Market can be grateful, at least, for the roof above their heads. It looks sturdy and strong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDES, ADELAIDE C.
description: RUDES--Adelaide C. Survived by loving son Alan, sonin-law Edward Forrest, beloved grandchildren Jonathan and Courtney. Graveside services Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARKER, SHIRLEY MARGOLIN
description: PARKER--Shirley Margolin. We extend sincerest condolences to the Parker family: Jeff and Naava, Drew and Careena, Michael and Toby, Keith and Allison, Julie, Mrs. Razelle Margolin Wender and 17 beloved grandchildren, all of whom cherished and looked up to this Grand Dame of Memphis. Deeply proud of her family and seriously connected to her yiddishkeit, she will long be remembered by all for her elegance and charm. With a zest for life and concern for others, she displayed great courage and dignity. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Jack C. Bendheim, Pres. Erica Jesselson, Chair Paul S. Glasser, Nat'l Executive Director

title: Shiites Get Demand: Drop Jaafari From Race
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 2 - Leaders of Iraq's Kurdish, secular and Sunni Arab parties asked the main Shiite alliance on Thursday to withdraw the interim prime minister, Ibrahim al-Jaafari, as its candidate for prime minister in the next government, saying Mr. Jaafari failed to contain the sectarian violence that swept the country over the past week.

title: Bush and India Reach Pact That Allows Nuclear Sales
description: NEW DELHI, March 2 - President Bush and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India announced here on Thursday what Mr. Bush called a "historic" nuclear pact that would help India satisfy its enormous civilian energy needs while allowing it to continue to develop nuclear weapons.

title: Obituary: Arnold A. Rogow, 81, a writer who put history on the couch
Hoyas' First Thompson Era Has Long Life on the Payroll
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 - Five years after John Thompson Jr. resigned as the men's basketball coach at Georgetown, he remained the university's second-highest-paid employee, behind only the president.

title: S.E.C. to Issue Guidelines on Subpoenas to Journalists
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 - Responding to criticism, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday that it would move quickly to write a policy that determines when it is appropriate to issue subpoenas to journalists.

title: It Is European, but It Is Not a Union
description: IF Europe had an effective advertising regulator, the European Union would have to change its name. This is no union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUESTONE, ROSE (ROSE BLUE)
description: BLUESTONE -- Rose (Rose Blue). Suddenly on March 2, 2006. Beloved daughter of the late Irving and Frieda. Renowned author of over 150 books for children. She will be missed and mourned by her cousins and many friends.

title: Under Tight Security, Bush Arrives in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 3 A President Bush arrived here today for a 24-hour visit to a capital locked down under extraordinary security, as a broad coalition of political parties shut down shops and transportation across the country and planned more demonstrations for the weekend.

title: Briefcase: Job slots follow 'snowbird' workers
National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Commission Members Resign In Protest
description: Two members of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich's commission on discrimination and hate crimes have resigned in protest of the inclusion on the panel of a representative from the Nation of Islam. The members who resigned are Lonnie Nasatir, the regional director of Anti-Defamation League, and Richard Hirschhaut, executive director of the Illinois Holocaust Museum and Education Center. Mr. Nasatir had called for the removal of the Nation of Islam representative, Sister Claudette Marie Muhammad, saying she should be held accountable for what he characterized as anti-Semitic, antigay and racist statements made by Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam. Ms. Muhammad said she believed in fairness to all people and would work to eradicate hate and discrimination. GRETCHEN RUETHLING (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Liberal Democrats Elect New Leader
description: Sir Menzies Campbell, a veteran Scottish lawmaker, foreign affairs specialist and former Olympic sprinter, was chosen to lead Britain's opposition Liberal Democrats and replace Charles Kennedy, who resigned in January after acknowledging an alcohol problem. The Liberal Democrats, the smaller of two main opposition parties, campaign on their commitment to civil liberties and their opposition to the war in Iraq. The leadership contest also evoked personal issues. One opponent of Sir Menzies reversed previous denials by saying he had had homosexual relationships, while another withdrew after press reports of a relationship with a male prostitute. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Wednesday about Steve Francis' first week with the Knicks after his trade from the Orlando Magic misstated the duration of his $62.5 million contract. It is for four seasons through 2008-9, not for the four years after this season.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about disagreement among labor leaders over a guest worker proposal for foreigners referred imprecisely to the position of Eliseo Medina, vice president of the Service Employees International Union. While Mr. Medina supports giving millions of illegal immigrants the right to work in the United States -- a position shared by President Bush -- he has also called for those immigrants to be granted citizenship, a position that Mr. Bush has not articulated.

description: HAYWARD, Calif., March 2 - A trial that could determine the fate of California's $3 billion stem cell research program ended quietly Thursday after three and a half days of mundane proceedings that belied the stakes involved.

title: Walking the Thin Masculine Line
description: PARIS, March 2 - Whenever I leave a fashion show, Bernard Alloux, the taxi driver who sees that I get to the shows on time, sweetly inquires, "Bon dfil?" This always makes me laugh. What can I tell him?

title: Benjamin Matthews, Singer, Dies at 72
description: Benjamin Matthews, an operatic bass-baritone who was a founder of the Opera Ebony company, died on Feb. 14 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Push to Create Standards for Documents
description: With government records, reports and documents increasingly being created and stored in digital form, there is a software threat to electronic access to government information and archives. The problem is that public information can be locked in proprietary software whose document formats become obsolete or cannot be read by people using software from another company.

description: OKIN--Minnie. Of Hewlett, NY. Beloved wife of 60 years of the late Jules Okin, died peacefully at age 86. Devoted mother of Lewis and Rona; loving grandmother of Alex, Beth, Brian, David, Michelle and Rebecca; great-grandmother of Daniela, Julia and Madeline; Loved by Dan, Ken, Mort and Roberta and adored by many nieces, nephews and friends. Contributions in Mrs O's memory may be made to: The Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America and The Smile Foundation. Services "Boulevard-Riverside" 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 12:30 P.M. Friday.

Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS NEHEMIAH, ELAINE
description: ABRAMS NEHEMIAH -Elaine. Wife of the late Milton Nehemiah. Soulmate to her cherished Sidney Abrams. Loving mother of Michael and Roberta Abrams, Linda and Jerry Gershon, and Mark Abrams. Adored Nana to Gary and Jill, David and Nicole, Laurie and Mike, Seth, Jeffrey, Jason and Kelli. Proud great-grandmother to nine at last count with yet another one on the way. Her family revels in her 85 years of life "peppered" with kindness and inspiration. Those of us who love and miss this much beloved woman take comfort in knowing that "a cup of coffee from the urn, not the pot," is waiting for her. Services are on Sunday at 11:30 A.M., Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Much Talk of a Nuclear Renaissance, but So Far Little Action
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - With industry hopes rising for a revival in orders for nuclear power reactors, the sale last month of Westinghouse's former nuclear division to Toshiba might stand out as a landmark. But not necessarily because the industry seems ready to take off.

title: Coke Bottlers Challenge Wal-Mart Deliveries
description: Wal-Mart suppliers are willing to go to great lengths to meet Wal-Mart's needs. For Coca-Cola, doing so has meant going to battle with some of its own bottlers.

title: Chimps Display a Hallmark of Human Behavior: Cooperation
description: One of the hallmarks of being human is cooperation. No other primate exhibits the same kind of helpfulness to others. Humans have made even violence a highly cooperative effort, and scientists have wondered how far back in evolution this trait goes.

description: ROSENTHAL--Maurice Milton (Sharkey). WWII veteran, passed away peacefully on March 1, 2006. Former resident of Trenton, NJ and Boca Raton, FL. He is survived by his beloved wife, Beverly, sister, Dorothy Saaz, sons, Andrew and Robert, daughter, Jane Schorr, son-in-law, Marc Schorr, and cherished grandchildren, Seth and Courtney Schorr. Services will be held at Temple Beth El, Boca Raton, Friday, March 3, 12 noon.

title: Six Animal Rights Advocates Are Convicted of Terrorism
description: An animal rights group and six of its members were convicted of terrorism and Internet stalking yesterday by a federal jury that found them guilty of using their Web site to incite attacks on those who did business with or worked for a British company that runs an animal testing laboratory in New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: An Entertainment Events listing in The Arts yesterday for a concert last night by the New York Philharmonic included an outdated reference to the conductor. As reported in the "Arts, Briefly" column, Christoph von Dohnanyi withdrew from the concert -- and its repeat performances tonight, tomorrow and Tuesday -- because of illness. Those concerts are being conducted by Ludovic Morlot.

title: Witness Comes Back to Describe a Beating
description: Ramondo Jack and Romona Moore were raised three-tenths of a mile apart in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. The last time Mr. Jack saw Ms. Moore, on a visit to the old neighborhood, he said, she was lying on a basement floor, stripped to her underwear and chained by the neck and arms. Her eyes were blackened, her face swollen and bloodied, her voice weak from crying.

description: GREENFIELD--Marvin. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to Barbara, Felicia, Eric and the grandchildren. Marvin was a dear friend and will be sorely missed. The Stoppelmann Family

description: HENRIQUES--John T., M.D. on February 28, 2006. Loving husband of the late Mary (nee Murphy), beloved father of Ann, Mary Marsden, John, Raymond, Thomas & James. Cherished grandfather of ten, dear brother of Virginia McEvoy. Visitation Sunday 2-4 & 7-9PM at The Michael J. Higgins Funeral Service Inc., New City, NY. title: Roland L. Kohloff, 71, Master of the Timpani, Is Dead
description: Roland L. Kohloff, principal timpanist of the New York Philharmonic for 32 years, who was known for his effortless grace on one of the orchestra's most exposed instruments, died on Feb. 24 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 71.

title: Israeli Found Spy's Data Irresistible
description: JERUSALEM, March 2 - The Israeli intelligence handler of Jonathan Pollard, the American convicted of spying for Israel, says in an interview that Mr. Pollard provided such good information that he could not face stopping the operation even though it was aimed at Israel's closest ally, the United States.

title: Even the Legal Do-Gooders Have Their Own Sordid Sides
description: YOUNG lawyers in love is somehow a comical notion, like battlefield dentists. "Conviction," a new crime series created by Dick Wolf, takes the romantic entanglements of prosecutors quite seriously, which in itself is evidence of how far this drama veers from the familiar "Law & Order" formula.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOSSETT, O. MILTON
description: GOSSETT--O. Milton. Known to all as Milt. Passed away March 1. I knew him for 21 years as my boss and friend. A great man, a do gooder to hundreds and an icon in the world of advertising. He and his wonderful wife Anna welcomed me to their home and made me feel one of the family. My heartfelt sympathy goes to Anna, their children Susanne, Tom, Michael and Lori and their daughters and sons-in-law Julie, Renee, Patrick and Ralph and their beloved grandchildren. He will be greatly missed. Stella

title: National Briefing | Washington: Homeland Security Official To Resign
description: Matthew E. Broderick, the senior Department of Homeland Security official who accepted blame for not ensuring that Michael Chertoff and the White House were fully informed about reports of levee breaches on the day Hurricane Katrina hit, has said he will resign at the end of March. Mr. Broderick ran the Homeland Security Operations Center, which received reports of the breaches. Mr. Chertoff said Mr. Broderick, a retired brigadier general in the Marines, "left an indelible mark on the department." Russ Knocke, a department spokesman, said the resignation was not forced. ERIC LIPTON (NYT)

title: Jolley Returns to MetroStars
description: The MetroStars reacquired defender Steve Jolley yesterday in a trade with F.C. Dallas. Jolley, 30, played in 104 games for the MetroStars, third on the team's career list, from 2000 to 2003. The MetroStars sent a fourth-round pick in Major League Soccer's 2007 supplemental pick to Dallas for Jolley.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Prison Siege Ends
description: The police said they had moved rioting prisoners at the high security Pul-i-Charkhi prison outside Kabul into a new cellblock and had regained control of the prison after five days of unrest in which 5 prisoners were killed and more than 30 injured. "The evacuation was done peacefully," said Mohammad Qasem Hashemzai, the deputy minister of justice. "If we had tried to force them to move to another cellblock, it could have been done in one hour. But we wanted to move them peacefully." CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

title: Puerto Rico: It works. So don't fix it
Paunchy Detective Pants Up, Down and Over the Streets of New York With a Prisoner
description: For the first adrenaline-spiked hour of his new action flick "16 Blocks," the filmmaker Richard Donner brings back the 1980's in high-concept style. One of the action auteurs of that often cinematically benighted decade, Mr. Donner directed all four films in the "Lethal Weapon" franchise (1987-1998), which was a mistake: by the time the final installment limped into theaters, its stars Mel Gibson and Danny Glover looked as exhausted as the action and dialogue. Despite the entertaining lunacy of his thriller "Conspiracy Theory," Mr. Donner faltered badly in the 1990's with films like "Maverick" and "Assassins," both of which epitomized all the worst excesses of Hollywood, including a profound lack of imagination.

title: With 65 Still Entombed at Mexican Mine, Ache Deepens
description: SAN JUAN DE LAS SABINAS, Mexico, March 2 - There is no hope at the mine here now, only the anguished, wrung-out ache to recover the bodies of their loved ones, to put an end to the waiting, the praying and the torturous talk of miracles.

title: Keeping a Fall Festival Alive the Whole Year-Round
description: The Jerusalem Chamber Music Festival, which the pianist Elena Bashkirova started in 1998, is held every September and attracts an international slate of mostly young musicians (but also some older ones, among them Ms. Bashkirova's husband, Daniel Barenboim). Between seasons, ensembles from the festival get its name around by touring, and on Tuesday evening, Ms. Bashkirova and a handful of string and woodwind players offered the first of two concerts at Zankel Hall.

description: A former bartender at John A. Gotti's social club testified yesterday that the club had hot-pink walls and an elaborate buzzer system and that a crucial prosecution witness -- a turncoat mobster who claims that he made plans in the club to carry out a kidnapping Mr. Gotti had ordered -- was never there.

title: Senate Panel Rejects Ethics Office Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 - Senators backed away Thursday from expansive lobbying law changes for the second time this week, overwhelmingly voting down a proposal to create an independent office to investigate ethics abuses in Congress.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Overturns Ban On Sikh Dagger
description: The Supreme Court unanimously struck down a Montreal school board ban on the wearing of ceremonial daggers known as kirpans by Sikh students, saying the ban infringed religious freedom. The Montreal case began in 2001 when a 12-year-old Sikh boy, Gurbaj Singh, refused to hand over his four-inch kirpan to his principal and his family took the matter to court. Sikh men are obliged to wear the kirpan at all times as a reminder to fight for justice. In 2004, the Quebec Court of Appeal ruled that the kirpan violated a prohibition against students carrying of "weapons and dangerous objects." In its ruling yesterday, the Supreme Court said, "A total prohibition against wearing kirpans to school undermines the value of this religious symbol and sends the message that some religious practices do not merit the same protection as others." CHRIS MASON (NYT)

title: Correction
description: On Jan. 30 I cited an article in The American Prospect that reported that Indian tribes who hired Jack Abramoff had reduced their contributions to Democrats by 9 percent. Dwight Morris, who prepared the study on which the article was based, says on The American Prospect's blog that "there is no statistically valid way to calculate this number given the way the data were compiled." The American Prospect was sloppy, and so was I for not checking its methodology.

title: Hamas, in Russia, Gets Chilly Warning to Recognize Israel
description: MOSCOW, March 3 A The leaders of Hamas, the radical Islamic group elected to govern the Palestinians, began a high-profile, three-day visit to Russia today by praising President Vladimir V. Putin for inviting them, only to receive a pointed warning that the organization had to recognize Israel and dismantle its militias or face isolation and even irrelevancy.

title: The Big Question
description: Since the start of the Iraq war, it's been clear that "victory" rested on the answer to one Big Question: Was Iraq the way Iraq was because Saddam was the way Saddam was, or was Saddam the way Saddam was because Iraq was the way Iraq was -- a country congenitally divided among Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds that can be held together only by an iron fist.

description: DETROIT, March 3 A The Dana Corporation, an auto supplier facing dwindling cash and a federal investigation into its accounting, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection today, becoming the latest auto parts maker to falter as American car companies downsize.

title: THE MONTH OF MARK
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music buses will be in full force this month, as the academy celebrates a man capable of drawing even the most neighborhood-bound of Manhattanites to brave the Brooklyn wilds. The great modern choreographer Mark Morris, above, is honoring his dance group's 25th anniversary, and everyone is invited to the monthlong party. (The studio shows of smaller works at the company's luxurious Fort Greene home, down the street from the academy, are already sold out.) There will be photography exhibitions; musical performances, including karaoke with Mr. Morris as host, at the BAMcaf; a screening of Mr. Morris's 1992 "Hard Nut," a "Nutcracker" satire with a heart of gold; showings of some of his favorite movies, like Robert Altman's "Nashville"; and a pair of dialogues on collaborators and music. The dialogues, conducted with the quick-witted, eminently quotable Mr. Morris and others, are not to be missed. And, oh yes, three programs of intelligent, humanistic dancing, from the 1981 religious work "Gloria," set to Vivaldi, to two New York premieres, "Cargo" and "Candleflowerdance." Sadly, Mr. Morris himself won't dance in any of these programs. But he will try his hand at conducting: as always, the company will perform to live music, and Mr. Morris will have a go with the baton. Birthday indulgence? Hardly. The musically agile Mr. Morris, the onetime enfant terrible of the dance world, has steadily expanded his bag of tricks since arriving on the scene with a bang all those years ago. (Ballet? Check. Opera? Why not. Brooklyn dance empire? Sure.) He rarely disappoints. (The formal dance festivities begin with a performance of Program A on Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., but the Month of Mark gets started tonight with a 9 o'clock performance of the Western Caravan swing band. Howard Gilman Opera House, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100; bam.org or mmdg.org for details on various events.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO THE LISTINGS: MARCH 3 - MARCH 9

title: 54 Years Together, but Now Facing the Challenge of Alzheimer's
description: "Norman & Beatrice," a new play by Barbara Hammond, is subtitled "A Marriage in Two Acts," and this indeed it is: a slice-of-life portrait of a couple as they become familiar with each other through a half century. The onset of Alzheimer's disease in the husband provides an opportunity for Ms. Hammond to celebrate the love and caring that inhere in a happy, 54-year-young marriage. The play is sentimental and clearly affectionate, but it is life sliced thin. Its undoubted warmth and the likability of its title characters will suit undemanding tastes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, ABRAHAM
description: MILLER--Abraham, 91, died at home on February 25, 2006. He will be missed by wife Mildred, daughters Elizabeth and Naomi, many friends, and former colleagues from Montefiore Medical Center.

title: Bird Flu Won't Wait
description: Hanover, N.H. - AS avian flu makes its way from Asia across Europe, the United States has yet to meet the challenges that this potential epidemic and other biological threats pose to our health and security. One challenge in particular needs attention: the shortfall in countermeasures like vaccines.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bank Expansion A Sign Of Growing Presence
description: In a sign of how financial institutions are rapidly expanding their footprint in New York, Bank of America agreed yesterday to add 522,000 square feet to the space it has already leased in a tower under construction at 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas, the developer Douglas Durst said yesterday. The new lease increases the bank's space in the 51-story Bank of America Tower at One Bryant Park by a third, giving it a total of 1.6 million square feet, or 77 percent of the building. The bank and Mr. Durst are partners in the $1 billion project, which is scheduled to be completed in February 2008. The financial industry signed leases for 4.2 million square feet in Manhattan last year, according to the brokerage firm Cushman & Wakefield.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HINTON, JAMES
description: HINTON - James. The Trustees and Staff of the Hudson River Museum record with sorrow the passing of Jim Hinton, Trustee of the Museum. He was a researcher, teacher, filmmaker, photographer and, above all, an artist whose photographs bear eloquent testimony to the tragedies and triumphs of African-Americans and are a powerful witness to an important part of American history. Jan Adelson, Chair Michael Botwinick, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDNER, JOSEPH HOWARD
description: GARDNER--Joseph Howard, 78. On March 1, 2006. Cherished husband of Charlotte for 47 years. Incredibly devoted father of Danielle and the late Douglas (Jennifer). Brother of Florence Strauss. Adored grandfather of Michael and Julia. A true New Yorker, and a graduate of New York University, he was born, bred and resided his entire life in Manhattan. He enjoyed 50 summers as a respected member of the Seaview community in Fire Island, where he met his wife Charlotte, and, later in life, enjoyed spending time in Boca Raton, FL. Since 1968, he relished his career as a real estate developer, helping create the Chelsea and Soho neighborhoods by renovating the first buildings in those areas. Through his company P & J Realty, he changed the face of commercial and residential real estate in the Union Square area. A leader in the industry and a man noted for giving back and supporting the community, he was on many boards and contributed to many organizations including the YMCA, the NYU Stern School of Business, the Union Square Partnership, the 34th Street Partnership and the Real Estate Board of New York. He was a man known by one and all for his deep integrity, his relentless strength, his sharp intelligence, his steadfast courage and his unending generosity of spirit. He earned the deep respect and admiration from all who knew him. He will be deeply missed by all whom he touched. The world is a lesser place without Joseph Gardner. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, March 5th at 11:45 A.M., at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Since Mr. Gardner strongly believed in supporting the youth of New York, in lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Prep for Prep, 328 West 71st Street, New York, NY 10023, or The Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Sixth Avenue, New York, NY 10018.

title: Captain of Your Destiny, Rented by the Weekend

Inconvenient, to say the least, because this wasn't Mr. Briskman's own yacht, which he could take out at any time, but one that he and his wife and friends had rented just for this weekend.

title: Gazing at a Genteel World About to Be Shoved Aside
description: In H. H. Arnason's standard textbook "History of Modern Art," you will find a discussion of the English abstract painter Ben Nicholson, but no mention of his father, William Nicholson, a successful artist in his time who, alas, contributed little to the progress of Modernism. Though he worked into the 1940's, Sir William was a throwback, a 20th-century Chardin devoted to capturing in paint -- and especially in still lifes -- what Marcel Duchamp dismissed as merely "retinal" experience. Today, however, judging by a beautiful exhibition of easel-size paintings at the Paul Kasmin Gallery in Chelsea, the elder Nicholson seems the far more compelling artist.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Scarsdale: Pastor Resigns After Criticism
description: The pastor of Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, a prominent Roman Catholic parish in Scarsdale, submitted his resignation yesterday. The pastor, the Rev. Robert J. Verrigni, had been under fire for months from members of the parish who accused him of wasteful spending, indiscriminate firing of employees and dictatorial management. In a letter that will be read to parishioners on Sunday, Cardinal Edward M. Egan, archbishop of the Archdiocese of New York, said Father Verrigni remained a "priest in good standing" and would become the master of ceremonies at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The cathedral's current master of ceremonies, Msgr. John T. Ferry, will become the new pastor of Immaculate Heart of Mary on March 20, the letter said. MICHAEL LUO (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Avian Flu Briefing
description: A top government health official said the United States was only about "50 percent" prepared for an avian flu pandemic. In a Congressional hearing, the official, Dr. Julie Gerberding, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and other experts said preparations could take months or years. They said the United States should probably be spending more in Africa, where infected poultry were recently found. The United States has allocated $280 million to help mitigate the spread of the disease abroad, said Dr. Kent Hill, assistant administrator in the United States Agency for International Development. BRIAN KNOWLTON (NYT)

title: EU making France a takeover test case
PINO PASCALI
description: In the 1960's, artistic formalism blossomed into a near-religious belief system. For some critics, the significance of, say, taking sculpture off the pedestal and putting it on the floor approached that of Neil Armstrong's step down onto the surface of the moon. This made formalism ripe for satire by artists like Claes Oldenburg, Bruce Nauman and Pino Pascali, an irreverent Italian sculptor better known in Europe than in the United States. Each of the works from the 60's in Gagosian's delightful time capsule of a show playfully riffs on a formal innovation in modern art. Taking aim at Minimalist sculpture, Pascali made simple, floor-bound shapes resembling big black shark fins, turning the gallery hardwood into a metaphorical ocean's surface. Having fun with puritanical Minimalist painting, he made an almost all-white picture whose slightly convex surface, punctuated at the bottom edge by a dark, triangular patch, mimics the curves of a nude woman's torso. And he mocked macho industrial assemblage by constructing sculptures from wood and found materials that evoke pieces of military artillery. A big drab-green example on worn rubber tires (above) points its barrel upward at an unmistakably phallic angle. The simulated weapons also reflect a generation's anxious preoccupation with the war in Vietnam. Sadly, Pascali died in a motorcycle accident at 32 in 1968, leaving us to wonder what such a talented mischief-maker might have done had he had more time. (Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, between 76th and 77th Streets, (212) 744-2313, through March 11.) KEN JOHNSON THE LISTINGS: MARCH 3 - MARCH 9

description: At this moment in time, there is no more meaningful a place than Pakistan to illustrate the state of America's relations with the Muslim world. The country is ground zero in the fight against global terror. Anyone needing a fresh illustration need look no further than yesterday's bombing outside the American consulate in Karachi, which killed four people. Beyond the hunt for Osama bin Laden on the Afghan-Pakistan border, Pakistan is where radical fundamentalism is increasingly taking the moderate Islamic world hostage.
