title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEGAL, ARNOLD
description: SEGAL--Arnold, March 1, 2006 of Maplewood, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Hattie for 68 years, exceptional father to Richard and Poppy, Kenneth and Karen, Stephen and Patricia, extraordinary grandfather to Cory, Randi, Robyn, Allyson, Michelle, Adam, Adina, Noah and Zachary, proud great-grandfather of Benjamin, Nathan, Sarah, Joseph, Caroline, and Jared, and dear brother to Charles. In conjunction with his late brothers Joseph, Hyman, and Max, and his brother, Charles, Arnold was a founding and dynamic partner of Segal and Segal, a real estate development company founded in 1950. Throughout his life, Arnold exemplified the best that humanity has to offer. He gave his love, his time, and his resources generously to his family, his friends, his community, Israel and the world at large. He was a natural leader who inspired everyone by his example and commitment. Arnold was a Vice President and Chairman of the Building Committee at Congregation Beth El, where he was a long time member. Together with Hattie, he was a founder of The Children's Institute, where he served as President from 1975-1979. Over his life, he was active in Jewish Federation, State of Israel Bonds, Interns for Peace, American Jewish Committee, Jewish Welfare Board and B'nai Brith. With Hattie, Arnold created parks and libraries in Israel, supported scientific research at The Weizmann Institute, Johns Hopkins University, and Mt. Sinai Hospital, improved hospital facilities at St. Barnabas and Mt. Sinai, and endowed services for needy children through the Jewish Community at Metro West. Arnold loved life and everyone in his life loved him. Funeral services were held at Congregation Beth El, 222 Irvington Ave. South Orange, N.J. on Thursday March 2, 2006. Shiva will be observed at the Segal Residence, 616 South Orange Ave., Maplewood, N.J. 07040, on the evenings of March 2 and March 4, and during the day of March 5. Information call Bernheim-Apter - Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel (800) 938-6372. Contributions can be made to the Segal Family Food Allergy Research Fund, payable to Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, Box 1049, NY,NY 10029, Attention: Clare Garfield or to The Children's Institute, 1 Sunset Avenue, Verona, New Jersey 07044.

title: Theater Listings
description: 'THE 25TH ANNUAL PUTNAM COUNTY SPELLING BEE' As anyone who has snickered about Lake Titicaca from the back of a classroom knows, it is not difficult to make dirty jokes out of even the driest pedagogy, and in the hormonal cauldron of high school, it is all but inevitable. So the occasionally presented "adults only" variation on this musical about the agonies and ecstasies of a competitive provincial spelling contest A with bawdy and otherwise rude dialogue substituted throughout A is not simply a raunchy indulgence but also a riotously close look at the characters' most ticklish thoughts. Already fidgety, the teenage contestants (above, Jose Llana and cast members) are further tortured by peculiarly suggestive new words ("acouchi," "vas deferens") and definitions ("despite the excruciating pain, Frankie took some comfort in his suppedaneum"), and from their judges, they receive the academic equivalent of a pie in the face. (One of the students, Logainne, is said to be banned from her local movie house because of an indecent exposure during "Fahrenheit 9/11.") Jay Reiss, who played Vice Principal Douglas Panch until October and continues to write for the show, said the concept began as a way to entertain himself and the cast during rehearsals. "I would flip through the dictionary for words and see how fast I could make up a definition for them," he said. "They tended toward the risquA." The last of these shows this season A which are prominently advertised as unsuitable for children A will be presented on Sunday night, but since they have proved to be a smart marketing gimmick, bringing fans back to the theater, expect a return in the fall. (7:30, Circle in the Square, 254 West 50th Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200.) BEN SISARIO

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Court Fines 3 China Aviation Officials
description: A Singapore court imposed total fines of 700,000 Singapore dollars ($432,000) on three top mainland Chinese directors of the fuel importer China Aviation Oil (Singapore) for their involvement in the company's collapse in 2004. China Aviation's chairman, Jia Changbin, and two other directors, Gu Yanfei and Li Yongji, all pleaded guilty this week to charges they helped conceal the company's losses in a vain attempt to rescue it. China Aviation once held a near monopoly on importing jet fuel to China, but nearly collapsed after losing $550 million betting incorrectly against the price of oil. Its former finance chief, Peter Lim, was sentenced last month to two years in prison and fined 150,000 Singapore dollars, or $92,600. The trial of the company's former chief executive, Chen Jiulin, is to begin Wednesday. WAYNE ARNOLD (NYT)

The parliamentary voting had been scheduled for March 19 but will be put off, probably until mid-April, because of delays in tabulating ballots from the first round of voting and other logistical problems. No new date was set for the inauguration. Meanwhile, violence continues to plague the capital, Port-Au-Prince. The bodies of two Haitian security guards employed by the United States Embassy were found not far from the ambassador's residence. They were shot and killed after leaving work on Wednesday. title: 36 Hours in SoMa, San Francisco
description: IF you visit the SoMa district of San Francisco, you can eat a five-course meal while you sit on an oversize bed and watch a performance artist stretch the definition of theater. You can drop in on a penguin feeding or paddle a kayak in search of floating baseballs in the bay. This stretch of the city south of Market Street, long known for its alternative art and music scene, has matured into a mix of trendy restaurants, gritty bars, swank hotels and warehouses reworked to stage live music. It has a bustling waterfront, a major league baseball stadium and engrossing museums. SoMa's character has been shaped by recent cycles of boom and bust. The district lost some of its edge during the frenzy of the late 1990's, as soaring rents shut down galleries and nightclubs and stock-inflated Internet start-ups moved in. When the high-tech bubble burst, SoMa's landscape shifted once again. Lofts languished vacant, and the well-to-do young people on Razor scooters vanished overnight. Lately, though, new life has sprouted. There is some scruffiness, and you can still duck into a club too cool to post its name above the door. But for all its youthful spirit, SoMa feels more grown-up -- not stodgy, but adult -- than ever, with family attractions by day and energy that lingers after dark. JOSH SENS

title: Arts, Briefly; Moving on Broadway
description: Many maneuvers for plays on the Great White Way: first, "The Lieutenant of Inishmore," Martin McDonagh's acclaimed comic blood-bath, is heading to Broadway to occupy the Lyceum Theater, starting April 18. The play, Mr. McDonagh's fourth to make it to Broadway ("The Pillowman" played there last year), opened to raves on Monday at the Atlantic Theater Company in Chelsea. Moving from the Lyceum to the Schoenfeld is "The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial," starring David Schwimmer. It starts there on April 14. The Schoenfeld had been rumored to be a possible home for a transfer of David Lindsay-Abaire's family drama "Rabbit Hole," but that play is staying at the Biltmore for an extra week till April 9 before making way for "Shining City," a psychological thriller from Conor McPherson, which will start previews on April 20. JESSE McKINLEY

title: 2 German Roles: Opposing War and Aiding U.S.
description: BERLIN, March 2 - Did the German government lie? Was it talking out of both sides of its mouth? Did it betray a moral trust by giving the United States cooperation in the Iraq war, as a steady drumbeat of news disclosures -- some accepted by the government, some vehemently denied -- have been saying?

title: Intel lowers its estimate for revenue
Natasha Sweeten
description: Edward Thorp Gallery 210 Eleventh Avenue, at 24th Street, Chelsea Through March 11

title: Guantnamo Detainee Seeks Court Action
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 - A prisoner at the American-run detention center in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, who says he was tortured when the authorities subjected him to force-feeding in a restraining chair to break his hunger strike, asked a federal district judge Thursday to intervene in his case.

title: Even the Legal Do-Gooders Have Their Own Sordid Sides
description: YOUNG lawyers in love is somehow a comical notion, like battlefield dentists. "Conviction," a new crime series created by Dick Wolf, takes the romantic entanglements of prosecutors quite seriously, which in itself is evidence of how far this drama veers from the familiar "Law & Order" formula.

title: Correction
description: A map last Friday with an article about the Big Sur area of California showed the location of the Post Ranch Inn, a resort in the region, incorrectly. It is near the town of Big Sur.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a report that detailed abuses of suspected subversives by the Mexican military during the country's "dirty war" from the late 1960's to the early 1980's misstated the name of the private research group that posted the report on its Web site. It is the National Security Archive, not Archives.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about a report that detailed abuses of suspected subversives by the Mexican military during the country's "dirty war" from the late 1960's to the early 1980's misstated the name of the private research group that posted the report on its Web site. It is the National Security Archive, not Archives. (Go to Article)

title: For Thirsty Farmers, Old Friends at Interior Dept.
description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Seek Van's Driver
description: The Police Department is looking for the driver of a white Chevrolet van that was seen in Crown Heights around the time a man was shot dead there while parking his car. The van was seen on a security videotape heading south on Schenectady Avenue, a block south of where the man, Frederick Klein, 47, was shot at 1:30 a.m. on Tuesday on Carroll Street. The video was obtained yesterday from a commercial establishment and investigators said its driver might have seen the shooting. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Briefly: Louisiana's governor wrong on hurricane
Michael S. Joyce, Research Patron, Dies at 63
description: Michael S. Joyce, who as steward of the Olin and Bradley foundations was an influential patron of leading conservative research and civic organizations, died on Feb. 24 at a hospice in Germantown, Wis. He was 63 and lived in West Bend, Wis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KREMSDORF, SYLVIA B., (NEE BAUM)
description: KREMSDORF -- Sylvia B., (nee Baum). Beloved wife of Julian. Devoted and adored mother of Arlene Thomashow, Joel and Nancy Kremsdorf and Wendy Kremsdorf. Loving grandmother of Debra Thomashow and Shana Thomashow. Loving sister of Seymour Baum. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St, Friday at 12:45PM. She will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved her. Donations can be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage, New York City.

title: An exported genocide
Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bail Refused For Day Care Worker
description: Basing the decision on a videotaped statement, a judge refused bail yesterday to a day care worker accused of having sex with a 4-year-old boy in her charge. The worker, Khemwatie Bedessie, 37, accused the boy of instigating the events, saying he "called her to the bathroom" and "knew what he was doing," according to the Queens district attorney. Ms. Bedessie is charged with raping and sexually abusing the boy at the day care center, Veda's Learning World, in Richmond Hill. Ms. Bedessie's lawyer, Robert Lucks, called her statement "inherently unreliable." JANON FISHER (NYT)

title: Diesels may return to Japan roads
Why People Resist Higher Gas Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Walking on Coffee, Trying to Get a Fix on a Master of Impermanence
description: PHILADELPHIA - One of the distinguishing characteristics of 20th-century art was the romance of ephemeral or immobile artworks. You know the litany: performances captured only on film; temporary installations; self-destructing art objects; isolated, decaying earthworks known mostly from photographs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Utah House of Representatives' defeat of a bill intended to challenge the theory of evolution in high school science classes paraphrased imprecisely from a reaction by Casey Luskin, a spokesman for the Discovery Institute, which promotes the idea of intelligent design in explaining the origins of life. Although he said the vote would not have an effect outside Utah, he did not say it was a purely local Utah matter.

title: Archivist Urges U.S. to Reopen Classified Files
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 - After complaints from historians, the National Archives directed intelligence agencies on Thursday to stop removing previously declassified historical documents from public access and urged them to return to the shelves as quickly as possible many of the records they had already pulled.

title: Shiite Imams Lash Out at Critics of Prime Minister
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 3  Shiite imams at Friday prayer services across Iraq lashed out angrily today at the nation's Kurdish, Sunni Arab, and secular political leaders, who have launched an effort to prevent Prime Minister Ibrahim al Jaafari, a Shiite, from retaining his post in the new government.

title: A Heroine in a Hurry, via Ibsen
description: HIGH wind alert: what appears to be a hurricane has unexpectedly blown into Brooklyn, where it is likely to rage throughout much of the month of March. Though it has thus far confined its activity to a small area -- the stage of the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music -- it is inflicting considerable havoc there. Pillow cushions, curtains, furniture covers, bunches of flowers and even small actresses are tirelessly picked up and tossed about. Hurricane Hedda is the name of this disruptive force of nature. And as generated by Cate Blanchett, the Oscar-winning movie star, it is unlike any other squall you might have encountered.

title: As Victims' Relatives Watch, Nurse Who Killed 29 Gets 11 Life Terms
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., March 2 - Charles Cullen, a lonely, sneaky nurse who pleaded guilty to killing 29 patients and told authorities he may have killed many more, was sentenced on Thursday to 11 consecutive life terms, with no hope for parole for 397 years.

title: 2 more arrested in U.K. heist
Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about New York City's agreement to adopt measures to control the use of force by guards against inmates in city jails used an incorrect given name in some copies for the city's correction commissioner. He is Martin F. Horn, not John.

title: If not U.S. as world government, then who?
City Inmate Population Up; Brooklyn Jail May Reopen
description: The number of inmates in New York City jails has been rising faster than correction officials had anticipated, by 9 percent since Jan. 1, leaving the jails at close to their current capacity.

title: The Worst Knicks Ever? Read This And Tremble
description: Larry Brown pushed, and his players pulled. Brown prodded and poked. The Knicks pouted and plummeted. But after all the scrambled lineups and all the divergent agendas, they all may yet get on the same page. Sadly for them, that page could be No. 164 in the team's media guide.

title: From the Onion to Comedy Central to the Oscars
description: HE asked for a pneumatic tube, but his otherwise affable Comedy Central employers -- the cheapskates -- refused to fork over anything more than the cost of a scooter. That is why Ben Karlin, the executive producer of "The Daily Show With Jon Stewart" and co-executive producer, with Mr. Stewart, of a spinoff news spoof, "The Colbert Report," shuttles between his shows' separate studios in the far West 50's on a scooter.

title: The Gospel vs. H.R. 4437
description: It has been a long time since this country heard a call to organized lawbreaking on this big a scale. Cardinal Roger Mahony of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles, the nation's largest, urged parishioners on Ash Wednesday to devote the 40 days of Lent to fasting, prayer and reflection on the need for humane reform of immigration laws. If current efforts in Congress make it a felony to shield or offer support to illegal immigrants, Cardinal Mahony said, he will instruct his priests -- and faithful lay Catholics -- to defy the law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIBACK, ESTELLE
description: RIBACK - Estelle. Aptly named, Estelle was indeed a star, the embodiment of grace. Our love goes out to Arnie and all their children. West End Synagogue A Reconstructionist Congregation

title: Global capitalism as a least worst system
Sources of Help for Immigrants
description: Hospitals in the United States are required to provide emergency care regardless of immigration status. But beyond emergencies, the availability, rules and risks of health care for noncitizens, legal and illegal, vary widely around the country.

title: As Family Mourns, Rewards Are Offered in Killing of Student
description: Reward money and memorials -- but still no sign of a suspect.

title: Pope's Shooting Laid to Soviets by Italian Panel
description: ROME, March 2 - Citing new photographic analysis, an Italian parliamentary commission has concluded that top Soviet leaders were behind the failed plot to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981.

title: Australia won't sell India uranium
Baghdad curfew brings calm after killings
U.S. is '50%' prepared for flu, expert testifies

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUKOFF, IRVING F., PH.D.
description: LUKOFF--Irving F., Ph.D. The Columbia University School of Social Work records with profound sorrow the recent death of Professor Emeritus Irving F. Lukoff on February 27. A member of the faculty from 1968--1991, he was former Director of the School's Center for Demonstration and Research and a distinguished educator and author who made lasting contributions to the profession. Heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family. Jeanette C. Takamura, Dean

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Classical

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Economy Minister Warns About Growth
description: Economy Minister German O. Gref said that the quality of economic growth was declining, and that he feared there might be a sudden drop in stock prices after Russia's equity benchmarks soared to records last year. "We're very afraid of the formation of a so-called bubble," Mr. Gref, left, said at a weekly cabinet meeting in Moscow. Russia's dollar-denominated RTS index surged 83 percent last year, and has added a further 30 percent this year. Mr. Gref said underinvestment was eroding the economy's eight-year-old boom. Growth slowed for a third year in 2005, to 6.4 percent, as oil output advanced at the slowest pace in six years.

title: Publicis Groupe looks for acquisitions
News Analysis: Bush to face tough questions back home on India pact
description: WASHINGTON  The nuclear deal with India, if approved by U.S. Congress and America's allies, will strengthen ties with a country that has already begun to be more aligned with the United States, but it also complicates efforts to stop the spread of nuclear weapons to Iran and other foes, diplomats and experts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOHLOFF, ROLAND
description: KOHLOFF--Roland. The entire Juilliard community mourn the passing of Roland Kohloff, a member of the faculty since 1978 and former Chairman of the Percussion Department. A brilliant performer, dedicated teacher, and compassionate human being, Roland was a passionate advocate also for his students and for his art. With enormous energy and a wonderful smile, Roland approached all endeavors with an enthusiasm that was contagious. His personal and artistic integrity made him a respected and trusted colleague. Our condolences go to his entire family. He will be deeply missed by us all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

title: European movement with Zero as the sum of its parts
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bloomberg Aide Moves To M.T.A.
description: Susan L. Kupferman, 47, director of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's Office of Operations since 2002, resigned yesterday to become the president of M.T.A. Bridges and Tunnels, an arm of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Ms. Kupferman had overseen the Mayor's Management Report, an annual statistical portrait of city agencies, and started a section on the city's Web site that allowed New Yorkers to compare services in their communities. At the authority, Ms. Kupferman will succeed Michael C. Ascher, who retired in October. Ms. Kupferman will also resign from the authority's board, where she has been one of the city's four representatives since 2002. WINNIE HU (NYT)

title: Wal-Mart Extending Dominance of the Grocery Business
description: Last year, Coca-Cola was preparing to introduce a diet soda, to be called Coke Zero. But executives at Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest retailer, thought they had a better idea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'NEILL, MARGARET (NEE DELAHANTY)
description: O'NEILL--Margaret (nee Delahanty). On February 28, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Thomas P. Loving mother of Patrick J. and the late James Keating. Dear sister of Patricia, Thomas, Jimmy, and the late Brother David Delahanty F.S.C. Devoted grandmother of Megan. Former Secretary of Immaculate Conception School. Reposing at O'SheaHoey Funeral Home, Inc. 2913 Ditmars Blvd. Astoria Thursday & Friday 2-5 & 79:00 P.M. Funeral Mass Saturday at Immaculate Conception Church, 9:45 A.M. Interment St. John Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to The James Keating O'Neill Foundation, P.O. Box 5524, Astoria, NY 11105.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: To be or not to be the Bard's portrait?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Insurance Rules Proposed For Tour Boats
description: Gov. George E. Pataki introduced legislation yesterday that would require the operators of commercial boats to take out insurance policies ranging from $10 million to $100 million. The operator of a boat that capsized in Lake George last year said that he could not pay insurance claims to the victims of the accident, which killed 20 of the 48 people on board, because his insurance company contended that his policy covered only accidents on land. Under the proposal made by the governor, who remains hospitalized in Manhattan after complications from an appendectomy, boats carrying up to 10 passengers would be required to have a minimum $1 million insurance policy. Larger boats would need more coverage; boats with a capacity of more than 100 passengers would need $100 million. JENNIFER MEDINA (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Votes to Renew Broad Antiterrorism Law The Senate overwhelmingly passed legislation renewing the sweeping antiterror law known as the USA Patriot Act, ending a months-long impasse on Capitol Hill and virtually guaranteeing that the measure will go to President Bush to be signed. The vote was 89 to 10. PAGE A14

description: "The idea is to let people get on with their research and not reclassify documents unless it's absolutely necessary."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRENNAN, URSULA
description: BRENNAN--Ursula. March 24, 1920-March 2, 2006. Mainboucher model, Editor, Bantam Books. Survived by brother Alan, Pittsford, NY and two nephews.

title: Soccer: Corruption without borders in Belgian scandal's China link
Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, GERALD LIEBERS
description: WOLF--Gerald Liebers. Beloved husband of Audrey Laibson Wolf, father of Marc, Ralph, Amy, father-in-law of Kevin, grandfather of Molly, brother of Ellis, dear brotherin-law and uncle. We will miss his warmth, love, humor, curiosity, rich appetite for new adventures and his music. He was an outstanding anesthesiologist, internationally known for his research in operating room fires, superb teacher and mentor. He was Emeritus Professor of Anesthesiology at the State University of New York/Brooklyn and Visiting Research Professor at Cooper Union. A graduate of Vanderbilt Medical School. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, at Temple Sinai, 1 Engle St., Tenafly, NJ. Donations may be made to the North Jersey Symphony Orchestra or Temple Sinai Music Fund. For information, "Wien & Wien" 800-322-0533.

title: Rock/Pop Listings
description: Pop

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Adidas Posts Loss After Reebok Purchase
description: Adidas-Salomon, the world's second-largest maker of sporting goods after Nike, had an unexpected fourth-quarter loss after acquiring Reebok International. The net loss was 4 million euros ($4.8 million), or 2 cents a share, Adidas said at its headquarters in Herzogenaurach, Germany. The company was expected to earn 5 million euros. Reebok's revenue will fall about 5 percent in 2006 after orders at the end of the quarter sank 22 percent, Adidas said. Herbert Hainer, the chief executive, aimed to dispel speculation that Adidas wanted to position Reebok as a lower-price brand, saying it would remain a "performance" brand.

title: Sales Slowed for Retailers in February
description: Shoppers curbed their retail spending in February, according to reports released yesterday, as a blast of winter weather hurt demand for spring apparel.

title: Out with the revolution: It's time to get rich!
Vaunted and Taunted
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 2 - From the time he appeared for warm-ups before playing Florida State at the Civic Center here on Wednesday, J. J. Redick of top-ranked Duke was met by familiar heckling, a crude sign that made an obscene reference to his sister and even a body-painted message that questioned his sexual orientation.

title: BlackBerry Maker Reaches Deal in Patent Dispute
description: OTTAWA, March 3 A The prospect of a shutdown of BlackBerry wireless e-mail service in the United States evaporated today as the two companies in the patent dispute reached a $612.5 million settlement.

title: After Surgery, Toms Just Happy to Play
description: MIAMI, March 2 - David Toms is playing golf these days like a new man. After undergoing heart surgery three and a half months ago, Toms is ranked ninth in the world and sixth on the P.G.A. money list.

title: The Bright Side of Industry Upheaval
description: Orlando, Fla. - IN front of an electric blue backdrop that resembled a computer screen, speakers at the annual media conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies stressed that their industry must cater to consumers who are empowered by technology and ever-widening content choices.

title: Biennial 2006: Short on Pretty, Long on Collaboration
description: THERE are plenty of people rooting for this latest Whitney Biennial, hoping it recalibrates the image of the art world as something other than youth-besotted and money-obsessed. It's a start, just barely. I imagine it will provoke much head scratching by uninitiated visitors. This typically huge exhibition is very much an insider's affair, a hermetic take on what has been making waves. It will seem old hat to aficionados and inscrutable to many others.

title: Europeans Again Lift Rates and Hint at More Increases
description: FRANKFURT, March 2 - With Europe seemingly on firm economic footing, the European Central Bank on Thursday raised interest rates for the second time in three months and signaled more increases to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AUSTRIAN, BEATRICE L
description: AUSTRIAN--Beatrice L, 97. On March 2, 2006. Wife of the late Ray Austrian, mother of Caryl and James (Linda). Grandmother of Jan, John and James (Lesley Johnson) Levinson, Julie Spund, Cynthia (John) Weber and Robert (Jeanne) Austrian. Great-grandmother of Katherine, Claire and Blake Levinson, Jacob and Rachel Spund, Robert and Mitchell Austrian, Austin, Bennett and Graham Weber. Interment private. Please remember her with contributions to The Eye Bank, 120 Wall Street, New York, NY 10289-0801 or www.eyedonation.org.

title: Toys 'R' Us Wins Ruling in Amazon Dispute
description: Toys "R" Us won a lawsuit yesterday against Amazon.com that will allow the toy seller to set up its own Web site and end an agreement to sell products on Amazon's site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAWITZ, IRWIN
description: RAWITZ--Irwin. On February 28, 2006, at the age of 87. Loving husband of Ann for fifty years. Devoted father of Gary, Stella, Marcy, Mitchell, and Melissa. Proud grandfather of Andrew, Alexander, and Brittney. He was very wonderful.

title: Back of the Envelope
description: Buy American: Overseas companies, particularly European ones, have shown a new aggressiveness when it comes to deal making in the United States. Half of the 10 biggest takeover offers so far this year have been made by foreign suitors.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Royalties Must Be Paid In Crude, Not Cash
description: Venezuela, the world's fifth-largest oil exporter, is demanding that the country's four heavy-oil joint ventures pay their royalties in crude rather than in cash. "We can gain a lot more" with this kind of payment, the energy and oil minister, Rafael Ramrez, told reporters in Caracas. Last month Mr. Ramrez said that the ventures would have the option of paying their 16.67 percent royalties in cash. The companies in the ventures include Exxon Mobil, Chevron, ConocoPhillips and Total of France. The four paid about $1.6 billion in royalties last year, Mr. Ramrez said.

title: No headway in nuclear talks between Europeans and Iran
Arts, Briefly
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORRIGAN, CONSUELO REYES
description: CORRIGAN--Consuelo Reyes. Of Bradenton, FL, age 76, died on February 28, 2006 of a heart attack. Known as Connie Reyes to her many friends in the art world. Longtime partner of the late sculptor Ronald Bladen. Loving mother of the late Paul and Ethan Corrigan, loving aunt of Trina Reyes and Peter Rienecker, dear friend of her separated husband Arnold Corrigan. Beloved by her grandnieces and grand nephew and her many art children. She will be sorely missed by her friends, colleagues and students in the "art world". Private services in Florida. Memorial service in New York City to be arranged.

title: Support the Troops? Here Are Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEWIS, MATTHEW D.
description: LEWIS--Matthew D. 9/27/58-3/3/96. Gone 10 years, sorely missed each day. Mother, Dad, and Janet

title: Senators Threaten to Intervene to Improve Mine Safety
description: Frustrated by delays in updating safety regulations and adopting new technology to protect miners, lawmakers told federal mining officials yesterday that it was time for Congress to intervene.

title: No progress in EU talks with Iran on nuclear plan
Sikorsky and Striking Workers Say They Are Dug In
description: STRATFORD, Conn., March 2 - With a heavy snow pelting them, a ring of pickets stood outside Sikorsky Aircraft's main plant here today, as they have since a week ago Monday, and made it clear that the company's managers were not the only ones digging in for a long fight.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Increase Of Nuclear Power Output
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has approved a 20 percent increase in power output at the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant in Vernon. The commission said the decision came after a two-year review of the plant. Power at the plant will gradually increase by 100 megawatts. The plan was opposed by a number of residents around the plant. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: MIDWEST

title: Those Distant Days of 2001, Revisited Without the Buzz
description: Maybe it was inevitable. All those old alt-rock bands have been getting back together: the Pixies, Mission of Burma, Dinosaur Jr., Gang of Four and the rest. The musicians realized they still liked playing together. And the fans realized they would still pay to watch it. So why not?

title: Cricket: India rallies after Hoggard blitz
Antarctica Surveys Show Melting Ice Is Causing Rising Sea Levels
description: Two new satellite surveys show that warming air and water are causing Antarctica to lose ice faster than can be replenished by interior snowfall and thus are contributing to rising global sea levels.

title: HAVENS | Wellington, Fla.; A Place Where Horses Reign
description: THREE decades ago, Bill Ylvisaker, an enthusiastic polo player who was then president of a Chicago company called Gould Inc., gazed over the tennis-court-flat pastures owned by a Florida farmer named Charles Wellington and figured they would make great polo fields.

title: Panel to Expand Inquiry on Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 - Leaders of the House Intelligence Committee agreed Thursday to expand their inquiry into the National Security Agency's domestic surveillance program, but Republicans rejected a broader effort by Democrats for President Bush to turn over detailed White House records on the operation.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Feb. 21, about depression and pregnancy, used an incorrect estimate from a medical journal for the number of women affected. As many as 800,000 women in the United States each year suffer moderate to severe depression during pregnancy -- not 80,000.

title: Loss of Antarctic Ice Increases
description: Two new satellite surveys show that warming air and water are causing Antarctica to lose ice faster than it can be replenished by interior snowfall, and thus are contributing to rising global sea levels.

title: Free-Agency Delay Saves Jets' Mawae, at Least for the Moment
description: The N.F.L.'s delay to the start of free agency until Monday may not save center Kevin Mawae from getting the ax from the Jets.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Leaves 'Lost' a Wreck
description: The 90-minute "American Idol" on Wednesday, when the top 10 male contestants performed, continued to steamroll the competition. The talent show's 29.18 million viewers put Fox far ahead in first place in Nielsen's estimates. The network's premiere of "Free Ride" followed "Idol" and lost more than half of its audience; the slacker comedy drew 14.24 million viewers. On ABC, "Lost" suffered from "Idol" encroachment into the 9 p.m. time period. The plane crash mystery delivered its lowest ratings for an original episode this season, with 16.34 million viewers. Following "Lost," ABC's "Barbara Walters Special" (10.26 million), decoupled from its usual platform before the Academy Awards, took third place behind both CBS's "CSI: New York" (13.73 million) and NBC's "Law & Order" (12.41 million). KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TENEN, STEVEN
description: TENEN--Steven. On March 1, 2006. Of Washington Square Wines. Beloved son of Eileen and the late Robert. Loving brother of David and Diane Neski. Brother - in - law of Diane and Steven. Beloved uncle of Michael and Andrea Neski, and uncle to Bonnie, Amy and Rebecca Tenen. Reposing at Beth Abraham Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. Services Sunday March 5, 2006 at 12:30. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. For further information call 212-614-2300.

title: Microsoft Accuses Europe of Colluding With Rivals
description: BRUSSELS, March 2 - Microsoft's battle with the European Commission escalated Thursday, as the company accused the commission of colluding with its competitors in the software market and of again withholding documents it says are crucial to its defense in an antitrust case.

title: Loss of Antarctic Ice Increases
description: Two new satellite surveys show that warming air and water are causing Antarctica to lose ice faster than it can be replenished by interior snowfall, and thus are contributing to rising global sea levels.

title: Briefly: Police raid meeting of Protestant militants
A Christmas Truce Forged by Germans, French and Scots
description: "Joyeux Nol," a glossy French antiwar movie with melted snowflakes in its eyes, tells the true story of an improvised Christmas truce during the first year of World War I. The visually sweeping film, written and directed by Christian Carion, is the kind of feel-good, feel-sad movie with a message that invites you to bask in the glow of communal bonhomie, as enemy soldiers lay down their arms, stagger out of their trenches and sing carols together on a frigid Christmas Eve.

title: Support the Troops? Here Are Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Chimps Display a Hallmark of Human Behavior: Cooperation
description: One of the hallmarks of being human is cooperation. No other primate exhibits the same kind of helpfulness to others. Humans have made even violence a highly cooperative effort, and scientists have wondered how far back in evolution this trait goes.

title: Blanco Assured Levees Were Safe
description: The Associated Press has obtained video of a briefing that took place between the White House and FEMA officials as Katrina made landfall.

title: Older, Wiser, and Making a Difference
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: South Africas Edgars Shops in Australia
description: Edgars Consolidated Stores, South Africas biggest retailer by market value, will bid for Coles Myers department stores to expand in Australia.

title: Judge Dismisses Shareholders Putnam Suit
description: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit brought on behalf of Marsh & McLennan shareholders alleging the companys failure to disclose improper trading at its Putnam Investments unit allowed Marsh stock to trade at inflated levels for a certain period, a regulatory filing said.

title: Spitzer Investigates Title Insurers
description: New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer may have found a new industry to investigate. State authorities are looking into whether some of the nations biggest title-insurance companies illegally paid secret rebates and referral fees that could have raised costs for those buying or refinancing a home, The Wall Street Journal said.

title: Brokerage Firm David Lerner Agrees to Fines
description: For the third time in less than two years, David Lerner Associates, an investment brokerage firm based in Long Island, N.Y., has agreed to fines and other penalties to settle regulatory complaints about its marketing practices.

title: CFOs: From Pedestal to Prison
description: The age of the rock star chief financial officer is over. From 1998 to 2000, CFO magazine handed out 28 Excellence Awards to finance chiefs who had won praise from auditors, analysts and investors for innovative approaches to what had traditionally been a buttoned-down job.

title: Mittal Plan Includes Few Job Cuts
description: An industrial plan presented by Mittal Steel to the French government on its hostile bid for Arcelor reportedly said that there will be almost no loss of jobs from the acquisition.

title: CIBC First-Quarter Results Top Expectations
description: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce shares rose to a record as first-quarter profit excluding one-time items topped expectations. The shares rose $1.67 or 2.10 per cent to $81.23 in Toronto trading. Earlier, they touched $81.75. The previous record high was $81.20, reached last August.

title: Merrill Eyes Rising Asian Real Estate Market
description: Merrill Lynch, the worlds biggest securities firm, will hire 15 or more bankers to finance and invest in Asian property, as it seeks to double profit and catch rivals in a region where real estate prices are climbing.

title: Hilton Picks Advisers for U.K. Hotel Sales
description: Hilton Hotels Corporation, of the United States, has appointed advisers to sell two of the biggest British hotels acquired as part of its 3.3 billion pound takeover of Hilton International, The Times of London reported.

title: Bell Globemedia May Stage IPO
description: Bell Globemedia is considering an initial public offering, according to documents filed by its shareholders Wednesday with the federal communications regulator. The disclosure came as BGM kicked off an application for approval from the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission of a recent deal that will change its ownership structure.Go to Article from The Globe and Mail>>

title: Citi May Trim Legg Mason Stake
description: Legg Mason has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to register nearly 12.5 million shares of common stock that would allow Citigroup to sell much of the Legg stake it acquired in last years asset swap.

title: Anti-Deer Device Maker Scares Up $4 Million
description: Gardeners have long used homemade remedies to keep hungry deer from eating their rhododendrons and tulips. Pleasantville, N.Y.-based Nature Technologies has raised $4 million in venture capital funding to market a more elegant remedy  an ultrasound device designed to pipe out high-frequency noise that scares deer.

title: News Corp. Closes In on Next Web Deal
description: News Corporation has been eerily quiet since it went on a billion-dollar Internet spending spree last year. But Rupert Murdochs deal-making machine is getting back in gear.

title: Icahn Ends UAE Contract Pinned to Time Warner Stock
description: Carl Icahn and Istithmar Media Investments, a fund for the royal family of the United Arab Emirates, ended an advisory agreement for the familys $427 million bet on Time Warner.

title: Pulse
description: This winter black reclaimed its status as a chic  essential, but this spring, retailers are moving toward a warm, stylish navy blue.

title: Theyre On to Us': Enron Witness Tells of Skillings Angst
description: The former chief executive of Enron, Jeffrey K. Skilling, told other top executives theyre on to us, after a small analyst firm produced a research note critical of some company transactions, a former executive testified on Thursday.

title: Key Republican Lawmaker Vows to Kill Dubai Ports Deal
description: A Dubai-based companys effort to manage several United States ports will face opposition from one of the most prominent House Republicans on military issues. Rep. Duncan Hunter, R-Calif., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said Thursday he would try to scuttle the deal with Dubai Ports World as lawmakers complaints about the Bush administrations handling of the issue continued to spread.

title: Stonebridge Recapitalizes Defense Contractor
description: Stonebridge Partners remains committed to once-troubled defense contractor BondCote, opting to refinance the company through a $28.5 million recapitalization rather than sell it after more than a decade of ownership.

title: Drugmaker ARCA Gets $15 Million in Funding
description: ARCA Discovery said it has raised a $15 million Series A led by Atlas Venture to seek market approval for a congestive heart failure drug. The Denver-based company believes the drug, a beta-blocker known as bucindolol that was languishing after decades of development efforts, will serve as an effective, personalized treatment for congestive heart failure in a subset of patients.

title: Microsoft Accuses Europe of Colluding With Rivals
description: Microsofts battle with the European Commission escalated Thursday, as the company accused the commission of colluding with its competitors in the software market and of again withholding documents it says are crucial to its defense in an antitrust case.

title: Carlyle Takes Stake in Pipe Company
description: Carlyle Group, the $33 billion multinational investment company based in Washington, has agreed to buy a controlling stake in pipe manufacturer John Maneely, of Collingswood, Pa.

title: Apax Puts $29 Million Into Photo Firm
description: Apax Partners is taking a walk down the aisle with photography company Pictage, investing $29 million in equity for a majority stake in the company, which provides a portal for wedding and other professional photographers to print, store and sell photos.

title: Intel Invests in Small Cisco Rival
description: Lockdown Networks faces some pretty tough competition, locking horns with none other than Cisco Systems to create a system for identifying network security threats. Lockdown would appear outgunned in this fight. But with the help of Intel, which is pumping $3.1 million into the company, the 5-year-old company may have a chance of succeeding.

title: Del Monte Takes Meow Mix, Sells Other Units
description: Del Monte Foods said Thursdy that it would buy the cat food maker Meow Mix Holdings for $705 million and sell its private-label soup and baby food businesses to focus on its higher-margin branded businesses.

title: Dassault Systemes Acquires U.S. Software Firm
description: French software company Dassault Systemes said Thursday it had agreed to acquire money-losing MatrixOne of the United States for about $408 million in cash.

title: Funds of Funds Gain Buyers, Lose Investors
description: A recent flurry of deals in funds of funds shows that the business is rapidly changing. Since June, institutions have bought, at high prices, nine funds of funds, compared with eight such deals from 2000 to 2005, according to one major investment banks data.

title: Refco Creditors Blame Banks for Woes
description: Creditors of scandal-ridden trading firm Refco have taken aim at Wall Streets top investment banks for failing to uncover the fraud that plunged the company into bankruptcy just a few months after its IPO.

title: S.E.C. to Draft Policy on Journalist Subpoenas
description: Responding to criticism, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday that it would move quickly to write a policy that determines when it is appropriate to issue subpoenas to journalists. The decision was announced by the S.E.C. chairman after a unanimous vote of the commissioners.

title: Equitable Buys Gas Utilities From Dominion
description: Dominion Resources on Thursday said it would sell its natural gas utilities in Pennsylvania and West Virginia to Equitable Resources for $970 million in cash.

title: Xstrata Stirs Speculation of Falconbridge Bid
description: The head of Xstrata  on Thursday repeated his position that the Swiss mining giant has no interest in holding a minority stake in any company, leading to renewed speculation that Xstrata could launch a bid for control of Falconbridge.

title: U.K. Water Company to Sell Construction Business
description: Water company AWG has sold part of its Morrison construction business for 42 million pounds. Under the deal, Galliford Try will acquire Morrisons project investments business and investments in two early stage private finance initiative projects. The utility and facilities services businesses, which make up the majority of Morrison, are not part of the deal and remain with AWG.

title: CSG Systems Picks Up Telution
description: CSG Systems, a provider of customer care and billing solutions for cable and satellite companies, said it acquired Telution, a provider of operations support system software. The purchase price is about $22 million in cash. In addition, the agreement provides for contingent payments of up to $8 million over the next three years.

title: Northstar Neuroscience Files for IPO
description: A Seattle medical device company planning an initial public offering, which would be the first Washington state IPO in nine months. Northstar Neuroscience, whose first product is designed to enhance recovery of hand and arm movement in stroke patients, has filed to raise up to $85 million through an IPO.

title: Boston Scientific Sets Vote on Guidant Merger
description: Boston Scientific has scheduled a special shareholder meeting for March 31 for a vote on the companys proposed $27 billion merger with Guidant. The transaction is expected to close during the week of April 3, Boston Scientific said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Thursday.

title: Or Maybe Not
description: Yahooligans apparently are not on ABCs polling list. Users of Yahoo! Movies picked Brokeback Mountain as their choice for best picture to the tune of 41 percent. The Brokeback partisans also pushed Jake Gyllenhaal over the top in the supporting actor category. If only the Bagger had seen this earlier.

title: BT Reportedly Considered for $35 Billion Buyout
description: BT is being examined as a potential bid target by a number of global private equity firms in a move that could value the telecommunications group at a minimum of 20 billion pounds ($35.1 billion), The Times of London reported.

title: G.E. Sees Hefty Returns From Glenworth Sale
description: General Electric said on Thursday it will receive net proceeds of $2.8 billion from the sale of its remaining stake in insurer Genworth Financial.

title: Post-Google, Hambrechts OpenIPO Gains Traction
description: If the question of the moment is, What did we do before Google? at W. R. Hambrecht, the investment bank in San Francisco, the answer is, A lot less business.

title: Thank You for Playing
description: ABC, which is hosting the Oscars, commissioned a fairly extensive poll about this years best picture nominees and found out there is a clear winner: none of the above.

title: Merrill, JW Childs Buy Marketing Firm for $1.05 Billion
description: A Merrill Lynch unit and JW Childs Associates subsidiary agreed Thursday to buy a majority stake of closely held Advantage Sales & Marketing from buyout firm Allied Capital for about $1.05 billion.

title: U.S. Opens Inquiry into Online Music Pricing
description: Investigators from the Justice Department said Thursday that they were examining the recording industrys practices for setting prices for music sold online, according to people briefed on the inquiry.

title: Wilbur Ross Adds to Auto-Parts Rollup
description: A company led by financier Wilbur Ross has closed on its purchase of the European operations of bankrupt automotive parts supplier Collins & Aikman, without the participation of Lear, though the sides are still discussing a deal.
Selborne Journal: 3 March 1759:  The Cantaleupes looking not quite right, I plunged the pots up to their brims in the mould.

title: Sudden Impact
description: Call it a rookie mistake, or an epiphany; the Bagger has a revelation yesterday at 3 p.m. when the editor at the House of Many Doors called to finalize his picks for the newspaper. The clouds parted at the last minute and he found himself saying the word Crash when his best picture choice came up. Youre sure you want to change it from Brokeback?  the editor asked. He was sure. For about 38 seconds and then pickers remorse set in. He had wanted to throw a wild card in, something that would fly in the face of conventional wisdom, but youd think picking Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room would have done it. Nope.

AK Steel Stock Surges After Report of Takeover Talks
description: Shares of AK Steel surged 23 percent on Friday after a newspaper reported that U.S. Steel was in talks to acquire the Middletown, Ohio-based company.

Mr. Hoyt asked that The Times publicly acknowledge that it should have noted in its Page 1 article that Knight-Ridder had published a similar mine safety story on Jan. 6, 2006.

Grandfather of Kelli and Andrew Braun, Jessica and Andrew Rich, Alison Gottlieb and Geoffrey Friedman, Debra and Pat Ewing. Great-grandfather of Jeffrey, Matthew, Sam and Coby. Beloved best friend of Adrian Bernick. A man whose warmth, integrity and passionate commitment to improving the lives of others will always inspire. Services Sunday, 12 noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Donations in his memory may be made to Workmen's Circle Center for Social and Economic Justice, 45 E. 33rd St., NYC 10016 or YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, 15 W. 16th St., NYC 10011.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Briton Takes No. 2 Post
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan's chief of staff, Mark Malloch Brown of Britain, left, was promoted to deputy secretary general, the organization's No. 2 position. He will replace Louise Frchette of Canada, who announced her resignation in December. Mr. Malloch Brown, the former director of the United Nations Development Program, joined Mr. Annan in January 2005 to help speed a wide-ranging reform of the United Nations. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

title: Brown Ponders Having Surgery
description: Knicks Coach Larry Brown said that he was still pondering his options for coping with a bladder condition, and that off-season surgery was possible. But Brown said he had no reason to believe he will miss games, as he did last season with Detroit.

title: Another Day, Another Collar: Knicks Choke
description: Only inches separate Larry Brown from his players when the Knicks huddle, and mere feet when the ball is in play. Despite this proximity, the chasm between Brown's mouth and his players' ears remains as vast as the gap between the number of Knicks' victories and the number of losses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MCELWAIN, RUTH VAN DEVENTER JONES
description: McELWAIN--Ruth Van Deventer Jones, Mar. 2, 1924-Dec. 8, 2005, daughter of the late Mr. & Mrs. Nicholas Ridgely Jones of NYC and Glen Cove. As Beverly Gray, she performed as a vocalist in numerous nightclubs and later cofounded the Broward women's Chorus in Florida. A generous supporter of animal rights, she is greatly missed by her three nephews-Bouvier, Ridgely and Christopher Beale. Interment at the Locust Valley Cemetery on March 5, 2006, 1PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRYFOOS, HON. ROBERT J.
description: DRYFOOS--Hon. Robert J. On March 2, 2006. Son of the late Edith and Jerry Dryfoos, survived by Susan Dymond and their family Clifford, Jason and Abby Fishkind, and two adoring granddaughters. He will be forever remembered as a courageous, passionate man whose love of life and all things New York was equalled only by his generosity, steadfast friendship and the joy he took in being "Grandpa Bob." Service Sunday, March 5, 10:00 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76 Street & Amsterdam Ave.

description: LONDON, March 3 - Prime Minister Tony Blair has indicated that God influenced his deliberations when he committed British troops to fight alongside American forces in Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Feb. 16 about 19 watercolors by William Blake that are to be auctioned on May 2 at Sotheby's misstated the title of one. That work, illustrating a line in Robert Blair's 1743 poem "The Grave," is titled, "Our Time is fix'd; and all our Days are number'd," not "Our Time if Fix'd, and All Our Number'd."

title: In Canada, Serious Skiers Enroll in a Serious School
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia - Whistler Mountain opened on a recent morning to a rare mix of blue skies and a foot of new powder. Whooping and laughing, most of the expert skiers headed up the peak chair to where snow the consistency of lightly whipped cream filled the couloirs and bowls. Far below, so low that the skiers on the peak looked like black dots, I joined 50 other expert skiers on gentle bunny slopes.

title: At Saint Laurent, a Blueprint for the Future
description: PARIS, March 3  Just what made Stefano Pilati leave the gilded cage of the Intercontinental Hotel for a pink room at the Pompidou Center is hard to say. What made him do an entire Yves Saint Laurent collection without a single pantsuit  or a fur or a leopard print  is also hard to say.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Official's Absence Attributed To Illness
description: Huang Ju, China's sixth-ranking Communist Party official and the top manager of the country's financial sector, has been hospitalized because of illness but is recovering, a spokesman for the top advisory body to the National People's Congress said. Speculation has swirled about Mr. Huang for weeks after he did not appear at several high-profile events attended by all the other members of the ruling Politburo Standing Committee. A former Shanghai party boss, Mr. Huang is thought to have close ties to the former top leader, Jiang Zemin, and his absence, if prolonged, could present President Hu Jintao with the chance to consolidate his grip on power. JOSEPH KAHN (NYT)

title: Picking the Cream of the Cream
description: INVESTMENT advisers often say that they are searching for companies that offer good shareholder value. Makes sense, but what does it mean exactly?

title: Shiite Clerics Scold Foes for Campaign Against Jaafari
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 3 - Shiite clerics at Friday Prayer services across Iraq lashed out angrily at the country's Kurdish, Sunni Arab and secular political leaders, who are mounting an effort to prevent Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari, a Shiite, from retaining his post in the new government.

title: Cinderella Is a Myth, and David Is a Lie
description: ST. LOUIS - THE great attraction of the N.C.A.A.'s Division I basketball tournament is its promise of a sprawling democracy. The tournament is a free-for-all in which 65 teams, from programs with operating budgets ranging from $2 million to $90 million, meet on a level court. Everyone has a chance to reel off a string of victories and reach the Final Four.

title: Lessons From Another Insurgency
description: Washington - DURING his trip to South Asia, President Bush has done his best to whistle past the diplomatic graveyard of Kashmir, issuing only bland encouragements to the leaders of India and Pakistan to resolve the status of the disputed territory. That's a shame, because instead of ignoring Kashmir, Mr. Bush and his administration should be studying it as a case study in dealing with an insurgency.

Greatgrandmother of Dana, Sophie, Margaret, Samantha and Cole. Visiting Saturday March 4, 7-9PM. Service Sunday 11:30AM at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: New Strategy on Clean Air
description: The steady erosion of the nation's clean air laws under the Bush administration has inspired Roy Cooper, North Carolina's attorney general, to adopt an unusual legal strategy to force out-of-state power plants to stop sending air pollution into his state. In late January, Mr. Cooper asked a federal court to declare air pollution from 11 power plants owned by the Tennessee Valley Authority in Alabama, Tennessee and Kentucky a "public nuisance" under common law.

description: A federal judge who struck down what he called New York State's undemocratic system of selecting trial judges said yesterday that he would allow it to remain in place for the November election.

description: The Rev. Earl Stallings, a prominent Baptist pastor in Birmingham, Ala., who in 1963 risked the rejection of his own white congregation, and worse, by seating African-American worshipers among them at his Easter service and urging reconciliation amid the city's erupting racial antagonisms, died on Feb. 23 in retirement in Lakeland, Fla. He was 89.

title: In Shift, Trenton Will Raze X-Rated Theater Near School Site
description: TRENTON, March 3 - Reversing an earlier stand, the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation has decided to demolish an X-rated theater and a hotel frequented by prostitutes, adjacent to the site of a proposed elementary school.

description: For more than 40 years, Hexagon Laboratories made pharmaceuticals on a quiet stretch of Peartree Avenue not far from Co-op City in the Bronx. When the company abandoned the site in 1989, it left behind thousands of gallons of toxic waste.

title: House Speaker Offers Hope for New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 3 - Six months after he said it did not make sense to rebuild parts of New Orleans, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert stood amid the rubble of the Lower Ninth Ward on Friday and, in a reversal, spoke words of comfort.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'CSI' Cuts Down 'Idol'
description: With Wednesday's broadcasts, the February ratings sweep came to an end. It was a peculiar one. The Olympics, once ratings champions, were good enough to put NBC in only third place in the sought-after 18-to-49 demographic, though the network won among total viewers for the first time since the May 2002 sweeps. ABC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, but excluding the Super Bowl, Fox, the "American Idol" network, won the all-important advertising sales measurement. CBS wasn't really in the race, as it ceded the competition by broadcasting repeats most of the month. But this week, CBS peeked out from under the covers, and on Thursday it was No. 1 among total viewers, as usual. Fox ranked first for the night among 18-to-49-year-olds. Its "Idol" (26.18 million estimated viewers) battered CBS's "Survivor" (16.24 million) for the second week in a row. But at 9 p.m., CBS's "CSI" (27.57 million) drew a larger audience than "Idol," which no other show has done this season when "Idol" was on the schedule. The forensics crime series (in which Marg Helgenberger, above, stars as Catherine) beat Fox's "Skating With Celebrities" finale (14.15 million). KATE AURTHUR

title: Cannibal Wins Ban of Film in Germany
description: FRANKFURT, March 3 - For more than three years, the man known as the Cannibal of Rotenburg has held Germans in grisly thrall, with his lurid tale of killing and eating a willing victim he found through the Internet.

title: Deep Ocean of Computer-Generated Sound, From 1978
description: The music of Iannis Xenakis can shuttle seamlessly between extremes: from ancient mythology to modern science, from the intensely visceral to the impossibly cerebral and from private insight to public spectacle. Few of his works spanned these poles as effectively as his landmark electro-acoustic tape piece, "La LAgende d'Eer," which was played on Thursday night at Anthology Film Archives. Written for the opening of the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris in 1978, "La LAgende d'Eer" is a sweeping 45-minute work that takes its title from the myth of Er as recounted in Plato's "Republic." The music is a dense futuristic assembly of materials including non-Western percussion and constructed noise, and a dizzying array of computer-generated sound derived from Xenakis's complex theories of probability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOKOLOW, ARTHUR D.
description: SOKOLOW--Arthur D. Age 77, passed away peacefully at his Riverdale, N.Y. home on March 2, 2006. Beloved brother of Martin Sokolow and the late Ruth White and great friend of Jane Genth. A graduate of Horace Mann School and Colorado College, he served as a 1st Lieutenant in the 45th Infantry Division in the Korean War, and later worked as a financial and real-estate professional in Arkansas and New York. A gourmet cook and opera lover, Arthur was unfailingly kind, courageous, loyal, and hilarious--with a runaway laugh that his many friends will remember and miss. A memorial will be held in the spring. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: Accusations of New Attack Threaten Sri Lankan Cease-Fire
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, March 4  Less than two weeks after both sides pledged to halt a spate of violence that pushed this island nation once again to the brink of war, ethnic Tamil rebels today accused the army of killing two of its fighters in a pre-dawn ambush. The military denied any involvement.

An esteemed national leader, Marty also served in several top Wisconsin campaign positions. His great achievements on behalf of Israel, the Jewish people, and the community in general were recognized and praised by our organization and many others. Our heartfelt condolences to his sons, Larry and Daniel. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and may his memory be for a blessing. Joshua Matza President & CEO Burton P. title: In Reversal, Wal-Mart Will Sell Contraceptive
description: Relenting to pressure from state government officials, Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that it would begin carrying Plan B, an emergency contraception pill, in all of its United States pharmacies by the end of the month.

title: A Load of Manure
description: Bolinas, Calif. - TALK of reducing our dependence on foreign oil through alternative energy sources like biomass is everywhere these days -- even on our president's lips. As a livestock farmer and environmental lawyer, I've paid particular attention to discussion about using manure as "green power." The idea sounds appealing, but power from manure turns out to be a poor source of energy. Unlike solar or wind, it can create more environmental problems than it solves. And it ends up subsidizing large agribusiness. That's why energy from manure should really be considered a form of "brown power."
