title: Will the Real William Shakespeare Please Stand Up?
description: LONDON, March 1 - The first painting donated in 1856 to the new National Portrait Gallery here was of William Shakespeare, already well enshrined as the nation's literary idol. For the gallery, the oil recorded as NPG 1 seemed like a singularly apt founding work for its collection. And now, as the museum celebrates its 150th anniversary, it is again in the limelight.

title: No Iraq Trip for Legislator Who Opposed Deal on Ports
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 - Representative Peter T. King's prominent opposition to a proposal to allow a Dubai company to take over some terminal operations at American ports may have earned him some punishment from the Bush administration: He has been grounded.

title: Fairfield Coach Will Not Be Back
description: Fairfield Coach Tim O'Toole announced he would not return next season. O'Toole said his contract expired at the end of the season, and Athletic Director Eugene Doris told him earlier this week that it would not be extended.

title: A Growing Anger Over Unpaid Rebates
description: WHEN my husband went shopping for a memory card for our digital camera, he looked at several and was finally swayed by one offering a $20 rebate.

title: Discovering What Happens Next
description: The White House has a sorry history of withholding information that the public and Congress need to make informed policy judgments. A proposal in President Bush's new budget would take that damaging tendency one step further by eliminating a government survey that captures the real-world impact of welfare reform, Medicaid, child-support enforcement and many other policies and programs.

title: Court Suspends a Ruling in Satmar Case
description: In the latest twist in the bitter battle for the leadership of the Satmar sect of Hasidic Jews, an appellate court yesterday suspended a judge's decision that had effectively given a faction from Orange County control of the group.

title: Human Rights at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Knew of Investigation of Labor Leader
description: Correction Appended

title: The War in Iraq: It's Decision Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A map with an article on Wednesday about bird flu in France carried an incorrect credit. It was prepared by The New York Times, not by Rina Castelnuovo. (Go to Article)

title: Teachings of a Missionary From the Old World
description: A man, a plan, a viola da gamba: Jordi Savall. That's all that was onstage at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday night -- a bearded man playing an amber instrument in muted light -- and it was more than enough to fill an evening, richly.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 7 P.M. (Showtime) SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW -- (2004). Gwyneth Paltrow and Jude Law (above) star as a fearless metro-desk reporter and her heroic aviator ex-boyfriend. When gigantic robots invade New York, they have to locate some missing scientists and save the world. Angelina Jolie turns up, with a British accent and an eye patch. Almost everything but the actors in this comic-book-noir fantasy is computer-generated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKLE, MARIA
description: FRANKLE--Maria, on March 3rd, 2006. Loving widow of Albert Frankle. Beloved mother of John Frankle and Rabbi Judith Frankle Bardack. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Lisa, Susan, Amy and Jill. Adoring great-grandmother of Sophie, George, Eli, Matthew, Ilan and Orelle. Funeral services Sunday, 11 AM, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. (corner 91st St.).

title: Ex-Congressman Gets 8-Year Term in Bribery Case
description: SAN DIEGO, March 3 - After acknowledging that he had "made a very wrong turn," former Representative Randy Cunningham was sentenced in federal court here on Friday to eight years and four months in prison for taking $2.4 million in bribes from military contractors in return for smoothing the way for government contracts.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column in Weekend yesterday about the conductor James Levine's fall during an ovation at Symphony Hall in Boston on Wednesday night described it incorrectly. He fell down on the stage; he did not fall off it.

title: Corrections
description: A map with an article on Wednesday about bird flu in France carried an incorrect credit. It was prepared by The New York Times, not by Rina Castelnuovo.

title: A Voice That Gives Healing to the Wounded and Weary
description: And once again, Barbara Cook: is there anything left to say about this magnificent singer who seems to be everywhere at once these days, defying age, gravity and musical category?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PITTARI, ROSALIND
description: PITTARI--Rosalind, on March 2, 2006. Survived by son Lloyd Goldstein and wife Bernice, granddaughter Sharon, sister Annette Gelber, niece Suzanne Rinaldo, cousins Marjorie and Lois Goldstene. Services March 6, 11:30am Riverside Chapel, Brooklyn. Interment Pinelawn Cemetery.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,291 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Bird Flu Death Reported
description: The Hong Kong government said the authorities in China's adjacent Guangdong Province had notified them that a 32-year-old man in Guangzhou, formerly Canton, fell sick with what they suspected was avian flu on Feb. 22 and died Thursday. China has had eight confirmed human deaths from bird flu. The province, which concealed the emergence of the SARS virus for four months in late 2002 and early 2003, has not acknowledged a flu problem in birds despite a spate of deaths of wild birds and backyard chickens in Hong Kong near the Guangdong border. KEITH BRADSHER (NYT)

title: The Mayor Speaks His Mind
description: In his first term, Michael Bloomberg was often diplomatic to a fault. He was loath to criticize publicly members of his adopted Republican Party in Washington and Albany. He preferred working behind the scenes -- with mixed success -- to change policies that were often at odds with city needs as basic as security and the schools. Now, in his second and final term, Mr. Bloomberg seems to have decided he isn't taking any guff from anyone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, GUSTI
description: COHEN--Gusti. A true woman of valor died on March 3. Devoted wife of the late Tuvia Cohen, beloved mother of Ilan and Amir, dear motherin-law of Iris and Joan, adoring grandmother to Danielle, Jordana, Natalie and Adam. Services Sunday, March 5, 9:30AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, NY. Burial in Israel.

title: Vermont Losing Prized Resource as Young Depart
description: POULTNEY, Vt. - Not long ago, Ray Pentkowski, the principal of Poultney Elementary School, published an unusual request in the school newsletter. Please, he urged parents, have more babies. The school desperately needs them.

title: The Challenges of an Oversize World
description: A familiar streak of bad faith runs thought TLC's dwarf reality series, "Little People, Big World." It's the same bad faith that informs documentaries about transsexuals and anorexics.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday of Brig. Gen. Robert L. Scott Jr., the World War II fighter pilot who wrote the memoir "God Is My Co-Pilot," misstated the given name of the missionary doctor whose invocation of God while he was treating the pilot's wounds inspired the book title. He was Dr. Fred Manget, not Frank.

title: After Battle Forces Priest Out, Scarsdale Congregation Is Divided and Bitter as Ever
description: The restiveness at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale, one of the most prominent parishes in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, began last spring.

title: The Long Studio Decline
description: TREND watchers will keep their eyes on the 78th annual Academy Awards tomorrow to see if the following continues to hold true:

title: Doral Delivers an Encore of Dueling Honchos
description: MIAMI, March 3 - As Tiger Woods was leaving the interview room of the Ford Championship at Doral on Friday, Phil Mickelson was coming in. Mickelson extended his hand enthusiastically and said, "What's up, man?" Woods nodded, shook his hand and left without further interaction.

title: One of Four Candidates Quits Republican Race for Governor
description: ALBANY, March 3 - Assemblyman Patrick Manning dropped out of the governor's race on Friday after his long-shot candidacy for the Republican nomination was weighed down by revelations of an extramarital affair and by lukewarm support from conservatives.

title: Women on the Early (and Late) Shift
description: To the Editor:

title: Cash Film's Missing Ingredient: Religion
description: Johnny Cash's three enduring obsessions are summarized in the title of a Cash retrospective released by Sony in 2000: "Love, God, Murder." But "Walk the Line," the film about his life, deals prominently with just two of those three themes: it is a love story about Mr. Cash and June Carter that takes place before they were married, and it shows Mr. Cash onstage ripping through some of his songs about brutality and its consequences.

title: Digital Methods Help Replicate Artworks
description: As Hippocrates noted, art is long and life is short. But the life of some ancient art is growing shorter, hampered by environmental factors like climate, light, pollution -- or by dynamite.

title: Put Him In, Coach, Young's Ready to Play
description: PHOENIX - SOMEDAY Alex Rodriguez and Derek Jeter may quit messing with Michael Young's baseball life. In the meantime, Young, an unusually broad-minded and gracious player, doesn't mind their interference a bit.

title: After Stint of Crime, Art Forger Sells Genuine Fakes
description: FAIROAK, England - AFTER many years as an art forger, both criminal and legitimate, John Myatt has a thing or two to say about the vagaries of the art market.

title: Underwriting Hamas
description: America cannot bankroll a Hamas government that preaches and practices terrorism, denies that Israel has any right to exist, and refuses to abide by peace agreements signed by previous Palestinian governments. That should be blindingly obvious. America is engaged in a global armed struggle against terrorism. It is firmly allied with Israel and is committed to Israel's survival.

title: Iran Softens Tone, but Talks With Europeans on Nuclear Program End in Bitterness
description: VIENNA, March 3 - If diplomacy were a courtship, the rendezvous between Iran and Europe in a Viennese mansion on Friday could be called a failed seduction.

title: Women on the Early (and Late) Shift
description: To the Editor:

title: Sather Was Given Time to Turn Around Rangers
description: While discussing the Knicks during an interview with reporters Wednesday, James L. Dolan, the chairman of Madison Square Garden, compared Isiah Thomas with Glen Sather.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bomber Wounds 5 Canadian Soldiers
description: A suicide bomber rammed a car carrying explosives into a Canadian troop convoy in the south, killing himself and wounding five Canadian soldiers, one seriously, Afghan and coalition officials said. The attack was on the main road between Kandahar and the military air base where American and coalition forces are based. Canadian troops are steadily taking over military command of Kandahar Province from American troops ahead of the transfer of command for the six southern provinces from the United States-led coalition to a NATO force. RUHULLAH KHAPALWAK (NYT)

title: Proud Death Stalks the Stage, Sandwiched by Bits of Fun
description: It is a clich of commentary about Paul Taylor that his works are divided between light and dark. As if to prove that even the hoariest clichs sometimes reflect the simple truth, Mr. Taylor's two New York premieres in his winter season at City Center season epitomize the dichotomy. "Spring Rounds," seen at the opening-night gala on Tuesday, was light. "Banquet of Vultures," introduced last night, is dark. Very dark.

title: Peter Osgood, 59, Glamorous Star of English Soccer, Dies
description: Peter Osgood, a star of English soccer in the late 1960's and early 70's, and a glamorous figure for the Chelsea club, died Wednesday after collapsing at a family funeral in Slough, near London. He was 59.

title: Hamas Delegation Visits Moscow for a Crash Course in Diplomacy
description: MOSCOW, March 3 - Russia greeted the leaders of the militant Palestinian group Hamas on Friday with a pointed warning that the organization had to recognize Israel and dismantle its militias or face isolation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETRELLI, JOSEPH A.
description: PETRELLI--Joseph A. A resident of Rye, NY, passed away peacefully at his home on March 2, 2006. He was born on September 24, 1921 in New York City. He graduated from Stuyvesant High School and City College of New York. He served his country during World War II as a Captain in the Army Corps of Engineers. He worked for Mobil Oil Corporation for 35 years, where he was a Vice President in charge of Engineering operations. He is survived by his beloved wife of 56 years, Winifred, and was a devoted father to his five children: Joseph (Susan) Petrelli of Harrison, NY, Margaret (Ted) Duncan of Vero Beach, Fl, Dr. Mary (Dan) Petrelli of Boxford, MA, Dr. James Petrelli of Guilford, CT, and Susan (Bill) Doran of New York, NY. He was a cherished grandfather to his 13 grandchildren. Please contact Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY for further information. A wake will be held Sunday, March 5, 2006 from 3-5. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Resurrection Church on Monday, March 6, 2006 at 10 AM. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, Fourth Floor, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: A Commitment to Rail
description: To the Editor:

title: Even a Healthy Wright Raises Questions for the Yanks
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 3 - Both pitchers who started here Friday signed three-year, $21 million contracts before last season. Jon Lieber went to the Philadelphia Phillies from the Yankees and won 17 games. Jaret Wright went to the Yankees from the Atlanta Braves and won five.

title: Muslims in America
description: The number of Muslims living in the United States remains a subject of debate. The most reliable estimates range from three million to six million. Neither the Census Bureau nor Citizenship and Immigration Services collects information on the religious affiliation of individuals. Surveys paid for by religious organizations, both Islamic and non-Islamic, have been suspected of either underestimating or inflating the total. Those estimates based on self-reporting by mosques are thought to overstate membership. But it is also believed that many Muslims do not attend mosques regularly, and that the number of those who respond to surveys is low.

title: Corrections
description: An Associated Press obituary on Monday and in some copies on Sunday about the actor Don Knotts gave an erroneous explanation of why his character on "The Andy Griffith Show," Deputy Barney Fife, armed himself as a lawman with only a single bullet in his shirt pocket. He did it because he was accident prone; he had not shot himself in the foot.

title: Another Bailout Is Sought for Nassau Health Agency
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., March 3 - In the past two years, Nassau County's fiscally troubled health care agency revamped itself, refinanced its debt, cut 900 jobs, changed presidents and planned to break even by the end of 2005.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Saturday about the author Frederick Busch misidentified the university where he earned a master's degree. It was Columbia, not Colgate, where he taught. The obituary also misstated the year he began to teach at Colgate. It was 1966, not 1976.

title: Barbara Guest, Pioneering Poet of the New York School, Is Dead at 85
description: Barbara Guest, a prominent modernist poet who was the only woman to be a member of the famed New York School of poets of the late 1950's and early 60's, died on Feb. 15 in Berkeley, Calif. She was 85. Ms. Guest, who had lived in Berkeley for the last decade, formerly resided in Manhattan and Southampton, N.Y.

title: A Little Bit of Puerto Rico Finds the Mets' Complex
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 3 - Carlos Beltran rounded a corner in the Mets' minor league clubhouse looking for someone who could remove the perplexed expression from his face.

title: Henry M. Morris, 87, a Theorist of Creationism, Dies
description: Henry M. Morris, the father of modern creationism, whose prolific writings sought scientific validation for a literal interpretation of the Bible and provided the intellectual underpinnings for attacks on evolution as an account of world history, died last Saturday in a hospital near San Diego. He was 87.

title: Pakistan Is Tense as Bush Arrives on 24-Hour Visit
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 3 - President Bush arrived here on Friday for a 24-hour visit to a capital locked down under extraordinary security, as a broad coalition of political parties closed shops and halted transportation across the country and planned more demonstrations for the weekend.

title: For Lieutenant Governor, a Possible Move to the Court
description: ALBANY, March 3 - Lt. Gov. Mary O. Donohue is being considered for a federal judgeship by the White House after being recommended by Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Correction Appended

title: Chrysler's Goal: Keep Success but Lose Incentives
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., March 3 - By all rights, Chrysler should be celebrating its status as the most successful Detroit automaker. Instead, like a tightrope walker facing a stiff gale, Chrysler's ability to keep moving forward is being sorely tested.

title: Women on the Early (and Late) Shift
description: To the Editor:

title: Rules on Hospitals Let Medicare Dollars for Less-Sick Patients Slip Away
description: A nasty infection and dehydration landed Rose Schultz in Christ Hospital in Jersey City, but after a week she no longer needed the expensive, rigorous care of a hospital ward, and Medicare had stopped paying for it. Yet she was still weak and off-balance, in no shape to go home.

title: New Drugs Hit the Market, but Promised Trials Go Undone
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 - When it approves new drugs for sale, the Food and Drug Administration often requires their manufacturers to study whether they are working as intended and whether they have unwanted side effects. But the agency reported Friday that two-thirds of the studies had not even been started.

title: Gladwell vs. Gladwell
description: SIX years ago in the Washington Monthly, Malcolm Gladwell faced off against Adam Gopnik, his fellow New Yorker writer, in a debate over Canada's single-payer health care system. Mr. Gopnik favored it; Mr. Gladwell opposed it vigorously. "Canada has achieved a wonderful thing, which is universal health care coverage," he said then. "But it has achieved it at a price, and that is quality of care."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARIN, SHIELA
description: MARIN--Shiela. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member, and extends condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Harry S. Katz, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, DAVID
description: BROWN--David. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, David Brown, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Eleanor and family. Old Westbury Golf and Country Club David Simon, President Steven Tolman, Secretary

title: Pilots Agree to Pay Cut at Northwest
description: CHICAGO, March 3 - Pilots at Northwest Airlines agreed yesterday to a $358 million annual pay cut, averting the threat of a strike and positioning the carrier for a potentially rapid exit from bankruptcy.

title: Thank You, Thank You, Thank You
description: WOW! This is a huge surprise. I mean, I don't even remember applying to Yale. Kidding, kidding. So many people to thank; I don't even know where to begin. There's my whole team at Scarsdale High: my guidance counselor, Mr. Rondtree -- Rondtree, you rock! My behavioral therapist since fifth grade, Mrs. Klein -- we did it! It's not Harvard, but it's better than Syracuse! Of course, everyone on the Wampanoag Elder Council: thank you for granting me tribal status and allowing me to claim Native American heritage on my application. I know my dad does a lot of legal work for you guys, but I'd like to think you consider me a real American Indian. Finally, I want to thank Dana Schwartz, and just as much, really, Dana's mom, Jocelyn, for letting Dana go to the prom with me even though she's a sophomore. Dana, even though you puked, you made that night very special, if you know what I mean, and I thank you for it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACCORMICK, MONICA
description: MacCORMICK--Monica. On March 2, 2006. Beloved wife of Alexander M.C. MacCormick, loving mother of Alexander C. and Fiona L. MacCormick. Beloved Farmor of Molly & Alex. Devoted sister of Evelyn DiBona. Her spark and enthusiasm for life, family and friends will be missed greatly by all. Funeral private.

title: Officials Say Port Company Faces More Intensive Review
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 - The deeper review promised by the Bush administration of a Dubai company's plan to take over some terminal operations at several American ports will include inspections at the ports, background checks on employees and an examination of the efforts of the United Arab Emirates to fight terrorism, senior officials said Friday.

title: Anatomy of a Schoolmate's Murder
description: They come from around the country to study the science of murder, and to prepare themselves to catch criminals. For many, until last week, crime was something from a textbook, something ugly they had yet to confront personally.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Thursday about a note of thanks that Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. wrote to Dr. James C. Dobson, founder of Focus on the Family, referred incorrectly to Dr. Dobson. He is an evangelical Christian, but not an evangelist.

title: She Croons. He Howls. Will They Connect?
description: Makoto Matsushima and Mariko Ogawa are separated by just a few feet at the end of Pappa Tarahumara's "Island," but they might as well be on different stages. Gazing into the rafters, their bodies finally still, they seem to contemplate alien worlds.

title: The Challenges of an Oversize World
description: A familiar streak of bad faith runs thought TLC's dwarf reality series, "Little People, Big World." It's the same bad faith that informs documentaries about transsexuals and anorexics.

title: A Lion of Drama Lets His Operatic Soul Roar
description: It was something in the eyes.

title: Four Men Rob Brooklyn Jewelry Store
description: Four gunmen wearing ski masks stormed into a jewelry store in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday morning and shot the owner and an employee after the owner tried to chase the thieves, the police said.

title: Running, Jumping, Standing, Staring
description: The performers who grace Martine Pisani's "Sans" appear to be examples of Everyman, yet despite their casual street clothes and lightheartedly awkward movement, they are articulate, virtuosic dancers to the core. The piece's three stars A Theo Kooijman, Laurent Pichaud and Olivier Schram A use a barren stage to create a landscape of chance encounters. The problem is that in Ms. Pisani's seemingly droll world, everything translates but the humor. It's like watching Monty Python dubbed in French.

title: Hamas Delegation Visits Moscow for a Crash Course in Diplomacy
description: MOSCOW, March 3  Russia greeted the leaders of the militant Palestinian group Hamas on Friday with a pointed warning that the organization had to recognize Israel and dismantle its militias or face isolation.

title: Bush Says Pakistan Cannot ExpectNuclear Deal Like One With India
description: ISLAMABAD, March 4 -- President Bush made clear today that Pakistan should not expect anytime soon a civilian nuclear agreement like the one the United States reached only days ago with India, and he bluntly said that the two archrivals on the subcontinent cannot be compared to each other.

title: Breast Cancer Delays Sentencing of Lawyer Convicted in Terrorism Case
description: More than a year has passed since Lynne F. Stewart, a defense lawyer who proudly calls herself a radical, was convicted of aiding terrorists in a high-profile federal trial in New York. But she still has not been sentenced.

title: She's Beautiful, She's Tough, She's Genetically Modified
description: The latest in movies structured around futuristic eyewear and ultratoned abdominals, "Ultraviolet" stars Milla Jovovich in the highly believable role of a genetically modified human named Violet. Violet is a Hemophage -- part vampire, part chameleon, all model -- and is one of the many victims of a government experiment to improve on nature. Like the Replicants in "Blade Runner," the Hemophages have become a danger to society and must be destroyed.

title: By Most Measures, a Housing Boom for the Ages
description: THE great American housing boom is coming to an end, according to virtually every commentator. But if that is true -- and by no means do the statistics yet prove it -- it has been a phenomenal rise. Never in the last quarter-century has the United States experienced two years in which real home prices rose as much as in 2004 and 2005.

title: Vodafone Says Japanese Unit Has a Suitor
description: TOKYO, March 4 - Vodafone may be ready to throw in the towel in Japan, one of the largest and toughest cellphone markets.

title: Hoping for Best in Home Sales, 2 Sides Sit Tight
description: Along much of the East and West Coasts, home buyers and home sellers are engaged in a stare-down.

title: Noodle Prices Rise, Along With Chinese Tempers
description: LANZHOU, China - One difference between China's remote west and the rest of the country is what people choose to put in their stomachs. Noodles, not rice, are the favorite dish, none more so than the steaming bowl of beef noodles named after this decaying provincial capital on the Yellow River.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GROSS, JOAN
description: GROSS--Joan. Twenty-three years now. Beautiful woman, we keep on loving you. All of us

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Con Ed Finds 1,214 Stray Voltage Sites in One Year
description: Consolidated Edison, responding to testing requirements imposed after a woman was electrocuted while walking her dog in the East Village in 2004, found 1,214 instances of stray voltage during a yearlong examination of electrical equipment on city streets, officials disclosed at a City Council hearing yesterday.

title: Dana, a Parts Supplier, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: DETROIT, March 3 - The Dana Corporation, an auto supplier facing dwindling cash and a federal investigation into its accounting, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday, becoming the latest auto parts maker to falter as American car companies downsize.

title: INSIDE
description: Hamas, in Moscow, Tries Its Hand at Diplomacy A Hamas delegation arrived in Moscow for its first official visit to a non-Muslim country since winning the Palestinian elections. A lecture by Russia's foreign minister on recognizing Israel seemed to have little effect. PAGE A6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOSICK, MIRIAM
description: LOSICK - Miriam. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the passing of our longtime member, Miriam Losick. Condolences are extended to the entire family. Dr. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi George Bean and Janene Edlin, Presidents

title: Principles Defeat Politics at the U.N.
Bush Plan Would Raise Deficit by $1.2 Trillion, Budget Office Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 - President Bush's budget would increase the federal deficit by $35 billion this year and by more than $1.2 trillion over the next decade, the Congressional Budget Office reported on Friday.

title: 3 Israelis Set Off Fireworks Inside Church
description: JERUSALEM, March 3 - Three Israelis, one of them said by the police to be mentally disturbed, caused panic on Friday night when they set off loud fireworks during a service at the Roman Catholic Basilica of the Annunciation in Nazareth, in Israel's northern region of Galilee.

title: The Anguish of Being an Analyst
description: YOU never know what's going to set someone off. Consider the case of Michael Mayo, who runs the financial services research team for the Prudential Equity Group.

title: Lawyer in Teenage Sex Case Is Caught in Village Hotel
description: After a brief manhunt, a tax lawyer accused of repeatedly hiring two under-age sisters for sex and paying their mother to allow it was arrested early yesterday in an East Village hotel room, where detectives also found thousands of dollars in cash.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Rogue Unit May Have Carried Out Media Raid
description: The evening raid on a television station and newspaper printing plant in Nairobi on Thursday appeared to divide the government, with some top officials defending the operation but others condemning it as illegal and unwise. The newspaper, The Standard, reported that the attack was carried out by a clique of senior police officers without the knowledge of the police commissioner, Hussein Ali. MARC LACEY (NYT)

title: Japan Expected to Shift Policy and Raise Rates
description: TOKYO, March 3 - A recent stretch of hard-won inflation could prompt the Bank of Japan to scrap its extremely loose monetary policy as early as next week, economists said. The decision could have ripple effects throughout the world's financial markets.

title: Out of Old Mines' Muck Rises New Reclamation Model for West
description: BRECKENRIDGE, Colo. - Pollution saves fish is like man bites dog.

title: Gladwell vs. Gladwell
description: SIX years ago in the Washington Monthly, Malcolm Gladwell faced off against Adam Gopnik, his fellow New Yorker writer, in a debate over Canada's single-payer health care system. Mr. Gopnik favored it; Mr. Gladwell opposed it vigorously. "Canada has achieved a wonderful thing, which is universal health care coverage," he said then. "But it has achieved it at a price, and that is quality of care."

title: Times Are Good, Except Where They Aren't
description: PEOPLE may not fully accept it, but the economy is growing, both in the United States and around the world. Some central bankers say it is growing too quickly. European governments apparently think that market forces are getting out of control and are acting to slow them down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TATE, FREDERICK GEORGE
description: TATE -- Frederick George. age 81, retired attorney and former partner at Rogers & Wells in New York City, died in Washington D.C. on Monday, February 27, of a heart attack. He was the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wills Hills Tate of Wakefield, MA. He is survived by his wife Janice, son Thomas and granddaughter Cecilia. The family will hold private services and burial in Wakefield, MA.

title: BlackBerry Service to Continue
description: Correction Appended

title: Bush, in High-Tech Center, Urges Americans to Welcome Competition From India
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 3 - Before arriving in Pakistan, President Bush finished his two-day visit to India with a speech praising the new warmth in Indian-American relations, and urged Americans to welcome rather than fear India as an economic competitor.

title: Mixing Fact and Fiction to Open Up Larger Reality
description: The Lebanese artist Walid Raad operates on the premise that a familiar form can be revived by interjecting a new subject or a more urgent narrative. His first solo show in the United States, at the Kitchen in Chelsea through next Saturday, suggests that he is sometimes right. Its title is a mouthful: "The Dead Weight of Quarrel Hangs: Documents From the Atlas Group Archives."

title: In an Odd Pairing, an Ideal Complement
description: The orchestra musicians and singers who have worked with the exacting conductor Riccardo Muti over the years can tell you that he is a high-maintenance maestro. Though he brought glory to La Scala during his long tenure as music director of that company, it was not that surprising that his relationship with the orchestra imploded last year, and Mr. Muti quit.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 22 about the resignation of Harvard's president, Lawrence H. Summers, misidentified the car driven by Derek Bok when he held that office. Dr. Bok (whose tastes were contrasted with Dr. Summers's limousine-riding style) drove a Volkswagen Beetle, not a Volkswagen bus.

title: Foiled in the U.S., Singapore Port Operator Seeks to Invest Elsewhere
description: SINGAPORE, March 3 - Perhaps no one has the right to be more disappointed that Dubai is buying the storied British container port operator at the center of the political storm in the United States than the company it outbid, PSA International of Singapore.

title: Gaza Crossings: Choked Passages to Frustration
description: Correction Appended

title: U.S. Isolated in Opposing Plan for a New U.N. Rights Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 3 - The United States has found itself isolated in its opposition to a proposal to replace the discredited Human Rights Commission, and its pledge to vote against adoption of the plan has thrown the United Nations into turmoil.

title: A Milestone Debut for a Young Conductor
description: There must have been a lot of pressure on the 32-year-old French conductor Ludovic Morlot, who made his unexpected subscription concert debut with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening. On a few days' notice, he stepped in for the formidable maestro Christoph von Dohnanyi, who withdrew because of illness (reportedly bronchitis).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PUTNAM, DAVID F.

I'm not sure if that's the result of a rare rhetorical skill or some sort of genius. But it's definitely funny. I know I'm still laughing.

title: Fixing a Hole
description: Dexterity, ingenuity, stick-to-itiveness: I possess none of these qualities but lately have become obsessed with the people who do. As it turns out, an army of the competent have taken to the Internet in recent years, starting up blogs that follow, step by grueling step, the renovation of their old houses. The typical houseblog features a young, earnest married couple, of relatively modest means, who have purchased a tumbledown house in an up-and-coming neighborhood. Their blog, along with the dozens it links to, serves as an informal bulletin board for anyone looking to, say, learn how to tuck point or rescue a distressed corbel. But the immense popularity of houseblogs is impossible to account for in strictly utilitarian terms. "Our Old House," for example, is a no-frills blog detailing the digging of a new basement. A fair sampling of its chapter headings would include "Digging and Preparation" and "More Digging." Yet this otherwise unprepossessing Web site has registered more than 100,000 page views. And that pales in comparison with "Jeannie" and "Aaron," of www.houseinprogress.net, whose rescue of a "sad, neglected, muddled" Chicago bungalow started out, like most houseblogs, as a modest e-circular for friends and relatives. The site now gets 1,300 unique visitors a day and has tallied 2.7 million page views so far.

title: Global Positioning Systems: On Road or Trail, Navigating Made Simple
description: WE weren't looking for much -- a small tin filled with plastic frogs and snakes. But even the best consumer navigation aid at the time -- a small handheld global positioning system (G.P.S.) receiver -- couldn't get my sons and me closer. Looping around in circles and under trees, the G.P.S. hopscotched us through a Boston park in search of the treasure, or geocache, as it's known in the sport of geocaching. But the leafy canopy above us scrambled the G.P.S. signal, and the trinkets remained elusive. We were close, but not quite there.

title: The Brief History of the Dead
description: When the blind man arrived in the city, he claimed that he had traveled across a desert of living sand. First he had died, he said, and then-snap!-the desert. He told the story to everyone who would listen, bobbing his head to follow the sound of their footsteps. Showers of red grit fell from his beard. He said that the desert was bare and lonesome and that it had hissed at him like a snake. He had walked for days and days, until the dunes broke apart beneath his feet, surging up around him to lash at his face. Then everything went still and began to beat like a heart. The sound was as clear as any he had ever heard. It was only at that moment, he said, with a million arrow points of sand striking his skin, that he truly realized he was dead.

The road ends where the lift line to Al's Run begins, a harrowing-looking bump run that must, in part, account for Taos's reputation as one of skiing's most daunting challenges.

title: Not Enough, But Tasty

The good news is that its 2005 sauvignon blanc is one of the finest Long Island has produced in a decade and there is an ample supply -- for now. title: The Collective Conscious
description: Contemporary art is a multibillion-dollar global industry. But why does such a big deal look so small, so slight, with its bland paintings, self-regarding videos, artful tchotchkes and shoppable M.F.A. artists-to-watch? There has to be another way to go, an alternative to a used-up "alternative." By far the most interesting option so far, one that began to be news a few years ago and has increased its visibility since, is the work of miniature subcultures known as collectives. Basically, art collectives do away with the one-artist-one-object model. They come in various sizes and formats: couples, quartets, teams, tribes and amorphous cyberspace communities. Sometimes a group of artists assumes the identity of a single person; sometimes, a single artist assumes the identity of many. Membership may be official, or casual, or even accidental: friends brainstorming in an apartment or strangers collaborating on the Internet from continents away. And they may or may not refer to their activities as art. Research, archiving and creative hacking are just as likely to produce objects, experiences, information that is politically didactic or end-in-itself beautiful, or both. One way or another, joint production among parties of equal standing -- we're not talking about master artist and studio assistants here -- scrambles existing aesthetic formulas. It may undermine the cult of the artist as media star, dislodge the supremacy of the precious object and unsettle the economic structures that make the art world a mirror image of the inequities of American culture at large. In short, it confuses how we think about art and assign value to it. This can only be good.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 5-March 11; FILM
description: If you missed the superb French film "Kings and Queen" when it opened last year, here's your chance to watch it in all its big-screen glory. At once a post-mortem of a failed marriage and a brutal character study times two, the story hinges on a gallery owner, Nora (EMMANUELLE DEVOS), and her unstable former husband, a violist named Ismael (MATHIEU AMALRIC), both of whom seem to inhabit not just different universes, but also different movies. The writer and director ARNAUD DESPLECHIN is one of the most exciting filmmakers working today, and as he digs deep into these radically different, self-interested subjectivities, he employs discordant tones and moods, and a couple of stunning narrative turns, including a late-act twist of the Oedipal knife, that testify to his restless genius. Anthology Film Archives, 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 505-5181.

title: It's Time for Rutgers To Unveil Its Plans
description: After months of public meetings, pointed discussions and gnashed teeth over how to rearrange undergraduate life at Rutgers, Richard L. McCormick, the school's president, is expected to make his long-awaited recommendations to the university's governing body this week.

title: Catching the Wind, Woods Sails Into the Lead
description: MIAMI, March 4 - The much-anticipated showdown between Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson on Saturday in the Ford Championship at Doral had nothing of the excitement of last year's final, as the two had predicted.

title: Wen predicts a slowdown
Other Voices: Mulling the Meaning of Journalists' Discounts
description: Even if The Times has negotiated deals fair and square, passing special benefits unavailable to the public on to Times employees will surely expose your newspaper to suspicions.

title: The Story of O's
description: Rob Walker's Feb. 19 Consumed column brought back memories of the days when my children were babies and toddlers. We never traveled anywhere without Cheerios. Picking up the O's one by one and popping them into their mouths kept the children busy. My late husband, Stephen Davol, who taught child development at Mount Holyoke College, predicted that Cheerios was creating a generation of children with highly developed fine-motor skills. I'm sorry that he didn't conduct any research to prove his theory!

title: After Neoconservatism
description: The articles by Francis Fukuyama, Nir Rosen and Dexter Filkins ("Strategy Tragedy?") made me reach for my copy of Paul Berman's March 23, 2003, Times Magazine article, "The Philosopher of Islamic Terror," about Sayyid Qutb. At the end of the article, Berman asks who in the West is going to speak up as the counterbalance to the deep philosophical ideas articulated by Qutb and being acted upon by Zarqawi and others. Political leaders, he reminds us, "speak of United Nations resolutions, of unilateralism, of multilateralism, of weapons inspectors, of coercion and noncoercion" while concluding that "This is no answer to the terrorists." I'm still waiting for the hero of this war on Islamo-fascism to emerge.

description: KESSLER--Jerome. In memory of Jerome Kessler a visionary real estate entrepreneur and long time business partner. His achievements are notable, among them, Metro Tech in Brooklyn and River Plaza in the Bronx. Our condolences to his wife Norma and his children Mitchell, David and Lisa. But there has been nothing quiet about the early-morning activity at the market, which is known as Sun Fresh Produce and occupies a bustling mini-warehouse in an otherwise nondescript gray building.

title: Up Front
description: This week marks the debut of "Across the Universe," a new science fiction column by Dave Itzkoff. An editor at Spin magazine and the author of "Lads: A Memoir of Manhood," Itzkoff became a sci-fi fan while in grade school. "I was a bit of an insomniac when I was a kid," he said in an e-mail message, "partly because of an irrational fear that the world was going to be destroyed either by a nuclear war or by crashing into the sun. When I couldn't sleep, I'd usually watch reruns of 'The Twilight Zone' on WPIX -- many of which end with the world being destroyed either by a nuclear war or by crashing into the sun. I found it oddly comforting to see these apocalyptic scenes played out, and also to learn that these fears weren't mine alone." Itzkoff hopes his column "can help demystify the genre for readers who believe, mistakenly, that sci-fi and fantasy books have nothing to offer them, and to show them that the boundaries of these categories are fluid and ever-expanding. As far as I'm concerned, books like Jared Diamond's 'Collapse' and Don DeLillo's 'White Noise' qualify as science fiction, as do films like 'A History of Violence' and television series like 'Lost.' " On a scale of 1 to 10, we asked him, how geeky are you? His response: "I would rate myself about a 6; I have an impressive collection of vintage action figures, but I also have a girlfriend."

Items should be submitted by mail at least three weeks in advance to New Jersey Cultural Calendar, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 5, 2006
THE WEEK AHEAD: March 5-March 11; THEATER
description: One of the great things about the theater is the sense that anyone could be the next Shakespeare. Actors write plays, directors write plays, and, of course, writers write plays. Heck, even critics get into the act sometimes, although rarely to great effect. Here's hoping, however, that GORDON COX, a reporter at Variety and a former critic for Newsday, has better luck with "Phenomenon," a new play at the HERE Arts Center following the adventures of a waitress, a busboy, a geologist, a cowboy and, yes, a journalist on the day before the Mount St. Helens eruption in 1980. Conceived and directed by ALYSE ROTHMAN, with text by Mr. Cox, the show is described as multimedia, including projections, animation and, presumably, good-old fashioned newspaper writing. Through March 25 at HERE, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Dominick Street, South Village, (212) 868-4444; $18.

title: A Lot of Alohas
description: Nonstop domestic air service to Hawaii reached record levels last year as airline capacity rose by 9.1 percent to a record 7.2 million. This year, there are new flight choices. Last week, US Airways started nonstop daily service between Las Vegas and Kahului, on Maui, and flights three times a week between Phoenix and Kona on Hawaii. In late April, ATA will begin nonstop daily service between Ontario International Airport (in California) and Honolulu. ATA's current San Francisco-to-Hawaii flights will be shifted to nearby Oakland; service to Hilo will be added. In June, Hawaiian Airlines will begin San Diego-to-Kahului service.

A fashion stylist and costume designer, Ms. Phillips has 18 films and dozens of music videos to her credit. Best known perhaps for putting much of the dazzle into Madonna's ever-evolving stage persona, she has made a near fetish of hiding her own light behind a curtain.

title: Hot-Cold Baths in Quebec
description: HERE are the basics of thermotherapy: Heat yourself up in a sauna or steam room like a microwaved burrito. Then catapult your steaming body into icy water -- if a 40-degree pool doesn't seem cool enough, try a 34-degree river. Cap it off with a period of rest, during which your beating heart will sound like Buddy Rich pounding on a bass drum. Repeat. The effect is guaranteed: profound shock, followed by a feeling of relief that you are still alive.

title: Scientific Americans
description: IN case there's any doubt that the subject of Allegra Goodman's disturbing new novel is topical, note this headline from the Jan. 19, 2006, New York Times: "Cancer Study Was Made Up, Journal Says." Substitute Nature for The Lancet, the British medical journal that was forced to retract the study referred to in The Times; trade rogue tumors for cancer of the mouth; move the lab to Cambridge from Oslo (but keep the funding source, the National Institutes of Health); supply a new virus as the successful therapy, and there is Goodman's "fiction." The only real difference between the story she has devised and the one reported in the newspaper is that the newspaper article is unequivocal: There's no question that the Norwegian scientist "manipulated" the data.

The show may have made it to the air with its quirkiness intact, but the original pitch differed from the final product in one glaring way: Mr. Goss wasn't in it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETRELLI, JOSEPH A.
description: PETRELLI--Joseph A. A resident of Rye, NY, passed away peacefully at his home on March 2, 2006. He was born on September 24, 1921 in New York City. He graduated from Stuyvesant High School and City College of New York. He served his country during World War II as a Captain in the Army Corps of Engineers. He worked for Mobil Oil Corporation for 35 years, where he was a Vice President in charge of Engineering operations. He is survived by his beloved wife of 56 years, Winifred, and was a devoted father to his five children: Joseph (Susan) Petrelli of Harrison, NY, Margaret (Ted) Duncan of Vero Beach, Fl, Dr. Mary (Dan) Petrelli of Boxford, MA, Dr. James Petrelli of Guilford, CT, and Susan (Bill) Doran of New York, NY. He was a cherished grandfather to his 13 grandchildren. Please contact Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY for further information. A wake will be held Sunday, March 5, 2006 from 3-5. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Resurrection Church on Monday, March 6, 2006 at 10 AM. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, Fourth Floor, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: ADRIAN MOLE AND THE WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION. By Sue Townsend. (Soho, $24.) In "The Adrian Mole Diaries," a success of near-Potteresque proportions back in the mid-1980's, Townsend set her hero's teenage angst against the more serious travails of Margaret Thatcher's Britain. In successive diaries, Townsend followed Adrian through marriage and fatherhood, and success as a chef at a trendy London restaurant with his own TV cooking show. This latest installment finds him on the downslope, post-marriage and post-fame, 34 years old and working in a bookstore back in his native Leicester. It is autumn 2002, and Adrian is quarreling with a travel agent who won't refund the 57.10 deposit for a vacation he canceled when Tony Blair announced Saddam Hussein needed only 45 minutes to deploy weapons that could demolish Cyprus. This hopeless pursuit -- and Adrian's increasing disenchantment with Blair and the Iraq war -- underpin a story that gently tweaks many aspects of life in contemporary Britain: condo-loft conversions (Adrian buys one at "The Old Battery Factory, Rat Wharf," overlooking a canal inhabited by viciously territorial swans), credit card debt, New Agers and writers' groups. Significantly, the only successful member of Adrian's group is an old lady who writes doggerel about her cats.

The lobster fishermen allege that a pesticide manufacturer is responsible for destroying the fishery and their way of life. They certainly have a case, but more to the point, what happened more than six years ago could easily happen again, unless we make some changes now.

title: After Neoconservatism
description: Francis Fukuyama (Feb. 19) does not quite argue it this way, of course, but his article suggests that the neoconservatives rushed into the Iraq war because they actually believed their own propaganda that the Soviet empire fell apart as a direct result of the neoconservative policies of the Reagan era. In fact, economically, politically and culturally, the empire was already disintegrating by the 1980's. During both the 1980's and in recent years, neocons believed in their cherry-picked intelligence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDNER, JOE
description: GARDNER--Joe. Joe Gardner was one of a kind. In an age of rough-and-tumble real estate developers, Joe was like an oasis. He was kind, generous, thoughtful, considerate, honorable and committed to doing the right thing at all times. Over 25 years of doing business with P&J Realty, Newmark Knight Frank and its partners were comfortable in the knowledge that our clients who leased space in his buildings would be happy and well taken care of. He was a pioneer in the residential conversion business in Midtown South, Greenwich Village, Chelsea and SoHo. Joe's life changed drastically after 9-11, with the loss of his only son, Doug, who was his right hand and best friend. We mourn Joe's loss. He will be missed by all of the partners and brokers at Newmark Knight Frank. Our hearts go out to Danielle and Charlotte, who we hope will find peace and solace in their memories of such a great and wonderful man.

title: Bridge Plan Rattles Seattle Enclave
description: SEATTLE - IN 1993, Jonathan Dubman, a former business analyst and software engineer for Microsoft, bought a five-bedroom Cape in the city's Montlake neighborhood. He said he chose Montlake, which borders Lake Washington, because of its central location near the University of Washington and the Washington Park Arboretum. He also liked the neighborhood's "lack of ostentation" and proximity to Route 520, a freeway that cuts through the neighborhood before crossing the lake and touching ground in Medina, home of Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLARKE, EVELYN A.
description: CLARKE--Evelyn A., age 84, died peacefully in the early morning of February 21. Born in East Orange, NJ on October 9, 1921, she was the oldest child of Evelyn Mansfield Clarke and Allen Hillyer Clarke. Raised in Summit, NJ, she attended the Kent Place school where she distinguished herself in the classroom and especially on the athletic fields. She majored in Zoology at Smith College (B.S. 1943) and later attended the Yale School of Nursing prior to marriage in 1946 to Charles Kennedy M.D. of Buffalo, NY. They were divorced in 1966. She subsequently earned a M.S. in Chemistry from the Univeristy of Pennsylvania and joined the faculty of Philadelphia Community College in 1970 where she taught until 2003. A licensed private pilot, she was also a cycling enthusiast, pedaling across Europe and the Rockies in her early 60's. She was an ardent advocate for equality in opportunities and status for women. A loving mother, she spent very little on herself, but denied her children nothing. She is survived by one sister, Jacqueline C. Walker of Montpelier, VT, her daughters Jacqueline C. Kennedy of Somerville, MA and Carol Kennedy Radmer of Valley Park, MO, and her son Allen C. Kennedy of New York City and his sons, her grandchildren, Ian and James. In lieu of flowers please make donations in Evelyn's name to Episcopal Community Services of Philadelphia, 225 S. 3rd St, Philadelphia, PA 19106

For all of the axis-of-evil rhetoric that has come out of the White House, the reality is that the Bush administration has done more to empower Iran than its most ambitious ayatollah could have dared to imagine. Tehran will be able to look back at the Bush years as a golden era full of boosts from America, its unlikely ally.

title: The 60th Brick in His Wall
description: Since reuniting at Live 8 for a performance in July and seeming to patch up their differences, David Gilmour and Roger Waters of Pink Floyd have dashed fans' hopes that the band would tour . Those in need of a Floyd fix aren't out of luck, though. Mr. Gilmour, who turns 60 on Monday, is releasing his first solo album ("On an Island") in 22 years and for the first time in 12 years is touring small European halls (next month, the United States). So many milestones, so many guitar solos, yet he isn't fazed. He recently spoke by phone with Joe Brescia. Herewith, excerpts from their conversation.

description: To the Editor:

title: Selling the Air Above
description: ON an island where there is often nowhere to build but up, the air in Manhattan can get pretty pricey. Air-rights deals, or the sale of unused development rights from one property owner to another, are generally considered the business of big-time developers. But in cheek-by-jowl Manhattan, homeowners, small-building owners and co-op boards can often find themselves involved, too. While potentially lucrative, such deals are complex and can even raise ethical quandaries for property owners.

title: Ranches Without the Work
description: There are some people who define a vacation house by the number of yards from the beach or the proximity to decent lattes. Then there are those who harbor a secret hankering to rope calves or shovel the rocks out of an irrigation ditch on their days off. For them, shared-ranch properties offer a way to have your ranch and leave it too. For around a million dollars and upward, it is now possible to buy into any of the West's several new "integrated ranch developments." Among the many amenities: wide-open spaces, horses on demand, cows masticating by the house, huge trout leaping out of private streams, fences to fix when and if homeowners feel like it. They can play in the mud in their Carhartts, or not.

title: Agents Provocateurs
description: It is deeply unfortunate that for so long the image of the New York City real-estate world has been represented by a man with a bright red necktie, a bad comb-over and a penchant for gold lettering. These are in fact very stylish times for real estate. Some of the most exciting architecture since who can remember when is being developed, commissioned, built, hyped and sold, adding renewed sex appeal to the urban landscape. There is, for example, the Urban Glass House, Philip Johnson's last project. There are the architect Jean Nouvel's 40 Mercer and Norman Foster's 610 Lexington Avenue. And the people who hold the key to this real-estate-obsessed city? They are the brokers and the developers. People like the RFR Holding co-founder, Aby Rosen, and the Sunshine Group's James Lansill and Prudential Douglas Elliman's unsinkable Dolly Lenz. You can either love them or hate them, but please don't burst their bubble.

title: Ex-congressman gets 8 years in prison in bribecase
Pearl of the Orient
description: IT is the highest house in all of Zhenjiang, tucked behind bamboo above the Yangtze mist shrouding Cloud Scaling Hill. The former occupants lie buried on two continents: the parents nearby, their famous daughter beneath Pennsylvania farm soil in a grave marked with her Chinese name. She arrived in China as a child of missionaries. Now, steles resembling tombstones front her gray brick childhood home. In English, the epitaph reads, "Here lived Pearl S. Buck, American author, born 1892, died 1973." The more effusive carving in Chinese cites a Nobel Prize and the praise of a president: "Nixon called her a bridge between the civilizations of East and West."

title: When Good News Is Bad News
description: EVEN if the employment report on Friday offers job numbers that seem just right, do not be surprised if the markets take it badly. It happened last month, and one fund manager expects a reprise.

title: Pro-Israel Lobbying Group Roiled by Prosecution of Two Ex-Officials
Other Voices: Mulling the Meaning of Journalists' Discounts; Where Are the Roll Calls?
description: Blaming space constraints for the omission of roll-call votes is like blaming mopeds for the energy crisis. The roll calls squeeze more concentrated information into a space the size of a small classified ad than does any news story.

title: INSIDE
description: Schools Avoid Ranking, Vexing Some Colleges Thousands of high schools have stopped giving students' class rankings to colleges, saying they could harm students' admissions chances. But some colleges are saying that strategy can backfire. PAGE 29

title: Warm, Warmer, Warmest
description: One of the hottest environmental battles has been over oil drilling in the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, but the sad reality is that much of the Arctic plain will probably be lost anyway in this century to rising sea levels.

title: In the Company of the Courtesan
A Day Later, N.F.L. Talks Still Sputter
description: Negotiations between the N.F.L. owners and the players union broke off yesterday, decreasing the likelihood of a new labor agreement before the scheduled start of free agency tomorrow.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Who Needs the Mortgage-Interest Deduction?
description: One of the first financial lessons I learned from my father was that when you buy a house, you get a tax break from deducting the interest on your mortgage. Therefore, he would explain as if it were as natural as pivoting at second base on a throw from shortstop, a person could afford to pay more for a house that he owned than he would on a residence that he was only renting and on which he didn't get the tax break.

title: The Status of Puerto Rico (2 Letters)

title: Bradley in Final After Knocking Off Wichita State
description: ST. LOUIS, March 4 - With a twisting, one-handed dunk late in the first half Saturday, Bradley's Patrick O'Bryant came alive in a big way.

title: NEUTRAL, PLEASE
description: General Motors' outspoken vice chairman, Robert A. Lutz, acknowledged that he was a little too outspoken last week.

title: For $612.5 million, BlackBerrys to keep running
Graduation Rates Adjusted Down
description: ON-TIME graduation rates in Westchester high schools are substantially lower than districts have been reporting, according to new statistics from the State Education Department.

title: Tar Heels Send a Message
description: DURHAM, N.C., March 4 - Cameron Indoor Stadium shook from the roar of the ovation before the final home game for J. J. Redick, Shelden Williams and the rest of a Duke senior class special enough to redefine this already storied program.

title: Other Voices: Mulling the Meaning of Journalists' Discounts; Where Are the Roll Calls?
description: When I sit down to read a newspaper, I don't want to be told to go to a Web site to get information as important as a record of votes cast. Going to a Web site involves much more time and effort than going to a continuation page.

title: U.S. Judge to Rule Whether Confession in Israel Can Be Used
description: CHICAGO, March 4 - A federal judge heard arguments on Friday about whether a confession made to Israeli security agents by an American citizen could be used in a trial in which he is accused of laundering money for Hamas to finance terrorist acts.

title: The Cat Ladies Sing
description: Correction Appended

title: How Much Profit Is Lurking in That Cellphone?
description: IN some ways, wireless is the new China. Both are huge, largely untapped markets for news and entertainment media companies. And media executives have made a lot of dreamy statements about both of these markets and funneled a lot of effort into them. Yet neither has yet translated into a significant new businesses for established companies, which are feverishly seeking ways to grow in a world of technological and competitive obstacles.

title: Clean Air
description: WASHINGTON - Environmental regulators tend to see their world through the prism of science. But these days, the science dominating their world view is not biology or chemistry, but economics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRYFOOS, HON. ROBERT J.
description: DRYFOOS--Hon. Robert J. On March 2, 2006. Son of the late Edith and Jerry Dryfoos, survived by Susan Dymond and their family Clifford, Jason and Abby Fishkind, and two adoring granddaughters. He will be forever remembered as a courageous, passionate man whose love of life and all things New York was equalled only by his generosity, steadfast friendship and the joy he took in being "Grandpa Bob." Service Sunday, March 5, 10:00 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76 Street & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Loud Leaf Blowers and Frayed Nerves (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: 90-Year-Old Fears a Big Rent Rise
description: Q. My client, a 90-year-old widower with no family, rents a nonregulated co-op apartment in Manhattan. His lease expires this spring, and he is frightened that his landlord will not offer him a renewal lease at a reasonable rent. The landlord says that the "proper" rent for the apartment is about four times the amount that my client is now paying. Can this man be evicted if his landlord raises the rent by that amount? Rise Landsman, M.S.W.

title: For-Sale Subtleties
description: My wife and I signed a contract to buy an apartment. The sellers' fast-talking real-estate broker assuaged our fears that new development might block the spectacular river views. We subsequently learned that development is planned within two years. We're convinced that the broker acted badly, but are the sellers also ethically complicit? Could we confront them with our displeasure as a way to void the deal?

title: So Many Musicals to Write, So Little Time
description: Correction Appended

title: Analysis, or Just Dictation?
description: WOULD you be uneasy if the man who is the chairman, chief executive and president of a company whose stock you owned decamped without warning after almost 20 years on the management team?

title: ICING ON THE CHECK
description: Shareholders of United Technologies may have thought that George David, the chairman and chief executive, had been fully compensated for a job well done when he received more than $14 million in salary, bonus, perquisites and stock options last year. But proxy statements show that the board handed Mr. David, 63, an additional one million options, valued at almost $13 million, for various "accomplishments," including helping to plan his eventual retirement and having been named the best aerospace C.E.O. by Institutional Investor. PATRICK McGEEHAN

title: As if Hit by a Bus
description: To the Editor:

title: Postpunk'd
description: Punk rock was great and it made for a great story. The Ramones and other upstart bands came out of nowhere, playing songs that were loud, fast and obnoxious. With more passion than skill, they made the established rock stars look like pompous windbags. The movement came to a fitting end with the self-destruction of the Sex Pistols in 1978. Johnny Rotten turned back into John Lydon, Sid Vicious overdosed and everybody else pulled their safety pins out of their cheeks. Since then, scores of writers and filmmakers have been attracted to punk's outrageous characters and shapely plot.

title: Finding a Family House (Cue the Bagpiper)
description: TO Celine Cheddy, a house meant space and freedom. To her husband, Garry Cheddy, it meant responsibility and repairs.

title: It Is What It Is
description: "'We went through it thoroughly yesterday," said Scott McClellan, the White House press secretary, somewhat testily after being badgered recently about the Cheney hunting accident. "It is what it is, and I think it's time to move on."

title: Odes to Suburbia
description: FOLK singers have long written songs of love about freight trains and racehorses, but some have also written with disdain about the suburbs. And no community's name signifies suburbia more than Levittown, which listeners believe has been pilloried in song for decades.

title: Why Rules Can't Stop Executive Greed
description: IN the arena of executive compensation, two recent developments stand out against the backdrop of continuing looting. First, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced plans to make corporations more fully disclose executive pay. Second, a study by Mercer Human Resource Consulting found that more companies were imposing performance targets on the stock and options they granted to C.E.O.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, PHILIP B.
description: MILLER--Philip B. A brilliant thinker, inspiring teacher, and charming human being, died February 10, 2006, in Manhattan. Born in Boston, in 1930, he earned a B.A. from Bard College and a Ph.D. from Yale University. He began his career teaching comparative literature and German at Princeton University, before moving to City College, City University of New York, retiring in 1999. He was a Fulbright Scholar at the University of Munich. His edited translation, "An Abyss Deep Enough: Letters of Heinrich von Kleist," was a New York Times 1982 Notable Book of the Year. As son, brother, uncle, grand-uncle, teacher, & friend, Phil brought his unique combination of kindness and humor, erudition and wit. He will be forever missed.

title: Totalitarian Fairy Tale
description: NEW BRUNSWICK - "ONCE upon a time" never resonated with more menace than in "The Pillowman," Martin McDonagh's sardonically funny yet horrifying drama onstage here at the George Street Playhouse. In an evening of gripping theater directed by Will Frears and featuring a superb cast, it is striking that this Kafkaesque tale manages to eke out a happy ending.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 5-March 11; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: This is the week of serious overprogramming in the art world. First, the Whitney Biennial is in full swing. On Friday, the Armory Show, one of the nation's largest contemporary art fairs, opens on the piers on 12th Avenue at 50th and 52nd Streets. And by midweek a huge contingent of New York dealers and collectors will be jetting to Maastricht, the Netherlands, for the mammoth European Fine Art Fair, which also begins on Friday.

title: The City's Homeless: Visible, and of Value
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week Ahead: March 5 - 11
description: THEATER

title: The Toll From Turin: A Damage Assessment
description: Lost in the excitement of the Olympic hockey tournament in Turin, Italy, was the toll it took on N.H.L. teams, the Ottawa Senators in particular.

title: The Albany Papers
description: Somewhere on the second floor of New York's gloomy State Capitol, there are stacks of documents relating to Gov. George Pataki's 12 years in office. The papers and e-mail messages range from the governor's proposals for cutting taxes to his own personal files and diaries.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Tepperman, John Griffin
description: Wendy Beth Tepperman and John James Griffin were married last night at the Plaza Athne in New York. Judge Loretta A. Preska of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated.

title: Psychotherapy's Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Shrouds and Black Markets
description: East Montpelier, Vt. - TEN days before Christmas, I received a call from a detective with the Brooklyn district attorney's office. He wondered if I had heard anything about the office's investigation into the illegal sale of more than 1,000 bodies by several funeral homes in the area. I told him I had not. He went on to explain that the bodies were stolen and parts of them sold to several different processing plants. It sounded macabre, and I don't really remember much more after he said, "We have evidence that your father's body was one of the ones taken."

title: At Satellite Courthouses, 9/11 Relatives Will Watch Moussaoui's Sentencing
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 - When lawyers make their opening statements on Monday in the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui in a Virginia courtroom, Sally Regenhard intends to be in Lower Manhattan. Against the advice of friends, she is planning to watch the proceedings on closed-circuit television at the Moynihan federal courthouse, just blocks from where her son died on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: An L.I. Highlight From Both Forks
description: Cellar 72, a new store at 1355 Second Avenue (72nd Street), carries one of Long Island's finest sauvignon blancs in a decade, the Channing Daughters 2005 Channing Perrine sauvignon.

title: What Does It Mean to Be Educated? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, GUSTI
description: COHEN--Gusti. A true woman of valor died on March 3. Devoted wife of the late Tuvia Cohen, beloved mother of Ilan and Amir, dear motherin-law of Iris and Joan, adoring grandmother to Danielle, Jordana, Natalie and Adam. Services Sunday, March 5, 9:30AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, NY. Burial in Israel.

title: Finding Historical Loops, and Opening Them
description: For nearly 25 years, Lawrence Weschler has been collecting what he calls convergences, tearing out images from magazines, advertising and newspapers that recall works of art or nature or even science.

title: All the World's a Turntable
description: SOMETIMES Andre McLeod works the door at Nublu, a small lounge in the East Village. And sometimes he works the turntables.

title: Hernandez Shows Mets His Stuff, but at Shortstop
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 4 - Anderson Hernandez's dynamic effort in the Mets' 5-4 victory on Saturday against the Washington Nationals provoked this question: Can Hernandez improve his standing in the second-base competition if he plays shortstop?

title: A Force of Nature, and What She Built
description: IF you were a child living in Evelyn Steger's neighborhood, you would make up stories about her, just as children have always invented stories about people who live alone in houses that aren't like others. Among the clipped, smooth lawns and new crop of grandiose facades of East Island in Glen Cove, Dr. Steger's low, meandering modernist house peeks out through twisting trees like a living creature caught in a cartoon landscape.

title: Welcome to Long Island. Now Cut Electric Rates.
description: DURING the Revolutionary War, the redcoats occupied Long Island longer than any other place in the Colonies. Now, 222 years later, the British are back -- this time in business suits, armed with billions to buy KeySpan, the private partner in the private-public system that supplies energy to Long Island.

title: Other Voices: Mulling the Meaning of Journalists' Discounts; Where Are the Roll Calls?
description: Would you have us believe that the only problem with The Times's no longer printing tables with roll-call votes is that the paper is so very tight on space? And that now we can find that information on the Web site -- maybe?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUCCIA, ANNA
description: MUCCIA--Anna. Died peacefully in Vero Beach, FL on February 11, 2006. Anna was born in NYC on February 22, 1910. Beloved wife of the late Carrol A. Muccia. She is survived by her devoted children, Carrol A. Muccia Jr., Diana Muccia and Peter Muccia. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth Pyle, Timothy Muccia, Anne Droesch, David Muccia and Bianca Muccia. Dearest nanny to 12 great-grandchildren. Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Wednesday March 8, 10 AM at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY.

title: Grief and Rage, Distilled Into Generosity
description: PURDYS - WHEN Gina Arena of Purdys eulogized her 6-year-old son, Jimmy, last September, she told his nearly 1,000 assembled mourners that "the ripple effect of his life will be felt forever."

title: CALENDAR
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance by e-mail, to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959.

title: Give a hand to justice in Iraq
The Obscure and Uncertain Semiotics of Fashion
description: ONE of the more striking trends at the Paris fashion shows last week was the obscuring, by masks, hoods, hats and swaths of fabric, of the radiant faces of the models.

title: Devils Keep Their Cool to End Rangers' Streak
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 4 - Darius Kasparaitis is a hitter, not a fighter, and definitely not a scorer. Whether he is also a cheap-shot artist depends on whether you talk to his teammates or his targets.

title: DATEBOOK
description: MAYRHOFEN, AUSTRIA So far this season, the Tyrolean ski resort town of Mayrhofen has seen more snow than it has in more than 40 years, with good conditions expected through April. This is good news for Snowbombing, a snowboarding and music festival that promises skiing all day and "beats by night."

title: A Vase That's Accidental Art
description: HIS political philosophy now largely out of vogue, the 19th-century Russian anarchist Mikhail Bakunin is best remembered for declaring, "The passion for destruction is also a creative passion." Based on that utterance, Mr. Bakunin might have gotten a big kick out of the Run Over by Car Vase, a product that could hardly have a more accurate name: it's a metal container that has been warped by an automobile's wheels, to the point that it's barely recognizable as a standard flower holder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, DR. FRANK FULTON III
description: ROSS--Dr. Frank Fulton III, 81. Professor emeritus of communication, scholar, and beloved mentor, died January 30, 2006. Dr. Ross was born in Ryan, Iowa on December 30, 1924. Lovingly known as Fulton to family and friends, he served in the U.S. Army Field Artillery Division in World War II. Fulton received his Doctorate Degree in Communications from Columbia University Teachers College in 1963 and began teaching at Hunter College. During his tenure at Hunter, Fulton was on a variety of departmental and College - wide com mittees. He received many teaching awards through out his career, including the Hunter College Presidential Award for Excellence in Teaching in 1987. Dr. Ross retired from teaching in 1999. Dr. Ross is survived by family in the mid-west, one daughter, friends, colleagues and countless students whose lives were enriched and influenced by his teaching and mentorship. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held at Hunter College on April 23, 2006 in the Lange Recital Hall from 2-5PM in the afternoon. A donation can be made to the Hunter College Foundation to the F.F. Ross Scholarship Fund, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: The Spirit of New York
description: Gardiner, N.Y. - SUPPOSE you decide to spend the weekend upstate, looking forward to visiting a favorite bistro or tavern. When the server asks for your drink order, you'll most likely order a glass of wine or a mug of beer. Since holders of wine and beer permits are allowed to serve wine and beer that are up to 24 percent alcohol by volume (or what's known as 48 proof) and, oddly enough, the Korean distilled spirit soju, defined specifically as "imported from Korea," your waiter can easily comply with your request. But if you wanted to order any other distilled spirit, for instance a local fruit brandy made from Hudson Valley apples grown in the orchard down the road, you'd be out of luck. You'd have to go to a bar or a restaurant with a much harder to obtain and costlier full liquor license.

Travelers on the Road to Discovery, Fueled by the Imagination

description: If this past month has been Round One of the Senate match-up between Robert Menendez and Thomas H. Kean Jr., Mr. Kean was clobbered.
