description: As you suggested, I have looked more closely at the employee discounts available to all who work at The New York Times. Here are my thoughts:

title: Army Ordered to Look Again at Battle Death
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 - In a rare rebuke of military investigators, the Defense Department inspector general has told the Army to open a criminal inquiry into the shooting death of Cpl. Pat Tillman, the former professional football player whose enlistment in the Army drew national attention, Pentagon officials said Saturday.

title: 'The Life All Around Me by Ellen Foster'
The Producers
description: Los Angeles - AROUND midnight tonight, after what will undoubtedly be an excruciatingly long Oscar kudo-cast, the Academy Award for best picture will finally be announced. The expectant faces of all the producers of the five nominated films will be pasted on plasma screens, computers and cellphones around the world, but only one movie will send its producers to the stage to accept that tall gold statue that is the object of so much affection.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with a review of two shows at the Nassau County Museum of Art, "Reginald Marsh" and "Infamous New York: Bosses, Burlesque & Mayhem," misattributed one work, "The Millionaire." It was painted by Jack Levine, not by Reginald Marsh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TATE, FREDERICK GEORGE
description: TATE -- Frederick George. age 81, retired attorney and former partner at Rogers & Wells in New York City, died in Washington D.C. on Monday, February 27, of a heart attack. He was the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wills Hills Tate of Wakefield, MA. He is survived by his wife Janice, son Thomas and granddaughter Cecilia. The family will hold private services and burial in Wakefield, MA.

title: U.S. Commander Meets With Iraqi Leaders on Impasse Over Premier
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 4 - The top American military commander in the Middle East met in Baghdad on Saturday with senior Iraqi politicians, and appeared to press American demands for a quick resolution of the dispute over the post of prime minister in the new government.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted last Sunday for a picture of the director Ian Judge with an article about problems at the English National Opera. The photographer was Gail Howland.

title: Endangered Species
description: The Boston-Minneapolis Hypothesis

title: Home Economics
description: Edward L. Glaeser grew up on the East Side of Manhattan, went to school in Princeton, N.J., and Chicago, lived for a time in Cambridge, Mass., and Palo Alto, Calif., and recently moved with his wife and young son to a house on six and a half acres in the affluent suburb of Weston, Mass. To Glaeser, this last move has been a big adjustment. For one thing, he is not a good driver, and the new commute has prompted him to leave his house by 6 a.m. so as not to get ensnared in the morning rush hour. For another, Glaeser and the suburbs are clearly an unholy marriage of sensibilities, especially since his new house is bordered by about 600 acres of conservation land. "I wake up every day, thinking, My goodness, how many units of housing could you build here?" he says. Glaeser is a creature of density. An economist at Harvard, he has spent almost his entire professional life walking around, and thinking about, cities -- seeking explanations why some metropolitan areas thrive and some suffer and what factors make some places pricey and some cheap. He is just 38. In the years since earning his Ph.D. at the University of Chicago, though, he has been prolific and provocative in a way that has left many of his colleagues awestruck. "I think he's a genius," says George Akerlof, an economist at the University of California, Berkeley, who was awarded a Nobel Prize in 2001. Gary Becker, an economist at the University of Chicago and a Nobel laureate, notes that before Glaeser came along, "urban economics was dried up. No one had come up with some new ways to look at cities." David Cutler, Glaeser's Harvard colleague and an academic star in his own right, puts it this way: "I think Ed is probably the most exciting urban researcher in half a century, if not longer."

title: On Advertising: Getting in the game
Republicans Take Two Seats With Ease
description: Republicans won resounding victories Tuesday in two special elections to fill State Assembly seats in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: A Virtual Retirement Home
description: Without hammering a nail or meeting with a planning board, some residents of Princeton, N.J., have built a new community. Don't go looking for the brick and mortar signs of something as obvious or visible as a planned retirement community, however. This one calls itself a Community Without Walls (C.W.W.), and exists mostly in the emotional bonds between its members. Its specifics may be unusual, but its goal -- to allow people to stay at home while they age -- is part of a national trend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEIGH, JANE HORN
description: LEIGH--Jane Horn. Died peacefully on February 22, 2006 in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved wife of Samuel Leigh, devoted mother of Steven Horn Leigh and Nancy Leigh. Grandmother of Cassandra "Casey," Jordan and Brian Leigh. Sister of Sola Lee Kaye of NYC. She was fiercely devoted to family, and her sense of humor will be sorely missed. She was an excellent bridge player and an avid gardener. Her flowers will miss her too. Interment was private.

title: Energy Exploration
description: WASHINGTON - At the Bureau of Land Management, the question used to be whether to approve a company's application to drill for oil or gas on public lands. Now, as prices for natural gas explode, the question is how quickly, cheaply and efficiently the bureau can make the application decisions, which means, generally, approving them.

title: Military Maneuvers With Computer and Color
description: From the day when Eric Chan and Heather Schatz switched seats in a figure drawing class as undergraduates at the University of California, Berkeley, and finished each others' compositions, they have engaged in a back and forth that underpins all of their art. Producing work under the name ChanSchatz since graduating in 1990, the two artists (who are husband and wife) have since expanded their collaboration to include an ever-widening pool of guests as they explore how different ideas and groups of people intersect in contemporary life.

title: In Serbia, Deaths Set Off a Lucrative Race for Profit
description: Correction Appended

title: Radio Days
description: IF you have been in TriBeCa lately, or even if you haven't, you may have heard the newest voice of downtown, an Internet radio station called tribecaradio.net that has been broadcasting since January. The station's founder, as well as its program director, advertising chief and supervisor of technical support, is a local musician named Leigh Crizoe, who, additionally, is the host of "The T Train With Leigh C," a music program that the station broadcasts whenever airtime is empty.

title: Correction
description: The Square Feet article last Sunday, about the developer Frank J. Sciame, misspelled the given name of the actress whose home he acquired in Old Saybrook, Conn. She was Katharine Hepburn, not Katherine. The article also misstated the name of a Lower Manhattan building that Mr. Sciame's company restored. It is the Seamen's Church Institute, not Seaman's.

title: Cried and Cried
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS

description: To the Editor:

title: Country and Western New Jersey
description: ASBURY - AS the long bright days shortened last autumn, and slid into the crusty deep freeze of winter, I heard the faint siren call of a warm, smoky, line-dancing roadside honky-tonk calling out to me. I could hear the din of greetings and laughter, the sharp crack of breaking billiard balls and the ringing out of clinking glassware, like so many jostling wind chimes enlivening the still night.

title: Other Voices: Mulling the Meaning of Journalists' Discounts; Where Are the Roll Calls?
description: I went to Google to see how long it would take to find the roll-call votes that The Times didn't publish. Eight seconds and one click. I love The Times, but I don't see it as the ultimate source for the details behind the news -- that's too much to ask of any single entity.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 5, 2006
The Big Oyster
description: In 1609, when Henry Hudson, a British explorer employed by the Dutch, sailed into New York Harbor on his eighty-five-foot ship, Halve Maen, with a half-British, half-Dutch crew of sixteen, he found the same thing Mackay would two and a half centuries later-a local population with the habit of feasting on excellent New York Harbor oysters.

title: The Search for Illegal Immigrants Stops at the Workplace
description: IT may seem that the United States government has declared all-out war against illegal immigration. During the last decade, the budget dedicated to enforcement of immigration laws has grown by leaps and bounds. The Border Patrol has about three times as many agents as it did in the early 1990's, and the southern border has been laced with high-tech surveillance gadgetry.

title: Civilians flee Pakistan border fighting
The For-Sale Society
description: What could be more solid, more firmly rooted, than real estate?

title: A South Korean's Dream: The Pyongyang Express, Spanning Decades of War and Enmity
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 28 A He is 82 years old and on a recent day was still frail from a winter bout of pneumonia. But Kim Dae Jung is planning what could be his last great act for inter-Korean conciliation A an inaugural train trip from Seoul to Pyongyang.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTROFF, HAROLD
description: OSTROFF--Harold, on March 2nd, 2006. Husband of the late Frieda. Father of Madelon and Philip Braun and the late Sandra Ostroff. Grandfather of Kelli and Andrew Braun, Jessica and Andrew Rich, Alison Gottlieb and Geoffrey Friedman, Debra and Pat Ewing. Great-grandfather of Jeffrey, Matthew, Sam and Coby. Beloved best friend of Adrian Bernick. A man whose warmth, integrity and passionate commitment to improving the lives of others will always inspire. Services Sunday, 12 noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Donations in his memory may be made to Workmen's Circle Center for Social and Economic Justice, 45 E. 33rd St., NYC 10016 or YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, 15 W. 16th St., NYC 10011.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Feb. 19, about no-fault divorce, misstated the number of states where courts can order that child support be paid until a son or daughter is 21. New York is not the only state to allow such orders; at least two other states do as well.

title: OUT-BOX
description: Here are the five most e-mailed articles from nytimes.com/sports for Feb. 25 to March 3.

title: Club Med for the Multimillionaire Set
description: Tim Blixseth, a 55-year-old self-made billionaire, is rarely seen wearing a tie, or even sporting a reasonably close shave, and yet he nonetheless conveys an impression of neatness and energetic efficiency. Frequently tan, always fit and compact, he makes a point of bounding up every flight of stairs he encounters, a policy that combines his two most salient qualities: boyish enthusiasm and a strong sense of discipline. Having made his fortune buying and selling timber properties, Blixseth, in the past seven years, has shifted the focus of his considerable energy to the luxury-resort business, starting with the world's only private golf and ski resort, the Yellowstone Club near Big Sky, Mont., which he conceived of, financed and built. More recently, he has taken his luxury real-estate aspirations global, which explains his near-constant tan, a result of his personally comparing and contrasting and scooping up extravagant properties in various Sun Belts around the world. The end result of his acquisitions, a collection of nine vacation properties that Blixseth plans to call Yellowstone Club World, will essentially be an opulent time-share program for the richest of the world's rich.

title: Fire in Brooklyn Leaves Bedridden Woman Dead
description: An 82-year-old woman who was bedridden died early yesterday after a fire swept through a four-story building in Brooklyn and her relatives were unable to save her, according to the authorities and her family.

title: Correction
description: A listing in the Residential Sales chart last Sunday for a one-bedroom condominium in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan, which sold for $730,000, misstated the address. It is 640 First Avenue, not First Street.

title: 'The Case for Goliath'
description: At the beginning of the twenty-first century, a term came into use to refer to the American role in the world that conjured up images of Roman legions with helmets, metal breastplates, and sharp lances keeping order in the ancient world, bearded Habsburg grandees riding on horseback along cobblestone streets in Central Europe, and British colonial officials in pith helmets presiding over tropical kingdoms. The term was "empire." Many books and articles appeared advancing and exploring the proposition that the United States had become, without officially acknowledging it, what the largest and most powerful political units of the past had proudly proclaimed themselves to be.

title: Elizabeth Axelrod and Benjamin Brucker
description: Elizabeth Ann Axelrod, a daughter of Jane and Michael Axelrod of Roslyn, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Benjamin Michael Brucker, the son of Dona and Andrew Brucker of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas officiated at Oheka, the Otto Kahn house in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y., with Rabbi Barry Kenter taking part.

title: He's Battered, but His Agenda Isn't Beaten
description: WASHINGTON

title: Cocktail Fixings and Video Art at James Chicago
description: The James Chicago, the second hotel from the New York restaurateur Stephen Hanson and the Equinox Fitness Club founder, Danny Errico, begins accepting guests later this month, with an official opening on April 20.

title: Keeping a Child's Nightmares at Bay
description: Mount Kisco - WHEN the Journal of the American Medical Association reported a large increase in the number of preschoolers being treated with psychiatric medications a few years ago, worried parents inundated Four Winds, a psychiatric hospital for children and adolescents in Katonah, with phone calls.

title: Older, Wiser
description: THE LIFE ALL AROUND ME BY ELLEN FOSTER

title: Knicks Find Poise and a Moment of Happiness
description: MILWAUKEE, March 4 - So starved for a moment of joy, so desperate for a chance to celebrate something, anything at all, the Knicks broke into chest bumps on the Bradley Center court late Saturday night.

title: When Renderings Clash With Reality
description: MONTCLAIR - AS the first of 10 huge homes being built on the site of the former Marlboro Inn began to rise last fall toward its full height and breadth, so did the hue and cry.

title: The Scent of a Man
description: THE camera, one of the most artful and habitual liars ever invented, should never take the stand. And yet wouldn't it be fun to see it break down under cross-examination? Admit its disingenuous ways and woeful inadequacies? Confess that its blank Cyclopean blink is as subjective as a hostile witness?

title: Reds' Encarnacion Surprises Johnson and Yanks
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 4 - Randy Johnson's first spring start might have gone just fine, but a hitter he had never heard of intervened.

title: West Hollywood: Sunset Tower Hotel
description: THE BASICS -- When the hotelier Jeff Klein purchased the historic Argyle two years ago, he announced that he planned to restore elegance to the tacky Sunset Strip. Renamed after months of renovations that took place while many guests had to maneuver a hotel lobby that looked, at times, like a construction site, the chic new 74-room Sunset Tower hotel does hark back to the golden era when this Art Deco landmark was an apartment building housing the likes of Bugsy Siegel (evicted for gambling), Frank Sinatra and Marilyn Monroe. But the old-school dcor and pretensions come with lackluster service.

title: Where Quizzes Are Stop and Pop
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sharing the Joy
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 5-March 11; TELEVISION
description: When did March become a great month for television? Besides the OSCARS (Sunday at 8 p.m. on ABC) and a slew of network premieres, there's also MTV's "8th & OCEAN" (Tuesday at 10:30 p.m.), which has the same reality/not reality ethos as the mesmerizingly beautiful "LAGUNA BEACH." The action takes place among models who are roommates in Miami's South Beach, following them and their Faye Dunaway-like agents through their glitzy, empty lives. Backstabbing twins, SABRINA and KELLY -- who one suspects might actually be named after the "Charlie's Angels" characters -- are just one highlight.

title: With Kidd Thinking Small, Jefferson Plays Big
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 4 - Chris Bosh of the Toronto Raptors was having his way with the Nets during the second half Saturday afternoon. He scored repeatedly from the outside as the Nets scrambled to try to stop him.

title: Amid the Glitter, Jersey City's Growing Pains
description: JERSEY CITY - IN this city by the river, where glimmering towers now poke into the sky, newfound prosperity is trickling from the Hudson waterfront to the traditional downtown neighborhoods. Here is a wine bar, a French cafe, another luxury condominium. On nearly every block, it seems, there is a Dumpster signaling a freshly gutted and soon-to-be-rehabbed home.

title: Scientific Americans
description: INTUITION

title: Medicaid
description: WASHINGTON - Conservatives say the Bush administration has not done much to cut the growth of federal entitlement programs. In fact, the administration supported the biggest expansion of Medicare in the history of the program.

title: Correction
description: The Field Notes column last Sunday, about wedding dress rentals, misspelled the surname of a playwright who was married in 2004. She is Laura Rohrman-Paperny, not Roehrman-Paperny.

title: Pitch Limits Squeeze a Classic Strategy
description: The World Baseball Classic, the sport's attempt at a world championship, has not been greeted warmly. With all the complaints -- the tournament should not be held during spring training, too many stars are dropping out, the pitchers will return to their clubs looking like the Venus de Milo -- the Australian shortstop may as well be Chicken Little.

title: At These Parisian Landmarks, Shhh Is the Word
description: Correction Appended

title: Vouchers
description: WASHINGTON - Though President Bush quickly abandoned the conservatives' longstanding demand for school vouchers in 2001 when he needed bipartisan support for his major education law, No Child Left Behind, vouchers have not disappeared.

title: Cultivating Music Lovers
description: Correction Appended

title: Tamil Rebels Tie Deaths to Army
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, March 4 - Barely a week after both sides pledged to halt a spate of violence that pushed this island nation once again to the brink of war, ethnic Tamil rebels on Saturday accused the army of killing two of their fighters in an early morning ambush. The military denied any involvement.

title: Two versions of pride in Sydney celebrations
The Smartest Guy in Summit?
description: ALEX GIBNEY, the Oscar-nominated director of the high-octane documentary "Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room," says that he was not particularly interested in filming the Enron story at first. For one, it violated rule No. 1 of the filmmaker's handbook: Never make a movie about accounting. Then, he read the book of virtually the same name by Bethany McLean and Peter Elkind, reporters for Fortune magazine, and changed his mind.

title: Filming Los Angeles From the Gutter Up
description: JOHN FANTE led the kind of scrappy, yearning, hard-drinking Hollywood-besotted life you could write a book about, and he did, several times. One version, his 1939 novel "Ask the Dust," is the inspiration for the new movie of the same name, opening Friday. It was written and directed by Robert Towne, who is himself a fabled Hollywood character, the screenwriter of both "Chinatown" and "Shampoo," which are the Old and New Testament, roughly, of Los Angeles mythology.

title: And This Year's Oscar Goes to ... a Movie That Takes a Stand
description: This year's best picture nominees include a gay cowboy movie, and one about racial conflict in contemporary Los Angeles. There's a movie about the cycle of violence in the Middle East; one about a writer whose homosexuality, if not his journalistic ethics, is treated sympathetically; and one about a crusading TV newsman who took on a right-wing demagogue.

title: Dollars Without Borders
description: GLOBAL CAPITALISM

title: Correction
description: A review on Feb. 12 about "War of Nerves: Chemical Warfare From World War I to Al-Qaeda," by Jonathan B. Tucker, referred imprecisely to the United States' use of tear gas and the defoliant Agent Orange in the Vietnam War. Unlike most of the other substances discussed in the review, neither was designed to cause direct casualties. However, the use of tear gas to flush enemy soldiers from hiding and Agent Orange to destroy overhead cover provoked debate about whether they should be counted as true chemical weapons under international law.

title: A Home's Novel Features: Blue Sky, and Branches
description: The feud between John Schwing and Ryan Pedram sounds like the start of a biblical parable: Two men own neighboring plots of land, and three trees grow on the line between them.

title: How to Build a Low-PVC, Reduced-Plastic, Polar-Bear-Sensitive House
description: If the greenest house is no house at all, what's the next best thing? For homeowners like Tony and Sally Grassi, ecologically responsible construction isn't just about minimizing the immediate impact on the environment (their new 3,000-square-foot house in midcoast Maine was built on the site of a small hunting lodge) or energy consumption (photovoltaics, or solar panels, will supply some of their energy needs). It's about materials, especially plastics, adhesives and additives.

title: Nothing but Blue Skies Do I See
description: This winter black reclaimed its status as a chic fashion essential, but to celebrate spring retailers are softening up just a touch and moving toward a warm, stylish navy blue. Not just for mechanics' uniforms or nautical ninnies, navy accessories and clothes in supersoft knits, patent leathers and everything in between are crowding store shelves and racks. Here are the freshest ways to lighten up in blue.

title: Where Quizzes Are Stop and Pop
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A byline on Page 3 of the Travel section today for an article about Paris libraries is misspelled. The writer is Richard B. Woodward.

title: French Marine Is Killed in a Clash Linked to the Taliban
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, March 4 - A French special forces marine died from his wounds after a clash on Saturday with insurgents believed to be linked to the Taliban in southern Afghanistan, American military officials said.

title: Master Suite, Ocean Views, Harem Room and Piano Bar (Seats 200)
description: There's one, it seems, in every city: the home, once loved and adored, now sits semi-abandoned and unsold, an embarrassment to both its owners and the real-estate agent charged with dispatching what, after an unseemly interval, has come to be known in the business as a white elephant. Maybe the house is priced too high -- eight figures can be steep, even for movie stars and software moguls, even in places like Malibu or Seattle. Maybe a house just needs too much work for its price point.

title: Thousands rally against U.S. in Jakarta
An ex-convict challenges shackling women in labor
Executive's Big Trade (Himself)
description: When a general manager moves midseason from a contender to an also-ran, it should raise eyebrows, but that was nothing compared with the reaction to Bryan Colangelo's jump to Toronto from Phoenix last week.

title: County's Latest Perp Walk, on All Fours
description: YOU'VE heard of Megan's Law, right? Well, the best and brightest in Westchester's bureaucracy have now come up with a kind of Megan's Law for dogs.

title: Gasol Showing Growth With the Grizzlies
description: The more people ask Pau Gasol about his beard this season, the less he wants to shave it. His mother wanted it neat; he went wild.

title: COMINGS & GOINGS
description: Aeromexico is offering first-class air fare for as low as $399 round trip on a number of routes it flies from the United States to Mexico through Dec. 10, including San Diego to Los Cabos or Loreto; Houston to Mexico City; and Las Vegas to Guadalajara. Phoenix to Mexico City costs $449, and Miami to Mrida is $599. Rates don't include taxes and fees, which can be up to $100. All those swanky Hamptons restaurants that are so hard to get into during high season are trying to lure diners back while it's still cold. During the annual Hamptons Restaurant Week, March 26 to April 2, more than 70 restaurants will offer a $19.95 three-course meals as well as special deals on Long Island wines. Participating restaurants include Della Femina, Nick and Toni's and Tierra Mar. The Hampton Luxury Liner bus will offer special trips from Manhattan for $19.95, about 40 percent off. Fine dining at sea: Radisson Seven Seas Cruises has joined with the Htel Plaza Athne in Paris for food- and wine-themed voyages on the Seven Seas Voyager in May and the Seven Seas Navigator in August and December. The sailings will feature dishes prepared by guest chefs and wine masters of the Plaza Athne restaurant, headed by Alain Ducasse, right, but Mr. Ducasse will not be sailing. Philippe Marc, chef of the Relais Plaza restaurant in the hotel, will join the May voyage. The hotel's head sommelier, Didier Thomas, will sail in August, and the head pastry chef, Christophe Michalak, in December. Trafalgar, an escorted tour operator, is offering a $200 discount for couples on a number of air-inclusive vacations to Europe, including Amsterdam, London and Paris, if booked and a deposit is paid by March 17 for travel from April 3 through October. Starting March 27, Air Tahiti Nui will fly twice a week from Kennedy Airport to New Zealand, with a stopover in Papeete, Tahiti. Passengers depart New York at 5:15 p.m. and arrive in Auckland at 5:40 p.m. two days later, after crossing the International Date Line. Return flights, which will also stop in Tahiti and leave three times a week from Auckland, make up for the long flight by taking off at 1:05 p.m. and arriving in New York the same day at 2:25 p.m. IN TRANSIT

title: This Is the Tale of Our Castaways
description: THERE is a grown-up love story unfolding on "Lost," but it's often overshadowed by flashier hook-ups. Sure, Kate and Sawyer are hot. But for the teary-eyed pleasure of watching two characters in love falling apart and coming together again, it's hard to beat the South Korean husband-and-wife castaways, Sun and Jin Kwon.

title: The last dictator of Europe
Laugh Lines
description: Jay Leno

title: All the Love a Mortgage Can Buy
description: A precious and rare opportunity family apartments on Gramercy Park. The effortless luxury home for a parent with services and amenities created exclusively for a family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACCORMICK, MONICA
description: MacCORMICK--Monica. On March 2, 2006. Beloved wife of Alexander M.C. MacCormick, loving mother of Alexander C. and Fiona L. MacCormick. Beloved Farmor of Molly & Alex. Devoted sister of Evelyn DiBona. Her spark and enthusiasm for life, family and friends will be missed greatly by all. Funeral private.

title: Extending the reach of an author's pen
U.S. Gives India Applause, Pakistan a Pat on the Back
description: NEW DELHI, March 4 - President Bush leaves this region having declared India and Pakistan strategic partners. But his declarations spoke just as loudly of the shifting balance of power in the region, and the world.

title: The Quarrel
description: Correction Appended

title: Psst... Have You Heard About Bushwick?
description: On a rainy winter afternoon, just a few minutes after running over a stray hubcap, just after having to pull his beat-up Toyota sedan off a beat-up section of the beat-up Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and having to run the little white car back and forth until at last the hubcap broke free, Tom Le, choreographer-turned-real-estate-agent, re-enters the mad rush of the highway and a mile or so later exits as planned, ending up on a detour, Park Avenue. "I'm running a little late," he says, semicalmly, into his cellphone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRENNAN, URSULA
description: BRENNAN--Ursula. March 24, 1920-March 2, 2006. Mainboucher model, Editor, Bantam Books. Survived by brother Alan, Pittsford, NY and two nephews.

title: This Hot Stove Goes Clickety-Clack
description: This winter meeting began in New Jersey and rolled toward New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLAFTER, HORACE
description: KLAFTER--Horace. On March 3, 2006 of Jericho, NY. Beloved husband of Laura and of the late Corinne. Devoted father of Lois and Jerry, David and Nancy, Beth and Beth, Perry and Diane, Steven and Anita. Loving grandfather of Daniel, Jordan, Rebecca, Ben, Deborah, Gabe, Sam, Ben, Deborah, Julia, Adam, David and Ava. A remarkable friend, loved by many.

title: After Neoconservatism
description: Fukuyama advocates a retreat from the foreign-policy realism that implies an embrace of friendly tyrants, and I do not disagree. But let us embrace the realism that acknowledges the corollary of his apt point that the struggle for the hearts and minds of ordinary Muslims is a long one and may fail: terror attacks are likely to continue and will therefore continue to provide a pretext upon which an imperial presidency can encroach upon Americans' civil liberties.

title: Back Rent? Norwalk Symphony Is All Paid Up
description: FOR the Norwalk Symphony Orchestra, the news was like a crisp concerto.

title: The Lemongrass War
description: NANI TANZIL, a 52-year-old Indonesian immigrant with chiseled hair and a perennial smile, had spent five years despondently rolling sushi at various Midtown supermarkets. Then, in January 2003, in a bold leap of entrepreneurship, she quit her job and transformed the crammed kitchen of her apartment in Elmhurst, Queens, into what Indonesians call a warung, or food stall.

title: Iran threatens jump in atom work
Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, DAVID
description: BROWN--David. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted father of Leslie and Harlan Rausch, Elyce Singer and Caroline and Jeffrey Bloom. Loving brother of Bernard. Adored grandfather of Amy, Jonathan, Joshua, Stefanie, Haley and Zachary and great grandfather of Emma. Services on Sunday at 1 P.M., at "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: OUTDOOR SHOWERS
description: There's only so much hoteliers can do to enhance the indoor bathing experience. Soaking tub? Check. Shower head the size of a dinner plate? Got that. So more resorts are turning their attention to the outdoors, to give guests that commune-with-nature experience.

title: Old and new media meet but can't make connections
AT&T set to buy BellSouth in $65 billion bid to form phone giant
The Albany Papers
description: Somewhere on the second floor of New York's gloomy State Capitol, there are stacks of documents relating to Gov. George Pataki's 12 years in office. The papers and e-mail messages range from the governor's proposals for cutting taxes to his own personal files and diaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOVOK, HAROLD
description: NOVOK--Harold on March 3, 2006. Beloved husband of Florence, loving father of Marilyn R. Schulman and Janet A. and Ivan Brown. Cherished grandfather of Scott and Michele Schulman, Darren and Amy Schulman, Vanessa and Scott Nied, Derek and Nikola Brown and Dustin Brown. Adored great grandfather of seven. Graveside services at 11am on Sunday, March 5, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY. For more information call Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, 800-247-5235

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the 2006 summer cruise season misspelled the name of a mosque in Istanbul, a port of call for cruise ships. It is the Suleymaniye, not Sulimaniye.

title: Priya Sachdev and Vikram Chatwal
description: Correction Appended

title: To Democrats Hungry for Senate, a Pennsylvania Seat Looks Ripe
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa. - Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, the third-ranking Republican in the Senate leadership, sums up his race for re-election this year with a paradoxical pride: "The other side of the aisle wants to beat me more than anything you can possibly imagine," he told the Greater Lehigh Valley Auto Dealers Association not long ago.

title: Alumni Condos on Campus
description: For a healthy 40-something, I spend an unhealthy amount of time fretting over retirement. Not the part I should be worrying about -- namely, how I will pay for it? -- but rather the fact that the available how's and where's seem so unappealing. I can't see myself in the unvaried sunniness of Florida, nor do I want to shovel my own snow. A standard retirement village feels bland, but a mixed-age town-house development would be so focused on young families that I would be an afterthought.

title: Upscale Condos in the County's North
description: YORKTOWN

title: LEFT BRAIN FOR HIRE
description: As an accountant, Greg C. Fenton is not your typical number cruncher. Though he makes his living with a calculator, Mr. Fenton is an art lover and collector. More than 20 percent of his clients are not-so-starving artists he has helped guide through the morass of tax preparation, financial planning and portfolio management. And amid the artists displaying their wares at the Artexpo this weekend at the Javits Convention Center, Mr. Fenton will be looking for clients for his firm, Cambridge Cape Cod Advisors, based in Sandwich, Mass.

title: Battle of London has global flavor
Hollywood's Crowd Control Problem
description: TONIGHT, an expected 41 million Americans will tune into the 78th annual Academy Awards to watch a spectacle largely honoring films they have not seen and may never get around to watching. Much has been made, in particular, about the smallness of most of the nominees for best picture, which usually refers to their modest budgets and absence of stars, but also rightly suggests an economy of ambition and scale. With the exception of Steven Spielberg's "Munich," a political thriller about the 1972 Olympics massacre and its aftermath, these are intimate stories in which most of the action involves characters talking and occasionally shouting at one another. They were also released by an independent or studio specialty division (Little Hollywood, not Big).

title: Hooked on Online Psychics
description: FOR Sarah Lassez -- a winsome actress who has appeared in more than 20 movies, alongside actors like Matthew Modine, Rose McGowan and Dennis Hopper -- the seemingly inevitable Hollywood bout with addiction she experienced a few years ago was accompanied by the usual handmaidens of a habit: career uncertainty, romantic turbulence and nagging fears of future obscurity. At her darkest moments it cost her $1,000 a month, more than her rent. But perhaps worst of all was the effect her addiction had on those around her.

title: What Does It Mean to Be Educated?
description: To the Editor:

title: Let There Be Light, But Less of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WERNICK, DR. JACK H.
description: WERNICK--Dr. Jack H. Of Millburn, NJ, on March 3, 2006. Beloved husband of Charlotte and the late Sylvia. Father of Phyllis (Dr. Robert) Lauer and Rosanne Wernick, and beloved grandfather of six. Service today at noon, at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ; 800-938-6372.

title: Other Voices: Mulling the Meaning of Journalists' Discounts; Where Are the Roll Calls?
description: I have been irked for some time by the omission of roll-call votes. This is galling in the face of the space lavished on such urgent news as the fashion show, dining, escapes, automobiles and so on and so on. It becomes even more galling as the war news worsens and Rome burns.

title: After Neoconservatism
description: After noting the need for "a political contest for the hearts and minds" of Muslims, Fukuyama refers to the prospect of a more moderate Hamas as someday making possible a Palestinian-Israeli peace. No mention of the United States' support for Israel's oppressive occupation and seizure of Palestinian land and water resources as a reason for Palestinian violence and Muslim and Arab anger. No need apparently for changes in United States and Israeli actions. We cannot win the hearts and minds of people by facilitating their oppression and seeking to control their resources.

title: Laos: Out From Under an Opium Cloud
description: THURSDAY night in Vang Vieng in northern Laos, and the guesthouses along the Nam Song have gone dark. The thin clouds no longer glow with that fluorescent warmth of a small town below.

title: The Toll From Turin: A Damage Assessment
description: Lost in the excitement of the Olympic hockey tournament in Turin, Italy, was the toll it took on N.H.L. teams, the Ottawa Senators in particular.

title: The Funny Pages
description: I've been meaning to write for months. Each Sunday, I seem to have read half the paper before I remember: when I do, I flip frantically to find the Funny Pages. There, every week, I am surprised, delighted and relieved to read and reread yet another installment of Chris Ware's "Building Stories." I never expected something so cool from The Times Magazine. Many thanks.

title: Principles Defeat Politics at the U.N.
description: IN the global struggle for the advancement of human rights, the United Nations has reached a defining moment. The president of the General Assembly, Jan Eliasson of Sweden, has led five months of negotiations to develop a proposal to reform the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. Although the commission has accomplished many things, including the adoption of human rights standards, treaties and fact-finding mechanisms that measure the performance of governments, it has become more of a political battleground than a meaningful force for protecting victims of human rights violations, and it must be reformed.

title: After Neoconservatism
description: "Benevolent hegemony" is an absurdity. Only hegemons think of their reign as benevolent; those whom they dominate think of their masters as imperialists and oppressors. If ever there were a kindly overlord, it was the United States' erstwhile mother country, which inculcated representative government, civil rights and common law. But our founding fathers were not grateful for the benevolent British once the French and Indian War came to an end. We should also remember that, when compared with the colonial experience elsewhere in the British Empire, as in India or South Africa, the grievances of the American colonists were downright petty.

title: Welcome to Limbo
description: THE BRIEF HISTORY OF THE DEAD

title: The Seasoned Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Was cartel just noodling, or was price for real?
Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLPER, DAVID
description: WOLPER - David. Beloved husband of Vera. Father to Ilene and sister and brotherin-law Harriet and Bill Barash. We will all miss him dearly.

title: Dumplings That Say 'Chinatown'
description: HAVE you ever eaten a soup dumpling, also known as a juicy dumpling? A few years ago this Shanghai specialty was the rage in the Chinatowns in Manhattan and Flushing, Queens. But until Shanghai Pavilion opened in Port Washington, I had never seen it on a menu in Nassau or Suffolk County.

title: Iraq's Jordanian Jihadis
description: Nir Rosen's coverage of jihadi culture in Jordan was sobering (Feb. 19). It's important that we as a nation try to understand the roots of such virulent hostility. Rosen's reporting comes at a critical time: a Danish paper's printing of cartoons considered blasphemous has raised the tension between East and West to a fever pitch. Dialogue is crucial now, and Rosen succeeds in facilitating thought and debate.

title: Pizza, Not Elk Chops, on a Budget Ski Trip to Jackson, Wyo.
description: Correction Appended

title: He's Battered, But His Agenda Isn't Beaten
description: WASHINGTON - PRESIDENT BUSH has survived rough scrapes before, bouncing back after the reports of torture by American troops at Abu Ghraib, for example, and later the furor over his Supreme Court nomination of Harriet E. Miers and the slow response to Hurricane Katrina.

title: Oscar May Love a Film on Newark's Nasty Politics, but Newark Largely Missed It
description: NEWARK, March 3 - Four years ago, the windows of Lenny Zizel's clothing store here in the heavily Portuguese Ironbound neighborhood were draped with campaign signs for Cory Booker, then a city councilman who went on to lose a brutal race for mayor against the incumbent, Sharpe James.

title: Conduct With All You've Got, Conk Out During Intermission
description: LONDON - VALERY GERGIEV, the energetic, continent-hopping Russian conductor, had met his match: a vicious virus caught during a monthlong tour. He lay in a hotel room here last month, the covers pulled to his chin, hair matted as he sweated out a fever. His cultivated 5 o'clock shadow had moved well past midnight.

title: When New York Votes, Let's Get It Right
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFERENCE TOURNAMENT TIME
description: Winning Bids Belmont, with an overtime victory over its crosstown rival Lipscomb in the Atlantic Sun final, earned its first bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament. "We're glad to be one of the teams playing one of those teams," Coach Rick Byrd said.

title: Giving Birth in Chains
description: America regards itself as an eminently civilized country, but in many states female prisoners who give birth are required to be held in shackles during labor. Besides being grotesquely inhumane, this appalling practice is medically dangerous.

title: In Florida, No Hurry, Worry or Middle Seat
description: IMAGINE a commuter railroad where the tracks are lined with palm trees, the cars are airy and spacious and a monthly ticket costs $80, no matter how far you ride.

title: Macarena Di Dio and Brian Byrnes
description: Maria Macarena Di Dio, the daughter of Maria Beatriz Lopez Di Dio of Buenos Aires and the late Jose Luis Di Dio, was married on Friday to Brian Fitzgerald Byrnes, a son of Maureen Knerr Byrnes and Kevin G. Byrnes of Phoenix, Md.

title: In New Haven, a Premiere Gets the Star Treatment
description: ONE name, Branford Marsalis, may at least sound familiar. A jazz saxophonist, Mr. Marsalis is a three-time Grammy-award winner, the former music director of "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno," and brother of the renowned jazz trumpeter Wynton Marsalis.

title: Will the Real Mob Please Stand Up
description: THE made-up mob world stars the Sopranos, who return to HBO next Sunday. The real mob world stars Vinny Gorgeous and Junior Gotti, whose trials are returning tales of funny names, fickle families and matter-of-fact violence to New York courtrooms. How closely does either script reflect the state of the mob in America today? Jerry Capeci, whose latest book, "The Complete Idiot's Guide to the Mafia," was published last year and who writes a column about organized crime for his Web site, ganglandnews.com, and The New York Sun, weighs in on fellas good, bad and not-quite-obsolete.

title: Trying to Corral Rebels on a Roll

The doors of the motel, on North Conduit Avenue in Springfield Gardens, Queens, had been chained and padlocked; a yellow restraining order affixed to the glass with duct tape was barely hanging on. Inside the front windows, there stood a cheerful, lonesome Christmas tree, its ornaments and tinsel twinkling in the afternoon sunlight.

title: Will the Real Mob Please Stand Up

The real mob world stars Vinny Gorgeous and Junior Gotti, whose trials are returning tales of funny names, fickle families and matter-of-fact violence to New York courtrooms. How closely does either script reflect the state of the mob in America today? title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABBE, RICHARD FREDERICK
description: RABBE--Richard Frederick. 93, born June 12, 1912 in New York, NY, passed away on Saturday October 7, 2005 in Naples, FL. Son of the late Frederick Rabbe and Amelia Voege Rabbe, he graduated from The Dwight School for Boys and was the Class of 1935 at Colgate University, Hamilton, NY. He served stateside as a captain in the US Army during WWII. Formerly a resident of New York, NY and East Hampton Long Island, he retired as Vice President for Sales at Harris Structural Steel Co., Inc., a fabricating and erecting concern founded by his late father-in-law, George William Harris. He was instrumental in obtaining the awards for the Brooklyn Tower of the Verrazano Narrows Bridge, the Betsy Ross (Pennsauken) Bridge and the Delaware Memorial Bridge II contracts along with many other private and public works projects. From 1966 to 1975, he served as a director of the American Institute of Steel Construction, Inc. Richard was a member of the Maidstone Club (East Hampton, NY) as well as the Moorings Country Club and The Royal Poinciana Golf Club in Naples. He is predeceased by his wife of 60 years, Marjorie Harris Rabbe and a sister, Ruth R. Kranich (Mrs. Jules G.) of Essex, CT. He is survived by two sons, Richard John of San Jose, Costa Rica and George William of Naples and Sherman, CT; along with two grandchildren. Services will be private for the immediate family. In lieu of flowers, contributions on his behalf may be made to Trinity-by-the-Cove Episcopal Church, 553 Galleon Drive, Naples, FL 34102.

He had bequeathed the annuity to his church, St. Stanislaus in New Haven, but Mr. Laskowski, a dishwasher at the Omni Hotel in New Haven who always prided himself on paying his bills, needed the cash.

title: Stay in Touch
description: Thomas Suozzi is off and running for governor, and some on Long Island are starting to feel a little lonely without their Nassau County executive. Don't forget about us, one newspaper editorial warned, expressing the concern -- seconded by some columnists and voiced on this page last October, when it endorsed Mr. Suozzi for re-election -- that Nassau might suffer if it were being run at a distance by a distracted campaigner with Albany on the brain.

title: Inside the List
description: OUT OF VENICE: "In the Company of the Courtesan," Sarah Dunant's moody and bristling new historical novel, set in Venice in the 16th century, enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 6. This is Dunant's second book to make the Times list; her previous novel, "The Birth of Venus," had a nine-week run in 2004. Dunant, who was born in 1950, is much more familiar in her native England, where she's presented programs on BBC radio and television and is a well-regarded cultural critic. Earlier in her literary career she was known for a series of thrillers that featured a "feminist private eye" -- one critic's term -- named Hannah Wolfe. (Hannah was good company: "The baddies are never quite the ones you want them to be," she cracked in one novel.) These thrillers usually tackled thorny topics like animal rights and surrogate motherhood. Critics have tended to approve of Dunant's move into historical fiction, a tough genre to master. ("There are no paeans to the watery beauty of Venice," Laura Miller wrote about Dunant's new book in Salon. "Dunant doesn't make a fetish out of romantic love either. . . . 'Courtesan' finally emerges as something very rare, a celebration of the complicated and undersung affections that flourish between colleagues and friends.") Last year Dunant told an interviewer: "The skills I learned from thrillers -- how to construct a compelling story, how to hold the reader, how to play with them, how to not let you want to put the book down -- all these have not deserted me. They have, I hope, simply been used on a bigger canvas."

title: Freehold Heat
description: FREEHOLD - OUTSIDE looking in is a bad place to be, when bitter, dirty gusts bring tears to your eyes and make you hug your coat to yourself all the tighter. Luckily, there is a good antidote in Freehold where the tortilla chips are warm, the seafood soup is spicy, the shark tacos are tender and the fried pork rinds are stacked high in their glass display boxes.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 5-March 11; POP/JAZZ
description: For hip-hop fans, this week starts early. At the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island, the hip-hop radio station Power 105 is giving itself a birthday party on Sunday. The exuberant veteran BUSTA RHYMES is the scheduled headliner; expect a frenetic version of his current hit, "Touch It." (Perhaps he'll also talk about the police investigation into the recent death at his video shoot, though he'll have to do it carefully. Fans would probably love to hear him say he won't talk to the cops, but his lawyers would probably be less enthused.) He is to be joined by the brash young Harlem hip-hop star JUELZ SANTANA, the emerging crooner NE-YO, the Atlanta group DEM FRANCHIZE BOYZ and, perhaps best of all, the thrilling R & B star KEYSHIA COLE; she sounds ferocious even when -- as on her current hit, "Love" -- she's merely telling everyone how happy she is. 1255 Hempstead Turnpike, Uniondale, N.Y., (516) 794-9303; $35.50 to $95.50.

title: Home Sweet Debt
description: Every night, like millions of other homeowners, I lock the doors, turn off the lights, peer out the windows to check for burglars and go to bed inside my money. It's all around me, in the walls and ceilings, under the floors and spread across the yard. Some nights, when I'm lying very still, I imagine that I can even feel it growing. That faint vibration in the foundation? That subtle rumbling in the Sheetrock? It's not a small earthquake; it's equity accumulating in the cozy three-bedroom portfolio I call home.

title: The Spirit of New York
description: GARDINER, N.Y. - SUPPOSE you decide to spend the weekend upstate, looking forward to visiting a favorite bistro or tavern. When the server asks for your drink order, you'll most likely order a glass of wine or a mug of beer. Since holders of wine and beer permits are allowed to serve wine and beer that are up to 24 percent alcohol by volume (or what's known as 48 proof) and, oddly enough, the Korean distilled spirit soju, defined specifically as "imported from Korea," your waiter can easily comply with your request. But if you wanted to order any other distilled spirit, for instance a local fruit brandy made from Hudson Valley apples grown in the orchard down the road, you'd be out of luck. You'd have to go to a bar or a restaurant with a much harder to obtain and costlier full liquor license.

title: The Suburban Solution
description: Bernie Tetreault was driving along Good Hope Road, past the Baptist churches and check-cashing storefronts that populate Washington's poorest neighborhood, when a dented green street sign caught his eye. It marked the way to the Frederick Douglass Dwellings, a place that no longer existed. "Yeah, those are gone," he said. "That's Henson Ridge." Tetreault, 67, an adviser to the District of Columbia Housing Authority, has the clipped demeanor of a city manager, which he once was; in those few words, he had summed up the death and revival of an entire community. Where the Frederick Douglass public-housing project once stood -- violent, run-down, rat-infested -- the city government was erecting Henson Ridge: several hundred new homes, painted in shades of cream and taupe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOHUT, SUSANNE A.
description: KOHUT--Susanne A., 90. Passed away peacefully March 3, 2006, surrounded by loving family and devoted caregivers. Her husband, Anthony Kohut, predeceased her in 1984. A graduate of Mt. Saint Vincent and Fordham Graduate School of Social Work, she spent her half-century career devoted to people in need. She retired from Saint Vincent's Department of Social Services and spent her time actively with her family and her pets, making many new and valuable friends along the way. Her generosity of spirit, beauty, humor and elegance will be greatly missed. She is survived by her niece Susan Amendola Niemi, grandnieces Michele Keeler, Christine Spencer and SamanthaGrace Niemi; grand-nephew Thomas M. Rossetti; and great - grandnieces Alison Arendale, Corrinne Keeler and great - grandnephew Scott Spencer. We will all miss our wonderful "Aunt Sue." Funeral on Thursday, March 9th, at 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers to Saint Vincent's Catholic Medical Center or to Bide-A-Wee Shelter for Animals.

You have towns that are now 60 or 70 years old, which means that the roads need repair, and the homes in many cases need repair. I am thinking of places like Hempstead on Long Island. Or the suburbs of Cleveland or Pittsburgh or Detroit or Philadelphia -- that's where you see the real decay.

title: After Neoconservatism
description: I appreciate the fresh thinking Fukuyama has given to the disastrous, imperial outlook of the neoconservative movement, but why, oh why, did he have to identify the founders of the cause and others by their religion? He constantly refers to any figure as Jewish if he is so, while refraining to identify the religious affiliations of other figures in the movement. This is, in itself, a form of anti-Semitism, as if being Jewish were a racial trait rather than a religious selection. I hope Fukuyama, who is evidently on a campaign to reform the movement and send it in a new direction, learns to refrain from this old shibboleth as he strives in his new direction.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: DUBAI, UNITED ARAB EMIRATES
description: SKI DUBAI, AN INDOOR SKI RESORT AT THE MALL OF THE EMIRATES, JAN. 2, 2006 - Nureen Kelly, 11, of Sydney, Australia, left, with her sister Zali, 6. "I know, the snow in Dubai is a bit odd if you haven't been there and seen it. It's not happening outside in Dubai itself, it's just happening, like, in a mall. There's a hill that you ski down, and then there's a straight area where you can ride toboggans and have snowball fights. It's a great place to make snow angels if you even dare to. 'Cause if you dare to make a snow angel, all the snow will come down your back and stuff. We did, and I had a kind of brain freeze. We'd like to visit Dubai again, but I wouldn't exactly move there. Home is where the heart lives, so, yeah, that's what Sydney's like with us." As told to Seth Kugel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERK, DR. CHARLES
description: BERK -- Dr. Charles. On March 4, 2006 seven weeks short of his 96th birthday. His wife Helen Goell Berk, with whom he enjoyed 60 years of marital bliss died in 1993. Born in Manhattan but raised in Brooklyn, the two principal loves of his life were his family and the practice of medicine. After graduating at age 22 from the Long Island College of Medicine he conducted a general practice in Brooklyn for 45 years. He moved to Lakehurst, NJ, in 1977, leasing a new office, from which he practiced for an additional nine years. Following his "real" retirement in 1996 he moved back to Manhattan. His more than 50 years of private practice were interrupted only for World War II. He enlisted in the Army Medical Corps shortly after Pearl Harbor, rose to the rank of Captain and Company Commander, and led one of the first medical units onto Utah Beach on D-Day. Outside of medicine his life centered on the large, extended Berk/Goell family. Dr. Berk is survived by his youngest sister, Shirley Sherwin of Queens; his two sons, Richard Berk of Seattle and Dr. Paul Berk of New York and his wife, Nicole; grandchildren Claire Ancona-Berk of New York, Philip Berk of Boston, Ted Berk and his wife Naomi Weinberg of London, and David Berk (age threeand-a-half) of New York. He was thrilled by the arrival of great-granddaughter Samantha to Ted and Naomi in London just four weeks ago. Service Sunday 1 PM at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALMER, JULIA REED
description: PALMER--Julia Reed, 90. Of New York City and Mt. Desert, Maine, on February 25, 2006, after a long life and a brief illness. Wife of the late Arthur E. Palmer, Jr. Beloved mother of Constance Hildesley, Lansing Palmer, Stewart Palmer and the late Susan Palmer, all of New York City. Devoted grandmother of Mark Hildesley, Morgan Hildesley, Laura Bartsch, Lansing Palmer, Jr., and Blair Palmer, and great-grandmother of Griffin and Spenser Bartsch, Emma and Sophie Hildesley, and Rebecca Palmer. She was an inspiration in the field of literacy, and continued to teach and to campaign for her causes to the last day. She had an answer for all, delivered with an earnestness belied by a twinkle in her eye. We will miss her always. Funeral service private. A memorial service will be held in Maine at a later date. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to Jan Hus Presbyterian Church, 351 East 74th St, NY, NY 10021.

description: WERNER PASCHKE of Ronkonkoma loved adventure. When his son Kurt Paschke of Holbrook bought a Harley-Davidson four years ago, the elder Mr. Paschke was the first to jump on the back of the motorcycle.

title: Deadline Draws Near For Keeping 2 Statues
description: The Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk has 10 days left to come up with about $89,000 to keep at least one of the two statues that once belonged to the mansion's owner.

title: A Godly Hero: The Life of William Jennings Bryan
description: Salem may never be more than a pleasant stop along the interstate highway that slices through the verdant prairie of south-central Illinois. Stretched out beyond the sign listing a population of eight thousand is the usual array of chain hotels and restaurants, gaudy gas stations and car washes, and tiny convenience stores. An imposing new Caterpillar rental and repair place suggests that the local economy is thriving, while twenty-six local churches compete to fill a set of loftier needs. Yet one can stroll down the main street of Salem in the middle of a weekday in summer without encountering more than a handful of residents. The nearest movie theater is down in Centralia, sixteen miles away.

title: Internet 'fast lane' could carry heavy toll
That's Maestro Tolstoy, if You Please
description: Tolstoy's Waltz Lera Auerbach, pianist; Chiyuki Urano, baritone. Bis 1502; CD.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 5-March 11; DANCE
description: SUSAN MARSHALL is celebrating her 20th anniversary as a choreographer this season. She made her debut in 1985 at Dance Theater Workshop, and this week she's back there again. The new workshop is larger than the old one, but it still counts as an intimate space next to some of the theaters in which Ms. Marshall has more recently worked. So for her new "Cloudless," she proposes to explore subtle and intimate details of movement that the close-up proximity of the dancers will provide. Wednesday through Saturday (and March 15-18) at 7:30 p.m., 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077 or www.dtw.org; $15 and $25.

title: Responses to the Review of 'Breaking the Spell'
description: In this week's Book Review, philosopher Daniel Dennett writes to protest Leon Wieseltier's strongly critical review of his book "Breaking the Spell: Religion as a Natural Phenomenon," in which Dennett uses evolutionary theory to explain how religious belief took root in the human mind, how it evolved, whether it's really good for us, and if it isn't how we can get rid of it. But Wieseltier's review also prompted heated conversation in the blogosphere, with one blogger calling it "a kind of political/theological Rorschach test" in a time of passionate debate over the proper relationship between science and religion.

title: Bird flu spreads in France
Handling the Hudson Boom
description: The wave of housing development up and down the Hudson Valley could solidify the region's revival or wreck it. Old industrial sites and other open spaces are proving irresistible to builders, and the number and scope of the proposed projects have stirred legitimate worries that poorly planned growth could end up replacing the Hudson's industrial wasteland with a suburban one.

title: Paperback Row
description: EMPIRE RISING, by Thomas Kelly. (Picador, $14.) "Nothing," Kelly writes at the outset of his sprawling historical novel, "gets built in Gotham without a kickback." He's referring to the construction of the Empire State Building in 1930, and the Irish immigrants and municipal graft that made it possible. At the story's center are Johnny Farrell, a corrupt mayoral aide, and Mike Briody, a construction worker who runs guns for the Irish Republican Army. Kelly mixes his fictional characters with historical ones, and the dialogue and atmospherics are pitch-perfect. In the Book Review, Joe Klein called "Empire Rising" an "ode to urban grease; I'll never look at that grand old building the same way again."

title: The Sub
description: The phone jarred me awake at the usual time, around 6 or 7 a.m. It was a call to substitute-teach, a job I had been doing for several years. First in Florida, and now in New York City.

title: 'Everybody' Has It? Check the Facts to Make Sure
description: "But everybody has one." That's a child's time-honored line when trying to persuade a parent to buy some gadget or electronic goody. And surely that child should be spared the humiliation, the downright horror, of being deprived of something that "everybody" has.

title: As Crisis Brews, Iran Hits Bumps in Atomic Path

title: Torture and Death of Jew Deepen Fears in France
description: BAGNEUX, France, March 3 - Two strips of red-and-white police tape bar the entrance to the low-ceilinged pump room where a young Jewish man, Ilan Halimi, spent the last weeks of his life, tormented and tortured by his captors and eventually splashed with acid in an attempt to erase any traces of their DNA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOKOLOW, ARTHUR D.
description: SOKOLOW--Arthur D. Age 77, passed away peacefully at his Riverdale, N.Y. home on March 2, 2006. Beloved brother of Martin Sokolow and the late Ruth White and great friend of Jane Genth. A graduate of Horace Mann School and Colorado College, he served as a 1st Lieutenant in the 45th Infantry Division in the Korean War, and later worked as a financial and real-estate professional in Arkansas and New York. A gourmet cook and opera lover, Arthur was unfailingly kind, courageous, loyal, and hilarious--with a runaway laugh that his many friends will remember and miss. A memorial will be held in the spring. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

description: I'M bringing a sleeping bag and two outfits, my Carhartt overalls, shorts and a hoodie, and my toothbrush," said Diana Silvestri, 19, a University of Hartford sophomore from New Fairfield, as she prepared for spring break.

title: A 'Raisin' With Appeal, if Not Crystal Clarity
description: SIDNEY POITIER was the first Walter Lee Younger. He played the role in the 1959 Broadway production of "A Raisin in the Sun" and in the 1961 film. With an actor of such immense, restrained power, there was no doubt that the play Lorraine Hansberry had written was Walter's story. He represented a changing consciousness among black Americans as the civil rights movement lay right around the corner.

title: This Very, Very Old House
description: In 1625, a carpenter named Pieter Fransz built a house on the outskirts of Amsterdam. He was young, ambitious and lucky enough to belong to one of history's greatest generations: his life spanned the course of his country's golden age, when tiny Holland became an empire and Amsterdam grew into Europe's wealthiest city. Fransz walked the streets with Rembrandt; he saw a forest of masts grow in the harbor, as ships returned from the East Indies laden with pepper and nutmeg, a sack of which could make a man wealthy for life. He and his family prospered along with the city; 17 years after building his house, he was rich enough to buy the one next door, into which his daughter and her husband moved. In 1683 he was still listed as the owner of both properties. Happiness isn't registered in municipal archives, but the image of this one not terribly consequential human life that remains on the palimpsest of time speaks of contentment: a man who has lived beyond the normal life span of his era, surrounded by family, financially successful.

title: Reverse Mortgages: A Windfall for Co-ops
description: REVERSE mortgages enable older owners to borrow against the equity in their homes, allowing them to supplement their retirement income. Unlike other loans, a reverse mortgage does not saddle the borrower with yet another monthly bill. Instead, repayment of the loan and the accumulated interest are deferred until the borrower dies, sells the house or moves.

title: In the Alps, Wide-Open Slopes and Crowded Bars

We lurched out of the tram at the top, but we weren't there yet. Awaiting us when we got off were more than 100 steel stairs that we still had to clamber down before we could begin our off-piste adventure in the French Alps.

title: There Goes the Neighborhood
description: As I write this, I have a dead-on view of what feels like a crime being committed, a tableau perfectly framed through the window of my home office. Across my quiet suburban street, a man in an orange helmet has roped himself to a healthy old sycamore, 100 feet tall. He is systematically chain-sawing it to the ground. Two beefy accomplices, sweatshirt hoods pulled up tight on this blustery day, wait below to dispose of the fallen carcass. They gather up the heavy branches, then wrestle them into a brightly painted yellow mulch machine that does its work with an awful grinding sound.

A member representing the Workmen's Circle since 1974, and Director since 1975, Harold was a formidable voice in directing the Atran Foundation's philanthropy. He will be sorely missed. Diane Fischer, President

title: Looking Ahead
description: HOT SEAT -- Andrew S. Fastow, Enron's former chief financial officer, is expected to take the stand as a prosecution witness in the trial of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling in Houston. The question hovering over his testimony is whether prosecutors will be able to use him to prove a broader conspiracy at Enron or the defense will be able to convince the jury that the fraudulent buck stopped with Mr. Fastow. (Monday.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Two Teachers Sue The Police
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that it had sued the city on behalf of two teachers at the New School for Arts and Sciences, a public high school in the Bronx. The teachers, Quinn Kronen and Cara Wolfson-Kronen, were arrested on March 8, 2005, after Mr. Kronen questioned an officer's decision to handcuff several students who had been fighting. The teachers, who later married, were charged with disorderly conduct, but the charges were dismissed at arraignment. The suit alleges that the two were verbally harassed and intimidated and that their civil rights were violated. The complaint, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, seeks clearer rules on police conduct, improvements in training and unspecified damages. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg defended the police conduct in stopping the fight yesterday but did not address the treatment of the teachers.

title: Military recruiters win access suit
G.M. to Sell Bulk of Stake in Japan's Suzuki
description: TOKYO, March 6 A General Motors said today that it would sell most of its 21 percent stake in Suzuki Motor of Japan, earning G.M. some $2 billion in much-needed cash as it struggles to restructure after massive losses.

title: Key Bush Ally in Congress Won't Seek Re-election
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 A Representative Bill Thomas, a conservative Republican from California's Central Valley who has been a strong backer of President Bush's policies, announced today that he will not seek re-election this fall.

description: JERUSALEM, March 5 - Israel's acting prime minister, Ehud Olmert, will seek to evacuate additional West Bank settlements and define Israel's permanent borders if his Kadima Party wins this month's national elections, a top ally of Mr. Olmert said Sunday.

title: Schubert's Farewell Lament of Rustic Love
description: Tucked among the piano sonatas, chamber pieces and song sequences of Schubert's last year is a curious yet compelling composition called "Der Hirt auf dem Felsen" or "The Shepherd on the Rock." Musically, it is a duet between a singer and a clarinet with piano accompaniment, or maybe it is a trio equally distributing importance among the participants.

title: James Levine, Injured, Quits Tour With Boston Symphony
description: A fall by the conductor James Levine onstage at Symphony Hall in Boston last week has apparently injured the rotator cuff in his right shoulder, forcing him to cancel his first tour as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and threatening his crowded schedule at the Metropolitan Opera, officials of the two institutions said yesterday.

description: The Panasonic Corporation of America in Secaucus, N.J., has awarded its creative account to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, part of MDC Partners. Billings were estimated at $60 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Firefighter Injured In Manhole Blaze
description: A firefighter was injured on Saturday night while extinguishing a fire in an underground utility service vault, fire officials said. Firefighters responded after an explosion blew off a manhole cover about 9:30 p.m. in the 900 block of Leggett Avenue in Longwood, fire officials and a spokeswoman for Con Edison said. The firefighter, assigned to Engine 73, was taken to Jacobi Medical Center; his injuries were not life-threatening, the officials said. D. Joy Faber, a Con Edison spokeswoman, said the cause of the explosion was under investigation.

BUSINESS DIGEST
description: With Star Witness Set to Appear at Enron Trial, Some Wonder if His Testimony Is Even Needed A steady drumbeat of damaging testimony in the criminal trial against the former Enron executives Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay has led legal analysts to praise the case the government has presented so far. But some analysts said the very strength of that testimony raises questions about the risks prosecutors will be running when they put Andrew S. Fastow, Enron's former chief financial officer, on the stand this coming week. [Page C1.]

title: Frank Little, 69, Met Tenor and Educator, Dies
description: Frank Little, a tenor who sang at the Metropolitan Opera for five seasons but ultimately left the stage for a career as an arts administrator and educator, died on Feb. 22 at a palliative care center in Skokie, Ill. He was 69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUZESI, DR. STEPHEN
description: FUZESI--Dr. Stephen. 85, of Hamden, CT, died suddenly on March 3, at the Yale New Haven Hospital. He was the husband of Martha Jancso Fuzesi. Born January 10, 1921, in Nagybereg, Hungary, a son of the late Jozsef and Terez Fuzesi, he received a doctor of laws degree in Budapest. After the 1956 Hungarian Revolution, he immigrated with his family to the United States, where he earned advanced chemistry degrees. A senior research chemist, he retired in 1995 after 31 years at Olin Corporation. He was the inventor of numerous chemistry patents and served as chapter president of the Sigma Xi society. In addition to his wife, he is survived by two sons and their wives, Stephen and Nancy Fuzesi Jr., of Greenwich, CT, and Drs. Laszlo and Wendy Fuzesi of Essex Fells, NJ, as well as four grandchildren: Stephen and his wife Lauren of Washington, DC, Timothy of New York City, and Sarah and Katharine of Essex Fells, NJ. Contributions can be made to the Hungarian Cultural Society of Connecticut, 762 Bethany Mountain Road, Cheshire, CT 06410.

title: In Break From Code, Gotti Women Soak Up Trial Spotlight
description: Call it the Soprano effect. To spectators at John A. Gotti's racketeering trial, it often seems as if life were imitating television, and that the airing of every intimate detail of the fictional mobster Tony Soprano's life has broken down a social code that once prevented real-life mobsters from exposing their private lives and peccadilloes, from girlfriends to illegitimate children, in public.

title: The Dresses, Low Cut, but the Tones Were Lofty
description: With movies like "Brokeback Mountain" and "Crash," 2005 was billed as the year of the message movie, but films do not lead the culture as they once did. Mostly the message of last night's Academy Awards show was a self-congratulatory one from Hollywood to itself: we care, we dare.

A Singer With Plenty of Swing and No Shortage of Cheek
description: A swinging clown who playfully sabotages the conventional image of a lounge singer as a graceful, silver-tongued smoothie, Michael Bubl brought his affectionate subversion of the Sinatra archetype to Radio City Music Hall on Saturday evening. The 30-year-old Canadian singer drew the kind of sexy, upscale audience most rock stars only dream about: hordes of beautiful, adoring, expensively accessorized young women and their dates. The singer went out of his way to thank the men for showing up and promised obliquely but with a leer that he would put air in their tires so they could "go home and ride those bikes."

title: Protesters Jam Bangkok, but Rural Thais Love the Leader
description: BAAN SUKSOMBOON, Thailand, March 5 - From her wooden stilt house surrounded by rice paddies, Sudjai Srimongkol stared down at her grunting piglets and chirping chicks on Sunday, shrugging off a question about the tens of thousands of antigovernment demonstrators who had gathered a six-hour-drive away in Bangkok.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he had met with the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, to discuss state aid for building and repairing New York City schools, a signal that they might be trying to resolve a simmering dispute between the city and Albany.

title: Religious Strife Is Pushing Iraq towards Civil War
description: The conflict between Shiite and Sunni Muslims in the Iraqi cities of Baghdad and Basra is overshadowing the insurgency against occupation forces, as armed groups controlled by radical clerics take over power in the country. As Iran systematically expands its influence in southern Iraq, the Americans are being relegated to a secondary role.

description: AUSTIN, Texas, March 5 (AP)  It had been seven years since Texas had won a basketball title. Even the 2003 team that made it to the Final Four did not win the Big 12.

Service will be held Tuesday, March 7, 2006, at 11 am, at I.J. Morris Funeral Directors, 2230 Hollywood Blvd, Hollywood, FL 33020; 954-921-1776.

title: A Soul Adrift in Texas, Looking for a Place to Nest

title: Arts, Briefly; After the Olympics
description: NBC won all three Fridays during the Olympics with relative ease. Last Friday, the network unveiled a rejiggered lineup featuring the move of "Las Vegas" from Tuesday and "Conviction," the new legal drama from Dick Wolf, the creator of "Law & Order." The schedule gained ground on CBS, which has dominated Friday nights all season, but didn't manage to win outright. NBC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, with an average of 11.04 million viewers in primetime. ("Las Vegas" drew 10.87 million and "Conviction" 10.15 million.) But CBS managed to bring in 11.88 million; its biggest draw was "Ghost Whisperer" with Jennifer Love Hewitt (12.28 million) at 8 p.m., which faced down NBC's game show "Deal or No Deal" (12.09 million). Without the Friday results show of "Dancing With the Stars," ABC fell to third place for the night. Its "In Justice" particularly suffered from the absence of "Dancing," bringing in only 6.6 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Nothing but gray skies...
Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLFSON, DAVID
description: WOLFSON - David. Passed away peacefully on March 3rd, 2006. Born on May 7th, 1914. He was predeceased by his wife of 61 years, Frieda. A true gentleman and mensch of the old-school, he was an exceptional father to Andie (Jimmy) Koplik, Larry (Robin) Wolfson, cherished grandfather of Kimberly, Kacey, Emily and Jeremy. Devoted great-grandfather to Levi, Wyatt, Jaden and Noah. His Orthodox Jewish background and upbringing, and love of music and singing were important to him throughout his life. A remarkable man who served with great distinction and honor in WWII, and was a true war hero earning the Distinguished Service Cross and five Battle Stars. He was a graduate and supporter of Columbia University, and an ardent fan of the New York Yankees. Remarkably, when he was well into his 80's he was still able to read his daily papers without benefit of reading glasses. He was well known for his love of family, deep integrity and steadfast courage, and will be missed by all who knew and loved him deeply. Miriam, Jody, Greg, Eric and Peter

title: Corrections

Garry Lace was the chief executive of the London office of the advertising agency Lowe Worldwide, part of the Interpublic Group; he was not chief executive of the Interpublic Group.
