title: India Urges Diplomacy on Iran Nuclear Issue
description: NEW DELHI, March 6 A Prime Minister Manmohan Singh told members of Parliament today that his country, in keeping with its principles of "nonalignment," would consider the question of Iran's nuclear ambitions only according to India's national interests and "not at the behest of other nations."

title: In Immigrant Georgia, New Echoes of an Old History
description: Savannah, Ga. - The Coke-bottle glasses of hindsight can leave even profound historical miseries all blurry with sentimentality. That's one way to explain the Savannah Irish Festival, a two-day celebration of the Great Famine's great contribution to this lovely Southern city -- the migration of thousands of starving laborers who toted barges, lifted bales, dug ditches and cellars, and put down roots here in the mid-1800's.

title: As Tired as an Old Polling Place
description: HOW embarrassing. New York is 50th of 50 -- the caboose. Every other state in the union has managed to come up with a plan to upgrade its voting system, but New York is in such bad shape that the federal government is suing.

title: The Long March to the Red Carpet, Slow and Painful
description: LOS ANGELES, March 5 - His hair is gray and short, in a military style. Bobby Moresco, 54, couldn't look Hollywood if he tried. Nonetheless, as an Oscar nominee and with the awards a week away, he is a hot property. At L'Ermitage hotel in Beverly Hills on Feb. 22 he is sipping red wine, and all of a sudden he's a name. "Bye, Bobby!" sings an agent from the United Talent Agency, which represents him. Mr. Moresco is slouched along the banquette, wearing a crewneck sweater with no shirt underneath, and jeans. He is still jet-lagged from London, where he won the Bafta, the British equivalent of the Academy Awards, as a co-writer of "Crash" with Paul Haggis. He also has the Oscar nomination; he was a producer as well, but not among those eligible for a statue if "Crash" wins best picture.

title: Profit up at HSBC amid 11% cost rise
Bouncer at SoHo Bar Is Questioned in Slaying of Student
description: The investigation into the murder of a young graduate student more than a week ago intensified yesterday as investigators questioned a potential suspect, a bouncer at the downtown Manhattan bar where witnesses last saw her alive. At the same time, detectives broadened their search of the building where the man worked, combing for clues from the basement to the roof.

title: Anarchy Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: PARIS, March 5 - Maybe it was the hour, 9 a.m. on a Saturday, or the uniformed waiters handing out coffee and pain au chocolat that had the sad impact of muzzling any stirrings of a fashion anarchy in the audience of Junya Watanabe's show. The models stormed out onto a runway strewn with garbage, wearing patchwork coats made of army surplus fabrics with punkish black boots and belts studded with spikes. Their heads were fiercely taped up with bits of latex, chains and protruding nails. Adorable!

title: Iran Maintains Defiant Stance as Atomic Agency Takes Case
description: TEHRAN, March 5 - Iran on Sunday reiterated its warning that it would begin making nuclear fuel on an industrial scale if the United Nations nuclear agency decided to send its case to the Security Council in its meeting on Monday.

title: Four Plots With a Car in Common

In the acknowledgments for "Indelible" in 2004, Ms. Slaughter wrote, "I've had Sara drive a BMW in every one of these books in the hopes that the nice folks over in Munich will thank me with a shiny new 330Ci."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Tenant Charged With Murder
description: A man whose former girlfriend was found dead in his apartment on Friday was charged yesterday with second-degree murder. The man, Randy Punnett, and the woman, Maria Perez, lived in the same building, a three-family house at 12 Harbor Road, the police said. They said that Ms. Perez, 22, and her three children lived on the first floor, and Mr. Punnett, 30, on the third floor. On Friday, Ms. Perez's live-in companion, Larry Dante Saap, reported her missing. That same day, he confronted Mr. Punnett in a hallway, and then barged into his apartment, where he found Ms. Perez's body, the police said. On Saturday, the city medical examiner ruled the death a homicide and officers arrested Mr. Punnett at the Cosmopolitan Motel on Hylan Boulevard, the police said.

title: Late-Night Extension for N.F.L. Labor Talks
description: In a dramatic change of heart late last night, the National Football League and its players association delayed the start of free agency until Thursday. The league also agreed to take the players association proposal for an extension to the collective-bargaining agreement to a vote of the full ownership group tomorrow.

title: Wall St. Cheers Phone Deal; AT&T to Cut 10,000 More Jobs
description: AT&T's proposed $67 billion purchase of BellSouth was received warmly by Wall Street today, and even critics who expressed concerns about the acquisition's impact on competition acknowledged that the deal should easily win regulatory approval.

title: Former Hit Makers Taste the Upside of the Outside
description: When you go from the margins to the mainstream, that's crossing over. When you go from the mainstream to the margins, that's crossing under: television commercials become viral video files, canceled sitcoms become cult-classic DVD's. Unlike a crossover, a cross-under usually isn't planned; if anything, it's planned against. But it can be a pretty good career move, regardless.

description: LOVETT--Helen, 82, of Boynton Beach, FL. Formerly of Douglaston, NY, and Cranbury, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Martin Lovett; mother of Phyllis and Larry Mazer, and Ronald Lovett; grandmother of Erick Eidus and Zachary Mazer; sister of Ralph Stein and his wife Hannah, and the late Rubin Stein and his wife Jean. title: Test Cars Keep Returning to a Town's Icy Embrace
description: KAPUSKASING, Ontario - WITH spring's arrival just weeks away -- and the prospect of winter's icy grip finally relenting -- a principal attraction of this remote Ontario outpost is fading quickly. Its draw is not one that communities normally promote: a climate that, for nearly half of the year, is exceptionally cold and exceptionally snowy.

title: Hazards of Boom-Time Borrowing
description: The last recession in the United States ended in November 2001. Since then, labor productivity and business profits have been strong, but wages have barely budged, the personal savings rate has gone negative, and a record share of household income is now spent to pay interest on accumulated debt.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Boy's Body Recovered
description: Police divers yesterday found what they believed to be the body of a 14-year-old boy who leaped into the East River on Friday morning, the police said. The boy, Sydney Hatchett, jumped into the river about 8:30 a.m. as he was walking his sister, 6, to school. She ran home and told her mother, who dialed 911, the police said. They said the boy jumped into the river several hundred feet north of the Manhattan Bridge. His body was found in the water near South and Montgomery Streets.

title: Asian group ends with flourish
Paid Notice: Deaths   UJHELY, GERTRUD B., PH.D., R.N.
description: UJHELY--Gertrud B., Ph.D., R.N. On March 4th, 2006, at the age of 83. She was severly handicapped by a respiratory collapse following a fall at home. Dr. Ujhely was born in Vienna, Austria. A jewish girl of sixteen, she was at the opera when the German army marched in and the Nazi era began. Dr. Ujhely graduated from the School of Nursing at the American University Hospital in Beirut, Lebanon, and worked in Israel. She came to the United States in 1952, worked in psychiatric nursing. She attended Hunter College, Teachers College at Columbia University and New York University. She taught at Rutgers University in New Jersey and became professor and Director of the Adelphi University Graduate Psychiatric Nursing Program for a number of years. She resigned that position to pursue her last professions as a Jungian psychoanalyst and several years lecturer of the Jung Institute in New York City. Dr. Ujhely is survived by her companion of many years Honora Farrell, and by cousins: Erich Medak of Queens, NY; Kurt Medak of East Meadow, LI; Eva Marshal of California; Victor Reiss of Jerusalem and Daniella Glueck Flint of London. Funeral service is Monday, 6 pm, at "Gutterman's Inc," 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, LI.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Reward Offered In Fatal Fire
description: The police are offering a $12,000 reward for information that leads to the arrest or conviction of the arsonist who started a fire that killed four people in Prospect Heights on Feb. 24. The fire, at 1033 Pacific Street, started when someone poured a flammable liquid on the building's stairwell and set it ablaze, authorities have said. Thick smoked trapped Assita Coulibaly, 31; her daughter, Miriam, 3; and her son, Mohammed, 1, inside their apartment, where they were later found dead. Another resident, Sherri Williams, 32, died when she jumped from a fourth-floor window and landed on concrete stairs. Ms. Coulibaly's husband, Kassoum Fofana, 41, survived. Anyone with information is urged to call Crime Stoppers at (800) 577-TIPS.

Hilarie has been a very special daughter, sister, wife, mother, niece, cousin, aunt and friend to all. She brought into our lives her wonderful/special husband, Michael and also enriched our lives with Danielle and Matthew--the two greatest and loving kids. Hilarie was truly a woman of valor and will be greatly missed by all whose lives she touched. Hilarie, I know you are going to a place filled with love and comfort--you deserve it. Rest in peace. Love you forever. Mom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOHUT, SUSANNE A.
description: KOHUT--Susanne A., 90. Passed away peacefully March 3, 2006, surrounded by loving family and devoted caregivers. Her husband, Anthony Kohut, predeceased her in 1984. A graduate of Mt. Saint Vincent and Fordham Graduate School of Social Work, she spent her half-century career devoted to people in need. She retired from Saint Vincent's Department of Social Services and spent her time actively with her family and her pets, making many new and valuable friends along the way. Her generosity of spirit, beauty, humor and elegance will be greatly missed. She is survived by her niece Susan Amendola Niemi, grandnieces Michele Keeler, Christine Spencer and SamanthaGrace Niemi; grand-nephew Thomas M. Rossetti; and great - grandnieces Alison Arendale, Corrinne Keeler and great - grandnephew Scott Spencer. We will all miss our wonderful "Aunt Sue." Funeral on Thursday, March 9th, at 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers to Saint Vincent's Catholic Medical Center or to Bide-A-Wee Shelter for Animals.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Leaders Criticize Mayor Over Port
description: Representative Jerrold L. Nadler of Manhattan and Councilman David Yassky of Brooklyn yesterday criticized the Bloomberg administration's handling of the Red Hook Container Terminal on the Brooklyn waterfront. The city's Economic Development Corporation, which oversees city-owned piers, wants to build a huge passenger cruise ship terminal on the site and has not decided whether to renew the lease of American Stevedoring Inc., which operates the terminal. Mr. Nadler and Mr. Yassky urged the city to renew the lease, set to expire in March 2007, or to sign a lease with another container-terminal operator. The corporation has proposed creating a new container terminal at Sunset Park, Brooklyn, and moving the jobs there, but Mr. Nadler and Mr. Yassky said the agency had done nothing to implement that idea. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he was sympathetic, but added that the city's port resources were limited. "We're trying to keep a port facility, a container facility, in Brooklyn and there is a need for it, but I think just if you look at the land, there's never going to be the kind of land you need to build an enormous one," he said.

Paid Notice: Deaths   CHAPLIN, SIDNEY
description: CHAPLIN--Sidney. Executive Vice President, General Manager, Southern Wine & Spirits of Nevada, a division of Southern Wine & Spirits of America, Inc., died on March 2, 2006; he was 82, and died after a short illness in Miami, Florida. A Brooklyn, New York native, Mr. Chaplin graduated from Tilden High School, located in Brooklyn. Following high school, he attended Long Island University for two years. During World War II, Mr. Chaplin served in the United States Air Force. After his military service for our country, he started his working career as an insurance salesman in New York City. After that, in his first job in the wine and spirits industry, which became his lifelong career, Mr. Chaplin joined Ontario Liquor Distributors, a wine and spirits wholesaler, which was based in Rochester, New York, and where over the years he rose to the post of General Manager. Following this, Mr. Chaplin joined Buckingham Importers, a former importer and marketer of Cutty Sark Scotch, as its sales executive for upstate New York through 1968. Then, in 1969, Mr. Chaplin, along with his brother, Harvey R. Chaplin, joined Southern Wine & Spirits of America, Inc., where Harvey R. Chaplin today is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Based in Miami, Mr. Sidney Chaplin served in a variety of senior sales and administrative roles for seven years. In 1976, Mr. Chaplin was appointed Executive Vice President of Southern Wine & Spirits of Nevada in Las Vegas. In fulfilling his industry responsibilities, Mr. Chaplin always spent a great deal of time with the distributor's numerous suppliers and brand owners, displaying a personal touch and an equally unwavering commitment to fostering strong relationships with all the Company's customers, suppliers and employees alike. "Our father really loved his children and especially all his grandchildren. He really had a passion for family, and for work; and he truly believed in hard work. He was also very involved not only with the establishment of Temple Beth Sholom in Las Vegas, but was a generous supporter of many civic and philanthropic activities, though never sought the limelight for all his contributions," said Larry Chaplin, Sidney Chaplin's son who is Administrative Vice President of Southern Wine & Spirits of America, Inc., and speaking on behalf of his mother, Shirley, and his siblings, Ward and Randi. Mr. Chaplin's brother, Harvey, said: "My brother will be missed by his family, his friends and his business associates. He had a big heart and he shared it with many, many people." Sidney Chaplin is survived by his wife Shirley, his children, Laurence (Larry), Ward, and Randi; his brother, Harvey; and his grandchildren, Joshua Paul, Kerry Michele and Ashley Ann.

title: Too Hot to Handle, Too Hot to Not Handle
description: The polemics and outrage in the theatrical community last week after the New York Theater Workshop postponed its production of "My Name Is Rachel Corrie" might have been as intense as the uproar the company feared had it actually presented the play. The postponement of this one-woman drama about a 23-year-old pro-Palestinian American activist killed by an Israeli bulldozer in the Gaza Strip in 2003 has been attacked as an act of censorship. One of the play's creators compared the decision to backing down in the face of a McCarthyite "witch hunt." Hundreds have sent e-mail messages accusing the theater's directors of everything from cowardice to being "Zionist pigs."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BISNOFF, ROY
description: BISNOFF--Roy. Passed away peacefully in Boca Raton, FL, after a long struggle with emphysema, on March 4th, 2006. Beloved for his acerbic wit and self-depricating humor, Roy was a sought after companion for many devoted friends during his 76 years as a resident of New York and Florida. Roy and his late wife Elaine, who predeceased him in 1985, settled in Jericho, NY, and raised their two children, Susan (Julian), now of Florida and Kenneth (Michelle), now of California. Three beautiful granddaughters gave Roy tremendous joy: Emily (9), Isabella (9) and Jessica (2); he adored watching them grow and collecting their photos. Roy leaves behind his dear and only brother, Alvan (Claude) of Manhattan, and beloved brother-in-law, Burt Simon, of Brookville, LI, as well as his nieces and nephews: George, Julie, Lauren and Steven, all of New York. Roy, many may miss you, but we adored and loved you. May you truly rest in peace. Graveside services Wednesday, March 8th, 11 am, Old Montefiore Cemetery, Queens. In lieu of flowers the family would welcome donations to Schneider Children's Hospital, North Shore Long Island Jewish Medical Center; 516-465-2550.

title: BofAs Hotel Project Draws Fire From Realtors
description: Bank of America  proposed Ritz-Carlton Hotel may showcase the emerging wealth of Charlotte, N.C., but its also causing some influential real estate pros to see red. The National Association of Realtors thinks a federal regulators approval of the project opens the door for further bank involvement in real estate development.

title: Disney Still Faces Some Challenges
description: When Robert A. Iger takes the stage at the Walt Disney Companys annual meeting in Anaheim, Calif., this Friday, things will be calmer than they have been for some time. But Mr. Iger, Disneys new chief executive, still has plenty of big issues to grapple with: figuring out the role of Steven P. Jobs in the company; finding a new Disney chairman and reorganizing the movie studio.

title: Scottish Company Circling Cable & Wireless
description: Thus, the Glasgow-based telecommunications company, may start a takeover bid for  Cable & Wireless, according to bankers in London.

title: U.S. Steels in Talks to Buy AK Steel
description: United States has opened talks to acquire AK Steel in a deal aimed at forging a stronger market presence in the rapidly contracting global steel industry, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported on Friday. Shares of AK Steel surged 23 percent that day.

title: Foiled in the U.S., Singapore Port Operator Seeks to Invest Elsewhere
description: Perhaps no one has the right to be more disappointed that Dubai is buying the storied British container port operator Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation than the company it outbid, PSA International of Singapore.

title: Langone Firm Cleared by NASD
description: Kenneth Langone has scored a big win against Wall Street regulators nearly three years after his investment bank was accused of operating a pay-to-play scheme for hot IPOs.

title: Introducing The All New DealBook, Updated Throughout The Market Day
description: Today, we have some very exciting news of our own to announce. We have started DealBook on the Web, a continuously updated service with news exclusives, up to the minute analysis and, of course, smart summaries of the best, most important and relevant news from around the Web. The site is available to readers for free at nytimes.com/dealbook.

title: Barrons Roundup: Shiny New Spinoffs, NYSE Overpriced?
description: As conglomerates like Tyco International and Cendant prepare to jettison chunks of their business, the cover article in Barrons points out that shares of corporate spinoffs have a habit of beating the market. The reason? It may be that they get greater focus from management once on their own, or it could be that investors prefer pure-play stocks. Other companies to watch for spinoff opportunities include Wendys, First Data, Sprint Nextel and Liberty Media.

title: EU Questions Frances Role in Suez-GDF Merger
description: European Union regulators say France may have broken European law by engineering a merger between utilities Gaz de France SA and Suez that prevented a rival bid from Enel of Italy.

title: Spanish Giant May Be Weighing Bid for BAA
description: BAA is on alert as speculation swirled in Madrid that a Spanish-led consortium could launch a 10 billion pound assault in the next week.

title: Toro Energys IPO 190 Percent Oversubscribed
description: Renewed investor hunger for uranium stocks has resulted in an $18 million share offer for junior explorer Toro Energy to close early and heavily oversubscribed. The company closed its initial public offer four days early after receiving applications for more than $52.5 million worth of stock, making the offer more than 190 percent oversubscribed.

title: As NYSE Finalizes Merger, It Looks for Acquisitions
description: The New York Stock Exchange, on the brink of becoming a publicly traded company, is ready to use its new stock to snap up other exchanges in a race for market domination.On Tuesday, the NYSEs merger with electronic rival Archipelago Holdings becomes final, and an upcoming stock offering will net the new company, now called NYSE Group, up to $2 billion.

title: In Enron Chess Game, Lawyers Weigh Value of One Piece
description: Do federal prosecutors in the Enron trial need the headache of calling Andrew S. Fastow, the Enron figure some view as the governments star witness?

title: Making Lava out of Fudge
description: Here is the correct way to make fudge, from Mark Bittman's "How to Cook Everything." (John Wiley and Sons).

title: Toll Coughs Up to $863 Million for Logistics Firm
description: Toll Holdings, Australias biggest freight company, offered to buy the logistics unit of Singapores SembCorp Industries for S$1.4 billion ($863 million) to expand in Asia.

title: Two Knight Ridder Suitors Losing Interest
description: Two groups of private investment firms that have been weighing takeover offers for newspaper chain Knight Ridder appear to be fading as serious contenders for the San Jose, Calif.-based company.

title: Hedge Fund to Vote Against Chiron Merger
description: Hedge fund ValueAct Capital, which owns 9 percent of Chirons shares, plans to vote against the companys acquisition by Novartis. Emeryville, Calif.-based Chirons shareholders are scheduled to vote in a special April 12 meeting on the transaction, which several hedge funds that hold shares have said undervalues Chiron.

title: Apax Takes Stake in Learning Annex
description: Private equity firm Apax Partners has acquired a large minority stake in The Learning Annex, known for its self-help seminars that feature speakers such as Donald Trump and Anthony Robbins, The New York Post said.

title: Investors Hungry for New H.I.G Fund
description: Investors are already jockeying for a share of the $650 million that they expect H.I.G. Capital to raise for its next buyout fund, even though the Miami-based firm isnt expected to hit the road until April.

title: Russias Razgulay to Raise $144 Million
description: Russias top grain processor, Razgulay, is raising $144 million in an initial public offering as it becomes the countrys first large agro-industrial firm to list, the company said on Monday. Razgulay, also Russias top rice producer and third-largest sugar firm, said it would place shares at $4.80 each in Moscow, at the upper end of its forecast range.

title: Carlyle Bid Talks for U.K. Telecom Stall
description: Talks over a bid by United States private equity firm Carlyle Group for British telecommunications company Kingston Communications have stalled because of a disagreement over the price, Reuters reported.

title: General Motors Board May Review Cerberus Bid for GMAC
description: General Motors Corp.s board may review a bid for a majority of its finance unit today as the automaker seeks preliminary agreement on a sale this month, Bloomberg reported.

title: MGM, Weinstein to Team Up?
description: Harvey Weinstein, the former co-founder of Miramax Films, is set to reach a deal to make movies for MGM Studios, BusinessWeek reported.

title: HSBC Reports Record Profit
description: HSBC Holdings Plc, Europes biggest bank by market value, reported a 17 percent increase in 2005 profit, helped by consumer lending outside Britain. Net income rose to $15.08 billion from $12.92 billion a year earlier, the London-based lender said today in a Regulatory News Service statement. That beat the $14.51 billion median estimate of 11 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News.

title: Chinas ICBC Considers Four Banks for $10 Billion IPO
description: The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is looking to hire Merrill Lynch , Credit Suisse, China International Capital and its own investment banking arm, ICEA, to arrange its $10 billion initial public offering, The South China Morning Post reported.

title: After-Shots
description: Paul Haggis sitting on a couch with his daughters at the Chateau Marmont while the kids handed the Oscars back and forth like the shiny nice playthings that they are.

title: Quote That
description: George Clooney, accepting an Oscar for best supporting actor:

title: Providence and Goldman to Buy Education Management for $3.4 Billion
description: The Education Management Corporation, the nations second-largest commercial school and education company, is planning to announce today that it has agreed to be sold to Providence Equity Partners and the private equity arm of Goldman Sachs for $3.4 billion in cash, according to executives involved in the deal.

title: Phone Giants Line Up All-Star Antitrust Team
description: Its too early to tell whether AT&T and BellSouth will hit any regulatory snags in their proposed $67 billion merger. Given the roster of high-powered antitrust lawyers theyre bringing into the deal, though, its clear they arent taking any chances.

title: Rug Burns
description: The Bagger is not your average red carpet reporter. To do the job, you need stamina  lockdown started three hours before the awards  a working knowledge of current celebrities, and the ability to come up with a question that will spark the faintest bit of interest from nominees who have spent months answering other dumb questions. The Bagger fails on all three counts. But he did gain a durable regard for those who practice the craft, who manage to reach down and come up with that fashion bit or that detail about star-prep for the day. Some even managed to bring poetry out of the event.

title: Behind the RIM Settlement: Good Lawyering, Bad Pizza
description: After nearly five years of feuding, how did Research in Motion and NTP go from a stalemate to a settlement in just seven days? According a story in The Globe and Mail, ending the bitter patent dispute over the BlackBerry e-mail device took a compromising RIM lawyer, hours of tough negotiations and some very bad pizza.

title: The Generous, Winning Spirit
description: Cathy Schulman and Bob Yari, two producers of Crash who are madly suing each other, had some real dtente going. The Academy and the Producers Guild had denied Mr. Yari producing credit with Ms. Schulmans vigorous concurrence. But when she got up to hit the thank you list of those responsible for the film, she thanked Yari not once, but twice:

title: Buffett Calls CEO Pay Ridiculously Out of Line
description: In his annual letter to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders, Warren Buffett had harsh words for overpaid chief executives, and again sounded a warning about the risks of derivatives.

title: An Accident Waiting to Happen
description: Its 3 a.m. and the Bagger has wandered back to the hotel. The Sofitel may be under a punishing renovation, but they have a milk and cookies plate that rocks. Good thing, too, because the In-and-Out Burgers went fast at the Vanity Fair party at Mortons. The Bagger considered knocking down Mischa Barton to get one of those suckers, but he was worried he might get 86-ed.

title: Perellas New Firm Nears Fundraising Goal
description: Joe Perella, Morgan Stanleys former top M&A banker who is famously starting his own boutique along with colleague Terry Meguid, is nearing completion of his $1 billion fundraising goal for the fledgling firm, Investment Dealers Digest said. For a start-up boutique to raise $1 billion in only about six months is impressive, especially for a banker with no track record as a money manager.

title: AT&T Shares Slip as Investors Weigh $67 Billion BellSouth Deal
Morgans Mack Plans $600 Million in Cuts
description: Morgan Stanley Chief Executive Officer John Mack, who has fired 1,000 brokers and two dozen senior bankers since taking over in June, plans to cut more than $600 million in costs during the next two years.

title: BT Denies Reports of Private Equity Suitors
description: BT Group, the United Kingdoms largest telecommunications company, on Sunday dismissed a report that it may be the subject of a 25 billion pound ($43.9 billion) bid by private equity firms, saying it hasnt received any offers.
Selborne Journal: 6 March 1759:  Ventured to mat-down the Cucumber-frames untriged for the first time. Continual rain.

title: Linde Seals  $14 Billion Deal for BOC of Britain
description: Linde, Germanys biggest maker of industrial gases, has agreed to buy BOC Group of Britain for 8 billion pounds ($14 billion) to become world leader in the market for gases used in factories, refineries and hospitals.

title: Paris Collections
description: The fall ready-to-wear season ended with spectacular symmetry: a Marc Jacobs collection for Louis Vuitton that reprised the urban waif layers of his show in New York a month ago.

title: Blackstone Targets Office REITs With $5.6 Billion Buyout
description: In what may be the start of a string of office real-estate deals, private equity firm Blackstone Group has agreed to buy CarrAmerica Realty for $5.6 billion. CarrAmerica, a real estate investment trust that develops and runs office properties, said Monday that its board of directors has approved the transaction and recommended that shareholders vote in favor of it.

title: To Raise Cash, G.M. Plans to Slash Suzuki Stake
description: General Motors plans to sell most of its stake in Japans Suzuki Motor for $2 billion, a move that will raise much-needed cash for the auto maker as it struggles with massive losses and a declining market share in the United States.

title: Shales: Stewart Less than Letterman
What Bush Boom?
description: One of the main criticisms I have received from friends on the right about my new book, Impostor: How George W. Bush Bankrupted America and Betrayed the Reagan Legacy, is that it ignores an important point  that Mr. Bushs tax cuts have been so good that they in effect compensate for or excuse his huge increases in spending and other anti-free market policies.

title: Bushs Foreign Policy: Sharansky Dissents
description: President Bushs foreign policy has another high-profile defector: Natan Sharansky. Last year Bush described Sharanskys The Case for Democracy as the book that summarizes how I feel about foreign policy, despite the fact that in the book Sharansky opposes using elections as the true test of democracy and argues that holding elections too quickly can undermine a countrys democratic transition.

title: Carlyle-Riverstone Fund Sets $1.5 Billion Deal With Encana
description: Continuing to shed noncore assets, EnCana struck an agreement with a private-equity-backed energy fund to sell its gas storage business for about $1.5 billion. The Canadian natural gas producer said Monday that an energy fund managed by Riverstone Holdings and the Carlyle Group has agreed to acquire assets including five facilities in Alberta, California and Oklahoma.

title: Kohls Hands Off Credit Card Business to J.P. Morgan
description: The department store chain Kohls said Monday that it would sell its private-label credit card accounts to J.P. Morgan Chase for about $1.5 billion and put the proceeds toward a $2 billion share buyback program. The total purchase price on the credit-card deal will be equal to the size of the receivables on the transactions closing date, which is expected within 90 days.

title: Apax Co-Founder to Step Down; Will Start New VC Fund
description: Alan Patricof, the co-founder of the private equity firm Apax Partners and an original investor in Apple Computer and America Online, plans to announce today that he will leave Apax to start a venture capital fund for emerging wireless, media and entertainment companies. Mr. Patricof, 71, said yesterday in an interview that he would remain an adviser to Apax and run his new fund, Greycroft Partners, from its offices in New York.

title: UPDATE: Is NBC Stealing iVillage at $600 Million?
description: As NBC Universal unveils its $600 million deal for womens Internet network iVillage, venture capitalist Paul Kedrosky crunches the numbers. His conclusion: This is an unqualified good deal for NBC, he writes, comparing the price tag to last years $580 million purchase of MySpace by News Corporation.

title: Industry Group Asks Government to Block Phone Merger
description: An industry association that represents many upstart phone companies wasted little time in blasting AT&Ts proposed $67 billion acquisition of BellSouth.

description: Barbara Bailey, a Philadelphia lawyer, explains  how teenagers go about getting a judicial bypass to get an abortion without parental notification. (Producer: Shayla Harris)

title: Parking Dreams
description: The Brooklyn house that Celine and Garry Cheddy bought comes with the ultimate city luxury  a driveway and a garage.

title: In Praise of the Part-Time Soldier
description: For this deployment to Iraq, I was called and asked by the Army to volunteer for a tour of duty. I had not been in a unit for years. The Inactive Ready Reserve (I.R.R.) is where I was administratively assigned. I.R.R. soldiers are the break glass in case of war people needed to round out a units numbers before they deploy to a combat zone. Even though I had been out for years, I couldnt say no.

title: A Knights Tale
description: More is better, at least when it comes to body armor. Thats the opinion youll read in most mainstream media outlets. No doubt youll find tales that our body armor is in short supply, and that the meager amount of gear we do possess is ineffective. Well, in bitter opposition to the classic male mantra I am here to definitively state that more is not better. Not only is every Marine who goes outside the wire equipped with the latest in protective gear, but it is absolutely effective. The unfortunate yin to this yang is that it seems if bullets dont kill me, the crushing weight of my combat load may just have my number.

Bloomberg has dispatched a host of city officials and political supporters, from Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein to former Mayor Edward I. Koch, to urge community boards around the city to lobby Albany for increases in school-construction aid.

title: The Business of Government
description: There are any number of object lessons in the downfall of former Representative Randy Cunningham, the greedy politician, dubbed Duke, who took millions of dollars in bribes in return for doling out scores of millions in sweetheart defense contracts. Mr. Cunningham, a Republican, was sentenced to eight years in prison. His ill-gained riches included a Rolls-Royce, a yacht and a Louis-Philippe commode. For all that, far more stunning dimensions of influence peddling in Washington came to light recently when Mitchell Wade, the contractor who bribed Mr. Cunningham, also confessed to providing jobs to the son of a Pentagon official charged with oversight of his business and, later, to that official.

QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The sponsors and supporters of this bill believe that abortion is wrong because unborn children are the most vulnerable and most helpless persons in our society. I agree with them."

description: LESLIE--Rosalind, 76. Of Stratford, CT., on March 4, 2006 in Norwalk, CT. after a long courageous fight with Scleraderma. Wife of the late Joseph Leslie, and beloved mother of Fern Perlman Schwartz, Mindy Wallach and Susan Greisman. Mrs. Leslie graduated from Herbert Lehman College, Summa Cum Laude. In addition to her daughters, she is survived by seven grandchildren. Her love of learning was her legacy to her children and her grandchildren. Services on Tuesday, March 7, 2006 at 10:00 AM from Temple Israel in Westport, CT.

title: Factory Orders Slipped 4.5% in January
description: Orders placed with factories in the United States dropped 4.5 percent in January. It was the biggest decrease since July 2000, but a smaller fall than had been forecast. The decline reflected reduced demand for Boeing aircraft, according to a report from the Commerce Department. Excluding transportation, orders rose 1.6 percent.

Study Details Link of Drugs and Thoughts of Suicide
description: Antidepressant drugs raise the small risk of suicidal thoughts and behavior in depressed children and adolescents, scientists at the Food and Drug Administration are reporting today in a detailed published account of findings they reached in 2004.

title: Russia and West Split on Iran Nuclear Issue
description: VIENNA, March 6 - A serious rift emerged Monday when Russia split with the United States and Europe over Iran's nuclear program after the Russians floated a last-minute proposal to allow Iran to make small quantities of nuclear fuel, according to European officials.

title: Memo Pad
description: CROWDED FLIGHTS -- Planes are more crowded than ever on domestic routes, even as fares continue inching up, and the monthly traffic data explain why. American Airlines said its domestic capacity, or the number of seats available, dropped 3.5 percent, while domestic revenue passenger miles -- defined as one paying passenger flown one mile -- rose 2.2 percent. Delta Air Lines, which is operating in bankruptcy protection, reported a 17.6 percent drop in domestic capacity against a 12 percent drop in revenue passenger miles. (On the other hand, Delta reported a 22.4 percent jump in capacity on Latin American routes, reflecting its push into more lucrative markets.) Northwest Airlines, also operating in bankruptcy, reported a 7.6 percent drop in domestic seats against a 6.5 percent decline in revenue miles flown. Continental Airlines reported 4.9 percent more domestic seats but a rise of 11.3 percent in revenue miles flown. United Airlines, newly emerged from bankruptcy, had 3.5 percent more domestic seats available in February, against a 6.7 percent rise in revenue miles flown. Southwest Airlines' capacity increased 8.5 percent, but its passenger revenue miles jumped 17.3 percent.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Property Tax Rebates Offset Increases
description: The city finance commissioner, Martha E. Stark, said yesterday that the $400 annual property-tax rebate approved in 2004 largely offset the effect of higher property-tax rates that took effect in 2003. Ms. Stark said that the average increase in taxes for one-, two- and three-family houses totaled $743 in the last three years, while most owners received two rebates totaling $800. The figure, presented at a City Council hearing, surprised several lawmakers and the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr. An assistant finance commissioner, Sam Miller, said taxes increased far more slowly than market values because of state-mandated assessment caps SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: A Powerful House Republican Plans to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 - Representative Bill Thomas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and a chief legislative architect of the Medicare prescription drug law and the Bush administration's tax cut agenda, announced Monday that he would retire at the end of this year.

title: Obituaries: Ali Farka Tour, Malian celebrated for his music
World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Opposition Leader Ordered To Prison
description: Sanjar Umarov, the leader of the Sunshine Coalition, the main opposition movement, was sentenced to nearly 12 years in prison on charges of tax evasion, fraud and other financial crimes in a case his family has called a farce. Mr. Umarov publicly criticized the government of President Islam A. Karimov after the bloody crackdown set off by an antigovernment demonstration in Andijon in May. His family said he was tortured after his arrest in October. "With all of the repressive measures the government has taken in the past months, the sentencing was not a surprise," his son Arslan said by telephone from his home in Tennessee. "We will appeal." Also yesterday, two Western-financed nonprofit groups -- Freedom House and the Eurasia Foundation -- were forced to stop their work in Uzbekistan. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: Whales in the Way of Sonar
description: The debate over whether the Navy's use of sonar to detect submarines is harming whales and other sound-sensitive species is back again. This time the battleground is the waters off the southeastern United States, where the Navy hopes to establish a training area for sailors who need to practice their sonar skills in a shallow ocean environment. The plan has aroused justifiable concern not only from environmental groups, but also from the federal and state agencies responsible for protecting marine life. If these concerns cannot be allayed, the project should be denied a permit to proceed as now planned.

title: Owners Meet Today on Union's Proposal
description: National Football League owners will meet today to consider the players union's final proposal to extend the collective-bargaining agreement before free agency is scheduled to begin Thursday. But the proposal will be presented to the 32 owners without the explicit endorsement of Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, and there is no tentative agreement in place.

description: XANTHOS--Marina. On March 5, 2006. Beloved mother of Evan, Cassandra & Molly. Adored grandmother of Rourke and loving sister of Hercules and Mary. Marina was courageous, dedicated and an enlightened friend who spread joy and knowledge to all.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Suozzi Rejects Running On Republican Line
description: The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, a Democrat running for governor, has ruled out the possibility of running on the Republican line. Mr. Suozzi, who is running in a primary against Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, said yesterday that he had received support from Republicans in local races, but dismissed speculation that he would run on that line. Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican leader of the state Senate, said in a television interview on Sunday that there was speculation about "the possibility of crossover," but yesterday, he said he would not pursue the idea. JENNIFER MEDINA (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Sleepy Hollow: Boy Dies In Icy Pond
description: A 6-year-old boy died after he fell into a pond while walking his neighbor's dog last evening, the police said. The boy, Julian Geach, left home about 5:30 p.m. with the dog, which his family was caring for. About 6:15 p.m., when the boy had not returned, his parents called the police. The dog was found near Fremont Pond, about a half-mile from the boy's home. A team of divers broke through the thin sheet of ice and slush on the pond's surface and recovered the boy's body, about 30 feet from the shore. He was taken to Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in Sleepy Hollow, where he was declared dead at 10 p.m. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: U.S. Is Seeking Better Balance In Iraqi Police

Its first United States staging will be at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis from June 27 through July 1, not at Lincoln Center, where it will appear later in July.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Wednesday about the Manhattan Theater Club's production of "Defiance" referred incorrectly to a previous role played by Stephen Lang, one of the actors. In "A Few Good Men" he played a Marine officer, as he does in "Defiance," not an Army officer. A listing of credits with the review misstated the play's running time. It is 90 minutes, not 2 hours 30 minutes.

title: Aid Group Takes Out Insurance on Drought in Ethiopia

title: AT&T Aims to Become All Things to All Customers
description: Is bigger necessarily better when it comes to running a telecommunications company? Apparently AT&T thinks so in announcing plans to buy BellSouth, the primary phone and broadband provider in the Southeast, for $67 billion.

title: Arts, Briefly; For a Square, SpongeBob Is Really Popular
description: February's cable ratings show how the race between USA Network and TNT has heated up in recent months. In Nielsen's estimates for primetime, USA edged out TNT among total viewers in February, but TNT, helped by the N.B.A. All-Star Game and Nascar, squeaked by USA in the younger adult demographics. In the competition between these broad entertainment channels, which sprinkle in sports and the "Law & Order" franchises, USA's year-over-year ratings are up in double digits, while TNT has slipped. The most-watched basic cable show in February was a prime-time "SpongeBob SquarePants" special (8.56 million) on Nickelodeon. KATE AURTHUR

title: Tensions Increase Over Delay of a Play
description: Just a week after a potential production of the controversial British play "My Name Is Rachel Corrie" was delayed at the New York Theater Workshop because of political concerns, the Royal Court Theater in London said it was considering several other offers to take the play to New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: As Wal-Mart Works With Bloggers, Questions Arise on Their Independence Under assault as never before, Wal-Mart is looking beyond the mainstream media and working directly with bloggers, feeding them exclusive nuggets of news, suggesting topics for postings and even inviting them to visit its headquarters. The strategy raises questions about what bloggers, who pride themselves on independence, should disclose to readers. [Page C1.]

title: Lundqvist Returns, but Rangers Lose Again
description: Henrik Lundqvist could have been excused for feeling a bit lonely in the third period last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Dies In Fall
description: An elderly woman died from a suspicious fall in the stairwell of her East Side apartment building yesterday afternoon, the police said. The woman, Phyllis Weiner, 89, was taken to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital about 2:20 p.m., where she was pronounced dead on arrival. Ms. Weiner lived in an 11th-floor apartment at 157 East 57th Street. It is an elevator building, but her body was found on the 10th-floor landing. Investigators said it was unlikely that she had entered the stairwell by herself because she used a walker, which was found on the 11th floor. Ms. Weiner's purse was missing and a nephew, Michael Zerin, said she had gone to the bank earlier in the day. The police said they had no suspects. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Sheriff's Deputy Charged in Man's Shooting After Car Chase
description: LOS ANGELES, March 7 A A sheriff's deputy in San Bernardino County whose videotaped shooting of a man poised to surrender drew national attention has been charged with attempted voluntary manslaughter.

Metro Briefing | New York: Union Leader To Form Special Committee
description: The president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., Denis M. Hughes, announced yesterday that he would appoint a special committee to handle matters at the New York City Central Labor Council regarding a federal investigation of the council and its president, Brian M. McLaughlin. Mr. Hughes said that Mr. McLaughlin, a Democratic assemblyman from Queens, would remain in charge of the council, but would not have a voice in decisions regarding the investigation. Last Thursday, F.B.I. agents raided the council's offices and Mr. McLaughlin's Queens office as part of an investigation into accusations of bid rigging for city contracts for street and traffic lights. Carolyn Daly, Mr. McLaughlin's spokeswoman, said yesterday that Mr. McLaughlin insisted he was innocent. STEVEN GREENHOUSE (NYT)

title: Customers Will Miss Much More Than Shoes
description: WITH just a cursory glance down, the owner of Craig's Shoes in Lower Manhattan sizes up feet with long-practiced accuracy.

title: American Missing From Tape of Hostages in Iraq
description: Three Western peace advocates abducted in November in Iraq were shown in a videotape on the Arab television channel Al Jazeera today, but a fourth man, an American, who was kidnapped with them did not appear.

title: F.A.A. Seeks New Source of Revenue in User Fees
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 - The airline ticket tax, the 7.5 percent added to every passenger ticket, has helped finance the Federal Aviation Administration through good times and bad, but with the decline in ticket prices, the government is looking for a new revenue source.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Anthrax Patient Improves
description: Vado Diomande, the New York City musician and drummer who contracted inhalation anthrax last month from making drums with untreated animal skins, was upgraded from serious to fair condition yesterday, the first change since Feb. 24, when his condition was downgraded from stable to serious. "He is breathing without assistance and eating solid food," said Alexander Harman, Mr. Diomande's brother-in-law. "He has his voice back." Mr. Diomande has been hospitalized in Pennsylvania since he collapsed after a musical performance there on Feb. 16. Meanwhile, workers continued to clean an eight-story Brooklyn warehouse where Mr. Diomande worked on the skins. The third and sixth floors of the warehouse, which house commercial lofts used by about 30 tenants, remained sealed yesterday. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: South Dakota Bans Abortion, Setting Up a Battle
description: Gov. Michael Rounds of South Dakota signed into law the nation's most sweeping state abortion ban on Monday, an intentional provocation meant to set up a direct legal challenge to Roe v. Wade, the 1973 United States Supreme Court decision that made abortion legal.

title: City Schools That Work
description: MILWAUKEE - At first glance, the near north side of Milwaukee can be a bleak place, now that it has lost the department stores, factories and other businesses that used to thrive there. But if you want to see inner-city children getting a good education, it's the most beautiful spot in America.

title: Report Cites State's Laxity on Donations in Campaigns
description: ALBANY, March 6 - Pop quiz: Who is allowed to take bigger campaign contributions, a New York State lawmaker or the president of the United States?

description: FRANKFURT, March 6 - DaimlerChrysler has dismissed or suspended several employees after an internal investigation uncovered evidence that its executives paid bribes in Asia, Africa and Eastern Europe.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Rises 25% at HSBC
description: HSBC Holdings, Europe's largest banking company by market value, posted a 25 percent increase in its second-half profit, buoyed by lending to consumers and companies. Net income rose to $7.49 billion, from $5.98 billion in the period a year earlier, surpassing analysts' expectations. Profit for all of 2005 was up 17 percent, to $15.08 billion. Shares of HSBC rose 14.5 pence, or 1.5 percent, to 9.895, on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Widow of Christopher Reeve Dies of Cancer
description: Dana Reeve, an actress who became an advocate for the disabled after her husband Christopher Reeve became paralyzed, died on Monday night of lung cancer at the age of 44, said Kathy Lewis, the president and chief executive officer of the Christopher Reeve Foundation.

title: Los Angeles Retains Custody of Oscar
description: LOS ANGELES, March 6 - In the hierarchy of place here, there is no more exalted locus than the Chateau Marmont. The hotel high above Sunset Boulevard has launched a thousand clichd magazine profiles, is legendary for bad behavior by its inmates, and is the place where business is not so much done as memorialized.

description: The young Egyptian professional could pass for any New York bachelor.

title: Where Killers Roam, the Poison Spreads

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Signs Law Allowing Shooting Down Of Hijacked Planes
description: President Vladimir V. Putin signed a law allowing security forces to shoot down hijacked aircraft or destroy hijacked ships if they risk endangering important facilities or populated places. The rules were part of a slate of new powers the Russian government has enacted since terrorists seized a public school in Beslan in 2004. The siege ended with 331 deaths, not counting the terrorists. More than half of the dead were children. The new law would allow the government to down aircraft or sink ships even when hostages are on board. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: Learning to Love Overload
description: PARIS, March 6 - The fall ready-to-wear season ended with spectacular symmetry: a Marc Jacobs collection for Louis Vuitton that reprised the urban waif layers of his show in New York a month ago. And the best of what fell between these bookends, from more than 100 shows, told a similar story. It was about a strong silhouette.

title: Microsoft and Intel roll drums for 'ultramobile' PC

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 6 - President Pervez Musharraf lashed out Monday at President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan for "bad-mouthing" Pakistan in recent weeks and casting doubt on its commitment to fight terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRYFOOS, ROBERT
description: DRYFOOS--Robert. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member, Robert Dryfoos. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shiva will be observed at the home of Susan Dymond, 300 E. 74th St on Monday & Tuesday evenings from 6-9. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Alfred D. Youngwood, Pres.

The sale has also raised speculation about what G.M. plans to do with its 7.9 percent stake in Isuzu Motors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMSON, IRENE E. (NEE SCHAFFEL)
description: ABRAMSON--Irene E. (nee Schaffel). Passed away on Sunday, March, 4, 2006, after fighting cancer for the past 24 years. Irene was born and lived in Manhattan until 1979, when she moved to Florida, where she became a permanent resident. Her parents, Bernard and Claire Schaffel predeceased her. She is survived by her husband, Harvey; her son, Brett, Mark and Andrew, two granddaughters, and an uncle. Graveside services will be held at Lakeside Cemetery, 10310 N.W. 25 Street, Miami, on Wednesday, March 7, at 11:30 A.M.

title: Under Shadow of Sharon, Israeli Election Campaign Begins
description: JERUSALEM, March 7  Ehud Olmert, the acting prime minister and leader of the new Kadima Party, has been renamed "Smolmert," in an effort to label him dovish and left-wing ("smol" is Hebrew for left). Benjamin Netanyahu of Likud, the former prime minister known as "Bibi," is pictured as shifty-eyed, bloated, anxious and untrustworthy, giving himself pep talks ("I can do this, I'm the Bibi"). Amir Peretz, the Moroccan-born leader of the Labor Party, is portrayed as an inexperienced socialist simpleton, with Israel's Russian-born voters reminded of how much he looks like Stalin.

That age-old question pushed to the fore in a program of dances by Aviva Geismar, performed by her Drastic Action company on Friday at the wonderfully funky little West End Theater on West 86th Street. Ms. Geismar clearly has strong ideas about what she wants to express. But with the exception of one dance, those ideas and their manner of expression remained frustratingly impenetrable.

Jonas Blane (Dennis Haysbert, near right, best known as the first president on Fox's "24") leads covert special-forces operatives on undercover missions around the world. In the series premiere, the team faces a hijacked plane full of European businessmen, and Jonas faces a brand-new recruit (Scott Foley, above right, who was Noel on WB's "Felicity").

Former wife of the late Manuel I. Quintana; she is survived by and was the loving mother of Manuel H. Quintana, Brooklyn, NY, Carlos W. Quintana, Quilcene, WA, I. Carmen Quintana, Chicago, IL and Nicolas I. Quintana, Cos Cob, CT, six grandchildren and two sisters, Mrs. George Cheston, Philadelphia, PA and Mrs. Charles A. Meyer, Lake Forest, IL. title: Arts, Briefly; Change of Command At 'Commander in Chief'
description: The troubled ABC drama "Commander in Chief" has lost its second supervisor in a season. Steven Bochco, right, has yielded control of the series to work on his own pilot, ABC executives said yesterday. Mr. Bochco, the creator of some of television's most praised dramas, including "Hill Street Blues" and "NYPD Blue," took over "Commander in Chief" in October when ABC removed the show's creator, Rod Lurie, from day-to-day supervision. "Commander in Chief," which stars Geena Davis as the first female president, started the season with strong ratings, but after several weeks, the production crew fell behind in delivering episodes, and the ratings began to fade. ABC installed Mr. Bochco, who was already signed with its affiliated studio Touchstone to develop another drama. Mr. Bochco took some weeks to make changes in the direction of "Commander in Chief," but ratings never recovered, and ABC shelved the series in February, saying the move was temporary. It is scheduled to return April 18 and will finish the season, ABC said, with Dee Johnson, another executive producer, as the new supervisor. Mr. Bochco will remain an executive producer, but ABC executives said he had left the series and was now shooting his pilot, a crime drama called "Hollis and Rae," in Savannah, Ga. BILL CARTER

Arts, Briefly; Washington Ballet Contract Agreement
description: The Washington Ballet said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with its dancers and their union regarding a new contract, after what the president of the union called a marathon bargaining session. Details were not disclosed. In December, the ballet canceled productions for February and March because of a weekslong labor dispute. The two sides had reached an impasse when the company said the dancers were on strike, and the dancers' union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, contended that they had been locked out. The dancers had said they were seeking a new contract to protect their jobs, safety and health. They specifically cited concerns over the scheduling of rehearsals and performances and the way management had handled dismissals. The company argued that problems revolved around artistic control. JOHN FILES

title: Officials Outline Steps to Improve Port Security
description: With the volume of international cargo flowing through the port of New York and New Jersey reaching another record last year, public officials said today that they were taking actions to improve security there.

title: Nets Make the Kings Feel Right at Home
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 6 - During the past three months, the Nets built a reputation as one of the N.B.A.'s toughest teams at home. But against the Sacramento Kings on Monday night, they played as if they were a thousand miles from Continental Arena. The Nets were outhustled on defense and had no semblance of rhythm on offense.

Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, MARILYN LORETTA
description: LEWIS--Marilyn Loretta. After making a courageous battle against cancer Marilyn Loretta Lewis died on March 5, 2006 at Lawrence Hospital. She was a beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Bernard Lewis, her two children, Lawrence Lewis and Elizabeth Donenfeld, her four grandchildren, Scott, Samantha, Max and Eli, in addition to her brother Morris Lang. She was trained as a clinical nutritionist and physician's assistant and managed a chiropractic office for forty years. A memorial service will be held on March 7, 2006 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 Broad Street, Fleetwood, New York beginning at 3:00PM. For directions look at www.theriversidememorialchapel .com/directions.htm Any donations made on the decedent's behalf shall be made to Lawrence Hospital, 55 Palmer Avenue, Bronxville, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHUMAN, RICHARD MATTHEW
description: SCHUMAN--Richard Matthew. On March 5, 2006. Beloved son of Andrea Schuman. I'll never let you go, I love you so much. You were my life. Cherished grandson of Walter Green. A Funeral service on Tuesday, 11 A.M., at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Potential Opponent For Clinton
description: K. T. McFarland, left, a former spokeswoman for the Reagan Defense Department, formed an exploratory committee yesterday to raise money to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in this year's Senate race. A stay-at-home mother for the last 21 years, Ms. McFarland, a Manhattan Republican, also set about raising her national profile. She appeared on MSNBC's "Hardball," and in response to questions, said that a nuclear Iran was "the single biggest national security situation we face." Ms. McFarland would oppose John Spencer, a former mayor of Yonkers and a favorite of conservatives, for the Republican nomination. PATRICK HEALY (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERGER, GUSTAV
description: BERGER--Gustav, 85. Master art conservator, researcher, inventor, lecturer and author, died peacefully at home, March 5, 2006. Recipient of national and international honors, including Honorary Membership in the American Institute for Conservation and the Austrian Cross of Honor for Art and Science, First Class. Survived by his loving wife of 59 years, Mira, his adoring sons, Ron and Raphael, daughters-in-law, Carol and Lisa, grandchildren Joshua, Jesse, Isaac, Rachel and Dr. Andrea Berger, and great-granddaughter, Amelia Rasmussen-Berger. Services Wednesday 11:30 AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Revising Art History's Big Book: Who's In and Who Comes Out?
description: In some ways, art history is like an episode of "The Sopranos." A relatively small number of artists are welcomed into the family of the famous, their works immortalized in museums and on postcard racks -- in other words, they are made. But hit men, otherwise known as critics and scholars, are lurking around every corner, waiting to whack even the most sterling reputation.

title: The Comedy Is Restoration, but the Sex Is Timeless
description: The playwright David Grimm had his first exposure at the Public Theater several years ago when the protagonist of his play "Kit Marlowe" entered the opening scene by swinging in on a rope, stark naked. His latest work, "Measure for Pleasure," opening tomorrow, also at the Public, includes a bit with a Puritan and a golden phallus that makes the naked rope-swinging look positively tame.

title: Sex and a Monster Mother Seething in Sunny Spain
description: "Seven Sex-Starved Women Found Festering in Sealed-Up Mansion!" Thus might a tabloid headline or a B-movie trailer sum up "The House of Bernarda Alba," Federico Garca Lorca's 1936 tragedy of repression in provincial Spain. This simple, sensationalist sentence also captures, more or less, the tone of "Bernarda Alba," Michael John LaChiusa's musical adaptation of the play, which opened last night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.

11 Including an Iraqi General Are Killed in Baghdad Attacks; Army Says a G.I. Died Sunday
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 6 - A series of guerrilla attacks in and around Baghdad killed at least 11 people on Monday, including an Iraqi general, and wounded at least 58, officials said. The American military announced that an American soldier had been killed in Anbar Province, the western desert region that has become a wellspring of the insurgency.

title: Discovering a Hidden Trove in a Little-Known Latin World
description: If your instrument is the viola da gamba, you are likely to discover composers and works that fell out of the repertory long before there was a standard canon. Jordi Savall has devoted himself to bringing this music back to life, both in his solo gamba recitals and in performances and recordings with his ensembles. On Saturday evening at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Mr. Savall led two of his groups -- the robust chamber band, Hesprion XXI, and the vocal ensemble, La Capella Reial de Catalunya -- in a program of Spanish and Latin American Baroque works.

title: A Minor-Key Life With Regret as Motif
description: Bearing witness is one of life's central activities, perhaps the essential one, in the world of Wallace Shawn, the playwright and actor gifted at drawing portraits of souls standing on the sidelines, observing the traffic of human existence and occasionally stretching a yearning hand out to the tumult.

description: WASHINGTON, March 6 - Every 11 years or so, the Sun reverses its magnetic field, producing a cycle marked by solar flares, sunspots and magnetic storms that can have disruptive effects on Earth.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Icahn Wins Board Seat
description: Carl C. Icahn has won support from 35 percent of shareholders in the KT&G Corporation, a Korean tobacco producer, giving him enough votes to secure a seat on the board, its chief executive, Kwak Young Kyoon, said. A proxy fight has helped lift KT&G's share price about 15 percent since reports on Jan. 18 that Mr. Icahn was seeking changes.

title: Ali Farka Tour, Malian Guitarist and Songwriter, Is Dead
description: Ali Farka TourA, the self-taught Malian guitarist and songwriter who merged West African traditions with the blues, died in his sleep on Monday at his farm in the village of Niafunke in northwestern Mali, the Ministry of Culture of Mali announced. He had been suffering from bone cancer. He was born in 1939, but did not know his birth date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIDEN, ELLIOT
description: SEIDEN--Elliot, 81. Passed away March 5, 2006. Longtime companion and friend of Peter. His sense of humor and his love for the English Language and Literature will be missed. Funeral at 5 P.M. today, at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry (Saw Mill exit 17). Visiting 3-5 PM today. Memorials to St. Cabrini Nursing Home.

description: The demolition of a 150-year-old synagogue on the Lower East Side is generating widespread criticism among preservationists, who say that one of the city's historic religious buildings has been lost because too little was done to save it.

title: MTV comes to small screen for T-Mobile users
Paid Notice: Deaths   PARRY, GEORGE KRAMER
description: PARRY -- George Kramer. Died on March 4, 2006 in New York City. Born on December 24, 1934, he was the son of Henry Laurens Parry and Olivia Kramer Parry of Great Neck, New York. A longtime resident of New York City and Stowe, VT, George will be greatly missed by his beloved wife, Catherine King Parry, his daughter, stepchildren, sisters and a legion of nieces and nephews. His energy, generosity and adventurous spirit enriched many lives. George skied for the University of Vermont where he was President of the SAE fraternity. His career on Wall Street spanned over 40 years. His life long participation in active sports took him to Stowe, VT. where he served until 2005 as a Mountain Host on Mount Mansfield. His passion for scuba diving and his love of Central Park provided him the unique opportunity to explore and beautify the Central Park reservoir. While diving in 1999, he discovered a section of the original reservoir fence, which is well over 100 years old. As a direct result of this discovery, the Central Park Conservancy has since then restored the fence to its original grandeur. A memorial service will be held at Brick Church, Park Ave & E 91st St, on Monday, March 13, 2006 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the George K. Parry Memorial Fund, C/O the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th St, New York, NY 10022.

title: 18 Days After Burst Appendix, Smiling Governor Goes Home
description: Eighteen days after suffering a burst appendix, Gov. George E. Pataki left the hospital and went home at last yesterday, walking slowly but smiling and saying, "I never thought I'd enjoy the fresh air as much as I do today."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a dispute over a reduced rate of income taxation for Americans who own homes in the United States Virgin Islands misstated a proposal for easing the residency requirement for homeowners, which is now 183 days a year. The proposal would reduce the requirement to an average of 122 days a year over three years, not a total of 122 days over three years. (Go to Article)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Campaign Financing Dispute
description: The California Democratic Party said it had filed a complaint accusing Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and Senator John McCain of Arizona of violating federal campaign finance law. The complaint, to the Federal Election Commission in Washington, accuses the two, both Republicans, of violating the law by soliciting contributions as large as $100,000 to attend a fund-raising dinner in Beverly Hills on March 20 at which Mr. McCain is to be the featured speaker. The Democrats say the donations being solicited for Mr. Schwarzenegger's re-election campaign exceed limits in the 2002 campaign finance law co-sponsored by Mr. McCain. Aides to Mr. Schwarzenegger and Mr. McCain said the event complied with all relevant state and federal campaign finance laws. In response, the California Republican Party prepared a complaint for the F.E.C. accusing Phil Angelides, a leading Democrat seeking to unseat Mr. Schwarzenegger, of violating campaign finance laws by using Senators Dianne Feinstein and Barbara Boxer and Representative Nancy Pelosi, all California Democrats, to solicit illegal soft-money donations to his campaign. An aide to Mr. Angelides said the fund-raising appeals were completely legal. JOHN M. BRODER (NYT)

title: Plaintiff Offers Concession at 'Da Vinci Code' Trial
description: As the lawsuit over "The Da VinciCode" resumedyesterday inHigh Court inLondon, oneplaintiff concededthat hehad overstatedhis assertion ina pretrial statementthat DanBrown, the author of the internationalbest seller, had taken 15 pointscentral to his plot from an earlierbook, The Associated Press reported.The testimony came from MichaelBaigent, who, with his co-authorRichard Leigh, is suing Mr.Brown's British publisher, RandomHouse, for copyright infringement.Mr. Baigent, Mr. Leigh and HenryLincoln, who is not suing, are the authorsof the 1982 book "The HolyBlood and the Holy Grail." Like "TheDa Vinci Code," it theorizes that Jesusmarried Mary Magdalene, thatthey had offspring and that their linecontinues. Under cross-examination,Mr. Baigent, who had cited book reviewsto support his statement, reactedto a Random House lawyer'sdeclaration that it was false. Mr. Baigentpaused and responded, "In thatcase, you are correct," adding, "Ithink my language was infelicitous,and I think I have to agree with youon that." Mr. Brown is expected totestify this week.

title: A Sure Sign of Hypocrisy
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. - BEFORE we get to the World Baseball Classic, let's deal with a peripheral issue and make one thing perfectly clear. His denials to the contrary, George Steinbrenner was responsible for the ridiculously self-serving sign that was posted Saturday at Legends Field in Tampa, Fla.

title: Owning Elvis
description: There was never much doubt that Elvis was Elvis, even without his music. If Hollywood didn't quite make that clear to us, Andy Warhol did. Now comes Robert F. X. Sillerman, a media billionaire (and chancellor of the Southampton College of Long Island University) who has paid $100 million for the rights to Elvis's name and likeness -- but not his music, which is owned by Sony BMG. Buying Elvis Presley Enterprises isn't like buying, say, a Graceland mansion cookie jar, something you do just to remember the King. Mr. Sillerman intends to expand the brand and turn a profit. And you thought there was already enough Elvis in the world.

description: Having started construction last November on a retaining wall for a sixth and temporary PATH track at the World Trade Center transportation hub, the Port Authority has decided not to build that track.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BONDY, THOMAS J.
description: BONDY--Thomas J. Died in Phoenix, Arizona, on March 7, 2005, after a brief illness from liver cancer at the age of 70. A refugee of the Holocaust from Czechoslovakia, he arrived in New York at the age of five with his mother and brother; the rest of the family perished. He began his career in the textile industry in the early 1960's and eventually became the owner and president of Pomezia Textiles. He was a magnetic, kind, generous man who loved life to the fullest. He will always remain in the hearts of his wife, Magda Bondy and his three children and three granddaughters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEADER, RUBY FELT
description: LEADER--Ruby Felt, 92. Wife of the late Dr. Sidney D. Leader, died peacefully on Sunday, March 5. Mother of Steven and his wife Barbara, and the late Aviva (Isobel) Kirsch. Devoted grandmother to Deborah Beth, Gabrielle, Jaclyn, and Allison, and great-grandmother to Genevieve Spring and Mason Trimbell. Her family and her community were the center of her life. She had an indomitable spirit and held us all to a high standard. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel (76th St. and Amsterdam), Tuesday, March 7, at 1:15. title: Witnesses Testify That Gotti Left Behind 'This Life' of Crime
description: Throughout his racketeering conspiracy trial, John A. Gotti has maintained that the charges are all a mistake, that he gave up the life of a Gambino crime family leader long ago. Yesterday, a parade of witnesses -- a lawyer, his cousin and his younger brother -- took the stand to swear that Mr. Gotti was not the person prosecutors say he was.

title: Arts, Briefly; Kurt Masur Leaves A Performance
description: The conductor Kurt Masur, below, fell ill during intermission at a performance with the London Philharmonic in Dublin and was taken to an emergency room on Sunday. A spokeswoman for the National Concert Hall in Dublin, Sinead Doyle, said Mr. Masur, 78, reported heart palpitations and spent the night in the hospital. He was released yesterday and flew to Germany. R. Douglas Sheldon, the orchestra's manager for touring, said that doctors had found nothing wrong with Mr. Masur's heart and that he was suffering from a virus. Mr. Masur, the principal conductor, was to take the orchestra on a 16-concert American tour starting on Wednesday in Santa Barbara, Calif. Osmo Vanska, music director of the Minnesota Orchestra, will take charge for the first four concerts, Mr. Sheldon said. No decision has been made on when Mr. Masur will rejoin the tour, he said. The orchestra is due at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center, where Mr. Masur once held sway as music director of the New York Philharmonic, on March 20. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Seeking a Willing Heir, an Aristocrat Turns to America
description: NORTH NEWTON, England, March 2 - WANTED: Heir for $13 million estate, including 13th-century manor house, in bucolic Somerset. Must be able to pay $140,000 annual upkeep and meet incidental costs of, for example, repairing the driveway ($70,000) and fixing the stables ($1 million).

description: A few years ago, when an exceptionally high incidence of meningitis was found in deaf children who had cochlear implants, it revived early fears about the devices.

Bosworth, referred incorrectly to Oakland, Calif., of which Gertrude Stein said "there is no there there." (The reviewer said that Stein's famous remark could apply as well to Italian Fascism.) Although she spent much of her childhood in Oakland, it was not her birthplace. She was born in Allegheny, Pa., which is now part of Pittsburgh.

title: Tipping Is Part of Travel, So What About the Maid?
description: OH, I'm a regular Daddy Warbucks when it comes to tipping. Unless I spot a waiter deliberately putting his or her foot in the soup, I'm probably going to leave 20 percent or more. It was then under the control of Russia, not Poland, which had been partitioned and was itself under mainly Russian control at that time.

title: Unnatural Selection
description: Denver - THE side show of jury selection all too often takes over the circus in American trials. And the central culprit in that takeover is the peremptory challenge, a practice by which lawyers may exclude a certain number of prospective jurors without having to prove, or even state, a justification. Since peremptory challenges are not mandated by the federal or any state constitutions, Congress and state legislatures could abolish them tomorrow. They should.

title: Mr. Bush's Asian Road Trip
description: There is a lot of good a president can do on a visit to another country: negotiate treaties that enhance American security, shore up a shaky alliance, generate good will in important parts of the world. Unfortunately, President Bush didn't do any of those good things on his just-completed visit to Pakistan and India and may have done some real harm.

title: Theme of London Book Fair Is What Technology Can Do
description: LONDON, March 6 - If this year's London Book Fair had a theme, it would be technology. The most popular event on Sunday, the opening day, was a lecture by John L. Needham of Google, about that Internet company's Book Search program. The lecture hall was full to capacity 15 minutes before the scheduled start time, and many who could not fit into the session lingered by the door, hoping to slip in if anyone left early.
