title: Serb Who Aided Hague Tribunal Called a Suicide
description: PARIS, March 6 - Milan Babic, a wartime Serbian leader who was closely cooperating with prosecutors, committed suicide in a prison cell of the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, the court said Monday.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Jail For Court Clerk
description: Kimberly Williamson Butler, the New Orleans clerk of criminal court who spent a week as a fugitive, was sentenced to three days in jail and fined $500 for contempt of court, WWL-TV reported. Ms. Butler had gone into hiding after refusing an order to give up some of her responsibilities in applying for federal money to clean up the flood-damaged courthouse. After turning herself in last week, she announced she was quitting her job to run for mayor.

title: Down by 23, Hofstra Rallies, but It's Too Little, Too Late
description: RICHMOND, Va., March 6 - The final horn blared and the five Hofstra players still on the floor here Monday night were swallowed by North Carolina-Wilmington's swarm of fans, beach balls and confetti. The Pride players slowly made their way through the mayhem, their faces dour. The Seahawks had just finished a 78-67 victory against Hofstra in the Colonial Athletic Association tournament final in front of 4,580 fans at Richmond Coliseum.

title: Landmark Ferry Building May Become Food Market
description: The little-used Battery Maritime Building, a freshly renovated and richly riveted Beaux-Arts landmark in Lower Manhattan that still serves as the gateway to Governors Island, would become a culinary temple in a redevelopment plan offered yesterday by the Bloomberg administration.

title: Rutgers Chief Said to Plan End to Separate Women's College
description: Correction Appended

title: The spirit is invisible in Cash portrayals
Paid Notice: Deaths   BAFARO, CARL A.
description: BAFARO--Carl A. "Tony", 62, of Worcester, MA, died Saturday, March 4, 2006. He leaves his wife of nearly forty years, Carol A. (Guptill) Bafaro; a son, Frank Bafaro II, and his wife Catherine, of McLean, Virginia; two daughters, Laura Ann Bourdelais, and her husband David, of Worcester, and Amanda Bafaro Speed, and her husband Benjamin, of Atlanta, Georgia; three brothers, Joseph J. Bafaro of Shrewsbury, Richard Bafaro and Francis Bafaro, both of Worcester; two sisters, Sara Howard of Shrewsbury, and Theresa Bafaro of Worcester; many nieces and nephews. A sister, Lorraine Blais predeceased him. Carl was born in Worcester, the son of Frank and Mary S. (Pingatore) Bafaro. He graduated, Cum Laude, from Northeastern University with a Bachelor of Science Degree; he then earned his M.B.A. from Harvard University, in 1970. Mr. Bafaro was a Managing Director for Rothschild Inc., an investment banking firm in New York City, and many other positions with financial companies. He loved spending time with his family and good friends. He was truly an academic, always searching for knowledge, inspiration, love, and peace. He was a member of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church. The funeral for Carl will be held Wednesday, March 8, from the Mercadante Funeral Home & Chapel, 370 Plantation Street, Worcester, with a Mass at 10:30 A.M. in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Saint Ann Church, 24 Mulberry Street, Worcester. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Joslin Juvenile Diabetes Center, Development Office, One Joslin Place, Boston, MA 02215.

title: Eathon G. Hall Jr., 40, Museum Curator, Dies
description: Eathon G. Hall Jr., an innovative curator in New York and New Jersey who became devoted to providing art and curatorial training to high school students in Newark, died on Feb. 18 while on vacation in So Paulo, Brazil. He was 40.

title: Local Officials Seek Help From U.S. on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 - Gather 100 local officials from 30 states -- Democrats and Republicans from big states and little ones -- and there are probably few issues on which all will agree. But President Bush's record on illegal immigration apparently is one.

title: Clearing Out Your Cellphone
description: Everybody knows that when you sell your computer, you should erase the hard drive so the next owner doesn't get to enjoy all your banking records, love letters and photos.

title: Tight Web reins in China still let criminals operate
Walking the Party Line, With a Whiff of Party Time
description: HAVANA, March 6 - With an equipment bag slung over his shoulder, headphones dangling by his ears and his baseball cap tilted a little to the left, Yuliesky Gourriel could have been any college player on any American campus. But he is someone much different. He is a huge part of the future of Cuban baseball.

title: Small and Subtle Symbols in a Game That Recalls Shame
description: The Club at La MaMa E.T.C. is an intimate little incubator of a space. It's a good place to "hatch," as Wallie Wolfgruber & Friends did this weekend.

title: In China's heart, its name barely known
TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Fastow Says Enron Executives Approved Deals to Hide Losses
description: HOUSTON, March 7 A Enron's former chief financial officer told a jury here today that his bosses and the company's board were aware of and signed off on two off-the-books partnerships that he proposed to help bolster the energy company's profits and hide losses from investors.

title: Official Says City Hospitals Are Running Short of Money
description: Correction Appended

title: Asian airports lead in a passenger poll
Paid Notice: Deaths  KALB, KOMARIN, SHARON
description: KALB - KOMARIN - Sharon. Age 50, of Flanders, New Jersey passed away on March 6, 2006. Beloved wife of Gary Komarin. Loving mother of Jenna Heller Komarin, Zoe Peyton Komarin and Wyatt Lowell Komarin. Devoted daughter of Judy and Morton Kalb. Dear daughter-in-law of Frances Komarin. Adored sister of Laurie Kalb Kaswiner and her husband Dr. Lee Kaswiner and Dr. Thomas Heller Kalb and his wife Dr. Robin Bell Kalb. She is survived by loving aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews and many cousins and friends. A "celebration of Sharon's life" will be held on Wednesday, March 8, 2006 at 1:30PM at Temple Sholom West Essex, 760 Pompton Avenue, Cedar Grove, NJ. 973-239-1321. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate donations in the memory of Sharon Kalb-Komarin to Ovarian Cancer research organizations such as Gilda's Club or The Judy and Morton Kalb L'Chaim Fund at the JCC. 973-530-3402. Shiva will be observed Thursday, March 9, 2006 from 3-9PM at the home of her sister Laurie Kalb Kaswiner, 4 Trent Court, Morristown, NJ 07960.

title: Prosecutor Urges Death for Concealing Sept. 11 Plot
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 6 - A federal prosecutor on Monday asked a jury to sentence Zacarias Moussaoui to death, saying his willful decision to conceal his knowledge of the Sept. 11 terrorist plot when he was arrested weeks earlier made him responsible for the thousands of deaths that day.

title: That's the Way the Paperback Crumbles
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Names, Biting Talk in Disparate Settings
description: David Mamet is famous for bringing a terse military staccato to the vernacular of real estate salesmen, con men and gamblers. On "The Unit" on CBS, the playwright turns over his distinctive dialogue to actual soldiers.

title: Labor costs add to fears on inflation
Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a dispute over a reduced rate of income taxation for Americans who own homes in the United States Virgin Islands misstated a proposal for easing the residency requirement for homeowners, which is now 183 days a year. The proposal would reduce the requirement to an average of 122 days a year over three years, not a total of 122 days over three years.

title: Point Guard and Coach Go Another Round
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 6 - A point guard is said to be the player who extends his coach's presence onto the court, which implies a fluid relationship or, at worst, a bit of creative tension. In the case of the Knicks, there has been a lot more tension than creativity between Coach Larry Brown and guard Stephon Marbury, which probably helps explain why the team has been so overmatched this season.

title: Soccer: In France, the kids learn to fight political battles
For Hospital Menus, Overdue Surgery
description: In her family, the Filipino dishes that Felipa Tobias cooked were the standard by which all others were judged. That made the food she encountered at the Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens particularly hard to stomach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUNNINGHAM, EVELYN NONA
description: CUNNINGHAM--Evelyn Nona, 90. On Wednesday, February 15, 2006 at Paoli, PA. Beloved wife of Dellwyn Cunnigham and sister of Carol Fitz of Rockport, MA. Graduate of Massachusetts College of Fine Arts, Boston. Freelance fashion artist and worked for Music Book Publishers. A memorial service will be held 4:00 PM, Thursday, March 9, 2006 at the West Chester Area Senior Center, 530 East Union St., West Chester, PA 19382. (Inquiries-610-696-1181).

title: Scientists Say Next Solar Cycle Will Be Strong but Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  Every 11 years or so, the Sun reverses its magnetic field, producing a cycle marked by solar flares, sunspots and magnetic storms that can have disruptive effects on Earth.

title: Fun With Food
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Cramer Watch: We Watch, So You Dont Have To
description: Last night, James J. Cramer picked a handful of stocks on his Mad Money program on CNBC that may move today as a result. Among his most interesting picks was Atheros Communications (ATHR), a maker of microchips that extend the range of wireless devices and reduces power consumption. He said Atheros would be a big winner as a result of AT&Ts proposed deal with BellSouth. He called Atheros part of a 12-step program for Intel-a-holics. (He thinks investors should get out of Intel.)

title: Ex-Trader on Philadelphia Exchange Wins Assault Suit
description: A former Philadelphia Stock Exchange trader has won a $1.9 million judgment against the exchange and a fellow trader who he said assaulted him on the exchange floor.

title: Dana Finance Chief Shifts to Consultant
description: The Dana Corporation, the auto and truck parts maker, said Monday that its chief financial officer, Robert C. Richter, retired two days before the company filed for bankruptcy last week and would be paid $35,000 a month as a consultant.

title: Is Antitrust No Longer the Issue?
description: While government officials and industry lobbyists say the AT&T-BellSouth deal faces few regulatory obstacles, changes in the regulatory climate, as well as the marketplace, may bring different political headwinds.

title: AT&T Move May Spur Verizon to Make a Deal of Its Own
description: AT&Ts $83 billion deal to buy BellSouth may spur rival Verizon Communications to go on the prowl for deals.

title: Dubai Deals in the American Way
description: Dubai, already a tourism giant, wants to run United States ports and be the Wall Street of the Persian Gulf. Time magazine wonders: Isnt that the American way?

title: DaimlerChrysler Suspends Employees in Bribery Inquiry
description: DaimlerChrysler has dismissed or suspended several employees after an internal investigation uncovered evidence that its executives paid bribes in Asia, Africa and Eastern Europe.

title: Cisco Picks Up Video Surveillance Firm
description: Cisco Systems is getting into the security surveillance market with the acquisition of a small company called SyPixx Networks. The networking giant is paying $51 million in cash and options for SyPixx, which has developed software and hardware products that allow existing analog video systems to operate as part of a digital IP network.

title: ThyssenKrupp Is Said to Ponder Sale of Automotive Division
description: Germanys ThyssenKrupp is considering the sale of its automotive parts division after receiving several inquiries into the unit, The Wall Street Journal reported. A sale could amount to about 3 billion euros ($3.6 billion) for the steelmaker as it pursues a purchase of Dofasco of Canada.

title: Greenspan May Have Topped Pope in Memoir Auction
description: The feverish auction for the Alan Greenspan memoir appears to have broken with Penguin on top with a winning bid believed to be in the $8.5 million to $9 million range, The New York Post reported.

title: Longview Fibre Snubs Private Equity Suitors
description: Private equity firm Obsidian Finance Group and a timber investment management company have offered to acquire Longview Fibre for $26 a share in cash, but Longview has refused to discuss the proposal.

title: Defense Suggests That a Remark by Enrons Ex-Chief Was Sarcastic
description: With a pivotal government witness waiting in the wings, a defense lawyer in the Enron fraud trial sought on Monday to cast doubt on a former executives claim that the chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, fretted in 2001 that theyre on to us.

title: Soros Spinoff Raises $1.3 Billion Fund
description: Private equity firm TowerBrook Capital Partners, founded by senior executives from Soros Private Equity Partners, said it had closed its latest fund, TowerBrook Investors II LP, at $1.3 billion.

title: Banc Corp. to Buy Tampas Kensington BankShares
description: The Banc Corp. is set to expand its presence in lucrative Florida markets with the purchase of Kensington Bankshares for an estimated $71.2 million, the companies announced Monday.

title: Buena Vista Seeking Desperate Rerun Buyer
description: The studio behind Desperate Housewives is hoping a cable network will cough up more than $200 million to buy the popular ABC shows repeats. Disney-owned Buena Vista Television is reportedly asking about $1.2 million per episode of the catty dramedy in what could turn out to be a payday for the girls of Wisteria Lane, according to the industry trade magazine Broadcasting & Cable.

title: As Big Board Goes Public, Grasso Gets Deposed
description: Richard Grasso did more than invite the wrath of Eliot Spitzer by receiving more than $140 million in pay as head of the New York Stock Exchange. The outrage over his compensation forced the 213-year-old Big Board on a course that ends Tuesday with its transformation into a public company.

title: Macquarie Korea Fund Stock Debuts Amid Weak Demand
description: The Macquarie Korea Infrastructure Fund and its investors sold 940 billion won ($963 million) of shares in London and Seoul, less than the maximum sought as demand for stock wanes in Asias third-biggest economy.

title: General Atlantic Leads Fundraising for Chinese Internet Firm
description: As General Atlantic moves toward putting a third of its capital to work in Asia, the private equity firm has led a $48 million investment in Beijing-based Internet company Oak Pacific Interactive.

title: ATI Acquires Shanghais Macrosynergy
description: ATI Technologies, a Markham, Ontario-based world leader in graphic chips, is acquiring Shanghai-based Macrosynergy along with related personnel working in China and California, the company announced Monday

title: Enel Prepares Financing for Suez Bid
description: Italian utility Enel is organizing the financing to start a takeover bid for French power and water group Suez, La Tribune reported. Enel is currently gathering borrowing facilities of 45 billion euros to 50 billion euros ($54 billion to $60 billion) to proceed with a bid

title: Bacardi CEO Sees Industry Mergers Ahead
description: Bacardi USA is growing at a near double-digit rate, outpacing most of its competitors, according to the companys chief executive, who also said he expected further consolidation in the fast-compressing spirits industry.

title: Credit Suisse Leads $17.5 Million Round for Copan Systems
description: Copan Systems raised a $17.5 million Series C round in what is expected to be the last round before the disk-based storage company enters the public market later next year. New investor Credit Suisse Group led the round.

title: Broker Pleads Guilty to Using Inside Information
description: A former New York stockbroker pleaded guilty on Monday to trading on secret information about the pending acquisition by Applied Materials of Metron Technology after learning of it from his girlfriend, who was a lawyer on the deal.

title: BASF Extends Hostile Bid for Engelhard
description: German chemical company BASF said on Monday it had extended its tender offer for Engelhard of New Jersey. BASF extended the hostile offer until March 17. It is the second time it has moved back the deadline on the offer since beginning the bid in early January.

title: Chinese Record Labels Seek IPOs
description: Digital music firms Rock Mobile and A8 are vying to become Chinas first record label to go public. Both companies license popular recordings for sale as mobile ringtones, among other services. Rock Mobile earned nearly $9 million in 2004 and over $20 million in 2005, and may well join the long list of Chinese companies that hope to list in 2006.

title: Apollo Investments Success Spawns Few Followers
description: Apollos public fund, Apollo Investment, had teething pains on its 2004 debut. It has since rebounded smartly and is planning to raise more equity. Yet so far, Apollos success hasnt tempted imitators like KKR or Blackstone to launch similar funds. It might be time for a rethink, writes Antony Currie of BreakingViews.

title: Tax Holds Key to M&A Wave
description: Trade buyers  like Linde, E.ON, Ferrovial, maybe even Enel  aim to gear up their targets and save tax. These predators are stealing the LBO houses clothes. Their targets could  and should  do the same, according to BreakingViews.

title: U.S. Says Client May Be Paying Ex-KPMG Partners Legal Bills
description: Government prosecutors suspect that former partner KPMG Gregg W. Ritchie, one of the employees from the accounting firm indicted in September on charges of creating and marketing questionable tax shelters, is having his legal bills paid by Gary Winnick, the founder and former chairman of the collapsed telecommunications giant Global Crossing.

title: Public Storage Buys Rival Shurgard for $3.2 Billion
description: Self-storage company Public Storage has reached a $3.2 billion deal to buy smaller rival Shurgard Storage Centers, uniting two real-estate investment trusts in the self-storage space.

title: Icahn May Win KT&G Board Seat
description: American investors Carl C. Icahn and Warren Lichtenstein are set to win at least one board seat at takeover target KT&G Corporation, South Koreas biggest tobacco maker, the companys chief executive said.

title: Spain Vows to Defend Endesa from Unwanted Foreign Takeovers
description: Spain will fight to defend Endesa, the nations largest power company, from any unwanted foreign takeover in the face of pressure from the European Union to open its energy market, a government minister said.

title: HSBC Nears Completion of Investment Banking Build-Up
description: The bulk of the investment in HSBCs corporate, investment banking and markets arm is now complete, and the rate of cost growth at the division should come down this year, Stuart Gulliver, co-head of the investment banking arm, said on Monday.

title: Citigroup to Sell Legg Mason Shares
description: Citigroup  said late Monday that it planned to sell 8 million shares of Legg Mason acquired in an asset swap last year. Citigroup said that its investment banking unit would act as sole bookrunner in an underwritten secondary public offering, which could total 9.2 million shares if an over-allotment option is exercised in full.

title: Ahold Fraud Trial Opens in Amsterdam
description: Former top managers at Dutch supermarket and food service group Ahold went on trial on fraud charges Monday, the final act in an accountancy scandal that tainted one of the worlds largest retailers.

title: DataTreasury Sues 56 Banks Over Patents
description: DataTreasury., a Texas company that offers transaction processing and archiving software, has filed suit against 56 banks, bank holding companies and others claiming infringement of patents it owns.

title: The Next Junk Bond King?
description: Who are the heirs to Michael R. Milkens onetime throne as junk-bond king?

title: LSI Puts Chip Business Up for Sale
description: LSI Logic will put a chunk of its communications chip business on the auction block, as the company moves forward with a plan to recast itself as more than a supplier of custom-made chips

title: ICE Tries to Muscle In on NYMEX Sale
description: The upstart Intercontinental Exchange made an eleventh-hour bid late last week to break up the New York Mercantile Exchanges deal to sell a 10 percent stake to private equity firm General Atlantic.

title: Merrill Lynch in Pizza Hut Deal
description: Merrill Lynch & Co.s private equity arm has agreed to buy privately held NPC International, the worlds largest franchisee of Pizza Hut restaurants. The agreement is the latest in a series of acquisitions by private equity groups of fast food restaurant chains.

title: Italian Restaurant Chain Entices Buyout Firms
description: Bravo Development, operator of the Bravo and Brio casual Italian dining chains, is the latest restaurant company to tantalize the taste buds of private equity firms, with three or four buyout firms entering a final round of bidding for a stake of the company, LBO Wire reported.

title: Can John Mack Really Make Over Morgan?
description: Morgan Stanleys chief executive, John Mack, has lifted the black cloud hanging over the investment bank. But take a closer look at Morgan, and youll see that despite darkness being turned to light, the firm remains in a tricky competitive position  one that requires outsized strategic vision. And in certain corners of Wall Street there are those who wonder if Mr. Mack is the right man for the job.

title: Abortion Now a Wedge Issue for Dems?
Back in the Day
description: Three 6 Mafia werent always pulling up to the Oscars in a phat limo. Blogger Jim Hanas knew them when.

title: Posting the Mortem
description: Kenneth Turan of the Los Angeles Times minces few words on his way to indicting the Academy for picking Crash

title: Former SAC Managers to Start Hedge Fund
description: Two former porfolio managers at SAC Capital, one of the biggest and most influential hedge funds, are starting their own fund, Institutional Investor reports.

title: The Hunt for Homophobia
description: There is a firehouse of debate raging deep inside Bagger HQ here and especially here that defies easy summary, but suffice to say that many people feel that Crash fails to surpass its TV movie DNA while others argue  loudly and with a great deal of feeling  that the reason Brokeback Mountain fell short was that the Academy has latent and/or viral homophobia. The Bagger has his theories about why Crash won, but he also found himself drawn to James Bates technical, practical deconstruction of the vote.

title: Analysis: Cisco Goes Far From Home for Latest Purchase
description: Barely a week after Cisco Systems closed its $7 billion purchase of Scientific-Atlanta, the company is back on the acquisition trail.

title: Pick Six, or Eight, or Whatever Number Suits You
description: The Bagger was sort of excited about the Crash win because he was one of the few who put his nickel down on the film. (He has learned since yesterday that John Lippman, the veteran entertainment reporter for the Wall Street Journal, also picked the film, along with some other hardy souls.) Imagine, though, the Baggers surprise when he started checking his bookmarks and found out that he was wrong, that many people had seen it coming. He was confused  the last time he checked Gurus of Gold, the nexus of the punditocracy, Crash had no friends.

title: Blogging Toward Bethlehem
description: The Bagger is sitting on the floor of LAX, waiting for his red-eye. Why sit on the floor? Because adjacent to the floor is juice, glorious juice  as in electricity. Back when the Bagger did a very short tour on a national political campaign, he learned the definition of powerlessness. One of the veterans of the bus finally told him. Plug in first. Before you go to the bathroom, or call your wife, or have a smoke, plug in.

title: 'Brokeback' Marriages
description: Mar. 7 - Straight spouses in the San Francisco Bay Area discuss coping with husbands who come out gay after years of marriage.  Producer: Brent McDonald

title: Democrats Should Find God, Get Votes
description: In the April issue of the Washington Monthly, Amy Sullivan says that evangelical voters are to the Republican Party what African-Americans are to the Democrats: the key voting bloc, whose nearly unanimous support the G.O.P. requires for electoral success. President Bush peeled off enough black voters in 2004 to win re-election, while John Kerry was unable to make similar inroads among moderate evangelicals. But if Democrats could win only a handful of evangelicals, they could fracture the G.O.P.s governing coalition, Sullivan suggests:

title: HSBC Becomes Test Case in Bankers Gay-Bias Lawsuit
description: A former senior executive at HSBC Holdings who said that he was fired because he is gay is pressing a record discrimination claim in Britain in a case that will examine homophobia in the securities industry.

title: VNUs Board Meeting  Now to Weigh Takeover Bid
description: The board of VNU, the Dutch publishing and market research company that owns ACNielsen, is meeting in Amsterdam today to weigh a takeover bid worth more than $9 billion from a consortium of private equity investors, people involved in the discussions tell DealBook.
Selborne Journal: 7 March 1759:  Bright sun-shine all day; scalded some of the Cucumber-leaves.

title: EMC Bought Company Backed by Directors VC Firm
description: The latest acquisition by data storage giant EMC wasnt especially notable, except for one detail. It seems to have furnished an exit for a venture capital firm with ties to a member of EMCs board.

title: Photojournalist of Dignity Amid Oppression
description: Gordon Parks was the photographer and filmmaker who used his prodigious, largely self-taught talents to chronicle the African-American experience.

title: Vornado Confirms Talks With Mall Owner Mills Corp.
description: Vornado Realty Trust on Tuesday confirmed in a regulatory filing that it held informal talks with the Mills Corporation, stoking speculation of a deal between the two real estate companies.

title: Fastow, Taking the Stand, Says Enrons Earnings Were Juiced
description: Enrons former chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, told a jury on Tuesday that his bosses and the companys board signed off on two off-the-books partnerships that he proposed to help bolster the energy companys profits and hide losses from investors.

title: How J. Jill Was Lost: Liz Claibornes Four-Year Saga
description: As it prepares to merge with Talbots, womens apparel retailer J. Jill Group has filed a preliminary proxy statement that offers a blow-by-blow timeline of Liz Claibornes long and ultimately failed attempt to buy the company.

title: Armed With BlackBerry Bounty, Will NTP Sue Again?
description: With $612.5 million coming in from the maker of the BlackBerry messaging device, patent holding company NTP has plenty of ammunition for its next move  whatever that may be.

title: Mars Attracts!
description: Left, Mars 2112. Right, Mars Attacks.(Left, Barbara Alper for The New York Times; right, Warner Brothers)

title: Hewlett-Packard Sued Over  Fiorinas Severance Pay
description: In the latest outcry over CEO compensation, two union pension funds have sued Hewlett-Packard and its board over severance payments given to the companys former chief, Carleton Fiorina.

title: Pre-Announcement of Win a Trip With Nick Kristof Contest
description: Im looking for a masochist. If your dream trip doesnt involve a five-star hotel in Rome or Bora-Bora, but a bedbug-infested mattress in a malarial jungle as hungry jackals yelp outside  or if you know of an ex-boyfriend or ex-girlfriend whom you would like to suggest for such a trip  then read on.

title: Bubble? What Bubble?
description: Time Magazine is reporting that reports of the bursting of the housing bubble may be premature. The magazine says 2005 was another banner year for real estate. Whats more, Time says the growth was not in isolated spots. Citing data from Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, all but one of the 275 major metropolitan areas the agency surveyed showed rising housing values from 2004 to 2005. Still, there are signs of caution. The markets been incredibly strong, says OFHEOs chief economist, Patrick Lawler. But the rises weve seen over the last couple of years just arent sustainable.  RON NIXON

title: The Making of a Cover Photo
description: Last week, a reader wrote in with a question about the picture of George Clooney on the cover of the Feb. 19 issue of The New York Times Magazine. His message was sent to the picture editor at the magazine, who responded directly to the reader. Their correspondence is below.

title: Can You Afford to Live Where You Work?
description: They patrol the streets, teach the children, and tend the sick in Prince William County, Va., but many police officers, teachers and nurses cant afford to live in the county because of rising rents and housing prices, according to a Washington Post article. Attempts by a non-proft group to build lower cost housing for these workers have hit a snag as the county debates if it has the necessary services to support the additional housing. The situation will certainly be watched by other suburban communities around the country where middle-income public workers have been priced out of the towns where they work. RON NIXON

title: REIT Buyouts Stay Hot, Despite Rising Interest Rates
description: Blackstone Groups $5.6 billion deal to acquire  CarrAmerica Realty points out a paradox: Why havent climbing interest rates dampened interest in real estate investment trusts? Despite the rate hikes, one longtime bond analyst tells Forbes.com that REIT buyouts are likely to continue.

title: A Staff Visit
description: Life in Iraq can be pretty surreal. As I write this, Im just outside the city of Ramadi, Iraq, which is the southwest point of the infamous Sunni Triangle in the Al Anbar Province. I am a first lieutenant in the Utah Army National Guard, currently serving as the signal officer (SIGO) of a field artillery battalion. When the enemy shoots mortars or rockets at the thousands of soldiers, marines, and civilian contractors living on our F.O.B. (forward operating base), we shoot back. Were a lot better at it. The enemy doesnt usually hit what hes aiming for  we rarely miss.

title: Bushs Crisis of Competence
description: An emerging theme among conservatives is that President Bush may be right on the issues but has failed in the execution of his policies. In this respect, the administrations response to Hurricane Katrina may be hurting it more, at least among conservatives, than the problems in Iraq.

title: Defendant Offers Details of Jeep Attack at University
description: The man charged with nine counts of attempted murder for driving a Jeep through a crowd at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill last Friday told the police that he deliberately rented a four-wheel-drive vehicle so he could "run over things and keep going," according to court papers released yesterday by investigators.

title: Big East May Break Record in N.C.A.A. Draw
description: The Big East men's tournament beginning today may be a display of might and excess unlike anything ever seen in college basketball. There are terrific teams, very good teams, dangerous teams -- everything but bad teams. Notre Dame, seeded last in the 12-team field, won 15 games this season, has won 5 of its last 7 and took Connecticut into overtime before losing.

title: We'll Be Eating Out on This Stuff All Week
description: We'll Be Eating Out On This Stuff All Week When we left our story, LUDACRIS, in the crowd at the Vanity Fair Oscar party at Morton's, was telling JERRY BRUCKHEIMER how much he'd love to work with him someday.

title: University to Investigate Fusion Study
description: Purdue University has opened an investigation into "extremely serious" concerns regarding the research of a professor who said he had produced nuclear fusion in a tabletop experiment, the university announced yesterday.

title: 20 killed in terror bombings at India's Hindu holy city
English Singer With the Slithery Soul Groove of American Rhythm and Blues
description: LAKE HUNTINGTON, N.Y., March 4 - With a quick jab of his wrist, James Hunter began to play his guitar at a chilly community hall in this Catskills town 100 miles from Manhattan. He faced an empty dance floor but wore a confident grin as he cued his band in a tight, slithery soul groove with pulses of organ, stand-up bass and saxophone that instantly recalled early James Brown.

title: Preschool Admissions: Take a Deep Breath
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKOWITZ, STUART
description: MARKOWITZ--Stuart. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of Meryl and Lee (Diana). Cherished grandfather of Jamie and Carly. Services today 10:15, "Sinai Chapels," 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, FLORENCE
description: ALEXANDER - Florence. Mohegan Park Jewish Center joins Arthur Alexander in mourning the passing of his beloved mother, Florence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FLYNN, ROBERT HUGH
description: FLYNN--Robert Hugh. Bobby, you are always in our hearts and prayers. We miss you. Love, Ray, Joe & Carolyn

title: Preschool Admissions: Take a Deep Breath (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Elite Troops Get Expanded Role on Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 - The military is placing small teams of Special Operations troops in a growing number of American embassies to gather intelligence on terrorists in unstable parts of the world and to prepare for potential missions to disrupt, capture or kill them.

title: 'Desperate' and 'Struggle,' Words Familiar to the Nets
description: CHICAGO, March 7 - Outside the locker room before tip-off, Nets Coach Lawrence Frank expounded on how his players understood the word "desperate" as well as any team in the league. On the United Center floor moments later, the team president, Rod Thorn, sprinkled the word "struggle" throughout his assessment of the club.

title: Plaintiff Offers Concession at 'Da Vinci Code' Trial
description: As the lawsuit over "The Da VinciCode" resumedyesterday inHigh Court inLondon, oneplaintiff concededthat hehad overstatedhis assertion ina pretrial statementthat DanBrown, the author of the internationalbest seller, had taken 15 pointscentral to his plot from an earlierbook, The Associated Press reported.The testimony came from MichaelBaigent, who, with his co-authorRichard Leigh, is suing Mr.Brown's British publisher, RandomHouse, for copyright infringement.Mr. Baigent, Mr. Leigh and HenryLincoln, who is not suing, are the authorsof the 1982 book "The HolyBlood and the Holy Grail." Like "TheDa Vinci Code," it theorizes that Jesusmarried Mary Magdalene, thatthey had offspring and that their linecontinues. Under cross-examination,Mr. Baigent, who had cited book reviewsto support his statement, reactedto a Random House lawyer'sdeclaration that it was false. Mr. Baigentpaused and responded, "In thatcase, you are correct," adding, "Ithink my language was infelicitous,and I think I have to agree with youon that." Mr. Brown is expected totestify this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARNOW, MORTON CHARLES
description: WARNOW--Morton Charles, 80. Of Danbury, CT. died Friday, March 3, 2006 of natural causes. Morton served in W.W. II and wrote a novel, "Forced March," based upon his experiences as a Jewish POW. He was an inventor most recently of devices to assist the deaf. Morton was the son of Lucky Strike bandleader Mark Warnow and Sylvia Rappaport Warnow. He had been married twice and had three children by his first marriage.

title: Recipe: Duck and Andouille touffe
description: Adapted from Ken Smith

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday about closely contested Congressional races reversed the maps for the eighth and ninth districts of Indiana. The eighth district is in the west, the ninth in the southeast.

title: A Powerful Preacher Who Tries to Deflect Public Acclaim
description: When the stooped preacher, influential around the world, climbed to the pulpit at St. James Episcopal Church on Sunday, few in the small Manhattan congregation had any idea who he was.

title: Bombs Rock a City Holy to Hindus, Killing at Least 15
description: Correction Appended

title: Bush and the Nuclear Subcontinent
description: To the Editor:

title: Easy To Strain And Stow
description: All kinds of collapsible utensils are being introduced, many of them hard to clean and not that efficient. But I find real merit in the new collapsible strainers and colanders that can be flattened enough to slip onto a shelf or in a drawer, or to hang unobtrusively. This one-quart silicone strainer, the Pop by Dexas, opens with a flick of the wrist and is heat-resistant to 250 degrees Fahrenheit. It is $14.95 at Sur La Table stores and the Art of Cooking. Broadway Panhandler sells it for $13.95. FOOD STUFF

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Ex-Army Officers In Weapons-Smuggling Case
description: Four retired army generals and a colonel, all with links to the military intelligence service, have been indicted on charges of "illicit association" in connection with a secret sale of weapons to Croatia in 1991 said to have been organized by the Chilean military in defiance of a United Nations arms embargo. The investigative judge in the case also found that an army colonel who died in 1992, Gerardo Huber, was murdered "to neutralize the knowledge he had of the irregular operations" by members of the army high command and that an official cover-up was organized to hide that. LARRY ROHTER (NYT)

title: Fastow Testifies Lay Knew of Enron's 'Serious Problems'
description: HOUSTON, March 8 AKenneth L. Lay was well aware of the Enron's precarious state in 2001 even as he deflected increasingly tough questions about the company's finances from investors and reporters, Enron's onetime chief financial officer said today in the criminal trial of his former bosses.

title: Berlin gets a fast track at long last
Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,295 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: G.O.P. Senators Say Accord Is Set on Wiretapping
description: Correction Appended

title: The Last Flight of the Tortilla Chip
description: JOAN RAPPOPORT, a Wall Street events planner, used to hold a case of blue corn tortilla chips on her lap every time she flew back from Los Angeles.

title: Tough Hurdles for Companies in Move Back to New Orleans
Do Americans Want To Go It Alone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, DAVID H.
description: WOLF--David H. Passed away after a courageous battle with cancer on March 6th, 2006. Born on August 5th, 1946. A one-of-a-kind warm, caring, loving, and highly intellectual gentleman of the old-school, he is survived by his beloved wife, Dorothy, parents Ruth and Irving, and brother, Scott. He was a devoted father to Jonathan and Kim Wolf, Heather and Scott Gurfein, son-in-law of Norma and the late Joseph Weinstein, brother-in-law of Richard and Sandi Weinstein, grandfather of Morgan and Kyle, uncle to Alex and Casey. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday March 8th, 2006 at 12:15 pm at Community Synagogue Rye. Donations may be made to Gilda's Club Westchester or The Anatole & Arthur Charitable Foundation.

title: As the NYSE goes public, lawyers question Grasso over his pay
Handicapping the Big East Tournament
description: Breaking down the field at Madison Square Garden. By PETE THAMEL

title: A Dining Circle Dresses Up and Savors a Bygone Era
description: Correction Appended

title: U.S. general meets with Musharraf on militants
U.S. Businesses Are Lining Up Behind Dubai
description: As the Bush administration re-examines a proposal to allow a Dubai company to take over operations at some American ports, executives from unrelated businesses have quietly begun lobbying in Dubai's favor, fearing that recent fierce criticism could damage trade with the United Arab Emirates.

title: Russia and West Split on Iran Nuclear Issue
description: VIENNA, March 6 - A serious rift emerged Monday when Russia split with the United States and Europe over Iran's nuclear program after the Russians floated a last-minute proposal to allow Iran to make small quantities of nuclear fuel, according to European officials.

title: U.S. blanks Mexico, Dominic Republic and Puerto Rico win in World Baseball Classic openers
Food Aid Program Takes Out Insurance on Ethiopia Weather
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 7 - When a severe drought hits Ethiopia or some other poor country prone to the ravages of nature, aid agencies typically spend and spend. This year, though, one aid organization may get some money back.

title: N.F.L. Salary-Cap Math: Deals Full of 'Funny Money'
description: Each day in the National Football League, there are new tales of player contracts being restructured, altered or extended, all in the service of getting under the salary cap, the limbo bar of athletic compensation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the challenges facing New York City detectives trying to solve the killing of Imette St. Guillen, a graduate student, misidentified the area of Brooklyn where her body was found on Feb. 25. (A similar error appeared in an article in some copies yesterday about a search of the home of a bouncer who worked at the SoHo bar where Ms. St. Guillen was last seen alive.) Her body was found in eastern Brooklyn, not in the southern or southeastern part of the borough. A picture caption in some copies on Sunday about Ms. St. Guillen's funeral misstated the given name of a funeral director accompanying her family. He is Richard Gormley, not William.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Top Rating For Trade Center Tower
description: The United States Green Building Council, a nonprofit group that promotes energy efficiency in construction and design, today will designate 7 World Trade Center, a 52-story skyscraper at ground zero, as the first office tower in New York City to be certified as "green." The building, at Greenwich and Barclay Streets, developed by Silverstein Properties, is scheduled to open in May. The council cited the use of such design strategies as energy-conserving ultraclear glass, the recycling of rainwater to cool the tower, and construction from recycled materials. GLENN COLLINS (NYT)

title: Cheney Warns of 'Consequences' for Iran on Nuclear Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 - Vice President Dick Cheney declared Tuesday that the United Nations Security Council would "impose meaningful consequences" on Iran if it proceeded with uranium enrichment activities, and the Bush administration put an end to talk of compromise with Iran as floated by Russia.

title: Do Americans Want To Go It Alone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reality TV for Those Infatuated With Passing
description: If reality television can be said to be about anything at all, it seems to be about impersonation and the odd and increasingly tenacious hold it has on the American psyche. The crooked-nosed are made over and play the genetically good-looking. Heiresses get out of their $200,000 sports cars and enact the habits of the agriculturally inclined. A vegan mother from Boulder trades houses with an evangelical wife in Mobile, is encouraged to care about scripture and breakfast sausage, and essentially tries to pass.

title: Some Sleeping Pill Users Range Far Beyond Bed
description: With a tendency to stare zombie-like and run into stationary objects, a new species of impaired motorist is hitting the roads: the Ambien driver.

title: New plea in China Aviation case
Bush and the Nuclear Subcontinent
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight Looms on Lawmakers' Use of Corporate Jets
description: Correction Appended

title: Sheriff's Deputy Charged in Shooting After Car Chase
description: LOS ANGELES, March 7 - A sheriff's deputy in San Bernardino County whose videotaped shooting of a man poised to surrender drew national attention has been charged with attempted voluntary manslaughter.

title: Other Views: Asahi Shimbun, Daily Telegraph, Christian Science Monitor
All in the Family, Brothers Wage War on Uncle Fidel
description: MIAMI, March 6 - If Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart had his way, Cuba's baseball team would be barred from the first World Baseball Classic this month.

title: Bush Visits Gulf Region as It Struggles to Rebuild
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 8 A Saying he fully understood the "pain and agony" of this storm-battered region, President Bush urged local officials today to speed the removal of debris from Hurricane Katrina and said the federal government would rebuild the levees to provide greater protection against flood waters like those that swamped the city six months ago.

title: VW's Chief, Under Fire, Fights Back
description: WOLFSBURG, Germany, March 7 - With his job seemingly hanging by a thread, Volkswagen's chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, turned an annual news conference into a methodical defense of his tenure Tuesday, announcing plans to revive the lumbering company with zippy new cars and lower costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOKOLOW, RUTH
description: SOKOLOW--Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving mother of Suzin (Jeffrey) Herzfeld & Stephen (Patricia) Sokolow. Adored grandmother of Michael (Madelyn) Herzfeld, Scott Sokolow, Pamela (William) Randall, Lee (Daryoush) Larizadeh, Jacqueline (Daniel) Wachsman and Amanda Sokolow. Also survived by ten cherished great-grandchildren. Services Wednesday, 11:30AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Briefly: 3 arrested in burning of 9 rural churches
Given the Freedom, Tireless Reporters Excel
description: SILVER SPRING, Md. - CHELSEA ZHANG, a senior at Montgomery Blair High, is an ace reporter for the school's Silver Chips, one of the finest student newspapers in the country. In a recent issue, Chelsea had a front page article on the growing bureaucratic demands taking up teachers' time. The article quoted six teachers criticizing new policies being imposed by the Blair High principal and by Montgomery County officials. All six teachers were quoted on the record, with their names, a journalistic feat many grown-up reporters would have trouble matching.

title: Specter's Wiretap Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUCKER, MARJORIE B.
description: ZUCKER--Marjorie B. Internationally known platelet physiologist died peacefully at her home, March 7. Author of many papers, co-author with Aaron Marcus, M.D. of a book on "The Blood Platelet," one of the discoverers of the effect of aspirin on platelets, co-author with her husband Howard D. Zucker, M.D. of a book, "Medical Futility," editor of "The Right to Die Debate," and author of "The Squash Family Cookbook." A spirited woman with passionate love of the natural world: naturalist, birder, scientist, gardener. She loved music. Survived by her husband, Howard, son Andrew and his wife Elizabeth, daughter Ellen Harrison and her husband Richard, daughter Joan and her husband Joseph Zoeckler, daughter Barbara and her husband Barry Pinchoff, and eight grandchildren: Melissa, Rebekah, David, Matthew, Jessie, Marian, Lily and Leo. A Memorial will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOWD, ANTHONY P.
description: DOWD--Anthony P., 67. Of Colts Neck. Beloved Clan Leader of the Rowdy Dowd crowd, passed away at home on March 5, 2006. He was born to Walter J. and Marie R. Dowd in Brooklyn, NY. He was a member of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, Friendly Sons of the Shillelaghs, Founder of the Dad's Club of Ramstein AFB, Germany, member of the board for the Handicapped Boy Scouts of NY, member of Benevolent Paternal Order of Elks, Knights of Columbus and the Futures and Options for Kids. He attended Holy Cross University and graduated with a B.A. in Accounting. He was a retired Career Officer of the US Air Force, and a decorated Vietnam War Veteran. He was the founder of Dowd and Co. in New York City and was a member of both the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Futures Exchange for 25 years. He was also the founding father of the Dublin Financial Exchange in Ireland. His love for family and friends was only matched by his love of country and ancestry. He was predeceased by his wife Anne L. Dowd, a son Kevin W. Dowd, his parents. Surviving are his 5 children, a sister, and 11 loving grandchildren. Visitation will be held on Tuesday, March 7 and Wednesday, March 8, at the Waitt-Nelms Funeral Home, 501 Hwy 79, Morganville, from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, March 9, at 10 AM, in the St. Gabriel's Church. Interment follow in the St. Gabriel's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donation information may be found at www.waittnelmsfh.com

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Mayor Removed Over Deadly Club Fire
description: The mayor of Buenos Aires, Anbal Ibarra, was stripped of office as a result of a nightclub fire in 2004 that killed 193 people and injured more than 700. An impeachment trial that was pushed by relatives of the victims found Mr. Ibarra guilty of "poor performance of his duties" because he had failed to supervise nightclub inspections adequately. Criminal charges are pending against more than a score of other people, including musicians and the club's owner. LARRY ROHTER (NYT)

title: Red Bull May Buy the MetroStars
description: The Austrian company that makes and markets Red Bull, an energy drink, could emerge as the new owner and operator of the MetroStars after a meeting of Major League Soccer's board of governors today in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOLAN, GERARD J.
description: NOLAN--Gerard J. Passed away peacefully on March 6, 2006. Beloved husband of June E. Loving father of Pamela (John) and Douglas (Elizabeth). Treasured grandfather of Charlotte, Jack, Oliver, Jasper and Sadie Grace. In lieu of flowers the family would welcome donations to the Endowment for Scholarships, Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East 91 Street, NY NY 10128. Services at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81 Street at Madison Avenue, Thursday, March 9 at 3:30PM.

title: The Land With the Golden Hotel
description: After even a short walking tour of the new Emirates Palace hotel on the Abu Dhabi Corniche, a visitor might well start to wonder: is there anything here that glitters that is not, in fact, gold?

title: For Dessert, a Cake That Asks for a Snifter of Irish
description: AS enjoyable as aged grain or malt spirits may be to sip, they also have a place in the kitchen. Many dishes that are fortified with spirits like Irish whiskey wind up being savored with a glass of the same alongside.

title: Shares Fall on Texas Instruments Forecast
description: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell for a fourth day yesterday after Texas Instruments said first-quarter sales would fall short of its highest forecast and a government report signaled inflation may accelerate.

title: Barcelona, Juventus, Villarreal reach Champions League quarterfinals; Chelsea out
BCE Plans Spinoffs
description: BCE, the telecommunications holding company, will spin off several of the phone companies it controls into a new income trust. Income trusts are an increasingly popular structure in Canada that allows companies to largely avoid corporate taxes by distributing most of their profits directly to shareholders. Under BCE's plan, the rural landline operations of BCE's wholly owned Bell Canada in Ontario and Quebec will be joined with a wire line network in Atlantic Canada that is owned by Aliant, which is 53.2 percent owned by BCE. The northern Canadian operations of the Bell Nordiq Income Fund, which is also controlled by BCE, will also become part of the new income trust. The resulting income trust will hold 3.4 million local phone lines and have about 400,000 high-speed Internet customers. BCE, which is based in Montreal, will control 73.5 percent of the as-yet unnamed company.

title: They Came for the Chicken Farmer
description: This has been our nightmare since the Bush administration began stashing prisoners it did not want to account for in Guantnamo Bay: An ordinary man with a name something like a Taliban bigwig's is swept up in the dragnet and imprisoned without any hope of proving his innocence.

title: Dutch asylum debate has a face and name
Rattled Nerves and an Angry VolcanoTheater Review | 'Phenomenon'
description: The Nerve Ensemble's "Phenomenon" at Here Arts Center is an oddly entertaining amalgam of fragmented stories and story-telling styles, revolving around the single day before the infamous Mount St. Helens eruption on May 18, 1980. It was originally billed as a "multimedia theatrical event," including digital projections, but at the last minute the creators decided to cut the special effects. The result, combining down-home shaggy-dog tales with a quirky, spaced-out aesthetic, is both weirdly off-kilter and strangely effective.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Federal Mine Safety Rule
description: Federal mine safety regulators announced the approval of an emergency safety rule requiring coal mine operators to provide miners with an extra hour's worth of oxygen to be added to the hour's supply that miners are already required to carry. The rule, which takes effect Thursday, also mandates that coal companies create "lifelines," or ropes with cones along all primary and alternate escape routes, to help direct miners toward the surface after an explosion. The rules come in response to a spate of accidents in recent months that have left 24 miners dead this year. IAN URBINA (NYT)

title: EU experts back lifting of ban on British beef
Ex-Detective Pleads Guilty in Child Sex Case
description: A former New York City police detective has pleaded guilty to sexually assaulting two girls, ages 7 and 12, the Bronx district attorney's office said in a statement yesterday.

title: Edelweiss, With a Dash of Oompah
description: Correction Appended

title: From Vietnam to Boerum Hill
description: Just a couple of steps from the culinary melting pot that Smith Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, has become, there is Hanco's, a bright little Vietnamese sandwich shop with a counter and a few tables. Hanco Tang, the owner, below, sells the sandwiches, called banh mi, on warm, plump, crusty little baguettes ($4.25).

title: Arts, Briefly; Next Season Is Announced at City Opera
description: The New York City Opera yesterday announced next season's lineup, which will include new productions of Handel's "Semele," Donizetti's "Elisir d'Amore," Mozart's "Cos Fan Tutte," Rossini's "Donna del Lago" and Gilbert and Sullivan's "Pirates of Penzance." Julius Rudel, left, who was general director from 1957 to 1979, will return to conduct at the City Opera for the first time in more than 25 years, leading "Cos," which will be directed by Tim Albery and include Pamela Armstrong in the cast. The Donizetti production was created for the Royal Swedish Opera by the director Jonathan Miller. Stephen Lawless is directing "Semele." "Pirates" is a co-production with Glimmerglass Opera, with Lillian Groag directing and Lynn Hockney making her debut as choreographer. Chas Rader-Shieber will direct the Rossini in a co-production with the Minnesota Opera. The company also said it was reviving its productions of Korngold's "Die Tote Stadt," Humperdinck's "Hansel and Gretel" and Handel's "Flavio," with the counter-tenor David Walker returning in the title role. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Momentum surges in quest for antivirals
Patriot Act Revisions Pass House, Sending Measure to President
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 - The House passed revisions to the broad antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act on Tuesday, clearing the way for President Bush to sign legislation making permanent most of the major provisions of the original 2001 law.

title: The Dead Beat: Lost Souls, Lucky Stiffs and the Perverse Pleasures of Obituaries
Paid Notice: Deaths   PARRY, GEORGE KRAMER
description: PARRY -- George Kramer. Died on March 4, 2006 in New York City. Born on December 24, 1934, he was the son of Henry Laurens Parry and Olivia Kramer Parry of Great Neck, New York. A longtime resident of New York City and Stowe, VT, George will be greatly missed by his beloved wife, Catherine King Parry, his daughter, stepchildren, sisters and a legion of nieces and nephews. His energy, generosity and adventurous spirit enriched many lives. George skied for the University of Vermont where he was President of the SAE fraternity. His career on Wall Street spanned over 40 years. His life long participation in active sports took him to Stowe, VT. where he served until 2005 as a Mountain Host on Mount Mansfield. His passion for scuba diving and his love of Central Park provided him the unique opportunity to explore and beautify the Central Park reservoir. While diving in 1999, he discovered a section of the original reservoir fence, which is well over 100 years old. As a direct result of this discovery, the Central Park Conservancy has since then restored the fence to its original grandeur. A memorial service will be held at Brick Church, Park Ave & E 91st St, on Monday, March 13, 2006 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the George K. Parry Memorial Fund, C/O the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th St, New York, NY 10022.

title: EU kills plan to liberalize ports services
Slowly, Africa Starts to Care for AIDS Children
description: MASERU, Lesotho - Staff members of the new pediatric AIDS clinic here are used to seeing sick children. But rarely had they seen one so ill as the silent, twig-thin youngster led in by his grandmother one hot morning in February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIMMERMAN, EDWARD J.P.
description: ZIMMERMAN--Edward J.P. A former tax advisor to the Rockefeller family, died March 6, of heart failure, at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center near his home in New York City. He was 86 years old. A graduate of Harvard College and the University of Virginia Law School, he was a tax specialist associated with the Milbank firm and Rockefeller Family & Associates in Manhattan. He is survived by his wife, the former Starr Quigg, of New York, six children, twelve grandchildren, a brother, Peter, of Winchester, MA., and a sister, Mary, of Austin, Texas. A funeral will be held 11 A.M., March 10 at the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Pawling, New York.

title: Palestinian Bailout
description: JERUSALEM, March 7 - The World Bank released $42 million on Tuesday to help the debt-ridden Palestinian Authority pay salaries until the radical Islamic group Hamas forms the next government.

title: INSIDE
description: Gordon Parks, a Master Of the Camera, Is Dead An influential photojournalist and the first black staff photographer for Life magazine, Gordon Parks was 93. With a creativity that encompassed filmmaking, writing books and even composing, he often focused on the black experience but was never limited to it. One of his most celebrated portraits, right, from 1942, which he called "American Gothic," was shot after he had been refused service at a clothing store, a movie theater and a restaurant in Washington, D.C. PAGE C16

title: Kidnappers of Slain French Jew Tormented Family, Father Says
description: PARIS, March 7 - The captors of Ilan Halimi, the young Jew killed in a working-class Parisian suburb last month, hounded his family with as many as 40 telephone calls a day before the police advised the family to cut off communications, Mr. Halimi's father said in an interview published here on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALOMAN, HERBERT
description: SALOMAN--Herbert. On March 7, 2006. Loving father Blanche Pensky, Linda (Richard) Pellegrini and Edward (Patricia) Saloman. Beloved grandfather of Jason, Brian, William, Stephen, Jared, Zachary and Ethan. Devoted husband of the late wives Jean and Francesca. A 9:30 AM funeral home chapel service will be conducted on Thursday at the Garlick Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Annan Offers His Blueprint to Make the U.N. More Efficient
description: Correction Appended

title: Reader's Digest Landlord Seeks Tenants
description: Correction Appended

title: Nipping and Tucking on Both Coasts
description: There is a crash of ideologies between the country's two most self-regarding and fantasy-spinning power centers. The Bush crowd cringes away from gay cowboys spooning, gay authors flouncing, transgender babes exploring and George the Dashing Clooneying in movies about the glories of free speech and the dangers of oilmen influencing policy.

title: Take Egg Off Speed Dial
description: FOLLOWING a detailed recipe forwarded to me by a friend, I waited until 7 p.m., when my free minutes begin. I stood an egg in an egg cup between two short stacks of books. With my new Treo 650 I called my old Samsung cellphone, answering it when it rang. I laid the two phones on the books so their antennas pointed at the egg. Supposedly, this would give me a cooked egg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARKIN, HERBERT L.
description: BARKIN--Herbert L. Age 83 of Fairfield, CT previously of Harrison, NY, passed away peacefully in Fairfield on Tuesday, March 7. Dearest husband of Bunny Wiesenthal Barkin. Loving father of Joel L. and the late Paula Lee of Coral Springs, FL and Samuel and Madeleine of Rye Brook, NY. Devoted brother of Bernard L. and Barbara of Greenwich, CT. Beloved grandfather of Daniel and Jennifer of Coral Springs, FL and Robert and Allison of Royal Palm Beach, FL and Blake and Ashley of Rye Brook, NY. A selfless person he departed this life as he lived it with care and dignity. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, March 9th at 11:00 A.M. Congregation Beth El, 1200 Fairfield Woods Rd, Fairfield, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Anthrax In Musician's Apartment
description: Even though it was extensively cleaned on Thursday, the Manhattan apartment of Vado Diomande, 44, left, the musician who contracted inhalation anthrax last month, has once again tested positive for the presence of anthrax spores. The test results, which were received on Monday night, mean that the Environmental Protection Agency must clean the apartment again, said Mary Mears, a regional spokeswoman for the agency. A second round of cleaning is scheduled to begin today. A separate cleanup, of the Brooklyn warehouse where Mr. Diomande used untreated animal skins to make drums, continued yesterday, while he remained in fair condition at a hospital in Pennsylvania. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: ESPN Rejects CBS Bid to Share Vitale
description: Few people are as identified with a sport as much as Dick Vitale, a connection forged by nearly 27 years of calling college basketball games at a very high volume, complemented by an idiosyncratic hoops lexicon and a shiny head.

title: Federal Grants Are Set to Aid Cultural Activity Downtown
description: The New Museum of Contemporary Art, the Flea Theater and the National Museum of the American Indian are among 63 arts and civic organizations that are to benefit from more than $27 million in grants being announced today by state and city officials.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: Panel Criticizes County Borrowing
description: The state board that monitors Nassau County's finances sharply criticized a plan to borrow money to bail out the county-subsidized agency that operates a hospital and nursing home. The board, the Nassau Interim Finance Authority, said yesterday that new borrowing based on the expected proceeds of tobacco litigation was not "prudent or advisable." The board also objected to the use of the $120 million of bond money for operating expenses. But the deputy county executive, Helena Williams, said it was "sound fiscal policy" to use $98 million to pay debt and other costs at the health care agency and $22 million for other county health care programs. She said that the health agency would get aid only if it adopted changes to assure its solvency. BRUCE LAMBERT (NYT)

title: With a New Leader, Chile Seems to Shuck Its Strait Laces
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7 - This is the most socially conservative and tradition-minded country in Latin America, or so Chileans are accustomed to being told and to thinking about themselves. So how is it that the new president, who is to take office here on Saturday, is not just a woman, but also a single mother and an agnostic?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the challenges facing New York City detectives trying to solve the killing of Imette St. Guillen, a graduate student, misidentified the area of Brooklyn where her body was found on Feb. 25. (A similar error appeared in an article in some copies yesterday about a search of the home of a bouncer who worked at the SoHo bar where Ms. St. Guillen was last seen alive.) Her body was found in eastern Brooklyn, not in the southern or southeastern part of the borough. A picture caption in some copies on Sunday about Ms. St. Guillen's funeral misstated the given name of a funeral director accompanying her family. He is Richard Gormley, not William.

title: Prosecutors at Sept. 11 Trial Lay Out Activities of Hijackers
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 7 - Making their case to a jury considering whether to order the execution of Zacarias Moussaoui, government prosecutors on Tuesday meticulously recounted the activities of the 19 hijackers of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Update on Bob Woodruff

title: Symposium Guest's Word Stirs Controversy at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, March 7 - The editors of the Yale Law Journal knew they were courting controversy when they invited scholars to the campus for a symposium on executive power.

title: Small-Scale Atomic Research by Iran Is Risky, Experts Say
description: There are times when even a little bit of research can be a bad thing, especially if it centers on Iran and the bomb.

title: OPEC to Keep Oil Output Near Maximum Levels
description: VIENNA, March 8  OPEC, which exports nearly half the world's crude oil, said today that it would keep pumping near its maximum levels in an effort to cool down prices.

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAROTTA, JILL M.
description: MAROTTA--Jill M., 52. Passed away peacefully at home on March 4, 2006. Survived by her husband Paul, son Paul Laurence (Dawn), grandsons Donovan and Dylan, brothers Jan (Vicki) and Terry (Della) and sister Gretchen (George), who love her dearly, she will be missed every day as a person who could provide light on the darkest of days. She was loved and will be missed by her nieces and nephews: Selene, Matthew, Max, Lauren, Rachel, Alexandra, Jack, Jesse, Sarah, Katie, Joshua and Zachary. She was the loving godmother of Victoria and Leonardo. A resident of Port Chester, NY, Ms. Marotta (nee Magnuson) was born in Ishpeming, MI to John F. Magnuson and Joyce Olds. She grew up in Arcadia, CA. and Cleveland, OH. where she began her career as a professional dancer. She moved to NYC in 1980 and danced with a number of dance companies for 20 years. After retiring from dance because of an injury, she achieved her Bachelor's degree in history from Hunter College, graduating Summa Cum Laude, in 2001. A Memorial Service celebrating her life will be held on Sunday, March 12 at 10AM at the James Gunipero Funeral Home, 353 Westchester Ave, Port Chester, NY 10573. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Harkness Center For Dance Injuries, part of NYU Medical Center.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEININGER, WYSSE
description: FEININGER--Wysse.Was born in Stockholm, Sweden on May 8, 1912 and died in her sleep in her Manhattan apartment on March 3, 2006. Mrs. Feininger, nee Gertrud Hagg, completed primary and secondary education at the French School in Stockholm before enrolling at The Bauhaus where she studied graphic design. In 1933 she moved back to Stockholm and married Andreas Feininger. Their son, Tomas, was born two years later. In Sweden, Mrs. Feininger designed and painted porcelain at Gustavsberg in part under the guidance of her uncle, Wilhelm Kage, one of the outstanding ceramists of his time. As the clouds of war darkended the sky of Europe, her husband (who held US citizenship) decided to pull up roots and on December 6, 1939, the family sailed from Bergen, Norway, to New York on board the Oslofjord. In New York, and later in Connecticut, Mrs. Feininger worked as commercial illustrator and illustrator of children's books. When her husband joined Life magazine as a staff photographer in 1942, she increasingly became his "girl Friday", a role that he warmly acknowledged on many occasions. Even after he left the magazine in 1963, Mrs. Feininger carried on as her husband's helper and muse until he put aside his cameras for the last time in the mid 1990s. He died in 1999 and carried on for several years distributing many of his photographs to museums and cultural institutions. Mrs. Feininger is survived by her son, Tomas, a geologist, living in Quebec, three granddaughters, Anna and Ingrid of Ottawa, Canada and Erica, who lives in Massachusetts, three great-granddaughters, as well as numerous other relatives in Sweden.

title: Arts, Briefly; Black Anchor on French TV
description: Harry Roselmack, right, a 32-year-old journalist from the Caribbean island Martinique, will become France's first black television news anchor this summer. He will fill in for France's best-known anchor, Patrick Poivre d'Arvor, on the popular evening news while Mr. Poivre d'Arvor is on summer vacation. After race riots last fall, the French government has been pushing for greater racial diversity in the news media. JOHN TAGLIABUE

title: Possibility of Second Mistrial Hovers in Rape-Murder Case
description: The trial of two men accused of raping and murdering a Hunter College student has come to this: The mother of a sick girl has to decide whether to return to jury duty at 10 a.m. today. If she stays home, the defendants will be one juror away from a possible mistrial, their second.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PINKOWITZ, SAMUEL
description: PINKOWITZ--Samuel. Sam was blessed with a long life and a wonderful family. We extend our condolences to our dear friends Andrew and Mary Pinkowitz whose devotion is an inspiration. Daniel and Abigail Reingold

title: Arts, Briefly; '24' x 2 = 12.98 Million
description: The "24" character viewers love to hate made a very special appearance on Monday night. Yes, Kim Bauer (Elisha Cuthbert, below), the idiotic daughter of Jack (Kiefer Sutherland), who once managed to get caught in a cougar trap, found out during the two-hour episode that her father was alive. The "24" double feature, in which the fan favorite Edgar (Louis Lombardi) was killed, drew an estimated average of 12.98 million viewers and propelled Fox to a win for the night among adults 18 to 49, its first for a Monday this season. CBS's reliable Monday lineup was No. 1 in total viewers. That network's schedule featured "How I Met Your Mother" (10.22 million), "Two and a Half Men" (17.12 million) and "CSI: Miami" (18.2 million). CBS announced yesterday that all three had been renewed for next season. Also of note on Monday were the strongest ratings yet for NBC's "Deal or No Deal," which brought in 14.68 million viewers and won the 8 p.m. hour. And on ABC, the premiere of "Miracle Workers," the medical makeover show, finished third in the 10 p.m. hour, with 8.53 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Obituary:Gordon Parks, chronicled African-American life
description: NEW YORK  Gordon Parks, 93, the photographer, filmmaker, writer and composer who used his prodigious, largely self-taught talents to chronicle the African-American experience and to retell his own personal history, died Tuesday at his home in New York.

title: Lincoln Center Is Awash in Tchaikovsky and Shakespeare
description: Lincoln Center was positively awash in dramatic music of Tchaikovsky on Monday evening. As Valery Gergiev and the Metropolitan Opera were presenting the company's first production of "Mazeppa" next door (review, Page 1), Vladimir Jurowski and the Russian National Orchestra afforded an in-depth exploration of Tchaikovsky's ventures into Shakespeare in the second of their three concerts in Avery Fisher Hall.

description: THE South Slope restaurant scene has long been short on variety. Until recently, fried fish at Bar Minnow or fried veal at Cafe Steinhof were the best and almost the only options for diners prowling Seventh Avenue in this part of Brooklyn.

description: Three batters. Six pitches. One strikeout. Three outs. In his first appearance of the spring, in a 5-0 victory, Yankees closer Mariano Rivera appeared in midseason form.

description: JERUSALEM, March 7 - Ehud Olmert, the acting prime minister and the leader of the new Kadima Party, has been renamed "Smolmert" in an effort to label him dovish and left-wing ("smol" is Hebrew for "left").

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday announced a settlement with an online cigarette vendor that will allow the city to pursue residents for up to $33 million in unpaid excise taxes. It was the largest such settlement, officials said, since the city sued dozens of companies and individuals in 2003 for illegally selling cigarettes over the Internet to city residents.

description: WASHINGTON, March 7 - The Central Intelligence Agency objected to producing presidential briefing documents sought by lawyers for the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, according to an affidavit unsealed Tuesday in the C.I.A. leak case.

title: Being in Love Is Impossible, but Being Alone Is Even Worse
description: Jason Mantzoukas and Jessica St. Clair, who have collaborated several times, belong to the illustrious (and fading) tradition of bickering male-female comedy teams. And while Mantzoukas and St. Clair doesn't exactly roll off the tongue like Burns and Allen or Nichols and May, the pair do, to their credit, have the chemistry of an old married couple who fight better than they get along.

title: Arts, Briefly; Change at English Opera
description: The English National Opera, plagued recently by turbulence in its management ranks, announced yesterday that it had found a new music director. He is Edward Gardner, 32, music director of the Glyndebourne Opera Festival's touring arm, which produces opera in regional British theaters. This season, Mr. Gardner is making his debut at the Linbury Studio, a smaller hall at the Royal Opera House, with Mozart's opera "Il Re Pastore," and is conducting a new production of Donizetti's "Elisir d'Amore" at the Paris Opera. He has served as a guest conductor at a number of British orchestras, as well as at the Colorado Symphony, and this season will conduct the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra. He starts in May 2007, the house said. The previous music director-designate, Oleg Caetani, stepped aside in January before even starting in what was called a mutual decision, although he will continue conducting productions as a guest. The move was part of a chain of turnovers at the house, starting in May, when the executive director was ousted, followed by the departure of the chairman. DANIEL J. WAKIN

description: The hard news here is that James Levine, having injured a shoulder in a fall onstage in Boston last Wednesday, has bowed out of the Boston Symphony Orchestra's short tour, leaving his players in other hands. On Monday evening at Carnegie Hall, the tour's first stop, those hands belonged to Marek Janowski; the remaining concerts are to be led by David Robertson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALB, KOMARIN, SHARON
description: KALB - KOMARIN - Sharon. Age 50, of Flanders, New Jersey passed away on March 6, 2006. Beloved wife of Gary Komarin. Loving mother of Jenna Heller Komarin, Zoe Peyton Komarin and Wyatt Lowell Komarin. Devoted daughter of Judy and Morton Kalb. Dear daughter-in-law of Frances Komarin. Adored sister of Laurie Kalb Kaswiner and her husband Dr. Lee Kaswiner and Dr. Thomas Heller Kalb and his wife Dr. Robin Bell Kalb. She is survived by loving aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews and many cousins and friends. A "celebration of Sharon's life" will be held on Wednesday, March 8, 2006 at 1:30PM at Temple Sholom West Essex, 760 Pompton Avenue, Cedar Grove, NJ. 973-239-1321. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate donations in the memory of Sharon Kalb-Komarin to Ovarian Cancer research organizations such as Gilda's Club or The Judy and Morton Kalb L'Chaim Fund at the JCC. 973-530-3402. Shiva will be observed Thursday, March 9, 2006 from 3-9PM at the home of her sister Laurie Kalb Kaswiner, 4 Trent Court, Morristown, NJ 07960.

title: In broadband, big gains by small firms
Beware of What's Sold as Reform
description: Critical floor fights are looming in the Senate that will show whether Congress will ever find the courage to rein in its scandalous quid pro quo dependence on the powerful lobbying industry. Pending legislation has already been watered down in committee, most seriously with the rejection of a proposal for an independent office to investigate ethics abuses. Defenders of the Senate's status quo clubbiness insist that they are up to the task of reform through existing committees. But continuing revelations about the money-driven symbiosis of lawmaker and lobbyist make it clear that any law stripped of credible enforcement is an election-year charade.

title: Knicks Continue New Trend: Being Competitive
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 7 - James L. Dolan made a number of puzzling remarks when he spoke about the state of the Knicks last week, but whatever he said in private, it must have been inspirational.

description: About two dozen people with multiple sclerosis, some in wheelchairs and some in tears, implored the Food and Drug Administration yesterday to make the drug Tysabri available again, even though an agency official said that doing so would almost certainly lead to deaths.
