title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Three Charged With Extortion
description: Three men, including one whose parole led to an investigation into the state parole system two years ago, were charged yesterday with threatening an electrical contractor to force him to drop a job in favor of another contractor. Two of the men -- Angelo Prisco, 66, and Michael Visconti, 37 -- were charged with threatening an unnamed contractor in the summer of 2004 to force him to allow a company owned by John Cappelli, 70, to provide electrical service for an outdoor festival, federal prosecutors said. Mr. Prisco, Mr. Visconti and Mr. Cappelli were charged with conspiracy to commit extortion, prosecutors said.

title: People: Alan Greenspan, Paris Hilton, Edward Gardner
As Luck Would Have It
description: IT was too good to be true. Our top-rated Irish whiskey was a six-year-old single malt for $18 with the very Irish name of Erin Go Bragh. Trouble was, none of us had ever heard of it.

title: Time for Some Irish, but Why the Wait?
description: FIRST of all, let me extend a pre-emptive apology. It's not right that the issue of Irish whiskey comes up only in the days leading up to St. Patrick's Day. For a whiskey with such a pedigree to be consigned to the category of ethnic celebration -- not that there's anything wrong with that, as Jerry Seinfeld used to say -- pays dutiful lip service to a spirit that deserves much better.

title: Correction
description: The Pour column last Wednesday, about white Bordeaux, misspelled the surname of the winemaker at Clos du Val in Napa, Calif. He is Bernard Portet, not Portal.

title: The Quest
description: The working title is "Glacial Melt." It is made of dripping liquid plastic and wood. Deborah Fisher is a 34-year-old sculptor working at Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens. Her quest: "There has to be some way to look at climate change that isn't desperate, that doesn't waste time on blame or politics or collapse into end-of-times lists of future plagues and floods."

description: "America's Next Top Model," Tyra Banks's show, appears for a sixth round on UPN tonight, indicating that for half the audience it's still a goof and a novelty, and for the other half  the preteens, who are its fan base  it's an old classic, one that has offered inspiration and heartbreak to pretty girls since 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, WALTER THADDEUS, PHD.
description: BROWN--Walter Thaddeus, PhD. Of Hillsdale, NJ and Adirondack, NY died on March 5, 2006. He was 63 years old. A three time recipient of Fulbright Fellowships, Dr. Brown was Professor of African History and International Studies for 33 years at Ramapo College in New Jersey, during which time he brought the world to his students through his dynamic lectures illustrated with his own documentary photographs and his students to the world through the numerous trips he led to Ghana, Czech Republic, Russia and Jamaica. Throughout his career, Dr. Brown's studies focused on issues of ethnicity, religion and political change as they affected the lives of small minorities within cultures. Born in the Bronx, he received his BS from CCNY where he was a star lacrosse player and later inducted into the school's Athletic Hall of Fame and his MA and PhD from Boston University doing his field research in East Africa. His intellect, humor and passion for life will be deeply missed by students, colleagues, family and friends.

description: Citigroup said yesterday that it was blocking transactions on bank cards used in three countries, the latest sign of a card system breach that has prompted a number of banks to reissue thousands of debit cards.

title: Grass-Fed or Grain?
description: A REPORT published today by the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental group, confirms that meat and the milk from cows fed only grass have higher levels of omega-3's, beneficial fatty acids, than meat and milk from cows raised conventionally, on grain. Omega-3's may prevent heart disease and bolster the immune system.

title: Dana Reeve, Devoted Caretaker and Advocate, Is Dead at 44
description: Dana Reeve, who devoted herself to the care of her paralyzed husband, the actor Christopher Reeve, and became a forceful advocate for research into spinal cord injuries, died on Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 44 and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y., in Westchester County.

title: VNU split becoming more likely

description: IF there were a culinary equivalent of the Elgin Marbles for the Greeks, that would surely be their white, tangy national cheese, feta. But unlike the famous carvings from the Parthenon, which Lord Elgin carted off two centuries ago, the country's national cheese was recently returned to Greece by the European Union.

title: Parrish's Last Game? If So, It Was a Good One
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 7 - Mark Parrish, his knees encased in ice, playfully enlisted his teammates' help in the dressing room Tuesday night after he helped the Islanders beat the Devils, 2-1, in a shootout. He was looking for people to help him pack.

title: A Nice Guy, if You Ignore That Killer Alter Ego
description: Half of Juzo (Shun Oguri) is a mild-mannered Japanese construction worker; the other half (Shidou Nakamura), a panty-sniffing, child-abducting, gut-stabbing psychopath. They live, if you can call it that, in an apartment building designed for minimum exposure and maximum misery, right downstairs from a gangster named Toru (Hirofumi Arai). The halves of Jozu add up to "The Neighbor No. Thirteen," who is not, as you might have guessed, the luckiest of basket cases.

title: Sad Suspicions About Scores in Basketball
description: THE downfall of the "Goodfellas" mafiosi started with the Lufthansa job at Kennedy Airport in New York. At the time, it was the largest cash robbery in history. "Lufthansa should have been our ultimate score," Ray Liotta, playing the mobster Henry Hill, said in the movie. Instead, the movie gangsters called attention to themselves with flashy purchases like a hot-pink Cadillac and, as the police closed in, began killing each other.

Bank of Canada Raises Rate
description: As expected, the Bank of Canada raised its key overnight rate by one quarter of a percentage point yesterday to 3.75 percent. The increase was the fifth consecutive rise, and the central bank suggested another increase may come on April 25. Largely because of high energy prices, Canada's economy has been growing at a rate that has raised concerns about inflation. But the bank's rate strategy has been criticized by some Canadian exporters, particularly manufacturers. The rate increases have helped elevate the Canadian dollar to levels not seen since the early 1990's, making Canada's exports more expensive. In a statement, the bank acknowledged that the Canadian dollar "has recently moved above the range that had been assumed."

description: An article on Monday about a New York lawyer whose specialty is locating hard-to-find people, often relying on a large collection of old phone books, misspelled the name of two brothers who were known in the 1940's for hoarding items in their Manhattan home. They were the Collyer brothers, not Collier.

They still gazed into the absence. They still posed for photographs, adjusting their expressions the way you adjust a lens.

Fastow, the former chief financial officer and the Enron figure most vilified for the secretive transactions that artificially boosted Enron's earnings while making tens of millions of dollars for himself, took the stand in the six-week-old trial of the former chief executives Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay. Mr. Fastow wasted no time by quickly pointing fingers at his former bosses. [Page A1.]

title: It's Not the Bronx, but Williams Feels at Home
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 7 - The chants of "Ber-nie, Ber-nie" were not happening at Yankee Stadium on a cool October night. But, to Bernie Williams, hearing them at Hiram Bithorn Stadium on a warm March night felt just as pleasant. It felt like home. It was.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the challenges facing New York City detectives trying to solve the killing of Imette St. Guillen, a graduate student, misidentified the area of Brooklyn where her body was found on Feb. 25. (A similar error appeared in an article in some copies yesterday about a search of the home of a bouncer who worked at the SoHo bar where Ms. St. Guillen was last seen alive.) Her body was found in eastern Brooklyn, not in the southern or southeastern part of the borough. A picture caption in some copies on Sunday about Ms. St. Guillen's funeral misstated the given name of a funeral director accompanying her family. He is Richard Gormley, not William.

title: 29 bodies found in Baghdad as political stalemate persists
Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 28 about concerns raised by the Coast Guard over the deal with a Dubai company, DP World, incorrectly described legislation proposed by two Democratic Senators, Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York and Robert Menendez of New Jersey, and a correction in this space on Thursday also described it incorrectly. The bill would ban companies owned by foreign governments from taking over operations at American ports. It would not ban foreign-owned private companies from doing so. (The Dubai company is controlled by the emir of Dubai, which is part of the United Arab Emirates.)

title: Jazz at Lincoln Center Plans More 'Sweep' in New Season
description: Conservatism has been the charge most often leveled at Jazz at Lincoln Center by its critics over the years. So it is significant that the organization's next season, its third since it established a permanent home in the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle, advances the theme "Innovations in Jazz."

title: E-mail: Still a killer app?
Tough Hurdles for Companies in Move Back to New Orleans
description: Correction Appended

title: A Musical Where Satan Steals the ShowTheater Review | 'Paradise Lost'
description: It's hard to believe that all those theological ideas heaven, hell, sin, free will, redemption, forgiveness can fit into such a confined playing space, not to mention all those actors and musicians. But "Paradise Lost," a sung-through musical take on the Milton epic at the Producer's Club II, does a fair amount with a shoestring. This ambitious attempt by the young team of Benjamin Birney (music and lyrics) and Rob Seitelman (lyrics and direction) may not be the most marketable musical in the world beware any play where Satan (Paul A. Schaefer) gets the last bow but you've got to admire the effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASSAKIAN, EDWARD ZAREH
description: KASSAKIAN--Edward Zareh, 61. Of Westfield, New Jersey and Charlestown, Rhode Island; devoted husband of Sharon, beloved father of Steven and Jennie, loving brother of John Kassakian, died on Sunday, February 26, 2006 in Manila, Philippines. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM, Saturday, March 11, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (www.pancan.org).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOWLING, MARGOT C. NEE CLARKE
description: DOWLING--Margot C. nee Clarke. Of Amagansett, NY on March 3, 2006. Beloved wife of the late John J. Jr. Dear sister of the late Lawrence Clarke. Survived by sisters-in-law Mary Louise Dowling and Gail Clarke. Also survived by nephew Tom Clarke and niece Kelle Clarke. Mass held Tuesday, March 7 at Most Holy Trinity RC Church. Interment in Most Holy Trinity Cemetery, East Hampton. Memorial donations to The Convent of The Sacred Heart, East 91 Street, New York, NY 10128.

description: On Monday night, America's most popular reggae singer took the stage wearing a black hat and a long black coat, but it wasn't a costume. The singer is Matisyahu, a former hippie from White Plains. Once he followed Phish. Now he follows the teachings of Hasidic Judaism. And tons of fans follow him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, PHYLLIS
description: WEINER--Phyllis. Born August 14, 1917; died tragically March 6, 2006. Beloved wife of Max Weiner and the late Sidney Katz. Adored mother of Carol Katz and the late Fred Katz, loving mother-inlaw of Joan Katz Lesky and devoted grandmother of Seth and Sarah Katz. Caring stepmother of Hal and Marilyn Weiner and their family. A very special lady whose warmth, wit and charm enchanted all of us who knew and loved her. Services today 12:45, "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Convenes Antipoverty Group
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg convened a special commission yesterday at Gracie Mansion to develop strategies for helping the city's poorest residents. The mayor, who has pledged to fight poverty in his second term, gave the commission until Labor Day to recommend programs for addressing unemployment and other problems in low-income neighborhoods. The 32-member Commission for Economic Opportunity will be led by Richard D. Parsons, chief executive of Time Warner, and Geoffrey Canada, a nationally recognized children's advocate. WINNIE HU (NYT)

title: Whatever Happened to Little Edie?
description: Please welcome another first-class clairvoyant to the swelling ranks of those who dazzle by channeling dead celebrities on the stage and screen. Resurrecting that strange socialite-in-limbo known as "Little" Edie Beale in "Grey Gardens," the irritatingly mixed blessing of a musical that opened last night at Playwrights Horizons, Christine Ebersole easily matches the achievements of this year's newly anointed Oscar winners Philip Seymour Hoffman (who played Truman Capote in "Capote") and Reese Witherspoon (June Carter Cash in "Walk the Line").

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, RUTH
description: GOLDMAN--Ruth. Died in Boynton Beach, FL. on March 7, 2006. Beloved wife of Bert. Devoted mother of Arin Goldman, Ellen and Roger Roisman and Mindy and David Goldman. Adored grandmother of Carly and Adam Rappaport, Rachael Roisman and Danielle, Chelsea and Adam Goldman. She was very much loved and will be greatly missed by all whose lives she touched. Services Thursday, March 9, 2006 at 10 A.M., Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: New York Puts Mental Patients in Homes Illegally, Groups Say
description: New York State regularly sends patients from mental hospitals to nursing homes, where it illegally houses hundreds of them without the care they need and often under conditions that approach imprisonment, according to legal groups designated by the state to represent the disabled.

title: Briefly: Agency wants drug returned to market
Wal-Mart Looms Over 2 Bills to Improve Worker Health Care
description: ALBANY, March 7 - The national effort to force Wal-Mart and other employers to provide better health care coverage came to Albany on Tuesday, with legislators of both parties promoting bills that would require many businesses to provide insurance for some 450,000 workers who now lack it.

title: The beauty of baseball, Anti-Semitism in France
Former Parmalat Chairman Testifies at Trial
description: MILAN, March 7 - In a packed courtroom on Tuesday, Calisto Tanzi, the founder and former chairman of Parmalat, said he felt "pain and remorse" for his role in the company's collapse, but mostly blamed the company's banks for fostering a druglike dependence on credit.

description: The Swamp The Everglades, Florida and the Politics of Paradise By Michael Grunwald Illustrated. 450 pages. Simon & Schuster. $27.

description: Correction Appended

title: Flights to New York Are Delayed by a Computer Failure on L.I.
description: A computer failure yesterday at a radar center on Long Island forced air traffic controllers to hold planes bound for New York City as far away as Chicago. The planes were eventually allowed to take off, but with 15 miles between them instead of the usual 5.

title: From a Galaxy Far Far Away, Tchaikovsky's Ivan the Rebel
description: Though Tchaikovsky's "Mazeppa" is a staple of the Kirov Opera at the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, it has made it only to the periphery of opera companies outside Russia. When the Kirov came to the Metropolitan Opera House in the spring of 1998 to present four Russian operas, "Mazeppa," the least well known, proved a stunning revelation. Conducted by Valery Gergiev, Tchaikovsky's epic about the 17th-century Ukrainian separatist Ivan Mazeppa seemed an anguished, probing and noble work.

title: U.S. Human Rights Report Criticizes Iraqi Police
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 A Iraqi police units, often infiltrated and even dominated by members of sectarian militias, continue to be linked to arbitrary arrests and to the torture, rapes and sometimes deaths of detainees, the State Department reported today.

title: N.F.L. Owners Mull Proposal Made by Players Union
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex., March 7 - With N.F.L. owners spending about eight hours huddled in a hotel ballroom Tuesday, debating whether to accept or reject the latest offer from the players union, an air of uncertainty continued to hang over the league.

title: Reality TV for Those Infatuated With Passing
description: If reality television can be said to be about anything at all, it seems to be about impersonation and the odd and increasingly tenacious hold it has on the American psyche. The crooked-nosed are made over and play the genetically good-looking. Heiresses get out of their $200,000 sports cars and enact the habits of the agriculturally inclined. A vegan mother from Boulder trades houses with an evangelical wife in Mobile, is encouraged to care about scripture and breakfast sausage, and essentially tries to pass.

title: Report on Tutoring Firms Cites Problems in New York
description: Tutoring companies, rushing to tap into money available under the federal No Child Left Behind law, offered New York City principals thousands of dollars for school projects, doled out gift certificates to students and hired several workers with criminal backgrounds, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMORY, HARCOURT
description: AMORY--Harcourt, 82. Of Vero Beach, FL. Formerly of New York City and Pound Ridge, NY, March 1, 2006. Survived by his devoted wife, Jean Moore Amory, and their children Dita Amory Nickson, Jean Trudeau Fenn, Garry Trudeau, Michelle Trudeau and six grandchildren. Previously married to Dita Naylor-Leyland. Born in Beverly, MA. He attended Brooks School and Harvard University. Served in the American Field Service, British Eighth Army, and OSS during WWII. Services on Saturday, March 11, 2006, 11 A.M. at Saint Mark's Anglican Church in Vero Beach, FL. Contributions may be sent to the Indian River Memorial Hospital Foundation, 1000 36th Street, Vero Beach, Florida 32960, or Saint Mark's Anglican Church, P.O. Box 6994, Vero Beach, Florida 32961.

title: Technical Problems Cause Errors in SAT Test Scores
description: About 4,000 students who took the SAT last October received test scores that were lower than they should have been -- some by as much as 100 points -- because of technical problems in the scoring process, the College Board said yesterday.

title: 2 Big Shareholders Oppose $8.9 Billion Offer for VNU
description: By ERIC PFANNER

title: Sharing Whiskeys and Confessions on a Stormy Roman Night
description: Woman walks into a bar. It's no joke. Although there are some funny lines. You can hear her shouting in the back in Italian for the first moments of "L'Ultima Notte di Salom" ("The Last Night of Salome"), a short play with a Poe-like twist set in 1950's Rome. Arriving from the Istituto di Studi dello Spettacolo-Teatro Studio, a cultural association and theater training center in Rome, the play, by Emanuele Vacchetto, opened at La MaMa E.T.C. last week, performed in Italian with English supertitles.

title: What's Missing From Hollywood? Office Space
description: LOS ANGELES, March 7 - An unremarkable office building in Hollywood from the 1970's might seem an unlikely candidate for a Cinderella story. With an aging exterior of black glass and a billboard on the roof, the building, 1800 Highland, was nearly empty until recently. Its few tenants paid rent month to month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, CARYL MASYR
description: SMITH--Caryl Masyr. Died suddenly on Sunday, March 5. Memorial service will be held Thursday, March 9, Gramercy Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue at 10 AM.

title: Lawsuit Contests Pay Package Hewlett Gave to Former Chief
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 - Two large shareholders sued Hewlett-Packard on Tuesday, contending that a $21.4 million severance package for Carleton S. Fiorina, its former chief executive, violated the company's policy on executive compensation.

title: Testing for Silicosis Comes Under Scrutiny in Congress
description: Once seen as the next asbestos or tobacco for class-action lawyers, silica and the lawsuits related to it have instead become a messy legal morass for the doctors, X-ray screening companies and plaintiff law firms that have wound up as the subjects of numerous investigations.

title: N.Y.S.E.'s Big Day: From Private Club to Public Company
description: When John A. Thain, the chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, announced last April that the exchange would merge with the electronic trading system Archipelago, an emotional and logistical battle ensued to convert a 213-year-old club into a 21st-century business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IRVANI, RAHIM MOTTAGHI
description: IRVANI--Rahim Mottaghi, 86. Died at home in London on March 3, 2006. He will be missed by his wife Zinat; his daughters and sons-in-law Nezhat and Hassan Khosrowshahi, and Maryam and Vahid Alaghband; his son and daughter-in-law Bahman and Roya Irvani; sons Ali, Abbass, Abdulrahim, Behnam, Faramarz, Farhad, Fariborz, Farshad, Farzad, Farzan, Hassan, Kamal, Kourosh, Massoud, Mohammad, Mohammad - Hassan, Nourollah, Saeed, Shadab, Shademan, and Shahram; his grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

title: Dominicans Display Their Power and Their Passion
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., March 7 - Julio Diaz had to be here. Even if he lives in Washington Heights, and even if he paid $270 for his ticket, more than 10 times face value, he believed it was his duty to be at The Ballpark at Disney on Tuesday morning.

title: A Witness at Odds With What Some Others Have Said
description: No two witnesses in a criminal trial ever tell exactly the same story. Prosecutors and defense lawyers expect it. That seems to be holding true in the testimony of Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron.

title: For the Cocteau Repertory, Merger and a New Director
description: Amid growing financial worries and a shrinking subscriber base, the Jean Cocteau Repertory, a venerable classical theater troupe with a home on the Bowery, has decided to join with two other companies, its chairman said on Monday.

title: Ali Farka Tour, Grammy-Winning Musician of West Africa, Dies
description: Ali Farka Tour, the self-taught Malian guitarist and songwriter who merged West African traditions with the blues and carried his music to a worldwide audience, winning two Grammy Awards, died in his sleep on Monday at his farm in the village of Niafunke in northwestern Mali, the Ministry of Culture of Mali announced.

title: Ready, aim...pop! Clash in Spain has sparkling edge
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Ex-No. 2 Accused In Rape Trial
description: The rape trial of Jacob G. Zuma, left, the nation's former vice president, took a threatening turn as protesters burned photographs of his accuser outside the Johannesburg courthouse. Officials of the African National Congress, of which Mr. Zuma remains deputy president, and his legal defense fund distanced themselves from the protest. In court, Mr. Zuma's lawyers, who won court permission to examine the 31-year-old accuser's sexual history, questioned her statement that she had believed that she and Mr. Zuma, 63, who has admitted consensual sex with her, had had a father-daughter relationship before the alleged attack. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 28 about views on museum collecting expressed by Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, referred incompletely to the Met's policy on acquiring artifacts with a hazy provenance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, EDITH MCKNIGHT
description: MOORE--Edith McKnight. Of Hobe Sound, Florida on February 27, 2006 in her 91st year, beloved wife of William H. Moore for 69 years and mother of Pamela Olyphant of Bozeman, Montana, William H. Moore III of Greenwich, Connecticut and Timothy Moore of Silves, Portugal, eleven grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. She attended Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania and graduated from the Parsons School of Design in New York City. Later she started her own decorating firm "E. Moore Interiors". The family lived in Morristown, New Jersey and later moved to Old Lyme, Connecticut and then to Hobe Sound, Florida. She was an avid gardener and took great delight in garden design. Donations to Memorial Garden of Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island (772)546-8329.

title: G.M. Freezes Pension Plan of Its Salaried Workers
description: DETROIT, March 7 - The General Motors Corporation announced extensive changes to the retirement plans of its salaried employees on Tuesday, a decision that will cut its pension costs by $1.6 billion this year and lead to lower benefits for workers.

title: Obituary:Ali Farka Tour, Grammy-winning Malian musician
The Land With the Golden Hotel
description: After even a short walking tour of the new Emirates Palace hotel on the Abu Dhabi Corniche, a visitor might well start to wonder: is there anything here that glitters that is not, in fact, gold?

title: Low Pitch Counts Make for a Fast Game
description: PHOENIX - THE ages-old baseball clich has validity whether the early March games are played between the Yankees and the Mets at a picturesque spring training site in Florida or between two national teams from different countries at a major league park in Arizona. The pitchers are ahead of the hitters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REEVE, DANA
description: REEVE--Dana. The Board of Directors and staff of the Christopher Reeve Foundation mourn the passing of our devoted Chair, Dana Reeve, beloved wife of the late Christopher, mother of Will and step-mother of Matthew and Alexandra. We are extremely saddened by the death of Dana Reeve, whose grace and courage under the most difficult of circumstances was a source of comfort and inspiration to us all. The Foundation extends our deepest condolences and sympathy to the entire Reeve and Morosini families. Her legacy will live through the Foundation's continuing work in finding a cure for spinal cord injury and improving the quality of life for people living with paralysis. Contributions in Dana's memory can be made by visiting the Christopher Reeve Foundation website at: www.christopherreeve.org Kathy Lewis President and CEO Peter Kiernan Chairman

title: 23 bodies found dumped in Baghdad
Racial Tension, With a Laugh TrackTheater Review | 'Offspring'
description: Though the score is rap rather than soul, the spirit of the late 1960's hovers over "Offspring," a production by the Negro Ensemble Company at the 45th Street Theater. Written by Jimmy Barden, a former editor at The New York Times, this story of a middle-aged white socialite consorting with a young radical black man recalls both the comic collisions of race and class in the Norman Lear sitcom "The Jeffersons" and Tom Wolfe's famously cynical account of Leonard Bernstein's party for the Black Panthers, where "the very idea of them, these real revolutionaries, runs through Lenny's duplex like a rogue hormone."

title: Without Stars, UConn Claims Another Crown
description: HARTFORD, March 7 - At least in the fief where Rutgers rules, this Big East women's tournament was going to provide a glorious coronation of the Scarlet Knights and a rare dethroning of Connecticut. But the crown remains on a familiar, if slightly shaky, head.

title: A Generous Soul Celebrated in Almost Continual Music
description: Frank Loesser's music for "The Most Happy Fella" is more complex, varied and inventive than the scores of quite a few 20th-century works that proudly call themselves operas. Yet Loesser never thought of the show, which opened on Broadway 50 years ago, as an opera. "It's a musical, with a lot of music," he said. Actually, there is not just a lot, but almost continual music.

Some Sleeping Pill Users Range Far Beyond Bed
description: With a tendency to stare zombie-like and run into stationary objects, a new species of impaired motorist is hitting the roads: the Ambien driver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURRIE, RICHARD WALLACE
description: MURRIE--Richard Wallace. Of New York City, died peacefully at age 88 on March 6 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 30 years Rita T. Murrie, his stepson Steven Finley and stepdaughter Elizabeth Vary, four beloved stepgrandchildren, and his nephew William M. Clevenger and niece Mimi Chitwood. Dick was born in Hershey, PA on March 23, 1917, the son of William F.R. Murrie, who served as the President of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation from its incorporation in 1908 until 1947, and Sarah Maitland Murrie. Dick graduated from Lawrenceville School in 1935, from Princeton University, Summa cum Laude, in 1939 and from Yale Law School in 1942. He was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy, serving in both the North Atlantic and the Pacific from 1942 to 1946. Dick was a Senior Vice President and Fiduciary Counsel of Bessemer Trust Company, from which he retired in 1983, and served as the chairman of the Board of Pacific Inland Navigation Company. His prior marriage, to the former Elizabeth Horgan, ended with her death in 1975. He was a member of the Quogue Field Club, the Quogue Beach Club, the Princeton Club of New York, the University Club of New York, the St. Andrew's Society of New York, the Sons of the Revolution and the Society of Colonial Wars, and served as President of the New York Numismatic Club. Dick was a kind and generous man, an historian, a raconteur with a sharp mind, a quick smile and a ready laugh. He was beloved by numerous friends he easily accumulated over a long and very full life. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street on Thursday, March 9, from 2 to 4 PM and from 7 to 9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street at 10 AM on Friday, March 10, 2006.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (FX) BLACK. WHITE. It has been 45 years since the publication of John Howard Griffin's book "Black Like Me," the first-person story of a white man who posed as African-American and was shocked at the way he was treated. In this six-part documentary, beginning tonight, two families trade races (with the help of a lot of makeup), looking for more subtle signs of racism. The teenagers (Nick Sparks and Rose Wurgel, above) have a better time than the adults.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Sunday about Scott Maine, a pitcher at the University of Miami who survived a serious auto accident, misstated the range of the scale that doctors use to rank head trauma. It is 3 to 15, not 1 to 15.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Opposition Leader Cleared Of Rape Charge
description: A High Court judge dismissed a rape charge against the opposition leader Kizza Besigye, saying the prosecution was "crude and amateurish, betraying the motives behind the case." The government of President Yoweri Museveni brought the charge against Mr. Besigye before last month's presidential election. Mr. Besigye, who spent much of the campaign in jail or in court and finished a distant second, still faces charges of terrorism and treason. MARC LACEY (NYT)

title: Jealousy Led Bonds to Steroids, Authors Say
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 7 - A new book says Barry Bonds became a devoted steroid user who was motivated to start taking performance-enhancing drugs by his jealousy over the attention that Mark McGwire received during his memorable home run chase with Sammy Sosa in 1998.

title: Bouncer Is Held on a Parole Violation
description: Police conversations with a bouncer being questioned in the killing of a graduate student have ended for now, but he was still being held yesterday at Rikers Island because his job at a SoHo bar had kept him out past his parole curfew, officials said.

title: For Katrina Evacuee, Getting Help Is a Full-Time Job
description: Donna Fenton no longer consults the scrap of paper in her pocketbook when she needs the phone number for the Red Cross, or New York City's welfare office, or the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

title: Intel Announces a New Design for Chips
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 - The Intel Corporation went on the offensive on Tuesday, showing off a new design for powerful, energy-efficient processors that it hopes will help it gain back the market share it has lost to its rival, Advanced Micro Devices.

title: Rhapsody in Roux: A New Orleans Classic

title: Arts, Briefly; Update on Bob Woodruff
description: Bob Woodruff, the ABC News anchor who suffered serious head and other wounds in Iraq in a bomb attack in late January, is now sufficiently conscious to have said a few words to his family and has begun to learn to walk again, his brother David said yesterday on the ABC program "Good Morning America." Both David Woodruff and David Westin, the president of ABC News, who provided an update to that division via e-mail, emphasized that Mr. Woodruff's recovery was expected to be long and arduous. Mr. Westin noted that Mr. Woodruff, above right, "remains under fairly heavy medication for pain from his various injuries (which are healing well)." On "Good Morning America," David Woodruff told Diane Sawyer: "He's not talking up a blue streak. He's not sitting there having long conversations with anybody. A couple of sentences here, a few words there." Asked by Ms. Sawyer if his brother were "fully walking," David Woodruff said: "No. He's just getting up and getting in the process of rebuilding himself physically."

title: Enron Executive Points a Finger at Former Chiefs
description: HOUSTON, March 7 - More than four years after Enron collapsed into bankruptcy and its name became synonymous with corporate scandal, the three men most associated with that fall gathered in a federal courtroom here Tuesday and prepared to wage war.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Corrections
description: The Feb. 22 column by Maureen Dowd -- "G.O.P. To W.: You're Nuts!" -- misspelled the name of the Pakistani nuclear scientist who smuggled sensitive nuclear components to Libya, North Korea and Iran. His name is A. Q. Khan, not A. Q. Kahn.

title: When There's Only Snow On the Grill
description: RIBS are so closely associated with grilling that we can forget that the best ones are cooked very slowly. Once cooked, they may be crisped up on a grill, but the part of the procedure that makes them tender is indirect heat, the mark of true barbecue.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Two More Catholic Schools To Close
description: Two Roman Catholic elementary schools, one in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and the other in Bayside, Queens, will close this year because of declining enrollment and financial problems, a spokesman for the Diocese of Brooklyn said yesterday. The schools -- St. Anthony-St. Alphonsus in Greenpoint and American Martyrs in Bayside -- join Queen of Peace in Kew Garden Hills in Queens as schools in the diocese that will close in June. Several other schools are still being evaluated for closing. MICHAEL LUO (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 28 about concerns raised by the Coast Guard over the deal with a Dubai company, DP World, incorrectly described legislation proposed by two Democratic Senators, Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York and Robert Menendez of New Jersey, and a correction in this space on Thursday also described it incorrectly. The bill would ban companies owned by foreign governments from taking over operations at American ports. It would not ban foreign-owned private companies from doing so. (The Dubai company is controlled by the emir of Dubai, which is part of the United Arab Emirates.) (Go to Article)

title: MGM Said to Make Movie Distribution Deals
description: LOS ANGELES, March 7 - Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is expected to announce on Wednesday several new agreements to distribute movies made by other producers, according to several people apprised of the announcement.

title: The Call of the Wild Web
description: The proposed $67 billion megamerger between AT&T and BellSouth requires the scrutiny of regulators, in particular because it would continue the rapid reconsolidation of the old AT&T monopoly. The company has a strong argument for the deal, because the technological landscape is now completely different from the one in 1984, when Ma Bell was broken up -- as different as a rotary-dial phone tethered to a land line is from a cellphone with a wireless headset.

description: Three college students from the prosperous suburbs south of Birmingham, two of them 19 and one 20, were arrested today in the burning of nine Baptist churches in rural Alabama last month that federal officials say was a prank that spun out of control.

title: Provision of Antiterror Law Delays Entry of Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 - About 9,500 Burmese refugees scheduled to be resettled in the United States from Thailand this year are in limbo because their indirect support for armed rebels opposed to their repressive government has put them in technical violation of American antiterrorism law, government officials say.

title: The 'Grey Gardens' hothouse put to song

Letting India in the Club?
description: India is a country that had me at hello. Call me biased, but I have a soft spot for countries of one billion people, speaking a hundred different languages and practicing a variety of religions, whose people hold regular free and fair elections and, despite massive poverty, still produce generations of doctors and engineers who help to make the world a more productive and peaceful place. Sure, as today's bombings in India illustrate, it has its problems -- but it is not Iraq. It is a beacon of tolerance and stability.

Plaintiff Offers Concession at 'Da Vinci Code' Trial
description: As the lawsuit over "The Da VinciCode" resumedyesterday inHigh Court inLondon, oneplaintiff concededthat hehad overstatedhis assertion ina pretrial statementthat DanBrown, the author of the internationalbest seller, had taken 15 pointscentral to his plot from an earlierbook, The Associated Press reported.The testimony came from MichaelBaigent, who, with his co-authorRichard Leigh, is suing Mr.Brown's British publisher, RandomHouse, for copyright infringement.Mr. Baigent, Mr. Leigh and HenryLincoln, who is not suing, are the authorsof the 1982 book "The HolyBlood and the Holy Grail." Like "TheDa Vinci Code," it theorizes that Jesusmarried Mary Magdalene, thatthey had offspring and that their linecontinues. Under cross-examination,Mr. Baigent, who had cited book reviewsto support his statement, reactedto a Random House lawyer'sdeclaration that it was false. Mr. Baigentpaused and responded, "In thatcase, you are correct," adding, "Ithink my language was infelicitous,and I think I have to agree with youon that." Mr. Brown is expected totestify this week.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Abortions Blocked In Rapes, Report Says
description: Rape victims face so many hurdles when they seek an abortion that it is almost impossible to obtain one, even though Mexican law permits abortion for women who have been raped, a study by Human Rights Watch reported. Even if a woman wins approval for an abortion, she must run a gantlet of bureaucracy, it said. "At the core of this issue is a generalized failure of the Mexican justice system to provide a solution for rampant domestic and sexual violence, including incest," it said. The report proposed that states set up clear guidelines for legal abortions. Only Mexico City and 2 of the 31 states have such guidelines. ELISABETH MALKIN (NYT)

title: Better Names for Portable Wi-Fi Hot Spots
description: A couple of weeks ago, I reviewed portable Wi-Fi hot spots in my Times column. You insert a laptop high-speed cellular Internet card, and presto: everyone within 200 feet can get online at high speed, via Wi-Fi.

title: EU officials draw line on Poland protectionism
DeLay Beats 3 Rivals inTexas G.O.P. Primary
description: HOUSTON, March 7 - Representative Tom DeLay survived a challenge to his renomination for Congress Tuesday night, outpacing three Republican primary rivals seeking to capitalize on the criminal charges and ethics citations against him.

title: Lenovo steps out onto global stage
Corrections
description: "Don't Trash the Trash Plan," a March 5 editorial on Mayor Michael Bloomberg's plan to manage the city's solid waste, misspelled the name of a City Council member. Her name is Jessica Lappin, not Jessica Lapin.

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: From Vietnam to Boerum Hill
description: Just a couple of steps from the culinary melting pot that Smith Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, has become, there is Hanco's, a bright little Vietnamese sandwich shop with a counter and a few tables. Hanco Tang, the owner sells the sandwiches, called banh mi, on warm, plump, crusty little baguettes ($4.25).

title: Shiites Threaten to Block Opening Session of Parliament
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 7 - Shiite officials said Tuesday that they might block the opening session of the new Parliament that the Iraqi president has called for, further delaying the process of forming a full four-year government.

title: Iraq's Little Armies
description: WASHINGTON - WHILE the violence that followed the bombing of the Golden Mosque at Samarra in Iraq last month has abated, the larger problem it exposed continues: ever since Saddam Hussein fell, armed militias have roamed the country dispensing justice and retribution to other ethnic and religious groups as they see fit. Ideally, not only can the government and its American supporters stop this vigilantism, but they can also channel it into a productive role within the legitimate security services of the fledgling state.

title: Briefly: Tourists turning west in the Mediterranean
More Salmonella Is Reported in Chickens
description: CHANCES are higher than they were just a few years ago that the chicken you buy will be contaminated with the bacteria salmonella. But the government hasn't been doing much about the situation. It lacks the authority.

title: Bush and the Nuclear Subcontinent
description: To the Editor:

title: Racial Tension, With a Laugh Track
description: 45th Street Theater 354 West 45th Street, Manhattan (212) 279-4200 Through March 19

title: Krispy Kreme Names a Chief Executive, and Its Shares Jump Nearly 21%
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, the struggling company that was once a Wall Street darling, said yesterday that it had hired a new chief executive, giving hope to shareholders that better times might be ahead. Shares of the stock surged nearly 21 percent.

title: For Trader Joe's, a New York Taste Test
description: Monrovia, Calif. - IN an industrial park somewhere in Los Angeles, the pieces of the puzzle come together.

title: Correction
description: My column of Feb. 18 said that Scooter Libby testified that "superiors" had authorized him to leak classified information about Valerie Plame. Rather, Mr. Libby testified that "superiors" had authorized him to leak classified information from an intelligence report to rebut critics and justify the Iraq war, not information about Valerie Plame.

title: Preschool Admissions: Take a Deep Breath
description: To the Editor: Michael Slack

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOEVESDI, RENI
description: KOEVESDI--Reni, 84. Of Fort Lee, NJ, formerly of N. Miami Beach. Predeceased by her husband Dr. Alexander. Beloved mother of Eva Baer, loving grandchildren Michelle and Marc, and Debbie and Ricky, cherished greatgrandchildren Sam, Noah, Jake, Casey and Corey. Services are today, 10:30AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ.

title: Tape Shows Gotti Withdrew From Mob Life, Defense Says
description: The older man, his hair snowy white but his posture erect despite the ravages of neck and head cancer, sits on one side of a prison visiting table.

title: Walking the Runway Walk, Mile After Mile
description: "America's Next Top Model," Tyra Banks's show, appears for a sixth round on UPN tonight, indicating that for half the audience it's still a goof and a novelty, and for the other half -- the preteens, who are its fan base -- it's an old classic, one that has offered inspiration and heartbreak to pretty girls since 2003.

title: Iranian Uranium?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Get
description: The must-haves of the season.

title: The New Collectibles
description: Finders can be keepers.

title: The Originals
description: They're all a bunch of smarty-pants.

title: Gender Bender
description: It's a boy. It's a girl. It's androgyny.

title: The White Album
description: Genteel classics get a new wrinkle.

title: Designer Genes
description: The difference between one inseam and another is the difference in a label's DNA. This spring, several iconic houses decided to plunder their heritage, with collections that go back to the meaning of things.

title: Prints Among Men
description: A royal disarrayof clothing and accessories.

title: Rolling Stone
description: Confessions of a 21st-Century playboy.

title: Tijuana's Shantytowns
description: In Tijuana's shantytowns, Teddy Cruz may have found a new vision for suburban America.

title: Cerberus Becomes Lobbyist as Hedge-Fund Oversight Grows
description: With billions of dollars to deploy on leveraged buyouts and distressed-debt deals, Cerberus Capital Management already carries considerable clout on Wall Street. Now it is taking aim at K Street as well.

title: Continual Rain, 1759
description: Selborne Journal: 8 March 1759:  Continual rain all day.

title: Lala.com Mixes It Up With Networking-Music Site
description: Lala.com, a Palo Alto, Calif., start-up, is launching a service that is a mix of social networking, Internet swap meet and music store. Its MySpace.com meets eBay meets iTunes.

title: U.S. Businesses Are Lining Up Behind Dubai
description: As the Bush administration re-examines a proposal to allow Dubai Ports World to take over operations at some American ports, executives from unrelated businesses have quietly begun lobbying in Dubais favor, fearing that recent fierce criticism could damage trade with the United Arab Emirates.

title: AT&T Chief is the Obvious Winner in  Deal
description: There is one clear winner in AT&Ts $67 billion acquisition ofBellSouth : Edward Whitacre, the AT&T chief executive who pushed the deal through.

title: N.Y.S.E.s Big Day: From Private Club to Public Company
description: Today, the New York Stock Exchange begins its ultimate market test, as shares of the new public company, the NYSE Group, begin trading under the ticker NYX. The debate is whether the stock will become the next Chicago Mercantile Exchange, whose skyrocket rise since its initial public offering in December 2002 rivals Googles, or whether any run-up in value has already taken place.

title: KT&G Shares Rise After Franklin Mutual Supports Icahn
description: Shares of the KT&G, a South Korean tobacco maker threatened with a hostile takeover, rose after Franklin Mutual Advisors, its largest foreign shareholder, decided to support Carl Icahns and Warren Lichtensteins board nominees and seek higher dividends.

title: Et Tu, Butch?
description: OscarWatch.com pointed us to this pained yelp from The Film Experience about the dissing of Brokeback and with it, a key demo for the Oscars.

title: The Best Party Story Ever
description: Hank Stuever and William Booth, a pair of aces from the Washington Post, went to the Oscar parties so you didnt have to. And boy, do those boys know their way around a party and around a party story. A classic of the form:

title: What It Takes to Be a Corporate Raider
description: Why do some shareholder activists  fund managers who scoop up large stakes in a company and then campaign for changes  walk away victorious, while others retreat with little to show for their hard work? The answer, in a word, is investors.

title: Smart Money Makes Dumb Bet
description: A columnist at CNN who used the futures contracts on various Oscar picks ended up in the ditch after Crash won best picture and George Clooney won best supporting actor:

title: Elton John Mistakes Oscars for One of His Own Concerts
description: Calling the Sunday night Oscars, the most boring show ever, Elton John was again ragging on the Academy Awards, suggesting that the proceedings were predictable and that the Kodak Theater was the pits. The Bagger was working during the show, but the parts he saw seemed just fine and all. Still, he will have to defer to Mr. Johns obvious expertise when it comes to entertainment mediocrities.

title: Greenspan, Known for Opaque Speech, Must Deliver Entertainment
description: Alan Greenspan has agreed to sell his memoir for an advance of more than $8.5 million. But given that Mr. Greenspans notoriously opaque statements as Federal Reserve chairman sometimes confused even the closest observers of monetary policy, it remains to be seen whether he can write a book that appeals to a large general-interest audience.

title: Home Court Advantage
description: The Bagger had a very successful red-eye  he got on the plane with 90 minutes of nigh-nigh under his belt in the past 24 hours and he only woke up when the captain said that the flight attendants should be seated for arrival. He made a quick trip through work and then went into the city for HBOs Sopranos party that featured the first two episodes. The Bagger would like to share the amazing twists and turns of the first few shows, but producer David Chase seemed to indicate that he would order up a hit on anybody who shared the story lines before the show debuts Sunday.

title: Goldman Grabs UBS Real Estate Team
description: In a major hiring coup, Goldman Sachs has taken a team of five from UBSs highly regarded real estate group. The team is led by Michael Smith, who will become Goldman Sachs head of real estate investment banking and joins as a managing director. He was previously head of real estate at UBS and has been a specialist in this sector for 15 years.

title: British Union Leaders Troubled by BOC Takeover
description: British trade union leaders on Tuesday called for the government to intervene and stop the move abroad of another strategic asset, after BOC, the industrial gases company, confirmed that it had agreed to an 8.2 billion pound bid from Linde of Germany. The call follows a rush of bids for British companies in recent months while a wave of protectionism has swept through other European countries

title: Microsoft to Buy Internet Software Firms
description: Onfolio Inc., a privately held Cambridge company that makes software enabling Web surfers to store pages, pictures, and other Internet content and retrieve it later, has been acquired by Microsoft Corp. for an undisclosed sum, the companies are expected to disclose this morning.

title: Public Cos. More Willing to Be Wed to Private Firms
description: Public companies are getting a lot more comfortable being wooed by private suitors  because of the dowry. And theyre getting a lot more demanding,too. The ability to hunt in packs is letting private equity firms take on larger targets, and the financial commitments theyre providing are convincing companies that private buyers are as suitable as public companies to buy all or large units of their businesses.

title: LBO Firms Readying to Toil Chinas Good Earth
description: Could this be the year when leveraged buyouts become common place in China? Lawyers at Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, who advise on such deals, say 2006 may be a big year for the LBO scene in the mainland. They saythat as foreign investors vie to put money and their expertise in Chinese companies, there is mounting interest in access to a broader range of financing options to put their plans to work. And that means LBOs are on the table.

title: Venture Capitalist Donates $10 Million to Stanford for Corporate Governance Center
description: Stanford Law School said Monday that it has received a $10 million donation from legendary venture capitalist Arthur Rock and his wife, Toni Rembe, to support study of corporate governance.

title: Grasso Says Its Too Late to Settle With Spitzer
description: Richard Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said Tuesday it was too late to settle a lawsuit filed by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer over his controversial $193 million pay package.

title: Judge Gives OK for Overtsock.com Suit
description: A California judge has allowed Overstock.com Inc. to proceed with its suit against Gradient Analytics Inc. and Rocker Partners LP, Overstock said Tuesday evening.

title: Endesa Board Rejects Gas Natural Bid
description: Spanish electricity companyEndesa said on Tuesday its board had unanimously rejected a hostile takeover bid from energy company Gas Natural.

title: China National Building Material Takes Its IPO on the Road
description: The rapid growth in Chinas construction sector as well as the current liquidity- and sentiment-driven appetite for Chinese paper are likely to be key themes during the road show for China National Building Material Cos initial public offering that was launched yesterday.

title: BCE to Spin Off Aliant into C$8.5 billion Income Trust
description: BCE Inc. ramped up its corporate makeover Tuesday with plans to spin off Aliant Inc.s land-line business into an income trust that would create one of North Americas biggest rural telecommunications companies.

title: ArcLight Near Deal for FirstEnergy Unit
description: Energy-focused investor ArcLight Energy Partners is near a deal to purchase MYR Group Inc., a utility construction unit of public energy concern FirstEnergy Corp., said a person briefed on the transaction.

title: Mittal to Consider Change in Voting Rights After Steel Deal
description: Lakshmi Mittal, the Indian steel baron bidding for the European giant Arcelor, says that his family will consider making its voting rights in Mittal Steel equivalent to those of other shareholders if its contentious takeover bid for Arcelor were successful.

title: Mutual Insurance IPOS Mixed Bag, U.K. Report Says
description: Flotations of mutual insurers, such as that planned for Standard Life later this year, have been good for directors but bad for policyholders. That is the controversial conclusion of an All-Party Parliamentary report published today, called Windfalls or Shortfalls? The true cost of demutualisation.

title: Gear Test With: Dr. Jordan Metzl
description: In the past year, high-end skin-care companies have introduced new muscle rubs with pleasing odors and herbal ingredients.

title: VNU Agrees to $9 Billion Sale; Is the Price Too Low?
description: VNU, the Dutch owner of market researcher ACNielsen and Billboard magazine, accepted a 7.5 billion-euro ($8.9 billion) offer from a group of buyout firms including Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.

title: NFL, Regulators Desperately Seeking Hedge Fund Cash
description: The federal government and some current and former professional football players want to know what happened to the hundreds of millions of dollars that the players and hundreds of other investors poured into a Georgia hedge-fund group. Before they can find the money, they have to find Kirk Wright. Days after Wright and his company, International Management Associates, were sued in federal and state court, neither he nor the money has surfaced.

title: Former A.I.G. Chief Receives Internal Report
description: American International Groups former chief executive, Maurice Greenberg, and his lawyers have received an internal report that uncovered accounting fraud at the insurer.

title: Gordon Hull Launching Round for New Tech Fund
description: Looking to get his new venture firm off the ground, veteran venture capitalist Gordon Hull said that he has begun raising a $75 million tech fund, VentureWire reported. Hull left CMEA Ventures as general partner in December to launch Emeryville, Calif.-based Global Reach Ventures LLC, and recently began speaking to potential investors for the fund. He said that he is looking primarily at smaller institutional investors, including pension funds, universities, endowments and family offices.

title: Resevoir Capital Invests in New Overseas Hedge Fund
description: Reservoir Capital Group, a $2.8 billion hedge-fund firm, has invested $100 million in Octavian Advisors LP, a new fund that will sniff out special situations in overseas markets. Octavian will be run by Richard Hurowitz and Gregory Racz out of Reservoirs Madison Avenue headquarters in New York.

title: Former Parmalat Chairman Testifies at Trial
description: In a packed courtroom on Tuesday, Calisto Tanzi, the founder and former chairman of Parmalat, said he felt pain and remorse for his role in the companys collapse, but mostly blamed the companys banks for fostering a druglike dependence on credit.

title: Citigroup Blocks Cards in 3 Nations After Breach
description: Citigroup said yesterday that it was blocking transactions on bank cards used in three countries, the latest sign of a card system breach that has prompted a number of banks to reissue thousands of debit cards.

title: Devcon Acquires  Guardian for $65.5 Million
description: Devcon International Corp. said it and a subsidiary have completed their merger with Guardian International for $65.5 million. The Deerfield Beach-based security, construction and materials firm said Guardian provides security services throughout Florida and the greater New York metropolitan area.

title: PNC Financial Subsidiary to Open Minneapolis Office
description: PNC Financial Services Group Inc. is adding a Minneapolis office for its Harris Williams & Co. subsidiary. It is the second expansion since PNC acquired the Richmond, Va.-based mergers and acquisition advisory firm last October. A Philadelphia office was added in January 2006.

title: Danas Bankruptcy Rattles Industry, Gives Hope to Vultures
description: The bankruptcy of Dana, a 102-year-old auto parts maker, gives Ford, General Motors and other American automakers a taste of their own medicine. Danas woes reflect the constant pressure from automakers for lower prices and more flexible payment terms, which have been crushing one parts maker after another.

title: Enron Executive Points Finger at Former Chiefs
description: More than four years after Enron collapsed into bankruptcy and its name became synonymous with corporate scandal, the three men most associated with that fall gathered in a federal courtroom Tuesday and prepared to wage war.

title: MGM Said to Make Movie Distribution Deals
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is expected to announce on Wednesday several new agreements to distribute movies made by other producers, according to several people apprised of the announcement. MGM, owned by a consortium of media companies and private equity investors, is holding a news conference on Wednesday to discuss its plans and is portraying the new relationships as a reinvigoration of MGM. Under the agreements, they said, MGM will distribute movies made by the Weinstein Company; Bauer Martinez Entertainment; and Lakeshore Entertainment, which recently had hits with Underworld: Evolution and The Exorcism of Emily Rose.

title: Continental Resources Files for IPO
description: Continental Resources, an oil and gas company, filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday to raise up to $575 million in an initial public offering of stock. The lead underwriters for the offering are J.P. Morgan and Merrill Lynch.

title: Former Los Angeles Mayor to Run Housing Investment Fund
description: Former Los Angeles Mayor James K. Hahn is taking charge of a planned $800 million investment fund designed to help expand affordable housing and other real estate development projects for the city.

title: Designer Rent-a-Bag Firm Puts $8.25 Million in Its Purse
description: With designer-handbag rental company Bag Borrow Or Steal Inc., investors are betting that upscale, fashion-conscious women will spend hundreds of dollars a month to borrow the newest Gucci or Chanel purse.

title: Barclays Capital Names Asian Commodities Head
description: Barclays Capital has named Russell Norton in a new post of director and head of commodities for Asia, handling its planned growth in sales and trading. He will be based in Singapore.

title: Credit Agricole Says  Fourth-Quarter Profits Double
description: Credit Agricole, Frances biggest bank, said profit more than doubled in the fourth quarter as rising stock markets fueled earnings from fund management and investment banking.

title: Bon-Tons Shares Fall as  Deal for Stores from Saks Closes
description: Shares of Bon-Stores dipped on Tuesday, a day after the retailer closed on a $1.18 billion deal to purchase Carson Pirie Scott, Herbergers and Bergners stores from Saks Inc.

title: Linde Restructuring, Not BOC, Adds Value
description: Shares of Linde, the German conglomerate, have risen on the BOC takeover, even though it may be value-destructive. Why? Because Linde is gearing up and breaking itself up  which adds value. Linde has scrunched the lot together to sell investors the deal.

title: Googles New Ticker Symbol: OOPS
description: The Internets most closely watched company showed a bit too much leg last week. Google mistakenly posted internal financial projections on its Web site, the company said in a regulatory filing late Tuesday. Accidents happen, but this gaffe came barely a week after the search-engine heavyweight sought to clarify some not-so-rosy comments by its finance chief and ended up sowing even greater confusion over its prospects.

title: Wal-Mart Has Another Rival  in Bidding for Trust-Mart of China
description: Wal-Mart Stores and Carrefour may face a third challenger in the race to acquire Trust-Mart, one of Chinas leading retail chains. The Financial Times reports that Lianhua, the largest supermarket operator in China, has joined its United States and French rivals among the companies likely to submit preliminary bids for Trust-Mart by next weeks deadline. Trust-Mart is expected to fetch more than $1 billion.

title: Currents: London
description: Old friends must some day part, a fashion designer decides, for oven or table, the threads don't just lie there and more.

title: Personal Shopper
description: It's almost time for spring cleaning. Before rolling up your sleeves, take a look at some of this season's new tools.

title: Brothers in Orange
description: Doug and Gene Meyer's hot tropical style - their own version of Miami's flavors - quenches eyes parched from so many years of earnest good taste.

title: Samuelson: Wall the Border
Appaloosa Bets on Another Bankrupt Auto-Parts Maker
description: Hedge fund Appaloosa Partners may be positioning itself to stir things up in the bankruptcy of auto-parts maker Dana Corporation.

title: Englands Baby Problem
description: Madeleine Buntings thoughts on the ways in which a bias against having babies has permeated our culture is meant to apply to the culture of the United Kingdom, but her analysis in Londons Guardian of the phenomenon she calls anti-natalism seems perfectly applicable to the United States, even if U.S. birth rates are higher than Europes. (See, for example, this New Republic column by Katherine Marsh on how the wretched state of parenthood has become the story du jour. [$])

title: Easy Money Makes For a Bankers Paradise
description: Whether it is in the form of equity, high-yield bonds or leveraged loans, there is plenty of liquidity sloshing around the markets these days. The result, according to The Financial Times Lex column, is a kind of harmonic convergence for the financing of mergers and acquisitions. The abundance of options oils the machinery of deal-making and makes it easier for buyers and sellers to reach agreement.

title: With Exchange I.P.O.s, Who Needs Dot-Com Stocks?
description: As shares of NYSE Group pop out of the gate, we were interested to get the following numbers from Sandler ONeill & Partners showing the fantastic returns booked by exchanges that went public in recent years.

title: Analysis: Are VNUs Shareholders Right to Object?
description: VNUs agreement to sell itself for $9 billion to a consortium of private equity firms already has some shareholders irate. Fidelity International, one of its biggest shareholders, said Wednesday it was unlikely to support this offer, and Knight Vinke Asset Management, which controls about 2 percent of VNU, said it intends to reject the offer. And they may have good reason to kvetch. Some analysts have estimated that VNU is worth 30 to 35 euros per share, rather than the 28.50 the company accepted.

title: Nuclear Acceptance Is Hard to Come By
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans March 8 column, Letting India in the Club?

title: Bush Visits Gulf Coast
description: President Bush, visiting the Gulf Coast, said Wednesday that Congress must help this ravaged city recover from Hurricane Katrina by approving billions he has requested for levee repair and compensation for Louisianans who lost home

title: Directors Need Golden Parachutes, Too
description: Top executives regularly cash in when their companies get acquired thanks to change in control provisions in their contracts. But Michelle Leder of Footnoted.org notes that directors are getting into the act as well. Her examples come from the proxy statements of Dover Motorsports and Dover Downs Gaming and Entertainment, two companies controlled by Henry Tippie.

title: Looking for Flash, Micron Tech Picks Up Lexar
description: Micron Technology, the memory chip maker, plans to buy  Lexar Media in a stock swap, pushing further into the market for so-called flash memory chips used in portable consumer gadgets. Micron shares were down about 2 percent Wednesday afternoon, putting the value of the transaction at $672 million.

title: U.S. Joins Fraud Suit Against Mario Gabelli
description: Mario Gabellis legal troubles turned more serious on Wednesday when the Justice Department said it would join a civil fraud lawsuit against the famed money manager. The five-year-old private suit alleges that Mr. Gabelli, whose investment prowess has earned him the nickname Super Mario on Wall Street, created sham companies to bid for cellphone licenses at a series of Federal Communications Commission auctions between 1995 and 2000.

title: Big Board, Big Pop: NYSE Notches 25% First-Day Jump
description: Shares of the NYSE Group got a warm welcome Wednesday as the company formed from the New York Stock Exchanges historic merger with Archipelago Holdings made its debut as a publicly owned enterprise.

title: Martha and Rufus Wainwright | Musicians
description: For most kids, getting dressed is a chore. For Martha Wainwright, having a brother made it easier. We spent a lot of time dressing up as children, says Martha, pictured here in Rufuss Yves Saint Laurent pants and a top from Topshop. Adds Rufus, I used to dress her up when she was about 6 and parade her down the street. The singing siblings inherited an eclectic style sense from their musician parents, Kate McGarrigle and Loudon Wainwright III. But even with such a pedigree, they found that putting together looks for this shoot was double the trouble. Rufus stuck to very, very tight jeans by Diesel, a bracelet by Subversive Jewelry and a necklace by Julianna Raye Designs, because thats how he feels most at ease. Martha, who is most comfortable in big sweaters and underwear, went with something less expected. He was more prepared, she says, but hes got a lot more clothes than I do.

title: Stella Tennant | Model, Mother
description: Forget the Scottish countryside and all her wellies: Stella Tennant likes to look slick now and then. It helps that, working as a model for nearly 15 years, she has cultivated enough relationships to make picking up designer freebies her modus operandi. She also goes for a good afternoons worth of shopping at the Dover Street Market, where she found the shoes pictured here. For this photo session, at the Milestone Hotel in London, she also wore a YSL silk shirt and Dior jacket and trousers. I wear this when Im trying to look smart, she says, when Im turning up to work and want to look the part. Work includes a design consulting job with Burberry, balanced between motherly duties (she has four children). Tennant, in other words, has a flexible style. It changes with requirement, she says. One thing remains a constant, however: Her socks are always Turnbull & Asser.

title: The Wisdom of Crowds?
description: How else does one interpret the results of an L.A. Times/Bloomberg poll on what Americans think will happen to their real estate?

title: More on That Inverted Rate Curve
Nothing is Automatic
description: The Boy in the Big Housing Bubble is showing his annoyance over on his blog about the appearances this week of David Bach on the CBS Morning Show as he promotes his book, The Automatic Millionaire Homeowner. Ive commented on this book before, but Boy made some choice comments:

title: Is There a Silver Lining?
description: Paul L. Kasriel, the director of economic research at Northern Trust Company in Chicago, disagrees with David Leonhardts thesis that a declining real estate market isnt always a bad thing for a home owner. (Read Davids provocative thesis in the New York Times here or read his blog posting about it here.)

title: Real Estate Agent Excuse No. 43
description: A tip of the hat to the Seattle Bubble blog for finding this gem in the local newspaper:

title: The Effects of Slow Growth
description: The L.A. Times took a look at the growth-inhibiting policies of Santa Barbara, Calif., and didnt come up with anything too surprising. Just this:

title: They Call It Times Square... (2006)
description: For the final time, David Carr (a k a The Carpetbagger) goes to Times Square to share his thoughts on the end of the movie awards season. (Producer: Shayla Harris)

title: Video: They Call It Times Square for a Reason
description: For the final time (this Oscar season, at least), David Carr (a k a The Carpetbagger) goes to Times Square to on the end of the movie awards season. .

title: Go to War. Do Art.
description: Im a warrant officer-1 in the United States Marine Corps Reserve. Warrant officers are hybrids, not fully commissioned officers, and although drawn exclusively from the non-commissioned officer ranks, no longer enlisted marines. We are by and large the duty experts in a particular field; think of us as consultants. I am a combat artist for the Marines; a Winslow Homer in camouflage. I work directly for the Historical Division of the Marine Corps University and my orders from them are simple. Go to war. Do art. My output goes into The Marine Corps Combat Art Collection, which houses over 8,000 works of art. I think Ive got the best job in the military.

title: Errors in SAT Scores Raise Questions About Testing Company
description: The scoring errors disclosed this week on thousands of the College Board's SAT tests were made by a company that is one of the largest players in the exploding standardized testing business, handling millions of tests each year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REEVE, DANA
description: REEVE--Dana. The Miami Project to Cure Paralysis and The Buoniconti Fund deeply mourn the death of our beloved friend Dana Reeve, (wife of the late Christopher Reeve), a great inspiration to all of us in the fight against paralysis. Marc Buoniconti, the International Ambassador of The Miami Project, who himself was paralyzed in a football accident, said recently; "Every time I saw Dana she was always so full of life, very dynamic and charismatic. Any time she walked into a room it really lit up." Last April they lobbied together on Capitol Hill for increased federal funding for spinal cord injury research. Marc added, "We have a real opportunity to honor both Dana and Christopher by increasing pressure on lawmakers to pass a bill that would significantly increase funding for research. In doing that we can help fulfill the promise Dana made to Chris, which was the same as the one my dad made to me when I was first injured in 1985, to find a cure for paralysis." Our love and sympathy goes out to Dana and Christopher's son Will. We know that his parent's legacy will live on in him.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about funeral homes in Serbia that pay medical personnel for tips about possible customers misspelled the name of a city in Poland where there was a scandal over a similar scheme in 2002. It is Lodz, not Zodz.

title: Bush Signs Bill Renewing Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 A President Bush signed a bill today renewing the antiterrorism measure known as the USA Patriot Act at an upbeat White House ceremony that belied the bill's tortured history.

title: Arts, Briefly; Ne-Yo Is at No. 1; Johnny Cash Is Climbing
description: Propelled by the hit single "So Sick" on "In My Own Words" (Def Jam), the debut album by the R&B singer Ne-Yo, left, captured the No. 1 spot on the Billboard chart this week, with 301,000 sales, the biggest weekly sales for any album this year. From there, it's a big drop: the "High School Musical" soundtrack, on Disney, sold 128,000, and "If Only You Were Lonely" (Victory) by Hawthorne Heights, an Ohio rock band that has built a big following online, reached No. 3 with 114,000. The country star Alan Jackson is at No. 4 with his new "Precious Memories" (Arista). In the days leading to the Oscars, two Johnny Cash-related albums had significant sales boosts: "The Legend of Johnny Cash" (Universal), a retrospective, sold 80,000 copies, a weekly increase of 88 percent that sent it to No. 6, and the soundtrack on Wind-Up Records to the film "Walk the Line," for which Reese Witherspoon won best actress as June Carter Cash, rose 34 spots to No. 11. BEN SISARIO

title: Dispute closes enclave's borders
Fashion Goes West
description: SO "Brokeback Mountain" did not win the All-Around Champion award at the Oscar rodeo after all, despite odds in its favor. Its upset on Sunday is the stuff of cowboy legend, if not quite the Alamo. But the movie can lay claim to an achievement that no other film of 2005 can. With its representation of two plain cowboys who fell in love in plain old Western wear, it hit the fashion bull's-eye. Cowboy boots, snap-button shirts and big ol' belt buckles -- standards that have come and gone several times before -- are striding back into style.

title: G.O.P. Senators Say Accord Is Set on Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 - Moving to tamp down Democratic calls for an investigation of the administration's domestic eavesdropping program, Republicans on the Senate Intelligence Committee said Tuesday that they had reached agreement with the White House on proposed bills to impose new oversight but allow wiretapping without warrants for up to 45 days.

title: Bomb kills at least 9 people in Baghdad
Richard Kuklinski, 70, a Killer of Many People and Many Ways, Dies
description: Richard Kuklinski, whose lust for publicity nearly matched the blood lust he displayed in claiming to have killed more than 100 people as a Mafia hit man, died on Sunday in the prison wing of St. Francis Hospital in Trenton. He was 70.

description: When Canon transformed the popular 20D digital single-lens-reflex camera into the 30D, a new model that will be available next month, it did not surprise anyone by adding some advanced features from the company's higher-priced professional cameras. But the 30D also includes some features for users who are not highly trained pros.

description: WASHINGTON, March 8 - Facing accusations that lawmakers are not serious about breaking the tight bond between Capitol Hill and K Street, the Senate voted Wednesday to bar members of Congress and their aides from accepting gifts and meals from lobbyists.
