description: GENDER differences are a topic of endless discussion for parents, teachers and social scientists. The only place where they cannot be talked about seems to be Harvard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VILLAMENA, DR. ANTHONY
description: VILLAMENA--Dr. Anthony. Died on March 6, 2006 after a brief battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Cean Tillett Villamena, adored father of Vincenzo and Nicola, and dear brother of Dr. Diodato Villamena and wife, Karen. A dedicated psychiatrist, he was a fellow of the American Psychiatric Association, and past president of the Psychiatric Society of Westchester. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Friends School, New York University and New York Medical School. With a passion to help others, Tony was president of the Parish Council at Holy Family Church, he built homes in the U.S. and Mexico with Habitat for Humanity, and spread his love to everyone he touched. He will be deeply missed. Visitation on Thursday, 2-4 & 7-9 at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle. Mass will be celebrated Friday, 9:30 AM Holy Family Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Children in Torment
description: Two little boys -- toddlers in Yonkers -- died horrible deaths last July when they were left alone in a bathroom with scalding water running in the tub. The water overflowed and flooded the room. The children, in agony, were unable to escape as the water burned and blistered their feet and ankles and kept on rising. One of the boys struggled to save himself by standing on his toes, but to no avail.

title: A Baseball Tragedy
description: Any major league baseball career is a race for immortality, one that most players lose. The goal is to accumulate championships and Hall of Fame statistics before being forced off the field by injuries and age. It means having the right combination of talent, luck and perseverance, something that is easily said and hardly ever done.

title: Sounds of Politics: Clashing Themes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORFIT, SUZANNE T.
description: MORFIT--Suzanne T. Beloved friend, colleague, teacher, passed away in her sleep March 5, 2006. She grew up in Hartsdale, NY and Green Village, NJ. Educated at Seton Hall University and Rutgers University, she served the Bellmore-Merrick Long Island School System for 30 years as a social worker, specializing in treatment of at-risk adolescents and training other professionals in this critical area. A gifted, empathic psychotherapist, she touched many lives. Taken from us too soon, she will be missed and mourned, her legacy given to those she helped. Memorial services Saturday, March 25, 11AM at Marymount College, NYC.

title: The Many Faces of Every Family
description: With a Long Island whine and an alarm-clock laugh, Bev, one of the five family members lovingly realized by Sherry Glaser in "Family Secrets," which she wrote with her late husband, Greg Howells, comes off like your typical Jewish mother joke. She's the kind of woman who says that her nervous breakdown was perfectly timed because her husband, an accountant named Mort, had "Major Medical."

It was during seventh-inning renditions of "God Bless America," not during the national anthem before games.

description: THE dozen parents who met over coffee Tuesday morning at the Columbus Bakery on the Upper West Side had that look about them, the grim look of people who suddenly realized that they couldn't trust the solidity of the ground beneath their feet.

title: For Oven or Table (Careful: It's Hot)
description: Sophie Conran, the daughter of Terence Conran, said she designed tableware in her head for years and wanted to create something that looked as good in the kitchen as in the dining room. Her collection of porcelain tableware and accessories for Portmeirion, a British company (www.portmeirion.com), will be available in the United States in June, at $15 to $60. The pieces, in white, celadon and a creamy tan called "biscuit," include nesting bowls and a mortar and pestle, inset right. Ms. Conrad, 40, above with her two children and a friend, said her background as the owner of a pie company and as a working mother inspired her to make pieces that move from the freezer to the oven to the table. Store locations: (212) 889-3535. CURRENTS: LONDON -- KITCHENWARE

description: Rodney Strong, who left behind a career as a professional dancer to pioneer the mass production of fine wines in Sonoma County, died Sunday in Healdsburg, Calif. He was 78.

description: FURNITURE and rugs designed by the Meyers, bearing the label Doug & Gene, are sold at NiBa Home, a boutique in the Miami design district owned by Nisi Berryman and Beth Arrowood. Doug Meyer is the store's design director. The Meyers's square red Positano drink stand ($650) with a red Botero stool by James Duncan.

description: The Bloomberg administration acknowledged yesterday that its innovative agreement to let Snapple sell beverages in city-owned buildings in exchange for cash and tourism promotion had fallen far short of its goals, with the company failing badly to meet its sales targets since the deal began nearly two years ago.

description: LOPEZ--Virginia L. (nee Kehoe) on March 8, 2006. Graduate of St. Josephs College, Brooklyn and NYU Graduate School. NYC Board of Education teacher. Beloved wife of 55 years to Eugene R. Devoted mother of Eugene (Mary), Joseph (Arleen), Mary Lopez, Thomas (Donna), Margaret (James) Walker, Teresa (Thomas) Finlon, Loretta (Paul) Gomez. Proud grandmother of 16 grandchildren. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9 at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 10AM at St. Anselms R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers donations in Virginia's name to Calvary Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

description: Last week, I blogged about an article that describes how you can preserve snowflakes (essentially entombing them in transparent SuperGlue).

description: WASHINGTON, March 8 - The House Appropriations Committee defied President Bush on Wednesday evening, voting overwhelmingly to scuttle a deal giving a Dubai company control of some major seaport operations without awaiting the outcome of a 45-day review of potential security risks.

title: Bond Is Set at $25 Million in KPMG Tax Shelter Case
description: A federal judge granted bail yesterday to a former KPMG partner, David Greenberg, who is awaiting trial for selling questionable tax shelters, even as the judge blasted him over what he called secret partnerships full of ill-gotten gains.

title: Til Death Do They Part: Giambi and Bonds
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 8 - It may never end. Jason Giambi understands that now. Even after a vague apology, an award for comeback player of the year and the attempted restoration of his public image, Giambi remains tethered to Barry Bonds and the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative steroids scandal, though he is not the primary subject of the discussion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUCKERMAN, NAT
description: ZUCKERMAN - Nat. Dear friend and fellow racegoer, you were always a winner. Rest easy, Dennis

title: Robert J. Dryfoos, 63, Former Councilman, Dies
description: Robert J. Dryfoos, who played a critical role in the fight to save Radio City Music Hall from demolition and then represented the Upper East Side on the City Council for 11 years, died on March 2 at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. He was 63.

title: Briefly: Hostage standoff ends at French high school
The 411 on Directory Assistance
description: Calling 411 for directory assistance can be maddeningly expensive. Carriers like Sprint and Verizon charge more than $1 and sometimes as much as $2 a call from a cellphone..

title: Office space goes Hollywood
Bawdy Stand-Up in Wigs and Silk Britches (No Glossary Needed)
description: Smut has been around forever. No doubt naughty things were once scrawled on the walls of dank grottoes, inspiring snickers from cave men with low comic tastes, pained smiles from their more refined brethren. But as centuries pass, the language of the dirty joke and the lewd pun evolves, obscuring the ribaldry. Footnotes become necessary. Fun is spoiled.

title: Olmert Wants to Set Israeli-Palestinian Border by 2010
description: JERUSALEM, March 9 A Israel's acting prime minister, Ehud Olmert, said that if his Kadima Party wins national elections this month, he would seek to set Israel's permanent borders by 2010, and that the boundary would run along or close to Israel's separation barrier in the West Bank.

title: Owners In N.F.L. Accept Labor Deal
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex., March 8 - N.F.L. owners voted Wednesday night to accept a players union proposal to extend the collective bargaining agreement by six years, ensuring labor peace in the league through the 2011 season. The vote was 30 to 2, with the Cincinnati Bengals and the Buffalo Bills voting against it.

title: Malpractice Claims Rose Against New York City Last Year
description: Medical malpractice claims against city-run hospitals and other municipal health care providers rose last year for the first time in five years, and cost taxpayers about $145 million in settlements and judgments, according to preliminary data compiled by the City Comptroller's Office.

description: A Fashion Diary article last Thursday, about the reality show "Project Runway," misspelled the given name of a contestant. She is Zulema Griffin, not Zulena.

Vietnam and Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, an Escape From Stifling Cubicles and a Clueless Boss
description: The fact that America's baby Einsteins cruise through superenriched childhoods and rockin' luxury college years only to land in the stifling taupe of office cubicles in the prime of their lives is the master joke at the center of Office Pirates, a new entertainment emporium for men. Office Pirates, a Time Inc. Web site that first appeared on Feb. 22, is the cherished venture of Mark Golin, lad leader and former editor of Maxim and Details. Mr. Golin's boisterous sensibility is expected to attract ads for cars, liquor, food and girls. Or not girls, because you can't buy girls, but definitely the others.

title: As UN ponders Iran case, U.S. presses for sanctions
Soldiering On as World War II Winds Down
description: Set in Italy during the final weeks of World War II, "The Fallen" unfolds from the viewpoints of three groups of soldiers: German occupiers running low on numbers, food and patience; Italian reinforcements who resent the Germans' superior attitudes and equipment; and Americans struggling to differentiate among Fascist soldiers, Communist partisans and German spies.

title: On Deck for Bonds: Congress, U.S. Court, I.R.S.?
description: WHEN Barry Bonds was asked Tuesday to comment on the new book that details his alleged use of steroids for at least five seasons from 1999 to 2003, during which he hit 34, 49, 73, 46 and 45 home runs, he snapped: "I won't even look at that. For what? There's no need to."

title: Investigators Point to Images of Relics as a Smoking Gun
description: ROME, March 8 - As before-and-after images go, the slide projected in a darkened courtroom here on Wednesday was striking. On the left, two dirt-encrusted fragments of a terra-cotta figure, one of them darkened by smoke; on the right, a complete version of the figure, a dancing woman and satyr that was once part of a roof ornament of an ancient Etruscan building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARABEDIAN, CLAIRE
description: GARABEDIAN--Claire, a resident of Larchmont, died at White Plains Hospital on March 7, 2006 following her heroic battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Peter. Loving mother of Jennifer and David. Devoted daughter of Simon and the late Esther Dreilinger. Dear sister of Phyllis Sloate. Funeral Service Friday 10:30 AM at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY 10538. Interment at Wellwood Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to any cancer related charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKMANN, SELIG
description: BECKMANN--Selig. The officers, board, and members of Temple Emanu-El of Lynbrook record with great sorrow the death of our cherished past president. We extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Andrew Trevers, Pres Rabbi Scott Corngold

title: New Polish Chief a Skeptic on Integrated Europe
description: BERLIN, March 8 - When Poland was negotiating its entry to the European Union, its diplomats indicated that joining a politically integrated Europe was the best way to protect national interests. This belief in the power of community was shared by the other aspiring countries from the former Soviet bloc, which as a group greatly expanded the union in May 2004.

title: In New York, 3 New Spots
description: Shecky's, the media company that publishes beauty and shopping guides and is the host of a recurring shopping party "Girls Night Out," has opened its first store in SoHo, below, featuring more than 40 mini-boutique spaces. The offerings now include accessories by Kudra, Jody Singleton and Staci Schubert; handbags by Marie Elanne and Cammiehill; jewelry by Subversive Jewelry and T. Ross; housewares and gifts by Salontea by Tracy Stern; swimwear by Poko Pano; beauty products by Posh and Juara; and clothing by David Rodriguez, e.vil, Salt Works and Boiy Krazi. But the cast of designers will change continually. At 489 Broome Street, between West Broadway and Wooster Street, (212) 343-0100.

title: 2 Police Officers Accused of Taking Bribes From Brothel
description: It's one of the oldest forms of police corruption: taking money to look the other way. And that's what the two veteran police officers were doing in Flushing, Queens, federal authorities said today A they looked the other way while a bustling brothel brought in more than $1 million a year from customers who streamed in from shiny late-model cars double-parked outside.

title: Iraq not in civil war, Rumsfeld maintains
Paid Notice: Deaths   IRVANI, RAHIM MOTTAGHI
description: IRVANI--Rahim Mottaghi, 86. Died at home in London on March 3, 2006. He will be missed by his wife Zinat; his daughters and sons-in-law Nezhat and Hassan Khosrowshahi, and Maryam and Vahid Alaghband; his son and daughter-in-law Bahman and Roya Irvani; sons Ali, Abbass, Abdulrahim, Behnam, Faramarz, Farhad, Fariborz, Farshad, Farzad, Farzan, Hassan, Kamal, Kourosh, Massoud, Mohammad, Mohammad - Hassan, Nourollah, Saeed, Shadab, Shademan, and Shahram; his grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

title: China Returns Sharp Retort to U.S. Report on Human Rights
description: BEIJING, March 9 A China today criticized the human rights record of the United States, arguing that racial discrimination remained pervasive and that the American military abused prisoners held at detention centers abroad.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Man Sentenced For Illegal Plane Flight
description: A student pilot from Connecticut was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison for taking a plane on a joyride from Danbury, Conn., to the Westchester County Airport in June 2005. The pilot, Philippe Patricio, 21, pleaded guilty to reckless endangerment, unauthorized use of a vehicle and resisting arrest, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Prosecutors said Mr. Patricio, while intoxicated, took two 16-year-old passengers on an early morning flight on June 22, 2005, landing in Westchester when the single-engine plane began to run out of gas. The airport was closed when the plane landed, about 4:40 a.m., and no one was injured.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Arts, Briefly; Lower Manhattan Grants Receive Praise
description: At a news conference yesterday at which more than $27 million in grants to cultural and civic groups in Lower Manhattan were officially announced, Gov. George E. Pataki's chief of staff, John P. Cahill, said the grants would help "make sure Lower Manhattan is, in fact, not just a financial capital of the world, but a cultural capital of the world." John C. Whitehead, chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which will administer the grants, said to the many cultural groups present at the National Museum of the American Indian, a recipient, "Sorry none of you got more than you got, but our funds were limited." The grants, which ranged from $200,000 to $2 million, went to 63 organizations. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARKS, GORDON
description: PARKS - Gordon was so much to so many people, he became an Icon of his time. He was a beloved figure of multiple talents, but at ICP we knew him principally as a photographer. Cornell Capa included him with seven other photographers in his book "The Concerned Photographer II" published in 1972. We hosted a solo exhibition of his work in 1975, and included his work in exhibitions in 1974, 1983, 1988, 1989, 1993, 2003-2005. His spirit, his drive, his passion will inform our lives for as long as we can remember, and for that we are humbled and grateful. We express our sorrow at his passing, but venture to say that he will always be with us in his dignity and in his ability to connect with and express the human soul. Willis Hartshorn, Director Cornell Capa, Founding Director Emeritus For the Staff and Board of the International Center of Photography

title: Marketers Follow the Flock to Spring Break
description: MARKETING to students on spring break used to be simple: a company would set up a stand on the beach, hand out product samples and let the message spread itself.

title: Selig Puts Bonds and Book Under Further Review
description: PHOENIX - BUD SELIG, the baseball commissioner, sat in a room in the bowels of Chase Field facing dozens of reporters and cameras. The World Baseball Classic game between the United States and Canada was scheduled to start in about half an hour, but here was Selig trapped in a room answering questions about Barry Bonds and steroids.

title: Corzine Admits Error in Lending Ex-Aide $5,000 for Her Bail
description: TRENTON, March 8 - Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Wednesday that he made a mistake when he lent $5,000 in bail money to a Trenton lobbyist and former campaign aide who had been arrested for stalking the new chairman of the state Democratic Party.

Paid Notice: Deaths   AMORY, HARCOURT
description: AMORY--Harcourt, 82. Of Vero Beach, FL. Formerly of New York City and Pound Ridge, NY, March 1, 2006. Survived by his devoted wife, Jean Moore Amory, and their children Dita Amory Nickson, Jean Trudeau Fenn, Garry Trudeau, Michelle Trudeau and six grandchildren. Previously married to Dita Naylor-Leyland. Born in Beverly, MA. He attended Brooks School and Harvard University. Served in the American Field Service, British Eighth Army, and OSS during WWII. Services on Saturday, March 11, 2006, 11 A.M. at Saint Mark's Anglican Church in Vero Beach, FL. Contributions may be sent to the Indian River Memorial Hospital Foundation, 1000 36th Street, Vero Beach, Florida 32960, or Saint Mark's Anglican Church, P.O. Box 6994, Vero Beach, Florida 32961.

title: Sounds of Politics: Clashing Themes (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Both Sides of Inequality
description: For the past two decades, Annette Lareau has embedded herself in American families. She and her researchers have sat on living room floors as families went about their business, ridden in back seats as families drove hither and yon.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: W.H.O. Chief Warns On Bird Flu
description: Dr. Jong Wook Lee, the director general of the World Health Organization, urged African leaders to report quickly any suspected cases of avian flu and to resist the impulse to keep an outbreak quiet. "The lesson from SARS is you don't gain anything from sitting on the problem," he said during an interview in Kenya, the third stop on a tour of Africa, where the A(H5N1) strain of bird flu has been confirmed in Egypt, Nigeria and Niger, with several other countries investigating suspected outbreaks. "Three countries means it has arrived," he said. Africa will face a particular challenge because of the weak health infrastructure and the proliferation of what Dr. Lee called "backyard flocks" rather than industrialized poultry farms. In order to control outbreaks, governments must create funds to compensate farmers for their destroyed chickens, he said. As he has during other recent trips, Dr. Lee ate chicken to reinforce the message that they remain safe if cooked properly.

title: Suddenly, a Rebellion in theG.O.P. on a Signature Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 - After more than five years of allowing President Bush relatively free rein to set their course, Republicans in Congress are suddenly, if selectively, in rebellion, a mutiny all the more surprising since it centers on the party's signature issue of national security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOKOLOW, RUTH
description: SOKOLOW--Ruth. Ruth, a close relative and dear friend. We mourn your passing but know your children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren will always remember you with lots of love. May you rest in peace. Shirley and Harold Leviton

Pursuing a Famed Assassin at a Screenplay-Style Pace
description: Manhunt The 12-Day Chase for Lincoln's Killer By James L. Swanson 448 pages. William Morrow. $26.95.

title: A TV Game Device Expands the Action With Remote Controls for Up to 6 Players
description: Board games come to your TV screen with the ZAPiT Game Wave, a souped-up DVD player that is designed to receive signals from as many as six remote controls simultaneously. Every member of the family can have an equal chance to win points, by guessing the name of a famous prison on the Hudson (Sing Sing) or the name of the giant English passenger ship sunk in 1915 by a German U-boat (the Lusitania).

title: New York Asks Help From Poor in Housing Crisis
description: The New York City Housing Authority, landlord to more than 400,000 poor New Yorkers, is facing a budget shortfall of $168 million and has proposed narrowing the gap by charging residents new fees and increasing old ones for everything from owning a dishwasher to getting a toilet unclogged.

title: Tsegaye Gabre-Medhin, Ethiopian Poet Laureate, Dies at 69
description: Tsegaye Gabre-Medhin, an acclaimed Ethiopian playwright who was also the country's poet laureate, died on Feb. 25 in Manhattan, where he had lived since 1998. He was 69.

title: Trying to Turn Elaine Into Christine
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif. - Julia Louis-Dreyfus, who is starring in a new CBS comedy called "The New Adventures of Old Christine," sat before a roomful of television critics at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Pasadena in January. Confronted with questions about whether she was a victim of the " 'Seinfeld' Curse" -- which refers to the lack of success she, Michael Richards and Jason Alexander have had since "Seinfeld" ended its ratings-topping, award-winning 10-year run in 1998 -- she wittily deflected them.

title: Fastow Testifies Lay Knew of Enron's Problems
description: HOUSTON, March 8 - Andrew S. Fastow, the onetime chief financial officer of Enron, provided some of the strongest evidence yet linking Kenneth L. Lay, the company's founder and former chief executive, to a conspiracy to defraud investors. But Mr. Fastow's statements, coming in the sixth week of the trial of Mr. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, another former chief executive, were almost lost under a searing cross-examination by Daniel Petrocelli, Mr. Skilling's lead lawyer.

title: Who's Minding the Neighborhood? The Neighbors Are
description: Donnybrook Quarter, a two-month-old residential complex in East London, is an exercise in creating safe streets and grounds. Built for about $9 million by a nonprofit association, the block-size complex includes 37 residential units and 3 living and working spaces, each on a street and each with windows overlooking an enclosed T-shaped pedestrian zone. Watched over by residents, the area is designed to be a "vibrant and colorful" meeting place, said Peter Barber, the architect (peterbarberarchitects.com). The buildings are painted white to reflect light between them. Twenty-seven residential units, priced from about $310,000, have sold since January, and eight units are being rented. Don't look for parking spaces: there are none. Information: www.circleanglia.org. ROBERT SUCH CURRENTS: LONDON -- HOUSING

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Meadow: County Health Agency Starts Bailout Work
description: The Nassau Health Care Corporation began devising a new plan yesterday to solve its financial troubles. The agency, which runs a public hospital and nursing home, faces a 60-day deadline from the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, to produce the plan and qualify for $98 million in bailout aid. The agency's board welcomed Mr. Suozzi's former fiscal deputy, Arthur A. Gianelli, as its new chief operating officer. It also reaffirmed support of the agency's president, Daniel A. Kane, denying rumors that he might leave. Underscoring the need for the financial plan, the latest monthly report showed a $2.2 million deficit in January.

title: Labels Halt Downloads to Increase CD Sales
description: LOS ANGELES, March 8 - As blockbuster hits go, the R&B smash "So Sick" is hardly new territory for the 23-year-old singer known as Ne-Yo. Before crooning the song on his own album, he was a co-writer on the 2004 chart-buster "Let Me Love You" for the singer Mario.

Atlanta Jury to Decide Case of Former Mayor
description: ATLANTA, March 8 - After a seven-year investigation at City Hall that has already led to the convictions of 10 people, a jury will now decide whether former Mayor Bill Campbell was at the center of that corruption.

description: MUSCLE soreness is a great equalizer. Both regular exercisers and fitness newbies can be plagued by postworkout aches if their muscles "are not conditioned enough, not warmed up enough or not iced after exercise," said Dr. Jordan Metzl, who practices sports medicine at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan.

title: Rape and Kidnapping Cases May Offer Clues in Killing
description: The investigation into the death of a 24-year-old graduate student who was murdered and dumped in Brooklyn widened yesterday as detectives searched for links to at least three unsolved rape and kidnapping cases in Queens and on Long Island, officials in both jurisdictions said.

title: Watch TV or Work, All on the Same Computer Monitor
description: A bit of entertainment can enliven long computer sessions, especially when the computer is grinding away at downloading or some other task. So quite a few computer monitors now include TV tuners that can switch between a full-screen TV picture and a small picture-in-picture (PiP) window at one corner of the screen.

title: The Threads Don't Just Lie There
description: Helen Amy Murray, 25, has become an "it" girl on the London design scene for her sculptural made-to-order fabrics. Describing her technique as a cross between quilting and appliqu -- she won't say how it's done -- Ms. Murray said she was inspired by traditional woodcarving in India. Her designs, with geometric patterns and natural motifs, include wool and cashmere fabrics for walls and upholstery. A three-dimensional printed polyester fleece, inset, is called Rose. One-of-a-kind decorative pieces include "Birds and Flowers," shown behind her, which she made by printing and shaping silk satin. Ms. Murray makes her fabrics by hand in a London studio and prices them from about $5,300 a square meter, a little larger than a square yard. Information: helenamymurray.com. CURRENTS: LONDON -- TEXTILES

title: Home After Serving in New Orleans
description: Most college students would shrug if they heard that a campus bus was on its way home from a field trip. But at the State University of New York Maritime College in the Bronx, students and administrators feel a deep connection to the Empire State VI, the school's 565-foot, 17,000-ton training ship, floating classroom and nautical mascot.

title: U.S. tries to show proof of Moussaoui as threat
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Money For Ground Zero Workers' Treatment
description: For the first time, the federal government is financing health care treatments for thousands of firefighters, police officers and other first responders sickened by their work at ground zero in the weeks after the attack on the twin towers. The Bush administration announced yesterday how it will disburse $75 million in health care funds it had attempted to rescind until members of New York's Congressional delegation objected. The money will go to several screening and treatment programs, including one at Mount Sinai Medical Center that has examined more than 10,000 workers and ground zero volunteers. The money will also help finance the Fire Department's medical treatment program, a Police Department mental health program and the city department of health's World Trade Center Health Registry.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday with an article about a wiretapping agreement between Republican senators and the White House misidentified two Republican senators walking with a third, Mike DeWine of Ohio. They were Christopher S. Bond of Missouri, at left with lapel pin, and Chuck Hagel of Nebraska in the center. (Senator DeWine, properly identified, was at right.) A credit was also omitted in those copies; the photographer was Michael Temchine for The New York Times.

title: Scientist Says He Stands by Fusion Data
description: A nuclear scientist at Purdue said yesterday that he would cooperate with the university's review of his fusion research. "From a technical point, we stand by our data," said the scientist, Rusi P. Taleyarkhan, a professor of nuclear engineering.

title: China Attacks Its Woes With an Old Party Ritual
description: BEIJING, March 8 - Like a giant company concerned with organizational disarray and a sinking public image, the Chinese Communist Party is trying to remake itself into an efficient, modern machine. But to do so, it has chosen one of its oldest political tools -- a Maoist-style ideological campaign, complete with required study groups.

title: Indian City Shaken by Temple Bombings
description: VARANASI, India, March 8 - Their hushed voices were drowned out by the howls of demonstrators. Just a stone's throw away lay the gory wreckage of Tuesday's temple blast.

Kurt Masur had heart palpitations in Dublin and is day to day for the London Philharmonic's concerts in the United States. Christoph von Dohnanyi was out of the lineup at the New York Philharmonic a week ago, but he was back in uniform last night. And in other good news, Plcido Domingo is off the injured list and back singing in "Cyrano de Bergerac" at the Metropolitan Opera. Sports fans, it has been a tough month.

description: WASHINGTON, March 8 - The plan by Senate Republicans to step up oversight of the National Security Agency's domestic surveillance program would also give legislative sanction for the first time to long-term eavesdropping on Americans without a court warrant, legal experts said on Wednesday.

title: Exporting Censorship
description: AMERICAN technology firms are taking heat from the public and Congress for helping China's government police the Internet. But this controversy extends well beyond China and the so-called Internet Gang of Four: Google, Yahoo, Cisco and Microsoft. Just how many American companies are complicit hit home for me last month when dozens of readers of BoingBoing.net e-mailed us to say they had been suddenly denied access.

description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 8 - Prosecutors seeking the death penalty for Zacarias Moussaoui played a videotaped statement on Wednesday in which a member of an Islamic radical group testified that Mr. Moussaoui visited him in Malaysia in 2000 and said he had a dream to fly an airplane into the White House.

title: Corrections

description: Frank Loesser's music for "The Most Happy Fella" is more complex, varied and inventive than the scores of quite a few 20th-century works that proudly call themselves operas. Yet Loesser never thought of the show, which opened on Broadway 50 years ago, as an opera. "It's a musical, with a lot of music," he said. Actually, there is not just a lot but almost continual music.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: State And City Unemployment Falls
description: New York City's unemployment rate continued to decline in January to 5.6 percent from 5.8 percent the month before, according to data released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. The statewide unemployment rate fell to 4.6 percent from 5.0 percent, and the number of New York City residents with jobs rose to 3.58 million, the highest level since the state began collecting such employment data in 1978. "More New Yorkers have jobs today than ever before, a clear sign our five-borough economic development strategy is working," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said in a statement.

description: PARIS - THE somber threads and veiled faces at the fall fashion collections that wrapped up on Sunday can be explained easily enough by reading the daily news. These are dark and mysterious times. Ergo, designers have retreated to a comfort zone of layered cocoons, as seen at Marc Jacobs, Prada and Undercover.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Franco' Art Questioned
description: A planned auction in Seville, Spain, has ignited a dispute over the amateur artistic endeavors of the Spanish dictator Gen. Francisco Franco (1892-1975), left. A Seville-based auction house, Arte, Informacin y Gestin, announced yesterday that it would start bidding at $10,755 for three oil paintings it believed had been executed by Franco. The paintings depict scenes of Morocco, where he began his military career, and were signed with the pseudonym Geron, said the auction house director, Carmen Aranguren. They were to be sold on April 5 in what was touted as the first auction of Franco's work. But a spokesman for his family contested the authenticity of the paintings yesterday, saying that Franco painted only flowers, still lifes and copies of works, never Moroccan landscapes. He did not use a pseudonym, either, the spokesman told the Europa Press news agency. The auction house has decided to withdraw the paintings from the block until it can verify the artist, Ms. Aranguren said in a telephone interview. DALE FUCHS

It did not win a national championship or help upset a ranked opponent, but it gave Syracuse what every team is looking for at this time of year: a reason to believe it will make the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Jewish Panel Delays a Vote on Gay Issues
description: A committee of legal experts who set policy for Conservative Judaism decided yesterday at a closed-door meeting in Baltimore to wait until December to vote on whether to lift the movement's ban on gay rabbis and same-sex union ceremonies.

description: BARKIN--Herbert L. Age 83 of Fairfield, CT previously of Harrison, NY, passed away peacefully in Fairfield on Tuesday, March 7. Dearest husband of Bunny Wiesenthal Barkin. Loving father of Joel L. and the late Paula Lee of Coral Springs, FL and Samuel and Madeleine of Rye Brook, NY. Devoted brother of Bernard L. and Barbara of Greenwich, CT. Beloved grandfather of Daniel and Jennifer of Coral Springs, FL and Robert and Allison of Royal Palm Beach, FL and Blake and Ashley of Rye Brook, NY. A selfless person he departed this life as he lived it with care and dignity. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, March 9th at 11:00 A.M. Congregation Beth El, 1200 Fairfield Woods Rd, Fairfield, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

description: WASHINGTON, March 9 A Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld told senators today that the United States would count on Iraqi security forces to quell an all-out civil war in their country, but that America's paramount goal is to prevent such a conflict in the first place.

Pataki's plan to give some families a tax credit for their children's education, Assembly Democrats have come up with their own proposal: a tax credit for every child in families earning up to $150,000 a year, according to lawmakers who were briefed on the proposal.

title: Steely Dan's Voice, Wry as Ever, if Less Sure
description: Those meticulous jazz-rockers Steely Dan built a career on seeming coolly unfazed. But the solo efforts of its principals, Donald Fagen and his snarkier counterpart, Walter Becker, prove what we all knew: that insouciant affect is usually the result of peer pressure. We can only be thankful that these two egged each other on to produce epics of yacht-rock detachment like "Rikki Don't Lose That Number," and "Deacon Blues."

Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMONS, GERTRUDE (MORIARITY)
description: SIMONS--Gertrude (Moriarity), 89. Of Tamarac, FL (formerly of Great Neck, NY) died Monday, March 6, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Simons of Superior Printing Ink Company. description: JERSEY CITY, March 9 A A 13-year-old girl who had been missing from Jersey City since Monday was found early this morning in Brooklyn after she called her mother from a payphone, the authorities here said.

title: Facing Facts on Iran
description: If reality bent to tough talk, Iran would have been forced to stop its uranium enrichment program a long time ago. The Bush administration sounded very stern this week in swatting down a tentative Russian attempt to work out a compromise with Tehran. Unfortunately, the depressing truth is that the United States has very few other options when it comes to making Iran stop working on projects that could lead to nuclear weapons, and Iran knows it.

description: Stocks ended the day narrowly mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rising slightly and the Nasdaq composite index declining. Shares of a New York Stock Exchange security rallied in its first regular day of trading.

description: As snow fell lightly on Broome Street in SoHo one evening last month, three women in their 40's sipped tea inside an artist's studio and charted a journey through unfamiliar territory. The landscape, viewed on an iMac monitor, was at once barren and lush, its undulating sands and craggy outcroppings morphing into gently rhythmic waves. It could have been anywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEVALT, SALLY YOUNG
description: GEVALT--Sally Young, 85. Died March 8 at Faulkner Hospital in Boston with her sons present. Gevalt, who practiced in Sharon, Conn. She is survived by her three sons, Frederick III of Arlington, Mass.; Peter of New York City; and Geoffrey of Hinesburg, VT.; and five grandchildren, Emelie, Peter Jr., Anna, Jake and Lily. A funeral service will be held Monday at 2 P.M. at St. John's Church in Salisbury, Conn. In lieu of flowers, those who wish are asked to send a donation to the Salisbury Ambulance Service in Salisbury, Connecticut.

title: Gotti Was Set to Lead Mob, His Lawyer Tells Court
description: Standing Mafia tradition on its head, John A. Gotti's lawyer declared in open court yesterday that Mr. Gotti was the "heir apparent" to the Gambino organized crime family in 1992, after his father, then the boss of the family, was sentenced to life in prison.

title: Cuban Player Has Moments Made for History
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 8 - Yuliesky Gourriel had his moments, his look-at-me, his bet-you-cannot-stop-watching-me moment for Cuba in the World Baseball Classic on Wednesday. Gourriel fashioned a series of magical moments, showing why he is the slickest player on a team that is usually shrouded in mystery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protests At Columbia Lecture
description: A historian who argues that Jewish organizations exploit the Holocaust to deflect criticism from Israel drew dozens of student protesters last night during his lecture at Columbia University. Norman Finkelstein, a DePaul University professor who is the son of Holocaust survivors, gave a talk titled "Israel and Palestine: Misuse of Anti-Semitism, Abuse of History." Some students in attendance quietly held up two-sided red signs that showed a picture of his face with a red heart, followed by the word "Hezbollah." They also handed out fliers outside. "We're angry because a lot of what Norman Finkelstein says is repugnant and is based in Jewish conspiracy theories that easily spin out of control into anti-Semitism," said Avery Katz, the vice president of LionPAC, a pro-Israel student group that helped coordinate the protest. The lecture was sponsored by 10 student groups. "I feel very glad that students who oppose the event are voicing their opposition and engaging in the dialogue," said Sakib Khan, 21, a Muslim Students Organization member who helped arrange the lecture. He said he hoped the event would stimulate conversation that had been stifled by last year's disputes between pro-Israel students and pro-Palestinian professors.

title: The Enduring Allure of Scratching on Metal
description: In the midst of printmaking's digital revolution, old-fashioned etching is having a revival as many contemporary artists turn to the techniques mastered over centuries by Drer, Rembrandt, Goya and Picasso.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia Opens Defense In Bosnia Genocide Case
description: In the first case in which one nation is accusing another of genocide, the International Court of Justice in The Hague began hearing the defense of Serbia in a lawsuit brought by Bosnia. At the court, which arbitrates disputes between nations, Bosnia is charging that Serbia tried to destroy Bosnia's Muslim population in the 1992-95 war, and it is suing for damages, not yet defined. For the past 10 days, Bosnia has argued its case. Serbia opened its defense by questioning that genocide had been committed and by challenging the jurisdiction of the court in the dispute.

title: Berlin Journal; Just a Rail Hub? Or a New Sort of Compass for Europe?
description: BERLIN, March 8 - Nobody in Berlin, it is safe to say, has failed to see it, the enormous construction site bristling with cranes in the middle of what used to be the desolate no man's land between the eastern and western halves of the city.

title: Bank of Japan scraps super-easy monetary policy
World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Soldiers Clash With Oil Protesters
description: Federal troops and striking oil workers clashed as the government of President Alfredo Palacio tried to control demonstrations that have cut production by the state-owned Petroecuador by about three-quarters. The day before, the government, which has frequently been battered by protests along Ecuador's oil-producing north, declared a state of emergency to revive the industry considered the country's economic lifeline.

title: Personal Shopper; For My Next Trick, The Dirt Will Disappear
description: IT'S almost time for spring cleaning. Before rolling up your sleeves, take a look at some of this season's new tools. Vacuum cleaners in permutations that evoke spaceships, robots and S.U.V.'s are vying to unseat the bagless Dyson, although in informal tests I found that few can claim its ease of handling and power (which is potentially hard on fragile long-haired rugs).

DeLay Revels in an Easy Primary Victory
description: HOUSTON, March 8 A Fresh from his rout of three challengers in the Republican primary on Tuesday, Representative Tom DeLay released a statement Wednesday headlined "DeLay Delivers an Old Fashioned Texas Whoopin'."Final figures from the Texas secretary of state's office gave Mr. DeLay 62 percent of the vote, a ratio of more than two to one over his closest rival, Tom Campbell, a lawyer, who received 29.9 percent. Two other contenders, Mike Fejtland, a lawyer, and Pat Baig, a teacher, received 4.6 percent and 3.3 percent, respectively. Mr. DeLay rolled up 20,558 votes. Mr. Campbell had 9,937; Mr. Fejtland, 1,550; and Ms. Baig, 1,115.

title: With an Ambitious Agenda, Homeland Security Chief Steers Clear of Fault-Finding
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 - Even by Washington's caffeinated standards, Michael Chertoff's to-do list is ambitious: cut illegal immigration, make ports, subways and chemical plants less vulnerable to terrorist attack and fix FEMA fast, because hurricane season starts in less than 90 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALB, KOMARIN, SHARON
description: KALB - KOMARIN - Sharon. With deepest sorrow we mourn the passing of this blue-eyed wonder, mother of Jenna, Zoe, and Wyatt. Wife of Gary, daughter of Judy and Morty Kalb, sister of Tom Kalb and Laurie Kalb Kaswiner, and daughter-inlaw of Francie Komarin. Sharon had a deep appreciation for the most elemental aspects of life, a no-nonsense 'look things in the eye' manner, and a true sense of commitment to her children and her husband in everything she did. Sharon was possessed of a terrific ear for language, and was working on a novel as well as several short stories at the time of her passing. She also collaborated on a childrens book with her husband, Gary, which will soon be published. We have in Sharon, a truly beautiful individual both physically and spiritually. We love you up to the sun and moon and stars for all time.

title: Faulty Screening of Truck Drivers Puts Ports at Risk, New Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 - The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is failing to properly screen truck drivers allowed onto port terminals, according to a new federal report that found that nearly half the drivers whose backgrounds were checked had possible criminal histories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEEDS, BEATRICE G. (NEE BETTE GORDON)
description: LEEDS--Beatrice G. (nee Bette Gordon). On March 7. Beloved wife of Norman. Most amazing mother and friend of Frederic G. Leeds and Patrice and Steve Leeds Richman. Cherished grandmother of Jessica and Hagan. Loving sister, aunt and friend. A celebration of her life will take place at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring Street, NYC, Friday, March 10, from 3-5 PM. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory, for ovarian and fallopian tube cancer research, to M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcomb Blvd., Houston, TX 77030 would be appreciated.

title: Bernard Malamud's Daughter Finally Tells His Secrets
description: MILTON, Mass. - In 1997, Janna Malamud Smith, daughter of the writer Bernard Malamud, published a book called "Private Matters" in which she argued for the importance of privacy in a culture of talk shows and tabloid journalism. Human dignity, Ms. Smith wrote, is based on shielding and protecting the deepest parts of the self from scrutiny. Moreover, the most important of human relationships are formed within the carapace of privacy.

title: Miami Design Duo, Sunny Side Up
description: MIAMI - ONE hot Saturday in February, the Meyer brothers were giving a visitor a long, slow tour of the new-new Miami, which, post-Wilma and in mid-boom, looked a lot like Beirut circa 1987, what with all the chewed-up palm trees, gaping lot holes and block-long piles of rubble. "They call that the Martyr of Biscayne," said Doug Meyer, 44, pointing out a little 1960's commercial building on Biscayne Boulevard that he said is about to feel the thwack of a wrecking ball.

description: GAZA - Ahmed al-Meghani, the Palestinian attorney general, has a large desk buried under stacks of pastel folders. It is the only way, he says, that he can keep track of his 52 separate investigations of suspected official corruption.

title: A London Judge Weighs the 'Code'
description: The author suing Random Housefor copyright infringement insistedyesterday in a London court that"fairly specific" similarities existedbetween his work and the Dan Brownnovel "The Da Vinci Code," but concededcertain differences, The AssociatedPress reported. "We werewriting historical conjecture, andMr. Brown was writing a novel," theauthor, Michael Baigent, testified.He and his co-author Richard Leighare suing Random House, the novel'spublisher in Britain. They maintainthat the best-selling Brown novel"appropriated the architecture" oftheir 1982 nonfiction book, "The HolyBlood and the Holy Grail." The judge,Peter Smith, said that the Brownnovel used some of the same materialas Mr. Baigent's book "and comesup with an entirely different plot,"then asked, "Are you saying theycan't do that?" Mr. Baigent replied,"No, I'm not, my lord." But, he said,Mr. Brown "used the results of ourhistorical conjecture without going through the steppingstones."

title: The Lawsuit Over Producer Credit for 'Crash' Gets Personal
description: LOS ANGELES, March 8 - The warm and fuzzy glow of an Oscar night surprise quickly faded as a top executive of the movie academy described one of the producing team behind the best-picture winner, "Crash," as throwing a tantrum in suing over credit for the film.

title: Looking for Depth at Quarterback, Jets Meet With Redskins' Ramsey
description: With Chad Pennington under contract for at least one more season, the Jets continued their quest to stabilize their quarterback spot yesterday, bringing in the Redskins' backup Patrick Ramsey for a visit.

Like Mark Morris leading the audience in karaoke, which already happened on Saturday -- sorry!

title: OPEC to Keep Output Near Maximum Levels
description: VIENNA, March 8 - OPEC said on Wednesday that it would keep pumping oil near its maximum levels in an effort that could cool down prices.

title: Two Brothers, Turning Ordinary Surfaces Into Gold
description: Ian and Richard Abell, 31-year-old twins, call themselves design alchemists. Their London company, Based Upon, works with architects and designers to produce elements like wall panels and flooring using a liquid metal that can be applied to almost any surface. (David Collins commissioned wall panels for the new Nobu Berkeley restaurant in London.) The company is the first in Europe to use this technique "with a contemporary aesthetic," said Richard Abell, at left below, with his brother. The company has also made stylized versions of furniture, like the Hara Chair by Giorgio Gurioli for Kundalini ($3,500), below, available in a bronze, antique silver or rust finish; www.basedupon.co.uk or 011-44-208-320-2122. CURRENTS: LONDON -- FURNISHINGS

title: Justice Dept. Report Cites F.B.I. Violations

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Union City: Police Seize Large Amount Of Heroin
description: Eight men were arrested on Monday and charged with various drug offenses after officers found nearly 28,000 bags of heroin in secret compartments inside several vehicles, Hudson County authorities announced yesterday. In a series of raids in Union City, Hoboken and North Bergen, narcotics officers seized 22,000 bags of heroin from a 2000 Ford Explorer and 5,000 bags of heroin from a 1998 Lincoln Navigator, said Edward J. DeFazio, the Hudson County prosecutor. Mr. DeFazio said the drugs were worth about $250,000.

A Note of Vintage Miles DavisFrom a Trumpeter's Ensemble
description: Miles Davis is considerably more than a touchstone for the trumpeter Wallace Roney. Through most of the 1980's, the endorsement and close guidance of Davis reinforced Mr. Roney's reputation as one of the blazing talents of a new generation. And in 1991, the legend brought his protg onstage as backup at the Montreux Jazz Festival, passing the torch in an almost literal sense. It's a chicken-and-egg question as to how the relationship affected Mr. Roney's trumpet style, but there's no mistaking the basic connection: in terms of color, timbre, articulation and vocabulary, what you hear points unmistakably to Miles.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Joey': New Night, Same Old Story
description: "Joey," the "Friends" spinoff on NBC that stars Matt LeBlanc, left, has failed, and its time-slot switch to Tuesdays was another monument to that failure: the first new episode of "Joey" in months drew an estimated 4.12 million viewers, and among 18-to-49-year-olds it was nearly beaten by a "Gilmore Girls" rerun on WB. Fox was far and away the winner on Tuesday, when "American Idol" (28.26 million) and "House" (20.64 million) both outdrew all competitors. But CBS, which placed second for the night, did very well with the debut of "The Unit." That new David Mamet series delivered 18.19 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Opposite "The Unit" and "House," ABC's premiere of "Sons & Daughters," its semi-improvised family comedy, wilted, with 8.35 million tuning in for the first episode and 7.48 million watching the second. Notably, "Sons & Daughters" did beat NBC's "Scrubs," its comedy competition in the hour. KATE AURTHUR

title: Inviting Anarchy Into My Home
description: Greensboro, N.C. - ON Aug. 1, 2002, I left behind the comfortably roomy semicircle marked "married-couple household" on the Census Bureau pie chart and slipped into an inconspicuous wedge labeled "two or more people, nonfamily." Having separated from my husband of 28 years the day before, I opened our three-bedroom 1927 Colonial Revival house to a group of men and women less than half my age. Overnight, the home I had lived in for 12 years became a seven-person anarchist collective, run by consensus and fueled by punk music, curse-studded conversation and food scavenged from Dumpsters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURRIE, RICHARD WALLACE
description: MURRIE--Richard Wallace. Of New York City, died peacefully at age 88 on March 6 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 30 years Rita T. Murrie, his stepson Steven Finley and stepdaughter Elizabeth Vary, four beloved stepgrandchildren, and his nephew William M. Clevenger and niece Mimi Chitwood. Dick was born in Hershey, PA on March 23, 1917, the son of William F.R. Murrie, who served as the President of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation from its incorporation in 1908 until 1947, and Sarah Maitland Murrie. Dick graduated from Lawrenceville School in 1935, from Princeton University, Summa cum Laude, in 1939 and from Yale Law School in 1942. He was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy, serving in both the North Atlantic and the Pacific from 1942 to 1946. Dick was a Senior Vice President and Fiduciary Counsel of Bessemer Trust Company, from which he retired in 1983, and served as the chairman of the Board of Pacific Inland Navigation Company. His prior marriage, to the former Elizabeth Horgan, ended with her death in 1975. He was a member of the Quogue Field Club, the Quogue Beach Club, the Princeton Club of New York, the University Club of New York, the St. Andrew's Society of New York, the Sons of the Revolution and the Society of Colonial Wars, and served as President of the New York Numismatic Club. Dick was a kind and generous man, an historian, a raconteur with a sharp mind, a quick smile and a ready laugh. He was beloved by numerous friends he easily accumulated over a long and very full life. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street on Thursday, March 9, from 2 to 4 PM and from 7 to 9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street at 10 AM on Friday, March 10, 2006.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Mine Safety Nomination Goes To Senate
