description: Andrew S. Fastow, the onetime chief financial officer of Enron, provided some of the strongest evidence yet linking Kenneth L. Lay, the companys founder and former chief executive, to a conspiracy to defraud investors. But Mr. Fastows statements, coming in the sixth week of the trial of Mr. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, another former chief executive, were almost lost under a searing cross-examination by Daniel Petrocelli, Mr. Skillings lead lawyer.

title: Hedge Funds Feeling Hot, Hot, Hot For Latin America
description: Emerging-markets hedge funds have generated big returns so far in 2006 on the back of surging Latin American stock markets. Managers investing and trading in Latin America were by far the best performers in February, gaining 9.42 percent on average.

title: Private Equity Deal in India Goes Sour
description: Private equity firm Actis deal to buy into one of Indias only remaining large domestic confectionery players, Nutrine was called off at the eleventh hour early this week underscoring once again how tenuous are the agreements reached with family-owned businesses in Asia. Actis had been in negotiations with the Reddys, the family that owns Nutrine, since the middle of 2005.

title: Center Parcs Sold to Blackstone
description: Holiday park operator Center Parcs has agreed to a 205.4 million pound takeover offer at 80 pence a share, a fifth less than its flotation price in late 2003. The cash offer by private equity group Blackstone has received irrevocable undertakings from holders of 23.5 percent of Center Parcs.

title: Online Social Atlas Start-Up Has Prominent V.C. Backers
description: People obsessed with famous film shoots or even the tastiest local burritos have a new outlet for their passions: Online maps. Platial, a two-month-old upstart, lets people save personal places of interest to a Google map, and then share those landmarks with friends or the community at large, creating a kind of social atlas, according to the company.

title: Executive Exodus at UBS
description: UBS has lost four of its most senior staff in the past two days. Warren Woo, the banks global head of financial sponsors and leveraged finance  the unit responsible for arranging and financing leveraged buyouts  yesterday became the latest senior departure.

title: Strong Revenue Gains Seen for Wall Street
description: The big Wall Street banks are expected to post strong first-quarter revenues, defying analysts who caution the good times may stop rolling and warn their high-flying stocks are increasingly at risk of losing steam. Starting next week, Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., Bear Stearns Cos. and Morgan Stanley combined are expected to report a revenue increase of about 12 percent.

title: About That Coffee Chain I.P.O.? Nevermind.
description: Tullys Coffee shareholders werent laughing about the companys initial public offering, an event that was jokingly announced at the annual shareholder meeting Wednesday  only to be retracted hurriedly after rounds of applause showed that the listeners didnt understand that it was a yarn.

title: N.Y.S.E.s Bubble May Burst
description: The Big Boards debut was a home-run. The stock of NYSE Group surged, valuing former seats at $6.9 million apiece  up four times from a year ago. But at 66 times earnings and a secondary offering on the way, its valuation doesnt look sustainable. It looks like a squeeze, says Breakingviews.

title: With Merger, N.Y.S.E. Acquires a Different Culture
description: The New York Stock Exchange- Archipelago merger highlights a fundamental dynamic of dealmaking thats often overlooked. In every deal, there is a financial acquirer and a cultural acquirerand they are not always the same company.

title: China National Building Materials Raises I.P.O. Price
description: China National Building Materials Group increased the price range for its initial public offering to raise up to US$231 million, from US$218 million previously, Dow Jones reported.

title: V.C. Firm  Diverted $9 Million in Funds, S.E.C. Says
description: A venture-capital firm misappropriated $9 million from investors, including Philadelphia and Pennsylvania pension funds, the Securities and Exchange Commission alleged yesterday in a federal lawsuit.

title: V.C.s Still See Appeal of Pocket P.C.s
description: Two years ago, San Francisco technology start-up OQO was winning high praises. But OQO, which develops hand-held computers, hasnt gained the mass appeal expected of it, instead catering largely to a niche market of technology enthusiasts and a handful of corporations.

title: Neuromed Secures $25 Million in Funding
description: Neuromed Pharmaceuticals Inc., a calcium-channel drug developer whose lead product is a treatment for chronic pain, has secured a $25 million Series D round led by new investor James Richardson & Sons Ltd. The round, which included the support of all of the Conshohocken, Pa.-based companys existing investor syndicate, is less than the $40 million target Neuromed said it was seeking.

title: Personal Bee Lands $3 Million
description: After inking $3 million in commitments from Mohr Davidow Ventures, the Personal Bee Inc. is gearing up for a public launch of its do-it-yourself news Web site. Like a number of emerging sites aimed at aggregating online news, Personal Bees software is designed to synthesize and organize information from blogs, newspapers and other media outlets into topic-specific portals, or bees.

title: Intel Invests in WiMAX Start-Up
description: Beceem Communications Inc., a provider of chipsets for Mobile WiMAX technology, has received a significant investment from Intel Capital, the venture capital arm of Intel.

title: North Carolina Biotech Firm Raises $3 Million
description: A Triangle biotech with ties to Duke University has landed a multi-million-dollar venture funding deal that is likely to lead to a handful of new hires and a larger facility.

title: On eBay: NYSE I.P.O. Commemorative Bells
description: Has it come to this? The bell that opens trading on the New York Stock Exchange has been a cherished symbol of the exchange for much of its storied history. Now, N.Y.S.E. bells are being hawked on eBay.

title: Imax Up for Sale; Will Time Warner Bite?
description: Imax is officially in play.

title: An introduction
description: Behind a Formula One race weekend, behind the sports competition we see on television or live at the track, lies a world as lively and bizarre as P.T. Barnums travelling shows more than a century ago. As a journalist who has covered the sport for more than a decade, I travel on average every second week for more than half the year, following this Formula One caravan from country to country. Each race consists of a long weekend filled with the different sounds, odors, sights and customs of the country and the racing paddock in a huge adventure only a small portion of which can be shared with readers of the sports pages.

title: Sharper Image Under Siege in Latest Proxy Challenge
description: These days, any company whose stock has lost a third of its value can expect to hear from a hedge fund. High-tech gadget retailer Sharper Image got the dreaded call on Thursday in the form of a proxy filing byKnightspoint Group, which claims to own 12.8 percent of its shares and wants to replace its board.

title: Blodget: Google Click-Fraud Settlement Very Material
description: We dont know if we should be taking advice from Henry Blodget, the disgraced Internet research analyst, but he makes some very compelling points about Googles announcement Wednesday that it settled a class-action lawsuit against the company for click fraud for $90 million. The announcement, which the company has downplayed as immaterial, could presage future problems for the company, according to Mr. Blodget. And hes not alone. Last night on CNBCs On the Money, David Vise, a Washington Post reporter and the author of The Google Story, concurred with Mr. Blodget.

title: Step inside the paddock
description: Both traditional journalism and Formula One racing have at least one thing in common: they are sometimes accused of being too elitist. A reader of a newspaper rarely has a chance to guide a journalist into doing a specific story. Letters to the editor are a potluck affair; their publication depends on the decision of an editor and perhaps on how talented the letter writer is. In Formula One too, only a select few have the chance to get into that place that Jackie Stewart, the three-time world champion, calls, the inner sanctum, or the paddock, where the teams do their business.

title: Weisberg: The Democrats Three Stooges
Fighting the Wake-Up Call for N.Y.S.E.s Extended Hours
description: John Thain, the chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, has been pushing to start trading at 8:30 a.m., contending that it would make the Big Board more competitive with other exchanges in Europe and elsewhere. But now, according to Charlie Gasparino on CNBC, Mr. Thain may be getting some resistance to his plan from an unlikely source: Jerry Putnam, founder of Archipelago Holdings and the NYSEs new co-president.

title: Deconstructing the Hedge Fund for the Masses
description: By now, youve probably seen the television commercials for Monaco-based Superfund, which bills itself as a hedge fund for the masses. You may want to do a bit of homework before jumping into this fund. It may be a mousetrap for fees.

title: Schumacher promoting road safety
description: Critics of motor racing object that it leads to reckless driving. But there are theories that few people are as aware of the dangers of highway accidents as a highly trained racing car driver. You kind of wonder sometimes, though, when you hear about Formula One drivers receiving tickets for speeding at speeds most of us cannot even imagine doing even on a race track. (I think of the cases in the last few years of Juan Pablo Montoya in the south of France, and Ralf Schumacher in Austria.)

title: Morgan Stanley Lures Another Brokerage Executive From Merrill
description: Morgan Stanleys newly fancified global wealth management group  until recently, it was just known as the retail brokerage unit  has hired another executive away from Merrill Lynch.
Selborne Journal: 9 March 1759:  Raised the frames the thickness of one brick. Cantaleupes look in general very well: plenty of plants at present. Vast storm in the Evening, & very heavy rain.

title: The Left Debates Impeachment
description: The liberal backlash against the liberal case for impeaching President Bush is in full swing. You may have missed the impeachment mania among some on the left, but its gone from a simmer to a boil in liberal magazines and blogs since the National Security Agency wiretapping scandal hit the newspapers. Harpers and The Nation have put the issue on their covers, bloggers like Berkeley economist and former Clinton Treasury official Brad DeLong bang the drum for the idea almost daily, and Garrison Keillor endorsed the idea last week in Salon. Theres even a new book, Articles of Impeachment Against George W. Bush.

title: As Bankers Rate Their Bonuses, Plenty of Grumbling at Citigroup
description: Last year was a record for outsized bonuses on Wall Street. Goldman Sachs famously handed out $11 billion in extra cash at Christmas time. So it is with some interest that we noticed a survey, albeit a completely unscientific one, conducted by the London Web site Here Is the City about how bankers felt about their bonuses.

title: Thats a Lot of Hourly Fees. Weil Gotshal & Manges Hits $1 Billion Mark
description: Weil Gotshal & Manges has passed the $1 billion mark for fees, according to Legal Week. It becomes the seventh US firm to break the one billion dollar barrier for fee income, Legal Week reported. Weil Gotschal said it had a 12 percent increase in its revenues from $908 million to $1.02 billion while average partner profits rose from $1.7 million in 2004 to $1.85 million in 2005.

title: Oil Familys Feud Lands in Bankruptcy Court (But Not For Long)
description: A group led by private equity firm Evercore Capital Partners is buying Davis Petroleum, the oil company of the late Los Angeles billionaire Marvin Davis, for $150 million.

title: Hedge Fund Returns: Flat Again in February
description: The news in hedge fund land isnt getting better. The Greenwich-Van Global Hedge Fund Index preliminarly reported returns of 0.10 percent in February. Thats not horrible  the S&P and Dow Jones Index were positive, but only barely. However, it does not bode well for all those fund that havent kept up with the market for the past two years.

title: Any Day Now?
description: Photo: Andrew Carmellini during his days at Caf Boulud. (Carol Halebian for The New York Times)

title: Should Cendant Be Taken Private?
description: Business Week floats a clever thought on how to fix Cendant: take it private. Pointing out that Henry Silverman , Cendants chief executive, is a former Blackstone Group partner, the magazine said he even half-jokingly threw out a $25 billion to $30 billion price tag in a recent conference call.

title: Does Money Make the Parent?
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 9 column, Both Sides of Inequality:

title: And Hewlett Begat Agilent, and Agilent Begat Verigy
description: Is there anything Wall Street cant spin off? Agilent Technologies, whose $2.16 billion split from Hewlett-Packard churned up $91.8 million in underwriting fees in 1999, filed with securities regulators on Thursday to cut loose its money-losing chip testing subsidiary. (Like Agilent, the new spinoff has one of those synthetic names that sounds vaguely familiar: Verigy.)

title: Why the Private Equity Firms in the VNU Deal Cant Lose
description: If the private equity consortium trying to buy VNU is blocked by shareholders, they get a nice big $30 million consolation prize. Our mergers and acquisitions reporter in London, Heather Timmons, just brought this to our attention:

title: Tim Hortons Offering Puts Canada on a Sugar High
description: Combining two national passions  doughnuts and ice hockey  Tim Hortons carries a natural fascination for citizens of Canada. And with Wendys International preparing an initial public offering for the coffee-shop chain, named after founder and hockey legend Tim Horton, Canadians are apparently clamoring to get shares in the I.P.O.

title: Google Looking for Compliance Help
description: It is probably just coincidence. But on Thursday, there was a new entry on help-wanted Web site Craigslist announcing an opening at Google, whose problems with click fraud and inadvertent leaks of sales forecasts have been endlessly discussed of late:

title: Marty Liptons Free Advice on Defending Against Activists
description: Martin Lipton, the takeover lawyer who founded Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, has recently been on a crusade against hedge funds and activists. In his latest missive to his clients on March 7, he offers a six-step plan to eradicate all those pesky shareholders.

title: Buy REIT; Load It Up With Debt; Repeat
description: Anyone wondering why real estate investment trusts keep getting bought at large premiums should take a closer look at Blackstone Groups $5.6 billion acquisition of CarrAmerica  this week.

title: Heading West
description: Curbed.com, the raucous, sexy and hilarious blog about real estate in all its glory and gore in New York, has launched a satellite in San Francisco.

title: Think Small
description: There was a time when size mattered  buying big sent a message to the world (or at least the neighborhood) that you were wealthy and powerful. Apparently, it may now send the message that you are just taking on too much debt.

title: Brussels Sprouts (Wait, Keep Reading)
description: (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

title: Will Private Equity Step Into Dubai Ports Mess?
description: It seemed all but inevitable that Dubai Ports World would give up control of its port terminals in the United States  acquired through its purchase of Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation  in order to end the agony of a new security review in Washington.

title: 'Evil'
description: Stephen Holden reviews "Evil," a Swedish film directed by Mikael Hafstrom and set at an elite boys' secondary school in the mid-1950's.

title: What Half-a-Million Will Buy
description: This game never gets old. If you live in one of the still extravagantly priced coastal markets, you can weep when you see what your money could buy if you were just willing to give up your cramped studio and move to the heartland. If you live in the midwest, you can gasp at what those crazy people are willing to pay for what looks like not a whole lot.

title: Bidding Group Emerges for Univision
description: A consortium has emerged to buy Univision: Grupo Televisa, Venevision, Providence Equity Partners, Madison Dearborn Partners  and Haim Saban have teamed up, people involved in the bid tell DealBook. The group may prove to be the bidder to beat because Televisa has a contract through 2017 to provide Univision with programming that could be pivotal in its ability to outbid rivals.

title: 'Failure to Launch'
description: Stephen Holden reviews the romantic comedy "Failure to Launch," starring Matthew McConaughey and Sarah Jessica Parker.

title: The 40-Year Loan
description: Will the 40-year mortgage  for many years a niche market  eventually move into the lending mainstream? Realty Times, the online real estate publication, suggests in an article that it just might happen.

title: Botanical Garden in Winter
description: March 9 - Times culture editor Patricia Cohen shares one of her favorite winter retreats: the lush conservatory at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.  (Producer: Shayla Harris)

title: A Conversation with William Wegman
description: Artist William Wegman discusses his work and his 36-year  retrospective at the Brooklyn Museum. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: What I Left Behind, and Why
Metro Briefing | New York: Judge Orders Re-Evaluation Of Harbor Dredging
description: A federal judge has refused to halt the multibillion-dollar dredging of the Port of New York, but gave the Army Corps of Engineers four months to assess whether the project would harm a planned cleanup of the waterways around New York. Judge Shira A. Scheindlin of Federal District Court ruled that the corps would have to reconsider the environmental and health concerns connected with the dredging. The area being deepened is heavily contaminated with dioxin left over from the manufacture of Agent Orange during the Vietnam War. The Natural Resources Defense Council and other environmental groups claim that the corps underestimated the extent to which the dredging could spread pollution and interfere with a cleanup already approved by the federal Environmental Protection Agency. ANTHONY DEPALMA (NYT)

title: Back of the Envelope
description: Big blockbuster deals typically grab all the attention in the market, prompting investors to take a new look at who might be next. But such deals rarely provide support for the market for very long.

title: Johnson Keeps Focus on Progress, Not Results
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 9 - Randy Johnson surely knew what this looked like, an outing as unsightly as a garbage scow. So when Detroit first baseman Chris Shelton grounded into a double play to end the fourth inning on Johnson's 64th and final pitch Thursday, Johnson raised his arms, a gesture that sent chuckles through the crowd at Legends Field.

title: Quiet Epiphanies for 4 on a Sunday Afternoon
description: One of the beautiful things about the movies is how they can burrow into our beings, turning a public expression into a private ritual. Once, that might have meant strutting across a room like James Cagney or drooping like Ali MacGraw. The charmingly low-key Mexican film "Duck Season" changed the way I pour soda. In this hymn to friendship, a young teenage boy fills two glasses with Coke for himself and a friend. As the dark, fizzy liquid precariously climbs toward the rim of each glass, the boy gives the signal: "Finger." His friend places a digit above the rim, a gesture that stops the foam from brimming over and yields perfectly equal shares. You can pour a single glass of soda, but how much nicer it is to pour for two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLMAN, NEIL H.
description: MILLMAN--Neil H. The partners and staff of Hecht and Company, P.C. are deeply saddened by the passing of Neil H. Millman, Esq. Neil was associated with our firm for over 30 years and played an integral part of its success. He was not only a brilliant tax advisor but also a person who cared deeply about the well being of his clients. He leaves a void which will not be easily filled. Our sincerest condolences are extended to his wife Susan, to his son Matthew and to the other members of his family. Donald Hecht and Michael Hecht

title: The Harrowing Tales of the Deceitfulness of Hearts From a Highly Deceitful Author
description: Not every book receives the film adaptation it deserves, but such is certainly the case with the collection of short stories "The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things." Published in 2001 under the name JT LeRoy, this assemblage of extravagant horror purports to tell the autobiographical ordeals of a cross-dressing, H.I.V.-positive, underage former prostitute from West Virginia who from the age of 4 had been subjected to various evils by his whore of a mother and her cretin boyfriends and Bible-thumping parents. Dennis Cooper was a JT LeRoy booster, as was Dave Eggers, who vowed that both "The Heart Is Deceitful" and the similarly themed LeRoy novel "Sarah" would "prove to be among the most influential American books of the last 10 years." Somewhere, probably hell, William S. Burroughs laughed.

title: Shame of Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia's Touring Swans and Dreamers
description: IN the 1930's and 40's, two companies with the magic words Ballet Russe in their names crisscrossed America, fostering a passion for ballet and, incidentally, forming an inextricable link between ballet and Russia in the public's mind. The whole endearing, inspiring and sometimes tacky tale is recounted in the recent documentary film "Ballets Russes."

title: McClatchy Is Said to Lead in Knight Ridder Bidding
description: The McClatchy Company emerged yesterday as the leading bidder to acquire Knight Ridder, which owns The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Miami Herald, with a binding bid worth more than $4.8 billion in cash and stock, according to people involved in the auction.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ALPERN, WILLIAM
description: ALPERN--William. Dear Daddy,Miss you more and more each day. Your Daughter

title: Subway ticket machines could detect bombers
As Trade Deficit Grows, So Do Tensions With China
description: HONG KONG, March 9 - With the United States reporting on Thursday yet another surge in its trade deficits with China and the rest of the world, economic tensions are rising again as Washington prepares for the long-delayed visit of President Hu Jintao late next month.

title: A Blank Check for the President?
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutor seeking Berlusconi charges
Ready for the next pandemic?
Joseph H. Gardner, 78, a Developer Who Saw Gold in Industrial Lofts, Dies
description: Joseph Howard Gardner, a Manhattan real estate developer who had a knack for identifying emerging neighborhoods and transforming them into residential magnets by converting rundown buildings, died on March 1 at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 78.

title: Supersized, Supercruel and Absurdly Powerful
description: Fatboy murders with impunity, curses constantly, shouts ignorant insults and devours chairs and crowns without even so much as a burp. But what makes the title character of this knockabout satire easy to stomach -- if you'll excuse the pun -- is that he's also one highly entertaining stage presence, thanks to a roaring performance by Del Pentecost that comes off like a 70-minute temper tantrum.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Alan Greenspan's book contract with Penguin Press misstated the title of another book published by the same imprint. It is "Ghost Wars," by Steve Coll, not "Ghost Soldiers."

title: The Legacy of the Soldiers on Skis
description: THEY were skiers and soldiers, trained to use their mountain skills in combat, and when they returned from war they helped build the American ski industry as we know it. They were the men of the Army's 10th Mountain Division, and they fueled the post-World War II skiing boom as pioneering instructors, resort developers, equipment designers and manufacturers, lodge owners, coaches, international competitors, ski-shop and ski-area owners and ski writers.

title: Talks Open to Try to Revive World Trade Agreement
description: LONDON, March 10 A Officials from the countries that account for 60 percent of global trade opened talks in London today to try to break their long-entrenched differences in hopes of saving a mired international trade agreement.

title: U.S. envoy urges summit of Iraq leaders
As 'Sopranos' Returns, Art Irritates Life
description: UNLESS you've been hibernating all winter, you probably know that they are back on Sunday, Tony and the gang, that fun- and gun-loving brigade of sociopaths, the kinds who know how to put the Freud in schadenfreude.

title: Iraqi Forces Would Handle Any Civil War, Rumsfeld Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Thursday that the United States would seek to avoid putting its forces in the middle of any civil war in Iraq, as he emphasized that America's goal was to prevent the violence from worsening into full-fledged sectarian fighting.

title: 36 Hours in Winston-Salem, N.C.
description: WINSTON-SALEM is a place of peculiar juxtapositions. At cafes, immaculately coiffed Southern socialites sit beside pierced and tattooed students from the North Carolina School of the Arts, and an idle brick smokestack from a century-old R. J. Reynolds tobacco plant stands near a domed Cesar Pelli skyscraper that looks like a giant roll-on antiperspirant. You can go to an art museum in what was once a tobacco tycoon's mansion and you can take in Nascar races or visit a museum devoted to stock cars. The city -- known as the birthplace and home of Krispy Kreme Doughnuts -- has galleries that sell turned wood furniture and hand-stitched quilts. Winston-Salem (population 187,500), in the Piedmont region at the base of the Blue Ridge Mountains, was created in 1913 after the consolidation of the post offices of two adjacent small towns: Salem, founded in 1766 by the Moravian Protestant sect, and Winston, established in 1849 and named for a local Revolutionary War hero. Events like the National Black Theater Festival, held every two years, and the annual RiverRun International Film Festival attract tens of thousands -- but perhaps the biggest draw is the relaxed Southern sensibility, which makes it the kind of place where lingering over a sweetened iced tea is always encouraged. KATE MURPHY

title: Bush Says Political Storm Over Port Deal Sends Wrong Message
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 A President Bush said today that he was concerned that United States alliances would be weakened in the Middle East by fallout from the aborted takeover of American port terminal operations by a Dubai company.

title: Lawyer for Bouncer Raises Objections
description: The police yesterday failed to link a bar bouncer at the center of an investigation into the murder of a graduate student with the rape of a woman in Queens after the victim did not pick the man out of a lineup.

title: Visitors From the Planet of Romantic Comedy
description: Fans of reality television who consume the dryly amusing, fatally titled romantic comedy, "Failure to Launch," can be excused from worrying that they have suddenly developed double vision. The movie's hunky, pathologically lying heartthrob, Tripp, played by Matthew McConaughey with a smirk and a swagger, is almost a dead ringer for Travis Stork, the honey-dripping Prince Charming of "The Bachelor: Paris."

title: Formula One: 100 years of racing, and still quarreling in the fast lane
That Big Nose Is Back, and So Is the Voice That Goes With It
description: The hole in the middle of the Metropolitan Opera's recent revival of "Cyrano de Bergerac" has been filled. Franco Alfano's opera in Francesca Zambello's production was created last season as a vehicle meant to carry Plcido Domingo farther along his amazing route of twilight stardom. The title role sits well on his deepening tenor voice, and here was a chance to be a dashing swordsman, wear a long nose and act up a storm. A rarely performed piece with lovely music received exposure it is not used to.

title: 'Silent Tort Reform' Is Overriding States' Powers
description: WASHINGTON - SUPPORTERS and detractors call it the "silent tort reform" movement, and it has quietly and quickly been gaining ground.

title: What a New Pair of Eyebrows Can Do for 2 Swindlers
description: Class meets crass. Sparks fly. Romance blooms. The formula that launched a thousand old Hollywood vehicles has now given a caffeinated shot of confidence to the con game that propels "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels," the year-old musical at the Imperial Theater. Say hello to the new Astaire and Rogers (O.K., make it Martin and Lewis) of Broadway, Jonathan Pryce and Norbert Leo Butz.

title: Changing U.S. Audience Poses Test for a Giant of Spanish TV
description: LOS ANGELES, March 9 - Rosa Guevara, a Mexican-American dental hygienist, grew up with the Univision network's Spanish-language soap operas, which she still watches. But Mrs. Guevara, 59, now watches alone.

title: Wanted: Alternative to Hillary Clinton
Trade officials to try to end WTO deadlock
Review: Consider the Lobster
U.N. Council to Chastise Iran but May Sidestep Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 9 - The Security Council is considering a statement listing multiple failures by Iran to meet the demands of the International Atomic Energy Agency over its nuclear program and urging it to comply, but making only passing mention of punishment for continued resistance.

title: The Church and the Illegal-Immigration Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: With Encore, McNamara Closes Curtain on UConn
description: Syracuse's Gerry McNamara did it again -- almost exactly 24 hours later and only a few feet away from the same spot.

title: SAT Errors Raise New Qualms About Testing
description: The scoring errors disclosed this week on thousands of the College Board's SAT tests were made by a company that is one of the largest players in the exploding standardized testing business, handling millions of tests each year.

title: Film in Review; The Hills Have Eyes
description: Opens today nationwide Directed by Alexandre Aja 107 minutes

title: SAT Errors Raise New Qualms About Testing
description: The scoring errors disclosed this week on thousands of the College Board's SAT tests were made by a company that is one of the largest players in the exploding standardized testing business, handling millions of tests each year.

title: Arts, Briefly; Lonergan Broadway Debut to Star Matthew Broderick
description: Kenneth Lonergan, with his run of Off Broadway hits ("This Is Our Youth," "Lobby Hero") and an Oscar-nominated film ("You Can Count on Me"), is now ready to add a Broadway debut to the list, and he is doing so with an old friend. Yesterday, a group of big-shot Broadway producers, including Scott Rudin, Carole Shorenstein Hays and Roger Berlind, announced that next spring they would bring to Broadway Mr. Lonergan's newest play, "The Starry Messenger," a comedy-drama starring his old buddy Matthew Broderick (currently appearing on Broadway in the hit revival of "The Odd Couple"). Mr. Lonergan, right, will also direct "The Starry Messenger," which tells the story of an astronomy teacher (Mr. Broderick) at the Hayden Planetarium who is trying to divine the secrets of the universe and marriage. No theater or additional casting has been announced, but an April 2007 opening is anticipated.

title: The Hamptons in Winter: Less Glamour, More Elbow Room
description: NEW Yorkers going to the South Fork of Long Island in summer don't drive the Long Island Expressway; they endure it. But on the way out from Manhattan on a morning in February  a Saturday morning, no less  bumper-to-bumper traffic had gone into hibernation. Exits passed quickly, and then boom, Southampton appeared. Elapsed time: under two hours.

title: The Church and the Illegal-Immigration Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Obituary: John Profumo, 91, cabinet member in sex scandal
Art in Review; Birdie Lusch
description: KS Art 73 Leonard Street, TriBeCa Through March 18

title: Move That Ship. It's Time for an Art Fair.
description: THERE was the year when the Belgian artist Wim Delvoye wanted to bring in a bunch of live pigs (tattooed), setting off a scramble for health permits and proper pigpens. There was the year of the blinding snowstorm, the year of the checkers-playing chimpanzees, the year that someone wanted to turn the lower level into a conceptual ice-skating rink.

title: Palestinians growing desperate for money
The twisted religion of Blair and Bush
Saturn Moon Has Geysers, Hinting Life Is a Possibility
description: With newly discovered signs of liquid water, a moon of Saturn joins the small, highly select group of places in the solar system that could plausibly support life.

title: Retailers tailor style to suit older women :
Love in the Time of March Madness
description: THE N.C.A.A. tournament invariably leaves everybody feeling warm and fuzzy. I sure hope it does this year: we need a hug and a hero more than ever.

title: On a River's Frozen Falls and Twists
description: ON a bright and below-zero February morning, in the deep gorge of a white-water river, eight bundled figures skied downstream in a line. The Manitou River, flowing fast under thin surface ice, was in its final mad descent from the hills of Minnesota's steep North Shore. Lake Superior, a swelling, frigid mass at the river's mouth, brewed up fog and wispy apparitions in the icy morning air.

title: Corrections

It was 1934, not 1936.

title: Beyond Dogs: Wegman Unleashed
description: The retrospective of William Wegman's multifarious career that opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum simultaneously confirms why Mr. Wegman hasn't always received the respect he deserves and why he deserves it. The short explanation -- on both counts -- is that he has been too innovatively funny for too long and on too many levels (visual, verbal, commercial and arty) for people to see the serious artist behind the inveterate jokester. He's also been funny in too many mediums for his achievement to be easily grasped.

title: HAVENS | Historic District, Charleston, S.C.; Charming and Venerable, With Kayaking Nearby
description: THE Ashley and Cooper Rivers, sparkling blue in the early morning sunlight, flow into Charleston Harbor and form a verdant peninsula where towering moss-draped oaks and tall palmetto trees shelter one of the country's most beautiful historic neighborhoods. Justly famous for its charm, the peninsula -- variously called the Historic Peninsula, Historic Charleston and the Historic District -- draws a steady stream of appreciative visitors, swelling to tens of thousands during the 17 days of arts performances in the late-spring Spoleto Festival.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Rikers Island: Correction Dept. Chaplain Placed On Leave
description: The Department of Correction placed its top chaplain on administrative leave yesterday while department officials review statements, captured on audiotape last year, in which he compared the Bush administration to terrorists and made remarks saying Jews controlled the media. The chaplain, Umar Abdul-Jalil, an imam who is director of the department's ministerial services division, was suspended with pay after excerpts of his lecture to a group of Muslims in Arizona last April were published yesterday by The New York Post. Mr. Abdul-Jalil, 50, was recorded saying, "We know that the greatest terrorists in the world occupy the White House, without a doubt. " Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he would meet with Correction Commissioner Martin F. Horn and city lawyers to discuss the case. PAUL VON ZIELBAUER (NYT)

title: The Listings: March 10 - March 16; 'ASUNDER'
description: Jen Abrams was getting ready for rehearsal when the telephone rang one bright September morning five years ago at the WOW Caf Theater in the East Village. Ms. Abrams answered and heard the astonishing news that New York City was willing to sell the city-owned building that housed WOW for a mere $1. The bad news was that the tenants, who also include several other arts organizations and a housing rights group, would need to raise $2.5 million to bring the building up to code standards. WOW, whose name stands for Women's One World, had been founded two decades earlier with the vision of providing a space for performing arts by women. That dream had been realized. Perhaps this could be, too. So Ms. Abrams and others set about raising some $90,000. Now WOW and the other tenants have taken ownership of the building, a milestone Ms. Abrams will acknowledge with "Asunder," an evening of new dances by herself, Clarinda Mac Low and Tara O'Con. A specialist in contact improvisation, a highly developed improvisational and choreographic style, Ms. Abrams will present "8:55 a.m." (above, with Ms. Abrams, left, Jodi Bender and Ariel Polonsky), a dance about three women responding to the chaos of the city. Ms. Mac Low, a longtime presence on the downtown dance scene and probably the only choreographer with a degree in molecular biology and biochemistry, will investigate the lives of tyrants in "Which." And in "Sternum," Ms. O'Con, who works with Stephen Koplowitz, will explore how the body articulates itself when emotions are pushed beyond reason. ("Asunder" will be performed tonight through Saturday and March 16 to 18 at 8 p.m. at the WOW Caf Theater, 59-61 East Fourth Street, between the Bowery and Second Avenue, East Village, (212) 696-8904; $12; $10 for students.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Rye: Rabid Cat Attacks Several People
description: Westchester County health officials said yesterday that several people in Rye had been attacked by a stray rabid cat, and they urged anyone who may have had contact with the animal to seek treatment. The animal, a small black cat with no tail, attacked at least three people this month near a golf course on Soundview Avenue, said a spokeswoman for the county Health Department, Mary Landrigan. They are receiving treatment, Ms. Landrigan said, but she added that others might have unknowingly been exposed to the virus, because symptoms of rabies can take several weeks to appear. ANAHAD O'CONNOR (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Slim Criticizes Central Bank
description: Carlos Slim Hel, the world's fourth-richest person, said Mexico's central bank had hurt the country's competitiveness. Mr. Slim, left, who controls Telfonos de Mxico and Amrica Mvil, the country's dominant fixed-line and mobile phone companies, made the comments one day after Guillermo Ortiz, president of Mexico's central bank, said the two companies hurt the country's competitiveness through high rates. Mr. Slim said that the Bank of Mexico, by making low inflation its only goal, had pursued a tight monetary policy that had caused the peso to appreciate. "This hurts our competitiveness, creates problems and restrains domestic consumption," Mr. Slim said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BMW 2005 Profit Flat
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke, the world's largest maker of luxury cars, said profit stalled last year after posting a record in 2004 because of more expensive raw materials and the cost of guarding against a stronger euro. Net income was little changed at 2.24 billion euros ($2.67 billion), or 3.33 euros a share, BMW, which is based in Munich, said in an e-mailed statement. Revenue for the full year increased 5.2 percent, to 46.7 billion euros, a record that the company said it expected to break in 2006. The company's chief executive, Helmut Panke, told investors a year ago that profit would stagnate in 2005 because of about 1 billion euros of costs related to higher oil and steel prices, as well as the expense of hedging against currency shifts. BMW builds about two-thirds of its vehicles in Germany, which has the second-highest labor costs in Europe, while it sells only a quarter of them in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAW, WILLIAM
description: SHAW--William. Died March 9, 2006 at the age of 81. Beloved husband of Jacqueline who passed away in 2004. He is survived by his loving daughters Linda & Deborah and his brother Jerome Shaw, as well as sons-in-law Bruce and Neil and seven grandchildren. Founder, President and Chairman of the Board of Volt Information Sciences, Inc. Services will be held Sunday, March 12, 2006 at 12:00 P.M. at Riverside Memorial Chapel 21 West Broad St. Mount Vernon NY. In lieu of flowers the family has requested donations be made to the National Parkinson Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Ave, Bob Hope Road, Miami, FL 33136-1494 or www.parkinson. org. William Shaw and his younger brother, Jerome Shaw, invested $13 and founded Volt in 1950. As leader of the fledgling company, William Shaw sought a name that would suggest the image of "potential" and "high energy," and the name "Volt" was selected. "Information Sciences" later was added because it indicated leading-edge technology in many disciplines in the marketplace. "Bill Shaw overcame great physical challenges and was an amazing example of what you can accomplish through persistence and belief in yourself," said Jerome Shaw, Executive Vice President. "He had excellent business abilities and was an extremely wise and capable businessman. I was a sponge at his side and was constantly learning. When Volt was 20 weeks old and slightly off the ground, Bill invited me out for a Saturday walk. On that walk Bill offered me 50 percent of Volt. It was an unbelievably generous offer. My brother and I were very close. He was my brother, my boss, and my best friend. That closeness grew to a unique relationship, which has lasted our lifetime. I will miss him profoundly." During more than five decades at the helm of Volt, William Shaw used his abilities to envision and build an innovative, global organization that emphasizes sound financial management, the development of human potential and the application of new technologies. His drive, imagination, and creativity while President and Chairman of Volt, highlights of which are described below, have led to Volt's tremendous growth from a startup entrepreneurial venture to a Fortune 1000 corporation. Volt originally provided technical publication services. Under Bill Shaw's direction, Volt developed significant engineering knowledge and publication reproduction expertise in the early days of the Atlas and Mercury space programs, which were crucial to the Company's initial success. Later, when asked to provide large numbers of temporary personnel to staff various client projects and businesses, Bill embraced the challenge, thus fostering Volt's entry into the employment marketplace. This staffing division was the forerunner of Volt Services Group, which today has more than 300 branch offices across the U.S., Canada, Europe and Asia. When the opportunity to purchase Autologic, a leading-edge electronic imaging and typesetting company, presented itself in 1971, Bill welcomed the chance to apply its capabilities to Volt's existing operations and expand successfully into new opportunities. The Autologic business gave Volt strong entree into telephone directory production and services. While Autologic itself has been sold, as a result, Volt Directory Systems and Services today is one of the nation's largest independent directory producers as well as providing multimedia services to publishers on four continents. Volt's growth in providing technical services and professionals to telephone companies, provided Bill Shaw a strong base upon which to launch the Company's telecommunications services division in 1976. From the performance of a full range of engineering, construction and installation services, this division continues to incorporate emerging technologies in business systems integration and local and wide area network installation as well as wireless services. Seeking business opportunities in the growing technology arena, Bill Shaw expanded the Company through further acquisitions. In 1980, Volt acquired Volt Delta and Maintech, establishing the computer systems subsidiary, which pioneered computer-generated directory assistance systems and voice enhancement features. Today, as part of Volt's Computer Systems segment, VoltDelta markets a suite of Internet-based information services solutions to telecommunications companies worldwide. Maintech's services portfolio includes hardware maintenance, network operations center services and technology refresh services. Further corporate milestones achieved by Volt under Mr. Shaw include listing on the New York Stock Exchange, inclusion in a Standard and Poor's Index, achieving ISO-9002 certification, adopting Six Sigma methodologies, as well as receiving numerous awards of recognition from corporate and community organizations. In December 2006 Mr. Shaw was instrumental in the Volt Delta Resources LLC subsidiary's acquisition of Varetis Solutions GMBH and the repurchase of a minority interest from Nortel Networks which it had received for contributing certain assets and certain liabilities of its directory and operator services business to VoltDelta in August, 2004. "We grieve the loss of my uncle," said Steve Shaw, Executive Vice President andCEO of Volt. "Volt has lost a remarkable man, leader, visionary and friend. His loss will be deeply felt throughout the organization." Bill Shaw will be profoundly missed by his family and friends, company employees, past and present, and by the individuals and organizations he influenced and affected throughout the business community.

title: The Listings: March 10 - March 16; ANTHONY BRAXTON 12+1(TET)
description: Thirty years ago, it was difficult to claim fealty to jazz and not confront, in one way or another, the intense and rigorous music of Anthony Braxton. As a composer, theorist and saxophonist, Mr. Braxton, above, exemplified the brazen intellectualization of jazz's avant-garde; his pieces often included instructions in the form of geometric pictographs, and his process revealed an affinity for classical conceptualism. This was a compelling enough alternative -- in the era that officially gave rise to jazz repertory on the one hand and commercialized fusion on the other -- to sustain the support of a major label and the attention of the mainstream media, at least for a few heady years. Mr. Braxton has been tirelessly prolific since that cultural moment, but he has also become something of a recluse, establishing himself at Mills College in the 1980's and Wesleyan University since the 90's. Last fall, Wesleyan, in Middletown, Conn., toasted Mr. Braxton's 60th birthday with a three-month series of performances and lectures, including a colloquium discussing his influence. The ensemble that Mr. Braxton leads here could serve the same purpose, stocked as it is with younger players fluent in his language; some, like the cornetist Taylor Ho Bynum and the saxophonist Steve Lehman, are Wesleyan alumni who have been applying Braxtonian methods to their own projects. But of course, the reason not to miss this engagement is Mr. Braxton himself, whose playing is as terse and riveting as ever, and whose concept has never faltered in its evolution. (Thursday through March 19 at 8 and 10 p.m., Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121; cover, $25 to $27.50, with a $10 minimum.)

title: O'Higgins the Liberator Is Reclaimed From the Military
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 9 - Not long after seizing power in 1973, Gen. Augusto Pinochet built an Altar of the Fatherland and had the remains of Bernardo O'Higgins, the hero of Chilean independence, moved there. Chilean democrats have been struggling ever since to wrest O'Higgins from the military and restore his legacy to the entire nation, and on Thursday they finally succeeded.

title: Red Bull Is New Owner, and Name, of MetroStars
description: The person at the other end of the phone line said "Good morning, MetroStars," and then quickly corrected himself, saying, "Ah, I mean good morning, Red Bull New York." And nearly as quickly, the terminally mediocre MetroStars of Major League Soccer received a bracing jolt of Red Bull.

title: 36 Hours in Winston-Salem, N.C.
description: WINSTON-SALEM is a place of unusual juxtapositions. At cafes, immaculately coiffed Southern socialites sit beside pierced and tattooed students from the North Carolina School of the Arts, and an idle brick smokestack from a century-old R. J. Reynolds tobacco plant stands near a domed Cesar Pelli skyscraper that looks like a giant bottle of roll-on antiperspirant. You can go to an art museum in what was once a tobacco tycoon's mansion and you can take in Nascar races or visit a museum devoted to stock cars. The city  known as the birthplace and home of Krispy Kreme Doughnuts  has galleries that sell turned wood furniture and hand-stitched quilts. Winston-Salem (population 187,500), in the hills of the Piedmont region at the base of the Blue Ridge Mountains, was created in 1913 after the consolidation of the post offices of two adjacent small towns: Salem, founded in 1766 by the Moravian Protestants sect, and Winston, established in 1849 and named for a local Revolutionary War hero. Events like the National Black Theater Festival, held every two years, and the annual RiverRun International Film Festival attract tens of thousands  but perhaps the biggest draw is the Southern pace, which makes it the kind of place where lingering over a sweetened iced tea is always encouraged.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blair Apology For Brazilian's Killing
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair met with President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of Brazil at the end of his state visit to Britain and offered "deepest regrets" for the killing of Jean Charles de Menezes, a Brazilian electrician who was shot dead in the London Underground in July by police officers who had mistaken him for a suicide bomber. Mr. da Silva urged the British government and courts to "investigate what needs to be investigated" to secure justice for the victim's family. Prosecutors have not yet said whether the officers involved will be brought to trial. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

title: Jobs Grow and Wages Rise as Economy Picks Up Steam
description: The economy added jobs at a brisk pace last month, but the unemployment rate ticked up slightly as more people sought work, the government reported today. Analysts said the numbers suggested that the economy was strong and benefiting from mild weather at the start of the year.

title: The Listings: March 10 - March 16; 'LETTERS TO SALA: A YOUNG WOMAN'S LIFE IN NAZI LABOR CAMPS'
description: It didn't seem so at the time, but Sala Garncarz was one of the lucky ones. When the Nazis invaded Poland in 1939, she was a 16-year-old Jewish girl living in Sosnowiec, a town close to the German border. She volunteered to take the place of her older sister, Raizel, who had been ordered to report to a Nazi forced labor camp for six weeks. But the six weeks stretched into almost five years of servitude for Sala, in seven different camps, with a pittance for wages or none at all, filthy quarters and an abundance of typhus-carrying lice. Her luck was that her labor-worthiness as a seamstress saved her from Auschwitz, a main extermination center, where her parents and other family members died. The story of Sala (she is alive and well at 82 and has grandchildren with her husband of 60 years, Sidney Kirschner) is told in a stirring new exhibition at the New York Public Library, which draws on more than 300 cherished letters from family and friends; photographs (above, Sala, from 1945); and a diary that she managed to squirrel away during her years of servitude (for a while the Nazis let forced laborers send and receive mail, provided it was written in German). Crucial elements of her saga -- which she kept under wraps for more than 50 years -- include the protective support of an older campmate, Ala Gertner, later hanged at Auschwitz for her part in an uprising there; the kindness of a local German family to whose home she was sent under guard to use its sewing machine; her close comradeship with female workers at the various camps; her introduction to her husband, then a G.I., at a Rosh Hashana service after the camps were liberated; her postwar discovery of her two surviving sisters; and her emigration as a war bride to the United States in 1946. (Sue and Edgar Wachenheim III Gallery, first floor, New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089, through June 17.)

title: Japan Central Bank Declares an End to the Economic Blahs
description: TOKYO, March 9 - It's official: Japan's financial crisis of more than a decade is over. That was the message Thursday from the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, as it announced the end of an unusual financial experiment: a lush monetary policy adopted five years ago as an emergency measure to resuscitate a moribund economy. The policy, which propped up banks by loading them with cash, allowed the cost of borrowing to drop virtually to zero.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about deadly bombings in the Hindu holy city of Varanasi, in India's Uttar Pradesh state, misstated the cause of a train fire that led to India's last major spasm of sectarian religious violence, in Gujarat state four years ago. A government investigation panel announced in January that the train fire was accidental, not an arson attack.

title: State School Aid Distribution Harms L.I., Officials Contend
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., March 9 - State aid to public schools might not seem like a salvational issue, but at a gathering that was part tent meeting and part campaign rally, local officials said on Thursday that the inequitable distribution of state aid threatens a very way of life in the suburbs.

title: One Man, Three Wives and Many Troubles
description: The shocking thing about polygamy is not the sex, it's the deference. The practice institutionalizes female rivalry and wives' need to please their man -- a life sentence of cajoling and Cosmo tricks (never let him see you angry; dance in Saran Wrap when he comes home from work). Things are hard enough in the war between the sexes. Polygamy turns the battle into a Rorke's Drift where the women have about as much chance as Zulus armed with spears.

Roy Haynes: Attention Getter, on the Beat and Off
description: ON the wall of his wood-paneled basement in his suburban Long Island home, the drummer Roy Haynes has a large poster of his idol, the Count Basie-band drummer Jo Jones. In the picture, taken in 1940, Jones stands outside of a building in a hat, suit and full-length overcoat, holding a cymbal with his left hand and a brush with his right. The stance is all casual defiance: Jones's feet are spaced apart, his chin and his eyebrows are raised. "He was the man," Mr. Haynes said. "And he carried himself like that."

title: Chile's Socialist Leader Stepping Down Amid Praise from U.S.
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 10  Ricardo Lagos barely squeaked into office here six years ago, winning just a hair over half the vote in a hard-fought runoff. On Saturday, however, he will step down as president of Chile with three quarters of the population saying it approves of his performance, according to recent opinion surveys.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Fire Disrupts Rail Service
description: An underground railway fire led to the evacuation of thousands of San Francisco commuters on BART trains, stopped BART service for two hours and closed five train stations and the three-mile Transbay tunnel between San Francisco and Oakland. Officials said the fire, which started around 9:30 a.m. and sent billowing black smoke up vents to the street, appeared to be caused by debris on the tracks. At least three people were treated for smoke inhalation. City streets near station entries were closed, and above-ground trolleys were stopped, snarling traffic throughout downtown. CAROLYN MARSHALL (NYT)

title: The Harrowing Tales of the Deceitfulness of Hearts From a Highly Deceitful Author
description: Not every book receives the film adaptation it deserves, but such is certainly the case with the collection of short stories "The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things." Published in 2001 under the name JT LeRoy, this assemblage of extravagant horror purports to tell the autobiographical ordeals of a cross-dressing, H.I.V.-positive, underage former prostitute from West Virginia who from the age of 4 had been subjected to various evils by his whore of a mother and her cretin boyfriends and Bible-thumping parents. Dennis Cooper was a JT LeRoy booster, as was Dave Eggers, who vowed that both "The Heart Is Deceitful" and the similarly themed LeRoy novel "Sarah" would "prove to be among the most influential American books of the last 10 years." Somewhere, probably hell, William S. Burroughs laughed.

title: The Listings: March 10 - March 16; 'THE LIEUTENANT OF INISHMORE'
description: The longstanding battle between cat people and dog people is turning into a blowout -- at least in regard to the New York theater scene. More than five years after Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical "Cats" closed on Broadway, feline-themed plays have become something of a cottage industry. This season, there are acrobatic cats in the long-running "Moscow Cats Theater," now playing at the Lamb's Theater, and anthropomorphized kitties in "Indoor/Outdoor," a play running at DR2 Theater. "Dog Sees God," a poorly received sendup of the "Peanuts" comic strip, may have piqued the interest of dog lovers, but to no avail: Snoopy dies before the play even begins. Sound gruesome? It's nothing compared to the pet fatalities in Martin McDonagh's "Lieutenant of Inishmore," a superb comedy in which cats figure largely in much of the dialogue and all of the major plot twists. The play, which is running at the Atlantic Theater before moving to Broadway later in the spring, begins with two men (above Peter Gerety, left, and Domhnall Gleeson) staring at the dead cat of a sadistic terrorist who eventually decides to form a splinter group whose aim will be to track down and destroy cat-killers, the lowest form of human (or any other) life. Dog murders, he says, are something else entirely. Considering the success of "Inishmore," don't be surprised to see a musical version of "Garfield" opening soon. (336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 239-6200.)

title: Mars Spacecraft Brakes Into a Successful Orbit
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 A The most sophisticated spacecraft ever sent to Mars slipped into orbit around the planet on Friday after successfully firing braking rockets and maneuvering itself into position while pleased controllers monitored from Earth.

title: Build the Memorial First
description: The centerpiece of the rebuilding of downtown Manhattan is the memorial to the victims and survivors of Sept. 11, 2001. Over the last four years, the design for that monument has been chosen carefully, and then refined for reasons that range from the structural to the aesthetic. Like everyone concerned about this crucial site, we have our doubts about some details of the final plan. But the most important thing, by far, is to get the memorial built, and built swiftly.

title: Univision May Have New Suitor
description: A consortium of companies and investors that includes the Mexican television giant Grupo Televisa has emerged as a potential bidder for Univision, the largest Spanish-language television and radio company in the United States.

title: Legal Costs of Shelter Case Hurt Deutsche Bank Profit
description: Deutsche Bank said yesterday that it had reduced its 2005 earnings by nearly $300 million to cover newly discovered legal costs related to its role in creating and selling questionable tax shelters.

He said: "Persons who have unauthorized possession, who come into unauthorized possession of classified information, must abide by the law. That applies to academics, lawyers, journalists, professors, whatever." The quotation came from the Jewish Telegraphic Agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GHRISKEY, H. WILLIAMSON
description: GHRISKEY--H. Williamson. Of Greenwich, CT, passed peacefully at home on March 6, 2006. Loving husband of the late Flora Roberts Ghriskey. Treasured Father of Susie, Bill, Marcia, Timothy and Gigi. Cherished Grandfather of sixteen and Great-Grandfather of four. A good friend to so many. Born October 16, 1912 in Philadelphia. Son of Charles and Lillian. Brother of Susan and Lillian. Graduate of Episcopal Academy '30, Princeton University '34 and Harvard Business School '36. Lieutenant Commander of U.S. Navy. First Boston Company '36-'42. President of Neville, Rodie and Shaw '47'78. Vice-Chairman of Trainer Wortham '78-'88. From 1988 to today, Managing Director of Trainer Wortham. Never retired. A great investor, and a trusted counsel to his clients and to all of us. Former Chairman and President of Investment Counsel Association of America. Formerly on Boards of Hartridge School, Pingry School, Edgartown Yacht Club, St. Barnabas Church. Member of Round Hill Club and Racquet & Tennis Club. In lieu of flowers, donations to Williamson Free Trade School, Media, PA or St. Barnabas Church, Greenwich, CT. Memorial service on Friday, April 7 at 11 AM at St. Barnabas Church.

He predicted the deal would usher in a new era of corporate partnerships that would harness the power of the market to spread the city's image around the world.

title: Where 'Buy Low and Sell High' Are a Co-op's Fighting Words
description: Morningside Gardens is a rarity in real-estate-mad Manhattan, a co-op apartment complex that middle-class New Yorkers can afford. Apartments sell for a fraction of what they would bring on the open market. For the chance to live free of a crushing mortgage and in a community that is unusually mixed, residents accept a trade-off: they give up the possibility of making a killing when they sell.

title: Other Art Fairs Hitch a Ride on Armory's Buzz
description: Art lovers worried that the once-titanic Armory Show has cut back from 189 galleries in 2004 to only 154 this year can take heart: at least four other fairs are also happening in New York this weekend, bringing the total number of dealers back up to a respectable 341.

title: Inquiry Finds Lax Federal Inspections at Kosher Meat Plant
description: An internal report from the Agriculture Department has found that one of the nation's leading kosher slaughterhouses violated animal cruelty laws and that government inspectors not only failed to stop the inhumane practices but also took improper gifts of meat from plant managers.

title: Citing Collusion, New Jersey Sues Over School Site Price
description: NEWARK, March 9 - State officials contend that the troubled New Jersey School Construction Corporation overpaid for the site of a school in Union City because the property owner and city officials colluded to inflate the site's appraised value.

Then it charges right at all of us cowering behind the wooden barrier at the edge of the ring, kicking up dust and ramming those two nubby horns into the chipped-up wood.

title: How Paul Klee's Star Rose in America
description: FOR a long time the Swiss-born artist Paul Klee (1879-1940), regarded as a leading modernist figure in Europe, didn't believe his delicate, chimerical work had much of a future in the United States. In fact,this country's culture played a very minor role in his consciousness. Unlike some of his European colleagues, he had no hankering to experience firsthand the brassy, bustling American scene; he never even visited.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, GERALD L., M.D.
description: WOLF--Gerald L., M.D. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Gerald L. Wolf, M.D., professor emeritus and former vice chairman of anesthesiology. Dr. Wolf was well known for his research, most recently concerning the prevention of surgical fires. He also was a much-admired teacher, lecturer, author and mentor. Our condolences are extended to his family, colleagues, and friends. John C. LaRosa, M.D., President Eugene B. Feigelson, M.D., Dean of the College of Medicine James C. Cottrell, M.D. Chair of Anesthesiology

title: Challenging the Damage That Boys Do
description: Ruthless teenage pecking orders, be they street gangs or snooty alpha girls and their retinues, seem to be hard-wired into society. Each of these expressions of the primal human need to create hierarchies comes equipped with its own elaborate rites of passage. But as countless stories of fraternity hazings gone awry have demonstrated, the boundary separating playful humiliation from life-threatening sadism can be awfully thin. Is such ritualized behavior really unavoidable?

title: Art Show Is Disrupted by Carbon Monoxide
description: High carbon monoxide levels forced the evacuation of a New York art show as it was preparing for its opening yesterday, the Fire Department said.

description: Bergen County authorities said today that they had arrested a 19-year-old man and charged him with criminal sexual contact after he picked up a 13-year-old Jersey City girl who ran away from her home on Monday and engaged in improper sexual conduct with her.

title: Land mine kills 26 in Pakistan
The World Tour Rolls Into Town, Sprawling but Tidy
description: THE ARMORY SHOW 2006, which opens on Piers 90 and 92 today, calls itself the International Fair of New Art. But what it really is is the New York leg of what has become, over the past few years, a single, floating, continuous trans-Atlantic art fair that periodically alights in one city or another -- Miami, Cologne, Basel, London -- to hawk its wares and replenish its stock.

title: Arts, Briefly; Berlin Is to Help Renew The Staatsoper
description: The State of Berlin has agreed to contribute to the renovation costs for the Staatsoper Unter den Linden, bringing the renovation of the opera house closer to realization. The federal government has already agreed to contribute to the estimated cost of $135 million for the modernization of the house's stage machinery. First opened in 1742, the Staatsoper has had numerous technical problems that the renovation should address. The opera's music director, Daniel Barenboim, has been among those repeatedly calling for modernization of the building. The Circle of Friends of the Staatsoper Unter den Linden will donate $36 million toward the renovation, which could start in 2008. In a separate financing matter, the State of Berlin announced that over the next three years it will reduce annual subsidies for state operas by $16 million from the current $134 million.

description: MANNARELLI--Catherine. She lit up our Purim Festivals with professional talent and authority. title: U.S. to Abandon Abu Ghraib and Move Prisoners to a New Center
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 9 - The American military said Thursday that within the next several months it planned to relocate all its detainees from Abu Ghraib prison, the sprawling penal compound west of Baghdad that became notorious throughout the world after photographs were made public of American soldiers abusing Iraqi prisoners there.
