description: The London Stock Exchange, Europe's biggest stock market, announced today that it had received and rejected a $4.1 billion cash bid from the Nasdaq Stock Market, indicating that the arms race among the world's leading exchanges is well under way.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Attackers Shoot 2 Men, Killing One
description: Two men were shot, one fatally, by two other men about 4:40 p.m. yesterday in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The gunmen fled from the scene of the shooting, in front of 215A Lexington Avenue. David Pierre, 22, who lived in the building, was declared dead on arrival at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center. The other victim, who was not identified, was in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said. No arrests have been made, they said last night.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 1 about arguments before the Supreme Court over the estate of the Texas oil tycoon J. Howard Marshall II omitted credit for the reported comments of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., Justice Stephen G. Breyer and E. Pierce Marshall, a son involved in the lawsuit. The article also omitted credit for a description of Anna Nicole Smith, a former Playboy model who married Mr. Marshall 14 months before he died. The quotations and the physical description were all supplied by The Associated Press.

title: But Can It Be Bottled Like Evian?
description: Yesterday's announcement that scientists have seen Yellowstone-like geysers of water vapor and ice particles erupting on a moon of Saturn is yet another stunning achievement for a NASA spacecraft that is exploring the planet and its environs. If confirmed, this discovery will be the first time any water geyser has been detected outside Earth. It immediately raised the possibility that tiny Enceladus, an enchanting snowy white satellite of Saturn, might harbor the conditions for life.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo Republic: World Bank Debt Relief
description: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund approved $2.9 billion in debt relief, but the country must take concrete steps to combat corruption in its state-owned oil company to make the deal irrevocable. The government has agreed to improve the company's internal financial controls and to require company officials to publicly declare any conflicts of interest. Paul D. Wolfowitz, the World Bank president, pushed for the conditions. CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

title: A Trip to the Desert Stirs the Savage Beast
description: It is not the lucky ones who die first, as the grisly tag line of "The Hills Have Eyes" promises, but rather Beauty, one of two German shepherds belonging to a nice all-American family who thought it would be cute to take the scenic route to California.

title: Agent Says He Thought Moussaoui Knew About Plot
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 - An F.B.I. agent told a jury on Thursday that when he arrested Zacarias Moussaoui on immigration charges three weeks before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks he was convinced that Mr. Moussaoui was an Islamic extremist who knew about some terrorist plan involving airplane hijackings.

title: Do's and don'ts of home buying
Paid Notice: Deaths   MAYBRUCK, CHARLES N., ESQ.
description: MAYBRUCK -- Charles N., Esq. Born in NYC. Received his Juris Doctor from NYU Law. Loving and devoted husband of 66 years to Bunny. Spectacular father to Richard and Jenny. Beloved grandfather of Martin, Nadine and Michael-Anne. Proud greatgrandfather of Sarah. He was wonderful and his spirit will live on in all of us always. Services today, 11:30AM, Frank E. Campbell. Family will receive visitors Sunday from 1PM on at 530 Park Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A column by David Pogue on NYTimes.com and in the weekly Circuits e-mail newsletter last Sept. 1, about the computer technology services of DriveSavers, misconstrued the terms under which The Times accepts free use of goods or services for review. The policy allows temporary loans from vendors or manufacturers of equipment or materials for review, and they must be returned after testing. The Times pays for services it reviews, and has contacted DriveSavers to arrange payment for those described in this column. (Go to Article)

title: Why Not Let Companies Ignore a Law?
description: WHEN Christopher Cox, a California congressman, was named to head a bitterly divided Securities and Exchange Commission nine months ago, many doubted that he would be a tough regulator.

title: Abduction Tale Doubted as Girl, 13, Turns Up
description: A Jersey City teenager who vanished on her way to school on Monday turned up unharmed in New York City yesterday, and the police said her chilling story of abduction, confinement in a dark basement and sexual abuse -- told in cryptic text messages to her mother -- appeared to be false.

title: Finding the heart of Jesus amid the many apparent contradictions
Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the American Israel Public Affairs Committee and the indictments of two former officials of the group, who are accused of passing on classified information, omitted the credit for the source of a quotation from United States District Judge T.S. Ellis III, who is presiding over their case (an article on Feb. 12 also omitted the credit). He said: "Persons who have unauthorized possession, who come into unauthorized possession of classified information, must abide by the law. That applies to academics, lawyers, journalists, professors, whatever." The quotation came from the Jewish Telegraphic Agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEWIRTZ, MARVIN H., PH.D.
description: GEWIRTZ--Marvin H., Ph.D., 78. Extraordinary public servant, research scientist, peace activist, he guided N.Y.C. Department of Health research interns, influenced child health and urban education programs and urged public outcries to end nuclear weapons proliferation. Active for his community to the end, he was loving and dedicated as husband to Michelle M. Boston, father to Michelle Gewirtz, grandfather to Emma and Nora Kako, brother to Jerome Gewirtz, son of the late Hyman and Fannie. A good friend, an athlete, a man of moral fiber, he endeared himself to all who knew him. Memorial service at Riverside Memorial Chapel (76th St and Amsterdam), on Sunday, March 19, at 4:00. Memorials to City Parks Foundation to support athletic programs for youth.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Money Approved For Waterfront Improvement
description: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation approved the payment of nearly $150 million yesterday for the planning, design and engineering of enhancements to the East River waterfront. The work seeks to improve access to the East River esplanade with new pavement, benches, lighting and plantings at spots including St. Catherine's, Montgomery and Peck Slips. A new entrance would be created extending from Montgomery Street north past Pier 42, with a new vehicular access drive and pedestrian and bike paths. The money will also be used to plan a redevelopment of several piers and a corridor along a two-mile segment of the waterfront. The projects are to be completed in stages from 2010 to 2015. GLENN COLLINS (NYT)

title: A Dose of French Film, Civil and Sane
description: THE image of that ageless free spirit Charlotte Rampling cuddling an 18-year-old Haitian youth on a Caribbean beach in the film "Heading South" is charged with so many erotic, political and cultural connotations, they are almost too much for one movie to handle. The self-appointed queen bee among the middle-aged white women who go to an out-of-the-way Haitian resort to enjoy the sexual favors of handsome black beach boys, Ms. Rampling's Ellen imagines herself a master of this game until her favorite lover, Legba (Mnothy Cesar), lands in serious trouble. When she discovers how truly cheap life is for the impoverished citizens in a third world dictatorship (the story is set during the Duvalier era in the late 1970's), her self-assurance crumbles.

title: Threat From Bird Flu
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Fed, Exuberance
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 - From an airy oval-shaped office with a striking bay window offering a panoramic view of a downtown street here, Alan Greenspan is trying to replicate his long-ago life as a Wall Street economic forecaster. But with a big difference.

title: Blind flight, equally blind pursuit for Saddam
Spent/Thrift: Getting gadgets without a byte to the wallet
Garrett Scott, 37, Who Directed Award-Winning Documentary, Is Dead
description: Garrett Scott, an independent filmmaker, died in Coronado, Calif., on March 2, two days before his documentary "Occupation: Dreamland" received an Independent Spirit Award at a ceremony in Santa Monica. He was 37.

title: London exchange rejects Nasdaq
Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, JOSEPH L.
description: KLEIN--Joseph L., a Naples, Florida resident for the past 36 years, born July 20, 1910, in Manhattan, New York City, passed from his earthly stewardship to eternal life on Wednesday, March 8, 2006, by the Will of God, in Naples. His beloved wife, Vera, predeceased him when she was called to her heavenly reward on March 3, 1992. He was a career police officer in the New York City Police Department, with 35 years of service. He retired in May, 1971, with Rank of "Deputy Chief." His assignments were many and varied, working his way from foot patrol in the 7th Precinct in Manhattan to command of the 11th Division in Brooklyn, a post he held for five years, until retirement. In 1960 he was Captain of the 60th Precinct (Coney Island). An interesting note, from Memorial Day to Labor Day, 1960, from Park Department records, some 45 million people who visited this recreational facility were policed by a patrol force of 400 men under his command. He supervised Patrol, Administrative and Plainclothes duties in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. While assigned as Administrative Officer of Brooklyn South Patrol Forces, he authored an article on "Police Administration" that was published in the "Police Management Review". He conducted "Operations Management Seminars" and "Criminal Investigation" courses at the New York City Police Academy. He served as a Panel Member of the Civilian Complaint Review Board. During retirement, in July of 1994, he prepared a manuscript, chronicling some of the experiences of his interesting thirtyfive career years, rising up through seven ranks and working for nine Police Commissioners. In December of 1996 his book, "THE POLICE CAREER: An Endless Challenge," published by Vantage Press, was officially released on the literary market. In January of 2003 he conceived the idea to document his "MEMOIRS," covering the date of his birth, July 20, 1910, to 1936. He felt that his experiences were of such caliber, unique, unusual, beyond comparison and challenge, that they were worthy of documentation. He "lived out" his ambitions and youthful fantasies, as preludes to his "Police Career." The bottom line is that he played Broadway and he patrolled Broadway. "MEMOIRS, 1910 to 1936: That Shaped My Life" was published in 2004 by Vantage Press. He is a Life Member of the following Organizations: The P.B.A. of the New York City Police Department, The Captain's Endowment Association, The International Association of the Chiefs of Police, The International Police Association, the U.S. Section, District 11. He is a member of The New York Veteran Police Association, S.O.A.R. and Central Florida 10-13, and The Florida Peace Officers' Association. He is a Life Member of The Naples Cruise Club, The Naples Sailing and Power Squadron and The Naples Elks #

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 9, 2006

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEPRIN, JACK
description: WEPRIN--Jack. 1930-1996. A dear friend is never forgotten. Martin

title: John T. Kramer, 68, a Scholar Who Helped Shape Poverty Laws, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 - John T. Kramer, a legal scholar and champion of civil rights who helped shape the nation's poverty laws , died on Wednesday at his home in New Orleans. He was 68.

title: Stomping, Flexing and Some Vernal Romps, Too
description: There are three principal programs in the Mark Morris Dance Group's 25th-anniversary season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, along with a garland of sometimes amusing ancillary events. Like Mr. Morris leading a karaoke session, which happened Saturday -- sorry!

title: Famous Hawks Try Again to Fill a Familiar Empty Nest
description: It is becoming a New York rite of spring. Pale Male and Lola are back on the nest.

title: City May Gain 200 Teachers Designated as Masters
description: Principals of troubled New York City schools will be permitted to hire master teachers, a position created in the latest teachers' contract that will pay veteran educators an additional $10,000 to combine regular classroom work with mentoring less-experienced teachers, according to a memorandum issued yesterday by the city's Education Department.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Convicted Of Slashing Officer's Throat
description: A Queens man was convicted yesterday of slashing a police officer's throat a year ago. The defendant, Radcliffe Meeks, 33, of Saint Albans, was convicted of first-degree attempted murder and other charges, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Meeks faces up to 25 years to life in prison when he is sentenced next month. Prosecutors said Mr. Meeks used a carpet knife to slash Officer Robert Burns, who tried to arrest him at Dunkirk Street and Elmira Avenue after a homeowner reported that a man had threatened to shoot him. Mr. Meeks was disarmed when Officer Burns's partner shot him in the arm. Officer Burns recovered and returned to duty.

title: U.S. Squeezes North Korea's Money Flow
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 - Six months after the Bush administration blacklisted a bank in Macao accused of laundering money for the North Korean government, senior administration officials say the action has proved to be far more effective than anyone had dreamed.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Circuits pages of Business Day yesterday about a Sony high-definition video camera, the HDR-HC3, referred incorrectly to its forms of storage. It indeed records video to Mini DV tapes, in addition to storing digital still photos on Memory Stick Duo and Memory Stick Pro Duo cards.

title: A Blank Check for the President?
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Leader Faces New Troubles as Election Nears
description: ROME, March 10 A A month before tight national elections, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi was besieged today by two new embarrassments: Prosecutors asked that he be put on trial for corruption, and his health minister resigned over accusations that he spied on political opponents.

title: The Real Costs Of School Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Anatomy of a partnership
Briton Tackles Formidable Britten Works
description: The English tenor Ian Bostridge began his tenure as one of this season's Perspectives artists at Carnegie Hall with a Britten recital at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening: on the face of it, not a daring program.

title: Judge Declares Mistrial in Gotti Case
description: After a jury proclaimed itself hopelessly deadlocked, a Manhattan judge declared a mistrial this afternoon in the racketeering case of John A. Gotti, who contended that he had renounced his position as the "heir apparent" to the Gambino crime family.

title: Baseball: Mexico routs Canada to advance
Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMAN, ISRAEL, DDS
description: HOFFMAN--Israel, DDS. Died on March 4, two days shy of his 94th birthday, in Boston. Survived by Sylvia (nee Goldberg), his wife of 65 years, daughters Amy Feldman (Richard) and Ellen Hoffman (Ken Loveday), grandchildren Eric Feldman (Michelle) and Rebecca Micucci (Michael), and great granddaughter Isabella. He served as an Air Force captain in North Africa and Italy during WWII, returning to practice dentistry in Elmhurst, Queens until age 79. A 54-year resident of Beechhurst, he will be lovingly remembered for his scientific curiosity, passion for gardening and--until his last day--wry sense of humor. Memorial donations may be made to the National MS Society, 101A First Avenue, Suite 6, Waltham, MA. 02451.

title: Arts, Briefly; Does 'Top Model' Look Good to CW?
description: The sixth season of "America's Next Top Model" began on Wednesday, and it put UPN in second place for the night among women 18 to 34, the demographic that this lame duck network aims for. The enduring popularity of the Tyra Banks-led "Top Model," which drew 5.23 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates for the two-hour premiere, seemingly makes it a sure thing for the new CW network, which will arise from the merger of UPN and WB. By its final half-hour, which featured the ouster of Kathy and a requisite tearful "Just you wait" speech, 6.51 million viewers were watching "Top Model." But Wednesday was also "American Idol" night, and that meant that Fox was No. 1 in the key ratings demographic over all, as that talent competition drew 29.95 million viewers. "Idol" still hasn't lifted "Bones," the criminal procedural that follows it, nearly as much as it did "House" last season. "Bones" brought in an audience of 12.11 million, which meant it lost more than 17 million "Idol" viewers.

title: Yukos sued by banking consortium
National Briefing | Washington: Probation For Marion Barry
description: A federal magistrate judge sentenced Marion S. Barry Jr., 70, a former mayor of Washington and a current member of the City Council, to three years of probation for failing to pay taxes. The judge, Deborah A. Robinson, also ordered Mr. Barry to comply with any drug treatment or counseling requirements imposed by the probation office. Mr. Barry tested positive for cocaine and marijuana use in a court-ordered drug test last year. He pleaded guilty in October to two misdemeanor charges for failing to file his income tax returns for 2000. Mr. Barry served three terms as mayor from 1978 to 1990 before spending six months in prison for drug possession. He then served another term as mayor from 1994 to 1998 and was elected to the Council in 2004. JOHN FILES (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORTNOY, SAMUEL
description: PORTNOY--Samuel, 84, died March 8 in Portland, Oregon, from cancer. Beloved husband of Theo, loving father to Lois and Eli, son-in-law Dean Richards and granddaughter Anna, brother to Martin and the late Minna Ring. Orignally from Queens, he graduated from Union College and NYU School of Dentistry. He had been a resident of Scarsdale and Amagansett, L.I. and practiced in Manhattan and Scarsdale for over 50 years. He resided in Orlando, FL until his illness where he practiced pro bono dentistry for the Coalition for the Homeless. A lover of people, the life of any social gathering with a keen ability to relate to anyone and devoted to his patients, he will be greatly missed by all who knew him.

title: Swedish Works Across the Centuries Take a Place in the Lights
description: From Sweden, Works Across the Centuries Take a Place in the Lights

description: In percent

Paid Notice: Deaths   TSANG, CHIH
description: TSANG--Chih. Age 98, died on March 6, 2006 in New York. Born in Imperial China, his life successfully bridged the many changes that China underwent in the 20th century and demonstrated the opportunities available in post WWII America. The father of three, grandfather of seven, and great-grandfather of five, he also helped educate many nephews and nieces in the U.S., contributing to both his native and adopted lands. For more info, call: McMahon Lyon Hartnett Funeral Home: 914-949-7777.

title: 4 Iraq veterans in Japan commit suicide
Rangers Add Ozolinsh to Their Defense
description: As the N.H.L. trading deadline approached yesterday, the Rangers acquired the veteran defenseman Sandis Ozolinsh, who missed three months with Anaheim this season because of a knee injury and his voluntary entry in the league's substance- and alcohol-abuse program before playing for Latvia in the Olympics.

title: Arbitrator to Decide Awards in Boston Church Abuse Cases
description: BOSTON, March 9 - A second group of plaintiffs who say they were abused by priests in Boston has reached a settlement with the archdiocese here, agreeing to allow an arbitrator to determine the monetary award they will receive.

title: Madrid bombing case nearly ready
Paid Notice: Deaths   PARKS, GORDON
description: PARKS -- Gordon was so much to so many people, he became an Icon of his time. He was a beloved figure of multiple talents, but at ICP we knew him principally as a photographer. Cornell Capa included him with seven other photographers in his book "The Concerned Photographer II" published in 1972. We hosted a solo exhibition of his work in 1975, and included his work in exhibitions in 1974, 1983, 1988, 1989, 1993, 2003-2005. His spirit, his drive, his passion will inform our lives for as long as we can remember, and for that we are humbled and grateful. We express our sorrow at his passing, but venture to say that he will always be with us in his dignity and in his ability to connect with and express the human soul. Willis Hartshorn, Director Cornell Capa, Founding Director Emeritus For the Staff and Board of the International Center of Photography

description: Correction Appended

title: Post-Soviet Enclave Losing Lifeblood Trade
description: MOSCOW, March 9 - The government of a self-declared republic in Eastern Europe said Thursday that it was facing an economic and human crisis under pressure from Ukraine and the West to halt its unregistered trade.

title: Interior Secretary to End Tenure Marked by Conservation Battles
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 A Gale A. Norton, who as interior secretary has been a key player in the Bush administration's efforts to exploit natural resources on federal lands and a focal point of dissatisfaction by environmentalists, announced today that she was resigning, effective at the end of the month. She said that she had accomplished much of what she had intended to do, and hinted at fatigue.

title: The Hamptons in Winter: Less Glamour, More Elbow Room
description: NEW Yorkers going to the South Fork of Long Island in summer don't drive the Long Island Expressway; they endure it. But on the way out from Manhattan on a morning in February -- a Saturday morning, no less -- bumper-to-bumper traffic had gone into hibernation. Exits passed quickly, and then boom, Southampton appeared. Elapsed time: under two hours.

title: How the Clock Ran Out on the Dubai Ports Deal
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 - For days, White House officials and Congressional Republicans had prodded the United Arab Emirates and its state-owned DP World to give up on plans to acquire several port terminals in the United States, officials involved in the conversations said.

title: Bush Urges More Money for Religious Charities
description: COLLEGE PARK, Ga., March 9 - President Bush said Thursday that his administration had made progress by awarding more than $2.1 billion last year to social programs operated by churches, synagogues and mosques, a modest increase over 2004.

title: The Real Costs Of School Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Investing: Skewed for growth
Imax Seeks Sale to Company With Much Deeper Pockets
description: OTTAWA, March 9 - Imax, the company that specializes in outsize movies, said on Thursday that it would try to sell its operations to a corporation that is more on the scale of its giant screens.

title: Shame of Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Victory by Mexico Keeps U.S. Hopes Alive
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 9 - Members of Team USA were bewildered on Thursday, not because they sustained a shocking loss to Canada a day earlier but because they were still trying to understand the international tie-breaking system of the World Baseball Classic.

title: On the town: Action figures make tracks
Kidney Problem for Floyd Discovered After an Exam
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., March 9 - Several years ago, when the N.B.A.'s Alonzo Mourning found himself dealing with the serious issue of kidney failure, Cliff Floyd commiserated with him. For Floyd, there was a natural link. His father, Cornelius Floyd, has also lived with kidney failure. As a 13-year-old, with no driver's license, Cliff Floyd remembers driving his father to an emergency room to deal with his advancing kidney problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINKOWITZ, STANLEY, MD.
description: MINKOWITZ--Stanley, MD. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is saddened by the death of Dr. Stanley Minkowitz. Dr. Minkowitz had been associated with Maimonides Medical Center for many years. He was Director of Pathology from 1981 through 1994. He was instrumental in upgrading the Pathology Department and continuing an approved residency program. After leaving Maimonides he went into private practice with his son. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. Ira Mayer, MD, President Warren Wexelman, MD, President-Elect Steven Farber, MD, Secretary-Treasurer

title: Up Close and Personal in the Selection of a Jury
description: With the exception of the census, the driver's license line at the Department of Motor Vehicles and the midday crush in Times Square, there may be no better place to see democracy in action than during the selection of a jury.

title: A Blank Check for the President? (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Scenes From 'Pineapple Soup!'
description: The new show from the Paper Bag Players, a children's theater company, shows how far energy and a lot of paper can go.

title: Tipping Point vs. Freakonomics
description: Malcolm Gladwell, the best-selling author of The Tipping Point and trend-tracking guru to Wall Street and corporate America, has offered his take on Freakonomics, another best-selling book that makes surprising connections between social trends and market forces.

title: Hells Angels Wants to Stomp on  Disney Biker Movie
description: The Hells Angels Motorcycle Corporation. is suing a division of Walt Disney, Buena Vista Motion Pictures and a film production company for infringing on its trademark in the development and production of Wild Hogs, a comedy about middle-aged bikers.

title: Under Pressure, Dubai Company Drops Port Deal
description: The state-owned Dubai company seeking to manage some terminal operations at six American ports dropped out of the deal on Thursday, bowing to an unrelenting bipartisan attack in Congress that swept aside President Bushs efforts.

title: Pulse
description: For the beach, an atoll of necklaces, what the actress is wearing, peasant chic, no permafrost, something borrowed, something buff.

title: Start your engines!
description: The sound of the new Formula One V8 engines ripped across the desert outside Manama today as the series carried out its first practice session. They are just as loud as before, but lower pitched, and with a couple of V10s screaming around in harmony, there is room for discord.

title: Societe General Seen as a Possible Citigroup Target
description: The French government, which has thwarted takeovers in several industries in recent years, may soon face a major challenge in banking.

title: Merger Produces a Leading Retail Lender in New York
description: Power Express Mortgage Bank has acquired Berkshire Financial Group, a deal that makes the firm a top retail lender in New York state. Keith Kantrowitz, founder and president, said this is the first of many strategic acquisitions planned by Power Express as part of its national growth strategy.

title: Zucker Takes Helm at Hudsons Bay
description: Hudsons Bay, the Canadian retailer being taken private, said Thursday that American billionaire and new owner Jerry Zucker has become chief executive, effective immediately, and that the former chief executive, George Heller, will retire but remain a director.

title: Pitney Bowes Sells Lease Unit
description: Pitney Bowes , the largest supplier of postage meters and mailing machines in the United States, said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its Imagistics International Inc. lease portfolio to De Lage Landen Operational Services LLC, a unit of Rabobank Group of the Netherlands, for $280 million to $290 million.

title: Red Bull Takes a Shot With Purchase of MetroStars
description: Anschutz Entertainment Group has sold the MetroStars of New York and New Jersey, one of the five Major League Soccer teams it owned, to Red Bull , the Austrian company which produces the popular caffeinated drink. The team has been re-branded Red Bull New York, with a new logo and uniform.

title: British Property Web Site Prices IPO
description: Residential property Web site Rightmove has been valued at 425 million pounds after pricing its initial public offering at 335 pence amid strong investor interest.

title: Small Gain for Eagle Test Systems IPO
description: Eagle Test Systems  generated a slight gain Thursday as shares of the chip-testing company made its debut just months after withdrawing its deal.Eagle Test Systems opened at $16.65, above its $15.50 price. The IPO changed hands at $15.55 in recent action on the Nasdaq.

title: Game Over? Atari Receives Delisting Notice
description: Ataris days on the Nasdaq market may be numbered. The besieged video-game software maker warned investors on Thursday that it has received a delisting notice from the Nasdaq, because its stock price no longer meets the markets minimum bid price.

title: Brinks Sets a  Dutch Auction for 10 Million Shares
description: Brinks, following a round of activist activity, authorized a Dutch auction self-tender offer for as many as 10 million of its shares, or about 17 percent of its outstanding stock. The tender price range will be $47.50 to $52.50 per share. There are 58.7 million outstanding shares.

title: Islamic Bank Readies for  London I.P.O.
description: Britains first Islamic investment bank is to go public on the London Stock Exchange by the end of June with a 300 million pound price tag. The European Islamic Investment Bank, which is compliant with Sharia law, is planning to launch a 200 million pound fund-raising as part of its move on to the LSEs junior Alternative Investment Market.

title: Hybrid-Electric Car Systems Maker Raises $25 Million
description: ISE Corporation, a supplier of electric and hybrid-electric drive systems, has raised $25 million to make big trucks more environmentally friendly. The companys modular manufacturing of drive systems for trucks and buses, airport equipment, and military vehicles allows it to customize electric and hybrid-electric systems to customers specifications.

title: PacketFront Lands $27 Million Deal, Mulls IPO
description: Broadband access equipment vendor PacketFront  has landed a five-year, 23 million euro ($27.4 million) deal from Danish utility SEAS-NVE for its FTTH hardware and software. Now the company is considering an IPO.

title: Trilogy Partners Eyes Seattle Start-Ups
description: Trilogy Partners, the newly formed investment firm of former T-Mobile USA and Western Wireless Chief Executive John Stanton  continues to place bets on Seattle-area wireless and telecommunications startups.

title: Software Firm Bluespec Gets $4.5 Million in Funds
description: Bluespec has received $4.5 million in its second round of funding from Atlas Ventures and North Bridge Venture. To date, Bluespec, which makes electronic design automation tool sets, has received a total of $13 million in funding from Atlas Venture and North Bridge Venture Partners.

title: Volkswagen Sells European Rental Car Business for $1.5 Billion
description: Volkswagen has agreed to sell its Europcar rental car business to Eurazeo for 1.26 billion euros ($1.5 billion) to raise cash for a reorganization.

title: VNU Faces Uncertain Future
description: With its takeover plan on the rocks, VNU is facing an uncertain future alone, hunting for a CEO, slashing costs and coping with disgruntled investors who disagree over the market research giants strategy.

title: Fox Paine Co-Founder Takes a Back Seat
description: As Fox Paine & Company gears up to market its third fund, co-founder Saul A. Fox is dialing back his role at the firm, handing control over to fellow co-founder W. Dexter Paine III and three younger partners.

title: Permira Increases Offer for HMV
description: HMV has disclosed that the private equity firm Permira has increased its indicative offer for the music-to-books retailer to 210 pence a share. Permira made an offer of 190 pence a share in February that was rejected as undervaluing the business.

title: Filofax, Symbol of the 80s, Sold to Private Equity Firm
description: Letts Filofax, maker of the ultimate Eighties accessory, has been bought by Phoenix Equity Partners in a 45 million pound deal. The company, which makes the diaries and paper-based organizers that came to symbolize 1980s yuppiedom, was sold by Dunedin Capital Partners, the venture capital firm based in Scotland.

title: Levine Leichtman Expanding Into Distressed Debt
description: Levine Leichtman Capital Partners has added its name to the small but growing ranks of mid-market buyout shops raising distressed debt funds. The firm, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., manages about $1 billion across three structured equity funds. It has already collected around $300 million for Levine Leichtman Capital Partners Deep Value Fund. The closings put the firm well on its way toward the funds roughly $500 million target.

title: eBay Connects With Meetup.com
description: eBay yesterday joined five other investors to purchase a minority share in community Web site Meetup.com. The investment will total just more than 10% equity interest in Meetup.com, which connects folks to affinity groups like stay-at-home moms or Chihuahua lovers for offline gatherings.

title: Archipelago Investors Cash In
description: Private equity firm General Atlantic Partners LLC and Wall Street stalwart Goldman Sachs Group Inc. took a chance on Archipelago Holdings Inc. as it was just starting up in January 1997. With Archipelago now a part of the NYSE Group, those early investors are poised to cash in big.

title: Real-Estate Hedge Funds on the Radar
description: Several notable names are in the midst of raising money for new real estate-focused hedge funds. Among those getting in on the act, are Jay Leupp, managing director of equity research at RBC Capital Markets and Colony Capital, a firm headed by legendary real estate investor Tom Barrack,.

title: Fastow Admits He Cant Prove He Made Illegal Side Deals With Enrons Former Chief
description: Andrew S. Fastow conceded on Thursday that he had little proof that Enrons former chief, Jeffrey K. Skilling, made secret side agreements with him to purchase company assets.

title: Canadian Banks Safe Despite High Consumer Debt, UBS Says
description: Even though Canadians are shouldering record levels of personal debt, it would take a dramatic rise in interest rates and a major shift in consumer borrowing before bank earnings would suffer, according to UBS Securities Canada Inc.

title: Compass Bancshares Wins Approval for TexasBanc  Buy
description: The Federal Reserve Board this week gave final regulatory approval to Compass Bancshares Inc.s purchase of TexasBanc Holding Co. and its subsidiary, TexasBank.

title: Gabelli Vows to Fight Allegations
description: Investor Mario Gabelli vowed Thursday to fight allegations he tried to swindle the government, as shares of his company, GAMCO Investors Inc., bounced back a day after the Justice Department moved to join a civil lawsuit against him.

title: Goldman and Lehman Expected to Lead Profits Higher
description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. probably will lead Wall Street to its second-highest quarterly profit, as fees from advising on the most mergers since 2000 made up for slower growth in trading.

title: Goldman a Victim of Its Own Success
description: Goldman Sachs  was excluded from Chinas biggest initial public offering because it is already arranging the countrys third-largest share sale, bankers at competing securities firms said.

title: Morgan Stanley Makes Leveraged Finance Hires
description: Morgan Stanley continued to build its leveraged finance business by hiring two veteran executives from GE Capital, according to a memo on Thursday from Michael Hart, global co-head of the acquisition and leveraged finance group.

title: McClatchy Is Said to Lead in Knight Ridder Bidding
description: The McClatchy Company emerged yesterday as the leading bidder to acquire Knight Ridder, which owns The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Miami Herald, with a binding bid worth more than $4.8 billion in cash and stock, according to press reports. Texas Pacific Group and Thomas H. Lee Partners, submitted a nonbinding bid, known as an indication of interest, for about $4.7 billion in cash, these people said.

title: Google Gets Writerly With Software Acquisition
description: Showing that its more than a little interested in enabling people to handle office tasks over the Internet, Google said Thursday that it has snapped up Writely, a maker of a Web-based word processor.

title: Thain Expects to Play Active Role in Exchange Consolidation
description: New York Stock Exchange Chief Executive John Thain said on Thursday that he aims to play an active role in the next round of consolidation in the exchange sector, and that worries about competition from overseas rivals had driven the Big Boards move to go public.

title: Imax Screens Suitors
description: Imax, the company that specializes in outsize movies, said on Thursday that it would try to sell its operations to a corporation that is more on the scale of its giant screens.

title: Televisa Group Takes Pole Position in Race for Univision
description: A consortium of companies and investors that includes the Mexican television giant Grupo Televisa has emerged as a potential bidder for Univision, the largest Spanish-language television and radio company in the United States.

title: Uniteds Restructuring Includes a Hefty Bill from Lawyers
description: United Airlines three-year bankruptcy restructuring, the largest and longest in the industrys history, will end up costing the carrier more than $335 million in fees to lawyers and consultants, court documents show. The fees include $99.8 million charged by the airlines lead law firm during the 38-month process, Chicago-based Kirkland & Ellis LLC, pending formal approval by U.S. Bankruptcy Court.

title: Investors Undaunted by Hedge Fund Meltdowns
description: Hedge fund blowups make for scary headlines but so far they have not frightened investors into looking more closely at how these slightly regulated funds operate before putting money in, new research shows.

title: S.E.C. Is Going Too Far in Corporate Crackdowns, Chamber of Commerce Says
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, which gained more authority to punish corporate wrongdoing in a government crackdown on fraud four years earlier, is going too far, according to a U.S. Chamber of Commerce.

title: Sun Microsystems Gets a Little Help from Its 170 Lawyers
description: Sun Microsystems General Counsel Mike Dillon, who is at the helm of the companys roughly 170-lawyer legal department, is crucial in helping the Silicon Valley computing giant navigate its deals, including its multibillion-dollar spending spree last summer. Dillons team defies the classic image of in-house lawyers lined up in offices alongside the chain of command. The legal department is instead tethered together in a highly unconventional arrangement: Many work off-site connected into Sun by computer.

title: Bob Igers Big Day at the Mouse House
description: Dashing concerns that hed be slow to step out of the formidable shadow of his predecessor, Michael Eisner, Walt Disney s chief executive, Bob Iger, quickly moved to center stage. He reeled in dissident shareholders, dismantled the companys unpopular strategic planning group and orchestrated a $7.4-billion acquisition to bring Pixar Animation Studios into the Disney family for good.

title: Entrepreneur Knocking on Door of London Exchange
description: The London Stock Exchange is to investigate the suitability of Robert Bonnier, the colorful entrepreneur, to head a listed company again after he announced his comeback this week.

title: Silent Tort Reform Is Overriding States Powers
description: Supporters and detractors call it the  silent tort reform movement, and it has quietly and quickly been gaining ground.

title: Google Cant Click Away Fraud Worries
description: Google seems to think it has wiped away its click fraud worries by settling a class-action suit. It hasnt. Google is trying to argue that click fraud is just a blip on the huge Internet-advertising radar, but the settlement indicates that its at least a problemsomething Google executives were loath to admit just a week ago.

title: Airlines Accused of Price-Fixing in Suit
description: Eleven of the worlds major airlines, including British Airways, Deutsche Lufthansa, United Airlines and Japan Airlines, have been sued by a Tanzanian company, which accuses them of conspiring to fix fuel price surcharges for cargo flights.

title: New Colony
description: Fifteen Gulf Coast artists who were uprooted by Hurricane Katrina have been relocated to Manhattan.
Selborne Journal: 10 March 1759:  Vast tempest all night, & this morning; which at noon blew-down the weather-cock on the tower.

title: TNRs Mea Culpa on Healthcare
Carlyle Group Targets Public Works With Latest Fund
description: Carlyle Group, the politically plugged-in private equity giant based in Washington, is moving even deeper into the public sector.

title: Paging Carl Icahn! Shareholders Push to Expense Proxy Fight Costs
description: Shareholder activists are going to love this: A major institutional shareholder is pushing American Express, Citigroup and Bank of New York to amend their bylaws to allow for reimbursement of expenses in proxy contests where a dissident shareholder seeks to elect less than a majority of the board. The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) is the one pushing the proposal and has suggested that not just the winners should be reimbursed, but losers too.

title: Citadel CEO Hedges His Bets on I.P.O. Question
description: Kenneth Griffin is quite happy to tell the Chicago Tribune about how well his hedge fund is doing so far this year. Well, not happy enough to disclose firm numbers  but he did say that the year-to-date performance at Citadel Investment Groups biggest fund, Kensington, was better than the anemic 7 percent gain it achieved in 2005.

title: Defending Private Equity (And Getting Mom and Pop to Invest)
description: In the latest sign that private equity mania has filtered down to Main Street, retail-investor-oriented SmartMoney.com is running a question-and-answer story about buyout activity and how individual investors can get in on the act.

title: Unloading on the Ports Deal
description: Rarely is there such unanimity in opinionland: The Dubai ports flap has been bad for the United States. At times like these, the key question for editorial writers, columnists and bloggers is whether to react with sorrow or with anger.

title: Googles Writerly Deal: A Symptom of Start-Up Fever?
description: Two major questions emerge from Googles recently announced acquisition of Web-based word-processing start-up Writely. The obvious one  how does it fit Googles business strategy?  is generating a lot of discussion, as one would expect. But the secondary question  why are tiny Internet companies with no business model being bought so quickly?  is getting louder as well.

title: Ask Science
description: This week, Kenneth Chang answered reader questions about his article Visual Lesson on Lava Spares No Calories from this week's Science Times.

title: Where Were You on March 10, 2000?    The Nasdaq Was at 5,048.
description: With all the Google-watching of late, we failed to notice that Friday marked the sixth anniversary of the all-time high for the Nasdaq index.

title: Nasdaq Is London Calling: L.S.E. Rebuffs $4 Billion Offer
description: It may be in the market for a buyer, but the London Stock Exchange is apparently not impressed with a recent approach from the Nasdaq Stock Market. The London exchange said midday Friday that it had rejected an offer from the Nasdaq to acquire it for 950 pence per share in cash, or about $4 billion.

title: Typecasting Roles
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Update: Spurned by London, Nasdaq Stock Still Surges
description: Shareholders of the Nasdaq Stock Market werent put off by Fridays news that its offer to buy the London Stock Exchange had been swatted down. In fact, they seemed positively thrilled. They sent Nasdaqs shares up more than 6 percent Friday afternoon in much heavier-than-normal volume.

title: Could Tough Love From Cheney Calm Iraq?
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans March 10 column, Mr. Nasty, Brutish and Short-Tempered

title: Analysis: Was Nasdaqs CEO Caught Bluffing?
description: Robert Greifeld, Nasdaqs chief executive, may have been caught bluffing, according to our Wall Street reporter and resident exchange expert, Jenny Anderson.

title: Credit Suisse Spreads the Stock-Bonus Love
description: There are a lot more golden handcuffs being passed around at Credit Suisse.

title: High and Lo
description: Anita Lo, chef, offers up a garlicky pork belly dish at Annisa.(Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

title: Steps to Avoid War
description: Michael R. Gordon reports that even as the U.S. invaded, Saddam Hussein saw Iraqi unrest as the top threat.

title: The Weapons Question
description: Michael R. Gordon reports that even as the U.S. invaded, Saddam Hussein saw Iraqi unrest as the top threat.

title: Saddam's Defenses
description: Michael R. Gordon reports that even as the U.S. invaded, Saddam Hussein saw Iraqi unrest as the top threat.

title: Betting on Biloxi
description: As casinos become the dominant force in the local economy, who wins and who loses as Biloxi, Miss., rebuilds?  (Producer:  Craig Duff)

title: Vows: Gia Miller and Daniel Doron
description: Daniel Doron and Gia Miller describe their inital meeting during a blind date, and Daniel's creative marriage proposal. (Producer: Kassie Bracken)

title: Plight Deepens for Black Men
description: A number of new studies indicate that poor black men are making no gains against poverty. (Produced by Matthew Orr & Adam Ellick)

title: The Moussaoui Sentencing
description: The Times's Neil A. Lewis discusses the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui.

title: Be on TV!
description: Here is your opportunity to be on TV. Or at least earn $500.

title: Nashville Gets Hot
description: If you listen carefully, youll hear the sound of hundreds of Nashville residents applying to be real estate agents. It is one of the few major markets these days that is showing home sales increasing year over year despite mortgage rates hitting 2 1/2 year highs.

title: The Bubble in Housing Stocks
description: Even if we never get that satisfying crash in home prices that the bubble bloggers long for, we may be getting one in the shares of publicly traded home builders.

title: The Advice Stays the Same
description: The doyen of New York real estate, Barbara Corcoran, sat down with ABC News to offer home owners advice on what to do in this market.

title: When Your Garage is a Hangar
description: This is probably interesting to only a very limited audience, but youll have to forgive me because my wife is a pilot and every so often she talks about the idea of living in a place where wed have a runway in the backyard.

title: A Bargain Is In the Eye of the Beholder
description: To prepare for the conversion from rental to condominium, the building where Aleeza Wadler and Dmitry Nemirovsky live, on West 79th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, got a $4 million revamp. This included a switch from manned to automatic elevators.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a civilian review board's decision to charge a deputy police chief in New York with abuse of authority for his role in an arrest during the 2004 Republican National Convention referred imprecisely in some copies to the status of seven other complaints against the police stemming from the convention. The board completed its review of those cases on Wednesday; they are not still open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICHOLSON, WILLIAM BRYCE
description: NICHOLSON--William Bryce. 93. On February 27, of Short Hills, NJ. Retired Vice Chairman of Union Carbide Corp. Survived by his wife, Marion; daughter, Jan; and daughter, Barbara McFadyen, and her two children, Rachel and Ryan, and grandchild, Nicholas. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM on Monday, March 13, at the Community Congregational Church, 200 Hartshorn Drive, Short Hills.

title: Anna Moffo, 73, a Star at the Met Opera, Is Dead
description: Anna Moffo, an American soprano who was beloved for her rosy voice, dramatic vulnerability and exceptional beauty, died on Thursday night at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in New York. She was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 10, 2006

title: Dutch Court Convicts 9 Under Tougher Antiterror Law
description: PARIS, March 10 - A Dutch court on Friday found nine members of a radical Islamist group guilty of belonging to a terrorist organization and handed down sentences of as much as 15 years in prison.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Survivor' vs. 'Idol'
description: "American Idol" is killing "Survivor." On Thursday, it narrowed the talent pool to 12 finalists, delivering a typically huge 26.3 million viewers for Fox; CBS's "Survivor," once a giant of reality television but for the last three weeks a lagging competitor to "Idol," had 15.3 million. In Nielsen's estimates for the night over all, CBS was No. 1 in total viewers, thanks to "CSI" (27.2 million) and "Without a Trace" (20.3 million). But Fox won among 18-to-49-year-olds even though "The O.C." (7.5 million) lost a vast majority of the "Idol" audience. Though they were in direct competition on Wednesday at 10 p.m., FX's premiere of "Black. White." (4 million) and Bravo's "Project Runway" finale (3.4 million) both scored very high ratings for cable programs. "Runway," in which Chloe Dao won the design competition, brought in the best ratings in Bravo's history. KATE AURTHUR

title: Newsmaker and Film Star, Bonds Puts ESPN on Spot
description: With Barry Bonds, real life is altering the original concept of ESPN's scheduled 10-hour cinma vrit series. No longer is it a behind-the-scenes look at his outsize celebrity as he chases Babe Ruth's and Hank Aaron's home run totals.

title: Some Finding Perils in Online Real Estate
description: For the last few years, real estate transactions over the Internet -- where buyers need never set eyes on the property they purchase -- have become increasingly common.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MODELL, MICHAEL S.
description: MODELL--Michael S. March 11, 1953--April 28, 2001. On your birthday we celebrate your spirit and the very special man you were. We love you and miss you more with each passing day. Mom, Dad and the family

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Hitler-Bush Case Is Resolved
description: A high school geography teacher in Aurora who compared a speech by President Bush to language used by Hitler and sparked an uproar in the Denver region will return to the classroom on Monday after an investigation by school officials. The teacher, Jay Bennish, who had been on paid leave from Overland High School, said he was trying to make students think in a lecture on Feb. 1 that a student recorded. The State Board of Education split on Thursday, four Republicans vs. four Democrats, over a resolution condemning Mr. Bennish. A bill in the State Senate would allow teachers to be fired for violating school district policies that require balanced presentations. KIRK JOHNSON (NYT)

title: Employers Sharply Criticize Shift in Unionizing Method to Cards From Elections
description: Above the photographs of Fidel Castro, Kim Jong Il of North Korea and an American union president, the full-page advertisement contains a provocative quotation: "There is no reason to subject the workers to an election."

title: U.S. Pushes for Broad Coalition as Iraqi Parliament Prepares to Open
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 10 - The American ambassador to Iraq, seeking to break the stalemate over the formation of a new government, is urging the nation's political leaders to hold a conference somewhere in Iraq to broker a grand coalition, the embassy's spokeswoman said Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISEMAN, JAY
description: ISEMAN--Jay. The partners, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death on March 9th of Jay Iseman, beloved wife of our former partner and of counsel, Joseph S. Iseman. We express our deepest sympathies to her descendents. $(6$)ISEMAN--June L. "Jay", 81. Passed away peacefully on March 9, 2006. Survived by husband, Joseph S. Iseman, children Anne, Susan, and William Hamilton and six grandchildren. She was born in Fertile, MN. Active in community affairs, a splendid athlete, and a successful interior designer. Family will receive friends at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY 10580 on Saturday, March 11, 7-9PM. Service to be held at Rye Presbyterian Church on Sunday, March 12 at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Roker Adult Center, 252 Bryant Ave, White Plains, New York 10603.

title: U.S. Shakes Up Airport Security at Newark
description: The federal government is shaking up the management of security operations at Newark Liberty International Airport, which has been plagued by screening lapses and poor morale.

title: Western Lenders File Suit for Their Piece of Yukos Oil
description: MOSCOW, March 10 - A consortium of Western banks led by Socit Gnrale of France filed suit in Moscow Friday seeking to have the Yukos Oil Company declared bankrupt just over a year after the Kremlin seized its largest production asset in a politically tinged tax dispute.

title: The Collapse of the Port Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy Meets Girl, Then They Both Meet the Folks in the Audience
description: The six actors in Jeffrey Sweet's "Bluff" have a great time working the incongruity-filled script. Now if only they weren't so intent on making sure the audience knows they're having a great time.

title: Judge Issues Secret Ruling in Case of 2 at Mosque
description: A federal judge issued a highly unusual classified ruling yesterday, denying a motion for dismissal of a case against two leaders of an Albany mosque who are accused of laundering money in a federal terrorism sting operation.

title: Recapturing an Old Fount of Euphoria
description: Before James Brown, there was George M. Cohan, at least when it comes to the label "the Hardest-Working Man in Show Business." Before his death in 1942, Cohan almost single-handedly invented the American musical comedy, writing more than 50 shows (more than 40 of them before 1920), and hundreds of songs: brash, cocky, energetic and endlessly euphoric. This also describes "George M. Cohan Tonight!," the new one-man musical starring Jon Peterson and devised by Chip Deffaa, at the Irish Repertory Theater.

title: Christian Worker Kidnapped in Iraq Last Year Is Found Slain
description: An American Christian aid worker kidnapped last year in Iraq has been killed, according to the State Department and the group he worked with.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about negotiations over Iran's nuclear program misstated a word in part of a comment by the Bush administration's representative to the International Atomic Energy Agency, Gregory L. Schulte. He said Iran's leaders had chosen "a course of flagrant threats and phony negotiations," not "phone negotiations."

title: With Stars Out of Camp, Prospect Takes Advantage
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 10 - With so many big names still at the World Baseball Classic, the team that the Yankees brought to face the Reds at Ed Smith Stadium on Friday barely made a ripple on the pizazz scale. Mike Mussina pitched, and only three of the nine hitters in the lineup had any significant major league experience: Miguel Cairo, Kelly Stinnett and Russ Johnson.

title: Queens Men Seek Seat in a Congress 2,500 Miles Away
description: If the voters turn out for Jairo Casas this Sunday, he will say goodbye to all that -- meaning, all that shark cartilage, bee pollen and cat's claw -- and take up a prestigious congressional seat in Colombia, representing Jackson Heights and other enclaves of Colombian expatriates beyond New York.

title: The Collapse of the Port Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Spacecraft Enters Orbit Around Mars
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 - The most sophisticated spacecraft ever sent to Mars slipped into orbit on Friday after successfully firing braking rockets and maneuvering itself into position while tense controllers monitored from Earth.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about negotiations over Iran's nuclear program misstated a word in part of a comment by the Bush administration's representative to the International Atomic Energy Agency, Gregory L. Schulte. He said Iran's leaders had chosen "a course of flagrant threats and phony negotiations," not "phone negotiations."

title: Funeral for Gordon Parks
description: The funeral service for Gordon Parks, the photojournalist, filmmaker and writer who died last Tuesday, will be held on Tuesday at 2 p.m. at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122nd Street, Morningside Heights.

title: Key Player for President Is Resigning at Interior
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 - Gale A. Norton announced Friday that she was resigning as interior secretary, saying that she had accomplished much of what she had intended to do, and hinting at fatigue.

title: Negotiators Hope to Make Progress on Trade Pact
description: LONDON, March 10 - Officials from the countries that account for 60 percent of global trade opened talks in London on Friday to try to break their long-entrenched differences in the hopes of saving a mired international trade agreement.

title: The Consequences of War Can Be Deep and Everlasting
description: Lurking somewhere in "Savages," a ramrod-stiff new play by Anne Nelson at the Lion Theater on Theater Row, is a cogent, compelling op-ed piece yearning to be set free.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Halt To Adoptions
description: Catholic Charities, the social services branch of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, will stop arranging adoptions because state law requires it to assist gay and lesbian couples. The agency, which has been providing adoption services for more than 20 years, said it could not "reconcile the teaching of the church" with state law. The four bishops in the state announced last month that the church would petition for an exemption from the antidiscrimination law, and seven board members of Catholic Charities resigned in protest. Gov. Mitt Romney announced plans for a bill to give religious organizations that provide adoptions an exemption to antidiscrimination laws. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: Washington Post to Cut 80 Newsroom Jobs
description: The Washington Post is planning to cut about 80 jobs, or about 9 percent of its newsroom, over the next year, joining a roll call of major American newspapers reducing editorial positions as the industry continues to face a sluggish advertising environment and declining circulation.

title: Sweet She Ain't, and She Has the Stories to Prove It
description: THE Inner Circle, a troupe of current and former City Hall reporters with not enough stage fright, will present its annual follies at a Midtown hotel tonight. Hundreds of people who like to be in on the joke will watch as journalists lampoon the bluster and blunder that can sometimes define civics in this city.

title: Man's Shoes Set Off Alarm at La Guardia
description: Security officials evacuated a terminal at La Guardia Airport for about two hours yesterday afternoon after a traveler walked away from a checkpoint wearing shoes that had set off an alarm.

title: New Hurdles for Premier as Election Nears in Italy
description: ROME, March 10 - A month before tight national elections, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi was hit Friday with two embarrassments: Prosecutors asked that he be put on trial for corruption, and his health minister resigned over accusations that he spied on political opponents.

title: Contractor Pleads Guilty to Theft From Roslyn Schools
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., March 10 - When he used a Roslyn school district credit card in 2002 at a Home Depot store in Selden, John McCormick unwittingly set off a chain of inquiry that eventually led investigators to uncover the theft of $11.2 million from the district.

title: Racing to Albany, Spitzer and Suozzi Also Race to Airwaves
description: There are few New York Democrats as competitive as the two men seeking the party's nomination for governor this year, Eliot Spitzer and Thomas R. Suozzi, and it appears that their rivalry extends even to getting the first television campaign commercials of 2006 on the air.

title: Report Offers More Details on Fund-Raiser for Rell
description: HARTFORD, March 10 - When the chief of staff to Gov. M. Jodi Rell called top state administrators into her office late last year and asked them to distribute invitations to their subordinates for a campaign fund-raiser for the governor, not everyone agreed and some who did were clearly uncomfortable doing so, according to a report by the State Elections Enforcement Commission.

title: A Mosque Is Lost, and Interfaith Bonds Are Found
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. - Imam Rasul Faheem Seifullah, leader of the Al-Baqi Islamic Center here, says he has always considered building bridges to other religious groups as an important part of his ministry. When a fire destroyed his mosque in December 2004, those bridges became lifelines for his small congregation of Sunni Muslims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLABBY, JOHN J., THE HONORABLE
description: CLABBY--John J., the Honorable, on March 9, 2006. Retired Supreme Court Justice, Courts of Queens. Beloved husband of Gloria and the late Emily G. Loving father of Susan Young (John), Daniel (Marian) and the late John. Beloved grandfather of John, Kathleen, Michael, Susan A. and Thomas. Devoted brother of Robert. Loving uncle of Ann Carrozza and other nieces and nephews. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing. Mass of Christian Burial Monday at St. Mel R.C. Church at 10:30AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-10. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Flushing Hospital, Cardiology Department, 45th Ave at Parsons Blvd, Flushing, NY 11355. $(6$)CLABBY--John J., Hon. The Queens County Bar Association records with deep sorrow the passing on March 9, 2006 of its distinguished member, retired Justice of the Supreme Court and Past President 1972-1973. Viewing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 PM and 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10:30 am, St. Mel's Roman Catholic Church, 28-28 154 Street, Flushing. George J. Nashak, Jr., President

title: Ambien in the Driver's Seat
description: Some people who use the popular sleeping pill Ambien sure seem to be having bizarre experiences these days. The incidents they report range from middle-of-the-night telephone conversations that they don't remember the next morning to truly dangerous behavior that threatens harm to themselves or to others. Ambien has been implicated in enough automobile accidents that it has commanded the attention of top forensic scientists.

title: About That Rebellion ...
description: We keep hearing that the Republicans in Congress are in revolt against the president.

title: A Blog Writes the Obituary of TV
description: ONE recent week, the video blog Rocketboom drew an average of 200,000 people a day to watch its short daily news reports on technology, the arts and other topics.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GONZALEZ, ARKY
description: GONZALEZ - Arky. Died March 11, 2004. Formerly with Time-Life. We miss your wit and humor-sparkling and dry. We love you and remember you each day. Love, Maura

title: The Collapse of the Port Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Rite of Spring, Upper West Side Version: Allmans Are Back
description: The Allman Brothers Band started their annual spring ritual on Thursday night, with the first of 14 concerts at the Beacon Theater. That many shows, spread out over three weeks in a midsize theater, means that the audience is spared the indignity of piling inside an arena in New Jersey. It also means that the stage can become a lab, with different guests and different approaches to second-set jams.

title: Class, Child-Rearing And Destiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Describes the Circumstances for a Levee Failure
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 10 - One of the city's major levees failed during Hurricane Katrina because of a combination of factors that had not been anticipated by the Army Corps of Engineers when it planned the city's flood protection, according to a new report that the corps released Friday.

title: Deconstructing the Hidden Exploitations
description: Watching Francesca Harper ridicule beauty pageants for nearly two hours is difficult, but not because beauty pageants are vapid or antifeminist or exploitative. The real trouble occurs simply because, in the end, you can't help rooting for the pageant.

title: Mayor Says Dubai Deal Critics Were Slow to Raise Objections
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used some decidedly caustic language yesterday in criticizing public officials for belatedly raising questions about port security, concerns that derailed a deal with a Dubai company to take over several American port operations.

title: A Primer to the Climbs and Falls of Men
description: One day in the not-to-distant future, a Ph.D. candidate is going to write a dissertation on the climbing tribes of the early 21st century, how they endured lives of extreme asceticism in a society increasingly based on materialism, where they worshipped (from Nepal to the boulders in New York's Central Park) and the artifacts they left behind. But until that piece is written, I would like to offer the following guide. I have no academic credentials and cannot even pretend that this is objective, but I have been a member of several of these tribes over the course of my climbing career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTER, ROBERT H.
description: ALTER--Robert H., 77. On March 10, 2006. Founder, Past President and CEO of Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau, founder and past President of Temple Beth Shalom, Member of the Broadcasting and Cable Hall of Fame since 2003. He was a resident of Hastings - on - Hudson and Martha's Vineyard. He served on many community and professional boards. Survived by his beloved wife, Lucile, cherished daughters Deborah Alter, Amy Alter Jeffereis and Midge Alter Caparosa, five adored grandchildren, his mother-in-law Sylvia Levine. Predeceased by daughter Maureen Baron. Funeral at 11 A.M. Sunday Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY (Saw Mill Exit 17). Memorials to ALS Foundation, Temple Beth Shalom or Young Adult Institute, NY, NY.

title: Spring Is Near, but the Traditional Welcoming Kites of Lahore Are Grounded
description: QUETTA, Pakistan, March 10 - For the first time in memory, no kites will flutter in the Lahore sky for the boisterous spring festival known as Basant, which this year falls on Sunday.

title: After Katrina, Artists Find a New Colony
description: Like other circumstantial heroes of Katrina, Dan Tague did his part. With a canoe and later a motorboat, he said, he and his friends plucked 40 to 50 people from the roofs and attics of the Mid-City neighborhood in New Orleans and ferried them to dry land.

title: Plowing the Seas With That Iconic Bearded Pirate
description: It's hard to imagine Clint Eastwood in a pirate movie, but if he made one, he might seem a lot like James Purefoy in the National Geographic Channel's "Blackbeard." This Blackbeard never actually says, "Make my day," but you can tell he's thinking it.

title: Corrections
description: Correction Appended

title: Chile's Socialist President Exits Enjoying Wide Respect
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 10 - Ricardo Lagos Escobar barely squeaked into office six years ago, winning just a hair over half of the vote in a hard-fought runoff. On Saturday, though, he will step down as president of Chile with three-quarters of the population saying they approve of his performance, according to recent opinion surveys.

title: Giants Sign Sam Madison
description: Filling several voids in the secondary is an off-season priority for the Giants, and the team did not wait until the start of free agency to make its first big move. Sam Madison, a four-time Pro Bowler who spent the first nine seasons of his career with the Miami Dolphins, agreed to terms with the Giants yesterday, according to Madison's agent, Drew Rosenhaus.

title: Symbol of Abu Ghraib Seeks to Spare Others His Nightmare
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 8 - Almost two years later, Ali Shalal Qaissi's wounds are still raw.

title: They've Got Spirit! But It Isn't All Cheers
description: It could have been called "Top Cheerleader" or "Project Cheerleader," but this is Lifetime, where things are always a little off, so the reality show that starts tomorrow night is called "Cheerleader Nation," employing a titling tic that is well past its heyday.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Merrill Lynch Pays Its Chairman $37 Million As Investment Banks Report Salaries The chairman of Merrill Lynch, E. Stanley O'Neal, left, received 2005 compensation of $37 million, an increase of 15 percent over 2004, while the chief executive of Bear Stearns Companies, James E. Cayne, received at least $28.4 million, up 8.8 percent, according to regulatory filings yesterday. Mr. O'Neal, 54, received $700,000 in salary and a bonus of $34.3 million that included $20.2 million in restricted stock. He was also tentatively awarded $2 million that the company included in his total compensation but will get it only if Merrill hits a profit target over the next three years. Mr. Cayne received $200,000 in salary, a $12.7 million bonus, $10.3 million of restricted stock, and $5.2 million of other compensation. Among other chief executives, Henry M. Paulson Jr. of the Goldman Sachs Group Inc. received $38.8 million, while Richard S. Fuld Jr. at Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. was paid $34.5 million. (REUTERS)

title: Who's Afraid of Polygamy?
description: If gay marriage becomes legal, its opponents have been warning, the next step in America's moral deterioration will be legalized polygamy. These conservatives won't be happy with "Big Love," the HBO series starting tomorrow night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MINDLIN, MICHAEL
description: MINDLIN--Michael. Always thinking of you especially today, your birthday. Freda

title: Anthrax Patient's Condition Slips to Serious
description: A drummer from Manhattan who contracted inhalation anthrax last month after working with unprocessed animal skins suffered a "temporary setback" on Thursday evening, and was downgraded to serious condition, hospital officials said yesterday in a statement.

title: The Collapse of the Port Deal (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating 25 Years Onstage and in the Classroom
description: Rebecca Kelly Ballet celebrated its 25th anniversary with a gala event at John Jay College on Thursday that included guest artists, heartfelt speeches and a video montage of Ms. Kelly's work onstage and in the classroom.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Another Loud Summer for Ozzfest and Warped

title: Sailing Calmly and at Warp Speed Through Water and Fire
description: Paul Taylor and his choreography have been much praised for the questionable virtue of accessibility. Nothing mysterious about his dances, people say. They are feel-good fun that anyone can enjoy.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Croatian Journalist Fined
description: The Yugoslav war crimes tribunal fined a journalist and a former Croatian intelligence chief $18,000 each for publishing the name of a secret witness and the testimony he gave in the trial of Tihomir Blaskic, a Croatian officer. The court said that Markica Rebic, the former intelligence chief, provided the material that was published by Ivica Marijacic, the editor of the Hrvatski List newspaper in November 2004. It is the first time the tribunal has punished a journalist for contempt of court. Four other Croatian journalists are awaiting trial for similar disclosures of secret information. MARLISE SIMONS (NYT)

title: A Bartok Opera in Concert, About Death and Matrimony
description: James Levine is hurt and has missed the Boston Symphony's road trip this week. Kurt Masur had heart palpitations in Dublin and is day to day for the London Philharmonic's concerts in the United States. Christoph von Dohnanyi was out of the lineup at the New York Philharmonic a week ago, but he was back in uniform last night. And in other good news, Plcido Domingo is off the injured list and back singing in "Cyrano de Bergerac" at the Metropolitan Opera. Sports fans, it has been a tough month.

title: U.N. Delays Action on Rights Council Opposed by U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 10 - The United Nations on Friday extended by a week its deadline for seeking approval of a new human rights council that is opposed by the United States but backed by rights groups and a vast majority of the 191 member states.

title: Before Balco, Bonds Was Almost a Brave
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. - WITH Barry Bonds immersed in a renewed steroids frenzy, what could be more timely than a book disclosing that it might have all been avoided? Had the Pittsburgh Pirates not reneged on a trade in 1992, nine months before Bonds became a free agent and signed with the San Francisco Giants, Bonds would have been a member of the Atlanta Braves.

title: Class, Child-Rearing And Destiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Faulted on Response to Antitrust Ruling in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, March 10 - The European Commission on Friday again accused Microsoft of flouting a 2004 antitrust ruling, with an independent monitor calling the company's responses "incomplete, inaccurate and unusable."

title: Split Verdict Ends Trial of Ex-Mayor of Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, March 10 - After a five-year investigation that culminated in a two-month-long trial, it took the jury hearing the federal corruption case against former Mayor William C. Campbell only two days to find him not guilty of perhaps the most serious charges against him: racketeering and bribery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOORSTEIN, MAXINE
description: BOORSTEIN - Maxine. Be loved wife of Alan. Devoted mother of Jonathan. Loving daughter of Selma Odze. Dear sister of Warren Odze. Adored sister-in-law of Martin, Raymond and Richard. Dear aunt and great-aunt. Will be missed by all who knew her. Services Sunday 10AM, "Sinai Chapels," 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: U.S. Spacecraft Enters Orbit Around Mars
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  The most sophisticated spacecraft ever sent to Mars slipped into orbit on Friday after successfully firing braking rockets and maneuvering itself into position while tense controllers monitored from Earth.

title: Traveling Troupers Find All the World's a Fringe
description: When John Clancy helped found the New York International Fringe Festival nine years ago, its productions were synonymous with anonymous. Then "Urinetown," from the 1999 festival, transferred to Broadway (and made money), and the Fringe suddenly wasn't only fringe anymore. Since then more than a dozen of its shows have gone on to various runs Off Broadway and beyond.

title: Of Crowds, Couples and Loners
description: Human relationships are the focus of Donna Scro Gentile and her Freespace Dance company. But specific relationships were only hinted at in Ms. Gentile's new "Human Walls," on Thursday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. Instead, 25 men and women surged about the luminous space, moving in and out of large patterns and peeling off into couples for encounters that suggested love and hostility as a musical ensemble performed Glen Fittin's commissioned score.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,300 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Take Your Pills, All Your Pills
description: Joseph A. Brocato's weekly self-injections of a drug to treat hepatitis C left him so feverish and fatigued, he said, he often thought of quitting. He didn't, thanks to a nurse who urged him by phone to stay the course.

title: London Rejects Bid by Nasdaq
description: The London Stock Exchange, Europe's biggest stock market, announced yesterday that it had received and rejected a $4.1 billion informal cash offer from Nasdaq, an indication that the arms race among the world's leading exchanges is escalating.

title: National Briefing
description: ROCKIES

title: Class, Child-Rearing And Destiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Port Deal's Collapse Stirs Fears of Repercussions in Mideast Ties
description: Correction Appended

title: Construction About to Start on Ground Zero Memorial
description: Without the fanfare attending previous milestones at ground zero, construction of the World Trade Center memorial and museum will begin on Monday.

title: Thriller No. 3 for McNamara and Syracuse
description: For two star-kissed afternoons at the Big East tournament this week, Gerry McNamara's clutch shooting reminded everyone at Madison Square Garden of the transcendent power of postseason basketball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REEVE, DANA
description: REEVE--Dana. The Williamstown Theatre Festival Board and Staff offer our condolences and sympathies to the Reeve and Morosini families for the untimely loss of their beautiful Dana. It is a great loss to the WTF family. Her generous and creative spirit will be remembered at the Festival.

title: No Stranger to Fine Cognacs
description: A WINTER wind sliced through the sidewalks of TriBeCa like a giant razor blade, chafing my cheeks and piercing all the way to my spine. I hiked up the collar of my overcoat, walking faster. My wife and son had just taken a flight to a Central American resort. Left alone to labor in gloom, I was hoping to take the edge off the cold, dark night even as the words of my existential philosopher hero, Albert Camus, rattled my brain.
