title: From a Great 10-Cent Player, a Lesson in Maximizing Cards
description: Most good bridge players compete in tournaments, so that their names become known. But a few prefer the quiet of the rubber-bridge and Chicago tables. They like to win money and sleep in their own beds at night. One example was Richard Ferrelli, a regular in the 10-cent game at the Regency Whist Club in Manhattan, who died on Feb. 28.

title: What a Play Should Do: The Tale of Rachel Corrie
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Lady of the Miracle of the Rubes
description: IT was enough that Gonzaga alighted on college basketball in the 90's as a perpetual "Hoosiers" film loop before the team eventually opened a sparkling new gym off its vast hoop profits.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Outsourcing the Picket Line
description: AS corporations become increasingly global, unions must, too, so that they can remain effective, argues Andrew L. Stern, president of the 1.8-million-member Service Employees International Union.

title: Crowd Control at Classic Is a Sign of the Times
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 10 - Several hours before Puerto Rico clobbered Cuba, 12-2, Friday night, some San Juan police officers, Major League Baseball security officials and the game's promoters filed past two glass doors into the staff office of the World Baseball Classic here.

title: Class, Child-Rearing and Destiny (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: For Second Time, a Jury Fails to Reach a Verdict on Gotti
description: For the second time in six months, after more than a dozen witnesses, including turncoat mobsters -- and despite the efforts of top prosecutors and investigators -- a Manhattan jury failed to reach a verdict yesterday in the case of John A. Gotti, the son of the famous Mafia boss.

title: Sailing Calmly and at Warp Speed Through Water and Fire
description: Paul Taylor and his choreography have been much praised for the questionable virtue of accessibility. Nothing mysterious about his dances, people say. They are feel-good fun that anyone can enjoy.

title: A Big Deal Overshadowed by the Politics of Ports
description: MULTIBILLION-DOLLAR mergers of companies with household names are not often swept aside by other news just days after they are announced, but by yesterday it was almost easy to forget that the week began with AT&T's bid for BellSouth.

title: Emphasizing the Humor in a Problem Play
description: It is fortunate for the theater, not to mention newspapers, that hypocrisy, corruption and sexual entanglements in high places have never gone out of fashion. It was as true at the beginning of the 17th century as it is in the 21st, and for that reason alone a play like "Measure for Measure" can still engage an audience, especially in a solid revival like the one now being staged by the Pearl Theater Company.

title: Australia Deals With Letdown on the World Stage
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., March 10 - The Italian hitter looped a foul down the right-field line Tuesday, and Justin Huber, the first baseman for Australia, sprinted after it.

title: The Collapse of the Port Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: The Collapse of the Port Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTSTEIN, SADIE MACHANOFSKY
description: ALTSTEIN--Sadie Machanofsky, 93. Wife of the late Louis, mother of Howard (Helene), Joel (Nan) & Michael (Janet). Grandmother to Sam (Lisa), Rachel (Andy), Richard, and Lily. Great grandmother to Audrey, Lois, Minna, Jacob and Isaac. Like the candles that lit her Shabbat table each week, her memory will burn bright forever. May her memory be a blessing. Funeral at Congregation Beth Elohim, Brooklyn, Sunday March 12 at 9:45 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVEN, NETTIE
description: LEVEN--Nettie. Beloved wife of the late Raymond. Loving mother of Barbara and Anthony Muriello, Renee and Stuart Baritz, and Joseph Leven. Dear sister of Leo Geller. Adoring grandmother of Nanci and Michael, David and Laurie, Lindsey and John, Jared, Casey, Seth and Alexis, and Andrew. Services will be held on Sunday, 11:30AM, March 12, 2006 at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, N.J. Family requests donations be made to Temple Beth El, 222 Irvington Ave, So. Orange, N.J. 07079 or to UJAFederation of N.Y., 130 E. 59th St, NY, NY 10022.

title: John Profumo, 91, Former British Minister Caught in Sex Scandal, Dies
description: LONDON, March 10 - John Profumo, whose highflying political career in Britain ended in a cold war scandal of sex and espionage that gave way to a lifetime of atonement, died about midnight on Thursday. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINC, JACK
description: MINC--Jack, 79. Real estate professional, Holocaust survivor. Born in Gotha, Germany. Beloved father of David, Daniel and Roberta Minc. Beloved stepfather to Veronica Landet, Jennifer Mayer, Gregory Mayer, Julia Mayer Janovic and beloved grandfather to Rebecca, Daniel, Aaron, Jesse, Jared, Pierre, Phoebe, Graham, Amelie, Takeshi and Luka. Services Sunday at 12 noon at Gutterman's, Woodbury, NY. 516-921-5757

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLMAN, NEIL H.
description: MILLMAN--Neil H. The partners and staff of Hecht and Company, P.C. are deeply saddened by the passing of Neil H. Millman, Esq. Neil was associated with our firm for over 30 years and played an integral part in its success. He was not only a brilliant tax advisor but also a person who cared deeply about the well being of his clients. He leaves a void which will not be easily filled. Our sincerest condolences are extended to his wife Susan, to his son Matthew and to the other members of his family. Donald Hecht and Michael Hecht $(6$)MILLMAN -- Neil. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Neil Millman. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: 3 Students' Perspective on Tragedy of Darfur
description: To build awareness of the violence in Darfur, an earnest if cursory MTV documentary decides not to explain the motives of janjaweed marauders, the history of ethnic tension in the region, the intricacies of an intra-Islam clash. Made by well-meaning college students, "Translating Genocide" never depicts a single militant, except in children's crayon drawings of the pillaging of their villages.

title: U.S. Takes Momentum Into the Second Round
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 10 - Less than 24 hours after facing the humiliation of first-round elimination, the United States players approached their game with South Africa on Friday realistically. With Roger Clemens pitching, they needed to beat their seemingly overmatched visitors to advance to the second round of the World Baseball Classic.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page summary on Thursday about soda consumption referred imprecisely to sales for 2005. While the number of cases of soda sold in the United States declined for the first time in 20 years, sales revenue did not (because prices were higher).

title: If He Retires, Tagliabue Wants Easy Transition
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, responding to speculation that he may be considering retirement, said in an interview yesterday that he wanted a smooth transition to his replacement, although he did not give a timetable for his departure.

title: Joplin's Rich and Tender Fable of Liberated Slaves
description: To appreciate Scott Joplin's wonderful opera "Treemonisha," you have to accept this 1911 work as a product of its time. The story, with a libretto by Joplin, is a homey parable about a plantation community of freed slaves in the back country of Arkansas in the 1880's. The gullible residents are easy prey for a conjurer who spreads superstition and sells people "bags of luck" to ward off bad things. Treemonisha, the adopted daughter of good-hearted parents, is the community's only educated member, having received schooling from a white lady in the next town in exchange for laundry services.

title: Willy Frank, Proselytizer for New York State Wines, Dies
description: Willy Frank, a tireless promoter of New York wines who transformed Dr. Konstantin Frank Vinifera Wine Cellars into one of the Finger Lakes' best known and most respected wine producers, died on Tuesday in Naples, Fla., where he had gone on a business trip. He was 80 .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, CATHERINE R. (NEE CARNEY)
description: FITZGERALD--Catherine R. (nee Carney) on March 10, 2006. RN and retired teacher NYC Board of Ed. Beloved wife of the late George Howard. Loving mother of Lizabeth Wolkoff (Barry) and Edward. Proud grandmother of Jason, Stephen & Theresa. Funeral Monday 9:30 A.M. from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 10:30 A.M. St. Thomas Aquinas R.C. Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting Saturday & Sunday 25 & 7-9 P.M.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burgundies Will Be From Burgundy
description: The United States and the European Union signed an agreement allowing the United States to export wine to Europe made using methods banned in many European countries, including aging wine in steel barrels to which oak chips have been added rather than in traditional oak barrels. In exchange, the United States agreed to limit its winemakers' use abroad of names like Port, Sherry, Chianti, Burgundy and Champagne, which refer to specific production regions in Europe. The agreement resolves many, but not all, of the issues of a trade dispute that lasted two decades. "Like a good wine, this agreement took time," said Rob Portman, the American trade representative. SARAH LYALL (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WRAY, JOE D. MD, MPH.
description: WRAY--Joe D. MD, MPH. The faculty, students, alumni, and staff of the Mailman School of Public Health of Columbia University mourn the passing of Professor Emeritus, Joe D. Wray, one of the world's leading experts on child health. He was committed to medical and public health education and spent many years serving communities in Thailand, Colombia and Turkey. He was a dedicated teacher to countless numbers of students of the School and we will miss him. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife, Beth, children and grandchildren. Allan Rosenfield, MD Dean Mailman School of Public Health Columbia University

title: No Stranger to Fine Cognacs
description: A WINTER wind sliced through the sidewalks of TriBeCa like a giant razor blade, chafing my cheeks and piercing all the way to my spine. I hiked up the collar of my overcoat, walking faster. My wife and son had just taken a flight to a Central American resort. Left alone to labor in gloom, I was hoping to take the edge off the cold, dark night even as the words of my existential philosopher hero, Albert Camus, rattled my brain.

title: Judge Tries Compromise On Briefs Libby Is Seeking
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 - A federal judge ruled on Friday that I. Lewis Libby Jr. was entitled to review a limited amount of information from highly classified intelligence documents in order to defend himself against charges that he lied about his role in disclosing the identity of a C.I.A. operative.

title: Rite of Spring, Upper West Side Version: Allmans Are Back
description: The Allman Brothers Band started their annual spring ritual on Thursday night, with the first of 14 concerts at the Beacon Theater. That many shows, spread out over three weeks in a midsize theater, means that the audience is spared the indignity of piling inside an arena in New Jersey. It also means that the stage can become a lab, with different guests and different approaches to second-set jams.

title: A Path to a Seat on the Board? Try the Fairway
description: When John J. Mack began his effort to recruit and promote new talent at Morgan Stanley, he did not have to stray too far afield -- or off the fairway, for that matter.

title: A Sage Voice of the West Still Has Plenty of Life
description: ALBUQUERQUE, March 10 - No. 11 on the Western Writers of America's list of the best western authors of the 20th century answers the door of his subdivision hacienda in jeans and cowboy boots, an ivory shirt, black wool vest and a black bandana fastened with a silver Indian clasp.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about census data showing that whites will soon constitute a minority in the New York metropolitan area misstated a statistic comparing the region with the 87 other metropolitan areas in the nation that have a population of at least 500,000. New York, Houston and Honolulu are the only three in which the population of three minority groups -- but not the same three -- each exceeds their share of the national population. In New York and Houston, those groups are blacks, Asians and Hispanics; in Honolulu, they are Asians, American Indian/Alaska Natives, and people who claim two or more races.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOFFO, ANNA
description: MOFFO--Anna. The management and staff of Sony BMG Masterworks join the family, friends and admirers of the great American soprano, Anna Moffo in mourning her passing. Ms. Moffo was one of the most distinctive and beautiful singers of her time. She made her greatest recordings for RCA Red Seal, and they will continue to be among the glories of our catalogue. Ms. Moffo's legacy of recordings for the label offers perhaps the most eloquent testimony to the expressive beauty, affecting power and inimitable charm of her singing. In sorrow at her loss, we salute her greatness, which echoes in the radiance of her voice. Gilbert Hetherwick President Sony BMG Masterworks $(6$)MOFFO SARNOFF -- Anna. Age 73, died on March 9, 2006 after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Robert Sarnoff. Loving stepmother of Rosita Sarnoff, Serena Benenson and Claudia Sarnoff. Grandmother of Adam, Toby and Felicia Benenson. Beloved sister of Nicholas Moffo, Jr. One of the greatest sopranos of her time, Anna brought joy to opera lovers throughout the world. Her many memorable roles included Mimi, Manon, Liu, Cio-Cio San, Violetta and the Countess. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St on Monday March 13 from 6-8 and Tuesday March 14 from 5-7. Funeral Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 50th St and 5th Ave on Wednesday, March 15 at 10AM. Burial private. Contributions in her memory should be made to the American Cancer Society, 19 W 56 St, New York, NY 10019. $(6$)MOFFO SARNOFF -- Anna. Beloved member of the American Cancer Society family who led a remarkable life dedicated to music and devoted to humanity. She captivated the world with her extraordinary voice, grace and beauty. She captured our hearts with her passion for life. She will always be loved and treasured beyond measure. We deeply mourn her passing and, in her honor, we pledge to continue the fight against cancer and never give up. Brava La Moffo! American Cancer Society Donald Distasio, CEO Diana Feldman, Chairman Special Events Luis and Terrianne $(6$)MOFFO SARNOFF -- Anna. March 9, 2006. Opera Orchestra of New York notes with great sadness the death of legendary opera star, Anna Moffo. Miss Moffo was a devoted and active Director bringing her knowledge, wit, wisdom and charm to Opera Orchestra. An advocate for young singers, she nurtured and supported their careers. Her glorious voice, extraordinary talent, and great beauty will long be remembered by all those whose lives she touched. Alfred Hubay, President Eve Queler, Music Director $(6$)MOFFO SARNOFF -- Anna. The Richard Tucker Music Foundation mourns the passing of Anna Moffo, the great American soprano, a beloved colleague of Richard Tucker and a generous supporter and friend. Her glorious artistry, her stunning beauty and her personal warmth will always be remembered. Sanford H. Fisher, Chairman Barry Tucker, President

title: World Briefing: Africa, Europe and Asia
description: AFRICA

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in an article yesterday about a guilty verdict in the first corporate whistle-blower case to emerge from Iraq misstated the origin of the Federal False Claims Act, under which the conviction was obtained. The law is not new, but dates back to the Civil War and was amended in 1986.

title: Nortel Networks to Restate Earnings for the Third Time in Three Years
description: OTTAWA, March 10 - The telecommunications equipment maker Nortel Networks said Friday that it would restate its financial results for the third time in three years.

title: Open Doors Don't Invite Criminals
description: Cambridge, Mass. - LAW enforcement officials, politicians and social scientists have put forward many explanations for the astonishing drop in crime rates in America over the last decade or so, and yet we remain mystified. Studies have shown that while each of the usual suspects -- a decline in crack use, aggressive policing, increased prison populations, a relatively strong economy, increased availability of abortion -- has probably played some role, none has proved to be as dominant a factor as initially suggested.

title: Push to Tighten Lobbying Rules Loses Strength
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 - The drive for a tighter lobbying law, just two months ago a major priority on Capitol Hill, is losing momentum, a victim of shifting political interests, infighting among House Republicans and a growing sense among lawmakers of both parties that wholesale change may not be needed after all.

title: For Muslim Who Says Violence Destroys Islam, Violent Threats
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10 - Three weeks ago, Dr. Wafa Sultan was a largely unknown Syrian-American psychiatrist living outside Los Angeles, nursing a deep anger and despair about her fellow Muslims.

title: Palestinian Authority Faces Budget Crisis, Official Says
description: JERUSALEM, March 10 - In the last two weeks, the Palestinian Authority has been given about $70 million -- more than $40 million released by the World Bank, nearly $21 million from the European Union and $10 million from Norway. But even when all that money arrives, the Palestinian Authority will have only 95 percent of the money needed to pay February's overdue salaries, according to the Palestinian economic minister.

title: Arts, Briefly; Art Fair Opens Late
description: The Scope show, one of several major art fairs in New York this weekend, opened yesterday after carbon monoxide found during a press preview on Thursday forced an evacuation. The Fire Department said it received a call about a "hazardous condition" at the show, in a former warehouse at 11th Avenue near 46th Street, at 4:30 p.m. on Thursday. Alexis Hubshman, president of Scope, which focuses on emerging artists, said yesterday that it was still unclear who made the call. "We don't know if it was a competitor or who it was," he said. "We have our suspicions." After firefighters arrived, they detected high levels of carbon monoxide in one area of the space, possibly coming from a forklift that had been removing crates. Mr. Hubshman said the forklift was no longer being used. RANDY KENNEDY

title: How About a Fresh Helping of Secrecy?
description: Within an administration besotted with secrecy, it is heartening to find the National Archives inviting critical notice of the way intelligence agencies have been secretly denying public access to thousands of previously declassified documents. The archives director, Allen Weinstein, has heeded the complaints of historians and politely asked agencies to put their reclassification mania on hold while an audit is completed on the damage done thus far to the public's right to know.

title: You Can't Tell the Players Without a Bookmark
description: William Oldham showed up yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn with another man's book. This was somewhat strange.

title: Former White House Aide Is Arrested on Theft Charges
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 - A former top White House aide was arrested on Thursday in the Maryland suburbs on charges that he stole merchandise from a number of retailers, the police in Montgomery County, Md., said Friday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Book on Barry Bonds Rushed to Stores
description: Gotham Books has moved up the publication date by four days and expanded its press run for "Game of Shadows: Barry Bonds, Balco and the Steroids Scandal That Rocked Professional Sports," following the enormous publicity generated by an excerpt published this week in Sports Illustrated. Gotham, an imprint of the Penguin Group USA, will now release the book on March 23 and ship 190,000 copies to stores instead of the originally scheduled 50,000, a spokeswoman said. The book, by Mark Fainaru-Wada and Lance Williams, reporters for The San Francisco Chronicle, offers details about charges that Mr. Bonds made extensive use of steroids in his pursuit of the major league home run record. Based on prepublication orders, the book has ranked in the top 10 of both the Amazon.com and Barnes & Noble.com best-seller lists for much of the week.

title: Corrections
description: A Square Feet article in Business Day on Wednesday about renovations at the corporate campus in Chappaqua, N.Y., where the Reader's Digest Association has its headquarters, misstated the acreage. The site is 116 acres, not 14.

title: The Future Divined by the Crowd
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts last Saturday about the Russian National Orchestra's visit to New York misidentified the speaker who recited excerpts from Shakespeare in performances at Lincoln Center. It was Michael Cumpsty, not Richard Thomas, who had originally been scheduled in that role.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a $5,000 loan for bail money that Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey gave a former aide who was charged with stalking Assemblyman Joseph Cryan of Union County misidentified the county where Mr. Cryan's father, John, was once the sheriff. It was Essex, not Union.

title: They've Got Spirit! But It Isn't All Cheers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YANOFF, ALLEN
description: YANOFF--Allen. Taken away at the peak of his life, Allen served as the doctor's doctor, legendary mentor and role model for hundreds of physicians, the man we all turned to for his wise counsel and balanced judgement that he shared with us so generously. Sincerest condolences to Laura, David and Julie. Dr. Michael & Joyce Frank

description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 10 - On Friday morning, the Ohio State Buckeyes heard the relatively good news that the N.C.A.A. would allow them to play in this year's national basketball tournament and that future banishment from the event would not be forthcoming.

title: Abduction Tale Called Fake as Girl's Friend Is Arrested
description: Prosecutors looking into the three-day disappearance of a 13-year-old Jersey City girl said yesterday that she had apparently faked her own abduction and skipped school last Monday to meet a 20-year-old man for sex, and they announced that he had been charged with criminal sexual contact.

Crombie, former TWA executive. Survived by sons, David A. of New Haven, CT, Michael F. of Greensboro, NC, Timothy J. of Tarrytown, NY and Nicholas E. of Dallas, TX; daughters, Alison Gunsberg of Rochester, MI and twins, Jeanne Crombie Rhodes of Stamford, CT and Pamela Crombie Calman of Harrison, NY, 11 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, March 11th, 10:30 AM, St. Joseph's Cathedral, Hartford, CT.

description: 11:30 P.M. (NBC) SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE -- Matt Dillon (above), tonight's guest host, didn't win an Oscar last weekend (George Clooney beat him out as best supporting actor), but "Crash," the movie in which he plays a racist L.A. policeman, did. Tonight's musical guests are the Arctic Monkeys, the British band whose debut album, "Whatever People Say I Am, That's What I'm Not," released in January, is already being called a rock classic.

description: When John Giuca was convicted last year for the murder of a Connecticut college student, prosecutors said they were not done with the case. Inside a Brooklyn courthouse, supporters of Mr. Giuca are not done with the prosecutors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UDEL, DR. MELVIN
description: UDEL--Dr. Melvin, 81. Of Saratoga Springs, New York, died March 6, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Bracey Udel, he is missed by daughter Lisa, son-in-law Timothy Kramer, and many other family members and friends. Melvin was born in Baltimore, MD. on 28 August 1924 to Fanny and Solomon. He was an Assistant First Lieutenant in the US Navy, serving from 1943-1944. Melvin went on to become a psychiatrist renowned for his work in alcohol and drug addiction.

The Future of Natural Gas Pricing Could Be a Trans-Atlantic Tug of War
description: JUST when natural gas prices seemed likely to hit the moon this winter, much of the United States had the warmest January in history. With gas inventories high, prices plunged. Natural gas is now unusually cheap relative to oil.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on March 3 about an Interior Department official who helps oversee water contracts referred imprecisely to a denial by a former Interior official, J. Steven Griles, that he had violated ethics rules. Mr. Griles was investigated by the department's inspector general, who issued a report in March 2004 that was critical of him but did not find he had violated ethics rules. It was during the course of the inquiry that Mr. Griles said he had not violated rules, not when he stepped down from the department a year ago.

title: A Rock Band With Angst, Onstage and Off
description: "33 to Nothing" has a good beat. You can dance to it. Or, at least, nod your head to its downtown Bowie-cum-Coldplay groove. Labeled a "play with music," this latest production from the Argo Theater Company about a band's breakup is a cross between a play and a house concert. Although some of the best musicians don't act very well, and some of the best actors have more attitude than musical chops, it's a lively experiment that combines heartache, humor and powerful songs.

title: The More Sensible Sex? It's a Tie
description: I JUST read a book called "Money, A Memoir: Women, Emotions and Cash" (Holt, 2006) by Liz Perle. It's a smart, compelling analysis of why women "spend more on face creams and shoes than we do on our retirement funds" -- among other financial foibles.

title: Senate Proposal Would Provide City Schools More Money
description: The Republican-controlled State Senate began printing bills last night that call for more education spending than Gov. George E. Pataki proposed in his budget plan, but far less than New York City officials say they are owed by a court order, officials said.

title: Separate and Unequal for Gypsies
description: For all the difficulties Muslim immigrants face, Europe's most-abused group is still, by far, the Gypsies. They are compelled to live in slums, shunted off to inferior schools and denied jobs. They are subjected to pogroms, forced sterilization and police abuse.

title: British Tycoon Who Drowned Was Investigated for War Crime
description: LONDON, March 10 - The sudden death of the news media tycoon Robert Maxwell by drowning almost 15 years ago was as dramatic and mysterious as his life. Those who believe that it was not an accident -- that perhaps he jumped, rather than fell, from his yacht into the Atlantic in November 1991 -- have generally based their theory on the troubles overwhelming his vast business empire, which collapsed soon after he died.

title: G.O.P. Peers Hail Maverick Who Opposed Bush on Ports
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 - Representative Peter King of New York is the kind of Republican who has been something of an outcast in the clubby world of Washington Republicans. He can be pushy, outspoken and fiercely independent -- a New Yorker, that is.

title: Gentrification Changing Face of New Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, March 8 - In-town living. Live-work-play. Mixed income. The buzzwords of soft-core urbanism are everywhere these days in this eternally optimistic city, used in real estate advertisements and mayoral boasts to lure money from the suburbs and to keep young people from leaving.

title: Small Pieces Assembled Into a Big Picture
description: Susan Marshall made her name as a modern-dance choreographer with small, precise gestural dances that intensely evoked a story rather than told it. Then she opened out into dances filled with suggestive props and set elements. In "Cloudless," at Dance Theater Workshop, Ms. Marshall has returned to small-scale work, prompted, she says in a program interview, by the intimacy of the workshop's black-box theater.

description: COPENHAGEN, March 10 - Denmark sought Friday to tamp down the fierce Muslim protests over cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad at a conference with Muslim preachers and scholars that produced calls for dialogue but also fresh protests over the Danish government's refusal to apologize for the publication.

title: Snow Falling on Skiers
description: Anchorage - LAST week, I led the search for a 24-year-old snowboarder who had only recently returned home to Alaska from Iraq. Out with two friends on a clear day, he touched off an avalanche that carried him into a steep-walled gully and buried him in a 1,600-foot-stretch of deep, rock-hard debris. His mother takes some comfort in knowing that he died doing something he loved. I have trouble getting past the fact that he needn't have died at all.

description: The price of home electronics declines each year as advances in technology keep making them better -- with a few notable exceptions.

title: Setback to Bush on Ports Deal Casts a Shadow Over His Agenda
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 - President Bush's inability to hold sway over his party on the ports deal involving Dubai suggests that he faces trouble keeping Republicans together on his major policy initiatives this year, including overhauling immigration laws, approving new trade pacts and locking in his tax cuts, lawmakers and aides said on Friday.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Rations To Refugees Are Cut
description: The United Nations World Food Program said it was halving rations of sugar, salt and legumes to as many as 3.5 million needy people in Sudan, including many in camps in the Darfur region, because of a cash shortage to buy the items in local or regional markets. The United States, overwhelmingly the major contributor to the Sudan operation, has given $114 million in food but generally does not provide cash to purchase food in Africa. The reductions in rations will not affect cereals, blended foods or vegetable oil. The agency said it had raised only 15 percent of what is needed for Sudan this year, leaving it "critically short of funds." CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

Campbell, the chairman and chief executive of the Regal Entertainment Group, the nation's largest chain of movie theaters, would be nervous after 2005, when total admissions in the United States fell 8.7 percent, the third consecutive yearly decline. But if he is worried about the drop-off, he's not letting on.

title: A Conversation of Cultures, Spoken Through a Cello's Voice
description: The cellist Maya Beiser treats her concert programs as expansive, evening-length compositions, with themes and counterthemes. "Almost Human," the title of her program on Thursday evening at Zankel Hall, refers to the cello's ability to approximate the shapeliness of the human voice. But in a way, the cello's quasi-vocal qualities were merely a countertheme. The main theme was cross-cultural dialogue, and to that end, Ms. Beiser pulled in composers and styles from all over, and played works mostly written for the occasion.

title: Protests in Manama
description: Traffic was thick last night on the way back to the hotel from the circuit after police blocked roads around Manama. Before the race weekend, news reports said there might be protests from a local group trying to use the massive media coverage of the race to draw attention to their plight. The protest not only happened, it turned violent.

description: Until the last seconds of the first qualifying session of the 2006 Formula One season the big story was the new qualifying system itself. Then, suddenly, as the identity of the pole winner became clear, the story suddenly switched.

title: A Wrongful Birth?
description: Like most American women who give birth to a severely handicapped child, Donna Branca became pregnant with A.J. well before the age of 35. Had she been older, her doctors would almost certainly have recommended amniocentesis to screen for genetic disorders. But she was 31, so they did not, despite the fact that she had an unusual pregnancy. Branca bled during her first trimester, a possible indication of birth defects, and at her midterm sonogram, when she was 20 weeks pregnant, her fetus looked smaller than it should have based on when her doctors originally presumed she conceived. Branca had not gained much weight, either, but her doctors -- whom she is barred from identifying, by a legal settlement -- saw no cause for alarm. "Looking back now, of course, it's easy to say I should have asked more questions or maybe been a little more concerned," she told me last fall, sitting in her grassy backyard in Orangeburg, 20 miles north of Manhattan. Branca is a pretty woman, dark and compact, with a winning suburban New York accent. She glanced at A.J., a 6-year-old with a head of dark curls and the mental capacity of a 6-month-old. Her 3-year-old twins from a subsequent pregnancy ran around collecting acorns.

title: Jagger's Edge
description: Mick Jagger was the Swinging Sixties made flesh. Along with his ragtag court of haute-bohemian gypsies like Marianne Faithfull and Anita Pallenberg, this son of a gym teacher and an Avon Lady was the embodiment of a high-low society that brought together models and photographers, plutocrats and aristocrats into one drugged-out, sexed-up jet-set happening. As the music critic Nik Cohn once wrote, by 1966, "Jagger was the most wanted guest in the world, the final face, the ultimate. For one pout of his red lips, any millionaire hostess going would have promised away her life."

title: Pakistan cracks down on lethal 'kite duels'

description: EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP - AMID a sea of tan town houses here is the home of Margaret and Haim Bar-Akiva, longtime irritants to the Twin Rivers Homeowners Association. The fines and fights have worn them out.

title: Texas A&M Loses, but Is Far From Defeated
description: DALLAS, March 11 - As the Texas A&M junior guard Acie Law IV walked solemnly off the court at American Airlines Center on Saturday afternoon, a crowd of Aggie fans stood patiently near the railing of the arena's northwest corner.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SAUL, ANDREW
description: SAUL--Andrew. Born 3/12/58 - 6/18/03 Your 48th birthday. So sorely missed and all memories of you are ever so vivid. I carry your heart with me. I carry it in my heart. I am never without it. May your gentle soul rest in eternal peace. Your loving brother, Gregg

title: Reykjavik
description: WHY GO NOW In 2006 the United States population will reach 300 million, and Iceland's will hit 300,000. In national pride, the two countries will remain about equal, which goes a long way toward explaining why Reykjavik, Iceland's capital, refuses to feel like a small town. About two-thirds of Icelanders live in the city and its suburbs, and if the concentration of museums and galleries, bookstores, excellent restaurants and lively night spots per capita isn't the highest in any city in the world, it has to be close.

title: A Quiet Slice of New York Waterfront
description: GLORIA KEK was only beginning to think about buying something on Staten Island when she came upon an ad in the local newspaper for an open house in the borough's Rosebank section. She went right over after her church service that Sunday morning, but was too early. When she returned to the waterfront town house later in the day, she was almost too late. There were barely 10 minutes to go before the doors closed on the lavishly furnished model home, but in the end that was more than she needed.

title: Call Him Ishmael. (He Has the Whale.)
description: "MY man is all in white, and I like that!" Will Castro, 40-something celebrity car customizer, exclaimed, focusing on an older man who had driven up in a white Cadillac. "White suit, white shoes -- white glasses, even."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, SEYMOUR
description: GOODMAN - Seymour. On March 10, 2006, of Tamarac, FL, and Roslyn, NY. Devoted and loved son, husband, father, grandfather and brother. You will always be in our hearts. Esther, Rhonda (Kenny), Andrea (Clarence), and Steven (Deborah), Alexis and Jacob. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset.

title: A Place to Work on Darwin's 'Abominable Mystery'
description: They will not be cloning sheep, engineering mutants or genetically modifying corn in the new biological research laboratory. And its ZIP code isn't in Berkeley, Cambridge or even Manhattan.

title: A House Call (Just Don't Call Her a Hypochondriac)
description: LANSING, Mich. - ANN KRON is allergic to weather, water and yellow dye No. 2. In fact, she's pretty much allergic to everything. No one has quite explained the medical basis, but since she was a child, Ms. Kron has had what she calls "terrible reactions" to air, water, weather and other invisible assailants. Reactions often involve complete collapse, sometimes for periods of six months to a year.

title: The Oscar for Best Banned Picture
description: Correction Appended

title: Thank You for Insulting Our Sandals
description: IN "Thank You for Smoking," an acerbic new movie about a tobacco lobbyist, the camera paints a quick but telling portrait of his bane, Senator Ortolan Finistirre, an antismoking environmentalist Democrat from Vermont, played by William H. Macy. A poster of Cheddar cheese hangs on his office wall. Tins of maple syrup crowd his desk. The proof positive of his moral rectitude, however, comes in a cutaway shot of the senator's feet encased in thick white socks and sandals.

title: Couple Found Dead in Car With Engine Running
description: A man and a woman were found dead inside a parked car in a Queens garage early yesterday, having apparently inhaled carbon monoxide fumes by accident, the authorities said.

title: Hallelujah and Namaste
description: THREE flights above the rumbling traffic of the Avenue of the Americas, well-sculptured women and men rushed into Dana Flynn's Sunday yoga class just before noon. Within minutes, they were lined up on mats, legs crossed, backs straight, being led in chant as they stared at mandarin and fuchsia walls.

title: Up Front
description: If you ever wondered what happened to the Jacqueline Susann-style blockbuster, you might just find it on the "young adult" list -- but with 21st-century Range Rovers, "low-rise rhinestone Juicy jeans" and drugs like Viagra and Ecstasy. Naomi Wolf didn't hate everything about the books she read for her essay this week on teen-queen fiction ("Wild Things," Page 22); Massie, the central character in the best-selling "Clique" series, "like all memorable tyrants is charismatic, and she is funny," Wolf wrote in an e-mail message. And as the author of "Promiscuities," a memoir about her own coming-of-age experience, she doesn't have a problem with teenagers thinking about sex -- they're going to anyway. But she was unprepared for some of the content of series like the "Gossip Girl" and "A-List" books, which are aimed at 14-and-up readers but are often read by younger girls. A sex scene might be "smoothly folded in after a riff on, say, a hated principal -- in other words, very adult material spliced abruptly in between ordinary teenage preoccupations and grievances," Wolf noted.

title: To Japanese Nationalists, Only the Y Chromosome Counts
description: TOKYO - IT was one of the biggest rallies in support of Japan's imperial system since the end of World War II: Some 10,300 men and women gathered at the Budokan martial arts arena to protest a proposal that would let women become empresses and pass along title to the Chrysanthemum Throne. At the end, the throng stood and raised their arms in unison while shouting, "Long live the emperor!"

title: The War at Home
description: FALLING THROUGH THE EARTH

title: Buttoned-Up Bouncers on Defensive
description: ON most nights of the week between 11 p.m. and 4 a.m. you'll find Carlos Robinson -- all 6 feet 9 inches of him -- looming over the velvet rope at Lotus or the Double Seven, two of the more prominent nightclubs in the glitter gulch of New York's meatpacking district. He's the guy with the bulging arms, shaved head and 5.2-carat diamond earring in his right ear. When platoons of status-hungry night crawlers bum rush the door, he fends them off. If, after a few hours, patrons have had a few too many shots of Grey Goose, it is Mr. Robinson who escorts them to the curb.

title: Corrections
description: An excerpt in the Reading File column last Sunday from an article published last month in The Times of London about the evolution of blond hair included a reference to a study, attributed to the World Health Organization, that predicted that blond hair would become extinct in 200 years. In 2002, after the first news reports about the study, W.H.O. said it had never done research on the subject and that it had no knowledge of how the reports originated.

title: Winter Green
description: Green, as fresh as spring grass on a Swiss mountainside, is a popular color this winter, left, right and above. Through much of the last century, there was a superstition about wearing green, which was largely reserved for celebrating the 17th of March, bottom row, as seen in 2005. But during the late 50's and 60's, green coats were part of the pastel Easter fashion coloring. ON THE STREET

title: The Remix; Local Color
description: Mention the word descamisado -- Spanish for "shirtless" -- to most men's-wear designers, and they're likely to conjure up visions of Puerto Rican go-go boys at the Roxy. But for the English-born James Abbott, who worked for the cult label Body Map before moving to California 11 years ago, the association is somewhat more political. "That's what Che Guevara and Eva Pern used to call the working poor," he says.

title: The Remix; Got Game?
description: The Hemingway-style adventurer may have faded into legend, but the bush jacket is back with a vengeance. Military-inspired shirts and jackets were all over the runways for spring, though you wouldn't mistake any of the models for big-game hunters. The safari, a name that the bush jacket acquired in the late 1960's, has always had a certain manly, aristocratic appeal, probably from the Anglo-Indian officers who wore it -- "khaki," after all, is Hindi for "dust covered." Teddy Roosevelt's trip in 1909 to the Kenyan bush (dressed by the outdoor specialist Abercrombie & Fitch, yes, that A&F) first made Americans safari savvy, while Hemingway, in the 30's, made safari jackets chic. Esquire promoted them as day wear, and Hollywood took up the look in movies like "Mogambo." But the safari jacket was all but extinct when Yves Saint Laurent revived it in 1968. Suddenly, both sexes were great white hunters, men wearing theirs with scarves, shades and sideburns. In the 70's, in fact, Banana Republic built an entire retail concept around it. And now, these many years later, the store is going back to its archives, with a Heritage Collection. Wear the new safari with something washed out, lest you look like a character from "The Mummy." ROBERT E. BRYANA

title: You Got a Problem With Queens?
description: WHENEVER our friends the Mosses say, "Let's get together soon," my husband and I agree, mentally mapping out the best way to get to their apartment on the Upper West Side. Do we take the car and spend $30 for parking? There's also the F train to the D to the No. 1 uptown. Or, of course, we can always take the R train to 57th Street and walk from there.

title: Movies
description: SERPICO (1973) Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 11 When Al Pacino (above right) played Frank Serpico, a real New York police officer, a noticeable percentage of the youth of America considered the word "pig" a synonym for "cop." So moviegoers ate up Mr. Serpico's no-good-deed-goes-unpunished story in which he learns about widespread police corruption, reports it and soon finds himself in danger, turned upon by his fellow officers. The film, directed by Sidney Lumet, still stands up as drama and as an intriguing example of early Pacino style. Mr. Pacino won a best-actor Golden Globe for the role.

title: The Remix; Tracks | Pleasure-Cruising
description: For the multimillionaire and petrol head Klaas Zwart, owning both a race team and the car company Ascari -- the maker of the KZ1 supercar, with a top speed of 200 miles per hour -- wasn't enough. He needed a private track to enjoy the fruits of his pleasure. Zwart chose a valley near Ronda, Spain, for his Race Resort Ascari.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of an article last Sunday about the musical "Grey Gardens" misstated the production's category. It is playing off Broadway, not on Broadway.

title: Japanese Without All the Fusion
description: IN an age when every new Asian restaurant seems to be a fusion of this-and-that, it is refreshing to visit Kobis, a relatively new arrival in Fairfield, which is what it is: Japanese, period.

title: Knight Ridder Newspaper Chain Agrees to Sale
description: Knight Ridder, the second-largest newspaper company in the United States, agreed Sunday night to sell itself for about $4.5 billion in cash and stock to the McClatchy Company, a publisher half its size, according to people involved in the negotiations.

description: Q: As a staunch neoconservative and the author of a new feminism-bashing book called "Manliness," how are you treated by your fellow government professors at Harvard? Look, if I only consorted with conservatives, I would be by myself all the time.

title: The Freshman
description: I was moved by the story of Rahmatullah Hashemi but was dismayed to read of his sponsor's advice not to develop his talent in science because "the world doesn't need an Afghan astrophysicist." Maybe that is exactly what is needed. There is no better way to learn why reason and tolerance should be valued over dogma and violence than through the study and practice of a science. Not to mention the economic argument that development of a country's science is the surest route to economic progress. Beyond that, it seems that Hashemi has earned the right to what most American undergraduates take for granted, which is to study for a career in whatever subject interests him.

title: Designer Genes
description: The difference between one inseam and another is the difference in a label's DNA. This spring, several iconic houses decided to plunder their heritage, with collections that go back to the meaning of things.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHAN, BLANCHE BILLOW
description: COHAN -- Blanche Billow. March 10, 2006, two days after her 93rd birthday. She stayed for the party and now has joined her beloved husband Leo. Dear sister of Selma and Muriel. Loving mother of Mike and Carol, Susan and Ken, grandmother of Edward and Patrice, Peter and Melissa, Sandy and Rob. Greatgrandmother of Lee, Olivia, Luke, Hadara and Molly. Private service and interment March 12. Donations to Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79 St, NYC; Jewish Museum of NY; and NARAL.

title: HELP FOR A RARE WARBLER
description: To the Editor: In "The Flip Side of the Bahamas" (Feb. 19) Denny Lee could probably not be expected to know that the Bahamian island of Eleuthera is also the primary winter home of the rare Kirtland's warbler (Dendroica kirtlandii).

title: The 'Notwithstanding' Code
description: In most of the English-speaking world, "notwithstanding" is an overly long synonym for "in spite of" or "nevertheless." In Albany, notwithstanding is a four-letter word.

title: Mexican Land Boom Creates Commotion in Whale Nursery
description: LAGUNA SAN IGNACIO, Mexico, March 7 - This remote lagoon, surrounded by salt flats, mesas and desert, has been a sanctuary for gray whales for centuries.

title: The Freshman
description: I thoroughly enjoyed reading about Rahmatullah Hashemi's journey from the Taliban to Yale. Conspicuously absent was any mention of his encounters and relationships with the Jewish population at Yale. Given that he ate his meals at the Slifka Center, because it served kosher food, it would logically follow that he spent much time with Jewish noshers. Your writer missed an opportunity to question Rahmatullah about his views of the Jewish people and about whether his experiences at Yale affectedthose views.

title: The Vendetta Behind 'V for Vendetta'
description: Correction Appended

title: Moored in Legend, and the Talk of the Town
description: THERE is nothing odd about the rusty steel anchor that sits on a small pedestal outside 874 President Street, a Tudor-style town house near Eighth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Nothing, except that few of the people living in the building know anything about the four-foot-high structure other than the fact that it makes for a nice conversation piece and a handy landmark for friends and delivery people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERLINER, ARNOLD
description: BERLINER--Arnold, formerly of East 53rd St., NYC, resident of Miami Beach, died March 6, 2006. Life partner of Stephen B. Grundstein. Brother of Alice Cahn. Uncle of Mara, Lisa and Ayla. Great-uncle of Milo, Riva, Talia and Lucas.

title: The Zone; Kit and Run
description: Call it what you like -- medicine bag, Dopp kit, shaving arsenal -- but a traveling case of essential drugstore items is always worth keeping on standby. Remember to restock, and you'll never have to translate "under-eye brightening cream" into the local idiom. JAMIE WALLIS

title: New Orleans: W New Orleans
description: THE BASICS -- The mood in New Orleans these days will be familiar to anyone who was in New York after Sept. 11. People are gentle, unwilling to inflict more pain on anyone. This isn't a city where you're going to complain if, say, your toast is cold or your eggs are undercooked. So when I arrived at the W in late February, I was inclined to overlook faults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLMAN, NEIL H.
description: MILLMAN--Neil H. On March 9, 2006 at age 61. Devoted and cherished husband of Susan (nee Cooper). Adored father of Matthew. Dear son of the late Abraham and Rhea and brother of Barbara Rose and the late Elaine Kammerman. A graduate of Brown University, Columbia Law School, and New York University Tax Program. Devoted friend and advisor to many people who shall miss his wise counsel. His passing is a great loss for his family, friends and clients. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the CSS Program, Beth Israel Cancer Center, 10 Union Square East, 4A, New York, NY 10003.

title: Islanders Consider Another Tambellini
description: Perhaps the person most interested in Jeff Tambellini's debut with the Islanders on Friday was watching in Vancouver, British Columbia: his father, Steve, who is considered a candidate to be the Islanders' next general manager.

title: The Remix; The Inside Track
description: To outmaneuver Rolls-Royce and Bentley, Maybach has a $370,000 sport model with a raging V12 and a souped-up interior. Although it comes pre-pimped with Old World niceties like a Champagne refrigerator, additions like a carbon-fiber dashboard and snow-white interior accelerate the style. Here's an inventory of details of the 57 S, and shortcuts for acquiring Maybach-level luxury. JONATHAN S. PAUL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIANNETTI, ANTHONY M.
description: GIANNETTI--Anthony M. 81, of Palm Harbor, FL died March 7, 2006 at the Mease Countryside Hospital in Safety Harbor, FL. He was born in Newark, NJ, lived for a time in Caldwell, NJ, and moved to Florida from Toms River NJ in 2002. He was a truck driver for the New York Times, and was a member of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union. He was a member of the St. Luke the Evangelist Catholic Church in Palm Harbor, and served in the European Theater during WWII with the US Army. He was preceded in death by his brothers Daniel and Michael, and by his sister Catherine Vuono, Ann Giuliano and Celeste Galife. He is survived by his wife of 53 years Rose, sons Joseph and his wife Patricia of New Port Richey, FL, Dr. Anthony and his wife Karen of Glenside, PA and Gerard and his wife Malinda of Roseland, NJ, sister-in-law Maryann Giannetti of Niles, OH, grandchildren Gabrielle, Angela, Anthony Jr. and Bruno, and by his nieces and nephews Leonard Giannetti, Marian Munley, Barbara Vuono, Susan Longacre, Dana Butto, John Galife and Maryann Post. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Parkinsons Disease Association (904-953-7030) or Hospice of the Florida Suncoast (727586-4432) would be appreciated. For information: Moss Feaster Funeral Home in Palm Harbor (727) 562.2090.

title: German Merck planning hostile offer for Schering
Iraqi Leader, in Frantic Flight, Eluded U.S. Strikes
description: Saddam Hussein turned to his sons. as American troops were fanning out across Baghdad. "We are leaving now," he said.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: BAHRAIN
description: IN THE DESERT AT SUNSET, SOUTH OF JEBEL DUKHAN, DEC. 14, 2005 - Cmdr. John S. Keating from Sun Prairie, Wis., left, with his friend Eric Glaser from Sacramento, Calif., at the Tree of Life, which has an unknown source of water. "Eric and I were in the Navy together -- we both got out in 1993, but, in June, I got a recall to come to the Persian Gulf. I had the morning off, and he flies for ATA now, flying troops over here. So I picked him up at the airport and showed him around. The tree is kind of like a check list -- a thing you might want to see when you come. A lot of people carve their initials into it, and I'm like, 'Why do you have to do that?' But, as they say here, inshallah -- whatever God wills." As told to Austin Considine

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "You've got such longevity in that White House team that they are tired. They need a break. They need a big piece of good luck. I don't know what it is."

title: Sorry Salutes
description: To the Editor:

title: Shantytowns as a New Suburban Ideal
description: TIJUANA, Mexico - TEDDY CRUZ has been shuttling between suburban San Diego and the shantytowns of Tijuana for more than a decade now. From anthropologists to urban planners eager for an insider's view, visitors pepper him endlessly with requests for tours.

title: Crypts Near Civil Rights Hero Now Command a Premium
description: DETROIT, March 10 - How much should it cost to spend eternity near the woman responsible for the seminal moment in the civil rights movement? The Woodlawn Cemetery here, where Rosa Parks and members of her family are entombed, says $60,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOTTERS, ALBERT
description: LOTTERS--Albert. Our beloved Abracha, age 95. A most wonderful and devoted husband of Joyce and the late Ninette. Loving parent to Larry, Barbara, Fred, Patti and David. Adoring grandfather of Carly, Talia, Rebecca, Eric, Zachary and Pamela. A spirited survivor who remained a joy to all who knew him.

title: The Talk
description: Jib

title: Sip of the Iceberg
description: There was a huge controversy several years ago in the science world when an endocrinologist discovered that exposure to a common weedkiller, atrazine, caused male frogs to develop female sex organs. Men who want to explore the rarefied milieu of ice wines, those richly textured, frozen-on-the-vine nectars, take heart: your sex organs won't budge merely by drinking wines associated with the gentler gender -- women and non-soccer-playing Britons. Ice wines are for anyone well connected enough to find them, well heeled enough to afford them and savvy enough to appreciate that they're not just dessert wines; they're dessert. Made from grapes harvested and quickly pressed while frozen (producing an incredibly sweet and concentrated elixir), they provide men with a golden opportunity to practice their sipping skills; guzzling is frowned upon by most everyone with ovaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERRIS, DONALD L.
description: PERRIS--Donald L. Of Cleveland, OH, beloved husband of Barbara F. Perris (nee Fisher); dear father of Katherine P. Torgerson (Kenneth A.) of Cleveland Hts, OH, David P. Perris and Barbara A. Perris, both of NYC, NY; grandfather of Travis Kinsey and Leslie Kinsey; step-grandfather of Kirstin T. Knight (Hyperion) and Ryan P. Torgerson (Paige); step - great - grand father of four; brother of Alan H. Perris (Joan) of San Mateo, CA, and the late Howard Perris. The family prefers that those who wish may make contributions in his name to The Ireland Cancer Center of University Hospitals of Cleveland, PO Box 74947, Cleveland, OH 44101-9927; The Gates Mills Land Conservancy, PO Box 13, Gates Mills, OH 44040; or the Sanibel Public Library, 770 Dunlop Rd, Sanibel Island, FL 33957. Memorial services will be held Friday, March 31, at 4 PM, in The Drury Theater of The Cleveland Playhouse, 8500 Euclid Ave, Cleveland, OH. Friends may call at Brown - Forward Funeral Home, 17022 Chagrin Blvd, Shaker Hts, OH, Monday, March 13, 5-7 PM. For additional information and directions log on to www.legacy .com; 216-752-1200.

title: Gordon Gekko, Meet the Kids
description: AFTER Black Monday, the day of the stock market crash of 1987, an official from the National Association of Securities Dealers called a meeting of Wall Street power players to discuss how to remedy the system. What is remarkable is that the meeting took place not in a boardroom but in a local bar, Harry's at Hanover Square. Harry's had so quickly become a downtown institution that The Wall Street Journal published a front-page profile of it in 1976, just four years after its founding by Harry Poulakakos, a Greek immigrant.

title: Prix: Alonso back in a familiar spot: First
As Oilers Wobble, Lowe Makes Some Moves
description: With his team clinging to the eighth and final Western Conference playoff spot with only five weeks left in the regular season, Edmonton Oilers General Manager Kevin Lowe was busy as last Thursday's trading deadline approached.

title: The Freshman
description: It wasn't just luck that broughtRahmatullah to Yale. It was Mike Hoover and Bob Schuster, who advocated for him, and Dean Shaw, who got past his initial reaction, "It's the enemy." Being accepted, forgiven for his associations andvalued forhis individuality is the greatest educationRahmatullah will receive. If he can bring that back to his home country, perhaps his daughter will get to go to Yale, too.

title: Sister Buildings Show Their Age Quite Differently
description: AN Art Deco flying buttress? That's one of the nice little touches you get with the apartment house at 19 East 88th Street, at the corner of Madison Avenue, built in 1936.

title: SEAL HUNTS AND TOURISM
description: To the Editor: "Urging Americans to Look North, Beyond the Border Hassles" (Practical Traveler, Feb. 26) focuses on the fact that Canada is concerned about the drop in tourism coming from the United States, and is taking steps to "lure more Yanks across the border."

title: The Mystic Artists: A Puget Sound Quest
description: THE painting -- a big, dark cityscape of Seattle as seen from Capital Hill, with Lake Union shining like a whale in the foreground and the hump of Queen Anne Hill rising behind into the belly of a low black cloud -- is so tactile and kinetic it makes you want to touch the paint. And that's exactly what John E. Braseth, co-owner of the Gordon Woodside/John Braseth Gallery in Seattle, does.

title: Svidler Gives Topalov Trouble With an Offbeat Ruy Lopez
description: Although Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria has been considered the man to beat for the world championship, he got off to a shocking start at the Linares tournament, which opened in Morelia, Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLAU, GERTRUDE
description: BLAU--Gertrude. It is with deep sadness we mourn the passing of Gertrude Blau at the age of 97. Married for over 70 years to the late Louis Blau. Devoted mother of Yosef, Norman and Andrea. Loving grandmother of five and great-grandmother of 12. She will be missed by us all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEEDS, SUSAN
description: LEEDS--Susan. Died March 10, 2006. An admirable talent for friendship, Susan lived life to its fullest. She leaves behind her adored husband Chris Chisholm and many heartbroken friends. Susan made me feel treasured. I loved her; she will live on in me. Sally Haver

description: Less than two years ago, Marc E. Smith took charge of combining the supermarket chains Stop & Shop and Giant Food. Now he is retiring at 52 -- with no explanation.

description: A 31-year-old Brooklyn man was shot and killed early yesterday after an argument at an East Flatbush nightclub, the authorities said.

title: With Certain Words, Watch Your Mouth
description: To the Editor:

title: Tension Headaches in the Corner Office
description: LEADERS of large companies are under stress because of global competition, rapidly changing technologies and financial pressures, says Michael Patsalos-Fox, chairman of the Americas region for McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm. Here are excerpts from a conversation:

title: The Get; Dapper's Delight
description: 1. Tom Kalenderian, the men's honcho at Barneys New York, can identify a seven-centimeter tie at20 paces and a hand-stitched buttonhole at 40. He can (and will) wax poetic on the toe-box construction of a custom shoe. And don't get him started on Neapolitan suits. Having worked for 27 years for the store that introduced Armani to America, he has a soft spot for Italian tailoring: "Italians have a knack for blending their respect for heritage with modern simplicity." Here he wears a made-to-measure jacket by Gianluca Isaia ($1,995) and a shirt ($350) and tie ($105) from Battistoni, a label he describes as "part of the Italian businessman's suit of armor."

title: Man of the Cloth
description: In the reception room of a small but Wallpaper-worthy town house in Mayfair, London, a handful of the city's richest young men about town are gathering. The house belongs to a celebrity and wit who can make or break reputations with a look. A gourmand, gambler, nightclub maven and connoisseur of fine art and furnishings, he is also the best-dressed man in the world, and his revolutionary sense of style will change men's fashion forever. In a moment, these chosen few will be granted entrance to his private chambers to watch him dress. Fortunately, they have time on their hands, as it can take hours for their host to achieve his trademark effortless elegance.

title: Studies Find B Vitamins Don't Prevent Heart Attacks
description: A widely promoted B vitamin regimen for the prevention of heart attacks and strokes has shown no beneficial effects in people at high risk, researchers are reporting today.

title: Briefly: Fatal bird flu strikes 4th African country
For Green Music, Rainbow Bands
description: There are no "songs" in Irish traditional music; there are "tunes." A young woman, packed in a tight circle in the corner of this dark bar, starts one off with a series of smooth draws across the strings of her fiddle. A man joins on banjo, a woman on the concertina, then two more fiddlers. Feet stamp the worn floor. It is Monday night at Mona's, the time when one can hear a bit of Ireland on Avenue B in the East Village.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of an article last Sunday about the musical "Grey Gardens" misstated the production's category. It is playing off Broadway, not on Broadway.

title: Secret Agent Man
description: When the British actor Daniel Craig -- rough, tough and blond! -- was selected to channel the myth of James Bond, there were howls of complaint, as there have been ever since Sean Connery took off his Rolex Submariner watch, drank the last sip of his vodka martini (shaken, not stirred) and handed over the secret-service gizmos to his successors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, MARTIN
description: SOLOMON - Martin. On March 8, 2006. Devoted father of Dane, Scott and Lisa, grandfather of Lindsey, Jared, Adam and Arielle. He joins his wife, Elaine, in eternal rest. An artist, a teacher, a friend who left his mark on this world through his life and his works.

title: Grand Prix, in 100th Year, Fuels Debate Over Engines
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, March 11  This year is the centennial of Grand Prix racing, and although the technology has changed beyond recognition, at least two common denominators remain: speed and controversy.

title: The Mozarts We Don't Know
description: ANYONE with the faintest connection to classical music likes Mozart. Hating "Don Giovanni" or the "Jupiter" Symphony would be like hating a sunset. Mozart has come not just to represent musical beauty but, in a way, to define it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMUTIS, H.E. AMBASSADOR ANICETAS
description: SIMUTIS--H.E. Ambassador Anicetas, Special Advisor to the Republic of Lithuania's Mission to the United Nations, on March 8, 2006 at the age of 97. Beloved husband of the late Janina Ciurlys Simutis. Loving father of Aldona and Julius. Beloved grandfather of Algis, Vilius, Laima, Kristina, Andrius, Vincas Sruoginis, Anna and Janina Simutis. Great-grandfather to Aurimas, Dainius and Ilona Bukauskas. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), 81st St. and Madison Ave., NYC, on Monday, March 13, from 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday at 10:15AM, Transfiguration R.C. Church, 64-25 Perry Avenue, Maspeth, NY.

title: Bloggers at the Gates: What Was Good for EBay Should Be Good for Politics
description: After the disastrous 2004 election, prominent Democrats gathered in Monterey, Calif., to discuss what to do next. The organizers scheduled a session on coalition building, but each special interest complained that its issue was being slighted. In the end, the coalition-building session broke up into five separate groups, each focusing on its own issue.

title: Riviera Maya Adds Another Deluxe Place to Stay
description: Amansala's Casa Magna is the newest luxury property on Tulum Beach, that increasingly popular strip of sand on the Riviera Maya in Mexico. The inn, consisting of two villas, the first of which officially opened in January, was once a vacation home of the Columbian drug lord Pablo Escobar, according to Melissa Perlman. She bought the villas in June after they had been seized by the Mexican government and had stood abandoned for 10 years.

title: MICHAEL JOHN LaCHIUSA; Another Composer of Merit
description: To the Editor:

title: Bracket Provokes Its Own Madness for the N.C.A.A.
description: The bracket is the star. A road map of hypnotic, straight-line symmetry leading to the Final Four, it is revered for both its simplicity and its complex possibilities. When empty, the bracket stirs hype and imagination. When filled with 65 teams at their starting lines, it stirs even more.

title: Can Network Theory Thwart Terrorists?
description: Recent debates about the National Security Agency's warrantless-eavesdropping program have produced two very different pictures of the operation. Whereas administration officials describe a carefully aimed "terrorist surveillance program," press reports depict a pervasive electronic net ensnaring thousands of innocent people and few actual terrorists. Could it be that both the administration and its critics are right? One way to reconcile these divergent accounts -- and explain the administration's decision not to seek warrants for the surveillance -- is to examine a new conceptual paradigm that is changing how America's spies pursue terrorists: network theory.

title: 4 U.S. Soldiers Are Killed in Afghan Attack
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 12 A Four American soldiers were killed in a roadside bomb explosion in eastern Afghanistan today, and two suicide bombers in a car blew themselves up next to the vehicle of the chairman of Afghanistan's upper house of Parliament here in the capital, killing at least two people and wounding at least seven others, officials said.

title: Three Challengers Ready to Face Trunzo
description: Gone are the days when Democratic leaders went begging for someone to run against State Senator Caesar Trunzo. Three would-be challengers are stepping forward, propelled by recent Democratic victories and the growing perception that the veteran senator, who is also the Islip Republican leader, is vulnerable.

title: The Rudeness of Strangers
description: On a recent holiday I was dining with my partner, Ira, at a romantic restaurant on the rugged east coast of Barbados. At one table, a stunning older woman -- tan and with fine blond hair catching the Atlantic breeze -- was eating alone. Was she an actress? An aristocrat? Lonely? In the name of international cordiality, I wanted to relieve her of her solitude and invite her to our table to share the evening. But how to do it?

title: The Silver Is Antique, Though the Search Isn't
description: IN "The Merchant of Venice," the prince of Arragon chooses the silver casket and finds inside only "the portrait of a blinking idiot."

title: The Get; Chrono Quartet
description: Who says you can't Stop time?

title: Several Million Little Dollars
description: If James Frey is still smarting from his public flogging at the hands of Oprah Winfrey, perhaps he will feel some comfort this month when checks for more than $4.3 million show up in his mailbox -- royalties on sales in the last three months of last year of his now-discredited memoirs, "A Million Little Pieces" and "My Friend Leonard." And he has earned an additional $1.5 million since he admitted making things up.

title: Minneapolis Regional
description: No. 1 VILLANOVA WILDCATSBecause of injuries, Coach Jay Wright has had to rely on a small lineup all season, and it has worked wonders. With three and sometimes four guards on the court together, Villanova matched its best conference victory total (14) since joining the Big East in 1980. Guards Randy Foye, Allan Ray, Mike Nardi and Kyle Lowry accounted for nearly 80 percent of the team's scoring this season. Ray sustained an eye injury at the Big East tournament but is expected to receive medical clearance to play.

title: Today's Franchisee Thinks in Multiples
description: JENNIFER SOLOMON of Dobbs Ferry spent 11 years as an equity analyst in Manhattan, leaving her career in 2001 to have children. She has now decided that it is time to get back into business -- this time in a more entrepreneurial capacity.

title: A Happy Ending for Some, a Comedy of Errors for Others
description: WHEN the Paramount Pictures unit of Viacom announced two months ago that it would acquire DreamWorks SKG for $1.6 billion, the deal was heralded as a "coup" and a "fantasy come true" by the news media and analysts alike.

title: Mrida: Finding a Home (Cheerios Included) in Mexico
description: WITH its narrow sidewalks, cobblestone streets and chalky colonial buildings painted the color of Easter eggs, Mrida is home to a growing number of expatriates. Sitting on the breezy veranda of a hotel that was once a 19th-century hacienda, one expatriate, Ellen Fields, said, "Even though Mrida is a city of almost a million people, it seems like a small town if you're an expat because we all know each other."

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 12, 2006
The Postmodern Moralist
description: CONSIDER THE LOBSTER

title: Leg Man
description: Lions and lambs aside, March is the month to switch from winter's dense stews to a tender roast. And a good boneless leg of lamb needs little fuss. The source of the meat rivals the recipe in the eventual outcome, and the meat from 3-Corner Field Farm in Shushan, N.Y., is inimitable. By the end of serving one of its prime pieces of lamb, I'll have handed out the company's Web address to my guests and sermonized on how pasture-feeding the sheep subtly layers the flavor of the meat. Which is why the cooking is minimal: a night in the refrigerator with garlic, lemon and rosemary, and then an hour in the oven on a heavy roasting pan. It's a tremendous return on so little effort -- and you get to show off your carving skills at the table.

description: In Her Own Style

title: The New So Paulo
description: Correction Appended
