title: Miami Revise
description: Crockett and Tubbs return to the scene of the crime this summer in the big-screen version of "Miami Vice," but their look will be on the street any day now. Versace did its take with snug white pants and dusty pastel shirts; Coach even added a slip-on leather espadrille. The best way to update the 80's look is to add slick accessories like the custom-painted gold Motorola Razr cellphone, available this summer from Voce (www.voce.com) -- all the better to put the Raleigh's cultural attach, Manij, on speed dial. With a gold Richard Mille tourbillon chronograph, you can make it to the opening at the new Emmanuel Perrotin gallery on time. Arrive in your Chris-Craft Corsair 36 cigarette boat or a Ferrari, like the new F430 Spider. Elvis (above left) just might fit in the back seat. CHRISTINE MUHLKE The Remix

title: Out of the Vault, It's Liza With a Zing
description: TORONTO - LIZA MINNELLI purses her lips around a cigarette as she ponders the moment. It was 1972, a year when she was savoring the unanimous critical praise and box-office success of "Cabaret," Bob Fosse's musical about pre-World War II Berlin. In the central role of Sally Bowles, Ms. Minnelli had delivered a brilliant performance, as a singer, dancer and actress. The year of 1972, she thought to herself at the time, couldn't get any better.

title: Sailing Away
description: ON its maiden arrival in New York in June 1911, White Star's giant liner Olympic berthed at the Chelsea piers, at 700 feet the longest in Manhattan. But the vessel's stern still jutted 180 feet out into the Hudson River. Clearly, Europe's naval architects had surpassed New York's harbor engineers.

title: Stars and cars
description: Ive always been a rock music fan, so I was delighted when I saw that among the people taking part in a celebrity race Saturday afternoon and Sunday morning in Bahrain were Jay Kay, of Jamiroquai, and Rick Parfitt of Status Quo  but above all, Nick Mason of Pink Floyd, one of my favorite groups since the early 1970s.

title: How I Became a Bush Critic
description: On Friday, Paul Krugman got his revenge on me. Back in September 2003, I wrote a column that was rather rough on him. In it, I likened him to Donald Duck during one of his tirades, with steam pouring out of his ears, because he seemed so angry all the time.

title: The Fog of Home
description: The other morning I walked out of my hooch and saw antennae standing watch like silent sentinels, sticking their heads up out of the fog. The sun looked like a silver coin through the haze. You could stare right at it. The horizon was shrouded. I heard a large explosion, but the sound was compressed as if in a vacuum; it was hard to tell if it was an I.E.D. on a road just outside the F.O.B. or a mortar attack inside the wire. By mid-morning, the clouds served as a prism and there was a golden glare all over the world. It wasnt the kind of gold you might imagine while reading a poem by Robert Frost. It was the fallow brown of a vast desert come to steal away the mirage of safety.

title: Cheers for NBC
description: Since Ive lambasted the networks in the past for missing the boat on Darfur, I take my hat off to NBC for sending Ann Curry and a first-rate crew to the Chad border. We traveled together much of the time on this trip, and they were great. I gather that Anns reports will be on the Today Show Monday and Tuesday, the NBC nightly news on Monday, and Dateline sometime soon as well. Ann also writes about Darfur in her blog, Curry Commentary.

title: Police Say DNA LinksBouncer to Slain Student
description: Conclusive DNA evidence shows that blood found on plastic ties used to bind the graduate student who was sexually assaulted, strangled and dumped in a forlorn marshland in Brooklyn two weeks ago belonged to a bouncer at the Manhattan club where she was last seen alive, the police said yesterday.

title: Scant Bidding for Knight Ridder Tells Story of Decline
description: Knight Ridder ended up attracting only one newspaper bidder in its highly publicized auction, underscoring the fog hanging over the industry and the unique challenges facing the company.

title: Arts, Briefly; Google's Book Deal
description: Google is about two months away from offering consumers the ability to buy the full text of books online from publishers who participate in its Book Search program, the company said on Friday. Last week it began seeking publishers in the United States and Britain that would be willing to sell permanent online access to books through the Book Search site (books.google.com). Jim Gerber, Google's director of content partnerships, said the program was part of a "suite of tools" that the company was planning to "generate more book revenues" for publishers and for Google. The publishers would set the price for the digital access and decide which of their books to include in the program and whether to allow consumers to print a copy of the purchased book. EDWARD WYATT

Arts, Briefly; Stern's Bile Lifts 'Hannity'
description: "8th & Ocean," a new MTV reality series in the style of the network's popular "Laguna Beach," drew 2.4 million viewers in its Tuesday debut, a majority of whom were in the 12-to-34 demographic the channel seeks. It followed the second episode of the most recent "Real World," set in Key West, Fla., which delivered 3.1 million. Also on Tuesday was Part 1 of a Fox News interview with Howard Stern, above, on "Hannity & Colmes" (1.83 million), featuring the beginning of Mr. Stern's "I Hate Les Moonves" tour, a tirade against CBS, his former employer, and its chairman, Leslie Moonves, over the company's lawsuit against him. The "Hannity & Colmes" ratings for Tuesday and Wednesday, with the second half of the interview, were well above average for the month of February. KATE AURTHUR

title: Heart Implant Reduces Severity of Migraines, Study Finds
description: Closing a hole in the heart that as many as 25 percent of adults have from birth did not prevent major migraine headache attacks, according to the initial results from a British clinical trial presented today at a cardiology meeting in Atlanta.

title: Upset 'Brokeback' Fans Advertise Their Feelings

title: Advocates Hope Ruling Renews Focus on 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 - Advocates for repealing the ban on military service by openly gay men and lesbians say they hope that their cause may be helped by the Supreme Court decision barring universities from keeping military recruiters off their campuses in protest of that ban.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man, 20, Killed In Fight
description: A 20-year-old man was fatally stabbed and a 16-year-old boy critically injured yesterday afternoon during a fight in the Fresh Meadows section, the police said. The man, who was not identified pending notification of his family, was stabbed several times about 4:30 p.m. during a fight with three others, one of whom was the injured teenager, who suffered head injuries, the police said. The man was found near 195th Street and 73rd Avenue. Last night at the scene, a woman who said she saw the attackers drove off in a silver sedan with New Jersey plates after putting their weapons in the trunk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUMITS, WILLIAM J.
description: SUMITS -- William J. On March 10, 2006, in Fairfax, VA. He was 91. Son of the late Frank & Rosa (Bugyin) Sumits. William enjoyed an expansive career as a photographer that took him from the stockroom at Eastman Kodak to Chief Photographer for TWA. He later worked as a photojournalist, becoming Chief of the Photography Lab for Life Magazine, where his work was the focus of many photo essays. During his tenure at Life, he photographed Winston Churchill among several other noteworthy figures. His work included photographing the return of the Apollo astronauts and pictures of many Vatican treasures. William went on to work as the Assistant Photo Editor for Playboy Magazine prior to accepting a position as Head of the Photo Department at the National Gallery in Washington D.C. Predeceased by his beloved wife Madge Sumits. He is survived by his cherished children, William W. Sumits of Redwood City, CA and Marcia Spizzirro of Harrison. Also survived by six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Visitation Tuesday morning, 10am12, at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck, where a funeral service will begin at the funeral home at 12 noon. Interment at Greenwood Union Cemetery. For more information, 914-698-5968.

title: Severe Storms in Midwest Expected to Move East
description: Severe thunderstorms with the potential to spawn tornados were expected to move eastward today into the Ohio Valley and western New York and Pennsylvania after causing 10 deaths and extensive damage in the heart of the Midwest on Sunday night and early this morning.

title: Developer's High-Rise Plan Stirs Concern in the Diamond District
description: Gary Barnett has come a long way since he got his start as a diamond merchant two decades ago in Antwerp. He came to New York in the early 1990's, got into real estate, and runs a business that has seven major projects in Manhattan.

title: Heart Implant Reduces Severity of Migraines, Study Finds
description: Closing a hole in the heart that as many as 25 percent of adults have from birth did not prevent major migraine headache attacks, according to the initial results from a British clinical trial presented today at a cardiology meeting in Atlanta.

title: The Dearly Departed, Lingering This Side of Paradise
description: Requiems operate on one side of the grave or the other. Some celebrate arrival in another world. Others depict the difficulties in getting there. The deceased of Faur's Requiem, for example, are already among the angels, singing sweetly, softly and almost with a sigh of relief. The Verdi Requiem, on the other hand, lingers this side of life and looks reluctantly over the brink.

title: 4 American Soldiers Killed in Afghan Blast
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 12 - Four American soldiers were killed in a roadside-bomb explosion in eastern Afghanistan on Sunday, and two suicide bombers in a car blew themselves up next to the vehicle of the chairman of Afghanistan's upper house of Parliament here in the capital, killing at least two people and wounding at least seven others, officials said.

title: Temple's Basketball Coach Retiring

title: The Search for Fresh Attractions
description: The giant twists of blackened wreckage have disappeared, along with most of the graffiti scrawled toward the heavens by the angry, mournful public. But one adaptive visitor to the crater that was the World Trade Center had brought a white ink marker to use on the severe black panels at the overlook, printing a sweet message: "Yo New York, I hope you are feeling better." On a sunny March day inching toward spring, the words echoed the sad resolve of Whitman's long-ago message of "when lilacs last in the door-yard bloom'd."

Philip Shapiro, President

title: Ex-Judge in Iraq Stands by Death Sentences for 148 Shiites

title: As Syria's Influence in Lebanon Wanes, Iran Moves In

title: Looking Ahead

Wall Street firms set records last year, but this year seems to be shaping up even better. Goldman Sachs is expected to lead the way with spectacular numbers, particularly in stock and bond underwriting (Tuesday), followed by Lehman Brothers (Wednesday) and Bear Stearns (Thursday.)

More important, the administration sees what sort of basic commitments are needed if southern Louisiana is going to have the chance to rebuild itself. But he is going to have to push hard on the storm victims' behalf. There are frightening signs coming from Washington that legislators may shortchange distressed homeowners, playing politics as usual with relief funds.

description: WASHINGTON, March 13 A President Bush pushed back today at critics on both the left and the right who have urged that American troops be withdrawn before they are caught in a civil war, arguing in the first of a new series of speeches that his strategy is working and declaring, "We will not lose our nerve."

description: Miles Davis is being inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame tonight. Not as an "early influence," as Hank Williams, Louis Jordan, Louis Armstrong, Bessie Smith and Jelly Roll Morton were; that category is for artists whose careers were established long before rock 'n' roll began. (The hall has not inducted anyone in that category since 2001.) Davis is being recognized as a rock star.

Paid Notice: Deaths   UDEL, DR. MELVIN
description: UDEL--Dr. Melvin, 81. Of Saratoga Springs, New York, died March 6, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Bracey Udel, he is missed by daughter Lisa, son-in-law Timothy Kramer, and many other family members and friends. Melvin was born in Baltimore, MD. on 28 August 1924 to Fanny and Solomon. He was an Assistant First Lieutenant in the US Navy, serving from 1943-1944. Melvin went on to become a psychiatrist renowned for his work in alcohol and drug addiction.

Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, are running for the nomination.

title: China nears Australian uranium deal
Arts, Briefly; Kerouac's 'Beat Generation' Onstage
description: Jack Kerouac, below, was known for his prose, man, but he wrote other stuff, too, including "Beat Generation," the aptly titled play he jotted down in 1957, just after the publication of "On the Road." The play lay dormant until it was rediscovered by Sterling Lord, Kerouac's longtime agent, who turned up a manuscript while working on his memoirs recently. The actor Ethan Hawke and a few friends read an excerpt at the New York Public Library last fall, and next spring it is to be produced. Richard Kimmel will direct and is working out some kinks in the script. The production, the play's first, is to be staged at the Box, a new, as yet uncompleted theater on Chrystie Street on the Lower East Side. No casting has been announced, but only hipsters need apply, dig? JESSE McKINLEY

title: Six Teams State Their Case for the Four Top Seedings in the Women's Draw

Beloved grandmother of Robert (Pamela), Joel and Leah. Most loving greatgrandmother of Sara and Joshua. Former Vice President Entertainment Unlimited Artists Bureau. title: With Its Swagger Back, Cuba Whips Venezuela
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 12 - Pedro Luis Lazo of Cuba stood on top of the mound like someone standing on top of the world. He scooped up the rosin bag, slapped it a few times, then slammed his hand against his glove. The excess powder spilled off him, briefly creating a haze around him.

title: Nudging Russia's President
description: This summer, President Vladimir Putin of Russia is to play host to heads of the world's most powerful democracies in the glorious city of St. Petersburg. It is a chance for Mr. Putin to seal Russia's membership in the Group of 8. But there are many people -- most recently Senator John McCain -- who are so outraged about the way Mr. Putin has been de-democratizing Russia that they want President Bush to boycott the meeting. A better course would be for the United States and the other members of the group to make it clearer that membership in their club requires a functioning democracy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Arrested After Crash
description: A man was arrested on charges of driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident after a crash that critically injured a woman early yesterday, the police said. The police said the man, Paray Balron, 23, of 105th Street, was driving his Nissan eastbound on 86th Avenue shortly after 2 a.m. when it struck a Hyundai at 111th Street in the Richmond Hill section. The driver of the Hyundai, a woman whose name was not immediately released, was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. Mr. Balron fled and was arrested about a block away, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TYSON, CORNELIUS JOHN JR.
description: TYSON--Cornelius John Jr. Son of Dr. Cornelies J. Tyson, Chief of Surgery at St. Vincent's Hospital, and Dorothy Anne Comfort, died peacefully March 9, 2006, at 87 years. He graduated from St. Ignatius Loyola and Great Neck High School. After the premature death of his father, he completed his B.A. on scholarship at Princeton University, graduating with honors with the class of 1939. Awarded an M.D. from Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons. He was commissioned a lieutenant, serving the U.S. Navy Medical Corps in the Pacific and European theaters and in the Normandy invasion. Devoted husband for 52 years of Patricia Burke Hale, who predeceased him March 6, 2005. He is survived by six children, Robert Hale of Plainsboro, NJ, Annie of Berkeley, CA, Patricia of Alexandria, VA, Cornelius J. III of Long Island, ME, Agnes Hale of Sydney, Australia, Philip Comfort of South Portland, ME, and six grandchildren, Andrew, Rebecca, Cornelius J. IV, Jamila and Jamari Jackson, Spencer, and a sister, Margaret Gengler of Baltimore, MD. He maintained a private practice in internal medicine for 52 years, serving patients and others in need with compassion and care, making house calls until retirement at 83 years old. He was Associate Clinical Professor and recipient of the Columbia University P & S College Alumni Association Gold Medal in recognition of his lifetime dedication to training young physicians in the highest standards of medical care. He was a lifelong resident of Manhattan and a summer resident of Cushing's Island, ME. He was a member of the Century Association, the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and New York Botanical Gardens. His endless generosity is a continuing inspiration to all who knew him. A Funeral Mass will be said on Thursday, March 16, 2:30 PM, St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street.

title: Going to the Museum? Take Sunscreen and Get Ready to Dance
description: As all D.J.'s know, there is a maneuver called beat match that involves melding the tempo of a new tune with the one on the previous track. For two New York architects, that music-mixing technique proved the inspiration for "Beatfuse!," the winning entry in a design competition that annually transforms the courtyard at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens.

title: When a Stranger Intimidates
description: "Hard Right," written and directed by David Barth, has the feel of a play rushed to the stage before it was ready. Very little has been properly thought through, from the set, which is supposed to be a middle-class home but looks more as if it were cobbled together at a thrift shop (no designer is credited), to the clumsy blocking that sometimes shields the audience from the speaker.

title: Tax Madness
description: Senate Republicans desperately want to pass a fresh round of tax cuts for investors this spring. But they're afraid they can't muster the 60 votes required for bills that worsen the long-term deficit. We certainly hope that's true. At a time when Congress is slashing programs for low-income Americans, there's no justification for the sought-after cuts, which would extend special low tax rates for investment income and would mainly benefit people who make more than $1 million a year.

title: Modern Art Steps Up at Fair of Old Masters
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, March 12 - The rosy-cheeked image of the 17th-century poet and scholar Anna Six-Wymer in a stiff white ruff is exactly what visitors arriving at the European Fine Art Fair expect to see: a recently reattributed Rembrandt portrait, making its first public appearance in more than a century. This year is, after all, the 400th anniversary of Rembrandt's birth, and this small Dutch city is in the heart of old-master country.

description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: EarthLink, Atlanta, selected Lowe Worldwide, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its television, online and direct-marketing creative account, formerly at Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Miami, part of MDC Partners. Spending was estimated at more than $50 million. The gain for Lowe came after several recent large account losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEEGAN, JANE LUCEY
description: DEEGAN--Jane Lucey at home in Providence, Rhode Island 10 March 2006. Partner and muse in the jewelry firm Jeff Deegan Designs with her husband. Born 14 July 1951 in Perth Amboy, New Jersey to the late James J. and Winifred Lucey, Providence resident since 1978; member of the Handicraft Club. Graduate of Rosemont College. Survived by husband J.F. Deegan III and sons Seamus Brew Deegan of Long Beach, California and Liam Lucey Deegan of Providence. Sister of Denis J. Lucey III MD of Philadelphia and Deborah L. Kroop of Woodbury, New Jersey. Jane requests in lieu of flowers a donation to Dana Farber Cancer Institute or buy something nice for yourself.

title: Milosevic Died of Heart Attack, Autopsy Shows
description: THE HAGUE, March 12 - An autopsy showed that a heart attack killed Slobodan Milosevic, the United Nations war crimes tribunal said here on Sunday evening in a terse announcement. The statement served only to deepen the mystery over the circumstances surrounding Mr. Milosevic's abrupt death just as his prolonged trial was finally nearing an end.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the State Department's criticism of Iraq in its annual report on human rights abuses misstated the timing of comments by Baktiar Amin, a former Iraqi human rights minister, who said that some violations in his country included systematic torture. He made the observation on Feb. 6, 2005 -- not last month.

title: Anna Marly, 88, Dies; Inspired French Resistance in Song
description: Correction Appended

title: Some Studying Is Required
description: As usual, the N.C.A.A. tournament selection show featured plenty of surprises. A few teams considered national powers received lower seedings than expected. A few teams below the nation's elite level were seeded like royalty.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: As Media Companies Continue to Search For Tech Businesses to Buy, the Field Narrows Both digital-era and traditional media companies continue to scour the Internet for emerging content and technology companies. But the pickings of obvious acquisition candidates, while hardly exhausted, are slimming, according to financiers, entrepreneurs and industry analysts who follow the sector. That leaves the media companies trying to figure out which of the emerging generation of Web sites have lasting business models or, at least, can continue to build traffic. [Page C1.]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKINNER, SUSAN
description: SKINNER - Susan. Passed Sunday, March 5, at age 53. A memorial service to be held Tuesday, March 14, at 5 pm, Our Lady of Good Counsel RC Church, 230 East 90 St, NYC. She is survived by her mother Coral Skinner Clarke, and three sisters, Angela, Helen and Margaret.

title: Upstate New York Farms Begin Raising New Crop: Electricity From Windmills
description: LOWVILLE, N.Y. - William and Patricia Burke have lived in their white Colonial-style farmhouse on the edge of the Tug Hill plateau for 36 years. And for 35 of those years they have cursed the winter wind as it whistled through every crack and hole in the house.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Circuits pages of Business Day on Thursday about a new laptop computer from Lenovo misstated the model name. It is the Lenovo C100, not the ThinkPad C100; the model is not part of Lenovo's ThinkPad line.

title: Seinfeld's Buddy Elaine Is a Divorced Mom Now, and Her Name Is Christine
description: The so-called curse of "Seinfeld" lives on: none of the secondary characters from that series have starred in a successful sitcom since its finale in 1998. So "The New Adventures of Old Christine," starring Julia Louis-Dreyfus, is pretty risky. On the other hand, the Boston Red Sox finally did win the World Series.

title: Critic's Choice: New CD's
description: Nicolai Dunger "Here's My Song" (Zo)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a study in the journal Health Affairs assessing the impact of payment methods on doctors' choices of cancer drugs misstated the scope of the findings. Although some of the discussion in the article referred to the continuing practice of payment to cancer doctors for the drugs used by patients, the Health Affairs study dealt only with Medicare reimbursement for such drugs from 1995 to 1998, not current payment methods.

title: A Studio Boss and a Private Eye Star in a Bitter Hollywood Tale
description: TEMECULA, Calif., March 12 - The phone rang in Linda Doucett's desert ranch house here in the late spring of 1998. It was her ex-fianc, the comedian Garry Shandling, calling. Again.

title: Alabama animal tests positive for mad cow
Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 19 about a $65 million renovation of the Apollo Theater in Harlem misidentified the fabric used for its new seats. They are made of polyolefin, not velour. A picture caption misidentified an object in the lobby. It is a replica of the Tree of Hope, which contestants in the theater's amateur nights rub for good luck; the original tree is stored backstage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, ROY BENIS
description: FRIEDMAN--Roy Benis. Writer and beloved husband of Dr. Louise (nee Shapiro) Friedman, died March 12, 2006. Loving father of Rebecca Friedman and father-inlaw of Kevin Claphan. Brother of Sally Durman. Graveside services Tuesday, 11am, Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. For information, contact Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY.

title: British plan to reduce troops in Iraq by 10%
Vodafone's 'Life President' Quits
description: LONDON, March 12 - Sir Christopher Gent, who helped build Vodafone Group into the world's largest mobile phone company, gave up an honorary position at the company on Sunday amid reports suggesting that he was trying to undermine the current chief executive, Arun Sarin.

title: Briefing: Fresh charges against founder of Livedoor
From Sunny to Dark to a Loving Flourish
description: The Saturday afternoon Paul Taylor program at City Center ended with "Esplanade," one of his greatest works, already reviewed this season. The performance was a delight and left everyone smiling upon departure.

title: Bernie Geoffrion, 75; Popularized the Slap Shot
description: Bernie Geoffrion, the Montreal Canadiens' Hall of Fame wing who popularized the slap shot, a weapon that changed the face of hockey and brought him the enduring nickname Boom Boom, died Saturday in Atlanta. He was 75.

title: Sometimes, Success at the Table Means Waiting for the Misstep
description: Bridge is a game of mistakes. Everyone makes them, even the best players. But part of the art of being a winner is to take advantage when an opponent errs. Cezary Balicki, a world champion from Poland, did exactly that on the diagramed deal, which occurred during the Hilton Head Regional last month.

title: Is This Any Way to Pick a Jury?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Da Vinci Code' author offers peek inside
World Cup photo dispute is settled
Study Finds More News Media Outlets, Covering Less News
description: The third annual review of the state of American journalism found that while there were more media outlets this year than ever, they were covering less news.

title: Capital One Reportedin Deal for North Fork
description: The Capital One Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the North Fork Bancorporation for about $14.6 billion in cash and stock, people involved in the negotiations said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Considers Status Of Chaplain
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he expected to decide soon how to handle the case of the Correction Department's top chaplain, Umar Abdul-Jalil, who was placed on paid administrative leave on Thursday. The New York Post quoted Mr. Abdul-Jalil, a Muslim imam, as saying in a lecture last year that Jews controlled the media and that "the greatest terrorists in the world occupy the White House." Mr. Bloomberg said he had talked with top city officials and other clerics and had read the lecture. "Part of it is what I think's right and part of it is what's legal," the mayor said. "He is a Civil Service employee and I want to understand the law, as well as understand exactly what he said and what his performance is, and then I'll make a decision as to what I think is right." Supporters of the imam, including some other members of the clergy and the president of the 11,000-member union of correction officers, rallied yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DUNDES, LESTER
description: DUNDES--Lester. Always remembered, always loved.

title: 3 Groups Give to Pataki PAC While Dealing With the State
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's Virginia-based political action committee has received three $25,000 contributions so far this year from groups with interests before New York State government, campaign filings show.

title: Carmakers bolster U.S. operations
Moussaoui trial teeters on the brink
Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERGER, MAURICE H.
description: GREENBERGER -- Maurice H. December 15, 1909 to March 12, 2006. Dear husband of Lillian. Devoted father of son Henry and daughter Martha Wexler. Loving grandfather of Catherine, Rebecca and Judith and greatgrandfather of Samantha Grace. Graveside service 1pm Tuesday, March 14, at the Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Requiescat in pace.

title: Judge May Deny Death Penalty in Moussaoui Trial
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 13 A An angry federal judge put the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui on hold today and said she was considering ending the prosecution's bid to have him executed following a disclosure that a government lawyer had improperly coached some witnesses.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged In Pawnshop Killing
description: The police arrested a Brooklyn man on Saturday night and charged him with killing a pawnshop owner during a robbery on Jan. 19. The police charged that the man, Demetrious Green, shot the owner, Richard Schoenfeld, in the face during a robbery of his Richlantic Gold and Silver Exchange, in Richmond Hill, Queens. Mr. Green, 29, of Watkins Street in Brownsville, was charged with second-degree murder and other offenses. The police said he forced his way behind a security door and shot Mr. Schoenfeld, 40, of Merrick, Long Island, once with a 9-millimeter pistol before grabbing several pieces of jewelry.

title: Nelson spotlights a musical monument
Corrections
description: The David Pogue column in Business Day on Thursday, about a new portable music player from Samsung, referred imprecisely to the compatibility of another player, the Sonos Digital Music System, with certain music files. While the Sonos product plays many songs downloaded from Windows-based music services, it cannot currently play those that use the digital-rights protection system that Microsoft calls "PlaysForSure."

title: Gilbert Y. Steiner, Author and Theorist on Welfare Issues, Dies at 81
description: Gilbert Y. Steiner, an author and authority on American welfare and family policies, and, for many years, a mainstay of the Brookings Institution, died March 1 at a hospice in Washington. He was 81 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: U.K. leaving door ajar for Tehran
China's car industry outgrows the castoffs
Yankees' Chacon Gets His Bearings
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 12 - In Shawn Chacon's last game at Yankee Stadium, he was booed off the mound. But that was a good thing.

title: Exxon gets Indonesia venture cleared
Milosevic may be buried in Belgrade
Rescuers in northern Chinese coal mine explosion find 12 bodies
Taking in the Enron Trial While in the Neighborhood
description: With Richard M. Scrushy, the former HealthSouth chief executive, facing numerous civil suits from investors and a criminal bribery case on the horizon, you might think he would want to avoid courthouses in his downtime. Nonetheless, he found time in Houston last week to sit in on the trial of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffery K. Skilling, who are accused of conspiring to defraud Enron. Mr. Scrushy even took time to comment on CNBC.

title: Britain Wants to Leave the Door Open to Negotiate With Iran
description: LONDON, March 13 A Britain's foreign secretary, Jack Straw, said today that any diplomatic pressure on Iran from the United Nations Security Council should be "incremental" and "reversible."

title: Bush's Stay in Dangerous Pakistan Rewards an Ally
description: WASHINGTON - President Bush has been back from the Asian subcontinent for more than a week now, but one big question from his trip remains: How did it happen that the president spent a night in Pakistan, the assumed haven of Osama bin Laden and one of the one most dangerous countries in the world?

title: Jobs stall as Europe recovers
A Bush Alarm: Urging U.S. to Shun Isolationism
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 - The president who made pre-emption and going it alone the watchwords of his first term is quietly turning in a new direction, warning at every opportunity of the dangers of turning the nation inward and isolationist, and making the case for international engagement on issues from national security to global economics.

title: For muslim who says violence destroys islam, violent threats
Livedoor faces criminal complaint, could lead to delisting
Newspaper Chain Agrees to a Sale for $4.5 Billion
description: Knight Ridder, the second-largest newspaper company in the United States, agreed last night to sell itself for about $4.5 billion in cash and stock to the McClatchy Company, a publisher half its size, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: The Camera Diet: Now You Can Lose 10 Pounds Without Even Trying
description: For digital camera makers, it's a mode, mode, mode, mode world.

title: Fall Claims Life of Olympic Snowboarder
description: At the first major snowboardcross race after the distinctive event's successful debut at the Turin Olympics, the snowboarder Jonatan Johansson of Sweden died from injuries sustained in a fall during a warm-up run yesterday at Whiteface Mountain in Wilmington, N.Y.

title: With election nearing, Belarussians crack down
Shiite Vigilantes Kill 4 in Sign of Lawlessness in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 13 A Shiite vigilantes seized four men suspected of terrorist attacks, interrogated them, beat them, executed them and left their bodies hanging from lampposts in a Shiite slum today, according to witnesses and government officials.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 12, 2006

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about lobby reform efforts in the Senate that would limit lawmakers' use of corporate jets reported an incorrect ranking, from the Political Money Line, for the travel expenses of Senator Saxby Chambliss, Republican of Georgia. He ranked third -- not first -- among current senators who reimbursed companies for jet travel from 2001 through 2005. (The majority leader, Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, spent the most, followed by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut.) The Political Money Line issued a correction on Thursday.

title: Arts, Briefly; A Home for a Cube
description: A sculpture by a German artist of a large black cube resembling the Kaaba at Mecca may have found a home in Hamburg, Germany, after being rejected by Venice and Berlin. Last year the artist, Gregor Schneider, wanted to install the work in St. Mark's Square in Venice, saying the piece "might remind us of the cultural elements we have in common." But the city turned it down for security reasons, and a similar plan in Berlin also failed. Last week the German news media reported that the city of Hamburg had expressed interest in including the piece in an exhibition next year of work by Kasimir Malevich, the early-20th-century Russian Suprematist. Mr. Schneider, who won the Golden Lion at the 2001 Venice Biennale for his design of the German pavilion, has said that his cube evokes Malevich's paintings of black squares as much as it does the Kaaba. SARAH PLASS

title: When Cars Sat for Portraits, Truth Was Often Stretched
description: WHILE elegant prewar classics and rare Italian sports cars are still setting sales records when they cross the auction block, lately it has been automakers' dream cars from the 1950's that are drawing top prices from high-rolling car collectors.

title: Capital One to Buy North Fork for $14.6 Billion
description: The Capital One Financial Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire North Fork Bancorporation in a cash and stock deal valued at $14.6 billion that would make Capital One less like a credit card company and more like a major bank.

title: Wireless: Turning cellphones into portable offices
Gross Neglect
description: When it comes to providing desperately needed services for children who have been beaten, starved, sexually abused or otherwise mistreated, the state of Mississippi offers what is probably the worst-case scenario.

title: Baghdad Market Bombings Kill 46 and Wound 200
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 12 - Six car bombs exploded at dusk on Sunday in four crowded markets in a Shiite area of eastern Baghdad, and an Interior Ministry official and witnesses said the bombs killed at least 46 people, wounded more than 200 others and spurred Shiite militiamen to take to the streets.

title: 'Da Vinci Code' author takes stand in copyright lawsuit
Saddam-era judge admits sentencing Shiites to die
Senator to Propose Censure of Bush Over Spy Program
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 - Senator Russell D. Feingold said Sunday that he would introduce a measure in the Senate to censure President Bush over the domestic eavesdropping program.

title: Ministers fail to find solution to 'Suez crisis'
Corrections
description: An entry in the News Summary on Thursday about a visit to Germany by President Lech Kaczynski of Poland misidentified the current holder of the presidency of the European Union, which rotates among the members. He is Chancellor Wolfgang Schssel of Austria, not Mr. Kaczynski.

title: Trail is steep in Israel as Labor candidate tries to forge new leftist coalition
Dancers Who Make a Chestnut Come Alive
description: The audience cheered when the handsome Prince Dsir kissed the beautiful Princess Aurora awake, in the Tchaikovsky Ballet and Orchestra performance of "The Sleeping Beauty" on Saturday night at the Lehman Center in the Bronx. The epitome of 19th-century ballet, "Beauty" is also a rather long-winded, refined retelling of the fairy tale, presented here with the reduced scenic effects of a touring production. But the performers, from Perm in Russia, are not only fine dancers but also terrific storytellers. And they made theatrical magic for the audiences at Lehman and, the night before, at the Tilles Center in Brookdale, N.Y., in "Swan Lake."

title: Other Views: The Economist, Irish Times, Korea Times
Rabbis Train for Questions About Fertility Medicine
description: It sounds like the setup of a joke: 20 rabbis walk into a fertility clinic.

title: Searching the World, From Jersey City
description: Correction Appended

title: A Tirade Sparked Syracuse's Surprise Run to the Title
description: The Syracuse assistant Mike Hopkins sat in a quiet corner of the locker room late Saturday night, his crisp sky-blue shirt perfectly summing up the improbability of the Orange's run to the Big East tournament title.

title: New charges filed in Livedoor scandal
Iran Rejects Russian Offer to Defuse Nuclear Dispute
description: TEHRAN, March 12 - Iran said Sunday that it had rejected a Russian proposal for a compromise on Iran's intention to enrich uranium. Iran also made a vague threat that it might drop out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty over the decision by the United Nations' nuclear monitoring body to forward its case to the Security Council.

title: Buyers Search Online, but Not by Brand
description: People searching for products online are a perfect target for advertisers, because they are essentially declaring their desire to make a purchase. Recognizing this, many companies pay search engines to show ads to users who have searched for their brand names.

title: Death Poses Challenges as Serbia Faces Past and Future
description: BELGRADE, Serbia and Montenegro, March 12 - The death of Slobodan Milosevic just as his long war-crimes trial was nearing an end poses new complexities for Europe and the United States, which both hoped to solve outstanding problems in the Balkans this year that are a legacy of Mr. Milosevic's role in the region's three wars in the 1990's.

title: Sharpen Your Pencils: Drawing the Way to Indy
description: ATLANTA Strongest of the regionals. When West Virginia is seeded sixth and George Washington, with only two losses, is No. 8, it is a sure sign of depth. No. 4 L.S.U. has the talent to make a deep run, but no team is hotter than No. 5 Syracuse. Still, look for No. 1 Duke and No. 2 Texas to line up in the regional final, with the Blue Devils advancing.

title: Lundqvist and Rangers Fall Short Again
description: At first glance, it would seem to be an anomaly. As of yesterday morning, the Rangers' rookie goaltender, Henrik Lundqvist, had the best goals against average in the N.H.L.

title: Trichet calls rate rises smooth
Land of the Big Puts 'Too Big' to the Test
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 12 - Discretion is prized here in Connecticut's richest town, so for Greenwich to be having a public row about what lies at the end of one man's private drive is a bit unusual.

title: Stung by vote, Koizumi vows to push move of GIs
Going to the Museum? Take Sunscreen and Get Ready to Dance
description: As all D.J.'s know, there is a maneuver called beat match that involves melding the tempo of a new tune with the one on the previous track. For two New York architects, that music-mixing technique proved the inspiration for "Beatfuse!," the winning entry in a design competition that annually transforms the courtyard at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOFFO SARNOFF, ANNA
description: MOFFO SARNOFF - Anna. Age 73, died on March 9, 2006 after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Robert Sarnoff. Loving stepmother of Rosita Sarnoff, Serena Benenson and Claudia Sarnoff. Grandmother of Adam, Toby and Felicia Benenson. Beloved sister of Nicholas Moffo, Jr. One of the greatest sopranos of her time, Anna brought joy to opera lovers throughout the world. Her many memorable roles included Mimi, Manon, Liu, Cio-Cio San, Violetta and the Countess. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St on Monday March 13 from 6-8 and Tuesday March 14 from 5-7. Funeral Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 50th St and 5th Ave on Wednesday, March 15 at 10AM. Burial private. Contributions in her memory should be made to the American Cancer Society, 19 W 56 St, New York, NY 10019.

title: Questions Are Raised About the Safety of a Major Heart Drug
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHAN, BLANCHE BILLOW
description: COHAN -- Blanche Billow. March 10, 2006, two days after her 93rd birthday. She stayed for the party and now has joined her beloved husband Leo. Dear sister of Selma and Muriel. Loving mother of Mike and Carol, Susan and Ken, grandmother of Edward and Patrice, Peter and Melissa, Sandy and Rob. Greatgrandmother of Lee, Olivia, Luke, Hadara and Molly. Private service and interment March 12. Donations to Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79 St, NYC; Jewish Museum of NY; and NARAL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EMMET, DIANA L.
description: EMMET--Diana L., 40, on March 8th, 2006. Born in Paris, France and a longtime New Yorker. A graduate of the Professional Children's School, Ms. Emmet had been a competitive figure skater and was until recently a skating coach at Wollman Rink. Diana was also a well-loved speaker for Love Heals. She had scores of devoted friends who visited frequently during her short illness. She is survived by her mother, Margaret Louise Emmet, her sisters, Claudia (Tina) Williams and Daphne Denat, her loving partner, Scott Wynn, and six nieces and nephews. Visiting hours will be Sunday, March 12th, and Monday, March 13th, from 4 to 6 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. A funeral mass will be held on Tuesday, March 14th, at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St. Contributions in her memory may be made to Love Heals, the Professional Children's School or Rivington House.

title: Many Charities Founded After Hurricane Are Faltering
description: Since Hurricane Katrina, the Internal Revenue Service has used a fast-track approval process to grant tax exemptions to almost 400 new charities that said they planned to assist the disaster's victims. But one that distributes leather jackets to address the special needs of sadomasochists? Another that hands out new underwear?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a newly discovered eruption of Mount Vesuvius, about 1780 B.C., misstated the location of Pompeii, the resort that was buried in the eruption of A.D. 79. As shown in the map with the article, Pompeii was five miles southeast of Vesuvius, not southwest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHALEN, THOMAS C.
description: WHALEN--Thomas C., Amagansett, New York. Succumbed to cancer on Friday March 10. He is survived by his wife Emily, daughters Emily DeMello of Forest Hills and Annie Petrocelli of New York City and grandsons Thomas and Richard. He is also survived by a brother Edward of Hillsboro, Fl. and a sister Mary of Milton, MA. A Memorial service is planned for later in the spring. Any contributions in his name may be made to Calvary Hospital in Bronx, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YANOFF, ALLEN
description: YANOFF--Allen, a quintessential physician; he was the doctor's doctor. We went to him for advice about pedestrian problems because his judgement was sound and unerring. We went to him to discuss matters of extraodinary medical complexity, seeking and finding solutions that were not to be found in journal articles, textbooks or perhaps anywhere else. He was mindful of the need to keep high-quality medical care alive, and to this end he championed a Medicare voucher system as a means of revitalizing our ailing healthcare system. He was tough, never complained even when facing bleak prospects and worked until the day before he died. He was a great doctor. Jeffrey Matos, M.D. Marshall Matos, M.D. Nicholas Skipitaris, M.D. Steven Zweibel, M.D.

title: Online Auteurs Hardly Need to Be Famous
description: Correction Appended

title: Budget Restraint Emerges as G.O.P. Theme for 2008
description: MEMPHIS, March 12 - As prospective Republican presidential candidates search for themes to distinguish their prospective campaigns, and distance themselves from the embattled incumbent in the White House, they appear to be in agreement on what one central issue should be in 2008: Curbing the federal spending that has soared under President Bush.

title: Judge recesses Moussaoui trial
A Makeover at the 'Trading Spaces' Network
description: "Live and Learn" is the new tagline for Discovery's TLC network starting March 27. Network executives hope it conveys to viewers that the channel is now a place for adults in their 30's who are what the network refers to as "in transition" -- buying their first house, getting married or having children.

title: Maureen Stapleton, Oscar-Winning Actress, Is Dead at 80
description: Maureen Stapleton, who created a gallery of pugnacious, sometimes profane but always vulnerable heroines on Broadway, in movies and on television and who won an Academy Award for her fiery performance as the anarchist Emma Goldman in "Reds," Warren Beatty's 1981 epic about the Russian Revolution, died today at her home in Lenox, Mass. She was 80.

Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAAR, LOUIS
description: KRAAR--Louis. Died suddenly of a heart attack at his home on Manhattan's Upper West Side, on Friday, March 10, 2006, age 71. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Maureen Aung-Thwin, his children Jennifer and Adam, brothers Ronald and Martin, and two greatly-loved grandchildren, Kyra and Amelia. Louis is also greatly missed by his beloved mother-in-law, Margaret Aung-Thwin of Montreal, and Rangoon, Burma; the entire Aung-Thwin and Hodgson families; and his worldwide circle of friends and colleagues. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Rogosin Institute, New York City, are appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERLMAN, IDA
description: PERLMAN - Ida, age 93. Passed away peacefully on March 11, 2006. Loving wife of the late Nat. Beloved mother of Joseph and Beverly Gordon, Renee and Seymour Gettinger. Dear sister of Doris Center and the late Helen Levy. Adoring grandmother of Jill, Gregg, Caryn, Alan, Jodi, Mari and Douglas. Proud great-grandmother of Ali, Carly and Jessica. Graveside services Tuesday, 1pm, at New Montefiore Cemetery. Contributions may be made to the NYC Chapter of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 733 3rd Avenue, NYC 10017.

Arts, Briefly; 'Failure' Tops at Theaters
description: Three new films took over the box office this weekend. The romantic comedy "Failure to Launch" (Paramount), starring Matthew McConaughey and Sarah Jessica Parker, below, reached No. 1 with $24.6 million in ticket sales, according to studio estimates. "The Shaggy Dog" (Buena Vista), starring Tim Allen, a remake of the 1959 Fred MacMurray-Annette Funicello hit, played second fiddle with $16 million, and another remake, "The Hills Have Eyes" (Fox Searchlight), directed by Alexandre Aja (Wes Craven made the original in 1977), was close behind with $15.5 million. "16 Blocks" (Warner Brothers) dropped two spots in its second week, to No. 4, with $7.3 million, bringing its total to a slim $22.6 million, and "Madea's Family Reunion" (Lionsgate), which held the No. 1 spot for the last two weeks, was next with $5.7 million, for a three-week gross of $55.7 million. Taking advantage of its Oscar for best picture, Lionsgate re-released "Crash" in 150 theaters; it took in $357,000 over the weekend, for total sales of $53.7 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, VANDER POEL, WENDY
description: RUSSELL-VANDER POEL-Wendy. A lifelong resident of Oyster Bay, Long Island, died peacefully at home on March 9, after a long illness. Mrs. Russell is survived by her daughters, Wendell Miller Steavenson of London, England, and Gretchen Miller Elkus of Ligonier, PA, six grandchildren, William M. Duryea III, Melissa Duryea Lewis, Wendell E., Michael McL. and Alexander H. Steavenson, and James M. Elkus, and five great-grandchildren. She was born on February 6, 1919, to Gretchen Billings and William Halsted Vander Poel of New York and Oyster Bay. Mrs. Russell served for many years on the boards of The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, The EyeBank for Sight Restoration and The Hutton House Lectures of C.W. Post. A memorial service will be held on March 17th at 11 am, at Christ Church, 61 East Main St, Oyster Bay. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, 1 Bungtown Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724; or The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration, Inc., 120 Wall Street, New York, NY 10005. For further information please contact the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home, Inc; 516-922-6700.

title: The Struggle for School Aid From Albany
description: As New York City has stepped up pressure on Albany for more money for city schools, all eyes have been on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has flexed his political muscle to get more aid for school construction.

title: Wegman's comic, richly human world
Shiite vigilantes execute 4 suspected terrorists
Don't Always Follow the Crowds
description: Connecticut and Duke, here we go again. These teams received top seedings in the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament, so pundits across America will fall all over themselves predicting a Duke-UConn battle for the national title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULDOON, SISTER CATHERINE
description: MULDOON--Sister Catherine. Sister Catherine Muldoon, known in Religious life as Sr. Marian Catherine, beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mary the Queen, died Saturday, March 11, 2006. Recognized nationally as a prominent figure in nursing education and nursing service, Sister was a sought after speaker for a variety of professional nursing organizations. She is survived by a nephew John R. Muldoon and a cousin Patricia Kennedy. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, NY on Tuesday from 11-2pm with a prayer service at 1:30pm. Reposing at St. Vincent's Hospital Chapel, 158 W. 12th St., NYC, Tuesday from 4-8pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10am, at the St. Vincent's Hospital. Interment to follow at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   JACOBS, LEE
description: JACOBS--Lee.I miss you and think aboutyou every single day. Love-Aimee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAIOCCO, RIZIERO
description: BAIOCCO - Riziero. Passed away on March 9. He is survived by his wife Mary, his children Benjamin, Dr. Peter J. and Marylou Baiocco, Rosemary and Joseph Walsh, eight grandchildren and two great great-grandchildren. We love and miss you. May you rest in peace.

title: Britain to Reduce Its Troops in Iraq to 7,000
description: LONDON, March 13 A Britain said today that it would reduce its troop strength in Iraq by about 10 percent beginning in May, bringing the level to about 7,000, the lowest since the war started in 2003.

title: Mark Morris With His Offbeat Ways to Pass a Saturday Hour
description: One of the nicer aspects of Mark Morris's monthlong celebration of his company's 25th anniversary is a string of three hourlong programs devoted to his "Solos, Duets and Trios." They take place on late Saturday afternoons in the large fifth-floor studio of the Mark Morris Dance Center, cater-cornered from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and are long since sold out.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9:30 P.M. (CBS) THE NEW ADVENTURES OF OLD CHRISTINE -- Julia Louis-Dreyfus (left), forever beloved (in a sinister way) as Elaine on "Seinfeld," gives the prime-time sitcom world another try. This time she's the title character, a divorced mother who is running a gym, putting her son into a snobby private school and trying to maintain a friendly relationship with her ex. He, inconsiderately, has a new girlfriend, also named Christine.

title: Pride Loses, Pirates Win in the N.C.A.A.'s Version of 'Deal or No Deal'
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 12 - Coach Louis Orr raised his arms, leaped from his chair and bolted out of the room when he saw Seton Hall's name flash on a big TV screen Sunday night, confirming that his team had received an invitation to the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament.

description: To the Editor:

Merck of Germany Expected to Seek Control of Schering
description: A German drug and chemical company, Merck KGaA, plans to make a 14.9 billion euro ($17.7 billion) hostile bid today for a German rival, Schering A.G., the target company said yesterday. Schering, the world's largest maker of oral contraceptives, said it intended to reject the unsolicited offer.

title: Income Inequality: More Get Less
Law School vs. School Laws
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The New So Paulo
description: Long overshadowed by Rio de Janeiro, a newly hip So Paulo is beginning to emerge as a lively weekend destination for American tourists.

title: Why drivers cant do up their own seat belts
description: In a response to my Step inside the paddock post, a reader came up with the very interesting question, Why do drivers need someone else to help apply their safety belts in the race car?

title: Want a Top Job on Wall Street? Start Playing Golf
description: Two of the first directors named to Morgan Stanleys board last summer were members of the Golf Club of Purchase in Westchester County, where John J. Mack, Morgan Stanleys chief executive, is a member, as are two of his recent appointees to the investment banks management committee. Charles R. Schwab, the founder and chairman of Charles Schwab, has one of the better handicaps among chief executives and together with four of his directors is a member of the San Francisco Golf Club, one of the most exclusive in the country. Two of the four  Frank C. Herringer, the former chief executive of Transamerica, and C. Preston Butcher, a real estate developer  belong to Cypress Point, another elite golfing enclave that counts Mr. Schwab as a member. Richard M. Kovacevich, the chief executive of Wells Fargo, has four directors on his board who belong to at least one of his three primary golf clubs: San Francisco, Cypress Point and Burlingame. And Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Citigroup, belongs to Augusta National, the holy grail for golf-loving businessmen, with two of his fellow directors: Kenneth T. Derr, the former chief executive of Chevron, and George David, the chief executive of United Technologies.

title: Baja for Beginners
description: On a family vacation to Todos Santos, Mexico, a swell time is had by all.

title: The Get
description: Hit the road, with duffel bags, foot candy, fold-up bikes and windbreakers.

title: Does Majority Rule? This Weeks Proxy Votes Will Decide
description: The week ahead will bring three closely watched votes on what may the hottest corporate-governance issue out there: majority election proposals.

title: Barrons Roundup: Funds Get Frisky, Drunk on NYSE
description: There may be more merger action in the mutual-fund sector, as banks, brokerages and insurers decide to sell out rather than run the risk of seeming to favor their own funds.

title: DreamWorks Deal May Not Have Hollywood Ending
description: When the Paramount Pictures unit of Viacom announced two months ago that it would acquire DreamWorks SKG for $1.6 billion, the deal was heralded as a coup and a fantasy come true by the news media and analysts alike.

title: Knight Ridder Sold to McClatchy for $4.5 Billion
description: Knight Ridder, the second-largest newspaper company in the United States, announced this morning that it agreed to sell itself for about $4.5 billion in cash and stock to the McClatchy Company, a publisher half its size. McClatchy will pay $67.25 per share consisting of $40.00 in cash and a fixed fraction of .5118 of a Class A McClatchy share. McClatchy will also aassume $2 billion in debt.

title: Enough Troops?
description: Michael R. Gordon reports on disagreements within the U.S. command about the Iraqi military threat.

title: Book Sourcing
description: Michael R. Gordon explains his reporting for a series of articles adapted from his book, "Cobra II: The Inside Story of the invasion and Occupation of Iraq."

title: Merck of Germany to Seek Control of Rival Drug Maker
description: A German drug and chemical company, Merck KGaA, plans to make a hostile bid of 14.9 billion euros ($17.7 billion) on Monday for its German rival, Schering, the target company said.

title: Hungry Media Companies Find a Meager Menu of Web Sites to Buy
description: Media companies are still hungry. Is there much left for them to consume that theyll find satisfying?

title: Talent Agencies May be Ripe for Consolidation
description: For more than a decade, the five largest talent agencies  Endeavor, ICM, William Morris Agency, Creative Artists Agency and United Talent Agency  have operated without a significant buyout or start-up in their circle. But in recent months, as a wave of acquisitions has shrunk the number of buyers that agents sell to, many believe its a matter of time before the agency business contracts.

title: On the Block: A Dozen Newspapers That McClatchy Will Divest
description: As part of McClatchys Deal for Knight Ridder, it said it would sell 12 Knight Ridder newspapers, including the Philadelphia Inquirer and San Jose Mercury News. Others include Knight Ridders other Philadelphia paper, the Daily News; Akron Beacon Journal (OH); Wilkes Barre Times Leader (PA); Aberdeen American News (SD); Grand Forks Herald (ND); Ft. Wayne News- Sentinel (IN); Contra Costa Times (CA); Monterey Herald (CA); and Duluth News Tribune (MN). The St. Paul Pioneer Press (MN) is to be sold due to anticipated anti-trust concerns involving McClatchys (Minneapolis) Star Tribune.

title: Blackberry Maker Buys Software Firm
description: Research In Motion said Friday that it has acquired Ascendent Systems, a privately held software firm, and released an updated version of its corporate server, giving it new tools to more tightly connect its BlackBerry to corporate phone and data services.

title: Capitalia Purchases Intesa Stake to Thwart Takeover
description: Capitalia, whose shares rose 7 percent last week on merger speculation, said it purchased a 2 percent stake in Banca Intesa worth 696 million euros ($827 million), a move that may thwart a possible takeover bid for Capitalia by Italys second-largest bank.

title: Denver Law Firm in Merger Talks
description: One of Denvers largest law firms is in merger talks that could add nearly 80 lawyers to its rolls. Sherman & Howard is negotiating with Phoenix-based Jennings Strouss & Salmon, which has 77 lawyers, primarily in Phoenix. Sherman & Howard has 130 lawyers in Denver, making it the second-largest firm based here, tied with Holme Roberts & Owen.

title: Wall Street Insider Uses  His Quill to Strike Rival Grubman
description: In his book about dishonesty on Wall Street, Confessions of a Wall Street Analyst: A True Story of Inside Information and Corruption in the Stock Market, Dan Reingold takes aim rival Jack Grubman.

title: Bell Mergers Give Cable Companies Even More to Worry About
description: In the chess game between the cable companies and their nemeses, the Bell phone companies, the Bells may be gaining ground. Phone mergers  including AT&Ts recent proposal to take over BellSouth  could give the Bells more power to cut prices, move faster into television and expand their advantage in the wireless market.

title: Intel Is Expanding V.C. Arm
description: Intel Capital is bucking the trend of corporations pulling out of the private equity market. Last year, Dell Inc. closed its investment shop, Dell Ventures, about a month after Applied Materials Inc. shut down its VC arm, Applied Materials Ventures.

title: Blackstone, KKR May Team Up for Portugal Telecom Bid
description: A group of buyout firms including Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. may team with Portuguese entrepreneur Miguel Pais do Amaral in a bid for the countrys biggest telephone company, said people with knowledge of the talks.

title: As L.S.E. and Nasdaq Resume Talks, Eyes Turn to NYSE
description: Shares of the London Stock Exchange surged as much as 24 percent after the Nasdaq Stock Market offered 2.4 billion pounds ($4.1 billion) to buy the 308-year-old exchange and create the first trans-Atlantic equity market. While the L.S.E. rejected the Nasdaqs offer Friday, the two will soon resume takeover discussions, as the New York Stock Exchange, now called NYSE Group, considers making its own offer.

title: Wikia Takes In $4 Million in Funding
description: It might take two years for popular online nonprofit encyclopedia Wikipedia to raise $1 million. But for Wikia, the for-profit company from Wikipedias co-founder Jimmy Wales, all it took was a single stroke of the pen to raise four times as much.

title: Goldman May Report Record Profits
description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc., the worlds second-biggest securities firm by market value, may report a record profit tomorrow, led by investment gains and fees from advising in mergers.

title: Vodafones Gent Resigns Amid Signs of Palace Intrigue
description: Sir Christopher Gent, who helped build Vodafone Group into the worlds largest mobile phone company, gave up an honorary position at the company on Sunday amid reports suggesting that he was trying to undermine the current chief executive, Arun Sarin.

title: State-Run Indian Lender Plans IPO
description: Power Finance Corporation, a state-run Indian lender to electricity utilities, plans to sell shares in an initial public offering because it wants to increase lending, Chairman and Managing Director V.K. Garg said.

title: Behind the Cinergy-Duke Deal
description: Negotiations that led to the pending merger of Cinergy and Duke Energy involved lots of give-and-take over board seats, executive job titles and severance costs, a recent merger filing shows.

title: Corruption and Remorse: A Tale of Two Fastows
description: A federal court in Houston was supposed to be the stage this week for one of the most indisputably evil of white-collar criminals, Andrew S. Fastow, to incriminate his notorious ex-bosses at Enron and then get ripped to shreds by their lawyers.

title: Auto Parts Maker Dana Meets With Creditors
description: Dana Corporation said Friday it hopes to emerge from bankruptcy within 18 months, and its chief executive told creditors that the auto parts company plans to further wean itself off of three major customers, the Big Three auto makers.

title: Banks Sue to Declare Yukos Bankrupt
description: A consortium of Western banks led by Socit Gnrale of France filed a lawsuit in Moscow on Friday to declare the Yukos oil company bankrupt just over a year after the Kremlin seized its largest production asset amid a politically tinged tax dispute.

title: A Nasdaq Bid For London May Spark European Mergers
description: Nasdaqs bid for the London Stock Exchange may spark broader European consolidation. Euronext and Deutsche Boerse wont want to be gobbled up by whichever American exchange misses out on L.S.E. And its not just exchange executives who will be thinking hard. National politicians will probably be keen to see exchanges merge.

title: Studio Boss and a Private Eye Star in a Bitter Hollywood Tale
description: Brad Grey, chairman of Paramount Pictures, may have ties to Anthony Pellicano, the celebrity private detective who is at the center of a mushrooming federal investigation that has consumed Hollywood for months, and who was indicted on wiretapping and conspiracy charges last month, according to the accounts of several people involved in the investigation.

title: Morgan Stanley to Triple Japanese Real Estate Investment
description: Morgan Stanley, which bought $8 billion of Japanese real estate last year, says it will triple investment in Chinese property this year, shifting emphasis from Japan in a bet on the worlds fastest-growing major economy.

title: Australias Toll May Win Bid for Port Operator Patrick
description: Toll Holdings Ltd., Australias biggest freight carrier, may win a seven-month hostile bid for port operator Patrick Corporation after the antitrust regulator dropped its opposition to the A$4.3 billion ($3.1 billion) offer.

title: Australian Gas Counterbids for Alinta
description: Australian Gas Light, the nations biggest energy utility, countered a takeover plan from Alinta by offering A$2.72 billion ($2 billion) in shares for the smaller rival.

title: Yell Is Said to Be Circling Spains TPI
description: British directory publisher Yell Group has hired Goldman Sachs to advise it on a potential bid for Telefonicas TPI directories business, The Sunday Times of London reported.

title: Livedoor May Sell Stake in Wake of Investigation
description: Livedoor, the Japanese Internet company accused of securities fraud, says it may sell a stake to outside investors after a raid on its offices set off a 91 percent slide in market value.Go to Article from Bloomberg News>>

title: Report Sees Busy Year for Entertainment Deals
description: Its only March, but PricewaterhouseCoopers is already forecasting that 2006 could bring the most media- and entertainment-related deal activity in the last six years. (Deals, by their definition, include spinoffs and minority squeeze-outs as well as mergers and acquisitions.)

description: As McClatchy lays out its plans for acquiring newspaper chain Knight Ridder, the fate of a one-third stake in CareerBuilder, an online classifieds business, remains unclear.

description: As Watson Pharmaceuticals coughs up $1.9 billion to acquire rival Andrx, one analyst is speculating that other makers of geneic drugs will face increased pressure to bulk up as well.

title: Touching a Nerve on Commissions
description: The Inman News Service, which specializes in real estate news, runs a blog. Bradley Inman posted an item there about what he calls the real estate industrys elephant in the room  falling commissions. He said, It is happening now. Why?

description: In the highlands of Nicaragua, a coffee plantation re-invents itself for visitors. (Produced by Naka Nathaniel)

description: Joe Sharkey discusses how to find the gems amid a sea of travel blogs with surly, half-baked reporting.

title: One Marines Routine
description: My average day is actually pretty predictable when Im not out on an operation. Being a creature of habit I try to stick to the routine I have found. It seems the more I repeat my endless iterations of eating, sleeping, working, and exercising, the faster the calendar pages flip. Now, its not as if I am hating life out here. On the contrary, the opportunity to have a positive impact during a pivotal point in our history is the type of stuff dreams are made of. To help capture or kill my nations enemies is just icing on the cake. However, small, achievable goals make for a happy deployment.

Mr. Bisman, at New York University, started a nonprofit record label, JDub, and his friend at the New School, who called himself Matisyahu, worked on his reggae toasting skills.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Trichet Comments on 3 Economies
description: The European Central Bank president, Jean-Claude Trichet, left, said expansion in the world's three largest economies was robust enough to withstand the first round of concerted interest rate increases in six years. The pace of global expansion "is certainly encouraging," Mr. Trichet told a news conference after meeting with his Group of 10 colleagues in Basel. Central banks are "paving the way for sustainable growth" by ensuring stable prices. The Bank of Japan last week joined the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank in tightening monetary policy to head off inflation. The Bank of Japan cut the amount of cash it provides to lenders and may raise rates this year as economic growth quickens. Investors expect the Fed and the European Central Bank to continue raising rates as their economies expand. "There seems to be acceptance that the big three central banks envisage further tightening," said Julian Callow, chief European economist at Barclays Capital in London. "The G-10 appears confident about the pace of economic expansion."

title: Chaney Is Retiring as Coach at Temple
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 13 - John Chaney, the Hall of Fame basketball coach whose personality could be as complicated as the matchup zone defense he preferred, announced his retirement from Temple on Monday.

title: Emphasizing the Humor in a Problem Play
description: It is fortunate for the theater, not to mention newspapers, that hypocrisy, corruption and sexual entanglements in high places have never gone out of fashion. It was as true at the beginning of the 17th century as it is in the 21st, and for that reason alone a play like "Measure for Measure" can still engage an audience, especially in a solid revival like the one now being staged by the Pearl Theater Company.

title: South Korea Continues to Find Motivation
description: Anaheim, Calif. - BEFORE the World Baseball Classic, South Korea was not considered on the level of the United States, the Dominican Republic, Venezuela, Puerto Rico, Cuba, or even Japan. But the South Koreans won Pool A by beating Japan in the final game of the first round and were the tournament's only undefeated team as they entered last night's game against the United States.

title: Corrections

title: A Troupe From Down South Reveals Its Secret Weapon
description: Atlanta Ballet's only New York appearance, at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts, seemed like an innocuous way to spend a drizzly Sunday afternoon. But the attractive company, directed by John McFall, possessed a secret weapon apart from its lovely, well-trained dancers: the New York debut of the choreographer Christopher Hampson, long recognized in ballet circles as "the other Christopher."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOFFO SARNOFF, ANNA
description: MOFFO SARNOFF - Anna. Age 73, died on March 9, 2006 after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Robert Sarnoff. Loving stepmother of Rosita Sarnoff, Serena Benenson and Claudia Sarnoff. Grandmother of Adam, Toby and Felicia Benenson. Beloved sister of Nicholas Moffo, Jr. One of the greatest sopranos of her time, Anna brought joy to opera lovers throughout the world. Her many memorable roles included Mimi, Manon, Liu, Cio-Cio San, Violetta and the Countess. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St on Monday March 13 from 6-8 and Tuesday March 14 from 5-7. Funeral Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 50th St and 5th Ave on Wednesday, March 15 at 10AM. Burial private. Contributions in her memory should be made to the American Cancer Society, 19 W 56 St, New York, NY 10019. $(6$)MOFFO SARNOFF -- Anna. The Board of Directors of the Licia Albanese-Puccini Foundation mourns the death of the esteemed member of our Board, Anna Moffo Sarnoff. She gave unsparingly of her many talents not only to the opera world, but also to her devoted friends, her grateful students, and the humanitarian causes she championed. We depended on her wise counsel and judgment, and she leaves a void that will serve as a reminder of her knowledge, her artistry, her elegance, and her beauty. Thank you, Anna, for having given us so much. Licia Albanese Gimma Chairman and Founder $(6$)MOFFO SARNOFF -- Anna. The Board and staff of New York Festival of Song mourn the passing of Advisory Board member Anna Moffo Sarnoff, whose longstanding support honored and sustained our work. A great talent and a great beauty in voice, person, and character, she remains with us in spirit, cherished and remembered always. A song cycle by Paul Moravec, commissioned by NYFOS and dedicated to Anna's memory, will be premiered on April 11, at Merkin Hall. $(6$)MOFFO SARNOFF--Anna. The Daniel Ferro Vocal Program mourns with great sadness the death of Anna Moffo, friend, advisor and supporter. Anna's beautiful voice and impeccable musicianship will inspire young artists for years to come. Joy and Daniel Ferro $(6$)MOFFO--Anna, rest in peace amongst the angels. Thank you for your grace and beauty and all the glorious performances that filled our hearts. Teresa Stratas $(6$)MOFFO SARNOFF--Anna. A beloved friend and a great artist who has given of herself to so many. We will miss you. Frank & Raquel Celenza

title: Drop Out of the College
description: The Electoral College is an antidemocratic relic. Everyone who remembers 2000 knows that it can lead to the election of the candidate who loses the popular vote as president. But the Electoral College's other serious flaws are perhaps even more debilitating for a democracy. It focuses presidential elections on just a handful of battleground states, and pushes the rest of the nation's voters to the sidelines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HYMAN, HELEN KANDEL
description: HYMAN--Helen Kandel, 85. Died at home in Westport, Ct. on March 6, surrounded by her children, grandchildren and adoring dog. She was born in Manhattan, the daughter of Jessie and Isaac Leon Kandel, and graduated from the Horace Mann School and Barnard College. Her professional career began at CBS during the Golden Age of radio, where she wrote dramatic scripts. After starting a family, she continued writing as a freelancer, while living abroad for extended periods with her husband, sociologist Herbert Hyman, and their children. She co-authored "You and Your Aging Parent" (1976), and "Growing Older Together" (1992), which have been translated into many languages. A third edition was planned at the time of her death. Widowed for twenty years, she is survived by her daughter, Lisa Horowitz and her husband Ted, of Westport; her son David and his wife Eugenie, also of Westport; her son Alex and his partner Deborah Levitzky, of Washington, D.C. and New York City; four grandchildren, Daniel and Anna Horowitz, Nicholas and Graham Hyman; her brother Alan Kandel and his wife Carol, of Detroit; as well as many good friends and admirers from a long, rich life. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Save the Children or Mid-Fairfield Hospice. Burial was private. A memorial will be held at the Westport Playhouse on March 26 at 2 PM.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: A Challenger For Lieberman
description: Ned Lamont, a Greenwich cable executive, formally announced an upstart bid yesterday to challenge United States Senator Joseph I. Lieberman in a Democratic primary, saying the three-term incumbent's continuing support for the war in Iraq was evidence that he had abandoned the party that elected him. "Nobody will be calling me George Bush's favorite Democrat," Mr. Lamont said. A February poll by Quinnipiac University showed Senator Lieberman leading Mr. Lamont by 55 percentage points. The same poll showed Mr. Lieberman's job-approval rating was 63 percent. To qualify for the Aug. 8 primary, Mr. Lamont needs 15,000 signatures or support from 15 percent of the delegates at the state party's convention in May. WILLIAM YARDLEY (NYT)

title: Rice Seeks to Strengthen U.S. Ties to Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, March 14 -- Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice sought today to expand a "strategic partnership" with Indonesia, including increased military cooperation following the decision last year to resume military aid that had long been cut off because of Indonesia's human rights difficulties.

title: A Rare Predator Bounces Back (Now Get It Out of Here)
description: OCHOPEE, Fla.  In the weeks before Valentine's Day, a healthy Florida panther kept emerging from the dense, sloshy wilderness around Big Cypress National Preserve to kill things he shouldn't: chickens, ducks, a turkey, a pig and a house cat, all on residential property that his stealthy species normally shuns.

title: Cost Concerns for F.B.I. Computer Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 - The long-stalled effort to overhaul the Federal Bureau of Investigation's antiquated computer system could cost another half-billion dollars to complete, and it runs the risk of continued overruns, a Justice Department report concluded Monday.

Terrance Wright, a Fort Bragg officer recently back from Iraq, seemed to hiccup almost constantly for weeks before he died,' his family says."
