title: As Howard Stern Ranted, David Letterman Debated
description: It was not surprising that Howard Stern wore a T-shirt that said "I Hate Les Moonves" for his interview with David Letterman on CBS on Monday night. His language, by shock-radio standards, was quite mild: he merely described the chief executive of CBS and his former boss as "the biggest jerk on the planet." (On Fox News, he used one of his favorite expressions on Mr. Moonves: "pig vomit.")

description: LEVY--Morris. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Morris Levy, associated with The Times from December 1946 until retiring in July 1986.

title: Arts, Briefly; Ratings After 'Seinfeld'
description: The two episodes of the series debut of "The New Adventures of Old Christine," the latest post-"Seinfeld" comedy of Julia Louis-Dreyfus, left, helped CBS win Monday night's race in Nielsen's estimates. The half-hour episodes delivered 12.48 million viewers at 8:30 p.m., then 15.27 million at 9:30 p.m., both above average for those time slots. ("Two and a Half Men" was shown in between, and had 17.56 million viewers.) But NBC and Fox also had reason to be happy. NBC's game show "Deal or No Deal" easily won the 8 p.m. hour in total viewers (15.38 million) and among 18-to-49-year-olds, and lifted the network to a second-place finish over all in that age group despite its weakened "Apprentice" (9.91 million). And Fox's "24," which featured the deaths of Tony Almeida (Carlos Bernard) and Lynn McGill (Sean Astin), drew 13.57 million viewers, winning the 9 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49. When "Prison Break" returns with new episodes at 8 p.m. next Monday, Fox will present a formidable challenge to CBS in the sought-after 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

If they lose, if they don't make it to the semifinals in San Diego, it doesn't matter to me. I'll be there to watch whichever four teams make it.

description: WASHINGTON, March 14 - Senate Republicans on Tuesday narrowly defeated an effort to impose budget rules that would make it harder to increase spending or cut taxes, a move that critics said that showed Republicans were posturing in their calls for greater fiscal restraint.

It was late September, some two weeks before the start of practice for Army.

description: BOLOCAN--Dr. Hyam. The Department of Psychiatry of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Medical College of Cornell University regrets the passing of our esteemed and beloved faculty member, Dr. Hyam Bolocan, a much-loved teacher, an influential mentor, and a loyal sweet friend. He added immeasurably to our patients' care and our students' wisdom. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Dr. Jack D. Barchas Chairman Dr. Philip J. Wilner Medical Director

The Quest
description: Welcome to Burlesque 101 at the Red Hots Burlesque School of Shimmy, where 17 beginners -- including one man -- learn the history of burlesque, how to develop a costume and comic character and how to pick a stage name. Armed with boas, shimmy skirts and feather fans, they tackle the bump, the grind, the shimmy and the shake.

title: Reservoir Dam Bursts in Hawaii; One Is Killed and 7 Are Missing
description: HONOLULU, March 14 - One person was killed and as many as seven were missing on Tuesday morning after an earthen dam burst on the North Shore of Kauai, sending a wall of water from the mountains toward the ocean, ripping up a highway and lifting several houses off their foundations.

title: Sony Shares Fall; Delay on New Console Feared
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, March 15 - Shares of Sony, the ailing Japanese electronics giant, fell as much as 2 percent in early trading Wednesday in Tokyo amid renewed speculation that the company might delay the release of its newest game console.

title: Arts, Briefly; Gas Chamber Exhibition Closed In Germany
description: A town near Cologne, Germany, has suspended an installation by a Spanish performance artist that resembles a gas chamber after Jewish leaders and Holocaust survivors complained, officials said. For the piece, "245 Cubic Meters," the artist, Santiago Sierra, hooked the exhaust pipes of six cars up to an old synagogue in Pulheim, flooding the interior with carbon monoxide. Visitors to the installation, which opened on Sunday, were outfitted with breathing masks, above, and were accompanied through the building by a fireman after signing a release saying that they understood the gas was poisonous. Stephan J. Kramer, the general secretary of the Central Council of Jews in Germany, has called the work deeply offensive, but the mayor of Pulheim, Karl August Morisse, defended it, saying that the gruesome facts of the Holocaust were "openly addressed." Mr. Sierra, 39, who lives in Mexico, has said that his work is a protest against the "trivialization of the Holocaust." The piece was to run each Sunday through April 30, with a break for Easter on April 16, but a spokesman for the town said that a pause would allow for more debate. SARAH PLASS

title: Elder Posada's Trek: Cuba to a Box Seat
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 14 - Jorge Posada Sr. could not continue to live the way he was living, so he was willing to die to try and change things. Living in Cuba had become that unbearable to him. Posada had no freedom and no future, he said, so he had to escape.

title: A Plea for Forgiveness Sweetens Intricate Twists and Turns of Justice in Iran
description: In "Beautiful City," two troubled young friends in Iran, Akbar (Hossein Farzi-Zadeh) and Ala (Babak Ansari), are confined to a juvenile detention center, Akbar first for the murder of a girlfriend, Ala for petty thievery. Akbar has just turned 18, the age at which convicts are transferred to the adult facilities and can be legally executed.

One rape occurred in Nassau County, and the second rape and the kidnapping took place in Queens.

title: Learning Curve Is Steep at End of Mets' Rotation
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 14 - A group of Dominican natives on the Mets gathered beneath a clubhouse television Monday afternoon to watch their homeland's World Baseball Classic game against Cuba. Off to the side, away from the hollering and hooting and cap-waving, sat a native of Scottsdale, Ariz., who had just as much interest in what was unfolding.

title: Family lawyer says Milosevic will be buried in Belgrade

Bloomberg suspended the Correction Department's top chaplain for two weeks yesterday in connection with remarks he made about the White House being occupied by terrorists. The mayor acknowledged that the words were "inappropriate and offensive," but he also offered a vigorous defense of the right to free speech, which he said was under increasing attack.

title: The Internet Campaign Loophole
description: For all the avowals to put the brakes on ethical lapses, the House is showing its true colors with an attempt to turn the Internet into a free-flowing big-money trough for uncontrolled political spending. The measure would exempt political ads on the Internet from a reform law barring corporate and union donors from buying up grateful candidates with six- and seven-figure contributions.

title: World Bank imagines dark Palestinian days

Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a study on the economic and social impact of the growth in the number of Americans over age 65 paraphrased imprecisely from an observation by Richard J. Hodes, director of the National Institute on Aging. Although he acknowledged in response to a question that there is some public concern that older Americans would drain government coffers and devour health care resources, he himself did not express that fear. He said decreasing disability rates among older Americans could blunt such economic effects.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the top chaplain for New York City's jails, a Muslim imam who was placed on leave for his comments about terrorists in the White House, misspelled his surname. He is Umar Abdul-Jalil, not Abdul-Jamil.

title: In Iran, Dissenting Voices Riseon Its Leaders' Nuclear Strategy

Now, while the top leaders remain resolute in their course, cracks are opening both inside and outside the circles of power over the issue.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Presidential Candidate For The Main Opposition
description: The main opposition group, the Brazilian Social Democratic Party, chose Geraldo Alckmin, the governor of So Paulo State, the country's biggest and richest, to challenge President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva in October. The party had been divided for months over whether to choose Mr. Alckmin or Jos Serra, the better-known mayor of So Paulo, Brazil's largest city. Mr. da Silva, who has not officially announced his candidacy for re-election, has been weakened by a corruption scandal, and the Social Democratic Party is seen as having the best chance of beating him.

title: Few Riders, Much Vision in Connecticut Rail Plan
description: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn. - The future would be all bustle and efficiency: Riders would step off commuter trains here throughout the day, breeze through a new station and then step onto shuttle buses that take them a few miles west to Bradley International Airport, where they jet off to spread the news that central Connecticut is built for business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONNELLY, RITA
description: CONNELLY--Rita, 93. Rita Gorman Connelly of Sea Island, Georgia and Saltaire, New York died peacefully at her home on March 11. Beloved wife of the late Paul W. Connelly, mother of Patricia McAllister and the late Jeanne Heurtematte and the late Paul W. Connelly III; grandmother of Cristin and Paul W. Connelly IV, Michael, Andrew and Matthew McAllister, Darcy Heurtematte Langdon and great grandmother of Grace Connelly Langdon. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated at 11AM on April 1 at St. William's Catholic Church, St. Simons Island, Georgia. Donations may be made to Trinity College, 125 Michigan Avenue, NE, Washinton, DC 20017-1094.

title: Ex-Enron Officer Says He Warned of Shady Partnerships
description: HOUSTON, March 14 - A former Enron managing director who evaluated risk for the company testified on Tuesday that he strenuously objected to the formation of off-balance-sheet partnerships directed by Andrew S. Fastow and urged the company to "come clean" about the risks they posed.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Feb. 11 about the federal investigation of Anthony Pellicano, a former Hollywood private detective, referred incorrectly to computer data seized in a raid on his office in 2002. (The error also occurred in articles on Feb. 6 this year and on Oct. 19, 2005.) Investigators said they had recovered storage devices with a capacity of 3.868 terabytes of data, which they said would be the equivalent of two billion pages of double-spaced text. They did not find two billion pages of notes and wiretap transcripts.

title: Grown-Up Pomegranates and Pears
description: New to the long list of pomegranate products is Pama, a liqueur that is more sweet than tart and is a superb cocktail enhancement. A splash of it in Champagne gives new personality to a kir royale, and it's an excellent addition to a cosmopolitan, a margarita, a shot of silver tequila or gin on the rocks. It does wonders for a bowl of berries. Pama Pomegranate Liqueur is made in Kentucky by Heaven Hill Distillers and is available in New York for about $25 at the Park Avenue Liquor Shop, and Astor Wines & Spirits. It will be sold nationwide in about a month.

title: U.N. Investigator Calls Beirut Assassins Professional
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 14 - Planning for the assassination last year of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, was so thorough, disciplined and meticulous that the perpetrators were probably experienced operatives, according to a report circulated Tuesday by the head of the United Nations investigation.

title: Belittling the Big Man: It Works for the Buckeyes
description: To motivate Terence Dials last season, the assistant coach Dan Peters of Ohio State referred to him by the nickname Tinkerbell. It was not a compliment for a large center on a basketball team to be compared to the elusive fairy represented by a point of light in "Peter Pan."

title: The Dictator Who Got Away
description: Budapest - THE Danube flowed dark and slow as winter dusk fell on Belgrade. My instructions were precise: Slobodan Milosevic's lawyer would meet me on a certain riverboat at 5 p.m. The road was deserted, the only sign of life the hum of traffic on a distant bridge. The boat was empty, apart from three men huddled in a corner, wreathed in cigarette smoke. They fell silent as I stepped inside.

More than 700 Albany students were camping outside the university gym waiting for tickets to the America East Conference championship game that would eventually propel Brown's team into the N.C.A.A. tournament.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, BRETT J.
description: MEYER--Brett J. Age 60, died on March 12, 2006, after a courageous fight against Lymphoma. Brett was an ethical and devoted attorney who served as a partner at the law firm of Pryor, Cashman, Sherman and Flynn. Brett is survived by his loving wife of 34 years Patricia, his two children Damon and Elizabeth, his mother Elaine, his brother Douglas, sister-in-law Jill, nieces Emily and Sara and an energetic Labrador Retriever, Maggie. Brett's integrity, his perpetual optimism and his never ending love of life will live on in his friends and family, and he will be deeply missed. Services on Thursday, at 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. In lieu of flowers please send donations in Brett's name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRWAN, RICHARD F.
description: KIRWAN--Richard F., 74. Died March 6, in St. Thomas, USVI, of cancer. Survived by Helen, his wife of 35 years; son Richard; daughters Sydney Kirwan and Alicia Carusona; brother Roger; sisters Carol Aikenhead and Clare Briody; six grandchildren; many loving relatives and friends. A graduate of the School of Hotel Administration at Cornell, he was manager of private clubs and restaurants and owned a bistro in Manhattan. In St. Thomas, he served as president of the Board of Realtors, was a Rotarian, and was President of the Council on Alcoholism St. Thomas (COAST). Memorial service, Saturday afternoon, March 18, Holy Family Church Columban Hall, Cassi Hill, St. Thomas, VI.

title: Brown Launches a Full-Court Rant
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 14 - Larry Brown and Stephon Marbury have vastly different ideas about what ails the Knicks. Logically, one of them is wrong. Brown is pretty sure it is not him.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Utility Companies Keeping Some Tax Collections By Including Subsidiaries in Financial Reports In a practice that is legal in most states, many electric utilities across the nation are collecting billions from customers for corporate income taxes and then keeping the money rather than sending it to the government. The practice involves using losses from subsidiaries to reduce taxes. [Page A1.]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHANDLER, SYLVIA (NEE GANZ)
description: CHANDLER -- Sylvia (nee Ganz). On March 13, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Martin "Pat". Dearest mother of Susan (Allan) Pessin. Devoted sister of the late Daniel (Beverlee) Ganz. Loving sister-inlaw of Jack & Ruth Chandler, Frances DuBow, and the late Bernie DuBow and also the late Bess & Chip Harris, Doris and Mike Foreman, Zelda and Norman Friedman, Kahn and Kate Chandler, Al and Alva Chandler, Frank and Yetta Chandler and Ann Chandler. Dear cousin and caring aunt to many. Services Thursday, 1:00 PM "Gutterman's Inc", 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIND, ROBERT
description: SIND--Robert. The Board & Staff of Northside Center mourn the passing of Robert Sind. Bob was a Board Member/Treasurer, advisor, committed supporter and good friend. He used his special skills to help Northside continue to make a difference in the lives of children. We extend our condolences to the family. Northside's Board, Staff, children & families

title: William Pfaff: When a young Frenchman's fancy turns to revolution
At Long Last, Wine in the Mail
description: IT was almost too easy. For years I had been thwarted by Navarro Vineyards' policy of bypassing retail stores. Instead, Navarro's fine gewrztraminers and late-harvest rieslings from Mendocino County were sold only through restaurants or by direct sale to customers. As a New York resident, I was out of luck. That is, until last May, when a Supreme Court ruling struck down bans on out-of-state wine shipments in New York and Michigan. Then in July, New York passed a new law allowing residents over the age of 21 to do the civilized thing.

title: Other Views: Globe and Mail, Christian Science Monitor, Bangkok Post
Skiing: Walchhofer seals 2nd title
Amos, Andy and Company Are Seen Through Time's Lens
description: In the American cultural revolution known as political correctness, the zeal with which some reformers attacked perceived offenses to good taste often resulted in collateral damage to genuine artistic achievement. Carl Clay and his Black Spectrum Theater Company have sought to rehabilitate one of the victims with an original play titled "Kingfish, Amos and Andy," an amusing, nostalgic and fond tribute to one of the funniest shows in the early days of television.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the Dames of Beef, women who dine at venerable New York restaurants while wearing vintage clothing, misspelled the name of a restaurant that one member visited as a child. It was Rumpelmayer's, not Rumplemeyer's.

title: Passed Ball Lets the Dominicans Advance
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 14 - When players are representing their countries in a new international tournament, there are no easy ways to succumb, no simple ways to explain the loss back home. Losing on a passed ball is one of the worst ways to see a passionate pursuit end.

title: Italian Rivals Debate the U.S. Way: Boringly
description: ROME, March 14 - Many here hoped for the kind of public drama Italy loves, that something decisive might happen on this night Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and his challenger Romano Prodi finally faced each other in their first televised debate of this tight race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SARACH, ALFRED
description: SARACH--Alfred. Born December 25, 1924 died March 11, 2006, father and teacher of American History at Central Commercial High School, Norman Thomas High School and Touro College. Survived by his sons Omar and Jason. He rests peacefully now.

title: Case Involving Errors in Teacher Test Is Settled
description: The Educational Testing Service, one of the biggest testing organizations in the United States, has agreed to pay $11.1 million to settle a class-action lawsuit about errors in the scoring of a widely used teacher licensing examination, according to court-approved settlement papers released yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about clinical trials of NMT Medical's heart implant device for the treatment of migraines misstated the title of John Barr at AGA Medical, a competitor that has a similar device ready for testing. He is chief operating officer, not chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAFRO, DR. ABRAHAM I.
description: SAFRO--Dr. Abraham I. Of Fort Lee, NJ. Husband of Helene nee Horowitz. Father of Bruce Safro, Reina Pattner & Robert Safro. Grandfather of Jason Safro, Jocelyn Pattner, Sandra Safro and Justin Pattner. Services Wednesday 10 A.M. "GuttermanMusicant," 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOK, JEAN, M.D.
description: COOK--Jean, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is profoundly saddened by the passing of its former associate dean of students and associate professor of medicine emeritus. He joined the Einstein faculty in 1958, and impressed colleagues as a dedicated physician with a sharp, keen intellect and gentle, dignified manner. For more than a decade, he also was a devoted dean of students whose wise counsel helped guide generations of future doctors to success. To friends, colleagues, and students he was known to be honest, sincere, and warm, and a great lover of music. His fair-minded, supportive approach always focused on the best interests of students, for whom he was always deeply concerned. He was much loved by all who knew him and he will be greatly missed. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

title: A new standard formula: Social + responsibility = reward
House Leaders Plan to Support Measure Restricting Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 - After weeks of internal wrangling over a measure to tighten lobbying laws, the House Republican leadership decided Tuesday night to back a measure that would temporarily bar lawmakers from privately financed trips and require lobbyists to disclose their gifts to lawmakers.

Knight Ridder Chief Expresses His Regrets Over Deal to Sell Newspapers
description: The chairman and chief executive of Knight Ridder, P. Anthony Ridder, who sold the newspaper chain to the McClatchy Company on Monday, said last night that he resisted the sale and then sought to persuade McClatchy to keep most of the company's 32 papers.

Ex-Firefighter Pleads Guilty to Assault in Firehouse Brawl
description: A former firefighter who struck a colleague in the head with a chair during a brawl at their Staten Island firehouse on New Year's Eve 2003 has pleaded guilty to assault, prosecutors announced today.

title: Dubai and Dunces
description: When it came to the Dubai ports issue, the facts never really had a chance -- not in this political season. Still, it's hard to imagine a more ignorant, bogus, xenophobic, reckless debate than the one indulged in by both Republicans and Democrats around this question of whether an Arab-owned company might oversee loading and unloading services in some U.S. ports. If you had any doubts before, have none now: 9/11 has made us stupid.

A Vegetable (Well, Fruit) That Deserves Attention
description: BACK in the 70's, there was one way to cook winter squash: you cut it in half, scooped out the seeds, threw some butter and brown sugar in the cavity (or, if you were sophisticated, maple syrup) and baked it. Then you put it on the table so people could pick at it, without much gusto.

title: Rumsfeld Hints at Troop Increase During Pilgrimage Surge
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld gave a strong hint on Tuesday that American troop levels in Iraq might be increased in coming days, perhaps only slightly and temporarily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCGUCKIN, ROBERT H. III.
description: MCGUCKIN--Robert H. III. Died on Sunday, March 12, 2006 at age 63 at his home in Alexandria, VA. after a valiant nine month battle with neuroendocrine cancer. Beloved husband of Barbara J. Katz. Devoted father of son Robert Lawrence and his wife Dana Elizabeth and daughter Catherine Eli zabeth. Loving grandfather of Caitlin Elizabeth, Mary Kathleen and Robert Michael. Director of Economic Research at the Conference Board in New York City and former Chief of Center for Economic Studies at the U.S. Census Bureau. Friends may call at Jefferson Funeral Chapel, 5755 Castlewellan Drive, Alexandria, VA on Wednesday, March 15 from 7-9 PM where funeral service will be held on Thursday at 12:30 PM. Private family burial will follow. The family will observe Shiva from Friday March 17 until Thursday March 23. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name may be made to the American Economic Association Pipeline Project, (supporting underrepresented minorities pursuing graduate studies in economics), Vanderbilt University, 2014 Broadway, Ste 305, Nashville, TN 37203 or the Health Care Reform Research Program of the Center for American Progress, 1333 H. St, N.W., 10th flr, Washington, DC, 20005 or St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, www.stjude.org/tribute

title: Arts, Briefly; From Edinburgh
description: "Guardians," an award winner in the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last summer, will be presented at the Culture Project (45 Bleecker Street) next month. The play, to be directed by Jason Moore ("Avenue Q"), tells the story of a disgraced American soldier and an ambitious British journalist on a collision course over the publication of embarrassing photos. Performances are to begin April 1; Katherine Moennig and Lee Pace will star. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Hamburg exits UEFA Cup
Four-Leaf Clovers Are Different, Aren't They?
description: THE standard greeting among Irish-Americans begins: Where are your people from? The question represents less a challenge to one's Irish credentials and more a quest for that singular moment of commonality, when oceans and decades shrink to reveal an ancient bond so moving it nearly escapes articulation.

title: Mob Boss Takes Hit; Housewife Implicated
description: In the last two years, Tony Soprano managed to restore his marriage, his sister Janice had a baby, and his Uncle Junior lost his marbles. As for the HBO drama "The Sopranos," it seems to have lost a bit itself -- in terms of viewers who tuned in to Sunday's season premiere, that is.

description: MOFFO SARNOFF - Anna. We mourn the passing of our dear friend Anna Moffo Sarnoff, daughter-in-law of beloved Women's Division leader Lizette H. Sarnoff, in whose memory the Lizette H. Sarnoff Award for Volunteer Service was created. Anna Moffo received the National Women's Division's Spirit of Achievement Award in 1967. We extend our deepest sympathy to her entire family. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University National Women's Division Linda Altman National President Judy R. Rosenberg Chairwoman Executive Committee Janet Hershaft, President New York Chapter

title: Italy Makes Its Choices of Antiquities to Lend Met
description: MILAN, March 14 - Acting on an accord reached last month, the Italian government is offering to lend the Metropolitan Museum of Art an array of artifacts recovered from graves in the ancient region of Etruria, in west-central Italy, to reciprocate for the Met's return of objects that Italy claims were illegally excavated from its soil.

title: Letter From Maastricht; An Art Fair Where Wealth Is on Display With the Rembrandts
description: Maastricht is perhaps best known for the 1992 treaty signed within its precincts, bearing its name and setting the course for modern European political integration. That's enough to keep almost anybody away. But for 10 days each year, this well-scrubbed southern Dutch city of 130,000 is one of the most glamorous and, on a per capita basis, wealthiest places on earth. This week, as they have every March since 1975, everybody who is anybody in the global art market is descending on Maastricht for the European Fine Art Fair, known as Tefaf, which is for art what the Cannes Film Festival is for film.

title: Ice Retreats in Arctic for 2nd Year; Some Fear Most of It Will Vanish
description: For the second year in a row, the cloak of sea ice on the Arctic Ocean failed to grow to its normal winter expanse, scientists said yesterday. The finding led some climate experts to predict a record expansion of open water this summer.

title: Knock, Knock. It's Indian Comfort Food.
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a project to teach Americans to sing the national anthem misstated the range between the song's lowest and highest notes. It is an octave and a fifth, not an octave and a half.

description: Correction Appended

title: Arts, Briefly
A Power Surge of Shostakovich for His 100th
description: The celebration of Mozart's 250th anniversary hasn't quite evaporated, but it is moving aside to let some light shine on Dmitri Shostakovich, whose centenary is in September. Valery Gergiev's complete symphony cycle at Avery Fisher Hall, which began with performances by his Kirov Orchestra of the Maryinsky Theater on Sunday afternoon and Monday evening, may prove to be the brightest achievement of that celebration. Such was the power he brought to these performances that even cobwebbed agitprop like the Symphony No. 2 ("To October") and the almost unbearably bombastic Symphony No. 7 sounded innovative and daring.

Cooke - Kennedy Funeral Home, W. 72nd St., NYC, Hodder and Sons Funeral Home, McLean Ave., Yonkers, NY and presently at Williams Funeral Home, Bx., NY. title: Leaping Over Hurdles and Words in Ireland
description: A Fine Place to Daydream Racehorses, Romance and the Irish By Bill Barich 223 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: INSIDE
description: Mike Wallace to Retire From CBS's '60 Minutes' As he nears his 88th birthday, Mike Wallace, who started his career at CBS in 1951 and swore he would never leave alive, has decided to step away from "60 Minutes," where he has been for 38 years. One of the inventors of the television interview, he has sat across from everyone from Yasir Arafat to Carol Burnett. While saying he would cut back three years ago, he kept up a brisk pace, saying, "I wouldn't know what else to do."

title: Israelis Seize 6 in Raid on Prison in the West Bank
description: JERICHO, West Bank, March 14 - With tanks, bulldozers and helicopters, Israeli military forces besieged a Palestinian prison here for 10 hours on Tuesday before seizing six Palestinian inmates. The men had been held for four years in an unusual arrangement that involved the United States and Britain.

title: Retail Sales Fell in February, but Not as Much as Expected
description: Retail sales fell sharply in February from a big spike the month before, the government reported yesterday, as the weather turned cooler, car sales dropped and gasoline prices eased.

title: A Cloudy Night for Stars, but Others Could Shine
description: "Oh, for a Mary Curtis-Verna," a friend of mine is fond of saying. His meaning: not every singer is a star, but some of the journeyman singers of yesteryear -- like Ms. Curtis-Verna, a capable soprano -- might stack up beautifully in comparison to some of the stars of today.

title: Facing Death, His I.Q. Low, Man Wins Rare About-Face
description: In an unusual about-face, a divided three-judge federal appeals panel has reversed its own unanimous decision in a capital case.

title: Oxfam Halts Operations at One of Its Offices in Indonesia as it Audits Funds
description: Oxfam, the international relief organization, has temporarily suspended its operations in Aceh Besar in Indonesia, the country hit hardest by the 2004 tsunami, after a routine internal audit uncovered financial irregularities there.

title: Seoul formally opens checkpoints
A ruse or poisoning? Medical mystery swirls around Milosevic
Mild Mexican in a Mirthful Setting
description: A COLLECTION of milagros, brightly colored cut aluminum decorations in a seemingly endless range of shapes, from hearts to cactuses, cover one wall at El Centro, a new Mexican spot on Ninth Avenue and 54th Street. Corona bottles have been repurposed as parts of the lighting fixtures and as salt and pepper shakers. Glossy and gaily colored Mexican tablecloth material is employed as upholstery. The effect is cheery if kitschy; it says less "this is a really authentic Mexican place" and more "this is a really fun place to drink margaritas."

title: U.S. to Vote No on a New U.N. Rights Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 14 - The United States will call for a General Assembly vote on the proposed Human Rights Council on Wednesday, and vote against it, a senior Bush administration official said Tuesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mamaroneck: Officer Pleads Guilty To Drug Charges
description: A former Mamaroneck police officer pleaded guilty yesterday to selling cocaine and trying to buy thousands of dollars' worth of stolen property. The officer, Frank Dellacamera, 39, was arrested in 2004 after a six-month sting operation by the district attorney's office. Prosecutors said that Mr. Dellacamera was recorded selling cocaine to an undercover officer in White Plains and trying to buy more than $5,000 in electronics equipment that he believed had been stolen. Mr. Dellacamera's case made headlines after the F.B.I. recorded reputed mob figures boasting in 2004 that the husband of the former district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, had tipped them off about the investigation into Mr. Dellacamera. Mr. Pirro denied the accusation. ANAHAD O'CONNOR (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Endorses Spitzer
description: One of New York's largest private-sector unions endorsed Attorney General Eliot Spitzer yesterday in his bid to become governor. The union, Local 32BJ S.E.I.U., praised Mr. Spitzer's efforts to obtain back pay for workers and strengthen oversight of corporations. Union officials said the executive board unanimously approved the endorsement. Local 32BJ represents 85,000 members, including more than 60,000 building workers in New York, union officials said.

title: A Southern Star Rises in the Lowcountry
description: CHARLESTON, S.C. - EATING well, very well, is nothing new in the marshy, island-rimmed Lowcountry of South Carolina. The complex and amply documented culinary traditions of this elegant peninsular city and its hinterland stretch back into Colonial times.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Pemex Suspects Big Oil Find
description: Petrleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state-owned oil company, known as Pemex, is drilling an exploratory well in the Gulf of Mexico that might lead to the discovery of as much as 10 billion barrels of petroleum, according to the chief executive, Luis Ramrez. Pemex began drilling in December at a location 60 miles from the port city of Coatzacoalcos, Mr. Ramrez said.

Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa and told jurors that the two retired New York detectives had served as killers for the mob, murdering at least two men and kidnapping another on its behalf.

description: Stocks rallied to their highest levels since 2001 yesterday as bond yields tumbled and Goldman Sachs reported a quarterly profit that was much higher than expected.

title: Japan Puts U.S. Team on the Brink

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9:30 P.M. (5) THE LOOP -- Series premiere. A fun-loving recent college graduate, Sam (Bret Harrison), has become an airline executive in Chicago. He's constantly torn between his dronelike office existence and the party-all-the-time attitude of his roommates. And he's in unrequited love with one roommate, Piper (Amanda Loncar, above, with Mr. Harrison), a Catherine Zeta-Jones look-alike. This new sitcom likes to introduce its characters with on-screen descriptions. Mimi Rogers, for instance, who plays Meryl, a work colleague, is identified as "Predator." The explanation for Sam's rowdy brother, Sully (Eric Christian Olsen), is "Mom smoked grass during pregnancy."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARHART, WENDY
description: CARHART--Wendy. Died on Monday, March 13, at home in New York. Beloved daughter of Lucile and Amory S. Carhart, she is survived by her brother Amory Jr., her aunt Nancy H. Biddle and many cousins. A love of animals marked her life and she served for many years on the board of the ASPCA. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the ASPCA.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: U.S. Warns Of Reprisal In Threat To Curb Flights
description: If President Hugo Chvez's government goes through with plans to suspend flights by American carriers, the United States will retaliate with a similar ban, the American ambassador in Venezuela, William Brownfield, said. Venezuela's civil aviation authority said last month that it planned to end flights by Delta and Continental and reduce those by American Airlines unless the Federal Aviation Administration lifted years-old safety restrictions on Venezuelan airliners that serve American airports. The restrictions on American flights are to go into effect at the end of the month. "Hopefully that will not happen," Mr. Brownfield said, "because if that happens, it is not only possible or probable but an absolute certainty the U.S. government and Transportation Department would suspend flights by Venezuelan airlines."

title: A Composer Bypasses the Narrative for a Philosophical Vision of Faust
description: LYON, France, March 10 - Endlessly revisited over the last five centuries, the legend of Faust and his pact with the Devil may not seem like a highly original subject for Pascal Dusapin's new opera, "Faustus, the Last Night." Indeed, in the 19th century alone, Faust inspired operas by Louis Spohr, Hector Berlioz, Charles-Franois Gounod and Arrigo Boito.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Feb. 11 about the federal investigation of Anthony Pellicano, a former Hollywood private detective, referred incorrectly to computer data seized in a raid on his office in 2002. (The error also occurred in articles on Feb. 6 this year and on Oct. 19, 2005.) Investigators said they had recovered storage devices with a capacity of 3.868 terabytes of data, which they said would be the equivalent of two billion pages of double-spaced text. They did not find two billion pages of notes and wiretap transcripts.

title: A Cultural Touchstone Connecting Europe and Islam
