description: THESE restaurants are among the best in the Charleston area:

title: Secret Avian Flu Archive
description: At a time when health authorities are racing to head off a possible avian flu pandemic, it is distressing to learn that the World Health Organization is operating a secret database that holds the virus's genetic information. A lone Italian scientist has challenged the system by refusing to send her own data to the password-protected archive. Instead, she released the information publicly and urged her colleagues to do the same. She is surely right. The limited-access archive should be opened or bypassed immediately to encourage research on this looming health menace.

title: Text on Iran's Nuclear Work Is Under Study by U.N. Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 14 - Security Council members got their first look at a proposed statement on Iran's nuclear program on Tuesday, but the session failed to settle key differences, and more meetings were scheduled for Thursday and Friday.

title: Andrall E. Pearson, 80, Pepsi Executive Who Led a Spinoff, Is Dead
description: Andrall Edwin Pearson, a former president of PepsiCo who as an adviser after leaving the company helped engineer the spinoff of Pepsi's fast-food businesses -- KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut -- died on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, BERNARD
description: GREENBAUM--Bernard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bernard Greenbaum, associated with The Times from October 1957 until retiring in February 1988.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Lobbying Commission Chairman To Step Down
description: The acting chairman of the state lobbying commission, Patrick J. Bulgaro, said yesterday that he planned to step down as chairman this week and would nominate Paul L. Shectman, who was appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki, to replace him. The move is unusual because Mr. Bulgaro was appointed by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, who is often at odds with the governor, and would have Pataki appointees as both chairman and co-chairman. But Mr. Bulgaro said he believed that giving the governor more control of the commission would increase the chances that the governor would push to reform the state's lobbying laws, including a ban on gifts from lobbyists, which the governor called for last year. MICHAEL COOPER (NYT)

title: Hussein Testimony Prompts Closure of Court to Public
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 15 - Saddam Hussein took the witness stand today for his first formal testimony in his trial, and delivered an incendiary political diatribe that urged Iraqis to cease the sectarian bloodshed and carry on the war against the Americans. The presiding judge closed the session after Mr. Hussein, wearing thick reading glasses, kept on lambasting the court.

title: As Contract Talks Start, Building Workers Focus on Health Care Costs
description: As contract talks started yesterday, the president of the union representing 28,000 doormen, elevator operators and other service workers at 3,500 New York apartment buildings predicted that negotiations would be especially tough this year.

title: U.S. security strategy singles out Iran
Dubai company will sell its U.S. port operations
TechBrief: EBay to expand staff at Dublin headquarters
Islanders Continue Mastery of the Devils With a Rout
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 14 - The regular season drags on for five more weeks, and the only bad thing for the Islanders is that not one of their last 18 games will be against the Devils -- one opponent they can shove around.

title: Working It Out
description: Cambridge, Mass. - HIGHLY educated women are getting a bum rap from the press. There has recently been a spate of news and opinion articles telling us that these women, especially graduates of the best universities and professional schools, are "opting out" in record numbers, choosing the comforts of home and family over careers.

title: Large Oil Spill in Alaska Went Undetected for Days
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 - The largest oil spill to occur on the tundra of Alaska's North Slope has deposited up to 267,000 gallons of thick crude oil over two acres in the sprawling Prudhoe Bay production facilities, forcing cleanup crews to work in temperatures far below zero to vacuum and dig up the thick mixture of snow and oil.

title: Rangers' Slide Hits Six Games
description: RALEIGH, N.C., March 14 - For most of this season, the Rangers have exceeded expectations. But lately they have resembled the team almost everyone predicted they would be.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about media companies that pay to use videos and other material created by their audiences misstated the amount paid for each piece of work by the cable channel Current TV. Since January, the amount has ranged from $500 to $1,000, not $250 to $1,000.

title: Factory Owner Fights an Annex for Overcrowded Clifton High
description: CLIFTON, N.J. - IN the steely light of 6 a.m., Peter Movillo drives toward his daily destiny, the most unlikely traffic jam in town. He has been awake for an hour already, showering and dressing for his classes at Clifton High School. He urges his wheezy Integra into the student parking lot, ostensibly a privilege given seniors with top grades, but more like proof of the aphorism that no good deed goes unpunished. By 6:15, nearly an hour before first bell, all the spots will be taken, Peter knows from experience. If he gazes down the rows of cars, he will see classmates napping, doing homework, chewing breakfast bars, applying makeup in rear-view mirrors.

title: Improvisation Runs in the Family
description: Correction Appended

title: She Has a Prize, and Carp Are Breathing Easier
description: Correction Appended

title: For 6 Who Serve the Public, Time for Some Public Recognition
description: The professor had a lead for the job hunter with the brand-new master's degree who was frustrated that she had not landed anything: "Call my friend Gene."

title: Bourse sets new rulesin Italy
Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Saturday with an article about an exhibition at the New York Public Library that chronicles the Holocaust experiences of Sala Garncarz Kirschner, a Jewish woman from western Poland, misstated the given name of a granddaughter who was shown with her at the library. She is Gabrielle Kirschner, not Abby.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Ground Broken On Development Project
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the Bronx borough president, Adolfo Carrin Jr., broke ground yesterday for a 170,000-square-foot, two-story retail and office center in Melrose. Scheduled for completion in 2008, the $56.7 million project is expected to create 225 permanent jobs, house a new Department of Finance office as well as Staples, Rite Aid and other stores, and include a renovated four-story parking garage that has been vacant for years. The city's Economic Development Corporation arranged the sale of the city-owned land for $1 million to the developer, the Related Companies, and provided a $4 million low-interest loan, while the city's Industrial Development Agency provided $1.8 million in real estate and tax benefits for the project, which is supposed to help revitalize the South Bronx. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: Union Chief Will Seek New Vote on Rejected Transit Contract
description: The president of the transit workers' union, Roger Toussaint, made a surprise announcement last night that he would seek to submit the union's rejected contract to a new vote by the city's 33,700 subway and bus drivers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASTLE, ROBERT D. (BOB)
description: CASTLE--Robert D. (Bob). Age 69, died March 8, 2006. Treasured husband of Joan, brother, uncle and friend. Memorial service Saturday, March 18, 2006 at noon at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street.

title: NASA Delays Shuttle Flight by Six Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  Additional space shuttle flights will be delayed from May until July, at the earliest, to replace faulty fuel tank sensors, a NASA official said Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review of Blaue Gans last Wednesday referred incorrectly to kohlrabi, an ingredient in one dish. It is a stem, not a root.

title: Slices of a Southern Summer
description: NEW ORLEANS - JOANN CLEVENGER believes the idea to top fried green tomatoes, a Southern classic, with shrimp rmoulade, a Creole standard, came to her in a dream.

title: Milosevic burial set for his Serbian hometown
Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSELL, WENDY VANDER POEL
description: RUSSELL -- Wendy Vander Poel. The trustees, faculty and staff of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory are deeply saddened at the passing of Wendy Vander Poel Russell. Mrs. Russell was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Laboratory since 1984, serving as Secretary from 1985-87 and 1992-97 and thereafter as an Honorary Trustee. Her grace, leadership and irrepressible enthusiasm were valued by everyone at Cold Spring Harbor. She will be greatly missed. To her daughters, family and many friends, we express our deepest sympathy. Eduardo Mestre, Chairman Bruce Stillman, President James D. Watson, Chancellor W. Dillaway Ayres, Chief Operating Officer

title: EU court cuts fines of 2 in vitamin cartel by 20%
A Troubling Finance Tool for Companies in Trouble
description: When a company goes the route of PIPE's, you can bet that it is in trouble, unable to raise funds through conventional routes. But such companies can often raise millions of dollars, thereby postponing disaster.

title: Cramer Celebrates Himself
description: We at DealBook usually enjoy James. C. Cramers insight on stocks, and we have almost come to accept  or at least overlook  his chair-hurling and other histrionics. Tuesday night, however, even we were surprised by the antics on his Mad Money one-year anniversary program on CNBC, an hour-long celebration that made Mr. Cramer seem even more of a caricature of himself (if that was possible).

title: Personal Shopper
description: Cluttered closets and tangled hangers are a perennial problem. Help is on the way with new hangers designed to hold onto their charges.

title: Currents
description: A Times Square hotel embraces the dark side, walls that speak satire, an exhibition of streamlined design and the return of two Fishs Eddys.

title: Bank Mergers Payout Plan Questioned
description: The compensation adviser behind an estimated $135 million payout to the chief executive of North Fork Bancorporation has also received fees for other services from the bank in recent years, according to regulatory filings.

title: Overstock.com Squeezes Short Sellers With Mysterious Stock Rise
description: Short sellers have been the bane of Patrick Byrne, the outspoken CEO of online discounter Overstock.com. Now, with his companys stock notching huge but mysterious gains this week, he is enjoying a bit of revenge as bearish investors run for cover.

title: Icahn Hedge Funds Take Aim at Micron-Lexar Deal
description: Investors, including Carl Icahn-controlled hedge funds, are trying to break up Micron Technologys $680 million deal to acquire chip maker Lexar Media in hopes of putting a bigger price tag on the company.

title: Bush Official Calls Reviews for Deals Adequate
description: The Bush administration pushed back Tuesday against Republican lawmakers plans to change the review process for foreign acquisitions, saying national security was already the top concern of the committee that approved  Dubai Ports World s aborted takeover of several port terminals in the United States.

title: British Watchdog Clears Deutsche Borse for London Bid
description: British competition regulators have cleared the way for the Deutsche Borse to buy the London Stock Exchange after the German company agreed to measures to ensure the independence of the L.S.E.s clearing provider.

title: Alinta May Take Deal Directly to Australian Gas Light Shareholders
description: Alinta , Western Australias biggest natural gas retailer, says it may make a direct offer to shareholders of Australian Gas Light  and bypass directors who rejected a proposed A$8.9 billion ($6.6 billion) takeover.

title: Has Dell Acquired Alienware?
description: Dell has moved to quash rumors that suggested the company had acquired rival PC vendor Alienware. Speculation about a possible buyout has been rife since Rahul Sood, chief executive of Voodoo PC, an American computer supplier, posted his thoughts on such a move on his blog.

title: CVS Executives Leave Amid Accounting Inquiry
description: CVS, the drugstore chain, says that its chief controller and its treasurer have left the company, following an internal investigation that turned up accounting errors made in 2000.

title: Wal-Mart and Tesco Consider Carrefours South Korean Outlets
description: Wal-Mart Stores and Tesco of Britain may bid for the South Korean outlets of Carrefour of France, company officials said on Wednesday, amid signs of a consolidation in the countrys $120 billion retail sector.Carrefour, the worlds second-largest retailer after Wal-Mart, may offload some of its South Korean outlets, although the sale process has yet to be kicked off, an official at its public relations agency in Seoul said.

title: Jones Apparel Is Said to Be Lead Bidder for Kate Spade
description: Bidding is heating up for Kate Spade and Laura Mercier, two brands that have been put up for sale by their majority owner, the Neiman Marcus Group, The New York Post said.

title: KKR Seen as Leading $13 Billion GMAC Bid
description: Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts is leading a group that has reportedly made an offer of as much as $13 billion to buy a majority stake in the financing arm of General Motors.

title: A Trend for Public REITs: Going Private
description: Since 2004, 12 real estate investment trusts, or REITs, representing all commercial property sectors  office, industrial, retail, hotels and apartments  have been acquired by private companies, and two other buyout offers are pending, both involving the Blackstone Group, a private equity firm in New York.

title: Danish Drug Developer Raises $48 Million
description: Santaris Pharma , a Copenhagen-based biopharmaceutical drug developer focused on the treatment of cancer, has secured 40 million euros ($48.1 million) of Series B funding to further its clinical and preclinical development efforts.

title: New Global Telecom Is Reborn as a VOIP With VC Cash
description: New Global Telecom , once a voice-services provider that succumbed to bankruptcy during the telecom bust a few years ago, has raised a $10.75 million Series A round in its new life as a voice-over IP company.

title: The House of Morgan Is Also Your House
description: First-time visitors to Wall Street often stand in front of No. 23, the once-fabled House of Morgan, and stare up at the tall, cramped columns of the New York Stock Exchange across the way, or down the six blocks to the East River, turning over in their minds the vastness of the fortunes made and lost in that short stretch of real estate.

title: Unisys Sells Stake in Japanese Arm
description: Unisys said Tuesday that it planned to sell its 28 percent stake in Nihon Unisys of Japan, for $350 million. The divestiture is part of Unisys plan to reduce costs in the wake of a difficult fiscal 2005.

title: Murdoch Sounds the Death Knell for Media Barons
description: News Corporation chief Rupert Murdoch has warned that power is tilting away from traditional media as consumers flock to the Internet, posing a serious threat to existing business models.

title: British Publisher Considers Newspaper Sale
description: Daily Mail publisher DMGT is considering of a sale of its southeastern local newspapers, which are part of Northcliffe, the regional newspaper group it failed to sell at the end of last year.

title: Oil Executives: Mergers Arent to Blame for High Gas Prices
description: Exxon Mobil Corp. Chairman Rex Tillerson and ConocoPhillips Chairman James Mulva on Tuesday rejected complaints by lawmakers that mergers are boosting oil, natural gas or gasoline prices.

title: Carlyle Is Said to Be Planning Japanese Wireless Firm I.P.O.
description: Japanese wireless service operator Willcom, owned by the  Carlyle Group and the Japanese electronics maker Kyocera, is expected to soon start choosing book-runners for its public share offering planned as early as next year.

title: Cairn Energy to Float on Mumbai Exchange
description: Europes largest independent oil company, Cairn Energy, said it will float up to 80 percent of its business on the Mumbai stock exchange and return the proceeds to shareholders.

title: Rosneft Plans Mammoth I.P.O. in Fall
description: Rosneft, Russias state-owned oil company, is preparing what may be the worlds biggest-ever share offering as early as October. The company, which pumps more oil than Algeria, may offer as much as $20 billion of stock on domestic and foreign markets.

title: Trump on (Who Else?) Trump
description: Billionaire investor/TV personality/multitasker Donald Trump and other noted rich people will share their moneymaking secrets at a mammoth two-day real estate conference later this month in San Francisco.

title: Skype Backers Get Behind AllPeers
description: The venture capitalists behind Skype are placing a new bet on AllPeers, a start-up based in Oxford, England.

title: Hedge Fund Regulators Diverge: More Access or Tighter Oversight?
description: Regulators around the world are taking diverging approaches to hedge funds, with some  such as those in Hong Kong and the United Kingdom  considering making these investment pools more accessible to consumers, while others pushing for tighter oversight.

title: Ex-Enron Officer Says He Warned of Shady Partnerships
description: A former Enron managing director who evaluated risk for the company testified on Tuesday that he strenuously objected to the formation of off-balance-sheet partnerships directed by Andrew S. Fastow and urged the company to come clean about the risks they posed.

title: S.E.C. Chief Calls for Re-Examination of Exchange Regulation
description: The rapidly changing landscape of the markets, with big stock exchanges transforming into for-profit businesses, means that regulators must reexamine the system of U.S. exchanges self-regulation, the governments top securities regulator said yesterday.

title: Whos Afraid of Banking at Wal-Mart?
description: Wal-Mart, again and again, over the last few years, has tried to open a bank. And based on everything we know about the company, a Wal-Mart bank would almost certainly make life difficult for the Citigroups of the world and bring down A.T.M. fees.

title: Tchenguiz in Talks With Apax on U.K. Pubs Bid
description: Robert Tchenguiz is seeking to beef up the funding for his mooted 4 billion-pound-plus bid for Mitchells & Butlers (M&B), the pub and restaurant operator, by joining forces with Apax Partners, The Times of London reported. Mr Tchenguizs R20 investment vehicle has held detailed talks to persuade the private equity firm to join a consortium that is already believed to include HBOS, Goldman Sachs and Royal Bank of Scotland.

title: Parsons Backtracks on Warner Music Remarks
description: Time Warners chief executive, Richard Parsons tried yesterday to smooth Edgar J. Bronfmans ruffled feathers after he made disparaging comments about Warner Music in a New Yorker article.

title: Hedge Fund Hires Former Clinton Adviser
description: Sandy Berger, a former national security adviser to under President Clinton, is poised to join hedge fund DB Zwirn as a special adviser. DB Zwirn is thought to have hired Mr. Berger to gain access to his network of business and government contacts as it eyes new investment opportunities.

title: BET Founder Buys Bank to Create Firm Aimed at Blacks
description: Robert L. Johnson, the founder and former chief executive of Black Entertainment Television, has acquired a tiny Florida savings and loan and plans to move it to Washington to use as the springboard for a large consumer financial services company aimed at black customers.

title: Electrical Retailer Kesa Rejects Private Equity Bid
description: Kesa Electricals, which owns the electrical retailer Comet has rejected a 1.7 billion pound bid, setting off a wave of speculation that buyers could be waiting in the wings for other British high-street stalwarts.

title: U.S. Scales Back Demands for Google Data
description: After the Justice Department drastically reduced its request for information from Google, a federal judge said on Tuesday that he intended to approve at least part of that request.

title: U.S. Investigates Pension Fund at Northwest Air
description: The Labor Department is investigating whether Northwest Airlines systematically shortchanged its employee pension fund over three years, then avoided having to make a $65 million payment to the fund by filing for bankruptcy protection just one day before the payment was due.

title: A Troubling Finance Tool for Companies in Trouble
description: When a company goes the route of PIPEs, you can bet that it is in trouble, unable to raise funds through conventional routes. But such companies can often raise millions of dollars, thereby postponing disaster.

title: Dow Jones Settles With Cantor Fitzgerald
description: Dow Jones & Co. said Tuesday it agreed to pay $202 million to settle litigation with Market Data Corp. and Cantor Fitzgerald Securities over a contract guarantee it had issued to those companies in 1995.

title: U.S. Ends Inquiries, Clear Channel Says
description: Clear Channel Communications, the nations largest radio station owner, said on Tuesday that the Justice Department had closed two antitrust investigations into its broadcast and concert business without taking action.

title: Federated Settles With Spitzer on Ad Sales
description: Federated Department Stores , the parent of Macys and other chains, agreed to pay $725,000 to resolve an investigation by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, into misleading advertising practices and phony sales promotions.

title: Refco Held $525 Million in Fake Bonds
description: Refco held offshore accounts with as much as $525 million in fake bonds, indicating the futures brokers troubles may be more extensive than previously reported, according to four people with direct knowledge of evidence gathered by federal prosecutors investigating Refcos collapse.

title: Italian Stock Exchange Unveils New Rules
description: The Italian stock exchange, seeking to reassure investors after a run of scandals that culminated in the spectacular collapse of the food group Parmalat two years ago, introduced a new disciplinary code on Tuesday aimed at strengthening corporate governance among listed companies.

title: As Howard Stern Ranted, David Letterman Debated
description: It was not surprising that Howard Stern wore a T-shirt that said I Hate Les Moonves for his interview with David Letterman on CBS on Monday night. His language, by shock-radio standards, was quite mild: he merely described the chief executive of CBS and his former boss as the biggest jerk on the planet. (On Fox News, he used one of his favorite expressions on Mr. Moonves: pig vomit.)

title: What's Hot
description: Style phenomenas from the Paris fashion shows.

title: Close Fits
description: Makers of athletic clothing say their new "compression apparel" can give you more energy.

title: IRS Official Wants More Light On Corporate Tax Returns
description: Lawmakers should consider making corporate tax returns public to encourage businesses to follow tax laws, IRS Commissioner Mark Everson said Tuesday.

title: Living in the Store
description: The apartment-atelier of Dimonah and Mehmet Iksel  showcases their wall panels, Iranian carpets and mix of furniture.

title: FEMA Trailers, Vital but Vulnerable
description: Nearly 90,000 lightweight trailers house victims of Hurricane Katrina in an area prone to flooding, tornadoes and, of course, hurricanes.

title: Morris: Bush Lacks a Daily Majority
Deal Chatter Lifts Shares of U.K.s Hanson
description: Shares of construction materials company Hanson touched an all-time high on the London Stock Exchange on Wednesday amid speculation that the company may sell its United States business or that French rival Lafarge might bid for the company.

title: Job of the Day: Condo Ombudsman
description: Yep, condominium ombudsman is a state office in Florida (Nevada, too). It deals with the many disputes, mostly financial, involving condominium boards.
Selborne Journal: 15 March 1759:  One of the Cucumber-plants has a Male-bloom fully expanded. The weather very wet, & stormy. Sowed the Celeri Hand-glass.

title: As Former Apple Executives Seek Deals, Road Show Raises Questions
description: Three former Apple Computer executives, including former chief Gilbert Amelio and co-founder Steve Wozniak, have raised $150 million for company whose sole purpose is to search for technology-related acquisitions.

title: Lehman Profit Tops Forecasts (But Unlike Goldman, No Gasps)
description: Lehman Brothers reported record quarterly profit and revenue in the fiscal first quarter, exceeding most analysts expectations for the bulge-bracket investment firm. But coming after out-of-the-ballpark earnings results from Goldman Sachs on Tuesday, which left some analysts at a loss for words, Lehmans upbeat numbers couldnt help looking a bit, well, anticlimactic.

title: Salon: Why Were Publishing Every Abu Ghraib Photo
description: The Abu Ghraib box set: Salon publishes what it calls an annotated archive of the Abu Ghraib scandal, the complete collection of the 279 photos and 19 videos of Abu Ghraib abuse first gathered by the Armys Criminal Investigative Command investigation.

title: First Google, Now Andrx: Cant Anyone Keep a Secret?
description: Andrx must be reading the same investor relations manual as Google.

title: Whats Good For General Motors Is Another GMAC Bid
description: Shares of General Motors  ticked up as much as 2.8 percent early Wednesday on a report that a group led by the private equity firm Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts had offered $12.5 billion to $13 billion for a majority stake in its financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.

title: Next in Spitzers Sights: H&R Block
description: He has already shaken up the investment banking and insurance industries with his investigations. And as of Wednesday, the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, has a new target: H&R Block, the largest tax-preparation company in the United States.

title: Dubai Ports Fuzzy Transfer Becomes Full-Fledged Sale
description: Clearing up lingering doubts about what exactly would become of the port operations it controls in the United States, Dubai Ports World said Wednesday it would sell the assets outright.

title: New Frontiers
description: Two recently reported items caught my eye. Actually, they caught a friends eye, and thanks to his thorough reading habits and Internet vigilance, I can share them here.

title: Big Foot Lives!
description: Monster platforms and wedges make the world your stomping ground.

title: Was Leak of GMAC Bid a Pressure Tactic?
description: Wednesdays report of a bid of as much as $13 billion for General Motors Acceptance Corporation may have been part of a strategy to apply pressure to the other interested party, a group led by Cerberus Capital Management.

title: Tour du Jour?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Ahead of Huge I.P.O., Morgan Stanley Banker Headed for Rosneft
description: Peter OBrien, a senior investment banker at Morgan Stanley in Moscow, is reportedly planning to join Russian state-owned oil company Rosneft as chief financial officer.

title: Real Estate Market Getting Soft? George Soros Son Hopes Not
description: Jonathan Soros, the son of George Soros, is trying his hand at market timing. But unlike his financier father, Jonathan is apparently trying to time the real estate market.

title: From O to AAA:  Hearst Takes  Stake in Fitch
description: Hearst, whose vast media holdings include O: The Oprah Magazine, is taking a small step into the credit-rating business.

title: U.S. to Dubai: Drop Dead
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans March 15 column, Dubai and Dunces

title: Newark '06: The Race for Mayor
description: The Times's Damien Cave analyzes the upcoming race for the mayor of Newark. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: Report Backs Iraq Strike
description: The Times's David E. Sanger discusses an updated draft of the Bush administration's national security strategy which identifies Iran as the greatest future challenge to the U.S.

title: The Line-Item Veto Folly
description: On March 6, President Bush sent legislation to Congress that would give him line-item veto authority. He argues that much low-priority spending gets tucked into spending bills and he is largely powerless to stop it because the president can only veto entire bills, not just individual provisions. Like many presidents before him, such as Ulysses S. Grant, Mr. Bush wants the power to veto specific spending projects without having to veto an entire appropriations bill.

title: Darfur Orphans
description: Mike Simon, the NBC cameraman who accompanied Ann Curry on our collective trip to Darfur, has posted a moving blog about what he saw on our trip. Its always irritating when these camera people turn out to be wonderful writers as well. Heres Mike Simons blog.

title: The Combat Artist
description: Im going to make an assumption that you would probably like to ask me three questions: What does war have to do with art? What is a combat artist? And why would the United States Marine Corps, of all organizations, send fine artists into harms way? Ill try to answer these as best I can over the next couple weeks. At the same time I hope to provide a glimpse of who I am, both as artist and marine.

title: Stalled Talks Are More Bad News for Pataki
description: ALBANY, March 15 - When talks on how to rebuild the World Trade Center site foundered Tuesday night without an agreement, it was more bad news for Gov. George E. Pataki. The governor has made the rebuilding of the site a legacy issue, only to see construction there stymied by delay after delay as his final term in office winds down.

title: Portrait of Artist as Impresario, and Other Premieres
description: Not that Benjamin Millepied, 27, a principal with New York City Ballet, is necessarily near retirement. But he seems to be a restlessly curious artist, and Tuesday night he put himself before the public as dancer, choreographer and impresario in a generous program consisting of four world premieres. The run of his Benjamin Millepied & Company continues at the Joyce Theater through Sunday.

title: A Doctor? He Is One on TV
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. - JUST before her tummy tuck last week, Dorie Valdez lay on a gurney in a surgical suite watching her plastic surgeon, Dr. Roberto M. Rey Jr., teach a nurse to use nunchucks. Dr. Rey spun the weapon in the air, flicked it at an imaginary opponent and deftly tucked it under his armpit.

title: Unsolicited Bid Is Expected for Vodafone Unit in Japan
description: A group of private equity firms is planning to make an unsolicited $15 billion cash bid for the Japanese subsidiary of Vodafone, in what could become the largest buyout in Asia, people involved with the offer said last night.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the ideological debate over socialism and capitalism at the current session of China's legislature gave an incorrect university affiliation in some copies for Mao Shoulong, a public policy specialist who was quoted discussing the erosion of a consensus about ideology. He is with People's University in Beijing, not Tsinghua University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICE, CHRISTINE C. (NEE CARROLL)
description: RICE--Christine C. (nee Carroll) of Garden City, NY on March 15, 2006. Beloved wife of 52 years of Laurence J. Rice. Loving mother of Laurence, Louis, Timothy, Paul, Mary Ann, Ellen, Kathleen, Christine, Elizabeth and Sheila. Adored grandmother of Kevin, Brian, Denis, Paul, Ellen, Julia, Mary, William and David. Cherished sister-in-law of Maura Murphy, Charles E. Rice and the late James B. Rice. Loving mother-in-law of Cheryl, Jana, Sheila, Owen and Michael. Daughter of the late Walter F. and Mary Carroll. Proud graduate of the College of Mount St. Vincent (1949). The family will receive friends at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, NY Thursday 7-9 p.m., Friday 2-4 p.m. and 7-9 p.m. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:45a.m. at St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Franklin Avenue, Garden City, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Alzheimer's Association, Long Island Chapter, 3281 Veterans Memorial Hwy, Suite E-13, Ronkonkoma, NY 11779.

title: Small Group of Loyalists, Mostly Old, Mourn Milosevic
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, March 16 A They were his deepest loyalists, only 1,000 or so strong, most of them old and quietly angry. "He killed no one," said Jugoslava Lekic, 73, named for the nation that she believes Slobodan Milosevic died trying to save.

title: 3 killed as protests rage over gold mine
Israel and Palestinians Trade Angry Barbs on Prison Raid
description: JERUSALEM, March 15 - Israel and the Palestinians traded recriminations on Wednesday in the aftermath of an Israeli raid on a prison in Jericho, in the West Bank.

title: On Australia visit, Rice critical of China's military expansion
Kurds Turn Violent in Protest Against Their Leaders
description: HALABJA, Iraq, March 16 A For nearly two decades, Kurds have gathered peacefully in this mountainous corner of northern Iraq to commemorate one of the blackest days in their history. It was here that Saddam Hussein's government launched a poison gas attack that killed more than 5,000 people on March 16, 1988.

title: All About Andy
description: The testimony by Andrew Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, has certainly provided the dramatic high point thus far in the trial of the company's former top executives. But Mr. Fastow's testimony may have helped the defendants -- Kenneth Lay and Jeffrey Skilling -- as much as it helped the prosecutors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNARD, CHARLES W., III(CHICK)
description: BARNARD--Charles W., III(Chick) Retired Senior International Insurance Executive for American Foreign Insurance Association and Cigna, died March 11, 2006 at the age of 80. A native of Newburgh, he graduated from Storm King School and then served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during W.W. II. Chick graduated from Amherst College in 1949 and began his successful insurance career with his first posting in Calcutta, India. Later service with the company took him back and forth to a variety of positions in Japan and the United States. He retired in 1985 and settled in Cape Cod, moving to Jacksonville, FL in 2004. Chick was an avid tennis player and was active in alumni affairs for Amherst College. He was widely respected for his achievements and experience in the insurance industry. Chick is survived by his wife Margaret (nee Blue) "Brownie" Barnard, his sons Andrew (Sarah) of Dobbs Ferry, NY and Daniel of Boston, daughter Adrienne (Daniel) Dahlberg of Missoula, MT, two grandchildren Samantha Barnard and Benjamin Dahlberg. Another son, Stephen, died in 1979. Funeral service at 9:30 AM Monday, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry (Saw Mill Exit 17). Visiting Sunday 79PM. Those wishing to make a memorial contribution may donate to The National Parkinson's Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Ave., Miami, FL 33136.

title: Chinese dissident's asylum stay called unjustified
In Macabre Detail, Witness Tells of Murders for Mob by Detectives
description: The witness was a geriatric pot dealer who, along with smuggling drugs, had illicit fingers in everything from Burkina Faso diamonds to leisure suits.

title: Common Sense 1, Dubai Port Deal 0
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Flavor Flav Draws for VH1
description: "Flavor of Love," the VH1 reality show following the rapper Flavor Flav's search for a mate, concluded on Sunday night with the channel's highest ratings ever. Nielsen's numbers for the show grew significantly over its run, and for the finale, 5.88 million viewers watched Flav, above, pick Hoopz over a woman named New York; the winner was given a set of gold teeth. Tuesday's two-hour "American Idol" delivered an enormous audience estimated at 32.53 million, allowing Fox to run away with the night in every major demographic. But in adding "The Unit" (17.78 million) to its Tuesday schedule, CBS has found a good pairing with "NCIS" (17.61 million): military dramas stand up well against "Idol." But CBS's "Amazing Race" has not benefited from its move to 10 p.m. That long-running reality series, such a ratings success a year ago, is sinking. Tuesday's episode drew 9.59 million, and was beaten by a repeat of NBC's "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" in both total viewers (11.22 million) and the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

title: Act 2: Enter Happiness, Howling
description: Maplewood, N.J. - FUR is flying in the home of Christine Ebersole. One of the three cats, spooked by the three dogs, has had an "Exorcist" moment and has taken a vicious slash at Ms. Ebersole, who has run, in pajamas and robe, to the kitchen to ice her arm. From her howls, one fears the worst. But soon Ms. Ebersole, who talks a mile a minute and who uses the word darling often and with ironic inflection, is back.

title: INSIDE
description: Security Strategy Update Stands by Attack on Iraq An updated version of the Bush administration's national security strategy, the first in more than three years, gives no ground on the decision to order a pre-emptive attack on Iraq in 2003, and identifies Iran as the country likely to present the greatest challenge to the United States. A 48-page late draft of the update was released before a formal presentation today. PAGE A6

title: New York Settles With Woman Abused at 2000 Parade
description: New York City agreed today to pay $125,000 to a Wellesley graduate who sued the Police Department for failing to heed her calls for help when a mob of men doused her with water and beer, tried to strip off her pants and sexually molested her during the Puerto Rican Day Parade in June 2000.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Principals Declare An Impasse
description: The union representing public school principals and assistant principals, hoping for the intervention of a state mediator, declared yesterday that its contract talks with the city were at an impasse. Jill S. Levy, president of the union, the Council of School Supervisors and Administrators, said the main sticking points were salaries and the city's demands to limit certain seniority rights of assistant principals. Ms. Levy accused Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein of trying to drive a wedge between the city's 1,400 principals and 3,100 assistant principals. Jordan Barowitz, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, declined to comment on specifics. The union's contract expired on June 30, 2003. ELISSA GOOTMAN (NYT)

title: With an Assist to Freud, Marbury Says Brown Has 'Insecurities'
description: The building known as Madison Square Garden is not one space but two -- a hallowed arena attached to a less venerable theater. The Knicks, having proven themselves inept on the hardwood, might consider relocating to the stage next door. At the moment, they are far more compelling as a soap opera than as a basketball team.

title: Briefly: Senate increases limit on debt to $9 trillion
U.S. blasted for pushing Jakarta for court treaty
Common Sense 1, Dubai Port Deal 0
description: To the Editor:

title: In Epoch of Man, Earth Takes a Beating
description: Field Notes From a Catastrophe Man, Nature and Climate Change By Elizabeth Kolbert 210 pages. Bloomsbury. $22.95.

title: Belarus Arrests Dozens Days Before Disputed Election
description: MINSK, Belarus, March 16 A Days before a presidential election already seen as unfair, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko's administration has intensified the atmosphere of fear and tension, arresting dozens of campaign workers and other opponents. Today, the country's security chief warned that any opponents who gathered to protest the election's outcome could face criminal charges for terrorism.

title: Martnez and Floyd in Better Health
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 15 - Manager Willie Randolph likes to say his mood can be measured by how long Ray Ramirez, the head trainer, spends in his office every morning.

title: U.S. opens large-scale assault on Iraqi rebels
Union Is Pessimistic on a Deal To Avert a Shutdown at Delphi
description: DETROIT, March 15 - Leaders of the United Automobile Workers union, who met Wednesday in Detroit, said they doubted that a deal could be reached on an assistance plan for the Delphi Corporation before a deadline on March 31.

title: For Elderly, Antidepressants May Trump Psychotherapy
description: Antidepressants work better than psychotherapy in preventing relapses in elderly men and women who have recovered from depression, a new study suggests.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Co-Op City Security Goes On Strike
description: The private security force that patrols the Co-Op City housing development went on strike yesterday morning after failing to reach a contract agreement with the company that operates the complex. The entire 81-member Co-Op City Police Benevolent Association and 75 lobby attendants, who belong to the same union, walked out over differences about pension benefits and work rules, including a management proposal to reduce patrols, the union said. Representatives from the Riverbay Corporation and Marion Scott Realty, which manage Co-Op City, did not return calls seeking comment. TIMOTHY WILLIAMS (NYT)

title: Other Views: Daily Star, Sydney Morning Herald, Frankfurter Allgemeine
No end to Refco's problems
Millions in Yukos Debt Acquired
description: MOSCOW, March 15 - The Russian state oil company Rosneft has acquired $482 million in debt that the troubled oil company Yukos owed to Western banks, Yukos said Wednesday. The step raised the possibility that Rosneft might acquire Yukos's remaining assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNAMARA, PATRICIA M. (NEE DEL BALSO)
description: MCNAMARA -- Patricia M. (nee Del Balso) at home in Greenwich, CT. on March 13, 2006. Beloved wife for fiftyfour years of Daniel J. Loving mother of Joseph (Noreen), Daniel (Patricia), Patricia (Brien), Kelley and Jean (Gerard) Burke and devoted grandmother of thirteen. The family will receive friends at The Leo P. Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT on Friday, March 17 from 2-5 and 79 PM. A Funeral Mass will be said on Saturday, March 18 at 9:00 AM at St. Paul R.C. Church, 84 Sherwood Ave, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Patricia Del Balso McNamara Scholorship Fund at the College of Mt. St. Vincent, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Riverdale, NY 10471-1093.

title: Nuclear power for India is good for us all
Your TV Is HD, and Now Your Camera Can Be, Too
description: The L85 from Samsung, a retro-styled point-and-shoot model, is the first still camera to tap into the high-definition craze. It has a High-Definition Multimedia Interface (HDMI) port, allowing it to transfer data to high-definition TV's and other devices.

title: For Elderly, Antidepressants May Trump Psychotherapy
description: Antidepressants work better than psychotherapy in preventing relapses in elderly men and women who have recovered from depression, a new study suggests.

title: Schedule of Slobodan Milosevic's funeral
Schools Strike a Nerve. Parents Yell.
description: ANYONE who doubts the importance New Yorkers place on education -- singled out as their top priority in poll after poll -- should see the e-mail messages that poured in after last Thursday's column about the frustrations of parents trying to get their children into "gifted" programs on the Upper West Side.

title: Scientists Get Glimpse of First Moments After Beginning of Time
description: Using data from a new map of the baby universe, astronomers said today that they had seen deep into the big bang that allegedly started the universe and had got their first detailed hint of what was going on less than a trillionth of a second after time began.

title: Microsoft's new strategy takes the fight to IBM
Arts Center Has a Plan to Help Newark Revive
description: NEWARK, March 15 - For nearly 40 years, Newark has been trying to fight its way back from the riots of the 1960's and a generation in which people and businesses spilled out of the city to the suburbs on the highways that crisscross it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 8 about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's nationwide fund drive, which Democrats see as a suggestion that she is preparing a run for president in 2008, misspelled the surname of a venture capitalist who is one of her fund-raisers. He is Alan Patricof, not Patricoff. The article also misstated the title of another fund-raiser, Fred P. Hochberg. He is dean of a unit of the New School known as Milano the New School for Management and Urban Policy; the parent university does not itself have a dean.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) AMERICAN INVENTOR -- You can tell this new reality show is from Simon Cowell and the producers of "American Idol." Tonight's two-hour series premiere is all about the open casting calls. Instead of demonstrating their singing voices, contestants will show off their prized inventions in hopes of winning the $1 million prize. Some of the inventions (like Paul Dureus's "pillow ponytail headgear mask," above) are stranger than others.

title: Where All the Strings Are Strong, All the Horns Good-Looking
description: Garrison Keillor's evening with the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday went in several directions. A big crowd at Avery Fisher Hall was entertained by all of them.

title: Milosevic's Body Taken to Serbia; Funeral a Political Issue
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, March 15 - The body of Slobodan Milosevic was returned to Serbia on Wednesday, providing a test for a government loath to give its former president anything resembling a state funeral.

title: Trailers, Vital AfterStorm, Now Pose Risks
description: PORT SULPHUR, La., March 11 - In its rush to provide shelter for victims of Hurricane Katrina, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has created a pressing new Gulf Coast hazard: nearly 90,000 lightweight trailers in an area prone to flooding, tornadoes and, of course, hurricanes.

title: Dubai Firm Verifies Plan On U.S. Ports
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 - The Dubai-owned company that acquired several port terminals in major East Coast cities confirmed Wednesday that it would sell those operations to an unrelated American buyer, ending speculation about the ambiguity in its previous statements that it would "transfer" the terminals to a "U.S. entity."

title: Spitzer Sues H&R Block on I.R.A.'s
description: H&R Block, the nation's largest tax-preparation service, was accused yesterday of selling inappropriate savings plans to hundreds of thousands of income tax filers, in the latest attack on the company's push to offer other financial services.

title: Stay-at-Home Appliances With Looks Built for Speed
description: "The origin of streamlining trains, airplanes and automobiles, like the Alfa Romeo of 1914, was in Europe," said David A. Hanks, who, with Martin Eidelberg, curated "American Streamlined Design: The World of Tomorrow," opening today at the Bard Graduate Center in Manhattan. But products whose silhouettes suggested speed while masking function evolved in the United States, where curves added consumer appeal, Mr. Hanks said. The circa 1937 Airflow fan, top, designed by Robert Heller, evokes an airplane. A 1930's iron, above, also suggests speed. Through June 11; 18 West 86th Street. Information: www.bgc.bard.edu. ELAINE LOUIE CURRENTS: EXHIBITIONS

title: Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: Attack Ads on Cable TV Join School Financing Fight
description: ALBANY, March 15 - A state senator from Queens is facing something lawmakers here rarely have to contend with -- a negative television commercial. An education advocacy group is paying for an advertisement claiming that the Republican lawmaker, Serphin R. Maltese, "votes year after year to underfund our schools."

title: Rumsfeld's Blinkers
description: Some weeks nothing happens; some weeks change history. The week of March 24, 2003, was one of those pivotal weeks. U.S. troops had just begun the ground invasion of Iraq. They were charging north, but hadn't reached Baghdad. The Fedayeen had begun to launch suicide attacks and were putting up serious resistance in Nasiriya.

title: Corrections
description: For the Record

title: As U.S. Dissents, U.N. Approves a New Council on Rights Abuse
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 15 - With the United States in virtually lone opposition, the United Nations overwhelmingly approved a new Human Rights Council on Wednesday to replace the widely discredited Human Rights Commission.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Sentencing In Case Of Abandoned Girl
description: A Queens man who pleaded guilty to killing his companion and abandoning her 4-year-old daughter on a dark street last September was sentenced yesterday to at least 27 years in prison. The man, Cesar Ascarrunz, 32, a Bolivian doctor who worked as a porter, was given 25 years for first-degree manslaughter in the killing of Monica Lozada-Rivadineira, 26, in their Forest Hills apartment. He left her body in a garbage bag on the street and abandoned her daughter, Valery, above, on a street in Middle Village, prosecutors said. Mr. Ascarrunz was also sentenced to two to seven years in prison for reckless endangerment. Valery is staying with relatives while a judge determines custody. COREY KILGANNON (NYT)

title: Common Sense 1, Dubai Port Deal 0
description: To the Editor:

title: Charity Delays Tsunami Work as Audit Finds Irregularities
description: Oxfam International, the relief organization, said yesterday that it had temporarily suspended its operations in a district at the northwestern tip of Sumatra, in the Indonesian archipelago -- the region hardest hit by the tsunami in December 2004 -- after a routine internal audit uncovered financial irregularities there.

title: On Ireland's big day, missing the soul of it all
Robert C. Baker, Who Reshaped Chicken Dinner, Dies at 84
description: Robert C. Baker, an agricultural scientist who looked at chickens and envisioned chicken nuggets, not to mention chicken hotdogs, helping transform what is now a $29 billion poultry industry, died on Monday at his home in North Lansing, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Clinton Rival Admits Problems
description: K. T. McFarland, a Republican challenging Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton this year, said yesterday that she had "no excuses" for failing to vote in some recent New York elections. Her spokesman, Bill O'Reilly, said she would cancel her voter registration in the Hamptons, where she has a home, since she is already registered on the Upper East Side and state law forbids being registered in two places. He said that Ms. McFarland had never voted twice in the same election. Ms. McFarland's voting irregularities were reported yesterday in The New York Post. Republican allies of Ms. McFarland said they did not anticipate legal trouble, but said it was a political headache because she came across as an unprepared first-time candidate. PATRICK HEALY (NYT)

title: Bulky Refrigerators and Neo-Sconces
description: Q. I'm not a fan of bulky refrigerators. Do svelte versions exist?

title: A Harlem Pastorale For Walls That Speak Satire
description: "I've always loved toile fabrics," said Sheila Bridges, top, an interior designer in Manhattan whose projects have included the Harlem office of Bill Clinton. Her satirical spin on the classical toile de Jouy pastoral scene, wallpaper called "Harlem Toile de Jouy," above, presents "a distorted view of African-American life, of what people think when they think of Harlem, whether it's the boom box, the dancing, the men playing basketball, or the girls playing double Dutch," she said. It comes in deep yellow (custom colors are available); $178 for a five-yard roll, 27 inches wide, with a minimum of 10 rolls, from info@sheilabridges.com. ELAINE LOUIE CURRENTS: WALLPAPER

title: Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: Call for Censure Is Rallying Cry to Bush's Base
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 - Republicans, worried that their conservative base lacks motivation to turn out for the fall elections, have found a new rallying cry in the dreams of liberals about censuring or impeaching President Bush.

title: An economic miracle
Solid Reports From the Fed and Sears Push Shares Higher
description: Stocks rose yesterday after earnings from Sears Holdings exceeded estimates and a Federal Reserve survey showed steady economic growth.

title: Bill Cardoso, 68, Editor Who Coined 'Gonzo', Is Dead
description: Bill Cardoso, a writer and an editor who might have been lost in the haze of the hip, offbeat, drug-tinged world of 70's journalism had he not come up with the perfect word to describe Hunter S. Thompson's roller-coaster prose -- "gonzo" -- died on Feb. 26 at his home in Kelseyville, Calif. He was 68.

title: Professor at Columbia Retracts Papers Over Research Questions
description: A Columbia University chemistry professor has retracted two papers and part of a third published in a leading journal after experiments performed by a graduate student could not be reproduced.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: New Picture Of John Paul's Illnesses
description: A new book by Pope John Paul II's long-time personal doctor, Renato Buzzonetti, recounts years of medical problems confronted stoically and only with great reluctance. The Italian-language book, released in Italy this week, said that the pope had long ignored pain that turned out to be a large abdominal tumor removed in 1992 and had to be talked out of a trip to Sicily only a day after he slipped in the bath and broke a thigh bone. It also said that the pope exhibited symptoms of Parkinson's disease as early as 1991, though the Vatican did not acknowledge it until 2003. Called "Let Me Go," after a part of the pope's last words, the book also adds to the Vatican's already detailed account of John Paul's last days before dying last April.

title: Hundreds line up to view Milosevic's coffin
Capturing Caged Hens on Video Brings a Charge of Burglary
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARHART, WENDY
description: CARHART--Wendy. The staff of Doyle New York is profoundly saddened by the loss of our longtime friend and colleague, Wendy Carhart. We will miss Wendy's whimsical sense of humor, her professionalism, her generosity and her common sense. We extend our sincere sympathy to the Carhart family. Kathleen M. Doyle, Chairman

title: Senators going to China to voice trade concerns
People: Jack Black, George Clooney, John Ritter
A Candid Dutch Film May Be Too Scary for Immigrants
description: NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands, March 15 - This is not exactly a run-of-the-mill homework assignment: watch a film clip of an attractive woman sunbathing topless, and try not to be shocked.

title: Song's success finally returns home
China courts Kazakhstan as a secure supplier of oil
Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: Here's Help In Taming The Monster In the Closet
description: CLUTTERED closets and tangled hangers are a perennial problem for spring cleaners, even those with closets big enough to walk around in. Wire hangers get caught in each other's hooks, and clothes have a way of sliding off plastic hangers.

title: From Jail Cell, a Convict Challenges a Prosecutor
description: A decade ago, the paths of a prosecutor and a young drug abuser crossed in a murder conviction. It was an ordinary verdict at an extraordinary time, a redeeming victory for the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes.

title: Sleeping Your Way to a Fuller You
description: Medical researchers may have inadvertently discovered a perfect way to slow the indiscriminate use of sleeping pills in this country. Just warn all users that the most popular sleeping pill may cause some of them to eat while asleep and gain lots of unwanted pounds.

title: Combating a Suspicious Scourge on Staten Island
description: AH, springtime on Staten Island. Crocuses bursting forth, the clatter of construction equipment -- and the sweet scent of burning marsh grass in the air. This springtime, anyway. The island's desolate half-trashed wetlands have been hit with a string of unseasonable and therefore suspicious brush fires.

title: Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: Everything Is All Right, Up Tight
description: CAN clothes really give you more energy? Makers of athletic clothing say their new "compression apparel" can. Tights, shorts and tops made with bands of extra-thick stretchy fabric -- designed to hug key muscles like the glutes, the quads, the hamstrings and the calves -- are said to keep the muscles warm and well-supported and thus give them more power and endurance. But the scientific evidence is inconclusive.

title: EU seeks assurances from Russia on energy
Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a speech by President Bush in which he defended his policies on Iraq misstated the precedent for his assertion that America's enemies would emerge from Iraq either "emboldened or defeated." He used that phrase last August in a speech in Nampa, Idaho; this was not the first time he had discussed such a possibility.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about colleges and universities that have opened minority scholarships and other programs to whites included an erroneous reference from Princeton to eligibility for a seven-week summer program. It is for college juniors, not high school juniors.

title: Once a Vision of Water, Mexico's Capital Now Thirsts for It
description: MEXICO CITY, March 15 - In his chronicle of the Spanish Conquest, the soldier Bernal Daz marveled at the invaders' first glimpse of Tenochtitln, the Aztec capital set on an island in a vast lake. The city and lakeside towns, he recalled, "rising from the water, all made of stone, seemed like an enchanted vision."

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
2 Times Reporters Win Prize for Articles on Spying
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 - James Risen and Eric Lichtblau of The New York Times have won the Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting for their coverage of the Bush administration's domestic eavesdropping program.

title: Turning the Television Into an Electronic Easel for Future Mondrians
description: The role of the TV screen continues to expand with the V.Smile Art Studio, a large battery-operated children's drawing tablet. The $30 device, made to work with the V.Smile TV Learning System (sold separately for $50), also includes one software "smartridge." Plug everything in and your TV screen turns into a large blank easel surrounded by 15 color selections, plus icons for all the basic drawing functions like erase, fill, cut and paste.

title: Hussein Urges Iraqis to Unify in War on U.S.
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 15 - Saddam Hussein took the witness stand on Wednesday for his first formal testimony in his trial and delivered an incendiary political diatribe that urged Iraqis to stop sectarian bloodshed and to carry on the war against the Americans. The presiding judge halted the session after Mr. Hussein, brandishing thick reading glasses, repeatedly lambasted the court.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on March 7 about women who are married to gay men referred imprecisely to the eight children of King James I of England and Anne of Denmark. They were born between 1594 and 1606, not all in the 16th century.

title: Skiing: Kostelic seals crown
Leaving Las Vegas With a Little Secret
description: I DON'T particularly like the Rolling Stones, mostly because a few years ago I sat behind Keith Richards at a screening of the movie "Traffic," and he kept banging his chair into my shin and never apologized. But a couple of weeks ago, at the urging of friends, I got on an airplane and flew six hours to see the Stones in concert in Las Vegas.

title: Warning on Enron Recounted
description: HOUSTON, March 15 - Sherron S. Watkins, the Enron vice president celebrated for trying to warn the company's founder, Kenneth L. Lay, that the company could "implode in a wave of accounting scandals," recounted to jurors on Wednesday how her efforts fell on deaf ears just five months before Enron collapsed into bankruptcy.

title: A Backup Player Begins His Solo Act
description: IN the year since Miguel Adrover's tumultuous career came to an unceremonious end -- he closed his business and moved home to Majorca -- the cautionary tale of his failure has taken on a romanticized patina. He is now the stuff of legend, like fashion's Wild Bill.

title: M.T.A. Dismisses (for Now) New Vote by Transit Workers
description: A day after the president of the city transit workers' union proposed a new vote on a contract that was narrowly rejected in January, Peter S. Kalikow, the president of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, responded angrily yesterday that the dispute should be resolved through binding arbitration.

title: Oh, Her Again
description: Oh, Her Again

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOSTER, NANCY ADAMSON
description: FOSTER--Nancy Adamson. September 18, 1923--March 13, 2006. Daughter of Percy and Lillian Adamson, sister of Ronald D. Adamson, wife of David W. Foster. Beloved mother of Gray, Margaret, Jan, Ian and Nina Foster. Devoted grandmother to Tad Kreager, Meg Almanza, Christopher Starr, Andrew Roney, Joey Foster, Lily Basye and eight great grandchildren. A woman of extraordinary grace, beauty, dignity, kindness, humor and intelligence. She was a lifelong Democrat with an unfailing belief in justice and political responsibility. She loved her family, books, summertime, New York, lilacs, fashion, good tea, raspberries, art, friends and conversation. Forever, the Queen of our hearts.

title: A lesson from Ireland: Never say 'always'
A Connection Kit for the Laptop, Sized to Fit in the Suitcase
description: While most hotel concierges these days are willing to lend you a computer cable to connect to a hotel's broadband service, bringing your own equipment may be more convenient. The Notebook Essentials Collection from Verbatim includes just about everything a wandering laptop user might need, and more.

title: My Other Job Is Triathlon
description: BY the time he turned 47, Abe Borenstein had finished two dozen marathons and was looking for a new challenge, ideally one that would be a little easier on his middle-aged hips and knees. So last year he entered a sprint triathlon. That is the shortest kind, usually requiring a half-mile swim, a 13-mile bike ride and a three-mile run. But it was still a challenge for a man who at the time could swim only three laps in a pool.

title: Crossing a Fine Line on Witness Coaching
description: The terrorism trial of Zacarias Moussaoui is teetering on collapse, thanks in large part to a government lawyer's efforts to shape the accounts of federal aviation officials set to testify in the case.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Warehouse Opens After Anthrax
description: Three weeks after officials confirmed that a 44-year-old New York City man had contracted inhalation anthrax, prompting the police to seal a Brooklyn warehouse where he worked, the building was reopened yesterday to most commercial tenants. The cleanup began on March 2 but took longer than expected. "To come back feels great, but it's definitely an eerie feeling," said Lincoln Mayne, 34, a fashion designer who returned to his third-floor studio. The sixth floor, where the anthrax patient, Vado Diomande, worked, remained closed yesterday for a final inspection. Mr. Diomande, 44, was in fair condition at a Pennsylvania hospital. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: Math Professor Wins a Coveted Religion Award
description: Continuing a recent trend in which the world's richest religion prize has gone to scientists, John D. Barrow, a British cosmologist whose work has explored the relationship between life and the laws of physics, was named the winner yesterday of the 2006 Templeton Prize for progress or research in spiritual matters.

title: A Mystical Quest That Now Requires Tunes for Nirvana
description: Remember "Siddhartha"? You know, the novel by Hermann Hesse you probably read in the spiritually questing days of youth, also known as high school. Perhaps somewhere between the revelation that was "Atlas Shrugged" and the greater revelation that was "The Catcher in the Rye"?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNEDY, KEVIN J.
description: KENNEDY--Kevin J. Age 45 yrs. on March 13, 2006 after a short illness. New York State Licensed Funeral Director formerly of Joseph T. Kennedy Funeral Home, Amsterdam Avenue, NYC., Walter B. Cooke - Kennedy Funeral Home, W. 72nd St., NYC, Hodder and Sons Funeral Home, McLean Ave., Yonkers, NY and presently at Williams Funeral Home, Bx., NY. Beloved son of James T. and the late Lillian (nee Walsh) Kennedy. Adored brother of Karen Kennedy, Lynn (Andrew) DeNatale, Christine Kennedy Pedone and James (Denise) Kennedy. Loving uncle of Christine Kennedy, David (Jennifer) Kennedy MacIntyre, Andrew and Christopher DeNatale, Jennifer, Mellissa and James Kennedy III and Jenviev Pedone. Dear Great Uncle of Matthew, Alexander and Kaitlyn. Fond friend of John Dowdie Jr., Family will receive friends Wed. March 15 from 5-9 PM at Williams Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at W 232nd St., Bx. The family will also receive friends on Thursday, March 16 at the McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home, 220 Glen St., Glen Cove, NY from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St. Gertrude's Church, 28 School St., Bayville, NY on Friday, March 17 at 10 A.M. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the Calvary Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY would be appreciated.

title: Angling for the Edge in Tennis? Wear Red
description: THERE was a time, before I started playing in a tennis league, when I thought that the most difficult peace to negotiate would be a settlement in the Middle East.

title: News Analysis: Europe fails to adjust to U.S. shift of focus
Around the World in Four French Rooms
description: PARIS - FUSION design is not a new idea, but if you want to get a sense of the harmony that can result from the artful melding of different traditions, step through the portals of an 18th-century building near the venerable Palais Royal. Continue up to the third-floor apartment of Dimonah and Mehmet Iksel, a couple who practice the design equivalent of spicing matzo ball soup with Turkish cardamom.

title: When Moviegoers Vote With Their Feet
description: LAS VEGAS, March 15 - In a loud corner of the Bally's hotel convention floor, a dozen beefy, bare-chested men wearing chicken masks and black Lycra tights leapt from a wrestling ring onto the exhibition floor. It was a welcome distraction at the annual ShoWest convention this week, where the aim is to whip up enthusiasm among movie theater owners for the coming summer blockbusters.

description: ROME - Governments worldwide have spent billions planning for a potential influenza pandemic: buying medicines, running disaster drills, developing strategies for tighter border controls. But one piece of the plan may be missing: the ability of corporations to continue to provide vital services.

title: Hop on My Bandwidth
description: St. Louis - SHOULD we be worried about wireless "piggybacking?" Millions of homes now have wireless Internet networks, and many of them are not protected by passwords. "Piggybacking" occurs when someone -- a next-door neighbor or a stranger parked across the street -- finds an open network and logs on.

title: Arts, Briefly; Kremlin Museum Grows
description: The 200-year-old State Kremlin Museum in Moscow, with treasures ranging from ancient icons and imperial regalia to nine Faberg eggs, will begin a $50 million expansion this year that is to include the construction of a new conservation and exhibition facility outside the Kremlin walls, officials said. The museum, a complex of cathedrals and palaces near President Vladimir V. Putin's quarters, has 1.5 million visitors a year, and has been so cramped for space that much of its holdings -- including the bulk of its icon collection, for example -- cannot be displayed. The museum's bicentennial began with a ceremony last week attended by Mr. Putin that displayed some of the restoration work that has already been completed, including 15th-century frescoes in the Annunciation Cathedral. The Kremlin's tallest structure, the Belfry of Ivan the Great, which dates to the 16th century, was also restored. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

The same is true of Sony Bend's stealth-action game Syphon Filter: Dark Mirror, made for the Sony PSP hand-held game console. It is not better than stealth-action games for the Xbox or the PlayStation 2, but one is simply awestruck that so much can be squeezed into such a tiny package.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Anna Marly, who wrote the melody for the anthem of the French Resistance in World War II, misstated the Russian word for partisan, which she used as a rhythmic accent. It is partizan, not partinski. The obituary also misspelled the surname of the Resistance leader who urged the preparation of a French version of the song. He was Emmanuel d'Astier de la Vigerie, not d'Astair.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Charged In Child's Beating
description: A 2-year old girl was beaten by her mother and critically injured, the authorities said. The mother, Antonia Ramirez, 30, was arraigned early today on charges of assault and reckless endangerment and was held without bail. Prosecutors said that in a videotaped statement, Ms. Ramirez admitted shoving her daughter into an entertainment center in her apartment on Central Avenue in Bushwick. They added that investigators found bloody sheets in a garbage can and a clump of the girl's hair next to a television stand in the apartment. Ms. Ramirez took her daughter to Brooklyn Hospital Center early on Tuesday, saying she had found the girl unresponsive in the apartment, the police said. Prosecutors said the girl was not expected to survive. Ms. Ramirez is seven months pregnant and has three other children, who were placed in the custody of the Administration for Children's Services, the authorities said.

title: Letter from Jerusalem: With Hamas victory, a changed Middle East
Paid Notice: Deaths   HOUDE, RAYMOND W., MD
description: HOUDE--Raymond W., MD. The Department of Pharmacology, Weill Medical College of Cornell University mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague who passed away on March 8, 2006. Ray was a graduate of the NYU Medical School. In 1948 he began his life-long association with the Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center. He was Head of the Analgesic Studies Section and then Chief of the Pain Service. Ray literally developed the field of the clinical pharmacology of opioid analgesics. He developed the tools to measure subjective responses like pain and pain relief that are now routinely used in adult and pediatric pain patients. His table of relative analgesic potencies of the clinically used opioids formed the basis for dose conversion tables that are used throughout the world and are found in virtually every Pharmacology text. Ray was a member of the Department of Pharmacology since the 1950's and taught in the medical pharmacology course for many years. He was a founding member of the International Association for the Study of Pain, the American Pain Society and the Eastern Pain Association and the recipient of many awards for his contributions to our understanding analgesic drugs and their appropriate use in the management of pain. Dr. Lorraine Gudas Chairman, Dept. of Pharmacology

title: Enel to meet with Kroes
Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAYS, HENRY ''CHARLIE''
description: SHAYS -- Henry "Charlie". Loved by his wife Rona, five children, seven grandchildren, and sister, Charlie Shays died March 13, 2006 in Sarasota, FL. A son of immigrants and CCNY and Yale Law School graduate, Charlie will be remembered as a man who loved his family, friends, and his dog, Max. He held infinite information and a huge intellect with an unsurpassed wit. Passionate about lawyering, Judaism and collecting, Charlie was a fiercely moral man who lived what he taught. A beloved curmudgeon, he had a great run. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Doctors Without Borders or the charity of your choice. Burial Friday, March 17, 11 AM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery on L.I. Shiva will be observed at the Berlsteins, 870 UN Plaza, March 17, 2-5, March 18, 6-9 PM.

description: FERNBACH--Max. Died March 14, 2006, in New York, N.Y. Beloved uncle, brother, friend, mentor and guardian of us all. Survived by nephews Edward Fernbach (Karen) of Great Neck, N.Y., Lewis Fernbach (Temma) of Springfield, N.J., Kenneth Graiser (Grace) of Marietta, Ga., Alice Knapp of Orlando, Fl; grand nieces and grand nephews Faith, Keith, Marcy, Audrey, Samantha and Benjamin and all of his friends at the McBurney YMCA, especially Joseph Pasquanza and Ramon Dinglasan. Memorial Service at McBurney YMCA, date and time to be announced.

title: Stones Kill 4 Indonesian Officials in U.S. Mine Protest

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: H&R Block Sued by New York Attorney General Over High-Cost Individual Retirement Accounts The New York attorney general has accused H&R Block, the tax-preparation service, of steering hundreds of thousands of its clients into individual retirement accounts that were "virtually guaranteed to lose money" because of low interest rates and high fees. [Page C1.]

title: Theater Addresses Tension Over Play
description: Today is the third anniversary of the death of Rachel Corrie, a 23-year-old from Washington State who was killed by an Israeli Army bulldozer in the Gaza Strip as she tried to protect a Palestinian home. But the focus of many of the commemorations scheduled by supporters around the world is a small nonprofit stage, the New York Theater Workshop, that recently delayed a production of a British play based on her e-mail messages and diary entries, "My Name Is Rachel Corrie."

title: Polygamy and the Marriage Market: Who Would Have the Upper Hand?
description: MOST people believe that consenting adults should be free to do as they please, provided they do not cause unacceptable harm to others. The difficult question, of course, is what constitutes unacceptable harm. The debut on Sunday night of "Big Love," the new HBO series about a polygamous fictional family in Salt Lake City, has touched off renewed debate about this question.

Beloved father of Martin, Neil and Daniel and proud grandfather of Diana, Allison, Theodore, Harry, Matt, Charlie and Katie. Dearest brother of Harriet. His memory will live in the hearts of his loved ones forever. Service Friday, March 17, 11am Temple B'nai Yisrael, Route 22 and Banksville Rd, Armonk, NY 914-273-2220. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDEN, PATRICIA
description: LINDEN--Patricia, 80, of New York City. On March 9th. She had been in failing health for several years. She leaves behind her beloved son and daughter-in-law, Peter and Joanne Linden of Houston and her grandson, Christopher Linden of Nashville. A highly regarded editor, journalist and author, she wrote a number of in-depth articles on a wide range of topics for a number of magazines. She served as Contributing Editor for Boston Magazine and Town & Country Magazine under Frank Zachary for whom she wrote primarily in the 1970s and 1980s. She also was a contributing writer for such publications as Avenue, Esquire, Harper's Bazaar, Reader's Digest, Travel & Leisure, Ultra and Veranda. Additionally, she briefly published I.D. Confidential, a newsletter for interior design professionals. In the early part of her career in Boston, she worked as a copywriter and became the owner of an advertising agency, Imagination, Inc. Later she became Editor of Epicure Magazine. Published under the aegis of S.S. Pierce Co., Epicure was one of the first glossy magazines devoted to fine cuisine. Ms. Linden was also the author of several books. Her titles included: Cooking with Bernard, Levin's Laws, Living in Style, The Woman's Selling Game and Women & Work. Funeral services will be private.

After disappearing in February they have reappeared inside two Uptown stores, Gracious Home at 1992 Broadway (67th Street) and Gracious Home at 1220 Third Avenue (70th Street). The new shops offer only new dinnerware with fanciful designs by Cynthia Rowley and others -- exclusive to Fishs Eddy -- and colorful accessories like carnival glasses ($4.75), above. He was only 31 at the time, but he was old for his age. Every season he played had stretched into October, the blessing and the curse of pitching for the Yankees.

Ms. DeLonge's Ava club chair, named for her 3-year-old daughter, is covered in synthetic suede ($299) and has a matching ottoman ($99). The pieces also come in cotton and in vintage fabrics. In May Ms. DeLonge will introduce a play table lacquered in colors like lime and tangerine ($299), with matching stools ($50 each). title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Indians Protest Free-Trade Talk With U.S.
description: Interior Minister Alfredo Castillo resigned as thousands of Indians blocked highways to protest President Alfredo Palacio's efforts to negotiate a free trade agreement with the United States. The Indians, who say an agreement would batter their way of life, have burned tires and tussled with police officers trying for two days to control the demonstrations, which have buffeted Ecuador's tiny economy. Mr. Palacio, who has been hit by one protest after another since taking office last year, has said he would seek to sign a deal that would be equitable to all Ecuadoreans.

title: Eyecatching And Fun For Spring
description: Alessi has two new products this spring: the indoor-outdoor Moiramoira tablecloth and placemat set, and the stainless steel and glass Blow Up table. Moiramoira ($105), by Ron Arad, comes with a length of humble oilcloth, 55 by 71 inches. Its honeycomb pattern, in gray or orange, looks like moir when the set's four transparent placemats and eight coasters are added, above left. The Blow Up table ($364), above right, by Humberto and Fernando Campana, is 17 3/4 inches across and 17 3/4 inches high. Both products are at Piazza Italia in Montclair, N.J., (973) 744-5533. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: DCOR
