title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, EDWARD A.
description: KATZ--Edward A. Of Basking Ridge, NJ and Palm Beach, FL on March 13, 2006 in Palm Beach, FL. Loving husband of Betty Katz. Edward is also survived by his children: Mimi Levine of LaJolla, CA; Lawrence Katz of Caen, France; and Neva Watson of Morristown, NJ. He is also survived by his sister, Elayne Bernay of NYC; 10 grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Edward served in the Army during WWII in the Army Air Corp as a Sergeant. Edward owned and operated Suburban Furniture Company in Succasunna and retired in 1988. Shiva will be on Thursday March 16 all day and Saturday March 18 in the evening.

description: Those who invest or work in the video game industry expressed little surprise yesterday at Sony's announcement that it would delay its next PlayStation console until November. The shock appeared limited to the industry's customers: everyday gamers. And the beneficiary seemed to be Microsoft.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 16 A The American military announced today that it had begun its largest air assault since the invasion of Iraq in 2003, while Iraqi legislators convened the long-awaited first session of the new Parliament in the capital, even in the absence of any agreement to form a full government.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, BRETT J.
description: MEYER--Brett J. Everyone at Pryor Cashman Sherman & Flynn LLP is deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our partner, Brett J. Meyer. The dignity and courage Brett displayed while fighting lymphoma -never complaining, always optimistic and endlessly upbeat were an inspiration to us all. He was a dedicated partner and colleague, whose leadership, intelligence and strength of character will be dearly missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to Brett's wife, Patricia, and his children, Damon and Elizabeth. Pryor Cashman Sherman & Flynn LLP

title: City Takes Steps to Balance Its Water Needs With Flood Protection Upstate

description: JERUSALEM, March 15 - If Israel withholds revenues from a Hamas-led Palestinian Authority and donor countries reduce aid, the Palestinian areas will be thrown into a deep depression, with personal incomes dropping 30 percent this year alone, according to a new World Bank study.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review in Weekend on March 3, about "Mussolini's Italy," by R. J. B. Bosworth, misidentified the architect of the Stazione Termini in Rome, which was cited as a remnant of the Fascist era. The part of the station built between 1938 and 1942 was designed by Angiolo Mazzoni; the rest, built between 1948 and 1950, was by Eugenio Montuori and Annibale Vitellozzi, among others. Pier Luigi Nervi was not the architect.

title: The Shape of Robots to Come
description: A segmented tower on a metal and plastic base swiveled around. Two glowing segments, suggesting a head, tilted forward and spoke: "Hello. My name is Scoty. Let me explain a few things about myself."

title: TV Stations Fined Over CBS Show Deemed to Be Indecent
description: The Federal Communications Commission leveled a record $3.6 million fine yesterday against 111 television stations that broadcast an episode of "Without a Trace" in December 2004, with the agency saying the CBS show suggested that its teenage characters were participating in a sexual orgy.

title: Panel Urges Replacing New Jersey School Building Unit
description: New Jersey should abolish a troubled agency responsible for building and renovating schools in the state's poorest districts and replace it with a new government authority, according to a report released yesterday by a group convened by Gov. Jon S. Corzine to advise him on the issue.

title: An Innocent, Coming of Age in Boontling
description: It sounds as if Eisa Davis can't help herself, she's made giddy by language. In her play "Bulrusher," which opened at Urban Stages on Saturday, she tickles the ears of her listeners by using a regional jargon from Northern California known as Boontling: "Nice out in the buzzchick field." "Fourth of Jeel." The terms for baseball field and Fourth of July are among the more neutral expressions, considering that a number of Boontling words are related to sex, or "heel scratchin."

title: U.S. and Australia Take Different Tones on China's Rising Power
description: SYDNEY, March 16 A Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and the foreign minister of Australia struck markedly different tones today over the rising power of China, with Ms. Rice criticizing its military expansion and the Australian warning against trying to "contain" Chinese ambitions.

title: Scientists Get Glimpse of First Moments After Beginning of Time
description: Using data from a new map of the baby universe, astronomers said today that they had seen deep into the big bang that allegedly started the universe and had got their first detailed hint of what was going on less than a trillionth of a second after time began.

title: What Every Iraqi Should See
description: The trial of Saddam Hussein should be a showcase for a better Iraq. It should clearly demonstrate that decades of secret trials and summary verdicts are giving way to a new era of transparency and the rule of law. It should be showing these things, but thus far it has fallen disappointingly short.

title: Hanging tough against tyranny
QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It rattles, it rolls. It is like telling you to get out."

title: As if That Fire Needed Fuel
description: Wouldn't it be nice if, just once, the players in the disaster movie that is Middle East politics didn't perform true to type? Unfortunately, the events in the Palestinian city of Jericho this week show that's a pretty far-fetched thought, so the conflict continues its never-ending run, fueled, this time, by Britain and America.

title: Is Ivory-Billed Woodpecker Alive? A Debate Emerges
description: The ivory-billed woodpecker? That's the bird that went extinct, and was rediscovered, and then there was some argument but it's all settled now and the great creature lives, elusively, in an Arkansas swamp, with a chunk of federal money to keep it comfortable. Right?

title: Write Grandma a What?
description: YOUR Mom probably did, and her mother or father almost definitely wrote letters, but chances are that you don't. And when it comes to your kids -- no way.

title: With Energy-Tax Bonanza, Wyoming Schools Enjoy Windfall
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo. - Forget the bucking bronco. A clattering cash register has become the more apt symbol of Wyoming in the energy rush.

title: Editor's Note
description: David Pogue, whose column for Circuits normally appears on this page, is on vacation until next Thursday.

title: Briefly: U.S. military leaving Iceland after decades
The Glamour (Sigh, Whine) of Heartbreak
description: Thanks to a nation of enthusiastic high-school kids, emo bands are everywhere; plaintive punk has become the soundtrack of white adolescence. Thanks to a nation of enthusiastic downloaders, sexually explicit images of celebrities are everywhere, too. And last week these two trends finally collided, as Web sites began posting a series of extraordinarily revealing photographs of Pete Wentz, the bassist and lyricist for the emo band Fall Out Boy.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: News Analysis: What price democracy?
Math Professor Wins a Coveted Religion Award
description: Continuing a recent trend in which the world's richest religion prize has gone to scientists, John D. Barrow, a British cosmologist whose work has explored the relationship between life and the laws of physics, was named the winner yesterday of the 2006 Templeton Prize for progress or research in spiritual matters.

title: World Briefing: Europe, Asia and Americas
description: EUROPE

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: NFL: Browns grab Pats veteran
South Korea Wins, and Americans Catch a Break
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., March 15 - For the second time in the World Baseball Classic, the United States team survived off-day elimination. The Americans lived for another day Wednesday night as South Korea, the Classic's only unbeaten team, defeated Japan, 2-1, in the type of scintillating game these teams have been known to play.

title: Report Backs Iraq Strike and Cites Iran Peril
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 - An updated version of the Bush administration's national security strategy, the first in more than three years, gives no ground on the decision to order a pre-emptive attack on Iraq in 2003, and identifies Iran as the country likely to present the single greatest future challenge to the United States.

title: Despite Dire Predictions, Money Measures Always Talk
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 - Despite broad bipartisan agreement that the government is barreling toward a fiscal train wreck, simultaneous Congressional consideration of three major money measures is proving just how hard it is to change course, especially in an election year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLOY, HERBERT
description: ALLOY--Herbert. On March 14, 2006, of Old Bethpage, NY. Beloved husband of Natalie. Devoted father of Robin, Cathy and Laurie. Cherished grandfather of Erika. Services Friday, at 12 noon, at "Gutterman's" 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Thai Leader Ponders Leaving Post Awhile
description: BANGKOK, March 15 - Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra of Thailand said Wednesday that he might step aside temporarily in the face of huge continuing protests, but he kept open the option of getting tough instead by declaring a state of emergency.

title: Economy Growing at Moderate Pace in Most of U.S., Fed Says
description: The economy expanded at a moderate pace across most parts of the country in January and February, while higher energy and materials costs persisted, the Federal Reserve said yesterday.

title: Is Ivory-Billed Woodpecker Alive? A Debate Emerges
description: The ivory-billed woodpecker? That's the bird that went extinct, and was rediscovered, and then there was some argument but it's all settled now and the great creature lives, elusively, in an Arkansas swamp, with a chunk of federal money to keep it comfortable. Right?

title: Atlantic Tops Nominee List for Awards
description: Despite unusual turmoil last year, and no permanent editor since Michael Kelly stepped down in 2002, The Atlantic Monthly received eight nominations for National Magazine Awards yesterday, outpacing even The New Yorker, which has dominated the field for eight years.

title: Census Shows Slight Dip in City, but Demographers Beg to Differ
description: The engine driving New York City's population growth -- immigration -- appears to have slowed slightly, contributing to a tiny decline in the city's population in the year ended July 1, 2005, according to estimates released yesterday by the Census Bureau.

title: Mad for Mangoes
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran and U.S. agree to talks about Iraq
Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGELMAN, JOSEPH
description: SIEGELMAN--Joseph. On March 14, 2006. WWII veteran. Violinist with the NYC ballet for 30 years and expert on stringed instruments and bows. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of the late Janet O'Rourke. Dear brother of Henry. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Services Friday 11:30 AM at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A booming China saps labor and supply
Only deepest loyalists view Milosevic's coffin
Lawyers for Libby Subpoena Reporter and New York Times
description: Lawyers for I. Lewis Libby Jr., a former aide to Vice President Dick Cheney who faces charges of obstruction of justice, served subpoenas on Tuesday on The New York Times Company and a former reporter for The Times, Judith Miller.

title: American Raid on Insurgents Kills Civilians in Sunni Town
description: Correction Appended

title: Dutch Doctors Say Dissident Did Not Belong in Chinese Asylum
description: BEIJING, March 16 A Dutch psychiatrists have determined that a prominent Chinese dissident who spent 13 years in a police-run psychiatric institution in Beijing did not have mental problems that would justify his incarceration, two human rights groups said today.

title: Jewel in the rough of Jamaica
Arts, Briefly
description: A Rapper, a High School and Two Men in Black

title: Bush Picks F.D.A. Chief, but Vote Is Unlikely Soon
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 - President Bush nominated Dr. Andrew C. von Eschenbach to serve as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, but a dispute over the "morning after" contraceptive pill all but ensures that the nomination will go nowhere for months or even years.

title: U.S. Overture to London Exchange Stirs Talk of a Merger by European Rivals
description: FRANKFURT, March 15 - The lengthy mating dance among European stock exchanges may be entering its final whirl, as a potential American takeover of the London Stock Exchange has driven two rival exchange operators, Euronext and Deutsche Brse, into serious merger talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTHOLOMEW, PATRICIA S.
description: BARTHOLOMEW--Patricia S. On March 10, 2006. Beloved wife of Geoffrey. Loving mother of Rebecca Soller and Rafe Bartholomew. Daughter of George and Patricia Procak, sister of Fran Noyes, Tina Tyler, Kate Douglas and Betsy Larkin. Professor Emeritus, Dr. Bartholomew was Chair of the Dept. of Hospitality Management at NYC College of Technology, CUNY from 1990-2000 and Dean of the School of Professional Studies, 2000-2002. Donations in her memory may be made to "NYC College of Technology Foundation," Patricia Bartholomew Scholarship, 300 Jay St., Brooklyn, NY 11201. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St at 3:30PM, Sunday, March 19, 2006.

title: Cover the Queen With a King? Not Necessarily
description: There are pro-am events in some sports. The best known are in golf, where the pro can use his own clubs and worry primarily about his game. In bridge, though, the pro has an inexperienced partner and is using unsophisticated methods, not having a fraction of the agreements he has with his regular partner. This can be frustrating, but the pro is putting something back into the game that has given him so much.

title: Corrections
description: An essay in Science Times on Tuesday on movies about mysticism and quantum physics referred incorrectly to parapsychologists, who investigate psychic phenomena like telekinesis and telepathy. Their group, the Parapsychological Association, has been affiliated with the American Association for the Advancement of Science since 1969; it was not expelled 30 years ago.

title: Sports of the Times; Brees's Signing May Force Jets to Reroute
description: Correction Appended

title: Exploding Latino Market Becomes Attractive to Banks
description: FOR decades, the words Latino market conjured up images of mom-and-pop groceries selling fresh tortillas and specialty spices. But today, those words translate to El Dorado for increasing numbers of businesses in the Los Angeles area and elsewhere.

title: France debates new tunes for iPod
Virus 911
description: Omaha - WIRETAPPING without a warrant isn't the only surveillance controversy we have to worry about. There is an even more dangerous one. Few people, even lawmakers, realize that federal law does not mandate that any doctor, hospital, laboratory, city or state report human diseases directly to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, our nation's medical counterpart to the Pentagon and Department of Homeland Security wrapped into one. And that applies to diseases as potentially devastating as avian flu.

title: U.S. forces launch 'major Iraq assault'
New Mandate for the BBC: Put Entertainment First
description: LONDON, March 15 - The last few years have been rough for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It lost a bitter fight with the government and suffered the resignation of its top two officials in 2004 over its news coverage of British intelligence leading to the Iraq war. It has reorganized itself up and down, begun to lay off thousands of workers and worried endlessly about its viability at a time when the broadcasting landscape is changing at a dizzying pace.

title: Germans get hostilein bids, too
Patriots Lose McGinest As Exodus Continues
description: The exodus of key players from the New England Patriots continued yesterday when linebacker Willie McGinest signed with Cleveland.

title: Readers Respond to 25 Key Questions on Iraq
description: Robert Britton, San Francisco: 1. It is time to stop giving military support to countries, sects, tribes, that are used to suppress citizens and neighbors.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the "Arts, Briefly" column yesterday about a Master of Fine Arts program planned by Pace University in Lower Manhattan with the Actors Studio referred incorrectly to the present and future location of the studio. It was not homeless for nearly a year, and it will remain on West 44th Street. It does not have a new home downtown at Pace; what is new is its affiliation with Pace, after an 11-year collaboration with the New School that ended last May.

title: Passion for Classic Throws ESPN Curve
description: Fans are riled that ESPN and ESPN2 have not shown every game of the World Baseball Classic, which is good news for Major League Baseball.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BMW Expects 22% Rise in Annual Profit
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke forecast a 22 percent increase in profit this year, helped by sales of its new 3-Series sedans and by the sale of a stake in the Rolls-Royce Group. Pretax profit this year will rise to 4 billion euros ($4.8 billion), from 3.29 billion euros in 2005, the chief executive, Helmut Panke, said at a news conference. Spending on raw materials and currency hedging will be less of a burden on earnings than in 2005, he said. BMW is based in Munich.

title: Protests Heat Up as France Feels the Chill of Change
description: PARIS, March 16 A Once again, students are on the barricades in France, evoking comparisons to the uprising of May 1968. But this is not a revolt. It is not 1968 revisited.

title: Navigate First, Then Get Into Your Car
description: The first portable satellite-navigation unit from Sony, the NV-U70 Nav-U, gives directions that are loud and clear, but not always easy to program.

title: Southeast Asia, Too, Is on Map of Islamic Art
description: CANBERRA, Australia - In this sleepy capital, where talk usually centers on domestic politics, the National Gallery of Australia is provoking a more worldly debate: What is Islamic art? Can it embrace art and artifacts from Southeast Asia, where Islam has been a dominant religion since the 15th century but whose lush tropical lands were largely cut off from the inspirations of the Ottoman, Persian and Mughal empires?

title: Ex-attorney generalturns into a lobbyist
Key rates
description: In percent

title: Correction
description: An editorial in Tuesday's Times gave the wrong figures for the numbers of people charged and convicted by the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. The tribunal has indicted 160 men and one woman, not 161 men. Forty people have been found guilty by the tribunal, not 32.

title: Fuji TV to unload stake in Livedoor
Doubts greet Pemex's claim of big deepwater strike
Stop Bush's War
description: "By some estimates," according to a recent article in Foreign Affairs, "the number of Iraqis who have died as a result of the [U.S.] invasion has reached six figures -- vastly more than have been killed by all international terrorists in all of history. Sanctions on Iraq probably were a necessary cause of death for an even greater number of Iraqis, most of them children."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSELL, WENDY VANDER POEL
description: RUSSELL -- Wendy Vander Poel. The Board of Directors, Medical Advisory Board and staff of The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration wish to express our sincere condolences to the family of Wendy Vander Poel Russell, our Honorary Director who served on the Board of our organization for 27 years and as President from 1981 to 1988. She imbued strength and optimism and through her generous support of eye donation, helped to save thousands of men, women and children from blindness. Her contributions to society and her wonderful spirit will be missed. The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration, Inc.

title: A Second Vote for a Transit Contract
description: The men and women who keep New York's buses and subways running voted down a good contract by a mere seven votes in January, shocking everyone, perhaps most of all the transit union's president, Roger Toussaint. Now Mr. Toussaint believes that he can tilt the scale to win approval for the contract, so he wants a revote. As peculiar as that may sound, he has a point.

title: The International Traveler Q & A: Venturing into the Yukon
An Irish Face on the Cause of Citizenship
description: Rory Dolan's, a restaurant in Yonkers, was packed with hundreds of illegal Irish immigrants on that rainy Friday night in January when the Irish Lobby for Immigration Reform called its first meeting. Niall O'Dowd, the chairman, soon had them cheering.

title: NCAA: BC snares victory in double OT
National Briefing | Washington: A.C.L.U. Intervenes For Muslim Scholar
description: The American Civil Liberties Union asked a federal court in New York for a preliminary order to stop the administration from banning a prominent Swiss Muslim scholar from speaking in the United States. The scholar, Tariq Ramadan, has been barred from this country since his visa was revoked in July 2004, a week before he was scheduled to begin a job at the University of Notre Dame. Administration officials explained the action by citing a USA Patriot Act ban of foreigners who "espouse terrorist activity." Mr. Ramadan has been invited to address a writers' conference in New York on April 25.

title: Grasso Motion to Dismiss Claims Is Denied
description: A judge yesterday denied a request by Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, to dismiss most of the claims made in a lawsuit to recover some of his pay.

title: Knowing What's Hot Is Easy. Explaining It? Not So Much.
description: LIKE mayflies or cicadas, some style phenomena pop up suddenly, startlingly ubiquitous, and coming from no one knows where. There are people who boast of having the prescience to spot trends coming, who claim to have foreseen the stratospheric rise of premium denim or the baffling surge of flip-flops on city streets in March. Yet those same people, one observes, tend to fall silent when trends wane and dwindle and the time comes for the Uggs life span to end.

title: Thaksin takes a step back from hints he would quit
Court and Parole Transcripts Hint at Personality of a Suspect With Many Names
description: The prisoner was angry. He was to appear before Justice Eugene P. Bambrick in Part K-11 of State Supreme Court in Queens to be sentenced for drug possession, but he would not enter the courtroom.

title: Did Someone Say Sleep? A Times Square Hotel Embraces the Dark Side
description: The Plaza had Eloise. The Night Hotel, which opened this week in the theater district, has the fictional Knight family, headed by an Aristotle Onassis-like character complete with dark glasses and a trophy wife; three nubile, lightly dressed daughters (by a previous, forgotten liaison); and a heavily tattooed son. Photographs of this anti-storybook family engaged in various suggestive antics (composed with the help of models) line the halls of the hotel, a study in black and white designed by Mark Zeff of Zeff Design, below on left, and by the hotel's owner, Vikram Chatwal, below on right. Mr. Chatwal also owns the Time and Dream hotels in Manhattan. "The concept was to create a 21st-century manor house and throw in a little Blakes hotel of London," Mr. Zeff said, referring to a boutique hotel in South Kensington with elegant interiors by Anouska Hempel. "And a little Gothicness." Mr. Chatwal added that "dark and decadent is certainly an aspect" of the dcor.

title: Asian directorsstruggle to connect
Paid Notice: Deaths   PEARSON, ANDRALL E.
description: PEARSON--Andrall E. The family of Andy Pearson extends our heartfelt thanks and appreciation for the tremendous outpouring of sympathy we have received following our sad loss. Andy was well-loved by his family and friends, and we will miss him dearly. We have planned a Memorial Service to be held at the Reformed Church, 180 Pondfield Road, Bronxville, NY on Saturday, March 18, 2006 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Cardiovascular Research Fund at the NYU Medical Center, 560 First Ave & 32nd St, New York, NY 10016. Joey Pearson Jill, Alan, Alex and Hilary Rappaport

title: Chrysler's Salaried Workers to Pay More for Health Care
description: DETROIT, March 15 - Chrysler, which is trying to persuade union members to accept less-generous health care benefits, said Wednesday that most of its salaried employees would pay more for their health coverage beginning next year.

title: Razorbacks Regain Their Edge
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., March 16 A Each day, when Coach Stan Heath of Arkansas goes to work, he is reminded of the Razorbacks' rich basketball history. His office is just down a long, winding corridor leading to the display case for Arkansas' lone national championship trophy. Above the court at Bud Walton Arena, where the Razorbacks play, are pennants noting each of the program's previous postseason accomplishments.

title: Seton Hall Sees Itself in Wichita State's Climb
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 15 - Of all the unlikely meetings in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, few would have predicted last November that Seton Hall and Wichita State would find themselves here.

title: Credibility Gap Closes for Classic
description: WATCHING the United States sit by helplessly last night gave huge credibility to this strange new event called the World Baseball Classic. The United States survived when South Korea defeated Japan, 2-1, but now the Yanks still have to beat Mexico tonight to be sure of advancing. The big winner is the Classic itself.

title: EU addresses deadly threat of rising resistance to antibiotics
Developer Told to Build 9/11 Site or Stand Clear
description: One day after critical talks on the rebuilding effort at ground zero collapsed, the Pataki administration said yesterday that it would not reopen negotiations with the developer Larry A. Silverstein. It challenged him to start building the $2.3 billion Freedom Tower next month or "move out of the way."

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Asia, Europe, Americas
description: ASIA

title: New York and Florida
description: TODAY Ben Sherman, the brand that got its start in swinging England in the 1960's, will open a flagship store in SoHo. The brand, which came to define the Mod moment with men's shirts with buttoned-down large-rolled collars, has more recently evolved to blend modern styles with a Mod sensibility.

title: Muslim, French - and proud to be both
Paid Notice: Deaths   BISSINGER, ELLIE
description: BISSINGER--Ellie. The Board of Governors and members of the Falls Country Club, Lake Worth, FL, note with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Ellie Bissinger. We extend deepest sympathy to her beloved husband, Chuck, and family. Robert Rachesky, President

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged In Drug Killings
description: Ramon Pequero, identified by prosecutors as an enforcer for a drug ring based in the Frederick Douglass Houses, a city project on the Upper West Side, has been indicted for the murders in 2001 of two rival drug dealers, the Manhattan district attorney's office said yesterday. Mr. Pequero, 26, was charged in the shooting deaths of Tyrell Williams, 19, in a Columbus Avenue lobby in the housing project, and of Al Cruz, 31, nearby. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)

title: Krstic Does Enough Scoring as Nets Shut Down Portland
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 15 - For three quarters Wednesday night, the post was dominated by Portland's Zach Randolph, a young, gritty player who can dictate a game on offense with both touch and power.

title: U.S. and allies' fighter jet program hits turbulence
Moussaoui Prosecutors Seek Security Officials' Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 - Federal prosecutors in the death penalty trial of Zacarias Moussaoui asked Judge Leonie M. Brinkema on Wednesday to overturn her ban on testimony from government aviation officials because they believed that the ban crippled their case.

title: Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: More companies are splitting top board and executive jobs
Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "The Emperor Jones," "Bulrusher" and "Ring of Fire."

title: Day 1 of the Tournament
description: The 2006 N.C.A.A. men's tournament got under way on Thursday with 16 games.

title: A Complex and Modern Cultural Gumbo
description: The thoroughly postcolonial show at the International Center of Photography is stimulating, astringent and brimming with life.

title: Family and Friends
description: The Museum of Fine Arts presents a rambling and uneven 50-year retrospective devoted to David Hockney's extensive work in portraiture.

title: M.B.A.s and the Altar of Kravis
description: Does the B in M.B.A. stand for buyouts?

title: ONeal Held Talks with North Fork
description: Merrill Lynch chief Stanley ONeal explored a takeover of North Fork Bancorp, the Long Island bank that agreed to a $14.6 billion sale this week, according to Bloomberg News.

title: The Battle for Newark
description: Trying to make sense of Newark politics can sometimes feel like passing through a carnival funhouse, at night, alone, in dark glasses.

title: Rosneft Buys Yukos Debt, Sparking Takeover Rumors
description: The Russian state oil company Rosneft has acquired $482 million in debt that the troubled oil company Yukos owed to Western banks, Yukos said Wednesday. The step raised the possibility that Rosneft might acquire Yukoss remaining assets.

title: Dresdner Bank Helps Push Up Allianz Profits
description: Allianz, Europes largest insurer, reported an almost tripling in fourth-quarter profit, helped by investment gains and improved earnings from banking and asset management.

title: DP World Hires Advisers for U.S. Ports Sale
description: DP World retained Deutsche Bank Securities  as a financial adviser on the sale of its American port operations. Sullivan & Cromwell will serve as its legal adviser.

title: U.S. Overture to London Exchange Stirs Talk of a Merger by European Rivals
description: The lengthy mating dance among European stock exchanges may be entering its final whirl, as a potential American takeover of the London Stock Exchange has driven two rival exchange operators, Euronext and Deutsche Brse, into serious merger talks.

title: Ericsson Bid for Juniper Unlikely, Analysts Say
description: Analysts are playing down reports that Ericsson is planning to buy Juniper Networks. Shares of Juniper rose 5.3 percent Tuesday to $20.21 on rumors that the Swedish telecommunications equipment giant is considering a bid for the Sunnyvale, Calif., maker of networking gear. While not ruling out such a deal, analysts noted that Ericsson is still absorbing British equipment maker Marconi, which it bought last year for $2.1 billion.

title: First Atlantic Takes a Swing at Golfsmith IPO
description: First Atlantic Capital Ltd. is gearing up to begin the process of exiting Golfsmith International Holdings Inc., a golf retailer it bought four years ago and has helped to expand with new stores and acquisitions. Austin, Texas-based Golfsmith International has filed for a $115 million initial public offering.

title: Kiss Rocker Simmons Aiming His Love Gun at IPO
description: Gene Simmons, the tongue-wagging singer for the rock band Kiss, is planning a spring IPO for their pay-television venture known as NGTV, short for No Good TV, which will feature frank celebrity interviews and nudity.

title: Goldman Strikes Out on Its Own in India
description: Goldman Sachs ended a 10-year securities alliance with Indian billionaire Uday Kotak, seeking to expand in a market where share sales rose by more than 50 percent to a record last year. Goldman said it sold its 25 percent stakes in two ventures with Kotak Mahindra Bank Ltd. for 3.33 billion rupees ($75 million) and will apply for licenses to start a financial- services firm in India.

title: Ex-Morgan Stanley Execs Pandit and Haven to Open Hedge Fund
description: Vikram Pandit and John Havens, former top executives at Morgan Stanley, will probably open a hedge fund next month after raising at least $2 billion from investors, said three people with knowledge of their plans. Old Lane  will invest in areas ranging from energy to infrastructure projects in India, said the people, who declined to be identified because the firms plans arent public.

title: Unsolicited Bid Is Expected for Vodafone Unit in Japan
description: A group of private equity firms is planning to make an unsolicited $15 billion cash bid for the Japanese subsidiary of Vodafone, in what could become the largest buyout in Asia, people involved with the offer said last night.

title: Big Name Buyout Firms to Open Their Wallets in India
description: India may lure a record $4 billion in private equity next year as buyout firms such as Actis Capital LLP and Blackstone Group LP, undeterred by soaring valuations, raise their bets on the worlds second-most populous nation.

title: Enrons Watkins : Accounting Just Doesnt Get That Creative
description: Sherron S. Watkins, the Enron vice president celebrated for trying to warn the companys founder, Kenneth L. Lay, that the company could implode in a wave of accounting scandals, recounted to jurors on Wednesday how her efforts fell on deaf ears just five months before Enron collapsed into bankruptcy.

title: Malaysian Banks Agree to Merge
description: CIMB Groups Bumiputra-Commerce Holdings, Malaysias second-largest lender, upped its offer for Southern Bank to M$6.7 billion ($1.8 billion) on Wednesday, after months of heated negotiations over the nations largest banking takeover.

title: Wireless Firm Icera Pockets $40 Million
description: Wireless chip maker Icera has closed a $40 million Series C round that is expected to push the start-up into production. London-based Amadeus Capital Partners, which had kept its eyes on the company for years, presented a term sheet three weeks into Iceras fund-raising effort and eventually led the round.

title: Carlyle and Newbridge Vie For Taiwanese Cable Firm
description: Carlyle Group and Newbridge Capital are the leading contenders to buy a unit of Taiwans Eastern Multimedia Group, as they seek access to Asias third-biggest cable-television market, Bloomberg reported.

title: Exploding Latino Market Becomes Attractive to Banks
description: Financial institutions interested in serving the growing Latino market are multiplying. Two financial groups are each raising $20 million to $30 million to start banks in Los Angeles aimed specifically at Latino consumers and small companies.

title: Start-Up Pins Hopes on Perfect Cup of Joe
description: Is the world ready for an $8,000 drip coffee maker? The Coffee Equipment Company, an eight-person start-up in Ballard, Wash., has bet $1 million that it is.

title: Energy Spectrum Drills Cash Into Start-Up
description: Energy Spectrum Partners has invested $30 million of equity in start-up drilling company Forrest Drilling, anticipating strong demand for oil rigs from energy producers.

title: Barrick Gold Completes Placer Dome Acquisition
description: Barrick Gold has acquired all remaining shares of Placer Dome, sealing its $12.1 billion takeover and creating the worlds largest gold miner.

title: More Mining Mergers Expected
description: Last year, takeover activity in the global metals industry hit a record high and this year and next year should see even more mergers and acquisitions in that sector, according to Desjardins Securities.

title: TV Stations Fined Over CBS Show Deemed to Be Indecent
description: The Federal Communications Commission leveled a record $3.6 million fine yesterday against 111 television stations that broadcast an episode of Without a Trace in December 2004, with the agency saying the CBS show suggested that its teenage characters were participating in a sexual orgy.

title: Icahns Tobacco Raid Draws Heat in South Korea
description: Many South Koreans believe they have seen the ugly face of American capitalism  and it bears an uncanny resemblance to Carl Icahn. As the South Korean business community expresses outrage over the corporate raiders moves against tobacco firm KT&G, the company is relying on more proven defenses already at hand.

title: Former CAO Chief Pleads Guilty
description: Chen Jiulin, the former chief executive of China Aviation Oil (Singapore) , pleaded guilty Wednesday to six charges related to a $550 million derivatives trading scandal that drove CAO, Chinas biggest jet fuel trader, to the brink of bankruptcy in 2004.

title: Ex-Trader Sentenced for False Reporting
description: A former trader for Reliant Energy, Jerry A. Futch Jr., has been sentenced to almost five years in prison for submitting false information about natural gas trades to an industry publication, in what prosecutors called the first such case in the nation.

title: Should the Philippines File for Chapter 11?
description: In the midst of the latest crisis in the Philippines, with a coup attempt afoot, a state of emergency declared, thousands massing in the streets and President Gloria Macapagal Arroyos administration coming unhinged, a friend suggested that what the country should really do is go into receivership.

title: The Race for Governor May Be Spitzer vs. Spitzer
description: Since he announced his intention to run for governor of New York 14 months ago, it doesnt take a political insider to know that the only person who can defeat Eliot Spitzer is Eliot Spitzer, David Weidner writes in MarketWatch.

title: Grasso Motion to Dismiss Claims Is Denied
description: A judge on Wednesday denied a request by Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, to dismiss most of the claims made in a lawsuit to recover some of his pay.

title: HIG Capital Gets Into the Hedge Fund Game
description: Big buyout firms arent the only ones in the private equity industry setting their sights on the hedge fund market. Miami-based HIG Capital Management has set up a new hedge fund affiliate and plans to raise $500 million for a debut hedge fund, according toLBO Wire.

title: News Podcasting Raises $5.5 Million From Investors
description: Eight months ago, entrepreneur John Furrier started carting a microphone around Silicon Valley, interviewing friends in the venture capital and technology business and posting the resulting podcasts online. Now he has raised $5.5 million from venture investors to turn his Podtech Networks into a full-on news service.

title: China Communications Construction Picks Underwriters
description: China Communications Construction Group has picked Merrill Lynch and UBS to handle its IPO, which could raise roughly $1 billion, Reuters reported.

title: Ukraine Blocks Steel Factory Privatization
description: The Ukraine Parliament on Wednesday passed a measure that would prevent the government from selling the Nikopol steel factory to the private sector, the second such attempt by lawmakers to keep it under state control. The Parliament voted 271 to 0 to put Nikopol on a list of enterprises that could not be privatized through 2007.

title: China Merchants Bank to Sell 15% Stake in Hong Kong Offering
description: China Merchants Bank, Chinas sixth-largest lender, plans to sell about $1.7 billion of shares in Hong Kong as growth in the worlds fourth-largest economy increases demand for loans. Merchants Bank will sell 2.2 billion shares, or a 15 percent stake, when market conditions are suitable, the Shenzhen-based lender said.

title: President of Japanese Cable Firm to Buy Livedoor Stake
description: Japanese cable broadcaster Usen Corporation said Thursday its president will personally buy Fuji TVs stake in disgraced Internet portal Livedoor. Usens President Hideyasu Uno will purchase all of Fuji TVs 12.75 percent interest in Livedoor for 9.5 billion yen ($81.2 million), the company said.

title: Princely Riches for Troubled Saudi Exchange
description: The Saudi stock market breathed a sigh of relief on Wednesday as Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, the worlds eighth-richest man, promised to invest almost $3-billion into the battered bourse.

title: French Supermarket Chain Casino to Dispose of Assets
description: Casino Guichard-Perrachon plans to sell 2 billion euros ($2.41 billion) of underperforming assets and dispose of its stake in a closely held supermarket company amid competition from Carrefour. The food retailers shares rose as much as 7.9 percent, the most in three years.

title: Aleris Swallows Chunk of British Steel Business
description: Steel company Corus has signed a letter of intent to sell a large chunk of its aluminium business for 570 million pounds. The American company Aleris International has agreed to acquire Corus downstream aluminium rolled products and extrusions business. Corus stakes in Canadian and Chinese joint ventures are also included in the agreement.

title: France Tells European Regulators  It Felt Compelled to Act on Suez
description: France has told European regulators that the utility Suez and the state-owned Gaz de France felt compelled to accelerate merger talks, with the explicit encouragement of the French state, after learning that a foreign bidder intended to break up a company that France felt could become a European champion, according to people familiar with the French position and internal documents the European Commission received from Paris.

title: First comments, second race
description: Ralf Schumacher.

title: Images From 'Slavery in New York'
description: A book based on an exhibition at the New-York Historical Society examines the complex situation that New York found itself in as a Northern slave city.

title: Greenhill Woos Another Citigroup Banker
description: For the second time in a week, investment banking boutique Greenhill & Company has hired a banker away from financial services giant Citigroup.

title: Engelhard Will Open Books to BASF
description: Ending a two-month stalemate, chemical company Engelhard  of the United States has agreed to share nonpublic financial data with its unwelcome suitor, Germanys BASF.

title: Wall St. Threepeat: Bear Stearns Reports 36% Rise in Profits
Times Video: State of the Race
description: Damien Cave provides a handy video primer on the city of Newark and previews the race for mayor.

title: Motorola Invests in Chinese Private Equity Fund
description: Motorola announced on Wednesday that its venture capital arm has become of the largest stakeholders in Shanghai NewMargin Venture Capital Enterprise, a $35 milllion private equity fund that focuses on high-tech, high-growth companies in China.

title: Kurds Destroy Shrine in Rage
description: Protesters in a Kurdish area of Iraq destroyed a museum dedicated to the memory of a poison gas assault by Saddam Husseins government that killed more than 5,000 people in 1988.

title: E.W. Scripps Extends Internet Push With uSwitch
description: Call it Shopzilla, the sequel.

title: Brown-Forman Adds Chambord to Liquor Cabinet
description: Brown-Forman, the producer of Jack Daniels, Southern Comfort and Finlandia Vodka, has agreed to pay $255 million to acquire Chambord, a brand of black raspberry liqueur.

title: Jones Apparel Said to Bid For Kate Spade
description: There seems to be a lot going on at Jones Apparel Group besides just selling clothes.

title: Waiting for Mayor James
description: Its 10 a.m. at City Hall. Do you know where your mayor is?
No Selborne Journal. Gilbert White returns tomorrow, with more of the cucumber and canteloupe saga.

title: Iraq War Still A Good Idea
Kraft Tosses Milk-Bone to Del Monte for $580 Million
description: Del Monte continued to bulk up its pet food holdings with Thursdays agreement to buy Milk-Bone, which makes dog treats, for $580 million. Earlier this month, Del Monte snapped up cat-food brand Meow Mix for $705 million.

title: Lining Up Against the Line-Item Veto
description: George Will joins the chorus against the line-item veto (which President Bush has asked Congress to give him) in his Washington Post column: It would aggravate an imbalance in our constitutional system that has been growing for seven decades: the expansion of executive power at the expense of the legislature. This ongoing development has been driven by wars hot and cold, and by todays, which is without a foreseeable end. Will also suggests that the idea is unconstitutional and, on top of that, wouldnt do anything to reduce spending (and might even make it worse).

title: Real Estate Ads Move to the Web
description: Real estate ads, like the classifieds, are increasingly moving online. Search Engine Watch notes the example of a Minnesota-based realtor, Edina Reality, which is in the middle of a campaign to shift ads that have traditionally been in newspapers or on TV or radio to the Web. The move could create additional problems for those traditional media companies, which are struggling to preserve their advertising revenues. One small comfort for the time being: most of the online ads are being placed with Web sites run by those traditional media outlets.  RON NIXON

title: Six Apart Gets $12 Million (But Most Bloggers Knew That)
description: In the virally gossipy world of blogs, a press release is often superfluous. That seemed to be the case as Six Apart, which created the popular blog publishing software Movable Type and blog-hosting servce TypePad, officially announced the closing of a $12 million round of venture capital financing. (Full disclosure: The New York Times blogs run on WordPress, a Movable Type rival.)

title: Hedge Funds Hoard Reaches $1.5 Trillion
description: The worlds hedge funds now have an estimated $1.5 trillion at their disposal, according to a report on Thursday in The Daily Telegraph. The figure, which the newspaper credits to HedgeFund Intelligence, represents a 50 percent jump from the estimate of $1 trillion of funds under management in 2004.

title: On N.Y.S.E. Floor, Bracing for Change
description: Floor traders and specialists on the New York Stock Exchange are worried about the possibility that the exchange may be planning to bypass them altogether in the trading of Exchange Traded Funds, according to SquawkBlog.

title: Hedge Fund Takes Aim at Delphis Board
description: David Tepper is turning up the heat on Delphi, the bankrupt auto-parts giant in which his hedge fund, Appaloosa Management, owns a 9.3 percent stake.

title: From Patagonia to The Parthenon
description: Restaurants that Ive visited recently  but probably wont review, if I do, for at least another month or so  include Industria Argentina, Kellari, A Voce and Buddakan. Tomorrow, A Voce and Buddakan. Today, Industria Argentina and Kellari. Heres what struck me about them:

title: Not That Beaujolais
description: My wife and I have a Tuesday night ritual. Every other week or so after the late class at my dojo, I stop off at a nearby Haitian restaurant to pick up a couple of orders of griot.

title: Citigroups Carpenter Strikes Out on His Own
description: Michael Carpenter, who was once considered the heir apparent to Citigroups Sandy Weill, is ending his 11-year career at the financial services powerhouse.

title: A True Newarker
description: Sharpe James appeared at a local elementary school this morning with First Lady Laura Bush, and after accepting a $14 million reading grant from the Department of Education, he was hit with the question of the day: Will he run for a record sixth term?

title: A Dangerous Game of Rummy
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 16 column, Rumsfelds Blinkers:

title: Condo Conversion Craze
description: With everything from old warehouses, libraries, schools and factories being turned into condos these days, youd think another conversion would just pass along as an un-read press release.

title: The Siren Song of Private Equity Pay
description: The allure of working at a privately held company may be raising the stakes for their publicly traded counterparts, The Economist reports.

title: How About Reality For a Change?
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts March 16 column, Stop Bushs War.

title: Special Delivery
description: Mayor Sharpe James threw off a varsity jacket, stripping down to gym shorts and a tank top, at just about 4 p.m. Then, wearing a straw hat, he hopped onto a Newark Police Department bicycle and rode off in City Hall to the city clerks office, carrying the remaining petitions he needs to get on the ballot for May 9. He has not yet said if this special delivery means he is officially in the race.

title: Special Delivery: Update
description: Mayor James (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

title: Concern Over Price of Scripps British Shopping Trip
description: Broadcasting and publishing company E.W. Scripps got some static Thursday over its agreement to buy uSwitch, an online shopping service based in Britain, for $366 million.

title: Meanwhile . . .
description: Filing deadline? What filing deadline?

title: 'Find Me Guilty'
description: Stephen Holden reviews the gripping courtroom drama "Find Me Guilty," Sidney Lumet's first feature film in seven years.

title: 'Don't Come Knocking'
description: Stephen Holden reviews "Don't Come Knocking," a surreal epic-manque that reunites the playwright and screenwriter Sam Shepard with the great German director Wim Wenders.

title: 36 Hours in Lower Manhattan
description: The Times' Ariel Kaminer spends 36 hours enjoying the sights, sounds, and flavors of downtown Manhattan. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: The Brooklyn Bridge
description: Times reporter Warren St. John talks about the pleasures of walking and biking across the Brooklyn Bridge.(Producer: Shayla Harris)

title: The Ivory-Billed Debate
description: The Times's Jim Gorman talks with Joel Cracraft of the American Museum of Natural History about the controversy surrounding the ivory billed woodpecker. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: Keeping an Appointment in Samarra
description: Late last month I was filling in as the company commander for my unit while our real commander was back home for leave. During that time, the company had a mission planned that was no different than many of the others I had been on in the past. While any mission can be dangerous, this was supposed to be vanilla. I was not expecting to do anything more than make sure the is were dotted and the ts crossed.

title: Idaho Governor Selected to Lead Interior Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - Moving quickly to fill the latest vacancy in his cabinet, President Bush on Thursday named Gov. Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho as his choice to be the next secretary of the interior.

title: Arts, Briefly; Another 'Idol' Victory
description: It is rare that a single half-hour television show can lift a network to a first-place finish in the ratings for the entire night. But most shows are not "American Idol." On Wednesday at 9 p.m., the first results show of its final round drew an audience of 27.84 million in Nielsen's estimates, giving Fox an easy victory. The series premiere of "The Loop" followed, and, as often happens with shows after "Idol," half the audience was lost: 13.75 million tuned in. Earlier in the night, Fox's "Bones" delivered 12.13 million viewers. In recent weeks, the network has given that crime series a post-"Idol" berth to boost its audience, and has now moved the show to 8 p.m. The strategy appears to have worked: "Bones" tied for first for the hour among adults 18 to 49, and placed second in the time slot to CBS's "Survivor" recap (12.69 million) in total viewers. ABC's combination of piggybacking "Lost" and "Invasion" has been less successful. Wednesday's episode of "Lost" (7.14 million) at 9 p.m. was a low-rated repeat, causing the creeping aliens of "Invasion" to tank at 10 p.m., with 7.23 million.

title: A Bona Fide Soprano Entertains His Jury
description: Correction Appended

title: Crash, Bang, Boom Across the Universe
description: MY daughter, Mira, calls it the big boom, the asteroid impact that spelled the death of the dinosaurs. She's only 3 and still gets scared, or so she says, when it comes up on her favorite Disney dinosaur movie, so I don't think I will be taking her to "Cosmic Collisions," a new show at the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Inflation Slowed Last Month
description: Inflation slowed sharply last month, the Labor Department reported yesterday, providing comfort to many investors that the Federal Reserve might be moving closer to ending its campaign of raising interest rates.

title: Chairman of House Science Committee to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 A Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert of New York, a centrist Republican who became a national science advocate while looking out for his upstate district, announced today that he would not seek re-election.

title: Girl Power on the Boys Soccer Team
description: Opens today nationwide Directed by Andy Fickman 105 minutes

description: WHO -- Sandy MacGregor, 64, and Marilyn Abraham, 55, publishing consultants from Santa Fe, N.M. WHAT -- 33-foot-long Itasca Suncruiser motor home MANUFACTURER -- Winnebago Industries

title: Ray Meyer, Former DePaul Coach, Dies at 92
description: Ray Meyer, a Hall of Fame basketball coach at DePaul University who launched his career by tutoring an awkward sophomore named George Mikan and went on to win 724 games over 42 seasons, died today, the school's athletic director, Jean Lenti Ponsetto, told The Associated Press. He was 92.

title: Tickling the Funny Bone of Christian America
description: Opens today in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Washington and eight other cities Directed by Leslie Small 88 minutes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OLDANI, ELIZABETH MARIE (DIEHL)
description: OLDANI -- Elizabeth Marie (Diehl). Age 76. Ann Arbor resident transitioned in life peacefully at her home surrounded by her husband and children on March 13, 2006. "Betty" was loving wife to John Francis Oldani for over 57 years. Cherished mother to Mary Elizabeth (Brian) Metzger, Anne Catherine (Daniel) Berkeley, John Francis Jr. (Karen), Margaret Mary (Paul) Boissevain, Francis Andrew (Sue), William Edward (Sharon), James Joseph, Mary Therese, Mary Agnes (Robert) Lovelace, Mary Josephine (John) Osborne, Raymond Anthony (Christine), Thomas Joseph (Kara), Rita Mary, Mary Jane (Todd) Hart, Mary Lynn (John) Gary, and Michael Joseph (Lisa). Elizabeth's legacy of love lives on in 34 treasured grandchildren and five great - grandchildren. "Big" sister to Marion Irene Oldani (deceased), Dorothy Ann Bejin, Genevieve Beatrice Pfaff, and Jane Francis Gatlin (deceased). Elizabeth lovingly devoted her life to family and had an uncanny ability to make each feel they were the favorite. She enriched the lives of all who met her with unwavering acceptance and unselfish love. An endearing woman who recorded favorite prayers on recipe cards, Betty eased pain with words of wisdom and humor. Her perpetual spirit lives on in a favorite quote: "Seek rather what unites, not what may separate you from one another."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Colombian Drug Suspect Extradited
description: Julio Csar Lpez Pea, a Colombian accused of sending more than $100 million worth of cocaine and heroin to the United States, was extradited from Colombia and arraigned yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Mr. Lpez Pea is charged with being a top trafficker in the Norte Valle organization and operating a cocaine laboratory in Colombia that produced hundreds of pounds of cocaine a week. He is also charged with sending millions of dollars' worth of heroin to the United States hidden within the surfaces of suitcases. He pleaded not guilty. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

title: Vodafone, bruised, hangs up on Japan
Paid Notice: Deaths   SAPIR, MORRIS (MOISHE)
description: SAPIR--Morris (Moishe). Beloved husband of Thelma (Terry). Father of Michael & Rachel (Roger). Grandfather of Gemma, Stacie, Kellie, Ryan. Funeral Sunday 10 AM, Marathon Jewish Center, 24537 60th Avenue, Douglaston. Shiva March 19-26.

title: It's Not the Sights, It's the Sounds
description: I WANTED to kiss Lori Austin, the waitress behind the counter of August 25, a diner near Wales Center, N.Y. I had been pretending to look at the wall art -- a sunset landscape painted on a circular saw -- but was actually straining to listen in on the conversation three elderly women were having at a nearby table. I was not having any success. The more I listened, the more quietly they talked.

title: Diner's Guide
description: Diner's Guide presents excerpts from recent restaurant reviews.

title: Companion of Roslyn Schools Chief Is Sentenced to 1 to 3 Years for His Role in Embezzlement
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., March 16 - As the story of the $11.2 million Roslyn school embezzlement unfolded over the past two years, prosecutors and auditors often remarked on the almost giddy abandon with which a few administrators dipped into school funds to pay for personal indulgences like vacation trips, luxury homes, jewelry and pedicures.

title: Should the President Be Censured?
description: To the Editor:

title: America's Iran Policy: Iraq
description: The Bush White House issued its latest national security strategy doctrine yesterday, and it identifies Iran as the "single country" that poses the greatest danger to the U.S. today. The report, however, doesn't say what exactly we should do about Iran. But here's what I think: The most frightening, scary, terrifying thing we could do to Iran today -- short of an outright attack -- is to get out of Iraq.

title: The Return of the Regenerated: A New 'Doctor Who'
description: Correction Appended

title: Bonds Is on Selig's Mind; Decision to Come Later
description: Commissioner Bud Selig acknowledged yesterday that Barry Bonds is on his mind, but he said he had not decided what course of action to follow. "I spent the airplane ride out here today thinking about it, and I'll continue to do that," Selig said in Anaheim, Calif., before the start of the United States-Mexico game in the World Baseball Classic. "I have made no decision."

title: Corrections
description: The Boldface column on Wednesday, about an induction ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, included one performer erroneously among those present. Jeff Tweedy, of the band Wilco, was on tour in Florida.

title: No Bum Heels for Achilles of Troy
description: Everything went perfectly for Achilles of Troy on the racetrack this winter. He was 3 for 3 at Aqueduct, emerging as a top contender for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTH, MARGARET
description: ROTH--Margaret, 88. Died peacefully on Tuesday after a lengthy struggle with Alzheimer's. Beloved companion of Robert Furchgott, Nobel Laureate, wife of the late Stephen Roth. All caring mother of Jane and James Roth, cherished grandmother of Melina and Jack Roth and Jennifer and Michael Sweet. Maggie was an avid gardener and the proud matriarch of the Gallagher clan. Happy St. Patricks Day! In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation, Westchester Chapter.

title: United States Runs Out of Chances in Classic
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., March 16 - This time, the United States did not have South Africa and its teenagers to kick around.

title: Softbank agrees to buy Vodafone's Japan mobile unit
U.S. officials warn about abortion pill
Arts, Briefly; Spain Tries to Halt Auction
description: The Spanish government is trying to halt a planned auction of five 10th-century wooden beams from the Great Mosque of Crdoba, below, until the police can determine whether they were removed legally, the Ministry of Culture has announced. Christie's of London plans to auction the intricately carved beams on April 4, with bids ranging from $180,000 to $520,000 each. But upon learning about the auction last week, the ministry asked Interpol to investigate how the beams left the country, citing a 1985 law prohibiting export of any piece more than 100 years old. The Christie's catalog says the beams were removed either when the mosque's roof was replaced in the early 18th century, or during renovations in the early 20th century. Church officials in Spain, who oversee the mosque, have said that they may have lost track of some pieces in the multiple renovations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about media companies that pay to use videos and other material created by their customers misspelled the surname of an editor for the Web site iFilm, which accepts submissions. He is Jake R. Sarnowski, not Sanowski.

title: Fewer Chiefs Also Serving as Chairmen
description: Disney did it. So did Fannie Mae, Hewlett-Packard and Dell. Most companies in Britain do it. And now, more American companies are doing it, too: wresting board chairmanships away from chief executives.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
U.S. Lawyer in Terror Case Is Put on Leave
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - The government lawyer whose improper coaching of witnesses and other actions have jeopardized the death penalty case against Zacarias Moussaoui has been forced to take a leave from the Transportation Security Administration, a department spokeswoman said Thursday.

title: The Listings: March 17 - March 23; BRING 'EM HOME NOW CONCERT FOR PEACE
description: On the third anniversary of the invasion of Iraq, Cindy Sheehan, the antiwar protester, begins a 15-city speaking tour with a concert featuring politically active artists. Proceeds will benefit Veterans Against the War and Veterans for Peace. The evening's guest hosts include Jane Fonda, Alec Baldwin, Margaret Cho (top right) and Janeane Garofalo. Musical performers include Michael Stipe (bottom left), Rufus Wainwright, Bright Eyes, Public Enemy's Chuck D (top left), Steve Earle, Fischerspooner, Peaches and Devendra Banhart (bottom right). Mr. Stipe has been eloquent and outspoken for two decades, rarely falling into cause-rock clich. "When the President Talks to God" by Bright Eyes' Conor Oberst is one of the era's more biting anti-Bush anthems. Chuck D, representing the pop left's small hip-hop wing, has recently had a hard time linking his trademark righteous rage to compelling music. Mr. Earle has written an ironic love song to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and a tune placing himself in the mind of John Walker Lindh, the American who joined the Taliban. It will be interesting to see how the less famously politicized artists, like the electro-pop singer Peaches and the freak-folk troubadour Mr. Banhart, will place themselves in this context. (Monday at 8 p.m., Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Manhattan, (212) 564-4882; $28 to $150.)

title: 10 Years After Girl's Murder, DNA Link Results in Arrest
description: COLCHESTER, Conn., March 16 - For almost a decade after her body was found in a Florida river, there was no suspect in the death of Cherie Morrisette, 11. But the police here announced on Thursday that a New Britain man would be charged with her rape and murder after a DNA database linked him to the crime.

title: Class Sizes Still Too Large in New York, Hevesi Finds
description: New York City's classes in kindergarten through third grade have gotten smaller over the past six years, according to a state audit released yesterday. But the audit, by Alan G. Hevesi, the state comptroller, found that the classes are still larger than they should be under state policy, despite a decline in enrollment in those grades and an influx of nearly $500 million in state money earmarked for class size reduction.

title: Chirac seeks to calm anger in France over new labor law
South Koreans catching baseball fever
Has Blair stayed too long?
It Was a Sailor's Life for Them, Back in 1812
description: STANDING on the deck of the U.S.S. Constitution in a snapping breeze, hearing the halyards clank and looking skyward at the rigging, can make anyone feel like a sailor. Add in a maritime museum with cannons and hammocks, a World War II destroyer to explore and a panoramic view of Boston Harbor from the Bunker Hill Monument, and for both adults and children, a day at the Charlestown Navy Yard makes for a satisfying taste of going down to the sea in ships.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Accountant Charged In Salvation Army Theft
description: An accountant who worked in the Manhattan office of the Salvation Army was charged yesterday with stealing $166,914 from the charity, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, announced. The accountant, Winferd F. Keaton, 45, of Edison, N.J., worked at the Salvation Army from April 2004 to December 2005, and was responsible for keeping records for a homeless shelter and a drop-in center, prosecutors said. During that time, prosecutors said, Mr. Keaton deposited 51 Salvation Army checks in his personal account. He converted about half the money to cash, prosecutors said, and used the rest to pay bills, including restitution to another charity he stole from.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Scripps Buys Web Company
description: The E. W. Scripps Company said that it had bought the British Internet company uSwitch.com for $366 million to expand its Internet price comparison business. The purchase of the closely held uSwitch, which helps users compare prices of a variety of services, adds to the Shopzilla search engine that Scripps bought in July. Scripps, which is based in Cincinnati, said the uSwitch deal would cut profit 10 cents to 15 cents a share this year. "The online price comparison business is just in its infancy," Frederick Searby, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities, wrote in a note to investors. "The acquisition could launch Shopzilla into new pricing categories, notably services, in the U.S." Scripps shares fell $1.70, or 3.5 percent, to $46.30.

title: Stocks: Economic data bolster U.S. shares
Braids of Faith at Baba's Temple: A Hindu-Muslim Idyll
description: VARANASI, India - They came to banish ghosts, find a cure for eczema, seek succor for a cheating husband or an unruly child. Their feet bare, their heads covered, the believers, both Hindu and Muslim, entered the shrine in droves, stopping only to kiss each stair.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ground Broken For Industrial Center
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg broke ground yesterday on a 33,000-square-foot production and distribution center for Brass Masters, which makes brass fixtures in India and sells them to specialty hardware stores, architects and interior designers in the United States. The center, which is in East New York and should be completed this year, is expected to cost $2.7 million and to employ 45 people. The company is one of the first to benefit from a program by the mayor's Office of Industrial and Manufacturing Businesses that grants a one-time tax credit of up to $1,000 per employee for companies that establish a new job in any of the city's 16 new industrial business zones. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: China drops at least part of case against researcher
NCAA Tournament: Tennessee avoids first-round upset on last-gasp jumper
Who Is This Masked Avenger? Guy Fawkes, Count of Monte Cristo or a Clone?
description: Thumb suckers of the world unite, the most hotly anticipated film of the, er, week, "V for Vendetta," has arrived, complete with manufactured buzz and some apparently genuine British outrage. Concocted by the same team behind the "Matrix" franchise, this future-shock story about a masked avenger at war with a totalitarian British regime was drawn along the usual Orwellian lines but is clearly meant to have more than a passing resemblance to our current political environment.

description: GLASS--Wendy, 80, on March 15, 2006. Loving mother of Robin Chess and Tim Glass. Adoring grandmother of Jamar, Jasmine, Sam and Rebecca. Dear sister of Nathan Davis and the late Natalie and Ellen. Graveside service, Woodlawn Cemetery 12 noon Friday March 17. Contributions in her memory may be made to City Harvest, Inc. 575 8th Ave, 4 floor, NY, NY 10018.

description: MEXICO CITY, March 16 - Analysts say they are skeptical of news this week from the Mexican state oil monopoly that exploratory drilling in the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico shows signs of a giant new oil field.

description: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Svetozar Ristovski Not rated; 103 minutes

description: BURCHENAL--Joseph. We celebrate Joe's life as a pioneer in the field of cancer treatment and research and the man who shaped our careers and had tremendous impact on our lives. description: DALLAS, March 16  The loudest cheer to reverberate through Oral Roberts University's golden-themed campus this year may have occurred during an announcement at student chapel in January.

title: Corrections
description: A sports chart on Tuesday showing the pairings for the N.C.A.A. women's basketball tournament included an outdated reference to the 13th-seeded team in the Cleveland Regional. It is Missouri State; its name was changed last August from Southwest Missouri State. The chart also misstated the dates of the national semifinals and final in Boston. They are April 2 and 4, not April 1 and 3.

title: Panicis the real danger
B.J. and Tony Morris's Free Flying Adventures
description: Like most of us running out for a quart of milk to the corner store, B.J. and Tony Morris run out to other states and countries because they can fly for free, using employee passes from Delta Air lines where both formerly worked. The Atlanta couple takes elaborate trips to Europe and elsewhere, but what seems most notable are the mundane trips. Mostly they fly first class or business class. The following dates are taken from a logbook maintained by the Morris's and interviews with the couple.

title: Boston College's Victory Is True to Form
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 16 - Boston College is a team that never rattles but rarely dominates. The Eagles execute well enough to have won nine straight overtime games, but the same team that plays possession-for-possession with Duke can't easily dispatch Drake or Stony Brook.

title: Arts, Briefly; Masur Drops Out of American Concert Tour
description: A lingering viral infection has left Kurt Masur too exhausted to conduct, forcing him to cancel his appearances with the London Philharmonic Orchestra on its American tour, including concerts at Lincoln Center on Monday and March 26. "He is on the mend, but he does not yet have the energy to come back full speed," Stefana Atlas, his agent, said. Mr. Masur, right, is resting at his home in Leipzig, Germany, she said, and hopes to be back for his next scheduled engagements at the beginning of April, with the Bavarian State Opera Orchestra in Munich. He fell ill during a concert in Dublin on March 5. Organizers were hoping he could join the 16-concert tour with the London Philharmonic, of which he is the principal conductor, until he decided this week to cancel the whole thing. Roberto Minczuk will take his place on Monday, conducting Dvorak's Symphony No. 8. In the same concert, Anne-Sophie Mutter, who was to have performed the Beethoven Violin Concerto with Mr. Masur on the podium, will instead play Mozart's Concertos Nos. 1 and 3, and conduct the orchestra herself. Yan Pascal Tortelier will conduct on March 26, as well as on many of the tour's other dates; Neeme Jarvi will take over at the Tilles Center on Long Island and at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark this weekend.

title: Screeners reportedly fail security test at airports
Gourmet Paris fare going to the dogs
France and Germany Converge Uneasily Over a Piano Keyboard

He was born in 1961 in Lyon to a French father who played the violin and a German mother who was his first piano teacher.

title: House Approves $4.2 Billion in Aid Sought by Louisiana

But Louisiana officials and the Bush administration succeeded yesterday in persuading the House to approve $4.2 billion in hurricane relief that state officials say is crucial to their effort to rebuild houses and apartments ruined by last year's storms.

Metro Briefing | New York: Ground Zero Worker Dies Of Cancer
description: A paramedic who died of lung cancer on Wednesday may be recognized under a new law meant to provide increased benefits to responders who became ill working on the World Trade Center site. The paramedic, Deborah Reeve, 40, who worked at ground zero in the months after 9/11, developed a persistent cough, and in late 2003 was told she had mesothelioma, an asbestos-related form of cancer, said her husband, David Reeve. Patrick Bahnken, president of the union local representing emergency medical technicians and paramedics, said that a medical board had approved Ms. Reeve's benefits under the new law, and that a final determination would be taken up in April. KAREEM FAHIM (NYT)

Lukashenko's administration has intensified the atmosphere of fear and tension, arresting dozens of campaign workers and other opponents. On Thursday his security chief warned that any opponents who gathered to protest the election's outcome could face criminal charges for terrorism.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dermatologist Sentenced To 20 Years
description: David Wexler, a former dermatologist, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 20 years in prison for illegal narcotics distribution after he improperly prescribed drugs like Xanax and Percocet for a patient in an insurance fraud scheme. He was convicted of submitting thousands of false claims to Medicare for surgery on Barry Abler, including claims for 1,300 facial incisions. Mr. Wexler collected $425,000 for the claims, the trial showed, and he paid Mr. Abler $700 a month and supplied him with drugs to secure his cooperation. Mr. Abler died of a drug overdose in May 2001. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

Although it includes a plan to comply with a court order requiring more education aid for New York City, it is not clear whether the proposal would, in fact, comply, according to the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, which sued over the state's education financing system.

Jesse Jackson and others have denounced the vote, saying that with so many of the city's residents still displaced, it will disenfranchise blacks. ADAM NOSSITER (NYT)

Tanenbaum, to the development of the Linux operating system. While the system's creator, Linus Torvalds, has acknowledged the influence of Mr. Tanenbaum's Minix system on his own work, no Minix code was incorporated into Linux.

title: Subtlety Steps Aside, and an Adventurer Emerges
description: Over the course of a 35-year association with the German record label ECM, the pianist Bobo Stenson has earned a reputation for subtlety, sonority and a gently shimmering kind of abstraction. Yet Mr. Stenson, Sweden's pre-eminent jazz musician, has always been an adventurer, with a more dynamic approach than his recordings might suggest. The finest and most frustrating thing about his ECM output -- including his last two trio releases, "Serenity" in 2000 and "Goodbye" in 2005 -- is the undercurrent of risk that swirls, often unseen, beneath the music's glassy surface.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Attack In Chelsea Clothing Shop
description: Two men were pistol-whipped and one was shot in the leg yesterday afternoon during a robbery in Chelsea, according to the police and a victim. At 4:10 p.m., a man entered a third-floor shop at 1160 Broadway, a commercial building at West 27th Street that houses mainly clothing wholesalers. He struck the owner, Tim Sarder, 41, and an employee, Shamsudin Haq, in the head with a handgun and fled with cash. Mr. Sarder said that after he and Mr. Haq left to seek help, the attacker shot Mr. Haq as he was going down the stairs. The police said he was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center and was expected to recover. COLIN MOYNIHAN (NYT)

title: Four Dead in Accident on Thruway
description: TUXEDO, N.Y., March 17 A Four people, including three children, were killed this morning on the New York State Thruway when a tractor-trailer collided into a van whose driver had been checking for a possible flat tire, the New York State Police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANSEN, WENDY GRISWOLD HOWES
description: HANSEN--Wendy Griswold Howes. Born October 30, 1955. Died on March 15, 2006. She will be missed and mourned by her three children AshleyAnne Howes Hansen, William Griswald Hansen and Henry Christian Oliver Hansen. On her dying days she was surrounded by her children, her mother Jennifer, her siblings Deborah Fraser Howes, Cynthia Merrill Howes Hartnagel and Christopher John Ashley Howes; her cousins Jennifer & Geoff Judge and Maryann Casati; her aunt and uncle Margot and Jerry Judge and her nieces Magnolia and Clara Jane Swanson and her friends. Wendy's strength came from her family, especially the love of her children and her parents Jennifer Howes and Oliver Howes who died January 29, 2006 from prostate cancer. Cancer took another life with Wendy's death. Visiting hours at the Nardone Funeral Home in Peekskill, NY, Friday, March 17, 5-9 PM. Funeral services at the Nardone Funeral Home on Saturday, March 18 at 11 AM.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: $50,000 Bonds For Fire Defendants
description: A federal judge in Birmingham set bond at $50,000 each for three college students charged in the fires at rural churches last month. The defendants, Matthew L. Cloyd, Russell L. DeBusk Jr. and Benjamin N. Moseley, have been in federal custody since March 8. Anticipating the possible release, state authorities filed state arson charges early yesterday. If the men had made federal bond, they would have been immediately re-arrested and held on the state charges. JIM NOLES (NYT)
