title: Arts, Briefly; Microsoft in Deal With Epic Records
description: One day after Sony announced a delay for its forthcoming PlayStation 3 video game console, Microsoft tried to show that it was moving ahead with its Xbox 360 platform as it announced a modest promotional deal with Epic Records to provide high-definition videos as free downloads over the Xbox Live Internet service. The companies also said that Epic artists, including the singer Natasha Bedingfield, left, would play games against users over the network. As Microsoft tries to expand its foothold in the gaming market, Xbox Live has emerged as perhaps its most important weapon because its Japanese rivals -- Nintendo and Sony -- offer no similar service. So in addition to delivering worldwide gameplay, Microsoft has been offering additional video programming, like movie trailers, over the service. Later this year, Microsoft may offer a more extensive iTunes-like service that will allow Xbox 360 users to download full music tracks to the machine's hard drive. Microsoft's game unit is also trying to move into television. Earlier this week, the company announced a deal with 4Kids Entertainment, the company behind the Cabbage Patch Kids and Yu-Gi-Oh!, to develop a new television and game franchise called Viva Piata.

title: Astronomers Find the Earliest Signs Yet of a Violent Baby Universe

title: Greed vs. Good at Ground Zero
description: Larry Silverstein, the Manhattan developer, nearly came to a deal with public officials this week about who would build what at ground zero. The terms were overly generous to Mr. Silverstein, and he was very lucky to get them. The Port Authority would have taken over the construction of the Freedom Tower, which is expected to be the new focus of the Lower Manhattan skyline. Mr. Silverstein would have gotten control over three other prime sites nearby and many other benefits, including a substantial reduction in his rent. He would also have been appointed as the "development adviser" on the Freedom Tower -- a post that would command a hefty fee and almost no risk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDEN, PATRICIA
description: LINDEN--Patricia, 80, of New York City. On March 9th. She had been in failing health for several years. She leaves behind her beloved son and daughter-in-law, Peter and Joanne Linden of Houston and her grandson, Christopher Linden of Nashville. A highly regarded editor, journalist and author, she wrote a number of in-depth articles on a wide range of topics for a number of magazines. She served as Contributing Editor for Boston Magazine and Town & Country Magazine under Frank Zachary for whom she wrote primarily in the 1970s and 1980s. She also was a contributing writer for such publications as Avenue, Esquire, Harper's Bazaar, Reader's Digest, Travel & Leisure, Ultra and Veranda. Additionally, she briefly published I.D. Confidential, a newsletter for interior design professionals. In the early part of her career in Boston, she worked as a copywriter and became the owner of an advertising agency, Imagination, Inc. Later she became Editor of Epicure Magazine. Published under the aegis of S.S. Pierce Co., Epicure was one of the first glossy magazines devoted to fine cuisine. Ms. Linden was also the author of several books. Her titles included: Cooking with Bernard, Levin's Laws, Living in Style, The Woman's Selling Game and Women & Work. Funeral services will be private.

title: Smaller Than a Football Field
description: According to the National Association of Home Builders, the average size of an American house these days is a little over 2,300 square feet. That number, like the average American shoe size, seems to be steadily increasing. (The two are not necessarily correlated.) But when it comes to Greenwich, Conn., you can forget about average. Greenwich is a town of big incomes, big egos and big houses, including one that, even in the planning stages, riled its potential neighbors. When a hedge-fund manager wanted to build a 39,000-square-foot house in Conyers Farm, a neighborhood -- i.e., a closely guarded development -- that includes the 27,000-square-foot house of David Stockman, President Reagan's budget director, even Greenwich, where only shoe size is average, was startled.

title: After a Half-Century, Taking a Census of Hockney's People
description: BOSTON  Around 1966, when Pop, Minimalism and Color Field painting were the preferred options for a serious artist, the British painter and Los Angeles resident David Hockney embarked on a daring exploration of what was then thought irretrievably retrograde: realist painting. Over the next decade, he created full-figure portraits of people, alone or in couples, that were as intimate as they were monumental and as poetically thrilling as they were visually lucid. The best of them can still be counted among the most memorable artworks of the postmodernist era.

title: Top Birder Challenges Reports of Long-Lost Woodpecker
description: The ivory billed woodpecker? That is the bird that went extinct and was rediscovered, and then there was some argument. But it is all settled now, and the great creature lives, elusively, in an Arkansas swamp, with a chunk of federal money to keep it comfortable. Right?

To celebrate, the Mets' network gave itself a party on the plaza outside its studio on Avenue of the Americas. YES had no gala outside its Manhattan office or its Stamford studio, but at the time the Yankees' channel was enmeshed in what would be a yearlong boycott by Cablevision.

title: The Listings: March 17 - March 23; EUGENE ANDOLSEK: 'KALEIDOSCOPIC VISIONARY DRAWINGS'
description: In 1953 Eugene Andolsek began to draw in the evenings at his kitchen table partly to relieve the persistent anxiety that he was going to be fired from his job as an office worker, and he continued to do so for the next 50 years. He never thought of his hair-raisingly beautiful drawings as serious art, but he did save them in trunks. Recently, an attendant in the assisted-living center in western Pennsylvania where Mr. Andolsek now lives discovered his drawings, of which there are thousands. Then a series of fortuitous connections brought them to the attention of Brooke Davis Anderson, a curator at the American Folk Art Museum, and she put some in "Obsessive Drawing," an exhibition that remains on view at the museum through Sunday. Another display of Mr. Andolsek's work at the American Primitive Gallery is his first solo show. Mr. Andolsek, who no longer draws because of failing eyesight, worked on graph paper using rulers, compasses and black ink to generate linear patterns, which he then colored in with store-bought inks that he mixed to achieve nonstandard hues. The finished drawings (an example is above) variously resemble Asian mandalas, stained-glass windows, Oriental carpets, Victorian wallpaper, needlepoint and psychedelic abstractions. The drawings pack an immediate revelatory punch and then become hypnotically absorbing to study at length. You may sense something mystical in them, as if Mr. Andolsek had tapped into deep structures of consciousness. He was a humble alchemist who turned ink and paper into visionary gold. (American Primitive Gallery, 594 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1530, through April 12.)

title: The Listings: March 17 - March 23; DANCEOFF!
description: Showcases for emerging choreographers are always chancy affairs. But Terry Dean Bartlett, co-curator of Danceoff!, is pretty confident that audiences will walk away satisfied. The series, which was born at Galapagos Art Space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and has come to various theaters throughout the city, seeks to maintain a theatrical, cabaret-style aesthetic that Mr. Bartlett feels is missing from many experimental downtown performances. As Mr. Bartlett (who is also a member of the troupe Streb) sees it, serious and entertaining do not have to be mutually exclusive concepts. "I'm not a fan of dance that's treacly and pandering -- I hate that just as much as 'I'm just going to have feedback for music, not spend any time on choreography, I'm so experimental!' dance," said Mr. Bartlett (above with Katie Workum, the series co-curator). This session's roster includes work by Jonah Bokaer, a Merce Cunningham dancer who is working with motion-capture technology to combine film and live performance; Cynthia Hopkins, a 2005 Bessie Award recipient, who will present a work-in-progress excerpt from "Tsimtsum," which can be seen in its entirety at Dance Theater Workshop in April as part of the "Sourcing Stravinsky" program; Will Rawls, an elegant, captivating dancer who is worth watching no matter what he's doing; and others. For the choreographers, it's a chance to present short pieces in a relaxed workshop setting. And audiences can get a sneak peek at things to come, with the knowledge that, even if one dance is a stinker, it's only seven minutes long. (Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 and 10 p.m., Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, (212) 477-5288, ps122.org; $15; members, $10.)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Gives New Berlin Airport The Go-Ahead
description: Plans for a new international airport on the site of Schnefeld Airport in the former East Berlin can go ahead, Germany's highest administrative court ruled. Residents had filed some 4,000 complaints in an effort to block the $2 billion project. The court imposed restrictions on night flights from midnight to 5 a.m. The new airport, Berlin-Brandenburg International, is to open by 2010. The more centrally located Tegel, Berlin's busiest airport, and the Nazi-era Tempelhof Airport will then be closed. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

title: A Last-Gasp Shot Allows the Volunteers to Exhale

title: Sane Chinese Put in Asylum, Doctors Find

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLANIGAN, BRIGID SNOW
description: FLANIGAN--Brigid Snow. Beloved wife of 51 years of Peter Flanigan, died peacefully on March 16, 2006. Mrs. Flanigan was the mother of Brigid S. Lezak of Portland, OR; Sister Louise Marie Flanigan of Birmingham, AL; Dr. Timothy Flanigan of Tiverton, RI; Megan Skakel of Greenwich, CT; and Robert Flanigan of NYC; and grandmother of 14 grandchildren. Mrs. Flanigan was the daughter of George Palen Snow and Carmel Snow of Long Island and NYC. Throughout her life, Mrs. Flanigan was interested in education, serving at her death on the Board of the Purchase College Foundation of SUNY College at Purchase, and on the Advisory Board of St. Ann Elementary School, on 110th Street in Manhattan. She attended Brearley School, Foxcroft School and Barnard College. Friends may visit at 220 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, NY, from 4:30 PM to 8:00 PM, on Sunday, March 19. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said at Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY, at 11:00 AM, on Monday, March 20. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to your favorite charity.

Or so it proves to be for Jan Maxwell, in the underpowered revival of Joe Orton's "Entertaining Mr. Sloane" that opened last night at the Laura Pels Theater. Ms. Maxwell, who last year snatched personal victory (and a Tony nomination) from the yawning jaws of the defeat called "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang," again demonstrates that she is one of our most ingenious actresses, retailoring an ill-fitting part to her own specifications and making it as snug as a glove.

title: Some Old Irish Songs With Punk and Pop
description: Shane MacGowan took the stage yesterday evening, intoning some profane verses from Lou Reed's "Sister Ray," and then the Pogues fired into "Streams of Whiskey." When Mr. MacGowan removed his sunglasses, a few songs into his first performance in New York with the band in 15 years, you could look him in the eyes. Not the whites of them: he looked half-asleep, heavy-lidded, his face a slack, puffy frown surrounding missing teeth. The upper third of his face, anyway, was the most expressive part of his body.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Antiviral Drug Sales Rose After Flu Reports
description: Data collected by the state and city Health Departments show a sharp spike in purchases of antiviral medications last October, after news reports about avian influenza and the potential for a pandemic. The data showed a 67 percent increase above normal in purchases of antiviral medicines used to treat the flu, according to a report from the federal Centers for Disease Control. Health officials have warned that taking antiviral medicines as a precaution could mean they are unavailable when needed during an actual outbreak and could lead to the development of drug resistance by viruses. MARC SANTORA (NYT)

title: Colorful and Clashing: Looking at Africa
description: IF Martians tuned in to our television news broadcasts, they'd have a miserable impression of life on Earth. War, disease, poverty, heartbreak and nothing else. That's exactly how most of the world sees Africa: filtered through images of calamity. "Afro-pessimism" is the diagnostic term that Okwui Enwezor, the Nigerian-born art historian and curator, uses for the syndrome. And he has offered bracing antidotes to it in two major photography exhibitions.

description: Ray Meyer, a Hall of Fame basketball coach at DePaul University who launched his career by tutoring an awkward sophomore named George Mikan and went on to win 724 games over 42 seasons, died today, the school's athletic director, Jean Lenti Ponsetto, told The Associated Press. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, JAMES H.
description: SCHWARTZ--James H. Columbia University Medical Center lost one of its leaders in neurobiology with the passing of James H. Schwartz, M.D., Ph.D. Dr. Schwartz was Professor of Physiology & Cellular Biophysics, Psychiatry, and Neurology (in the Center for Neurobiology and Behavior) at the College of Physicians & Surgeons. Dr. Schwartz joined Columbia in 1974 when he and Nobelist Eric Kandel moved their collaborative research from NYU to P&S and the New York State Psychiatric Institute. Their collaboration is credited with contributing to the modern transformation of electrophysiology into molecular neuroscience. Dr. Schwartz was one of the original editors of the extraordinary textbook in neuroscience, "Principles in Neural Science," which will soon be published in its fifth edition. Dr. Schwartz left an important legacy in neuroscience at Columbia, and we were proud to have him as a colleague and mentor. We extend our sympathies to his family. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President, Columbia University Medical Center Dean, College of Physicians & Surgeons

I'm serious about this. On a platform stage, holding a ball, there was the late, great Holzman, with that trademark wry smile, stonewalling his way through another interview, as was his wont throughout his career.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLOY, HERB
description: ALLOY - Herb. In sym pathy--The United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County, Inc. deeply regrets the loss of a devoted Board member and tireless supporter of our agency, Herb Alloy. Mr. Alloy became actively involved with UCPN in 1959, joining the Board of Directors in 1977. The following year he was asked to serve as one of the Association's Vice Presidents, a position he held until 1991. Among Mr. Alloy's many achievements was the founding of the organization's Business & Industry Fundraising Campaign, which raised over $2 million under his Chairmanship. He was currently a member of the Executive Committee as well as Admissions & Discharge, Budget & Finance, and the Bayville Committees. Herb Alloy's 47 years of dedication and involvement have had a profound impact on the services provided to the children and adults with disabilities at UCPN, and his wisdom and guidance shall be sorely missed. We express our deepest sympathies to his wife, Natalie, and his family and friends. Thomas Connolly, President

National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Jury Deadlocks In Arson Trial
description: A deadlocked jury led a federal judge to declare a mistrial in a case against two men charged in the December 2004 arsons that caused $10 million damage to a subdivision in southern Maryland. On its fifth day of deliberations, the jury told the judge, Roger W. Titus of Federal District Court, that it could not reach a verdict in the case against men, Michael M. Everhart, 21, and Roy T. McCann, 23, both of Waldorf. Prosecutors said they planned to retry the men. The blazes destroyed or heavily damaged 26 unoccupied houses at the Hunters Brooke subdivision in Indian Head, 25 miles south of Washington. GARY GATELY (NYT)

title: New York, naturally
From Flirtation to Fury: A Nail-Bomber's London Tale
description: Anyone who wants to see what British physical theater at its finest is all about need look no further than Performance Space 122, where a piece called "Sinner" by a group called Stan Won't Dance has taken over the upstairs space through Sunday. I saw it Wednesday night, and thought it the best dance event of the season.

title: One Woman's Happiness and Hysteria
description: Clouds of gorgeous music float through the Italian melodrama "Don't Tell" like soap suds in a bubble bath. That music, composed by Franco Piersanti, defines the dreamy tone of a psychological mystery that begins with a Hitchcockian nightmare and develops into a protracted, "Marnie"-like detective story. As promising as its premise may sound, the movie never pulls itself out of the bathtub, and eventually the suds melt into an oily scum.

title: After a Half-Century, Taking a Census of Hockney's People
description: BOSTON - Around 1966, when Pop, Minimalism and Color Field painting were the preferred options for a serious artist, the British painter and Los Angeles resident David Hockney embarked on a daring exploration of what was then thought irretrievably retrograde: realist painting. Over the next decade, he created full-figure portraits of people, alone or in couples, that were as intimate as they were monumental and as poetically thrilling as they were visually lucid. The best of them can still be counted among the most memorable artworks of the postmodernist era.

title: When Latvian Eyes Are Smiling
description: Milford, Mich. - LAST year they opened a new Irish pub on Main Street here. O'Callaghan's they call it, and it's owned by two Palestinians who did it up in high Paddy style, with snugs and dark hardwoods, Guinness and designer lagers and a couple of imported boyos behind the bar. The dcor came from Dublin in a kit. The lads came on their own from Wexford to pull pints, pour shots and give out with the brogue-y chat that separates an Irish pub from every other kind.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Parliament Set To Investigate Help For U.S. In Iraq Invasion
description: Three opposition parties -- the Greens, the Left Party and the Free Democrats -- have secured enough votes for a formal parliamentary investigation into allegations that the German intelligence service helped the United States during the invasion of Iraq, which the German government vehemently opposed. The government has been trying to head off an investigation. A vote to set up an inquiry is expected at the end of the month. The inquiry would also focus on whether Germany served as a silent partner of the United States in the abduction of Khaled el-Masri, a German citizen of Arab descent who was taken to an American prison in Kabul, Afghanistan, where he said he was held and tortured for five months after being mistaken for a terrorism suspect, and on the purpose of hundreds of C.I.A. flights between 2001 and 2005 that crossed German airspace. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNARD, CHARLES W., III(CHICK)
description: BARNARD--Charles W., III(Chick) Retired Senior International Insurance Executive for American Foreign Insurance Association and Cigna, died March 11, 2006 at the age of 80. A native of Newburgh, he graduated from Storm King School and then served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during W.W. II. Chick graduated from Amherst College in 1949 and began his successful insurance career with his first posting in Calcutta, India. Later service with the company took him back and forth to a variety of positions in Japan and the United States. He retired in 1985 and settled in Cape Cod, moving to Jacksonville, FL in 2004. Chick was an avid tennis player and was active in alumni affairs for Amherst College. He was widely respected for his achievements and experience in the insurance industry. Chick is survived by his wife Margaret (nee Blue) "Brownie" Barnard, his sons Andrew (Sarah) of Dobbs Ferry, NY and Daniel of Boston, daughter Adrienne (Daniel) Dahlberg of Missoula, MT, two grandchildren Samantha Barnard and Benjamin Dahlberg. Another son, Stephen, died in 1979. Funeral service at 9:30 AM Monday, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry (Saw Mill Exit 17). Visiting Sunday 79PM. Those wishing to make a memorial contribution may donate to The National Parkinson's Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Ave., Miami, FL 33136.

The Listings: March 17 - March 23; RICHARD EGARR
description: The cozy concert room at the Frick Collection has become one of the best places to get a first hearing of instrumentalists and singers who are new to New York but have thriving careers elsewhere. On Sunday, the Frick introduces Richard Egarr, a British harpsichordist who will make his New York debut playing Bach's "Goldberg" Variations. Mr. Egarr, above, plays music from the 15th century to the present, but thanks to an enormous and quickly proliferating discography, he is becoming known best for his thoughtful, inventive performances of Baroque works, as both a soloist and an ensemble player. A recent recording of the Bach Concertos, with Andrew Manze and the Academy of Ancient Music, on the Harmonia Mundi label, was richly endowed with fresh phrasing ideas and an irresistible energy, as were collaborations with Mr. Manze on the Biber "Rosary" Sonatas and works by Corelli and Handel. Mr. Egarr's latest recording, also for Harmonia Mundi, is an involving traversal of the work he is playing on Sunday, the Bach "Goldbergs," along with the 14 "Goldberg" Canons that were discovered in 1974. A firm believer that this music was tailor-made for the harpsichord, however compelling it may sound on the piano, Mr. Egarr produces a rich sound that sings in the slow variations and roars in the brisker, more forceful ones. This breadth of tone is a good thing: he takes every last variation in his 90-minute account, but the work seems to zip by in no time. (5 p.m., the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 547-0709; $20. Sold out.)

Actually sitting among that cowardly crew must be maddening.

title: A Colossus Is Camping in the Met's Great Hall
description: Correction Appended

title: BAA turns down bid
A few greats spur a frenzy of buying at Maastricht fair
Corrections
description: The Joe Nocera column in Business Day on Saturday, about prediction markets, in which groups of people guess or bet on something with the results aggregated into a consensus, misstated a line from the actor Geoffrey Rush in "Shakespeare in Love" that was used to explain how the aggregated information tended to reflect events accurately. He said, "It's a mystery," not a miracle.

title: Hamas Would Keep Fatah Out of Palestinian Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM, March 17 A The leaders of the Islamic group Hamas said today that it would propose a new Palestinian cabinet consisting of Hamas and independent figures, with the participation of no other party. Hamas said it expected to give the list to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Saturday after Mr. Abbas's Fatah faction announced, as expected, that it would not participate.

title: Should the President Be Censured? (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
Smoke 'Em if You Got 'Em; His Career Depends on It
description: Glibly funny and eager to please, the film version of Christopher Buckley's novel "Thank You for Smoking" is not unlike the down-and-dirty habit of its title. Like cigarettes, this wisp of a film from the newcomer Jason Reitman won't do much for your brain cells, but it may provide some transitory pleasure from its ostensible equal-opportunity political skewering. Certainly for admirers of its star, the consistently reliable Aaron Eckhart, who plays Nick Naylor, the fast-jiving, fast-running cigarette lobbyist who holds the story together even as he almost falls apart, there is something rather nice about lighting up together, as it were, even by proxy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAEBER, RUTH R.
description: GRAEBER--Ruth R. Died March 15. A women of many talents, her death is a great loss to her many friends, her surviving son David, and the organizations for which she worked as a volunteer. Christine Volkmar

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lower Inflation in Labor Department Report May Mean End to Interest Rate Increases Inflation slowed sharply last month, the Labor Department reported, providing comfort to many investors that the Federal Reserve might be moving closer to ending its campaign of raising interest rates. [Page C1.]

title: Ann Calvello, 76, a Legend in Roller Derby's Rowdy Rinks, Dies
description: Ann Calvello, whose bad-girl attitude, madcap makeup, polka-dot hair and savage style of play made her a legend in the flamboyantly indecorous sport-cum-circus that is roller derby, died on Tuesday at a hospital near her home in San Bruno, Calif. She was 76.

title: Where to Go for a Good Talking To
description: An abundance of lectures can be found every month around the city. Here is a sampling:

title: Should the President Be Censured?
description: To the Editor:

title: Deep Underground, Toiling for $2.50 a Day
description: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Richard Ladkani and Kief Davidson Not rated; 82 minutes

title: Fighter Jet Partners Pressure the Pentagon to Share More of Its Critical Technology
description: The F-35 Joint Strike Fighter -- a $256 billion fighter jet program led by the United States and co-financed by eight allied nations -- was supposed to be a model of international cooperation. But because of American reluctance to share critical technologies, some of the biggest partners are threatening to withdraw.

title: Yukos founder's charity is targeted
Nuclear Reactors Found to Be Leaking Radioactive Water
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend last Friday misstated a film title at one point and, because of an editing error, misspelled a co-star's surname at another. The film is "Ask the Dust," not "Ask the Dusk," and the co-star is Colin Farrell, not Ferrell.

title: Microsoft Reveals Plan to Take Business From I.B.M.
description: Microsoft began a $500 million marketing campaign yesterday to stir enthusiasm among corporate customers for its new products and grab business from I.B.M., its biggest rival in the business technology market.

title: Diesel! The Musical
description: Diesel! The Musical

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Teacher In 'Crucible' Case Quits
description: The drama teacher at a high school in Fulton, where the school superintendent canceled a production of Arthur Miller's "Crucible" to avoid controversy, has resigned. The teacher, Wendy DeVore, quit on Tuesday, after she had criticized the superintendent's handling of the matter in a message to a Web log that found its way back to school officials. Ms. DeVore said she was told her remarks bordered on insubordination and would make it difficult to persuade the school board to extend her contract next year. In an e-mail message, Ms. DeVore said she "finally had enough of being put under a microscope." Kathy Wright, a district spokeswoman, said federal privacy laws prevented her from commenting on the resignation. DIANA JEAN SCHEMO (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, WALLACE
description: GREENBERG--Wallace. Rest in peace. Sheila & Fred Small, Susan & Julia Presten, and Jennifer Small & Adam Wolfensohn

title: U.S. study on fighting terrorism finds flaws
World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Goldman To Start New Firm
description: Goldman Sachs ended a joint venture with an Indian financial company and announced that it would establish its own investment banking and securities firm in India. "The Indian market represents tremendous growth and opportunity," L. Brooks Entwistle, chief executive of Goldman Sachs India, said in a statement. "Now, more than ever, there is a compelling case for us to build an onshore presence which is fully integrated with our global businesses." The company ended its decade-old collaboration with the Indian financial house Kotak, selling its 25 percent stakes in two ventures with Kotak Mahindra Bank for $75 million. Several global investment banks are rapidly expanding in India, where economic output has grown 8 percent in the last two years. SARITHA RAI (NYT)

title: Seniors Show Rookie Coach How It's Done in March
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 16 - When Wisconsin-Milwaukee opened the season with a 27-point loss to Memphis and lost again in the third game of the season to Tennessee Tech, there was some concern that the Panthers, with four returning senior starters, were going to be ruined by a change of coaches.

title: Judge Rejects Tankleff's Bid for New Trial
description: In a case that has drawn national attention and criticism from criminal justice experts, a judge today rejected a prisoner's appeal to overturn his convictions for the murders of his parents in their waterfront home on Long Island in 1988.

title: Peter Halasz, 62, Playwright Who Staged His Funeral as Theater, Is Dead
description: Peter Halasz, a Hungarian-born avant-garde playwright, actor and director, who founded the Squat/Love Theater collective, an Off Off Broadway ensemble of the 1980's, died last Thursday at the home of a daughter in Brooklyn. He was 62 and lived in Budapest and Staten Island.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Alpine: New York Police Official Guilty In Highway Altercation
description: A deputy commissioner in the New York Police Department, Garry McCarthy, was found guilty yesterday in connection with an altercation a year ago with two New Jersey police officers. Mr. McCarthy, a deputy commissioner of operations who oversees the Compstat crime-tracking program, was fined $200 for blocking traffic during a Feb. 18, 2005 dispute at a gas station along the Palisades Interstate Parkway. Mr. McCarthy approached two plainclothes members of the Palisades Interstate Police who had just issued a summons to Mr. McCarthy's 19-year-old daughter, who was driving another car. A judge ruled that Mr. McCarthy had blocked traffic with his police-issued vehicle while he and his wife confronted the officers. The officers grabbed Mr. McCarthy's gun and handcuffed him, and restrained his wife when she attempted to recover the gun.

title: As Senators Debate Immigration Bill, Frist Offers His Own
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - Senator Bill Frist, the Republican leader, introduced a stringent border security bill on Thursday, rejecting pleas from senators in his own party who appealed for more time to finish legislation that would create a guest worker program for foreigners and a legal remedy for millions of illegal immigrants already in the United States.

title: Grasso Said to Have Refused Questions in Trading Inquiry
description: Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, invoked his right not to incriminate himself during a deposition last June by the Securities and Exchange Commission, a lawyer in the New York attorney general's office said yesterday.

title: An Extended Version of the Saturday Interview
description: In its fourth- quarter earnings report, packaged goods giant Procter & Gamble had one particularly dark cloud in a generally bright update: Hurricane Katrina was making a mess of its coffee business, 50 percent of which is produced at four facilities in New Orleans that were impacted by the Aug. 29 hurricane.Though the plants were among the first back in operation after the hurricane struck on Aug. 29, there are still, as Doug McGraw, the executive in charge of vice president of global coffee for Procter & Gamble, put it, Aholes on the shelvesA where Folgers and Millstone, ProcterAs brands, should be. Mr. McGraw spoke recently about the coffee business, the impact of the hurricane and how the business is doing now.

title: The War in Iraq: Critics Left and Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Who, Regenerated
description: Christopher Eccleston, below, stars on the Sci Fi Channel in a remake of the cult-favorite British series about an extraterrestrial who time-travels in a phone booth.

title: Sensitive New Age Guys in Training
description: FOR young women today, Chicago seems to be the new Alaska -- a remote, primitive place where single men are plentiful and still relatively unspoiled.

title: Other views: Le Monde, Chicago Tribune, Montreal Gazette
Mediator Says Transit Talks Should Go to Arbitration
description: Correction Appended

title: Regional Transit Council Puts Hudson Tunnel on List
description: A group of New York political leaders and transportation officials threw their support yesterday behind a project that would start in New Jersey -- a $6 billion rail tunnel under the Hudson River.

title: A Texas Festival Recalls Ye Olde Club-Hopping Days
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 16 - What moves faster: a song or an airplane?

title: An Old Spot Revives With a New Outlook
description: WHEN Whaleback was taking a dive toward dormancy in 2001, Damian Biron, 12, of North Sutton, N.H., saw the signs of trouble for the beloved but beleaguered ski area in Enfield, N.H. "We knew they were shutting down," he said, "because they had all these really great deals, like $5 tickets and ladies' specials."

title: Expressing Eagerness to Build, Developer of 9/11 Site Asks Pataki to Revive Talks
description: Still reeling from the collapse of talks on the rebuilding of ground zero, the developer Larry A. Silverstein implored Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday to resume negotiations in the interest of "getting the World Trade Center rebuilt."

title: Embracing Islamic art from Southeast Asia
Caught Up in DNA's Growing Web
description: THE announcement this week that DNA from a paroled violent felon working as a bouncer matches that found on plastic ties used to bind a murdered graduate student highlights DNA's power to implicate people already in state databases.

title: The War in Iraq: Critics Left and Right (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: After Jagr Shoulders the Blame, Rangers Help Carry the Load
description: Steve Rucchin called it the biggest goal of the Rangers' season.

title: A Film Prompts Observations About God
description: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Francesco Cabras and Alberto Molinari Not rated, 75 minutes

title: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: 3 Ex-Presidents Face Charges Over Foreign Oil Deals
description: Moving on a complaint filed by leftist groups, Attorney General Pedro Gareca charged three former presidents and eight former energy ministers with violating the Constitution in signing dozens of contracts with foreign energy companies over the last decade without Congress's approval, Bolivian radio reported, according to Reuters. The contracts, which included oil companies in Brazil, France and Spain, attracted billions of dollars in investments, but angered groups that accused the firms of plundering Bolivia's resources. The government of President Evo Morales is now renegotiating contracts that will cost the companies much more in taxes and royalties. The charges, which also include "economic crimes," were leveled against former Presidents Carlos Mesa, Gonzalo Snchez de Lozada and Jorge Quiroga. JUAN FORERO (NYT)

title: Softbank to Buy Vodafone Mobile Unit
description: TOKYO, March 17 A Softbank, the Tokyo-based Internet company, will buy Vodafone's Japanese cellphone unit in a deal worth $15.4 billion, the companies said Friday, ending the British mobile giant's bruising foray into one of the world's largest and toughest markets.

title: SETBACK FOR KAZ MATSUI
description: The Mets' Kazuo Matsui enlisted a private coach during the off-season to help him limit the injuries that have dominated his two disappointing seasons. No exercise could have prevented the knee injury Matsui sustained during the first inning of last night's 6-5 victory over Atlanta in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: Top Birder Challenges Reports of Long-Lost Woodpecker
description: The ivory-billed woodpecker? That's the bird that went extinct, and was rediscovered, and then there was some argument but it's all settled now and the great creature lives, elusively, in an Arkansas swamp, with a chunk of federal money to keep it comfortable. Right?

title: Hamas aims to dominate new cabinet positions
A Festival of Loud Sounds for Reasonable Musicians
description: In 1981, the downtown New York art scene, full of gleefully dissonant music, prompted the rock critic Lester Bangs to write a short article for The Village Voice with the title, "A Reasonable Guide to Horrible Noise."

title: Kurds Destroy Monument in Rage at Leadership
description: Correction Appended

title: On Politics, Hedge Fund Managers Tip Their Hands
description: The hedge fund industry is not just getting bigger and richer; it is also getting more politically active.

title: Day 2 of the NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament
description: Another 16 games were played as the second-round matchups were set.

title: Mark Cuban, CEOs and the Big Lie
description: Mark Cuban has leveled criticism at plenty of people in his day, including members of the National Basketball Association and, ahem, some other people we know pretty well.

title: Venus Shadows
description: Selborne Journal: 17 March 1759:  Vast storms still. Cucumbers thrive, but not the Cantaleupes.

title: German Companies No Longer Warm and Fuzzy
description: The German chemical and drug maker Merck KGaA, which traces its beginnings to 1668, is abandoning Germanys tradition of corporate cooperation.

title: Regulators Would Share Power in Trans-Atlantic Exchange Merger
description: Securities regulators on both sides of the Atlantic would split oversight of any combination of the London Stock Exchange with an American market, officials and analysts say. Both the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq are still mulling offers for the L.S.E., but momentum appears to be building for a buyout of the exchange by one entity or the other.

title: ConAgra Sheds Seafood, Cheese Businesses
description: Focusing on what it calls its highest potential brands, ConAgra Foods Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell its seafood and cheese lines in addition to the planned sale of its refrigerated meats businesses.

title: LOreal Luxuriates in Body Shop Buy
description: LOreal SA, the worlds largest cosmetics maker, agreed to buy Body Shop International Plc, the U.K. retailer of natural beauty products started 30 years ago by Anita Roddick, for about 652 million pounds ($1.14 billion) in cash. Body Shop is becoming more valuable as the company positions itself nearer the luxury end of the cosmetics market to avoid direct competition with companies such as Tesco Plc in the U.K and Wal-Mart Stores Inc.

title: Prada Ready to Say Ciao to Helmut Lang
description: First Prada parted with Jil Sander, now it is bidding farewell to Helmut Lang. Less than a month after selling Jil Sander, Prada has inked a deal to sell the Helmut Lang brand, Womens Wear Daily reported. An announcement is expected as early as Friday. The name of the buyer could not be learned, but sources in New York indicated that it is a Japanese company. Prada declined to comment Thursday.

title: Colgate-Palmolive  Sizes Up Listerine
description: Colgate-Palmolive sees Pfizers Listerine mouthwash as something that could fit very well in its oral care product lineup, and would look at other parts of Pfizers business up for sale but would not overpay, Colgates president said on Thursday. Ian Cook, the companys president and chief operating officer, told investors at a Bank of America conference that Listerine was strategically right and that Colgate would look at buying the brand very, very aggressively.

title: Softbank Buys Vodafone Unit, Thwarting Private Equity Bid
description: Softbank , Japans second- largest Internet access provider, agreed on Friday to buy Vodafone Groups Japanese mobile-phone unit for 1.8 trillion yen ($15.4 billion) in Asias biggest leveraged buyout.

title: I.B.M. Buys Language Analysis Systems
description: I.B.M. on Thursday announced plans to acquire Language Analysis Systems, a maker of multicultural name recognition technologies. LAS technology is designed to be used for such issues as ferreting out criminals who attempt to hide their identity through multiple variations of their name.

title: North Fork Deal Caps an Investment Banks Comeback
description: This weeks sale of North Fork to Capital One for $14.6 billion was not just an important deal for both companies, it was a particularly bittersweet moment for one of the advisers, Sandler ONeill & Partners. North Fork Bancorporation has been a major client of Sandler ONeill, a boutique investment bank, for nearly two decades. In those years Sandler ONeill has seen of its 171 employees  including its founder Herman Sandler who began the relationship with North Fork head John Kanas  die in terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, only to re-emerged as an increasingly powerful force behind a bevy of midsize  and sometimes big  banking deals.

title: Lawyer of Many Hats in Tax Shelter Case
description: As Deutsche Bank negotiates with federal prosecutors on a possible settlement over questionable tax shelters, one person has an unusual degree of involvement.

title: Bear Stearns, Hub of Market Timing Abuses, Settles With S.E.C.
description: Bear Stearns  has agreed to pay $250 million to settle regulators claims that it was at the center of a system for clients to break mutual-fund trading rules.

title: Enel to Meet With European Regulator About Suez Bid
description: Enel of Italy, in an effort to drum up regulatory support for its bid to buy the French utility Suez, will meet Tuesday in Brussels with the European Unions competition commissioner, Neelie Kroes.

title: Morgan Stanley Dismisses Retail Chiefs
description: The head of the retail brokerage unit at Morgan Stanley, James P. Gorman, dismissed two of the units top sales executives on Thursday and will take direct oversight of the banks 9,526 financial advisers.

title: Earthlink Pours $50 Million into Covad
description: EarthLink said Thursday that it had made a $50 million equity investment in Covad Communications Group, a broadband access wholesaler, to fund the expansion of the companies co-developed voice services to eight new markets.

title: Soros Group Said to Be Near Deal for DreamWorks Library
description: Viacom Inc.s Paramount Pictures was near a deal last night to sell the film library of Dreamworks SKG for about $900 million to an investment fund controlled by George Soros, people involved in the talks said. The deal, which has been under negotiation for several months, is expected to be announced as early as today.

title: All Eyes on Tim Hortons I.P.O.
description: Tim Hortons plans to raise a hefty $551 million in its initial public offering next week as the doughnut chain spins off from Wendys International.

title: Optasite Gets Funding for Cell Phone Towers
description: Optasite , an owner and operator of cell phone towers, has raised a $60 million Series C round of funding to help it accommodate the growing appetites of mobile carriers  both virtual and traditional  for building out network coverage. The Series C was led by new investor Key Venture Partners.

title: British Tech Company Laird Plans Rights Issue
description: Technology and security systems group Laird is to start a 117.8 million pounds rights issue to finance acquisitions as the company announced an increase in underlying profit. Laird will offer 4 shares for every 17 held at 325 pence each, a 26.8 percent discount to Thursdays closing price, after acquiring antennae specialist Receptec for 51 million pounds.

title: British Buyout Firm May Get Physical With New York Sports Clubs
description: Town Sports International, owner of New York Sports Clubs, is in talks to be acquired by British buyout giant BC Partners in a deal that could top $650 million, The New York Post reported.

title: Halliburton Unloads KBRs Production Services Arm
description: Halliburton said on Thurday that KBR has agreed to sell the production services group, part of the companys Energy and Chemicals division, in a management buyout deal expected to close in the second quarter.

title: Apsrey, Jeweler to the Stars, Is Said to Be Close to a Sale
description: Financially troubled British luxury retailer Asprey is near a deal to be sold to a group of private investors, according to The New York Post. As part of that deal  which was reportedly being finalized last night, but could still fall apart  Aspreys New York flagship is to be closed, these people continued.

title: Behrman Capital to Triple Its Investment in Athena Sale
description: Behrman Capital is set to realize three times its investment in neurological testing company Athena Diagnostics , which it has agreed to sell to Fisher Scientific International for $283 million in cash.

title: Fewer Chiefs Also Serving as Chairmen
description: Disney did it. So did Fannie Mae, Hewlett-Packard and Dell. Most companies in Britain do it. And now, more American companies are doing it, too: wresting board chairmanships away from chief executives.

title: Chinese Construction Group I.P.O. Takes Off
description: China National Building Materials has raised $232 million from its initial public offering after strong investor interest allowed it to fix the price at the top end of the range.

title: Same Washington, Different Office
description: In the era of the Jack Abramoff scandal, former attorney general, John Ashcroft, has become a Washington lobbyist, setting himself up as something of an anti-Abramoff and marketing his insiders knowledge of how Washington works.

title: Bain Capital Amassing $10 Billion for Takeover Fund
description: Bain Capital LLC, the Boston-based buyout firm that acquired Dunkin Donuts earlier this month, is seeking $10 billion for its biggest takeover fund, Bloomberg News reported. U.S. buyout firms including Bain, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. and Blackstone Group LP are amassing record-sized funds to make larger acquisitions.

title: Citigroup Lures Morgan Stanley China Banker
description: In what has become a game of Mainland musical chairs between two of the worlds largest banks, Citigroup has announced that Morgan Stanleys former co-head of China investment banking, Jing Zhao has joined the firm. The appointment by Citigroup comes one day after Zhao left Morgan Stanley and less than two months after the bank hired Wei Christianson, from Citi, as its new managing director and China CEO.

title: France Weighs Forcing iPods to Play Other Than iTunes
description: In the digital music market, France is singing a different tune.

title: New York State Raises Cash for Israeli Start-Ups
description: The New York State pension fund is investing $100 million in a fund of funds dedicated to Israeli high-tech venture capital, said John Chartier, spokesman for New York State Comptroller Alan Hevesi. The fund, tentatively called the New York State Retirement Fund Israel Venture Fund, hasnt officially closed yet, but is already seeking investment opportunities.

title: Grasso Said to Have Refused Questions in Trading Inquiry
description: Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, invoked his right not to incriminate himself during a deposition last June by the Securities and Exchange Commission, a lawyer in the New York attorney generals office said yesterday.

title: Hank Greenberg Goes to War
description: One year after Hank Greenberg was forced out of the insurance empire he built, the wounds are still raw. Then again, his battle against AIG has only just begun, writes BusinessWeek.

title: Shifts at T. Rowe Price
description: George A. Roche, who helped build T. Rowe Price Group into an international investment manager of $270 billion and most recently served as chairman, will retire this year after four decades, the company said yesterday in a statement.

title: Google Bolsters Beltway Contacts
description: In its growing quest to peddle influence in Washington, Google has contracted with a lobbying firm that employs Josh Hastert, son of the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Dennis Hastert.

title: Ron Burkle May Pony Up for Orphaned Knight Ridder Newspapers
description: Ron Burkle, billionaire supermarket magnate and celebrity investor, has emerged as a suitor for the dozen newspapers McClatchy Co. is unloading in the wake of its $4.5 billion purchase of Knight Ridder Inc. The union representing workers at many of the papers tapped Burkle, head of closely held investment firm Yucaipa Companies of Los Angeles, as a deep-pocketed investor to bid on the papers

title: Start-Up  Formed by Apple Co-Founder Shuts Down
description: Wheels of Zeus, the start-up formed by Apple Computer co-founder Steve Wozniak a few years ago, has been closed. The Ravix Group, a consulting firm that provides financial and human resources advice, is helping WoZ wind down its affairs.

title: Break Up the Oil Giants?
description: Oil giants like BP should break themselves up. The notion is based on more than mere financial wizardry or broking whimsy. It also makes good strategic sense. There are few good reasons for oil firms to keep their upstream and downstream units together. There are many to split them apart.

title: Why Toyota Will Never Buy G.M.
description: As General Motors slides deeper into financial distress, it is tempting to imagine rival Toyota Motor riding in to end G.M.s misery by buying it.

title: Pulse
description: This season's lacy items come in many incarnations: bold brights, spray-painted metallics, simple shoes or heavy intricate bangles.

title: Telefonica Dials Up Deal for Its Mobile Phone Unit
description: Telefonica , Spains largest phone company, has offered to buy the shares it doesnt already own in its Telefonica Moviles mobile subsidiary for 3.46 billion euros ($4.2 billion) to gain access to all of the units earnings.

title: Icahn Candidate Wins Board Seat in South Korea
description: Carl Icahns candidate won a seat on the board of KT&G, South Koreas biggest tobacco company, bolstering his proposal to split up the 8.6 trillion won ($8.9 billion) company.

title: Perellas Boutique Woos 2 More Bankers
description: Add two more names to the list of high-profile recruits at the (still unnamed) firm founded by ex-Morgan Stanley investment bankers Joseph Perella and Terry Meguid.

title: Using Stereotypes for Good, and Not for Evil
description: "Minoriteam" is a provocative animated show that sends up bigotry.

title: Justice Seen Building a Case Against Maytag Deal
description: Justice Department lawyers are preparing a possible challenge to Whirlpools proposed $1.7 billion acquisition of Maytag, Bloomberg News has reported, citing people familiar with the case.

title: Airport Operator BAA Shoots Down $15 Billion Offer
description: BAA, which runs Gatwick and Heathrow airports in London, flatly rejected on Friday a $15 billion offer from Grupo Ferrovial of Spain and declared that it would not even enter into discussions on the matter.

title: In Case You Missed It
description: Heres a link to todays article in The Times about yesterdays events, bicycle, petitions and mayor included.

title: St. Paul Travelers in Merger Talks With Zurich (Or Maybe It Isnt)
description: St. Paul Travelers Companies is discussing the possibility of a merger with Swiss insurance heavyweight Zurich Financial Services, according to The Wall Street Journal. The talks are preliminary, the newspaper said, and may go nowhere.

title: A Generational Divide
description: The Star-Ledger offers a broad overview here of what the re-match between Mayor Sharpe James and Cory Booker, the opponent half his age, might look like. The gist: get ready for another race that centers on the generational divide between the mayors combative vision forged in the furnace of the Civil Rights movement and Mr. Bookers newer, younger take that demands accelerated change.

title: Paramount  Sells DreamWorks Library
description: Viacoms Paramount Pictures has greenlighted a $900 million movie deal.

title: L.A. Times: No to Preventive War
SBA Sets $1 Billion Deal for Wireless Tower Company AAT
description: Three years after selling a big piece of its wireless tower portfolio to AAT Communications, SBA Communications has turned around and agreed to buy all of AAT.

title: Officer Krupke, the Merger Made Me Do It
description: Do big bank mergers lead to more crime? It may sound unlikely, but a new study finds a relationship  albeit a small one  between bank consolidation and property crime. This is not an excuse for violating the law, writes Floyd Norris of The New York Times, but it reveals a surprising side effect of reduced competition.

title: Whos Trying to Evade Censure?
description: Liberal columnists, magazines and blogs continue to debate whether Democrats should support Russ Feingolds resolution to censure President Bush for warrantless domestic wiretapping. There are two competing equilibria among those who think Feingolds move was bad politics: One side says Feingolds move was a selfish calculation to promote his (expected) 2008 presidential campaign, and Democrats should steer clear of censure while they focus on recapturing the House  and even the Senate  in 2006. The other side says, look, of course Feingolds censure resolution was a bad idea, but now that hes gone ahead with it, its an even worse idea for Democrats to oppose it.

title: New Yorkers Celebrate St. Patrick's Day
description: Though fewer and fewer New Yorkers claim Irish ancestry, thousands of revelers turned out to celebrate St. Patrick's Day, lining the route of Friday's parade.

title: Ask Science
description: Dennis Overbye answered reader questions about his essay "Far Out, Man. But Is It Quantum Physics?" from this week's Science Times.

title: C.E.O. in Strip Club Scandal Gets Parting Gift
description: Robert McCormick, the former chief executive of Savvis Communications who was forced to resign after it emerged in October that he spent $241, 000 on his companys corporate credit card at Scores, the Manhattan strip club, is still getting paid his bonus  prorated through November when he left the company.

title: Watch and Wonder
description: For those of you who missed the nightly news and Mayor James spectacular petition drop-off, Channel 2 has some colorful video.

title: Telecom Giants Vie For Riverstone Networks
description: Ericsson has emerged as the top contender to acquire Riverstone Networks, a bankrupt maker of Ethernet routers that Lucent Technologies had previously agreed to buy.

title: Word Perfect
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Theories, Theories, Theories
description: After Mayor Sharpe Jamess circus-like, under-the-wire filing for re-election yesterday, political observers were left struggling to find a coherent explanation for what, exactly, he was up to.

title: The Delicate Balance Between Iran and Iraq
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans March 17 column, Americas Iran Policy

title: Second  Try to Take Home Builder Private; Investors Hope for More
description: Shares of William Lyon Homes shot up more than 30 percent Friday as investors bet that the companys chairman and controlling shareholder, General William Lyon, will be forced to raise his bid to take the company private.

title: Braking the engines, slowing the spectacle
description: The new engine rule affected the Formula One spectacle more on the second race weekend than during the first, as Friday practice in Sepang showed. One of the biggest weaknesses of the new V8 engines is their reliability, simply because they have not had the time to be developed enough. As before, an engine must last for two races and if it is replaced  unless it blows during the race  the driver loses 10 spots on the starting grid.

title: How Sweet the Sound?
description: At the Newark Health and Extended Care Facility, where he dropped in on an afternoon concert for some elderly residents today, Cory Booker was prevailed upon to lead the audience in song.

title: Icahn Steps Into Lexar-Micron Merger
description: Carl Icahn is at it again. The activist investor revealed on Friday that funds he controls have bought a 6 percent stake in memory chip maker Lexar Media and indicated that he may push for a higher price from its proposed acquirer, Micron Technologies.

title: Magazine Cover of Mark Warner
description: Despite the Editors Note published Wednesday about the coloring in the March 12 Magazine cover picture of Mark Warner, readers continue to express puzzlement. I share their concerns.

title: Duck Meatballs and Peking Duck
description: Andrew Carmellini making his grandmothers ravioli. (Joe Fornabaio for The New York Times)

title: The Biggest Thing to Hit Manhattan . . .
description: . . . is the little store from, Pasadena, Calif.

title: Bleak Open Houses
description: Another indication that the New York City housing market is slowing can be found in a report on open houses released yesterday by the Manhattan brokerage firm  Barak Realty.

title: Moving Up in Silicon Valley
description: Like many other parts of the country, sales in Californias Silicon Valley are not quite as robust as they used to be, according to brokers there. Nonetheless, prices keep breaking records, Realty Times notes in a report this week. The median single-family home price on closed sales, the online publication said, rose to a record $765,000 last month, eclipsing the previous $760,000 record set in June 2005.

title: Tarzan, Meet Taxes
description: High closing costs came as a surprise to Jamie Fritz and Niki Scalera Fritz when they bought their brand-new condominium at 555 West 23d St. The couple moved to New York from Las Vegas for Nikis role in the new musical Tarzan, soon to open on Broadway.

title: Diseases on the Brink: Polio
description: The Times's Celia W. Dugger and Donald G. McNeil Jr. discuss five diseases on the brink of eradication.

title: Musings on Falluja
description: I can now say I have seen the much-touted city of Falluja. From the Euphrates River in the west to the rolling farmland just outside the eastern Cloverleaf overpass, it is a city with as many personalities as it has citizens. The history I know says that Falluja has always been a haven for criminals, a place that Saddam Hussein decided to ignore and let fester in an already not-so-humanitarian Iraq. One of our native linguists tells me it was a last stop for truckers coming out of Jordan to get some tasty shish kebob before they entered the crowded metropolitan area of Baghdad. Beyond that, I cannot speak for its history, but I can tell you that today, Falluja, like many cities, runs the gamut from gorgeous to ghastly.

title: Ramsey Joins Jets; Abraham Wants Out
description: The Jets made one of their biggest moves of the off-season yesterday, acquiring quarterback Patrick Ramsey from the Washington Redskins, and were working toward another by trying to trade the disgruntled defensive end John Abraham.

title: Paul Taylor as Humorist, Theatricalist and Artist
description: There are many Paul Taylors, each distinctive and all appearing in an extraordinary retrospective season at City Center that ends tomorrow.

title: Matsui Slides Out Of the Mix For Now
description: The Mets spent the better part of the off-season formulating ways to upgrade at second base, and only after failing did they, begrudgingly, offer a full endorsement of Kazuo Matsui.

title: Those Nocturnal Adventures on Ambien (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief sports article on Tuesday about Justine Henin-Hardenne's third-round victory in a tennis tournament in Indian Wells, Calif., referred incorrectly to her schedule since she quit the Australian Open final because of a stomach problem. This was not her first tournament; she won the Dubai Open in her return to competition last month.

title: Picasso's Daughter Says Drawing Is a Fake
description: Maya Widmaier-Picasso, a daughter of Picasso who authenticates works attributed to him, said yesterday in Paris that a $40,000 drawing purchased by a California man through Costco last year was a fake.

title: Dutch Autopsy on Milosevic Finds No Evidence of Unusual Drugs
description: THE HAGUE, March 17 - A Dutch autopsy on Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president who was found dead in his cell last week, detected no evidence of any toxin, nonprescribed medication or even abnormal levels of his prescribed medicines, the United Nations war crimes tribunal announced Friday.

title: U.S. Lawyers Keep Silence on Listening In
description: Is the government secretly monitoring communications between plaintiffs and their lawyers in a federal class-action lawsuit against former Attorney General John Ashcroft and other top officials? Government lawyers yesterday politely refused a court order that they answer that question, asking instead that the court reconsider the order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKLAR, SAMUEL
description: SKLAR--Samuel. On March 16, 2006. Devoted husband of the late Sadie, loving father of Irene and Marvin. Devoted grandfather of Helene, Richard, Marc and Michelle. Cherished great grandfather of Daniel, Talia, Erica, Sarah, Dylan and Nicholas. Services Sunday, 10:30AM at the graveside at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: An Actress Upstaging Her Talent and Ibsen
description: The comforting blandishments that often come with celebrity are well known. Big money. First-class travel. Access to those yummy gift suites that give harried stars easy access to free spa treatments and flat-screen TV's. The cruel trappings are also familiar. Fender-benders with the paparazzi. Being forced to describe the provenance of your undergarments while on the red carpet.

title: Police Captain Is Found Not Guilty on 2 of 3 Charges
description: Eric Adams, a Police Department captain who faced discipline for comments during a television interview in October, has been found not guilty of two of the three internal charges against him, including that he misled the public during the terror alert last fall, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: An Unassuming Witness, Steeped in the Underworld
description: To look at him, one might never guess that Burton Kaplan devoted 40 years to a protean life of crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENDELMAN, MARK
description: ENDELMAN - Mark. The friends of Mark Endelman express our deep sorrow at the loss of a man who did so much to help others, in government, in philanthropy, in business, and in the lives of those seeking guidance on the Path beyond the self. "Those whom God wishes to bless, God puts in their hands the means of helping others." H.R. Moody, Chairman, Technical Assistance Found.

title: Study Is Said to Find Overlap in U.S. Counterterror Effort
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Charles Wins Judgment On Travelog
description: A High Court judge ruled that The Mail on Sunday violated Prince Charles's privacy when it published excerpts from a document in which he mused on the 1997 transfer of Hong Kong to the Chinese. The newspaper had argued that the document, which the prince distributed to a circle of acquaintances and in which he complained about having to fly business class and referred to the Chinese leadership as "appalling old waxworks," was a legitimate object of public interest because it expressed the political views of the heir to the throne. But while the court barred the newspaper from publishing the document in full, it said that the paper had a right to make its case in court for the right to publish seven similar documents leaked by a disgruntled former aide to Charles. SARAH LYALL (NYT)

title: China May Release Jailed Times Researcher, Lawyer Says
description: BEIJING, March 17 - Chinese authorities on Friday withdrew at least part of the case against a Chinese researcher for The New York Times, in a surprise legal maneuver that left unclear whether he would soon be released as President Hu Jintao prepares to visit the United States next month.

title: Vote in Belarus Brings Fears and Warnings
description: MINSK, Belarus, March 18 - There are no campaign posters or billboards here, not even for President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, who has otherwise thoroughly orchestrated his re-election to a third term on Sunday.

title: Human Rights Violators
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Conductor Enters, Bringing an Infusion of Vitality
description: For whatever reasons, during Kurt Masur's tenure as its music director, the New York Philharmonic did an inadequate job of bringing in the new generation of conductors. Under Lorin Maazel, though, the orchestra has seemed much more focused on cultivating younger talents -- not just established figures, like Robert Spano, David Robertson and Alan Gilbert, but newcomers, like the 32-year-old Frenchman Ludovic Morlot, who excited the players in his debut earlier this month, stepping in for the eminent Christoph von Dohnanyi, who was ill.

title: The Meaning of Life, or the Joys and Challenges of Life With Chopsticks
description: Randall David Cook's new play, "Sake With the Haiku Geisha," a collection of five anecdotes inspired by the playwright's own experience as an English-language teacher in Japan, is an often observant, witty evening about the ways in which other cultures can unexpectedly impinge on our own individual experience. When Mr. Cook reaches for broader statements about humanity, though, those strengths of observation and humor fall by the wayside.

title: After 2 More Deaths, Planned Parenthood Alters Method for Abortion Pill
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  After receiving reports that two more women died after taking abortion pills, Planned Parenthood, the nation's largest provider of abortion and contraceptive services, announced that it would immediately change the way it gives the medicines.

title: U.S. Team Simply Not Ready in March
description: SAN DIEGO - WHILE Commissioner Bud Selig ponders the possibility of an investigation of Barry Bonds, he might want to consider an inquiry into the premature elimination of the United States team from the World Baseball Classic. If he were to conduct such a study, he might find George Steinbrenner hiding in a corner rubbing his hands in glee as he removes pins from voodoo dolls of United States players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANSEN, WENDY GRISWOLD HOWES
description: HANSEN--Wendy Griswold Howes. Born October 30, 1955. Died on March 15, 2006. She will be missed and mourned by her three children AshleyAnne Howes Hansen, William Griswald Hansen and Henry Christian Oliver Hansen. On her dying days she was surrounded by her children, her mother Jennifer, her siblings Deborah Fraser Howes, Cynthia Merrill Howes Hartnagel and Christopher John Ashley Howes; her cousins Jennifer & Geoff Judge and Maryann Casati; her aunt and uncle Margot and Jerry Judge and her nieces Magnolia and Clara Jane Swanson and John Ellis. Wendy's strength came from her family, especially the love of her children and her parents Jennifer Howes and Oliver Howes who died January 29, 2006 from prostate cancer. Cancer took another life with Wendy's death. Visiting hours at the Nardone Funeral Home in Peekskill, NY, Friday, March 17, 5-9 PM. Funeral services at the Nardone Funeral Home on Saturday, March 18 at 11 AM.

title: Trading the Hummer for a Honda
description: Correction Appended

title: Now G.M. Has Woes on Audits
description: There was a time when General Motors was seen as the paragon of financial quality. Its bonds were rated triple A, and it was known for the most conservative accounting. Let other companies use liberal accounting rules to make results look better; G.M. did not need such things.

title: World Briefings: Europe, Asia
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a dispute between Wegmans, the supermarket chain, and a group of animal rights activists over the treatment of hens at the company's egg farms misidentified the magazine that named the chain one of the nation's best workplaces. It was Fortune, not Forbes. The article also misstated the affiliation of Dr. Benjamin Lucio-Martinez, a veterinarian who defended the company's practices. Wegmans uses his services through the Cooperative Extension at Cornell University, where he is a professor. He is not the chain's employee.

title: Hedge Fund Chief Can't Get to Russia
description: MOSCOW, March 17 - Russia has been holding up an entry visa to William F. Browder, who controls a $4 billion hedge fund in Moscow and is the largest foreign investor in the country's stock market.

title: As Spring Thaws the Caucasus, Birds and Fear Are Flying North Through Georgia
description: TBILISI, Georgia, March 16 - In the early morning hours, the cobblestone alleys that wander this city's slopes are normally crowded with schoolchildren, walking in groups with their backpacks and books. But such sights have lately become rare.

title: With an Improbable Finish, Crawford Buries the Pistons
description: Larry Brown spent the early part of last evening marinating in a virtual nightmare of his own creation: on one bench were the Detroit Pistons, the team he led to a title before relationships soured. On his own bench were the Knicks, where souring relationships now overshadow a sour record.

title: Arts, Briefly; Basketball on CBS
description: This week, CBS's usual Thursday-night lineup -- "Survivor," "CSI" and "Without a Trace" -- was benched for the first round of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. In Nielsen's preliminary estimates, the prime-time games put CBS in second place among total viewers and third among adults 18 to 49, and the telecast's ratings were up from the corresponding night last year. With CBS out of the way, ABC was able to win the night, thanks to the premiere of the Simon Cowell-produced competition "American Inventor," which drew an estimated audience of 14.2 million over two hours. But a typically weak showing for "Primetime" (8.7 million) at 10 lowered ABC's average and allowed NBC to finish a close second in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox placed a distant fourth among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. Its comedy "The Loop," which got considerable exposure in a post-"American Idol" slot on Wednesday, fared poorly in its regular slot on Thursday at 8:30 p.m., bringing in only 4.78 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: 'Choose Life' Plates Are Upheld
description: A federal appeals court upheld the legality of Tennessee's anti-abortion "Choose Life" license plates, three years after they were approved by state lawmakers. The decision, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, earned praise from Tennessee Right to Life, a group that opposes abortion. The group's president, Brian Harris, said the decision vindicated his belief that states could enact policies that "favor childbirth over abortion." Keri Adams, a spokeswoman for Planned Parenthood of Middle and East Tennessee, said that she was disappointed by the ruling and that the group had not decided whether to appeal. The Tennessee ruling is at odds with one issued by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit that said a similar South Carolina plate was illegal. DAVID FIRESTONE (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 'Quartermaster' For Pakistani Militants Jailed
description: A London court sentenced Mohammed Ajmal Khan, a 31-year-old Briton, to nine years in prison on charges of acting as a quartermaster for the Pakistan-based terrorist group Lashkar-e-Taiba, which is said to have links to Al Qaeda. He was also among a group of Muslim men in the so-called Virginia jihad case charged by the American authorities last September with aiding the terrorist group. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

title: Those Nocturnal Adventures on Ambien
description: To the Editor:

title: For Small-Town Team, Big Rally, Dream Finish
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARASH, MITCHELL
description: BARASH--Mitchell. Goodbye, dear friend. Leah & Harry

title: This Time, Bradley Pulls The Upset Over Kansas
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., March 17 - The day before the Kansas Jayhawks' first game in the N.C.A.A. tournament, their sophomore center Sasha Kaun said Coach Bill Self compared his young team to a box of chocolates.

title: Trading Rubatos With the Virtuoso Who Pioneered Solo Harmonica
description: There may be no living jazz musician better loved than Jean (Toots) Thielemans, the harmonica virtuoso who came to America from his native Belgium more than 50 years ago. Mr. Thielemans, who turns 84 next month, has gamboled through seemingly the entire landscape of mainstream jazz during his career; from gypsy swing to bebop and every variety since. Along the way he developed an exuberantly expressive voice on the chromatic harmonica, pioneering its use as a solo instrument. And at every turn he made friends, including an illustrious and kaleidoscopic array of fellow musicians.

title: A Tiki Room With Aisles of Discounts Makes Its City Debut
description: New York City -- sharp-elbowed metropolis of ambition -- was having a nice day yesterday. Trader Joe's, a California-based grocer of antic charm and discount prices, opened its first store in the city, in Union Square, to the giddy excitement of the long-since converted and a few startled novices.

title: Google Ordered to Submit Data for Child Pornography Study
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 - As expected, a federal judge ruled on Friday that Google, the Internet search engine, must turn over some search data including 50,000 Web addresses to the government for a study of child pornography online.

title: Teenage Girl With Issues and Salinger
description: If you are going to write a play about the tortuous rite of passage of a charmingly precocious adolescent, using "The Catcher in the Rye" as the central reference is not necessarily the most propitious strategy. It invites a comparison that is virtually impossible to satisfy.

title: Arts, Briefly; Boston Museum Chief Heads to Rome to 'Listen'
description: The director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, will meet with Italian culture officials in Rome next month to discuss the possibility of returning several antiquities that might have been looted, the museum announced. Dawn Griffin, a spokeswoman for the museum, said this week that the planned meeting between Malcolm Rogers, right, its director, and aides to Rocco Buttiglione, Italy's culture minister, grew out of a correspondence initiated by the museum last November. That was when Marion True, a curator at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, went on trial in Italy on charges of trafficking in looted antiquities, along with Robert Hecht, a dealer who has sold many ancient objects to the Museum of Fine Arts. Although the Boston museum was not named in the case, documents in the trial listed more than 30 objects in its collection as evidence, and Italian prosecutors said they had been illegally removed. Ms. Griffin said the Italian government had as yet made no formal claims against the museum. "Absolutely no information has been given to us about what objects are in question, and there's no outline for discussions right now," she said. "So we're really looking at this as an opportunity to go listen." Last month the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York reached a landmark agreement to return almost two dozen items in exchange for long-term loans of other antiquities from Italy. RANDY KENNEDY

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) WALKOUT -- Alexa Vega (left), the young Miami-born actress best known for the "Spy Kids" movies, takes on a

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend on March 3 about photographs by Anthony Lepore at the Marvelli Gallery in Chelsea described one work incorrectly. It shows a woman holding a minister's belt, not touching his "exposed private parts."

title: Valley of the Rolls
description: I'm not going all confessional, like one of these bare actresses baring her soul on the cover of Vanity Fair. But I have a desperate secret, as the actresses like to say, that may help others if I talk about it.

title: Torre Enjoys Dinner Over Game
description: Given a choice of watching the World Baseball Classic or going to dinner with Stan Musial on Thursday night, Yankees Manager Joe Torre chose dinner.

title: Telling You So, Again
description: SOON after the dot-com bubble burst, it became fashionable to say there had been only a few voices in the wilderness warning of the doom that lay ahead, as most of the country stampeded to certain financial ruin. In reality, warnings were issued all the time; they just went unheeded.

title: L'Oral Is Paying $1.1 Billion for Body Shop
description: LONDON, March 17 (AP)  Body Shop International, the British retailer that promotes natural-based cosmetics, said on Friday that it had agreed to be taken over by L'Oral of France in a cash deal worth 652 million ($1.14 billion).

title: Lester Is First Black in Cup Field in 20 Years
description: HAMPTON, Ga., March 17 - Bill Lester became the first black driver in 20 years to qualify for a race in Nascar's top series Friday night.

title: The Mayor and the Imam
description: When a government employee says "the greatest terrorists in the world occupy the White House," he is bound to raise some hackles, but should it be a dismissible offense? The chief chaplain for the New York City Corrections Department, Imam Umar Abdul-Jalil, made that remark in a speech last year in Tucson before a group of Muslim students. For good measure, he also took a shot at "Zionists of the media." What made the case seminal was Mayor Michael Bloomberg's response. He arrived at a Solomonic solution and, in the process, also found his voice on an issue that has challenged his administration in the past: free speech.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,306 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article last Saturday profiled Ali Shalal Qaissi, identifying him as the hooded man forced to stand on a box, attached to wires, in a photograph from the Abu Ghraib prison abuse scandal of 2003 and 2004. He was shown holding such a photograph. As an article on Page A1 today makes clear, Mr. Qaissi was not that man.

title: Swallowed in a Sea of Green
