description: IN the air the bagpipes sounded, on the pavement the feet pounded, and by chance did you see Rosemary Cosgrove? In yesterday's green-and-gold flow up Fifth Avenue, among the hundreds of thousands celebrating St. Patrick's Day, did you see her?

title: On Night of Star Power, an Understudy Shines
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 17 - The stage was set for an All-Star showdown: Kobe Bryant vs. Vince Carter, two of the N.B.A.'s most exhilarating high-wire acts.

title: In With the New, Four Times, From Mark Morris and Others
description: BOSTON, March 17 - Fresh from a run of performances last weekend of Frederick Ashton's "Fille Mal Garde," which epitomizes classical charm, the Boston Ballet has shifted gears sharply. The company is now offering a program of four new works, including two world premieres and one Boston premiere.

title: An Exile Sees Graft as a Piece of Kenya's Social Puzzle
description: OXFORD, England - THE question that seems to spring to mind in conversation with John Githongo, Kenya's exiled anticorruption czar, is this: Is he some kind of African Lenin -- as some have suggested, and not just because of his goatee -- awaiting the call home to a land on the verge of change? Or is he, as his critics depict him, a man who has betrayed his roots, his class, his ethnicity and his nation by displaying its dirty laundry at a safe range of 4,000 miles?

title: Surprising Montana Is a Team of Underdogs
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 17  Montana's reserve forward, Mike Chavez, is the only American Indian playing in the N.C.A.A. tournament. The Grizzlies' backup point guard, Bryan Ellis, hails from a hardscrabble section of east Detroit filled with abandoned houses. Their reserve shooting guard, Matt Martin, comes from Spearfish, S.D., and chose Montana because it was the closest Division I school to recruit him. Missoula is 668 miles  a nine-hour drive  from Spearfish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWE, RUTH D.
description: LOWE--Ruth D., 81. Passed away March 14 after a brief illness. The brevity of her passing contrasted with her long, vibrant family and social life. Daughter of Dr. Wheeler and Laura Davey, she grew up in State College, PA. After graduating Penn State University, she came to New York to sing professionally in well-known 1940's big bands under the name of "Betty Barton." In 1949, she married Monroe W. Greenthal, founder of the Monroe W. Greenthal Co. advertising agency in New York City, with whom she had four children. Widowed in 1963, she married again in 1973 to Harry K. Lowe, chairman of Prospect Press. Her loved ones will deeply miss her unquenchable interest in everything New York, sparkling wit, sharp intellect, and most of all, the sound of her voice, for she lived her life as one great song. She is survived by her children, Stanley, William, David and Paula Greenthal; Mr. Lowe's daughter Michaella Balaban; six grandchildren; two nieces and their children. Funeral Services will be private.

title: Chacon Struggles
description: Shawn Chacon struggled so much early in the Yankees' 5-2 loss to the Cardinals yesterday that he reached his 80-pitch limit in three and two-thirds innings. PAT BORZI (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Michael Jackson Shuts His Ranch House

title: Hints of Corruption Lead Some to Urge Blair to Resign
description: LONDON, March 17 - Compounding woes for Prime Minister Tony Blair, his Labor Party acknowledged Friday that it had received more than three times the amount it had previously reported in secret campaign loans.

title: In Transition to Professional Game, College Coaches Often Lag
description: San Diego - FOR the next two weeks, college basketball fans will watch some of the greatest minds in the sport going at one another: coaches in small programs taking on and beating larger programs, and highly regarded coaches in established programs crushing rivals with fewer resources.

title: Hold the President Accountable
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Two States Propose Laws to Stop Wal-Mart Banks Lawmakers in Michigan and Maryland have introduced bills to restrict Wal-Mart Stores' ability to operate banks in their states. Representative John Gleason in Michigan, a Democrat, proposed a bill yesterday that would bar industrial banks like the one Wal-Mart is seeking to start. Brian Moe, a Democrat the lower house in Maryland, introduced legislation yesterday that would ban Wal-Mart bank branches from its stores. Industrial banks can accept deposits and lend money, raising the possibility that Wal-Mart could open branches in its more than 3,300 United States stores. Wal-Mart has said its bank, to be based in Salt Lake City, would be used for credit card processing to cut fees the chain pays and that it had no plans to open retail banking operations. "We have no intention of doing what they seem to be trying to prevent," a Wal-Mart spokesman, Marty Heires, said. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

title: Prada to Sell a Fashion Unit to a Japanese Concern
description: Prada Holding agreed yesterday to sell Helmut Lang, the unprofitable fashion house that it bought in 1999, to the Link Theory Holdings Company of Japan.

title: Russia Effectively Closes a Political Opponent's Rights Group
description: MOSCOW, March 17 - The bank accounts of a foundation led by an imprisoned Russian businessman, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, were frozen Friday by court order, the foundation and its bank said, a move that strongly suggests the organization is about to be shut down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LILIS, RUTH, M.D.
description: LILIS--Ruth, M.D., 80. Professor Emeritus at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine died on March 17, 2006 at her home in New York City. Surived by her husband Dr. Michael Lilis, daughter Elena Lilis Werner, son-in-law Louis G. Werner, grandchildren Genevieve & Kennett and sister Dr. Judith Lowe. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Sunday 4-7 PM with Service Monday, 9:30 AM. Burial to follow at Southampton Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCMANUS, DENIS J.
description: McMANUS--Denis J. Devoted and loving husband of his best friend Jeanne (nee Killeen). Proud father of Denis, Patrick, and Thomas. Loving brother of James, Maureen Spillane and the late Eugene Jr. and John (Jack). Dear son of the late Eugene and Helen (nee Kearney). Loving uncle of Denise, Michael, and Robert Spillane. Reposing at the McManus-Ahern Funeral Home, Inc., 445 West 43rd Street, NYC, Saturday from 29 P.M. Transferal to the Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, New Jersey for Visiting 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Sunday and Monday. Mass of Christian burial will be Tuesday at the Church of the Assumption, Emerson, N.J. at 9:30 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Queens, NY. For info please call McManus-Ahern Funeral Home, at 212-757-0230.

title: Testing Errors Prompt Calls for Oversight
description: As the College Board races to score the final 1,600 exams from its problem-ridden October SAT test, a string of recent testing errors around the country has college and high school officials, testing experts, students and parents asking with rising urgency, Who is watching the testing industry?

title: Spinal Disk Closer to Losing Medicare Aid
description: The clock is running out on Johnson & Johnson's efforts to stop the federal government from barring Medicare coverage of its implantable spinal disk, Charit.

title: A $65 Table, and a Tale to Tell Around It
description: Funny how a piece of furniture can bring strangers together.

title: The End of Greater Serbia
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, March 17 - As Belgrade girds for the funeral of Slobodan Milosevic on Saturday, the vision that he used to propel himself to power also appears to be dead.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in the Inside Art column of Weekend yesterday about the video "Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidal's 'Caligula,' " by the Italian artist Francesco Vezzoli, misidentified the museum that is receiving it as a gift. It is going to the Guggenheim Museum. (The video is playing in the Whitney Biennial, at the Whitney.)

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: Judges Overturn Bush Bid to Ease Pollution Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  A federal appeals court on Friday overturned a clean-air regulation issued by the Bush administration that would have let many power plants, refineries and factories avoid installing costly new pollution controls to help offset any increased emissions caused by repairs and replacements of equipment.

title: Co-Chairman at Interpublic Group Takes Over As His Fellow Executive Announces Retirement
description: David A. Bell, co-chairman at the troubled Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, is retiring, Interpublic said yesterday, and will take the post of chairman emeritus, serving as a consultant. The other co-chairman, Michael I. Roth, left, will become the sole chairman while continuing as chief executive. The shift came as Mr. Bell's most recent one-year contract with Interpublic expired. Mr. Bell, 62, gave up the post of chief executive to Mr. Roth in January 2005 after two years. He became chief executive as Interpublic sought to address operational and financial problems that began in 2002. Mr. Bell joined Interpublic, which owns agencies like Campbell-Ewald and Deutsch, in 2001 as vice chairman, when the agency company where he was chief executive, True North Communications, was acquired by Interpublic. Mr. Bell has spent 39 years in advertising. STUART ELLIOTT (NYT) BUSINESS BRIEFS

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: First Trial In Nuclear Black Market
description: Gotthard Lerch, a 63-year-old German engineer, went on trial in a Mannheim court on charges of helping Libya acquire nuclear weapons technology in violation of German export laws. Investigators say Mr. Lerch, who was arrested last year, was a part of the nuclear black market that Abdul Qadeer Khan, the Pakistani nuclear engineer, operated for two decades, and he is the first suspected member of that nexus to be tried anywhere. Prosecutors say he received $34 million for supplying Libya with components for centrifuges capable of enriching uranium. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Liberia Wants Ex-Leader Extradited From Nigeria President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has asked Nigeria to extradite Charles Taylor, the former Liberian president and guerrilla, for trial in Sierra Leone. Mr. Taylor, in asylum in Nigeria since 2003, stands indicted on 17 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity. PAGE A4

title: In Louisiana, Graft Inquiries Are Increasing
description: KENNER, La. - Long before this suburb west of New Orleans was shaken by Hurricane Katrina, it was notorious for its fierce political infighting, for name-calling and mudslinging, for charges and countercharges of cronyism and corruption.

title: After 2 More Deaths, Planned Parenthood Alters Method for Abortion Pill
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 - After receiving reports that two more women died after taking abortion pills, Planned Parenthood, the nation's largest provider of abortion and contraceptive services, announced that it would immediately change the way it gives the medicines.

title: Sunni Leaders Say U.S.-Iran Talks Amount to Meddling
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 17 - Sunni Arab political leaders on Friday denounced an agreement between the United States and Iran to hold face-to-face talks about solutions to the unrest in Iraq, saying the conversations would amount to meddling by foreign nations in Iraq's domestic affairs.

title: No Free Ride for Lee, Just the Ride of His Life
description: DALLAS, March 17 - The white sign with scrawled orange handwriting raised by a Bucknell fan Friday after the ninth-seeded Bison's 59-55 victory against eighth-seeded Arkansas was rather fitting: "Charles Lee MVP."

title: Just Latin and Asian Treats on the Menu
description: SAN DIEGO, March 17 - There were no Derek Jeter sightings, but Cuba's Yulieski Gourriel, the Jeter wannabe, was here. Chipper Jones does not have a locker, but South Korea's Seung Yeop Lee, another impressive slugger, does. The only all-American thing about the first World Baseball Classic is that the games are being played here.

title: George Mason Proves Bid Wasn't a Fluke With Upset
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 17 - George Mason University, one of the teams whose inclusion in the N.C.A.A. tournament provoked much criticism of the selection committee, is staying for at least one more round in the Washington Region after dispatching the perennial title contender Michigan State, 76-65.

title: Boston Church Returns a Tainted Donation
description: A Boston church that spent a $2.3 million gift from a follower later charged in an investment scam has decided to give the same amount to a fund for victims of the fraud.

title: Another Black Eye for H&R Block
description: H&R Block's Express I.R.A. lets tax filers deposit all or part of their refunds directly into retirement savings accounts. Theoretically, it's a great way to save because the money is stashed away before it can be spent. But the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, says that in practice, it's a lousy deal. In a lawsuit filed this week, Mr. Spitzer contends that the accounts are "virtually guaranteed to lose money" because of low returns and high fees.

title: Those Nocturnal Adventures on Ambien
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgetown Comes Alive in 2nd Half
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 17 - Last fall, when John Thompson III first laid eyes on Roy Hibbert, his 7-foot-2 freshman center, his first thought was far different from what his Hall of Fame father, John, thought when Patrick Ewing and Alonzo Mourning showed up on the Georgetown campus. Hibbert had the long, lumpy body of a scarecrow. He was seriously dexterously challenged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCHUGH, CATHERINE (NEE MCCARTHY)
description: McHUGH -- Catherine (nee McCarthy), September 29, 1914-March 16, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Thomas. Born Corlinan, Balinalee, County Longford, Ireland. Mother of Peggy (Rich), Tom (Deb), Kevin (Geri), Rosemary (Steven). Grandmother of Brian (Kim), Cathy (Chris), Rosemary, Sean, Liz, Tess, James and the late Felicia. Great grandmother of Danielle and Matthew. Donations in her memory to the Children of Bellevue, 462 First Ave, NY, NY 10016.

title: FEMA Will Try to Recoup Millions Distributed for Hurricane Relief
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 - Acknowledging that it wrongly distributed tens of millions of dollars in hurricane relief last year, the Federal Emergency Management Agency said Friday that it would try to recoup aid from thousands of individuals or families who fraudulently or otherwise wrongly collected money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMPOSELLO, PATRICK J.
description: POMPOSELLO--Patrick J., 67. Of Sciota, PA died March 16, 2006. Husband of Marilyn (Mills) Pomposello. Prior to his retirement in December 1994, Mr. Pomposello served as Manhattan Borough Commissioner for the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation. Survived by sons: Patrick, Michael, Steven and Roger; seven grandchildren: Patrick, Alexander, Michelle, Megan, Shen-li, Michaela and Roger Jr. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday March 20 at 10 AM at the Church of St Luke, 818 Main St. Stroudsburg. Burial in Buena Vista Cemetery, Brodheadsville. Viewings on Saturday March 18, 6-8 PM and Sunday March 19, 2-4 PM and 6-8 PM at the Joseph J. Pula Funeral Home, 23 North Ninth Street, Stroudsburg, PA.

title: O.K., It's Not a Pink Pony. But What Is It?
description: According to its title, we know what Yvonne Meier's latest work is not. But "this is not a pink pony: take 1 and 2," which opened Thursday night at the Kitchen, elegantly avoids positive identification, from the first unveiling of a deer statue in a hazy spotlight, to the two men, dressed in ape suits, who carry the somewhat-resisting, underwear-clad Marion Ramirez offstage at dance's end.

title: Agency Sees Little Risk From a Leak at Indian Point
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said in a report released yesterday that the risk from the tritium-contaminated water leaking from the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor is so small that it is unlikely to affect the health of plant workers or the public.

title: The Price of a Safe Landing
description: Correction Appended

title: At Just the Right Time, Arizona Finds Old Form
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 17 - Hassan Adams, recently arrested, was the game's leading scorer. Chris Rodgers, once kicked off the team, had the steal and the layup that provided the biggest lead. Jawann McClellan, once suspended from the squad, cheered from the end of the bench with his wrist in a cast.

title: Hold the President Accountable
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stroke Adds to Uncertainty in Illinois Race
description: CHICAGO, March 17 - A fiercely fought Democratic primary for president of the Cook County Board of Commissioners took a dramatic turn this week when the incumbent suffered a stroke that will keep him hospitalized until after Tuesday's election.

title: After All, Seedings Are Merely Numbers
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 17 - North Carolina, the defending national champion, and Connecticut, seeded No. 1 over all this year, survived the valiant efforts of the upset-minded pretenders Murray State and Albany yesterday.

title: Homeless Man Convicted of Stalking Television and Radio Commentator
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEWIS, MORTON V.
description: LEWIS--Morton V. 7/27/23--3/18/86. He has outsoared the shadow of our night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   NASO, JOHN F.
description: NASO--John F. Courageous, funny, feisty and always there for us. We miss you. Your family

title: National Briefing: West, Southwest, Midwest, South, New England, Washington
description: WEST

title: Ex-Columbia Student Says Disputed Chemistry Research Is Sound
description: A former graduate student at Columbia University whose research is at the center of three papers retracted by a leading chemistry journal is disputing accusations that her experiments cannot be reproduced.

title: Judges Overturn Bush Bid to Ease Pollution Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 - A federal appeals court on Friday overturned a clean-air regulation issued by the Bush administration that would have let many power plants, refineries and factories avoid installing costly new pollution controls to help offset any increased emissions caused by repairs and replacements of equipment.

title: That Other Madness This Month: Mergers
description: MARCH madness is not limited to college basketball. Billions of dollars in mergers were announced this week, building on the momentum created when AT&T offered to acquire BellSouth for $67 billion earlier in the month.

title: Arts, Briefly; Radio Employees Charged
description: Three former employees of Michigan Radio -- one of the largest public radio outlets in the country, with stations in Ann Arbor, Grand Rapids and Flint -- have been charged with embezzlement involving kickbacks in exchange for sponsorship. Indictments issued on Thursday in Ann Arbor charged Michael Coleman, Justin Ebright and Jeremy Nordquist with accepting a variety of gifts from underwriters, including golf club memberships, spa treatments and Persian rugs. The University of Michigan, which owns Michigan Radio, began a criminal investigation in November after a former director found irregularities in the station's fund-raising practices and bookkeeping. That director later resigned but has not been charged with a crime. An internal audit has uncovered at least $50,000 in misappropriated funds and donations, the university said. The three men all resigned before they were indicted. Mr. Coleman, the former deputy director, is now general manager of WDET, a Detroit public radio station. JEREMY W. PETERS

title: Ex-Columbia Student Says Disputed Chemistry Research Is Sound
description: A former graduate student at Columbia University whose research is at the center of three papers retracted by a leading chemistry journal is disputing accusations that her experiments cannot be reproduced.

title: For High School Coach, Points Are Not the Point
description: GIVEN the likelihood that another New York City public schools championship trophy will be awarded to Coach Ed Grezinsky and his Murry Bergtraum High School girls' basketball team tomorrow, Vera Springer said it would be only fair if she and her Louis Brandeis High School players could be appropriately feted as the 2005-6 season concludes.

title: An Immigration Breakthrough
description: The clock was running out on the Senate Judiciary Committee this week, and with it the chances for a meaningful overhaul of the nation's immigration laws. After weeks of work, the committee members faced a rigid deadline to get a bill ready before next week's recess. But about all they had agreed on were various ways to tighten the borders. It was increasingly likely that Congress's message to 12 million illegal immigrants would end up being this: Thanks for the help -- now get out.

title: Setting a Dubious Record, Again, but Still Not Out of Line
description: THE balance-of-payments deficit in the United States set another record in the fourth quarter, as it rose to 7 percent of the gross domestic product.

title: Exiled From Ground Zero, Arts Center Loses Leader
description: After a long power struggle set off by the Drawing Center's bid for a new home at ground zero, the center announced yesterday that its executive director, Catherine de Zegher, would resign at the end of the month.

title: Sidestepping the Camp in a Work by Stein and Thomson
description: It is all too easy to turn Virgil Thomson's "Four Saints in Three Acts" into quaint camp. But a performance by the Mark Morris Dance Group, its musical ensemble and the Riverside Choral Society Chamber Singers on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music gave the 1934 opera just the right sweetness and sense of airy space.

title: Judge Gives Prosecutors New Chance in Terror Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 - The judge in the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui said on Friday that prosecutors could try to find new, untainted aviation-security witnesses to replace those who were barred from testifying because they were improperly coached by a government lawyer.

title: Albany Unleashes, but Huskies Go the Distance
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 17 - When Connecticut won the national championship in 2004, Albany finished last in the America East Conference. UConn won 33 games that season against some of the nation's toughest competition; Albany won 5 against some of the weakest.

title: Transit Union to Revote on Contract Deal
description: The executive board of the transit workers' union last night authorized its president, Roger Toussaint, to hold a revote on the contract deal that union members rejected by just seven votes in January.

title: Arts, Briefly; Closing Arguments by 'Da Vinci' Defense
description: A lawyer for Random House declared in a London court yesterday that Dan Brown had not stolen ideas for his best-selling novel "The Da Vinci Code" from another book and that, even if he had, "the ideas are of too general a nature to be capable of copyright protection." Random House U.K., the British publisher of "The Da Vinci Code," is being sued by Michael Baigent, left, and Richard Leigh, two of the three authors of "The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail," a 1982 nonfiction book that posits that Jesus had children with Mary Magdalene and that their descendants are alive today. In his closing arguments, John Baldwin, the Random House lawyer, said that the case was "now in tatters" and that Mr. Baigent, who testified last week, was either "extremely dishonest or he is a complete fool." The lawyers for Mr. Baigent and Mr. Leigh will present their closing arguments on Monday. SARAH LYALL

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: The Allowance: It's Not Just About Money
description: I CANNOT let my children read this column. It turns out, if there was a minimum wage for allowances, my husband and I would be severely violating it.

title: Jericho Prison Raid: Pointing Fingers
description: To the Editor:

title: Opening the Door on the Credit Report and Throwing Away the Lock
description: In a dozen states, legislatures have set up procedures for residents afraid of identity theft to lock and unlock their credit reports.

title: Please Stay Tuned
description: SportsNet New York faced more technical problems yesterday when a power surge in its Rockefeller Plaza building caused the Mets' new station to run a continuous loop of announcements promoting itself.

title: A Paler Shade of Green
description: While their cultural visibility remains high, the number of New York City residents claiming Irish ancestry dropped by more than a third between 1980 and 2000, according to figures from the U.S. Census Bureau.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, LEROY BENATAR
description: BLOCK--Leroy Benatar, 88. A Madison Avenue legend in his time while at Grey Advertising, later a great financial adviser, died peacefully at home on March 17. Roy was a Captain in psychological warfare in World War II. At Dartmouth College (class of '38) he played in the Barbary Coast Orchestra. Beloved by his many dear friends and his long-time companion Doris Willens Kaplan. Visiting Saturday March 18, 2-5PM and Sunday March 19, 11AM-2PM at Nolan Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave., Northport, L.I. (631-754-2400). Memorial service at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSTEN, THOMAS HADLEY
description: JOSTEN--Thomas Hadley. 93, of NYC, died January 24, 2006 in Wickenburg, AZ. Retired advertising executive, investor, sailor, navigator, expert shot, raconteur, art collector, and connoisseur of fine food and drink. Only son of the late A.M. Josten and grandson of Otto H. Josten, founder of Josten's Inc., Owatonna, MN. Tom was born December 10, 1912 in Owatonna, MN. He attended Carleton College, Duke University (Trinity College, BA 1934), University of Chicago, and the Harvard Business School (AMP 1946). During WWII he served as a naval aviator with the VR2 Squadron at Alameda Naval Air Station and the VR11 Squadron in Honolulu. He flew in the South Pacific as navigator on the PBM Mariner, the PB2Y, and the DC-4. He joined Young & Rubicam in 1953, and retired in 1977. He was a member of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and served as Commodore from 1985 to 1986. He was also a member of the New York Yacht Club, the Royal Yacht Squadron, the Imperial Poona Yacht Club (Revolting Colonies Outpost), the University Club, the Newport Reading Room, the Leash, and the Piping Rock Club. Survived by sister Roberta (Bobbe) Torgerson, brother-in-law Allan (Torg) Torgerson and uncle to Chris, Sally, Julie, Tom, and Ande, he never once missed spending Christmas with his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMS, ALAN SETH
description: ABRAMS--Alan Seth. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member, Alan Seth Abrams. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Alfred D. Youngwood, Pres.

title: They Skip the Bio and Cut to the Cole Porter Chase
description: In the language of Cole Porter: oo-la-la-la! C'est magnifique!

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a classical music listing in Weekend yesterday misidentified the boys' choir that is to perform at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday in the Basically Bach Festival. It is the Boys Choir of St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue; the Boys Choir of Harlem was originally scheduled but withdrew.

description: Correction Appended

title: O Housewives, O Pageants, O 1950's
description: A promising premise is sabotaged by uneven acting and an underdeveloped central relationship in "Mrs. California," the first of two plays by Doris Baizley opening in New York this month.

title: An Original at the Piano Who Features Both Orderliness and Suppleness
description: The German pianist Alexander Lonquich has a thriving career in Europe, and he recently made a more global impression by way of an ECM recording devoted to French music. But although he is 45, his appearances in the United States have been few, and his recital on Wednesday evening at the 92nd Street Y was his first in New York.

title: Open and Fair: Why Wall St. Hates Auctions
description: Correction Appended

title: Bridge; Pro or Am, Being Overeager Can Derail a Good Defense
description: Inexperienced players have a tendency to win tricks too quickly, especially when defending. That mistake was spotted on the diagramed deal from last Sunday's Samuel Stayman Memorial Pro Am in West Palm Beach, Fla. The only difference is that the erroneous early capture was executed by a pro.

title: Tomorrow Is Another Campaign
description: Not since Scarlett O'Hara vowed to save Tara has an embattled Southern belle portrayed herself with such pathos. "I'm going to put everything on the line," vowed Congresswoman Katherine Harris, announcing on national television her plans to spend $10 million from a personal inheritance to try to save her floundering Senate campaign. "Everything," Ms. Harris said, choking back tears. "Not just my career and my future, but my father's name."

title: Softbank to Buy Vodafone's Japan Cellphone Unit for $15 Billion
description: TOKYO, March 17 - Softbank, the Japanese Internet company, will buy Vodafone's Japanese cellphone unit in a deal worth $15.4 billion, the companies said Friday, ending the British mobile phone giant's foray into one of the world's largest and toughest markets.

title: Tens of thousands bid final farewell to Milosevic
Spitzer as a Taciturn Go-Getter
description: This 30-second advertisement for Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, a Democratic candidate for governor, began running on Thursday on network and cable broadcast stations in New York City and its suburbs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Judge Sets Conditions to Allow Serial Killer to Donate Kidney
description: NEWARK, March 17 - A judge in Somerset County Superior Court signed an order on Thursday that would allow the convicted serial killer Charles Cullen to donate one of his kidneys as long as he and his doctors met a new series of conditions, including providing a guarantee that the recipient's insurance would pay all costs.

title: 4, Including 3 Youths, Die as Tanker Hits Stopped Van
description: TUXEDO, N.Y., March 17 - Four people, including three minors, were killed and another child was critically injured when a tractor-trailer slammed into the back of their stopped minivan on the New York State Thruway on Friday morning, the police said.

title: Dwelling in Spain, With Visits to France and Italy
description: The Spanish gambist Jordi Savall and various configurations of his magnificent Hesprion XXI ensemble seem to have taken up residence in New York these last few weeks, with concerts at several halls and a church, as well as a master class and a public interview. Actually, Mr. Savall and his musicians have visited other American cities between these New York concerts, but the party came to an end -- or at least, the New York installments did -- with a concert in the Medieval Sculpture Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday evening.

title: Cited as Symbol of Abu Ghraib, Man Admits He Is Not in Photo
description: In the summer of 2004, a group of former detainees of Abu Ghraib prison filed a lawsuit claiming that they had been the victims of the abuse captured in photographs that incited outrage around the world.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "They haven't done anything to control any spending - zero, zip and nada."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FREYDBERG, SHIRLEY K.
description: FREYDBERG -- Shirley K. March 18, 1917--April 18, 2005 Happy Birthday, Mom. We love and miss you very much. You're in our hearts and thoughts. Tom, Peter, Michele, Rick

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 17, 2006

title: Challenger Pulls Ahead of Chip Giant
description: THE year is still young, yet the two leading makers of semiconductors for personal computers have already experienced moves of 20 percent in their stocks. To the great chagrin of Intel shareholders, no doubt, their stock has fallen, while Advanced Micro Devices' has rallied.

title: Monitoring Indecency, Pushing an Agenda
description: Indecency, as Janet Jackson showed, is all in the context. People complained to the Federal Communications Commission about the performer's wardrobe malfunction because it happened during a Super Bowl halftime show -- viewers don't expect lewdness until the commercials.

title: Seeking Return of His Pet, a Ferret Lover Gets a Severe Beating
description: Joe Serrano wanted his ferret back, and for that he got a beating from which he may not recover.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article last Saturday profiled Ali Shalal Qaissi, identifying him as the hooded man forced to stand on a box, attached to wires, in a photograph from the Abu Ghraib prison abuse scandal of 2003 and 2004. He was shown holding such a photograph. As an article on Page A1 today makes clear, Mr. Qaissi was not that man.

title: How I Learned to Love the Wall
description: New Haven - ON March 28, Israelis will elect a new prime minister to replace the ailing Ariel Sharon. But I'd bet my last shekel that I'll continue to hear the phrase "Ariel Sharon's apartheid wall." It's a phrase spoken -- make that spewed -- on almost every university campus I visit in North America and Europe.

title: Satirical Superheroes for the Rude Set
description: They don't leap tall buildings in a single bound or scale skyscrapers. They don't transform into not-so-jolly green giants or zoom around in tricked-out sportsmobiles. Instead, Minoriteam -- a motley band of minority superheroes -- uses stereotypes to fight their archenemy: racism.

title: An Open Chute, a Gust of Wind and a Sport Is Born
description: THE DALLES, Ore. - Steve Schieberl made a short hike from his car to a hilltop one recent morning in Oregon's Columbia River Gorge. After a swig of Red Bull, he floated his parachute in a light breeze with the help of a friend, ran a dozen steps down a 45-degree slope and launched into the air, reaching about 30 miles an hour toward the bottom of the hill and punctuating the curling ride with a whoop as he toed down.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRISBANE, DORIS FAUSER
description: BRISBANE--Doris Fauser of Glen Cove, L.I. on March 16, 2006, age 80. Beloved wife of the late Seward. Loving mother of Arthur (Jo), Charles (Deborah), Aleta Heisig (William), Peter (Diane), Maria (Wallace). Dear sister of the late Charles and Joseph Fauser. Cherished grandmother of Allison, Madeline, Laura, Dana and Kyle Brisbane, Allaire Heisig, Olivia and Ian Henderson. Devoted member of St. John's of Lattingtown Altar Guild. Visiting at Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove Sunday 3-6pm and Memorial service held on March 23 at 11am at St. John's of Lattingtown. Burial private.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an agreement by the Bush administration to supply nuclear energy assistance to India referred imprecisely to the legal status of the plan. It calls for changes in the law that would permit the United States to assist India with civilian nuclear technology, which otherwise would be prohibited under current law because of India's nuclear weapons activities. If Congress agreed, the deal's provisions would not violate United States law.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an agreement between Iran and the United States to hold talks about the violence in Iraq referred incorrectly in some copies to the country whose nuclear program has been referred to the United Nations Security Council for possible punitive action. It is Iran, not Iraq.

title: Rahlves Ends Career With 12 Cup Victories
description: ARE, Sweden, March 17 A Daron Rahlves retired from international Alpine ski racing Friday and will leave the sport rivaling Picabo Street as the most successful American downhiller in history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLANIGAN, BRIGID SNOW
description: FLANIGAN--Brigid Snow. Beloved wife of 51 years of Peter Flanigan, died peacefully on March 16, 2006. Mrs. Flanigan was the mother of Brigid S. Lezak of Portland, OR; Sister Louise Marie Flanigan of Birmingham, AL; Dr. Timothy Flanigan of Tiverton, RI; Megan Skakel of Greenwich, CT; and Robert Flanigan of NYC; and grandmother of 14 grandchildren. Mrs. Flanigan was the daughter of George Palen Snow and Carmel Snow of Long Island and NYC. Throughout her life, Mrs. Flanigan was interested in education, serving at her death on the Board of the Purchase College Foundation of SUNY College at Purchase, and on the Advisory Board of St. Ann Elementary School, on 110th Street in Manhattan. She attended Brearley School, Foxcroft School and Barnard College. Friends may visit at 220 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, NY, from 4:30 PM to 8:00 PM, on Sunday, March 19. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said at Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY, at 11:00 AM, on Monday, March 20. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to your favorite charity.

title: Verdict Upheld in 1988 Killings of L.I. Couple
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
New York Congressman Won't Seek 13th Term
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 - Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert, a moderate Republican from central New York who became a national advocate of science and a champion of environmental protection, announced Friday that he would not seek re-election.

title: If I Had a Million Dollars
description: TRUE, $1 million isn't what it used to be. There are now more millionaires nationwide than people who are unemployed.

title: Ray Meyer, Former DePaul Coach, Dies at 92
description: Ray Meyer, a Hall of Fame basketball coach at DePaul University who began his career by tutoring an awkward George Mikan, modern basketball's first superstar, and went on to win 724 games over 42 seasons, died yesterday at an assisted-living facility outside Chicago, said Scott Reed, the university's sports information director. He was 92.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the New York City Transit labor dispute misspelled the surname of the state mediator who recommended that it be resolved by binding arbitration. He is Richard A. Curreri, not Currieri.

title: A Hurricane and Espresso. What's Next?
description: In its fourth-quarter earnings report, Procter & Gamble had one particularly dark cloud in a generally bright update: Hurricane Katrina was making a mess of its coffee business, which got 50 percent of its supply from four sites in New Orleans.

title: Top Indonesian Generals Take Control of Restive City
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 17 - Indonesia's top military and police generals took control of the provincial capital of Jayapura in Papua on Friday, ordering the arrest of university students and directing the riot police to fire into the air as they patrolled the streets.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Arms Dealer Found Guilty
description: A Pakistani arms dealer accused of illegally exporting military aircraft parts from the United States was found guilty of multiple violations of the Arms Export Control Act. A federal jury in San Diego convicted the dealer, Arif Ali Durrani, of four counts of exporting defense articles without a license and one count of conspiracy. Prosecutors had accused Mr. Durrani of illegally exporting military aircraft parts to the United Arab Emirates, Malaysia and Belgium. Mr. Durrani spent five years in prison after he was convicted in 1987 for selling guidance systems for antiaircraft missiles to Iran. Sentencing is scheduled for June 5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENSON, THERESE L.
description: STEVENSON--Therese L. of Bedford, NY died on March 16, 2006 at age 64. Terry was born on December 17, 1941 in Bronx, NY to Daniel, Aloysius and Margaret Stevens Lawler. She was was educated in New York and graduated from St. Barnabas High School in 1958. She earned a Bachelors degree in English from Fordham University, School of Education, New York, NY in 1962. In addition, she earned a master's degree in Special Education from Hunter College in 1966. On April 27, 1963, she married John C. Stevenson at St. Brendan's Church in Bronx, NY. Therese and John started off in Mt. Vernon, NY before moving to New Rochelle in 1966. In 1973, the couple moved to their current address in Bedford, NY. Mrs. Stevenson taught deaf children at Junior High School 47 on 23rd Street, New York, NY in 1962 to 1963 and at St. Joseph's School for the Deaf, Bronx, NY from 1963 to 1966. Locally, Terry was a sustaining member of the Hopp Ground Garden Club. The Maxine's and was a member of St. Patrick's Church in Bedford, NY. She is survived by her husband, John C. Stevenson; son Timothy D. Stevenson, his wife, Meghan and granddaughters Merritt and Kenna of Trumbull, CT; daughter, Christine E. Stevenson of Sarasota, FL; son, William H. Stevenson and his wife, Rossana; son, Captain Thomas M. Stevenson of Ft. Rucker, AL; and daughter Anne T. Stevenson of Herndon, VA. In addition, she is survived by her brothers John E. Lawler of Yonkers, NY; Brendan A. Lawler of Somers, NY; Lawrence S. Lawler of Mamaroneck, NY; Robert P. Lawler of Seaford, NY and her sisters Joan Cirrone of San Luis Obispo, CA and Kathleen Gerard of Cortlandt, NY.Family members who died earlier include her father, Daniel in 1967 and her mother, Margaret in 1975. She was also predeceased by her sisters, Marjorie Slaiman in 2002 and Patricia Odell in 2003 and her brothers Daniel in 1990 and James in 2004. Calling hours are 2:00 pmto 4:00 pm and 7:00 pm to 9:00 pm on Saturday and 2:00 pm to 5:00 pm on Sunday at Cassidy Flynn Funeral Home, 288 Main Street,Mt. Kisco, NY. The funeral is at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford, NY at 10 AM. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. Friends may send memorial donations to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, Suite 8400, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10131-0112

title: Brooklyn Officer's Shot Misses Suspect and Grazes Comrade
description: A Brooklyn police officer accidentally shot another officer in the leg yesterday while trying to shoot at a teenager who was pointing a gun at him, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DIMOND, THOMAS
description: DIMOND--Thomas. Friend, counselor and benefactor, today we join your friends and loved ones in celebrating your memory. Love, Wiebke & Tim Sullivan

title: 2nd Autopsy in Youth Boot Camp Death Fails to End Questions
description: MIAMI, March 17 - Martin Lee Anderson was buried a second time this week, more than two months after he died following a confrontation with guards at a boot camp for teenage offenders in the Florida Panhandle. But questions about his death, and whether the state should close all its boot camps in the aftermath, are very much alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOMBERG, CAROL
description: TOMBERG--Carol. On March 17, 2006. Beloved sister of Iris and Linda. Cherished sisterin-law of Bernie and Mickey. Loving aunt of Michael and Emily, Debbie, Steven and Barbara, Betsy and David, Laura and Richard, and Ricky. A woman of strength, creativity and a lover of the arts. We will miss you. Graveside service Sunday 11 AM at the Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing.

title: Port Authority Rejects Silverstein's Offer to Talk

title: John Wilde, 86, Painter of Surreal Comic Images, Dies

title: The Chick-Lit Pandemic
description: IN the near decade since Bridget Jones first hit the world stage -- endearing, hung over and running late for work -- an international commuter train of women has been gathering speed close behind. From Mumbai to Milan, Gdansk to Jakarta, regional varieties of chick lit have been sprouting, buoyed by the demographic that's both their subject and readership: 20- and 30-something women with full-time jobs, discretionary income and a hunger for independence and glamour.

title: A Premiere for the State And for the New Conductor
description: IT'S an unusual task for any composer: Write a symphonic work that pays homage to New Jersey. But it should also celebrate a new conductor, share a program with Mendelssohn and Shostakovich, justify its expense and serve as an orchestra's single world premiere for an entire concert season.

title: Extreme Vintage Makeover
description: LIKE a family that dispersed over the decades, then gathered all at once for a family reunion, the furniture from the old house on Lyme Street in Old Lyme will be coming home soon.

title: Can a Mediator Heal the Rift in the Diocese?
description: SAYING that Long Island Catholics cannot continue to endure deep divisions in their diocese, a group of priests is calling on Bishop William F. Murphy and an influential lay group, the Long Island Voice of the Faithful, to let a mediator help settle longstanding differences.

title: The House Calls

"This house once had extensive termite damage," said Mr. Zappulla, who owns Zappulla Property Inspections, also in Manasquan, which covers Ocean, Monmouth, Middlesex and Union Counties.

title: A Familiar Photo, Reconsidered
description: To the Editor:

title: The Remix; The Art Hotel
description: On a list of things that Louisville, Ky., is known for, cutting-edge art ranks somewhere far below baseball bats, horse racing and good bourbon. Steve Wilson hopes to change that. With his wife, Laura Lee Brown, Wilson is scheduled to open a boutique hotel, 21C (for 21st century), in April that will showcase works from his $10 million art collection. All the artists represented are living, and the art is daring -- Andres Serrano's photos of the homeless, a mouse-infested video from the Brooklyn artist Adam Stennett. (Many of the more confrontational works will be displayed in a free museum inside the hotel, and the 90 rooms will feature smaller works on paper.) Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 21C occupies five buildings (four warehouses and a bank) that cost $26 million to renovate and took six years to complete. It will be part of the city's downtown renaissance, which includes a science center and the Muhammad Ali cultural center. Welcome to the new Louisville, slugger. 21C Museum Hotel, 700 West Main Street; (502)589-4690; www.21cmuseumhotel.com. PAUL L. UNDERWOOD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UNGERS, SIMON
description: UNGERS--Simon, 1957-2006. Architect and artist, passed away on Monday, March 6, in Cologne, Germany after a long illness. He was probably best known for the critically acclaimed "T-House" in Upstate New York. He was internationally known and respected not only as an architect, but also as an artist who maintained a lifelong investigation into abstraction, reversal and the void. Simon is survived by his wife, Janet O'Hair, his parents, Liselotte and Mathias Ungers, sisters, Sibylle Rowan and Sophia Ungers. A memorial service will be held at the AIA, Center for Architecture, 536 LaGuardia Place, NYC, Wednesday, March 22, at 6 PM.

title: Red Bulls Offer Free Trip to Opener
description: The New York Red Bulls of Major League Soccer are offering the team's fans a free trip to Washington for the club's 2006 season opener against D.C. United on April 2.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 19-March 25; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Aficionados of large-form chamber music know those hidden gems: Mozart's Gran Partita for 13 instruments, the Schubert Octet for winds and strings, the Dvorak Wind Serenade. On Sunday, a member of that category gets a hearing at Weill Recital Hall: the BEETHOVEN SEPTET, for clarinet, bassoon, French horn, violin, viola, cello and double bass, which was one of Beethoven's most popular pieces during his lifetime. The performers are the MET CHAMBER ENSEMBLE. The program includes a fine contrasting spread of pieces by Schoenberg, Berg, Carter and Webern. 5 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; $92.

description: TESTED: Chevrolet Malibu Maxx WHAT IS IT? Four-door midsize sedan with a hatch in lieu of a trunk. WHAT MAKES IT RUN? 3.5-liter pushrod V-6 (201 horsepower); four-speed automatic; front-wheel drive. HOW MUCH? Base LT $20,790, LTZ $24,090. Test car $24,240 including $1,270 option group 1SB (front-seat side air bags, side curtain bags, rear audio controls with headphones, six-way power driver's seat, remote starter), $995 DVD entertainment system. title: Home Economics
description: My compliments to Jon Gertner for his wonderfully informative article on Edward L. Glaeser, the Harvard economist who has been revitalizing urban economics (March 5). I enjoyed the details of his investigations of factors affecting the supply of housing and other structures that may help to explain their rapid increase in value in major cities. When I was growing up, I watched my father, an urban planner, write very detailed zoning codes for small, fast-growing cities. Reading your article, I now realize that I may have my father and his profession to thank in part for the rapid appreciation in the value of my house.

title: Final Thoughts
Dark Days for Tony Soprano
description: The first episode of the new season of "The Sopranos" literally ended with a bang last week. Tony Soprano had a bullet in the belly, after being shot by his increasingly demented Uncle Junior, and the show's fans were left wondering if he would survive. The episode also featured a vicious mob beating, a snitch dropping dead in an F.B.I. agent's car, and a suicide by hanging. Season 6's dark and bloody premiere was a reminder of why "The Sopranos" is one of the most compelling television shows in a long time. But it also suggests why viewership may decline this year, as it seems to have done already.

title: Correction

title: The Other Florence
description: Passing through on Highway 72, you could easily mistake Florence, Ala., for a backwater of Winn-Dixies and double-wide trailers. But turn off, and the city -- population 36,264 -- soon reveals its attractions: elegant 19th-century buildings, a living musical heritage and very fine fried okra. Five years ago, when Natalie Chanin returned home to start her clothing company, Project Alabama -- known for high-fashion garments that are hand-stitched by local quilters -- she was a pioneer, but today Florence is in full swing.

Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance by e-mail, to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959.

title: The Ticket; Hush Money: $470 Spirit Rock Meditation Center
description: Too much talk can be toxic. A week of golden silence can be surprisingly affordable. Vipassana meditation centers, located on both coasts, promise to cleanse your mind without taking you to the cleaners.

description: THE DOCTOR'S DAUGHTER

title: The Doctors Daughter
description: The moment I awoke I knew that something was terribly wrong. I could feel it in that place behind my breastbone, where bad news always slides in like junk mail through a slot. It was there that I first acknowledged my parents would die someday ("Oh, sweetheart, but not for such a long, long time!"); where I knew I was ugly and would never be loved; where I suffered spasms of regret about my marriage and my children, and fear of their deaths and of my own. God knows there were plenty of things wrong in the larger world I could easily have named, and that aroused a similar sense of dread, but whatever was lodged in my chest that April morning was personal, not global. I knew that much, at least.

She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Memorial service Sunday, March 26, 11 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

description: My congratulations to Michael Sokolove for his thoughtful insights in his March 5 Lives column. I've tucked it away to reread and remind me that I am not alone in mourning the changes to the neighborhood. The aesthetic, emotional and physical consequences of the current building boom have not received nearly enough attention in the press. Sokolove hit the nail on the construction head!

description: STRATTON, Vt., March 18 - This has been the year of Shaun White. He won the three foremost snowboarding events of 2006 -- first the Winter X-Games, then the Olympics and, on Saturday, the United States Open Championships.

title: The State of Iraq: An Update
description: AS we reach the third anniversary of the start of the war, the confusion on the ground in Iraq seems to have spread to American generals' public pronouncements. Last Monday, just days after saying that pacification efforts with the Iraqis were going "very, very well," Gen. Peter Pace, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told an audience that Iraq is "a place that is having some real difficulties right now" and that "everything is in place if they want to have a civil war." Unfortunately, an examination of trends in Iraq backs up General Pace's later, more sober comments.

title: I Need to Woman Up and Do This on My Own

At 21 he had been convicted of a gang-related murder, which occurred three years before, and on this day he was in the 13th year of a 20-year sentence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, JOSEPH ADRIAN CLAIRMONT
description: MOORE -- Joseph Adrian Clairmont, 76, passed away peacefully on March 15th. He leaves behind the legacy of a loving family; Mary Somers Moore, his sister Patricia Ryan, his children Christopher Somers Moore, Frederick Clairmont Moore II, Mary-Elizabeth Ward Moore, Anne Clairmont Moore, and Alison Moore Harris, his longtime companion Bernard Baxter, his grandchildren Emerson Moore, Timothy Moore, their mother Juliet Faber Moore and his son-in-law King Harris. Early on, he learned firsthand the rudiments of international business from his Canadian father, Frederick C. Moore, who joined the fledgling General Motors Corporation during its formative years. Mr. Moore retired from a career that spanned four decades of successfully resolving a wide variety of public relations challenges. During his career at Eaton Corporation, he pioneered the broad multinational corporate approach to doing business when he spearheaded the corporate communications staff. In 1971, Moore edited PR Quarterly's two issue special on multinationalism --then a brand new word coined by Business Week. He later established Moore & Company, whose clients included Prudential-Bache Securities, Brunschwig et Fils and numerous non-profit foundations. His love of history and antiques manifested itself in his last endeavour, Moore & Company Antiques. A memorial service will be held on April 21st, 10:30 AM, at St. Thomas More Church, 89th Street between Park and Madison Avenues. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Calvary Hospice, New York.

He is survived by wife, Keiko; daughters, Shannon Lea Lucansky & Sayako Huddleston. They dread appearing vulnerable and keep silent until, all too often, personal relationships have been damaged beyond repair.

title: The Ticket; Two Hundred And Fifty Dollars To Bounce Away Your Toxins
description: Unless new information emerges on the health benefits of Twister, rebounding is likely to remain the most painless (and ridiculous-looking) way to detox for the foreseeable future. The process -- involving a mere 15 minutes a day of bouncing on a minitrampoline -- is said to be good for cleansing the lymphatic system, all while you grin like an idiot. The Needak Rebounder -- $250; www.needak-ebounders.com -- is a trampoline small enough to fold up and fit in a special purse so that you can look like a dork on the road, too. Hooray!

title: A New Spot, Irish in Name Only
description: REVELERS looking for a bar to celebrate St. Patrick's Day might have been a little disappointed if they went into F. H. Riley's in Huntington. Despite its name, this new spot is not an Irish pub but a white tablecloth American fusion bistro.

title: Working on His Movie Star Badge
description: Two years after "Napoleon Dynamite" popped up at the Sundance Film Festival and went on to become a cult hit, Hollywood is finally figuring out what to do with Jon Heder, the film's lanky, likable, but decidedly unconventional star. Mr. Heder, now 28, has six films headed toward the screen, including "The Benchwarmers," set for release on April 7 by Sony Pictures and Revolution Studios, and "School for Scoundrels," a Weinstein Company comedy. In addition, Fox is releasing a special-edition "Napoleon Dynamite" DVD on May 16.

Both seem destined for N.B.A. careers, but both were merely role players Saturday on the biggest play of the season for L.S.U.

title: Giving Birth to 'Baby,' in Front of Everyone
description: TERE O'CONNOR is more than just another choreographer. He is deeply invested in the work of younger artists, whom he has come to know through his classes in dance composition. He is a fiery addition to most panel discussions, even when he is in the audience. His writing, like his talking, can waver between frustratingly opaque and incredibly lucid. When it's good, it reflects the same qualities found in the best of his dances: a cogent balance of logic and poetry.

title: Where Parking Is Scarce, as Are the Signs
description: With all its nautical clutter, Bridge Street on City Island in the Bronx resembles a collection of maritime clichs. On the west side of the street, against the water, sit a yacht-sales outfit -- its hulls leaning against each other, and swathed in plastic -- and a place where beer and bait can be bought at the same counter. The salty sea winds blow through the street and make the hinged store signs flap, and the wood-frame houses have weathered to a dull gray.

title: Cash and Carry Democracy
description: THE fact that an individual is allowed to give more money to a candidate for New York State office than to a presidential contender should tell New Yorkers that our campaign finance laws need to be fixed.

title: Dream House
description: When the artist Gustave Moreau died in 1898, he bequeathed his three-story house, containing more than 1,200 paintings and 12,800 drawings, to the French state. His only wish was that the collection be kept together forever. "Taken as a whole," he stated, "they give an idea of what kind of an artist I was, and in what kind of surroundings I chose to live my dreams."

title: A Pioneer Knows When to Move On
description: THE first time Pep Gay went to Brooklyn, he was scared. It was 1996, and he had arrived in New York a year earlier from Spain, where he had spent his youth helping cut meat at his parents' carnicera in Barcelona.

description: TECHNOLOGY stocks are supposed to be the vehicle of choice for investors interested in high-powered gains. So why have many of the biggest names been such laggards lately?

title: Spain Scrambles to Cope With Tide of African Migrants
description: MADRID, March 18 - Spain's deputy prime minister began an emergency visit to the Canary Islands on Saturday to discuss ways to control a record flow of African migrants arriving in boats from Mauritania that has led to at least 25 deaths in the last week.

title: On Advertising: Monitoring a market
Spiking at Sublime
description: SOMERSET - GO to Jo-Sho, and before the night is out and you are full of mysteriously crunchy raw octopus pickle -- or rice-wrapped salmon balls, or exceedingly delicate and succulent egg custard with seafood, or impossibly light tempura -- you may be humming that Beatles tune, or at least thinking of the lyrics: "I don't know why you say goodbye, I say hello.

title: Go With God
description: A waterbuck charges up the hill and forages in the shade of a spiky candelabra-shaped euphorbia tree. Impala and Thomson's gazelles graze on the plains below, just a few miles from Lake Nakuru National Park, in Kenya. Rain is in the air; squalls scud across the wide valley floor, drenching the parched grassland. Tomorrow the flowers will bud, and the yellow and gray grasses will show a fluorescent green sheen. Chris Foot, a lay preacher with the Vineyard church, offers cocktails from a brass-bound chop box on a card table. "Footstep Safaris is where Dom Prignon meets the Bible," Foot says as he serves vodka, gin and single-malt Scotch to the group. "My safaris are for people who want to take God on vacation with them."

title: A Curve Too Far Throws Jagr for a Loop
description: The Rangers' Jaromir Jagr, perhaps the N.H.L.'s best player, was disqualified from participating in a shootout March 8 in Atlanta because the curve of his stick blade was deemed illegal. That incident helped ignite a debate over the rule.

title: High: Vegas on $1,000 a Day
description: THERE he was, Mr. Barry Manilow, looking retro-glam and kinda-fab, splashed across a billboard on my way from the Las Vegas airport to the Mandalay Bay Hotel. Red satin jacket, plenty of hair, dreamy smile. He was playing the Hilton, and I had $1,000 to spend. But on Barry Manilow? I didn't think so.

title: An editor's dose of harmony for Little Saigon's wounds
Having a Blast, for a Good Cause
description: COLIN PEPPARD doesn't exactly conjure the image of a philanthropist. Lanky with a mop of tousled hair, he works for a nonprofit and rides public transportation most places. Mr. Peppard has never been invited to a black-tie gala charity event, nor has he written any $500 checks to save the children, the dolphins or the rain forests. Young, male and short on expendable income, Mr. Peppard is, by all demographic qualifiers, the anti-donor.

description: New Jersey is home to many sites that offer echoes of the Revolutionary War, even more than 200 years later. After all, George Washington and his troops marched from the Hudson to the Delaware, and historical markers abound.

title: Lesley Friedsam and Peter Damisch
description: THEY met at a grave site, a beautifully desolate spot at the bottom of the planet typically inhabited by king penguins and southern elephant seals. In December 2003 Lesley Jennifer Friedsam, a divorce lawyer, and Peter Whiton Damisch, an owner of a sailing school and sailboat chartering company, had each been lured there by a passion for icebergs, wildlife and adventure.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 19-March 25; POP/JAZZ
description: MARCELO D2, the rapper from the popular Brazilian band Planet Hemp, jostles hip-hop against samba rhythms on his recent record, "A Procurada de Batida Perfeita," produced by the Beastie Boys associate MARIO CALDATO JR. Earlier this year, Marcelo D2 was one of the saving graces on the new Sergio Mendes record, but that may not have done him any favors in introducing him to American audiences. Perhaps his show this week will help. Opening for him is CURUMIN, a singer from So Paolo, whose own first album, "Achados e Perdidos," embraces 1970's Brazilian funk from a modern hip-hop perspective. Wednesday at 9 p.m., S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston, South Village, (212) 243-4940; $18 in advance, $22 day of show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PECK, JANE REIFFEL
description: PECK--Jane Reiffel. March 16, 2006 at home in Chappaqua, NY. Wife of Robert B. Peck. Sister of Betty Ann Bry. Mother of Lisa Peck MacPhail, Amy Peck Sinsheimer, Susan Peck Kineke; motherin-law of Allen MacPhail, Ralph Sinsheimer, Paul Kineke. Grandmother ("Mimi") of Lucy, Bryan, Kate MacPhail; Max, Teddy, Molly Sinsheimer; Emily, Jay Kineke. Born February 21, 1929 to the late Isidore and Antoinette Reiffel. Florist, artist, avid traveler, matriarch of her loving family. Creative and full of life, she will be dearly missed by the many who loved her. Funeral private, memorial at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Jacob Burns Film Center, Pleasantville, New York. "Earth laughs in flowers." --Ralph Waldo Emerson.

title: Border War
description: Warminster, Pa. - THE horticultural world is having its own debate over immigration, with some environmentalists warning about the dangers of so-called exotic plants from other countries and continents "invading" American gardens. These botanical xenophobes say that a pristine natural state exists in our yards and that to disturb it is both sinful and calamitous. In their view, exotic plants will swallow your garden, your neighbors' gardens and your neighbors' neighbors' gardens until the ecosystem collapses under their rampant suffocating growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAYS, HENRY ''CHARLIE''
description: SHAYS -- Henry "Charlie". Loved by his wife Rona, five children, seven grandchildren, and sister, Charlie Shays died March 13, 2006 in Sarasota, FL. A son of immigrants and CCNY and Yale Law School graduate, Charlie will be remembered as a man who loved his family, friends, clients, and his dog, Max. He held infinite information and a huge intellect with an unsurpassed wit. Passionate about lawyering, Judaism and collecting, Charlie was a fiercely moral man who lived what he taught. A beloved curmudgeon, he had a great run. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Doctors Without Borders or the charity of your choice. A Memorial Service will be held in Sarasota at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINSTON, RICHARD ALAN
description: WINSTON--Richard Alan Passed away on March 15, due to complications following surgery. He was 78. He is survived by his wife and best friend of 18 years, Susan Harnick Winston; daughters Lisa Winston Wilentz and Stephanie Winston-Vann; granddaughter Dana Wilentz: sonsin-law Wayne Wilentz and Christopher Van; sister Carol Herman Janis and beloved cats Marcel, Winnie, Trixie and Norton. He was predeceased by his wife of 24 years, Zena Lakriz Winston; parents Charles and Gertude Winston and cat Rex. A baseball and swimming star at Horace Mann School, where he was also president of his senior class of 1945, he chose to forego a possible future on the pitcher's mound to join the family business, Harry Winston Inc., founded by his uncle. He worked at Harry Winston for 56 years as sales executive and Vice President. Richard will be remembered by everyone who knew him for his gift of making everyone he met feel like a friend for life, his passion for fishing, and most of all his love for his family, friends and life. A memorial service will take place April 20 at 2:30 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York, New York. Contributions in his memory can be made to The New York Hospital Weill-Cornell Breast Center 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10021

Yet keen amateurs -- whether their sporting tastes run toward meat and potatoes or pheasant and leek -- are no less in need of a focused period of practice to sharpen their skills and prepare for the season. title: Cross-Country Dining
description: Across-country road trip is a great excuse to eat burgers and chips. It's also a unique opportunity to see what American chefs are doing with local ingredients. My recent journey from San Francisco to New York had a high-low theme, thanks, in great part, to Mike Sarcona, a San Francisco classic-car broker who found me the '78 Porsche 911 Targa of my dreams -- at a price that would make a Saturn blush. My boyfriend, Oliver, and I decided to keep lunches and snacks to local, 1978-priced pit stops, while dinners were Porsche-appropriate feasts that required rather dexterous parking-lot wardrobe changes.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: BHUTAN
description: ABOVE THE PARO VALLEY, NOV. 15, 2005 - Franois Suquet, a retired oil engineer from Aix-en-Provence, France, gazes at the Taktsang monastery, an ancient holy site. "Each year, I organize a trip for a group of friends, and we go someplace different, mixing a few days of physical activity with a place that's culturally interesting. We were surprised at how long it took to hike to the monastery. At first, it seemed far. Then it suddenly seemed to be quite close, and we thought we were nearly there, before realizing, 'No, we still have another hour.' It was impressive that people had been climbing up there to pray since the eighth or ninth century, according to what they told us. And, in visiting the inside of all those little chapels, we discovered at once the richness of the decoration and the intensity of those praying, who seemed completely enchanted by this mythic space. " As told to Austin Considine

title: Amid the Facades, Furrowed Brows
description: ON May 22, 1936, the photographer Berenice Abbott ambled along the Brooklyn waterfront, thrilling to river-wrapped vistas and old warehouses that glowered with imposing grandeur. Crossing the narrow streets on one of her celebrated sorties to shoot the surging metropolis for the federal Works Progress Administration, she turned her lens upon a sleek new structure rising at 11 Water Street, beneath the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Home Economics
description: There is a certain "let them eat cake" aspect to the anti-zoning view. Almost no one with money, despite the rhetoric, is actually against zoning; you can see the truth of this by examining areas that are nominally against zoning, like Houston. In such areas, the very first thing many people do when they get money is to move into private communities, with private zoning.

I resist the urge to leap from bed and whip up a 1-2-3 yellow cake from my fudge-stained, dogeared "Joy of Cooking."

title: Memories of the Future

The article also renders part of a quotation from her incorrectly. title: Inside the List
description: DOG'S LIFE: John Grogan's "Marley & Me," about the misadventures of "the world's worst dog," and James L. Swanson's "Manhunt," about the search for Lincoln's assassin, continue to move serious units -- Grogan's book is No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list for the sixth consecutive week, and Swanson's is No. 4. Careful students of the best-seller list won't be surprised: dog books and Lincoln books are longtime regulars on this page. (Asked to come up with a surefire best-seller title, the Random House co-founder Bennett Cerf is said to have replied: "Lincoln's Doctor's Dog.") As it happens, the Book Review hasn't reviewed Grogan's book, or Swanson's. Why not? The long answer: Both books were read carefully by editors here, and their merits were weighed against the hundreds of other books we receive each month. The short answer: We get a lot of books about dogs and Lincoln. I finally bought a copy of "Marley & Me" last week, not long after my son's puppy ate, in two sickening gulps, the decomposed body of a car-flattened squirrel. (I wanted to see if Marley could top that -- the answer, basically, is yep.) The prose in Grogan's book is as friendly and as sloppy -- and, ultimately, as annoying -- as a golden retriever who won't get his head out of your lap. It's easy to see why some of Grogan's colleagues at The Philadelphia Inquirer, where he is a columnist, are puzzled about, and envious of, his success. (Philadelphia magazine recently printed a story about Grogan filled with mean, and unattributed, comments from his co-workers about his "cutesy-poo" writing.) Grogan is having the last laugh, however. More than a million copies of "Marley & Me" are in print, and film rights have been sold to the producer of "Dude, Where's My Car?"

title: The Stuff That Happened
description: Three years ago, the United States invaded Iraq. We can all run the story through our minds: Shock and Awe, Coalition of the Willing, Mission Accomplished, looting, "Stuff happens," no W.M.D., suicide bombers, purple fingers, blasted shrine.

title: Deep in China, a Poor and Pious Muslim Enclave
description: DONGXIANG, China - No, the old man answered, standing in his bare home deep in a mountain ravine, he had never seen an airplane. The man, Tie Yongxiang, has never watched television, either. He listened to the pop quiz and seemed pleased when he could answer the last question in the affirmative.

title: Bratislava Weekend

Translation: take it easy, relax and have a good time. It's also the name of Slovakia's famous music festival, a sure tip-off to the national temperament.

title: Mozart Concertos, His Way
description: THE Polish-Hungarian pianist Piotr Anderszewski brings myriad colorings, a poetic sensibility and a prodigious though idiosyncratic technique to his performances. He is also known for his fiercely original interpretations, and this aspect of his playing can sometimes be perplexing. In his extraordinary recital last season at Zankel Hall, he gave an expansive account of Bach's formidable Overture in the French Style and demonic performances of searching works by the Polish composer Karol Szymanowski. But what sent everyone home talking was his craggy, mystical and inexorable account of Chopin's Sonata in B minor. His conception may not have been the way I think of the piece, but I will never forget having heard it.

title: Hideout Hideaway
description: When the Colombian cocaine kingpin Pablo Escobar wanted to get away, he would fly to his two oceanfront mansions in Tulum, Mexico. Hidden in the jungle, the estate was a place for refuge, wild parties and business. According to locals, helicopters landed on the roof at all hours. In 2005, 12 years after his death, the properties were acquired by Melissa Perlman, a New Yorker who had started the nearby Bikini Boot Camp. Casa Magna ("Pure House") opened to paying guests in December; the other is to open this year. Casa Magna has eight palatial bedrooms ($3,900 a week). Lounge in a hammock on the beach, snorkel the reef or venture into a maze of tunnels: You never know what you'll find. -- JULIE EARLE-LEVINE

title: A Serving of Comedy, Steamed
description: KRISTEN SCHAAL is arguing vehemently that Christopher Columbus sailed the ocean blue in 1592. Or 1692? Fortunately Ms. Schaal, who looks a bit like Betty Boop, is not a historian -- she's an award-winning comic. Last weekend she was named the best alternative comedian in the country at the annual Aspen comedy festival in her native Colorado. In November she won the New York Comedy Festival's Andy Kaufman Award. In between getting awards, she is a host, with Kurt Braunohler, of "Hot Tub," a weekly variety show in the Peoples Improv Theater in Manhattan, featuring everything from jugglers to burlesque.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUESTONE, DR. HARVEY
description: BLUESTONE -- Dr. Harvey. The Board of Trustees of Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, as well as its medical, nursing, administrative, and Department of Psychiatry staff mourn the passing of Dr. Harvey Bluestone. Dr. Bluestone served, with distinction, as Chairman of Bronx-Lebanon's Department of Psychiatry. During his 40 years of service, the hospital's Department of Psychiatry emerged as a leader in the mental health field, widely recognized for its comprehesive, innovative, and results-oriented programs at the inpatient and outpatient levels. The Bronx-Lebanon family extend our sincere condolences to the Bluestone family. Shirley Rodriguez Remeneski Chairperson, Board of Trustees Miguel A. Fuentes, Jr. President and CEO Dr. Milton A. Gumbs, VP Medical Affairs, Medical Director
