title: My Island Paradise
description: I wanted to take a trip with my girlfriend before we had our baby. She was about six months pregnant, and we both felt we needed one last fling with freedom before we were saddled with the excruciating pleasure of raising a child. Amy wanted to go to Mexico, to the beach. I had never been. I was slightly uncomfortable with the idea of Mexico. I was sure it was great, but I have an aversion to "great." Everyone I know had been to Mexico and enjoyed it, therefore "Why go?" was my feeling. I had this strange impulse to make the trip wonderfully terrible.

title: An Italian Personality All Its Own
description: LARCHMONT - IF Lusardi's, the venerable Italian restaurant at the center of this restaurant-rich village, were a Lamborghini, then the youthful Globe Bar and Grill, opened three years ago, would be the Vespa parked next door. With its saut station and wood-burning pizza oven in full view, the Globe offers show and substance in an atmosphere that, while bordering on raucous, promises an enjoyable night out.

title: In Secret Unit's 'Black Room,' a Grim Portrait of U.S. Abuse
description: Correction Appended

title: Lauren Levy and Joseph Harburger
description: Lauren Julie Levy, a daughter of Susan Heumann Levy and Alan Levy of Larchmont, N.Y., is to be married today in Old Greenwich, Conn., to Dr. Joseph Michael Harburger, the son of Roselyn Fischer Harburger and James A. Harburger of Katonah, N.Y. Rabbi Jeffrey Segelman is to officiate at the Hyatt Regency Greenwich.

title: Paternal Care
description: An attorney with experience in paternity-fraud cases, I was called by a man dating a divorced woman who told him her ex-husband is unaware that he is not the biological father of two of her three children; he pays child support and visits all three. My caller wonders if he should tell the ex-husband, whom he knows. He has no legal obligation to, but does the golden rule suggest an ethical one?

title: Standing Corrected
description: Soon after his appearance during the Super Bowl halftime show, Mick Jagger was berated in this space for saying, "All things come to he who waits." With icy humility, I explained that the sentence should go, "All things come to him who waits."

title: Smoking Ban Takes Effect, Indoors and Out
description: CALABASAS, Calif., March 17 - One of the toughest antismoking laws in the nation took effect here Friday, the same day that a satirical movie about a reptilian tobacco lobbyist, "Thank You for Smoking," opened across the country.

title: Drive, He Said: Anthony Invests In Auto Racing
description: If the rookie Indy Car driver P. J. Chesson can accelerate as fast as his new car's namesake (the Honda-Dallara will be called the Car-Melo), then one of the stranger sports crossovers in recent years will be a success.

title: How Pop Sounded Before It Popped
description: FOR a couple of months now my iPod has been stuck on Stella Mayhew's "I'm Looking for Something to Eat." It's a lurching little waltz-time pop tune, drawled over brass-band accompaniment. The lyric is hilarious, the lament of a gal on a diet who can't stop eating, and it climaxes with a glutton's soul cry: "I want some radishes and olives, speckled trout and cantaloupe and cauliflower/ Some mutton broth and deviled crabs and clams and Irish stew." I can't get it out of my head -- so far, it's my favorite record of 2006.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAYNARD, RUTH CORSON
description: MAYNARD -- Ruth Corson. Passed away peacefully at her home in Boca Grande, FL. on March 13 at the age of 60 after a valiant year-long battle with cancer. Beloved sole sister of Meg Gilsten Hale. Loving aunt of Rachel Hale and Lucas (and Michelle) Hale. Daughter of the late Ann and Sydney Wildman. Graduate of Skidmore College. At the time of her death she was a Managing Consultant with Fitch Ratings in the public finance group. Her career as a municipal bond analyst spanned over 38 years. Ruth was fiercely independent and did things her way, as anyone who knew her would agree. She defied convention when it came to medical advice and drove alone in her beloved Mercedes from Florida to New York and back this summer as well as from Florida to Dallas for Thanksgiving. She was an inspiration to all who knew her. For information regarding a memorial service please contact Ruth Navedo at 212-908-0500 ext 422. Donations in her memory may be made to Skidmore College Advancement Office for the Ann Wildman Scholarship Fund at 815 North Broadway, Saratoga Springs, NY 12866 or to Heifer Project Int'l, PO Box 8058 Little Rock, AR 72203.

title: Believers, Atheists and Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items should be submitted by mail at least three weeks in advance to New Jersey Cultural Calendar, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Here to Stay. For Now.
description: AFTER living for 14 years on four acres in Bedford, Greg Smith and Deborah Dodds were ready for a change. With 9-year-old twins, they wanted a home in a neighborhood, the kind of place where there are lots of kids and a spare cup of sugar is as close as the kitchen next door.

title: An Injustice Is an Injustice
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 19-March 25; DANCE
description: Yes, the monthlong celebration of the 25th anniversary of the MARK MORRIS DANCE GROUP has already been under way for almost two weeks, and you've seen Program A and B, and visited all three associated photographic exhibitions. But there's more to come, quite aside from Program C, which includes the New York premiere of Mr. Morris's most recent creation, "Candleflowerdance." This week, the Brooklyn Academy of Music adds "Morris & Movies" to its offerings: a collection of Mr. Morris's favorite films that includes Erich Von Stroheim's "Greed" on Thursday night; Vincente Minnelli's "Cabin in the Sky" on Friday; and Robert Altman's "Nashville" on Saturday. "The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T" and "Martin" (a vampire movie that Mr. Morris claims to identify deeply with) follow on March 26 and 27. Each film is preceded by shorts about Mr. Morris and his company -- true aficionados would not want to miss a rare Sesame Street appearance preceding "Fingers."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, LEROY BENATAR
description: BLOCK--Leroy Benatar, 88. A Madison Avenue legend in his time while at Grey Advertising, later a great financial adviser, died peacefully at home on March 17. Roy was a Captain in psychological warfare in World War II. At Dartmouth College (class of '38) he played in the Barbary Coast Orchestra. Beloved by his many dear friends and his long-time companion Doris Willens Kaplan. Visiting Saturday March 18, 2-5PM and Sunday March 19, 11AM-2PM at Nolan Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave., Northport, L.I. (631-754-2400). Memorial service at a later date.

title: The Remix; Peel Me a Grape
description: The ultimate "Sideways" trip for New World wine lovers is Mendoza, Argentina, just west of Buenos Aires. A new hotel, Cavas Wine Lodge, has opened in time for this season's harvest -- between early March and April. Situated on 35 acres of vineyards overlooking the Andes, Cavas is only a short drive from the award-winning producers of malbec and torrontes varietals. Hedonism is encouraged. Cavas's wine cellar carries a substantial selection of South American wines, and deluxe cabanas -- sleek adobe huts with plunge pools, interior stone walls, claw-foot tubs and outdoor showers -- practically sit amid the grapes. But there is more to do than drink wine: a special spa package includes a crushed-malbec scrub. Cavas Wine Lodge, Costaflores s/n, Alto Agrelo; 011 54 261 410 6651; ww.cavaswinelodge.com; doubles start at $310. Gisela Williams

title: Death Valley, Calif.: These Ghost Towns Have Clean Sheets
description: IN the moonlight 8,200 feet up on the ridgeline of the Inyo Mountains, one can make out the remains of a dozen miners' shacks slung across a ravine almost eight miles up a steep dirt road twisting up from the desert plains of Owens Valley.

title: Major Changes Raise Concerns on Pension Bill
description: With a strong directive from the Bush administration, Congress set out more than a year ago to fashion legislation that would protect America's private pension system, tightening the rules to make sure companies set aside enough money to make good on their promises to employees.

title: Splitting Up, Hollywood-Style,Means a Settlement and a Script
description: WANT to make sure your ex doesn't trash you to the tabloids? Hollywood lawyers have a simple solution: Write a script.

title: Restu Kusumaningrum and David Halpert
description: Restu Imansari Kusumaningrum and David Cyrus Halpert were married in New York on Friday by Judge Pierre N. Leval of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York, who officiated in his chambers.

title: RESPECTING DIFFERENCES
description: To the Editor: I was enjoying reading Michelle Green's "Bon Voyage to the Three-Bean Salad" (Feb. 26). All that came to a halt when Ms. Green began recounting how put out she was by wheelchairs next to the elevators. She went on to use objectifying and stereotypical language to describe older people on the cruise. One of the few cruise mates she deemed worthy of her association she could call only a "retiree."

title: 6-Year-Old Boy Dies in Newark House Fire
description: A 6-year-old boy died and his mother and grandmother were injured yesterday after a fire tore through the family's three-story house in Newark, authorities said.

title: A 'Neglected' Master
description: Modern poetry is long on Lucite but short on cash. As Philip Larkin once put it, a good poet has no trouble amassing "medals and prizes and honorary this-and-thats . . . but if you turned round and said, Right, if I'm so good, give me an index-linked permanent income equal to what I can get for being an undistinguished university administrator -- well, reason would remount its throne pretty quickly." Larkin was British, but his remark applies just as well to American poetry, which often has been a game for the amply trust-funded (Stein, Lowell, Bishop, Merrill) with occasional participation from the upper-middle class, and only rare appearances by actual po' folks (James Wright). Larkin's observation also helps explain why "medals and prizes and honorary this-and-thats" can be as important in the poetry world as the currency they so closely resemble. After all, when what you're mostly hoping to earn is prestige, the coin of the realm is the gold star sticker.

title: Building Stories
description: PART 26: 9 p.m. THE FUNNY PAGES: I: THE STRIP

title: If a Co-op Kills a Sale, Should It Say Why?
description: A PROPOSED amendment to the New York City Human Rights Law that would require a co-op board to disclose why it rejected a prospective buyer has elicited sharp reactions from lawyers who represent co-op corporations.

title: Death Valley, Calif.: These Ghost Towns Have Clean Sheets
description: IN the moonlight 8,200 feet up on the ridgeline of the Inyo Mountains, one can make out the remains of a dozen miners' shacks slung across a ravine almost eight miles up a steep dirt road twisting up from the desert plains of Owens Valley.

title: All Components in Sync, Gators Make It Look Easy
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 18 - Florida's early exits from the N.C.A.A. tournament in recent years have prompted troublesome suggestions about the Gators' program. The two that stung the most were that Coach Billy Donovan could recruit players but not coach them, and that those players were too selfish to respond as a team in the tense moments of the postseason.

title: QUICK BITE/North Arlington; Leave the Gun, Take the Pizza
description: Which is America's most famous pizzeria? Is it Lombardi's in Manhattan? Perhaps Spago in Beverly Hills? May I humbly suggest PizzaLand in North Arlington. Since 1999, millions of television viewers have "driven by" the tiny brick-front building during the opening credits of "The Sopranos." With the HBO series finally back with new episodes, I thought the time was right to pull over.

title: G.O.P. Battles in Bergen, And Fallout Could Spread
description: TRENTON - If you want a nominee for Nastiest Political Fight in 2006, the front-runner, hands down, has been the bloodbath that has erupted within the usually genteel Bergen County Republican Party.

title: A Crime Against Springtime
description: Spring will begin on Tuesday, but despite the change of seasons, a pall will be hanging over Union Square. Late last month, a man was charged with destroying plants in the park, and whether or not he is responsible for the destruction, for winter-weary New Yorkers the toll is heavy.

title: If the Spirit Moves You
description: VIDEO art.

title: SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENTS' COMPENSATION
description: Local school boards in New Jersey, driven by stiff competition for top-flight administrators, have given them "questionable and excessive" compensation packages that cost taxpayers millions of dollars and are often hidden from public view, according to results of a review by state officials released last Monday. The review, by the State Commission of Investigation, examined the payrolls of dozens of school districts and found that boards of education around the state have lavished officials with cars, computers, cellphones, improper pension increases and donations to tax-deferred annuities.

title: Fair Labels
description: To the Editor:

title: Oh, How the Haughty Have Fallen
description: IN the eight years since he stopped playing Detective Frank Pembleton on the police psychodrama "Homicide: Life on the Street," Andre Braugher has been chipping away at the public memory of the character. The effort has taken myriad forms. There was the consigliere he played in the indie pulp film "Thick as Thieves," the self-doubting doctor in the short-lived television series "Gideon's Crossing" and the early civil-rights agitator A. Philip Randolph in the television movie "10,000 Men Named George," originally shown on Showtime.

title: Medals, Not Movies, Make Snowboarders Into Stars
description: In the mid-1990's, Jeremy Jones was not a household name in the burgeoning snowboarding industry. Then in 1998, he was featured in "Decade," a snowboarding video, and the exposure made him one of the most well-known professionals.

description: HELLER--Sophie It's been a year and we miss your spirit and remember you every day. Love, Saul

description: About 1,000 people gathered near Times Square yesterday, in one of dozens of energetic and often unfocused rallies held in cities across the United States and around the world to protest the third anniversary of the United States invasion of Iraq.

description: On the first day of training camp, Jaromir Jagr all but guaranteed that the Rangers would qualify for the playoffs for the first time since the 1996-97 season.

description: Jeremiah Clayton Jones discovered that his former fiance was pregnant just three weeks before the baby was due, when an adoption-agency lawyer called and asked if he would consent to have his baby adopted.

Some believe wormholes are the answer, others pin their hopes on Einstein's "spooky action at a distance," and the recent discovery of a cosmic string may be inspiring a new generation of prospective time-tourists.

title: London Restaurants Where Good Things Come on Small Plates
description: EVERY veteran eater knows that appetizers are the best part of the meal at most restaurants, and many have taken to skipping entrees entirely. The small-plates concept, as it's usually called, gives form to this urge, offering smaller portions in larger numbers. And that concept may have more appeal for travelers to London than anywhere else in the world; there, we who are not paid in pounds are desperate for anything that will reduce the cost of a meal.

description: First, it was the New York/New Jersey Metrostars. Then simply the MetroStars, which rankled enough people on this side of the Hudson.

description: 1. Symptoms

description: By all rights, Mayor Michael Bloomberg's influence in Albany should be at its peak. It is an election year, a time when political popularity and money translate into clout. Mr. Bloomberg is quite popular and quite rich.

title: Weekends With Dad, Courtesy of D.S.L.
description: WITH work and the school week behind them, Charles A. Mason III and his daughter, Arielle, who live more than 1,500 miles apart, prepared for their scheduled weekend visit. There was no packing involved, no plane tickets, no car rides or drop-offs. All it took was some instant messaging on their home computers and a little fidgeting in front of their respective Webcams, and father and daughter were chatting, playing checkers and practicing multiplication tables.

The engineer Michael Scofield (Wentworth Miller) has gotten himself sent to prison as part of an elaborate scheme to spring his wrongly convicted brother. But as the show returns tonight after a four-month break, one crucial element of Scofield's escape plan has even some devoted viewers snickering in disbelief: origami.

description: It was the best week for stocks since the beginning of the year, as several economic reports suggested that inflation was under control while economic growth remained strong. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index both ended the week at fresh five-year highs.

Posters, photographs and a blanket from the New York Rangers (Mr. Saglimbeni is a devoted fan) hang on the walls.

I despise "Seventh Heaven," I explained, and yet I watch it every single week -- I am powerless to stop myself. And I don't love to hate it; I hate to hate it.

description: THE BASICS -- For a long time the best Barcelona hotels were clustered around Eixample or along Las Ramblas. In recent years, boutique hoteliers have opened new accommodations that place guests in the heart of the scenic Gothic Quarter or the too-trendy barrio of Born. The Grand Hotel Central, close to Born and the Gothic quarter, but in neither, sits on a block that until now has housed only less grand establishments.

title: More Shameless Pandering to That Over-89 Demographic
description: "BEFORE there was 'American Idol,' before there was 'Star Search,' " Pat Boone intones, "there was a landmark broadcasting series that launched the revolution in discovering new talent." The show, "The Original Amateur Hour," was shown on various stations between 1948 and 1970. The leathery Mr. Boone is the host of a DVD retrospective of the nation's just-folks talent contest, which featured fiddling farmers, trombone-impersonating boiler builders and whistling dentists vying for the top spot. Viewers called in (or wrote postcards!) to vote for their favorite act each week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIJTVLIET, JOOP
description: WIJTVLIET--Joop, of Vinkeveen, the Netherlands, died unexpected at 64 of a massive heart attack on March 13, 2006, while traveling in the US. He is survived by his wife Susanne, their two children Tina and Peter, brothers Frank, Hans and Paul, sisters Beatrijs and Ine Wijtvliet. We are deeply saddened by our loss. Memorial services will follow at a later date. Contact address in US, 175 East 74th Steet, New York, NY 10021.

title: Home Sweet Debt
description: It was reassuring to know that a longtimehomeowner like Walter Kirn (March 5) shares the same anxieties as younger, first-time buyers like me,who came of age in the real-estate bubble, squeezed every bit of cash out of our equityand now find ourselves with rising home-equity rates,modest appreciation and a sales market that has slowed markedly in some regions. Real Estate 101 is a self-taught course for most people, and the costs of miscalculating are rising. Kirn has identified a number of issues that deserve serious exploration. I think he'll find a large body ofinterested and emotionally-involvedreaders.

description: Jeannette MacPherson Young and Joshua Nicholas Levine were married yesterday at Union Station in Los Angeles. Douglas Penick, an uncle of the bride and a Universal Life minister officiated in the Fred Harvey Room, a restaurant at the station.

description: To propose that it is a breakthrough for a University of Chicago-trained economist to "discover" that government intervention, in this case through zoning and permits, distorts the market and raises the prices of housing excessively is equivalent to expressing surprise that a fox thinks there should be more free-range chickens.

title: The Get; Bratislava Weekend
description: Forget the agenda. The last thing you need to enjoy a weekend in Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia, is a rigid schedule. The key word here is pohoda. Translation: take it easy, relax and have a good time. It's also the name of Slovakia's famous music festival, a sure tip-off to the national temperament. FEDERICO CHIARA

description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 18 - A Saturday evening that was supposed to help resurrect the heavyweight division turned out to be just another night in which it remained in limbo.

title: VACATION FROM WHAT?
description: Who needs a vacation when the office is in paradise? The Maui Land and Pineapple Company, whose biggest shareholder is Stephen M. Case, a founder of America Online, spent $18,651 last year to buy back unused vacation time from Brian C. Nishida, an executive vice president.

title: Earthly Delights
description: From Lima to Berlin, let the grass grow under your feet.

title: The Talk; Under Siege
description: The official museum of St. Petersburg, Russia, the one with the lines and the gift shop, is the State Hermitage Museum. With its endless Baroque and neo-Classical facade, its echoing, high-ceilinged halls and acres of exhibits, it embodies the city's expansive, opulent past. But when I'm in St. Petersburg, as I was last June, I head for the State Memorial Museum of the Defense and Siege of Leningrad, at 9 Solyanoy Pereulok. The museum is small, only two stories high, and modest. Much of the art inside is the work of amateurs. The artifacts are rusty. If the Hermitage is all about abundance, the Museum of the Siege -- familiarly known as the Blockade Museum -- is a monument to deprivation. It defines the zero level of human existence, how much human beings can be stripped of, how little they can subsist on and remain human.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEARLE, EVELYN
description: SEARLE--Evelyn. Died February 28, 2006 after a short illness. Her grandfather, Seligman, a banker, helped the Union cause and raised funds selling bonds to Great Britain. Ulysses S. Grant, upon his ascendancy to President of the United States, requested her grandfather to be the Secretary of the Treasury. He declined. Eve traveled with an acting group performing Noel Coward plays touring both Connecticut and New York which horrified her grandfather prompting him to hire detectives to bring her home. Born in New York City, she attended Brearley in NY, later transferred to Swiss schools; spent four years in Paris, graduated, thereafter studied art in Paris, Venice, and Florence, Italy, studying at the Pitti and the Uffizi Galleries daily. Her father in the late 20's bought a villa in Cannes. Eve served as a hostess. Following World War II she worked processing American soldiers. Her primary interest was psychology and mental health. She moved to Topeka, KS, met psychiatrist Professor Karl Menninger, admired him and attended classes for psychiatrists. Professor Menninger was impressed with Eve's understanding of mental illness; she became Menninger's Director of the Women's Mental Hospital. Menninger requested that she teach mental health at Yale University. She established the first Department of Mental Health at Yale and led women to teach at universities. Frank Vanderlip, Chairman of New York's Committee on Mental Health Needs, asked her to make a study of all mental hospitals in NYC which made a lasting impact creating a lifetime interest in mental health. In Tucson, she led mental health groups bringing the needs of people with mental illnesses to the public's attention. She be came a founder of the Library at the University of Arizona and aided in mental health across America. She endowed the College of Nursing at the University of Arizona with nursing scholarships. She funded education at the Menninger School of Psychiatry through the Eve Searles Fund, endowing research of drug and alcohol addiction problems. She was an advocate for sufferers of men tal illness. Eve is survived by her beloved husband, Sidney Searles of Tucson and New York, her daughter, Audrey Palmer Neville of Los Angeles, son, Michael Palmer of London, step son, David Searles of Tucson, four grandchildren, five great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Tucson on April 9, 2006 at 3:30 PM at Adair Funeral Home, Dodge Chapel.

title: Pakistani Muslim emerges as Britain's king of the ring
At Risk
description: Lamont and Huber have been discussing their relationship and what Win might have figured out about what they've been up to. Meanwhile, Win has taken in Miss Dog, and Nana has warned him to watch out for an evil man.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Remix; Weirding Out
description: When you visit Barcelona, do you know which side of the tracks is the wrong side? Or where you'd go to find a Catalan hangout? An English newspaper? A fancy hotel library to read it in? Or where to see a declining drag queen (and Dal muse) named Violeta La Burra? That's why you need a copy of "Le Cool Changed My Life -- A Weird and Wonderful Guide to Barcelona" (23 euros, or about $27; www.lecool.com/book). A spinoff of a weekly culture magazine, Le Cool has become the travel guide for the been-there-done-that set. Any old guide can list hotels and landmarks and decent restaurants. Le Cool will not only send you to the most authentic tapas bar, but it will also tell you which bar stool to occupy. GISELA WILLIAMS

description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALLENAVE, TERESE
description: SALLENAVE - Terese. De cember 8, 2005 of fibrotic lung disease. R.N., state and federal wildlife rehabilitator, former board member of Humane Society, affiliated with various animal organizations, interpreter for NYC Marathon. She is survived by her sister Elsa of Buenos Aires. Services to be held at JeanBaptiste RCC, 76 St. and Lexington Ave., NYC, 2:00 PM, Saturday, March 25. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to B.A.R.C., 253 Wythe Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11211.

title: THE WELLNESS TICKET
description: 29 Ways to Love Your Liver. Open your pores and learn to like raw food. Welcome to the detox craze. From silent retreats to sweat lodges, T separates the wheat from the chaff, not that you should be eating wheat.

title: Why Nobody Heeds The Leaf-Blower Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: A Real Getaway
description: In the early hours of the morning, with the cool mountain breezes blowing, you can sit on a veranda in Bukavu and fancy that this seat of bloodshed and misery on the eastern border of Congo is, in fact, an Alpine retreat -- and that Lake Kivu, a thoroughfare for smugglers and guerrillas, is, in fact, Lake Como. And once, in an unimaginably remote era, they were. The Belgians who colonized Congo called Bukavu the African Riviera, and in the steep green hills around Lake Kivu they built fine villas from which to watch the bathing hippos and the flamingos that thronged the shore.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article in some copies last Sunday about Bernie Geoffrion, the hockey Hall of Fame right wing who died hours before the Montreal Canadiens retired his number, misstated the number of games he needed to score 50 goals in the 1960-61 season. It was 62, not 64. In some copies the article also misstated the year Geoffrion was named the National Hockey League's most valuable player (1961, not 1955); misstated the number of games he played in his career (883, not 823); and misstated the position he and Maurice Richard played. They were right wings; they did not play on the same line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DESTENAY, DORIANNE
description: DESTENAY--Dorianne On February 11, 2006, in Switzerland. Dorianne was born and initially studied in Prague. After emigrating in difficult circumstances postwar, she graduated from the Demoiselles de Decker in Brussels and the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris. She was a well known shoe designer in New York in the 60s. As a painter, she showed at Betty Parsons and the Bodley galleries. Her paintings figure in private and museum collections both in the US and abroad, including the Guggenheim. A devastating studio fire prompted to an additional career in fashion. She joined Chanel in 1981, where she played a pivotal role in launching the company's worldwide ready to wear operations, heading the company's North American fashion operations. After retiring in 1994, Dorianne made Europe her home but traveled often to Coconut Grove and her beloved New York. Dorianne used her impeccable taste to design and decorate the Portes des Iris, one of Switzerland's most prestigious and beautiful conference and banqueting centers. She lovingly restored and embellished the family's ancestral home, its unique clock tower and world famous Jardin des Iris. Dorianne is remembered for her challenging and original mind, complemented by her great beauty, elegance and refinement. Her self discipline and resilience overcame numerous adversities. She is sorely missed by her loving husband, Robert Bovet in Switzerland, her uncle Karel Jirousek in Vancouver, her cousins Ivana and Jindris, and by friends worldwide, who valued her heart, directness, and discernment. The family thanks the thoracic department at MSKCC in New York -to which support should be directed -Clinique Genolier and the esteemed advisors, who worked selflessly to prolong Dorianne's life. An April gathering of friends is being arranged by email. If without, call 212570-0324.

title: A missing director, an overlooked film, and another chance
Iranian Writer Released After Serving 6-Year Prison Term
description: TEHRAN, March 18 - An Iranian writer was released Friday night after serving a six-year sentence on charges brought after he wrote a book that accused government officials of playing a role in the killing of intellectuals.

title: Frequent Flier
description: I always cram Cipro and Ziploc plastic bags into my side pockets, but it's the impractical that is truly essential when you travel. That explains, sort of, why a nine-inch plastic doll that flies is the one item I cannot leave home without. Sky Dancer, replete with aqua-blue hair, is a true citizen of the world. Conceived in San Francisco, she hails from China, and her brown skin reflects her African heritage. She is a global ambassador, a twirling metaphor, a charmer of children worldwide. She was given to me years ago as I started Adventure Divas, an enterprise that began my career as a documentary filmmaker. She has since made a cameo appearance in every Divas film: she parted the Ganges River along with several other deities at a Hindu festival. She spun above the ruins of Persepolis in Iran. She traveled through the desolate Sahara with the fabled blue men of the desert. She mushed a pack of dogs across the Arctic and inspired me as I struggled up the Matterhorn. Several years ago, she landed on the Dangerous Dozen toy list put out by the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The report said that she can "fly rapidly in unpredictable directions, and can hit and injure." Haven't kids been flinging pointy objects into the air since time began? Or, as Sky Dancer might say, "Strong women have always been vilified by the patriarchy." She has since been re-released, but now she cannot fly as high. Of course, it's the original Sky Dancer, determined to fly in unpredictable directions, who continues to travel with me. HOLLY MORRIS TIMELESS

title: Kos Clbre
description: Q: As the founder of the left-leaning Daily Kos, the largest political blog in the country, did you find it hard to write "Crashing the Gate," an actual book, as opposed to your usual raw and episodic three-sentence musings? It was brutal. My co-writer, Jerome Armstrong, and I had no idea of what we were getting into. There came a point where we literally sat around for a day trying to figure out how to tell our publisher there would be no book.

title: COMINGS & GOINGS
description: Pillow menus are so pass. Las Ventanas al Paraso, a Rosewood Resort in Los Cabos, Mexico, just introduced a bed sheet menu, which offers guests who stay in ocean-view or oceanfront one- and three-bedroom suites a choice of four types of sheets: Egyptian cotton, Italian linen, silk or sateen. Guests who sleep like the princess and the pea can test a different set each day. This summer, Delta Air Lines plans to add 46 new daily departures to 17 nonstop destinations from Kennedy Airport in New York. By the end of the month, the airline also plans to begin allowing travelers flying out of Kennedy Airport to international destinations to check in at its kiosks instead of the counter. Guests with tickets on Hawaiian Airlines who are staying at four Outrigger and Ohana hotels on Oahu can now check in for their flights in the hotel lobby. The service, which costs $5 a bag, is also available to people traveling aboard Hawaiian who aren't staying at the hotels. Club ABC Tours, a private vacation club in northern New Jersey, is offering members three-night packages starting at $399, including round-trip airfare to London, on Virgin Atlantic from Newark or Kennedy Airport and a choice of hotel accommodations. The deal, called the London Go-Any-Day package, is good through the year's end for departures any day of any month, year round. Package prices vary depending on the month of departure and the choice of hotel. Membership, which starts at $30 a year for a family of four, is required to get the deal. On May 1, Occidental Hotels and Resorts is opening what it calls the first all-inclusive luxury resort on Aruba. A former Allegro property, the resort went through a nearly $24 million renovation and will open with 391 guestrooms, 6 restaurants and a casino. Room rates, which normally start at $262 a night a person based on double occupancy, are being offered at 20 percent off this May. The Smith's Hotel Collection -- those cheeky European guidebooks popular in Britain -- are being sold in American bookstores for about $30. The books focus on boutique hotels and offer first-person reviews from trendsetters like the fashion designer Stella McCartney and the restaurateur Oliver Peyton. Each guide comes with a Smith membership card and registration number for access to a concierge service and perks like room upgrades.

title: Adair Byers and Simon Scott
description: Adair Read Byers and M. Simon Scott were married yesterday evening at St. Luke's Episcopal Parish in Darien, Conn. The Rev. David R. Anderson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Heather Berkowitz and Adam Moskowitz
description: Heather Lindsay Berkowitz and Adam Scott Moskowitz were married last night at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan. Rabbi Bruce S. Block officiated.

title: Burning Love
description: LAST month, on one of the coldest afternoons this winter, a fire broke out in the basement of my apartment building on West 16th Street in Chelsea. It spread quickly through the airshaft to the neighboring building and burned through to the first floor.

title: 'Sound and Fury'
description: One afternoon in Las Vegas, while in bed with Muhammad Ali, I asked him to name the members of his entourage and list their duties. He took my pencil and held my reporter's spiral notebook inches above his pretty face. In childlike block letters, he printed a dozen names. Alongside the names he wrote dollar figures in estimate of each person's weekly salary. We lay there, shoulder to shoulder, one of us wearing clothes. Here's what I thought: Are we nuts, or what?

title: Versatile Big Man May Yet Hit Lottery
description: DALLAS, March 18  Two years ago, LaMarcus Aldridge flirted with the idea of skipping college and entering the N.B.A. draft. A standout at Seagoville High School here, he had been anointed the next big basketball star from Dallas, which has produced Chris Bosh, Larry Johnson and Kenyon Martin. But a stress fracture in his back prevented him from participating in workouts for N.B.A. teams, and after seeking advice from others  Shaquille O'Neal advised him to go to college  Aldridge enrolled at Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPSETT, DR. SAMUEL
description: LIPSETT--Dr. Samuel. Of Palm Beach, FL and Brevard, NC died peacefully on March 7, 2006. He was 95 and a respected physician. He was a graduate of George Washington University and its medical school. Dr. Lipsett was a US Army Major and served with troops liberating concentration camps during WWII. He was married to the former Anita Wise, who preceded him in death. Dr. Lipsett is survived by his wife Natalie, his children, Dr. Nathan Lipsett and Dr. Helen Lipsett Boehm, their spouses and four grandchildren.

title: Wonderful World?
description: We live in a world that is objectively more dangerous than the one we knew at the outset of the millennium; whatever our disagreements, since 9/11 both our foreign policy and our domestic politics have pivoted around this ineluctable fact. And because the terrorists who struck us represent a global phenomenon, we assume that the world is objectively more dangerous for everyone. But is it?

title: When Sellers Must Be Flexible

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERRONE, PRISCILLA GILLETTE
description: PERRONE--Priscilla Gillette, 80, Died at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York on Thursday, February 2, 2006 following a period of declining health. Priscilla Gillette was an outstanding vocal talent and made her debut in the first tour of "Brigadoon" in 194748. She went on to take the role of Alexandra Giddens (Zan) in "Regina," the 1949 adaptation of Lillian Hellman's "The Little Foxes." She had leading roles in Cole Porter's "Out Of This World" and John LaTouche's "The Golden Apple." Priscilla starred with Charlton Heston in "The Willow Cabin," a production of Westinghouse Studio in 1950, and had many roles in early television. She was also a familiar figure, in various roles over the years, on "The Edge of Night." She is survived by daughters Alexandra Lowell Gifford and Jeanne Rose Perrone, Her son Andrew David Perrone, and her grandchildren Jasmine and Jordon.

Sting's is ornamented with soft mosaics, like a stained glass window in a country cabin. Each was hand-built at Blatt Billiards on Broadway near East 11th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANFORD, LOUISE R. (NEE RITTER)
description: SANFORD--Louise R. (nee Ritter). 93, of Sarasota, FL, passed away Sunday, March 12, 2006 after a brief illness. Born and raised in Poughkeepsie, NY, she attended Vassar College and later married Charles W. Sanford of Arlington, NY. At the onset of WWII, Louise and Charlie moved with their first child to Baltimore, MD where Bendix Corporation employed Mr. Sanford. During the war, he oversaw Bendix sub-contracts for Defense Department weapons production, and Mrs. Sanford made a home for them in five different U.S. industrial centers. At war's end they had toured much of the eastern half of the U.S., and grown to a family of four. Post-war, they toured some parts again, Charlie leading and Louise with their two children following. She resstablished family homes and raised their son and daughter in Milwaukee, WI, St. Joseph and Benton Harbor, MI. Louise established new family bases, and honed a solid golf game, in Cleveland, OH, Greenwich, CT, and finally in Syracuse, NY. In 1971, empty-nesters Louise and Charlie Sanford retired to Vero Beach, FL where together they made still another home just for the two of them. After her beloved passed away in 1984, she relocated to Plymouth Harbor in Sarasota. Last Sunday, Mrs. Sanford made her final move. In addition to her beloved husband, her daughter Anne-Louise Welther of Naples, FL preceded her in death. Survivors include her son, Charles, Jr. and daughter-in-law Diane (nee Herro) of Chicago, IL, and her two granddaughters, Brooke Young of Chicago, and Deidre Sanford of Springdale, AR. Service have been held. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart, or Stroke, Asssociations.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 19, 2006
A Place of Their Own, Where Creativity Rules
description: IT is safe to say that no one visits Gallery 58 for the atmosphere. The so-called alternative art space founded by Orlando Reyes in Jersey City is not the pristine white box typical of, say, a gallery in Chelsea in Manhattan. It is an ad hoc display space in an old glass factory, where Mr. Reyes works on his abstract paintings in a back studio and has lived on and off with a number of artist friends. The open-plan kitchen doubles as a performance space.

title: The Ticket; Four Hundred Bucks
description: For Door-to-Door Detox. five-day juice cleanse, $400. Jill Pettijohn says her fruit and vegetable soups and smoothies clear the body of toxic residue. Delivered daily -- along with the thrill of knowing you share the same taste in health food as Steven Seagal. (212)945-9411; www.jillpettijohn.com.

la Mode
description: The bizarre goings-on of the recent shows was stuff to grab headlines, not to be confused with the way women really dress. In Paris, where the women are all about looking great, short skirts and legs etched in inky black are the look. Shoes, bags and kid gloves provide the only bits of color -- and not all at the same time. ON THE STREET

title: The Face Of Lima
description: The people of Lima, Peru, work hard -- often six days a week -- for barely enough to survive. Still, they know how to have fun. Going to the beach, dancing, sports and religious festivals are wildly popular. And so is eating well. With roughly 20 cooking schools in Lima and the "Novandina" (the new Andean cuisine) movement, the culinary arts have become not only a desirable profession but also a key to social mobility.. Written And Produced By Ann Marie Gardner

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 19-March 25; FILM
description: News of "ALIEN," "CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE THIRD KIND" or "2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY" back in theaters this week might not get movie buffs orbiting in anticipation. The director's cut of Ridley Scott's deep-space monster movie hit the multiplex in 2003. Stephen Spielberg's luminous extraterrestrial spectacular is far from obscure. Warner Brothers may have notoriously botched the 2001 rerelease of Stanley Kubrick's masterpiece, dumping it at Christmastime with next to no publicity. Still it visits Earth frequently enough to satisfy its cult. All three are on DVD, for what that's worth; movies in space need space more than most. Thing is, they're not just back but back-to-back, unspooling on a single day in Manhattan's most palatial movie palace. Get your sci-fi marathon on Sunday and Wednesday, when the Ziegfeld presents this brain-boggling triple feature. Admission for each film is separate but nicely discounted ($7.50 instead of $10.75), leaving you enough spare cash to stock up on Clif Bars and Visine. 141 West 54th Street, Midtown, (212) 777-3456.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BASS, CAROLE LINDA ROSE
description: BASS--Carole Linda Rose. Passed away March 6, 2006 at the age of 64. Carole was a gifted grade school teacher and stage theatre professional. She brought the joy of teaching and performing to thousands over the course of her 25 year career. Carole was the loving partner of Barry Hill, beloved mother of Mitchell and David Bass, cherished daughter of Al and Rose Rose, big sister of Jordan and Eileen Rose, sisterin-law to Cindy Rose, aunt of Amanda, Elyse, and Maurissa, mother-in-law to Carrie Bass and Susan Woolley, and grandmother of Oliver, Libby, Tyler, Erin, and Joshua Bass. She will be forever missed by all. Memorial service to be held for family and friends on April 30, 2006 at 12 noon at the Steven Wise Free Synagogue Westchester Hills Cemetery, 400 Saw Mill River Rd, Hastings on the Hudson.

Few of the shots went in, many of them deflecting off a workman's ladder positioned under the basket. The team with the best record in the league seemed decidedly aimless.

description: SPATZ--Paula. 88 of Louisville, passed away peacefully on March 15. A life long learner and avid reader, she graduated college at 73. She was preceded in death by her husband Jack, son Gene and sister Minna Schielman. She is survived by daughters Amy Lowen and Cathy Spatz Widom; granddaughters Rebecca Widom, Jessica Lowen and Hannah Lowen; and sons-in-law Michael Maxfield and Gary Lowen. title: A Suburban Switch: The Condo's the Thing
description: IN mid-November, Jin Kim and May Yee Yeoung, single professional women who have been roommates for two years, pooled their money and bought their first home, a luxurious two-bedroom condo just off Interstate 95 in Fairfield, 60 miles north of the rental apartment in TriBeCa where they used to live.

title: Endangered Species
description: It seems to me that, no matter what Stephen J. Dubner and Steven D. Levitt think of Realtors (Freakonomics, March 5), buying a home will never compare to taking a vacation or managing investments. It is a stressful, emotionally-charged process, requiring hand-holding and guidance such that few buyers or sellers are willing to attempt it on their own. Because the real-estate industry continues to require more work, not less, with property disclosures, environmental issues and inspections to contend with, it is unlikely a seller or buyer will have the time or confidence to go it alone.

title: The Silence of Bystanders
description: ALONG THE CHAD-SUDAN BORDER - I saw a lot of heartbreak on my latest visit to the fringes of Darfur: two orphan boys living under a tree after their family was murdered, a 13-year-old girl shot in the chest and a 6-year-old boy trying desperately not to cry as doctors treated shrapnel wounds to his leg.

title: 'Riding Rockets'
description: I was naked, lying on my side on a table in the NASA Flight Medicine Clinic bathroom, probing at my rear end with the nozzle of an enema. Welcome to the astronaut selection process, I thought. It was October 25, 1977. I was one of about twenty men and women undergoing the three-day physical examination and personal interview process that were part of astronaut candidate screening. Almost a year earlier NASA had announced they would begin accepting applications for the first group of space shuttle astronauts. Eight thousand had been submitted. NASA had whittled that pile to about two hundred, a cut I had miraculously made. Over successive weeks all two hundred of us would eventually find ourselves on this same gurney probing at our nether regions as we prepared for our bowel exam.

title: Home Economics

This article exemplifies the need for economists and urban planners to assess values to ecosystems and their life-sustaining processes and life-enriching public lands.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 19-March 25; THEATER
description: This week's biggest theater premiere -- and I do mean biggest, as in most gigantic, most expensive and most megalomaniacal -- is taking place north, far north, of Broadway. For it is in Toronto that the $27 million musical adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien's "LORD OF THE RINGS" is opening on Friday, at the Princess of Wales Theater, amid a swirl of press-office-generated statistics that bring to mind the publicity that surrounded Cecil B. DeMille epics. (A computer-controlled stage floor weighing 40 tons! 504 costumes, using more than 5,000 yards of fabric! 404 pairs of shoes and boots for the hobbits, dwarves, elves and ents!) Certainly, the creative team is as international as that of any gladiator movie of yore. The Indian composer A. R. RAHMAN and the Finnish pop band VARTTINA have composed the score in collaboration with CHRISTOPHER NIGHTINGALE (of London). The director, MATTHEW WARCHUS, is British and, strangely enough, best known on this side of the Atlantic for his minimalist productions of "Art," "True West" and "Follies." Be assured that Tolkien fanatics and speakers of Elvish will be out in force, eyes peeled for instances of heresy. Crazy, huh? Next thing you know there'll be a movie version. (416) 872-1212; $56 to $125.

title: Up Front
description: "THE talk of political Washington" is how Warren Weaver Jr., a reporter for The New York Times, described "The Emerging Republican Majority" in September 1969 in the pages of the Book Review. Its author, Kevin Phillips, was a 28-year-old lawyer working under his mentor, Attorney General John Mitchell, in the Nixon Justice Department. Weaver called his work "one of the most provocative political books of these perplexing days" but found it "not a little depressing to read," in large part because "full racial polarization is an essential ingredient of Phillips's political pragmatism."

description: 1. Symptoms

title: The Curious Travels of the Commodore
description: THE Commodore looks pretty spiffy, set against the newly cleaned limestone of the south facade of Grand Central Terminal. All brushed up and polished, the four-ton statue of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt is half a century older than the 1913 Beaux-Arts building. Actually, it is a mere fragment of a 150-foot-long bronze frieze illustrating the steamship and railroad magnate's accomplishments. Unlike the statue, it has disappeared without a trace.

title: Paperback Row
description: A CHANGED MAN, by Francine Prose. (Harper Perennial, $14.95.) In this provocative novel of ideas, Vincent Nolan, a disenchanted member of the neo-Nazi American Rights Movement, walks into the New York office of the World Brotherhood Watch, a human rights organization, and declares, "I want to help you guys save guys like me from becoming guys like me." As Vincent becomes the focus of a media frenzy (orchestrated by Meyer Maslow, the foundation's president and a Holocaust survivor), Prose exposes the moral failures of contemporary America. In the Book Review, Liesl Schillinger called "A Changed Man" "powerful, funny and exquisitely nuanced."

Paid Notice: Deaths   MALLOUK, GEORGE E.
description: MALLOUK--George E., 93, a long time resident and contributor to the communities of Garden City and East Hampton, died at home in Garden City, NY on March 15, 2006. He was born in Brooklyn in 1912, and was an alumnus of Blair Academy, Roanoke College, and the Paris Institute of Political Studies. Before World War II, he lived for six years in Cairo, Egypt, where he was a partner in a Chrysler-Plymouth dealership. He returned to Brooklyn to work in the family business, Elias Mallouk Realty Corporation. In 1941, he was drafted in the Army, where he advanced to the rank of Captain at 2nd Army Headquarters. After the war, he became president of Elias Realty Corporation, and moved with his thenyoung family to Garden City in 1950. He moved the company to Garden City and worked there until his retirement in 1991. George made many contributions to his community, church, and charitable organizations. He served in several leadership capacities at the Garden City Community Church, most recently as the honorary chair of the 75th anniversary celebration of the church. He served as trustee of Winthrop-University Hospital for 20 years, and was later an honorary trustee. He was also an honorary trustee of Lemoyne-Owen College. He is remembered lovingly for his uncommon kindness, generosity, and unflagging good cheer by his family and his many friends. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Ann Marmon Mallouk. They had five sons, John of Okeechobee, FL, Jeff of Princeton, NJ, William (deceased), James of Breckenridge, CO, and Thomas of State College, PA, and six granddaughters, Megan, Katie, Sarah, Laura, Amy, and Juliet Mallouk. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM on Saturday, March 25 at the Garden City Community Church, Stewart Ave. and Whitehall Blvd., Garden City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Winthrop - University Hospital, Mineola, NY, or to the Garden City Community Church.

But what it is really about is perception, and paying attention to things. I can't think of a more apposite theme for a visual arts exhibition.

He twirled his glass on the edge of the bar and frowned, but said nothing.

title: Home Sweet Debt
description: I appreciate the nostalgia for the riskless days of yore posed by Walter Kirn, some of which is surely tongue-in-cheek. More paths are closing and fewer new ones are emerging for economic self-empowerment that would allow you to manage all the risks of keeping, selling and optimizing the value of your home. We Americans of all incomes will need to manage more risks (not fewer) and become more sophisticated (not less) to actually live our lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GODWIN, HOMER COTTON
description: GODWIN--Homer Cotton. The world's best father, husband and friend passed away March 3, 2006 while attending his 50th high school reunion in Marco Island, FL. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Maureen Doran Godwin of Los Altos, CA., his daughter, Carrie May "Charly" Godwin of San Francisco, CA. and brother Luther and his wife Millie of Syosset. Homer's sister Myrtle and his parents predeceased him. Born August 28, 1938 in Brooklyn, the first son of William C. Godwin, M.D. and Martha Fennell, Homer was raised in Woodhaven and attended St. Paul's School in Garden City, where he met his best friends, Jan VanHeiningen and Jim Nolan, with whom he spent his last hours revisiting their youth. Homer was a graduate of Westchester Community College and Pace University. He was a computer professional who loved to mentor bright young people in his field and inspired many successful careers. Following his retirement in 2000, Homer enjoyed taking computer and audio classes at Foothill college. He loved music, cooking, and was a gifted photographer. Donations to the American Heart Association or The Cardiac Therapy Foundation of the Mid-Peninsula in Homer's name are appreciated.

When it comes to psychotropics, we are all men easily swept off our feet, composing bad love poems, willing to wine and dine at sky-high prices, only to break off our engagement with a stamp and a pout once we see our bride-to-be without her makeup.

description: SAN DIEGO - HOW are the Chicago Cubs going to take their turn this year and follow the Boston Red Sox and the Chicago White Sox as longtime losers turned winners if they can't keep their top two pitchers healthy? What's that? Kerry Wood and Mark Prior are ailing again? What else is new?

title: The Art Hotel
description: On a list of things that Louisville, Ky., is known for, cutting-edge art ranks somewhere far below baseball bats, horse racing and good bourbon. Steve Wilson hopes to change that. With his wife, Laura Lee Brown, Wilson is scheduled to open a boutique hotel, 21C (for 21st century), in April that will showcase works from his $10 million art collection. All the artists represented are living, and the art is daring A Andres Serrano's photos of the homeless, a mouse-infested video from the Brooklyn artist Adam Stennett. (Many of the more confrontational works will be displayed in a free museum inside the hotel, and the 90 rooms will feature smaller works on paper.) Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, 21C occupies five buildings (four warehouses and a bank) that cost $26 million to renovate and took six years to complete. It will be part of the city's downtown renaissance, which includes a science center and the Muhammad Ali cultural center. Welcome to the new Louisville, slugger. 21C Museum Hotel, 700 West Main Street; (502)589-4690; www.21cmuseumhotel.com. -- PAUL L. UNDERWOOD

title: Endangered Species
description: Residential Realtors have significant value for buyers and sellers for two main reasons: time and liability. Finding and selling a home are hugely time-consuming processes. On the buy side, I spend nearly 20 hours a week previewing homes, so that my clients do not spend their weekends looking at homes that do not meet their search criteria. It often takes buyers three to six months to find the right home. That's a lot of hours saved on their behalf and quite a few spent on mine.

title: Music Landmark Caught in Tug of Priorities After Storm
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 16 - The doors of the deserted Milne Boys Home flap open in the wind, and anyone who cares to brave the dank interior here in the heart of the drowned Gentilly neighborhood can find crumbling logbooks noting who visited in the early 1900's and yellowing sheet music in the attic.

title: The House Calls
description: ON a Sunday morning earlier this month, Dave Zappulla was inspecting the 1920's Craftsman colonial home of Ginny and Jim Stewart in Manasquan, N.J. "This house once had extensive termite damage," said Mr. Zappulla, who owns Zappulla Property Inspections, also in Manasquan, which covers Ocean, Monmouth, Middlesex and Union Counties.

title: HEART RISKS FOR WOMEN AND BLACKS
description: A study conducted by the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Brunswick has discovered that women and black people who have a heart attack in New Jersey are unlikely to undergo an angioplasty or a bypass afterward and are more likely to die as a result. The study examined 247,673 heart attack patients from 1986 to 2002 and found that women and blacks were 40 percent less likely to have follow-up procedures to repair their hearts. The study was presented at a conference of the American College of Cardiology.

title: COMPOUND PENSION
description: If shareholders of the Ryland Group, a homebuilder, panned the first special pension promised to the chief executive, R. Chad Dreier, what will they think of the sequel? Mr. Dreier, 58, already stood to collect $2.4 million a year for 15 years under a supplemental executive retirement plan. That arrangement, on top of Mr. Dreier's hefty annual pay, spurred a construction workers' pension fund to demand that all executive pensions be put to a vote of stockholders. But before a vote could be held, Ryland's board produced a second supplemental plan, just for Mr. Dreier, who signed a five-year contract in April. If he stays on until 2010, Mr. Dreier, who received $34 million in cash and stock and an additional $23 million in options gains last year, will be entitled to $3.84 million a year for 15 years.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MILSTEIN, BARBARA (NEE ADDUCHIO)
description: MILSTEIN--Barbara (nee Adduchio). Age 74. Died at home on March 15, 2006 surrounded by her family after a brave four-year struggle with ovarian cancer. A resident of Greenwich, CT and Jupiter, FL, she lives on in the hearts of her husband of 50 years, Sidney, three children, six grandchildren and scores of close friends. A graduate of New York University and Bridgeport University, she, along with her husband, led Aegis Productions, a documentary film production company in Manhattan. She later worked as a counselor in weight control programs. She served as a president in the League of Women Voters and as a trustee of William Patterson College. Contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County (www.hpbc.com) or to the Ovarian Cancer Research Foundation (www.ocrf.com).

title: The Suburbs, Unplugged
description: White Plains - WHEN my family and I moved to Westchester five and a half years ago from New York City, I resisted purchasing a second car. But I soon discovered that the lack of sidewalks made walking between home and the train station too risky and sharing one car was a logistical challenge. It seemed inevitable that we would succumb to the two-car suburban lifestyle.

title: Going With the Flow
description: Last spring, a battle over sewage wore on between two communities in Westchester, each with a credible claim to the moral and environmental high ground and with a comparable reservoir of virtuous stubbornness. This page held its nose and waded in between them.

title: The Remix; Auto Erotica
description: Stuttgart, Germany, is not only a host city for the 2006 World Cup. This wealthy gateway to the fairy-tale Black Forest is also the birthplace of the modern car: the Benz Patent Motor Car (1886) and the Daimler motorized vehicle (1886). And on May 20, Mercedes-Benz plans to open a stunning new house of worship (O.K., museum). Designed by the Amsterdam-based UN Studio, Van Berkel & Bos, the Mercedes Museum will house more than 170 models, from the legendary Mercedes Simplex and Emperor Hirohito's Benz Parsifal to Silver Arrows and Princess Diana's custom-made roadster. If you place your order with a dealer in the United States now, you can pick up your own custom-designed Mercedes near Stuttgart and tour the Karl Benz House in Mannheim and the BMW museum in Munich while catching a few World Cup matches en route. Then return to Stuttgart, and the Mercedes folks ship it to the States. Mercedes-Benz Museum; 011 49 711 172 25 78; www.mercedes-benz.com; e-mail: bmuseum@daimlerchrysler.com. CHARLES RUNETTE

title: Hamas Completes Lineup for Palestinian Ministries
description: JERUSALEM, March 18 - The militant Islamic group Hamas said Saturday that it had completed its lineup for a new Palestinian cabinet and would present it Sunday to the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, for his approval. An aide to Mr. Abbas said he was likely to give his approval.

Diplomacy is vastly preferred, President Bush and his aides insist. Yet it was no accident that the just-revised National Security Strategy declares: "This diplomatic effort must succeed if confrontation is to be avoided."

title: The Talk
description: dixie / (dix e) / n. / umbrella term for the South, sometimes used as a synonym for the Confederacy; these days, an apt handle for Southern-fried travel, e.g., ' "This summer, we're definitely doing Dixie, but we're torn between this chic boutique hotel in Kentucky and a quilting tour of Alabama"; any one of several Confederate war songs bearing this name; also, whistle Dixie, slang for engaging in unrealistic, rosy fantasizing, as in, ' "I don't care if you whistle Dixie for me, I am not flying coach to China."

title: PANEL URGES REPLACING BUILDING AGENCY
description: New Jersey should abolish a troubled agency responsible for building and renovating schools in the state's poorest districts and replace it with a new government authority, according to a report released last Wednesday by a group convened by Gov. Jon S. Corzine to advise him on the issue. The recommendation follows a series of highly critical government reports that found delays, cost overruns, mismanagement and waste at the agency, the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation. The corporation was responsible for overseeing the state's $8.6 billion school building program, which was concentrated in the state's poorest districts.

title: THE WORLD

The passion and privation are on display, but not much else; certainly not the country's formula for producing top players and championship teams, like the one that in the last 10 days has made its way from San Juan to San Diego for the final weekend in the World Baseball Classic. Obsessed by 90 Feet, Defined by 90 Miles

title: The Theater of the Street, the Subject of the Photograph
description: IN 1999 Philip-Lorca diCorcia set up his camera on a tripod in Times Square, attached strobe lights to scaffolding across the street and, in the time-honored tradition of street photography, took a random series of pictures of strangers passing under his lights. The project continued for two years, culminating in an exhibition of photographs called "Heads" at Pace/MacGill Gallery in Chelsea. "Mr. diCorcia's pictures remind us, among other things, that we are each our own little universe of secrets, and vulnerable," Michael Kimmelman wrote, reviewing the show in The New York Times. "Good art makes you see the world differently, at least for a while, and after seeing Mr. diCorcia's new 'Heads,' for the next few hours you won't pass another person on the street in the same absent way." But not everyone was impressed.

title: Seeking to Compete in the Sales Arena

Beloved mother of Helaine Packer, Jane Myerow and husband Michael, and Sheri Langel and husband James. Loving grandmother to Fran and husband Paul, Jordan, Bobby, Danny, Jonathan and Jenna. title: Sex, Lawsuits and Celebrities Caught on Tape
description: TWO years ago Red Light District, a little known video company in California, hit the jackpot when it landed distribution rights to the Paris Hilton sex tape, an explicit bedroom video shot by a former boyfriend. The DVD has sold some 600,000 copies, establishing Red Light District as the leading player in a lucrative niche of the pornography industry: a purveyor of explicit videos of famous people, sold to an eager public, often over the vehement objections of the participants.
