title: Before Its Time, the Death of a Newspaper Chain
description: ONLY a handful of days have passed since he announced the deal to sell Knight Ridder, but P. Anthony Ridder, the company's chairman and chief executive, already has ghosts to contend with. The biggest, of course, is the pending disappearance of the company his great-grandfather, Herman, founded in 1892 -- Ridder Publications, which merged in 1974 with Knight Newspapers to create what has for much of recent memory been the nation's second-largest newspaper group, with 32 dailies.

title: 'Easy Rider' Rides Again. Or Does It?
description: Ever since the cult favorite "Easy Rider" rode onto the big screen in 1969, filmmakers have dreamed of firing up Captain America's chopper again, and the fact that he and Billy, his fellow biker, were both killed at the end seemed to be no impediment to a sequel.

title: The Remix; Charleston, S.C. | Off The Menu
description: If you're seeking imaginative fare, the Belfast-bred chef Tim McCusker offers exotic combinations, like smoked quail with pumpkin ice cream, at A Culinary Art Company outside Charleston. But if you have your own inspiration, just tell McCusker, who keeps the kitchen door open. "They can write their own menu," he says. "I'll even bring them in the cooler to see what we got." A Culinary Art Company, 1035 Johnnie Dodds Boulevard, Mount Pleasant, S.C. Open Tuesday through Saturday, 5:30 p.m. until closing. Call (843)375-5988. HUNTER KENNEDY

title: Lukashenko wins Belarus election with over 90 percent of vote
We Love You, Now Beat It
description: You won't find him in anybody's corner. Oddly enough, you will find his name where Mississippi Avenue meets the Boardwalk in Atlantic City.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 19-March 25; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: With the Whitney Biennial safely opened and last weekend's Armory Show closed, this may be the time to get out of town. Los Angeles, where a new nonprofit contemporary art center with a promising future opened last night, beckons. Under the direction of LAURI FIRSTENBERG, former director of Artists Space in New York, LAXART will showcase new art and provide a forum for discussion and debate in a space designed by the architect PETER ZELLNER. Its inaugural show presents works by DANIEL JOSEPH MARTINEZ, whose site-specific works in painting, video, sculpture and public art adroitly combine formal, conceptual and political purposes. A billboard designed by Mr. Martinez broadcasts the message "the fully enlightened earth radiates disaster triumphant" over La Cienega Boulevard (between Venice and Washington Boulevards) through March 27. His exhibition at LAXART can be seen through April 29 at 2640 South La Cienega Boulevard, (323) 868-5893.

title: Baja for Beginners
description: '"Looking after children can be a subtle way of giving up," the novelist Edward St. Aubyn once wrote. If a vacation is thus a defining microcosm of family life at its presumed artificial best, then it will forever encapsulate your attitude of giving up, or giving in, or putting up a fight, usually at great cost to your nerves and sleeping schedules. It is the family vacations about which your children will brag or complain (or fake-complain) to their friends and future spouses and their own children, as in, "My parents dragged me to Epcot," or, "My parents made me do the midnight watch on a monthlong sailboat trip to Labrador." In short, this is how you will be remembered.

title: Google claims victory in data requests
Shocking and Enlightening
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Postpunk; Historical Fiction; Sci-Fi
description: Rip It UpTo the Editor:After reading Jim Windolf'sreviewof Simon Reynolds's''Rip It Up and Start Again''(March 5), I found myselfwondering whether it's onlybooks about pop music thatleave authors exposed tocharges of being ''brainy'' andusing ''99-cent locutions.'' Isthere another field in whichauthors are routinely taken totask for not condescendingto their subjects?DAVID GRUBBSBrooklyn

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: A Taste for Sushi, And Rhythmic Ranting

title: Melissa Bender and Ryan Goodman
description: Dr. Melissa Amy Bender, a researcher on infectious disease, was married in New York last evening to Ryan Goodman, a Harvard law professor. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated at the Central Park Boathouse.

title: ONE FOR THE PRICE OF TWO
description: How many millions of dollars does it take to replace a chief executive? At Mellon Financial, the punch line is more than 32. Mellon, a Pittsburgh-based money manager, hired Robert P. Kelly last month to take over for Martin G. McGuinn, who had two years left on a four-year contract. To lure Mr. Kelly, 51, who was chief financial officer of Wachovia, Mellon handed over shares and options worth $13 million, company filings show. Despite Mr. Kelly's arrival, Mr. McGuinn will collect $2.5 million a year in combined salary and bonus through Jan. 31, 2008.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SEMEL, ROBERT K.
description: SEMEL--Robert K. Three years have passed and our hearts are still broken. You are missed and loved every day. You will live in our hearts for eternity. Always and forever, Your wife Fran, Children and Grandchildren

title: Election is landslide for leader of Belarus
ON THE MARKET
description: Stuyvesant Heights Town House $1,200,000

title: Tempted to Cash Out, Some Homeowners Get Itchy Feet
description: WHEN my husband and I moved into our home in Chappaqua, N.Y., I was seven months pregnant, with a 3-year-old in tow. We were the new kids on the block, which was filled mostly with older couples whose children had grown.

title: They Can Go Home Again
description: A PERMANENTLY unfolded futon bed, piles of clothing and the smell of stale smoke make Sean Sciubba's cottage in Sea Cliff, N.Y., seem a lot like a college dorm room.

title: Crisp Images With a Blurry Back Story
The Silk Route
description: Whether By Land Or By Sea, The Road To Rajasthan Is Paved With Riches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORNBERG, PATRICIA
description: KORNBERG - Patricia. On March 13. Beloved wife of Harvey Kornberg, mother of Dai and Erica, grandmother of Hannah, Lila and Ruby.

title: White Leads the Way in Making Helmets Cool
description: For years, cooler heads prevailed in professional snowboarding as most riders eschewed helmets over concerns about their appearance. But a new generation, led by the Olympic gold medalist Shaun White, has emerged, showing more concern about protecting their heads than their images.

title: Lakshmi Sharma and Ravi Gangavalli
description: Lakshmi Sharma, the daughter of Dr. Uma Sharma and Vimal N. Sharma of Montville, N.J., was married on Wednesday evening to Dr. Ravi Venkata Gangavalli, a son of Siva Sai Kumari Gangavalli and Ranga Rao Gangavalli of Hyderabad, India. Pandit Kaushik M. Sastry, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony at Sri Venkateswara Temple in Bridgewater, N.J., with Pandit Dixit Sharma, also a Hindu priest, taking part.

title: Corrections
description: A detail image last Sunday with the Close Reading feature, about a painting by William Wegman that uses postcards of artworks, was published in error. The detail showed an unidentified work, not Magritte's "Boyhood of Icarus," which Mr. Wegman said was an anchor for the painting. A correct version of the image is online in an interactive graphic, at nytimes.com/design.

title: Baja for Beginners
description: 'Looking after children can be a subtle way of giving up," the novelist Edward St. Aubyn once wrote. If a vacation is thus a defining microcosm of family life at its presumed artificial best, then it will forever encapsulate your attitude of giving up, or giving in, or putting up a fight, usually at great cost to your nerves and sleeping schedules. It is the family vacations about which your children will brag or complain (or fake-complain) to their friends and future spouses and their own children, as in, "My parents dragged me to Epcot," or, "My parents made me do the midnight watch on a monthlong sailboat trip to Labrador." In short, this is how you will be remembered.

title: Public Comments by Justices Veer Toward the Political
description: Speeches by Supreme Court justices are usually sleepy civics lessons studded with references to the Federalist Papers and the majesty of the law. That seems to be changing.

title: The Get; Catch the Wind
description: AND ENERGIZE YOUR STYLE.

title: Peel Me a Grape
description: The ultimate "Sideways" trip for New World wine lovers is Mendoza, Argentina, just west of Buenos Aires. A new hotel, Cavas Wine Lodge, has opened in time for this season's harvest A between early March and April. Situated on 35 acres of vineyards overlooking the Andes, Cavas is only a short drive from the award-winning producers of malbec and torrontes varietals. Hedonism is encouraged. Cavas's wine cellar carries a substantial selection of South American wines, and deluxe cabanas A sleek adobe huts with plunge pools, interior stone walls, claw-foot tubs and outdoor showers A practically sit amid the grapes. But there is more to do than drink wine: a special spa package includes a crushed-malbec scrub. Cavas Wine Lodge, Costaflores s/n, Alto Agrelo; 011 54 261 410 6651; www.cavaswinelodge.com; doubles start at $310. -- Gisela Williams

title: Tales from Kyoto
description: Remember when we were little? And we tried to dig a hole to China? Well, Japan is sort of next to China  just as far away, where digging is concerned. And yet, when our happy little group got our shovels and boarded the plane to Tokyo, it took us only 11 hours to get there. Eleven hours for all that otherness.

title: In Search of the Next Great American Opera
description: Correction Appended

title: A Dark Carnival Shambles Back to Town
description: MILLBURN - FOR the 45 years since it opened on Broadway, "Carnival!" has always been an also-ran among American musicals. Based on the 1953 film "Lili," which starred Leslie Caron (no, the lilting "Hi Lili, Hi Lo" did not make the transfer to the Broadway stage), it opened in 1961 with the team of David Merrick and Gower Champion at the helm. Hanging on for 719 performances, "Carnival!" simply never entered the Broadway pantheon.

title: Pipe Down, We're Trying to Watch a Cartoon
description: LOS ANGELES - CALL them cellphone films: in "Chicken Little," "Madagascar," "Hoodwinked" and other recent American animated features, the characters chatter incessantly, as if they're trying to use up their last 500 minutes from Verizon. The audience isn't subjected to this barrage of words and jokes because the characters have something to say, but because filmmakers and studio executives are afraid to let them be quiet.

title: Insiders Say Corzine Plans New Unit for Child Welfare
description: TRENTON, March 18 - In a sweeping overhaul of New Jersey's troubled child welfare agency, Gov. Jon S. Corzine has decided to create a separate, cabinet-level department to manage the system, according to two administration officials who have been briefed on the plans.

title: Trying to Shed Light on the Muddle of Long-Term Care
description: Most people don't hesitate to insure their life, car or home. But insurance for long-term care? They'll think about it, thanks.

title: From Practical Gardener To Vertical Gardener
description: CAROLYN SUMMERS surrounded her house in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., with a deer fence last summer for practical reasons. But as a result, her garden has taken a new direction: vertical.

title: High-End Hotels Cropping Up in Suburbs
description: In an effort to expand their market reach, upscale hotels are increasingly heading to the suburbs and so-called second-tier cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLMES, FRANK E. JR.
description: HOLMES--Frank E. Jr. Former Executive Vice President of Encyclopaedia Britannica, died December 20 in Vero Beach, FL. A Wharton School of Business graduate, he spent nearly 40 years with Britannica, where he pioneered the development of leads through third-party mail inserts. Known as "Mr. Britannica", he built and managed the New York division, the company's most lucrative, and under his leadership the 238-year-old company enjoyed its most profitable years. He retired in 1992. Frank resided in Bronxville, New York; Southampton, New York; and John's Island, Vero Beach, FL. Frank is survived by his wife, Elizabeth; his three children, Hunter, Trilby and Blair; and his six grandchildren.

title: The Shockers Live Up to Their Name
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 18 - The coaching tree that finds its roots in North Carolina and Dean Smith can be credited with producing yet another up-and-comer making his first mark in the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament.

title: National Geographic travels far and speaks in many tongues
Torching the Library: Different Year, Same Temperature
description: ONE balmy Hollywood night in 1947, Ray Bradbury and a friend took an after-dinner stroll along Wilshire Boulevard. A police officer pulled over and asked what they were doing. Even then, it seems, nobody walked in Los Angeles.

title: FAMILY OWNERSHIP
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed "Taos Ski Valley; No Frills, Just Thrills," by Lisa Reed (Explorer, March 5), especially about how it maintains its rugged individualism, compared with slicker areas in Colorado. In 1983, I had the pleasure and the honor of spending an hour or so with Taos Ski Valley's founder, Ernie Blake, who at the time (I think) was about 70 but seemed much younger.

title: Other Views: The Australian, The Economist, Los Angeles Times
Cast of Lively Characters Puts Demons in Spotlight
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., March 18 - The Demons of Northwestern State may not win another game in the N.C.A.A. tournament, but they have brought a jolt of joy here from their home, Natchitoches in northern Louisiana.

title: Served as King of England, Said the Rsum
description: Q. You need to update your rsum. To what degree is it acceptable to embellish your skills and experience?

title: EU reviews duties on Hynix chips
AROUND THE REGIONS
description: ATLANTA

title: All but on the Ballot in Newark, but Not Yet on the Stump
description: NEWARK, March 18 - The story of Sharpe James seems to be stuck on pause. Even after delivering petitions Thursday to get on the ballot -- inside City Hall astride a bicycle, no less -- the clever, colorful five-term mayor of New Jersey's largest city still refuses to declare himself a candidate.

title: The Remix; Pod Potatoes
description: Armchair travel is now available in surround sound. The latest in virtual adventures are travel podcasts (for a directory, go to www.podcastalley.com). For example, "Notes From Spain" is broadcast from locations around Spain by an Englishman and his Spanish wife (www.notesfromspain.com). Adrenaline junkies can get their Jon Krakauer fix from the Everest Podcast (www.visiglow.com). Arthur Frommer's Budget Travel magazine has a series on North American destinations (www.budgettravelonline.com). And Lonely Planet's fortnightly "travelcast" features Tony Wheeler's must-visit sites for 2006 (www.lonelyplanet.com). Best of all, podcasts use up no suitcase space. ALEXIA BRUE

title: Injured Lindros Ponders Future
description: When Eric Lindros was selected with the No. 1 overall pick of the 1991 entry draft, he was hailed as the second coming of Gordie Howe.

title: County Will Pay Fine In Water-Pollution Case
description: Suffolk County has agreed to pay a $1 million fine to settle a water pollution case dating back six years. The County Legislature approved the settlement last week.

title: Leaving Iraq To the Iraqis
description: To the Editor:

title: Near a Main Artery in Dublin, a New City
description: HISTORICALLY and geographically, O'Connell Street is the heart of Dublin. The boulevard, which runs south about five blocks to the River Liffey, has emerged from several decades of seediness, thanks to a continuing refurbishment that aims to create a Hibernian version of the Champs-lyses, centered around a 394-foot-tall steel needle, the Spire of Dublin.

title: Bedell Merlot Gains a Fan
description: THE marketplace has rated Bedell Cellars's reserve merlot outstanding for years. Now a new book has done so.

title: G. William Miller, Former Chairman of Federal Reserve and Treasury Secretary, Dies at 81
description: G. William Miller, a businessman and investment banker who was chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and treasury secretary under President Jimmy Carter, died Friday night at his home in Washington. He was 81.

title: Laugh Lines
description: Jay Leno

title: 'The Caliph's House'
description: There was a sadness in the stillness of dusk. The cafe was packed with long-faced men in robes sipping black coffee, smoking dark tobacco. A waiter weaved between the tables, tray balanced on upturned fingertips, glass balanced on tray. In that moment, day became night. The sitters drew deep on their cigarettes, coughed, and stared out at the street. Some were worrying, others dreaming, or just sitting in silence. The same ritual is played out each evening across Morocco, the desert kingdom in Africa's northwest, nudged up against the Atlantic shore. As the last strains of sunlight dissipated, the chatter began again, the hum of calm voices breaking gently over the traffic.

title: Another Way to Sparkle
description: North Americans rarely encounter Argentine sparkling wine. Pascual Toso's bright vino espumoso, from Mendoza, is a nonvintage basic version. A simple steely white made from chardonnay grapes, this appetite-sharpener clicks with finger food.

title: From History Teacher To Tutor in a Click
description: THE Internet may have transformed the way we exchange information, but so far its effects on the student-teacher relationship have been fairly modest.

title: Smile When You Say That
description: WE had been living in Verona for about two weeks when we went for a walk in our neighborhood after supper one night and saw the sign in a yard: "A Hillbilly Lives Here," it read in maroon lettering on a white backboard. Beneath this declaration a girl's name was printed, and the bottom of the sign indicated that she went to Verona High School.

title: Psst. . .Have You Heard About Bushwick?
description: Robert Sullivan (March 5) discusses the new population of artists who have settled in Bushwick, a once-cheaper option to Williamsburg, which was a once-cheaper option to Manhattan. His article touches the surface of the next-neighborhood problem, but the problem runs deeper than real estate. The rapid turnover of neighborhoods is evidence that New York is hostile to its low-income populations: families and artists alike. It would be nice to see you address the critical issues, rather than market-speculate the next hot thing. And maybe it's time for the city government to adjust its priorities and get creative. Or are stable low-income housing and affordable artists' studios simply too much to ask for?

title: Juliane Gardner and Scott Spencer
description: Juliane Morse Gardner, a daughter of Naomi Gardner and Dr. Howard M. Gardner of Andover, Mass., was married last night to Scott Eric Spencer, a son of Pamela J. Spencer and David R. Spencer of Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Marc A. Gellman officiated at the Hyatt Regency Jersey City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, MELVIN
description: SCHWARTZ - Melvin. 87 years young. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Toby and Robert Berkowitz, and David Schwartz. Cherished grandfather of Steven and Michelle Berkowitz, and Aaron and Sarah Wodin-Schwartz. Dear brother of Alice Weber. Passionate tennis player. The best joke and story teller. Loved by all who knew him. Services "Boulevard-Riverside," 1450 B'way, Hewlett, LI, 2:15 pm, Sunday.

title: Near the Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts and Crafts in the Blue Ridge Mountains
description: Before spring has fully broken, and the streets of Asheville, N.C., are not yet thronged with visitors, the town radiates a comfortable desolation. Even the surrounding Blue Ridge Mountains look neglected and dozy, like a mussed lavender coverlet on an unmade bed.

title: A Price to Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Worshipers Warm
description: JUST heating the living room has proved difficult for many people this winter, as energy prices soared and a late-winter chill forced people to burn more fuel. But heating a house seems quaint compared with heating a 100-year-old gothic church that seats 1,100 people, or a church with giant stained glass windows.

title: Sheffield Says Back Is Against the Wall
description: Any number of reasons could have prompted Gary Sheffield to speak out the way he did yesterday in Jupiter, Fla. -- wanderlust, regret, frustration or stress.

title: Go With God
description: A waterbuck charges up the hill and forages in the shade of a spiky candelabra-shaped euphorbia tree. Impala and Thomson's gazelles graze on the plains below, just a few miles from Lake Nakuru National Park, in Kenya. Rain is in the air; squalls scud across the wide valley floor, drenching the parched grassland. Tomorrow the flowers will bud, and the yellow and gray grasses will show a fluorescent green sheen. Chris Foot, a lay preacher with the Vineyard church, offers cocktails from a brass-bound chop box on a card table. "Footstep Safaris is where Dom Prignon meets the Bible," Foot says as he serves vodka, gin and single-malt Scotch to the group. "My safaris are for people who want to take God on vacation with them."

title: State G.O.P. to Hold Convention on L.I.
description: New York Republican leaders announced last Tuesday that the party will hold its state convention in Nassau County this year for the first time in decades, calling it "a long-overdue return to our party's base."

title: White House Disputes Iraq Is Sinking Into Civil War
description: Three years after the American-led invasion of Iraq, top Bush administration officials today reiterated their upbeat assessment of the American military effort and political progress in the country, insisting that the violence plaguing Iraq did not amount to civil war.

title: Bratislava Weekend
description: Forget the agenda. The last thing you need to enjoy a weekend in Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia, is a rigid schedule. The key word here is pohoda. Translation: take it easy, relax and have a good time. It's also the name of Slovakia's famous music festival, a sure tip-off to the national temperament.

title: Is Prewar Losing Its Status to Glass?
description: FOR decades, Manhattan's graceful, well-constructed prewar apartments have lorded it over their bland, low-ceilinged postwar kin.

title: Cash and Carry Democracy
description: THE fact that an individual is allowed to give more money to a candidate for New York State office than to a presidential contender should tell New Yorkers that our campaign finance laws need to be fixed.

title: French Union Threatens Strike Over Labor Law
description: PARIS, March 19 A Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin of France faced an ultimatum from union leaders today to withdraw the employment law that set off huge nationwide demonstrations and sporadic violence over the weekend or face a general strike.

title: The Ticket; $11.09 Will Convert The Staunchest Of Skeptics To Raw Gourmands.
description: New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHANDLER, SYLVIA (NEE GANZ)
description: CHANDLER -- Sylvia (nee Ganz). On March 13, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Martin "Pat". Dearest mother of Susan (Allan) Pessin. Devoted sister of the late Daniel (Beverlee) Ganz. Loving sister-inlaw of Jack & Ruth Chandler, Frances DuBow, and the late Bernie DuBow and also the late Bess & Chip Harris, Doris and Mike Foreman, Zelda and Norman Friedman, Kahn and Kate Chandler, Al and Alva Chandler, Frank and Yetta Chandler and Ann Chandler. Dear cousin and caring aunt to many.

title: Cartagena
description: WHY GO NOW -- The people of Cartagena want the world to know that their city is not like the rest of Colombia. Perched atop South America on the southern rim of the Caribbean Sea, Cartagena feels a million miles from anything having to do with guerrillas, paramilitaries, narcotics or kidnappings.

title: A Place of Their Own, Where Creativity Rules
description: IT is safe to say that no one visits Gallery 58 for the atmosphere. The so-called alternative art space founded by Orlando Reyes in Jersey City is not the pristine white box typical of, say, a gallery in Chelsea in Manhattan. It is an ad hoc display space in an old glass factory, where Mr. Reyes works on his abstract paintings in a back studio and has lived on and off with a number of artist friends. The open-plan kitchen doubles as a performance space.

title: Love Among the Ruined
description: It might be difficult for some American viewers to appreciate the central metaphor in "Gideon's Daughter," a delicate film that has its United States premiere Saturday on BBC America, because you really had to have been British to feel the gut punch of the Millennium Dome project.

title: Basketball: Bradley pulls off another upset, downing Pittsburgh, 72-66
On His Canvas, the North Fork Never Looked So Good
description: 'Lemuel Maynard Wiles, American Painter'

title: Memories of the Future
description: I am an African, born in Nakuru, Kenya. These days, many of us in Kenya and elsewhere in Africa have been rendered immobile by history: we stand, like antelopes in the dark, watching the fiery headlights of the future bear down on us. But there is one small African country, Eritrea, that seems to have taken charge of its destiny and, with little support and few resources, willed itself into a viable nation.

title: How Fare the Beaches?
description: DEBBIE WHITCRAFT has been living at the Jersey Shore for 50 years, so sometimes she is a bit cavalier when it comes to the shifting sands on her beloved Long Beach Island.

title: Dashed Hopes for Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Captive Past
description: SLAVERY IN NEW YORK

title: Iraqis Forming Council in Bid to Include All Factions in Decisions
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 19 A Iraqi officials announced today that they had agreed to form a council of the country's top politicians to make policy on security and economic issues in the new government, in an attempt to include all of Iraq's major factions in the decision-making process at a time of rising sectarian tensions.

title: Shiite Pilgrims Are Walking Targets in Sectarian Conflict
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 18 - Shiite pilgrims are threading a needle of danger this week as they make their annual pilgrimage to a shrine in Karbala, in southern Iraq.

title: All Politics Is Thymotic
description: Correction Appended

title: The Ticket; 223: Spa Hours Of Rub-A-Dub-Dub.
description: Angel Feet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMSEN, THOMAS C.
description: THOMSEN--Thomas C. Age 85 on March 14, 2006 in Greenport, NY. Beloved husband of Eleanor Mann Thomsen. Loving father of Debbie Thomsen of Greenport, NY and Michael Thomsen of Newtown, CT, grandfather of Melanie Bittar of Doylestown, PA and Chelsea and Jordan Thomsen of Newtown, CT and great-grandfather of Justin and Matthew Bittar of Doylestown, PA. Predeceased by son Paul Thomsen. President of T.C. Thomsen & Associates, Financial Public Relations and Cross River Press, Publisher. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to East End Hospice, P.O Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, N.Y. 11978.

title: The Jersey Boys, and Their Obsession With Double-Knit
description: About seven years ago, the girlfriend of a writer named Paul Lukas grew weary of his eccentric habit of hollering at the television every time he noticed a quirk of sports uniform design. "She got tired of me shouting, 'Look at that guy's socks compared to that other guy's socks!' " Mr. Lukas, a goateed 41-year old Park Slope resident, recalled a week ago. "And she said, 'You know, Paul, I think you need an outlet.' "

title: For Documentary Maker, Marketing Is Last Hurdle
description: EARLIER this month Maria Pusateri of Syosset showed the documentary film she had spent three years making. The film, "Vito After," portrays the recent life of her brother-in-law Vito Friscia, a New York Police Department homicide detective who worked on site during the World Trade Center collapse and later spent months sifting its rubble at a Staten Island landfill. Like many other workers who responded on Sept. 11, he developed a debilitating respiratory illness.

title: The Suburbs, Unplugged
description: WHITE PLAINS - WHEN my family and I moved to Westchester five and a half years ago from New York City, I resisted purchasing a second car. But I soon discovered that the lack of sidewalks made walking between home and the train station too risky and sharing one car was a logistical challenge. It seemed inevitable that we would succumb to the two-car suburban lifestyle.

title: Formula One: Fisichella triumphs as Renault rules track in Malaysia
Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the popularity of movies in China referred incorrectly to the film "Initial D." It was a Japanese and Hong Kong production, not Taiwanese. The article also misstated the name of the fight choreographer for the coming film "The Banquet." He is Yuen Woo-ping, not Woo Yuen Ping.

title: Rumbling Trucks, Followed by Fretting Residents
description: BREAKFAST in Greg Bellows and Miriam Weiner's open, sunlit kitchen on 20th Street in South Slope, Brooklyn, features perfectly browned toast, tiny cups of frothy coffee, and, every few minutes, a rumbling noise. It starts quietly, builds within seconds, and ends in the clatter of truck parts and heavy cargo just outside the front door. Sometimes the floor vibrates.

title: Innovation may lower Net users' privacy
BEST SELLERS: March 19, 2006
Milan-San Remo Is a One-Day Sprint After the Long Tests
description: PARIS, March 18  The appetizers are finished, so it is time to crumb the table and move to the meat and potatoes.

title: Where Have You Gone, Molly Picon?
description: THERE are few traces left of the boisterous Yiddish theater that reigned along lower Second Avenue during the first half of the 20th century. Maurice Schwartz's vaunted Yiddish Art Theater, at the southwest corner of 12th Street, is now a multiplex. Across the street, a Japanese restaurant has taken the place of the Cafe Royal, a former mecca for Jewish intellectuals and artists. And the Second Avenue Deli, with its Molly Picon room and Yiddish Walk of Fame on the sidewalk outside, closed its doors in January after a rent dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANGER, ETHEL
description: SANGER--Ethel. 90, on March 18, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Maury Sanger. Loving mother of Elizabeth Sanger Zung, Gail Sanger, Mary Bryna Sanger, Diane Sanger and their husbands Dr. Murray Zung, Albert Fenster and Harry Katz. Adored grandmother of Jonathan, Matthew, Elizabeth, Robert, Amanda, Margot and Meredith. Services and interment private.

title: Jodi Segal and Seth Price
description: Jodi Ellen Segal, a daughter of Judy Segal and Ned Segal of Boynton Beach, Fla., was married last night to Seth Jay Price, the son of Merle Chait Price and Morton L. Price of New York. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum officiated at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington.

title: With Will Sheridan
description: Will Sheridan has a distinction in the Villanova lineup: He is the only starter who does not play guard. A 6-foot-8 junior from Bear, Del., he leads the team in rebounding (6.2 average). Today, he and the top-seeded Wildcats will face Arizona as they try to reach the N.C.A.A. Round of 16. JOHN BRANCH

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 19-March 25; TELEVISION
description: When we last saw the "PRISON BREAK" gang before the show went on hiatus in November, they were in a seemingly impossible situation. The escape plan Michael (WENTWORTH MILLER) devised had been thwarted, and the crew was stuck, powerless to advance yet unable to return to their cells. Monday's episode (Fox, 8 p.m.) will pick up that cliffhanger. In the coming episodes, Lincoln (DOMINIC PURCELL), Michael's brother, will be a dead man walking, though presumably without the dead-man part -- otherwise the show would end.

title: The Ticket; Five Alternatives to Twinkies to Keep You Snacking Guilt-Free On The Road
description: Cocoa-Sauce-Dipped Macaroons, $5 for 4 pieces; www.rawbakery.com.

title: The Remix; Fore Play
description: How to put some sex in your swing.

title: Movies on TV

title: The Country Between Us
description: There was no earthly explanation, when I first went to Haiti as a tourist in 1986, why it felt like home. The maze of market women and the taxis, like mobile artwork that moved through piles of rotting garbage -- it was nothing like the tree-lined, manicured streets of the Cleveland suburb where I grew up. But I smiled back at the people who smiled at me, a white woman walking and sweating just like them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KETCHAM, JAMES B.
description: KETCHAM--James B., 82, Died Thursday, March 16 at home in Jamestown, RI. He was the devoted husband of Ira D. (Davisson) Ketcham for 52 years. He was born in New York City in 1924. He was the son of Jean (Long) & William Tredwell Ketcham. He was a direct descendant of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt. Jim was a graduate of Lawrence School, The Hill School, Yale University, Class of 1945 W and attended Columbia University Medical School. He enlisted in the Army Air Corp (United States Air Force) in 1943 and was a recipient of the Legion of Merit Award for the invention of the M*A*S*H unit (mobile auxiliary surgical hospital). He was an Air Force Captain and was released from his duties in 1953 to pursue a career in business. He was an administrator for Sloan-Kettering Memorial Cancer Center, Paul R. Ray & Company and Kollmorgen Corporation where he retired in 1990. A long-time resident of Lawrence, New York, he retired to Jamestown, RI in 1995. He was both Junior and Senior Warden of Trinity-St. John's Church in Hewlett, New York and was awarded the Bishop's Cross. He was active in the Republican Party in both New York and Jamestown. He was a member of the Holland Lodge, The Reading Room of Newport, the Conanicut Yacht Club, The Rockaway Hunting Club, Lawrence Beach Club and the Cedarhurst Yacht Club. While at Yale University, he was one of the founders of the Nathan Hale Society. Besides his wife, he is survived by his son, George Ketcham of Newport, RI, and his daughters Laurie Camden Ketcham of Jamestown; RI, Susan Ketcham Coffin of Manchester By the Sea, MA and Brucie Ketcham Donahue of Northfield, VT. In addition, he is survived by sons-in-law Lloyd H. Coffin, III and Thomas Donahue and daughterin-law Mimi Ketcham; and grandchildren, Benjamin and Sarah Coffin, James and Catherine Donahue. A funeral service will be held at 11:00 on Saturday, March 25 at St. Matthews Parish, 87 Narragansett Avenue, Jamestown, RI. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to the Newport Hospital Foundation, 11 Friendship Street, Newport, RI 02840

title: The Remix; Hideout Hideaway
description: When the Colombian cocaine kingpin Pablo Escobar wanted to get away, he would fly to his two oceanfront mansions in Tulum, Mexico. Hidden in the jungle, the estate was a place for refuge, wild parties and business. According to locals, helicopters landed on the roof at all hours. In 2005, 12 years after his death, the properties were acquired by Melissa Perlman, a New Yorker who had started the nearby Bikini Boot Camp. Casa Magna ("Pure House") opened to paying guests in December; the other is to open this year. Casa Magna has eight palatial bedrooms ($3,900 a week). Lounge in a hammock on the beach, snorkel the reef or venture into a maze of tunnels: You never know what you'll find. JULIE EARLE-LEVINE

The small-plates concept, as it's usually called, gives form to this urge, offering smaller portions in larger numbers. And that concept may have more appeal for travelers to London than anywhere else in the world; there, we who are not paid in pounds are desperate for anything that will reduce the cost of a meal.

title: A C.E.O. Who Wouldn't Say 'I Settle'
description: Sandy, Utah - GARY D. KENNEDY, a 52-year-old former chief executive of a software company, was sitting on a black leather chair in his home office here in Sandy, an affluent suburb of Salt Lake City, beneath a painted portrait of his family. It was 1:15 p.m. on Dec. 15, 2005: he remembers it vividly. His wife, Jane, was standing over the fax machine when she noticed a strange expression on her husband's face. "What is it?" she asked.

title: The State of Iraq: An Update
description: AS we reach the third anniversary of the start of the war, the confusion on the ground in Iraq seems to have spread to American generals' public pronouncements. Last Monday, just days after saying that pacification efforts with the Iraqis were going "very, very well," Gen. Peter Pace, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told an audience that Iraq is "a place that is having some real difficulties right now" and that "everything is in place if they want to have a civil war." Unfortunately, an examination of trends in Iraq backs up General Pace's later, more sober comments.

title: The Remix; A French Legacy | Beirut Bonbons
description: Despite a semblance of peace since the Syrians pulled out, the dust never seems to settle in Lebanon. An earlier occupation, by the French before World War II, left a far more palatable legacy: Beirut has splendid patisseries. Some of the most extraordinary desserts are at Tamaris (011 96 1 1 996 500), a joint venture of Alain Ducasse and the Lebanese chocolatier Patchi, in the newly renovated downtown shopping district. Elegantly coiffed matrons and young women in Dior sunglasses and hijabs nibble signature Ducasse creations like bricks of Louis XV chocolate and tart scoops of pineapple and apple sorbets. Also popular is the no-frills catering depot Cannelle (011 96 1 1 336 798). Mouthwatering gteaux and outrageously dressed cakes are all on offer. And if you don't speak French, just point at the glass case -- they'll understand. Meghan Sutherland

title: Incoming!

This morning I was awakened by three big explosions that sounded way too close for comfort. I reached over and pressed the Indiglo light on my alarm clock. It was 0600  15 minutes before my alarm would have gone off. I got out of bed, stretching, and thought, Another lovely day in Ramadi.

title: Arts, Briefly; Lincoln Center's Round Table Approves Street Plan
description: Lincoln Center's various resident groups have unanimously approved final plans for the transformation of West 65th Street, and preparatory construction work on the $500 million project is to begin this week, Frank A. Bennack Jr., the center's chairman, is to announce today. Given the last several years of debate over the redevelopment plan, the moment is significant for Lincoln Center, said Reynold Levy, right, its president, and bodes well for fund-raising. "Not only is there unanimity and a very positive spirit, there has been very successful initial presentations to donors for large gifts," he said. "I believe the project is the better for all of this conversation, all of this dialogue." That dialogue included debate over whether to build a tunnel under the garage at West 65th Street. Mr. Levy said the development project board had decided against the tunnel because of projected costs -- more than $20 million -- and construction delays. Instead, the garage entrance's hours will be limited to two hours before curtain time, and cars will use several alternative exits. The resident groups have also approved conceptual designs for the next phase of the redevelopment, an overhaul of the fountain plaza and Columbus Avenue entrance. Both West 65th Street and the plaza were redesigned by Diller Scofidio + Renfro in collaboration with FX Fowle Architects. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Irish Journey From Hatred to Celebration
description: "A Night in November" begins one morning in late fall 1993, when a man in Northern Ireland is going through his morning routine of checking under his car for bombs. It ends seven months later at a bar in New York City filled with drunken, joyous Irishmen. This two-act monologue, revived at the Irish Arts Center, is a tour de force that charts one man's personal journey from an unexamined life as a bigoted Protestant in Belfast to an all-out embrace of Irish heritage and brotherhood -- even with Catholics.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bill For Retiree Insurance
description: City Councilman David I. Weprin, a Queens Democrat who is the Finance Committee chairman, said yesterday that he would reintroduce a bill to continue health insurance coverage for the spouse or domestic partner of a city retiree after the retiree's death. The bill, which Mr. Weprin proposed last year, was the subject of a hearing but was not voted on before the session ended. It would require the spouse or partner to pay 27 percent of the group rate for continued coverage and would cost $8 million a year at the outset, he said. The Bloomberg administration, which is trying to rein in the escalating cost of health insurance, pensions and fringe benefits, might oppose the measure.

title: A Painted Lady of Magazines, With Gravitas
description: CULLEN MURPHY and William Langewiesche have been the Tracy and Hepburn of The Atlantic Monthly for the last 15 years. Mr. Langewiesche has been nominated for National Magazine Awards eight times in the last eight years, including this year, and won the reporting category in 2002 for his article about the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990.

title: Critics' Choice: New CD's
description: Loose Fur "Born Again in the U.S.A." (Drag City)

title: Women Who Decide to Opt Out
description: To the Editor:

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Gordy Abel, national director for marketing at Carat Fusion, Boston, part of the Isobar unit of the Aegis Group, was promoted to vice president for marketing at Carat Fusion and a second Isobar agency, Freestyle Interactive.

title: For First Time in 6 Years, Nets Top Mavericks
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 19 - At first glance, there was nothing remarkable about the Nets' 100-89 victory against the Dallas Mavericks on Sunday. After all, the Nets had beaten some of the N.B.A.'s other elite teams this season, including the Detroit Pistons and the Miami Heat.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about the popularity of public lectures and readings in New York gave an outdated name at one point for a university that schedules them. It is the New School. (The New School for Social Research is a division.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERSCHBERG, NATHAN
description: HERSCHBERG--Nathan, 84, of Aventura, FL, and New York City. Died peacefully, surrounded by family on March 18. Beloved husband and best friend of Anna. Nathan is also survived by his loving daughter, Nancy and son-in-law Mitchell Muntner of Marlboro, NJ, and his cherished grandchildren Steven and Phillip. He was predeceased by his adored wife of 40 years, Francine (nee Schwartz), and his dear son, Charles. He is also survived by his wife's loving family, children Barry, Michael, grandchildren Ephraim, Aaron, Jonathan, Brian, and great-grandchildren Logan, Austin and Blake. Funeral services today (Monday), noon, at United Hebrew Center, 201 East Broadway, New York City. Interment to follow at Mount Hope, Westchester, NY. We will all miss him dearly.

title: Criminal court hears its first case
Other Views: The Nation, The Times, Sddeutsche Zeitung
Straphanger to Suspect, and Back
description: THERE is so much going on in New York that it is, of course, impossible to keep up. You can think you know about something, but you don't really, unless it touches you directly.

title: Hardballs Replace Softballs, and Bush Takes a Few Swings
description: WASHINGTON - At first it looked as if it was going to be another warm bath of a White House question-and-answer session with President Bush. There was a happy group of retirees arranged on a stage, a poster in red, white and blue that proclaimed "Strengthening Medicare" and a peppy president with microphone in hand.

title: A Berlin Painter, Jewish and Proudly Assimilated
description: Although the German painter Max Liebermann (1847-1935) was born into a rich family and enjoyed great success in his chosen field, he had a German problem that dogged him all his life. He was Jewish. True, he was a secular Jew who, while far from disguising his origins, regarded himself through assimilationist eyes. And in his work he steered away from religious subject matter.

title: Spreading Genocide to Chad
description: After the Holocaust, the world vowed it wouldn't stand back and allow genocide to happen again. Bosnia, Cambodia and Rwanda showed how empty that promise was. Darfur was yet another reminder that when it comes to standing up to stop the slaughter of entire peoples, the nations of the world remain pitifully inadequate.

title: Where is Europe's voice against genocide?
Arts, Briefly; 'Deal' Clinches Friday for NBC
description: As the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament continued Friday on CBS, NBC took the lead in Nielsen's estimates for total viewers. It had the night's most-watched program, the game show "Deal or No Deal," (below, the host Howie Mandel), which drew 12.31 million viewers; the network's "Las Vegas" (10.1 million) and "Conviction" (9.19 million) also benefited from the absence of CBS's "Numbers." In the preliminary ratings, CBS did manage to tie NBC among adults 18 to 49. For the week ending March 12, USA Network was the No. 1 advertiser-supported cable channel in prime time among both total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds. In the rankings for that sought-after age group's top-rated programs of that week, VH1's "Flavor of Love" finale and the premiere of "Black. White." on FX were first and second, respectively. FX finished in fourth place in the 18-to-49 demographic with a rating 33 percent higher than in the same week last year. And VH1 placed seventh among adults 18 to 49, with an improvement of 50 percent from the same week last year. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVICK, DAVID
description: LEVICK--David. 74, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Forest Hills, NY, passed away March 18, 2006. Beloved husband of Henrietta "Honey." Loving father of Edward (Ilyssa). Cherished grandfather of Samantha. Services Monday, 11:15 am, Beth Israel Chapel in Boynton Beach.

title: Microsoft Takes on Craigslist in the Battle for Classified Ads
description: CRAIGSLIST has taken on many giants. Can it survive a challenge from Microsoft?

title: Top UN powers meet to discuss Iran plan
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Missing Boy Found
description: A 4-year-old boy went for an early-morning walk yesterday while his father, Alfonso Cocco, of West 158th Street, was sleeping in their apartment, the police said. Mr. Cocco was unaware that his son, Ismaldo, who was in an adjacent room, had awakened, dressed and strolled ouside about 5 a.m., the police said. A livery cab driver called 911 after spotting the boy. A few hours later, Ismaldo was reunited with his mother, who, after returning home from work shortly after 5 a.m., had called the police to report him missing.

title: Imperialism Rises Again in the Chrysler Empire
description: THE Imperial, Chrysler's on-again-off-again luxury flagship dating back to the 1920's, has already died more deaths than Lazarus and returned in more incarnations than Vishnu. Should it surprise anyone that DaimlerChrysler is once again trying to exhume the body and breathe new life into it?

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the sports section on Feb. 24 with an article about Jimmy Rollins's 36-game hitting streak with the Philadelphia Phillies misstated the year in which Paul Molitor hit safely in 39 consecutive games. It was 1987, not 1945.

title: Grown Up Since 'Grease,' Returning as Judy Garland
description: Adrienne Barbeau's acting credits do not immediately appear to be the right training for playing Judy Garland in the desperate months before her death. She was the daughter in the 70's sitcom "Maude" and turned in famous performances as busty scream-queens in "The Fog," "Swamp Thing" and "Escape From New York." Most recently, she was Ruthie the snake dancer in HBO's "Carnivle."

title: A Song Cycle Intimately Journeys From Hope to Despair
description: Probably the last thing a listener wants to think about, in considering a performance of Schubert's "Schne Mllerin" by a brilliant singer like the bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff, is the tension between art and commerce. But hearing Mr. Quasthoff sing this 20-song cycle in Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, it was hard not to.

title: Yankees at Classic Tried to Sway Clemens
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 19 - The atmosphere around Legends Field had not been this energetic all spring. Alex Rodriguez, Derek Jeter, Johnny Damon and Bernie Williams returned from the World Baseball Classic and jumped right into the lineup Sunday against Cleveland.

title: Grisly Discovery Reopens Old Wounds in Village in India
description: PANDARWADA, India - One afternoon in March 2002, amid one of the worst outbreaks of sectarian violence in recent Indian history, 26 Muslim men and women were hacked to death by a mob of Hindu hard-liners as others hid in the wheat fields behind their homes in this dusty village. The victims' relatives saw the horror unfold.

title: Bill Beutel, 75, Dies; Longtime Anchor of 'Eyewitness News' in New York
description: Bill Beutel, who helped bring about a sea change in the nature of local television news as the dapper and unruffled anchor of "Eyewitness News" at WABC-TV in New York for more than 30 years, died Saturday at his home in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 75.

title: Accounts
description: KeyCorp, Cleveland, consolidated its marketing communications assignments, with spending estimated at $35 million, and awarded them to Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago. The work had been divided between GSW Worldwide, Columbus, Ohio, and Northlich, Cincinnati.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Pedestrian Fatally Hit
description: A man died last night after he was struck by two cars as he walked along the Van Wyck Expressway, the police said. The man, whose identity was not known, was walking in a southbound lane near Liberty Avenue in Jamaica about 7:30 p.m. when he was hit by the cars. One of the drivers stayed at the scene, but was not charged last night, while the other driver was being sought for questioning by the police. The man, who appeared to be in his 50's, was pronounced dead at the scene. It was unclear why he had been walking along the expressway.

title: Roundup:Tagliabue to retire as commissioner
German Coach and American Ways Are a Tough Match
description: DSSELDORF, Germany, March 19 - With the World Cup opening June 9, Germany is in a familiar panic as the host country, fearing that its coach is merely a "Baywatch" blond, more concerned with his tan lines than with the bottom line of winning a global soccer championship.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Conviction of Ex-Banking Star
description: A federals appeals court in New York this afternoon overturned the conviction of Frank P. Quattrone, the former star banker who had been found guilty of obstruction of justice, and granted him a new trial.

title: Hard times clip wings of free flight benefits

description: Correction Appended

title: Public sector strike talks snag in festering Germany
F.B.I. Discounted Suspicions About Moussaoui, Agent Says
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 20 A The F.B.I. agent who arrested and interrogated Zacarias Moussaoui just weeks before the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, told a jury today that his efforts to confirm his strong suspicions that Mr. Moussaoui was involved in a terrorist airline hijacking plot were thwarted by senior bureau officials in Washington who acted out of negligence and a need to protect their careers.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Mets' Julio Feeling for His Old, Sure Stride
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 19 - Not too long ago, Jorge Julio felt wanted -- really, truly wanted -- and, he said, he liked how that felt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GINSBERG, DOROTHY
description: GINSBERG - Dorothy. On March 18, 2006 (97 years). Beloved wife of the late Murray Ginsberg. Resident of The Bristol, formerly of Cherry Hill, NJ. Beloved aunt, greataunt and great-great-aunt. Everybody loved her. In our hearts forever. The Held and Honig Family

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Democrat Announces Candidacy
description: Andrea Stewart-Cousins, a Democrat and a Westchester County legislator, said yesterday that she would run again for the State Senate seat held by Nicholas A. Spano, a Republican. Two years ago, Ms. Stewart-Cousins ran against Mr. Spano in a challenge that led to a lengthy recanvassing of the ballots (it was the longest-running State Senate race since shortly before the Depression). Mr. Spano won by 18 votes after more than 114,000 ballots were counted. In her announcement, Ms. Stewart-Cousins was joined by leaders of community groups from across Westchester County and prominent Democrats, including State Senator David A. Paterson, the Senate minority leader.

description: To the Editor:

title: Pixar's Creative Force Gives a Glimpse of His Future With Disney
description: In the wake of its $7.4 billion acquisition of Pixar, the Walt Disney Company has been mum about what role John Lasseter, Pixar's chief creative officer, will play in reviving Disney's storied animation division, except to say that it is a big one.

title: Top Iraqi Leaders Agree to Form a Policy Council
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 19 - Iraqi officials announced Sunday that they had agreed to form a council of the country's top politicians to make policy on security and economic issues in the new government. The council, which will include the prime minister and president, is an attempt to include all the country's major factions in decision making at a time of rising sectarian tensions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Where Comedy Isn't King
description: Washington - I WAS only a few hours into my recent two-week stay in Baghdad when I first noticed the discordant images on Iraqi television: Between the grisly shots of war dead, pools of blood and burnt-out shells of cars came bits of wacky slapstick.

title: Leetch Expects Flood of Memories in Return to Garden
description: Brian Leetch said he knew what to expect at Madison Square Garden tonight, when he finally makes his first visit back to the arena he called home for almost 17 seasons. He will be in the lineup when the Boston Bruins play the Rangers, who traded him to Toronto on March 3, 2004, his 36th birthday.

description: For the first time, CBS SportsLine.com is offering viewers live video of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. And because many of the games are on during work hours, the Web site is offering something else: a way for basketball fans to conceal their viewing from their bosses.

title: Cyclone lashes Australia's northeast
N.Y.U. and Columbia to Receive $200 Million Gifts for Research
description: New York University and Columbia have each received donations of about $200 million, among the largest to academic institutions in recent years. The gifts, from different donors, come as both universities try to compete with rivals that have far larger endowments.

title: Palestinians Try to Flee Iraq, but Are Stopped by Jordan
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 20 A More than 100 Palestinians fleeing violence in Baghdad and seeking refuge in Jordan have been denied entry by Jordanian border officials for their failure to have proper entry permits, a spokesman for the Jordanian government said today.

description: Election Protest in Belarus President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus won re-election in a landslide as thousands of people protested in Minsk, ignoring threats of arrest and denouncing the election as a sham. PAGE A11

description: SANGER--Ethel. 90, on March 18, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Maury Sanger. Loving mother of Elizabeth Sanger Zung, Gail Sanger, Mary Bryna Sanger, Diane Sanger and their husbands Dr. Murray Zung, Albert Fenster and Harry Katz. Adored grandmother of Jonathan, Matthew, Elizabeth, Robert, Amanda, Margot and Meredith. Services and interment private.

title: Andrew Sherratt, 59, Who Studied Animal Husbandry, Is Dead
description: Andrew Sherratt, a British archaeologist whose explorations of animal husbandry and other civilizing practices shed light on European prehistory, died Feb. 24 near his home in Witney, Oxfordshire. He was 59.

title: Cinderella Now Lingers Longer at the N.C.A.A.'s March Dance
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 19 - When George Mason defeated the defending national champion North Carolina Tar Heels on Sunday, the upset capped four of the most harried days in the history of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament.

title: G.O.P. Roots for Suozzi and His Slingshot
description: After a stormy political winter, New York Republicans are suddenly speaking to donors, party activists, and reporters about a candidate for governor who just might help their chances to win this fall. Oh, and did they mention he was a Democrat?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Before Former Enron Chief Executives Testify, U.S. Hopes for Big Assist From Ex-Treasurer The government heads this week into the final stretch of its case against two former Enron chief executives. Prosecutors will be looking to end on a flourish with the testimony of Ben F. Glisan Jr., the only former top Enron executive who has already been sentenced. Mr. Glisan, the former treasurer, is the last power-hitter on the government's bench who is set to take the stand before the case shifts to the defense and what promises to be memorable testimony by the defendants, Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay. [Page C1.]

title: The Meaning of Life, or the Joys and Challenges of Life With Chopsticks
description: Randall David Cook's new play, "Sake With the Haiku Geisha," a collection of five anecdotes inspired by the playwright's own experience as an English-language teacher in Japan, is an often observant, witty evening about the ways in which other cultures can unexpectedly impinge on our own individual experience. When Mr. Cook reaches for broader statements about humanity, though, those strengths of observation and humor fall by the wayside.

title: G. William Miller, 81, Former Top Economic Official, Dies
description: G. William Miller, a businessman and investment banker who was chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and treasury secretary under President Jimmy Carter, died Friday night at his home in Washington. He was 81.

title: Behind Louisiana Aid Package, a Change of Heart by One Man
description: Louisiana was in a foul mood on the February day that President Bush's Gulf Coast rebuilding coordinator, Donald E. Powell, stood before an audience of fellow bankers in Baton Rouge.

title: A North Carolina Native Gains Sweet Revenge
description: DALLAS, March 19 - The junior forward P. J. Tucker of Texas was asked during a news conference Saturday about not being offered a scholarship by North Carolina State in his hometown, Raleigh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, LEROY
description: BLOCK--Leroy. One of the sweetest men to ever walk the face of the earth. Beloved friend and mentor from our first meeting in 1973, to being my dinner date on June 10, 1980, the night I met my future wife of 25 years, Hazel. Most intelligent and very different from all others. Most kind and caring. Never forgetting important occasions. You'll be dearly missed but in our hearts forever. All your friends already miss you. Love, Marvin and Hazel Shanken

title: All the World Loves a Clown? Be a Buffoon and You're Dead
description: Off Off Broadway theater is like a car at the circus -- just when you think you've seen the last clown, one more jumps out. But "Not Clown," a crafty piece of meta-theater created by the Austin, Tex.-based Physical Plant, is not just another clown show.

title: E. Russell Alexander, 77, Public Health Expert
description: Dr. E. Russell Alexander, an epidemiologist and public health official who helped curb deadly disease outbreaks and raised concerns about federal plans to thwart a potential swine flu epidemic in the 1970's, when a vaccine was linked to a neurological disorder, died on Feb. 26 at his home in Seattle. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MADISON, WILLLIAM A.
description: MADISON--Willliam A., 86, on March 18, 2006. Husband of Anastasia and the late Claire Madison. Mother of Deborah M. Nolan, William H., Thomas B.and Christopher K. Madison. Grandfather of Emily, Jessica, Frank, Bennett, William, Sarah, Nora, Lucy, Samuel, Magdalene, Devon, Claire and Avery and greatgrandfather of Aidan. Brother of the late Bert, Edna and Mildred. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass at Mary Manning Walsh Home, York Ave and 72 St, Wednesday, 9:30 am. Burial to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hanover, NJ.

title: It's Jones's Bet, but Parcells Holds Cards
description: NOT long after Terrell Owens's suspension and deactivation by the Eagles was upheld by an arbitrator late last season, the Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones, let the pro football world know that Owens, for all his past sins in Philadelphia and San Francisco, would be welcome on the Dallas ranch.

description: There is a heroic allure to ridding the planet of a horrible disease forever.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 19 - South Korea's loss to Japan on Saturday in the semifinals of the World Baseball Classic abruptly ended a winning streak that drew the kind of international recognition this country craves.

With 7,502 appearances or mentions of commercial products, the show had more than twice as many placements as the next most placement-filled series, "The Apprentice," also on NBC.

description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

Still Artfully Disaffected, but Becoming More Specific About Why
description: A fundamental tension flutters through the music of Stereolab. For much of its 15-year recording history, this British band has produced a gleaming alloy of retro-rock that offers the cool reassurance of meticulous order. But the group has also trafficked in pseudo-Marxist rhetoric, despairing or superior or alarmist in tone.

description: When I was a kid I had the wildest crush on my Uncle Breeze's wife, Betty. She was beautiful and with all my heart I wanted to grow up and marry someone just like her.

When Words Bear Witness
description: THE Supreme Court is scheduled to hear oral arguments today in two cases that may make domestic violence cases all but impossible to prosecute. The cases, Davis v. Washington and Hammon v. Indiana, raise the question of whether statements made to 911 operators can be admitted in prosecutions if those who made the calls refuse to appear in court. Such evidence has become crucial in bringing domestic abusers to justice.

description: Order was restored last night at Madison Square Garden, at least where it regards the proper alignment of the N.B.A. cosmos. As for the bickering Knicks, disorder was still the dominant theme.

A three-week course at Harvard Law School given by Thomas C. Goldstein, who helps run the Stanford clinic, also focuses on Supreme Court litigation.

title: The Downbeat and the Sly From a Band Rarely Seen
description: Silver Jews' miserablist maestro, David Berman, is not known for his rosy worldview. Since he formed his ragtag indie-rock band in the early 90's with future members of Pavement, Mr. Berman's downtrodden though often ironically comic lyrics have garnered a small, devoted following. But until now, Silver Jews (which counts Mr. Berman as the only constant member) has never toured. With last year's "Tanglewood Numbers" (Drag City), the latest and most acclaimed of its five albums as a foundation, the band is currently filling rooms like Webster Hall, which was packed both nights this weekend.

description: Murry Bergtraum defeated Francis Lewis for the Public Schools Athletic League girls' high school basketball championship yesterday in what has become a familiar sight this time of year at Madison Square Garden.

description: Thomas Liotti has been branded a big mouth for his self-promotion and propensity to tongue-lash prosecutors, police officers and even judges. He shrugs off the criticism, calling it a byproduct of being a lawyer who defends some of the most dangerous criminals to pass through any of New York's downstate courtrooms.

description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 19 - A clash between the police and antiwar protesters here nearly three years ago will cost the City of Oakland more than $2 million, including dozens of payouts to people injured when officers fired wooden dowels, bean bags and rubber pellets.

description: THE HAGUE, March 20 A It was a brief session but a momentous occasion at the International Criminal Court today, when a former Congolese warlord, the first person to stand trial before the new institution, faced the judges.

title: Protesters Charge Fraud in Belarus Presidential Vote
description: MINSK, Belarus, Monday, March 20 - An expected landslide for President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko drew several thousand Belarussians into the streets on Sunday, as protesters ignored swirling snow and official threats of arrest to denounce the election as a clumsily orchestrated sham.

description: Three strong favorites were beaten on Saturday in the four major prep races, further muddling an already muddled picture. Who wants to wear the blanket of roses? So far nobody has staked a strong claim. By JOE DRAPE

description: WASHINGTON, March 18 - An oil spill this month in Alaska, the largest ever on the North Slope, has raised new concerns among state and federal regulators about whether BP has been properly maintaining its aging network of wells, pumps and pipelines that crisscross the tundra.

description: TRENTON, March 19 - Placed into a region loaded with talented teams, Rutgers figured that a journey to Boston and the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. women's tournament would be filled with difficult challenges.

description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 19 - Connecticut finished a sluggish first half on a 15-2 run Sunday and ended up cruising past Coppin State, 77-54, in an N.C.A.A. women's tournament first-round game.

title: Arts, Briefly; Solzhenitsyn, Ready For Another Close-Up
description: Following a highly rated Russian television adaptation of "The First Circle," Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn is negotiating for a feature-film version of another of his Soviet-era dissident novels, "Cancer Ward," his wife, Natalia, said. "Talks are being held about filming 'Cancer Ward,' " she told the Moscow newspaper Izvestia last week, "but for now there are no concrete arrangements." The 10-part mini-series of "The First Circle" in January and February, about scientists in the forced labor camps known as the gulag, starred some of Russia's most popular actors and was narrated by the author. Mr. Solzhenitsyn, 87, who won a Nobel Prize in Literature in 1970, returned to Russia in 1994 after 20 years in exile, and in recent years has mostly kept a low profile, but the series thrust him back into the limelight and renewed debate about the gulag. "Cancer Ward," from 1968, is based on his hospitalization during a forced exile in Kazakhstan. Mrs. Solzhenitsyn also told Izvestia that her husband was completing the editing of his 30-volume collected works, the first of which will be published this year. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, MELVIN
description: SCHWARTZ--Melvin. Friend and tennis partner for 60 years. A unique man, dedicated to his family, to whom we extend our condolences. Debby and Frank Morgenstern

description: It seems insane that the National Park Service would even think of spending $600 million on a road that few people want and nobody needs -- especially when the service has barely enough money to keep up appearances. But that could happen unless the Interior Department musters the courage to resist Representative Charles Taylor of North Carolina.

description: MINSK, Belarus, March 20 A The United States today declared the results of the presidential election in Belarus invalid and called for a new race, even as President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko defiantly declared himself the winner of a third term.
