Paid Notice: Deaths   WINSTON, RICHARD ALAN
description: WINSTON--Richard Alan. The House of Harry Winston is saddened by the great loss of Richard Winston, former vice president and salesman extraordinaire. He will be remembered by all for his charming and gentle manner, the twinkle in his eyes, and his wonderful stories about Uncle Harry and the history of the House of Winston. An invaluable mentor to colleagues, he made close and lasting friendships with his clients, many of international renown, who valued his absolute discretion. In addition to diamonds, Richard's passions included baseball, fishing and golf. Our thoughts are with his wife and family. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Weill-Cornell Breast Center, c/o Dr. Alexander Swistel, 425 E 61 St, 8th flr, NYC 10021

title: U.S. presses Taiwan on weapons impasse
U.S. poultry industry braces for action
Timing Is Everything as Georgetown Clicks
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 19 - Roy Hibbert says he knows what a perfectly played Georgetown game looks and sounds like. It is a clock, one in which the complicated Hoya cut-and-pass offense moves in measured beats of sneakers squeaking around the court. It means playing the silent, smothering defense that causes a kind of creeping dread in opponents that their time is running out.

title: Japanese Lessons For Teachers
description: Randall David Cook's new play, "Sake With the Haiku Geisha," a collection of five anecdotes inspired by the playwright's own experience as an English-language teacher in Japan, is an often observant, witty evening about the ways in which other cultures can unexpectedly impinge on our own individual experience. When Mr. Cook reaches for broader statements about humanity, though, those strengths of observation and humor fall by the wayside.

title: Briefly: Uzbekistan expels UN refugee agency
Alinta bid bypasses directors
Arts, Briefly
description: V for Victory at the Box Office

title: A N.Y. School That Teaches Teamwork by Camping
description: After four days and nights camping in the Rockland County woods, Donnell Tribble, a baby-faced 15-year-old from Brooklyn with tight cornrow braids, learned to trust and depend on his classmates and his teacher.

title: Hamas, Failing to Find Partners, Proposes Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM, March 19 - Hamas delivered its proposed cabinet list to the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Sunday night. Hamas is expected to control the most important government ministries after weeks of negotiations failed to persuade other Palestinian parties to join its government.

title: Enron Prosecutors Have Another Key Witness, From Jail
description: The government heads this week into the home stretch of its case against two former Enron chief executives. Prosecutors will be looking to end on a flourish with the testimony of Ben F. Glisan Jr., the only former top executive who has already been sentenced in the Enron debacle.

title: People: Prince Charles, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, Jessica Simpson
Clothes Don't Make the Man, but Blue Wool Defines This Governor
description: TRENTON, March 17 - Bella S. Abzug, the outspoken feminist congresswoman, had her big hats. Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Paul Simon, two erudite senators, had their bow ties. And Mao Zedong, of course, had his Mao suits.

title: Being Prepared for a Worst That Never Shows Up
description: At this point, the Metropolitan Opera's production of Verdi's "Forza del Destino," now in the final week of its run, is like a piata: everyone has taken a swing at it. And while the conventional wisdom about each individual performer has covered the entire spectrum of opinion, the aggregate has shaded toward "disastrous." So it seemed reasonable, on Saturday night, to brace for a train wreck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASSINI, OLEG
description: CASSINI--Oleg. Born in Paris, France April 11, 1913. A man of many great talents, respected for his achievements and experiences in the world of fashion, an accomplished sportsman, raconteur, a man passioned by history and his love for animals, died in Long Island on March 17, 2006. He will be greatly missed by his loving daughters, Daria and Christina, his granddaughters, Delphina and Jasmina, grandsons, Alexander and Cedric, and his five greatgrandchildren, Callissia, Alexandre and Charles del Pozo, Spencer and Oliver PedderDavies. In lieu of flowers please make memorial contributions to The Training School at Vineland, 1667 East Landis Ave., Vineland, NJ 08361; (856) 794-9454; The North Shore Animal League of America, 25 Davis Avenue, Port Washington, NY 11050; 516-883-7575.

title: Zurich American Agrees to Settlement in Price-Fixing Suit
description: The Zurich American Insurance Company, a unit of the Swiss insurer Zurich Financial, agreed yesterday to pay $171.7 million in cash to settle allegations of commercial insurance price-fixing and bid-rigging with Texas and eight other states.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 11 about Freddie Laker, who introduced low-cost trans-Atlantic air travel, misstated the year that Laker Airways started service. It was 1966, not 1977. A reader's e-mail message about the error was initially misdirected at The Times.

title: The President and the Courts
description: Since the Republican majority has decided to allow President Bush to usurp Congress's role in matters of national security, the battle to save the constitutional balance of powers moves to the judiciary. A critical test of judicial independence will come this month, when the Supreme Court hears arguments in a case that has become a focus of Mr. Bush's imperial vision of the presidency.

title: Indonesia's Muslim party widens its appeal
Campaign in Sweden gets feisty
Merck to Enter a Venture for Pain Drugs
description: Merck & Company, stung by the withdrawal of Vioxx from the market, will enter a collaboration to develop new painkilling drugs with Neuromed Pharmaceuticals, a privately held biotechnology company.

title: Phone Call Alters Prospects for a Trainer and a Horse
description: Nine months after winning the Kentucky Derby with the 50-1 shot Giacomo, John Shirreffs was back to being just another trainer. By mid-February, he had just two victories this year and no prospects for the Derby.

title: Amazon Says Technology, Not Ideology, Skewed Results
description: Amazon.com last week modified its search engine after an abortion rights organization complained that search results appeared skewed toward anti-abortion books.

title: Behind Louisiana Aid Package, a Change of Heart by One Man
description: Louisiana was in a foul mood on the February day that President Bush's Gulf Coast rebuilding coordinator, Donald E. Powell, stood before an audience of fellow bankers in Baton Rouge.

title: At World Forum, Support Erodes for Private Management of Water
description: MEXICO CITY, March 19 - For more than a decade, the idea that private companies would be able to bring water to the world's poor has been a mantra of development policies promoted by international lending agencies and many governments.

title: Restoration of Synagogue Saves a Sense of History
description: Max Smith sat on a folding chair yesterday, gazing at the intricate terra-cotta carvings that adorn the facade of the Eldridge Street Synagogue on the Lower East Side, a sight that stirred memories of an era gone by.

title: Luna Leopold, River Researcher, Is Dead at 90
description: Luna B. Leopold, an ecologist and author whose studies of American rivers provided new insights into their depth, velocity and movement patterns that proved to be fundamental to all rivers, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 90.

title: Witness in Detectives' Trial Tells of Pressure to Cooperate
description: The federal trial of Louis J. Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa veered today from Brooklyn murder and Las Vegas lunacy to the high-stakes poker game played by government agents and gangland turncoats as the trial's star witness told the jury of the immense "pressure" placed on him to "crack" and cooperate against the two retired detectives in the case.

title: Justices Reach Out to Consider Patent Case
description: For the first time in a quarter-century, the Supreme Court will hear on Tuesday a case involving the basic question of what type of discoveries and inventions can be patented.

title: Dell to Double Workforce in India
description: BANGALORE, India, Mar. 20 A Dell, the world's largest maker of personal computers, plans to double its employee strength in India to 20,000, and is scouting for a site to set up a manufacturing unit in the country, its chairman, Michael Dell, said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Endorsements Made
description: Bill Perkins, a former City Council member who is running for an open seat in the State Senate, announced yesterday that he had been endorsed by three Democratic council members who represent parts of the Senate district, Robert Jackson, Miguel Martinez and Melissa Mark-Viverito. The incumbent senator, David A. Paterson, is not seeking re-election because he is running for lieutenant governor. C. Virginia Fields, a former Manhattan borough president who ran for mayor last year, is also running for the seat. Rodney S. Capel, the executive director of the New York State Democratic Committee, announced last week that he would not run. Mr. Perkins, 56, served on the Council from 1998 to 2005, and was barred by term limits from seeking re-election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUBER, CLAIRE
description: GRUBER--Claire. 97, of Whippany, NJ, formerly of Long Branch, on March 19. Beloved mother of Sheila, Marvin (Marian), and Jack. Adored grandmother of Lisa (Todd) Resnick, Joseph (Cary) Sternlicht, Betsy (Eric) Goldberg, Gail (Aaron) Siegel, Laura (Justin) Lansburgh, Allison (Barry) Fiedel, and Steven Gruber. Proud great-grandmother of 14 and greatgranddaughter expected in April. Chapel services 12 pm, Tuesday, at the BloomfieldCooper Jewish Chapels, 2130 Hwy 35, Ocean, NJ. Donation to Hadassah or the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Dipping a Toe in Supernatural Waters
description: A Dirty Job By Christopher Moore Illustrated. 387 pages. William Morrow. $24.95.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot At Nightclub
description: A 19-year-old man was shot and critically injured early yesterday inside a nightclub after he got into a fight with two patrons, the police said. The man, Albert Santana, was shot once in the face about 4 a.m. at Club Attractions, at 566 Nostrand Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant. The police said they were looking for two men who were seen fleeing just after the shooting, which took place as the club was closing. In November, a 55-year-old man was fatally stabbed at the same club after he tried to break up a fight between a patron and his daughter, who was tending bar.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Anne Braden, a civil rights activist of the 1950's, misstated the year of her graduation from Randolph-Macon. It was 1945, not 1954.

title: Is the Next Silicon Valley Taking Root in Bangalore?
description: BANGALORE, India, March 19 - Twenty young engineers, mostly from the Indian Institute of Technology, India's premier technology school, peer into computer monitors in the no-frills office of Read-Ink Technologies, a start-up company housed in a small building in the bustling Indiranagar neighborhood of this city.

title: Fed Chief Sees Need to Include Global Factors in Setting Rates
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the newly installed Federal Reserve chairman, suggested this evening that the central bank would need to pay more attention to global financial conditions in setting interest rates, moving beyond its usual focus on domestic economic forces.

title: U.S. firm stops some mining workafter attack in Indonesia
TiVo Has Been Cutting Out More Than Just the Commercials Lately
description: The first episode in the new season of "The Sopranos" ended in a classic cliffhanger moment, with Tony on the floor after being shot by his uncle Junior. But some viewers who recorded the show on their TiVo digital video recorders to watch later might not know how close Tony came to being whacked.

title: Finding Eternity in a Long Wash of Eighth Notes
description: It was an Anthony Braxton show, all right: a 13-piece band called the Twelvetet Plus One; a mess of instruments including bassoon, contrabass clarinet, trombone, vibraphone and drums; an abundance of sheet music. But Mr. Braxton's gig this week was not at a small, nonprofit arts center. It was at Iridium, a jazz club on Broadway at 51st Street.

title: Incumbent Remains Popular in Heartland's Rural Villages
description: KRUPITSA, Belarus, March 19 - Vladimir M. Grom pulled out of a case a bagpipe known here as a duda, assembled it and demonstrated its deep, resonant music.

title: Villanova's 'Road Trip' Gets a Rolling Push
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 19 - In a typical season, Villanova moves five of its biggest home games from its campus arena to the Wachovia Center. But knowing that the N.C.A.A. will not place a tournament team on a court where it has played more than three home games, and knowing that the N.C.A.A. prefers keeping top teams close to home in early rounds, Villanova played only three regular-season games at the Wachovia Center, preserving its chances to return for the tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSWICK, BRUCE H.
description: ROSWICK -- Bruce H. On March 18, 2006. Beloved husband of Melanie. Adored father of William and John. Special soul mate of Ajax. Loving son-in-law of Sue Smilow. Cherished brother-in-law of Candice Smilow, Riki and Herb Freedman. You will be in our hearts forever. Services Monday, 12 noon, at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Listen to the insurgents
Executives of utilitiesdefend deal at the EU
Meanwhile: Loosening up (again) with the Supremes
The Touch, the Feel, of That Written Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: French Protesters Set Strike Date
description: PARIS, March 20 A French students and unions stepped up pressure on the government today, calling for more demonstrations culminating in strikes next week to fight a hotly contested new labor law that makes it easier for companies to fire young employees.

title: A Seemingly Modest Fate for a Lofty Card
description: When a defender holds the trump ace, he exercises control over the play. And he usually likes that ace to capture at least one of declarer's top trumps. But occasionally the ace must be "wasted" because there is something much more pressing that needs to be done.

title: Popular Demand
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIFER, MONROE
description: SEIFER--Monroe, 89. Died March 17, 2006, at his winter home in Aruba. An inspiration to all for his generosity, positive spirit and determination, he was: developer/builder/operator of Holiday Inn Hotels and Motels (since 1950); Vice Chairman, Board of Trustees Lutheran Medical Center (since 1975); Chairman, Board of Trustees, Acting President at the New York College of Podiatric Medicine (since 1987); member, Planning/Development Committee at Maimonides Medical Center (1990-91); member, NYC Technical College Foundation (1980-87); member, Board of Trustees, Bay Ridge Jewish Center (since 1955), having served as former twoterm President, Chairman, Honorary Chairman of the Board of Governors; honored by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies for his lifelong commitment to the Brooklyn Jewish Community Council, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, United Jewish Appeal; founding member of the Citizens Committee for NYC (1975); awarded honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters by the New York College of Podiatric Medicine (1976); winner of national four-wall handball championships in the over 65 and 70 age groups and passionate about golf, which he played on the morning he died. He is survived by his wife of 25 years Vera, his children, Randy and Michael and their families, and his step-children, Gregg Stein and Dana Dince and their families. Private memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory can be made to Lutheran Medical Center or the Bay Ridge Jewish Center, both in Brooklyn.

title: The View From There: Beautiful and Doomed
description: Day by dispiriting day, senior writers and editors at The New Yorker, Vanity Fair and other Cond Nast magazines and top lawyers at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom are watching one of the perks of their Manhattan careers getting slowly gobbled up -- the view.

title: Guineans Sketch Their History, but Hipness Breaks the Spell
description: New Yorkers are now old friends with Les Ballets Africains and its fast-moving, exuberant dancing, vivid costumes and music played on traditional drums and stringed instruments. The reception the troupe, the 44-year-old national dance company of Guinea, received on Friday night at the Skirball Center was rapturous.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a secret Pentagon study analyzing the effectiveness of Special Operations forces misstated the timing of an assignment once held by Wayne A. Downing, the retired four-star general who is the author of the review. He was counterterrorism adviser to the current President Bush, not the first one.

title: Unhappy Anniversary in Iraq
Why Do So Few Women Reach the Top of Big Law Firms?
description: Although the nations law schools for years have been graduating classes that are almost evenly split between men and women, and although firms are absorbing new associates in numbers that largely reflect that balance, something unusual happens to most women after they begin to climb into the upper tiers of law firms. They disappear.

title: Biggest British Insurer Considers Getting Hostile With Rival
description: Britains biggest insurer, Aviva, said on Sunday that it would consider this week whether to make a hostile bid for a rival, Prudential, or to raise its offering price after a preliminary approach was rejected.

title: Alinta Presses Ahead with $5.1 Billion Hostile Offer
description: Alinta Ltd. made a hostile A$7.06 billion ($5.1 billion) bid for Australian Gas Light Co., the nations largest utility, bypassing directors who dismissed the same offer as too low. But Alintas offer is not going to go anywhere as its on the same terms as its earlier proposal which the AGL board has already said undervalues the company, said Chad Slater, who helps manage $54 billion including utilities stocks at BT Financial Group in Sydney. I expect the two companies will come together but it may take six to eight months to get an agreement.

title: Suitors Weighing BAA After It Rejects Spanish Bid
description: Infrastructure investors from Britain, Canada and Australia are all circling BAA, the owner of seven U.K. airports including Heathrow and Gatwick, which on Friday rejected an 8.8 billion pound bid approach from Spanish infrastructure company Grupo Ferrovial.

title: British Mergers Rife With Insider Trading
description: A study by the British stock market regulator found that there may have been insider trading in nearly a third of mergers and acquisitions announced in the country in the last several years. The Financial Services Authority said that between 2000 and 2004, there were price movements suggesting some informed trading in 28.9 percent of all takeover deals.

title: Brightcove Buys Web Video Tool Maker
description: Brightcove, an emerging company in Internet Protocol TV, has acquired MetaStories, which makes tools to enhance Web video.

title: Fired UBS Broker Crying Foul
description: A former UBS broker is stepping up a personal war against Wall Streets latest rampant abuse: eating its own. Evan Cole  the younger brother of designer Kenneth Cole  says he was fired by UBS and blacklisted in a trumped-up nightmare, just to wrest away $50 million of his clients money and avoid paying him six-figures to manage it.

title: Investment Banks May Be Undervalued
description: When Goldman Sachs reported record quarterly earnings for an investment bank last week, investors were more than just impressed. They faced having to rethink traditional valuations for brokerages altogether.

title: That Other Madness This Month: Mergers
description: March madness is not limited to college basketball. Billions of dollars in mergers were announced this week, building on the momentum created when AT&T offered to acquire BellSouth for $67 billion earlier in the month.

title: R.R. Donnelley Catches OfficeTiger by the Tail
description: R.R. Donnelley & Sons , the printing company, is expected to announce it is buying closely held outsourcing company OfficeTiger for $250 million, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Citizens Financial CEO Sees Salary Bonanza
description: Lawrence K. Fish, chief executive of Citizens Financial Group, earned more than $13 million in salary, bonus, and other incentives last year, more than doubling his compensation of 2004, the Royal Bank of Scotland, Citizens parent, said in a regulatory filing yesterday.

title: Wachovia to Look West for Acquisitions
description: In the wake of Capital One Financial Corp.s $14.6 billion purchase of North Fork Bancorp for, analysts say they expect Wachovia Corp. to look West for its next acquisition, rather than in the Empire State.

title: Before Its Time, the Death of a Newspaper Chain
description: In contrasting how Knight Ridder rolled over from Private Capital Management with how Time Warner recently dealt with demands from the financier Carl C. Icahn to break up that company, it may all come down to tactics.

title: While AT&T Does Deals, Verizon Spends to Hone Its Networks
description: Ivan Seidenberg, who created Verizon Communications by merging Nynex with Bell Atlantic and then buying GTE, is known in the telecommunications industry as a chief executive who makes all-or-nothing bets.

title: SBA Communications Buy Beefs Up Wireless Tower Holdings
description: SBA Communications on Friday agreed to buy AAT Communications for about $1 billion in cash and stock, reacquiring wireless towers in the Western United States that it sold to AAT three years ago.

title: Taking Aim at Wall Street Analysts
description: Mocking and maligning analysts has been a sport for investors ever since the Internet bubble burst. Still, despite public humiliation for a handful of analysts and a $1.44 billion settlement in 2002 involving 10 Wall Street firms research operations, investors still read analysts reports, and they still believe them.

title: Investment Bank McColl Garella Shuts Its Doors
description: McColl Garella, an investment-banking firm that focused on women-owned businesses, is closing less than four years after being started by Hugh McColl Jr.,the former Bank of America chairman, and investment banker Julie Garella.

title: Plan to Privatize Scottish Water May Draw Fire
description: The British government wants to privatize Scottish Water in an offering that would raise more than 2 billion pounds for the public purse but could cause a political storm in Scotland.

title: Auction Site in Bid to Go Public
description: Bidz.com filed late Friday to go public, as the online jewelry auctioneer plans to raise up to $57.5 million through the initial public offering of common stock. The Los Angeles-based company, which will apply to list on the Nasdaq stock exchange under the symbol BIDZ, said ThinkEquity Partners LLC will act as the underwriter of the deal.

title: Chinese Chip Maker I.P.O.  Gets on the Road
description: Chinese chip maker Advanced Semiconductor Manufacturing  is starting the formal roadshow for its initial public offering today with the aim of raising between $71 million to $97 million.

title: Breaking With Policy, St. Paul Travelers Denies Merger Rumors
description: Breaking with its own corporate policy, St. Paul Travelers Cos. on Sunday denied a report in The Wall Street Journal that its been in discussions on the possibility of a merger with Zurich Financial Services Group. The St. Paul, Minn.-based property-casualty insurer doesnt ordinarily comment on or respond to rumors or speculation, but in this case St. Paul Travelers said it issued the denial because of the factual and definitive manner in which the purported Zurich Financial talks were reported to be taking place.

title: Italian Banks Provoke M&A Chatter
description: Ever since BNP Paribas, Frances second-biggest bank by assets, swooped for Italys Banca Nazionale del Lavoro at the start of last month, Europes banking halls have been buzzing with rumors about the next move in the long-awaited consolidation of Italian banking. Most of the gossip has centred on a merger of Banca Intesa, Italys biggest bank by assets, and Capitalia, ranked fourth.

title: Floridas Freedom Bank Prices Offering
description: Freedom Bank, based in Bradenton, Fla., said it had begun a public offering of 1.2 million shares of stock at $13 a share. The $15 million to $17.2 million offering is expected to close on March 24. After the offering, shares of Freedom Bank will continue to trade on the OTC Bulletin Board under the symbol FBBF.

title: Tim Hortons Looks Ready to Score
description: Tim Horton shoots. He scores! Well, the IPO of the company Horton founded will score big with investors. The namesake of the quick-service Canadian restaurant chain died in 1974, but Tim Hortons, being spun off by Wendys, follows the strong debut of Chipotle Mexican Grill. That I.P.O. doubled on the first day of trading and established investor interest in the quick-service restaurant sector.

title: Is Bangalore the New Silicon Valley?
description: Bangalore has become a hotbed for technology start-ups. The new firms are drawn by the regions big pool of engineering graduates, many of whom have expertise in esoteric new technologies. That advantage, coupled with labor costs much lower than those of Silicon Valley, is starting to turn Bangalore, long a center for lower-end outsourcing services, into a center of higher-end innovation.

title: Mittal Frets Over Arcelors Plans to Thwart Bid
description: The chief executive of the worlds biggest steel maker Mittal Steel, Lakshmi Mittal said he was really worried by a plan by Arcelor management to spoil his 19 billion euro takeover bid.

title: Cash Comes Easy to Some Technology Start-Ups
description: The market for high-technology start-up businesses is so intense in Silicon Valley that some companies are being showered with millions of dollars from investors  without even asking for it. It is a phenomenon called pre-emptive financing, and it has become more common in the past several months.

title: Private Equity Is Luring More Top Executives
description: Becoming the chief executive of a big public company is the pinnacle of a business career.

title: New Enterprise Sets Its Sights on Motricity
description: New Enterprise Associates, one of worlds largest venture capital firms and a financial juggernaut that has propelled scores of technology firms into the public spotlight, has wireless upstart Motricity of Durham, N.C., in its crosshairs.

title: William Lyon Founder in 2d Bid to Take Company Private
description: On Friday, for the second time in a year, the founder and chief executive of William Lyon Homes made an unsolicited offer to take the Newport Beach-based real estate developer private. William Lyon, who served as a pilot in the Korean War and later commanded the Air Force Reserve, offered to buy the 51 percent of the company he doesnt already own for $93 a share.

title: Hopeful Start-Ups Will Strut Their Stuff for V.C.s
description: Thirty of the Midwests high-growth and technology companies will outline their business plans for an audience of venture capitalists at the seventh annual InvestMidwest Venture Capital Forum during the first week of April.

title: Boards Responsible for U.S. Corporate Pay Excesses
description: In an example of coporate pay excess, senior managers windfall on the takeover of North Fork Bancorp was so large theyve handed much of it back. But greedy C.E.O.s and compliant compensation consultants are not to blame for the pay scandal. Its lax directors who should take the rap, according to Breakingviews.

title: Housing Slowdown Is Weighing on Wall Street Profits
description: The Federal Reserves fight against inflation is taking a bite out of one of Wall Streets biggest money-makers: the $6.5 trillion market for packaging millions of home loans into tradable bonds.

title: Enron Prosecutors Have Another Key Witness, From Jail
description: The government heads this week into the home stretch of its case against two former Enron chief executives. Prosecutors will be looking to end on a flourish with the testimony of Ben F. Glisan Jr., the only former top executive who has already been sentenced in the Enron debacle.

title: Pixars Creative Force Gives a Glimpse of His Future With Disney
description: In the wake of its $7.4 billion acquisition of Pixar, the Walt Disney Company has been mum about what role John Lasseter, Pixars chief creative officer, will play in reviving Disneys storied animation division, except to say that it is a big one.

title: Justices Reach Out to Consider Patent Case
description: For the first time in a quarter-century, the Supreme Court will hear on Tuesday a case involving the basic question of what type of discoveries and inventions can be patented. Both sides say the case, which involves a blood test for a vitamin deficiency, could have a wide-ranging impact on the development of diagnostics, perhaps threatening many of the underlying patents for genetic and other medical tests.

title: London Exchange Shares Climb on Report of Renewed Talks With Euronext
description: Shares in the London Stock Exchange climbed more than 4 percent Monday morning, after The Sunday Telegraph reported the London exchange is considering renewing merger talks with pan-European rival Euronext.

title: Google Ordered to Submit Some Data to Federal Investigators
description: A federal judge ruled on Friday that Google must turn over some search data including 50,000 Web addresses to the government for a study of child pornography online.

title: Investment Firm Pursues Hollinger for Legal Fees
description: A judge has ruled that Tweedy Browne can pursue more than $5 million in legal fees from Hollinger International for its role in an investigation that led to the ouster of former Conrad Black as chairman and chief Executive.

title: Former Aptix Founder Cleared of Plot to Murder Judge
description: The founder of Silicon Valley high-tech company Aptix has been convicted of charges related to obstructing justice, perjury and witness tampering, but a federal jury cleared him of an allegation that he plotted to murder a San Francisco federal judge.

title: An English Lesson in Corporate Governance: Majority Votes for Directors
description: How can shareholders in American companies make directors more accountable? Having the right to kick them off the board is a start. It works in Britain. It might even help rein in runaway executive compensation.

title: For Sale On eBay: Cute Village, Only Used Once
description: The first town ever auctioned on eBay soon will be back up for sale on the online auction site. Nearly two years after he bought the tiny town of Bridgeville, Calif., Orange County financial adviser Bruce Krall said Friday he plans to re-auction the hamlet on eBay next month.

title: Prudential Shares Surge on Hopes for a Higher Takeover Price
description: Shares of Prudential of Britain surged as much as 14 percent on Monday on optimism that its larger rival Aviva will increase a $29.7 billion takeover offer. Prudential rejected the all-stock offer on Saturday.
Selborne Journal: 20 March 1759:  Cucumber-plants showed plenty of fruit for the first time; all on the second wood. Black weather, & continual showers.

title: Michaels Stores Explores a Possible Sale
description: Michaels Stores, the arts and crafts retail chain, said on Monday that it was exploring a sale of the company, which had a market value of $4.5 billion as of Fridays close. The company said in a statement that it had hired J.P. Morgan Chase as an adviser.

title: More Software Deals Ahead?
description: The recent uptick in software-industry mergers and acquisitions is expected to continue into 2006, according to a UBS Securities research report highlighted in Barrons.

title: Cramer Sees More Takeovers in Steel
description: A recent agreement to acquire Bayou Steel has TheStreet.coms Jim Cramer speculating that the steel sector is ripe for more takeover activity.

title: Use Your Imagination
description: Not so long ago I stopped in for a meal at Cafe du Soleil, a neighborhood bistro on the Upper West Side with food thats not bad at all. All the staples  steak frites, poulet roti, moules frites  are just fine, and the chefs more ambitious offerings, like grilled whole dourade and seared sea scallops, are pretty good, too.

title: VeriSign Opens Wallet Again for Wireless Content
description: Though it is better known as an Internet services and security company, VeriSign has been spending heavily to bolster the content management side of its business. The latest example is VeriSigns agreement to acquire privately held m-Qube, which makes software for delivering digital content to mobile phones.

title: Donald Trumps Latest Development
description: It took only 20 minutes for media-savvy real estate magnate Donald Trump to announce his latest achievement on the public airwaves. Mr. Trump announced the birth of his fifth child, an as-yet-unnamed baby boy, Monday morning in a telephone interview with MSNBCs Imus in the Morning.

title: SBS Fetches Big Premium in G.E. Takeover
description: An affiliate of General Electric announced on Monday that it would buy SBS Technologies for $16.50 a share, representing a fat 55 percent premium above the targets stock price at the close of trading Friday. The offer price was also well above SBS Technologies 52-week high of $12.51, reached in January.

title: Should Bush Shuffle the Cabinet?
Newark, U.S.A.: Donald Payne
description: The mayoral election in Newark four years ago brought to the surface a volcanic national debate over the state of black politics in America. It was a race between two Democrats, two African-Americans, and yet what emerged was a cavernous divide between two vastly different visions of the past, present and future of the black community. What was the lesson of that race  and will this race shed more light on the state of black politics?

title: Flatware Maker Oneida in Chapter 11
description: After a 2004 restructuring failed to remove enough debt from its balance sheet, tabletop flatware maker Oneida has turned to bankruptcy protection for relief.

title: Bushs Heir No Longer Apparent
description: A small number of Washington commentators and publications possess outsize influence in the so-called media primary that is, along with the money primary and the famous/important staffer primary, one of the early markers of presidential campaign success. Last year, a man most Americans have probably never heard of  Sen. George Allen of Virginia  was the favored pick of these Beltway pundits for the Republican nomination. (Yes, Washington opinion-makers have been pondering Campaign 2008 since George W. Bushs second inaugural, if not before.) Hotline editor Chuck Todd called Allen the races dark horse front-runner. Allen, an affable son of a former Washington Redskins (and Los Angeles Rams) coach with a fondness for football metaphors, was assumed to be W.s natural heir.

Bush has been spending like a drunken sailor on domestic programs is in danger of becoming one of those factoids that everybody knows to be true, regardless of the evidence. description: This has got to be the worst way to finance your home, but apparently it happens in Viet Nam. According to the Thahn Nien News.com (and a tip of the hat to Money and Markets, a goldbug Website, for spotting this one), you buy a home with the promise to repay a certain amount in gold in the future. The article doesnt make it clear how this works. (The article appears to have translated into English by the same guy who does the menus for Vietnamese restaurants.)

description: Lets see if this makes sense. You are a homeowner and you are in over your head in debt. Youd consider bankruptcy, but youd fail the means test for Chapter 7 protection from creditors and so youd have to file for a Chapter 13 repayment plan.

His professionalism and thoughtful approach to the news helped define television journalism in New York City for over three decades. The Society was fortunate to know Bill through his wife Adair, who has served on a number of committees since 1985 and most recently as an Advisor to the Marketing Committee. We extend our sympathies to Adair and the rest of the Beutel family. David T. Schiff, Chairman Board of Trustees Steven E. Sanderson, President and CEO $(6$)BEUTEL--Bill. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved member, Bill Beutel. He helped us preserve the rich theatrical roots of the Friars Club and his name belongs among the legendary and immortal Friars broadcasters such as Edward R. Murrow and like them, he shared a legacy of commitment to the very best. We are honored and proud to have been touched by this broadcast journalist and we extend our sincere condolences to his family. Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot Executive Director

Mr. Mintz, a lawyer, has taught at a private school in Greenwich Village and at law schools in Illinois and Rhode Island.

That, he recalled, is how far away his eldest son, Pat, who gave up a successful N.F.L. career to become an Army Ranger, was standing from his fellow Rangers when they shot him dead in Afghanistan almost two years ago.

title: Deficit Demagogues
description: Less than a week after he denounced the "wayward path" of deficit spending to a gathering of 2,000 Republican Party stalwarts, Senator Bill Frist, the Senate majority leader and would-be president, was busy presiding over business as usual in the Senate. Last Thursday, Mr. Frist, 49 of his fellow Republican senators and one Democrat approved a $2.8 trillion budget for 2007. The budget vote came just hours after Mr. Frist and 51 other Republicans voted to raise the nation's debt limit for the fourth time in five years -- this time by $781 billion, to nearly $9 trillion. All of that increase will be needed to pay for earlier tax cuts and spending increases, and, if the Republicans get their way on taxes, to pay for future deficit-financed tax cuts.

His fellow Democrats haven't exactly leaped to his side, but a recent poll indicated that 46 percent of the public considers censure warranted. If that figure increases, Mr. Feingold may have company.

With her beloved husband, Edward, Mrs. Hudes was a Guardian, supporting the university at the highest level and creating a fund to help talented young people benefit from the excellence of a Technion education. Sala and Edward Hudes also gave generously to other causes promoting the welfare of Israel and the Jewish people. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Edward Hudes and the entire family. Last year, the agency relocated to Romania more than 400 Uzbeks who had fled to neighboring Kyrgyzstan after Uzbek forces crushed an antigovernment demonstration in northeastern Andijon. Earlier this month, two Western-financed nonprofit groups -- Freedom House and the Eurasia Foundation -- were forced to stop their work in Uzbekistan. ETHAN WILENSKY-LANFORD (NYT)

Major projects included the Brooklyn Court House and Laguardia High School. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. D. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZECK, BELLE MAYER
description: ZECK--Belle Mayer. Prominent Rockland County Attorney, died peacefully at her home in Suffern on Saturday Evening. Born in Port Henry, NY on Ferburary 22, 1919, she moved to Suffern in 1925, where the Mayer family owned Suffern Distributors for forty years. Belle was a graduate of Suffern High School, attended Syracuse University and earned her JD at Fordham Law School. An accomplished attorney, she served as a prosecuting Attorney at the Nuremberg trials, working under Telford Taylor, on the I.G. Farben Trial. It was there that she met her husband, William A. Zeck (deceased, former NY State Supreme Court Justice). After their tenure at the Nuremberg Trials, the couple returned to New York, finally settling in Rockland County where they practiced law together for nearly fifty years, mostly at Mayer, Zeck and Prior. Belle continued her practice with the firm Coral Ortenberg Zeck and Codispoti retiring in 2000. She was a trustee of The Bank of New York, an original member of the Board of Trustees at Rockland Community College, a founding member of the Antrim Players, a candidate for the New York State Assembly in 1960, and a Democratic Party Activist. The annual award given by the Rockland Woman's Bar Association for Woman Attorney of the Year is the Belle Mayer Zeck Award. She is survived by her daughter Deborah Zeck Thorne of Nyack, her husband Eric Thorne, and their two children, Jessica and Andrew Thorne, as well as her son John Gustav Zeck of Littleton, CO, his wife Belva, and their two sons Daniel Zeck and Benjamin Zeck. Services will be held at the Montebello Jewish Center, Montebello Road, in Suffern at 12 Noon on Tuesday, March 21. The family has requested that donations in Belle Mayer Zeck's name be made through Planned Parenthood, the United Negro College Fund, Amnesty International or The Holocaust Foundation, at Harvard University

title: Making Water Flow Uphill (Think of It as a Hovercraft)
description: In a development that may lead to energy-saving devices like micropumps that are powered by waste heat and have no moving parts, researchers have discovered a new way to make liquids move in a controlled direction. In a process similar to the one that causes water droplets to dance across a hot skillet, liquids are suspended above a superheated, ratcheted brass surface on a thin cushion of vapor. The scientists, at the University of Oregon, say the flow of this vapor over the ratchets appears to make the liquid move. Movies of the process can be seen at www.uoregon.edu/linke/dropletmovies/. FRANK O'CONNELL

description: BAGHDAD, March 21  Insurgents returned to their old tactics today and stormed a jail at daybreak, killing 18 policemen and freeing all the prisoners inside.

description: Most murder defendants do not testify in court; the strategy is too risky. But then, most murder defendants do not take on a SWAT team with a kitchen knife, stab a lawyer during a courtroom escape attempt, apply to represent themselves, face banishment from the courtroom or make obscene gestures at the jury via videoconference.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Sears Holdings Persists in Sears Canada Offer
description: Sears Holdings extended a bid to acquire all of Sears Canada's shares until March 31 after the proposal was backed by just 9.5 percent of shareholders when an initial deadline expired late last week. The directors of Sears Canada recommended against the offer, valued at 16.86 Canadian dollars ($14.52) a share. With the shares that have been tendered, Sears Holdings now owns about 63 percent of the Canadian retailer. Sears Holdings ruled out increasing its offer for the company, based in Toronto, as well as any extensions of its deadline. An independent appraisal has valued the stock as high as 22.25 Canadian dollars ($19.16). Sears Holdings said it would support eliminating Sears Canada's dividends if the privatization bid failed. Six independent directors of Sears Canada have said they would not stand for re-election next month because of differences with Sears Holdings. The American company said it intended to replace them with employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIUSTI, DR. GINO
description: GIUSTI--Dr. Gino Husband, father, grandfather, executive, leader and friend, passed away on March 18, 2006 from complications due to cancer. He was 78. Born in New Kensington, Pennsylva nia on May 31, 1927 to the late Peter and Rose Giusti, Dr. Giusti attended the University of Pittsburgh where he earned a BS in Chemical Engineering in 1949, a Master's in Chemical Engineering in 1953 and a PhD in Economics and Business Administration in 1959. Dr. Giusti became affiliated with Texasgulf, a diversified natural resource com pany, in 1948 when he was awarded a research fellowship at the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research. He retired as President and Chief Executive Officer in 1989, after 41 years with the firm. While he had a long, successful business career, the love of his life was his wife and family. He married Ruth Greblunas in May, 1957 and together they raised five children in Stamford, Connecticut. Dr. Giusti was a devoted husband and took loving care of his wife, who fought her own illness, until she passed away on April 29, 2003. Dr. Giusti is survived by his sister, Jean DeValeria and her husband Herman, of Indianapolis, IN, and five children--Paul Giusti and his wife Kathy of New Canaan, CT, Dr. Susan Bristol and her husband David of New Hill, NC, Patricia Meiburg of Gahanna, OH, John Giusti and his wife Lisa of Hopkinton, MA. and Christopher Giusti and his wife Sarah of Herndon, VA. He also leaves ten grandchildren and innumerable friends. Friends may call on the family from 4:00 PM to 8:00 PM on Wednesday, March 22, 2006 at the Nicholas F. Cognetta Funeral Home, 104 Myrtle Avenue, Stamford, Connecticut 06902. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be sent to The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, 51 Locust Avenue, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: A Republican Rara Avis
description: A little over 10 years ago, an army of conservative Republicans led by Newt Gingrich and united by a political manifesto called the Contract With America swept into Washington. Among other things, they were determined to reverse a long and honorable tradition of bipartisan cooperation on laws protecting the country's air, water and wilderness. That most of these laws had been enacted under Richard Nixon was of no consequence to Mr. Gingrich and his acolytes, who divined (incorrectly, as it turned out) a strong public appetite for deregulation.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Change In Handling Of Abuse Claims
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago announced initiatives to improve the handling of sexual abuse accusations against priests. The archdiocese released the names of 55 priests who had had substantiated claims of abuse made against them since 1950. Officials have also hired a child welfare expert to train staff members on abuse reporting requirements and have improved reporting protocols with the authorities, said Jimmy M. Lago, chancellor of the archdiocese. A committee has also been appointed to help enact recommendations made in two independent audits. An audit conducted by a forensic investigation firm said a lack of communication among archdiocese departments had been the most significant failure in the handling of recent sexual abuse accusations against two priests. GRETCHEN RUETHLING (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about doubts raised over two Picasso drawings that were offered through Costco, the nation's largest warehouse club, misidentified one that was purchased for $40,000 by a California man in January 2005. It was a crayon drawing of a face, from 1970 -- not a drawing of a faun's face, from 1952. The 1952 drawing was not sold through Costco; a photograph of it, published with the article, was provided to The Times by the seller of the 1970 piece, who has also sold numerous other works through Costco in recent years. A correction on Friday misspelled the surname of the Picasso daughter who disputed the authenticity of a drawing attributed to him that was not sold through Costco. She is Maya Widmaier-Picasso, not Widmayer-Picasso.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, LEROY
description: BLOCK--Leroy. One of the sweetest men to ever walk the face of the earth. Beloved friend and mentor from our first meeting in 1973, to being my dinner date on June 10, 1980, the night I met my future wife of 25 years, Hazel. Most intelligent and very different from all others. Most kind and caring. Never forgetting important occasions. You'll be dearly missed but in our hearts forever. All your friends already miss you. Love, Marvin and Hazel Shanken $(6$)BLOCK -- Leroy. A man whose greatest creation was himself as a human being. No person who ever met Roy did not benefit from the experience. We love you, miss you, and will never forget you. Willa and Saul Waring

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Impersonator Sentenced To Prison
description: A Brooklyn man who impersonated city workers to steal from elderly homeowners was sentenced yesterday to 16 years in prison, said Rose Gill Hearn, commissioner of the Department of Investigation. The man, Shawn M. Brown, 54, was convicted last month of burglary, criminal impersonation and other offenses after prosecutors charged that he claimed to be a city tax collector or water inspector in order to get money from homeowners in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Prospect Heights and East New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Natural Gas Retailer in Hostile Move for Big Utility
description: Alinta, a natural gas retailer, made a hostile bid of 7.1 billion Australian dollars ($5.1 billion) for the Australian Gas Light Company, the nation's largest utility, bypassing directors who dismissed the offer as too low. Alinta offered shares equal to 19.31 Australian dollars ($13.97) for each Australian Gas share, it said. The company, based in Perth, bought 19.9 percent of Australian Gas last month, prompting a counterproposal to buy Alinta for 2.72 billion Australian dollars ($1.97 billion). Alinta's offer "is not going to go anywhere as it's on the same terms as its earlier proposal which the AGL board has already said undervalues the company," said Chad Slater of BT Financial Group in Sydney. "I expect the two companies will come together, but it may take six to eight months to get an agreement."

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Protest For Disabled Rights
description: About 400 protesters, many in wheelchairs, locked up major streets around downtown Nashville. They contend that the state is too quick to send disabled people to nursing homes instead of paying for community-based services that would help them to remain independent at home. They want lawmakers to approve a proposed law that would provide more state and federal money for home-based services. The group arrived without notice just as lawmakers from around the state were convening for the week's session. Demonstrators declined requests to clear the streets, and legislators were temporarily blocked from the Capitol's parking garage. BRENDA GOODMAN (NYT)

title: 2 Years After Soldier's Death, Family's Battle Is With Army
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. - Patrick K. Tillman stood outside his law office here, staring intently at a yellow house across the street, just over 70 yards away. That, he recalled, is how far away his eldest son, Pat, who gave up a successful N.F.L. career to become an Army Ranger, was standing from his fellow Rangers when they shot him dead in Afghanistan almost two years ago.

title: EU unveils its strategy to lure tourists to Europe
Arts, Briefly; If It's Sunday, It Must Be ABC
description: ABC's "Desperate Housewives" was a repeat on Sunday, but no matter: the network still won the night with ease. The victory was thanks to the 8 p.m. "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (16.15 million) and the popularity of the "Housewives" rerun (13.56 million); both won their time periods in Nielsen's estimates. On top of that, ABC's "Grey's Anatomy," in which the hospital's surgeons and interns engaged in a rash of obsessive-compulsive, paranoid behavior to try to reverse their bad luck with patients, was once again Sunday's most-watched program, drawing 21.11 million viewers. The recent surge in the ratings for "Grey's Anatomy" has hurt NBC's "Crossing Jordan," a competitor in the 10 p.m. hour. This week, that forensics drama starring Jill Hennessy brought in 10.12 million, and it had its lowest 18-to-49 rating ever for an original episode. Also on NBC, "The West Wing" continued to limp toward the finish line. The soon-to-be-extinct series attracted only 8.01 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

Major Strides in Fending Off Depression Among the Elderly
description: Many elderly people are already distressed by the increasing numbers of drugs they are taking, including painkillers and heart medication. Now, those who are also battling depression may be wondering where it all will end.

title: Consensus Still Eludes U.N. on Iran Compliance
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 21 A Drafters of a Security Council statement on Iran's nuclear program decided to revise it today after a lengthy meeting of senior diplomats from six nations failed to overcome objections from China and Russia to terms being advanced by the United States and Europe.

title: Disparities: Care After Heart Attack Appears Less Than Equal

description: The deadly strain of avian flu has not been found anywhere in the Western Hemisphere, but Mark Holden, a chicken grower for Tyson Foods in Ellijay, Ga., is not taking any chances.

title: Arts, Briefly; Judge Freezes Notorious B.I.G. Album
description: A federal judge has ordered a halt of sales of the debut album of the rap star Notorious B.I.G., who died in 1997. A jury determined that the title song of the album, "Ready to Die" (1994), included an unauthorized snippet of an Ohio Players tune. The move by Judge Todd J. Campbell of United States District Court in Nashville would freeze sales of one of rap's seminal albums -- it has sold about 3.3 million copies since its release -- though it was not clear when the ban would take effect. The decision came as a jury on Friday awarded $4.2 million in damages to the two companies that control the Ohio Players' recordings, Bridgeport Music and Westbound Records. The jury found that the Notorious B.I.G.'s label, Bad Boy Entertainment, improperly used a portion of the song "Singing in the Morning." Bridgeport and Westbound, which also control the music of the pioneering funk group Funkadelic, have filed hundreds of lawsuits to collect royalties over unauthorized samples. Bridgeport's effort began five years ago, after it won a dispute with the former Funkadelic leader, George Clinton, over copyright of the group's songs. In a separate case last year, Mr. Clinton won ownership of the master recordings of four of the group's albums from the 1970's and 80's. JEFF LEEDS

title: Managing Globalization: Costs of exporting labor
India to Expand Convertibility of the Rupee

The ruling, a rare reversal of a jury verdict, is a big setback for the government, which had sought to portray Mr. Quattrone as a symbol of Wall Street's excesses during the boom years. [Page A1.]

Modern marriage is presented as a bickering duet not just for prickly romantic partners but for musical instruments, too, in this sleek stylish production from director John Doyle in which the evening's 14 performers double as an onstage orchestra.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, JAMES H., M.D., PH.D.
description: SCHWARTZ--James H., M.D., Ph.D. The psychoanalytic community, no less than the neuroscientific one, owes a huge debt of gratitude to Dr. James H. Schwartz. In 1990, together with Dr. Arnold Pfeffer, he took the revolutionary step of forming an interdisciplinary seminar in which psychoanalysts discussed with neuroscientists (their historical archrivals) what they had learned about the workings of the mind. This would not have been possible had it not been for Dr. Schwartz's impeccable scientific credentials and the wide network of authorities that he could count as personal friends. In due course, he made them friends of psychoanalysis too. His efforts culminated in the establishment of the vibrant International Neuro-Psychoanalysis Society and its journal Neuro-Psychoanalysis, on whose editorial board he sat since its inception in 1999. The interdisciplinary seminar that he started still continues in the form of a monthly public lecture at the Arnold Pfeffer Center at the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. Our warmest sympathy to his family. Mark Solms, Ph.D., Director Arnold Pfeffer Center NY Psychoanalytic Institute

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about violence in Iraq misidentified the Shiite Muslim holy day that millions of pilgrims began celebrating in the holy cities of Najaf and Karbala, raising a security concern that caused the assigning of extra American troops to those cities. The observance is Arbaniya, which commemorates the end of the mourning period for Imam Hussein, grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, who was killed by an overwhelming force of rival Sunni Muslims near Karbala in A.D. 680. (Ashura, when Shiites re-enact Hussein's death, falls 40 days earlier.)

Tears are not far off; frustration is palpable. One woman holds a tiny puppy in her arms, but no one seems to notice.

title: Memo Pad
description: LOW FARES, CREEPING UP -- The average domestic airfare negotiated for corporations by American Express Business Travel hit a six-year low in 2005, the global travel management company said. The main reasons were "the introduction of simplified fares and more low-fare competition," said Andy McGraw, a senior vice president. But the average for domestic flights edged up 3 percent in the fourth quarter compared with the fourth quarter of 2004, as oil prices stayed high and carriers cut domestic capacity. This year, Mr. McGraw said, "corporate travel buyers will face a tough negotiating environment across the board," as prices rise for air travel, hotels and rental cars. The average negotiated first-class round-trip fare on 160 major international routes tracked by the American Express Business Travel Monitor was $11,610, up 4 percent, in the fourth quarter of 2005. The average negotiated round-trip business-class fare rose 5 percent, to $7,824, and for coach fares, the average rose 9 percent, to $2,226, American Express said.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Saturday, about pay for airline pilots, misstated what the top salary for a pilot in 1924 would be in today's money. It would be about $93,000, not $1 million. (Go to Article)

title: Visitors Seek a Taste of Revolution in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela - The actor Danny Glover has come. Harry Belafonte has also been here. So has the antiwar activist Cindy Sheehan, the prominent African-American writer Cornel West and Bolivia's new president, Evo Morales.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Chef Returns to 'South Park,' With a Difference

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (Bravo) THE REAL HOUSEWIVES OF ORANGE COUNTY -- Such a group of unlikable people! This documentary series with a strong reality-show feel introduces viewers to five California women in a wealthy gated community -- from left, Vicki Gunvalson, Jeana Keough, Johanna De La Rosa (front), Lauri Waring and Kim Bryant. Like the fictional women of "Desperate Housewives," three of the group do have careers. But their great life concerns include breast implants, Botox, pre-prom professional makeup appointments (for a 13-yearold), a high school boy's dream of bypassing college for a baseball career and the distress of one young man over his 24-year-old fiance's not turning into "that housewife that I've kind of dreamed of." Next week: Kimberly feels her car isn't good enough. Part 1 of 7.

title: More Variety for 'Goldberg': In 1600's Style, With Quills
description: A harpsichord recital at the Frick Collection is an exercise in architectural as well as musical balance: the proportions of the small, round hall are ideal for the instrument's intimacy. And attention to this kind of detail, and a satisfying sense of rightness, were hallmarks of Richard Egarr's appearance there on Sunday afternoon, playing Bach's "Goldberg" Variations on a model of a 1638 harpsichord, with real quills to pluck the strings.

title: F.B.I. Agent Testifies Superiors Didn't Pursue Moussaoui Case
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 20 - The F.B.I. agent who arrested and interrogated Zacarias Moussaoui just weeks before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks told a jury on Monday how he had tried repeatedly to get his superiors in Washington to help confirm his certainty that Mr. Moussaoui was involved in an imminent terrorist airline hijacking plot.

title: Reactions: In Children, Rise in Bacteria Is Linked to Smoke
description: Children exposed to secondhand tobacco smoke appear to be more likely to be infected with Streptococcus pneumoniae than those who are not.

title: Major Strides in Fending Off Depression Among the Elderly
description: Many elderly people are already distressed by the increasing numbers of drugs they are taking, including painkillers and heart medication. Now, those who are also battling depression may be wondering where it all will end.

title: Telenor Offers Deal to End Russian Feud
description: MOSCOW, March 20 - Telenor, the Norwegian mobile phone operator, offered on Monday to sell its Ukrainian telecommunications business to a Russian company for $5 billion in cash.

description: SANGER--Ethel. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Ethel Sanger, beloved mother of Mary Bryna Sanger, and extends deepest condolences to the family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about recent research on pregnancy, suggesting that its dangers can be explained by a tug of war between mother and fetus over nutrients, referred incorrectly to one process in this conflict. Fetal cells called trophoblasts invade the maternal blood vessels to draw nutrients from the mother; the invaders are not fetal blood vessels.

But that perk, a touch of jet-setting glamour in an increasingly dreary line of work, is now much harder to use because so many flights are full.

Grandfather of Emily, Jessica, Frank, Bennett, William, Sarah, Nora, Lucy, Samuel, Magdalene, Devon, Claire and Avery and greatgrandfather of Aidan. Brother of the late Bert, Edna and Mildred. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass at Mary Manning Walsh Home, York Ave and 72 St, Wednesday, 9:30 am. Burial to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, NJ.

She studied molecules that cause atherosclerosis (thickening and hardening of arteries), not arthrosclerosis (stiffness or hardening of joints).

description: The program was devoted largely to music of Arvo Prt, and on the strength of it, you might have wished for more. On the other hand, the mere four numbers from Rachmaninoff's glorious Vespers whetted the appetite for the whole work. You might even have wished for more music by Cyrillus Kreek on the basis of his "Five Religious Folk Songs."

title: When the Swallows Came to Baikal
description: Barn swallows are like Starbucks stores  everywhere people settle, they are sure to follow. The birds are thought to have rapidly expanded their range since humans started providing barns, bridges and other structures for their mud nests. It is uncommon today to find a swallow nesting the old-fashioned way, in a cave or a tree crevice.

title: Trio in an Unlikely Pairing of Schubert and Janacek
description: As part of his Perspectives series, Richard Goode and two young singers -- Matthew Polenzani, a tenor, and Tamara Mumford, a mezzo-soprano -- took over Zankel Hall on Sunday evening for a program split between Schubert and Janacek. It was an unusual composer pairing: Schubert wrote in the language of the Viennese classicists, through Beethoven; Janacek forged a style and language of his own. But the subject was passion, spiritual and carnal, with each composer taking a side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOSSETT, O. MILTON
description: GOSSETT--O. Milton. The Board of Directors and staff of The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration are deeply saddened by the passing of O. Milton Gossett, our first "Man of Vision" honoree, long-time Board member and Honorary Director. As chairman of Compton Advertising and later Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide, he generously supported our mission with priceless advertising and marketing techniques in the form of many outstanding public information materials. His largess was second only to his wonderfully kind and gentle manner. We shall miss him greatly. Patricia Dahl Executive Director/CEO The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration, Inc.

description: THE HAGUE, March 20  It was a brief session but a momentous occasion at the International Criminal Court on Monday, when a former Congolese warlord, the first person to stand trial before the new institution, faced the judges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRISBANE, DORIS FAUSER
description: BRISBANE--Doris Fauser. Of Glen Cove, L.I. on March 16, 2006, age 80. Beloved wife of the late Seward. Loving mother of Arthur (Jo), Charles (Deborah), Aleta Heisig (William), Peter (Diane), Maria (Wallace). Dear sister of the late Charles and Joseph Fauser. Cherished grandmother of Allison, Madeline, Laura, Dana and Kyle Brisbane, Allaire Heisig, Olivia and Ian Henderson. Devoted member of St. John's of Lattingtown Altar Guild. Visiting at Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove Sunday 3-6 PM and Memorial service held on March 23 at 11 AM at St. John's of Lattingtown. Burial private. Donations may be made to St. John's of Lattingtown.

title: Report Urges Requiring All Convicts to Give DNA
description: ALBANY, March 20 - A State Investigation Commission report released on Monday calls for DNA samples to be collected from anyone convicted of a crime, bolstering an effort by Gov. George E. Pataki to expand the state's DNA database.

title: Slapping King Coal's Wrist
description: The Bush administration's accommodation of the mining industry -- notably by packing the mine safety agencies with pro-management appointees -- has produced a marked decline in major fines for negligent companies. A recent data analysis by The Times documented a risky, business-friendly downturn in penalties since 2001. At the same time, nearly half of the announced fines still go uncollected.

title: Movie Musical 'Chicago' Prompts a Suit Over Profits
description: The producer of "Chicago," the Oscar-winning 2002 movie, is charging that Miramax has cheated him out of millions of dollars of profit from it by using deceptive accounting to understate revenue.

title: After highway chase, Israeli police seize 10 Palestinians
Israel Arrests 10 Palestinians with Bomb Hidden in Van
description: JERUSALEM, March 21 A Acting on an intelligence tip, Israeli police chased down a van as it raced along a main highway toward Tel Aviv today, arrested the 10 Palestinian occupants and seized a 15-pound bomb hidden in a bag.

title: French protests, again

description: Two months before the Iraq war began, David Kay reported to the Pentagon for a job in the agency being formed to run postwar Iraq. Kay, a former Defense Department scientist and weapons inspector in Iraq, was supposed to oversee the police.

title: The Shock of Lung Cancer, When It Strikes Nonsmokers
description: Dr. David A. Karnofsky was a brilliant oncologist working hard at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to provide the best possible therapies for cancer patients. My mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 1958, was one of them. And while he could not save her, we were ever so grateful for the caring way he treated her.

title: Emotional Rough Stuff Resonates Within a Family
description: When you think you know someone well and find out otherwise, it can be exciting. Plays are like that, too.

title: The Growth of a Tenor Voice Made Plain in Handel Works
description: However often you see him, the tenor Ian Bostridge remains a startling figure on the concert stage: tall and beanpole-skinny, like a Giacometti sculpture come to life, with the presence of an Oxford don. Some singers, when they use a music stand, try to detach themselves from the printed page. Mr. Bostridge, singing Handel arias with the Orchestra of St. Luke's on Sunday afternoon, seemed willingly to read from the music, like a professor giving a lecture, as if telling the audience about coloratura runs rather than, completely, showing them.

title: Bush Pushes His Defense of Iraq War, Saying It Can Be Won
description: Declaring that the war in Iraq can still be won, President Bush continued his effort today to convince the public that the war was necessary and worth the sacrifices involved.

title: New York City Adding 800 Police Officers, Bloomberg Announces
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced this morning that New York City would add 800 police officers and 400 civilians to the 36,450-officer Police Department in the largest city-financed expansion of the nation's largest police force since the Safe Streets/Safe City program began in 1993 under the Dinkins administration.

title: Chinese Regulators Caution TV Talent Shows
description: SHANGHAI, March 20 - One of China's most popular television programs last year, an "American Idol" knockoff called "The Mongolian Cow Sour Yogurt Supergirl Contest," is apparently about to be reined in by government regulators here.

title: Keith Jackson Mulls Retirement From ABC Sports
description: Keith Jackson has not retired from ABC Sports, but he is seriously contemplating it. He said last night that he planned to tell ESPN executives in discussions that begin today: "I'm retired. Talk me out of it.' "

title: New Business Blooms in Iraq: Terror Insurance
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - Twice in the past year, Muhammad Said has survived assassination attempts that left his car riddled with bullets. He works part time as a bodyguard for his father, a Baghdad city councilman, and helps a friend who has contracts with the American military. Both are very dangerous jobs.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of the fashion designer Oleg Cassini on Sunday misstated the surname of a surviving daughter. She is Christina Cassini, not Belmont.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Sees Bloomberg School Reforms as Model
description: The mayors of the country's two most populous cities, Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles, toured an elementary school in Brooklyn yesterday and both said afterward that Mr. Bloomberg's successful drive to place the schools under his control was a model that should be examined nationwide.

Carmel Cemetery in Queens, NY.
