description: HURA, Israel - In a sky blue bedroom they share but rarely leave, a young sister and brother lie in twin beds that swallow up their small motionless bodies, victims of a genetic disease so rare it does not even have a name.

title: Energy tops agenda as Putin visits China
Paid Notice: Deaths  BUGANZA, DR. GIANCARLO
description: BUGANZA--Dr. Giancarlo. A loving husband, father and grandfather, and a dear friend who was an integral part of our lives. He will be remembered as a renaissance man; a highly professional, skilled, caring physician. Gian Carlo was a poet and an artist, a being of great intellect. Gaby, Lew, Stephie, Rachel, Jeffrey, Ace, Sophie, Bennett

title: Should Frank Quattrone Be Retried?
description: As prosecutors consider the possibility of trying Frank Quattrone for a third time, many pundits on the Internet and elsewhere are saying, in essence: Hang it up.

title: BAE Denies It Plans to Bid for L-3 Communications
description: BAE Systems of Britain, Europes largest defense contractor, has denied it had plans to bid for L-3 Communications Holdings of the United States or to sell its stake in plane maker Airbus, after The Guardian reported BAE was mulling a $10 billion offer for L-3.

title: Dubai Will Delay Another Acquisition Involving U.S. Plants
description: The Dubai government delayed the $1.2 billion purchase of a military-equipment maker, the second time in a month that a takeover by the Middle East emirate has been jeopardized by U.S. security concerns.

title: Jones Apparel Board Is Said to Be Exploring  Sale of  Company
description: The board of Jones Apparel Group is said to be exploring several strategic options  including a possible sale of the entire $5 billion company, according to Womens Wear Daily.

title: British Investment Trusts to Merge
description: Two of Britains oldest and largest investment trusts are set to merge creating a 2.7 billion pound giant that could soon be knocking on the door for entry to the FTSE 100 index of top companies. The Dundee-based Alliance and Second Alliance will seek approval from 60,000 private investors for the merger.

title: Pfizer Is Poised to Add Another $10 Billion to Its Coffers
description: Potential buyers are knocking on Pfizers door for its $10 billion consumer products division, and people are scratching their heads over what the company plans to do once its gets its hands on the money.

title: Sears Extends Offer for Canadian Subsidiary
description: Sears Holdings  extended its offer to March 31 for investors to tender their shares after its $835-million takeover bid for subsidiary Sears Canada Inc. fell short. Should the offer not succeed, Sears Holdings warned it would support cutting Sears Canadas quarterly dividends and extraordinary distributions to shareholders this year.

title: Call for Silicon Valley to Buy The Merc
description: Twelve Knight Ridder newspapers are up for sale, including Silicon Valleys hometown paper, The San Jose Mercury News. Now, former Mercury News columnist Dan Gillmor is advocating a new plan: Yahoo should buy the paper, along with some others in the chain, to turn the Bay Areafar and away the best place for this in Americainto a living laboratory of tomorrows journalism.

title: Former NatWest Banker Attacks Extradition
description: David Bermingham, one of the three former NatWest bankers fighting extradition to the United States, responded to the defense of the Extradition Act by Andy Burnham, Home Office minister, in an letter in The Daily Telegraph last week.

title: Is the Honeymoon Over for John  Mack?
description: For all the changes made by Morgan Stanleys John Mack in his first nine months as chief executive officer, shares of the firm still trail their Wall Street peers.

title: Deltek Acquires Houston Software Company
description: Houston software company Welcom has been purchased by a Virginia competitor for an undisclosed price. Deltek, a private software firm of nearly 900 employees, acquired Welcom to expand its overseas markets and add to its customer base, said Kevin Parker, president and CEO of the Herndon, Va.-based company.

title: Nissan Sells Nissan Diesel Stake to Volvo
description: Nissan Motor agreed Tuesday to sell 13 percent of Nissan Diesel to Swedish auto company Volvo, which said the deal was worth $196 million. Nissan, Japans second-largest automaker, is the top shareholder of Nissan Diesel, with a roughly 19-percent stake in the truck maker, the nations fourth-largest.

title: Following Icahns Lead, Hedge Fund Buys Lexar Stake and Opposes Match
description: Micron Technologys $680 million purchase of Lexar Media hit a stumbling block after Elliott Associates took a 6.5 percent stake in Lexar and said it is against the bid.

title: Jefferson-Pilot Merges With Lincoln Financial
description: Shareholders of Jefferson-Pilot voted overwhelmingly Monday morning to approve a proposal that will merge the the Greensboro, N.C., company into the Lincoln Financial Group and relocate the headquarters to Philadelphia.

title: Alternative Investment Is Powering Wall Street Profits
description: One striking aspect of last weeks blowout quarterly investment bank results was how much of Wall Streets earnings these days are driven by the alternative investment juggernaut.

title: Microsoft to Buy Maker of Remote Sensors
description: Microsoft has confirmed that it plans to buy Vexcel, a maker of remote sensors, to help expand Microsofts digital mapping efforts. In a statement on Monday, Microsoft said the pending deal would help it with its efforts to deliver a dynamic immersive digital representation of the real world that provides the best local search and mapping experience.

title: Put Down the Pipe and Step Away from the I.P.O.
description: The I.P.O. propsectus is the stock markets Breathalyzer: Its reading can tell you whether executives and investors in a company are operating under the influence of some reality-distorting substance, according to TheStreet.coms Kevin Kelleher.

title: HBOS Plans Offering for Property Fund
description: Insight, the fund management division of HBOS, is planning to float British Land, Britains biggest buy-to-let property fund, The Times of London said. The company run by Duncan Owen is considering injecting a 300 million pound residential portfolio that it acquired from British Land, with a further 200 million pounds of assets that it owns or is in the process of buying, into a new listed vehicle.

title: Temasek Raises Cash in Singapore Telecom Share Sale
description: Temasek Holdings, Singapores state-owned investment company, raised $1.2 billion by selling shares in Singapore Telecommunications, giving the fund cash to expand overseas. Temasek sold 770 million shares at S$2.66 each, 5 percent less than the closing price yesterday, the fund said in a statement today.

title: Mobile Text Marketer Vayusa Raises $10 Million
description: Vayusa, which offers a service called MobileLime that lets grocery stores market to customers via mobile text messaging, has raised a $10 million Series A round of funding to help it expand westward in new United States markets.

title: Commercial Barter Company Raises $1.2 Million
description: International Monetary Systems has received a commitment for an additional $1.2 million in funding from the same private investors who provided the company with more than $1 million last year. The commercial barter services company will use the proceeds to finance its continued growth through acquisitions.

title: Branson Said to Be Looking at Bally Chain to Build Up  Fitness Business
description: Virgin Group, run by flamboyant British billionaire Sir Richard Branson, is eyeing a takeover of health club chain Bally Total Fitness as a way to grow its Virgin fitness club business in the United States The New York Post reported.

title: SVG Commits $3.4 Billion to New Permira Fund
description: SVG Capital, the British private equity investor and fund management business, has made the largest single commitment  to any fund by any limited partner  to the new fund being raised by Permira.

title: Asprey Sells Garrard to Yucaipa
description: Asprey International, newly minted parent of the Asprey and Garrard brands, has sold 100 percent of Garrard to the Yucaipa Companies for an undisclosed price. The spin-off comes just three days after the purchase of Asprey and Garrard by Sciens Capital Management LLC and Plainfield Asset Management LLC in a management buyout.

title: Fieldston Cooks Up Regal Kitchens Buy
description: A buyout group led by Fieldston Investors  has acquired kitchen cabinet maker Regal Kitchens for less than $30 million in equity and debt. C3 Capital Partners LP, Capital South Partners LLC and Bush ODonnell Capital Partners LLC provided just under $15 million in equity and subordinated debt for the deal, with each firm committing about $5 million each, LBO Wire said.

title: Delphi Has Put Dominoes in Motion
description: Delphis bankruptcy has become a scalding witchs brew that has engulfed General Motors and the United Automobile Workers. It has also splashed over other auto parts suppliers that followed Delphi into Chapter 11. G.M. has been particularly singed. The companys disclosure last week of inaccurate accounting, which forced it to increase its 2005 loss and delay filing its annual report, has shaken its financial credibility.

title: Bush Selects Energy Regulators Before Review of Deals
description: President Bushs newest selections to join the countrys federal energy regulator appear intended to appeal to the agencys main, often opposing, constituencies.

title: Providence and Goldman Get Life of Luxury With Kerzner Buy
description: An investor group including Providence Equity Partners and a Goldman Sachs  affiliate has agreed to buy hotel-resort owner Kerzner International for $3.6 billion, including assumed debt.

title: Forget the Share Price, What About the Parking?
description: At its annual shareholder meeting,  Hewlett-Packard management found itself surrounded by shareholders angry about the Hyatt Regency Century Plazas unglamorous parking charges: $8 for the first hour, $2 for each additional hour.

title: Enron Tried to Avoid Write-Down, Accountant Says
description: Enron tried to dodge accounting rules by dropping a plan to sell assets in a failed water business, a former Arthur Andersen accountant said on Monday at the trial of two former Enron executives.

title: Former Gemstar Chief Found Liable in Fraud
description: A federal judge found the former chief executive of Gemstar-TV Guide, Henry C. Yuen, liable for securities fraud, according to a ruling unsealed on Monday in a federal regulatory lawsuit that claimed Mr. Yuen inflated the companys revenue by $248 million to increase its stock.

title: French Firm Ventech Begins Raising Its Third Fund
description: Ventech, a French venture capital firm, has begun raising its third fund seeking 150 million euros (about $180 million), with a first close of 80 million euros expected in June. The Paris firms debut fund closed in 1999 with 61 million euros; its second pool of capital closed the following year with 112 million euros.

title: Sirius Radio Settles With 3 Music Companies
description: Sirius Satellite Radio has reached agreements with three major recording companies to settle disputes over a portable music player that allows users to store digital copies of music, a Sirius spokesman said Monday. Financial details were not disclosed.

title: Former CAO Head Gets Prison Sentence  for Role in Trading Scandal
description: The former head of jet fuel trader China Aviation Oil (Singapore) was sentenced to four years and three months in prison on Tuesday for his role in the city-states biggest trading scandal since the collapse of Barings Bank in 1995.

title: Brother of Google Co-Founder Uses Shell Company for Handheld Start-Up
description: Google co-founder Larry Page is an icon among Internet entrepreneurs, but his older brother Carl is no slouch either when it comes to technology start-ups.

title: Pension Funds Stakes in Hedge Funds Sparks Political Outcry in Massachusetts
description: Too much Massachusetts pension money is going into risky hedge funds, said secretary of state William Francis Galvin, putting himself at odds with state treasurer Timothy P. Cahill, who has praised the funds strong returns. Mr. Galvin singled out the growing hedge fund stakes held by the Massachusetts Pension Reserves Investment Trust, whose board Cahill chairs.

title: A Technology  Company That  Sues for a Living
description: While most technology companies make money by developing software, building hardware or providing services, Forgent Networks has taken a different route: It produces threats and lawsuits that try to cash in on ideas.

title: Tim Hortons Lifts Price Range for I.P.O.
description: Tim Hortons  is raising the price of its stock and granting its underwriters the option to buy more shares when the company goes public this week. Tim Hortons shares will likely be priced between $25 and $27 a share, up from $21 to $23 a share, the company said late Monday.

title: American Express Sells Brazil Operations to Bradesco
description: Banco Bradesco, Brazils largest private sector bank, said on Monday it had agreed to buy American Express operations in Brazil for $490 million.

title: Bank of America Chief Gets  Pay Cut
description: Bank of America s chief executive, Ken Lewis, received $22 million in compensation in 2005, a 3 percent cut from the previous year, the companys proxy shows. The bank paid Mr. Lewis a $1.5 million salary, $5.65 million bonus, $11.7 million of restricted stock and $2.93 million of stock options. Lewis, 58, also received about $248,000 in benefits including use of company airplanes and tax and financial planning services.

title: Infuriated Softbank Chief Is Said to Have Issued Vodafone an Ultimatum
description: Japanese Internet giant Softbank threatened to walk away from talks to buy Vodafones Japanese business if Vodafone spoke to any of the private equity firms also interested in buying it.

title: Bid for British Insurer Stirs Talk of New Wave of Mergers
description: Avivas bid for Prudential  of Britain aroused speculation Monday that consolidation would again sweep the insurance industry, sending stock prices up in Europe.

title: Telenor Offers Deal to End Russian Feud
description: Telenor, the Norwegian mobile phone operator, offered Monday to sell its Ukrainian telecommunications business to a Russian company for $5 billion in cash.

title: Overstock.com Father-Son Team Says Theres No Feud
description: There is a lot that Jack Byrne and his son, Overstock.com chief executive Patrick, cannot agree on. But the elder Mr. Byrne, who recently said his sons crusade against short-selling hedge funds might drive him to step down as Overstock.coms chairman, claims that the press has overblown the rift between the two.

title: Worrying About Mortgage Resets
description: The Big Picture runs through an analysis of why mortgages resetting to a higher interest rate is nothing to worry about.He does however amass a lot of evidenceand loads of chartsthat Americans inability to refinance will be killing consumer spending.

title: Looking for Sell Signals?
description: Forbes.com is running a little slide show that purports to tell when to sell in a number of major cities.

title: Idealabs Gross Hatches New Plan: Paying Off His Debt
description: Bill Gross, whose Internet incubator Idealab famously burned through $800 million in eight months during the technology boom, is looking for money again. This time, he wants cash from his own company to repay a $50 million personal loan.

title: Cuba Throws Bush a Beanball
Morgan Stanley Bulks Up M&A Financing Team
description: Just a few weeks after hiring a top leveraged-finance executive away from Citigroup, Morgan Stanley has gone back to poach two more managing directors.

title: Storm Victims' Burdens and Frustration Linger
description: Scott Frischhertz and his family have returned to their house; but most Katrina evacuees say they have not found a permanent place to live.

title: Imagining Candidate Gore
description: Former vice president turned journalism professor turned MoveOn speechmaker turned documentary filmmaker Al Gore said yesterday that he doesnt plan to run for president again, but hes not ruling it out, either: I havent reached a stage in my life where Im willing to say I will never consider something like this. But Im not saying that to be coy; Im just saying that to be honest that I havent reached that point.

title: Sorry, Right Number
description: The staff at Le Cirque (including Sirio Maccioni, the owner, at far right) fields a flood of reservation requests in 1997.(Librado Romero/The New York Times)

title: Blank Check I.P.O.s Draw Regulatory Scrutiny
description: Regulators at the NASD are in the early stages of an investigation into initial public offerings of blank check companies, according to TheStreet.com.

title: As Shares Soar, Jones Apparel Explores Sale of Company
description: With its stock surging more than 10 percent on Tuesday, Jones Apparel Group confirmed a report that it was exploring a possible sale of the company.

title: Alphabet Soup
description: Mayor Sharpe James continues to be coy about his intention to run for a record sixth term but, as far as Newark06 is concerned, he is in the race until he says otherwise.

title: The Keepers of the Past
description: To salvage toppled cultures and redress orgies of larceny, the best thing to do is consider the notion of stewardship.

title: Braised Pork With Red Wine
description: Mark Bittman shows how to prepare braised pork with red wine.

title: Dont Believe the Hype
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Selborne Journal: 21 March 1759:  Moved the seedling Cucumber-frames nearer to the two-light frames, & sowed it with radishes on very deep mould. Beautiful day.

title: Colgate, On Oral Health Kick, Swallows Toms of Maine
description: It may be looking at Listerine, but Colgate-Palmolive has made up its mind about Toms of Maine.

title: The Bicycle Act, Revisited
description: (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

title: Prince Set to Take Chairmans Crown From Weill
description: Clearing the way for Citigroups long-anticipated changing of the guard, the board has elected Charles Prince to succeed Sandy Weill as chairman.

title: Hot (and Cold) Spots for Retirement
description: What is a great  make that fabulous  place to retire? Inman News (subscription required) discusses the book 50 Fabulous Places to Retire in America, Third Edition. It notes that most places are in the Sunbelt, though three, surprisingly, are in Alaska.

title: X Marks the Spot
description: Not all the news coming out of flood-ravaged New Orleans is dreary.

title: To Every Thing There Is a Season
description: Today Im going to talk about the two things closest to my heart  the Marine Corps Combat Art Collection and my daughter.

title: Interview With Neil Young
description: Jon Pareles, a pop music critic for the Times, talks about the film "Heart of Gold" with Neil Young and Jonathan Demme at the SXSW festival.  (Producer: Craig Duff)

title: Neil Young on SXSW
description: Jon Pareles continues his discussion with Neil Young and Jonathan Demme, with Mr. Young's take on the SXSW music festival and his own work.   (Producer:  Craig Duff)

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (NBC) HEIST -- "This is just like 'Lethal Weapon,' except I actually do hate you," a white policeman tells a black one in the premiere episode of this cops-and-robbers series. But it feels more like "Ocean's 11," as playful, clever, totally professional thieves (including Seymour Cassel; Steve Harris, who was Eugene on "The Practice"; and Dougray Scott, above) set out to hit three Rodeo Drive jewelry stores during Oscar week. First, though, they have to rob a bank.

title: Professor X, 49, Hip-Hop Activist and Member of the Group X-Clan, Is Dead
description: Lumumba Carson, a hip-hop artist known as Professor X and a former member of the black nationalist rap collective X-Clan, died on Friday in Brooklyn. He was 49.

title: Decanting Robert Parker
description: PARKTON, Md. - IT has been a difficult couple of years for Robert M. Parker Jr., the wine writer who has famously been labeled the most influential critic of any kind in the world. Though Mr. Parker has gotten used to living with a big fat target painted on his back, the most recent series of attacks was especially galling to him.

title: Off the Menu
description: LOOKING AHEAD

title: Briefly: Lay knew about losses, ex-Enron official attests
Evacuees' Lives Still Upended Seven Months After Hurricane
description: Nearly seven months after Hurricane Katrina flooded New Orleans and forced out hundreds of thousands of residents, most evacuees say they have not found a permanent place to live, have depleted their savings and consider their life worse than before the hurricane, according to interviews with more than 300 evacuees conducted by The New York Times.

title: The Times Promotes Editor of Magazine
description: The New York Times has promoted Gerald Marzorati, editor of The New York Times Magazine, to the position of assistant managing editor. The appointment was announced by Bill Keller, executive editor.

title: Tokyo bourse plans 62 billion upgrade
Called by God to Help
description: LOS ANGELES - I'VE received a lot of criticism for stating last month that I would instruct the priests of my archdiocese to disobey a proposed law that would subject them, as well as other church and humanitarian workers, to criminal penalties. The proposed Border Protection, Antiterrorism and Illegal Immigration Control bill, which was approved by the House of Representatives in December and is expected to be taken up by the Senate next week, would among other things subject to five years in prison anyone who "assists" an undocumented immigrant "to remain in the United States."

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Customs Officer Convicted Of Bribery
description: A former Customs and Border Protection officer at Port Elizabeth was convicted yesterday of bribery and attempting to conceal an illegal immigrant from detection, said Christopher J. Christie, an United States attorney. The former officer, Hakan Ozcelik, 31, of Astoria, Queens, was charged on Oct. 7, 2005, and was convicted of accepting a $2,300 bribe for himself and another person from a cooperating witness in connection with a scheme to help the witness resolve a visa problem, the prosecutors said. He faces up to 27 months in prison.

title: Censure, Bush and Andrew Jackson (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: At elite French school, real revolutionaries
Russia's Energy Roadshow Is Taken for a Spin in China
description: Correction Appended

title: INSIDE
description: Breast Cancer Gene Test Can Give a False Result The widely used genetic test for breast cancer risk can miss mutations that help cause the disease, a new study says. The test missed the genetic mutations in about 12 percent of breast cancer patients from families with multiple cases of breast or ovarian cancer, the study's authors say. PAGE A20

title: Corrections
description: A note yesterday with an article about international reaction to the presidential election results in Belarus misstated the whereabouts of a contributing reporter, Dan Bilefsky. He was in Brussels, not Minsk.

title: Iraqi Official, Paid by C.I.A., Gave Account of Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 - Saddam Hussein's foreign minister was paid for information he supplied to the Central Intelligence Agency, through the French intelligence agency, that raised questions about the scale of Iraq's weapons programs, former intelligence officials said Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits in Weekend on Friday with a film review of "Find Me Guilty" omitted a producer and misidentified the role of another filmmaker. Bob DeBrino was a producer along with Bob Yari, Robert Greenhut and T. J. Mancini. George (Zakk) Vitezakis was an executive producer, with Oliver Hengst, not a producer.

title: Bouncer Indicted in Killing of John Jay Student
description: A grand jury in Brooklyn formally accused a nightclub bouncer of first-degree murder today in the case of Imette St. Guillen, the 24-year-old graduate student whose death has captivated the city for weeks, court and law enforcement officials said.

title: New Jersey Seeing Red Over Name
description: Delicate egos in New Jersey were wounded when Red Bull bought the MetroStars and immediately added the dreaded words New York to the team's name.

title: Superior Says He Didn't See Agent's Report on Moussaoui
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 21 - The F.B.I.'s top counterterrorism official at the time of the Sept. 11 attacks told a jury on Tuesday that he did not know that a bureau agent had filed a report three weeks earlier detailing his suspicions that Zacarias Moussaoui was involved in an imminent airline hijacking plot.

title: Councilman Considers Challenging Congressman
description: City Councilman Bill de Blasio, a Brooklyn Democrat, is considering challenging Representative Vito J. Fossella, the only Republican in the city Congressional delegation.

title: In Race to Lead Alabama, It's Politics as Unusual
description: ARLEY, Ala., March 18 - Lt. Gov. Lucy Baxley, surrounded by a knot of supporters wearing "We Love Lucy" stickers, was the first to arrive at the 47th annual Arley chitlin supper on Friday, shaking hands in the blustery cold outside the Meek Elementary School gymnasium.

title: Even Before, Recruiting for the Blue Could Be a Hard Sell
description: Wanted: 800 intrepid men and women willing to fight crime in the nation's biggest city. Starting pay is unimpressive, but sick days are unlimited and veterans can retire after 20 years with a pension worth half their salary.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Volvo to Buy Nissan Stake
description: Volvo A.B., Europe's largest truck maker, plans to buy 13 percent of Japan's smallest maker of commercial vehicles from Nissan Motor, in an effort to increase sales in Japan, China and Southeast Asia. Volvo will pay 1.5 billion Swedish kronor ($193 million) cash for 40 million Nissan Diesel Motor shares, becoming its largest investor. Volvo also has a four-year option to buy Nissan's remaining 6 percent stake in Nissan Diesel. The deal enables Nissan, Volvo and Nissan Diesel to cooperate on commercial vehicles with Dongfeng Motor, China's third-largest assembler, and to challenge DaimlerChrysler, which plans to start making trucks in Beijing this year.

title: Tasty Sounds
description: A PARTIAL list of radio stations featuring food programming is available at recipelink.com/tv.html under "radio cooking shows."

title: Longtime A.P. Correspondent Ousted From Job in Vermont
description: The longtime chief correspondent for The Associated Press in Vermont has been forced out of his job, stunning the state's journalists and politicians.

title: French Premier Considers Easing Job Law
description: PARIS, March 21 - Facing crippling strikes and growing civil unrest, Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin of France on Tuesday discussed watering down his contentious new labor law with legislators.

title: For the Love of Yakyu
description: What a game! Daisuke Matsuzaka gave up a leadoff homer to Eduardo Paret, but then retired 12 of 15 batters, easily outpitching Ormari Romero and Vicyohandry Odelin. Michihiro Ogasawara drove in three runs while Kosuke Fukudome, Hitoshi Tamura and Toshiaki Imae drove in two each. Akinori Otsuka struck out Yulieski Gourriel in the ninth to end the game, and the winners threw their caps, gloves and Sadaharu Oh into the air.

title: Family of 6 Survives 2 Weeks of Being Stranded in Snow
description: A family of self-described "wilderness rats" survived more than two weeks in a recreational vehicle that became stuck in the snow covered mountains of southwestern Oregon before being rescued late Tuesday.

title: EU sets tariffs on shoes from China and Vietnam
Standardized Tests Face a Crisis Over Standards
description: NEVER has the nation's education system been so reliant on standardized tests and the companies that make them. Thanks to the federal No Child Left Behind Law, this year, for the first time, every student from third to eighth grade and one high school grade must take state tests. That is about 45 million tests to be graded annually and it does not even include all the standardized tests now required for professional certification, or the SAT, ACT, AP, GRE exams, to name a few.

title: Derek Wan's 'Shadow: Dead Riot' Puts Zombies in Women's Prison
description: A cult classic is born in "Shadow: Dead Riot," and so is a rampaging corpse baby. Written by Michael Gingold and directed by Derek Wan, this berserk little B-movie is obviously the greatest zombie flick ever set in an experimental women's prison, easily the underground treat of the season, and totally off its rocker.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Anthrax Patient May Leave Hospital Soon
description: The condition of Vado Diomande, a drummer who contracted inhalation anthrax last month, has improved enough that hospital officials say he may be discharged in the next few days. Health officials believe that Mr. Diomande, 44, of Greenwich Village, contracted anthrax after working with unprocessed animal skins to make drums. He collapsed on Feb. 16 in Mansfield, Pa. On Monday, he was upgraded from fair to good condition at Robert Packer Hospital in Sayre, Pa.

title: Airlines banned or restricted
Getting Auto Workers to Leave a Golden Job
description: DETROIT, March 21 - The challenge that General Motors, Delphi and the United Automobile Workers have encountered in their talks on early retirement programs reflects the complexity in devising the perfect buyout.

title: No Breach Seen in Work in Iraq on Propaganda
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 - An inquiry has found that an American public relations firm did not violate military policy by paying Iraqi news outlets to print positive articles, military officials said Tuesday. The finding leaves to the Defense Department the decision on whether new rules are needed to govern such activities.

title: How the Study Was Conducted
description: The New York Times study of Hurricane Katrina evacuees was based on interviews with 337 people who left the New Orleans area in the wake of the storm. Interviews were conducted by telephone Feb. 16 to March 3.

title: Germany keeps curbs on workers from East
Pogue's List
description: From today's mailbag:

title: Afghan troops kill suspected Taliban rebels at Pakistan border
Letter From Toronto; A Revitalized Toronto Pins Its Hopes on the Hobbits
description: On a cool afternoon, just eight days before the world premiere of the megamusical "Lord of the Rings," the lobby of Toronto's 2,000-seat Princess of Wales Theater teems with excited young audience members. With opening night slated for March 23, they are here to attend a preview of the production, nearly five years and $23 million in the making. The buzz is palpable. Many have traveled from out of town to see the three-and-a-half-hour show and their hopes are high.

title: Insurgents captured after attack
Paid Notice: Deaths   WIJTVLIET, JOOP
description: WIJTVLIET--Joop, of Vinkeveen, the Netherlands, died unexpected at 64 of a massive heart attack on March 13, 2006, while traveling in the US. He is survived by his wife Susanne, their two children Tina and Peter, brothers Frank, Hans and Paul, sisters Beatrijs and Ine Wijtvliet. We are deeply saddened by our loss. Memorial services will follow at a later date. Contact address in US, 175 East 74th Steet, New York, NY 10021.

title: Abraham Is Happy After Trade to Falcons
description: In a stare down that took days to resolve, John Abraham got his wish yesterday. And so did the Jets.

title: EU places 92 foreign air carriers on blacklist
Flaw Seen in Genetic Test for Breast Cancer Risk
description: The widely used genetic test for breast cancer risk can miss mutations that help cause the disease, according to a new study, a finding that is likely to increase the pressure to develop more thorough testing methods.

title: Arts, Briefly; Julianne Moore to Star in David Hare Broadway Premiere
description: Julianne Moore, left, who had her big break in the cult Chekhovian riff "Vanya on 42d Street" in the early 1990's, is returning to the New York stage in a new play by David Hare, "The Vertical Hour." The production, announced yesterday by the producers Scott Rudin and Robert Fox, will be directed by Sam Mendes (who is also a producer of the play). No theater has been named, but the show is to open on Broadway on Nov. 30 at a Shubert house. The play -- Mr. Hare's first to open on Broadway since "Amy's View" in 1999 -- follows the story of an American academic and former war reporter whose vacation in Wales is seriously disrupted by a contentious older man. A world premiere, "The Vertical Hour" will open directly on Broadway; it is the first play of Mr. Hare's career to have its debut in the United States. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, LEROY
description: BLOCK - Leroy. A man whose greatest creation was himself as a human being. No person who ever met Roy did not benefit from the experience. We love you, miss you, and will never forget you. Willa and Saul Waring

title: Text: ETA's statement
Paid Notice: Deaths   GALLAHOU, MURRAY
description: GALLAHOU--Murray. Loving father of Evan. Caring husband of Phyllis. A world traveler, a dapper dresser and a kind, soft spoken, good hearted man. A dedicated Pharmacist. Services March 22, 11:00 AM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. $(6$)GALLAHOU--Murray. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to his wife Phyllis and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May his memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft President

title: Pet-Human Link Studied in Resistant Bacteria
description: ATLANTA, March 21 - Antibiotic resistance has long been an important human health problem. But now it is also showing up in a small but growing number of pets in this country, Canada and Europe, scientists and federal health officials said on Tuesday at the International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases here.

title: The Doctor Will See You for Exactly Seven Minutes
description: WHEN politicians speak of America's health care needs, they often miss an important point: the doctor-patient relationship has become frayed. Patients aren't unhappy just because health care costs too much (though they would certainly like it to be more affordable). Rather, people sense a malaise within the system that has eroded the respect they feel patients deserve.

title: Dual Duty for Violinist's Bow When a Conductor Is Ailing
description: Evidence of the recent and many misfortunes visited on the conducting world could be had at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night. The London Philharmonic appeared as scheduled in the first of two concerts, but with a different conductor (Roberto Minczuk) and a rejiggered program.

title: Aid Is Focus of Lawsuit by Students
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 - A student organization is suing the United States Education Department over a law that denies federal financial aid to 35,000 students a year because they were convicted of drug offenses while receiving the aid.

title: News Analysis: China and India's big debate on democracy
Timeline: ETA's armed struggle
Paid Notice: Deaths   CASSINI, OLEG
description: CASSINI--Oleg passed March 17, 2006 in Long Island. Born on April 11, 1913 in Paris, France to the Count and Countess Loiewski-Cassini. Oleg Cassini has received countless awards and accolades for his beautiful and romantic collections and for bringing American fashion to the world stage with his work for the First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy, and many glamorous film stars including Kim Bassinger, Grace Kelly (to whom he was engaged), and Gene Tierney (his former wife). He is survived by his loving wife Marianne, president of Oleg Cassini, Inc. (a former fashion model and cover girl), and daughters Daria and Christina, grandchildren Jasmina, Sedric, Alexander, Delphina; nieces Marina, Lee, Conner, Diana, Daniella; nephews Alexander, Nicholas, Demitri, Robbie, Brendan-Oleg, Sean, Robert, James, Michael; and all his beloved animals. Oleg is recognized as a great humanitarian by the Humane Society of the United States and was awarded his own charity C.A.R.E. by the Humane Society. The wake will be held on Wednesday, March 22, 2006 from 5PM to 8PM at the Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NY, NY 10028. A Funeral Mass will be said on Thursday, March 23, 2006 at 11AM, Our Lady of the Sign-Russian Orthodox Church of America, 75 E. 93 St, NY, NY 10028. 212534-1601. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Oleg Cassini C.A.R.E., "Cassini Animal Rescue", The Humane Society of the United States. $(6$)CASSINI--Oleg. Your grace, charm and passion have been an inspiration to all who have had the pleasure and privilege of sharing your world. To your wife, Marianne, and her sister, Peggy, who cared with such love and devotion over these many years, I extend my deepest sympathy. Annette Green $(6$)CASSINI--Oleg. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President

title: Bottom Line Wasn't Always About Money
description: Paul Tagliabue can retire knowing he was the $52 billion man.

title: The End User:Thinking different
Home Fuel Bills Show No Sign of Mild Winter
description: Americans have spent more money heating their homes this winter than in a generation, despite mild weather that has kept down the consumption of heating fuel.

title: Coast Guard Cadet Is Accused of Rape and Other Assaults at Academy
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., March 21 - A senior cadet at the Coast Guard Academy here was accused on Tuesday of raping his former girlfriend after she passed out drunk, and of several other sexual assaults of female classmates that could lead the 130-year-old academy to hold its first court-martial proceeding involving a student.

title: A Coyote Is Spotted Roaming Near the Zoo in Central Park
description: It started on Monday with reports of a strange, wolf-like creature in Central Park. The mystery deepened before dawn yesterday, when it was seen loping across the 65th Street transverse road.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Principal Faces Firing Over Test
description: The Department of Education said yesterday that it would move to fire the former principal of Public School 58 in Carroll Gardens, after an investigation found that she improperly gave students a look at questions on a statewide exam. The investigation found that the principal, Joyce Plush-Saly, had kept copies of a 2005 fifth-grade English field test, which should have been returned to the state, and gave them to students as practice material for this year's test, which was given in January and included some of the same passages. Ms. Plush-Saly was reassigned more than two months ago, pending the investigation. Jim Devor, a P.S. 58 parent who is a member of the District 15 Community Education Council, called the charges "wildly inflated." He said Ms. Plush-Saly was an "outstanding" principal.

title: Shift GIs in Korea to Taiwan? Never, China envoy says
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about New York City's efforts to regulate restaurants' use of the cooking technique known as sous vide, in which food is vacuum-wrapped and slowly heated, referred imprecisely to one form of the technique. Cooked food that is to be refrigerated and later reheated must first be chilled quickly in an ice bath, to inhibit bacterial growth.

title: Researchers Find New Details on Transmission of Avian Flu
description: Two groups of researchers, in Japan and in Holland, have discovered why the avian flu virus is transmitted rarely if ever from one person to another.

title: Israelis Chase Down Van Carrying a Bomb
description: JERUSALEM, March 21 - Acting on an intelligence tip, the Israeli police chased down a van as it raced along a main highway toward Tel Aviv on Tuesday, arrested the 10 Palestinian occupants and seized a 15-pound bomb hidden in a bag.

title: School Workers Seek Amnesty in City Offer
description: At least 132 people who work for the New York City public schools and live outside the city have acknowledged that they improperly send their children to city schools without paying tuition, Department of Education officials said yesterday.

title: Hornets Celebrate a Homecoming Game
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 21 - In that final electric minute, 16,799 fans inside New Orleans Arena stood and cheered.

title: Witness's Lawyer Testifies in Trial of Detectives
description: The witnesses, thus far, at the federal trial of Louis Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa have included a geriatric marijuana dealer, a murderous mob boss, a suntanned C.P.A. and a grieving Brooklyn mother whose son was shot outside her house on Christmas Day.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Westchester: Man Charged With Manslaughter
description: An 18-year-old from Bedford, N.Y., who was involved in two separate car accidents that killed a friend and left another friend seriously injured, was charged yesterday with vehicular manslaughter and 11 other counts, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Toxicology tests showed that the teenager, Ralph Tarchine, had been under the influence of marijuana at the time of the first accident, on Dec. 10, in which his friend Michael Plunkett, 17, was killed, the authorities said. On Jan. 27, Mr. Tarchine was involved in a second accident and the authorities said that he was drunk. Mr. Tarchine faces up to seven years in prison if convicted of vehicular manslaughter, said Lucian Chalfen, a spokesman for the district attorney's office. Mr. Tarchine was released on bail. ANAHAD O'CONNOR (NYT)

title: After 40 Years, Separatists in Spain Declare Cease-Fire
description: SEVILLE, March 22 A The militant Basque separatist group ETA, which has killed more than 800 people and terrorized Spain for nearly 40 years, announced a permanent ceasefire today, saying that it would turn its attention to achieving independence for the Basque region through politics.

title: Black Men on the American Ladder

Politics Is Driving Eviction in Newark, Tenants Say

title: When a Midmajor Is as Good as It Gets
description: THE Ozark foothills roll beneath a surprising oasis of culture and art deco design in a green patch of Oklahoma where the mayor promises 227 days of sunshine will pour over a city saluted as one of "America's Most Livable Communities."

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about plans by the McClatchy Company to sell The San Jose Mercury News and 11 other newspapers that it is acquiring as part of its purchase of Knight Ridder misstated the average operating profit margin at the papers McClatchy is keeping. It is 30.3 percent, McClatchy said, not 12 percent. The article also misstated the number of papers among those being sold whose workers are represented by unions. It is 9, not all 12.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PILMAR, HOWARD
description: PILMAR--Howard. Dear son, it is 10 years since you have been so brutally taken from us. I miss you and pray for justice. Dad

title: Gadgets of the Week: A really big show from a little gizmo
Lightning Rod for Fury Over Schools' Gifted Programs
description: Anna Commitante's office chair at the city Department of Education's headquarters is positioned next to an arched window with a view of yellow daffodils in bloom and Broadway just beyond. Her work space is a cramped cubicle, but this being the Tweed Courthouse -- an ornate gem with landmark status -- it is also rather pleasant.

title: Keeping Sap Flowing, and Pancakes Dripping
description: DARIEN CENTER, N.Y. - Eric Randall's family has produced maple syrup for more than 150 years in the tree-covered hills between Buffalo and Rochester.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about George Mason's run to the Round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament included an outdated reference to the arena where the Washington Regional semifinals and final will be played. It is Verizon Center; its name was changed on March 5 from MCI Center.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Friday about violence in the city of Halabja by Iraqi Kurds who accuse their leaders of corruption misidentified a building that was destroyed. It was a museum dedicated to the memory of people killed there in a poison gas attack by Saddam Hussein's government in 1988, not a shrine. The article also misstated the cause of the fire inside the building. It appeared to have been fed by propane gas released from a canister; it was not started by pouring propane and lighting it.

title: The Sizzle and Pop of Radio Cooking
description: TALMA GUY runs long-haul trucks out of Jacksonville, Fla., with her husband, Roger. To pass the time, they used to listen to political rants on talk radio or music on CD's.

title: Pataki Returns to Albany, and to Bolder Lawmakers
description: ALBANY, March 21 - After a sick leave of more than a month, Gov. George E. Pataki returned to Albany on Tuesday to reassert himself on budget negotiations and attempt to rein in the election-year spending plans of the increasingly restive Legislature.

title: No Blue Chips, Just Blue Collars
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 20 - When Craig Smith was a 16-year-old high school senior in Los Angeles, his mother drove him to the airport for the flight east on his recruiting visit to Boston College.

title: News Analysis: Merkel faces challenges at home
A Modern Gloss on 'Fidelio' at the Metropolitan Opera
description: Earlier this month, when James Levine announced that he had to withdraw from the rest of this season at the Metropolitan Opera because of a serious shoulder injury, Joseph Volpe, the company's intrepid general manager, hit the phones to line up replacements. Somehow he did it. He found suitable conductors to take over all 25 performances that Mr. Levine was scheduled to conduct at the house through May.

title: Security Council Is Stalled Over Iran's Nuclear Program
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 21 - After nearly two weeks of haggling, a deadlocked Security Council put off full consideration of Iran's nuclear program on Tuesday, amid indications that Iran was close to taking a major step in its efforts to enrich uranium.

title: Rutgers Goes From Tired-Looking to Tireless, With Tennessee Up Next
description: TRENTON, March 21 - Awakening from a slumber that had threatened to cause a premature end to its bid for the N.C.A.A. women's basketball championship, Rutgers finally put in a 40-minute performance Tuesday night befitting a top 10 team. The Scarlet Knights shot well, rebounded with passion, played outstanding defense and dominated an opponent that was overmatched.

title: Flaw Seen in Genetic Test for Breast Cancer Risk
description: The widely used genetic test for breast cancer risk can miss mutations that help cause the disease, according to a new study, a finding that is likely to increase the pressure to develop more thorough testing methods.

title: Chertoff Seeks a Chemical Security Law, Within Limits
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 - The nation must move rapidly to bolster protection of its chemical plants against a terrorist attack, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said Tuesday, urging Congress to adopt regulations that the industry has already largely endorsed.

title: Avoiding conflict over fuel
China and Russia pledge energy cooperation
Utilities and Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Arranged by Guidant May Aid Lawsuits and Critics
description: The Guidant Corporation may have gotten more than it bargained for when it appointed a panel last year to look into its practices after it came under scrutiny for its failure to publicize flaws in its heart devices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUNROE, MILDRED WARNER
description: MUNROE--Mildred Warner. Died March 17, 2006 gently among her closest family. Beloved mother and teacher. Survived by her children, grandchildren, sisters and others. Share thoughts at friendsofmillie.blogspot.com

title: Letter from Shanghai: Behind the U.S. decline of influence in China
It's blackjack, betting and, yes, Barry Manilow
Keen Company Stages a Love Story Beyond Words
description: The Keen Company, a six-year-old group with a reputation for serious, convincingly performed drama, does not indulge in the fashionable glibness or ironic detachment of many small theater outfits. In fact, its mission statement sounds like the earnest sweet nothings of the dream boyfriend from a chick-lit novel. "We are not afraid of emotional candor, vulnerability or optimism," it announces, and as promised, all three are prominently on display in its revival of "Children of a Lesser God."

title: The Manhattan of Beasts
description: WORD had come from the other side of the East River by police-radio crackle: They're in. Now, in the midnight freeze, a welcoming party of the enchanted and the less so stared into the Manhattan maw of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, waiting for the improbable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, ASHER W.
description: SCHWARTZ--Asher W. The Law Firm of O'Donnell, Schwartz, Glanstein & Lilly LLP notes with sorrow the death of its founding partner, Asher W. Schwartz. A graduate of Williams College and Harvard Law School where his personal papers were donated in 2001, he was a leading labor lawyer who founded our firm in 1948 and remained active in the practice of law until his retirement in 2001. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. $(6$)SCHWARTZ -- Asher. The Flight Engineers of American Airlines mourn his passing. We are eternally grateful for his over 35 years of dedication to our chapter. Our condolences to his family.

title: Recipe: Maple-Glazed Meatloaf
description: From the "Jimtown Store Cookbook," by Carrie Brown, John Werner and Michael McLaughlin (HarperCollins, 2002)Time: About 2 hours

title: In Astoria, a Grill for Neighborhood Folks
description: WE all have places that fill the inglorious role of providing a meal when you're on the way home, or in a hurry to get somewhere else, or otherwise unwilling to trek for sustenance.

title: U.S. senators try to sell Beijing on floating the yuan
Cheap eats go far (but not that far)
Corzine Proposes Tax Increases and Spending Cuts to Close Budget Gap

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Its Income Slipping, Jones Apparel Will Explore Possibility of a Sale Jones Apparel Group announced that it had retained Goldman, Sachs to explore a sale, a development with implications for Seventh Avenue designers and the dozens of retailers that stock its clothing. Despite assembling an impressive collection of midprice brands, industry executives and analysts say that Jones Apparel has stumbled in its efforts to satisfy its investors' demand for growth. Market Place. [Page C1.]

title: Fruit Gets Dressed Up as Caviar
description: FIRST it was carpaccio, which went from beef to beets, and now it's caviar. Considering the cachet (and rarity) of caviar, it's not surprising that some chefs would borrow the word for their own creations and call it dessert.

title: White House lobbies over India nuclear pact
Legal wrangles keep DuPont under fire
Briefly: Palestinians display internal tensions
EU announces blacklist of unsafe airlines
In a Shift, New York Says It Will Add 800 Officers
description: The New York Police Department, the largest in the nation, will add 800 police officers to its force of roughly 37,000 in its largest city-financed expansion since 1993, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: A Revitalized Toronto Pins Its Hopes on the Hobbits
description: On a cool afternoon, just eight days before the world premiere of the megamusical "Lord of the Rings," the lobby of Toronto's 2,000-seat Princess of Wales Theater teems with excited young audience members. With opening night slated for March 23, they are here to attend a preview of the production, nearly five years and $23 million in the making. The buzz is palpable. Many have traveled from out of town to see the three-and-a-half-hour show and their hopes are high.

title: A New Grip on 'Reality'
description: One of the most important laws of political debate is this: To name something is to own it. If you can name something, get that name to stick and therefore define how people think about an issue, your opponents don't stand a chance. One of the most pernicious things that Vice President Dick Cheney and Big Oil have done for years is to define "realism" when it comes to U.S. energy policy -- and therefore they have owned the debate.

description: Breaking News on Flavor Flav

title: Basque separatists declare permanent cease-fire
Iraq Veteran Wins Democratic Primary in House Race in Illinois
description: L. Tammy Duckworth, a retired Army major who lost both her legs in Iraq two years ago, squeaked by to win the Democratic primary in a Congressional race in suburban Chicago, setting up what will be a closely watched race to replace the Republican incumbent, Henry Hyde, who is retiring after 32 years.

title: Big Three to the Fore When the Nets Need It Most
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 - The Nets' three stars -- Jason Kidd, Richard Jefferson and Vince Carter -- outscored the Wizards' big three -- Gilbert Arenas, Caron Butler and Antawn Jamison -- by only 3 points Tuesday night. But it was the good timing of the Nets' big three that made the difference.

title: Stuttgart region's vigor is backdrop for election
First Stadiums, Now Teams Take a Corporate Identity
description: SPORTS fans have long been accustomed to stadiums and arenas taking on corporate brand names. Consider Busch Stadium, where the St. Louis Cardinals play, the Washington Redskins's FedEx Field and, of course, the home of the Houston Astros, known briefly as Enron Field.

title: China wins assurance on pipeline
Paid Notice: Deaths   KRONENBERG, JACK
description: KRONENBERG - Jack. Passed away peacefully on Friday, March 17, 2006 at age 87. Husband for 51 years to the late Evelyn; father of Scott Kronenberg (Cecilia) of Exeter, CA and Noah Kronenberg of North Bergan, NJ; grandfather of Hilary, Louis, Sara and Jeremy; brother of Betty Balsam (Barret) of Pembroke Pines, FL. A native of New York. A graduate from Boys High School and Brooklyn College class of 1939. He was involved in men's clothing manufacturing for 40 years. Funeral Services were held in Santa Rosa, California. Donations may be made to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society.

title: Lars Vogt Finds an Equilibrium in Disparate Piano Works
description: The German pianist Lars Vogt was in New York just a few weeks ago to accompany the violinist Christian Tetzlaff in an illuminating Brahms recital, and on Monday evening he returned to play a recital on his own at Zankel Hall. The music was by Mozart, Beethoven and Tatyana Komarova, a Russian composer who is also his wife -- three composers whose works cover many stylistic miles. Mr. Vogt accounted for their distinctive accents, yet there was a consistent interpretive quality that seemed to link them. Mainly, it was a sense of perfect equilibrium, a balance of lines that sounded simple and natural, but could only have been the result of thoughtful calibration.

title: Iraqi Insurgents Attack Jail, Killing 18 and Freeing Prisoners
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 21 - More than 200 masked insurgents stormed an Interior Ministry jail at daybreak on Tuesday, killing at least 18 police officers, freeing all the prisoners and leaving the facility a smoldering wreck.

title: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sale $33 million

title: Four Are Arraigned on Day-Trading Fraud Charges
description: Four executives at the day-trading firm of A. B. Watley were arraigned in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday on conspiracy and securities fraud charges stemming from a scheme to reap profits after eavesdropping on confidential conversations between stockbrokers and their clients.

title: Microsoft to Delay Next Version of Windows
description: Microsoft's long effort to deliver the next version of its Windows operating system suffered another setback yesterday when the company said that the system would not be ready for consumer personal computers for the holiday sales season.

title: Where Have All the Supermarkets Gone?
description: Once you could find them every few blocks or so in prime neighborhoods of Manhattan, but these days the local chain supermarket seems to be heading the way of the five-and-dime. Among the latest casualties is a D'Agostino market on University Place near Union Square, which is closing after two decades in that location.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about detainee abuse by a Special Operations unit in Iraq, Task Force 6-26, misstated the given name of the Defense Intelligence Agency's former director for human intelligence, who said he had not heard reports of abuse until he was briefed in June 2004. He is Maj. Gen. Michael E. Ennis, not George.

title: In Back-and-Forth Game, St. John's Is Left Behind
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 21 - Momentum, that slippery, elusive intangible, kept sliding out of the grasp of St. John's and Maryland on Tuesday night.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Looking for Third Receiver, Giants Meet With Johnson
description: Keyshawn Johnson is no longer the brashest receiver in the N.F.L., nor the most heralded.

title: Drug Makers Reach Accord in Patent Case Over Plavix
description: Sanofi-Aventis and its partner Bristol-Myers Squibb said late yesterday that they had tentatively settled a patent dispute involving Plavix, the anticlotting agent that is the world's second-best-selling drug.

title: Abbott President to Leave
description: The president and chief operating officer for pharmaceuticals at Abbott Laboratories, Jeffrey M. Leiden, will step down this month, the company announced yesterday.

title: Bush Says 'It's Time' for Unity Government in Iraq
description: President Bush continued his speaking tour today in support of his policies in Iraq, saying that he told American officials in Iraq that "it's time" for the political parties there to put aside their differences and form a government of national unity.

title: Shares Slump as Investors Worry Rates Will Keep Rising
description: Stocks slumped for a second consecutive day yesterday as a speech by the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, and a report on producer prices suggested that interest rates would keep rising this year.

title: INSIDE PITCH
description: Billy Wagner, the Mets' closer, said irritation in the tendon sheath in his left middle finger, from an injury last Thursday, would prevent him from pitching until this weekend at the earliest. Results from a magnetic resonance imaging examination Monday came back negative. (BEN SHPIGEL NYT)

title: Cricket: England draws comfort
Excerpts From the President's News Conference on the Iraq War and Iran
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference yesterday at the White House, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. A transcript is at nytimes.com/politics.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about the family of Xavier Nady, who is a contender for the Mets' right-field job, misstated the birthplace of the Hall of Famer Nap Lajoie. It was Rhode Island, not France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEUTEL, BILL
description: BEUTEL--Bill. The Board and Administration of Southampton Hospital and the Southampton Hospital Foundation mourn the loss of Bill Beutel, whose warmth, talent and friendship embraced our cause. A loyal friend, he shall be dearly missed. We offer our deepest sympathy to his wife, Adair, a much-admired former member of our Board, and to his family.

title: Standardized Tests Face a Crisis Over Standards
description: NEVER has the nation's education system been so reliant on standardized tests and the companies that make them. Thanks to the federal No Child Left Behind Law, this year, for the first time, every student from third to eighth grade and one high school grade must take state tests. That is about 45 million tests to be graded annually and it does not even include all the standardized tests now required for professional certification, or the SAT, ACT, AP, GRE exams, to name a few.

title: Skyscraper in Dubai halted by labor strife
Arts, Briefly; The Hot Seat Beckons Couch Potatoes
description: Four months later, the "Prison Break" gang is still stuck in the clink. In Monday's episode, the first since the Fox series went on hiatus, Lincoln (Dominic Purcell) was denied clemency, and the hour ended with him facing the electric chair. An estimated audience of 10.27 million welcomed this snail-paced frustration back into their lives, as "Prison Break" placed second among adults 18 to 49 in the 8 p.m. hour to NBC's "Deal or No Deal" (16.6 million). Over all, Fox placed second to CBS for the night. Its "24" delivered 13.64 million, and a win at 9 p.m. in the 18-to-49 demographic. Opposite the second half of "24," CBS's "New Adventures of Old Christine" (15.3 million) had a strong second week, giving the network its best ratings in the 9:30 p.m. time period this season. CBS's victory was solidified by "CSI: Miami" at 10 p.m. Its 19.52 million viewers buried NBC's "Medium" rerun (7.51 million) and ABC's sinking "Miracle Workers" (7.3 million). KATE AURTHUR

title: Take a seat and take your lumps, America
Medicare Backs Heart Device Screening
description: The Medicare program agreed yesterday to pay for a $400 test from Cambridge Heart to screen out heart patients who are not likely to benefit from an implanted defibrillator.

title: The Museum of Arts and Design Prepares for Its New Home
description: Arriving on her first day as director of the Museum of Arts and Design 10 years ago, Holly Hotchner was greeted by an eviction notice, a bookkeeper who said the museum could not make payroll and a rat scurrying across the floor of her sub-basement office. She had inherited an institution, then called the American Craft Museum, that was struggling with an operating deficit, virtually no endowment and stagnant attendance and membership. In fact, few people seemed to have heard of it.

title: Fly Into a Building? Who Could Imagine?
description: WASHINGTON - Three little words:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State Buys 1,000 Acres Of Woodlands
description: New York State is acquiring 1,000 acres of pristine woodlands -- home to loons, bald eagles and other wildlife -- in the northwest Adirondacks, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday. As part of the deal, 800 adjacent acres in the area of the Bog and Beaver Rivers will remain in the hands of its owner, the Sabattis Land Company, but will be protected by a conservation easement to prevent it from being developed. The Nature Conservancy and the Adirondack Land Trust brokered the $1.5 million deal on the state's behalf.

title: China to Raise Taxes on Gas Guzzlers and Chopsticks
description: HONG KONG, March 22 A The Chinese government will increase existing taxes and impose new ones on April 1 for everything from gas-guzzling vehicles to chopsticks so as to improve the country's environmental record, conserve energy and narrow China's wide gap between rich and poor, the official New China News Agency said Wednesday.

title: Rice Moves To Repair Ties With Alliance In Caribbean
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, March 21 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice arrived here on Tuesday evening on a mission to repair relations with another part of the world angry over the war in Iraq, and even angrier over the American role in Haiti.

title: Hold the Sour Cream: Herring Return to the Bronx River After 350 Years
description: To people of certain generations who grew up in the Bronx, a herring was something that came from a jar, a barrel or a deli counter, smothered either in sour cream or heavy oil. But it was definitely not something that wriggled in borough waters.

title: Never Mind the Sea Serpent, Where's My Salmon?
description: THE doorbell rang at 8:50 a.m. a couple of weeks ago. FedEx was at the door with an eagerly anticipated package from St. Johnsbury, Vt. The elusive, long-sought prize, a two-pound wild landlocked salmon nestled in a bed of ice, had been caught two days before.

title: UK court rules Muslim girl cannot wear Muslim robes
Seminary Students
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 32 Charged In Court Bomb Plot
description: A judge charged 32 suspected members of an Islamic terrorist cell with planning to pack more than 1,000 pounds of explosives into a truck and drive it into the National Court in Madrid, where nearly 1,000 people work, including judges and prosecutors who handle terrorism cases. The suspects, mostly Moroccans and Algerians who were arrested in the fall of 2004, had not yet obtained any explosives, but they had "expressed their intention to become martyrs for Islam" and presented a threat, said the judge, Fernando Grande-Marlaska of the National Court. "The development of the criminal act," he wrote, "begins when the ideological structuring of these groups begins." It was unclear when a trial would begin. RENWICK McLEAN (NYT)

title: Black Men on the American Ladder
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Bars His Appointees From Raising Funds
description: ALBANY, March 21 - Gov. George E. Pataki instituted a policy on Tuesday barring his appointees and commissioners from raising political donations and rebuked his hand-picked insurance superintendent, Howard D. Mills, for raising $15,000 last year.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,311 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Michael R. Gordon Answers Readers' Questions
description: Michael R. Gordon is the chief military correspondent for The New York Times. These questions are in response to articles adapted from his book, "Cobra II: The Inside Story of the Invasion and Occupation of Iraq," written with Bernard E. Trainor, a retired Marine lieutenant general and a former military correspondent for the newspaper.

title: The Quest
description: "I support the war," says James Brower, a 24-year-old corporal in the Marine Corps. "I am a marine. You can't claim the title without doing the duty." Corporal Brower served 7 months and 28 days in Afghanistan, became a New York City police officer and was recently reactivated. He leaves for Iraq today.

title: Trial Begins in Britain for 7 Accused of Roles in Qaeda Bomb Plot
description: LONDON, March 21 - In what has been billed by the police as a major terrorism trial, seven Britons appeared at the Old Bailey courthouse on Tuesday, accused of training in Pakistan to carry out bomb attacks in Britain more than one year before the London attacks in 2005.

title: A Match Made in Australia
description: YOU have to hand it to the Australians. By virtue of their geographical isolation, they were liberated from the ironclad wine rules of the Old World. Unlike the Americans, who have largely operated within the confines of European winemaking custom and tradition (though you can't always tell that from what's in the bottle), the Australians have freely tossed aside convention.

title: Army Dog Handler Is Convicted in Detainee Abuse at Abu Ghraib
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 - An Army dog handler was found guilty Tuesday of tormenting detainees at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq with his snarling Belgian shepherd for his own amusement.

title: Trial of 2 Ex-Detectives Veers From Murders to Movie Script
description: Roaring west again, the Brooklyn trial of two detectives charged with being hit men for the mob descended yesterday into the desert underworld as a bronzed and beefy government witness told the jury how he moved through Las Vegas, secretly recording mobsters at a community center for the elderly and acting as the house accountant for exotic dancers at a strip club called the Crazy Horse Too.

title: A Match Made in Australia
description: YOU have to hand it to the Australians. By virtue of their geographical isolation, they were liberated from the ironclad wine rules of the Old World. Unlike the Americans, who have largely operated within the confines of European winemaking custom and tradition (though you can't always tell that from what's in the bottle), the Australians have freely tossed aside convention.

title: Jones Looks at Selling Company
description: The Jones Apparel Group, the $5 billion clothing company, has been on a shopping spree over the last four years, acquiring two large apparel makers, Gloria Vanderbilt and Kasper, and the luxury retailer Barneys New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORENSTEIN, LARRY NEILL
description: ORENSTEIN--Larry Neill. (age 87). Musician, composer, advertising executive. Born August 30, 1918; died February 22, 2006 of complications from pneumonia. A memorial will be held at the Jazz Bakery in Culver City, California on Saturday, March 25 at 1 P.M. Please call (510) 910-2544 for further details or condolences.

title: 'TV Land Awards': Honoring Nostalgia and Classic Television
description: There are no snarky blogs and the mood on the red carpet is breezy. For those who like their awards programs drenched in warmth with a huge dollop of nostalgia, the annual "TV Land Awards: A Celebration of Classic TV" will be broadcast tonight. Each year, the program, which will be simulcast on TV Land and Nickelodeon's Nick at Nite, has attracted a longer roster of high-profile television stars.

title: Black Men on the American Ladder
description: To the Editor:

title: Lobbyist Reform as a Shell Game
description: The political gods had to guffaw when Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania was designated by the Republicans to be their headlined champion in the current reform effort to rein in lobbying abuses. In truth, Mr. Santorum had long been the G.O.P.'s eager point man in courting the lobbyists of K Street. But in January, as the Jack Abramoff scandal nipped at Congress, Senator Santorum swore off further inner-sanctum sessions with lobbyists, just in time for his tight re-election fight.

title: Big Fish in a Big Pond
description: AT the sushi bar, not far from our table, a handsome man takes a seat beside two attractive women, who expertly pivot in his direction, as if practiced at this kind of maneuver. He talks a lot. They laugh a lot. As the night moves along, both women hand him their cards. Their friendship had better be strong. It may soon face an awkward test.

description: WASHINGTON, March 21 - President Bush said Tuesday that the war in Iraq was eroding his political capital, his starkest admission yet about the costs of the conflict to his presidency, and suggested that American forces would remain in the country until at least 2009.

description: DORTMUND, Germany, March 21 - The Americans must impress only their manager, while their counterparts must appease a jittery nation when the United States and Germany meet here in a soccer friendly Wednesday night.

description: "Heist," an NBC series about a gang of stylish, high-stakes thieves, is set in Los Angeles, which makes sense, since there are a lot of stylish jewelry stores in Beverly Hills.

description: BLANK--Irwin M. Temple Sinai of Bergen County notes with sorrow the passing of our first fulltime Rabbi, who built our congregation during his 17 years here. A beloved Rabbi, distinguished communal leader and noted psychotherapist. May his dear ones be comforted and his memory be for a blessing. Dr. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi George Bean and Janene Edlin, Presidents

title: Moussaoui trial hears of brushoff by air agency
A Little Lesson the Yankees Should Heed
description: Tampa, Fla. - WITH the exception of a lanky frame that stretches to 6 feet 5 inches, Aaron Small fits his surname perfectly in the context of his professional standing. By the measure of the Yankees, he has a contract that is undersized, an ego that is not inflated, and expectations for him are not engorged.

title: Knicks Fall; Worse Yet, So Does an Injured Frye
description: Their present in tatters, the Knicks watched their future tumble into a heap last night. So it seems the season can, in fact, get worse.
