Executive at Siemens to quit early
The Museum of Arts and Design Prepares for Its New Home
description: Arriving on her first day as director of the Museum of Arts and Design 10 years ago, Holly Hotchner was greeted by an eviction notice, a bookkeeper who said the museum could not make payroll and a rat scurrying across the floor of her sub-basement office. She had inherited an institution, then called the American Craft Museum, that was struggling with an operating deficit, virtually no endowment and stagnant attendance and membership. In fact, few people seemed to have heard of it.

title: Free Flow: Clearer skies for safety in Asia-Pacific
For a Reasonably Priced Red, a Budget Cut of Beef. Keep the Change.
description: STARTING with a wine, then finding a complementary dish is counterintuitive. Usually you select the food, then the wine. As we tasted the juicy, fruit-forward, fairly one-dimensional shiraz-cabernet sauvignon blends from Australia, I asked myself, What would I order in a restaurant or prepare at home that would inspire me to choose one of these wines? Red meat was the simple answer.

title: New Scrutiny for Law on Detaining Witnesses
description: A 22-year-old federal law that allows people to be held without charges if they have information about others' crimes is coming under fresh scrutiny in the courts, in Congress and within the Justice Department after reports that it has been abused in terrorism investigations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Starts Effort Against Litter
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the sanitation commissioner, John J. Doherty, have announced a series of anti-litter advertisements for television, newspapers and magazines. The public-awareness campaign, announced yesterday, called "Stomp Out Litter," is an effort involving the Sanitation Department; Stomp, a theater troupe that mixes percussion, dance and comedy; Waste Management, which has contracts with the city to export trash to out-of-state landfills; and other groups. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: Cheap, Simple And Glorious
description: ONE of the great paradoxes of the modern supermarket is that the best cuts of meat are sometimes the cheapest. This is especially true of pork: the ultralean, tasteless tenderloin often costs four times as much as the nicely marbled and forgiving shoulder.

title: Jude Narita in 'Walk the Mountain,' on the Vietnam War's Effects
description: In dramatizing unspeakably horrific events, must an artist end up brutalizing her audience as well? Jude Narita's one-woman show "Walk the Mountain," about the hellish effects of the Vietnam War, reminds us that it's possible for a performer to treat both her material and her audience with respect.

title: Making Space for a Biotech Center
description: SKOKIE, Ill. - The acquisition and subsequent redevelopment of a former Pfizer pharmaceutical research facility here by Forest City, the Cleveland-based developer, promises to quadruple the amount of speculative office space available for biotechnology companies in the Chicago area.

title: Lawyers for Jailed Aide for The Times Press China for His Release
description: BEIJING, March 21 - Lawyers for a jailed Chinese researcher for The New York Times asked prosecutors this week to release him immediately in order to comply with a surprise court decision that withdrew the case against him.

title: Theodora Skipitares Brings Trojan War With Puppets to La MaMa
description: How is one to recreate the experience of Greek tragedy for the contemporary audience? The plays were performed in outdoor arenas for multitudes, there was little scenery, the actors wore large masks, declaiming their lines as a chorus cautioned, judged and commented. Splendor and scale helped inspire what the ancients called pity and terror: compassion for human endurance and awe at the ruthlessness of the powers that force us to suffer and change.

title: P.L.O. Rejects Platform Proposed by Hamas
description: JERUSALEM, March 22 A The Palestine Liberation Organization rejected today the proposed platform of the radical Islamic group Hamas, a development reflecting the internal Palestinian political tensions as Hamas prepares to assume power.

title: Study Says U.S. Companies Lag on Global Warming
description: European and Asian companies are paying more attention to global warming than their American counterparts. And chemical companies are more focused on the issue than oil companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about plans by the McClatchy Company to sell The San Jose Mercury News and 11 other newspapers that it is acquiring as part of its purchase of Knight Ridder misstated the average operating profit margin at the papers McClatchy is keeping. It is 30.3 percent, McClatchy said, not 12 percent. The article also misstated the number of papers among those being sold whose workers are represented by unions. It is 9, not all 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLZANI, ANSELMO
description: COLZANI--Anselmo. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the death of the distinguished baritone Anselmo Colzani, who sang nearly 300 performances of 18 roles at the Met between 1960 and 1978. He excelled in the Italian repertory, and shares the Met record for most performance as Jack Rance in "La Fanciulla del West" with the role's creator, Pasquale Amato, and was also heard in the title role of "Falstaff" in the premiere of the Zeffirelli production. He will be greatly missed and we extend our sincerest sympathy to his family. Joseph Volpe, Gen. Mgr. James Levine, Music Dir.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a Suffolk County Court judge's ruling to uphold the conviction of Martin H. Tankleff in his parents' murder in 1988 misspelled the name of the law school where a critic of the ruling, Barry Scheck, helped establish the Innocence Project, a legal clinic that works to exonerate inmates who claim they were wrongfully convicted. It is the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, not Carodozo.

title: Europe Declares Pipe Organs Health Hazards
description: LONDON, March 21 - There were bananas whose curvature could not be excessive, and rhubarb whose stalks must be straight, and they all belonged in the category of myths about the intrusiveness of European Union directives to its member states.

title: The dangers of grapefruit juice

New Directors/New Films: A World Tour of Cinema for Adults
description: Now in its 35th year, the pocket-size New Directors/New Films festival serves New York cinephiles looking to take a trip around the cinema world -- from Iceland to India and Ireland -- in 12 days. This year's selection, which gets off to a strong start tonight with Ryan Fleck's drama "Half Nelson," allows you to catch sneak previews (about half of the features have distribution) and discover more rarefied works that may never make it to a theater near you -- like the mesmerizing 162-minute German documentary "Into Great Silence," about Carthusian monks living in enveloping quiet in the French Alps, which shows next week.

title: Cycling: Narcoleptic won't rest until he races

Corrections
description: The Joe Nocera column in Business Day on Saturday, about an alternative method of taking companies public, referred incompletely to the lead underwriters for Google, which used an auction for its initial offering. Credit Suisse had the role, along with Morgan Stanley.

title: Spanish Court Acts to Suspend Hostile Bid for Electric Utility
description: A Spanish court ruled yesterday that Gas Natural's hostile bid to acquire the power utility Endesa should be suspended, saying it might have involved collusion with another Spanish company in violation of European Union regulations.

description: SYRACUSE, March 21 - Days after he compared upstate New York's sputtering economy to Appalachia's, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, a Democratic candidate for governor, spoke on Tuesday of his plans to revitalize upstate cities by revamping downtown areas and creating statewide programs for residential developments.

title: Anthrax Patient Tells Reporters He Will Dance Again

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMSON, JAMES GEIGER
description: WILLIAMSON--James Geiger. Of Pt. Pleasant Beach, New Jersey was a former resident of Short HIlls, New Jersey. He was born in Palm Beach, Florida. He graduated from McCauley High School in Chattanooga, Tennessee and the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, Virginia. Mr. Williamson was married to Sheila Campbell Williamson. He is survived by his two daughters, Anne Holman of Short Hills and Christina Donnelly of Jersey City, and a granddaughter, Campbell Holman. He retired as a Portfolio Manager from Shearson Asset Management. He was a member of the Short Hills Club, Manasquan River Golf Club and the Bay Head Yacht Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Williamson Family Fund of the Community Foundation of New Jersey, P.O. Box 338, Morristown, NJ 07963-0338. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 25, 2006 at 1:30 P.M. at Community Congregational Church, 200 Hartshorn Dr., Short Hills, New Jersey. To send condolences and for further information, visit bradleyfuneralhomes.com

description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., March 21 - The Rev. Donald MacMillan, unassuming priest, is now a cult Internet celebrity among the college set.

title: A Rare Takeover Attempt in Germany's Drug Industry
description: BERLIN, March 21 - Hubertus Erlen would rather talk about birth-control pills than poison pills. His company, Schering of Germany, is the world's largest maker of oral contraceptives, and it just won regulatory approval in the United States to market a new, lower-dose pill.

title: Crime problems dog Bulgaria as it courts EU
Evacuees' Lives Still Upended Seven Months After Hurricane
description: Nearly seven months after Hurricane Katrina flooded New Orleans and forced out hundreds of thousands of residents, most evacuees say they have not found a permanent place to live, have depleted their savings and consider their life worse than before the hurricane, according to interviews with more than 300 evacuees conducted by The New York Times.

description: James O. Freedman, a former president of Dartmouth College and the University of Iowa and a forceful voice against anti-Semitism and other forms of intolerance on college campuses, died yesterday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 70.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WERNE, IRENE GARROW, M.D.
description: WERNE--Irene Garrow, M.D. A retired pathologist and dedicated peace activist, died in her own home of natural causes at age 91 on March 17, 2006. She was the beloved wife of the late Dr. Jacob Werne and is survived by a sister, Ms. Eleanore Nyilas, her two daughters, Dr. Joellen Werne and Naomi Werne, Esq. (retired), and a son, Dr. Carl Werne, as well as four grandchildren, Joanna and Emily Werne and Laura and Jacob Smolowe.

title: A 3rd Rise in Core Wholesale Prices Spurs Concern Over Inflation
description: Prices at the wholesale level dropped unexpectedly in February, the Labor Department reported yesterday, but excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, the cost of goods increased, highlighting the potential for higher inflation later in the year.

description: ATLANTA, March 21  Antibiotic resistance has long been an important human health problem. But now it is also showing up in a small but growing number of pets in this country, Canada and Europe, scientists and federal health officials said on Tuesday at the International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLUSMAN, SIDNEY
description: GLUSMAN--Sidney. January 31, 1912--March 20, 2006. Beloved brother of Estelle. Devoted uncle of Steven, Joan, and John. Teacher, artist, benefactor. Services at "The Riverside", 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue, 11 A.M. Friday, March 24, 2006.

description: Knock-offs of "The Da Vinci Code," made-up memoirs and accounts of life with ornery pets are selling tens of thousands of hardcover copies a week. But publishers say there is no harder sell in the world of books these days than literary fiction.

description: LONDON, March 21 - The Archbishop of Canterbury opposes teaching creationism in school and believes that portraying the Bible as just another theory devalues it, he said in a newspaper interview published Tuesday.

description: Insurgents attacked a jail northeast of Baghdad, killing at least 18 police officers and freeing more than 30 prisoners. Page A12.

title: Elusive Coyote Is Captured in Central Park
description: A coyote roaming through Central Park today got a taste of what it's like to lead the police on a chase in New York City, where the tabloid media and countless other reporters and photographers will chase anything that gives chase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENHECK, VIOLA D.
description: ROSENHECK--Viola D. The Board of Directors and staff of The Riverdale Mental Health Association expresses its deepest sorrow to the family of V.D. Rosenheck. We share your loss of this wonderful, courageous woman, a longtime friend and 20 year member of our board. We will miss her valuable contribution to our agency and community. Sandra E. Lerner, Pres. Joyce M. Pilsner, Exec Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEURMAN, ANNE
description: FEURMAN--Anne. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Anne Feurman, beloved mother of Fran Szczesny, whose leadership and generosity deeply impacts millions of lives in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. We extend our deepest sympathies to Fran and her entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEICH, SEYMOUR J.
description: TEICH--Seymour J., 94. Of West End, NJ and Lake Worth, FL. Beloved husband and best friend of Lynne, father of Barbara Vali and the late Liz Missette, stepfather to Jan and Mark Ferguson, Joanne Nachmani and Anthony Amato. Pop Pop to Megan and Kevin Missette, Haley, Tia and Kellen Ferguson, Jackie Pacius and Alana & Jenna Nachmani, great grandfather to Taran & Declan Greenwald and Holly & Timmy Pacius. He was a Sr. VP with Macy's and Bamberger's for 35 years and then in the merger & acquisitions business at its beginning. His generosity and love of family and bridge was unquenchable. He was a man of great character, charm, a fantastic storyteller and truly unforgettable. Chapel services are at 10:00 AM Thursday, March 23 at Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels. Any contributions should be sent to the Leukemia Society.

title: Ecuador's President Declares a State of Emergency
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 22 APresident Alfredo Palacio of Ecuador declared a state of emergency late Tuesday as growing antiglobalization protests by thousands of Indians threatened to paralyze Latin America's fifth-largest oil producing country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEY, MORTIMER
description: COLEY - Mortimer, 97. Peacefully at his home in Bronxville, on March 19, 2006. Loving husband of Esther Gussaroff Coley. Father of Dorothy Coley. Grandfather of Lara Antonucci, great grandfather of four. He will be sorely missed by all. Graveside service at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings, on Thursday, March 23 at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUSTIEN, IRIS M.
description: BRUSTIEN--Iris M. On March 20. Beloved wife of Harold. Loving and devoted mother of Steven and Susan and their spouses Mary and Peter. Treasured grandmother of Matthew. Cherished sister of Libby and Jimmy and the late Helen and Roland. Exceptional sister-in-law to Rose. Adored aunt and greataunt. Her loving strength and devotion nourished us all. The world will not be the same without her. Services Wednesday, 11 AM, at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations may be made in her memory to the charity closest to your heart. $(6$)BRUSTIEN -- Iris. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our long time member Iris Brustien. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: A Dictator's 'Re-election'
description: As anybody who observed politics in the old Soviet Union knows, sending voters to the polls does not guarantee a real election. Democracy is about choice, not marching off to reaffirm the status quo. That's why Sunday brought the dismal news that Aleksandr Lukashenko, often called Europe's last dictator, had declared himself "re-elected" as president of Belarus with almost 83 percent of the vote.

Arrests Hold Down Protests on Belarus Vote
description: MINSK, Belarus, March 21 - The authorities arrested dozens of protesters on Tuesday, including prominent opposition figures, in an effort to squelch public demonstrations over the declared victory of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko in the presidential election on Sunday.

title: Texas Skies May Finally Be Set Free
description: THE airline industry's attempts to kill off Southwest Airlines finally seemed to have run their course by 1979. The established carriers had filed one lawsuit after another against Southwest, then a little Texas discount airline, and each had failed. "This litigation should have been terminated long ago," a federal appellate judge ruled. It had come to resemble "harassment," he wrote.

title: In All-Night Vigils, Opposition in Belarus Demands a New Dawn
description: MINSK, Belarus, March 22 A By midnight, as the temperature dropped ever lower and morning twilight was still five hours off, the core of Belarus's public opposition assumed its shape in the darkness.

title: On Houston, an Old Woman Bearing Gifts
description: First, a word about the name of the prepared food shop at 116 West Houston Street (Sullivan Street), which is to open on Friday. It is My Befana. Daniele Baliani, the chef and an owner, explained that in Italian legend, La Befana is an old woman who gives gifts to children on Epiphany, Jan. 6. "It was my most favorite day after my birthday," he said.

title: For Villepin, it's lonely out front

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 21 - On a day that Anna Benson and Bill Parcells were in the crowd for the Mets' exhibition game against the Orioles, Rickey Henderson had a rapt audience of his own.

title: Challenge to iPod Restrictions Advances in French Legislature
description: PARIS, March 21 - French lawmakers approved copyright legislation on Tuesday with a novel approach to the idea of digital freedom of choice: requiring online music vendors to make songs available for use on any digital player.

title: Darfur Attacks Overwhelm Peace Force, U.N. Reports
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 21 - The United Nations special envoy to Sudan said Tuesday that violence was rising in Darfur and that lack of progress in the south was jeopardizing a peace agreement that ended a separate conflict there.

description: HOUSTON, March 21 - Ben F. Glisan Jr., the government's last big witness in the Enron trial, testified on Tuesday that Enron was "weak" when Jeffrey K. Skilling resigned as chief executive in August of 2001, even as Mr. Skilling was claiming it was in "great shape."

title: Against the War, Michael Stipe, Steve Earle and Lots of Others
description: "Bring 'Em Home Now," a benefit concert at Hammerstein Ballroom on Monday night, brought plenty of powerful remarks from the speakers in its lineup, both comedic and serious, profane and sobersided. These speakers were secondary to the music, but musically the night was of limited use: much of it came across as camp, which isn't the greatest persuader in the war against the war against terror.

description: Two groups of researchers, in Japan and in Holland, have discovered why the avian flu virus is transmitted rarely if ever from one person to another.

description: THE CORNUCOPIA INSTITUTE, a nonprofit agricultural policy research group in Cornucopia, Wis., will release a report today that ranks organic milk and dairy products based on federal organic standards as well as environmental and humane concerns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIEDER, CHRISTENE (LEWIS)
description: RIEDER--Christene (Lewis). Entered into rest on March 15, 2006, of Mendham, NJ, former Director of Tour Guides for the United Nations, wife of the late Daniel M., sister of the late Troy Lewis Jr. Survived by many nieces and nephews. Visitation Saturday, March 25, 2006, from 9AM10AM at the Bailey Funeral Home, 8 Hilltop Rd., Mendham, NJ 973-543-4720. Funeral Service 10:30AM, St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Mendham. Interment Mendham Hilltop Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Assoc.

A Two-Hankie Recipe Collection
description: Recipes for cemetery ginger cookies and funeral pie might seem a bit morbid until you consider the source: "Food to Die For: A Book of Funeral Food, Tips and Tales," compiled by Jessica Bemis Ward (Old City Cemetery, 2005). This community cookbook, which benefits the Old City Cemetery in Lynchburg, Va., where some 20,000 souls are buried, is informative and entertaining. The book starts with recipes for casseroles to take to a wake or to the bereaved, followed by soups, salads and many desserts. (A funeral pie, by the way, features raisins and lemon rind.)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I don't think anybody cares, really. New Orleans is kind of like at the bottom of the country, and they just forget about us."

title: Aric Avelino's 'American Gun' Casts Handguns as the Villain
description: Put the word "American" in front of almost any noun, and you have a title that trumpets its own self-importance. And when that noun is "gun," and the project is a movie, the title implies an imminent bloodbath. But "American Gun," the debut film of Aric Avelino, who wrote the screenplay with Steven Bagatourian, is nothing like that. A stridently sorrowful polemic against the proliferation of handguns in the United States, it consists of three fictional vignettes, of which only one ends in a shooting death. Preferring to throw up its hands rather than shout itself hoarse, the film sustains a mood of paranoia faintly tinged with hope.

title: U.S. Indicts 50 Colombians for Drug Trafficking
description: Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales unveiled today an indictment against 50 leaders in Colombia's largest rebel group, charging them with sending more than $25 billion worth of cocaine into the United States and other countries.

title: $28 Million for the Bronx in the Yankees' Stadium Plan
description: As part of the Yankees' proposal to build a new stadium, the team will contribute $28 million to a trust fund and distribute 15,000 free tickets each season to Bronx groups, according to the draft plan of a community benefits program.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about New York City's efforts to regulate restaurants' use of the cooking technique known as sous vide, in which food is vacuum-wrapped and slowly heated, referred imprecisely to one form of the technique. Cooked food that is to be refrigerated and later reheated must first be chilled quickly in an ice bath, to inhibit bacterial growth.

title: Iraqi Insurgents Attack Police Paramilitary Unit
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 22  Insurgents laid siege today to the headquarters of a police paramilitary unit near the capital, lobbing a volley of mortars that killed at least one senior officer and injured at least five, Interior Ministry officials said.

title: Supreme Court Limits Police Searches of Homes
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 A A bitterly split Supreme Court, ruling in a case that arose from a marriage gone bad, today narrowed the circumstances under which the police can enter and search a home without a warrant.
