Paid Notice: Deaths   GLUCK, A. STANLEY
description: GLUCK--A. Stanley. Beloved husband of Anita, devoted father of Freema and Sheera, father-in-law of Harris. Loving grandfather or Arielle and Gabrielle. Stanley was a man of intelligence, integrity and honor. He and Anita were supporters of many organizations including The Jewish Theological Seminary, Park Avenue Synagogue, Solomon Schecter School of Manhattan, SAR Academy, UJA, Alyn Hospital. He was affiliated with Rothschild, Inc. for more than 58 years. He went to work every day. A dedicated colleague whose leadership, guidance and strength of character will be dearly missed. Stanley was deeply devoted to his family and possessed a unique zest for life. His commitment to work and causes was an inspiration to us all. A compassionate man beloved by many. He will be greatly missed and in our hearts forever. Funeral Services will be held at 11:30 AM on March 23, 2006 at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th St, NYC. $(6$)GLUCK--A. Stanley. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant and Honorary Trustee. We extend to his wife Anita, his daughters, Freema Nagler and Sheera Gluck, and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May his memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft President $(6$)GLUCK--A. Stanley. The American Friends of ALYN Hospital mourn the passing of our devoted Board Member and friend, A. Stanley Gluck. Stanley's passion and generosity to the handicapped children of ALYN Hospital in Jerusalem, Israel made all the difference and are already missed. Our sympathies are with his beloved wife, Anita, and their family.

title: Arts, Briefly; Beatles, American Style
description: Coming soon to record stores: "Help!," "Norwegian Wood" and "Ticket to Ride," as they sounded when first released in the United States 41 years ago. On April 11, Capitol will issue a four-CD box set, "The Capitol Albums Volume 2," with the American versions of four Beatles albums from 1965, "The Early Beatles," "Beatles VI," "Help!" and "Rubber Soul." When the first Beatles CD's were made in 1987, they were reissues of the British versions of the albums, which often had different titles, track lists and cover art; there were variations in sound, too. As on the first volume, released two years ago, the CD's will include both stereo and mono mixes, and 82 of the 92 tracks will be in versions never heard on CD. BEN SISARIO

title: National Briefing | West: California: Suit To Block Voting Machines
description: A group of 24 state voters sued Secretary of State Bruce McPherson and 18 county election officials to block the use or purchase of electronic voting machines made by Diebold. John Eichhorst, a lawyer representing the voters, said the machines were vulnerable to hackers and inaccessible to voters with certain disabilities, and produced a paper verification that might undermine audits. The spokeswoman for Mr. McPherson, Ashley Giozannettone, said she had not yet seen the lawsuit and could not comment on it. But she said the machines had passed two security reviews, and noted that the state certification included a requirement to adhere to "a strict set of security procedures" designed to prevent unauthorized access. CAROLYN MARSHALL (NYT)

title: Black Men on the American Ladder
description: To the Editor:

title: Digital Dialogue: We're talking SMS here...
Out of the Mailbox And Into the Stores
description: The muffins made by the New English Muffin company in Woburn, Mass. -- firmer and denser than typical supermarket muffins -- have until now been sold fresh only in the Boston area, and frozen by mail. Now they are available in New York, fresh. They have no additives or preservatives. Of the six flavors, I prefer whole-grain and five-cheese. The others are plain, cinnamon-raisin, blueberry and cranberry.

title: Citigroup Chief Will Add Chairman's Title, Ending Weill Era
description: The board of Citigroup announced yesterday that the chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, would soon also hold the chairman's title, which has long belonged to Sanford I. Weill.

title: In the Jungle, the Unjust Jungle, a Small Victory
description: JOHANNESBURG - As Solomon Linda first recorded it in 1939, it was a tender melody, almost childish in its simplicity -- three chords, a couple of words and some baritones chanting in the background.

title: Where in the World?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Personal Shopper
description: The challenge: seating and serving 10 guests. But no one said they have to sit together in matching chairs.

title: Currents: Los Angeles
description: Benefit with a twist: own a miniature Gehry, a vision of utopia, a gardener tends the indoors and more.

title: Gear Test With | Indoor Cyclists
description: Apparel makers have found a new way to stop workout stench in its tracks, by embedding antimicrobial agents into fabrics.

title: Koreas Largest Lender Set to Take Stake in Korea Exchange Bank
description: Kookmin Bank, South Koreas largest lender, is set to buy a controlling stake in Korea Exchange Bank that is valued at 6 trillion won ($6.2 billion), in the nations biggest acquisition, Bloomberg News reported.

title: A Rare Takeover Attempt in Germanys Drug Industry
description: As Hubertus Erlen, chief executive of Schering, scrambles to fend off a $17.7 billion takeover offer from its German rival, Merck, all the talk of poison pills, asset sales and possible competing bids by non-German companies is drowning out the news about Scherings product successes.

title: Spanish Court Says Gas Naturals Bid for Endesa Should Be Suspended
description: A Spanish court ruled Tuesday that Gas Naturals hostile bid to acquire Endesa should be suspended, saying it may have involved illegal collusion with another Spanish utility.

title: Falconbridge Prescribes Itself a Poison Pill to Fight Off Xstrata
description: Falconbridge  is fighting off a possible creeping takeover by Swiss miner Xstrata , which last year bought 19.9 percent of the Canadian copper and nickel company.

title: Analysts Throw Cold Water on Talk of a Possible Bid by Exxon Mobil in Europe
description: Energy analysts this week debunked market rumors that Exxon Mobil  was considering using its enormous cash reserves to make a bid on a European oil and gas producer.In the past week, shares of Spanish-Argentine refiner Repsol and BG Group have both risen on persistent market rumors that the worlds largest publicly traded oil company was eyeing an overseas acquisition.

title: Officials Fear Another Dubai Deal Backlash
description: Arab and American officials are growing nervous at the prospect of a second congressional uprising against the acquisition of American assets by a Middle Eastern-controlled company in the wake of the Dubai Ports World debacle.

title: AT&T Chief Says Merger Will Not Create Monopoly in Internet Access
description: Ed Whitacre, the chief executive of AT&T,rejected criticisms that its planned merger with BellSouth will form a near-monopoly for Internet access and give it the clout to dictate terms to Web sites if they want to remain reachable.

title: Lucent Wins Bankruptcy Auction for Riverstone
description: Lucent Technologies s $207 million cash bid for Riverstone Networks , an Ethernet infrastructure company, was declared the winner in an auction. The sale of Santa Clara, Calif.-based Riverstone is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court.

title: Aviva Signals It May Raise $30 Billion Bid for  Prudential
description: The prospect that Aviva increase its $30 billion offer for smaller rival Prudential of Britain has been heightened after the comapny made a statement saying it had not ruled out raising its bid.

title: Morgan Stanley Is Planning to Cut Research Jobs
description: Morgan Stanley is planning to cut about 50 to 60 equity research jobs in Europe and the United States so it can spend more money on emerging market research, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Swiss Private Bank Lets Foreign Directors into the Club
description: Pictet & Compagnie, the closely controlled Swiss private bank that runs the New York Police Departments pension fund, on Tuesday took the step of allowing non-Swiss managing directors to invest in the bank for the first time.

title: British Investor Group Warns Banks on Giving CEOs the Post of Chairman
description: HSBC and the investment bank Close Brothers will be warned next month by the Association of British Insurers about promoting their chief executives to chairmen. Britains biggest investor group will send out a so-called amber top signal to investors that they should question executives very closely before sanctioning a move by the chief executive to the top job.

title: Keeping Up With Google
description: New methods of structuring Internet search results are being exploited by start-ups hoping to compete with Google, which uses a significantly different technique of organizing its Web searches.

title: J.P. Morgan Sets $8 Billion Share Buyback
description: J.P. Morgan Chase said Tuesday that it would buy back up to $8 billion of its common shares in an effort to generate the greatest return for shareholders.

title: Bank of New York Should Spin Off Retail Unit, Analyst Says
description: Bank of New York  should consider spinning off its retail banking unit, following the announced $14.6 billion sale of North Fork Bancorp to Capital One Financial, writes Michael Mayo, an analyst with Prudential Equity Group.

title: Catheter Maker Raises $26 Million
description: EKOS , a developer of catheters for treating blood clots, said that it has raised $26 million in Series C financing. New investor Ascension Health Ventures led the round.

title: Top Court Puts Limits on Securities Lawsuits in State Courts
description: The United States Supreme Court put new limits on securities lawsuits, ruling that a 1998 federal law bars large class-action cases by investors who say they were duped into holding onto stocks and bonds.

title: ITV of Britain Turns Off Buyout Approach
description: ITV , Britains top commercial broadcaster, rejected a takeover offer from a group of buyout firms led by Apax Partners Worldwide and Blackstone Group.

title: Thomas Lee in Dispute With Refco Over Legal Costs
description: Thomas H. Lee Partners, the buyout specialist who orchestrated Refcos initial public offering in 2005 complained that Refcos creditors are improperly trying to bar him from tapping Refcos insurance policies to pay his legal costs.

title: Sale Is Brewing for Eight OClock Coffee Brand
description: Gryphon Investors is looking to sell the Eight OClock Coffee brand for more than $200 million, about twice what it paid for the company in 2003, LBO Wire said.

title: Four More Are Charged in Squawk Box Case
description: Four executives at the day-trading firm of A. B. Watley were arraigned in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday on conspiracy and securities fraud charges stemming from a scheme to reap profits after eavesdropping on confidential conversations between stockbrokers and their clients.

title: William Lyons Bid Spurs Talk of Buyouts Among Home Builders
description: General William Lyons second attempt in the last year to take the home-building company that bears his name private has investors wondering if more deals may be in the works within the sector.

title: Quattrones Win Is a Cautionary Tale for Enrons Judge
description: A federal appeals courts decision to overturn former star investment banker Frank Quattrone s conviction is a reminder to judges and prosecutors alike: get it right the first time or watch your case go up in smoke.

title: British Credit Rating Firm Is Said to Have Rebuffed Buyout Suitors
description: GUS, owner of Argos and Homebase, is understood to have rebuffed a 7 billion bid approach for its credit rating division Experian from a consortium of United States-based private equity firms, including Thomas H. Lee Partners  and Bain Capital.

title: Drug Makers Reach Accord in Patent Dispute Over Plavix
description: Sanofi-Aventis and its partner Bristol-Myers Squibb said late yesterday that they had tentatively settled a patent dispute involving Plavix, the anticlotting agent that is the worlds second-best-selling drug.

title: Accused Hedge Fund Manager Fears NFL Clients
description: The manager of a hedge fund accused of defrauding current and former professional football players is reported to be hiding out from former players who have threatened him.

title: Bank of America Found Guilty of Mismanaging a Nest Egg
description: Bank of America was found guilty Monday of mismanaging the nest egg of a retired executive who claimed bad advice from the bank cost him millions of dollars.

title: Ameriquest to Pay $50 Million in Restitution in California Under Settlement
description: The parent of Ameriquest Mortgage will pay up to $50 million in restitution for California borrowers as part of a settlement brokered with state attorneys general over claims of deceptive lending practices, a prosecutor said Tuesday. Some 725,000 borrowers in 49 states will be eligible to recover part of their losses through the $325 million settlement agreement.

title: Challenge to iPod Restrictions Advances in French Legislature
description: French lawmakers approved copyright legislation on Tuesday with a novel approach to the idea of digital freedom of choice: requiring online music vendors to make songs available for use on any digital player.

title: Noro-Mosley Partners to Retire
description: Noro-Moseley Partners s founder, Charles Moseley, and its general partner, Russell French, have decided not to participate in the firms newest fund, which is expected to hit the market within the next three months with a $200 million target.

title: Old Dutch Foods Puts Humpty Dumpty Deal Back Together Again
description: Winnipeg-based Old Dutch Foods  has agreed to buy Humpty Dumpty Snack Foods Inc. for $26.7 million or 2.85 a share in cash. The offer represents a premium of about 5 percent over the companys Monday closing price of $2.71.

title: Australia Greenlights Newmonts Boddington Stake
description: Newmont Mining got Australian government approval for the acquisition of Newcrest Minings 22.22 percent interest in the Boddington Project in Western Australia. Newmont will pay Australian $225 million for this acquisition and will increase its interest in Boddington to two-thirds.

title: Royal Dutch Shell Snaps Up Canadian Oil Sands
description: Royal Dutch Shell said on Tuesday its Shell EP Americas unit paid $400 million to buy 10 properties in northern Alberta, the highest price paid for Canadian oil sand leases last month.

title: L-3 Buys Two Firms to Bolster Security Systems Business
description: L-3 Communications Holdings , a New York-based government technology giant, has acquired two companies with advanced weapon-detection systems that it hopes to combine into a single device for use at airports, office buildings and elsewhere

title: Japanese Bank to Help Rosneft With Japanese I.P.O.
description: OAO Rosneft is to invite a Japanese bank to sell the companys shares during an initial public offering on the Japanese market, Rosnefts president, Sergei Bogdanchikov, said. The lead managers of the I.P.O. will be four respected banks, in addition, they will be joined by a Japanese bank, which will help them sell the companys shares in Japan, he said.

title: Commerzbank to List Real Estate Unit in Paris
description: Commerzbanks real estate unit Commerz Grundbesitz said it is planning an initial public offering on the Euronext Paris bourse for its Paris-based unit CegeREAL.

title: Nextest Systems Prices Its I.P.O.
description: Nextest Systems , a maker of systems to test computer chips, on Tuesday priced an initial public offering worth $75.6 million, according to an underwriter.

title: Ethical Consumer Values Spark Bids for Small Companies
description: The Colgate-Palmolive deal for Toms and LOreals recent purchase of the Body Shop reflect a growing appetite for ethical consumer products. Consumers have shown they are willing to pay a premium for natural products from values-oriented companies that make them feel good, and big marketers want a piece of the profitable trend.

title: Australias Toll Raises Hostile Bid for Patrick to $3.9 Billion
description: Toll Holdings, Australias biggest freight company, increased its hostile bid for Patrick Corporation, the nations largest port cargo handler, by 17 percent to as much as A$5.4 billion ($3.9 billion).

title: So SoHo
description: Donald Judd turned a factory building into a new way of living. His heirs want to make it come alive again.

title: The Jacques Goudstikker Case
description: Clemens Toussaint, a German art detective, has been hired to track down the collection of Goudstikker, Amsterdam's leading prewar collector in Dutch and Italian old masters.

title: The Futility of Fences
description: Selborne Journal: 22 March 1759:  Mowed the grass-plot for the first time: a vast plenty of Grass, which lined the Cucumber-bed. Made two beds, with one barrow of dung each, for two handglasses, for White-mustard, & cress.

title: I Do. Now Sign Here.
description: It is essentially a sidebar to a star-studded cover story on the divorce of financier Ron Perelman and actress Ellen Barkin, but New York magazines article on prenuptial agreements offers an interesting look at the uneasy union of love and high finance.

title: Morgan Stanley Extends Wall Streets Winning Streak
description: The parade of impressive earnings results from investment banks continued on Wednesday as Morgan Stanley reported record revenue and a 17 percent jump in profit for the fiscal first quarter. In doing so, it became the fourth brokerage firm in less than two weeks to surpass analysts estimates.

title: Now on Sale: Barneys, Anne Klein, Nine West
description: The Jones Apparel Group, the $5 billion clothing company, has been on a shopping spree over the last four years, acquiring two large apparel makers, Gloria Vanderbilt and Kasper, and the luxury retailer Barneys New York.

title: Prosperity (and $10K) for All
description: Charles Murray of the American Enterprise Institute has written a new book, In Our Hands: A Plan to Replace the Welfare State, in which he proposes replacing the welfare state with annual cash grants of $10,000 to every American. In todays Wall Street Journal, Murray, who also co-wrote the 1994 book The Bell Curve, presents the condensed op-ed version of his argument. America is so wealthy, he writes, that enabling everyone to have a decent standard of living is easy [$] :

title: G.M.s Buyout Deal Eases Fears of Delphi Strike
description: Hoping to avoid a painful and possibly lethal strike at a major supplier, General Motors reached an agreement with the United Auto Workers and Delphi on an employee buyout program.

title: Are Iraq Hawks Migrating From Bush?
description: During his press conference yesterday, President Bush said that the timing of the withdrawal of American troops from Iraq would be up to future presidents and future governments of Iraq. What the U.S. policy should be in Iraq  and in the broader war on terror  is shaping up to be as divisive an issue in the 2008 Republican presidential race as it is expected to be among Democratic contenders. Will the Bush Doctrine outlast the Bush administration?

title: Our Energy Outlook is Growing Dimmer
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans March 22 column, A New Grip on Reality

title: More on Parker
description: Robert M. Parker Jr. in Maryland.(Olivier Picard for The New York Times)

title: How an Anonymous Letter Helped Kmart Bag Sears
description: A year after Kmart completed its landmark merger with Sears, a report in The Chicago Tribune reconstructs the events that led to the $11 billion retail deal. (The mergers anniversary is Friday.)

title: Closer Look at Adam Morrison
description: To understand how Adam Morrison of Gonzaga has evolved from a virtually unwanted recruit to one of college basketball's leading scorers it is necessary to examine his roots.

title: Secret Commission Rebates
description: Whats wrong with your agent promising to rebate you all or a part of the fee that you are theoretically paying that agent when buy your house?

title: Headlines. Now Deadlines.
description: Mayor Sharpe James, who is presumably still running for re-election, has been all but invisible to the public in the days since his flamboyant appearance at City Hall last week just before the filing deadline for petitions.

title: Travelin From Timbuktu
description: Here were some comments from Tuesdays column on travel abroad. Matthew from New York writes: I think a full year in a single location would provide a far more enriching and valuable experience. Three months is far too short a period of time for most people to the grasp cultural subtleties theyll face to the extent that theyll be genuinely able feel a part of a community and understand the way members of that community view themselves in the world. An added benefit of a longer term stay would be the life-long bonds many of these young people would establish with the people theyll interact with on a daily basis. Imagine a generation of Americans who have deep, meaningful friendships with families abroad and the the degree of understanding and cooperation ties that solid would foster. Now thats the world I want my children to live in.

title: The Mystery of Brick Towers
description: Brick Towers (Marko Georgiev for The New York Times)

title: Who Is Sebastian Holdings? And Should Vivendi Care?
description: An obscure investment firm called Sebastian Holdings is reportedly jousting with French media behemoth Vivendi Universal in hopes of getting it to sell more assets.

title: In Pakistan, Hiding Out
description: Ive been in rural Pakistan the last few days, visiting my heroic friend Mukhtaran Bibi and interviewing some of the rape victims who flock to her from all over Pakistan. She truly is the Gandhi of the Punjab.

title: My Parochial Contest
description: Ive also been getting indignant emails from people who protest that they are excluded from my win-a-trip contest. In particular, there are students at foreign universities, like Anuj, who wrote from India: Im not saying, choose me, Mr. Kristof. All Im saying is give me and perhaps hundreds like me, whore as capable as American college students a chance to compete.

title: $1.6 Million in Ft. Myers? Fuggeddaboutit
description: The premiere episode of The Sopranos has one of Tonys soldiers trying to retire because he got a $2 million inheritance. In case you are waiting to see it on DVD, I wont spoil the story line, but suffice it to say, the soldier says he has already made an offer on a house on River Road in Ft. Myers, Fla.

title: This Fish Has Chops
description: At the TriBeCa seafood restaurant Fresh the other night, I had an entre I loved. It was advertised as a prime rib of swordfish, and it was a roughly 16-ounce cut, bone attached, that measured between three and four inches in thickness.

title: Yucaipa Hires Former Publisher to Aid Newspaper Bid
description: Hoping to bolster its upcoming bid to buy certain Knight-Ridder newspapers, private equity firm Yucaipa has recruited a former publisher of the Philadelphia Inquirer as a senior adviser. The hiring of Robert Hall could add momentum to Yucaipas effort, which has already won support from important labor union, The Newspaper Guild-Communications Workers of America.

title: V.C.s Lament: Lots of Start-Ups, Not Enough Buyers
description: Being a venture capitalist is apparently not what it used to be.

title: Newark '06: How Sweet the Sound?
description: Cory Booker, candidate for mayor, at the Newark Health and Extended Care Facility.

title: Hes Running for Senate
description: Though Sharpe James seems to be running the worlds most understated re-election campaign for mayor, he is, at least, continuing to take care of the political housekeeping for his other public office: State Senator.

title: Posting with Arianna
description: When Cory Booker wanted to get something off his chest this week, it was only natural that he should have done what so many other public figures are doing these days: he posted his complaint on the Internet.

title: Morgan Stanley Said to Lose Two Top Bankers
description: Two high-ranking bankers have reportedly left Morgan Stanley, including Henry van Dyke, the co-head of the securities firms North American financial sponsors group.

title: The Slingbox
description: The Slingbox lets you, the traveler, watch what's on TV wherever you are.

title: The Information-Age Marine
description: It wasnt long ago that hand-written letters from deployed service members were like gold to their families at home, and vice-versa. News traveled at a snails pace, and the information a service member read in correspondence with his loved ones was sure to be weeks if not months old. The information age has changed all that for good. Im sure my wife appreciates my e-mails, but I dont think any happy dances are transpiring as she checks her inbox, although I could be wrong.

title: Scent of a Person
description: WHEN it comes to fragrance, Trevor Mitchell is an equal opportunity sampler. Mr. Mitchell, a professional tenor, is not averse to a spritz of citrus or musk now and then. But neither is he shy or furtive about misting himself with essence of jasmine or tuberose.

title: Sonia Gandhi Steps Down as Indian Lawmaker
description: NEW DELHI, March 23 A Sonia Gandhi, the leader of India's governing Congress Party, resigned as a member of Parliament today in an attempt to defuse a dispute over claims that she had breached parliamentary rules.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: N.B.A.

title: National Briefing | Washington: A Push To Legalize Immigrants
description: The leaders of a coalition of unions, civil rights groups and immigration advocacy organizations said that they planned to organize rallies in 10 cities on April 10 to put pressure on Congress to pass legislation that would legalize the nation's 11 million illegal immigrants. The groups, which include the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights and the National Council of La Raza, said the rallies would take place in New York, Washington, Chicago, Denver, Los Angeles and other cities.

title: ABC's 'American Inventor': In the Spirit of American Know-How
description: Johannes Gutenberg jilted his fiance. Guglielmo Marconi supported Mussolini. Even Bill Gates is socially inept.

title: Questions Arise About Rsum of Challenger to Clinton
description: Correction Appended

title: Gene Scott, 68, Publisher of Tennis Week, Is Dead
description: Gene Scott, who served tennis for a half-century as a world-ranked player, tournament director, player agent, author and, perhaps most significant, the founder, publisher, editor and iconoclastic columnist of Tennis Week magazine, died Monday in the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 68 and lived in New York.

title: Retirement age raised for BA's flight crews
Let in the Light. Show Off the Tub. Who Needs Privacy?
description: WHEN Andrea Marpillero-Colomina, a student at Sarah Lawrence College, visits her father and stepmother at their loft in TriBeCa, she times her showers carefully. Her father, Sandro Marpillero, and stepmother, Linda Pollak, are architects who designed their windowless bathroom with a glass wall that allows them to see through the loft's triple-height living room to the garden out back.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Objects From a Master of Whimsy With a Wide and Long Career
description: Correction Appended

title: Can This Workout Be Saved?
description: BRYAN GILLETTE was pedaling behind his fiance up a steep hill in New Zealand during a driving rainstorm last year when he realized just how intricately nuanced and vexing communication with a partner can be at such times.

title: In theater of war, a playwright's realistic bent
Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDMAN, JAMES O.
description: FREEDMAN--James O. It is with deep sorrow that the Officers, Councilors, and members of the Trust of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourn the loss of James Freedman, distinguished legal scholar, university leader, and President of the Academy from 2000-2001. Throughout his academic career and as President of the University of Iowa and Dartmouth College, he worked to promote diversity and social justice and to strengthen the role of the intellectual in advancing the mission of a democratic society. In words and actions, he demonstrated the importance of what he called "an opening up of mind and spirit to a symphony of different persons, cultures, traditions, and languages." Nothing was more important to him than the values of a liberal education and the concept of "intellectual wholeness", ideals that are embodied in the work of the Academy. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Bathsheba, his family, and all those touched by his wisdom, eloquence, and grace. Patricia Meyer Spacks, President Louis W. Cabot, Vice President and Chair of the Academy Trust John S. Reed, Treasurer Jerrold Meinwald, Secretary Leslie C. Berlowitz, Chief Executive Officer

title: Endangering species: Poppies to songbirds
For Yankees and the Red Sox, It Might as Well Be July
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 22 - The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox can play it down all they want. Even in spring training, with a skeleton Boston lineup at Legends Field, these are still bitter rivals.

title: In Placid Iraqi Kurdistan, Strife to the South Elicits Little Sympathy
description: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq, March 19 - Like most young Kurds in this northern city, Asad Ali does not speak Arabic. He has heard about the rising wave of sectarian killings down in Baghdad, but it seems a world away from the quiet rhythms of daily life here in Kurdistan.

title: Ask Science
description: Benedict Carey answered reader questions about his article "RevisitingSchizophrenia: Are Drugs Always Needed?" from this week's ScienceTimes.

title: A Hundred Thousand Fish, Behind a Pane 2 Feet Thick
description: ATLANTA, March 19 - When you enter a zoo, you usually know pretty much where you stand: there are trees or rocks, sunlight or windows, bars or glass or fences. Zoos have traditionally been extensions of public parks, offering exotic marvels safely contained on home turf. Even fish can sometimes be found in such terrain, swimming about as they did in the well-stocked ponds of ancient rulers.

title: Israeli Arabs and the vote
Briefly: Opposition figure freed as EU weighs visa move
Film review: Chappelle's neighborhood riff on celebrity
Labor Protests Put French Premier in a Bind
description: PARIS, March 22 - Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin loves to portray himself as a fearless political warrior, alone against his enemies on the battlefield of power.

title: Different Drug Often Works in Depression, Study Finds
description: Some people with depression who do not recover with an initial course of antidepressant therapy can increase their chances of finding relief by trying other drug treatments, researchers are reporting today.

title: TV at the Hussein Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Long Road Out of Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: To All the Girls I've Rejected
description: Gambier, Ohio - A FEW days ago I watched my daughter Madalyn open a thin envelope from one of the five colleges to which she had applied. "Why?" was what she was obviously asking herself as she handed me the letter saying she was waitlisted.

title: Morgan Stanley Profits Soar but Its Retail Unit Is Ailing
description: Morgan Stanley reported a 17 percent gain in first-quarter profits yesterday as the firm's increased focus on riskier trading strategies began to pay off.

title: Damon Has Taken Id Out of His Idiot Act
description: Tampa, Fla. - PERHAPS Johnny Damon was less the free spirit in Boston than he was the skilled salesman. Perhaps the hair and beard were part of a disguise, a veneer, as he embraced and exploited an environment established by others and encouraged by Manager Terry Francona.

title: Awaiting Verdict, Victim's Family Feels '03 Killing Is Eclipsed Again
description: The story of Romona Moore seems timed to end as it began.

title: A new round of EU feuds
Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, PAULINE
description: SOLOMON--Pauline, 91. On March 21, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Leo Solomon. Devoted and cherished mother of Diane Solomon Jarett and Joan Weiss, and their spouses Barry and Allan. Adored grandmother of Brian and Michael Weiss. She was a teacher for many years at James Madison High School in Brooklyn. She had been a chorus girl in student productions at City College and danced her way through life, lighting up hearts and lives along the way.

title: Turning the Tables On Formal Dinners
description: AT an event in New York last week benefiting Diffa (the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS), 75 designers took on the challenge of creating settings for 10 dinner guests. Along with fine tableware, two practical ideas stood out: unmatched chairs and tables for one. "Very few people have formal dining rooms now," said one designer, Bill Sofield. "Small tables give flexibility for rooms to do double duty." Another designer, Vicente Wolf, interspersed chairs by Charles Eames and Philippe Starck. "You want variation," he said. Chairs, like guests, "give the space personality."

title: A Vision, Bruised and Dented
description: The big question in Democratic circles is, Who can win? The big question in Republican circles is, What do we believe? The setbacks in Iraq, the failure to limit the size of government and plummeting poll numbers have changed the way Republicans talk and govern.

title: Hofstra's Long Joy at Home Ends With Wrong Numbers
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., March 22 - During their National Invitation Tournament quarterfinal game at Hofstra Arena on Wednesday night, Old Dominion Coach Blaine Taylor and his staff took turns holding up white placards with large black numbers on them. Each number represented a coded indication of what defensive set the Monarchs were to employ.

title: 3 Western hostages rescued in Iraq
Panel Urges Lowering of Allowable Fluoride
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 - High concentrations of fluoride that occur naturally in a small minority of the nation's drinking water supplies can damage teeth and bones, and federal regulators should reduce the level that is considered safe for human consumption, a National Academy of Sciences panel said Wednesday.

title: Resisting Kiev, Crimeans hold toMoscow orbit
Unisys Pension Changes
description: Unisys, a provider of server computers and consulting services, will cut retirement costs by about $700 million over the next 10 years by revamping its American pension plans.

title: U.S. Travel Advisory Triggers Political Sparks in Italy
description: ROME, March 23 A An American travel advisory on possible dangers in Italy ballooned today into a campaign issue in the close national elections here, with opposition politicians suggesting that the advisory could be used as ammunition against them.

title: 2 venture capital firms give 'mash-ups' a go
Litter and the City
description: To the Editor:

title: Schrder critic is silenced
From Buenos Aires, Playful Spaces With Some California Dreaming
description: The Gerscovich brothers, Juan Diego and Fernando, hail from Buenos Aires but their Los Angeles design firm, Sundayland, takes its cues from 1970's California pop. For a tract house overlooking the Pacific, above, they combined a white leather Eames lounge chair with a cowhide rug dyed blue and a reproduction Louis XIV desk lacquered white. Nearby is their Woody lamp, with a walnut veneer shade ($1,650). The brothers' playful approach, explained Juan Diego Gerscovich, is to use "a few strong moves that radically change a product or a space." Sundayland's latest designs include a Persian car rug, called a Praying Car-Mat ($150 a pair) and the 1,000 Pound Table, a Styrofoam and vinyl coffee table that looks like a huge block of marble ($950). For information and store locations: sundayland.com.

title: A Vision of Utopia, Adapted as Shelter From the California Sun
description: In addition to an obsession with the color blue, the French artist Yves Klein often theorized about what he called "air architecture," structures composed of ephemeral elements like climate-controlled air and water, in which people would live, unclothed and in closer contact with nature. A Los Angeles-based architect, Franois Perrin, who recently curated and designed a show about Klein's architectural projects at the Museum of Applied Art in Vienna, was inspired by these utopian ideas when asked to renovate a 1,200-square-foot bungalow in Venice, Calif., owned by Gus Koven, a sound designer, and his wife, Stephanie, a doctor (right, with their 16-month old son Gustavo). For an extension to the bungalow, Mr. Perrin created a "solar umbrella" by wrapping translucent Polygal, a type of polycarbonate typically used in greenhouses, around a 600-square-foot wooden frame (above, inset) that opens up the dark interior.

title: Is Upstate 'Like Appalachia'? Well, Part of It Is Appalachia
description: ALBANY, March 22 - A candidate for governor compared upstate New York to Appalachia. The sitting governor called that an insult. Lost in the fracas was a geographical fact: In some places, upstate New York actually is Appalachia.

title: Paul Bunyan, Modern-Day Sex Symbol
description: LAST December John Martin sat in on a focus group for a trend-forecasting company at which young professionals were asked about their grooming habits. Mr. Martin found he had nothing useful to contribute. His shaving regimen involves the use of a razor about as frequently as the seasons change.

title: Rice Reduces Caribbean Ire, but Falls Short on Aid to Haiti
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, March 22 - After two days of meetings with Caribbean leaders, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice appeared to have cooled some of their anger toward the United States but failed to persuade them to embrace the new government in Haiti, United States officials said Wednesday.

title: In Reversal, Graduate School Applications From Foreigners Rise
description: The number of foreign students who applied to graduate programs in American universities during the current academic year increased by 11 percent from the year before, according to a survey to be released today. That growth reverses two years of decline that occurred in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Hispanic Society Board Endorses Plan to Leave Washington Heights for Downtown
description: The Hispanic Society of America, home to one of the largest collections of Hispanic cultural material outside Spain, has decided to move downtown from Washington Heights to draw more visitors and acquire the space it needs to display its art and artifacts.

title: WB Censors Its Own Drama for Fear of F.C.C. Fines
description: Concerned about the recent decision by the Federal Communications Commission to fine television networks for material deemed indecent, the WB network will broadcast a new drama next week that it has censored over the objections of the program's creator.

title: Sales of Existing Homes Surge, Defying Forecasts
description: Sales of existing homes surged surprisingly in February after falling for five months in a row, the National Association of Realtors reported today, reflecting a boost from unseasonably warm weather and signaling that the housing market remains healthier than some experts had suggested.

title: The Candidates' Money Race
description: As a cash-flow marathon, the 2008 presidential race is already under way, with fund-raising trumping innovative ideas and political experts predicting the death of public financing. This is a little-noticed American tragedy, as politics slips back toward the Watergate era. That was when the scandal of easy-money corruption prompted Congress to create the historic option of public election subsidies.

title: An External CD-DVD Recorder for All the Stuff You Want to Save
description: Complexity is often a feature of electronics products, one that buyers would rather do without. LG Electronics says its new external optical recorder, the GSA-5169D, makes transferring practically anything to CD's and DVD's -- like pictures, sounds and video -- a simple proposition.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSS, ALAN GORDON
description: ROSS--Alan Gordon. It's been five years, and we miss you every day. Love, Mom, Dad and Chris

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRESLIN, ROSEMARY
description: BRESLIN--Rosemary. Happy Birthday, Rosemary, We all miss you. With love, Dad, Ronnie, Patrick, Maria, Christina, Kevin, James, Kelly, Chris, Dee, Donald, Phyllis, Donald, Tara and Sean.

title: Kyrgyz, Afghan and Tajik Concert Sponsored by Aga Khan Music Initiative
description: The instruments were ancient, the music was old and new, and the presentation was subtly high-tech in "Music From Central Asia," a triple bill of ensembles from Kyrgystan, Afghanistan and Tajikistan on Tuesday night at the Miller Theater. The concert was part of a project sponsored by the Aga Khan Music Initiative, along with releases of albums by all three groups (and more to come), seeking to open Western ears to Central Asian music.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (BET) RIP THE RUNWAY -- Who would have thought fashion shows would become a popular prime-time genre? LL Cool J and Gabrielle Union are the hosts of this one, showing clothes from the likes of Todd Smith, Stephen Burrows and G-Unit. There are musical guests too, including Busta Rhymes. But the stars of the hour are Three 6 Mafia (above), whose song "It's Hard Out There for a Pimp" just won an Oscar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, ASHER WILLIAM
description: SCHWARTZ--Asher William. Principal in the law firm of O'Donnell and Schwartz of New York, died March 20, 2006 at his residence at The Osborn in Rye, NY. He was 94. Mr. Schwartz is survived by two sons, Alec M. Schwartz of Chicago, Fred E. Schwartz of Ithaca, NY, a daughter Susan Schwartz of San Francisco. Five grandchildren, two great grandchildren and a brother Dr. Martin F. Schwartz. Funeral services will be held at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY on March 26 at 1:30 PM. A reception at The Osborn will follow. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Legal Services of the Hudson Valley, 4 Cromwell Place, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: Britain Upholds School Ban on a Muslim Gown
description: LONDON, March 22 - Britain's highest court ruled Wednesday that a secondary school was within its rights to bar a female student from wearing a jilbab, a loose, ankle-length gown, instead of the regular school uniform.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about protests in France over a new law weakening job protection misstated the action employers would be allowed to take without cause toward new workers younger than 26 years of age. Such workers could be terminated within the first two years of employment, not laid off for two years.

title: When It Comes to Your Computer, Who's Really in Control?
description: A reader asks an intriguing question:

title: Queens Senator Is Accused of Throwing Coffee at Aide
description: ALBANY, March 22 - The state police are investigating an allegation that State Senator Ada L. Smith of Queens threw coffee at a member of her staff and pulled the staff member's hair on Tuesday morning, state officials said Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Vote Set On M.T.A. Labor Standoff
description: The State Public Employment Relations Board announced yesterday that it would meet in Albany today to vote on a recommendation that the contract dispute between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union be referred to binding arbitration. The authority supports arbitration, but the president of the local, Roger Toussaint, has called for a second vote on the contract proposal that his members narrowly rejected on Jan. 21. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: New Studies Warn of Effects of Melting Polar Ice
description: Within the next 100 years, the growing human influence on earth's climate could lead to a long and irreversible rise in sea levels by eroding Earth's vast polar ice sheets, according to new observations and analysis by several teams of scientists.

title: Studies Suggest Avian Flu Pandemic Isn't Imminent
description: Two groups of researchers, in Japan and in Holland, say they have discovered why the avian flu virus is rarely if ever transmitted from one person to another.

title: Jakarta tells Freeport, 'Start following rules'
World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Pope Drops 'Patriarch Of West' Title
description: Pope Benedict XVI has dropped "patriarch of the West" from his official titles, the Vatican said. The title was adopted in 642 by Pope Theodore I, and dropping it "is an act of historical and theological realism," the Pontifical Council for Christian Unity, which deals with ecumenical affairs, said in a statement. "Giving up the claim to this title could help ecumenical dialogue." Since assuming the papacy last April, Benedict has emphasized ecumenical sensitivity with Orthodox Protestant churches. The pope retains eight other titles: bishop of Rome; vicar of Jesus Christ; successor of the prince of the apostles; supreme pontiff of the universal church; primate of Italy; archbishop and metropolitan of the province of Rome; sovereign of Vatican City State; and servant of the servants of God.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Giuliani To Help Iowa Campaigns
description: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will campaign for fellow Republicans in Iowa this spring in the sort of trip that tends to stir talk of presidential ambitions. Iowa Republican officials said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani would speak at two fund-raising events on May 1, one for the Republican candidate for governor, Representative Jim Nussle; the other for the state's Republican Party and Jeff Lamberti, a state senator running for Congress. Sunny Mindel, a spokeswoman, said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani was going to Iowa only because "he's committed to seeing Republicans elected during the midterm elections." JIM RUTENBERG (NYT)

title: As Cameras Increasingly Go Digital, Can the Home Slide Show Be Far Behind?
description: Showing friends your photos on a big screen used to require nothing more than a slide projector and a screen (though a white wall would do). But showing digital photos that way has required either a portable player and a very expensive TV or a digital projector linked to a computer.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Police Commander Accused of Lying About Arrests During Convention
description: A civil liberties group accused the Police Department yesterday of providing false information used to prosecute hundreds of people arrested in protest marches during the 2004 Republican National Convention, and said that information might have tainted the arrests.

title: For French students, not such a testing time
Bayer of Germany Offers $19.5 Billion for Schering
description: LONDON, March 23 A The German drug giant Bayer A.G. stepped in as surprise white knight for Schering A.G. of Germany today with a cash bid of 16.3 billion euros, or about $19.5 billion.

title: Soccer: Ronaldo ends his goal drought
It Was Soriano's Move, So He Made It
description: JUPITER, Fla., March 22 - Like so many times in the past, Alfonso Soriano started a double play during Wednesday's game between the Washington Nationals and the St. Louis Cardinals. Only this time, he started it from the outfield.

title: Briton Tried to Buy A-Bomb, Prosecution in Trial Contends
description: LONDON, March 22 - The prosecution in the trial of seven men accused of having links to Al Qaeda and plotting to carry out bomb attacks in Britain said on Wednesday that one of the men had inquired about buying an atomic bomb from Russian mafia figures in Belgium.

title: Unions to Meet French Premier on Contested Labor Law
description: PARIS, March 23 - France's most powerful labor union federations agreed Thursday to meet Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin on Friday to discuss the country's hotly contested new employment law, even as fires burned in Paris after another demonstration against the law.

title: Gandhi resigns from Indian Parliament
Bush's Long Road Out of Iraq (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CHAPLIN, ARTHUR
description: CHAPLIN - Arthur. Even YOUR sense of humor can not make this 7th anniversary much fun. Mimi, etc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOBENE, NUNZIO
description: LOBENE--Nunzio. 87 years old of Pittsford, NY. Predeceased by his parents Angelo Lobene and Annetta (Ciofani) Lobene and his daughter Patty Lu. Survived by wife Patricia (Filippone) married 57 years; loving children, Mark and wife, Judith Modrak of New York City, Thomas of New York City and Barbara Vela of Chicago; beloved special granddaughter Katie Vela; wonderful cousins Lucia Talley, Florence Polino, sister-in-law June Fornieri; and other loved relatives and numerous friends including Anthony and Susan LoCurto. Former longtime resident of East Irondequoit and Pittsford, he spent the last six months in Chicago for medical treatment. He served in the European theater during WWII, was promoted to the rank of 1st Sergeant U.S. Army, and awarded the Bronze Star. A realtor for over 50 years, a certified appraiser, and a former Executive Vice President of the Rochester Real Estate Board and named Realtor of the Year, he achieved a reputation for probity and decency. He was also active in the ItalianAmerican Business Men's Association and other community events and charities. A former member of Penfield Country Club for 30 years, he spent many happy afternoons on the golf course. An avid story teller and regular letter writer, he entertained us all. We will miss our father's abundant love, lively spirit, and generous heart. A memorial service was held on Tuesday March 14th, at St. Ambrose Church in Rochester, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be directed to his medical providers, in the name of Nunzio Lobene, at the following address: GILD, University of Illinois Medical Center, Suite 1020, 840 S. Wood St, Chicago, IL 60612-7323.

title: China Tries to Charm Couple of Senate Skeptics
description: BEIJING, March 22 - Global Times, a tabloid newspaper in China's capital, usually offers its readers a rich diet of nationalist propaganda on subjects like Japanese war crimes and American hegemony.

title: Bertelsmann Weighs End to Its Privacy
description: BERLIN, March 22 - Bertelsmann, the global media empire, reported upbeat financial results on Wednesday, propelled by pop-culture sensations like the singer Kelly Clarkson and Dan Brown's thriller "The Da Vinci Code." But the company's most talked-about suspense story continues to be its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AKINS, CHARLES A.
description: AKINS--Charles A. We deeply mourn the death of our best friend, Charlie, who died on Wednesday, March 22, 2006 after a valiant fight against pancreatic cancer. He was 59. We already miss him more than words can say. Viewing will be at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. between 20th and 21st Streets, NYC (212-475-2024) on Friday, March 24, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Joseph's Catholic Church, 371 Sixth Ave. corner Washington Place, NYC (212741-1274) on Saturday, March 25 promptly at 9:30AM. Interment will be at Holy Cross Cemetery, 3620 Tilden Ave. at Brooklyn Ave., Brooklyn, NY (718-284-4520). In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021, attention: Dr. David D'Adamo. Irene and Harvey Pessar

title: George Bush's Trillion-Dollar War
description: Call it the trillion-dollar war.

title: 3 Western Aid Workers in Iraq Rescued in Military Operation
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 23 A Spurred by a tip from a detainee, a multinational military force stormed a house in western Baghdad early today and rescued two Canadians and a Briton who had been held hostage by a shadowy guerrilla group for nearly four months.

title: The Two Sides Of Israel's Barrier
description: To the Editor:

title: Sneakerhead Bonanza
description: THE rise of sneakerheads, as aficionados of artistically enhanced footwear call themselves, has had a contagious impact on shoe companies. It is rare this spring to locate a style that has not been touched by the hand of an artist, designer or cartoon character. That's the way sneakerheads like their shoes: expensive and unique.

title: A belated opportunity to kill the 'Wright tax'
Case for Moussaoui Execution Seems Bolstered by 2 Witnesses
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 22 - The government's effort to have Zacarias Moussaoui executed for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, which has been troubled by serious problems over the last two weeks, appeared to have been bolstered significantly on Wednesday by the testimony of its final two witnesses.

title: In 50-Yard Square in Belarus, a Country Within
description: MINSK, Belarus, March 22 - By midnight, as the temperature dropped ever lower and morning twilight was still five hours off, the core of Belarus's public opposition assumed its shape in the darkness.

title: Witness in Detectives' Trial Testifies About His Own Crimes
description: Steven Corso A tax cheat, thief and disgraced accountant A has spent the last two days at the racketeering trial of Louis Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa telling jurors that the two detectives moved to Las Vegas in the early 1990's and committed a smattering of federal crimes.

title: G.M. Will Offer Buyouts to All Its Union Workers
description: Correction Appended

title: More Laptop Than Cellphone, but It Still Fits in Your Pocket
description: The chasm between smart phones -- cellphones chock-full of computing features -- and laptops is fast closing. The new T-Mobile MDA, a cellphone powered by Windows Mobile 5.0, for example, has so many features you may just leave that laptop at home.

title: Recalling a coming-of-age ritual
Big, Maybe Ugly, but Their Role Heroic
description: NEW ORLEANS - They are monumental things, these structures, as tall as four-story buildings and as brutal as bad public art. Each of them slightly resembles a giant's chair with massive steel lattices of pipe braced and welded every which way.

title: Outrage in Afghanistan
description: What's the point of the United States' propping up the government of Afghanistan if it's not even going to pretend to respect basic human rights? President Bush himself said it was "deeply troubling" that an Afghan man is facing the death penalty for converting from Islam to Christianity.

title: French labor protests, Israel and America
Once Set for Life, Auto Workers May Have to Gamble
description: Correction Appended

title: So You Think You Can Just Adopt a Dog?
description: ALMOST as soon as Michele Pusateri and her two daughters chose a black-and-white terrier at a humane society shelter near their home in South Pasadena, Calif., they were told they did not qualify to own the dog.

title: Europa: In Germany, disquiet over French rebellion
Party hopes Germany's vote renews faded luster
Editors' Note
description: An article in The Metro Section on March 8 profiled Donna Fenton, identifying her as a 37-year-old victim of Hurricane Katrina who had fled Biloxi, Miss., and who was frustrated in efforts to get federal aid as she and her children remained as emergency residents of a hotel in Queens.

title: G.M. sells 78% of GMAC mortgage unit for $1.5 billion
TV Here, There, Everywhere
description: IN the olden days, Americans gathered in front of the television sets in their living rooms to watch designated shows at designated times. You had a choice of three channels, and if you missed the broadcast, you'd feel like an idiot at the water cooler the next day. Quaint, huh?

title: EU agrees to increasetariffs on leather shoes
National Briefing | West: California: New Challenge To Evolution
description: The five-member board of the Lancaster School District in Southern California voted unanimously on Tuesday to approve a new policy to encourage classroom challenges to the theory of evolution. The policy states that "students should learn that science never commits itself irrevocably to any fact," and that evolution is to be "taught as theory, as opposed to unalterable fact." Glenn Branch, deputy director of the National Center for Science Education, called the policy "stealth creationism," the latest effort by religious conservatives to introduce a Biblical view of the origins of life. Alex Branning, a supporter of the policy, said the guideline was meant to improve students' math and science results.

title: Mrs. Clinton Says G.O.P.'s Immigration Plan Is at Odds With the Bible
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton invoked the Bible yesterday to criticize a stringent border security measure that, among other things, would make it a federal crime to offer aid to illegal immigrants.

title: The Proto-Loft, Reborn
description: FLAVIN JUDD, 38, is as old as SoHo is.

title: Let in the Light. Show Off the Tub. Who Needs Privacy?
description: WHEN Andrea Marpillero-Colomina, a student at Sarah Lawrence College, visits her father and stepmother at their loft in TriBeCa, she times her showers carefully. Her father, Sandro Marpillero, and stepmother, Linda Pollak, are architects who designed their windowless bathroom with a glass wall that allows them to see through the loft's triple-height living room to the garden out back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TABAKMAN, SAMUEL
description: TABAKMAN - Samuel. A gentle Jewish man who was loved by all. Beloved husband of the late Mary. Loving father of David and Judi. Dear grandfather of Amber and Justin. Veteran of the U.S. Army. Associate Director of the Childrens Center in NYC. Chapel services Friday, 12 noon, at the Castle Hill Funeral Chapel, 1528 Castle Hill Ave., Bronx, NY, 718-828-9222.

title: Room for a Hood?
description: Q. A brick interior wall is shedding a white powder. Is there a solution that will retain the natural look?

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: 32 Years For Guerrilla Leader
description: Vctor Polay, the leader of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement that carried out a 126-day siege of the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima in 1996, was sentenced to 32 years in prison after he was retried on charges of terrorism. Mr. Polay was retried after a Peruvian court struck down the draconian antiterrorism laws under which he had been convicted. Jailed since 1992, Mr. Polay was known as the daring leader of a group that carried out political assassinations and attacks on high-profile targets.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 27 about residents of Glacier Circle, a self-planned housing development for the elderly in Davis, Calif., misspelled the surname of an architect in Nevada City, Calif., who imported from Denmark the concept he named co-housing, under which people buy homes in a community they plan and run together. He is Charles Durrett, not Durett.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIFER, MONROE
description: SEIFER--Monroe. Bay Ridge Jewish Center mourns the loss of our beloved past president and friend. Joel Sokol, President

description: GYORY--Robert S. July 20, 1918--March 23, 2005. Dear Bob, you are missed each and every day by your wife and all your family. Eleanor

The girl, Haleigh Poutre, is 12, not 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUNHARDT, PHILIP B. JR.
description: KUNHARDT--Philip B. Jr., 78. Died peacefully at his home in Chappaqua on March 21, 2006. The funeral of this beloved man will be held on Friday, March 24, 10:30 AM at St. Mark's Church in Mt. Kisco, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the International Rescue Committee or Manhattan Country School.
