title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Richard K. Root, the doctor reported killed by a crocodile while on safari in Botswana, misstated his medical specialty. He was an infectious disease specialist, not an epidemiologist.

title: Desperate Coaches' Wives
description: Among the challenges facing the Bradley Braves in the N.C.A.A. tournament is somehow picking up a tailored pantsuit with red accents.

title: Thai court voids decrees for utility's offering
Paid Notice: Deaths   VIDICH, ARTHUR J.
description: VIDICH--Arthur J. The New School notes with sadness the death of sociologist Arthur J. Vidich on March 16. His more than 40 years of teaching at The New School for Social Research and his numerous books and articles, including the classic "Small Town in Mass Society", have influenced generations of social scientists. The University is planning a memorial gathering at its Greenwich Village campus in mid-September. Details will be available at www.newschool.edu or at 212.229.5700 ext 3125. Philip Scaturro, Chair, Board of Trustees Bob Kerrey, President, The New School Ben Lee, Dean, The New School for Social Research

title: British Network Rejects Buyout Bid
description: LONDON, March 22 - ITV, the biggest commercial broadcaster in Britain, said Wednesday that it had rejected an approach from a group of buyout firms, under which a former head of the BBC would take over as ITV's chief executive.

title: The Odd Couple on the 15th Floor
description: SIX years ago Linda Rodin fell in love with two things: a color and a creature. Her quest to attain the first and tame the second have only lately been worked out.

title: Dear Web Log: Hated the Shampoo, Loved the Soap
description: "I am in Chicago, friends!" Kristen Kelly, 24, of Brooklyn, announced recently. "I do love this city and always enjoy visiting, but I wish the weather weren't so misty and dismal today. Anyhow, I did a very foolish thing and left my shampoo and conditioner at home. (I alternate between Pantene Blonde Expressions and Frdric Fekkai Baby Blonde), so I was stuck with whatever the hotel had to offer."

title: SAT Problems Even Larger Than Reported
description: The College Board disclosed yesterday that the problems resulting from the misscoring of its October SAT examination were larger than it had previously reported.

title: Roberts Dissent Reveals Strain Beneath Court's Placid Surface
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 - A Supreme Court decision on Wednesday in an uncelebrated criminal case did more than resolve a dispute over whether the police can search a home without a warrant when one occupant gives consent but another objects.

title: News Analysis: Taiwanese see storm across strait
The Container That Changed the World
description: THE political showdown over a Dubai company's plan to operate terminals at six American ports briefly focused public attention on one of the most significant, yet least noticed, economic developments of the last few decades: the transformation of international shipping.

title: U.S. presses China about researcher
When Good Investment Deals Go Bad
description: It's not quite 1999, but for entrepreneurs, the money is flowing again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENHECK, VIOLA D.
description: ROSENHECK--Viola D. The family of the late David Dibner is deeply saddened by the death of Vede Rosenheck, a dear cousin, a vital, courageous and loving woman. Our condolences to Steven and Robert, and their families. Frances, Brent, Daniel, and Mark Dibner

title: GM sells $8.8 billion stake in subsidiary
Sports of The Times; Tagliabue Knows When to Fold 'Em
description: Correction Appended

title: Barry Bonds and Baseball's Steroids Scandal
description: Game of Shadows Barry Bonds, Balco and the Steroids Scandal that Rocked Professional Sports By Mark Fainaru-Wada and Lance Williams 332 pages. Gotham Books. $26.

title: How to Engage Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: E.P.A. Warns Of City's Air Quality
description: People who live near congested highways and in large cities like New York face an increased risk of getting cancer from air pollution, according to a national study by the Environmental Protection Agency. The study was based on 1999 data, the most recent year available, and covers 177 toxins. But the study was criticized for excluding dioxins and the parts of diesel exhaust that are believed to cause cancer. Of all the states, New York has the most hazardous air, according to the study, and New York City has the most polluted air in the state. The agency said the study results should not be used to make state-by-state or city-by-city comparisons. Rather, like the results of an earlier study in 2002, they are intended to help state efforts to concentrate on and reduce pollutants. ANTHONY DEPALMA (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Former Enron Treasurer Says Ex-Chief Lied Ben F. Glisan Jr., Enron's former treasurer, testified that Kenneth L. Lay, a former chief executive, lied to credit rating agencies, employees and Wall Street analysts about the company's performance. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

title: A Camera Made for Pictures Shot in the Dark
description: Shooting digital photos in dim light poses several hazards: use flash (and risk red-eyed subjects), use very slow shutter speeds (blurry results from camera shake), or turn up the camera's ISO sensitivity for faster shutter speeds (grainy pictures). But digital single-lens reflex cameras, which can offer clear shots at high ISO settings, are heavy and expensive.

title: Jury Told Lay Lied on Enron
description: HOUSTON, March 22 - In seven weeks of court testimony, prosecutors landed only glancing blows against Kenneth L. Lay, a former chief executive of Enron who is on trial for criminal conspiracy and fraud. Mr. Lay's luck may have run out in Week 8.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 2 about the ballerina and movie actress Moira Shearer misspelled the name of the city where she was born. As a reader pointed out to The Times this week, it is Dunfermline, Scotland, not Dumferline.

title: Jagr Gets the Applause, Flyers Get the Victory
description: Jaromir Jagr was so dominant at Madison Square Garden last night that he was saluted with a standing ovation -- on a shot that was stopped. He deserved it, too. Jagr had already scored his league-leading 47th, 48th and 49th goals of the season.

title: Panel Advises Disclosure of Drugs' Psychotic Effects
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., March 22 - Stimulants like Ritalin lead a small number of children to suffer hallucinations that usually feature insects, snakes or worms, according to federal drug officials, and a panel of experts said on Wednesday that physicians and parents needed to be warned of the risk.

title: Sonia Gandhi steps down from Indian Parliament
World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Government Clamps Down On Protests
description: President Alfredo Palacio declared a state of emergency late Tuesday, the ninth day of protests by thousands of Indians against free trade talks with the United States that have closed off highways and led to millions of dollars in lost commerce. Troops deployed to rural highland communities outside of Quito, the capital, cleared tree trunks and burning tires, while firing tear gas at demonstrators. Protest leaders vowed to press on, while Mr. Palacio vowed to continue the trade talks. A final round of negotiations with the Americans is set for today.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Tuesday about "Suburban Shootout," on Oxygen, and "The Real Housewives of Orange County," on Bravo, referred incorrectly to the child of Lauri in "Real Housewives" who has been sent to a juvenile detention institution. It is her middle child, not her eldest.

title: West Virginia Taps Into a Rich Vein
description: Atlanta - DEFYING all the actuarial tables, the older generations are multiplying. Every year, more and more people get this dreamy look in their eyes when they relate their youthful experiences to Coach John Beilein of West Virginia University.

title: Physical Culture: Gear Test With Indoor Cyclists; Ah, the Sweet Bouquet of the Gym
description: SWEAT usually dries quickly from workout clothes, but the odor it leaves behind is hard to shake.

title: Back on His Feet, Anthrax Patient Plans to Dance Again
description: SAYRE, Pa., March 22 - Walking slowly but sporting a wide smile, Vado Diomande, the African dancer and drummer who contracted inhalation anthrax last month, entered a hospital auditorium here yesterday and spoke publicly for the first time since he fell ill. He thanked the doctors who have been treating him, talked about his plans for life after the hospital, and even did a quick dance.

title: Corzine Tests Get-Tough Budget Plan at a Diner
description: JERSEY CITY, March 22 - The day after unveiling his $30.9 billion state budget plan and its increased sales tax and collection of sharp cuts, Gov. Jon S. Corzine ate breakfast at a diner in this overwhelmingly Democratic city to test his talking points and defense of the harsh fiscal medicine he is proposing.

title: The Economist Names New Editor in Chief
description: The Economist magazine, the urbane British weekly that has been expanding its readership in America, today named its United States editor as its new editor in chief.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Library Branch To Reopen
description: The Brownsville branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, which was closed last Friday because of safety concerns, will reopen at 1 p.m. today, according to Ginnie Cooper, the executive director of the library system. On March 15, an employee at the branch, at 61 Glenmore Avenue, was injured and was hospitalized for a night after she tried to break up a fight involving several teenagers. After The Daily News reported the closing yesterday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said, "It did seem to me that the library vastly overreacted. We've asked the Police Department to make sure that there's plenty of protection there." SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: Woman Claiming to Be a Victim of Katrina Is Charged With Fraud
description: The police arrested a Queens woman yesterday, saying she had falsely claimed to be a victim of Hurricane Katrina and had taken thousands of dollars in aid from state and federal agencies.

title: Agent asserts Moussaoui's silence aided 9/11 plotters
Personal Style, Unleashed by Divorce
description: LAURIN SYDNEY, a New York interior designer, tells the story of a recently divorced client who fell victim to a syndrome she's been observing more and more lately. The client's husband "hated floral prints," Ms. Sydney said, "so she made me turn the bedroom into a mini Versailles. They had lived in all neutral colors before the divorce. I told her he would never see it and she should do what she really liked," but the client was adamant.

title: Sonia Gandhi Steps Down as Indian Lawmaker
description: NEW DELHI, March 23 A Sonia Gandhi, the leader of India's governing Congress Party, resigned as a member of Parliament today in an attempt to defuse a dispute over claims that she had breached parliamentary rules.

title: Panel Suggests Canada Ease Telecom Restrictions
description: OTTAWA, March 22 - A Canadian government panel has called for the elimination of foreign ownership restrictions on telecommunications companies as well as the deregulation of telephone and Internet services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLUCK, A. STANLEY
description: GLUCK--A. Stanley. Beloved husband of Anita, devoted father of Freema and Sheera, father-in-law of Harris. Loving grandfather or Arielle and Gabrielle. Stanley was a man of intelligence, integrity and honor. He and Anita were supporters of many organizations including The Jewish Theological Seminary, Park Avenue Synagogue, Solomon Schecter School of Manhattan, SAR Academy, UJA, Alyn Hospital. He was affiliated with Rothschild, Inc. for more than 58 years. He went to work every day. A dedicated colleague whose leadership, guidance and strength of character will be dearly missed. Stanley was deeply devoted to his family and possessed a unique zest for life. His commitment to work and causes was an inspiration to us all. A compassionate man beloved by many. He will be greatly missed and in our hearts forever. Funeral Services will be held at 11:30 AM on March 23, 2006 at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th St, NYC.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about protests in France over a new law weakening job protection misstated the action employers would be allowed to take without cause toward new workers younger than 26 years of age. Such workers could be terminated within the first two years of employment, not laid off for two years. (Go to Article)

title: Europe, Americas, Asia
description: ASIA

title: Lynn Jennings Makes Retirement Official
description: In the 1980's and 1990's, Lynn Jennings was America's star female distance runner, winning three world cross-country championships and an Olympic bronze medal in the 10,000 meters. She has not run since 1999, but never retired. Yesterday, at age 45 and in a teleconference from her home in Portland, Ore., she finally did.

title: Iraq War Veteran Wins Congressional Primary
description: CHICAGO, March 22 - L. Tammy Duckworth, a retired Army major who lost her legs in Iraq and has the backing of some of the Democratic Party's national leaders, declared victory on Wednesday in a close Congressional primary in suburban Chicago, setting up a carefully watched race for the seat of Representative Henry J. Hyde, a Republican who is retiring after 32 years.

title: The Bespoke Computer
description: It started when I decided I needed a new high-end PC for a book I'm writing on Vista, the much-delayed next generation of the Windows operating system.

title: U.S. warning triggers Italian political rhetoric
More Setbacks at Interpublic
description: DAYS before a crucial presentation to woo Wall Street, the troubled Interpublic Group of Companies demonstrated again yesterday why that charm offensive is needed.

title: BA to alter pension plan
Parents Held in Murder of Girl, 4, Long Missing
description: The mystery surrounding the murder of Jennifer Shafiq, a 4-year-old girl from Hollis, Queens, has lingered far longer than she was even alive. But resolution may be at hand, the authorities said, after the Suffolk County police arrested her parents on Monday night at police headquarters in Sacramento, Calif.

title: Bush's Long Road Out of Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: A Basketball Lifer Who Learned to Play With Fire
description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 21 - After grabbing a rebound for Gonzaga late in a first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game against Xavier, Adam Morrison screamed. In a furor, he slammed his head against the basketball three times, an unusual way to celebrate a pivotal play in the victory.

title: No Parent Left Unheard, Klein Says
description: THE schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, under fire from some agitated middle-class parents who suspect that the school leadership is dismissive of them and their children, is extending the olive branch.

title: Court Frees Driver Who Russians Rallied Behind
description: MOSCOW, March 23 A Russians, it is fair to generalize, have become largely inured to injustices carried out by or for the powerful and the privileged. But the judicial fate of Oleg Shcherbinsky has struck a chord deep in the Russian soul, perhaps because it involved a celebrity and an ordinary guy, a car crash and the grossly unequal rules of the road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, RAYMOND J.
description: WOLF--Raymond J. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Raymond Wolf, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Sylvia, and family. Old Westbury Golf and Country Club David Simon, President Steven Tolman, Secretary

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Council Approves Its Budget
description: The City Council yesterday approved its $50.8 million operating budget for fiscal 2007, a 2.5 percent increase over the previous year. The additional money will be used to upgrade the Council's computer system, cover rent increases for Council offices, and establish Council Stat -- an initiative to analyze and respond to constituents' issues. The Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, also introduced a package of legislation intended to limit the influence of lobbyists on city government, following up on a commitment that she made last month with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to address the issue. WINNIE HU (NYT)

title: Dow Up 81, Hitting Highest Level in Nearly Five Years
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose yesterday to its highest level in almost five years as the outlook for corporate earnings improved.

title: Heilman Pitches in to Remain in Rotation
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 22 - The only time the rivalry between Aaron Heilman and Brian Bannister may become manifest is on a football field in South Bend, Ind., in the fall, and that will be the case no matter who wins the fifth spot in the Mets' rotation.

title: Barring Evidence From Torture Is Considered
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 - The Defense Department is considering a formal rule prohibiting the introduction of evidence obtained through torture at military tribunals for terror suspects detained at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, a Pentagon spokesman said Wednesday.

title: 3 to Plead Guilty in Samsung Price-Fixing Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 - Three executives of Samsung, the largest supplier of computer memory for consumer electronics, have agreed to plead guilty and serve prison sentences in the United States for their roles in a price-fixing conspiracy, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OKEN, ESTHER
description: OKEN--Esther. Wife of the late Sidney, and dear mother of Phyllis and Edwin Stein, Stuart and Geri Oken, and Sally Oken; cherished grandmother of 12 and greatgrandmother of 11. Services Friday, 10 :30 AM at Beth Moses Cemetery., Pinelawn, L.I.

title: Other Views: South China Morning Post, Irish Times, Straits Times
Briefly: Japanese exports rise, helping trade surplus
Two Yankees Linked to Balco in Book About Bonds
description: A new book that details Barry Bonds's use of performance-enhancing drugs reports that Gary Sheffield allegedly received testosterone and human growth hormone from Greg Anderson, Bonds's trainer.

title: New Studies Warn of Effects of Melting Polar Ice
description: Within the next 100 years, the growing human influence on earth's climate could lead to a long and irreversible rise in sea levels by eroding Earth's vast polar ice sheets, according to new observations and analysis by several teams of scientists.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Metro Section on March 8 profiled Donna Fenton, identifying her as a 37-year-old victim of Hurricane Katrina who had fled Biloxi, Miss., and who was frustrated in efforts to get federal aid as she and her children remained as emergency residents of a hotel in Queens.

title: Studies Suggest Avian Flu Pandemic Isn't Imminent
description: Two groups of researchers, in Japan and in Holland, say they have discovered why the avian flu virus is rarely if ever transmitted from one person to another.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Piles Up Numbers
description: For a short while, "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" had a strong hour of television -- "My Name Is Earl" and "The Office" -- leading into it on 10 p.m. on Tuesdays. But those shows were moved to Thursday nights, and "SVU" is once again NBC's only winner on Tuesdays. This week, it delivered 13.43 million in Nielsen's estimates. Earlier in NBC's night, "Most Outrageous Moments" (5.56 million), which has taken the place of the shelved flop "Joey," and two episodes of "Scrubs" (5.86 million for the new episode, 5.77 million for a repeat) rated abysmally against a two-hour "American Idol." Fox's talent show brought in 33.21 million between 8 and 10 p.m., slaughtering nearly all of its competition and giving the network another victory for the night. The only programs that managed to stand up to "Idol" were, once again, CBS's "NCIS" rerun (11.55 million) and a new episode of "The Unit" (15.27 million). CBS placed a very distant second to Fox for the night. KATE AURTHUR

title: The Two Sides Of Israel's Barrier
description: To the Editor:

title: German Leader Nears the End of Her Political Honeymoon
description: BERLIN, March 22 - Call her the emerging star of European politics, but also ask: Will Germany let it last?

title: Happy Apples
description: Q. Every year, the Macs, Galas and other apples I grow in the mid-Hudson Valley are puckered, spotted and stunted. How do I grow big, beautiful apples without using too much poison, and when do I start?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Convicted Killer Appeals
description: Five days after a judge upheld Martin H. Tankleff's convictions for the 1988 murders of his parents, his lawyers filed another appeal yesterday claiming new evidence that they say identifies the real killers. Two new witnesses said two men privately admitted their guilt, according to legal papers. A third witness claimed that a police detective in the case had lied, a charge the detective has denied. A spokesman for the Suffolk County district attorney's office, which has fought to uphold the convictions of Mr. Tankleff, above, said he had not seen the filing and did not have a comment. BRUCE LAMBERT (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Just Around the Corner: Philharmonic Music in the Parks

title: Shabazz and St. Patrick's Reign
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 22 - For the third time in four years, the girls of Malcolm X Shabazz High School of Newark reign as New Jersey state basketball champions.

title: DanceOff! in a Showcase Ranging From the Urban to the Unearthly
description: Bless Cynthia Hopkins, who almost single-handedly saved the "DanceOff!" showcase on Tuesday night at P.S. 122 from being a witless, exasperating waste of time. In an excerpt from her new "Tsimtsum," which will be performed next month in the much-anticipated "Sourcing Stravinsky" program at Dance Theater Workshop, Ms. Hopkins conjured up a bizarre but magical and profoundly human creature, part muttering street crazy and part unnerving alien, and the world around it.

title: China Raises Taxes to Curb Use of Energy and Timber
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, March 23 - The Chinese government announced plans on Wednesday to increase existing taxes and impose new ones on April 1 for everything from gas-guzzling vehicles to chopsticks in a move to rein in rising use of energy and timber and the widening gap between rich and poor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAIER, NATHAN
description: MAIER--Nathan, from Fischach, Germany, age 100, on March 21, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Ella. Loving brother, uncle, cousin and good friend. Service Thursday 1PM at the Hebrew Tabernacle, Fort Washington Ave. and 185th St., NYC.

title: Insurgents Shower Iraq Police Center With Mortar Shells
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 22 - Insurgents on Wednesday laid siege to the headquarters of a police paramilitary unit near the capital, lobbing a volley of mortar shells that killed at least one senior officer and wounded at least five, Interior Ministry officials said.

title: Microsoft's Sense of Humor
description: Well, I'll be darned.

description: To the Editor:

description: Cleaning Out AOL's Art Room

title: Bayer bids 16.3 billion for Schering
In Reversal, Graduate School Applications From Foreigners Rise
description: The number of foreign students who applied to graduate programs in American universities during the current academic year increased by 11 percent from the year before, according to a survey to be released today. That growth reverses two years of decline that occurred in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Sandwich Shop Stays, Saved by a Regular
description: "I'M a preservationist," said Josh Konecky, 52, the big guy who has been standing behind the register since last fall at Eisenberg's Sandwich Shop. Before that, he was on the other side of the marble counter, on one of the 23 turn-stools, a regular with such a taste for old New York that he wanted to eat it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUEHNS, BONNIE JEAN
description: KUEHNS -- Bonnie Jean, passed away on Sunday, March 19. A member of the American Association for Mental Health Counselors, Bonnie was a Psychotherapist in private practice in Manhattan, NY. Services will be held Friday, March 24, 24PM & 6-9PM at the Glackin/ Saul Funeral Home, Hightstown, NJ 609-448-1801.

title: Panel Advises Disclosure of Drugs' Psychotic Effects
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., March 22  Stimulants like Ritalin lead a small number of children to suffer hallucinations that usually feature insects, snakes or worms, according to federal drug officials, and a panel of experts said on Wednesday that physicians and parents needed to be warned of the risk.

title: French protests turn violent
Philip Bowring: Neighborly talk in South Asia
The Joy of Being Blameless
description: The contrast could not have been more stark, nor the message more clear. On the day that a court-martial imposed justice on a 24-year-old Army sergeant for tormenting detainees at Abu Ghraib with his dog, President Bush said once again that Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, whose benighted policies and managerial incompetence led to the prisoner abuse scandal, was doing a "fine job" and should stay at his post.

title: Making the most of the euro
Where Even Grisly News Can Offer a Kind of Comfort
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 19 - As a military band played a dirge, the coffins that flowed out of Beirut's central military hospital on Saturday morning put some lingering questions to rest, but raised many others.

title: Microsoft Offers to Assist Rivals
description: BRUSSELS, March 22 - Microsoft offered on Wednesday to give rival software companies unlimited technical support to help them develop programs that work smoothly with the Windows operating system, the company's latest effort to comply with a European Commission order and avoid daily fines of up to 2 million euros ($2.4 million).

title: American B Team Gets an F in Germany
description: DORTMUND, Germany, March 22 - A second-tier American team left German fans in a first-rate tirade at halftime of Wednesday's friendly, which, to that point, lacked both goals and any signs of artfulness.

title: Times Company Reports Mixed Ad Results
description: The New York Times Company offered a forecast for its first quarter yesterday and reported a mixed performance for advertising in February.

title: A Weapon of Self-Destruction for Buyers
description: IN the Container Store universe linens are stored in acid-free tissue, and kitchen drawers are lined with lavender-scented paper. Cupcakes are toted to school in individual cupcake-shaped plastic containers, and quarters at the laundry are dispensed two at a time from a quarter-shaped holder.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 22, 2006

title: Military raid frees Western hostages in Iraq
Newspeak From Ashcroft
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncertainty Deepens on Fate of Times Researcher
description: BEIJING, March 23 A The United States government today continued to press China about the status of a jailed researcher for The New York Times, but the uncertainty about his fate deepened as a Chinese government spokesman appeared to cast doubt on whether the researcher would soon be released.

title: Bush's Long Road Out of Iraq
description: To the Editor:

Bouncer Indicted for Murder in High-Profile Rape and Strangling
