title: Panel Urges Lowering of Allowable Fluoride
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  High concentrations of fluoride that occur naturally in a small minority of the nation's drinking water supplies can damage teeth and bones, and federal regulators should reduce the level that is considered safe for human consumption, a National Academy of Sciences panel said Wednesday.

title: Who Will Work the Farms?
description: KINSTON, N.C. - In the plainspoken manner common to her fellow farmers, Faylene Whitaker has a message for members of Congress struggling to overhaul the nation's immigration law.

title: G.M. Sells 78% Stake in Mortgage Unit
description: DETROIT, March 23 A General Motors said today that it had sold a 78 percent stake in its commercial mortgage operation to an investor group for $8.8 billion, the latest move in the struggling automaker's efforts to raise cash.

title: Iraq Abuse Trial Is Again Limited to Lower Ranks
World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airline Says Profit Rose 12 Percent Last Year
description: The German airline Deutsche Lufthansa reported higher 2005 profit and said it would raise its dividend for the year. Lufthansa said its 2005 net profit rose 12 percent, to 453 million euros ($547 million) from 404 million euros in 2004, while operating profit rose 51 percent, to 577 million euros from 383 million euros. Lufthansa, which will report complete 2005 figures today, did not provide details as to how it achieved the positive results. The airline said earlier this year, however, that its passenger traffic had increased, especially toward the end of 2005. Lufthansa said it planned to raise its dividend 67 percent, to 0.50 euros, from 0.30 euros a share.

title: Case of wronged driver takes a turn
U.S. Indicts 50 Leaders of Colombian Rebels in Cocaine Trafficking
description: BOGOT, Colombia, March 22 - A federal grand jury in Washington has indicted 50 commanders of Colombia's largest Marxist rebel group, accusing them of running an extensive cocaine trafficking cartel that protects its operations through widespread killings and intimidation, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales announced Wednesday.

title: 'Bring 'Em Home Now' Concert: Music's Power of Protest
description: Do you enjoy music? Do you like music? In the film "V for Vendetta," those two rather ordinary questions are an incitement to revolutionary violence. The first comes near the beginning: the masked man named V, played by Hugo Weaving, has just met Evey Hammond, played by Natalie Portman, and this is evidently his idea of a pick-up line. "Do you enjoy music, Evey?," he asks, continuing, "I am a musician, of sorts." And soon Tchaikovsky's "1812 Overture" blasts out of London's loudspeakers, accompanied by an impressive rhythm section: an exploding building. This is protest music at its most spectacular -- sound as action.

title: Bloom may be off rose for the LSE deal
Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, PHILIP
description: SCHNEIDER - Philip. Great Neck. Beloved husband of Sandra. Father of Gail, Aaron, Perry, Charlotte, Yola. Grandfather of Shira, Gary, Elana, Avi, David, Lauren, Heather and four great grandchildren. U. of Wisconsin graduate, U.S. Army Purple Heart, ZOA lifetime member. Sinai Chapels, 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Queens, Thursday 12:15.

title: French unit of Liberty to be sold
Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARZ, DONALD K.
description: SCHWARZ -- Donald K. Passed away peacefully on March 22, 2006. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father of Naomi and Ruthe. Devoted uncle of Harriet. Grandfather of three. Uncle, great-uncle and great-greatuncle of many. A man of wisdom and gentle humor. We will miss him. Funeral service Friday, 12:15 PM, Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REIS, MARIAN
description: REIS--Marian, 96. March 22, 2006. Born in Vienna. Loving mother of Monica (Peter) de Janosi. Devoted grandmother of Paul (Lydie), Nicholas, Alexander (Amber). Greatgrandmother of Max and Evan. She will be missed.

title: A 25 Pedestrian Rest Stop, but Wait, It's a Model
description: The door to the stainless-steel box slides open, and one of New York City's more closely guarded secrets is revealed -- a self-cleaning pay toilet that will soon be coming to city streets.

title: The Search for Grown-Up Pants
description: MY daughter asked if I knew that open house started at her high school in half an hour, and what was I going to wear?

title: Correction
description: Last Sunday, I wrote that Plato used the word "eros" to signify the appetitive part of the soul. This isn't the first time I've been led astray by the power of eros. The correct word is "epithymia."

title: Benefit With a Twist: Own a Miniature Gehry
description: If a Frank Gehry-designed home is not in your budget, how about a cast bronze object by the celebrated architect that resembles a stacked helix of cut-out shapes? The Frostig Center, in Pasadena, Calif., which helps children with learning disabilities like dyslexia and mild autism, is selling the Gehry creation as part of its annual fund-raising drive, along with work by the artists Robert Graham and R. Kenton Nelson. Mr. Gehry made the object, which resembles his signature twisted skyscrapers, at the center's request. The edition of 200 costs $2,500 for numbers 1-50 and $3,200 for numbers 51-200 at thefrostigcollection.org CURRENTS: LOS ANGELES -- SCULPTURE

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "They may attack and beat us and inflict great trauma. But we have already achieved a result: we have shown our country that we are not afraid to stand against arbitrary rule."

title: Basque Fighters Set a Cease-Fire After Four Decades
description: SEVILLE, Spain, March 22 - The militant Basque separatist group ETA, which has killed more than 800 people and terrorized Spanish society for nearly 40 years, on Wednesday announced a permanent cease-fire, saying that it would turn its attention to achieving independence for the Basque region of Spain through politics.

title: Bush's Long Road Out of Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Killed, 20 Injured in Mudslide at Indonesian Mine
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 23 A Three people were killed and more than 20 injured when a wall of mud ripped through a cafeteria operated by the American mining company Freeport-McMoRan on the remote province of Papua, company and Indonesian officials said today.

title: Campaign Ad Attacks Wiretapping
description: Sean P. Maloney, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for attorney general, will begin broadcasting campaign television commercials today that take on the Bush administration's domestic eavesdropping program.

title: The International Traveler: Making sure your bag arrives, too
Citing friction, Japan freezes yen loans to China
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: In Sweeping Deal With Union, G.M. Offers Buyout Packages to Workers General Motors reached a landmark agreement with the United Automobile Workers intended to sharply reduce the ranks of an entire generation of autoworkers long envied by other blue-collar workers for their rich wages and benefits. G.M. said it would offer buyouts and early retirement packages -- ranging from $35,000 to $140,000 -- to every one of its 113,000 unionized workers in the United States who agrees to leave the company. [Page A1.]

title: 12 U.S. tourists on cruise are killed in bus crash
KPMG Revises Settlement on Tax Shelters
description: The accounting firm KPMG said yesterday that it had reached a revised settlement with tax shelter investors, but warned that the reduced agreement could still fall apart.

title: Diamond Jack Takes Center Stage Down Under
description: Australia is a popular place for bridge. There is always a convivial atmosphere. Even in a regular club duplicate, the boards are preduplicated, and you receive a printed copy of them afterward. And usually bidding is carried out by writing on a pad in the center (or should that be centre?) of the table. Even more foreigners would attend Australia's major tournaments if the country were not so far away.

title: New York Transit Contract Dispute Is Sent to Arbitration
description: Over the objection of the union that represents New York City's subway and bus workers, a state agency voted today to send the transit workers' contract dispute with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority into binding arbitration.

title: Papua refugees get Australian visas
'Bush Wars,' a Satirical Revue With an Agenda
description: Rick Meyerowitz, who drew for the 1970's-era National Lampoon, provides the program illustration for "Bush Wars," a satirical revue of song parodies and sketches conceived by Jim Russek and written by Nancy Holson. His drawing, a parody of the Al Hirschfeld illustration for "My Fair Lady," depicts a puppet master manipulating a marionette, but in this case, Dick Cheney, not Henry Higgins, holds the strings while George W. Bush instead of Eliza Doolittle does the dancing.

title: A Coyote Leads a Crowd on a Central Park Marathon
description: A coyote's romp in Central Park ended yesterday with a tranquilizer dart and a nap, but only after a messy breakfast (hold the feathers), a dip in a chilly pond and a sprint past a skating rink-turned-movie set.

title: Corzine Asks New Jersey to Bite a Fiscal Bullet
description: TRENTON, March 22 - Gov. Jon S. Corzine stormed into the State House in January with a financial background that, to many voters, suggested that Mr. Corzine could be New Jersey's swashbuckling fiscal savior -- an image that the new governor did little to deflect.

title: Another French exception: A rigid employment code
ICP Orchestra's Experimental Jazz Swings at Tonic
description: For the first 10 minutes of the ICP Orchestra's early set at Tonic on Tuesday night, the pianist Misha Mengelberg and the drummer Han Bennink indulged in an improvised duet, something they have been doing together for roughly 40 years. Their styles were complementary, if a bit bizarrely so. Mr. Mengelberg gave the impression of a man groping for the doorknob in a darkened room. Mr. Bennink occupied the same room, but with a different temperament, impatiently and heedlessly knocking things around.

title: Hollywood takes new tack against film piracy
Bush's Long Road Out of Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense Tries to Raise Doubts About Enron's Ex-Treasurer
description: HOUSTON, March 23 A Defense lawyers began an aggressive cross-examination of Enron's former treasurer today in attempt to show the tough tactics used by the government to induce cooperative testimony from a lower-level officer against the failed energy company's onetime top executives.

title: Forensic Evidence Credited in Murder Indictment
description: Even though the police have yet to determine exactly where Imette St. Guillen was killed last month, the Brooklyn district attorney and the police commissioner said today that a grand jury had indicted Darryl Littlejohn on murder charges on the strength of forensic evidence that ties the former bouncer to the young woman.

title: Giving Old Stereo Headphones a New Lease on Life in a Surround-Sound World
description: Headphones that let you hear surround sound have been around for a few years. But what if you want to hear surround sound through the stereo headphones you already own?

title: Soccer: Chelsea reach FA Cup semifinals
Bush Pressing the Iraqis to Build a Governing Coalition Quickly
description: WHEELING, W.Va., March 22 - President Bush took his campaign to convince Americans that the United States is winning the war in Iraq to a former country music concert hall here on Wednesday and declared to applause, "If I didn't think we'd succeed, I'd pull our troops out."

title: Jets Take a Pass on Whether Pennington Is Throwing
description: While the Jets have been retooling their roster, their off-season program began this week, with quarterback Chad Pennington returning to New York to continue his rehabilitation from shoulder surgery, General Manager Mike Tannenbaum said yesterday.

title: People: Camilla Parker Bowles, Steven Tyler, Fred Savage
State Department computer purchase from China draws fire
Are Late Innings the Time for a Relief Pitcher?
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 - President Bush's suggestion on Tuesday that he may add a new senior figure to his White House team raised questions about the future of two of his closest and most powerful aides, Andrew H. Card Jr. and Karl Rove, as they struggle to put Mr. Bush's White House back on course.

title: P.L.O. Rejects Proposed Platform of Hamas, Now Set to Take Power
description: JERUSALEM, March 22 - The Palestine Liberation Organization on Wednesday rejected the proposed platform of the militant Islamic group Hamas, reflecting the internal Palestinian political tensions as Hamas prepares to assume power.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the gentrification of the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood in Manhattan listed a celebrity erroneously among those who have lived in Manhattan Plaza, a government-subsidized rental complex that opened in 1977 largely for tenants in the performing arts. The saxophonist John Coltrane, who died in 1967, was not a tenant.

title: Adding Injury to Insult, Frye Is Lost for the Season
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 22 - Channing Frye leaves the Knicks' season just as he entered it, as the brightest source of optimism on a bleak gray canvas. But even symbols of hope are not immune to the franchise's toxic malaise.

title: Thomas Lee Steps Down From His Namesake Firm
description: Thomas H. Lee, the colorful financier who founded the buyout firm Thomas H. Lee Partners, said yesterday that he had stepped down from the firm as part of a long-arranged succession plan and would seek new opportunities in private equity and hedge funds.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: American Held In 2 Capital Blasts
description: The police arrested an American and his Uruguayan girlfriend and accused them of detonating bombs at two low-budget hotels in La Paz, the capital, overnight that killed two people and injured several others. President Evo Morales initially blamed terrorists for the bombings, but the authorities later said it appeared that the American, identified as Claudio Lestad, 24, of New Orleans, was an unstable drifter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHULMAN, DR. KENNETH
description: SHULMAN--Dr. Kenneth. Neurosurgeon. 1928-1981. In Remembrance. A cello is playing Bach Partitas for you today. Jeanie, Michael and Daniel

title: SAT Problems Even Larger Than Reported
description: Correction Appended

title: They Keep Killing Steve Buscemi, but He's Not Complaining
description: Directors adore Steve Buscemi. They lavish him with great roles, stellar dialogue, generous screen time, and then -- and there is no nice way to say this -- they generally bump him off.

title: Adopted in China, Seeking Identity in America
description: Correction Appended

title: Family Recalls 2-Week Ordeal in Mountains
description: For Pete Stivers and his family, it was just supposed to be an overnight trip to the Pacific Coast.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Workers Reject Pay Freeze
description: The union representing 28,000 doormen, janitors and other service workers at 3,500 apartment buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens rejected yesterday the building owners' demand that workers accept a one-year pay freeze and pay 15 percent of their health premiums. The Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, which represents building owners and managers, said a pay freeze was warranted because owners have already agreed to pay more for health coverage and because they are also being squeezed by higher taxes and energy costs. The building workers pay nothing toward their health premiums, which total around $10,000 per year per worker. The union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, has threatened a strike on April 21 if no agreement is reached by then. STEVEN GREENHOUSE (NYT)

title: Bernard Lacoste, Executive and Fashion Entrepreneur, Is Dead at 74
description: Bernard Lacoste, who inherited the Lacoste fashion company from his father, the French tennis champion Ren Lacoste, and directed its international expansion into a billion-dollar company recognizable by its signature crocodile logo, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Paris. He was 74.

title: City Opera in Adamo's 'Lysistrata,' About Making Love, Not War
description: In choosing classic works of literature as subjects for operas, many composers have been too deferential to their sources. Mark Adamo does not make that mistake in "Lysistrata, or the Nude Goddess," which received its premiere at the Houston Grand Opera last year and opened at the New York City Opera on Tuesday night.

title: At a Screening of a Comedy Thriller About Revenge
description: Bruce Willis and Sylvia Plath: Their Shared Secret Crush!

title: Lawyer for Earlier Witness Testifies for Prosecution
description: Thus far, the witnesses at the trial of two retired detectives accused of killing for the mob have included an old marijuana dealer, a murderous mob boss, a suntanned C.P.A. and a grieving Brooklyn mother whose son was mistakenly shot outside her house one Christmas Day.

title: Attack on Iraqi police unit kills at least 25
From the Landscape, Into the Air: A Gardener Tends the Indoors
description: Kevin Inkawhich, a landscape gardener, collects materials wherever he roams -- shiva seeds from India, for example, or red pine from the Adirondacks -- and fashions them into bespoke botanical mobiles that bring the outdoors in. One design, called Kookums, above ($2,500), features delicate, crinkly eucalyptus leaves painted shades of pink, yellow and blue. Jason Martin, co-owner of Silho Furniture, which sells the mobiles (for $850 to $4,300), said they work as a natural counterpoint in any contemporary space. For Mr. Inkawhich, 43, his creations, whether made from pine cones or camellia leaves, "are about beauty defying old age." Available at silhofurniture.com; Kevin Inkawhich, (310) 993-5559. KATHRYN HARRIS CURRENTS: LOS ANGELES -- MOBILES

title: Cuba on the West Bank
description: Jerusalem - FOR two months, the world has dithered over how to get a Palestinian authority run by Hamas to recognize Israel and renounce violence, and over how much aid and official contact to maintain until it does. The diplomats' refrain was that once Hamas appointed a cabinet, things would be clearer.

title: World Briefing: Americas, Asia, Africa, Middle East and Europe
description: AMERICAS

title: Bush pushes hard for India deal
Paid Notice: Memorials   FISHER, GRACE
description: FISHER--Grace. You're still sitting there on my shoulder, telling me to be happy and where the salad fork goes. I love you and miss you. Happy Anniversary. Monte

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,312 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Violence in Halabja
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq Abuse Trial Is Again Limited to Lower Ranks
description: Correction Appended

title: James Bai's 'Puzzlehead' Depicts a Love Triangle With a Twist
description: "Puzzlehead" plays out in a bleak and barren future where people have become so scarce that the only permissible use of technology is for repopulation. Fudging this rule somewhat, a lonely scientist builds a robot companion, an exact likeness of himself down to the bouffant hairstyle and lovelorn memories (Stephen Galaida plays both roles). He calls his creation Puzzlehead and trains him to play chess, clean house and spy on Julia (Robbie Shapiro), the pale, jittery salesgirl whom the scientist has been secretly coveting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEICH, SEYMOUR J.
description: TEICH -- Seymour J. The Board of Governors and members of the Elberon Bathing Club mourn the passing of our longtime member and friend. Our deepest sympathies to his family. Robert Fagenson, President

title: TechBrief: Siemens selling last of Infineon holdings
Allies Troubled by Afghan Threat to Christian Convert From Islam
description: The case of an Afghan man who could face the death penalty in his country for converting to Christianity from Islam has prompted a swift international outcry. President Bush said yesterday that he was "deeply troubled," and leaders of three other nations with troops in Afghanistan also voiced objections.

title: Common Sense in Maryland
description: Diebold, the electronic voting machine maker, suffered another sharp setback recently, when Maryland's House of Delegates voted 137-to-0 to drop its machines and switch to paper ballots. The vote came in the same week that Texas held elections marred by electronic voting troubles. Maryland's State Senate should join the House in voting to discontinue the use of the Diebold machines, and other states should follow Maryland's lead.

title: Anti-Semitism at ground level in France
Reinhold E. Rau, Taxidermist on a Quest, Dies
description: Reinhold E. Rau, a taxidermist who spent three decades pursuing his dream of breeding an extinct zebra back into existence and nearly achieved it, died last month at his home in South Africa. He was in his mid-70's.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about a loss of cachet for luxury sport utility vehicles misidentified the full-size S.U.V. made by Lincoln. It is the Navigator; the Escalade is made by Cadillac.

title: Different Drug Often Works in Depression, Study Finds
description: Some people with depression who do not recover with an initial course of antidepressant therapy can increase their chances of finding relief by trying other drug treatments, researchers are reporting today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASSINI, OLEG
description: CASSINI--Oleg passed March 17, 2006 in Long Island. Born on April 11, 1913 in Paris, France to the Count and Countess Loiewski-Cassini. Oleg Cassini has received countless awards and accolades for his beautiful and romantic collections and for bringing American fashion to the world stage with his work for the First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy, and many glamorous film stars including Kim Bassinger, Grace Kelly (to whom he was engaged), and Gene Tierney (his former wife). He is survived by his loving wife Marianne, president of Oleg Cassini, Inc. (a former fashion model and cover girl), and daughters Daria and Christina, grandchildren Jasmina, Sedric, Alexander, Delphina; nieces Marina, Lee, Conner, Diana, Daniella; nephews Alexander, Nicholas, Demitri, Robbie, Brendan-Oleg, Sean, Robert, James, Michael; and all his beloved animals. Oleg is recognized as a great humanitarian by the Humane Society of the United States and was awarded his own charity C.A.R.E. by the Humane Society. The wake will be held on Wednesday, March 22, 2006 from 5PM to 8PM at the Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NY, NY 10028. A Funeral Mass will be said on Thursday, March 23, 2006 at 11AM, Our Lady of the Sign-Russian Orthodox Church of America, 75 E. 93 St, NY, NY 10028. 212534-1601. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Oleg Cassini C.A.R.E., "Cassini Animal Rescue", The Humane Society of the United States.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Adviser Hired in Bid for 12 Knight Ridder Papers
description: The Yucaipa Companies, a buyout firm based in Los Angeles, has hired a former publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Robert J. Hall, to advise the private equity company on its bid for 12 Knight Ridder newspapers.

title: Sovereign Bank Settles Dispute With Shareholder
description: Sovereign Bancorp and its largest shareholder, Relational Investors, agreed last night to settle a legal dispute and a proxy battle that had gone on for about five months.

title: Tee-Hee T.V.
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Perfect Portraiture
description: Beneath the surface of Ingres's supernatural skill and imperious authority is art that is curiously touching.

title: Cruise-Mania at Yahoo
description: Some of us here at DealBook had the naive notion that movie stars would not be a big draw in tech-savvy places like Palo Alto and Cupertino, Calif., when silicon and smarts are worshipped above all else.

title: Dimon: Itching For a Fight?
description: Jamie Dimon does not hide his desire to serve payback on Citigroup, where he was ousted in 1998 after falling out with his former mentor, Sandy Weill. Now that Mr. Dimon has risen to the C.E.O. position at J.P. Morgan Chase and Mr. Weill is stepping down as Citigroups chairman, Mr. Dimon may have the perfect platform from which to try.

title: Centeris Raises Series B Round
description: Centeris, a software maker that integrates Linux servers in a Microsoft Windows network, said its raised $11.5 million in Series B financing. Participating venture capital companies included Trinity Ventures of Menlo Park, Calif., Intel Capital of Santa Clara, Calif., and Ignition Partners of Bellevue, Wash.

title: Koomkin Pays $7.2 Billion for Korea Exchange Bank Stake
description: Kookmin Bank, South Koreas biggest lender, has agreed to pay 7 trillion won ($7.2 billion) for a controlling stake in Korea Exchange Bank to secure its dominance in Asias third-largest economy.

title: Betting on a Bristol-Myers Takeover
description: Bristol-Myers Squibbs proposed settlement over its Plavix blood-thinning drug would remove a major obstacle to a takeover of the drugmaker, but such a deal would be far from guaranteed, analysts said on Wednesday.

title: Prudential Shareholders Seek Meeting With CEO
description: Prudentials biggest shareholders have called Mark Tucker, the chief executive, to a second round of meetings, after hearing Avivas case for a 17 billion pound merger of Britains two biggest insurers.

title: An IMAX Sale Could Be Cure for What Ails Movie Industry
description: Will anyone snap up IMAX, which put itself in play earlier this month? With the movie industry mired in a slump, many analysts think that the only way studios can get more sedentary cinephiles to leave the comfort of their couch is to offer a truly wowing experience.

title: Dell to Buy Alienware, a Maker of High-End PCs for Gamers
description: Dell said on Wednesday that it would buy the Alienware Corporation, whose high-end PCs are widely acclaimed by video gamers for their fast performance and sleek, U.F.O.-themed looks. Dell did not announce terms of the deal, which will help expand its offerings for the lucrative gaming and multimedia market.

title: Switchmaker Avocent Picks Up Agilent Unit
description: Switchmaker Avocent agreed to buy Agilent Technologies remote management business assets. Terms were not disclosed, but Avocent said it would get assets including integrated remote management chips and cards, and software utilities.

title: Sage of Britain Buys Norwegian Company
description: Sage Group, the British software company, has embarked on its biggest acquisition with a 334 million pound agreed offer for the Norwegian software and accounting firm Visma. The deal marks Sages first move into the Scandinavian market, and chief executive Paul Walker said he sees more takeover opportunities in the region.

title: Hollywood P.R. Firm in Bid for Freedom
description: A high-powered Hollywood public relations firm wants to buy back its freedom from its parent company, beleaguered ad giant Interpublic Group, according to The New York Post.

title: British Government Plans 50 Billion Sale of National Assets
description: The British government is to sell off assets including most of the state-owned nuclear industry, the Tote, public spectrum airwaves and Ministry of Defense firing ranges as part of plans which could raise up to 50 billion pounds for public spending.

title: Schering Prepares for Battle With Merck of Germany
description: Schering is devising a strategy to battle Merck KGaAs 14.6 billion euro ($17.7 billion) hostile offer but may have trouble competing with the 24 percent premium offered to shareholders. To that end, the company has tapped Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein and Morgan Stanley to prepare a strategy.

title: Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch in Legal Spat Over Retail Hires
description: Morgan Stanleys retail unit, which is now undergoing an extensive overhaul under its new head, James P. Gorman, experienced a particularly tough quarter. And while the presence of Mr. Gorman has helped stem stockbroker departures, his aggressive recruiting posture has drawn a stiff legal reaction from Merrill Lynch, Mr. Gormans former firm.

title: Ferrovial Given Deadline to Make an Offer for BAA
description: Grupo Ferrovial of Spain has been given one month to initiate a formal 9 billion pound bid for BAA, the owner of Heathrow airport, before being forced to abandon its acquisition hopes.

title: Bertelsmann Weighs Decision on an I.P.O.
description: The most talked-about suspense story at Bertelsmann, the global media empire and publisher of Dan Browns thriller The Da Vinci Code, continues to be its own.

title: Blank Check Companies Are On the Rise
description: Blank check companies, publicly held companies are created for the sole purpose of making acquisitions, are back. While still a small percentage of the total I.P.O. market, these deals are unquestionably on the rise.

title: Shanghai Prime Machinery Plans I.P.O.
description: Shanghai Prime Machinery has started to market an initial public offering that is expected to raise between $150 million and $175 million. It plans to list on Hong Kongs main board toward the end of April.

title: Nextest Systems Climbs on Debut
description: Nextest Systems gained in its stock market debut on Wednesday despite an overall downdraft in the technology sector. Shares of Nextest Systems rose $3.10, or 22.1 percent, to close at $17.10.

title: Mysterious Metaweb Raises $15 Million
description: Metaweb Technologies, a secretive San Francisco start-up, raised $15 million in a funding round led by Benchmark Capital, with participation from other investors, including Millennium Technology Ventures and the Omidyar Network, a mission-based investment group established in June 2004 by eBays founder, Pierre Omidyar.

title: Thomas Lee Steps Down From His Namesake Firm
description: Thomas H. Lee, the colorful financier who founded the buyout firm Thomas H. Lee Partners, said Wednesday that he had stepped down from the firm as part of a long-arranged succession plan and would seek new opportunities in private equity and hedge funds.

title: Texas Pacific and Cerberus in Push for Jones Apparel
description: Theres a fresh for sale sign hanging on Jones Apparel Groups door, and two aggressive private equity firms seem to be the ones knocking the loudest.

title: Donation Legislation  Could Cut Off Soros Cash for Democrats
description: House Democrats may have to pay a steep price to enact legislation overhauling lobbying rules: agreeing to restrict donations by some of their biggest backers.

title: Survey: Hedge Fund Investment to Grow 28% in 2006
description: Hedge fund investors expect the amount they put in to such funds to increase by 28 percent this year, according to a survey by Goldman Sachs. Global macro and equity long-short strategies are expected to see the greatest increase in capital allocation by asset weight, the study found.

title: Training Iraqi Security Forces
description: Three years after the invasion of Iraq, American troops are no longer simply teaching counterinsurgency techniques; they are trying to school the Iraqis in battling a Sunni-led rebellion without resorting to the tactics of a "dirty war," involving abductions, torture and murder.

title: Kesa of Britain Defends Private-Equity Snub
description: Kesa, the electrical goods retailer that owns Comet, has insisted it was right to reject a private-equity bid from Permira and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts , as it reported a slump in profits.

title: Jury Is Told Lay Lied on Enron
description: In seven weeks of court testimony, prosecutors landed only glancing blows against Kenneth L. Lay, a former chief executive of Enron who is on trial for criminal conspiracy and fraud. Mr. Lays luck may have run out in Week 8.

title: 3 Samsung Executives  to Plead Guilty in  Price-Fixing Case
description: Three executives of Samsung, the largest supplier of computer memory for consumer electronics, have agreed to plead guilty and serve prison sentences in the United States for their roles in a price-fixing conspiracy, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.

title: KPMG Revises Settlement on Tax Shelters
description: The accounting firm KPMG said Wednesday that it had reached a revised settlement with tax shelter investors, but warned that the reduced agreement could still fall apart.

title: Sovereign Bank Settles Dispute With Shareholder
description: Sovereign Bancorp and its largest shareholder, Relational Investors, agreed last night to settle a legal dispute and a proxy battle that had gone on for about five months.

title: Britain Plans Crackdown on Tax-Avoidance Schemes
description: Hedge funds and other London firms that pay out eye-watering bonuses to their star traders may be targets of the British government in an assault on tax-avoidance schemes.

title: Social Advocates Take a Page Out of Venture Capitals Book
description: Venture capitalists usually have a simple goal  make money  but byproducts of their investments often include job creation and an improved climate for entrepreneurs.

title: Panel Suggests Canada Ease Telecom Restrictions
description: A Canadian government panel has called for the elimination of foreign ownership restrictions on telecommunications companies as well as the deregulation of telephone and Internet services.

title: Rich CEO Pay Packages Just Get Richer
description: We are still in the early stages of proxy season, when compensation information appears in print, but a few trends are emerging. Some companies that once offered a slew of stock options are shifting to awards of restricted stock now that stock-option awards are being counted as expenses. Some of that restricted stock comes with strings attached, requiring the company to reach performance goals.

title: Financial Chief Quits Freddie Mac
description: Freddie Mac, the mortgage financing company, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Martin F. Baumann, had resigned.

title: Seeking to Mollify Europe, Microsoft Offers to Assist Rivals
description: Microsoft offered on Wednesday to give rival software companies unlimited technical support to help them develop programs that work smoothly with the Windows operating system, the companys latest effort to comply with a European Commission order and avoid daily fines of up to 2 million euros ($2.4 million).

title: M.I.T. Hires a Yale Director to Manage Investments
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has hired a director of Yale Universitys investment office as the new manager of its endowment, replacing Allan Bufferd, who has managed the fund for nearly two decades. Seth Alexander will become president of MIT Investment Management Company in May after a 10-year stint at Yale. He has particular expertise in marketable securities, timber, asset allocation hedge funds and international investments.

title: G.M. to Offer Buyouts to Workers
description: General Motors reached a landmark agreement Wednesday with the United Automobile Workers intended to reduce sharply the ranks of a generation of auto workers long envied by other blue-collar workers for their wages and benefits.

title: N.Y.S.E. Hybrid Gets Green Light
description: The New York Stock Exchange won the Securities and Exchange Commissions blessing to embark on the biggest overhaul of its trading system in three decades. The New York exchanges so-called hybrid market will combine traditional floor-based haggling with the speed of electronic trading.

title: Tim Hortons Is Set for Friday Debut
description: Wendys is set to spin off 15 percent of Tim Hortons, its Canadian doughnut chain named after a former NHL star. The shares are expected to price Thursday night and trade Friday under the ticker THI. Given all the excitement about the IPO, they could quickly get expensive.

title: Strategic Buyers: Theyre Baaack
description: Ebullient investment bankers, still celebrating a bumper year of merger activity in 2005 when deals worth some $1.1 trillion were completed in the United States alone, are sanguine that 2006 will generate even bigger advisory fees as the M&A wave gathers strength. A key reason for their optimism is the anticipation that corporate buyers will finally rejoin the party.

title: When Good Investment Deals Go Bad
description: For entrepreneurs and their start-ups money can come at a high price. The biggest problems, legal and financial specialists say, are deals that excessively dilute managements holdings in the company or require the company to cede too much control to the investor.

title: S.E.C. Fines Boston Capital $1.2 Million
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. has fined Boston Capital Securities $1.2 million for offering tax-advantaged limited partnerships in 2004 without getting approval from the association, and for inadequately supervising a 2002 public securities offering.

title: Deutsche Chief Executive Gets a Raise
description: Deutsche Bank  raised the pay of its chief executive, Josef Ackermann, 18 percent last year after profit rose to the highest since 2000. He received total compensation of 11.9 million euros ($14.4 million).

title: Business Meetings in a Strip Club?
description: Wearing a scanty blue gown with rhinestone clasps, Nicolette Hart explains how she can make up to $2,500 a night with investment bankers and their clients in a Manhattan strip clubs private rooms. Hart, who once worked for a venture-capital firm, always asks what brought the men together. They often say theyre having a meeting.

title: American Stock Exchange Ponders I.P.O.
description: The member-owned American Stock Exchange plans to become a for-profit company by next year, in preparation for possibly becoming a publicly traded company, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Selborne Journal: 23 March 1759:  Planted 4 of the double-Briars in the new-Garden against the street, & one in the front of the House; & the two long Lathyrus-roots against the apple-tree next Parsonss. Grubbd the orchard-walk, & planted it with Holy-oaks, & Wall-flowers. Potted some sweet-Williams. Removed the double jonquils, out of the orchard, under Lassams hedge.

title: Liberty Global to Sell French Cable Assets for $1.5 Billion
description: Liberty Global, a spinoff of John Malones cable empire, has agreed to sell its French unit for 1.25 billion euros ($1.51 billion) as it continues to shuffle its European holdings. Private equity firm Cinven and a cable company it controls, Altice, will acquire the business, which is called UPC France.

title: GMAC Sells Mortgage Unit to Buyout Group in $9 Billion Deal
description: General Motors announced that it sold a majority stake in the real-estate unit of its financing arm, General Motors Acceptance Corp., for $1.5 billion in cash. The buyer is a private equity group led by affiliates of Kohlberg Kravis Roberst & Co., Five Mile Capital Partners and Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, G.M. said.

title: Brick Towers
description: Brick Towers in Newark's Central Ward.

title: Roundup
description: The Sharpe James ticket is shrinking. Donald Payne Jr., an Essex County freeholder and the son of Newarks long-time United States Representative Donald Payne Sr., has abandoned the mayors slate and decided to run for the Municipal Council on his own. That means he wont have access to the $1.9 million that Mayor James has already raised for himself and his team of candidates. It also means he doesnt have to wait and wonder whether the mayor is in this race all the way.

title: When Dissent Goes AWOL
Ask Science
description: Benedict Carey answered reader questions about his article "Revisiting Schizophrenia: Are Drugs Always Needed?" from this week's Science Times.

title: First Debate  Almost
description: (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

title: Delphi Shareholders Get a Voice Thanks to an Activist Hedge Fund
description: Hedge fund Appaloosa Management has won its fight to form an official committee to represent shareholders of Delphi, the bankrupt auto-parts manufacturer once owned by General Motors.

title: Was Bushs Case for W.M.D. Solid?
description: Was President Bush right to use the threat of weapons of mass destruction as the basis for his public case for the invasion of Iraq?

title: Food for Thought
description: Id like to use this blog occasionally to discuss food-related books: not so much recipe collections or chef autobiographies, though I dont rule those out, as books that celebrate the love of food in other ways, sometimes even indirectly. I hope that by mentioning certain books Ill also elicit recommendations from people who post comments on this site.

title: The Real Budget Crunchers
description: Recently, there has been some discussion on the blogs about growth of the federal budget deficit under President Bush and what measures would be necessary to balance the budget without raising taxes. When I thought this matter through a few years ago, I concluded that it was impossible to cut spending enough to avoid a major tax increase. Moreover, I concluded that the magnitude of the tax increase was so great that it could only be achieved by adding a significant new revenue source  a value-added tax, or V.A.T.  to the federal tax system on top of all the other taxes. Today, I would like to walk people through the data sources so that they can draw their own conclusions about what needs to be done and what might be possible.

title: Analysts Warm to Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley felt the love from research analysts on Thursday, as three brokerages raised their stock-price targets or earnings forecasts for the securities firm. At SquawkBlog, though, things were not so upbeat. The blog, run by CNBC, berated Morgan Stanley over its investment banking business.

title: Live From Your Kitchen!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: How to Save Time Warner, Revisited
description: Carl Icahn wanted to carve it up into four pieces, but Business 2.0 editor-at-large Erick Schonfeld has a different prescription for what ails Time Warner. (Apparently it does not involve hiring Lazard or holding a press conference at New Yorks St. Regis Hotel.)

title: Tensions in Crimea
description: Stark ethnic and cultural divisions continue to haunt Ukraine with the approach of parliamentary elections.

title: Republicans Look for Something to Believe In
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 23 column, A Vision, Bruised and Dented:

title: A Trillion Dollars Goes a Long Way, Doesnt It?
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts March 23 column, George Bushs Trillion-Dollar War.

title: Online Search Provider Local Matters Plans I.P.O.
description: Local Matters, a company led by the founder of the pioneering mapping service Mapquest, filed with regulators to raise as much as $57.5 million in an initial public offering.

title: Bayer Makes $19.5 Billion Bid for Schering
description: Bayer, the German drug and chemicals giant, has emerged as the white knight for Schering, with a surprise $19.5 billion offer.

title: Dont Be Fooled by the Accent
description: This alarming piece by the BBC exposes scammy estate agents in Old Blighty. It was pointed out by my friends at Freakonomics, who are keenly interested in the behavior of agents.

title: 'Lonesome Jim'
description: Stephen Holden reviews Steve Buscemi's "Lonesome Jim," a deadpan comedy about a depressed writer who returns in defeat to his parents' home in rural Indiana.

title: 'American Gun'
description: Stephen Holden reviews "American Gun," a film featuring three vignettes about the proliferation of handguns in the United States.

title: Whos Afraid of Pay Disclosure? Not These C.F.O.s
description: A proposed rule requiring more disclosure of executive perks was hardly expected to be a hit with upper management. But many finance chiefs seem to support the measure, according to a survey scheduled to be released on Monday.

title: 'Spamalot' Celebrates One Year
description: "Spamalot" fans celebrate the Broadway musical's one-year anniversary by setting a record for the "World's Largest Coconut Orchestra." (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: In Iraqs Army, Winds of Change
description: The winds are high today. Theyre coming in from the west, perhaps originating over the Mediterranean or the Red Sea, kicking up the detritus from ages of warfare and history across this desert landscape, then gaining momentum until they reach me and swirl the dust around my feet.

title: An Entourage Update
description: There's a new minor update of Microsoft's e-mail program for the Macintosh, Entourage (which is the program I use most). It adds a really great feature: you can now search all your Entourage e-mail, contacts and calendar using Spotlight, the built-in Mac OS X search genie. Man, I've been waiting a long time for this--and it really works beautifully. (Hint: You have to make sure that in Spotlight preferences, "Mail" is turned on as a category to search.)

title: Title Hopes Revolve Around This Sun
description: PHOENIX, March 23 - The expectations had been moderate. Nobody had expected a sudden explosion. But then again, Amare Stoudemire's freakish athletic abilities have always catapulted him over the party line.

title: India Makes Overture to Pakistan as Bus Link Opens
description: NEW DELHI, March 24 A The Indian prime minister, Manmohan Singh, called today for a far-reaching "treaty of peace, security and friendship" between India and Pakistan, in an apparent attempt to staunch criticism from across the border for inaction on Kashmir. Islamabad, while politely welcoming the offer, pointed to the need to take on that contested province.

title: Musica Sacra Goes Back to Basically Bach
description: Unlike the title Mostly Mozart, which Lincoln Center guards closely, Basically Bach evidently denotes a movable feast. Richard Westenburg produced a festival under that name with his Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall from 1979 to 1989. Since 1993, a little festival at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Midtown has been using the title Basically Bach. And now the elephant is back in the room.

title: Kara Walker Makes Contrasts in Silhouette in Her Own Met Show
description: Following in the footsteps of the Museum of Modern Art, the National Gallery in London and many others, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has invited a living artist to assemble an exhibition using works from its collection. As nearly as the museum can ascertain, this is a first for the Met.

title: Paying for City Recreation
description: To the Editor:

title: New Directors/New Films Festival Reviews; Cavite
description: Directed by Ian Gamazon and Neill Dela Llana

title: D'Amato and Weld Locked in G.O.P. Feud
description: For the last few months, William F. Weld's bid to become governor of New York has had a sharp thorn in its side: the outspoken opposition of the onetime kingmaker of state Republican politics, former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who has said that Mr. Weld is "without any real experience" in New York.

title: Morrison's Burdens Give Him an Edge Over Redick
description: Oakland, Calif. - MORE than ever, the road to the Final Four is wide open. But the subtext of this college basketball season has become who will win -- who should win -- the Naismith player of the year award: Duke's J. J. Redick or Gonzaga's Adam Morrison?

title: Upbeat, Effervescent Sounds From Daryl Sherman and Vince Giordano
description: If two smile buttons were to meet and fall in love, their ideal wedding music might be the ebullient pre-swing jazz churned out by the singer and pianist Daryl Sherman with Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks (a band frequently heard on Woody Allen soundtracks). "The Park Avenue Whirl," their collaboration at Feinstein's at the Regency, resurrects a pop-jazz style synonymous with simplicity and joy. Performed in an authentic period style, the propulsive sounds of 1920's and 30's jazz are among the happiest effusions of American music.

title: A New Jersey Community Joins Together Again, This Time to Mourn
description: MONROE TOWNSHIP, N.J., March 23 - With its swimming pools and putting greens, reading clubs and bowling leagues, the Ponds retirement community bustles with so many organized activities that some residents view it as a kind of summer camp for their sunset years.

title: Young Americans, Doing Good (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Villepin refuses to repeal jobs law
No Trouble in Prison; in Trouble Outside
description: He could not finish high school because he was sent to prison, but he made sure to complete his general education diploma from there. He had never used drugs or abused alcohol, but he still attended jailhouse Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. And, though he maintained that it was not a bad temper but simply bad luck that plagued him, he enrolled himself in a prison anger-management program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, FLORENCE
description: ROBERTS - Florence. on March 22, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Missed by friends and family. Graveside services Sunday, 10:30AM, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Hadassah.

title: Young Americans, Doing Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Skip to the Virgin Islands
description: TAKE American Airlines' nonstop 8:05 a.m. flight on Friday, and lie on the pearly sand by 2 p.m. And don't worry if you left your passport at home. St. Thomas, known for its sapphire blue waters, duty-free shopping and hopping nightlife, is part of the United States Virgin Islands.

title: British terror trial told of plans to poison beer and burgers
Premiere Commission Holds Gala, With a Premiere by Lisa Bielawa
description: In 2001, the pianist Bruce Levingston started Premiere Commission, a foundation that, as its name suggests, supports the commissioning and first performances of new works. So far, it has done one or the other (not necessarily both) for 30 scores by a varied group of composers that includes Philip Glass, William Bolcom, Chen Yi, John Corigliano and Sebastian Currier.

title: People: Sharon Stone, Katie Holmes, Nanni Moretti
Child Welfare Agency, Spurred by 7-Year-Old's Death, Plans Data System Like Police Department's
description: The Bloomberg administration announced yesterday the creation of a new data collection and tracking system to assist the city's child welfare agency in identifying the most serious cases of abuse and neglect.

title: Working Hard to Do His Best, Again
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 23 - "I don't have to apologize to anybody," Randy Johnson says, and just as he does, a teammate walks by.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HERSEY, JOHN
description: HERSEY--John. June 17, 1914-March 24, 1993. A special man, forever missed. B.

title: Talks for Lucent May Signal End for 90's Symbol
description: Lucent Technologies, the phone equipment maker that became a symbol of last decade's boom-and-bust cycle in telecommunications, is in negotiations to be acquired by Alcatel of France for about $12.6 billion, people close to the discussions said last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHIPMAN, PAULINE (NEE TOURRE)
description: SHIPMAN -- Pauline (nee Tourre) of Manhattan, formerly of Muskegon, MI, on March 10, 2006. She was active in Civic Theatre playing the leading roles in "The Night of January 16th" and "The Man Who Came to Dinner". Founding partner in Tourre's Soda Grille until her marriage to George E. Shipman III. After his death, she owned and managed Shipman Industries. She retired from Time, Inc. where she had worked for SI, TIME and People magazines. She also appeared in TV commercials and print ads, and was a member of SAG and AFTRA.

title: Conservative Bush Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: Irish Eyes Are Winking, You Can Hear the Angels Laugh
description: DUBLIN, March 23 - At some point in each episode of his reality TV series, Des Bishop is sure to walk onto the stage of a grimy pub in a rough neighborhood, beam out at the crowd and say exactly what it doesn't want to hear.

title: G.M. Sells Big Stake in Loan Unit
description: DETROIT, March 23 - General Motors sold a 78 percent stake in its commercial mortgage business, one part of its vast financing division, to an investor group on Thursday, the latest move in the struggling automaker's efforts to raise cash. The deal includes $1.5 billion in cash and the repayment of about $7.3 billion in intercompany loans.

title: Women go 'missing' by the millions
Art in Review; Keizo Kitajima
description: New York Cohen Amador Gallery 41 East 57th Street, Manhattan Through April 1

title: Roundup: Henin-Hardenne makes early exit
Glassmaking in Vermont
description: IT doesn't get any more Vermont. Warmed chvre, roasted beets and fresh focaccia, served in an old millhouse over a rushing river, with views of graceful covered bridges spanning Quechee Gorge in central Vermont.

title: Broken Nose Keeps Posada Out of Lineup
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 23 - For the second consecutive day, a Yankees starter was hit with a baseball before an exhibition game and appeared to be hurt.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: School Employees Charged In Housing Fraud
description: Eight current and two former city school employees have been charged with improperly taking subsidies from the New York City Housing Authority, Rose Gill Hearn, the commissioner of investigation, said yesterday. Ms. Gill Hearn said that several defendants were charged with concealing their employment and income to avoid paying higher rent. The commissioner said that one defendant, Noreen Little, the principal of Public School 156 in Queens, had moved to Long Island but continued to tell the housing authority that she lived in city housing in St. Albans, Queens, so she could sublet her former apartment. She was charged with falsifying business records, Ms. Gill Hearn said. Ms. Little has been reassigned, said Keith Kalb, a Department of Education spokesman.

title: Climate Data Hint at Irreversible Rise in Seas
description: Within the next 100 years, the growing human influence on Earth's climate could lead to a long and irreversible rise in sea levels by eroding the planet's vast polar ice sheets, according to new observations and analysis by several teams of scientists.

title: London Calling
description: IF jet lag isn't a problem and you are prepared to accept the fact that your quality sleep hours will be spent on an airplane crossing the Atlantic Ocean, then London can be a great weekend getaway -- particularly in the spring, when it is still possible to find some good airfare-hotel packages. (For example, United was recently offering a four-night package in London, hotel included, starting at $499 a person, good for travel through the end of March.)

title: Remedies Abundant, but Wagner Bides Time
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 23 - Billy Wagner will try anything to heal the ailing middle finger on his pitching hand.

title: Firm Steered Home Buyers, Group Says
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 23 - A fair housing group filed a discrimination complaint against a large Westchester real estate company on Thursday, accusing it of systematically steering white home buyers away from black and Hispanic neighborhoods by telling them that the schools in those areas were terrible, even when that was not the case.

title: Without Bad Luck, He'd Have No Luck at All
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 - Behind the black patch over Victor Page's right eye is not an eye at all. It is a hole, deep and lifeless, where an eye was before Page was shot in the face.

title: 3 Hostages Rescued in Iraq
description: A multinational military force rescued two Canadians and a Briton held hostage in Iraq for nearly four months by a shadowy guerrilla group. Page A8.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 6 about the Republican primary race for Congress in the 22nd District of Texas referred imprecisely to eligibility for voting in the event of a runoff. A ballot may be cast by any voter who has not cast one in the primary of the opposing party; voting in a runoff is not limited to those who have cast ballots in the primary.

title: Old and New in Philadelphia
description: IN Philadelphia, one can be a history buff by day and a scenester by night. This year, the city is celebrating Benjamin Franklin's 300th birthday with an array of events (www.benfranklin300.com).

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Sonia Gandhi Quits Parliament
description: Sonia Gandhi, the leader of India's governing Congress Party, unexpectedly resigned her seat in Parliament in an attempt to defuse an opposition campaign over lawmakers holding multiple public posts. She also resigned her seat on the government-financed National Advisory Council, which consults the government on policy matters and was the source of the controversy. Mrs. Gandhi said she would run again for the parliamentary seat, but her decision to step down now was widely seen as a shrewd move to deflate the increasingly vitriolic opposition campaign. She remains at the helm of the Congress Party while appearing to have seized the moral high ground. AMELIA GENTLEMAN (IHT)

title: Tolkien's 'Lord of the Rings,' Staged by Matthew Warchus in Toronto
description: TORONTO - AN hour or so into what feels like eons of stage time, one wise, scared little hobbit manages to express the feelings of multitudes. "This place is too dim and tree-ish for me," mutters a round-ish, twee-ish creature named Pippin, groping through a shadowy forest in the second act of the very expensive, largely incomprehensible musical version of "The Lord of the Rings," which opened Thursday at the Princess of Wales Theater here.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about controversy over Newark's plan to demolish an apartment complex where the mayoral candidate Cory Booker lives misstated his monthly rent. It is $575, not between $700 and $1,000.

title: The Afghan Christian Who Faces Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASSINI, OLEG
description: CASSINI--Oleg. The years that we collaborated as licensees to bring your wonderful fragrances to market brought us to respect your creative genius, your marketing intuition and commitment to excellence. You will be remembered for setting the bar higher. James Morris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, HERMAN
description: KAPLAN - Herman, June 1918--March 2006. U.S. Army veteran, chemical engineer, businessman, executive service agency volunteer in Africa, Asia, Europe. Survived by his wife of 65 years and two daughters.

title: After 200 Years, the Fire Patrol's Time May Be Up
description: Even before New York City had a paid Fire Department, it had the New York Fire Patrol. And it still does, for now at least.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, RAY J.
description: WOLF--Ray J. Sorry our friendship was so short. Will miss you. We extend our sympathy to Sylvia, the children and grandchildren. Sandy and Gibby

description: A reader asks an intriguing question:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAMOT, DOROTHY
description: SAMOT--Dorothy. We extend our sincerest condolences to Barbara (and Morrie) Libman and David (and Robin) Samot on the loss of their beloved mother. Her great passion for music and deep sense of devotion to family instilled in her children, grandchildren, and greatgranddaughter a strong sense of values and cherished memories of their times together. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Family

title: Zelda, Clara and Other Women Gone Wild
description: Flapper A Madcap Story of Sex, Style, Celebrity and the Women Who Made America Modern By Joshua Zeitz 338 pages. Crown. $24.95.

description: Selected Works Zwirner & Wirth 32 East 69th Street, Manhattan Through April 1

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GENDLER, PAUL H.
description: GENDLER--Paul H. Dec. 23, 1925--Mar. 24, 2005 Dad, not an hour of any day goes by when I don't wish I could speak to you and share things with you. You will always be my guiding light. Ellen

title: What's Bad for G.M.
description: General Motors is in deep trouble. Each attempt to pull itself out seems to draw only more attention to how far it has sunk. It would be easy to write off the company, but we can't. We all want to see G.M. get out of this.

title: Hiking the Catskills
description: HIKING buffs headed for the Catskills need no introduction to Big Indian, N.Y., with its soaring mountains and many wide-ranging trails. But the hamlet, nestled along Ulster County Route 47, is also home to a little-known smattering of charming inns and lodges -- not to mention a hip little resort with an emerging music and art scene.

title: Brazil arrests Credit Suisse banker
Judges Once Again Order More Money for City Schools
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that New York City schools were being shortchanged by at least $4.7 billion annually in state aid, adding more firepower to the city's plea for more education money as lawmakers try to wrap up work on a state budget.

title: Testimony on Enron Weakened a Day Later
description: HOUSTON, March 23 - Under questioning by defense lawyers, Enron's former treasurer backed away on Thursday from statements that Jeffrey K. Skilling had supported a controversial off-the-books transaction as a way to skirt accounting rules, and admitted to other weaknesses in his earlier testimony.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

description: Court-Martial'd! A Play in One Act

title: More Than Just Coffee
description: In the highlands of central Nicaragua, a coffee plantation has re-invented itself as a mountain resort.

title: Blast in French university building kills one
Defying Trend, an Upturn in Home Sales
description: Sales of existing homes unexpectedly surged in February after falling for five months in a row, the National Association of Realtors reported yesterday, reflecting a lift related to unseasonably warm weather and signaling that the housing market is healthier than some experts had suggested.

title: Young Americans, Doing Good
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Hard to Be a Coyote in the City
description: It's one thing to see a pair of red-tailed hawks nesting on a precipice overlooking Central Park. There's not much question how they got there, after all. But it's another thing to see a coyote in Central Park, like the one that was pursued and finally captured earlier this week. That coyote helps us re-imagine the city's boundaries. How would a coyote slip into Manhattan? Suddenly you get a glimpse of how constricted our own access to the island is -- funneled across bridges and through tunnels. And yet, for all we know, it may be easier for a coyote to enter Manhattan now than it was when there were no bridges or tunnels and visiting Manhattan meant a long swim.

title: Climate Data Hint at Irreversible Rise in Seas
description: Within the next 100 years, the growing human influence on Earth's climate could lead to a long and irreversible rise in sea levels by eroding the planet's vast polar ice sheets, according to new observations and analysis by several teams of scientists.

title: New Music in Montreal
description: FIRST Seattle, then Williamsburg in Brooklyn. Now, as any pierced guitarist knows, Montreal is the current hotbed of indie music, thanks to a roster of crossover bands like Arcade Fire, Godspeed You Black Emperor and Wolf Parade. Before the spotlight dims, unplug your iPod and head north to get in touch with your inner groupie.

title: No agreement in talks on French labor law
Labor Law Protests in Paris Erupt in Violence
description: PARIS, March 23 A Cars were burned and shops smashed today in the center of Paris as vandals erupted from the ranks of student demonstrators trying to force the government of Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin to withdraw a new youth employment law.

title: Las Vegas in Niagara Falls
description: DAREDEVILS have gone over it in barrels. Sightseers have been drenched by its mist. And generations of newlyweds have gone, as an old song goes, "To Niagara in a sleeper, there's no honeymoon that's cheaper." But there's nothing chintzy about the Niagara Fallsview Casino Resort, a kind of mini-Las Vegas in Canada that uses the 170-foot-high waterfall as a spectacular backdrop for craps and blackjack.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GERMAIN, LAWRENCE
description: GERMAIN--Lawrence In loving memory of my dear husband, Lawrence, who passed away March 24, 1991. God Bless you Lawrence in your grave, God keep you in his care. And may He listen to my heart And hear my fervent prayer. May you have peace and rest at last From every care and woe, And may you sleep in comfort From the winds and rain and snow. God Bless you for your caring ways And all you tried to do, To bring me happiness on earth And make my dreams come true. Til the roses lose their petals And the heather sheds its dew Til the end of time, Dear Lawrence, I will love and pray for you

title: Tuberculosis Declines to Historic Low in the U.S.
description: Tuberculosis cases in the United States fell to historic lows last year, public health authorities said yesterday. At the same time, doctors said, there was a small but worrisome increase in the number of cases resistant to several drugs.

title: New Directors/New Films Festival Reviews; Eleven Men Out
description: Directed by Robert I. Douglas

title: Texas Gets Last Word With 3-Pointer at Buzzer
description: ATLANTA, March 23 - A more fitting end to the game would have been a dunk or short shot off the glass. The Texas Longhorns had hammered underdog West Virginia inside all night at the Georgia Dome. The last thing that should have been expected was a 3-point dagger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KONIAK, CHEROL
description: KONIAK - Cherol. Beloved mother, passed away March 3, 2006 in Kalamazoo, MI. Born in New York, 1913.

title: Worried About India's and China's Booms? So Are They
description: The more I cover foreign affairs, the more I wish I had studied education in college, because the more I travel, the more I find that the most heated debates in many countries are around education. And here's what's really funny -- every country thinks it's behind.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about a federal appellate court's decision to overturn the conviction of Frank P. Quattrone, the investment banker who had taken several technology companies public, misidentified the bank for which he worked during the initial offering of Amazon.com in 1997. It was Deutsche Bank, not Credit Suisse First Boston.

title: 36 Hours in Exuma, the Bahamas
description: THE real Exuma is a do-it-yourself place, best discovered with sand between your toes. On its unspoiled beaches, the only footprints are probably your own, and the clear Atlantic waters that feed them dance before you like a kaleidoscope of jades, purples and blues. It is also a place where street addresses are nonexistent and where you will have to slow down in spite of yourself: there is regular time, and there is Bahamian time, and the more you try to hurry, the longer it will take you to get there.

title: Bill Would Sell Part of New Jersey Turnpike, Garden State Parkway to Investors
description: TRENTON, March 23 - For years, people who did their insurance business with Prudential, one of New Jersey's signature companies, were told that they owned "a piece of the rock." Now, people may have an opportunity to own a piece of other prominent state symbols: the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway.

title: Score Is Too Small a Matter to Matter to Woods
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., March 23 - There is much that Tiger Woods can control: the trajectory of his shots, the access to his inner circle, the image he shows to the public. But Thursday, during the first round of the Players Championship, his mask of placidity slipped.

title: News Analysis: By leaving, Gandhi might gain
AOL Television Offers Shows We've Left Far Behind
description: LAST week, America Online introduced the first broadband television network on the World Wide Web, fueling the question, Has the Internet truly been a net positive for civilization? Realizing some aspect of the dream that was the failed AOL Time Warner merger, the network offers an inventory of dramas, comedies and "vintage" programming from the Warner Brothers archive, proving perhaps, as the fashion world has already demonstrated, that "vintage" in modern parlance has simply come to mean old.

title: Schering welcomes takeover bid from Bayer
The Churn
description: People

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Tuesday about the improving condition of Vado Diomande, a Manhattan man who contracted inhalation anthrax after working with untreated animal skins, misstated the date he collapsed after performing with his dance company. It was Feb. 16, not Feb. 17.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDERMAN, MORRIS
description: LINDERMAN--Morris. November 5, 1906-March 22, 2006. Predeceased by his beloved wife Mae, his life partner of 67 years. Loving, caring father to Essie and Marty, Gary and Janice. And his "adopted children" Rita and George Weissman. Adored "poppa" to his pride and joy Corey. Grandfather to Jennifer and Jeffrey. Great-grandpa to Dillon. Graduate of New York Law School and practitioner in New York for 50 years. Twice candidate for Municipal Court Judge in Bronx County. An exquisite gentleman. One of a kind. Who would walk into an elevator and doff his hat and say "good morning" to whomever was on that elevator. A fantastic kibitzer who could "mix it up" with the best of them. A brilliant scholar... always reading and questioning. He was the most gentle man who possessed the highest degree of tolerance and always looked to settle rather than wage war. As a father, he was beyond compare. Always there to try to ease pain and make things okay. Be at BLISSFUL PEACE Dad. May your mind be sharp and clear and may words never fail you. All my love, "Your Genius" (retired). Services 11:30 Sunday, Plaza Jewish CommunityChapel, Amsterdam Ave/91 St. NYC.

title: A Show of Hands on Wal-Mart
description: Wal-Mart, says the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, is a "generous and thoughtful" partner that has helped recover 140 missing children. Maybe so, but the liberal group Americans for Democratic Action argues that Wal-Mart is "socially irresponsible" for skimping on employee wages.

title: Mark Morris Gets in Touch With His Inner Folk Dancer
description: Mark Morris's inner Balkan dancer rose again in his charming new "Candleflowerdance," performed on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of his company's monthlong 25th anniversary season. It is tempting to attribute Mr. Morris's distinctively sweet and goofy humanism at least in part to his teenage years performing with a Balkan folk dance troupe. And the new piece, set to Stravinsky's Serenade in A, is one of his most tender.

title: Dr. James H. Schwartz, 73, Who Studied the Basis of Memory, Dies
description: Dr. James H. Schwartz, a neurobiologist at Columbia whose research helped explain the biochemical basis of learning and memory, died on March 13 at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital in Manhattan. He was 73.

title: Briefly: Iran is expanding work on uranium, envoys say
Paid Notice: Deaths   HORN, INEZ
description: HORN--Inez. The Board of Directors and the Resource Library Volunteers of Women At Risk extend our deepest sympathies to the family of Inez Horn. Through her caring, insight and dedication to Women At Risk's mission, Inez provided invaluable support to countless people with cancer. Her humor and warmth will be missed by all.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about General Motors' plan to offer buyouts to all its union workers misstated one severance alternative. (The error also occurred in a Business Day article about the reaction of workers to the plan.) Employees nearing retirement who agree to leave the job immediately will receive up to $2,900 a month until they reach their 30th anniversary of service at G.M. They must agree to retire at that point and will receive full pension. They cannot continue working in the interim, and the money is not in addition to their regular pay.

title: Europe Approves Energy Strategy But Stumbles Over Borders
description: BRUSSELS, March 24 A While European leaders meeting here agreed today to ban a number of top officials from Belarus from their 25-nation bloc, a two-day summit meeting here that was intended to revive momentum for stalled European integration was more notable for what was not discussed than what was.

title: Antiquing in the Catskills
description: LESS picked through than Bucks County, Pa., and much less expensive than Hudson, N.Y., Sullivan County in upstate New York is emerging as an antiquing destination. In recent years, antique shops -- which mostly resume peak season hours next month -- have sprung up in this corner of the Catskills, mirroring an influx of affluent second-home owners.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Writer's Lawyer Raises Insanity Defense
description: The lawyer for Peter Braunstein, a freelance writer accused of pretending to be a firefighter and sexually attacking a woman in Chelsea in October, told a judge and prosecutor yesterday that he was planning to use an insanity defense. Mr. Braunstein, who is being held in a hospital under suicide watch, is charged with kidnapping, arson and assault. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)

Review: The Collected Poems Of C. P. Cavafya
Bus Plunge That Killed 12 in Chile Echoes in New York Area

title: TV and Top Marketers Discuss the State of the Medium
description: AMONG themselves, advertising executives often declare the 30-second spot dead. But to hear television executives tell it, not only does television remain a potent medium, but those little ads are still going strong.

title: A Chinese Journalist in Jail
description: As China moves ahead steadily in the global marketplace, its ultimate success will depend not just on its buying power. Among other things, China must have a free press and a judicial system based on the rule of law rather than political power. One highly public test of both will be whether the Chinese authorities release Zhao Yan, who has been in jail for nearly 18 months on specious charges that he revealed state secrets to The New York Times.

title: Corrections
description: A drawing in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about Erketu ellisoni, a newly discovered dinosaur with an unusually long neck, carried an incorrect credit. The illustrator was Jason Brougham.

description: PRICE--Dr. Stephen S., Ed.D. On March 22, 2006. Beloved husband of Inge. Dear uncle of Richard Glovin and Debbie Glovin Rosenberg. Service private.

title: Economic View: Deficits that are here to stay
New Directors/New Films Festival Reviews
description: The designation "new" in the New Directors/New Films series suggests not only emerging talent but also fresh perspectives on the social and political pressures of the modern world. One of the best films, "Quinceaera," examines Mexican-American assimilation in a Los Angeles neighborhood during a real estate boom. A much bleaker view of cultural dislocation is presented in "Man Push Cart," a portrait of a Pakistani immigrant in New York. The fact that three movies having their first New Directors screenings this weekend -- "Quinceaera," "A Soap" and "Eleven Men Out" -- have gay and transgender themes suggests that these issues are not about to lose their currency.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Unions Agree To Meet French Leader
description: France's most powerful labor union federations agreed to meet Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin today to discuss the country's hotly contested new employment law as hundreds of thousands of students across France marched in protest against it, frequently clashing with the police. Several hundred people were reported arrested. The union federations had earlier refused to talk to the government as long as the law remained on the books. CRAIG S. SMITH (NYT)

description: WASHINGTON - THAT artists can go in and out of style is not news. The interesting question is why? Why besides the fickleness of taste would a given artist's work be so desirable at one time and not at another?

title: State Department Is Criticized for Purchasing Chinese PC's
description: HONG KONG, March 23 - A State Department purchase of more than 15,000 computers built by the Lenovo Group of China is starting to draw criticism in the latest sign of American unease about the role of foreign companies in the American economy.

title: Unknown No Longer, Memphis Marches On
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 23 - Heading into its Round of 16 game against Bradley, Memphis reigned as the great unknown in this N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Allows Work At Ground Zero
description: Rejecting a request to immediately halt work at the World Trade Center site, a State Supreme Court justice said yesterday that site preparation for the World Trade Center Memorial could continue until late April. "It seems to me that there's no building going on here, so we certainly don't need a temporary restraining order," Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich said, responding to a request by the families of trade center victims to halt construction of a $330 million memorial and a $160 million museum because, they argued, it would damage historic remnants in violation of state statutes. Lower Manhattan Development Corporation lawyers promised that only inspection, cleaning and protection of the remnants would proceed until an April 27 hearing. GLENN COLLINS (NYT)

title: Ethnic and Cultural Divisions Haunt Ukraine Before Vote
description: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine - There are few obstacles to speaking Russian here in Crimea since, after all, practically everyone speaks it at home, at school, at work.
