title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERTNER, JACK
description: GERTNER--Jack. The partners of Anchin, Block & Anchin LLP mourn the loss of their esteemed partner, Jack Gertner, of Forest Hills, Queens, on Wednesday, March 22nd, 2006. Prior to his retirement in 1990 Jack spent a lifetime career at Anchin, where he faithfully served clients and acted as the firm's Chief Financial Officer. He will be remembered as an eternal gentleman who was not only our friend, but a mentor to many young accountants who followed him. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Trudy, his two sons, Richard, a member of Anchin's Tax Department, and Robert, and their families. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family on the loss of our wonderful friend and mentor. The Partners of Anchin, Block & Anchin LLP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBENFELD, SONDRA
description: RUBENFELD - Sondra. On March 23. Beloved wife of Leon. Devoted mother of Terry and Carrie Rubenfeld. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie and Danielle. Service Sunday 10:00 A.M., March 26, 2006 "Parkside" Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRISCH, JEAN
description: FRISCH--Jean. On March 21, 2006. Beloved wife of Irwin J. (Mike) Frisch. Devoted mother of Barbara, Adrienne and Richard; cherished grandmother of Jeremy, Jesse, Andrew, Jonathan and Katherine. An active community member of Wynmoor serving as Director for 17 years, President of Antigua II for 13 years, Council Rep for eight years, and as a member of various committees; involved herself in all aspects of community life. Other previous service included Hadassah's Woman of the Year and typing braille for the blind. She will be dearly missed. Funeral services will be held Friday, March 24 at Star of David Chapel in North Lauderdale, FL. at 11:45 AM.

title: Master of Slow and Deliberate at Ground Zero

Silverstein strode into the conference room on the 15th floor of the Port Authority's Park Avenue offices, took off his coat and gulped down two cups of coffee, ready for the next round of talks about the future of ground zero.

title: Truly Micro Electronics in a Single Molecule

Off-Roading in a Hummer
description: CALL it off-roading for yuppies. At the 2,800-acre Nemacolin Woodlands Resort, about 70 miles southeast of Pittsburgh, guests can get behind the wheel of a Hummer H1 or H2 to explore more than 18 harrowing miles of rugged trails, rushing streams and steep hills, with names like the Rock and the Crater. Two hours at Nemacolin's off-road driving academy cost $125 ($275 if you left your Hummer at home and need to use one of the resort's).

title: Analysts Upbeat About Merger Talks Between Alcatel and Lucent
description: Analysts and investors of the beleaguered telecommunications equipment makers cheered merger talks between Alcatel and Lucent today, sending shares of the two companies and many of their peers higher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTLIEB, JEROME
description: GOTTLIEB - Jerome. The President and the Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center are deeply saddened by the death of Jerome Gottlieb, father of our esteemed Trustee, David Gottlieb. Jerome Gottlieb was a loving father and devoted grandfather. Our deepest and heartfelt condolences go out to his son David, daughter Jill, his four grandchildren and his entire family in this time of their great loss. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or Montefiore Medical Center. Spencer Foreman, M.D., Pres Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Hewlett-Packard Adds McCann to Agency Roster
description: Hewlett-Packard in Palo Alto, Calif., has added to its agency roster McCann Erickson Worldwide, part of the McCann Worldgroup unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle creative assignments, with spending estimated at $200 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teenagers Shot In A Crowd
description: Two 13-year-olds were wounded last evening at a Spanish Harlem basketball court when a gunman opened fire at someone else in a crowd of adults and children. The victims were taken to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital and were in stable condition, a police spokesman said. The police did not release the two names, but neighbors identified one victim, a girl, as Steveasia Sapp, who was hit in the face by a bullet that shattered several teeth. The other victim, a boy shot in the right leg, was identified by a friend as Travis Knight. Investigators at the scene said that a gunman wearing a parka entered the basketball court near the Woodrow Wilson Houses at 425 East 105th Street about 6:30 p.m. He fired five times, the investigators said, and at one point chased someone who was not wounded and disappeared in the chaos. ANTHONY RAMIREZ (NYT)

title: Argentina Marks 30th Anniversary of Murderous Regime
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24 A The posters and billboards vowing "Never Again" were put up days ago, accompanied by special museum displays, photographic exhibitions, books, public forums and television programs.

[Page A1.]

World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza: 2 Palestinians Killed Planting Bomb
description: The Israeli Air Force shot dead two Palestinians as they tried to plant a bomb along the Gaza Strip's eastern border with Israel. Islamic Jihad confirmed that two of its members were killed during an attempted bombing. The Palestinian security forces said they found a bomb at the scene and detonated it. GREG MYRE (NYT)

title: Military Lab Puts Name on a Long-Lost Airman

description: WASHINGTON, March 24 A President Bush campaigned in Indiana today on behalf of Representative Mike Sodrel, a vulnerable first-termer from the southeastern corner of the state whom Mr. Bush praised as his kind of Congressman.

title: Drum Circles: Where the Beat Goes On
description: ALONG with the chirping of birds and croaking of frogs, spring brings another sound: the slapping and thumping of fingers on taut leather drumheads. The end of winter means a returning bloom of the drum circle, as those that have hibernated or moved inside for the winter reverberate again through the open air.

description: NFR--Dearest N, March 24th, 1941, one of the best days. Today, not one of the best. I miss you. Love always, S

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The tradition in this country of a law enforcement agency that had absolute power over people, we've got to break them of that. I think it'll take years. You can't change a cultural mind-set overnight."

description: Theater

title: Back of the Envelope
description: Financing has been cheap, even as the Federal Reserve has been steadily pushing up interest rates since July 2004, and that has helped fuel the boom in mergers. Fed policy makers are widely expected to raise rates another quarter-point next week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Anthrax Patient Leaves The Hospital
description: Vado Diomande, the African dancer and drum maker who contracted inhalation anthrax last month, was released from a Pennsylvania hospital on Wednesday evening, hospital officials said yesterday. Health officials believe Mr. Diomande, 44, of Greenwich Village, contracted anthrax while making drums using unprocessed animal skins. He collapsed after a performance on Feb. 16. JOHN HOLL (NYT)

title: Shellfishing in Nantucket
description: NANTUCKET is closer to the Galapagos in its biodiversity than people realize -- it may be tucked up north, but it's only miles from the Gulf Stream, making it home to a veritable seafood market of clams, scallops, lobsters and quahogs. This requires some imagination in the summer, when the island is swarming with sun hats and madras-wearing mainlanders. So visit in the spring for an unobstructed view of nature.

title: 'Stoned' Follows the Guitarist Elbowed Off of the Stones' Wild Ride
description: The road of excess may lead to the palace of wisdom. The problem is getting there in one piece. "Stoned," Stephen Woolley's convoluted docudrama examining the final weeks in the life of the guitarist Brian Jones, a founding member of the Rolling Stones and pied piper of 1960's hedonism, stalls in its own laborious accumulation of detail.

title: In the Arena: Soccer's titans take old battle to court
Looking Done, U.C.L.A. Comes Back
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 23 - By scurrying back from deficits as large as 17 points in the regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament, U.C.L.A. showed that its East Coast style of basketball can reign on the West Coast.

description: DAFFODILS on Nantucket and lilacs in the Hamptons are all well and good, but if you want to take a plunge into the Atlantic Ocean any time soon, head for Bermuda.

description: Cablevision agreed yesterday to carry SportsNet New York, ending worries by Mets fans in the metropolitan region that the team's new channel would not be available in time for opening day on April 3.

They share a hometown, Natchitoches, La., but he did not attend the university.

description: The Economist, the urbane British weekly magazine that has been expanding its foothold in America, appointed its United States editor as its editor in chief yesterday.

title: Basque Nationalists See an Opening for Autonomy
description: MADRID, March 23 - The governing party in the Basque region of northern Spain said on Thursday that the permanent cease-fire announced Wednesday by the militant Basque separatist group ETA opened the way for the region to loosen its ties with the central government in Madrid.

title: Don't Take This Lying Down
description: Hartford - IN 1877, Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell, describing what he called his "rest cure" for hysterical women, wrote, "I do not permit the patient to sit up or to sew or write or read. The only action allowed is that needed to clean the teeth." At the end of six weeks to two months of such treatment, he expected that women would be good as new.

title: Part of Ex-Congressman's Ruined Life on Auction Block
description: RANCHO DOMINGUEZ, Calif., March 23 - In a final indignity after a stunning fall, pieces of the ruined life of former Representative Randy Cunningham were auctioned off in a government warehouse here on Thursday morning.

title: Citizen Oleg Is Set Free as Russians Jolt the Elite
description: MOSCOW, March 23 - Russians, it is fair to generalize, have become largely inured to injustices carried out by or for the powerful and the privileged. But the judicial fate of Oleg Shcherbinsky has struck a chord deep in the Russian soul, perhaps because it involves a celebrity and an ordinary guy, a car crash and the grossly unequal rules of the road.

title: Senator Is Summoned to Court on Coffee-Throwing Charge
description: ALBANY, March 23 - A summons was issued on Thursday for State Senator Ada L. Smith of Queens, ordering her to appear in criminal court here next month to answer charges that she threw hot coffee in the eyes of a member of her staff.

title: Bawag PSK linked to collapse at Refco
Asia, Americas, Europe
description: ASIA

title: ViewPoints: Criminalizing ignorance
Skeptics Blunting London Rumor Mill
description: LONDON, March 23 - Now that the first blush of deal fever has worn off, some London Stock Exchange brokers and traders are starting to ask what benefits, exactly, would come from combining with Nasdaq? The short answer is that no one is entirely sure.

title: Suburbia Explored at the Katonah Museum of Art's 'I Love the Burbs'
description: The suburbs have always -- well, nearly always -- been with us. In the sixth century B.C., rich urbanites retreated to the quiet, unspoiled outskirts of Babylon. Americans have taken the concept somewhat further; today more of us live in what the writer Michael Pollan has called Burbopolis than in urban centers, and issues like gardening, barbecues and Little League have been replaced by McMansions, highways and slums.

title: New Directors/New Films Festival Reviews; A Soap
description: Directed by Pernille Fischer Christensen

title: Evidence of Wiretaps Used in Suit
description: LOS ANGELES, March 23 - A screenwriter and his lawyer talk on the phone. They are in the heat of legal battle with a big-time producer over the profits from a hit movie. The lawyer says which of their arguments he thinks are strongest and how much he thinks their opponents will agree to pay in a settlement.

title: Weird Baltimore
description: WHEN the director John Waters proposed that his city's motto be "Come to Baltimore and Be Shocked," he was dead serious. Home to beehive beauty contests, macabre museums and the Edgar Allan Poe House, Baltimore is the capital of the lurid and offbeat.

title: 'Lonesome Jim' Discovers You Can Go Home Again (Hat in Hand)
description: The 27-year-old protagonist of Steve Buscemi's deadpan comedy "Lonesome Jim" lives out the worst nightmare of every bushy-tailed go-getter who moves to New York to Be Somebody (in his case, a writer) and fails miserably. After eking out a living as a dog walker, Jim (Casey Affleck) skulks back to his parents' home in rural Indiana with no idea of what to do next. As Robert Frost observed, "Home is the place where, when you have to go there, they have to take you in."

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about General Motors' plan to offer buyouts to all its union workers misstated one severance alternative. (The error also occurred in a Business Day article about the reaction of workers to the plan.) Employees nearing retirement who agree to leave the job immediately will receive up to $2,900 a month until they reach their 30th anniversary of service at G.M. They must agree to retire at that point and will receive full pension. They cannot continue working in the interim, and the money is not in addition to their regular pay.

title: Aging bull: Plazas struggle
Club Bouncer Is Arraigned in Murder of Graduate Student
description: A Queens bouncer strangled a graduate student while trying to rape or sexually assault her, then dumped her body in a lot near the Belt Parkway, prosecutors said yesterday a few hours before the bouncer was arraigned in a Brooklyn courtroom overflowing with reporters and family and friends of the slain student.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Tim Hortons Offering
description: Tim Hortons Inc., the Canadian doughnut chain, raised 783 million Canadian dollars ($671.3 million) in the biggest North American initial public offering in nine months. Tim Hortons, owned by Wendy's International, sold 29 million shares at 27 Canadian dollars each in Canada and $23.16 in the United States, the company said.

title: Waiting on Deck in Rights Lineup
description: With the final season of its six-year, $2.5 billion Major League Baseball deal looming, Fox still has not enlisted for a new contract.

description: "The Property Known as Garland" affords about 30 seconds of real pleasure, but they are not provided by Adrienne Barbeau, the star of this dull and tawdry bio-play by Ms. Barbeau's husband, Billy Van Zandt, which opened last night at the Actors' Playhouse.

title: Woman, 24, Says Neighbor Held Her Captive for 10 Years
description: Correction Appended

title: Arts, Briefly; New Shows, New Lineups
description: The television schedule featured several new shows and some shuffled lineups on Wednesday, but the results were status quo. In Nielsen's estimates, "American Idol" was the night's most watched program, and Fox won the night. On the half-hour "Idol," 27.27 million viewers said goodbye to Kevin Covais, a 16-year-old from Long Island. The premiere of "Unan1mous" drew 15.84 million viewers in the post-"Idol" slot. Behind Fox, ABC, CBS and NBC fought it out for second place among total viewers in a very close race, finishing in that order. (ABC was a clear No. 2 among adults 18 to 49.) ABC's "Lost" delivered an audience of 15.98 million, and led into the debut of "The Evidence" (9.23 million), which ranked second at 10 p.m. behind CBS's "CSI: New York" (13.9 million). NBC's crime entry during the 10 p.m. slot was its new series "Heist." Though the show brought in 8.74 million and finished third, it retained a good percentage of the "Law & Order" audience (8.95 million). After years of dominating the 10 p.m. hour, "Law & Order" moved this week to 9 p.m. to face "Idol," "Lost" and CBS's "Criminal Minds" (11.85 million).

title: Spotlight: Bulgari branches out
Mayor of Gary Announces Resignation After 11 Years
description: CHICAGO, March 23 - Scott L. King, the mayor of Gary, Ind., who tried through three terms to reverse the decline of his long-struggling city, announced his resignation Thursday after 11 years in office, saying he needed to earn more money to finish paying for his children's college education.

title: Merkel awaits verdict in German elections
Once Protected by Hussein, Palestinians Suffer Backlash
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 24 A The bill of death appeared overnight on Thursday, addressed to "the Palestinian traitors," and the killers were specific in their intent.

title: A Weekend Cruise
description: NOT sure if you can squeeze in a seven-day cruise? Royal Caribbean International, Disney Cruise Line and Carnival Cruise Line now offer three-night minicruises departing from Florida. The ports of call, of course, are limited. Royal Caribbean's Majesty of the Seas, for example, departs from Fort Lauderdale on Friday night, spends the next day on Coco Cay in the Bahamas, heads out to Nassau on Saturday, and returns to Florida at 9 a.m. on Monday -- just in time to rush back to the office by midafternoon, no one the wiser. Fares start as low as $289, based on double occupancy (866-562-7625, www.royalcaribbean.com).

title: Secretary of Homeland Insecurity
description: Sometimes it's hard to understand just how Michael Chertoff understands his title, secretary of homeland security. Take this week, when Mr. Chertoff appeared before executives of the chemical industry, whose plants remain one of the nation's greatest vulnerabilities more than four years after 9/11. Mr. Chertoff did not chastise the industry for failing to protect chemical plants adequately. He proposed weak federal safety standards. He did not even fully embrace a recently introduced bipartisan Senate bill that would create meaningful standards.

title: Art in Review; Tara Donovan
description: PaceWildenstein 545 West 22nd Street, Chelsea Through April 22

title: Sarah Caldwell, First Woman to Conduct at the Met, Dies at 82
description: Sarah Caldwell, one of America's best known and most adventurous conductors and opera directors and the founding director of the Opera Company of Boston, died Thursday in Portland, Me. She was 82.

title: Letter to the Secretary
description: Dear John Snow, secretary of the Treasury:

title: The Joys of Snow Without the Weather
description: IMAGINE there was a place to learn to ski or snowboard where good snow conditions are guaranteed, where the wind never blows, where it is never too cold and there could never be a whiteout blizzard.

title: Salsa Dancing in Puerto Rico
description: SALSA music may have originated in New York City, but San Juan, P.R., is its spiritual home. From gilded casinos to packed nightclubs, the infectious rhythm of salsa has hips swiveling and shoulders shaking until daybreak in this Caribbean capital. Dance lessons are available at places throughout the city, including Miguel Rodrguez's studio on Tuesday and Friday nights (211 Avenida Jos de Diego, 787-717-1255). Private lessons start at $25.

title: A Controversial Therapy for Diabetes Is Verified
description: Three groups of scientists report today that they independently replicated a controversial finding: severely diabetic mice can recover on their own if researchers squelch an immune system attack that is causing the disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCOTT, EUGENE L.
description: SCOTT--Eugene L. The U.S. Tennis Association Eastern Section Board of Directors, volunteers, staff and member organizations are profoundly saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Gene Scott, a board member and past president of the association. Gene spread the good news about tennis for 50 years--as a world ranked player, tournament director, author, television producer and commentator and through the written word in Tennis Week magazine, which he founded in 1974. We extend our sympathies to his family, especially his wife, Polly, and his children, Lucy and Sam.

title: For Knicks, Quality Time Is Quickly Approaching
description: In jollier times, before the Knicks turned the season into an exercise in self-parody, Coach Larry Brown would be coy about his lineup. In playful moments last October, he invited reporters who cover the team to submit ideas.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Courtroom Battle Spills Into the Bookstores

title: Briefing: Lafarge bid rebuffed by U.S. subsidiary
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Orange: 16 Injured In School Fight
description: Police officers used pepper spray to break up a fight yesterday morning at Orange High School, resulting in the school's brief evacuation and about 16 injuries, officials said. Three 17-year-old students began fighting around 10 a.m. and 200 to 300 students gathered to watch as officers responded, said Edward Lucas, the police director. The three students were charged with fighting, the police said, and 10 others were taken to hospitals with minor injuries, most with respiratory problems from the spray. JOHN HOLL (NYT)

title: The U.S. drive for nuclear intelligence
Europe Approves Energy Strategy and Belarus Restrictions, but Stumbles Over Borders
description: BRUSSELS, March 24 A European leaders agreed Friday to expand travel restrictions on top officials from Belarus, but a two-day summit meeting that was intended to revive momentum for European integration was more notable for what was not discussed than for what was.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on March 6 about the Republican primary race for Congress in the 22nd District of Texas referred imprecisely to eligibility for voting in the event of a runoff. A ballot may be cast by any voter who has not cast one in the primary of the opposing party; voting in a runoff is not limited to those who have cast ballots in the primary. (Go to Article)

title: 'Living Room in Africa,' With an Art Gallery Set Amid Poverty
description: "I had a farm in Africa," Isak Dinesen's memoir "Out of Africa" famously begins. But the odd young British couple in Bathsheba Doran's disturbing play "Living Room in Africa," at the Beckett Theater, has only a living room -- at least that is all that we ever glimpse of their rambling old house in a remote region of Africa. (The convincing set -- a staircase leading to an unseen upper floor, a banquette by the window and pea-green walls -- was designed by David Korins.)

title: Ingres at the Louvre: His Pursuit of a Higher Reality
description: PARIS - OUTSIDE the first gallery of the Ingres show here at the Louvre, his gigantic painting of Jupiter and Thetis from a distance might almost be mistaken for a copy of itself -- the colors are so lurid and the surface is so smooth. No matter how familiar Ingres is, like all great artists he suddenly looks unfamiliar whenever you see him.

title: The Listings: March 24 - March 30; ITALIAN JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: It would be misleading to cast the trumpeter Enrico Rava as the Miles Davis of Italian jazz. But there are a few ways in which Mr. Rava, above, does suggest Davis, who sparked his interest in the trumpet nearly 50 years ago. In addition to Mr. Rava's clear and melancholy tone, there's his presence: in Italy, he is not only the pre-eminent jazz musician but also part of the popular culture. More meaningfully, he has embraced the Milesian practice of absorbing younger talent into his ensembles, including the quintet he has led for the last six years. Introducing that group on a 2004 album, "Easy Living" (ECM), Mr. Rava spotlighted a pair of rising stars, the trombonist Gianluca Petrella (who has since released a noteworthy Blue Note album) and the pianist Stefano Bollani (who recently left the quintet to tend to a solo career); at the Montreal Jazz Festival last summer, he additionally showcased Francesco Cafiso, an alto saxophonist in his teens. Small wonder that Mr. Rava's influence will pervade a festival of Italian jazz at Birdland next week. His quintet appears on Thursday and next Friday, along with the pianist Enrico Pieranunzi (in a trio with the bassist Marc Johnson and the drummer Paul Motian, both Americans). Tuesday and Wednesday's program features ensembles led by the pianist Dado Moroni and the bassist Giovanni Tommaso, both close associates of Mr. Rava. And on April 1 and 2, Mr. Bollani and Mr. Cafiso will split the bill, leaving Mr. Rava's trumpet out of the mix but no doubt conveying some of his spirit. (Tuesday through April 2 at 8 and 10 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, www.birdlandjazz.com; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum.)

title: City Storm Evacuation Plan Is Unworkable, Report Says
description: Raising the specter of a hurricane inundating low-lying sections of the city with a 25-foot storm surge and shattering skyscraper windows into razor-like projectiles, a State Assembly committee yesterday criticized the city's storm evacuation plan.

title: Official at Saudi Company and Ex-Employee at Halliburton Unit Accused in Kickback Inquiry
description: The director of operations for a Saudi company that operates numerous dining facilities for United States Army troops in Iraq and Kuwait was arrested Wednesday and accused of making false statements in connection with what is believed to be a kickback scheme involving a major base near the border of the two countries, a federal prosecutor's office in Illinois said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUNHARDT, PHILIP B. JR.
description: KUNHARDT--Philip B. Jr., 78. Died peacefully at his home in Chappaqua on March 21, 2006. The funeral of this beloved man will be held on Friday, March 24, 10:30 AM at St. Mark's Church in Mt. Kisco, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the International Rescue Committee or Manhattan Country School.

title: Roh taps woman as nominee for No. 2 spot
Prosecution Of Moussaoui Finishes Up
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 23 - Prosecutors on Thursday finished presenting their case that Zacarias Moussaoui should be executed for the deaths that occurred on Sept. 11, 2001, offering evidence linking him to the paymaster of Al Qaeda who provided money to most of the 19 hijackers who died in the plot.

title: Philip B. Kunhardt Jr., 78, Writer and Producer of Documentaries, Is Dead
description: Philip B. Kunhardt Jr., a former managing editor of Life magazine who later became known as a writer and producer of historical documentaries for television, died on Tuesday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 78 and also lived in Hancock, Me.

title: Shares Slide as Price of Oil Feeds Fears of Higher Rates
description: Stocks fell yesterday after oil prices jumped and an increase in home sales added to concern that the Federal Reserve might keep lifting interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average had its biggest loss in about three weeks.

title: 'Summer Storm' Charts a Sexed-Up Season of Discovery
description: Opens today in Manhattan; also in Chicago; Los Angeles, Palm Springs, Santa Rosa, Santa Cruz, San Jose and San Diego, Calif.; Atlanta; Seattle; St. Louis; and Austin, Tex. Directed by Marco Kreuzpaintner In German, with English subtitles 98 minutes

title: The Afghan Christian Who Faces Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Climate Data Hint at Irreversible Rise in Seas
description: Within the next 100 years, the growing human influence on Earth's climate could lead to a long and irreversible rise in sea levels by eroding the planet's vast polar ice sheets, according to new observations and analysis by several teams of scientists.

title: When the Moon Hits ... That's Not Amore
description: When the Moon Hits That's Not Amore

title: French Talks Over Labor Law Prove Fruitless
description: PARIS, March 24 A Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin met with French union leaders today but failed to narrow their differences over a new labor law that has provoked mounting protests and troubling bursts of violence.

title: 'Inside Man,' a Crime Caper Starring Denzel Washington
description: FOR most of his career, the great and maddeningly unreliable Spike Lee has been anything but -- to borrow the title of his diverting new film -- an inside man. Mr. Lee, who hit the scene in the mid-1980's with "She's Gotta Have It," a barbed independent comedy that jump-started the black film movement and made him a national brand, has preferred to be seen as an outside man, a rebel who said what he wanted, when he wanted, far from the industry establishment. To judge from this precision-tooled amusement, Mr. Lee may have missed his calling (one of them, anyway) as a studio hire.

title: The Listings: March 24 - March 30; SILVER BELLES
description: Fay Ray has built ships for the Navy, driven a New York taxi and worked on the Alaska pipeline. Now, at 84, she is the youngest member of the Silver Belles, a troupe of former showgirls who danced at storied Harlem theaters in the 1930's and 40's. Organized 20 years ago by 96-year-old Bertye Lou Wood, the dance captain at the Apollo Theater in the 30's, the Belles have been dancing ever since, performing in theaters like Aaron Davis Hall and Carnegie Hall. On Sunday, they will be celebrated at the Apollo, during a showing of the documentary "Been Rich All My Life," a tribute to the often unheralded chorus girls by Heather MacDonald, the Sundance Award-winning director (above, High Rez, from 1938, some of whom are now members of the Silver Belles). Besides the film, there will be a tap dance performance directed by the choreographer and dancer Mercedes Ellington and accompanied by the Jazzberry Jam! trio, featuring Bertha Hope on piano, Carline Ray on bass and Paula Hampton on drums. Other guests include the tap dancer Karen Callaway Williams and the Cotton Club owner John Beatty. But the real stars are the five members of the Belles who, all told, represent almost 450 years of dancing history. (4 p.m., Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, Harlem, (212) 531-5305, ticketmaster.com; $10 to $30; $125 for VIP tickets, including reception, (212) 252-2778,)

title: Balance Sheet: Setting free the auditors
Love Him or Hate Him, but Remember Him
description: Atlanta - THE United States recently got skunked in international baseball and soccer matches, but seismologists have yet to measure any serious rumblings of mutiny.

title: Learn a New Cuisine
description: TIRED of Chinese takeout, but still confused about sauting versus stir-frying?

title: LIVING HERE | Houses With Docks; A Place for the Boat
description: WHO -- Bram Oudshoorn, 69, a retired mariner from Nanoose, British Columbia, and his wife, Marijke Oudshoorn, 65, a retired hairdresser WHERE -- Gabriola Island, British Columbia WHAT -- 2-bedroom house

title: Pataki's Point Man Tries to Strike a Bargain
description: KENNETH J. RINGLER JR., the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, is twiddling his thumbs, not because he's idling in his power broker-size office on Park Avenue South, but because he's nervous about making conversation, especially if it involves personal revelations. Or, even more traumatizing, professional revelations.

title: A Military Raid Frees 3 Hostages Held in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 23 - Acting on a tip from a detainee, a multinational military force stormed a house in western Baghdad early Thursday and rescued two Canadians and a Briton who had been held hostage by a shadowy guerrilla group for four months.

title: The Listings: March 24 - March 30
description: Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Judge Sets Deadline For Voting Plan
description: A federal judge ordered New York yesterday to produce a plan by April 10 to comply with provisions of the Help America Vote Act that require the state to create a database of registered voters and to make its voting machines usable by the disabled. New York has lagged behind all other states in complying with the law, which was passed after the 2000 presidential election, and on March 1 the United States Justice Department sued New York. The state said it would not be able to replace all of its lever-activated voting machines by the fall elections, but proposed an interim plan that would put at least one machine accessible to the disabled at each polling site. MICHAEL COOPER (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: New Central Bank Head
description: South Korea's presidential office nominated a Bank of Korea deputy governor, Lee Seong Tae, to succeed Park Seung as central bank leader. Mr. Lee, 60, is a 38-year veteran at the bank with a master's in economics from the University of Illinois. He was chosen to succeed Mr. Park by a presidential committee in Seoul, a spokesman said.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9:30 P.M. (Disney) HANNAH MONTANA -- Series premiere. Hannah (13-year-old Miley Cyrus) is a huge teenage pop star. She's also Miley Stewart, an ordinary middle school girl with a best friend (Emily Osment, Haley Joel Osment's younger sister), cool-girl tormenters and a protective father (played by her real father, the country music star Billy Ray Cyrus. above with Ms. Cyrus). It's fairly remarkable that Miley's friends don't recognize her, even up-close backstage, with blond hair and dark glasses. But that sort of thing always worked for Lucy Ricardo. And Clark Kent did it with just eyeglasses.

title: Speak Softly and Carry a Smaller Stick
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACMITCHELL, LESLIE
description: MacMITCHELL - Leslie. World-class distant runner in the 1940s. MacMitchell was undefeated in intercollegiate cross-country and in 1942 equaled the existing world record in the indoor mile run. He was king of the 1000 yard run, winning all his races at that distance. He leaves his wife Jill, one son and two daughters.

title: Sharon just a shadow now, but a big one
Taiwan opposition looks for accord on arms deal
'Martin'
description: In this splattery George A. Romero movie from 1977, the title character is not your typical vampire. In fact, he may not be a vampire at all. I mean, did Count Dracula ever need hypodermic needles (for sedation) or razor blades? Mr. Romero, the director who gave the world the ravenous 20th-century zombies of "Night of the Living Dead," plays around with the possibility that Martin (John Amplas, above) is just certifiably psychotic. The young man doesn't talk much in person, but he calls a late-night talk-radio host to chat about his blood-drinking habit. And he makes it clear that he doesn't believe in the supernatural. When an elderly white-haired man follows him around calling him Nosferatu, Martin corrects him with the truth: "I'm your cousin." When the movie is shown on Monday night, it will have the distinction of being part of two BAMcinmatek film festivals at once. One is "Some Kind of Horror Show," which ends on Thursday. And it is the closing feature of "Mark Morris & Movies," a five-day series of films chosen by the choreographer Mark Morris, whose dance group is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year with -- not coincidentally -- an engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Mr. Morris, who will introduce the early screening of "Martin," has eclectic tastes. He also liked Vincente Minnelli's all-black 1943 musical, "Cabin in the Sky" and Erich von Stroheim's 1924 silent masterpiece, "Greed." (Monday, 6:50 and 9:30 p.m., BAM Rose Cinemas, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100; $10.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, SYLVIA LIPSON
description: ALLEN--Sylvia Lipson. Born April 3, 1918 in Pittsfield, MA, died March 22, 2006 at NYU Medical Center. A graduate of The Ohio State University, she was elected to the national Mortar Board Society, received an M.A. in Social Welfare, and practised Social Work in Columbus, OH, Pittsfield, MA and Newark, NJ. She was a member of the American Association of University Women and The National Association of Women Artists. She studied with artists including Reuben Tam, Raphael Soyer, John Gundelfinger, and Jack Potter. She had a one-woman show at the Brooklyn Museum and exhibited at the Stony Brook and other galleries. A sister of actor Paul Lipson, she is survived by her beloved sister, Charlotte Paskin, who joins her three daughters and their families in loving mourning, and by her husband, Peter Allen, who keenly loved this most lovable of women and cherishes warm memories of 65 years together. A memorial concert celebrating her life will be held in late spring.

title: North Fork Wine Tasting
description: GETTING to Bordeaux can be a drag. Instead, pack some crackers and cheese and drive out to the North Fork of Long Island, where you can sample homegrown merlots, cabernet sauvignons and yes, even a few chardonnays at some 30 public tasting rooms.

title: Whitewater in the Adirondacks
description: AS snow starts to melt from New York's highest peaks, hardcore whitewater rafters flock to the Adirondacks for two big-boy spring rapids. The Lower Moose River at Old Forge has monster chops -- but for only four weeks beginning in April. If you go earlier, it's all ice; too late, and it's all rocks. The Hudson River Gorge, on the other hand, is navigable year-round, but snow runoff conspires with rain to create patches of experts-only Class V rapids the first three weeks of April.

title: Bird-Watching on Cape May
description: BEFORE the lifeguards start blowing their whistles, visit Cape May on the southern tip of New Jersey for a more subdued gathering. For the next several weeks, train your binoculars over the crashing coastline and open meadows to see migrating songbirds overlap with wintering waterfowl and raptors. This is one of North America's hottest birding spots, and the Cape May Bird Observatory, part of the New Jersey Audubon Society (609-861-0700, www.njaudubon.org), offers guided trips.

title: Spring Breaks; Maple Madness in Vermont
description: FOR those who like their pancakes hot and their maple syrup pure, this is the peak season to sample Vermont's iconic sweetener.

title: We Will Bury You, in Debt
description: WE'LL say this about the early days of the cold war: They taught us to brace for the worst.

title: Bush Is Facing a Difficult Path on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 - In the days before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, immigration policy was going to be President Bush's signature issue. It was central to his thinking as the former governor of a border state, key to his relationship with President Vicente Fox of Mexico and essential in attracting new Hispanic voters to the Republican Party.

title: China Adds to Uncertainty Over Jailed Times Aide
description: BEIJING, March 23 - The United States on Thursday continued to press China about the status of a jailed researcher for The New York Times, but the uncertainty about his fate deepened as a Chinese government spokesman appeared to cast doubt on whether he would soon be released.

title: Twenty Spring Breaks
description: SO you've been cooped up in your apartment all winter like a crazy person. O.K., maybe this winter wasn't so bad. In Maine, people played golf in January. In shorts. There was no ice for ice-fishing on Lake George. The sap ran early in New Hampshire. And in New York City, despite a record 26.9-inch snowfall in February, silk dresses outsold wool scarves at the Intermix boutique in the Flatiron district. Nationwide, it was the fifth-warmest winter on record, and fourth-warmest for New York City, according to the National Climatic Data Center.

title: Toshiba wins patent ruling in Hynix case
Italian banking gambit reveals Poland's unease
Cheney's Needs on the Road: What, No NPR?
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 - Vice President Dick Cheney may be a rock star only to his most ardent Republican supporters, but he has on-the-road demands just like the Rolling Stones. Still, Mr. Cheney appears easier to please than Mick Jagger or Keith Richards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOUDE, RAYMOND W.
description: HOUDE--Raymond W. The staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourn the death on March 8th of Raymond W. Houde. Dr. Houde served at MSKCC for more than 50 years and was recognized as an international authority on evaluation of drugs for pain relief. He pioneered the development and use of methods to assess pain and drug therapy for patients with cancer and was one of the first to investigate the sites of action, potency, and efficacy of morphine and other analgesics in patients with pain. The methods he and his MSKCC colleagues developed continue to serve as models for evaluating the efficacy of new analgesics and for measuring patients' differing sensitivity and tolerance to these drugs. His many awards include the 1992 Bristol-Myers Squibb Award for Distinguished Achievement in Pain Research. We extend our condolences to his family. Robert E. Wittes Physician-in-Chief Lisa M. DeAngelis Chairman, Department of Neurology Jerome B. Posner Attending Neurologist Kathleen M. Foley Attending Neurologist Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PENROSE, THEODORA (TEDDY) FERA
description: PENROSE--Theodora (Teddy) Fera. 94, died in Miami FL on March 21, 2006 following a long illness. Teddy, a long time Miami resident, lived a full and generous life making contributions to Adopt-a-Pet, the Shores Performing Arts Theatre and The American Red Cross, among other beneficiaries. She was born in the New York area on June 19, 1911, the daughter of Henry and Gertrude Fera. From 1939-1943, she lived in Trieste with her then husband Piero Janesich. Their son, Gregor J. was born in Trieste November 21, 1940. During this period, she was recruited by OSS to bring information helpful to the Allies to Allen Dulles in Switzerland. When his role was compromised, she continued to carry information to another OSS contact in Berne. In 1943 the OSS arranged her evacuation by car through occupied France to Lisbon. There she met a U.S. Naval Attache, Wesley Hargrett, who arranged for her return to America by Clipper. They met again after the war and were married. Hargrett adopted Teddy's son who took the name Gregor J. Hargrett. Gregor J. died in 1989. Teddy is survived by her adopted daughter, Gabriela M. Hargrett and two grandchildren, Cristopher W. and Lina M. Hargrett. Memorial contributions may be made in Teddy's name to The Humane Society of Greater Miami, 16101 W. Dixie Hwy, N. Miami Beach, FL 33160. For information: Stanfill Funeral Home, Miami, 305.667.2518. Interment in Montclair, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARIL, MICHAEL J.
description: GARIL--Michael J. Passed away on March 23 at the age of 39. For more than 31 of those years, Michael courageously--and without ever losing his sense of humor-faced many obstacles that would have easily beaten down a lesser person, and he overcame each and every one of them. He was dedicated to his family, his friends, his Dallas Cowboys and the fight against leukemia. To aid him in that fight, contributions in his memory can be made to the Michael Garil Fund for Leukemia Research, c/o Dr. Stephen Sallan at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, 44 Binney St, Boston MA 02115. Michael is survived by his parents, Ethel and Bernie, and by the spirit of his sister Stacey who passed away earlier. Funeral services will be held Sunday, March 26, at 11:45AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, NY.

title: Corrections
description: The Down Time column last Friday, about attractions for children at the Charlestown Navy Yard in Boston, misidentified the hometown of Eleanor Ahern, a young visitor there. She was from State College, Pa. (Madison, Wis., was the home of the aunt who accompanied her.)

National Briefing
description: SOUTH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIBOLK, BILL
description: SCHNEIBOLK - Bill. Col league, boss, and above all, good friend. Your kindness and humanity is our loss. We miss you. Your Mobil friends.

title: Wary of a New Web Idea That Rings Old
description: LAST September, when Di-Ann Eisnor, a 33-year-old entrepreneur, traveled to Silicon Valley to pitch her start-up business to venture capitalists, she stayed calm by reminding herself that it would be like mingling with strangers at a party. There might be instant rapport with some, while conversations with others might wither and die on the spot.

title: Two Freshmen and a Baby Leave Duke Wailing
description: ATLANTA, March 23 - J. J. Redick went to the Duke bench with 13 minutes 36 seconds remaining, his face flushed red, his head down. He had made just 2 of 12 field-goal attempts and Coach Mike Krzyzewski wanted Redick, the second-leading scorer in the nation and the career leading scorer in the Atlantic Coast Conference, to collect himself.

title: A Controversial Therapy for Diabetes Is Verified
description: Three groups of scientists report today that they independently replicated a controversial finding: severely diabetic mice can recover on their own if researchers squelch an immune system attack that is causing the disease.

title: ConAgra Foods Posts Loss
description: ConAgra Foods has posted its first loss in five years as it wrote down the value of some meat, cheese and seafood units singled out for sale.

title: Maryland Feels Forgotten, and the Coach Loves It
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 22 A En route back to campus after its lackluster victory over St. John's on Tuesday, the Maryland women's basketball team watched a satellite-television broadcast of top-seeded Ohio State falling to No. 8 Boston College. The commentators spent time talking about Baylor, the defending national champion, and how Tennessee, rather than Ohio State, should have garnered a No. 1 seeding.

title: Anselmo Colzani, 87, Baritone Who Was a Fixture at the Met, Dies
description: Anselmo Colzani, an operatic baritone whose dramatic sensibility helped make him a fixture at the Metropolitan Opera and other houses in the 1950's and 1960's, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Milan. He was 87.

title: 2 Guilty in 2003 Killing of College Student
description: A jury convicted two men yesterday of the kidnapping, rape, torture and first-degree murder of Romona Moore, 21, a Guyanese immigrant and Hunter College student whose body was dumped beside a parked ice cream truck along a Brooklyn roadside nearly three years ago.

title: A U.S. Advisory About Travel in Italy Becomes a Political Issue
description: ROME, March 23 - An American travel advisory on possible dangers in Italy ballooned on Thursday into an issue in the close national election campaign here, with opposition politicians suggesting that the advisory could be used as ammunition against them.

title: South Korea Nominates First Female Prime Minister
description: SEOUL, March 24 A A feminist legislator imprisoned under South Korea's former military dictatorship was nominated today as the country's first female prime minister, President Roh Moo Hyun's office said.

title: A 'South Park' Character's Return Becomes an Opportunity for Revenge
description: Isaac Hayes left "South Park" after an episode of the animated series on Comedy Central savagely mocked his religion, the Church of Scientology, and its most famous follower, Tom Cruise.

Young Americans, Doing Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Mud Kills 3 at Mining Company Under Fire in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 23 - Three people were killed and more than 20 injured when a wall of mud ripped through a cafeteria operated by the American mining company Freeport-McMoRan on the remote province of Papua, company and Indonesian officials said Thursday.

title: When 2nd-Home Owners Are Gone, Pests Can Become Guests
description: JIM and Sheila Williams and their two children have a second home in the Catskills that abuts state parkland and has been attracting black bears. The animals used to satisfy themselves with lurking at the tree line some distance away. But recently, the family drove up for a weekend at their 35-acre getaway, only to notice that a metal bench next to the house had been upended. And bent.

title: Energy Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Gov. Jon S. Corzine's proposed New Jersey budget and sales tax increase referred incorrectly to the repeal of the previous increase, signed by Gov. James J. Florio in 1990. It was repealed over his objection by the legislature in 1992 after Republicans gained control, not by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who defeated him the next year.

title: 'L'Enfant' ('The Child') Shows a Thief Who Eventually Finds Redemption
description: FOR the past decade, the Belgian brothers Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne have been building one of the most passionately engaged bodies of work in contemporary cinema. Characterized by an insistently moving camera, their films move fast even when the brothers do not. Since the release of their breakthrough film "La Promesse" in 1996, they have made just three other fiction titles: "Rosetta," "The Son" and now "L'Enfant" ("The Child"), stories about men and women engaged in a struggle -- for money, shelter, a break in the fence, a way into the world -- that is inscribed on the very surface of their restlessly beautiful images.

'The Lady in Question Is Charles Busch,' a Portrait of a Performer
description: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by John Catania and Charles Ignacio Not rated; 94 minutes

description: THE lure of kitsch led Leslie Herson to New Hope, Pa., but the nature and serenity of the region made her stay.

title: Singh calls for peace with Pakistan
Tuberculosis Declines to Historic Low in the U.S.
description: Tuberculosis cases in the United States fell to historic lows last year, public health authorities said yesterday. At the same time, doctors said, there was a small but worrisome increase in the number of cases resistant to several drugs.

title: Archi-Tourism in Cincinnati
description: CLOSER than Chicago and with plenty of direct flights, Cincinnati has become a must-see stop on the contemporary architecture circuit. It all began in 2003, when the architect Zaha Hadid completed the Contemporary Arts Center (44 East Sixth Street, 513-345-8400; www.contemporaryartscenter.org), a stack of shifting volumes that helped her win the Pritzker Prize.

title: Long After Strike Shut Subways, Dispute Heads Into Arbitration
description: Three months after a strike shut down the city's buses and subways during the holiday shopping season, the labor fight between 33,700 transit workers and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is being placed in the hands of three arbitrators.

title: Challenge for U.S.: Iraq's Handling of Detainees
description: CAMP JUSTICE, Iraq - The blindfolded detainees in the dingy hallway line up in groups of five for their turn to see a judge, like schoolchildren outside the principal's office.

title: INSIDE
description: Bayer of Germany Bids $20 Billion for Schering In a bid that could help partly restore Germany's historic prominence in the pharmaceutical industry, Bayer bid nearly $20 billion for its smaller rival, Schering, topping a $17.9 billion offer from Merck. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

title: The cost of bad news
Analysts Upbeat About Merger Talks Between Alcatel and Lucent
description: Analysts and investors of the beleaguered telecommunications equipment makers cheered merger talks between Alcatel and Lucent today, sending shares of the two companies and many of their peers higher.

title: Triathlons: The challenge of juggling it all
Garnett Gives the Nets a Preview of What Could Be
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 23 - Kevin Garnett entered Continental Arena on Thursday night with his Minnesota Timberwolves uniform, but he may not have the same uniform the next time he enters the building.

title: Maazel Conducts New York Philharmonic in Emotional Schoenberg and Thoroughly Modern Rachmaninoff
description: In the first two works on Wednesday night's New York Philharmonic concert, Lorin Maazel showed again how he can be an alternately confounding and astounding conductor.
