description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about questions concerning the background of Kathleen Troia McFarland, a Republican who is seeking to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, misspelled the surname of the secretary of state who held office when Ms. McFarland worked at the Pentagon. He was George P. Shultz, not Schultz.

title: Review: Mozart's Women
Police Locate Wife and Girls of Slain Pastor
description: NASHVILLE, March 23 - The wife and children of a slain Tennessee pastor were found alive in Alabama on Thursday night, almost 24 hours after church members found the minister's bloodied body in the family's home.

title: New Directors/New Films Festival Reviews
description: The designation "new" in the New Directors/New Films series suggests not only emerging talent but also fresh perspectives on the social and political pressures of the modern world. One of the best films, "QuinceaAera," examines Mexican-American assimilation in a Los Angeles neighborhood during a real estate boom. A much bleaker view of cultural dislocation is presented in "Man Push Cart," a portrait of a Pakistani immigrant in New York. The fact that three movies having their first New Directors screenings this weekend A "QuinceaAera," "A Soap" and "Eleven Men Out" A have gay and transgender themes suggests that these issues are not about to lose their currency. STEPHEN HOLDEN

title: Art in Review; 'Made in Palestine'
description: Contemporary Palestinian Art The Bridge 521 West 26th Street, Chelsea Through April 22

title: The Listings: March 24 - March 30; CHRISTINA KIRK
description: Ms. Kirk is the kind of actress who can make something out of nothing. A throwaway line becomes a hilarious joke. A silent moment communicates a wealth of character development. She would be a great asset in a terrible play -- resourceful actors always are -- but it just so happens that this tall, blue-eyed performer has a pretty good record downtown. To cite two of her more memorable turns, she found the quiet desperation and dark humor in the character of a writer in limbo in Melissa James Gibson's "[sic]" and proved that she could be a classical ingnue in the revival of the 1930's Kaufman and Ferber play "Stage Door." Followers of the Off Off Broadway theater scene have known about her talent for years, but in Lisa Kron's "Well," Broadway audiences are finally getting a chance to see her in a small role, which, as usual, she makes the most of. In this play within a play (or "theatrical exploration," as Ms. Kron calls it), Ms. Kirk (third from left) is a joyless woman named Joy, adopting a concave posture and hooded eyelids, the picture of ill health. If you thought your grandmother was passive-aggressive, you haven't seen this woman, who shares a room in the allergy ward with a young Ms. Kron, whom she seems to resent for not being quite allergic enough. "If you really love a food," she says, "chances are you're allergic to it." ("Well" opens Thursday at the Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200; $26.25 to $86.25.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Police Save Infant From Drowning
description: A man stabbed his girlfriend yesterday and jumped into the Narrows while holding their 8-month-old son, the police said. Officers pulled them from the water, saving the infant, but the man, Charles Walker, 32, who was submerged for more than 10 minutes, died at St. Vincent's Hospital, the police said. Investigators said that early yesterday morning, Mr. Walker, who lived in Stapleton, slashed his girlfriend's face. More than an hour later, officers saw Mr. Walker jump into the water with the boy. Officer Brian Sheehy jumped in and grabbed the baby, who was floating on his back. Another officer, Matthew Sullivan, found Mr. Walker under 10 to 15 feet of water. The girlfriend and her baby were in good condition last night, a hospital spokesman said. KAREEM FAHIM (NYT)

title: Tee-Hee T.V.
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Fun House
description: A designer's Milan apartment plays off both sides of his personality.

title: Uncharted Territory
description: A word of advice for adventurous surfers: Beware of the bears.

title: Pulse
description: What the salon owner is wearing, the lines don't form here, dragons at the door and like daughter, like mother.

title: Sad Money? Cramers Stock-Picking Prowess In Question
description: Jim Cramer, the explosive host of CNBCs popular Mad Money program, is getting a sell rating from some graduate students at Northwestern Universitys business school.

title: Israeli Firm Abandons U.S. Bid Over Security Objections
description: A leading Israeli software company abandoned its plans Thursday to buy a smaller U.S. rival in a $225 million deal because of national security objections by the Bush administration. Check Point Software Technologies in Ramat Gan, Israel, formally withdrew its proposal near the conclusion of a rare, full-blown investigation by a U.S. review panel over the companys plans to buy a smaller rival, Sourcefire.

title: Gannett Considers Offer For Some Knight-Ridder Newspapers
description: Gannett, the nations largest newspaper chain, said Thursday that it was weighing a bid for some of the 12 newspapers that McClatchy wants to sell after its planned acquisition of Knight Ridder this summer.

title: To Some, Third Quattrone Trial Is Overkill
description: What do John A. Gotti; Cendants former chief executive, Walter A. Forbes; and Frank P. Quattrone, the former investment banker, all have in common? As vastly different as those three cases are, they may all be threepeats, with each facing the prospect of a third trial in federal court.

title: British Watchdog to Loosen Hedge Fund Rules
description: The Financial Services Authority is to allow fund managers to market high-risk hedge funds to retail investors for the first time. Under current rules, British residents can invest in a collective fund of hedge funds, but do so at their own risk.

title: Former Qwest Executives Oppose Settlement
description: Two former Qwest executives have asked a federal judge to reject a $400 million proposed settlement of shareholder lawsuits stemming from an accounting scandal, saying it would bar them from seeking indemnification as they work to settle the claims.

title: Northwest Muscle May Leave Deep Bruises
description: Northwest Airlines, with the sharpest elbows in the industry, is hustling through bankruptcy proceedings, accomplishing in six months what took United Airlines two years.

title: 17-Year Sentence for Investor Who Looted Insurers
description: A federal judge on Thursday ordered Martin R. Frankel to serve the same sentence he got in 2004 for stealing $200 million from insurance companies: nearly 17 years in a federal prison. Mr. Frankel, a former financier, was ordered resentenced after a Supreme Court ruling last year gave judges more leeway in their use of sentencing guidelines.

title: In Winning Battle, Sovereign Management May Have Lost the War
description: Management of Sovereign Bancorp I may have won a battle but lost the war for long-term control of the bank.

title: Spitzer Sues Internet Firm Over Sale of E-Mail Addresses
description: New Yorks attorney general sued an Internet company on Thursday over the selling of e-mail addresses in what authorities say may be the biggest deliberate breach of Internet privacy. Attorney General Eliot Spitzer accused Washington-based Gratis Internet of selling personal information obtained from millions of consumers despite a promise of confidentiality.

title: Mobsters Charged in Penny Stock Scheme
description: Members of two New York organized crime families were arrested and indicted on Thursday for running a penny stock scam that controlled and extorted money from brokerage firms through bribes, threats and violence, prosecutors said.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry of Mills Becomes Formal
description: Mills Corp. in a filing late Wednesday said the Securities and Exchange Commission has commenced a formal investigation of beleaguered real estate investment trust.

title: Show of Hands on Wal-Mart Bank
description: An eclectic collection of 71 groups have signed up to testify before federal regulators deciding, of all things, whether Wal-Mart can open a bank. But like almost anything involving Wal-Mart these days, the dispute has less to do with specific legal or regulatory questions than it does with the deep rift the company has opened across the American landscape.

title: Former Enron Treasurer Backs Away From Testimony
description: Under questioning by defense lawyers, Enrons former treasurer backed away on Thursday from statements that Jeffrey K. Skilling had supported a controversial off-the-books transaction as a way to skirt accounting rules, and admitted to other weaknesses in his earlier testimony.

title: Tim Hortons Float Raises $627 Million
description: Tim Hortons eagerly-anticipated initial public offering raised around $672 million late Thursday for the coffee-and-doughnut chain, which is being spun off by Wendys International.

title: U.K. Government Gets Offer for Uranium Stake
description: The British government has already received an approach for its stake in the uranium enrichment company Urenco barely 24 hours after Gordon Brown, the countrys chancellor of the exchequer, announced in the budget there would be a wide-ranging divestment of publicly owned energy assets.

title: Vector Snaps Up WatchGuard Stake
description: Vector Capital  has acquired a 9 percent stake in Seattle-based WatchGuard Technologies and is looking to gobble up the rest. The San Francisco private equity firm submitted a letter to WatchGuards board last month saying that it was interested in an all-cash merger or tender offer that would provide a significant premium for shareholders.

title: Mexico Warms Up to Private Equity Investors
description: Private equity activity in Mexico is heating up as big players step into the market and the regulatory climate becomes more welcoming. Until recently, there were just a few leading private equity firms investing in Mexico. But lately the Carlyle Group and Morgan Stanley have been making moves to boost their profile in the country.

title: ITV Wants to BolsterDefense Against Private Equity Bid
description: ITV could return up to 1.5 billion to shareholders as it prepares to convince them that they should reject a private equity-backed takeover approach. Britains biggest commercial terrestrial broadcaster is constructing a bid defense despite a lack of support from its largest shareholder, Fidelity, which is understood to be keen for the buyout consortium to seek backing from other shareholders.

title: Schonfeld Group Moves Into Hedge Fund Game
description: The Schonfeld Group, well known for seeding and incubating proprietary traders, is rolling out a new vehicle run by the firms top guns, signaling its entry into the hedge fund world.

title: Private Equity Firms Going Clubbin
description: The grand ballroom at the Pierre Hotel in New York is an unlikely place to hear people talk about going clubbin, particularly when theyre a bunch of Wall Street types wearing expensive suits.

title: Tableau Software Already Envisioning and I.P.O.
description: Tableau Softwares chief executive, Christian Chabot, is confident that his three-year-old start-up will be the next big software company to emerge from Seattle. So confident that the 34-year-old already envisions the first sentence of an initial public offering prospectus  one he believes will read: Tableau is the worlds leading provider of visual analysis products.

title: Siemens Looks East for Venture Capital Opportunities
description: Siemens Venture Capital, the corporate venture arm for Siemens, said that it is setting up activities in India starting in June to look at investment opportunities both in India and China.

title: Smart Technology Unwinding
description: Smart Technology Ventures has decided not to raise another fund after it deploys the capital in its third and most recent vehicle, and at least one STV partner is mulling the creation of a new venture capital firm, VentureWire said.

title: Behind the Lexar Tussle, a Red-Hot Flash Market
description: Lexar Media, a Fremont, Calif.-based maker of flash memory cards, is suddenly a hot company among hedge funds and activist shareholders. Over the past few weeks, several investor groups, including billionaire investor and former corporate raider Carl Icahn, have snatched up its shares, setting the stage for a proxy fight.

title: VCs Take a Chance on Mash-Ups
description: Many venture capital firms are loath to finance mash-ups  online mapping services  in part because they are not readily defensible, meaning they might be replicated by others. Nonetheless, Kleiner Perkins and Omidyar Network, which was started by the founder of eBay, both decided to take a chance by making a small investment in mash-up Platial.

title: Andrx Has Miles to Go Before Deal Is Done
description: Generic-drug maker Andrx agreed on March 13 to be acquired by Watson Pharmaceuticals, No. 3 in generics, for $1.95 billion, or $25 a share, all in cash. But MMI Investments, the biggest stakeholder, with 12.3 percent, plans to oppose the deal, which is still awaiting regulatory approval, and others could follow suit.

title: Tekelec Gets Delisting Notice
description: Telecommunications developer Tekelec  on Thursday said it received a notice from the Nasdaq Stock Market on March 20, indicating possible delisting of the companys stock as it delayed filing of annual results.

title: J.P. Morgan Is Leaving Its Texas Home
description: The namesake of Texas tallest building will soon no longer be its largest tenant. J.P. Morgan Chase is vacating a hefty chunk of space in the 75-story downtown Houston skyscraper that bears its name. Located at 600 Travis, J.P. Morgan Chase Tower opened in 1981 and was originally named after the banks predecessor, Texas Commerce Bank.

title: Big Shareholder Says Husky Energy Is Not in Play
description: Hong Kong billionaire and major Husky Energy shareholder Li Ka-shing said he will not sell the Canadian oil and natural-gas producer, Bloomberg News reported Thursday. Speaking to reporters in Hong Kong Thursday, Mr. Li, who controls a total of 71 percent of the Calgary-based company, confirmed speculation that Husky has many potential buyers.

title: Former CSFB Analyst Files Bias Claim
description: An African-American Wall Street analyst with an Ivy League pedigree said Credit Suisse First Boston executives pushed her steadily down the corporate ladder, replacing her at each step with less experienced white men. According to an arbitration claim filed Tuesday by Anthia Christian, a former senior analyst and stock strategist CSFB, the firm waged a campaign of pervasive racial and gender discrimination against her.

title: What Dell Really Wants from Alienware
description: Dells move to buy Alienware on Wednesday could inject some life  otherworldly or not  into the worlds largest PC company. But what is Chief Executive Michael Dell really getting by buying a niche player in the high-end game machine business?

title: Western European Banks See Sunny Skies Ahead
description: Western European banks enjoyed a vintage year in 2005, as strong income growth, well controlled costs, and falling bad debts combined to produce strong increases in pretax profits. Early 2006 is likely to see a continuation of these factors, and while the headwind of an eventual normalization of credit quality and capital market conditions will inevitably crimp future profit growth, interest rate rises in the Eurozone may benefit margins.

title: British Life Insurer Sees Benefits in Consolidation
description: Life insurer Friends Provident, which saw profits rise 34 percent last year after international sales grew, said it could potentially benefit from takeover activity in the industry. The company has been seen as a possible target after larger rival Avivas approach to Prudential.

title: U.S. Steel: Eat or Be Eaten?
description: So its come to this in the global steel industry: You can make as much news talking about who youre not going to buy as you can actually making a bid. Earlier this month, Arcelors chief executive, Guy Dolle, grabbed headlines when he informed U.S. Steels chief, John P. Surma, that his company would not seek to purchase U.S. Steel.

title: U.S. Ports May Still End Up in Foreign Hands
description: United Arab Emirate-controlled DP Worlds auction of its U.S. port business gets under way, there is increasing concern that U.S.-based terminal operators lack the financing or the operational heft to take over some of Americas largest trade gateways. As a consequence, large private equity firms or foreign-based companies may ultimately lead the eventual purchase.

title: Suez Wants End to Speculation on Bid
description: Europes takeover wars touched fresh depths on Thursday when the French utility company Suez called on regulators to halt weeks of yo-yo speculation of its share price. Gerard Mestrallet, Suezs chief executive, blamed conflicting media reports over the Italian utility Enels plans to begin a hostile bid for Suez.

title: Skeptics Blunting London Rumor Mill
description: Now that the first blush of deal fever has worn off, some London Stock Exchange brokers and traders are starting to ask what benefits, exactly, would come from combining with Nasdaq? The short answer is that no one is entirely sure.

title: Japanese Securities Firm Said to Be Poised to Buy  Stake in Lender
description: Nikko Cordial may buy a 50 percent stake in Tokyo Star Bank Ltd., valued at about $1.2 billion, to become the first Japanese securities firm to acquire a commercial lender, Bloomberg News reported. Much of the stake will come from Lone Star Funds, the Dallas-based investment firm that owns 68 percent of Tokyo Star.

title: Reebok Club to Get $25 Million Makeover
description: The Reebok Club and six other upscale sports clubs are about to get a whole lotglitzier. Real estate developer Millennium Partners, which owns Reebok and five Sports Club/LA properties, plans to invest $25 million to beef up amenities, including the creation of mind/body centers and the expansion of the yoga and Pilates programs

title: Google Joining the S&P 500
description: Google will replace oil and gas producer Burlington Resources in the S&P 500 Index, Standard & Poors said on Thursday. Shares of Google are up sharply.

title: Bayer Makes $20 Billion Offer for Schering
description: In a bid that could help partly restore Germanys historic prominence in the pharmaceutical industry, the drug and chemical giant Bayer  late Thursday announced a nearly $20 billion offer for its smaller rival, Schering, topping a $17.9 billion offer by Merck of Germany

title: Talks for Lucent May Signal End for 90s Symbol
description: Lucent Technologies, the phone equipment maker that became a symbol of last decades boom-and-bust cycle in telecommunications, is in negotiations to be acquired by Alcatel of France for about $12.6 billion, people close to the discussions said late Thursday.

title: The Endorsement Game
description: Another day, another endorsement for Cory Booker. On Wednesday, he won the support of the local firefighters union and yesterday, Cleopatra Tucker, the influential wife of the late city councilman, Donald Tucker, announced that she would be backing the Booker team of candidates.

title: Leaving the Team
description: Sharpe James (Associated Press)

Selborne Journal: 24 March 1759:  Dressed the Rasps. Removed half the Capuchin, & Brown-Dutch Lettuces from Dame Tyrrels Garden back to the new-Garden. Sowed four Drills of Marrow-fat pease in Bakers hill. Sowed a drill of parsley. Yesterday a beautiful Summers day. Grafted my three Cantaleupe frames, & raised them 9 inches behind, & in proportion before. Hyacinths in bloom in the open air; & one Narcissus. Early Tulips have been blown above this fortnight.

title: When the Foods as Good as the Beer
description: (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)

title: Merck Drops Schering Bid After Bayer Rides In
description: Put off by the nearly $20 billion price offered by Bayer, Germanys Merck said Friday that it would abandon its effort to acquire pharmaceutical company Schering.

title: March Madness, Pols and Taxes
As Tim Hortons I.P.O. Soars, Wendys Stock Sags
description: Canadas iconic coffee-shop chain, Tim Hortons, lived up to the considerable hype surrounding its initial public offering on Friday. Its shares leapt 34 percent in early trading in what was the largest I.P.O. in North America so far this year.

title: Update: Details on Potential Lucent-Alcatel Merger
description: The details of a possible Lucent TechnologiesAlcatel merger continued to trickle out early Friday.

title: Does the Left Need Anger Management?
description: When Republican National Committee chairman Ken Mehlman  during an appearance ABCs This Week earlier this year  called Hillary Clinton an angry politician, a mini-hubbub ensued in the opinionsphere over the appropriateness of Mehlmans remark. This must have surprised Mehlman, since calling Democrats angry has been a standard Republican talking point for years.

title: Aviva, Feeling Prudentials Chill, Yanks $30 Billion Bid
description: Another hostile suitor has pulled in its horns. On the same day that Germanys Merck announced it would end its pursuit of Schering, insurance giant Aviva stepped up to say it has withdrawn its $30 billion bid to acquire rival Prudential.

title: On Education: Think Globally, not Locally
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans March 24 column, Worried About Indias and Chinas Booms? So Are They

title: Brick Towers Revisited
description: (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

title: Speaking in Plain English to the Treasury Secretary
description: Readers respond to Paul Krugmans Mar. 24 column, Letter to the Secretary

title: Google Gets S&P Pop (But Will It Last?)
description: Induction into the Standard & Poors 500 Index is a screaming buy signal for a stock, or so the conventional wisdom goes. Index fund managers are required to add such shares to their portfolios, triggering a wave of buying in the market.

title: Openings: PIXAR at the MoMA
description: Roberta Smith of The Times previews the Pixar exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: Clip from James Fotopoulous's Film
description: A scene from "Shattered," a film by James Fotopoulous.

title: The City's Faces
description: John Yang, whose photographs of New York's stone faces are on view at the Urban Center, talks about his works and his inspirations. Reviewed by Robin Pogrebin. Produced by Erik Olsen.

title: A Conversation with William Wegman
description: Artist William Wegman discusses his work and his 36-year  retrospective at the Brooklyn Museum. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: On Top Again
description: (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

title: More Ammunition For FSBO
description: Beware the burglar-broker.

title: Is It the Weather?
description: For weeks Ive seen comments in the press from real estate agents saying that the weather was keeping people from attending open houses and making offers.

title: The End of an Era?
description: Donald Bradley (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

title: The Easy Way to Real Estate Riches
description: Its been a good year so far for all the passive investors in real estate  that is, all of you whod rather sink a few dollars in a mutual fund or real estate investment trust rather than buy and manage property yourselves.

title: Merger of Equals? Credit Rating Firms Beg to Differ
description: Lucent Technologies and Alcatel may say they are discussing a merger of equals, but it is clear that Alcatel will bear most of the credit risk in such a deal.

title: Correction: Vivendi and Its (Potential) Activist Shareholder
description: In Wednesdays item about Vivendi Universal, DealBook misidentified an entity in connection with Sebastian Holdings, a investment firm that is reportedly considering an attempt to pressure Vivendi to sell certain assets.

title: Friday Deal Roundup: Campbell Soup, Warner Music and More
description: Citing disappointing growth in Britain and Ireland, Campbell Soup said Friday that it was considering the sale of its businesses in those countries. It said the British and Irish businesses have annual sales of about $490 million and include brands such as Homepride sauces, OXO dry stocks and Batchelors dry soup and meals.

title: World Cup at Silverstone
description: Formula One likes to boast that it is the third most watched sporting event in the world after the Olympics and World Cup soccer  but that it runs every two weeks, rather than every four years as with those events. So what happens when its races happen to clash with those events? This year the British Grand Prix was moved from its early to mid-July date to Sunday, 11 June. Unfortunately, though, the day before the race England plays Paraguay in the opening round of the World Cup at precisely the time that qualifying for the race is supposed to end.

title: Swallows Return to Madison Square
description: The Shake Shack, pictured here last summer, has returned.(Joe Fornabaio for The New York Times)

title: Bird Flu: Key Facts
description: Science reporter Denise Grady answers some frequently asked questions about the bird flu virus and the growing concerns about a  pandemic. (Producer: Shayla Harris)

title: A King Without a Kingdom
description: Will the political career of Sharpe James be over if he does not run for mayor?

title: Peace Corps
description: After my Tuesday column encouraging a gap year for students abroad, I had lots of emails from Peace Corps volunteers. Typical was this one from Kendra:

title: Coney Island
description: Times reporter Fernanda Santos talks about her fondness for Coney Island. (Produced by Matthew Orr)

title: Diseases on the Brink: Guinea Worm
description: Former President Jimmy Carter and the Times's Donald G.  McNeil Jr. discuss the ancient parasitic disease of guinea worm.

title: Warding Off Snake Eyes
description: When you spend a year in Iraq, driving around on dangerous roads or getting attacked with mortars and rockets on your base, you always wonder what kind of role luck plays in your life.

title: A Continental Shift
description: OTTAWA, March 24 - When the technology boom of the 1990's ran its course, the major companies producing telecommunications gear paid the price. But for all the pain of layoffs and retrenchment, they went through remarkably few consolidations and mergers.

title: Johnson's Crew Chief Returns After Four-Race Suspension
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., March 24 - Chad Knaus arrived at Bristol Motor Speedway on Friday both humbled and driven after sitting out the first four races of the Nascar Nextel Cup season.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. (Similar errors occurred in more than a dozen earlier articles, dating to July 2001.) Mr. Burnett is an executive producer of "Survivor," not the creator. Charlie Parsons, another executive producer of "Survivor," created the format, initially for a Swedish show, on which it is based.

title: Preachers in Kabul Urge Execution of Convert to Christianity
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 24 - Preachers used Friday Prayer services to call for the execution of an Afghan Muslim who converted to Christianity, despite growing protests in the West. The conversion of the man, Abdul Rahman, 15 years ago was brought to the attention of the authorities as part of a child custody dispute.

title: Corrections
description: A Sports of The Times column on Thursday about Paul Tagliabue's decision to retire in July after 17 years as commissioner of the National Football League credited him incorrectly with one policy change. The extension of the regular season to 16 games occurred in 1978, when Pete Rozelle was commissioner.

title: Israeli Athlete in '72 Games Recalls Terror
description: NEW HAVEN, March 23 - An Israeli athlete who survived the attacks at the Munich Olympics in 1972 spoke about his ordeal for the first time in the United States on Thursday night at Yale, warning that reprisal killings of terrorists only lead to "bloodshed and more bloodshed."

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Space Company Loses First Rocket
description: A private venture hailed as the beginning of an age of cheap and reliable access to space lost its first rocket over the Pacific Ocean about a minute after liftoff. The rocket, called Falcon, was launched from the Marshall Islands by SpaceX, which has $200 million in contracts from the Pentagon, foreign governments and private companies to put payloads in orbit. JOHN SCHWARTZ (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOODBURY, GEORGE F.
description: WOODBURY--George F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George F. Woodbury, associated with The Times from December 1948 until retiring in June 1988

title: Ruling With a Little Bark, but No Bite
description: ALBANY, March 24 - When a state appeals court ruled this week that the governor and the Legislature should come up with a plan to send billions of dollars more to New York City schools in this year's budget, they handed the education advocates a moral victory in the legal battle over education financing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OZAROFF, CELIA JEAN
description: OZAROFF--Celia Jean. On March 22, 2006, age 106. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Lila O. Kaplove (Jay). Loving grandmother of Dr. Kenneth A. (Debra Z.), James E. (Debra B.), Jules H. (Sharon G.). Loving great grandmother of Charly Rebecca, Jacqueline, Alizah, Jessica, Zachary, Jillian and Caroline. Services and interment private.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Jagr Scores 50th in Loss for Rangers
description: SUNRISE, Fla., Mar. 24 - The Rangers' success this season still surprises James L. Dolan, the chairman of Madison Square Garden.

title: Jury Weighing Fate of Ex-Governor of Illinois Has Its Own Problems
description: CHICAGO, March 24 - Jurors deliberating the federal corruption case against George Ryan, the former governor of Illinois, did not meet on Friday. It was arguably their best day so far.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. (Similar errors occurred in more than a dozen earlier articles, dating to July 2001.) Mr. Burnett is an executive producer of "Survivor," not the creator. Charlie Parsons, another executive producer of "Survivor," created the format, initially for a Swedish show, on which it is based.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bulgaria: Deal To Let U.S. Use Military Bases
description: Bulgaria will allow the United States to use two military airfields and a training ground in the country, Bulgarian and American officials announced. The agreement, for a 10-year period, will give American forces based in Europe a jumping-off point that is further east. NICHOLAS WOOD (NYT)

title: Take That Trip Without Going Into Debt
description: MY husband and I are squabbling over whether we can afford to take a vacation this year.

title: Go Away: You Can't Vote
description: The right to vote should never be curtailed in a way that disenfranchises a whole class of people. This view is gaining traction even in the Deep South, which pioneered the shameful state laws that barred nearly four million ex-felons, parolees and probationers from voting in the last national election. It's heartening to see those laws being modified or repealed across the country. But states will need to re-educate elections officials, who are often dismally ignorant of election laws and biased against people who have been convicted of even minor crimes. As a result, many men and women who have paid their debts to society remain disenfranchised, even in states that guarantee them the right to vote.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Chinese Man Guilty In 21 Deaths
description: A court found a 29-year-old Chinese gang leader, Lin Liang Ren of Liverpool, guilty of the manslaughter of 21 illegal immigrants who drowned while harvesting cockles in 2004. The Chinese cocklers were cut off by tides in Morecambe Bay in northwest England. Mr. Lin, his Chinese girlfriend and a cousin, all Liverpool residents, were also convicted of helping people breach immigration laws. Sentencing is expected on Tuesday, and they may be deported. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Despite Slips at the End, Florida Is Still Standing
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 24 - Corey Brewer will always remember the two floor burns he wore at the Metrodome on Saturday night, one that put the Florida Gators in the regional final and one that kept them there.

title: Bob Newhart, Button-Down Comic, Is Still Standing Up at 76
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24 - Hidden behind a wide black gate, with a fountain in front and a big pool in back that the grandchildren love to dive into, and with the bookcases inside cluttered with the likes of David McCulloch and Joseph J. Ellis, Bob Newhart's house in Bel Air would seem a perfectly comfortable spot for a man of 76 to cocoon and write his memoirs.

title: Yasuko Yokoshi Depicts Love, the Passage of Time, and the Everyday
description: Yasuko Yokoshi's evocative new "what we when we" is ostensibly about love and its expression in a world that has embraced worldwide cultural traditions and to some extent erased their distinctions. Three men and two women in traditional Japanese dress come and go, slowly but inexorably, during the 70-minute work, which was performed on Thursday night at the Danspace Project.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on March 13, about Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, and the allegations of steroid use by Barry Bonds in the coming book "Game of Shadows," misstated the origin of baseball's antitrust exemption in 1922. It was granted by a United States Supreme Court ruling, not by Congress.

title: Police Charge Pastor's Wife in His Slaying in Tennessee
description: Correction Appended

title: At 18, Oklahoma's Center May Be the Best Player Ever
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 24 - When the San Francisco 49ers would warm up for their annual charity basketball game, a young Courtney Paris would bellow with laughter.

title: Desmond T. Doss, 87, Heroic War Objector, Dies
description: Desmond T. Doss, who as an unarmed Army medic saved the lives of dozens of fellow soldiers under fire on Okinawa in World War II and became the first conscientious objector to receive the Medal of Honor, died Thursday at his home in Piedmont, Ala. He was 87. His death was announced by his wife, Frances, who said he had recently been hospitalized with breathing difficulties.

title: In Bills' Small Print, Critics See a Threat to Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - A little-noticed provision in two key Senate immigration bills would reshape the handling of immigration appeals cases and has touched off an outcry from several legal scholars, federal judges and the policy-making group for the federal courts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Afghanistan's prosecution of a man who converted to Christianity from Islam included an outdated affiliation for J Alexander Thier, who was a legal adviser to Afghanistan's constitutional and judicial reform commissions. He is with the United States Institute for Peace in Washington, not the Hoover Institution.

title: As Palestinians Wait at Iraqi Border, Others Get Threats
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 24 - The bill of death appeared overnight, scattered on doorsteps and littering the sidewalk. It was addressed to "the Palestinian traitors."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEADY, VIRGINIA SCHLEUSSNER
description: HEADY--Virginia Schleussner, 76. Beloved mother, grandmother and friend, and devoted ailurophile, Ginny contributed grace, wit, and a devastating sense of humor. A graduate of The Brearley School and Barnard College, she worked in PR and advertising before earning a Master's in comparative literature at Columbia University. She then taught at The Juilliard School for 15 years, humanities and ESL, and ultimately ran the Academic Department. Ginny had a lifelong commitment to the rescue and protection of abandoned cats. She died surrounded by family and friends on March 19 in Manhattan and is survived by her daughter, Sarah, two grandchildren, Thomas and Madeleine, and her niece, Laura. Memorial to be held at 12 noon on Sunday, March 26, at Frank Campbell funeral home, 81 St & Madison. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Virginia Heady Scholarship Fund for Veterinary Nursing, at Animal General, (212) 501-9600.

title: New York City Meets Stranger From the West: The Brush Fire
description: With a coyote roaming Central Park, celebrity news filling Manhattan blogs, and a Trader Joe's market opening near Union Square, New York City has a lot in common with Southern California these days. But now it shares something else: brush fires.

title: Off Secluded Shores, Another Alaskan Rush
description: YAKUTAT, Alaska - "I should get on with you," said a female flight attendant with a wink as I boarded a plane headed from Anchorage to Yakutat. "You're the only woman on here."

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. (Similar errors occurred in more than a dozen earlier articles, dating to July 2001.) Mr. Burnett is an executive producer of "Survivor," not the creator. Charlie Parsons, another executive producer of "Survivor," created the format, initially for a Swedish show, on which it is based.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, CAROL
description: ROSENBERG - Carol. Be loved wife of Steven. Loving mother of Scott and Melissa. Sister of Marilyn. Daughter of the late Pauline and Louis Weingarten. Daughter-in-law of Lillian and Abraham Rosenberg. Beloved sister-inlaw, aunt and dear friend. Service Sunday 1PM at Community Synagogue, 150 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALKOW, MICHELE G.
description: FALKOW--Michele G., 48, the beloved wife of Lewis R. Steinberg, died at home on March 24, 2006 of esophageal cancer. She was the devoted daughter of Seymour and Florence Falkow, the loving sister of Stephen Falkow, the aunt of Zachary Falkow, as well as the daughter-in-law of Shirley Sobel and the sisterin-law of Carol Strasser and Eric and Adele Steinberg. A librarian, lawyer, and law professor, she was also an avid recreational runner and a four-time finisher of the New York City Marathon. After graduating from Radcliffe College (Harvard University), where she was Arts Editor of the Independent, she received a J.D. from the New York University School of Law and an MLS from the Columbia University School of Library Service. She held a variety of professional positions, including an Associate Librarian and Adjunct Associate Professor at Fordham Law School, as Assistant Legal Writing Professor at St. John's University School of Law, as an Adjunct Professor at Rutgers University School of Communication, Information and Library Studies, and as Associate Director of the Library at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. She was also a past President of the Law Library Association of Greater New York, a Board Member of the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company and a Member of the Schlesinger Library Council at the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard. Her funeral will be held at The Riverside Funeral Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, at 1:15PM on Sunday March 26, 2006. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Michele G. Falkow '79 Fund for the Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, 10 Garden St., Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: Examining the Life of Tess Goell, a Pioneering Archaeologist
description: Tess Goell was the kind of American heroine that seemed to exist only in 1930's movies, played by Katharine Hepburn or Rosalind Russell. They were women bravely striding into what was largely believed to be a man's world -- flying planes, battling city hall, working in formerly all-male offices or newsrooms. Goell strode into archaeology, a divorced, hearing-impaired Jewish woman amid Muslims in southern Turkey.

title: Rival Gives Up Takeover Attempt on Prudential of Britain
description: LONDON, March 24 - Facing unhappy investors and an unfriendly board, the British insurance company Aviva withdrew its 17 billion ($29.6 billion) bid for its rival Prudential P.L.C. on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a woman in McKeesport, Pa., who said she had been held captive for 10 years by a man, Thomas Hose, included an erroneous reference from his lawyer to his whereabouts. He remains in police custody awaiting a bail hearing; he has not been released on bail.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'ER': Aging but Attractive
description: In Nielsen's estimates, Thursday was a mixed bag. NBC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, as its aging "ER" (13.63 million) was the highest-rated hour in that demographic for the night. NBC also benefited from pulling the flailing sitcom "Four Kings" at 8:30 p.m. and substituting a repeat of "My Name Is Earl" (8.71 million). CBS's N.C.A.A. basketball tournament coverage, featuring the upset by Louisiana State over Duke, drew the most viewers over all, and ABC managed to place second among total viewers. A Thursday edition of "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition," the first part of the emotional home show's series on Hurricane Katrina (10.72 million), led into the second week of "American Inventor" (12.99 million). The new Simon Cowell invention competition helped "Primetime" bring in 10.87 million viewers, and ABC was No. 2 for the night among adults 18 to 49. The criticism of its departed cast member Isaac Hayes and the Church of Scientology drew 3.5 million viewers to "South Park" for its Season 10 premiere on Wednesday. It was the highest-rated season premiere for the show since 2002. KATE AURTHUR

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. (Similar errors occurred in more than a dozen earlier articles, dating to July 2001.) Mr. Burnett is an executive producer of "Survivor," not the creator. Charlie Parsons, another executive producer of "Survivor," created the format, initially for a Swedish show, on which it is based.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWRENCE, FLORENCE W.
description: LAWRENCE--Florence W. On March 23. Adored wife of both the late Lewis R. Lawrence, M.D., and the late Samuel Rosenfeld, M.D., and cherished sister of the late Paul E. Wilson, M.D. Treasured by her children, Lynn and Jeffrey and their spouses Michael and Glenda. Beloved by all who met her for her gentle, sweet way, her immeasurable kindness and caring. Her generosity and goodness knew no bounds. A women of tremendous courage, who faced life's adversities head on with resilience and acceptance. We are grateful for the time we had her but her loss leaves a forever hole in all our hearts. Services Sunday, 1:00 PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Homeless Man Dies In Fire
description: A man was killed yesterday when a fire broke out in an abandoned building in Jamaica where he was sleeping, the Fire Department said. The fire began shortly before 4 p.m. in a basement room, where the victim was found, and raced through the rest of the two-story building at 87-46 168th Place. Several people identified the man as Raul Guerra, 48, from El Salvador. He was known as Chop Chop and did odd jobs in the neighborhood. ANAHAD O'CONNOR (NYT)

title: In Chicago, Energizing the Catholics
description: CHICAGO, March 24 - When the Rev. Robert Barron talks about why he thinks Jesus is the answer to what is missing in people's lives, he mentions St. Augustine's writings about the restlessness of the human heart. He also evokes less common figures in Roman Catholic sermons: Mick Jagger and Bono.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. (Similar errors occurred in more than a dozen earlier articles, dating to July 2001.) Mr. Burnett is an executive producer of "Survivor," not the creator. Charlie Parsons, another executive producer of "Survivor," created the format, initially for a Swedish show, on which it is based.

title: Follow the Chopsticks
description: China's relentless economic growth has created severe environmental problems and depleted its natural resources. Its energy demands have contributed to rising oil prices and the gases associated with global warming. So it is heartening when China, the world's most populous nation, takes steps to curb its appetites. We hope other countries (like the United States) may be similarly inspired.

title: First Rocket Is Lost by Space Company
description: A private venture hailed as the beginning of a new age of cheap and reliable access to space suffered a setback yesterday when its first rocket was lost over the Pacific Ocean about a minute after liftoff.

title: Warner Music to Acquire Ryko, Gaining Labels and Song Library
description: The Warner Music Group agreed yesterday to buy the Ryko Corporation for $67.5 million to gain independent labels and recordings by artists including Frank Zappa.

title: Privileged Conversations Said Not Excluded From Spying
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - The National Security Agency has the authority to listen without warrants to conversations between lawyers and their clients and doctors and their patients if a connection to Al Qaeda is suspected, the Justice Department told Congress in a report released Friday.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: A Petition To Overturn Abortion Ban
description: A coalition of abortion rights advocates began collecting signatures to overturn a new sweeping ban on abortion. If the group, the South Dakota Campaign for Healthy Families, which includes doctors, ministers and political leaders, collects 16,728 signatures by June 19, the law banning nearly all abortions will be put on the ballot in November as a referendum. MONICA DAVEY (NYT)

title: 'My War at Home': A Muslim Woman's Critique of Custom
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: American Gets 9 Years For Okinawa Rapes
description: An American civilian employee at the Kadena Air Base in Okinawa was sentenced to nine years in prison for raping two women, according to the Naha District Court. The worker, Dag A. Thompson, 36, reportedly a former marine who sold cars at the base, was sentenced for rapes in 1998 and 2004. NORIMITSU ONISHI (NYT)

title: No Small Feat as Villanova Cuts B.C. Down to Size
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 24 - The N.C.A.A. tournament, home to so many upsets, comebacks and buzzer-beaters, now has its goaltending violation for the ages.

title: In 'Shiloh Rules,' a Comedy, Civil War Re-enactors Do Battle
description: It's not easy finding a new take on something as heavily scrutinized as the Civil War, but Doris Baizley has done it in "Shiloh Rules," an inventive comedy with some drama, history and first-aid tips thrown in. Sterling performances by the six-member, all-female cast make the production, by the Flying Fig Theater and Middle Tennessee State University, a rewarding trip back to, well, the present.

title: Victims of Chile Bus Crash Are Flown to New York
description: Correction Appended

title: Manuel Valera Infuses Latin Rhythms With Modal Drama at Jazz Gallery
description: The blending of Latin music with jazz harmony and improvisation has produced more than a mere hybrid, as a survey of New York's younger players would reveal. Manuel Valera, a Cuban pianist in his mid-20's, illustrates that evolution handily: postbop and classical romanticism are as integral to his vocabulary as Latin folk forms, and they all find natural expression in his music.

title: Travel Deals Lost in the Details
description: THERE is a reason some of the deals on the auction travel Web sites sound too good to be true, Budget Travel reports.

title: H&R Block's Troubles Offer Opportunities for Some
description: It has been one black eye after another for H&R Block this tax season, and its competitors smell blood, which may be good for taxpayers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. (Similar errors occurred in more than a dozen earlier articles, dating to July 2001.) Mr. Burnett is an executive producer of "Survivor," not the creator. Charlie Parsons, another executive producer of "Survivor," created the format, initially for a Swedish show, on which it is based.

title: Brown Says He's Looking for Some Players Who Care
description: Larry Brown is taking the long view, perhaps because it is the only sensible thing to do, and undoubtedly because it is the only way to preserve his sanity.

title: French Dispute on Labor Law Remains Stalled
description: PARIS, March 24 - Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin met with union leaders Friday but failed to narrow their differences over a new labor law that has provoked mounting protests and bursts of violence.

title: George Mason Adds Tape to N.C.A.A. Highlight Reel
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - Throughout this week, large televisions in the George Mason student center played a nonstop loop of the Patriots' N.C.A.A. tournament victories against Michigan State and North Carolina. Between classes and during lunches, students stopped to watch their university's improbable run on the opening weekend.

title: Debating a spare, yet overwhelming, voice
Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about Liberia's request to Nigeria for the extradition of Charles G. Taylor, the former Liberian president, reversed the timing of his August 2003 move to exile in Nigeria and the war-crimes indictment against him by a United Nations-backed court in Sierra Leone on charges of having committed atrocities in West Africa during the 1990's. He was indicted before he went into exile, not after.

title: 'Stay Alive': In This Film the Murder Suspect Is a Beta
description: The star of "Stay Alive" is a cutting-edge video game, but the film still has hackneyed horror at its heart. And worse, it's not even the stylishly, wittily executed hackneyed horror of the "Scream" movies.

title: As Parents Age, Baby Boomers and Business Struggle to Cope
description: Nancy Goodman's employer, a telecommunications company in Boston, offers benefits to help employees care for elderly parents. But she found them nearly useless during four years of caring for her mother, who has Parkinson's disease, and her father, who died of kidney failure last year.

title: Owen's Attitude at Sawgrass: This Is the Week That Is
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., March 24 - As Greg Owen stood over his 3-foot par putt on No. 18 Friday at the Players Championship, the fans ringing the green were still. Even the wind, which had been blowing steadily all morning, paused.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column on March 10 about nominations for country music honors gave the name of the awards incompletely. They are the Academy of Country Music Awards, not just the Country Music Awards.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (BBC America) GIDEON'S DAUGHTER -- Bill Nighy (left), who has achieved American stardom late in life (after playing a wayover-the-hill rock star, the only bright spot in the inane film "Love, Actually"), stars in this haunting television movie as Gideon Warner, a London publicist with nearly godlike powers. But there's one thing he can't engineer: his daughter's forgiveness. Natasha (Emily Blunt) hates him for not being with her mother when she died. All these years later, Gideon may be able to find romance again, with a divorce (Miranda Richardson) whose son has died. But Natasha is his obsession. Like so many reasonable adults, he is a slave of his love for his child.

title: Brokers Plead Not Guilty in Eavesdropping Case
description: Three former stockbrokers from Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers Holdings and four former and current executives at the online brokerage firm A. B. Watley Group pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges involving a suspected scheme to let day traders eavesdrop on confidential conversations.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Afghanistan's prosecution of a man who converted to Christianity from Islam included an outdated affiliation for J Alexander Thier, who was a legal adviser to Afghanistan's constitutional and judicial reform commissions. He is with the United States Institute for Peace in Washington, not the Hoover Institution. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing Democratic women who are running for seats in Congress now held by Republicans omitted a footnote in some copies for the campaign in California's 50th District. The seat is vacant because of the resignation of Randy Cunningham, who was convicted of bribery.

title: Seton Hall's Orr Is Out Despite Winning Season
description: Louis Orr coached Seton Hall to a winning record in the Big East Conference this season and made the N.C.A.A. tournament, but that was not enough to keep him from being fired yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Guilty Plea In 10-Year-Old's Death
description: A man charged with molesting and killing a 10-year-old girl from Crothersville pleaded guilty. The man, Anthony R. Stockelman, 39, of Seymour, changed his plea after prosecutors agreed to seek life in prison without parole instead of the death penalty. Another man was initially charged in February 2005 with killing the girl, Katlyn Collman, after he falsely confessed to involvement, saying he was trying to scare her because she had witnessed methamphetamine production, the authorities said. Mr. Stockelman was arrested two months later, after DNA evidence linked him to the crime. GRETCHEN RUETHLING (NYT)

title: Iraqi Translator Is Accused of Bribery in Kickback Case
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it had arrested an Iraqi-American translator from Michigan on bribery charges in the latest case involving accusations of corruption, which have become a steady accompaniment to the war in Iraq.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Lawless Town's Police Chief Quits
description: Omar Pimentel, the chief of police of the violent border city of Nuevo Laredo, has resigned after nine months on the job, citing personal reasons. His predecessor was shot dead last June, seven hours after being sworn in. In a telephone interview, Mr. Pimenetel said, "My conscience is clear," adding: "I did the best I could. But something inside a man tells him when he should come and when he should go." GINGER THOMPSON (NYT)

title: Time to Stall a Bush Nominee
description: We don't generally approve of holding nominations hostage to other political objectives. But Senators Hillary Clinton and Patty Murray surely have good cause to block a vote on the nomination of Dr. Andrew von Eschenbach to become commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration until the agency makes a final decision on the morning-after pill. There is no excuse for the administration's endless obfuscation and delays on making the pill available without a prescription when the overwhelming bulk of expert opinion says it is safe to do so. The pill must be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, preferably within 24 hours, leaving little time to visit a doctor to get a prescription.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SACHS, ROBERT
description: SACHS - Robert. Former marketing Vice President Harper & Row, Publishers, died March 24. Mr. Sachs was born in Kansas City, Missouri, May 21, 1911 and retired from Harper & Row in 1977 after 30 years with the publisher. He served in the 110th Evacuation Hospital during World War II and was discharged as a captain. He was involved in bookselling and publishing as a salesman, editor, executive, and consultant for more than 50 years, and was a past president of the Pember Library and Museum of Granville, N.Y. and a past president of the Southern Adirondack Library System. Since 1999, he had lived in John Knox Village in Lee's Summit, Missouri. He is survived by his son, Charles, and two grandsons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEWELB, YOLA
description: GEWELB--Yola, 70, of Mahwah, NJ, tragically killed in an auto accident on Friday, March 24, 2006. Survived by her beloved husband Robert, loving children Allison (Robert) Hall, Neil (Susana), Lisa (Terrance) Byrne, and Jodi (Gerald) Hunt. Adoring grandchildren Stephanie, Matthew, Zachary, Jessica, Nicole, Ryan, Lauren and Jillian. Services are Sunday, 12 Noon at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: Senator Sets Hearing on Censure of Bush
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - The Senate Judiciary Committee has set a hearing for next Friday on the call by Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, to censure President Bush for his approval of a program to allow electronic eavesdropping without warrants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLARK, CLIFFORD L.
description: CLARK--Clifford L. On March 7, age 92. St. Luke's gifted choir director, much loved by his siblings, nephews and nieces in Canada. Memorial service April 1 at St. Luke's Chapel, NYC at 11AM. Donations: Amnesty International.

title: Metro Briefings
description: NEW YORK

title: Checketts Buys Blues and Savvis Center
description: Dave Checketts, the former president of Madison Square Garden, acquired the St. Louis Blues and the Savvis Center yesterday for what has been reported to be $150 million.

title: Colleges Slam the Door on Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: Drunken Driver Gets 3 to 9 Years in Hamptons Accident That Left 1 Dead and 3 Hurt
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., March 24 - Evandro Bertuccioli and Eva Krapfenbaur met 48 years ago while picking strawberries in the English countryside. He was 19, she was 17. They married three years later, raised two sons, and retired in 2003 with plans to spend many more years together in their house in Belgium.

title: H&R Block's Troubles Offer Opportunities for Some
description: It has been one black eye after another for H&R Block this tax season, and its competitors smell blood, which may be good for taxpayers.

title: Braving Jail for Democracy, but Is That a Goal or a Tool?
description: CAIRO - WHAT makes a person go to jail for his beliefs and fortifies that person to hold strong while the moments of life -- weddings, births, deaths -- pass by?

title: Washington Post Blogger Quits After Plagiarism Accusations
description: A 24-year-old blogger for The Washington Post, Ben Domenech, resigned yesterday after being confronted with evidence that he had plagiarized articles in other publications.

title: Colleges Slam the Door on Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq Qaeda Chief Seems to Pursue a Lower Profile
description: Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the Jordanian terrorist and the head of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, has sharply lowered his profile in recent months, and his group claims to have submitted itself to the leadership of an Iraqi.

title: A Fine That Fits the Crime
description: THE mutual fund scandals, which exploded with a thunderclap of attention in September 2003, are winding down. You might even say they are over. The more or less final act came earlier this month, when Bear Stearns agreed to a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under which it would pay $250 million to investors for its alleged fund-related transgressions.

title: Film review: A pleasant and vaguely irritating habit
In Mob Trial, a Spotlight on a Rogue
description: Steven Corso -- tax cheat, thief, disgraced accountant -- spent a good part of the week telling jurors at the racketeering trial of two retired New York detectives, Louis J. Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa, how the two men moved to Las Vegas in the early 1990's and committed crimes.

title: Julian Barnett Searches for Rehearsed Spontaneity
description: There's a recurring image in Julian Barnett's choreography, in which dancers, dressed in everyday clothes, ostensibly see each other for the first time. It's like looking at couples in a Banana Republic catalog. Believability is lost.

title: U.S. Maker of Building Materials Rejects Parent's Buyout Bid
description: Lafarge North America, the biggest producer of building materials in the United States, spurned a $3 billion buyout offer from its French parent yesterday and pushed for a sweetened approach.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. (Similar errors occurred in more than a dozen earlier articles, dating to July 2001.) Mr. Burnett is an executive producer of "Survivor," not the creator. Charlie Parsons, another executive producer of "Survivor," created the format, initially for a Swedish show, on which it is based.

title: Family's Goodbye for Crash Victims Is Rooted in Ritual
description: Amid the chaos of sudden death, it is only in a ritualized goodbye that any semblance of order can be found.

title: Bush, on the Road, Adds to G.O.P. War Chest
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 24 - President Bush took to the campaign trail Friday, raising $1.2 million for two of his party's most vulnerable incumbents: Representative Mike Sodrel of Indiana and Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania.

title: On Campus, a Good Man Is Hard to Find
description: When a boy opens his acceptance letter from college, he now has to wonder what most impressed the admissions officers. Did they want him for his mind, or just his body?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Largest Settlement To Date In Ferry Crash
description: New York City has agreed to pay $8.9 million to a survivor of the 2003 Staten Island ferry crash whose legs were crushed and had to be amputated. It is the largest settlement to date from the accident, and one of the biggest in the city's history, the city's Law Department said yesterday. The survivor, Paul Esposito, 27, above, was aboard the Andrew J. Barberi when it slammed into a Staten Island pier, killing 11 passengers and injuring scores of others. The settlement brings payments from the crash to nearly $12.6 million, the city comptroller's office said. WINNIE HU (NYT)

title: U.S. Inquiry Finds Russians Passed Spy Data to Iraq in '03
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - Captured Iraqi documents describe a Russian spy operation that was aimed at the United States Central Command in the early days of the American invasion of Iraq in 2003, according to a new American military report. The report says information on war plans and troop movements was passed through the Russian ambassador in Baghdad.

title: Social Workers at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "People liked the center, and Sharon promised to build them a home there. They liked the builder. But the wish for the center and the liking of the plans doesn't disappear."

title: As Indian Premier Calls for Treaty, Pakistan Says Kashmir Is the Key
description: NEW DELHI, March 24 - Prime Minister Manmohan Singh called Friday for a far-reaching "treaty of peace, security and friendship" between India and Pakistan, in what appeared to be an effort to stanch criticism from across the border for inaction on the contested Kashmir region.

title: Colleges Slam the Door on Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: First Lady Has Husband's Ear, Even About Staffing, She Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - President Bush has said he is listening to advice about his staff from a lot of people, and one of them is evidently his wife.

title: Colleges Slam the Door on Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: Sean Paul, Reggae King, Is Somewhat Hobbled, Not Humbled
description: Lots of dancehall reggae singers have spent lots of time trying to figure out how to turn Jamaican popularity into international success.

title: Red Cross Fires Administrators in New Orleans
description: In a major shake-up of its relief operations in New Orleans, the American Red Cross dismissed two key supervisors yesterday as part of a wide-ranging inquiry into the improper diversion of relief supplies after Hurricane Katrina, a Red Cross official said.

title: The Splice That Binds Two Giants
description: For Patricia F. Russo, pulling Lucent Technologies back from the brink of bankruptcy has not been enough.

description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. (Similar errors occurred in more than a dozen earlier articles, dating to July 2001.) Mr. Burnett is an executive producer of "Survivor," not the creator. Charlie Parsons, another executive producer of "Survivor," created the format, initially for a Swedish show, on which it is based.

title: Happiness Is a Warm Gun
description: WASHINGTON - It doesn't take much to make Dick Cheney happy. According to a list of his travel perks, printed by the Smoking Gun Web site, all he needs is a few cans of caffeine-free Diet Sprite, a big bed, a pot of decaf. (And global hegemony, of course.) Dr. Gloom, who once dismissed conservation as a "personal virtue," likes all the lights blazing before he gets to a hotel suite and all the TV's beaming Fox News.

title: Sharon's Spirit, and Absence, Pervade Election
description: JERUSALEM, March 24 - On Ariel Sharon's 78th birthday a few weeks ago, those closest to him joined his two sons around the bedside where he lies, silent and comatose, in a hospital on a hill high above Jerusalem. They chatted and ate cake made by a friend of his late wife, Lily, using her recipe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, MORTON F.
description: SIEGEL -- Morton F. On March 24. Beloved partner of Arlene Truen, adored father of Wendy and Scott Abish, loving grandfather of Hallie, Brett, Jake, Max and Harry, devoted brother of Selma Rosenberg & Sanford Siegel. He will be deeply missed by his family and friends. Graveside service Mount Ararat Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY, Sunday, March 26, 11 AM.

title: Health Experts Meet in Atlanta to Tackle the Deadly Animal-to-Human Link in Illness
description: ATLANTA, March 24 - Stronger ties between veterinarians and physicians are needed to prevent further outbreaks of the animal diseases that have caused deaths and serious illness among humans in many countries in recent years, international health officials said at a meeting here.

title: Sarah Caldwell, Indomitable Director of the Opera Company of Boston, Dies at 82
description: Sarah Caldwell, one of America's best known and most adventurous conductors and opera directors and the founding director of the Opera Company of Boston, died Thursday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. She was 82.

title: Norman Cleared in 3rd of 4 Trials
description: Clarence Norman Jr., the former Brooklyn Democratic party leader, was acquitted yesterday in the third of four criminal cases central to a wide-ranging corruption inquiry.

title: World Briefing: Americas, Europe, Africa, Asia
description: AMERICAS

title: Defiant Belarus Opposition Shifts to a Jailhouse Wall
description: MINSK, Belarus, March 24 - The young man stood by the prison wall and read the names to a crowd of family members.

title: Unwelcome Attention From Moussaoui Trial
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - The sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui was supposed to have been the government's best opportunity to hold someone accountable for the deaths on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARIL, MICHAEL J.
description: GARIL--Michael J. Passed away on March 23 at the age of 39. For more than 31 of those years, Michael courageously--and without ever losing his sense of humor-faced many obstacles that would have easily beaten down a lesser person, and he overcame each and every one of them. He was dedicated to his family, his friends, his Dallas Cowboys and the fight against leukemia. To aid him in that fight, contributions in his memory can be made to the Michael Garil Fund for Leukemia Research, c/o Dr. Stephen Sallan at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, 44 Binney St, Boston MA 02115. Michael is survived by his parents, Ethel and Bernie, and by the spirit of his sister Stacey who passed away earlier. Funeral services will be held Sunday, March 26, at 11:45AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALMER, RAYMOND
description: PALMER--Raymond. Thanks for all the rides home. Save me a seat at the family table. Bruce

title: Role Player Constructs His Legacy From Pain
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 24 - When guard Cedric Bozeman arrived at U.C.L.A. in 2001, he came billed with Hollywood-size hype.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Heilman Is Learning From the Master
description: Port St. Lucie, Fla. - AARON HEILMAN studies Tom Glavine -- the youngest presumed member of the Mets' starting rotation nesting in the dressing stall right next door to the oldest.

title: General Praises Iraqi Forces in Mosque Attack Mayhem
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - The United States commander for training Iraqi security forces expressed guarded satisfaction on Friday with the performance of new Iraqi Army and national police units in tamping down the sectarian violence that erupted after the bombing of the Golden Mosque in Samarra last month.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 15 about a rent battle at an old warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, misstated the name of a publishing concern that was housed there in the late 19th century. It was McLoughlin Brothers, not McLaughlin.

title: Chinese Computer Maker Is Open to Inquiry on Sale to State Department
description: Chinese Computer Maker Is Open To Inquiry on Sale to State Department The Lenovo Group of China said yesterday that it would welcome a United States investigation to quell concerns about any spy threat from a State Department order for more than 15,000 of its computers. "We have nothing to hide," said Jeffrey Carlisle, vice president for government relations at Lenovo, which bought I.B.M.'s personal computer division last May. But he said no investigation was warranted and expressed concern about the Chinese company being put at a competitive disadvantage in the market for government contracts. The espionage concerns were raised by Michael R. Wessel, a member of the United States-China Economic and Security Review Commission, who said the opportunity for gathering intelligence through hardware and software was "enormous" and needed to be investigated. (REUTERS)

title: Before Sharing Sad Fate, Crash Victims Shared Love of Adventure
description: Correction Appended

title: With Surplus, Albany Prepares Tax Cut Bounty
description: ALBANY, March 24 - Leaders in Albany are negotiating details of a multibillion-dollar tax-cut package for New Yorkers, with relief for married couples, parents and homeowners likely as lawmakers reap the bounty of a $2-billion-to-$4.5 billion surplus.

title: Are Pilots Overpaid?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Pope Installs 15 New Cardinals
description: Pope Benedict XVI elevated 15 prelates from 11 countries to cardinal at a ceremony at the Vatican, the first created since he was chosen pope last April. The new cardinals included two Americans, Sean Patrick O'Malley, 61, the archbishop of Boston, and William J. Levada, 69, the former archbishop of San Francisco and Portland who now has Benedict's old job of prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith. Two others were Bishop Joseph Zen Ze-kiun of Hong Kong, 78, a frequent critic of the mainland, and Pope John Paul II's longtime personal secretary, Archbishop Stanislaw Dziwisz of Krakow, 66. The ceremony raised the total number of cardinals to 193. Twelve of the new cardinals are under the age of 80 and are thus eligible to elect Benedict's successor. PETER KIEFER (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Saturday with a front-page article about New York City's proposal to charge fees at six recreation centers labeled a pair of bar graphs erroneously. The figures represented total attendance, including multiple visits by the same individuals, at recreation centers that have charged fees since July 2002 and at centers that have remained free; the figures did not represent membership. In the three years after the fees were imposed, attendance fell 11.7 percent at the centers with fees and rose 12.5 percent at the free centers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOETHER, HANNAH I., NEE ASCHKENASY
description: NOETHER--Hannah I., nee Aschkenasy, born in Cologne, Germany, October 3, 1915, died February 25, 2006 in Larchmont, NY, and was buried February 28, 2006 in Lausanne, Switzerland. She was a member of the Holland Refugee Committee, a founding member of the Larchmont Music Chamber Circle, a former board member of Young Audiences and of Help and Reconstruction, and a member of the Shaare Zedek Hospital Concert Committee. She was also the devoted wife of Rolf E.W. Noether. She is survived by her brother, Martin E. Aschkenasy; her daughters, Ursula Blumenthal and Carol Hochberg; her grandchildren: Philippe, Jonathan, and Benjamin Blumenthal and Ephraim, Benjamin, and Natasha Hochberg; and her great grandchildren: Emma, Raphael, Olivia, Daniel, Keren, and Yocheved. Her generous spirit and unwavering devotion to family, friends, and young musicians will live on. As an expression of sympathy, contributions are welcome to: Larchmont Chamber Music Circle: Young Musicians Fund (C/O Ms. M. Gallagher, 66 Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY 10538) and Shaare Zedek Hospital (49 West 45th St., Suite 1100, New York, NY, 10036).

title: Are Pilots Overpaid? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Google Finance: A Portal Play?
description: REACTION has been mixed, but mostly positive, to Google Finance, which went live this week. Despite a few bugs, most Google watchers seem to like the service's features, which include news items keyed to stock charts; recent company-specific blog posts; and pop-up information on corporate officers.

title: Selling the Forests
description: It's rarely a good idea to sell off assets to pay normal operating expenses. It's an even worse idea when the assets are chunks of national forest. But that's exactly what the Bush administration wants to do.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 13 about Tony DiSanto, executive vice president for series development and animation at MTV Networks, misstated the role of Mark Burnett, one of the "reality auteurs" to whom a media professor compared him. (Similar errors occurred in more than a dozen earlier articles, dating to July 2001.) Mr. Burnett is an executive producer of "Survivor," not the creator. Charlie Parsons, another executive producer of "Survivor," created the format, initially for a Swedish show, on which it is based.

title: Small Maker of Heart Devices Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry
description: Federal authorities are conducting an inquiry into Ela Medical, a small maker of defibrillators and other heart devices, according to a government official and an industry official.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, SYLVIA LIPSON
description: ALLEN--Sylvia Lipson. Born April 3, 1918 in Pittsfield, MA, died March 22, 2006 at NYU Medical Center. A graduate of The Ohio State University, she was elected to the national Mortar Board Society, received an M.A. in Social Welfare, and practised Social Work in Columbus, OH, Pittsfield, MA and Newark, NJ. She was a member of the American Association of University Women and The National Association of Women Artists. She studied with artists including Reuben Tam, Raphael Soyer, John Gundelfinger, and Jack Potter. She had a one-woman show at the Brooklyn Museum and exhibited at the Stony Brook and other galleries. A sister of actor Paul Lipson, she is survived by her beloved sister, Charlotte Paskin, who joins her three daughters and their families in loving mourning, and by her husband, Peter Allen, who keenly loved this most lovable of women and cherishes warm memories of 65 years together. A memorial concert celebrating her life will be held in late spring.

title: Tere O'Connor's 'Baby' Is a Structured Drive to Distraction
description: Early on in "Baby," Matthew Rogers tells the audience in a put-on twang that sometimes "my mind goes on a trip all over the place, just thinking about this or that."

title: Food Makers and Critics Break Bread
description: IF you want to get an earful about the sins of the food industry, spend a few hours with Kelly D. Brownell. Mr. Brownell, 54, is the chairman of the psychology department at Yale University. Early in his career, he conducted clinical trials aimed at treating obesity, and issues surrounding the obesity crisis -- nutrition, portion size, the prevalence of junk food, and so on -- have long been his primary focus.

title: Hate Crime by a Neo-Nazi Is Suspected in Stabbings
description: NEW PORT RICHEY, Fla., March 24 - In what the authorities described as a possible Nazi hate crime, a man wearing a gas mask broke into a woman's mobile home in this Tampa suburb early Thursday morning, slashed her face and arms, and fatally wounded a friend of her son by stabbing him in the neck.
