title: Red Cross Fires Administrators in New Orleans
description: In a major shake-up of its relief operations in New Orleans, the American Red Cross dismissed two key supervisors yesterday as part of a wide-ranging inquiry into the improper diversion of relief supplies after Hurricane Katrina, a Red Cross official said.

title: Swimmers From the North Delight Scientists and Sightseers
description: The inhabitants of Hoffman and Swinburne Islands, man-made piles in Lower New York Bay off Staten Island, have tended to be there not because they particularly want to be, but because they have to.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: More Students Get First High School Choice
description: The number of New York City public school students accepted into their first-choice high school rose again this year, education officials said yesterday, and fewer students than last year did not get any of their choices. More than 85,500 students applied, and 43 percent were matched to their first choices, an increase from 34 percent in 2004 and 37 percent last year, said David Cantor, a spokesman for the Department of Education. Eighty-three percent of students were matched with one of their top five choices, he said. SUSAN SAULNY (NYT)

title: Formalities Aside, the Devils Win
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 24 - Ken Daneyko had arrived at his private box at Continental Arena when Scott Gomez took the first shot of the game, a big slap shot, and scored. A memorable night for Daneyko became even better.

Quattrone, just days after a federal appeals court overturned his 2004 conviction on obstruction of justice charges.

title: The Abbey Theater's Fiach Mac Conghail Takes a Cue From Yeats
description: DUBLIN, March 24 - The Abbey Theater was already collapsing with debt when the government appointed Fiach Mac Conghail to be its next director early last year. Three days after he started in May as director-designate, a six-month temporary position, the financial picture went from bad to worse. Ireland's mismanaged national theater discovered that its convoluted accounting systems had misplaced an additional million euros ($1.2 million).

title: 'Orpheus Descending,' the Opera, Revived at Queens College
description: Making an opera out of a Tennessee Williams play is like orchestrating Debussy piano pieces, which sound orchestral but only when played on the piano. Certainly nothing could be more Baroquely operatic than "Orpheus Descending," the subject of Bruce Saylor's 1994 setting, now in a revival at Queens College.

title: Bridge; Defenders Holding Trumps Need Timing and Skepticism
description: All no-trump contracts are basically the same. When declarer first gets on play, he immediately attacks the suit(s) from which he must establish the tricks he needs for his contract. In my library, I have only two tomes devoted to no-trump, but I have numerous books on suit play. The introduction of a trump suit produces a great upsurge in complexity and possibility.

title: New Perspective, Same Old Passion

I'm not sure what Calipari was talking about -- probably a confrontation with one of his players. But it occurred to me that Calipari, after all these years, had not changed.

title: Rolf Myller, 79, an Architect and Writer, Is Dead
description: Rolf Myller, an architect whose eclectic pursuits included writing children's books, puzzle books and guides to erotic games and Chinese food, died on Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Out of the Doghouse Into the Grand Tier at the Opera House
description: I WAITED like some subway-riding Romeo, pacing back and forth across the piazza at Lincoln Center with my overcoat and blue blazer unbuttoned, a MetroCard and a pair of opera tickets clutched in my fist. The night was unseasonably mild and free of rain, and my suddenly defrosting heart fluttered at the sight of the fountain in the middle of the piazza spewing water against the velvet sky in little liquid galaxies.

title: A State Says Makers Must Pay for Recycling PC's and TV's
description: Gov. Christine O. Gregoire of Washington yesterday signed into law a bill mandating that electronics and computer companies pay for the recycling of old equipment, enacting the nation's most far-reaching electronic waste law to date.

title: Spitzer Assails Leadership in Ground Zero Stalemate
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, a candidate for governor, expressed concern last night that the Freedom Tower project at ground zero lacked "economic viability" and could turn into "a white elephant."

title: Godlight Theater's 'Fahrenheit 451' Offers Hot Ideas for the Information Age
description: In the most literal sense, the vision Ray Bradbury articulated in the 1953 novel "Fahrenheit 451" has not come to pass; there are more books now than ever. But in a snippet from a scalding monologue in the stage version of the tale now at the 59E59 Theaters, Captain Beatty (Gregory Konow), leader of the book-burning firefighters, shows that Mr. Bradbury's alarm applies just as well to the information-overload age as it did to the novel's alternate universe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSELL, HELEN
description: JOSELL--Helen on March 24, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving and devoted mother of Ruth & Eric Harris, cherished grandmother of Alexandra. Beautiful and brave, elegant and strong. Holocaust survivor and lady. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale. Graveside service Sunday, March 26, 11AM. Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

He was a 190-pound, 6-foot-6 high school center  a player politely labeled a tweener because he was neither skilled enough as a guard nor tall enough to play in the post.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Judge Approves Arena Financing
description: A judge threw out a legal challenge to the way Newark is financing its share of a downtown hockey arena now under construction. Judge Rachel N. Davidson of Essex County Superior Court ruled that it was proper for the city to bypass the city treasury and use money from a settlement with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to finance the arena's construction. Newark has earmarked more than $200 million of that money to pay off, over 35 years, bonds that were issued for the city's share of the $310 million arena, which will be the home of the New Jersey Devils. Ira Karasick, the lawyer for residents who brought the lawsuit, said that he would appeal. RONALD SMOTHERS (NYT)

title: Seeking Fiscal Health Without Gas Tax
description: CORVALLIS, Ore. - Two professors were cruising around the campus of Oregon State University here in a Ford Explorer. A wireless black box, mounted on the dashboard, tracked the miles in a test of a per-mile fee system that state officials said might one day replace the state's 24-cents-per-gallon gas tax.

title: In Basque Region's Capital, Fear Lingers Despite a Truce
description: VITORIA, Spain, March 24 - The permanent cease-fire announced this week by the militant Basque separatist group ETA officially took effect on Friday, but the climate of fear that the group has imposed on this city for decades showed few signs of easing.

title: Tackling the Animal-to-Human Link in Illness
description: ATLANTA, March 24  Stronger ties between veterinarians and physicians are needed to prevent further outbreaks of the animal diseases that have caused deaths and serious illness among humans in many countries in recent years, international health officials said at a meeting here.

title: Po Leyva, 88, Cuban Singer for the Buena Vista Social Club, Is Dead
description: Po Leyva, a songwriter and singer renowned in his native Cuba, who appeared in the film "Buena Vista Social Club," died on Thursday in Havana. He was 88 and lived in Havana.

description: THE man entered the conference room and exchanged hellos and good mornings with his three visitors. These pleasantries were brief, a kind of clearing of the throat. The light of a January day in upstate New York seeped past the barred windows.

title: Connecticut Keeps Enough in Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - Brandon Roy was a potential all-American in need of a breakout party. The day before Washington and its talented but somewhat anonymous guard played the top-seeded tournament favorite Connecticut, Roy received attention largely for not having received attention.

title: The Factories of Lost Children
description: Bethany, Conn. - NINETY-FIVE years ago, March 25 also fell on a Saturday. At 4:40 p.m. on that sunny afternoon in 1911, only minutes before the end of the workday, a fire broke out on the eighth floor of the Asch Building, a block east of Washington Square in Manhattan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Southampton College Taken In By State
description: Long Island University and the State University of New York have struck a $35 million deal to place Southampton College under the state's banner, starting in September. Under the agreement, announced yesterday, the State University at Stony Brook will operate the campus and offer undergraduate classes to 200 students initially. L.I.U. will maintain a minimal presence, through a few graduate and ancillary programs, for three years. The SUNY chancellor, John R. Ryan, said the new college -- to be named Stony Brook Southampton -- would offer studies in the environment, health sciences, and the arts, as well as marine sciences. JULIA C. MEAD (NYT)

title: On Coup's Anniversary, Argentines Vow 'Never Again'
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24 - The posters and billboards vowing "Never Again" were put up days ago, accompanied by special museum displays, photographic exhibitions, books, public forums and television programs. Then on Friday, Argentina came to a halt to mark the 30th anniversary of the military coup that ushered in the dictatorship that may have been the most murderous in modern South American history.

title: Mostly Reading and Math
description: Trying to meet the requirements of No Child Left Behind, thousands of schools are reducing class time spent on other subjects.

Selborne Journal: 25 March 1759:  First Cucumber-blossom fully expanded. Still, grey weather, with a very high Barometer. Some fruit shows on the first runners of some plants. The lining of grass-mowings gives a great Heat to the Cucumber bed. Hyacinths abroad full as early, as those in the Glasses.

Five years ago, Michael Taratuta suffered brain damage when he was struck by a piece of metal fence that fell from the roof. Had it not been for William de Hertburn's name change, the nation's capital might have been endowed with what a great many would regard as a far more appropriate moniker. De Hertburn sounds like heartburn, which is what Beltway commuters experience on a daily basis!

title: Paperback Row
description: PERFECT MADNESS: Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety, by Judith Warner. (Riverhead, $15.) This passionate denunciation of American-style mothering might do for overstressed 21st-century upper-middle-class American women what Betty Friedan's "Feminine Mystique" did for underemployed 20th-century ones. Interviewing 150 mostly well-off women, Warner draws two conclusions. The first is that in affluent America, mothering has gone from an art to a cult and moms are turning themselves into physically and financially depleted drones. Her second argument is that American mothers are backed into a corner by a lack of family-friendly policies (flexible child care, medical services) common in Europe.

title: On Canal Street, a Sooty Survivor of a Grander Time

title: Play It Again, Spike. It's Worth It.
description: SPIKE LEE'S new bank heist movie, "Inside Man," doesn't sound very Spiky. It's a studio film from a script he didn't write, a sleek but familiar cat-and-mouse story with Clive Owen as the bank-robbing cat and Denzel Washington as the detective mouse. But while the film does not offer a Spike Lee vision, he manages to leave some fingerprints. The setting is his usual -- fraught, multi-ethnic New York City -- and even while focusing on the hostage-taking robber and the detectives, the movie glances at issues he has addressed more consistently and thoughtfully than any other filmmaker: race, class and power.

title: Shedding Some Light On Our Addiction to Oil
description: HILLSBOROUGH - WHEN you pull into the driveway, there is nothing remarkable looking about Daniel and Laura McIntosh's old white clapboard farmhouse. But when Mr. McIntosh leads the way around to the side facing south, I see that its sloped roof is covered with flat solar panels, 42 of them.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 26 - April 1; TELEVISION
description: Back in 1972, LIZA MINNELLI, a fresh, exuberant 26-year-old (she turned 60 earlier this month), starred, triumphantly, in her own musical special, "LIZA WITH A 'Z.' " On Saturday night (at 8), SHOWTIME brings it back (restored and remastered, of course), with musical numbers ranging from "God Bless the Child That's Got His Own" to the novelty number "Ring Them Bells," about a lonely 30-ish New Yorker who meets the boy next door in Yugoslavia. The show, which finishes big with the title song from "CABARET," won four Emmys. BOB FOSSE's choreography didn't hurt.

title: Change Is a Force of Nature
description: NOT least among its contributions to popular culture, "Brokeback Mountain" has added a permanent subtext to the notion of two men on a camping trip. "Old Joy," the latest feature by the independent filmmaker Kelly Reichardt, may be less demonstrative than Ang Lee's tearjerker, but it's an altogether shrewder exploration of what can happen when two guys on the frontier lose themselves in nature. In Ms. Reichardt's minimalist road movie, a pair of friends from Portland, Ore., spend a weekend searching for a remote hot spring, and for something even more elusive: the tender, easy rapport they once shared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZINER, ZEKE
description: ZINER--Zeke, 86, March 19, 2006 in Branford, CT. Husband of Feenie, father of Marc, Joe, Amie, Ted and Eric. A tirelessly productive artist, loving and generous husband, father and friend. He personified integrity in both his life and his work.

title: Mob Trial As Family Plod
description: "FIND Me Guilty," Sidney Lumet's New Jersey new-Mafia legal procedural, is not exactly a guilty pleasure. For one, it relies too heavily on five of the most overused words in the cinematic language: based on a true story.

title: Here's an Idea: Let Everyone Have Ideas
description: LIKE many top executives, James R. Lavoie and Joseph M. Marino keep a close eye on the stock market. But the two men, co-founders of Rite-Solutions, a software company that builds advanced -- and highly classified -- command-and-control systems for the Navy, don't worry much about Nasdaq or the New York Stock Exchange.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
description: THE BRIDGE IN MOSTAR, FEB. 22, 2006 - Bregje Esmeijer, 30, an administrator from Gendt, the Netherlands. "I went to visit a friend, an American who lives in Bosnia. We met last year on a bus in Bolivia and just kept in touch. In Mostar there are certain streets where the buildings are just carcasses. They destroyed the bridge during the war and rebuilt it like two years ago. At noon, I was standing on it and looking over the river, because the water is so pretty. There was a call for prayer from the minaret, and at the same time the church bells started ringing. In a way, because the town is so divided, it was a bit weird -- it could be some kind of competition. But at the same time, I felt it was so beautiful: these two houses of God right next to each other, doing their own thing at the same time." As told to Seth Kugel

title: The First Family of Hyphy Pops a Collar (What'd They Say?)
description: WHEN he was in high school in Vallejo, Calif., in the mid-1980's, Earl Stevens would sit down with a dictionary, the big one, and pick out words to play with. He was the class clown, a drummer in the school marching band and a burgeoning rapper who, in between talent shows, would hone his verses while his brothers banged out beats on the walls.

title: COMINGS & GOINGS
description: After a four-year international tour, Pierre-Auguste Renoir's iconic painting "Luncheon of the Boating Party," above, and other masterworks by Monet, Degas and Bonnard, will be back on view April 15 at the Phillips Collection in Washington, which has been renovated and enlarged. Admission will be waived that weekend to celebrate the exhibition; after that, timed tickets are $12; $10 for ages 62 and up and students. The Ritz-Carlton, Washington, is offering a Boating Party Package from April 15 to July 31 that includes special access tickets that allow guests to see the exhibition any day or time during their stay. Rates start at $370 a night. Orbitz is offering $200 off any air and hotel package of four nights or more to Europe, Mexico and the Caribbean booked through the end of the month for travel April 17 to June 30. Air Canada plans to add two daily nonstop routes between the United States and its Toronto hub this summer. On June 2, the carrier will introduce a daily flight serving Salt Lake City and on July 1 will offer nonstop service between San Diego and Toronto. Spring breakers' party priorities have changed, according to Hotels.com, which recently commissioned a survey of 300 adults in the United States ages 18 to 22. About 69 percent said "Girls Gone Wild"-type spring break events "stopped being cool about five years ago." When asked to choose three essentials for an awesome spring break, a cool hotel, trendy restaurants and nearby shopping, as well as access to activities like bungee jumping, topped the list. Here's a way to get your hands on an advance copy of "Heat," Bill Buford's new book about the chef Mario Batali: take a vacation. Through a partnership with various publishing houses, Rosewood Hotels and Resorts is offering guests at its three Caribbean properties and its hotel in Los Cabos, Mexico, galleys of that and other books up to six months before they hit stores. On April 2, American Airlines will begin daily nonstop service between Chicago and Shanghai. Through June, frequent fliers on American can register at www.aa.com/aadvantage to earn an additional 15,000 miles for first- or business-class travel on the route or 7,500 bonus miles for certain economy fares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, HENRIETTA STRAIM
description: LIEBERMAN -- Henrietta Straim. Born February 25, 1914 in New York, died March 22, 2006 in Sioux Falls, South Dakota. Beloved wife of the late Dr. William Lieberman, prominent physician and surgeon and chief of the Unity Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. Proud mother of Robert S. Lieberman, PhD and Judge Peter H. Lieberman. Beloved motherin-law of Nancy J. Lieberman and Carla M. Lieberman. Services to be held Tuesday March 28, 2006 at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Long Island, NY.

title: Movies on TV
description: ALFIE (2004) Saturday at 6:10 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:30 a.m. on Showtime For heart and poignancy, this remake can't stand up to the 1966 original with Michael Caine as London's original swinging bachelor. And why move the story to New York? But casting Jude Law (left) makes up for a lot. Mr. Law is seductive as the handsome limousine driver who flits from woman to woman (among them, Marisa Tomei, Jane Krakowski and Sienna Miller), carefully avoiding commitment and meaning. The screenplay by Charles Shyer (who also directed) and Elaine Pope pulls off a neat trick: it finds an irreversible sexual betrayal that is as devastating to a 21st-century bachelor as that half-seen abortion was to Mr. Caine's Alfie. The depiction of older women is encouraging too. In the original, Shelley Winters seemed ridiculous; in this version, Susan Sarandon sizzles.

title: Lincoln's Winning Strategy for 2008
description: Let's say you're one of the 36,000 people thinking of running for president in 2008. You're wooing donors (like Zero Mostel in "The Producers"), rounding up consultants and pretending you respect journalists so they'll give you good press when you need it later on. But in the back of your mind you are wondering: How am I going to inspire a war-weary nation? How am I going to unite a bitterly divided land?

title: Colleges Say SAT Mistakes May Affect Scholarships
description: At many colleges, the biggest impact of the mistakes made by the College Board in scoring the October SAT will be on eligibility for scholarships, not on admissions decisions, college officials say.

title: Elizabeth Ceisler and Todd Conte
description: Elizabeth Ann Ceisler and Todd Douglas Conte were married last evening at the New York Palace Hotel. Rabbi Kenneth Stern officiated.

title: For Some Who Solve Puzzle, Medicare Drug Plan Pays Off
description: TULSA, Okla., March 21 - When Virginia G. Shores went to a pharmacy here to pick up five prescriptions, she thought she heard the pharmacist say she owed $250, but she was wrong. The cost, with her new Medicare prescription drug card, was just $50.

title: After Decades, New High-End Rentals
description: NEWARK - IT took five years of struggling to convince financiers that a high-end rental building in Newark made any sense at all. It also took a total gut rehab of a high-rise building that had stood empty for 20 years.

title: Millionaires Made Of Steel May Avoid An Old Tax
description: GREENWICH'S well-to-do have been known to drop $10 million for a house that makes a statement. Suits, dresses and accessories purchased at stores with long pedigrees and at cheekier newcomers with names like "Rags" can easily run into the thousands of dollars.

title: Searching for Dummies
description: Plainsboro, N.J. - TALK of decline was old news in academia even in 1898, when traditionalists blasted Harvard for ending its Greek entrance requirement. But today there's a new twist in the story: Are search engines making today's students dumber?

title: Anguish Before Another Big Test
description: STUNG by a record-setting wave of budget defeats in 2005, school districts across the Island are digging in to the budget process early this year.

title: Of the Rich, Eminent Domain ... and Golf
description: North Hills, N.Y. - IF they ever decide to rewrite "The Great Gatsby" as a land-use and property law textbook, it will read pretty much like the battle between the haves and the have-mores now playing out on the North Shore of Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   JANOFF, IZZY
description: JANOFF--Izzy. Dear Izzy, Nothing lasts forever but the love that bears your name. Betty, Jessica and Beryl and grandchildren

title: Deborah Morris and John Hollingsworth
description: Deborah S. Morris, a newspaper reporter, and John Damion Hollingsworth, a firefighter, were married yesterday at Christ Baptist Church in Coram, N.Y. The Rev. Willie R. Jones Sr., a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Why Is Michael Steele a Republican Candidate?
description: Correction Appended

title: Dylan Plays, They Score
description: When Bob Dylan begins his spring tour in Reno on Saturday, several thousand fans will be rooting for him to play one or another song. They won't be at the show. And they may not even like the song. But they are competitors in the Dylan Pool (pool.dylantree.com), an online game that awards points to players who correctly predict the lineup of the mercurial singer's concerts.

title: State Seeks Comments About Its Rest Stops
description: The state is planning to upgrade its highway rest areas and is seeking opinions from the public on what improvements are needed.

title: From Finland, Wearing Large Tutus
description: FINLAND, though internationally known for its music, architecture and design, has been keeping cultural secrets from America. Contemporary dance, for one.

title: Trans-Nascar
description: The word Nascar usually conjures up speed or adrenaline. But with "Inside-Out Nascar," an artwork by Dan Devine on view at the Pierogi gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, quiet contemplation is more the ticket. Mr. Devine, 65, an artist and former professional motocross racer from 1962 to 1972, said he spent about 1,000 hours turning a Chevrolet Monte Carlo Nascar inside-out, bumper to bumper.

title: After Katrina, Taking On 'Big Dogs'
description: JOHN ADRIANI JR., who grew up in Shelton, was drawn to New Orleans by his family. His father, John, was born and raised there, and John Jr. spent summers at his grandparents' home in the city. It probably was no surprise that he ended up attending college in New Orleans, and it probably is no surprise that he now wants to be mayor.

title: Nena O'Neill, 82, an Author of 'Open Marriage,' Is Dead
description: Nena O'Neill, one half of the husband-and-wife team whose best-selling book "Open Marriage" helped spread the youthful sexual revolution of the 1960's to the middle-aged, middle-class Middle America of the 1970's, died on March 9 in Manhattan. She was 82 and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: Robin Hood Joins the Sheriff's Department
description: THERE was Jon S. Corzine, at a debate in the 2000 Senate primary campaign, scolding former Gov. Jim Florio: If he had been the governor instead of Mr. Florio, the liberal outsider said, he would not have raised "the most regressive" tax -- the state sales tax.

title: Baked Greens and Ill Winds Conspire for Diabolical Day
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., March 25 - As Arron Oberholser stood on the 17th tee box at T.P.C. at Sawgrass on Saturday, his mind was like a radio caught between channels. He could not dial in on any single voice in his head because of the static created by a multitude of voices: one telling him to hit an 8-iron, another advising him to be mindful of the wind gusts and a third remarking on how cool it was to be tied for the lead in the third round of The Players Championship.

title: Disco Balls and Scents
description: "THIS room is like an organism," said David Sarner, an owner of Pink Elephant, the newest addition to Chelsea's club row on 27th Street. Dressed in a button-down shirt and a suit jacket, he dissected the anatomy of his amber-hued "ultra V.I.P. lounge."

title: A Squirrel That Can Dive Anywhere It Likes
description: WHAT makes someone an artist?

title: The Fallback
description: Democrats and Republicans alike can learn much from Mark Warner's consensus-building, nonpolarizing (and spectacularly successful) method of governing Virginia. At a time when Hillary Clinton is considered a virtual shoo-in for the nomination, the Democratic Party needs to reassess its lackluster strategy of nominating candidates who energize the party base while laboring to win one or two swing states. In contrast, Warner embodies what a Democratic candidate should be: a passionate Southern centrist who can attract voters beyond the coastal and urban areas of the country.

title: Mating Attack in the Endgame? Onischuk Shows How It's Done
description: The United States Championship, held at the NTC Promenade in San Diego from March 1 to 12, was won by Alexander Onischuk, who defeated Yuri Shulman in a rapid-play final by 1 1/2- 1/2. The two-game set-to was played at the pace of 30 minutes a game plus a bonus of five seconds a move.

title: Even the Losers Get Lucky Sometimes
description: FIRED! Tales of the Canned, Canceled, Downsized and Dismissed By Annabelle Gurwitch. 238 pp., Touchstone. $19.95.

title: The Her in History
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar Deadline For Summer Events
description: On May 21, the Westchester section will run a special summer calendar featuring selected arts and entertainment events and exhibitions taking place between Memorial Day and Labor Day.

title: A Dramatic Shut-In
description: It's hard to talk about theater in the morning and especially hard when the vacuum cleaner is so loud. As the playwright Richard Greenberg and the director Doug Hughes hung around the stage of the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center waiting for the noise to subside and their meeting to begin, some not-so-idle chitchat was in order. Hughes's Broadway production of "Doubt" had just changed casts and been re-reviewed, mostly positively, the previous day.

title: Oh, Where, Oh, Where ...
description: LAST Monday morning, Phoebe Booth received a call at her home in Redding, Conn., that compelled her to jump in her blue and white van and drive immediately to Flushing, Queens. That morning, there had been a sighting on Utopia Parkway of an extremely elusive subject: Ch. Bohem C'est La Vie, a k a Vivi, the show dog who escaped from the tarmac of Kennedy Airport five weeks ago.

title: Required for the Course: A Night at the Cabaret
description: The course description did not mention a field trip. But there they were, three students and the instructor, at the Cafe Carlyle, with the Verts murals on the walls and the candles flickering on the tables.

title: Buck Owens, Country Singer, Dies at 76
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 - Buck Owens, the maverick honky-tonk singer who scored a string of country hits that included "Act Naturally" and "Waitin' in Your Welfare Line" before steering country music to television as a co-host of the series "Hee Haw," died on Saturday at his home in Bakersfield. He was 76.

title: Medicine Is a Mixed Blessing for Cyclist
description: PARIS, March 25 A Franck Bouyer said he was touched by the support his fellow riders showed before the Cholet-Pays de Loire race. First they signed a petition calling for justice and then, as they gathered at the start line, a teammate read a statement urging officials "to agree finally on Franck's case and show their good faith."

title: A Woman Without Importance
description: KHANPUR, Pakistan - Aisha Parveen doesn't matter. She's simply one more impoverished girl from the countryside, and if her brothel's owner goes ahead and kills her, almost no one will care.

title: Florida Not Experiencing Any Sophomore Jinx
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 25 - The starting lineup for the Florida Gators was assembled mainly by the university's department of housing and residence education.

title: Something Fresh Wafting Up From a Times Square Grate: Art
description: Even in the cacophony of staccato noise that defines Times Square, one sound seems particularly intriguing. Depending on one's ear it is either a continuous oooom-like mantra, a moan, a reverberating bell or an organlike drone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESTABROOK, F. REED, JR.
description: ESTABROOK--F. Reed, Jr. The entire Avon Old Farms School community mourns the passing of our esteemed alumnus, Director, and former Board Chairman. A member of the Class of 1936, Reed Estabrook was "Mr. Avon Old Farms" to thousands of students, alumni, faculty and staff and their families. He served as an active member of the Board of Directors from 1948 until his death--providing extraordinary vision, leadership and support for every aspect of the School. He chaired the Board from 1965 to 1992. Moreover, he represented the School throughout the independent secondary school community and was instrumental in the founding of the Independent School Chairman's Association. In 1947--following World War II, when the School was closed and the property used as an army convalescent hospital--Reed Estabrook was joined by a small group of alumni and friends, who worked to reassemble a faculty, staff and student body to reopen the Old Farms campus. His remarkable endeavors and deep passion for the School during the next six decades helped position Avon Old Farms as one of America's great secondary schools. We join in extending heartfelt condolences to Reed's marvelous wife, Nancy, and to his entire family. Rolf H. Olson, Class of '59 Chairman Kenneth H. LaRocque Headmaster

title: 'Pets in America'
After the Shouting, the Dow Hardly Budges
description: Investors evidently had trouble making up their minds about the market last week. Stocks moved up and down, but when trading was over on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average was less than one point from its starting place at the opening bell on Monday.

title: Leon Daniel, 74, Correspondent for U.P.I., Dies
description: Leon Daniel, who covered a parade of major news events of the last half century as an editor and correspondent for United Press International, died last Sunday in Glen Ellyn, Ill., where he moved last summer. He was 74.

title: Blind Spots and Black Holes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANGELICH, GINA L. (DONATELLI)
description: ANGELICH--Gina L. (Donatelli). Of White Plains, NY, at age 32, received the Lord's embrace on December 27, 2005, after a courageous battle with lymphoma. Gina was the cherished wife and partner of George and the loving and attentive mother of Gretchen. She was fiercely devoted to family, and her sense of humor will be sorely missed. Gina's gentle nature concealed a powerful woman. Through her service as a Eucharistic minister, volunteer projects, and commitment to persons with disabilities, she was an example of how to live a virtuous and graceful life. Gina was dedicated to her students at Vassar College, where she empowered young minds to achieve their full potential. Previously, she educated students at Our Lady of Sacred Heart in Pgh, PA, where she succeeded in turning young people into scholars. Gina was a graduate of Duquesne University where she earned undergraduate and two graduate degrees. She is survived by a large family who deeply mourn the profound loss. The family thanks the Lymphoma Service at MSKCC, especially Dr. Hamlin, and Dr. O'Connor. Gretchen and I need you here, but God needed you more. We miss and love you honey. Until we meet again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORRIS, LAWRENCE B., JR.
description: MORRIS--Lawrence B., Jr. Of Darien, CT, died March 22 at age 88. He is survived by his wife, Betty Ann, and his three children: Larry Morris of Boxford, MA; Michele Carballude of NYC; Anne Keyser of Cambridge, MA; and six grandchildren. Memorial Service will be held at the Noroton Presbyterian Church, Darien, CT on Wednesday, April 12 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Quebec-Labrador Foundation, 55 S. Main Street, Ipswich, MA 01938. www. lawrencefuneralhome.com

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 12 about some parents' efforts to buy healthful products for their children misidentified a Seattle food co-op whose newsletter helped one parent in her shopping decisions. It is PCC Natural Markets, not the Puget Sound Community Co-op.

title: Mets Get Master's In Art Of the Steal
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 25 - With the powerful Florida sun overhead, two men walked slowly down the left-field line before a recent Mets game. The older man did all the talking. The younger man never moved his lips as he nodded.

title: A Wrongful Birth?
description: Perhaps there would be no need for "wrongful birth" lawsuits to collect monetary damages if these unfortunate new parents weren't burdened with lifelong, crushing financial responsibilities. Instead, our society could have the compassion to say, "There but for the grace of God go I," and provide some sort of birth-catastrophe insurance to pay the overwhelming costs of raising a profoundly disabled child.

title: The Lines Don't Form Here
description: Last winter's craze for Prevage MD, an anti-aging serum made by Allergan, the makers of Botox, continues. Available only in doctors' offices, 130,000 bottles of Prevage MD sold out in six months with a waiting list in tow.

title: Kristen Edgreen and Michael Kaufman
description: Kristen Elyse Edgreen, the daughter of Sherian C. Edgreen and Robert J. Edgreen of Summit, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Anthony Kaufman, a son of Margaret V. Kaufman and Dr. Leonard B. Kaufman of Glendale, Calif. The Rev. Paul T. Rock officiated at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Your Inner Modernist
description: RECOVERING YOUR STORY

title: More Than the Chili Is Three-Alarm
description: THE broad shoulders of the four firefighters seemed to take up half the space in Model T. Meats shop, a venerable Italian butcher on Graham Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. While the butcher piled $18 worth of skirt steak on the scales, someone cracked a joke about firefighters chasing skirts, and everyone laughed.

title: Correction
description: A photograph of a computer screen with a map of blue states and red states on March 12, with an article about Democratic strategy and prospects in the next midterm elections, reversed the color-coding of Lake Superior and part of Michigan. Lake Superior should have been colored white, not blue; the Upper Peninsula of Michigan should have been blue.

title: Briefly: Lull in fighting brings scholar's call for peace
The Modern Hunter-Gatherer
description: I. A WALK IN THE WOODS

title: Obituaries: Hans Singer, economist who studied world poverty
Roundup: Van de Velde ends 13-year title wait
A Fish Shack With a Secret (It's the Batter)
description: With its shack exterior, the Chippery Fish & Chips is a fish out of water among the split-level houses that line this stretch of South Avenue in Fanwood. But as much as its setting is curious, there is nothing fishy about the fish and chips it serves. The golden-fried fish is so good that customers will often pack in like sardines just to get a taste, and hopefully snag one of the few tables. If not, takeout works.

title: Dara Rakowski and Jay Godfrey
description: Dara Rakowski, the daughter of Shanea Rakowski and Dr. David Rakowski, is to be married this evening to Jay Godfrey, a son of Gina Godfrey and Paul Godfrey of Toronto. Rabbi Eliot H. Pearlson is to officiate at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Miami.

title: Nigeria is urged to hold warlord
FULL WALLET
description: A legal defense fund for Mario J. Gabelli should not be necessary. Mr. Gabelli, chairman and chief executive of Gamco Investors, is well armed for a legal battle with the federal government -- if he should have to reach into his bulging pockets.

title: The Right Start
description: Washington - ON March 13, the New York State Assembly recommended an additional $100 million in new money for the state's pre-kindergarten program. That means at least some state leaders in Albany have gotten their priorities right.

title: Kosher Allure in a Cabernet
description: The surprising sweetness in Baron Herzog's charming 2005 Jeunesse cabernet sauvignon recalls Manischewitz. The wine's name (meaning "youth") suggests Beaujolais nouveau. The grape variety originated in Bordeaux. The lush fruitiness is Californian. Thus this Central Coast red, from the Royal Wine Corporation's new winery in Oxnard, Calif., can provide hints of nostalgia and modernism at Passover seders starting April 12. Skyview, an emporium of kosher wines at 5681 Riverdale Avenue, the Bronx, charges $10.95 and delivers citywide. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: You Must Go On After Beckett. I Can't Go On After Beckett. Go On.
description: SOME years back, the playwright Tony Kushner amused a conference audience by talking about two different types of theatrical enterprises: "lasagna" dramaturgy and "matzo" dramaturgy.

title: Palm Springs
description: WHY GO NOW It's no news that Palm Springs is hot again. Between the design buffs who have rediscovered this mid-century-Modern oasis, and new resorts like the Parker Palm Springs, which fill up every weekend with spa-centric celebrity clientele, this desert town has returned as a Hollywood favorite.

title: SAME OLD SO PAULO
description: To the Editor: "The New So Paulo" by Dan Shaw (March 12), which discussed the highlights of the city, should have included the downsides as well.

title: Calendar Deadline For Summer Events
description: On May 21, the Long Island section will run a special summer calendar featuring selected arts and entertainment events and exhibitions taking place between Memorial Day and Labor Day.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: From Lap to Lap, via Internet and Airline
description: IF you want something badly enough, you'll find a way to get it. Even a pedigreed dog.

title: From Scottish Battlefields to a Classical Venue
description: For centuries, the drone of the bagpipe has been a cry to battle. It was an instrument of war, accompanied by drums and a dagger in the piper's sock. More recently, especially after Sept. 11, 2001, the bagpipe has been more visible as an instrument of lamentation.

title: Christ the King Lives Up to National Reputation
description: GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 25 - With four seconds left in the state Class AA title game, both teams seemed to move in slow motion as Tina Charles dribbled toward the hoop.

title: A Condo With a View (of the Opera)
description: THE developer of a Riverside Drive condominium who kicked off his marketing campaign with a concert by the pop singer Seal has taken a more classical turn. He is arranging with neighboring Lincoln Center to have Juilliard School students give monthly concerts in the new building and to give residents access to hard-to-get seats at performances usually earmarked for donors.

title: Neo No More
description: AMERICA AT

title: Bloom May Be Off Brown Tide, Experts Say
description: Southampton - RESEARCHERS who studied the still puzzling brown tide algae that laid waste to clams and scallops in the Great South Bay and the Peconics in 1985 and several years since are offering a glimmer of hope that the worst of the scourge may be over.

title: The Long Divorce
description: Everybody in New York has a bitter divorce story, even if it's not personal. We all know the friend who can pay either the lawyer or the rent. Battles over children become so brutal that they and their parents are left traumatized. It can never be pleasant to end a marriage, but it does not have to be as awful and take as long as it does in New York State.

title: In Dubai, an Outcry From Asians for Workplace Rights
description: Correction Appended

title: Parties Reach For Dueling Stars
description: Talk about clout.

title: Testing Presidential Waters as Race at Home Heats Up
description: CULPEPER, Va., March 21 - George Allen makes little secret that he is bored with life in the Senate.

title: Lost to War but Not Forgotten
description: Last week marked the third anniversary of the invasion of Iraq. Seven G.I.'s from Westchester have died in Afghanistan and Iraq. Following are their portraits:

title: The Basics; Is It a Civil War, Or Something Else?
description: Webster's New World College Dictionary defines civil war as "war between geographical sections or political factions of the same nation." Is that happening in Iraq? Here is how some have recently characterized the situation.

title: Planning the Great Escape
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y. - "MARCH is the month of expectation," Emily Dickinson wrote so plainly and so presciently up there in her agoraphobic attic in Amherst, Mass., that it seems she actually understood the early spring frenzy surrounding Berkshire summer rentals more than 100 years later.

title: Planning the Great Escape
description: New Paltz, N.Y. - "MARCH is the month of expectation," Emily Dickinson wrote so plainly and so presciently up there in her agoraphobic attic in Amherst, Mass., that it seems she actually understood the early spring frenzy surrounding Berkshire summer rentals more than 100 years later.

title: Sports of The Times; When They Say 'Athletes,' What Do They Really Mean?
description: Oakland, Calif. - FOR the last couple of days, Ben Howland, the U.C.L.A. coach, promoted the notion of Memphis's athleticism, though he was a little bit like Sonny Boy Williamson, fattening frogs for snakes.

description: Correction Appended

description: Correction Appended

title: 8 Sri Lankan sailors presumed dead after blast
Vatican says it's time for ties with Beijing
A Larger Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 26 - April 1; THEATER
description: Even had it not been killed by movies, vaudeville (1880-1930) would never have survived in today's entertainment market, where niche is everything. As demonstrated by the posters, joke books, recordings and rotogravures on exhibit in "VAUDEVILLE NATION," the concept was expressly anti-niche: comedy and melodrama, magic and animals, ballroom and tap dance, family fun and the amazingly bawdy Sophie Tucker. Closes Saturday, New York Library for the Performing Arts, 40 Lincoln Center Plaza, (212) 870-1630; free.

title: The Fallback
description: In your article, we learn that Warner is against gay marriage, for the death penalty and for parental notification in abortion. When are Democrats going to stop looking to Democrats who want to run in Republican clothing? President Bush won two national elections not by appealing to the other party, but by appealing to the base.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALDWELL, SARAH
description: CALDWELL--Sarah. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the death of our dear friend and colleague, conductor Sarah Caldwell. The first woman ever to conduct at the Met, she was not only a trail blazer, but made an incalculable contribution to opera in this country. Her probing intelligence, ready wit, and seemingly boundless energy will be sorely missed. Joseph Volpe, Gen. Mgr. James Levine, Music Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDERMAN, MORRIS
description: LINDERMAN--Morris. November 5, 1906-March 22, 2006. Predeceased by his beloved wife Mae, his life partner of 67 years. Loving, caring father to Essie and Marty, Gary and Janice. And his "adopted children" Rita and George Weissman. Adored "poppa" to his pride and joy Corey. Grandfather to Jennifer and Jeffrey. Great-grandpa to Dillon. Graduate of New York Law School and practitioner in New York for 50 years. Twice candidate for Municipal Court Judge in Bronx County. An exquisite gentleman. One of a kind. Who would walk into an elevator and doff his hat and say "good morning" to whomever was on that elevator. A fantastic kibitzer who could "mix it up" with the best of them. A brilliant scholar... always reading and questioning. He was the most gentle man who possessed the highest degree of tolerance and always looked to settle rather than wage war. As a father, he was beyond compare. Always there to try to ease pain and make things okay. Be at BLISSFUL PEACE Dad. May your mind be sharp and clear and may words never fail you. All my love, "Your Genius" (retired). Services 11:30 Sunday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Ave/91 St. NYC.

Sure, they have it, but topped with tropical fruits like tucum or cupuau and served with packets of mayonnaise.

title: Style; FUN.HOUSE

The shiny hand-held vacuum cleaner he created for Alessi is the epitome of modern sleekness, as are the plastic chairs and tables that he has designed for Magis. But Giovannoni has a playful side too -- one that conceives of things like a squirrel-shaped nutcracker (also for Alessi), a colorful update of Fiat's no-frills Panda or a whimsical, cartoonlike mascot for the National Palace Museum of Taiwan. Whether it's cool or kooky, Giovannoni seems to be able to turn from one to the other on a dime.

I was intrigued by several, but I found myself asking the same question of them all, Warner and Senator Clinton included: What makes you a Democrat? Democrats should choose a candidate by identifying the one who most forcefully articulates a Democratic vision, rather than by trotting out the best fund-raiser or the hottest new property every four years.

She was grateful for a polluted day on which to move; it capped an argument she had been making for months. For clean air, she told herself, they were leaving the only home her children had ever known. Her husband and son had taken the first car early in the morning. But then the cat had escaped, moments before Ann was to drive the family's second car away, and she and her daughter had spent the day in the empty, hot house, waiting for the fickle creature to return.

Seville's Holy Week Rituals Draw In an Outsider
description: ONCE again, it was Tuesday of Holy Week, and the Salinas family was nearly complete. Of the family's 12 grown children, all sons, 10 had made it back for the clan's annual party to coincide with the procession from the Baroque church of Santa Cruz, whose flat facade stands very tall across the street from their palatial home. Among the family members present was Miguel Salinas, the ninth son, and one of my closest friends in Seville. Like many a Sevillian affair, it was an elegant, theatrical occasion: dark suits and deeply polished shoes for the sons; understated dresses for their slender, polyglot wives; an open bar on the first floor that looked down on one of the mudejar patios with its delicate moldings, painted wall tiles and arcades.

But it waited until March 17, when the company filed its annual proxy, to put a dollar figure on his severance package. In a summary table, Mr. O'Dell's $4.01 million in "all other compensation," which a footnote explains includes $3.86 million in severance, certainly sticks out, particularly when compared with the $6,050 in "all other compensation" paid last year to Mr. O'Dell's replacement as chief executive, Thomas W. Swidarski.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, SYLVIA LIPSON
description: ALLEN--Sylvia Lipson. Born April 3, 1918 in Pittsfield, MA, died March 22, 2006 at NYU Medical Center. A graduate of The Ohio State University, she was elected to the national Mortar Board Society, received an M.A. in Social Welfare, and practised Social Work in Columbus, OH, Pittsfield, MA and Newark, NJ. She was a member of the American Association of University Women and The National Association of Women Artists. She studied with artists including Reuben Tam, Raphael Soyer, John Gundelfinger, and Jack Potter. She had a one-woman show at the Brooklyn Museum and exhibited at the Stony Brook and other galleries. A sister of actor Paul Lipson, she is survived by her beloved sister, Charlotte Paskin, who joins her three daughters and their families in loving mourning, and by her husband, Peter Allen, who keenly loved this most lovable of women and cherishes warm memories of 65 years together. A memorial concert celebrating her life will be held in late spring.

title: Books to Chew On
description: FOR certain voracious readers, April 1 has become a red-letter day: It's the one time of the year when they get to eat books. They won't eat just any book, only those prepared especially for the occasion, known as the Edible Books Festival and celebrated in libraries, bookstores, galleries and private homes around the world. Judith A. Hoffberg, a California librarian, came up with the concept over Thanksgiving dinner back in 1999 and decided it would be best observed on April Fools' Day, which also turns out to be the birthday of the French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin, author of "The Physiology of Taste" (1825). Hoffberg describes the festival as a low-key affair: "From 2 to 4 p.m., one looks at the books, and takes photographs, and oohs and aahs. And at 4, you serve tea and serve the books."

title: Global Beats With a Sanskrit Prayer or a British Flair
description: Anoushka Shankar's surname is synonymous with perhaps the most famous name in Indian music, Ravi Shankar, her father. A student of his, Ms. Shankar has played sitar with him in concert and on record. The family includes the singer-songwriter Norah Jones, her half-sister. "Rise" (Angel Records), her fourth album on her own, was released in September and nominated for a Grammy (like her first album, in 1998). "Playing Indian classical music, as intense and deep as it is, freshens my mind and ears to get lots of variety in the music I listen to," she said. Beginning in April, Ms. Shankar will be touring, first on the West Coast with her father and then for "Rise" in North America and Europe. Speaking by phone from India, Ms. Shankar talked to Winter Miller about what she has been listening to.

title: A Wrongful Birth?
description: Elizabeth Weil's article about the Brancas and their son A.J. was heartbreaking (March 12). It is interesting to note, however, that it is only our modern medical technology that makes some decisions so difficult. While A.J.'s parents signed a Do Not Resuscitate order, he would not have survived the first weeks after birth without oxygen and feeding tubes. Not too long ago (40 years? 50 years?), A.J. would have died on his own, shortly after birth, and while everyone would have felt sad, no one would have blamed the parents or the doctors.

He probably would not even need an official car -- just a sneaker budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMPSON, JANA D.
description: THOMPSON--Jana D. Jana D'Aun Thompson, president of Laudus Funds in San Francisco, died March 17 in her home surrounded by family and friends following an eight month battle with pancreatic cancer. She had turned 47 ten days earlier. Ms. Thompson, a native of Arlington, Texas, headed management of Charles Schwab's Laudus Funds. She joined Schwab in August 2000. Previously, Ms. Thompson cofounded the High Yield Group at Fleet Securities in New York City after serving as head of High Yield Sales for Citicorp. She spent most of her career on Wall Street with Lehman Brothers where she specialized in High Yield, Distressed and Emerging investment markets. Ms. Thompson graduated from Lamar High School in Arlington, Texas. She earned a B.A. in International Economics from the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., and an MBA in Finance from Columbia University in New York City. Ms. Thompson had a passionate interest in art, music, dance, sports and the community. She had served on the Board of Directors of ODC/Dance (Oberlin Dance Company) in San Francisco, and generously supported Doctors Without Borders, Emily's List, Planned Parenthood, the Women's Initiative for Self Employment (WISE), the Brent Woodall Foundation for Exceptional Children, Stern Grove Festival, San Francisco Ballet, Friends of Mountain Lake Park and a variety of emerging artists. A cycling enthusiast, she completed the 100-mile America's Most Beautiful Ride in 2004. She is survived by her partner Michael D. Browne and his children, Michael and Catherine, of New York City; her mother Janice D. Thompson, her father and stepmother Dr. Gerald G. Thompson and Linda Thompson, her brother Ken Thompson, his wife JoLee and their children Tori, Trace, Tanner and Tucker, her grandmother Dorothy Thompson, all of Arlington, Texas; her brother Kevin Thompson, his wife Patti and their children Meghan and Hank of Dallas, Texas; her sister Kelly Weeks, her husband David and their children Dylan and Zachary of Huntsville, Texas, and her extended family of treasured friends. The Jana D. Thompson Fund, an annual award to assist worthy students to study abroad, has been established at the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to the Fund. Checks should be made payable to the School of Foreign Service (memo line: Jana D. Thompson Fund) and mailed to: School of Foreign Service, Georgetown University, 301 ICC, Washington, DC 20057.

title: Skim Boards in Laguna Beach, Calif.
description: Being the son of a surgeon, Tex Haines felt pressure to enter the medical field. But while earning a bachelor's degree in biology from Stanford, he found himself designing skim boards in his shag-carpeted dorm room to appease his first passion. That passion traces back to 1961 when he started skimming at Victoria Beach, a cove in Laguna, acquiring an obsession for an ultra-underground pastime initially spawned by local lifeguards. In 1976, Mr. Haines sidestepped med school and opened Victoria Skimboards on Laguna Canyon Road, which snakes between golden bluffs overlooking Laguna's coastline. Thirty years later, at 53, Mr. Haines still skims regularly and remains "chief board tester."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, MARY LOUISE, ''MICKEY''
description: SIMON--Mary Louise, "Mickey", 92, on March 16. Tireless volunteer; friend and helper to all; beloved mother of William, Louise and Neal and grandmother of Alex, Sarah and Nicholas. Memorial service April 22, 2 p.m., Brick Church, 91st and Park.

title: A Poverty of the Mind
description: Cambridge, Mass. - SEVERAL recent studies have garnered wide attention for reconfirming the tragic disconnection of millions of black youths from the American mainstream. But they also highlighted another crisis: the failure of social scientists to adequately explain the problem, and their inability to come up with any effective strategy to deal with it.

title: Elections give boost to Merkel's coalition
Retired F.B.I. Agent Is Accused of Helping in Mafia Murders
description: A grand jury in Brooklyn has accused a retired F.B.I. agent of helping a Mafia killer and bureau informant murder or help murder at least three people, a law enforcement official with knowledge of the indictment confirmed yesterday.

title: Lisa Wanderman and Paul Gottlieb
description: Lisa Philippa Wanderman and Paul Gottlieb are to be married today by Zoe B. Zak, a lay cantor, in a Jewish service at the Kateri Residence, a nursing home in New York.

title: How to Look at a Gift Horse
description: Last week, General Motors, in a cost-cutting move, offered to pay 113,000 hourly workers and 13,000 workers at the Delphi Corporation to quit their jobs.

title: Retraining Laid-Off Workers, but for What?
description: Layoffs have disrupted the lives of millions of Americans over the last 25 years. The cure that these displaced workers are offered -- retraining and more education -- is heralded as a sure path to new and better-paying careers. But often that policy prescription does not work, as this book excerpt explains. It is adapted from "The Disposable American: Layoffs and Their Consequences" by Louis Uchitelle, an economics writer for The New York Times. Knopf will publish the book on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHIPMAN, PAULINE (NEE TOURRE)
description: SHIPMAN -- Pauline (nee Tourre) of Manhattan, formerly of Muskegon, MI, on March 10, 2006. She was active in Civic Theatre playing the leading roles in "The Night of January 16th" and "The Man Who Came to Dinner". Founding partner in Tourre's Soda Grille until her marriage to George E. Shipman III. After his death, she owned and managed Shipman Industries. She retired from Time, Inc. where she had worked for SI, TIME and People magazines. She also appeared in TV commercials and print ads, and was a member of SAG and AFTRA.

title: Cellphones in Flight? This Means War!
description: JOHN BELL HOOD may well have been the most destructive American of all time. He was a Confederate general of undisputed courage and daring, but dazzlingly little strategic or tactical wisdom. ("All lion and no fox," said Robert E. Lee about this horrifyingly misguided soul when it was really too late to do much about it.)

title: A Love Affair, Dumplings on the Side
description: IT'S a yin-yang kind of thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUFFY, BETTY MINOR
description: DUFFY--Betty Minor. The Board of Directors and Members of the International Fine Print Dealers Association sadly note the passing of our colleague on February 13, 2006. A member since 1987 and founder of the Bethesda Art Gallery, she will be remembered as a highly respected dealer who helped collectors rediscover early 20th Century American prints. We extend our condolences to her husband, Douglas Duffy, her two daughters, Wrenetta Ward Duffy, Elizabeth Woodford Lagrone, and their families.

title: The Day the House Blew Up
description: WE went out to the house last month to celebrate Valentine's Day. But then the house exploded. The house that we always joked would be taken from us because of our outsized love for it literally blew up.

title: ON THE WEB
description: In Madrid, the new Hard Rock Hotel on the Plaza de Santa Ana, above, is causing a stir among the area's residents. In a "Letter from Madrid," appearing on Wednesday, Dale Fuchs reports on the controversy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWRENCE, FLORENCE W.
description: LAWRENCE--Florence W. On March 23. Adored wife of both the late Lewis R. Lawrence, M.D., and the late Samuel Rosenfeld, M.D., and cherished sister of the late Paul E. Wilson, M.D. Treasured by her children, Lynn and Jeffrey and their spouses Michael and Glenda. Beloved by all who met her for her gentle, sweet way, her immeasurable kindness and caring. Her generosity and goodness knew no bounds. A women of tremendous courage, who faced life's adversities head on with resilience and acceptance. We are grateful for the time we had her but her loss leaves a forever hole in all our hearts. Services Sunday, 1:00 PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Development Plan Calls For Razing Historic Inn
description: The Canoe Place Inn, a Hampton Bays landmark whose charter dates to 1707, will most likely be torn down and replaced by a private residence club, said the Town of Southampton's supervisor, Patrick A. Heaney.

description: Theater

title: A Family Heirloom
description: At one time in my life I thought that I might be an artist. At that same point in my life I also felt that I might play professional football, and I wasn't that far past the point when I thought I could make myself invisible by shutting my eyes really tight.

title: Italian Mainstays With Unexpected Touches
description: THE Connecticut diner's appetite for Italian food is seemingly insatiable. Counting on this is Cantina Sforza, a recent arrival on the Post Road in Westport near the Norwalk line. Its older sibling, Via Sforza, is a few blocks southwest on the same road in Norwalk.

title: From School Auditorium to Capitol Records
description: THE day before his first public appearance as a singer and guitarist, 12-year-old Javier Coln was so nervous that he hid in the school nurse's office, claiming to be sick. He fooled everyone but his choir teacher, who tracked him down and insisted that he perform.

title: The Scourge of Suffolk Politics
description: AS Thomas J. Spota remembers it, when he first ran for Suffolk County district attorney in 2001, governmental corruption was not a big issue in his campaign platform.

title: Caroline Morris and Marc Lisker
description: Caroline Ellen Morris and Marc Russell Lisker were married yesterday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Robert Toren, an uncle of the bride, officiated.

title: In Club Land, 'Neighbors' Doesn't Mean Nearby
description: A STEADY line of cars, mainly yellow taxis and white limousines, crawled eastward through the night past the floodlit entrances to two of Manhattan's best-known nightspots, the strip club Scores and the nightclub Crobar. Each time a car stopped for more than a few seconds, a driver impatiently honked his horn. It was 2:30 a.m. on a Saturday in West Chelsea, and the party was in full swing.

title: Corrections

Plevan as leader of the New York City Bar Association. That former leader was Whitney North Seymour. (His son Whitney North Seymour Jr. was president of the New York State Bar Association.)

Devoted grandmother of Andrew S. Borrok, Ashley H. Lasker and Alix B. Mueller. Dear great-grandmother of Madeleine Lasker. Services and interment private.

The Board of Directors of The Calvary Fund, Inc. of Calvary Hospital, Inc. mourns with sadness the loss of Yola Gewelb, the wife of our loyal and dedicated fellow Board member, Robert Gewelb. We extend our condolences and deepest sympathies to Robert and the entire family. Richard E. Meyer, Chairman of the Calvary Fund Board of Directors Frank A. title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 26 - April 1; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: This is a week to celebrate ancient cultures. On Tuesday "Hatshepsut: From Queen to Pharaoh," an exhibition about the first important female head of state to rule Egypt (1479-1458 B.C.), opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: 'House Thinking'
description: Some places just feel like home. As soon as you walk through the door, you want to stay. You want to curl up by the fireplace, throw a party in the loft space, lounge on the old porch, or follow that staircase to wherever it goes. These special homes come in all sizes, shapes, and styles, from twee country cottages and grand prewar apartments to rambling suburban ranch houses and small beach condos. What they have in common is a tonic effect on your behavior: how you think, feel, and act. One indication that you're in such a home is that you feel both interested and relaxed.

A Genetics Assignment For Katrina Volunteers
description: DURING spring break, college students who weren't basking in Cancn could be found along the Gulf Coast, helping piece together what Hurricane Katrina tore apart. Some built houses; others removed debris. But one group of graduate students from Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers had a more delicate assignment. They spent a week working at the Louisiana Family Assistance Center in Baton Rouge helping reunite families and identify human remains through DNA testing.

title: Harlan Fabrikant and Brian Saroken
description: Harlan Elizabeth Fabrikant, the daughter of Sara Fabrikant and Charles Fabrikant of Palm Beach, Fla., was married there last evening to Brian Scott Saroken, a son of Lee McLaughlin of Singapore and Gerald Saroken of Bedford Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Dana Rone Saroken, the sister of the bridegroom, officiated at the Breakers hotel.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 26 - April 1; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: The KRONOS QUARTET has been such a tireless explorer of music from around the world that it sometimes seems like a musical travel agent for American audiences. Its latest exploit, "Notes From Azerbaijan," presents music by FRANGHIZ ALI-ZADEH, a "world-class pianist" (in the words of the Kronos violinist DAVID HARRINGTON) who brought the music of Messiaen, John Cage and George Crumb to her native republic. The program includes a sizable work by Rahman Asadollahi, a master of the garmon -- a kind of accordion -- and a political exile who now lives in Los Angeles. Sunday at 7:30, Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; $28 to $35.

title: The Salon Owner
description: With a name like Cozy, it's fitting that Cozy Friedman would become a symbol for the Manhattan stroller-pushing set. The owner of Cozy's Cuts for Kids, three popular uptown children's hair salons, Ms. Friedman provides legions of stylish Manhattan parents with that watershed moment: baby's first haircut.

title: Old World Italian (by Request)
description: THERE is bound to be a story behind a restaurant named Absolutely Mario. At the drop of a menu, Mario Garcia, the owner of this Farmingdale spot, will relate it.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: March 26 - April 1; FILM
description: "THE BEAUTY ACADEMY OF KABUL" is a documentary about what happens when a group of volunteer hairdressers (you didn't know there was such a thing?) set out for Afghanistan to offer their services to the women of the devastated capital city by training teachers for a new beauty school. Financed by American donors, the hairdressers, including three Afghan-Americans returning for the first time in two decades, teach the latest cutting and coloring techniques to aspiring beauticians. The film offers a rare glimpse into the world of Afghan women, usually seen as faceless, hooded creatures, while the director Liz Mermin channels her own sense of discovery on her first visit to the country. Not every movie can teach you, as this one does, about geopolitics and the transformative possibilities of a perm. Angelika Film Center, Mercer and Houston Streets, Greenwich Village; (212) 995-2000.

title: Hans W. Singer, 95, Creator of U.N. Development Program, Dies
description: Hans Wolfgang Singer, an economist who devoted his life to analyzing the causes and effects of poverty and helped create the World Food Program and the United Nations Development Program, died in his sleep on Feb. 26 in Brighton, England. He was 95.

While courts may find concepts like "suffering versus nonexistence" impossible to weigh, prospective parents are often better qualified to do so.

description: WASHINGTON, March 25 - The telephone lines in the unassuming Houston offices of Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, have been sizzling in recent weeks as anxious Republican voters call to find out precisely where their tough-minded senator stands on illegal immigration.

description: MENDELSOHN--Sylvia. On March 25, 2006, of Lake Worth, Florida (formerly of East Rockaway, NY). Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Loving mother of Rosanne & Howard Cohen & Paul & Shelley Mendelsohn. Cherished grandmother of Dori, Hal, Julie, Eric and David. Dear great-grandmother of Emma, Hope, Richie, Lucy and Jane. Devoted sister of Thelma and Bernard Teitelbaum and Martin & Norma Jean Freedman. Graveside service Monday, 1 PM, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: The Madman in the Attic
description: PLAYFULNESS isn't a quality normally associated with Ruth Rendell, whose imagination tends to dwell on the dark side. But writing as Barbara Vine in THE MINOTAUR (Shaye Areheart/Crown, $25), she drolly sends up the 19th-century Gothic novel by taking a perversely sober view of its romantic conventions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   READ, ALICE WINSLOW (FORMERLY MEADE)
description: READ--Alice Winslow (formerly Meade). Beloved mother of Everard Kidder Meade III, Devie Meade and Susanna Schindler, died March 4, Canaan, CT. Born August 26, 1919, Boston, Massachusetts to Alice (Thorndike) and John Devereux Winslow. She grew up in New York and Boston, graduated Concord Academy 1936, later studied art and voice in New York City, worked for American Women's Voluntary Services (WWII). 1944 married Everard K. Meade, Jr. of Clark County, Virginia, and raised three children in Virginia and New York. With a passion for opera and music, she was a Director of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, served as chairman of several committees and was Vice President for several years. After her divorce in 1969, she organized special events and was editor of Quarternotes for the New York Philharmonic. Retiring to Lakeville, Connecticut (1978), she was an active member of that community, served on a number of boards, helped organize a chamber music series, advocated for the mentally ill, and enjoyed being hostess for her great number of friends. Remarried in 1991 to Clifton Read of Cornwall Bridge, CT, widowed in 1994. Survived by her children (above), two step daughters, Alison Read and Sheila Botein, six grandchildren, two step grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Memorial Service: Trinity Church, Lime Rock, Connecticut, April 22, 2006, 2PM. Reception to follow. Donations: Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: Senators' China Trip Highlights Their Differences on Currency
description: HONG KONG, March 26 - A week-long trip to China by two senators sponsoring a trade bill targeting China's currency has revealed differences between them, the latest in a series of signs that they are less likely to press for a vote in the Senate during the week ahead.

title: Redirecting Bullets in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - I GOT back to Iraq two weeks ago, having been away more than a year. The first story I covered began with a tip that vigilantes had hanged four suspected terrorists from lamp posts in Sadr City, a Shiite slum. The minute I got to the scene, I realized I was stepping into a new Iraq. Another new Iraq, really; maybe even the third Iraq I have seen since I began reporting here in 2003.

title: She Has a Thing for Older Doctors. Especially Jerks.
description: "HOUSE" might have been conceived as a medical show, but it quickly evolved into a delicious Gothic romance, topped by a swirl of chick-lit froth. The acerbic, quirkily handsome doc (Hugh Laurie) with a bad leg is the sort of haunted Byronic figure who stirs in women the urge to nurture and redeem. To quote Dr. House, in an example of the show's self-referential sarcasm: "I'm not sad, I'm complicated. Chicks dig that."

title: An Artist and Inventor Working With Porcelain
description: PEOPLE sometimes die in gruesome ways, which can make identifying their remains difficult.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHAPMAN, JOHN H.
description: CHAPMAN--John H. March 24, 2006. Beloved husband of Gisele. Devoted father of Alex Chapman and Cate Chapman, the children of Clare Kenney Chapman, and stepfather of Judy, Nadia and Michele. Cherished grandfather of Jesse, Isabella, Isaac and Jack. His kindness and affection will be missed by all who knew him. Friends will be received on Wednesday, March 29, 2006, 4-7 pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

title: Up Front
description: NELLIE McKAY, the highly acclaimed young singer-songwriter, grew up listening to Patti Page, one of the subjects of Karen Schoemer's "Great Pretenders." In her review of the book (on Page 5), McKay, who is known for witty and biting lyrics as well as wide-ranging musical styles, champions 50's pop, though she has even more admiration for music from the 60's. "Because of the political content," she said in an e-mail message. "The music became a driving force in the civil rights and the peace movements, and a liberating influence on an entire generation." She's a fan of hip-hop, too, though with one crucial reservation. "I like the beat and fervor," she said, "but not the misogyny. Many hip-hop (and rock) artists denounce the war abroad while actively participating in the one at home." Like her idol Doris Day, McKay (pronounced Mac-EYE) is an ardent animal rights activist. Given her passion for artists with a political bent, it's fitting that she's about to appear in "The Threepenny Opera" at Studio 54. "I like Brecht's communist politics and his commitment to those politics," she said. And, of course, she also likes "Weill's intense musicality -- his scores and chord changes and interlocking melodies have no peer."

title: With Elton Brand
description: Los Angeles Clippers power forward Elton Brand is on the short list for the N.B.A.'s Most Valuable Player award this year. He played two years at Duke and was the consensus national player of the year in 1999. Before the N.C.A.A. tournament continued this weekend, Brand discussed Duke, his political interests (he has known Gov. George E. Pataki since childhood in Peekskill, N.Y.) and what's missing from his car.

title: Looking for More Money, After Reaching a Deal
description: LAST week, a group of investors agreed to acquire the company that owns the glitzy Atlantis resort and casino in the Bahamas, for $3.6 billion. The deal was notable for its size, but perhaps more so for a condition buried in the merger agreement that is popping up in the fine print of more and more deals: a "go shop" provision.

title: The Wrong Man: Deception, Mistaken Identity and Journalistic Lapses
description: BAD mistakes happen even at the best newspapers, and public editors should usually watch for patterns rather than single out a specific incident. But when a Times front-page article highlighting the sensitive detainee-abuse aspect of the Iraq war turned out to be fatally flawed, it seemed to me that a closer look at the journalistic practices involved was warranted.

title: When Alien Plants Escape the Garden
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Manliness and Men
description: Please tell me that Harvey Mansfield was just pulling our legs. He has identified himself, the president and vice president as manly men. If manly men are defined by their dogged refusal to allow facts to dislodge their most firmly held beliefs, then I agree.

title: With Some Limitations, a Bargain on Fares
description: IF you've ever traveled through Europe with a backpack and some time on your hands, you've probably ridden the rails using a Eurailpass, still one of the best ways to visit multiple countries in Europe in one trip. For travelers venturing to parts of the globe where there may not be an extensive rail network, air passes offer another way to cover large distances. The passes are sold by about a dozen airlines around the world, and typically allow you to fly to multiple cities within a country or region -- sometimes for hundreds of dollars less than you'd pay if you bought individual tickets. But consumers should be aware that the passes usually have to be used within 21 days or a month, and they often involve some booking quirks and restrictions.

title: The Arsenal
description: The trick to good baked beans is cooking them very slowly with indirect heat. James Beard's recipe calls for baking them in a tightly sealed casserole in an oven barely hot enough to toast bread. As the hours pass, the beans drink up a broth flavored with brown sugar (or molasses), mustard and pepper. The gentle cooking prevents the beans from breaking up and becoming mushy. By the time they're done, the pork is falling off its bones and the beans are the classic rusty brown. Be sure to season them amply with salt so the sweetness has a sturdy counterpart.

title: Born to Be Wild
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pride of Moose Factory
description: There is a town in north Ontario, a remote village called Moose Factory on an island near the mouth of an icy river. Eight hours north of Toronto by car, it is a long way indeed from the National Hockey League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALKOW, MICHELE G.
description: FALKOW--Michele G., 48, the beloved wife of Lewis R. Steinberg, died at home on March 24, 2006 of esophageal cancer. She was the devoted daughter of Seymour and Florence Falkow, the loving sister of Stephen Falkow, the aunt of Zachary Falkow, as well as the daughter-in-law of Shirley Sobel and the sisterin-law of Carol Strasser and Eric and Adele Steinberg. A librarian, lawyer, and law professor, she was also an avid recreational runner and a four-time finisher of the New York City Marathon. After graduating from Radcliffe College (Harvard University), where she was Arts Editor of the Independent, she received a J.D. from the New York University School of Law and an MLS from the Columbia University School of Library Service. She held a variety of professional positions, including an Associate Librarian and Adjunct Associate Professor at Fordham Law School, as Assistant Legal Writing Professor at St. John's University School of Law, as an Adjunct Professor at Rutgers University School of Communication, Information and Library Studies, and as Associate Director of the Library at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. She was also a past President of the Law Library Association of Greater New York, a Board Member of the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company and a Member of the Schlesinger Library Council at the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard. Her funeral will be held at The Riverside Funeral Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, at 1:15PM on Sunday March 26, 2006. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Michele G. Falkow '79 Fund for the Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, 10 Garden St., Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: 2006 Volkswagen Passat: Disengaged Drivers Wanted
description: Blissfield, Ohio - IF ever Volkswagen needed a hero, the time is now. Sales have dropped and the Phaeton luxury car flopped. Worse, VW's image has taken a beating from sludged-up engines, defective ignition coils and cellar-dweller reliability ratings.
