title: Mental Health Therapists Face Financial Stress as Fees Stagnate

But in 2005, she earned at least 10 percent less than the year before, while her practice-related expenses increased.

'Rebel in Chief'
description: It's February 2, 2005, and President George W. Bush has a lot on his mind. In a matter of hours he'll deliver the State of the Union address in the chamber of the House of Representatives in the Capitol. The speech will set both the tone and the agenda for his second White House term. And, as always, it will be nationally televised and watched worldwide as well. He's practiced the speech twice before on a TelePrompTer and may once more.

title: Corrections

It is a mainstream magazine, not one of the small amateur publications known as zines. The article also misspelled the names of two museums. They are Kunst-Werke Berlin, not Kunste-Werke, and Hamburger Bahnhof, not Bahnof or Bahnoff.

title: In a War, the Dance Floor's Deserted and the Tap's Run Dry
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 20 - When the Palestine Hotel opened in 1982, it was one of the grandest things Iraq had ever seen, at least in the last few thousand years since Babylon was built.

title: Airbus test halted by injuries
Inside the List
description: RACE MATTERS: "If we keep going the way we are," the PBS television host Tavis Smiley told a packed auditorium in San Francisco earlier this month, "this book is going to hit the New York Times best-seller list. I hope you understand the statement this will make . . . when we put this book on the list and force everyone to talk about it." The book Smiley was selling is called "The Covenant With Black America" (Third World Press), and it is indeed on this week's list -- it enters the paperback nonfiction rankings at No. 6. The book, which Smiley edited, is a data-packed manifesto about racial inequality in America circa 2006, with chapters on topics like health care and the justice system. "The Covenant With Black America" didn't make this list without some hard, and canny, work on Smiley's part -- he sold the book during a barnstorming 10-city tour, on which he was sometimes accompanied by the Princeton professor Cornel West, and he hopes African-American churches will push the book to their congregations, a strategy that worked for Rick Warren, the author of "The Purpose-Driven Life." Smiley and West recently made a somewhat surreal appearance on Fox News's "Hannity & Colmes." Alan Colmes warned early on that Sean Hannity was going to blow his lid. ("He's going to yell and scream about Harry Belafonte," Colmes said.) West called Hannity "brother Sean," but that didn't mellow things out. "The reason why black people do not support conservatives like you, my dear brother," West said, "is because your argument's not convincing when it comes to focusing on working and poor people."

title: Fund Manager, It's Time to Pick a Side
description: IT has been beyond exasperating to watch money managers, who are fiduciaries, vote their clients' shares in support of compliant or incompetent boards in recent years. With the exception of some public pension funds, institutional shareholders have uttered nary a peep about directors on the scene during significant accounting blowups or those who dispensed overly generous pay packages and perquisites to underperforming executives.

Parents of severely impaired children also worry about who will care for their childrenafter they're gone, and few have malpractice-settlement trust funds to rely on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEARLES, EVELYN
description: SEARLES--Evelyn. Died February 28, 2006 after a short illness. Her grandfather, Seligman, a banker, helped the Union cause and raised funds selling bonds to Great Britain. Ulysses S. Grant, upon his ascendancy to President of the United States, requested her grandfather to be the Secretary of the Treasury. He declined. Eve traveled with an acting group performing Noel Coward plays touring both Connecticut and New York which horrified her grandfather prompting him to hire detectives to bring her home. Born in New York City, she attended Brearley in NY, later transferred to Swiss schools; spent four years in Paris, graduated, thereafter studied art in Paris, Venice, and Florence, Italy, studying at the Pitti and the Uffizi Galleries daily. Her father in the late 20's bought a villa in Cannes. Eve served as a hostess. Following World War II she worked processing American soldiers. Her primary interest was psychology and mental health. She moved to Topeka, KS, met psychiatrist Professor Karl Menninger, admired him and attended classes for psychiatrists. Professor Menninger was impressed with Eve's understanding of mental illness; she became Menninger's Director of the Women's Mental Hospital. Menninger requested that she teach mental health at Yale University. She established the first Department of Mental Health at Yale and led women to teach at universities. Frank Vanderlip, Chairman of New York's Committee on Mental Health Needs, asked her to make a study of all mental hospitals in NYC which made a lasting impact creating a lifetime interest in mental health. In Tucson, she led mental health groups bringing the needs of people with mental illnesses to the public's attention. She be came a founder of the Library at the University of Arizona and aided in mental health across America. She endowed the College of Nursing at the University of Arizona with nursing scholarships. She funded education at the Menninger School of Psychiatry through the Eve Searles Fund, endowing research of drug and alcohol addiction problems. She was an advocate for sufferers of men tal illness. Eve is survived by her beloved husband, Sidney Searles of Tucson and New York, her daughter, Audrey Palmer Neville of Los Angeles, son, Michael Palmer of London, step son, David Searles of Tucson, four grandchildren, five great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Tucson on April 9, 2006 at 3:30 PM at Adair Funeral Home, Dodge Chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, RAYMOND JOSEPH
description: WOLF--Raymond Joseph. 85, died of bone cancer on March 22nd, 2006 at his home in Palm Beach, FL. He was the husband of Sylvia (Adams) Wolf. They were married for 60 years. Mr. Wolf was born on February 21, 1921, in Brooklyn, NY. He resided in Old Westbury, NY, New York City and Palm Beach. Mr. Wolf was the Founder of Rapid Park Industries, a leading New York City parking company. He was a WWII U.S. Army veteran and was among the troops in Okinawa. He was an avid golfer and life member of the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club. Mr. Wolf was also a member of The Breakers Club and served on the Board of Governors for the Palm Beach Opera House. He was a generous supporter of the UJA Foundation, HomeSafe of Palm Beach and Palm Beach AIDS Foundation. In addition to his loving wife, survivors include his four children and their spouses, Jeffrey and Jean Wolf of Steamboat Springs, CO, Brandon and Joelle Wolfe of Santa Barbara, CA, Kevin and Pam Wolf of New York City, NY and Pamela Wolf and Paul Boritzer of New York City, NY, ten grandchildren and a sister, Marion Rossin of Boca Raton, FL. The funeral and burial were held on Friday, March 24, at the Menorah Gardens and Funeral Chapel in West Palm Beach. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach.

Flipping through the channels, she came across the sight of a chubby, excitable boy of indeterminate age, dressed in a red plaid shirt and blue jeans, profusely thanking a pizza delivery man who had arrived at his apartment with a large cheese pie that contained, the boy claimed, a missing sneaker he had lost five months ago.

title: 'Body Brokers'
description: Joyce Zamazanuk knew that her son was dying. She knew it when the nurses quietly wheeled Jim to a private room on the seventh floor of the hospital in San Diego. His new room had a bed, a metal chair, and an oxygen tube, but little else. Outside, few visitors wandered the halls. A hush hung over the nursing station. Joyce thought, This must be where they bring the sick patients to die.

If Clinton were truly electable, when the time came to join the Senate, rather than carpetbagging to the blue, blue grasses of New York State, she would have been a "favorite son" from her home states of Arkansas or Illinois.

title: Ready for the Red Baron
description: DOGS are famously blessed with acute hearing, a trait that serves them well when guarding warehouses or sensing when Kibbles 'n Bits are poured into a bowl. But that hearing may be overwhelmed when a dog is taken aloft in a private plane, as Michele McGuire first observed in 2004. Finally confident that her puppy, Cooper, had outgrown the chew-anything stage, Ms. McGuire, an experienced pilot from Westminster, Md., took him along for a ride in her Cessna. Shortly after takeoff, however, it became obvious that Cooper was having a dreadful time.

title: The Conrad Tokyo
description: THE BASICS -- Opened this past summer, the Conrad Tokyo is the latest addition to the high-end hotel brand operated by the Hilton Hotel chain. Located on floors 28 through 37 in a high-rise building in the Shiodome area of Tokyo, the Conrad is a 290-room, premium-service hotel that caters to business travelers who want to be near downtown. An elevator from the ground-floor reception area shuttles guests to the 28th-floor check-in lobby, a double-height space that looks out onto Tokyo Bay. With an interior illuminated by glowing lightboxes and floor-to-ceiling wood paneling, the dcor of the hotel is decidedly modern but with warm and traditional touches.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ELIAS, MOLLY
description: ELIAS--Molly. Cherished wife of Ike, devoted beyond compare. Mother of Martin and the late Steven, idolized grandmother of Ian, Brett and Sean. Loving sister, aunt and friend. She knew only goodness and kindness. She always spoke about the family she loved. She will be loved and never forgotten by her beloved family. She was adored by all who knew her. title: A Wrongful Birth?
description: Regardless of how many studies have been conducted, only the parent of a special-needs child can truly understand the difficulties and heartbreak of being in such a situation.Two of my three childrensuffer from a genetic neuromuscular disease that causes significant physical and cognitive delays. Spend a couple of hours with my 8-year-olddaughter, who lacks the verbal acuity totell me what happened at school that day. Try to connect with my nonverbal, diaper-wearing6-year-oldson.Then look me in theeye and tell me that my "burden" does not differ from that of a parent with a typical child.

title: Too Much Isn't Enough
description: Q: As a wife, a mother of four and a symbol of female accomplishment who has served as the editor of Glamour, Cosmopolitan, Us Weekly, Marie Claire and other magazines, why would you stoop to writing a book like "The Joys of Much Too Much," which basically argues that greed is good? I think it is good to be greedy in terms of your dreams and in terms of trying to have everything you want out of life. The road to the richest life is one in which you partake of careerhood, lovehood, mommyhood -- all of those things.

title: The Crescent and the Gavel
description: Washington - DIVORCE proceedings bring out the worst in people. When Abdul Rahman tried to get custody of his daughters in Kabul, Afghanistan, his wife's family told the court that he was unfit to care for his children because he had converted from Islam to Christianity some 16 years ago. A zealous prosecutor, hearing of the case, charged Mr. Rahman with apostasy, a crime punishable by death under some interpretations of Islamic law. If Mr. Rahman does not repudiate Christianity, the judge in the case has said, he will get the death penalty.

title: Caution is a legacy at the Fed
Scenic Setting
description: JERSEY CITY - I'VE made two visits to Liberty House, and I'm still not sure I could find my way back. Enter the table-flat expanse of Liberty State Park, pass the spooky darkened hulk of Liberty Science Center (closed for renovations until summer 2007), bump down a narrow and seemingly endless cobblestone road until you're practically in New York Harbor -- oops! Did we miss a turn? Is that the Statue of Liberty?

title: Greenwich's Vanishing Rental Units
description: GREENWICH - WHEN Antares Investment Partners announced last month that it was buying two apartment complexes in Greenwich for $223 million, it touted the deal as the largest real estate acquisition in Connecticut history. Yet Antares's planned conversion of a total of 396 apartments to condominiums may have been even more momentous at a local level, where, for many residents, it marks the end of a competitive rental market.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about new American operas misstated the number of instruments needed in the orchestra for "Little Women." It is 18, not 28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARIL, MICHAEL
description: GARIL--Michael. The Board of Directors of Women At Risk extend our deepest sympathies to our valued board member, Ethel Garil and her family. Their strength during these difficult years has been an inspiration to us all.

title: Planning the Great Escape
description: New Paltz, N.Y. - "MARCH is the month of expectation," Emily Dickinson wrote so plainly and so presciently up there in her agoraphobic attic in Amherst, Mass., that it seems she actually understood the early spring frenzy surrounding Berkshire summer rentals more than 100 years later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLAKELY, NICHOLAS GERVAS
description: BLAKELY--Nicholas Gervas. Retired Professor of Spanish Studies at Dutchess Community College in Poughkeepsie, NY, died unexpectedly last weekend at his home in New York City. He was 69 years old and had successfully fought multiple myloma for four years. His death was caused by pneumonia-related complications. Mr. Blakely was passionate about arts, literature and Spanish culture. Other interests of his included foreign languages, poetry and amateur photography. He is survived by his sister, Sara Sieker; his son, Alexander Blakely; his daughter, Nicole Blakely; and his grandson Kaimana Seely. They will miss him dearly. Friends and family are invited to attend a memorial and reception at Alta in the West Village, on Tuesday, March 29th, from 6:00-9:00 PM.

Large settlements and damage awards have, unfortunately, been much maligned in recent years, and this article could have been an excellent forum in which to discuss the dire need for financial compensation as a result of such tragic medical malpractice.

title: Grocery Chain Sues Over Cigarette Sales

The Stars Shine, But Not Their Blogs

title: Like Daughter, Like
description: Women's clothing labels in the past shrank their designs into mini-lines for their customers' offspring. Now the tide is turning as children's designers expand their wares to fit adults. Eliza Gran put her homespun vintage-inspired stamp on a women's Liberty print shirt dress ($280) and denim skirt ($85, Bird in Park Slope; 718-768-4940) while Baby CZ now produces full-size replicas of its signature tunics ($88 to $210), velvet quilted jackets ($240) and cashmere turtlenecks for moms and dads ($345 at www.babycz.com). Lucy Sykes's new women's collection borrows fabrics and trims from her children's line. "It's more 'fashion family' than 'mummy and me,' " she said (here, a girls' top, $80, and skirt, $90, above, coordinate with a woman's shirt dress, $395; available at Saks Fifth Avenue). Nikki Kule enlarged and adapted Kule, her line of pint-size sportswear, after seeing mothers try to squeeze into their kids' pieces. But there's a slight difference between the women's ($252) and boys' ($150) raincoats: embroidered inside the pockets of the boys' coat are the words "dinosaurs" and "cool stuff."

title: Plan Is Floated to Open Choice of Premier to Iraqi Parliament
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 25 - Iraqi politicians say they are considering asking the main Shiite political bloc to allow a vote by the entire Parliament on a candidate for prime minister. In the proposed plan, the Parliament would choose among three candidates, including Ibrahim al-Jaafari, the current prime minister, the politicians say.

title: Europe rethinking role of public broadcasters
To Russia with Notions
description: Dmitri had warned me: "Are you sure you want to go to Moscow? We'll have to camp on the pullout couch. And my brother just moved into my mother's apartment with his girlfriend and her little girl." But I insisted. I had been dreaming of traveling with the man I love to his home city. Finally he relented. We would go for the new year.

title: An Extreme Changeover Has Hingis Back in Game
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 22  Across the net from Martina Hingis stood an opponent whose game she did not know well. This is a prosaic fact of Hingis's comeback, for during her three-year retirement a whole new crop of players sprouted on the WTA Tour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, ISAAC N.
description: WEINER--Isaac N. 69, of Wayne, NJ, and Sanibel Island, FL, on March 24, 2006. Co-founder of Pike Construction Co., Paterson, NJ. Former Board Member of Barnert Hospital in Paterson, NJ, the YM-YWHA in Wayne, NJ, and Congregation Beth Shalom in Pompton Lakes, NJ. He is survived by his beloved wife Terry, loving children Michael and his wife Diane, David and his wife Ronni, Danielle and her husband John, devoted sister Bette Verp and husband Martin, and cherished grandchildren Margie, Grace, Sally, Billye, George, Nathan, and Joseph. Donations to Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation or St. Vincent's Comprehensive Cancer Center, 325 West 15th St., New York, NY 10011, would be appreciated. Services are Monday, 12:00 noon, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Leader at Work, Sometimes Lost at Home
description: OVER the years I have written periodically of how being a parent can make one a better employee -- better at multitasking, organizing and managing time. This is not one of those columns. This is about the opposite phenomenon: about how being a whiz at work -- a dynamic leader, a whirlwind of productivity, an overachiever -- is little help at all when rearing children.

title: Recalling coup, Argentina vows 'never again'
A Conversation Between Composers, in Polish and Hungarian
description: 'Goulash!' Matt Haimovitz, cellist; DJ Olive, turntablist; John McLaughlin, guitarist; other performers. Oxingale Records OX2007; CD.

title: Cubicle Dwellers' Funniest Home Video
description: "I love these clips," said Patrice O'Neal, introducing snippets from shows like "Maury" and "Judge Hatchet" in which men ecstatically celebrate a negative result on a paternity test. "Because there's no greater joy in the world than hearing those five beautiful words, 'You are not the father!' "

title: 'Great Pretenders'
description: On an early spring day in 1998, I sat in a coach window seat of a descending American Airlines flight, panicking. Below me, the sun-bleached whiteness of the Los Angeles basin loomed closer and closer. I was due to land in twenty-eight minutes, yet I had no idea where I was going. I had no compass, no direction, no guidebook. My destination wasn't on any map; I wasn't even sure if it really existed. I had been to L.A. many times in the past, always with a purpose, always with my expenses paid. I had traveled as a journalist for newspapers and magazines, on assignment to write celebrity profiles and interview musicians. I always knew exactly where to go, and when. Publicists took care of everything. This was different. This time I was writing a book; I was on my own, flying under no prestigious banner, with no one to look out for me. It all seemed like a terrible mistake. I wanted to hit the call button and tell the flight attendant, Help me! I wanted to run up the aisle to the cockpit and instruct the pilots to turn the plane around and put me back on the ground in New York, where I would be safe. I pressed my nose against the window and breathed uneasily. It's not that I've never felt this scared before, I said to myself. It's that I've never felt this stupid.

title: Balancing the Doctor and the Patient

title: Longtime Companion Fights for Inheritance
description: PERTH AMBOY - FROM their introduction to each other 20 years ago to the sudden death of one of them last year, Rene Price always surprised Betty Jordan.

Plevan as leader of the New York City Bar Association. That former leader was Whitney North Seymour. (His son Whitney North Seymour Jr. was president of the New York State Bar Association.)

title: In Nigeria, Things Fall Apart
description: When President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria visits Washington this week, he will probably be lauded for his crucial role as a regional African leader. During his seven years in power, Mr. Obasanjo helped end Liberia's civil war by taking in the strongman Charles Taylor and refused to accept a coup in Togo. He was instrumental in making sure that the African Union did not destroy its international credibility by installing Sudan's president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, as its head despite the continuing carnage in Darfur. President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, the continent's other big player, could learn a lot from Mr. Obasanjo about how to use his country's economic and military strength to promote peace and stability around the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONG, DAVID
description: LEONG - David. Managing Editor, ASME; authority on Asian films. Services Monday, March 27, at Wah Wing Sang, 26 Mulberry St., NY City, 9:00-12:00 noon. Interment immediately following.

title: Note to Readers
description: Next week, The Times will begin publishing an expanded opinion page in the New Jersey section, adding editorials to the existing mix of letters to the editor and opinion essays on issues and ideas specific to New Jersey.

title: Gring, Rembrandt and the Little Black Book
description: AMSTERDAM IT has become a familiar story of late. The heirs of a Jewish art collector discover that paintings seized by the Nazis during World War II were never returned to the family. They start searching and, occasionally, they are lucky. A work is traced to a museum or spotted at an auction and, after lengthy negotiations, the rightful owners recover it or receive compensation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MASON, DONALD J. SR.
description: MASON--Donald J. Sr., age 66 years, died on March 20, 2006, at home at peace in Perry, Georgia. He is survived by six sons, two brothers and a loving aunt, Dorothy Latta. The family will receive friends from 3-5 pm & 7-9 pm Sunday, March 26, 2006 at Cotton Funeral Service, Newark, NJ. Funeral Service will be held 11 am on Monday, March 27, at Clinton Memorial AME Zion Church, Newark, NJ.

title: Engineers' Panel Urges Study of All Levees in New Orleans
description: The safety of New Orleans's battered levees is "open to question" until the entire system can be analyzed in light of new information about how the 17th Street Canal levee failed after Hurricane Katrina, according to a review panel of civil engineers.

title: Cassell Gives Clippers a Reason to Believe
description: The Los Angeles Clippers, being the Clippers, hit a franchise high Tuesday, then immediately tumbled into a funk.

title: Making a Mark With 'Off Market' Deals
description: A DECADE ago, Georgia Malone decided that she needed a change. She was a 43-year-old real estate lawyer and senior partner at one of the most prestigious landlord-tenant law firms in New York City. She had also just overcome a bout with cancer.

title: Not Easily Classified
description: I WAS at Virginia Tech and was thinking about being an engineer, but then I decided I didn't like engineering and switched to pre-med. I applied to the University of Michigan for sentimental reasons. I was born in Ann Arbor, still had a lot of relatives there, and the program had a good reputation. I was accepted.

title: A Momentary Pause
description: I have to keep reminding myself that it is only late March. I have been so eager for spring that it feels as though time has almost stopped. One reason may be that it was warm a few weeks ago and then the cold returned, putting the season on ice. But there is something else going on as well. Scientists say that spring comes earlier than it used to. The snow cover dwindles sooner and bud break comes earlier. And yet our awareness of that makes it feel as though spring comes even earlier than it is already coming. Global warming accelerates faster in our heads than it does in fact. March is not quite the new April yet.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article about Berlin last Sunday in T: Travel magazine referred incorrectly to Spex, a music and pop-culture publication. It is a mainstream magazine, not one of the small amateur publications known as zines. The article also misspelled the names of two museums. They are Kunst-Werke Berlin, not Kunste-Werke, and Hamburger Bahnhof, not Bahnof or Bahnoff. (Go to Article)

title: Ukrainians' deal blow to reformist leadership
Free Underground Rides for Kids
description: The London Underground, below, is getting more child-friendly. Starting April 2, children under 11 will be able to ride London's subway and the Docklands Light Railway free during off-peak hours. For the free travel, up to four children must be accompanied by a paying adult and ride after 9:30 a.m. on weekdays, or anytime on weekends or public holidays.

title: Waiting for G.E.
description: Never hold your breath waiting for actual progress in the cleanup of PCB's from the Hudson River. You'll pass out. Milestones in the river's slow recovery have been piling up for decades, at least on paper. But the chemicals haven't gone anywhere.

description: If you had any lingering doubts that the Internet was rapidly elbowing its way into becoming an outsize presence in the American household, check out new numbers from Nielsen/NetRatings.

title: Eat, Memory: Bean There
description: I bet we were the only people in my neighborhood growing up who ate B&M baked beans. We lived in La Jolla, Calif., 25 miles north of the Mexican border, where the only beans you saw were refried or served in salad. B&M beans came in a can, suspended in molasses with a chunk of salt pork. They seemed like the sort of thing you'd eat by the wood stove if you were snowbound in the mountains. They were a little heavy for La Jolla.

title: Yes, Forrester Lost, But He Also Won
description: When Douglas R. Forrester announced more than a year ago that he was seeking the Republican nomination for governor, he mentioned that he did so only after getting the green light from his daughter, Briana, who had been ailing because of a brain hemorrhage and Hodgkin's disease. These days, Mr. Forrester is back at the pharmacy benefits management firm he founded, BeneCard, and his daughter has recovered so much that she enrolled at The College of New Jersey in January. Ms. Forrester, 19, is taking classes in nursing and writing, and "she's very committed to giving back to the nurses who saved her life," said her mother, Andrea Forrester, who attended a fund-raising event Monday night for the United States Senate candidacy of State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr.

title: Moving Day Approaches for Creatures of the Lagoon
description: THE scene resembles something out of a horror movie. Hordes of slimy creatures crawl out of the dark woods looking for their ancestral breeding grounds. Thousands cross roads and some even try to crawl into homes.

title: A Dramatic Shut-In
description: It's hard to talk about theater in the morning and especially hard when the vacuum cleaner is so loud. As the playwright Richard Greenberg and the director Doug Hughes hung around the stage of the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center waiting for the noise to subside and their meeting to begin, some not-so-idle chitchat was in order. Hughes's Broadway production of "Doubt" had just changed casts and been re-reviewed, mostly positively, the previous day.

title: Shootouts in Florida Don't Favor Rangers
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 25 - By the time the puck was dropped here Saturday night, the scoreboard showed that the Flyers had already taken a 4-0 lead over the Ottawa Senators in Philadelphia.

description: SACRAMENTO - Thousands of schools across the nation are responding to the reading and math testing requirements laid out in No Child Left Behind, President Bush's signature education law, by reducing class time spent on other subjects and, for some low-proficiency students, eliminating it.

Sykes called Mrs. Barber, the wife of the detective who originally investigated Vivian Finlay's murder, and she confirmed that a man, who sounded young, called from the D.A.'s office a couple of months earlier asking her to send it.

description: To the Editor: Isn't it a scandal to know so much luxury coexists with so much poverty? There must be a strong demand for such absurdity.

title: Battle in Black and White
description: WHEN I was a kid, we visited my grandparents in Stuyvesant Town nearly every year. The apartment where my mother had grown up was filled with towers of books and foreign treasures, including a Torah scroll rescued from the Holocaust. I used to fall asleep on a sagging cot listening to footsteps and voices passing underneath my window, something impossible in the quiet Boulder, Colo., neighborhood where I lived. When I dreamed of city life, I saw those red brick structures, the tiled kitchen where my grandmother made meatloaf, the paved circle where we used to wait for my grandfather to pull up in his powder-blue Dodge Dart.

title: The Book Club Gets Real
description: BLOOMFIELD - YOU remember Mona Lisa Vito -- the gum-snapping, four-letter-word-spouting, maxi-haired and mini-skirted autodidact. (Her specialties were calibration, "positraction" and the ignition timing of 1955 Chevrolets.) As played by a very funny Marisa Tomei, who won an Oscar for the role in 1993, Mona Lisa's deadpan expert-witness testimony helped make "My Cousin Vinny" a hilarious movie.

title: Corrections

He is Robinson Crusoe, not Caruso. The column also misspelled the name of the native country of Pablo Escobar, a known drug lord who once owned the property. He was Colombian, not Columbian.

title: It's Not if, It's When: Waiting for the End, With Trepidation and Joy
description: Dix Hills - CRIES of "Hallelujah" rocked the great hall. About 2,000 worshipers clapped along as a 12-piece band and a 30-member choir performed "He Shall Reign for Ever and Ever." At the foot of the stage, patterned after the one in Radio City Music Hall, two young women in flowing white robes tied with purple sashes jangled tambourines.

title: Uniform Appeal
description: When word got out that the N.B.A. was going to institute a "business casual" dress code this season, controversy raged. Miffed players said that Commissioner David Stern's dress diktat -- collared shirts, dress slacks, khakis or jeans and shoes to team-related events and a sport coat if out of action and sitting on the bench during the game -- crushed their individuality. Some even saw racial implications in the rule, since Stern has long been vexed by the hip-hop style of bad boys like Rasheed Wallace and Allen Iverson, whose track suits, throwback jerseys and giant jeans he considered an affront to the white-collar fans he has coveted since the drop-off in television ratings and game attendance accompanying Michael Jordan's retirement. But for all the hoopla, Stern's attempt to make the N.B.A. dress like C.P.A.'s has been a brick: TV ratings for the 2006 All-Star Game were at a record low.

title: It Looks So Good on Paper. Why Doesn't It Work?
description: INVESTMENT advisers have been rolling out strategies to exploit the advantages of exchange-traded funds -- which, unlike mutual funds, can be traded throughout the day like stocks. Yet more often than not for advisers who publish investment newsletters, portfolios composed entirely of E.T.F.'s have turned in disappointing returns.

title: Young Yankee Takes Days With a Spring in His Step
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 - By coincidence, the side of Kevin Thompson's locker doubles as a wall where daily lineups and full rosters are posted in the Yankees' clubhouse at Legends Field in Tampa.

title: Neo No More
description: In February 2004, Francis Fukuyama attended a neoconservative think-tank dinner in Washington and listened aghast as the featured speaker, the columnist Charles Krauthammer, attributed "a virtually unqualified success" to America's efforts in Iraq, and the audience enthusiastically applauded. Fukuyama was aghast partly for the obvious reason, but partly for another reason, too, which, as he explains in the opening pages of his new book, "America at the Crossroads," was entirely personal. In years gone by, Fukuyama would have felt cozily at home among those applauding neoconservatives. He and Krauthammer used to share many a political instinct. It was Krauthammer who wrote the ecstatic topmost blurb ("bold, lucid, scandalously brilliant") for the back jacket of Fukuyama's masterpiece from 1992, "The End of History and the Last Man."

title: Bound, Blindfolded and Dead: The Face of Revenge in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 25 - Mohannad al-Azawi had just finished sprinkling food in his bird cages at his pet shop in southern Baghdad, when three carloads of gunmen pulled up.

title: Golf: Ames on course for redemption
This Shamus Goes to High School
description: RIAN JOHNSON'S "Brick," which won a Sundance prize last year for "originality of vision" and which opens in New York on Friday, is in many ways the quintessential indie film. It was made not just on a shoestring but on a raveled, threadbare one -- with money raised from Mr. Johnson's friends and family -- and it was shot in just 20 days and then edited on a Mac computer in Mr. Johnson's bedroom. The finished version includes the standard number of pretentious, lingering shots -- of shoes, in this case -- and is accompanied by a loud and extremely annoying score by Mr. Johnson's cousin Nathan. Among the instruments used to obtain what Nathan Johnson hoped would be a "junkyard" sound were cheese graters, filing cabinets and radiators.

description: Regarding Jeff Koons's portfolio on Gretchen Mol (Style, March 12), I think you are mistaking provocative views for provocative news.

title: Haltingly, Romania begins to clean up its act
Paid Notice: Deaths   HEADY, VIRGINIA SCHLEUSSNER
description: HEADY--Virginia Schleussner, 76. Beloved mother, grandmother and friend, and devoted ailurophile, Ginny contributed grace, wit, and a devastating sense of humor. A graduate of The Brearley School and Barnard College, she worked in PR and advertising before earning a Master's in comparative literature at Columbia University. She then taught at The Juilliard School for 15 years, humanities and ESL, and ultimately ran the Academic Department. Ginny had a lifelong commitment to the rescue and protection of abandoned cats. She died surrounded by family and friends on March 19 in Manhattan and is survived by her daughter, Sarah, two grandchildren, Thomas and Madeleine, and her niece, Laura. Memorial to be held at 12 noon on Sunday, March 26, at Frank Campbell funeral home, 81 St & Madison. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Virginia Heady Scholarship Fund for Veterinary Nursing, at Animal General, (212) 501-9600.

title: Rice hints at lower U.S. troop levels
Washington's Hottest Salon Is a Deathbed
description: THE other day when I called Art Buchwald, he couldn't come to the phone. John Glenn, the former senator, was at his bedside in the Washington hospice where, for 10 weeks now, Mr. Buchwald has been waiting to die.

title: Telecoms are hung up on the latest merger talks
For Instant Notice, and Worry, E-Mail Is Replacing Snail Mail
description: BENJI BAER, a marketing director in Stamford, Conn., was in a meeting one day recently when she received an upsetting e-mail message on her BlackBerry from the superintendent of her children's Westchester school district. It alerted parents to a recent attempted abduction in a neighboring town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASHER, MARK G.
description: ASHER--Mark G. Highly awarded Washington Post Sports Reporter 1945-2006 A Family's Memories. He started every day by asking his daughters "Are you doing what is right in your heart?" and he lived his life the same way. To their replies, he never said "What I would have done if I were you..." believing that people never get to be anybody but who they are. Those who couldn't see past Mark's physical condition no doubt wondered how he unfailingly answered "Great!" (with a big smile) when asked "How are you?" But the explanation was simple: Mark only wanted people to see through his less-than-healthy body to the healthy, vibrant presence inside. In turn, Mark gave what he wanted: acceptance. When a companion reacted negatively to two men holding hands, Mark replied "Isn't it wonderful that we're in America where they can do that in public?" And when he couldn't make his points gently, Mark battled. Society's treatment of people with disabilities and other inequities became his causes. His love for life showed in his love for food. If he hadn't been a sports reporter, Mark would have wanted to be a food critic. There was hardly a restaurant he hadn't visited. During his last days, when Mark couldn't drink or eat and his family told him they could not enjoy eating, he said, "Eat all the foods that I love for me and that will make me happy." Mark won numerous awards from the Associated Press Sports Editors Association: 1983 -1st Place, Best News Story; 1985 -5th Place, Best Enterprise Reporting; 1986 -2nd Place, Best Enterprise Reporting; 1986 -2nd Place, Best Investigative Reporting; 1990 -Best Sports News Story; and 1996 -4th Place, Best Enterprise Reporting. He was a Pulitzer Prize finalist in 1986, won the 1990 Associated Press's Chesapeake Mark Twain Award for Outstanding Achievement in sports coverage, the 1997 Society of Professional Journalists' Washington Dateline Award for Excellence in Local Journalism, and the 2002 U.S. Basketball Writers Association's Katha Quinn Award. He was a Washington Post Duke University Fellow from 1989-90. NBA Commissioner David Stern once called Mark "The Murray Chass of the Washington Post." The last few years of Mark's professional life were difficult. While grateful for the support of those who knew what he could still do, Mark felt the Post's changing culture brought in some people who only saw his disabilities. But to the end, as his beloved daughters, Lizzie and Melanie, and devoted wife, Elizabeth, fondly recall, Mark still replied to some of their calls with the classic reporter's line: "I have to call you back. I'm on deadline." Mark reluctantly retired on November 1, 2005. Asked by his children when he would have wanted to retire, Mark replied "I would like to have died in the newsroom." Elizabeth, Queenie, Mello

title: 'Recovering Your Story'
description: Marcel Proust's great classic, Remembrance of Things Past, is one of the longest novels ever published, comprising more than three thousand pages in the large-format, three-volume Random House edition. It weighs several pounds. You are not likely to carry it to the beach. When you open it up and start reading, you encounter a dense prose style, with lengthy sentences, ambitious metaphors, and little discernible plot. It appears to describe, in great detail, a bygone world: French society of the early twentieth century. For these reasons, you might well imagine that this book-whatever fame may be ascribed to it-is likely to be an arduous read, a massive project devoted to distant things, an impersonal act of labor.

title: Dragons at the Door? Just Let Them Fume
description: Superstition chic has reached a new threshold. In a time when nearly every neck and wrist is adorned with a good-luck charm, even doorknobs apparently require an accessory or two to ward off ill-intentioned spirits. To this end Carole Meltzer has created Door Guardians: jade, crystal, agate and tourmaline bracelets made to hang on door handles that are adorned with amulets, which are intended to increase the odds of good tidings -- and vice versa. The guardians ($125 at Roberta Freymann in New York, 212-585-3767) are available in two breeds: the dragon charm is said to promote harmony and lend protection and power; the fish charm (the sellout model) summons fertility, love and passion. Knock wood so you don't jinx yourself. PULSE

description: This Tuesday is a day full of love songs. You just have to decide what kind you like. A promising new R & B album hits shops that day for listeners who like their love songs to be not just memorable but functional, too. (Most R & B CD's are both interactive and self-reflexive: they're filled with songs designed to accompany the activities described in the lyrics.) AVANT, an underrated crooner, will release his fourth album, "Director" (Geffen). His current single, "4 Minutes," comes with a built-in timer: "I only got 4 minutes to say what I got to say."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAFTI, DR. JOAN HERZ
description: TAFTI--Dr. Joan Herz. Mother, wife, daughter, sister, (46) passed away at home last Sunday. Joan was devoted to her family and friends and was the loving mother of Ariana, age 10, the joy of her life. Joan was the cherished wife of Peter in whom she found a friend and life partner. Joan is survived by her devoted mother and father, Leslie and Dr. Marvin Herz. She is also survived by her sister Suzanne and husband Marc Daniel, her brother Joseph and wife Beth, nieces Julia and Jane, nephew Nicholas and father-in-law, Shapoor Tafti. As a psychologist, Joan helped her patients to cope more effectively with the problems of life, its challenges and blessings. When she entered a room, immediately it became suffused with warmth. Joan always maintained a positive attitude even while courageously fighting cancer over the past few years of her life. She was a graduate of Tulane, Harvard and Columbia Universities and served as an Adjunct Assistant Professor of Psychology and Education at Columbia University. Knowing Joan has greatly enriched the lives of all who knew her. A memorial service for friends and family will be held in late April. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the American Cancer Society.

For example, they may carry a prayer shawl to synagogue or push a child in a stroller.

While I understand that people eat rabbit meat, I think your inclusion of an unskinned dead rabbit in the photo was gratuitous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMPSON, JANA D.
description: THOMPSON--Jana D. Jana D'Aun Thompson, president of Laudus Funds in San Francisco, died March 17 in her home surrounded by family and friends following an eight month battle with pancreatic cancer. She had turned 47 ten days earlier. Ms. Thompson, a native of Arlington, Texas, headed management of Charles Schwab's Laudus Funds. She joined Schwab in August 2000. Previously, Ms. Thompson cofounded the High Yield Group at Fleet Securities in New York City after serving as head of High Yield Sales for Citicorp. She spent most of her career on Wall Street with Lehman Brothers where she specialized in High Yield, Distressed and Emerging investment markets. Ms. Thompson graduated from Lamar High School in Arlington, Texas. She earned a B.A. in International Economics from the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., and an MBA in Finance from Columbia University in New York City. Ms. Thompson had a passionate interest in art, music, dance, sports and the community. She had served on the Board of Directors of ODC/Dance (Oberlin Dance Company) in San Francisco, and generously supported Doctors Without Borders, Emily's List, Planned Parenthood, the Women's Initiative for Self Employment (WISE), the Brent Woodall Foundation for Exceptional Children, Stern Grove Festival, San Francisco Ballet, Friends of Mountain Lake Park and a variety of emerging artists. A cycling enthusiast, she completed the 100-mile America's Most Beautiful Ride in 2004. She is survived by her partner Michael D. Browne and his children, Michael and Catherine, of New York City; her mother Janice D. Thompson, her father and stepmother Dr. Gerald G. Thompson and Linda Thompson, her brother Ken Thompson, his wife JoLee and their children Tori, Trace, Tanner and Tucker, her grandmother Dorothy Thompson, all of Arlington, Texas; her brother Kevin Thompson, his wife Patti and their children Meghan and Hank of Dallas, Texas; her sister Kelly Weeks, her husband David and their children Dylan and Zachary of Huntsville, Texas, and her extended family of treasured friends. The Jana D. Thompson Fund, an annual award to assist worthy students to study abroad, has been established at the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to the Fund. Checks should be made payable to the School of Foreign Service (memo line: Jana D. Thompson Fund) and mailed to: School of Foreign Service, Georgetown University, 301 ICC, Washington, DC 20057.

title: Presto! A School for Magic Creates Hope Out of Thin Air

title: Arts, Briefly; Spike Lee Film Is Tops
description: "Inside Man" (Universal), the Wall Street heist film directed by Spike Lee in his most commercial effort to date, captured the top spot at the box office both nationwide and internationally this weekend, with an estimated $29 million in domestic ticket sales, according to studio estimates. The film, which stars Denzel Washington, Clive Owen and Jodi Foster, is the best opener ever for Mr. Washington, whose most recent No. 1 film, "Man on Fire," opened with $22.7 million in April 2004, as well as for Mr. Lee, below, whose documentary "Original Kings of Comedy" had his previous best first week with $11.6 million in August 2000. "V for Vendetta" (Warner Brothers), starring Natalie Portman and Hugo Weaving as freedom fighters in a futuristic Britain, was No. 1 last week but dropped sharply to take in only $12.3 million, bringing its gross revenues to $46.2 million. The other new film in wide release, "Stay Alive" (Buena Vista), which is set in New Orleans and features a deadly video game, opened at No. 3 with an estimated $11.2 million. Two holdovers in their third week of release rounded out the top five: "Failure to Launch" (Paramount) dropped to No. 4 with $10.8 million, bringing its cumulative take to $63.8 million, and "The Shaggy Dog" (Buena Vista) was at No. 5 with $9.1 million, for total sales of $47.9 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

Chien-Ming Wang, the starting pitcher Sunday, left with a bruised right kneecap in the third inning of the Yankees' 9-8 exhibition victory against the Detroit Tigers.

description: Ric Burns has carved a special niche in documentary filmmaking by addressing some of the seamier aspects of American history (the Donner Party, Coney Island) and bringing them vividly to life with deep psychological perceptiveness. From one perspective, his latest work, "Eugene O'Neill" stems from a similar impulse.

title: Mr. Schumer Goes to China
description: The good news is that Senators Lindsey Graham and Charles Schumer have started to inch away from their misguided attempt to club China for its currency policies. At the end of a fact-finding trip last week, Mr. Schumer told reporters he was no longer sure he would push for a vote to impose tariffs on Chinese imports into the United States. "The jury is out," he said. But, he said, "we are more optimistic that this can be worked out than we were in the past."

description: Leon Daniel, who covered a parade of major news events of the last half-century as an editor and correspondent for United Press International, died on March 19 in Glen Ellyn, Ill., where he moved last summer. He was 74.

title: American Repertory Ballet: Strong Women, Lithe Youngsters, Sharp Turns
description: The accent was on women on Saturday night when the American Repertory Ballet performed at Symphony Space. To start, there was Carmen de Lavallade, at 75 outperforming dancers a third her age in the company director Graham Lustig's "Dialogues." One of those ballets about a woman reliving her life and loves, "Dialogues" had a strong lead cast in Jennifer Cavanaugh, as the remembered self, and the pianist Max Midroit and the singer Lorraine Ernest, who performed the score by Pat Rasile. But few artists have quite Ms. de Lavallade's gift for eloquent stillness and for simple, quiet gestures that express whole worlds of emotion.

Robin Coombs, 85, Inventor of a Diagnostic Blood Test, Dies
description: Dr. Robin Coombs, a British immunologist who in the 1940's invented a blood test that bears his name and a version of which is still widely used to diagnose some kinds of anemia and to prevent negative reactions to transfusions, died on Jan. 25, said the British Society for Immunology, a professional group he helped found. He was 85.

Tora!" and "Fantastic Voyage," died early Saturday at the Motion Picture and Television Country House and Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 89.

title: The Formidable Brunhild as an Icelandic Hottie in 'Dark Kingdom'
description: Sex, spells, dragons, dwarfs, women warriors: the Nibelung saga, especially the story of Siegfried and Brunhild and their tragic love, is a warehouse of promising mini-series material. Yet unlike the Arthurian legend, with which it has a lot in common, the Nibelung story hasn't had much of an afterlife on the big or the small screen, turning up mainly in Fritz Lang's 1924 silent film "Siegfried" and indirectly and secondhand in the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy.

title: Its Hard Out Here for a Blimp
description: Since they were introduced in 1987, the blimps that represent Met Life have been all over the country, providing aerial coverage of golf tournaments and other sports events as well as flying over the offices and plants of companies that use Met Life to provide employee benefits.

Who Was George Mason?
description: For the next week or so, George Mason will be one of the biggest names in basketball. He had about as much influence on the game as Abner Doubleday had on baseball, which is to say none at all. But with the stunning entry of George Mason University of Fairfax, Va., in the N.C.A.A. tournament's Final Four, the question arises: Who was George Mason?

title: Sparing No Expense to Hear a Nuclear Waste Disposal Case
description: BETHESDA, Md., March 24 - It is a hearing room where, quite possibly, nobody will ever signal the "aha" moment of argument by waving a piece of paper, or brandish a highlighter to isolate a crucial fact. If it goes as planned, in fact, it will have hardly any paper at all.

description: DaimlerChrysler, seeking to end losses at its Smart division, says it plans to scrap a four-seat model, integrate its small-car unit into its Mercedes group and eliminate 300 jobs in Germany, spending 1 billion euros ($1.2 billion).

title: From Finland, Magnus Lindberg's Contemporary Music Feast
description: Magnus Lindberg, the plucky 47-year-old Finnish composer, is a major presence in Europe, though his music is heard too rarely in the United States. His best works fuse intellectual rigor with a sensual richness; he draws from the brainiest compositional techniques of the postwar decades but keeps the music's stitching on the inside. Listeners are confronted with swaths of bright primary colors, sometimes-velvety timbral detail and fast-breaking instrumental lines of great virtuosity. These essential qualities came through in the all-Lindberg program performed at Miller Theater on Friday night as the final installment of this season's excellent Composer Portraits series.

description: DESPITE their fuel economy advantage and a core of loyal customers, no new diesel cars can be sold in states that have adopted California's stringent emissions rules. description: Apple Computer will meet the Beatles' Apple Corps in court this week in London, where a judge will determine whether Apple Computer's iTunes online music service violates a 1991 agreement between the two companies that, the Beatles' Apple claims, blocked the computer maker from selling music.

description: PARIS, March 27 A French transit workers began striking late tonight as hundreds of thousands of people across France prepared to participate in nationwide protests against a hastily adopted new labor law.

description: Soundtracks to popular video games usually draw from three kinds of music: aggressive-sounding rock, aggressive-sounding rap and aggressive-sounding electronic music. But as virtual athletes round the bases in Major League Baseball 2K6, they will hear tracks from independent music acts including Yo La Tengo, Interpol and Belle and Sebastian, which are generally associated more with angst than athletics.

description: MOSCOW, March 26 - A detained opposition leader in Belarus faced a criminal charge on Sunday and was denied prison visits by a doctor and a lawyer, his wife said. Minsk, the capital, fell quiet after a violent police crackdown against antigovernment demonstrators on Saturday.

title: Leo Lutwak, an Early Critic of Fen-Phen, Is Dead at 77

title: UN reports asylum bid for convert
France's Misguided Protesters
description: For the second time in four months, French streets are filled with riot police, tear gas and rampaging youths. But the similarity is deceptive. Back in November, it was the sons of North African immigrants in their dreary suburbs exploding in frustration at the lack of jobs, prospects or programs. It was hard not to feel sympathy with their cause, along with outrage at their response.

title: Sports of The Times; Party Crashers Can Now Be Last to Leave
description: THESE things are not supposed to happen. Outsiders are allowed to entertain us in the first week or two of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament by giving fits to the big boys, but then they are supposed to dutifully get out of the way for the so-called programs, the collectors of all-Americans.

title: Buck Owens, 76, Country Musician and a Star of 'Hee Haw,' Is Dead
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 A Buck Owens, the maverick honky-tonk singer who scored a string of country hits that included "Act Naturally" and "Waitin' in Your Welfare Line" before steering country music to television as a co-host of the series "Hee Haw," died on Saturday at his home in Bakersfield, Calif. He was 76.

title: L.S.U. Is Pushing Forward Behind Tenacious Defense
description: ATLANTA, March 26 - As Texas center LaMarcus Aldridge came down the court to set up on offense against Louisiana State on Saturday, he pleaded with an official to watch out for the elbows and the shoves of the redshirt freshman Tyrus Thomas. Aldridge was also being leaned on by L.S.U.'s 310-pound center, Glen Davis, another unpleasant experience from which Aldridge needed relief.

title: So Far, Well-Balanced Blue Devils Look Unstoppable
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 26 A The sites and the opponents have changed for Duke as it has negotiated its way through the N.C.A.A. women's tournament, but not the story lines. For the third consecutive game, the Blue Devils won a one-sided game and looked like a team intent on winning a national championship.

title: Politics in Italy: Still a man's world
Same Guy, Smaller Kingdom
description: THE last thing Michael D. Eisner would seem to require is more exposure. title: A Community of Arabs Adrift and Apart Flounder in 'Iron Island'
description: A derelict oil tanker, anchored somewhere in the Persian Gulf, has become the slowly sinking home of a community of squatters in "Iron Island," an allegorical feature directed by the Iranian Mohammad Rasoulof. The squatters are members of an Arab minority in Iran's ethnic Persian society, and they are less oppressed than simply overlooked -- marginalized right out of the country and into the sea.

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: THE NEW GUY -- Ben S. Bernanke oversees his first Fed meeting as chairman this week. The two-day meeting begins today; a decision on interest rates is expected tomorrow. Economists predict that the Fed will again raise its benchmark overnight lending rate a quarter-point, to 4.75 percent.

description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 26 - Pressure mounted Sunday on Nigeria to arrest Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia who is under indictment for war crimes in connection with his role in the brutal, decade-long civil war here.

title: Drying Out the Insurgency
description: LONDON - AS we saw in the recent offensive by American and Iraqi forces against insurgents near Samarra, the term "air assault" has taken on a new meaning in military parlance. It now indicates taking troops into action by helicopter, rather than the widespread and often indiscriminately destructive firing of missiles or dropping of bombs from aircraft.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Shield' Ratings Slip
description: On the season finale of "The Shield" on Tuesday, a tearful and apologetic Shane (Walton Goggins) murdered Lem (Kenneth Johnson), his friend and fellow police detective, to prevent Lem from revealing the corrupt deeds their team had perpetrated. In Nielsen's estimates, the FX series attracted 3.2 million viewers. During its fifth season, "The Shield" drew an average audience of 2.8 million, down from the year before, when Glenn Close's season as a police captain lifted the show's ratings to an average 3.2 million. Elsewhere on cable, for the week ending March 19, USA Network ranked No. 1 in prime time in total viewers and adults 18 to 49, as it often has since the channel brought wrestling to its schedule. Its "Monk" (5.4 million) and two hours of "WWE Monday Night Raw" (5.3 million and 5.2 million) were the three most-watched programs of the week on basic cable. KATE AURTHUR

title: Kronos Quartet Infuses Zankel Hall With Sounds of Today
description: In its 30-odd years before the public the Kronos Quartet has shown little interest in conserving masterpieces. With its American tilt toward casual, sometimes-funky clothes and lighting effects, and its natural ease with electricity-induced sounds, the Kronos has kept its ear open to whatever composers happen to have on their minds at the time.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Killed In Subway Fall
description: A 53-year-old man died yesterday afternoon when he fell down the stairs to a Queens subway platform and crashed head-on into the side of an R train that was entering the station, the police said. Shortly after 2 p.m., the man, whom the police would not identify until notifying his family, was taken from the 74th Street-Broadway station in Jackson Heights to Elmhurst Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The police said they believed that the man had stumbled accidentally.

For Group of Singers, These Are the Days
description: Mario Bernal, 80, describes himself as "very inhibited and shy" and says he never sang until a few years ago. But there he was one day last week, in a bright red shirt and party hat, emerging from a group of 20 similarly garbed performers to render a rousing solo of a chunk of the robust drinking song "Those Were the Days."

title: Justices Will Hear Patent Case Against eBay
description: The United States Supreme Court will hear arguments on Wednesday in a protracted, closely watched patent case that pits a small company called MercExchange against eBay, the online auction and marketplace.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire In Federal Jail
description: A smoky fire in ductwork at a federal jail in Lower Manhattan yesterday forced the temporary relocation of 269 inmates, the authorities said, adding that two asthmatic prisoners were treated at the scene for minor breathing problems. The fire, which began just after noon on the fourth floor of the Metropolitan Correctional Center, was brought under control 90 minutes later. Fire officials said the inmates were moved to another section of the building until the fire was extinguished and the smoke had cleared. The jail, at Pearl Street and Park Row, holds inmates whose trials are under way at the federal courthouse across the street. Fire officials said the blaze had not been set.

title: Charting a course for Airbus
Busch Inspires Anger as He Rises Above It
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., March 26 - Penske Racing South has tried its best to remake the bad-boy image of its driver Kurt Busch this season. But maybe it should have left well enough alone.

title: Arts, Briefly; Piano Competition Begins
description: The early rounds of the fifth Honens International Piano Competition, which begin today, will be open to the public free at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia Theater at Symphony Space. The competition is to include 72 pianists from the ages of 20 to 30, representing 19 countries, and each performing a minirecital of 40 minutes. Recitals today will be played from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., 2 to 5:10 p.m, and 7 to 9:20 p.m. Tomorrow's competition takes place from 10 a.m. to 1:10 p.m.; Thursday hours are 10 a.m. to 1:10 p.m., 2 to 5 p.m. and 7 to 10:10 p.m., and on Friday, from 10 a.m. to 1:10 p.m., 2 to 6 p.m. and 7 to 10:10 p.m.. The quarterfinal, semifinal and final rounds of the competition for more than $84,000 in cash prizes and career development are to be held in Calgary, Alberta, from Oct. 19 to Nov. 3. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

title: Turning to Mammon to Spread the Gospel
description: A CHURCH that raised eyebrows with a provocative television commercial is resuming its advertising efforts with a campaign that seeks to emulate how the Gospel was spread: by word of mouth.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Transit Security Questioned
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner accused the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday of failing to comply with a confidential directive of the Department of Homeland Security from May 2004 that required transit agencies to remove garbage cans and other containers from subway and train platforms, and to replace them with clear plastic or bomb-resistant cans. The directive was issued in response to the Madrid commuter train bombings of March 2004. Officials of the authority could not be reached for comment yesterday, but in the past they questioned the effectiveness of blast-proof cans. Officials also said that garbage cans were essential, because trash and debris thrown on the tracks can cause fires and other hazards. Mr. Weiner, a Democrat who represents parts of Brooklyn and Queens, said the authority had failed to appreciate the risk that the cans could be used to store bombs.

title: GEORGE MASON vs. FLORIDA
description: THE MATCHUP The biggest question entering the Final Four weekend will be if George Mason can continue its improbable run. The only logical answer, at this point, is why not? After beating Connecticut, perhaps the most talented team in the country, George Mason is capable of winning two games and completing the quintessential underdog story.
