title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about statements from the United States and Europe that they would impose sanctions on Belarus over the crackdown on peaceful protesters after the country's presidential election referred incorrectly to a senior State Department official's estimate of the number of Belarus officials likely to face sanctions. The official said that "fewer than a dozen" officials were under sanctions now and that the number would probably increase "by a factor of five or six." The official did not say the number was likely to be more than 50.

title: I.R.L. Rookie Dies After Prerace Collision
description: The Indy Racing League rookie Paul Dana died yesterday after he was involved in a two-car collision during a practice session five hours before the season-opening race at Homestead-Miami Speedway in Florida.

title: Remaking Diesel's Image a Lap at a Time
description: EUROPEAN roads are bustling with modern diesel cars that do not spew stinky clouds of black smoke from their tailpipes or announce their presence with a truck-stop clatter from under the hood. But with few exceptions, American drivers cannot buy these refined models.

title: Elections over, task for Merkel is reform
Paid Notice: Deaths   KRENTS, IRMA (NEE KOPP)
description: KRENTS--Irma (nee Kopp), passed on peacefully at home on March 25th, at the age of 91. Adored wife of the late Milton Krents, cherished sister of Gertrude Wasserstrom, the late Evelyn Harris and the late Bernie Kopp, extraordinary mother to Larry Krents (Peggy), Babby Krentz Zuckerwise (David), and the late Harold Krents (Kit), very beloved "MaMa" to Andrew Krents (Jennifer Belle), Karen Krentz Neate (Will), Jamie Krents (Lisa), Willie Krents, Michael Krents, Randi Zuckerwise Madrid (Mark), Lena Zuckerwise, Laura Zuckerwise and new great-grandmother to Jasper Krents and Abigail Neate. Possessing great intellect, a special wisdom for life, a sharp wit, and tremendous warmth, Irma touched many lives. She was an award-winning scriptwriter, and she had an esteemed career in public relations and oral history. Her great faith, indomitable strength, and energy, together with her passionate and deep, self-less love for her family and others, enabled Irma to surmount many obstacles placed in her lovedones' way. Her Spirit and Love are everlasting. Funeral services Tuesday, 1 pm, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Donations may be made to The Calvary Hospital to the fund in memory of Harold Krents, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Merkel Coalition Maintains Hold in Early Surveys in 3 State Races
description: BERLIN, March 26 - Chancellor Angela Merkel's coalition of conservatives and Social Democrats on Sunday survived the first test of its popularity at the polls since German parliamentary elections in September as the parties held on to power in three states, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls announced by the state television networks.

title: Will New Windows Be Worth the Wait?
description: Wow. So Windows Vista has been delayed yet again. Now it's scheduled for early 2007. What's that, the 45th consecutive delay?

title: Other Views: Sydney Morning Herald, Los Angeles Times, The Hindu
The response to bird flu: Too much or not enough?
Paid Notice: Deaths   BAILEY, MILTON
description: BAILEY--Milton. Of Wayland, MA. On March 20, 2006. Devoted father of Joseph A. Bailey of Gill, MA. He was the brother of Pricilla Kolson of Poughkeepsie, NY; Bertha Weinstein of Wantagh, NY; Hyman Bialek of Silver Spring, MD; Isidore Bialek of River Edge, NJ; Benjamin Bialek of Costa Mesa, CA; and Jack Bialek of North Brentwood, NY. He was the husband of the late Lucille (Rubin) Bailey. Private funeral services were held at North Cemetery in Wayland, MA. For information call: John C. Bryant Funeral Home of Wayland.

title: Seattle Gunman PlannedAttack, Police Say
description: The 28-year-old man who killed six young people at a rave dance after-party before turning the gun on himself arrived with more than 300 rounds of ammunition but said only one sentence as he carried out the attack, the Seattle Police Department said today.

title: A Dry Run for Handling a Disaster in the City Railyards
description: How would New York City respond if a bomb filled with arsenic trichloride, a highly toxic liquid compound, were to explode on a freight train moving through a Queens railyard -- just when a commuter train carrying weekend passengers was traveling in the other direction?

title: CRITICS' CHOICE: NEW CD'S
description: Yeah Yeah Yeahs "Show Your Bones" (Interscope)

title: Interpublic's Controller Exits With Pay Package
description: Nicholas S. Cyprus, the controller and chief accounting officer of the troubled Interpublic Group of Companies, was dismissed with a lucrative exit package, Interpublic disclosed Friday in a regulatory filing.

title: More Litter in the City
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz at Lincoln Center Features LCJO
description: The Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra is one of the steadiest and most prestigious assignments for a working jazz musician. These benefits come with a certain sacrifice: members of the orchestra have no choice but to lean into its gravitational pull, losing themselves to a larger purpose and ideal. On Friday night at the Rose Theater, a concert called "LCJO in Small Doses" gave eight of those musicians a chance to break out of the orbit and make an impression. Intermittently, in flashes, they did.

title: On trade, the U.S. and China need to go global
Proving Point, Nets Stymie East Leaders on the Road
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., March 26 - The Nets brought a seven-game winning streak here Sunday night, but there was little doubt that a victory on the Pistons' home court would be a true barometer of their late-season play.

title: Illegal Immigrants, Duty and Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALISH, BEVERLY
description: KALISH - Beverly. Beloved wife of the late Max Kalish, cherished mother of Harry (Robin), Arlene (Stuart Sankel), Donald and Sindy Cohan. Adored grandmother of Chad, Sonya, Melanie, Danny and Max. Passed away on March 24th. A loving woman whose heart knew no boundaries and whose generosity, thoughtfulness, caring and gentleness will always be remembered by all who knew and loved her. Services will be held today at 12 noon at Weinstein - Garlick - Kirschen baum, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11230.

title: 'Dear Juliet': Seeking Succor From a Veteran of Love
description: "Dear Juliet," the letters all begin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PHANG, HELEN, R.N.
description: PHANG--Helen, R.N. Passed away peacefully on March 25 after a short illness. Helen was the doyenne of the operating room at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, and in this role always gave both extraordinary care to her patients and equally importantly by her example taught an entire generation of doctors, nurses, and other co-workers to always try and function at their highest possible level. We will always remember her humanity and her skill. Jay Lippman, M.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIN, KATHRYN A.
description: LEWIN -- Kathryn A. On March 26, 2006, in her 92nd year. Beloved wife of Harvey M. Lewin. Loving mother of Karen (Mark) and Robert (Susan). Adored grandma of Deborah, Alex, Jonathan and Jessica. She was a lifelong New Yorker, rabid Yankee fan, and original fan of Frank Sinatra. Special gratitude to Cynthia Smith, her loving caregiver. Her indomitable spirit will be missed by all who knew her. Service and interment private.

title: City Students Get a Lesson in Slow Justice
description: AN appeals court ruled yesterday that New York City schools were being shortchanged by at least $4.7 billion annually in state aid, adding more firepower to the city's plea for more education money as lawmakers try to wrap up work on a state budget.

title: EU plan would cap 'roaming charges'
LOUISIANA STATE vs. U.C.L.A.
description: THE MATCHUP Fourth-seeded Louisiana State has the best frontline at the Final Four, but this game will come down to whose guards hit shots. U.C.L.A.'s guards, Jordan Farmar and Arron Afflalo, may get more attention, but they are about even with L.S.U.'s Darrel Mitchell and Garrett Temple. Farmar and Afflalo combined to shoot 3 of 18 on Saturday against Memphis, and Mitchell and Temple shot 4 of 19 against Texas. Look for the Tigers' athleticism to lead them to the title game.

title: Chirac and English
In a Bruising Battle, Tennessee Comes Out on Top
description: CLEVELAND, March 26 - Tennessee had the height advantage and the historical advantage: 25 straight years in the N.C.A.A. tournament's Round of 16. When it counted, the Lady Vols also had Shanna Zolman and Candace Parker, two players who knew what had to be done and had the ability to do it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rally For Less Traffic In Central Park
description: About 150 people rallied yesterday in Central Park to call for a ban on vehicular traffic on the 6.1-mile main loop, which includes the East and West Drives, at all times this summer. Currently, traffic is permitted there on weekdays from 7 to 10 a.m. and 3 to 7 p.m. Transportation Alternatives, a nonprofit group for pedestrians and cyclists that organized the rally, announced that six members of the City Council whose districts adjoin the park favored an experimental summer-long ban. The group also said it had collected 100,000 signatures in support of a year-round ban. Neither proposal would affect the Central Park transverses, which are open to traffic at all times.

title: Keystone Komputers
description: It may sound incredible to anyone who's ever used the Internet, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation has struggled unsuccessfully for 10 years to come up with a workable computer system. The idea is to allow agents to quickly share discoveries and analyze information in ongoing investigations. The problem surfaced most grimly after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks when it emerged that the F.B.I.'s 1980's-era technology could not cross-reference words -- like, say, "flight" and "schools" -- for any agent who might have had advance suspicions about the suicide attackers' preparations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALKOW, MICHELE G.
description: FALKOW--Michele G. Our heartfelt condolences to Lewis R. Steinberg on the loss of Michele, a woman of scintillating warmth and keen intellect. Aliza R. Levine Rabbi Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Levine

title: Senate Debates Citizenship Eligibility for Immigrants
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee struggled to reach a compromise on an immigration reform bill today, trying to bridge an ideological divide between those who favor eventual citizenship and those who reject amnesty for people who entered the country illegally.

title: Bridge; With a Tournament Beckoning, Declining a Chance to Overruff
description: The deal in Saturday's column featured East's overruffing with a losing trump. This gained one trick in the short term but lost two tricks -- and the contract -- in the long run because East was endplayed and forced to give declarer access to winners on the board.

title: Mental Health Evaluation May Derail Case Against Afghan Convert to Christianity
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 26 - The case of an Afghan man facing the death penalty for converting to Christianity was returned to prosecutors on Sunday because of "investigative gaps," a move that will delay, if not scuttle, an investigation that has created an international uproar.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: AOL, part of Time Warner, signed four advertisers as the initial sponsors of a new free video service, In2TV, that offers computer users a chance to watch episodes of vintage television series. The shows include Alice, Chico and the Man, Falcon Crest, Maverick and V. The sponsors of the service (television.aol.com/in2tv) are Hershey, Intel, Kia Motors and Kraft Foods.

title: Europe is on sale and Goldman Sachs is buying
Rice to Ask Russia About Report That It Gave Iraq Data
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Sunday that the United States would seek clarification from Russia of an American military report that it had helped pass information to Iraq before the 2003 invasion, but she declined to make any specific allegations about Russian involvement.

title: In Ex-Detective's Trial, His Book Provides a Bizarre Plot Outline
description: Beneath the murders, the mobsters, the gamblers, the strippers, the tax cheats, diamond smugglers, thieves, hoods, cops, cons, corpses, crooks and marijuana dealers, there is -- at the core -- a book.

title: Reform Leader Suffers Setback In Ukraine Vote
description: KIEV, Ukraine, Monday, March 27 - President Viktor A. Yushchenko, who led a wave of popular protest to office promising a freer Ukraine aligned with Europe and the United States, suffered a stunning political defeat in parliamentary elections on Sunday, leaving him weakened and his reformist policies in doubt.

title: Stock Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: UConn Plays Its Part; The Problem Is the Role
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 - Every upset needs a victim. Every underdog needs a foil. And Connecticut, an 86-84 overtime loser to George Mason, played the roles perfectly.

title: China predicts gradual slowing of economic growth
French utility fighting to keep Belgian assets
Groundswell of Protests Back Illegal Immigrants
description: Correction Appended

title: Flapper: A Madcap Story of Sex, Style, Celebrity and the Women Who Made America Modern
Students With Grit and Courage Are Awarded Times Scholarships
description: Some teenagers work to buy an iPod or a cellphone. Anna Umanskaya works to pay the rent.

title: Gip Hoppe's 'Mercy on the Doorstep,' With Faith, Alcoholism and Real Estate
description: Religious faith faces down the allied forces of alcoholism and cynicism in Gip Hoppe's drama "Mercy on the Doorstep," which opened last night at the Flea Theater. The play ends with its characters firmly clinging to their opposed dogmas, which indicates that Mr. Hoppe has not settled for pat answers to complicated questions. Belief is presented neither as a handy cure for pathology nor as an easily punctured delusion.

title: Hyundai going to Czech Republic
Windows Is So Slow, but Why?
description: Back in 1998, the federal government declared that its landmark antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation was not merely a matter of law enforcement, but a defense of innovation. The concern was that the company was wielding its market power and its strategy of bundling more and more features into its dominant Windows desktop operating system to thwart competition and stifle innovation.

title: Sony and Bertelsmann May Alter Venture
description: The German media conglomerate Bertelsmann has initiated talks with the Sony Corporation about altering the companies' joint venture in the music business and perhaps selling Bertelsmann's half to Sony or another party, according to two people close to the venture.

title: Get Ready for No. 15 in a Series at the Fed
description: Correction Appended

title: Presto! A School for Magic Creates Hope Out of Thin Air
description: KHAYELITSHA, South Africa - Life is hard for the 750,000 or so people crammed into this shantytown, one of South Africa's largest and toughest. In the last census, in 2001,6 in 10 adults here said they had no steady income. What little money they have tends to vanish quickly, spent on essentials or stolen in the break-ins and robberies that are endemic here.

title: How Serious Is the Risk of Avian Flu?
description: Over the last year, it has been impossible to watch TV orread a newspaper without encountering dire reports about birdflu and the possibility of a pandemic, a worldwide epidemic.First Asia, then Europe, now Africa: like enemy troops movinginto place for an attack, the bird flu virus known as A(H5N1) hasbeen steadily advancing. The latest country to report humancases is Azerbaijan, where five of seven people have died. Thevirus has not reached the Americas, but it seems only a matterof time before it turns up in birds here.

title: The social realism of Spike Lee
Polish hikers abducted near Everest
Shiite Leaders, Furious Over Raid, Halt Talks on Government
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 27 A Frayed relations between Iraq's Shiite leadership and the American authorities came under increased strain on Monday as Shiite leaders expressed fury over an American-led attack on a Shiite compound and suspended negotiations over a new government.

title: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VARADY, PEGGY PRAG
description: VARADY--Peggy Prag. Died March 18. Widow of Fritz Varady. Chic, stylish and elegant, with a mischievous and wry smile beneath her southern charm. Ever strong and ever vulnerable.

title: North of the Border
description: "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free," wrote Emma Lazarus, in a poem that still puts a lump in my throat. I'm proud of America's immigrant history, and grateful that the door was open when my grandparents fled Russia.

title: Courting the Union Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: Bedouins' Genetic Betrayal

title: On the Ethanol Bandwagon, Big Names and Big Risks
description: Big name investors, like  Vinod Khosla, founder of Sun Microsystems and former partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, Sir Richard Branson, chairman of the Virgin Group, and Bill Gates of Microsoft, are embracing ethanol the plant-derived fuel that some say could rapidly displace gasoline.

title: Small Texas Town Draws Patent Litigation Disputes
description: The small Texas town of Marshall is an unlikely an unlikely hub in the lucrative universe of patent infringement litigation.

title: Bank Deal Starts Debate on Polish Role in United Europe
description: For those here who bristled at the Western European caricature of Polish workers as migrants who exploit a borderless Europe to snatch jobs from French and Dutch plumbers, Poland now has its own bogeyman: a giant Italian bank seeking to merge two of this countrys major banks.

title: Australian Stock Exchange Buys Sydney Futures
description: Australian Stock Exchange  has agreed to buy the countrys biggest futures market for A$2.25 billion ($1.59 billion) to increase its share of derivatives trading, which is growing faster than stock transactions.

title: Looking for More Money, After Reaching a Deal
description: Last week, a group of investors agreed to acquire the company that owns the glitzy Atlantis resort and casino in the Bahamas, for $3.6 billion. The deal was notable for its size, says Andrew Ross Sorkin in his DealBook column on Sunday, but perhaps more so for a condition buried in the merger agreement that is popping up in the fine print of more and more deals: a go shop provision.

title: Withdrawal of Check Point Bid Highlights Secretive Agencys Inner Workings
description: The decision by Israeli Internet software security company Check Point Software Technologies  to back out of its $225 million acquisition of software maker Sourcefire illustrates how a secretive interagency government panel uses its investigative muscle to stop foreign acquisitions of American assets deemed threatening to national security.

title: Australias Patrick Corp. Rejects Tolls Revised Offer
description: Patrick Corporation, Australias biggest port cargo handler, rejected Toll Holdings Ltd.s increased A$5.5 billion ($3.9 billion) takeover bid.

title: How Serious Is the Risk of Avian Flu?
description: Over the last year, it has been impossible to watch TV or read a newspaper without encountering dire reports about bird flu and the possibility of a pandemic, a worldwide epidemic. First Asia, then Europe, now Africa: like enemy troops moving into place for an attack, the bird flu virus known as A(H5N1) has been steadily advancing. The latest country to report human cases is Azerbaijan, where five of seven people have died. The virus has not reached the Americas, but it seems only a matter of time before it turns up in birds here.

title: Lottery Operator Tatersalls Bets On Unitab
description: Tattersalls Ltd., Australias largest lottery operator, agreed to buy Unitab Ltd. for A$1.8 billion ($1.3 billion) in stock to gain control of the nations second-biggest chain of sports betting shops.

title: Mack Says Morgans M&A Ranking Slide is Not a Trend
description: Morgan Stanleys chief executive, John Mack, said his firms falling ranking in fees from advising on mergers and acquisitions is no cause for concern. Morgan Stanley ranked second among financial advisers to global mergers and acquisitions in the fourth quarter with 79 announced transactions worth about $218 billion. So far in 2006, the worlds third-largest securities firm by market value has slipped to seventh place with 59 transactions worth about $190 billion, according to Bloomberg data.

title: Renovo Plans Listing in London
description: Pharmaceutical company Renovo plans to list on the stock market with an estimated value of up to 139 million pounds. The offer is expected to raise net proceeds of 40 million pounds to develop two drugs, Juvista and Zesteem, aimed at reducing scarring and accelerated healing following surgery.

title: How Investing in Wendys May Be a Back Door to Hortons
description: Acquiring stock in fast-food chain Wendys International Inc. may offer a cheap back door to a stake in Canadian coffee chain Tim Hortons Inc., which had one of the frothiest recent initial public offerings, according to Barrons.

title: Alcatel and Lucent: Let the Games Begin
description: It hasnt even happened yet, but the mere prospect of a $34 billion merger between telecom hardware makers Lucent Technologies and Alcatel has sparked a wave of speculation over which deals might be next in the telecom hardware industry. The need for consolidation in the sector has long existed, some analysts say, but this transaction  plus the recent megamerger of AT&T and BellSouth  could be the match that lights the dealmaking fuse.

title: Small-Cap Tech I.P.O.s May Heat Up Market
description: The heat radiating from the Nasdaq could be thawing out what has been a chilly initial public offering market for small-cap technology companies. On March 22, Local Matters, a maker of Internet search software for the Yellow Pages market, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to go public. It follows a March 17 filing from online jeweler Bidz.com of Culver City, Calif., and a March 1 filing from online real estate portal LoopNet of San Francisco.

title: German Parent Plans I.P.O. for American Water
description: The corporate parent of American Water said Friday it would pursue an initial public offering for the South Jersey company. RWE of Essen, Germany, said in November that it was considering a sale or a public offering of the company.

title: A Venture Capital Firm Makes a Name for Itself
description: Even within the chummy world of Silicon Valley venture capitalists, many people havent heard of Azure Capital Partners. To the extent they have, its usually because of the San Francisco firms ties to one of Silicon Valleys infamous characters. Azures four founders all rose to prominence while working for Frank Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse First Boston investment banker.Now Azure looks poised to make a name for itself.

title: Insurance Start-Up Gasping for Air
description: Investment bank Friedman, Billings, Ramsey Group , although with some other investors from the banking world invested millions of dollars in a start-up insurance company based in Bermuda that was pretty much blown away by hurricanes Katrina, Rita and Wilma.

title: Groove Mobile Hears Music to Its Ears
description: Groove Mobile, whose software powers the Sprint PCS Music Store, has closed on $8.5 million in Series B financing, bringing the total raised by the company to more than $20 million. Boston-based Egan-Managed Capital led the round, which closed in February.

title: Online Exchange Reels In Investments
description: Norwest Venture Partners has bet $12.5 million on HedgeStreet., a government-regulated online exchange for options and futures. HedgeStreet also secured a strategic investment from the Chicago Board Options Exchange. The CBOE, one of the largest equity options exchanges in the United States, provided seven-figures in capital as part of a strategic agreement, HedgeStreets chief executive, Steve Rac,e said.

title: Private Equity Bidders for ITV Consider Tweaking Their Offer
description: The trio of private equity houses stalking ITV are grappling with the 1.4 billion pound problem of how to offer shareholders that do not like their proposed deal an exit from the television company. Goldman Sachs, Apax Partners and Blackstone have been working all weekend to find a way of providing underwriting capacity from a third party that does not cost so much it wrecks the financial logic of their deal.

title: Permira Looks at Options for Travelodge
description: Permira, the private equity firm, is examining selling Travelodge, the budget hotel group, for an estimated 1.1 billion pounds. Grant Hearn, chief executive, said yesterday that a range of plans for the business were being examined, including an offering or sale.

title: Buyout Firm Corinthian Turns It Up With Disc Makers Buy
description: In its first deal since launching last year, middle-market buyout firm Corinthian Capital Group has purchased Disc Makers, which produces CDs and DVDs for musicians and corporations.Terms were not disclosed.

title: Green Is Also the Color of Money
description: Green technology is piping hot right now. Buzz echoed in the ballroom at the Cleantech Venture Network conference this week in San Francisco, where venture capitalists gathered to discuss the future of alternative energy investments.

title: Nomura Still Has a Ways to Go to Catch Up With Rivals
description: While Nomura Holdings  is poised to report the best profit in its 81-year history on record trading in a resurgent home market, Japans No. 1 securities firm continues to struggle as a global also-ran.

title: Platinum Buys 80% Stake in Americatel From Chilean Phone Company
description: Platinum Equity has agreed to buy an 80 percent stake of Hispanic-focused telecommunications company Americatel for $49.6 million, becoming the latest private equity firm hoping to capitalize on the growing population of Spanish speakers in the United States.

title: Goldman Sachs Plays Catch-Up With Fund of Funds
description: Goldman Sachs Asset Management has started marketing its third distressed fund of funds. The fund-of-funds branch of investment bank Goldman Sachs has set a target of roughly $600 million for the vehicle, but it appears likely to collect up to $1 billion, said potential investors.

title: Vague Law and Hard Lobbying Add Up to Billions for Big Oil
description: Last month, the Bush administration confirmed that it expected the government to waive about $7 billion in royalties from oil companies over the next five years, even though the industry incentive was expressly conceived of for times when energy prices were low. And that number could quadruple to more than $28 billion if a lawsuit filed last week challenging one of the programs remaining restrictions proves successful.

title: Lehman Gears Up for Big Japanese Push
description: Investment bank Lehman Brothers plans an aggressive push into Japan, where it hopes to double the size of its work force over the next three years, its head of Europe and Asia said.

title: Brazilian Police Arrest Credit Suisse Bankers
description: The Brazilian police arrested the head of Credit Suisse Groups private banking unit in Brazil and seized the passports of six other company bankers as part of a four- month investigation into money laundering and tax evasion, Bloomberg News reported.

title: ConocoPhilips Burlington Purchase On Schedule for Close
description: ConocoPhillips is on target to complete its purchase of Burlington Resources  next week, a Conoco spokeswoman said Friday. The deal should close March 31 pending Burlington shareholders approval.

title: Justices Will Hear Patent Case Against eBay
description: The United States Supreme Court will hear arguments on Wednesday in a protracted, closely watched patent case that pits a small company called MercExchange against eBay, the online auction and marketplace.

title: Zucker Looking to Unload About 80 Hudson Bay Stores
description: Jerry Zucker has approached some of Canadas largest retailers in an attempt to unload about 80 underperforming Hudsons Bay stores, but he isnt talking to key rival Wal-Mart Canada Corp., industry sources say.

title: True or False: A Hedge Fund Plotted to Hurt a Drug Maker?
description: At the heart of Biovails racketeering lawsuit against the $8 billion SAC hedge fund and the research firm, Gradient, is an audacious claim: that some of the nations biggest hedge funds colluded with independent research firms and analysts at big banks to produce purposely misleading research with the sole object of driving down a companys stock price.

title: Zurich Financial May Pay  $100 Million to Settle Investigations in U.S.
description: Zurich Financial Services, Switzerlands biggest insurer, may pay more than $100 million to settle bid-rigging and accounting investigations with American state regulators, Bloomberg reported. An agreement with officials in New York, Connecticut and Illinois may be announced as soon as Monday. Zurich Financial agreed March 19 to pay $171 million to nine other states investigating whether it rigged insurance bids.

title: City National Picks Up Independence Investment
description: City National is buying money management company Independence Investment from Manlife Financial. The exact price tag was not disclosed, but City National did say that the transaction would be all-cash, and is expected to close late in the second quarter. City National also said that the deal is expected to modestly add to the companys 2006 earnings.

title: Questions Raised About Google Founders Wooing of  Mayor
description: An article in the San Francisco Chronicle on Friday seems to suggest that Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin are currying favor with San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom at a time when Google is bidding for a contract to offer free wireless Internet to the citys residents. Google offered Mr. Newsom a ride on a chartered jet to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last year, the article says. The newspaper also obtained e-mails that show that Mr. Pages secretary contacted Mr. Newsoms secretary to invite him to a weekend in the trendy Squaw Valley ski resort a year ago.

title: Lafarge North America Rejects Parents $3 Billion Buyout
description: Lafarge North America, the biggest maker of building materials in the United States and Canada, spurned a $3 billion buyout offer from its French parent as too low.

title: Hyundai Shares Drop After Office Raid
description: Shares of Hyundai Motors and affiliate Kia Motors fell on Monday after prosecutors raided their offices in a probe that local media tied to lobbying.

title: S.E.C. Overturns Investment Bankers Lifetime Ban From the Industry
description: In a rare move, the Securities and Exchange Commission late Friday set aside a lifetime ban from the securities industry imposed on the former investment banker Frank P. Quattrone, just days after a federal appeals court overturned his 2004 conviction on obstruction of justice charges. The S.E.C. said that NASD, the market regulator that imposed the ban, violated its own rules in taking the action in November 2004.

title: For a 3d Time, Two Apples Meet in Court
description: Apple Computer will meet the Beatles Apple Corps in court this week in London, where a judge will determine whether Apple Computers iTunes online music service violates a 1991 agreement between the two companies that, the Beatles Apple claims, blocked the computer maker from selling music.

title: Players Big and Small Are Sifting Through Pieces of Knight Ridder
description: With the McClatchy Company set to accept bids, starting as early as tomorrow, for the 12 Knight Ridder papers it is selling, some of the potential buyers are looking at the country as if it were a giant chessboard.The goal is not to topple a king but to become one  a king of each regional market where potential buyers already own newspapers and can achieve economies of scale by buying pieces of Knight Ridder.

title: Goldman Sachs  in Two European Deals
description: KarstadtQuelle, Germanys largest department-store operator, agreed to sell its property to a joint venture with Goldman Sachs  for 4.5 billion euros ($5.4 billion) to eliminate debt.

title: Alcatel Board to Meet Thursday on Lucent
description: Signaling that any definitive word on a deal with Lucent Technologies will not come until late this week at the earliest, French telecom equipment maker Alcatel said Monday that its board planned to meet Thursday to discuss a possible merger with Lucent.

title: Investment Banks Are Said to Be Preparing $6 Billion Bid for Thomson
description: Investment banks are forming a consortium to bid more than $6 billion for French consumer electronics manufacturer Thomson, according to The Business newspaper in London.

title: Sony and Bertelsmann May Alter Venture
description: The German media conglomerate Bertelsmann has initiated talks with Sony about altering the companies joint venture in the music business and perhaps selling Bertelsmanns half to Sony or another party, according to The New York Times.

title: The Street Fight Donations
description: (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times; Marko Georgiev/For The New York Times )

title: Letters to Juliet
description: Thousands of letters a year are sent to Juliet, of Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet."

title: A Tuscan With a Mind of Its Own
description: Sometimes I fall in love with a producer from the moment I first taste his wine. I know, I sound gullible. But really, if you can sense a purity, a commitment, and of course deliciousness and complexity, why hold back?

title: Roundup: Ballot Printing Day
description: A new week. A familiar feeling.

title: Libertarians   From Downtown  Yes!
description: In what was arguably the biggest upset in the history of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, George Mason defeated Connecticut yesterday to advance to the Final Four. Conservatives and libertarians have long hailed George Mason as the university for their political soulmates. (See this National Review piece by John J. Miller.) At Reasons Hit & Run blog, Tim Cavanaugh responds to libertarian mecca George Masons victory by writing, For the first time ever, libertarians win something. He adds, You could tell by all those three-pointers that this was a team organized on the wisdom of distributed decision-making rather than central control. At Sports Illustrateds SI.com, basketball analyst Seth Davis suggests that an even better little-known team than George Mason was denied a bid to the tournament: Hofstra has to be like the best team in the country. They beat Mason twice. So, I think if Mason wins both games in Indianapolis, then they should have to play Hofstra on Tuesday. Well settle this thing once and for all.

title: Angular Apples
description: Selborne Journal: 27 March 1759:  Sawed-down those two espalier-trees in the New-Garden that bore angular apples: & employed John Lassam to graft the stems with some Cuttings from the Royal-russet in the Orchard. Grafted two of the Golden-pippins in the Orchard with Cuttings from the tree of the same sort.

title: Equity One Sells Texas Malls to Investcorp Joint Venture
description: Real estate investment trust Equity One is forming a joint venture with Investcorp of Bahrain to house 30 Texas shopping malls that Equity One now owns.

title: The End of an Era in Newark
description: A photographic look back at the 20-year political career of Sharpe James after it ended in 2006.

title: BMC Software to Buy Venture-Backed Identify for $150 Million
description: BMC Software said Monday it would pay $150 million in cash for Identify Software, an Israel-based company that makes software used to troubleshoot other software applications.

title: The Next 'Best Generation'
description:
Michael Fay, who recently returned to the United States, said, "The time I spend in the field with my fellow marines is truly the place where I live, flourish and originate."
Go to Frontlines

title: Work, But Dont Live in Tahoe

description: The plan of rival developers who want to turn 57,000 acres  of desert west of Albuquerque, N.M., into housing tracts is turning into a war, says the Las Vegas Review Journal.

title: Mr. Fukuyamas Plan B
description: Francis Fukuyama takes his neocon-repudiation book tour to The Wall Street Journal, where he co-authors an op-ed with Adam Garfinkle, the editor of Fukuyamas American Interest magazine, on why democracy promotion isnt the best way to fight Islamic terrorism. The Bush administrations misguided linkage of two separate, and sound, objectives is backfiring by defeating democracy and promoting terrorism, rather than the other way around, Fukuyama and Garfinkle suggest. Democracy promotion should remain an integral part of American foreign policy, but it should not be seen as a principal means of fighting terrorism, they write, adding:

title: Buy Seven For the Price of One
description: Are you looking for the next real estate opportunity? What if someone told you that for what you are paying for one house in Mill Valley, Calif., you could buy 23 apartments in Charlotte, N.C.? Good deal, huh?

title: Notes on Immigration
description: Immigration is an intensely painful topic for a liberal like myself, because it places basic principles in conflict. Should migration from Mexico to the United States be celebrated, because it helps very poor people find a better life? Or should it be condemned, because it drives down the wages of working Americans and threatens to undermine the welfare state? I suspect that my March 27 column will anger people on all sides; I wish the economic research on immigration were more favorable than it is.

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Conviction In Officer's Shooting
description: A St. Albans man was convicted yesterday of shooting a police officer in a struggle during an arrest in 1999, Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said yesterday. The man, William Hodges, 33, of Mars Place, was convicted of first-degree assault and other offenses. Prosecutors said Mr. Hodges grabbed Officer David Gonzalez's gun and shot him while the officer was searching him on Nov. 12, 1999. The charges against Mr. Hodges were initially dismissed in 2002 for lack of a speedy trial, but that decision was overturned on appeal and the charges were reinstated, Mr. Brown said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Inquiry Into Senator's Conduct
description: The Democratic leader of the State Senate appointed an investigative committee last night to examine charges that a Democratic senator, Ada L. Smith of Queens, threw hot coffee in the eyes of a member of her staff last week. Senator David A. Paterson of Manhattan, the chamber's minority leader, gave the committee of five senators a deadline of next Tuesday to recommend steps for dealing with "a clear pattern of inappropriate and unprofessional conduct on the part of Senator Smith." Based on a complaint by the staff member, Jennifer Jackson, Ms. Smith has been charged with third-degree assault, a misdemeanor. Mr. Paterson is the running mate of Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who is seeking election this year as governor.

title: Enron judge drops some charges against Skilling and Lay
Today's Sermon: Hip-Hop, Too, Can Be Holy
description: PATERSON, N.J. - IN the warm light seeping through the stained-glass windows featuring decidedly white-looking saints and angels, the Rev. Timothy Holder preached to the young people in the pews of St. Paul's Episcopal Church about the prophet Tupac Shakur.

title: EBay at the Bar
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments tomorrow in a bitter patent dispute between eBay and a small company called MercExchange. The court is being asked to decide whether MercExchange -- which holds a patent that, according to a court decision, eBay has infringed -- should be able to get an injunction to close part of eBay's site. For technical reasons of patent law, and policy reasons, the court should rule for eBay.

title: Bush names new White House chief of staff

description: The A(H5N1) influenza strain circulating the globe now may never seriously threaten humans, but for another subset of the earth's living creatures, it is already a disaster.

title: Protests Go On in Several Cities as Panel Acts
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 - Tens of thousands of immigrants here and in several other cities continued a wave of angry protests on Monday over Congressional proposals to arrest illegal immigrants and to fortify the Mexican border.

description: NEW ORLEANS, March 27  The battle among candidates for city office has begun, but running alongside it is a fight over the election itself.

title: Moussaoui Now Ties Himself to 9/11 Plot
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 27 - Zacarias Moussaoui, who is facing the death penalty for the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, took the witness stand in his own defense Monday, only to bolster the government's case by unhesitatingly acknowledging the charges in the indictment against him and adding a few new, self-incriminating statements.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the first meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers with Ben S. Bernanke as chairman misspelled the surname of the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, who has argued that the Fed needs to take a more global perspective in its deliberations. He is Richard W. Fisher, not Fischer.

title: Delphi Is Said to Offer Unions a One-Time Sweetener
description: DETROIT, March 27 - With a Friday deadline to reach a deal with its labor unions approaching, the auto parts supplier Delphi has proposed giving its factory workers $50,000 in exchange for a 40 percent reduction in pay, union officials who have been briefed on the plan said Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLASS, RUBIN

Adored grandfather. Services Wednesday, 12:PM, "Sinai Chapels", 162-05 Horace Harding Exp., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: $16.5 Million Airport Caper
description: The government agency that runs South Africa's airports is being bombarded with criticism after up to 15 armed men stormed a South African Airways Boeing 747 jet on Saturday and looted it of a cash shipment reported to total $16.5 million. The money, flown from Britain, was en route to Tanzania and another unidentified African nation when the gang, armed with AK-47 rifles, overpowered guards on an ostensibly secure apron at Johannesburg International Airport. Johannesburg's airport has been repeatedly hit by gangs targeting large hauls of cash and other valuables. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: Ehud Olmert and Family: At Home in Israel's Corridors of Power
description: In a new installment of "Frontline/World," Israel's acting prime minister, Ehud Olmert, and his wife recall the January night that their home became a kind of fortress, guarded by government agents and gawked at by reporters and onlookers. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon had suffered a stroke from which he has yet to recover, and succession plans went into effect. Today's election could formalize for Mr. Olmert a boost in power and, for his wife, Aliza, a loss of freedom.

title: Britain to miss its emissions-cutting target
New Rise in Number of Millionaire Families
description: The number of American households with a net worth of $1 million or more, excluding their principal residence, grew to a record 8.9 million last year, the British market research firm TNS Financial Services said in a report to be released today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Buying a Stake in British Bank
description: Temasek Holdings, Singapore's state-owned investment company, agreed to buy a 12 percent stake in Standard Chartered, the British lender, valued at about 2.3 billion ($4 billion). The deal will make Temasek the biggest shareholder in Standard Chartered, which gets two-thirds of its earnings from Asia. Temasek will purchase 152.4 million shares of Standard Chartered from Khoo TeckPuat Estate and plans to support the London-based bank "as a stable shareholder," Temasek said in a statement.

title: George Mason Won, and Now It's Found
description: FAIRFAX, Va., March 27 - George Mason stood in the center of the campus that bears his name wearing a green-and-gold cape and other mementos of victory -- a T-shirt, signs of support and, later in the day, green and gold balloons tied to his wrist. A proud bronze statue had gone schlock, and people stopped to take pictures.

title: Bill to Broaden Immigration Law Gains in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 - With Republicans deeply divided, the Senate Judiciary Committee voted on Monday to legalize the nation's 11 million illegal immigrants and ultimately to grant them citizenship, provided that they hold jobs, pass criminal background checks, learn English and pay fines and back taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, CAROL
description: ROSENBERG - Carol. The Berkshire Bank, its Board of Directors, officers, and staff mourn the passing of Carol Rosenberg, the beloved wife of Steven Rosenberg, President of Berkshire Bancorp Inc. We extend our deepest sympathies and heartfelt condolences to Steven, their children Scott and Melissa, and their entire family during this most difficult time and will keep them in our thoughts and prayers. She will be profoundly missed by all who were fortunate enough to know her. May the entire family be comforted and spared from further sorrow. Moses Marx, Chairman of the Board Moses Krausz, President

description: HARTFORD, March 27 - A state school for mentally retarded adults that came under federal oversight two decades ago because of flagrantly poor medical and psychological care has made significant improvements and should be released from the supervision of a monitor, a federal judge has ordered.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Rice To Go To Europe For Meetings On Iran
description: With negotiations over how to halt Iran's nuclear program still at an impasse, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice announced plans to meet with her European, Russian and Chinese counterparts in Berlin on Thursday. European and American negotiators said Russia, with partial support from China, was continuing to resist a Western push for unanimous adoption of a Security Council declaration calling on Iran to suspend its uranium enrichment activities. STEVEN R. WEISMAN (NYT)

description: A public already groaning under huge deficits does not need more red ink. An oil industry already rolling in record profits does not need more tax breaks. But both are sure to happen unless some way can be found to claw back from a decade's worth of Congressional and administrative blunders, aggressive lobbying and industry greed.

The relief may be especially welcome to women who have had breast cancer and cannot take estrogen.

title: Cindy Walker, 87, a Writer of Heartfelt Country Hits, Dies

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALDWELL, SARAH
description: CALDWELL - Sarah. New York City Opera mourns the passing of a great American operatic pioneer, as well as a dear friend and colleague. As founding director of the Opera Company of Boston, Miss Caldwell brought innovative repertoire, adventurous productions, and worldclass artists to America. She debuted at New York City Opera in 1973, as director of the New York stage premiere of Henze's "The Young Lord" (featuring Sir Rudolf Bing as Sir Edgar); and made her conducting debut here in 1976 with "The Barber of Seville", which she also directed, featuring Beverly Sills and Donald Gramm. As director, she gave City Opera a landmark production of "Ariadne auf Naxos" in 1973, and both directed and conducted "Falstaff" in 1979 with Donald Gramm. Miss Caldwell shared and inspired City Opera's visionary spirit, and we were proud to have had her as a member of our company. Paul Kellogg General Director

description: Do you like songs heavily steeped in nostalgia? Songs employing the carousel as a metaphor for the crazy whirl of life? Songs of romance tinted darkly with reflections on death? Songs that begin as wistful laments for lost youth -- or lost innocence, or lost love, or lost something else -- and gradually, inexorably evolve into stirring anthems to endurance? Songs accompanied by the plaintive whine of the accordion? Songs that sound French even when they are being sung in English?

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Housewives' Carries ABC
description: Half of the shows in ABC's Sunday lineup were repeats, but the network still managed to beat CBS. "Desperate Housewives," in which Gabrielle (Eva Longoria, below) and Carlos (Ricardo Antonio Chavira) weeded out ugly women who might give them a baby to adopt, was the night's most-watched program in Nielsen's estimates, with 21.34 million viewers. It was flanked by reruns of "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (13.04 million) and "Grey's Anatomy" (15 million). ABC began its night with an original episode of "America's Funniest Home Videos" (9.46 million) at 7 p.m. CBS easily won that hour, as N.C.A.A. basketball spilled over into prime time on the East Coast, helping to lift "60 Minutes" in the preliminary ratings. CBS placed second for the night among total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. In that age group, Fox was No. 3. The network's winners were "The Simpsons" (10.14 million) and "Family Guy" (8.15 million); its losers were the soon-to-end "Malcolm in the Middle" (3.6 million) and its slacker comedy "Free Ride" (4.89 million). KATE AURTHUR

title: Clinton Challenger's Adviser Says He'll Stay

Lowbrow Jokes Ad Nauseam From 'Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector'
description: Unpleasant, uncouth and painfully unfunny, "Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector" attempts lowbrow humor with neither the wit of the Farrelly brothers nor the raunchy inventiveness of Keenen Ivory Wayans. Aiming at audiences for whom no comedy is complete without lower-intestinal distress and projectile vomiting, the movie pursues its unsanitary goals with a relentlessness that makes "Dumb and Dumber" seem the epitome of sophistication. Prepare to be overcome with an irresistible urge to wash your hands afterward.

title: The Spread: In 3 Years, 3 Continents
description: In the early to mid-1990's, the A(H5N1) virus began quietly establishing itself in the poultry populations of Asia. Initially it caused only mild disease that escaped detection, but by 1997 the virus had mutated to a deadly form that could kill chickens within 48 hours. After a brief outbreak in 1997, the disease seemed to disappear. Then, at the end of 2003, A(H5N1) reappeared and has since spread to nearly 50 countries. ERIN AIGNER and DAVID CONSTANTINE AVIAN FLU | CALIBRATING THE MESSAGE

title: Status of Liberia's Indicted Ex-President Is Unclear

Taylor, the onetime warlord who became president of Liberia and who is wanted for war crimes by an international court based here for atrocities affecting Sierra Leone during neighboring Liberia's civil war.

title: Free Trade and AIDS Drugs
description: The countries of southern Africa have the world's highest rates of AIDS infection. These governments have a special need to make or buy low-cost generic drugs to save their citizens. World trade rules are amenable, containing safeguards that allow countries to use generics to preserve public health. But the Bush administration is now negotiating a free trade agreement with the Southern African Customs Union. It is important that the United States does not, in the process, restrict the ability of poor people to get generic drugs in these countries.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Two In Stolen Car Are Killed In Crash
description: Two men riding in a stolen car were killed early yesterday when their vehicle crashed into a New Jersey Transit bus in Newark, the authorities said. The two men, who were not identified by the police yesterday evening, were speeding in a 1989 Buick LeSabre on Broad Street near the Bears and Eagles Riverfront Stadium when the crash occurred, said Hubert Henderson, a police spokesman. The driver of the bus was taken to University Hospital with glass in his eyes, but was in good condition, Mr. Henderson said. The two passengers on the bus were not reported to have been injured.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Single Driver's License For 25 Countries
description: Drivers across Europe will soon be able to use a single credit-card-sized, counterfeit-proof driver's license that will do away with the 110 different versions that exist in the 25-nation bloc. The agreement was approved by the bloc's transport ministers and is to come into force by next year and apply to new driver's licenses by 2012. Tests for obtaining a license will remain the responsibility of individual countries. DAN BILEFSKY (IHT)

Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Secret Ruling Challenged
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union asked a federal appeals court yesterday to make public a secret ruling in a terrorism case that may involve warrantless domestic wiretaps by the National Security Agency. Judge Thomas J. McAvoy issued the classified ruling in federal court in Albany on March 10, after two defendants, Yassin M. Aref and Mohammed M. Hossain, asked him to dismiss charges against them if the government's evidence included warrantless wiretaps. Judge McAvoy declined to dismiss the case, but the defendants were barred from reading his ruling. Following an F.B.I. sting, Mr. Aref, who is a Muslim imam, and Mr. Hossain were accused of financing terrorism.

title: Hispanic Films Have Yet to Catch the Same Wave as Hispanic TV
description: MIAMI BEACH A The sizzle from a showing at last month's Miami International Film Festival had not yet cooled, but Francisca Schweitzer, a first-time filmmaker from Santiago, Chile, was already coming to terms with the probable fate of her movie, "ParAntesis" ("Time Off"): like most films of Latin provenance, it remained unlikely to find a distributor in the United States, no matter what the festival audience might think. "It is a small movie from a small country," said Ms. Schweitzer, 31, as she sat on a beach chair behind the National Hotel here. Nevertheless, "ParAntesis" is a slickly made tale of a Santiago relationship in crisis.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MILTON, ARTHUR
description: MILTON--Arthur. Died suddenly March 25. Born June 7, 1922 in New York City. Arthur loved his hometown and the U.S.A. He started his business career in 1945 and built an organization in every area of insurance and financial matters. Thousands benefited by his concepts, which strengthened their financial security. He was a consultant, writer of many books, advisor and friend to many. He created scholarships in memory of his beloved daughter, Patricia Ann, for the young or disabled so they would have an opportunity for a successful future. He cared. Survived by his wife, Phyllis; and his children, Donna Conte (Robert), Claudia Carman (Gary), Robert and Linda; grandchildren, Steven Conte (Karen), Lauren Alter (Peter), Pamela Tuchman (Bruce), Melissa Conte, Todd Conte (Elizabeth), Jennifer, Stephanie and Jonathan Carman; his great-grandchildren, Alex, Hunter, and Griffen; Alexa and Grant; Jordan and Dylan; his sister, Madaline Griffith and his brother, Jerome Lefkowitz. Services Wednesday, 11:45AM, at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to Guiding Eyes for the Blind, 611 Granite Springs Road, Yorktown Heights, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LISKOW, ARTHUR STANLEY, M.D.
description: LISKOW -- Arthur Stanley, M.D., 65. Of Tenafly, New Jersey, passed away Thursday, March 23. He was an Army Veteran of the Vietnam War. He was a radiation oncologist. He graduated from the University of Cincinnati Medical School, completing his medical training at NYU and Memorial Sloan - Kettering and was associated with Columbia Presbyterian before joining the private practice of Rosenbaum and Rosenfield. For the past ten years, he has been treating patients throughout the country. He is survived by his wife Karen and his two children, James and Amy. For info Barrett Funeral Home, Tenafly.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Minister Fatally Stabbed
description: A minister was found stabbed to death in his East Harlem apartment last night, the police said. The victim, the Rev. Philip Melvin Mann, 68, was found on the floor with a stab wound to his chest in his eighth-floor apartment, at the northeast corner of Central Park. No weapon was found and there was no sign of forced entry, the police said. He lived alone. Mr. Mann helped establish the Blessed Trinity Baptist Church on Malcolm X Boulevard almost 30 years ago, said Bill Perkins, a former member of the City Council and a longtime neighbor of the minister. Mr. Mann was honored recently at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture for his service to the community.

title: Memo Pad
description: A380 DEBUT -- Singapore Airlines plans to begin the first commercial service of the Airbus A380 in December, and will unveil its cabin design for the new superjumbo jet in September, according to Subhas Menon, the airline's vice president for the Americas. In an interview, Mr. Menon said that all 10 double-deck A380's that Singapore has ordered will be configured with about 475 seats in first class, business class and economy cabins. Most of the 12 other airlines that have ordered the jets -- none of them United States carriers -- have said they will fly their A380's with about 550 seats, though the plane can seat nearly 900 in an all-coach configuration. The first service will be on one of the airline's signature long-haul routes, Singapore to Sydney, Australia, with a London route to follow as more planes come into service, Mr. Menon said. In September, Singapore will unveil an A380 cabin design that stresses "convenience and comfort, as well as an enhanced ability to do some of the things people need to do on long-haul travel, like work, relax, sleep and get in shape," he said, adding, "We want to emphasize the space." The new business- and first-class seats will be introduced around the time British Airways is expected to announce details of a $170 million makeover of its own premium-class flat-bed seats. Singapore has not set a date for starting A380 service to and from the United States, but Mr. Menon said the carrier was looking more closely at using San Francisco International Airport, which has made the necessary modifications to accommodate the giant jet.

title: Adwaitya
description: Every now and then, the world marks the death of an exceptionally old human being, like Jeanne Calment, who died in 1997 at the age of 122. But today we pause to note the death of Adwaitya, an Aldabran tortoise who died last Wednesday at the Calcutta zoo. He is believed to have been about 250, nearly 80 years older than the next-oldest animal, a 176-year-old Galapagos tortoise living in Australia. We are ready simply to marvel at the fact of living to such a great age. But tortoise watchers of an earlier era were more likely to wonder why tortoises lived to such a great age.

Paid Notice: Deaths   KRENTS, IRMA (NEE KOPP)
description: KRENTS--Irma (nee Kopp), passed on peacefully at home on March 25th, at the age of 91. Adored wife of the late Milton Krents, cherished sister of Gertrude Wasserstrom, the late Evelyn Harris and the late Bernie Kopp, extraordinary mother to Larry Krents (Peggy), Babby Krents Zuckerwise (David), and the late Harold Krents (Kit), very beloved "MaMa" to Andrew Krents (Jennifer Belle), Karen Krents Neate (Will), Jamie Krents (Lisa), Willie Krents, Michael Krents, Randi Zuckerwise Madrid (Mark), Lena Zuckerwise, Laura Zuckerwise and new great-grandmother to Jasper Krents and Abigail Neate. Possessing great intellect, a special wisdom for life, a sharp wit, and tremendous warmth, Irma touched many lives. She was an award-winning scriptwriter, and she had an esteemed career in public relations and oral history. Her great faith, indomitable strength, and energy, together with her passionate and deep, self-less love for her family and others, enabled Irma to surmount many obstacles placed in her lovedones' way. Her Spirit and Love are everlasting. Funeral services Tuesday, 1 pm, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Donations may be made to The Calvary Hospital to the fund in memory of Harold Krents, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

Paid Notice: Deaths   HIGGINS, PATRICIA (NEE DE LA PENA)
description: HIGGINS--Patricia (nee de la Pena). Died in her Manhattan home after a long and courageous struggle with cancer on March 25, 2006 at age 79. She was born in Jersey City, NJ, lived in Valley Stream, LI, NY, until moving to CA where she married James J. Higgins, Esq., partner in Kirlin, Campbell and Keating, and returned to NY. She worked many years for Metro Creative Graphics, a nationwide advertising service in NYC. Widowed after 46 years of marriage, she is survived by her brother, Donald de la Pena, of CA, his wife, Carmel, his children, Michael de la Pena, Kimberly Taggart, and Christine Dunia and his four grandchildren living in CA and HI. Pat will also be missed by her dear friend Anne Cazeneuve, and her sister-in-law Mary E. Higgins, of Wilmington, DE, who were constantly with her in her last months; by several relatives in the NY-NJ area; and by many others who came to know her. An evening visitation will be at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday 7-9 P.M. A Mass will be celebrated at St. Jean Baptiste, Lexington Ave at 76 Street, Friday 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to: Jacob Perlow Hospice Home Visits, Continuum Care, 1775 Broadway, New York, New York 10019.
