title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article last Tuesday about "Wall to Wall Stravinsky," at Symphony Space, referred incorrectly to the original Chosen One in the ballet. It was not Nijinsky, who choreographed "The Rite of Spring"; the role was first performed by Maria Piltz.

title: Old-Timer's Advice to Today's Pitchers: Throw
description: FRANK NAVIN taught Elden Auker a simple lesson when Auker was a 22-year-old rookie with the Detroit Tigers.

title: Profit Rises at Walgreen Despite Fall in Drug Sales
description: The Walgreen Company, the biggest drugstore chain in the country, said yesterday its quarterly profit rose 6.6 percent as higher holiday sales outweighed a decline in demand for medicines during a mild flu season.

title: Preservationists Visit Hemingway's Cuba
description: Ernest Hemingway's 40-footblack-hulled fishing boat, the Pilar,will be getting the once-overfrom Dana Hewson, the vice presidentfor watercraft preservation atMystic Seaport in Connecticut, TheAssociated Press reported. Mr. Hewsonand members of the HemingwayPreservation Foundation have goneto Cuba, where he will examine andphotograph the boat at La FincaVigia, Hemingway's estate.

title: Prosecutors of 2 Ex-Enron Officials Could Rest Case Today
description: HOUSTON, March 27 - Defense lawyers sought on Monday to undercut testimony by Enron's former treasurer, Ben F. Glisan Jr., that he warned Kenneth L. Lay that Enron was running low on cash shortly before Mr. Lay told investors the company was financially healthy.

title: Mayor Offers Plan to Ease Traffic Congestion on Staten Island
description: With the population of their borough the fastest-growing in the city, Staten Islanders have persistently complained that a single problem -- traffic -- is harming the quality of life in a place that has experienced booming growth ever since the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge opened in 1964.

title: Enemy of Our Enemy
description: Washington - BUSH administration defenders, right-wing bloggers and neoconservative publications are crowing about Iraqi documents newly released by the Pentagon that, they say, prove that Al Qaeda and Saddam Hussein were in league.

title: Japan considers allowing military a role in space
The Presidential Suite Mystique
description: Morris Silver, a public relations executive, was remembering the day he tried to get a room at a Los Angeles hotel and was told it was full. "So they put me in the presidential suite."

title: As Prices Rise, Loyalty Follows the Lowest Fare
description: IN the domestic airline business, less bad news is good news these days.

title: Charges Expected Against Driver in Andes Bus Crash; Funeral Services Held for Several Victims
description: TRENTON, March 27 - The driver of the bus that crashed in the Andes last week, killing 12 tourists from New Jersey and Connecticut and injuring two others, is likely to be charged with involuntary manslaughter this week, according to prosecutors in Chile.

title: The Nets Let Two Nights Of Brilliance Say It All
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 27 - All season, the Nets have shied away from praising themselves. They have been tight-lipped about their accomplishments, saying only that they needed to continue to improve. Perhaps they were championing the role of the underdog.

title: After Vote, Ukraine Faces Uncertainty Over Coalition
description: KIEV, Ukraine, March 27 - Ukraine was in political gridlock on Monday as the parties that led in parliamentary elections jockeyed for advantage to appoint a newly empowered prime minister and government under President Viktor A. Yushchenko.

title: Europe and U.S. Consider Sanctions Against Officials in Belarus
description: MOSCOW, March 28 A The European Union and the United States are considering personal sanctions against more than 40 officials and state journalists in Belarus for their roles in election rigging and crackdowns on civil society there, according to Western diplomats and government officials.

title: Markets fear new finance minister in Brazil
N.F.L. in No Hurry to Name Commissioner
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., March 27 - The N.F.L. took its first steps toward finding a new commissioner Monday, but the search could take most of the off-season.

title: After 5 Terms as Newark Mayor, James Opts Not to Run Again
description: NEWARK, March 27 - Mayor Sharpe James entered his sixth race for mayor 11 days ago with the flourish of a Las Vegas heavyweight, arriving at City Hall astride a police bicycle to deliver his petitions in gym shorts. He dropped out on Monday, with a letter delivered to the city clerk only minutes before the ballots were to be sent to the printer.

title: An Upstate Congressman Faces a Rematch in the Fall Election
description: In 2004, Representative Thomas M. Reynolds guided Republicans to significant gains in the House of Representatives while surviving a challenge in his home district, which links the suburbs of Buffalo and Rochester.

title: French Youth at the Barricades, But a Revolution? It Can Wait
description: AVIGNON, France, March 25 - Adrien Reynaud is a revolutionary, but only part time.

title: Crash Being Investigated; Life Goes On for I.R.L.
description: Still resolute that they made the correct decision to race Sunday only hours after the death of the rookie driver Paul Dana, Indy Racing League officials and participants prepared yesterday for a testing session today at the same speedway in Florida.

title: The Whopper That Wasn't
description: LAST week, an angler from Carlsbad, Calif., named Mac Weakley was fishing on Dixon Lake, a reservoir near San Diego, when he landed a largemouth bass that weighed 25 pounds 1 ounce. The fish, if certified by the International Game Fish Association, would topple the current world record: a 22-pound, 4-ounce bass caught by George Washington Perry in 1932.

title: With Every Epidemic, Tough Choices
description: To warn. Or not to warn.

title: G.M. to Lay Off Several Hundred Employees
description: DETROIT, March 28 A General Motors laid off several hundred white-collar workers on Tuesday, the latest piece of a restructuring plan that is making deep cuts in all ranks of the company.

title: From the Chickens' Perspective, the Sky Really Is Falling
description: The A(H5N1) influenza strain circulating the globe now may never seriously threaten humans, but for another subset of the earth's living creatures, it is already a disaster.

title: People: Jet Li, Kevin Spacey, Scarlett Johansson
A Close Reading
description: A Close Reading

title: Roundup: Italy decides to bid for Games in 2016
News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9:30 P.M. (NBC) TEACHERS -- Series premiere. Fifty years after Eve Arden made Miss Brooks the country's favorite English teacher (and an inspiration to women who worked before it was the thing to do), Justin Bartha brings wisecracking manliness to the undisciplined classrooms of Filmore High. Gone are simple vices like rudeness and rowdiness. Here are apathetic colleagues, antiquated rules, students more interested in text-messaging and video games, and of course rampant A.D.D. Oh dear, what would Mr. Conklin think?

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Lottery Giant Seeks to Buy Sports Betting Shops
description: Tattersall's, Australia's largest lottery operator, offered to buy Unitab, an Australian chain of sports betting shops, for 1.9 billion Australian dollars ($1.3 billion) in stock. Shares of Unitab surged 13 percent, to 15.71 Australian dollars, as investors anticipated a higher bid. Tattersall's shares gained 7.2 percent, to 3.29 Australian dollars. The new company would own 13,750 slot machines and 1,150 off-track betting shops and would operate lotteries in Australia, South Africa and Pacific island nations.

title: National Opera Molds Wagner's 'Ring' to Fit American Myths
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 - If you put on a production of Wagner's monumental "Ring" cycle, you'd better have a novel concept. That's accepted wisdom in the opera world. We have had industrial age "Rings," an environmentally green "Ring," and several cosmic "Rings" with mystical lighting and abstract scenery.

title: Shiite Leaders Suspend Talks Over Government
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 27 - Frayed relations between Iraq's Shiite leadership and the American authorities came under increased strain on Monday as Shiite leaders angrily denounced a joint American-Iraqi raid on a Shiite compound and suspended negotiations over a new government.

title: At the U.N.: This Virus Has an Expert 'Quite Scared'
description: Dr. David Nabarro, chief avian flu coordinator for the United Nations, has become gun-shy about making predictions A in particular about if and when the A(H5N1) virus, now devastating bird populations around the world, will do the same to humans.

title: Ex-Detective Took Payoff, 'Errand Man' Says on Stand
description: In Elizabethan dramas, the cast of characters is wildly diverse, ranging from the noble lords and kings to the lowly fools and scullery maids.

title: At the U.N.: This Virus Has an Expert 'Quite Scared'
description: Dr. David Nabarro, chief avian flu coordinator for the United Nations, has become gun-shy about making predictions -- in particular about if and when the A(H5N1) virus, now devastating bird populations around the world, will do the same to humans.

title: Is It Time to Say Enough in Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefing: Bank of England chief calls situation 'benign'
Afghan Convert to Christianity Is Released, Officials Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Tuesday, March 28 - The justice minister announced Tuesday that a jailed Afghan man who faced the death penalty for converting to Christianity has been released.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A KPMG Partner Pleads Guilty in Tax Case And Will Cooperate in Investigation of Others David Rivkin, a partner at KPMG, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy and tax evasion in a case involving questionable tax shelters and agreed to cooperate with the government -- a development that might help federal prosecutors build a case against 16 remaining defendants and other companies that worked with KPMG to sell the shelters. [Page C1.]

title: Caspar W. Weinberger Dies at 88
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, who held high positions under three Republican Presidents and oversaw the biggest and costliest military buildup in peacetime history as Ronald Reagan's secretary of defense, died yesterday in Bangor, Me., after a brief illness. He was 88.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: 7 Inmates Die In Prison Riot
description: Seven inmates were killed and at least 17 more injured when inmates and the police clashed in a prison uprising in Tbilisi, the capital. Special forces units moved into the prison after inmates rioted, set parts of the prison on fire and refused to negotiate, according to regional news reports. The officers used batons and gunfire to regain control. Georgian officials accused prison mafia gangs of planning an uprising that would have led to the escape of many of the country's most dangerous criminals, and said the force was necessary. The opposition accused the government of slaughter. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: Two people killed in explosion in southern Israel
Letter from Paris: 4 simple rules for firing an employee in France
Our Trade With China
description: To the Editor:

title: Court puts supervisors in charge of Yukos
Retirees on 2 Drug Plans Must Make Choice
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 - The Bush administration notified hundreds of thousands of Medicare beneficiaries on Monday that they were listed on the rolls of two prescription drug plans and would soon be dropped from one. They will retain coverage under the other plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGBERG, JAN
description: ENGBERG--Jan. He lost his battle with heart disease on March 8 surrounded by family and friends. He is survived by his wife Marianne, son Ian, grandchildren Dean, Joshua & Mia. A tirelessly productive artistic and generous individual, he personified integrity in both his life and his work. Knowing Jan enriched the lives of all who knew him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HALPERN, JOEL
description: HALPERN - Joel. Twenty five years since your tragic fatal accident. Dad is by your side, as he chose to be. We all miss you and love you. Mother and Family

title: A Chance Find, and Voil! Goodbye, Hot Flashes. Hello, Sleep.
description: A widely used drug that has been mired in controversy for most of its decade-long life may now bring relief to postmenopausal women whose lives have been disrupted by unrelenting hot flashes. The relief may be especially welcome to women who have had breast cancer and cannot take estrogen.

title: Curb on Access to News in Prison Gets Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 - Pennsylvania went before the Supreme Court on Monday to defend its policy of denying most newspapers, magazines and photographs to its most incorrigible prison inmates against claims that the restriction violates the First Amendment. The policy is one of the most restrictive in the country.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,316 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 27, 2006

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAWEELI, DAVID
description: HAWEELI--David, 85. Of Greenwich, CT. and Sanibel, FL., passed away on March 24, 2006. He was born in Berlin, NH on April 18, 1920, the youngest of five children. David graduated from Mt. Hermon School in 1938, and from Brown University in 1942, where he played varsity football and formed friendships that lasted over six decades. He served as a gunnery officer in the U.S. Navy from September 1942 through April 1946 aboard the USS West Virginia, and was recalled to service in 1951 in the Korean War as an officer aboard the USS Des Moines. David served in a number of managerial and executive positions in his businss career, based both in the United States and Europe, with the Campbell Soup Company, International Basic Economy Corporation, Federated Department Stores, and Gulf + Western Industries, and was a director of Supermarkets Italiani for over 20 years. He is survived by his beloved wife of over 60 years, the former Henrietta Brooks Burbank, his daughter Ellen of Old Greenwich, CT, his son John of New York, NY, and his nephew Stephen of East Hampton, NY. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT Friday, March 31 at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the David Haweeli '42 Memorial Scholarship Fund being established at the Brown Sports Foundation, Brown University, Box 1925, Providence, R.I. 02912.

title: Brazil's Finance Minister Quits Amid Continuing Political Scandal
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 27 - Facing a long and politically damaging impeachment trial, Finance Minister Antonio Palocci of Brazil resigned Monday, the latest victim of the corruption scandal that has debilitated President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva and his government for nearly a year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Sentenced For Two Rapes
description: A Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison for raping a girl in Elmhurst in December 2003 and another girl in Woodside in October 2005, prosecutors said. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said the man, Jofre Bautista, 34, attacked the girls, 13 and 15, while they were walking home. Both were pulled into a vehicle and attacked at knifepoint. Mr. Bautista was charged with the 2003 attack on the basis of a DNA match.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Correction Officer Charged
description: A city correction officer was arrested yesterday and charged with disabling a video surveillance system to prevent it from capturing an assault on an inmate, said Rose Gill Hearn, the commissioner of the Department of Investigation. The officer, Nicholas Zito, 33, of Staten Island, was charged with official misconduct, a misdemeanor, she said. Ms. Gill Hearn said that Mr. Zito ran into the control room at the Anna M. Kross Center on Rikers Island on Oct. 5 while prosecutors say an inmate was being assaulted. She said the surveillance equipment stopped working just after he ran into the room. Previously, a correction officer was charged with assault, and a captain was also charged in connection with the incident. Both have pleaded not guilty. A call to Officer Zito's lawyer was not returned last evening.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Testers Slip Radioactive Materials Over Borders
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 - Undercover Congressional investigators successfully smuggled into the United States enough radioactive material to make two dirty bombs, even after it set off alarms on radiation detectors installed at border checkpoints, a new report says.

title: 'Trial by Water,' a Play of Vietnam's Immigrants
description: Stories of parents who send their children to a faraway paradise -- call it the immigrant's dream version of America -- are everlasting, the hardships endured becoming the stuff of family legends. But some journeys make headlines, as did the one on which Qui Nguyen has partly based his new drama, "Trial by Water," which opened on Sunday at the Culture Project in the East Village.

title: Office workers targeted in Baghdad kidnappings
Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDNET, ERNEST
description: RUDNET--Ernest, 65, of Tamarac, Florida. Passed on peacefully March 24, 2006. Devoted husband to Florie for 42+ years, beloved father to his children David, Colleen, Vance, Laurie, Brian and grandchildren Tyler and Ryan. Devoted brother to Gerald and deceased brothers Arthur and Irwin. Longtime associate of Goldman Sachs, partner of L.F. Rothschild and other prestigious Wall Street brokerage firms. Active member of A.H.R.C. of Nassau County, U.C.P.A. of Nassau County, and JAFCO of Sunrise, FL. His loving memory will be missed by all whose lives he touched.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: End Of The Line For U.N. Rights Commission
description: The much-criticized Human Rights Commission held its final meeting in Geneva, to be replaced in June by a new Human Rights Council approved by the General Assembly. The commission was faulted for allowing notorious rights abusers like Sudan and Zimbabwe to be members, and advocates of the new council believe its stricter admission standards will keep such countries off. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

title: Opening in London: Plenty of song, dance and spectacle
Paid Notice: Deaths   KEARNS, PATRICIA ANNE
description: KEARNS--Patricia Anne. The Boys Scouts of America, Greater New York Councils, acknowledge the passing of Patricia Anne Kearns, and extends its sincere sympathy to her family and friends. Our thoughts and prayers are with all of her loved ones, particularly her husband, William M. Kearns, Jr., a long-time friend, supporter, and Vice President of our Board of Directors. John F. McGillicuddy, President John C. Whitehead, Chairman Charles E. Rosser, Chief Executive Officer

title: Voters in Israel support parties vowing pullout
In Disgrace, and Facing Death
description: KHANPUR, Pakistan - Aisha Parveen will live another day. Indeed, at least another week.

title: For the Birds
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Google Joins Lobbying Herd
description: For years, Google has all but ignored Washington and its machinations. But the companys age of political innocence is clearly over.

title: Taking Blood Money from Sudan
description: Ive finally had a chance to look at the infamous Sudanese advertising insert published in The New York Times on March 20. Its an eight-page tribute to the Sudanese government, beginning with a cheery lead story, The Peace Dividend: Prosperity could lie ahead after years of conflict. It also shows a picture of what is supposed to be a sunrise on the Nile (although I think I recognize the scene, and if so its facing west and must be a sunset  a more apt metaphor).

title: Will This Man Regulate Hedge Funds?
description: Hedge funds, those traditionally publicity-shy investment pools, are already smarting over recent rule changes that forced them to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission. (In fact, a large minority of them have avoided registering by using loopholes in the new rules.)

title: Will Viacom Find Itself in the Facebook?
description: Facebook, the Web site where students around the world socialize and swap information, has put itself on the block, BusinessWeek reported in its online edition. The owners of the privately held company have turned down a $750 million offer and hope to fetch as much as $2 billion in a sale.

title: Bidders Eying Federated Stores
description: Target is eyeing locations put on the market by Federated Department Stores Inc. The Minneapolis-based discounter joins other retailers in the bidding for Federated stores, notably Nordstrom which has recently purchased seven Federated properties.

title: Former Morgan Stanley Exec at War With Investment Bank
description: Arthur Riel, a former Morgan Stanley technology executive at war with the firm over an alleged improper dismissal from his $500,000 a year job, has produced what he claims are smoking gun e-mails laying out proof of the Wall Street companys maneuvering.

title: McClatchy Sale Attracts Would-Be Press Barons
description: McClatchy Co.s recent announcement that it planned to sell the Herald and 11 other Knight Ridder Inc. newspapers as part of its $4.5-billion acquisition of the San Jose-based chain has led to a burst of interest by local businesspeople and groups in buying several of the publications.

title: Wall Street Bonuses May Be Big, But Theyre Fine-Tuned
description: After several years of working in the shadow of traders and fixed-income professionals, investment bankers in the U.S. are finally getting some respect. Bolstered by a sparkling year in M&A, which logged its highest volume since 2000, Wall Street firms boosted the compensation they paid to investment bankers by some 20 percent in 2005.

title: KKR Ready to Put Sealy IPO to Bed
description: Mattress maker Sealy set an expected price range of $14 to $16 a share for a planned initial public offering that would yield its controlling shareholder, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, about a 140 percent gain on its $436 million equity investment.

title: Can Jones Apparel Get the Deal Done?
description: When the Jones Apparel Group became the latest clothing manufacturer to put itself up for sale last week, some industry executives and investment bankers were left scratching their heads.

title: Lucent Talks Raise Issue of Security
description: As merger talks between Lucent and Alcatel continue to advance, attention is turning to the role Lucents fast-growing work for military and intelligence agencies may play in securing government approval for the trans-Atlantic deal.

title: Potential Deal for U.K. Ports Operator May Draw U.S. Scrutiny
description: If a Singapore-backed financial consortium proceeds with plans to buy Britains largest ports operator, Associated British Ports Holdings plc, the deal will most certainly draw scrutiny from Washington regulators and politicians due to the targets assets on both U.S. coasts.

title: Suez Battles for Deal on Two Fronts
description: In a fierce round of maneuvering to defend its deal with state-owned Gaz de France, the French utility Suez came out forcefully Monday against Belgian demands for sales of assets and then challenged European authorities to do something about an Italian law that prevents a takeover of its rival Enel.

title: Equity One Sells Property Stake to Investcorp
description: Equity One agreed to sell a controlling stake in 30 properties to private equity company Investcorp in a deal that will raise $327 million for the real estate investment trust.

title: Anheuser-Busch Eyes Indias Brew
description: The nations largest brewer has its eyes on the worlds second-largest country. Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. is engaged in talks with mid-sized breweries in India, according to a report published this week in Indias Economic Times newspaper.

title: Ex-Raytheon Chief Agrees to Fine and Forfeit of Part of Bonus
description: The former chief executive of the Raytheon Corporation, Daniel P. Burnham, has agreed to pay a fine and return part of a $1.75 million bonus to settle Securities and Exchange Commission accusations over improper accounting practices in 2000 and 2001.

title: Linden Lab Gets Second Round for Second Life
description: Linden Lab, the publisher of the popular virtual world Second Life, announced Tuesday an $11 million round of funding led by Globespan Capital Partners.

title: Bank of America Unit Prices Offering
description: Bank of America Corp.s MBNA America Bank has priced an offering of $750 million in asset-backed notes from the MBNA Credit Card Master Note Trust. The offering, slated to close Thursday, was lead managed by Banc of America Securities and co-managed by ABN AMRO Inc., Citigroup and RBS Greenwich Capital.

title: Canadas Stelco Wraps Up Restructuring Plan
description: Stelco said Monday it had wrapped up all the agreements that go along with its restructuring plan, including multiple loan documents and a pension deal with the Ontario government.

title: StreamCast Sues Kazaa and Skype
description: StreamCast Networks, creator of the Morpheus file-swapping software, has filed a lawsuit naming Kazaa and Skype Technologies, among others, as defendants. The suit, filed in United States District Court in the Central District of California, claims that StreamCast owns the technology underlying Internet-calling provider Skypes software.

title: After the Bust Comes the Real Challenge
description: Battered and bankrupt alike, take heart: The dot-com crash did more than cull the investor herd; it set in motion the next great wave of innovation. But now things will only move fasterand competition will only get hotter.

title: Moscow to Hear Yukos Bankruptcy Suit
description: The Moscow Arbitration Court was scheduled to hear a bankruptcy suit by a consortium of Western banks against Yukos on Tuesday. The creditor banks called for the company to be declared bankrupt because it defaulted on a US$1 billion syndicated loan that had been arranged three years ago by Societe Generale jointly with Deutsche Bank, Citigroup and HSBC.

title: Temasek Buys $4 Billion Stake in Britains Standard Chartered
description: Temasek Holdings Pte, Singapores state-owned investment company, agreed to buy a 12 percent stake in Standard Chartered Plc valued at about $4 billion, making it the biggest shareholder in the British lender.

title: Mercantile Bankshares Buys James Monore
description: Baltimore-based regional bank Mercantile Bankshares agreed to acquire James Monroe Bancorp for about $142.9 million in stock and cash.

title: Regulators to Stay Out of Internet Politics
description: Regulators brought Internet political advertising under the nations campaign finance law Monday but declared that all other political activity on the Internet would be untethered by federal rules.

title: Prosecutors of 2 Ex-Enron Officials Could Rest Case Today
description: Defense lawyers sought on Monday to undercut testimony by Enrons former treasurer, Ben F. Glisan Jr., that he warned Kenneth L. Lay that Enron was running low on cash shortly before Mr. Lay told investors the company was financially healthy. The defenses maneuvering came as prosecutors prepared to wrap up their case as early as today.

title: Zurich American to Pay $153 Million to Settle Bid-Rigging Case
description: The Zurich American Insurance Company said Monday that it would pay $153 million in restitution and penalties to settle accusations of bid rigging made by officials in New York, Connecticut and Illinois.

title: LaSalle Capital Gets Creative With Environmental Lighting
description: LaSalle Capital Group LP has bought a controlling stake of Environmental Lighting Concepts Inc., which makes bulbs and fixtures that simulate natural light, from Parallel Investment Partners. The secondary buyout, which closed Friday, values Tampa, Fla.-based Environmental Lighting at less than $50 million, which is typical of LaSalle Capital investments.

title: British Retailer to Spin Off Divisions
description: GUS Plc said it will separate its Argos retail unit and the Experian credit-checking division with independent listings on the London Stock Exchange. The process will take six to 12 months, GUS said today in a statement. London-based GUS has already spun off the Burberry Group Plc luxury-goods company.

title: Hollywood Wiretapping Case May Threaten Law Firms
description: Indictments stemming from Hollywoods latest celebrity scandal have struck fear into Los Angeles legal community. But its the civil fallout from private eye Anthony Pellicanos wiretapping indictment that instills true horror for law firms. While top entertainment lawyer Terry Christensen is the only attorney indicted so far in connection with Pellicano, several others face litigation that could cripple their practices  and possibly break up their firms.

title: G.M.s Jobs Bank Looms as Major Obstacle on Road to Survival
description: General Motors Jobs Bank, which pays idled workers a full salary and benefits even when there is no work for them to do, is one critical burden that G.M. has to carry as it embarks on one of the biggest challenges  and biggest balancing acts  of its corporate survival.

title: Surprise in Tax Case on KPMG
description: The governments criminal case against 17 former KPMG employees over sales of questionable tax shelters took an unexpected turn yesterday when one of them, David Rivkin, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy and tax evasion.

title: Early Google Backer Dials up Deal for Internet Phone Start-Up
description: Highly regarded venture capital firm Sequoia Capital, an early backer of Internet darlings Google and Yahoo, has pumped more than $2 million into a new Web-based phone company that claims to make cheap Internet calls as easy as surfing the Web. The new start-up, called Jajah, allows customers to use their existing landlines and cellphones to make cheap calls over the Web without having to install software or use microphones and other devices.

title: Allurent Reels In Polaris Investment
description: Allurent Inc., a maker of Internet applications for commerce Web sites, has received its first round of venture capital funding from Polaris Venture Partners, the company said on Monday. Cambridge, Mass.-based Allurent, which launched earlier this year, would not disclose the amount of the funding.

title: In Angel Investing, a Sisterhood Is Emerging
description: Angel investing has long been a boys club. Women today make up only 7.5 percent of the countrys 225,000 angels  individual investors who take equity stakes in start-ups. The good news is that women angels  who control a significant chunk of the $22 billion invested by angels each year  are more likely to bet on other women. And the Women angels across the country are increasingly starting investment groups to educate wealthy women on the fine points of dealmaking.

title: Medical Temp Firm Files for I.P.O.
description: CHG Healthcare Services Inc. registered Monday for an initial public offering of up to $115 million in common stock, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Salt Lake City company provides services in temporary staffing and permanent placement of physicians, nurses and other health care professionals.

title: TA Associates Feasts On Ready Cash
description: TA Associates Ltd. has closed its tenth buyout fund at its $3.5 billion cap, after seeing over $8 billion in interest. The firm also closed on TA Subordinated Debt Fund II LP, or TA SDF II, a $777.5 million capital subordinated debt fund.

title: Arch Rock Anchored by Intel Funds
description: Arch Rock, a start-up with roots at Intel Labs and the University of California, Berkeley, on Monday announced funding and described its plans to sell software for wireless sensor networks. The San Francisco-based company secured $5 million in initial funding from Intels venture investment arm, New Venture Associates, and Sashta Ventures.

title: French Construction Company to Raise $3.2 Billion to Fund Purchase
description: Vinci SA, the worlds biggest construction company, aims to raise as much as 2.68 billion euros ($3.2 billion) by selling shares to fund its purchase of Autoroutes du Sud de la France SA, Frances largest toll-road network

title: Himax Tech Preps for I.P.O.
description: Taiwan semiconductor maker Himax Technologies Inc. plans to raise about $430 million in its initial public offering on the Nasdaq this week Himax Technologies will offer 52 million American depositary shares at an expected price of $7.50 to $9 each, via underwriters Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse.

title: Murdoch Signs Up for Clintons Power Schmooze Fest
description: The incongruous Murdoch-Clinton romance, which has been hot for the past year or so, shows no sign of cooling down. Now, Rupert is greatly expanding his involvement with Bills big Clinton Global Initiatives annual powwow this September, shortly before Hillarys up for reelection, according to New York Magazine

title: New Breed of Trading Networks Threatens Exchange Giants
description: As exchange consolidation threatens to inflate trading costs, another breed of trading networks is popping up to challenge the big boys, and their early success suggests that pricing power in the stock trading business is a thing of the past.

title: J.P. Morgan to Increase India Staff
description: J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. Chief Executive Jamie Dimon said Monday that the Wall Street bank would hire another 4,000 staff in India this year, taking its total there to about 9,000. Dimon said the bank was increasing its presence elsewhere in Asia, with plans to hire 750 people in the Philippines this year and actively looking for acquisitions in China.

title: Mentor Unloads Urology Unit
description: Mentor made good on its promise to sell its urology-products business, announcing a deal Monday with the Danish medical-device company Coloplast for $463 million. Mentor has been seeking a buyer for the business since October.

title: Citigroup Said to Be Poised for Turkish Bank Bid
description: Citigroup is expected to submit a cash bid to acquire some or all of Finansbank, Turkeys eighth-largest bank by assets, in a transaction that could be valued at $5 billion or more, according to The Wall Street Journal. Citigroup and the National Bank of Greece are the final two bidders.

title: S.E.C. Subpoenas Gradient for Communications With Reporters
description: A March 10 S.E.C. subpoena to Gradient Analytics demanded the research shop provide records of all e-mail and phone contacts Gradient has had with approximately eight financial reporters, including journalists from Fortune, Forbes, The Wall Street Journal, and The New York Post.

title: NYT Roundup
description: From this mornings paper, here is the article on the decision by Sharpe James to step aside and the legacy he leaves behind. The Web site has posted a of pictures from his 36-year career in Newark politics. And Josh Benson takes a look at the campaign between now and the May 9 election.

title: How History Will Judge the Iraq War
Onward to Plan B
description: Today marks the beginning of the end of the Sharpe James era. The next mayor will take over July 1, which gives Mr. James only 95 more days to secure his legacy, line up jobs for his loyal hires at City Hall, and possibly throw a metaphorical wrench or two into the works if his nemesis Cory Booker ends up winning the May 9 election.

title: Burger King Explains Pre-I.P.O. Payments
description: Burger King has tweaked the registration for its initial public offering, and version No. 2 has some interesting additions.

title: Is Jamba Juice Deal Getting Frothy?
description: The prospect of swallowing smoothie chain Jamba Juice has pushed shares of Services Acquisition Corporation International to an all-time high this week. But TheStreet.coms Matthew Goldstein argues that investors who place bets on privately held Jamba Juice are relying on stale financial data  and could be paying top dollar.

title: A Common Bond
description: Take a look at this list of the Google keyword advertising rates compiled on the CyberWyre blog thats making the rounds in the blogosphere. Youll see two subjects dominate the list: trial lawyers seeking clients and mortgage brokers. (The amounts are in Canadian dollars.)

title: Whereabouts
description: Selborne Journal: 28 March 1759:  Put the male-bloom to three of the first fruit-Cucumber-blossoms, that were just turning-in, in order to set them. Sowed three pots more of Millers, & three pots of Waverley-Cantaleupes, two seeds in a pot; to supply the hills in Case of any failure. Millers marked as usual with sticks. Plunged the pots in one of the Cantaleupe-boxes.

title: A Plea for Openness from Political Bloggers
description: The Federal Election Commission ruled Monday, in a unanimous vote, that paid political advertisements are the only form of political activity on the Internet subject to federal campaign finance laws. As Adam Nagourney of The New York Times reports, the decision provides a broad exemption for all other Internet political activity, conducted by individuals or groups, even in direct coordination with a candidate. In an interview with Nagourney, F.E.C. chairman Michael Toner said, The commission established a categorical exemption for individuals who engage in online politics.

title: Apple C.E.O. Jobs Pays His Taxes  With Apple Stock
description: Normally, Steve Jobs every move is the subject of obsessive analysis by technology watchers. But it took nearly a week for much of the world to notice that Mr. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple Computer, had unloaded Apple shares worth $296 million, or more than half of his stake in the computer maker. (Perhaps the tech crowd was too distracted by the news last week that Google would be inducted into the Standard & Poors 500 index.)

title: Broadcom Workers Score Seats From Ducks Connection
description: We hope there are plenty of hockey fans working at Irvine, Calif.-based Broadcom. Thanks to Footnoted.org, we learned that the chip maker scored about 10,000 free tickets to selected games of the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim  which, as it happens, are owned by Broadcom co-founder and chairman Henry Samueli.

title: Wasting No Time
description: Deputy Mayor Ronald L. Rice, who is leaving his current job at City Hall at the end of the month, appears to be picking up the campaign where Sharpe James left off.

title: After Flip-Flop, Cablevision Moves Toward $3 Billion Dividend
description: It was proposed in October, withdrawn in December and put back on the table earlier this month. Now, Cablevision Systems controversial $3 billion dividend is a step closer to becoming reality.

title: Two Guys Hit the Road
description: Au Pied de Cochon in Montreal, Quebec. (Christinne Muschi/ The New York Times).

title: Reader Mail
description: On my columns on Aisha Parveen, a number of readers were frustrated by my lack of specific suggestions for how to address the problem. Lisa from Oakland writes: You did not mention to whom to write letters, etc. Ie, how can the average person do anything about this?

title: An Update on Aisha Parveen
description: I just had an update on Aisha Parveen. Shes really frightened, because in the last few days thereve been several new attempts to kidnap her. There had been one previous attempt, by her brothel-owners lawyer of all people. But in the last few days, thugs have made a concerted effort to find her and kidnap her. Presumably the idea is that then theyll kill her and shell stop embarrassing everybody by telling the truth.

title: Ann Currys Blog
description: This is revoltingly immodest, but Ann Curry of NBC wrote a lovely blog item about traveling with me.

title: Rice Gets Real
description: (Marko Georgiev for The New York Times)

title: Civil War or Sectarian Violence?
description: With the term civil war increasingly coming up in coverage of Iraq, Joe Cutbirth, of New York, asked how The Times defines civil war and sectarian violence. I passed his message to the newsroom, and asked to have someone respond. Here is the readers message, and the deputy foreign editors response:

title: Rack and Roll
description: Sascha Lyon at the bar of his eponymous restaurant.(Shannon Greer for The New York Times)

title: The SoHo Synagogue
description: Rabbi Dovi and Esty Scheiner have established a new  synagogue in SoHo that targets downtown hipsters. (Producer: Shayla Harris)

title: The Best Kind of Tax
description: In my previous post, I tried to show that the magnitude of growth in government spending already in the pipeline is so great that it cannot be contained just by cutting. Those who think otherwise usually fall into two camps: utopians who think Congress will someday slash programs like Medicare, even though tens of millions of voters depend on them, and those who dont know the nature of federal spending.

title: General Motors Cautions on a GMAC Sale
description: As potential buyers continue to kick the tires at General Motors financing arm, the company said Tuesday that recently discovered accounting errors would force it to restate financial results at that unit as far back as 2003. It also warned that a sale of the unit may never happen.

title: The Other Rice on the Ballot
description: Generational change is one thing. The council race in Newarks West Ward is quite another.

title: Culture and Patrimony: Who Owns Art?
description: The Times's Michael Kimmelman and Randy Kennedy discuss antiquities following the Metropolitan Museums' decision to return the Euphronios krater to Italy. (Producer: Brent McDonald)

title: Theater: The Abbey as a mirror to Ireland
'Tiger by the Tail' Portrays a Therapist Who Tries to Help a Convict
description: If the personal ad says "incarcerated," don't answer it. Jerry, a protagonist of Frawley Becker's new play "Tiger by the Tail," knows this -- he's a therapist, for goodness' sake -- and yet he falls anyway and writes to Maynard in prison. In short, he does the expected thing, setting the tone for a capable but overlong play that traffics largely in what one might call nuanced stereotypes: the liberal California therapist on one end of the equation; the convict dealing with injustice in a Florida pen on the other.

title: Judges on Secretive Panel Speak Out on Spy Program
description: Correction Appended

title: New Directors/New Films Festival Reviews; Into Great Silence
description: The 35th annual New Directors/New Films festival continues its cinematic world tour with selections from such ports of call as Ireland, Russia, the Netherlands and Texas. Today and tomorrow you can also catch encore screenings of "Eleven Men Out," "John & Jane Toll-Free," "Old Joy" and "Iron Island," along with almost half a dozen documentaries that were shown in past festivals. For further information about all these titles and for ticket availability: www.filmlinc.com.

title: The Power of Big Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Dubai turns focus to airports - Properties - International Herald Tribune
Snowboarders Take on Rock Star Status
description: Alan Watts has been reintroduced to Led Zeppelin, courtesy of his son Ben, a spindly 12-year-old who is a budding talent in the snowboarding world. When Ben takes a break from his 30-hour practice week and touring schedule that recently included stops in Switzerland and Stratton Mountain, Vt., he retires to his room in Bend, Ore., to strum a few Jimmy Page chords. Lately, Ben has been playing a Gibson Les Paul purchased with a sponsorship check handed out by Burton Snowboards after he won a competition in January.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on March 20 about the Bush administration's defense of its Iraq strategy misstated the magnitude of antiwar protests held in cities around the country on the weekend of March 18-19, the third anniversary of the American-led invasion. They were not all relatively small: while some 7,000 people demonstrated in Chicago on March 18 and smaller protests were held in other cities, a larger demonstration took place in Portland, Ore., on March 19, and organizers estimated that at least 10,000 people took part.

title: Follow the money, and it leads to sports
Paris and iPod: Who's crazy?
The Basque Spring
description: Zalduondo, Spain - THE story that began when a group of university students founded Basque Homeland and Liberty, the organization known as ETA, has finally come to an end with its announcement last week of a permanent cease-fire. If a satellite could detect surges of relief and happiness rather than clouds or storm systems, then the entire southwestern part of Europe would appear on every television screen, and the weatherman of the hour would describe "a sudden reduction in the force of gravity in the region of the Pyrenees," along with breezes and winds that can cure any melancholy.

title: The Memo About the Road to War
description: To the Editor:

title: Bluetooth technology to get a power boost
Tar Heels and Latta Keep Vols Under Foot
description: CLEVELAND, March 28 - When North Carolina and Tennessee met Tuesday night in the N.C.A.A. women's basketball tournament, the matchup was so intriguing and the teams so successful that the game had the aura of a national championship rather than the regional final it was.

title: And Yet, Petra, We Will Keep Asking
description: And Yet, Petra, We Will Keep On Asking

title: The Tastes of Bosnia Follow Those Who Fled
description: IN the last few years Bosnian products have quietly begun taking their place on the shelves of New York's ethnic groceries.

title: It Isn't Amnesty
description: Here's one way to kill a cow: take it into the woods in hunting season, paint the word "deer" on it and stand back.

title: Justices Hint That They'll Rule on Challenge Filed by Detainee
description: Correction Appended

title: Red Bulls Energetic on Making Moves
description: The synergy drink was stacked high in a tub of ice, there for the taking as the New York Red Bulls held their first official team function yesterday, news media day in Manhattan, since the company that makes the energy drink that made Austria famous took over the MetroStars of Major League Soccer.

title: Jersey City Ratchets Up Police Efforts Against Crime
description: JERSEY CITY, March 28 - After a spike in crime and mounting concern from residents, the police here say they are now turning a page in their efforts to fight crime and plan to carry out a fresh strategy to deal with it.

title: Germany and France deny deal on Alcatel
A Quiz for Would-Be Citizens Tests Germans' Attitudes
description: BERLIN, March 28 - What's the capital of Germany? Well, pretty much everybody knows that one. It's Berlin, of course.

title: Pressing a Claim for Dutch History
description: Correction Appended

title: Sports of The Times; Jagr Conjures Memories Of Some Ranger Greats
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y. - SOONER or later, almost any conversation about the Rangers these days gets around to Jaromir Jagr, and as Coach Tom Renney leaned against the glass wall of the team's weight room after practice yesterday, he quietly defined Jagr's value.

title: Antiquities and Politics Intersect in a Lawsuit
description: INCREASINGLY, the world of antiquities and museums has become a politically charged one, with museums acknowledging that art that was found to be looted must be returned. But when the objects come from a country that is viewed as an enemy rather than an ally, the arena of antiquities takes a different twist. Consider the fate of some artifacts from Iran.

title: Report Adds to Criticism of Halliburton's Iraq Role
description: Even as a Halliburton subsidiary was absorbing harsh criticism of its costs on a 2003 no-bid contract for work in Iraq, the government officials overseeing a second contract wrote that the company was running up exorbitant new expenses on similar work, according to a report issued yesterday by the staff for the Democrats on the House Government Reform Committee.

title: Time to Think
description: Philadelphia - AS high school juniors file into classrooms for their SAT's on Saturday, there will probably be some chatter about how more than 4,000 of last fall's tests were scored too low. What they probably won't be aware of is how many of their fellow students may end up with higher scores because they are allowed more time to take the test. Last year, more than 40,000 of the two million SAT takers were granted special accommodations, mainly because of learning disabilities. This represents a doubling in the past decade and a half.

title: Sometimes, Viewing Art Involves Breaking a Full-Court Press
description: I VISITED the Museum of Modern Art on a Sunday in early March to see the "Edvard Munch: The Modern Life of the Soul" exhibition. When the escalator deposited me on the sixth floor, where Munch's paintings and lithographs are hung, I came upon what seemed at first sight like standing room only at Madison Square Garden.

title: Son's Death in Iraq Prompts Bid for Congress
description: WILMINGTON, Del. - Michael S. Berg and his son Nick could not have been more different.

title: You Can Take This With You
description: AS a museum shopping bag makes its way around a city and beyond, it is not just promoting what's for sale in the store. It is also telegraphing a message to the world about the institution's mission and holdings -- a boon in an era when most museums have limited promotional budgets. "It is the one thing that is traveling and moving," said Richard Poulin, a principal in the New York design firm Poulin & Morris, which has designed bags for the Dahesh Museum of Art and other cultural institutions. "It's known as the moving sign."

title: Ex-Prisoners With Court Debt Must Have Vote, Judge Rules
description: Washington State may not deny former prisoners the right to vote simply because they are too poor to pay outstanding court costs, a state judge in Seattle ruled on Monday.

title: Leslie MacMitchell, 85, Runner Who Led U.S. Field in Early 40's, Dies
description: Leslie MacMitchell, the United States' best young mile runner just before World War II and the first college undergraduate to win the Sullivan Award as the nation's outstanding amateur athlete, died March 21 in San Jose, Calif. He was 85.

title: Neighbors keep distance as Hamas is sworn in
At Exxon, only a change of style
How Pink Slips Hurt More Than Workers
description: The Disposable American Layoffs and Their Consequences By Louis Uchitelle 283 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.95

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAJTELES, BERNARD
description: MAJTELES--Bernard. After a long illness he passed away on March 25, 2006. Survived by his loving wife of 47 years, Nancy Ann, his daughter Mary Ann, son-in-law Walter Lippman, and his two loving grandchildren Juliette and Mark Lippman. Funeral services were held privately.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 28, 2006

title: Obituaries: Cindy Walker, songwriter
Paid Notice: Deaths   TENNEY, DANIEL G., JR.
description: TENNEY--Daniel G., Jr. The Trustees, the Women's Board and the staff of The Boys' Club of New York express their deepest sympathy to his wife, Connie and the family of their dear friend. He was elected to the Board of Trustees in 1950 and gave unsparingly of his time and talents to help many thousands of boys to a better life. His generosity, good humor and commitment to the welfare of youth will be remembered by us all with deep affection. As friend, supporter and Trustee, Dan embodied The Boys' Club of New York's core principles of character, civility and community. The Boys Club of New York

title: Former Liberian president is arrested in Nigeria and flown home, officials say
3 Out of 4 Visitors to the Met Never Make It to the Front Door
description: SOME days the first thing visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art see is the soaring neo-Classical Great Hall punctuated by Corinthian columns, niches brimming with flowers and the spacious information desk. Other days, they may glimpse the interior of the famous Temple of Dendur, with its ancient ruins and sloping glass wall looking onto Central Park.

title: Panasonic Blu-ray device due in U.S. in September
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Central Bank Raises Interest Rates Again And Suggests Another Increase Is Likely The Federal Reserve's interest-rate-setting committee raised the benchmark federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 4.75 percent, and suggested that at least one more increase was in the cards. It was the 15th such increase in consecutive meetings of the group. [Page C1.]

title: Well Exercised and Supple, French Unions Flex Muscles
description: PARIS, March 28 - Armed with hot dogs and baguettes, balloons, buttons, banners and, of course, gallons of red wine, France's major trade unions set out Tuesday to change the law, or to bring down a prime minister trying.

title: Airbusclears a key hurdle
Competition Gives Flash to Photographers-on-the-Rise
description: Every year, a new class of photography students stages thesis shows and compiles portfolios, each hoping to become the next Irving Penn or Richard Avedon.

title: Salmon, Richly Spiced
description: AS a cook I prefer fresh wild salmon when I can get it, but I find farmed salmon to be no less desirable a product in the kitchen than farmed meat or poultry. There is no denying that there are issues to be resolved in the fish farming industry, but it is equally true that farmed salmon is inexpensive, about as fresh as any fish you can buy and, unlike its wild cousin, available year round.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stadium Plan Criticized At Hearing
description: The New York Yankees were on the defensive yesterday at a packed City Council hearing on their proposal to build a new $800 million stadium in the Bronx. Randy Levine, president of the Yankees, sought to emphasize the team's long history in the Bronx by showing a short video featuring Yankee players. Reggie Jackson, who is now a special adviser to the team, testified in support of the stadium. But Councilwoman Helen Diane Foster, whose district includes the South Bronx, and several other council members criticized the team for not doing more to help the community surrounding the stadium, which remains one of the poorest in the nation. Supporters say the stadium will bring new jobs and revitalize the Bronx, while opponents say that it will take away valuable parkland. The City Council is expected to vote on the stadium on April 5.

title: Robert W. Miller, 84, Who Studied A-Bomb Effect, Dies
description: Dr. Robert W. Miller, an epidemiologist who led an American team that determined that even fetuses had suffered damage from the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 84.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the National Basketball Association Development League misidentified one of the five first-round draft choices from 2005 who have played in it this season. He is Sergei Monia, now of Sacramento, who was sent down by Portland -- not Andray Blatche of Washington, who was a second-round pick.

title: Slick talkers from hip-hop's royal family
Weld Says He Backs Ending Taxes on Incomes Under $75,000
description: ALBANY, March 28 - William F. Weld, a Republican candidate for governor of New York, told a business group here on Tuesday that he favored eliminating the state income tax for people making less than $75,000 a year.

title: Abramoff Sentenced to Nearly 6 Years in Prison in Fraud Case
description: MIAMI, March 29 A The disgraced Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff was sentenced to nearly six years in federal prison today for his role in a fraud scheme involving the purchase of a cruise ship line.

title: Democrats Opening Assault on Bush Security Policies
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 - Seeking to capitalize on President Bush's troubles overseas, leading Democrats in Congress are unveiling a broad attack this week on the administration's security policies at home and overseas along with a set of proposals intended to demonstrate that they have a credible alternative.

title: Raiding the Souk: The Latest in Tagines
description: CAN modern technology go one better than cookware that has been used for centuries?

title: 'Drawing Restraint 9,' a Film Steeped in Ritual, With Whales and a Wedding
description: Near the end of Matthew Barney's visually spellbinding film "Drawing Restraint 9," a work that might be described as his "Moby-Dick," the voice of his co-star, Bjork, repeats a life-affirming motto in broken musical phrases: "From the moment of commitment, nature conspires to help you."

title: Bolton Presses for New Method of Calculating Dues at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 28 - John R. Bolton, the American ambassador, will outline a proposal for fundamental changes in calculating United Nations dues on Wednesday that he said would address Congressional concerns that "the United States doesn't get value for money."

title: Neglected Solo Gamers, Now Heroes Once Again
description: As the new video game The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion begins, the hero -- that's you, the player -- appears within a dank subterranean cell in a grim medieval dungeon, the silence broken only by the mad ramblings of another hapless prisoner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILTON, ARTHUR
description: MILTON--Arthur. Died suddenly March 25. Born June 7, 1922 in New York City. Arthur loved his hometown and the U.S.A. He started his business career in 1945 and built an organization in every area of insurance and financial matters. Thousands benefited by his concepts, which strengthened their financial security. He was a consultant, writer of many books, advisor and friend to many. He created scholarships in memory of his beloved daughter, Patricia Ann, for the young or disabled so they would have an opportunity for a successful future. He cared. Survived by his wife, Phyllis; and his children, Donna Conte (Robert), Claudia Carman (Gary), Robert and Linda; grandchildren, Steven Conte (Karen), Lauren Alter (Peter), Pamela Tuchman (Bruce), Melissa Conte, Todd Conte (Elizabeth), Jennifer, Stephanie and Jonathan Carman; his great-grandchildren, Alex, Hunter, and Griffen; Alexa and Grant; Jordan and Dylan; his sister, Madaline Griffith and his brother, Jerome Lefkowitz. Services Wednesday, 11:45AM, at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to Guiding Eyes for the Blind, 611 Granite Springs Road, Yorktown Heights, NY.

title: For First Time in 20 Years, Newark Looks to a Future Without Sharpe James as Mayor
description: NEWARK, March 28 - Six years ago, Nereida Perez was desperate for a job to help feed her two teenage children, so she asked Mayor Sharpe James for help. After filling out a few forms, she was hired as a crossing guard.

He opened by delving into the topic of the Euphronios krater, a 2,500-year-old Greek bowl that the Metropolitan Museum of Art has recently agreed to return to Italy. description: WASHINGTON, March 28 - Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg bluntly told a Congressional panel on Tuesday that a "god-awful piece of legislation" before the House of Representatives would cripple the city's ability to combat gun trafficking and "result in the shooting deaths of innocent people."

title: Michael Pollan
description: Michael Pollan, the author of The Botany of Desire and a recent cover article in The Times magazine answers readers' questions on how and why we hunt, gather and eat.

description: The studies linked below offer more detail on demographics and divorce. In general, they find that similar couples -- those of the same religion, for instance, or similar educational backgrounds -- are more likely to have a lasting marriage than spouses of different backgrounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAESS, KENNETH R.
description: KAESS--Kenneth R., President and CEO of DDB Worldwide, died peacefully on March 27, 2006 in his family home in Westport, CT. Ken was a beloved father to his children, Courtney and Christopher, a devoted son to Dr. Kenneth R. Kaess, Sr. of Redding, Connecticut and a dedicated brother to Karl Kaess of Wilton, Connecticut and Karen Clark of Greenwich, Connecticut. He is also survived by his former wife, Heidi Warner Kaess. Funeral services will be conducted at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 55 Myrtle Avenue, Westport, Connecticut at 11 AM on Friday, March 31st. Good friends, Reverend John Branson and Reverend Maryetta Anschutz will officiate. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Ken's name to Mermorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (Thoracic Oncology Research), 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York, 10021 and Builders Beyond Borders, 8 Willard Road, Norwalk, Connecticut, 06851. The funeral service is for close friends and family. A memorial service will be held at a later date in Manhattan. Ken will be missed by all whose lives he touched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINHARDT, JEAN STETTHEIMER
description: STEINHARDT--Jean Stettheimer. A consistent and significant contributor to many Santa Barbara charities and organizations, Jean Stettheimer Steinhardt passed away on Saturday, March 25. She was the daughter of the late Florence and Walter Stettheimer of Atherton, CA, the sister of the late Barbara S. Adler and the sister-in-law of the late Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President and General Manager of The New York Times, both of New York City. Mrs. Steinhardt lived her later years at the Casa Dorinda in Montecito, CA. Jean was a quiet force in making public and private gifts with a definite plan and a strong sense that such were her responsibilities. She did not seek public recognition but would have wanted to be remembered as a person who made a positive difference. Jean had a zest for life and leaves a legacy of wisdom, of strong conviction and of resolute character. She always cared and taught by example that life could be a blend of social concern and glamorous fun. She is survived by her daughters Felicia W. Rogan of Charlottesville, VA and Jill W. Cartter of Beverly Hills, CA. She was also the beloved friend and quintessential aunt of Bobbie Adler Katzander of New York City. No services are to be held. In keeping with her great sense of charitable responsibility donations can be made to the Cancer Center of Santa Barbara.

title: The End User: Adults only? Not so fast
Gravedigger's Secret Is Out, 20 Years Later, at Trial of 2 Ex-Detectives
description: A 56-year-old man with a 20-year-old secret told it in public for the first time yesterday: how, in 1986, he dug a five-foot-deep hole in the floor of a parking garage he owned and, under pain of death, dumped in a dead man he believed that two detectives, Louis J. Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa, had just helped kill.

title: This Land Is Our Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Classic Stage Company Serves Up Ancient Greek Cocktails With No Twist
description: T. S. Eliot, Edward Albee and Harold Pinter all had their goes at the cocktail-party tragedy, a form that Sophocles and Euripides never got around to writing. So Kelly Copper has tried to do it for them. Assembling a text from recently published bits and pieces of previously lost plays by those Greek masters, Ms. Copper has put together a play called "Fragment."

title: The Seductive Surplus
description: New York has a surplus, and that's leading the state into trouble. The word going around Albany is that after the legislators pass a budget of $112 billion or so this week, they will be able to "declare victory now and declare bankruptcy later." There's an uncomfortable amount of truth in the joke.

title: Much Ado About Mutton, but Not in These Parts
description: LOCUST DALE, Va. - HAVING buckled on his broadsword in the past to fight for organic farming and against modern architecture, the Prince of Wales recently launched a crusade to reawaken Britain's taste for mutton, which he calls "my favorite dish."

title: Ken Kaess, 51, Who Led Ad Agency, Is Dead
description: Ken Kaess, who as chief executive helped DDB Worldwide solidify its position as one of the world's leading advertising agencies by attracting major new clients and championing its digital operation even after the dot-com boom had faded, died on Monday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 51.

title: Teaching the Bible in Georgia's Public Schools
description: ATLANTA, March 28  Georgia is about to become the first state to approve the use of the Bible as a textbook in public schools.

title: Italy (sh!) has a problem
Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 21 about a ruin in Peru that some people say was a fertility temple misidentified the decade in which two archaeologists, Marion and Harry Tschopik, authenticated its walls as ancient. It was the 1940's, not the 1950's.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Accused of Concealing Evidence in Terror Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 A A grand jury charged today that a former federal prosecutor in Detroit who led one of the Justice Department's biggest terrorism investigations concealed critical evidence in the case in an effort to bolster the government's theory that a group of local Muslim men were plotting an attack.

title: Gunmen Kill Eight Workers at Iraqi Shop
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 29 - Gunmen in police uniforms burst into an electronics shop in one of Baghdad's ritziest neighborhoods, rounded up all the employees and riddled them with machine gun fire on Wednesday, Iraqi officials said.

title: Same Cellphone Carrier, Same User Interface
description: In my e-mail column last Thursday, I mentioned how much I liked the intuitive, smartly designed menu system of the LG 8100 cellphone. The implication was that LG Electronics should get the credit.

title: The Art of Conservation Sees Light at the Getty
description: Malibu, Calif. - A DECADE ago, when the members of the J. Paul Getty Trust set out to redesign the Getty Villa, a replica of a first-century Roman building and the site of the original J. Paul Getty Museum, they faced several daunting challenges. Among their priorities were improving parking and traffic flow in a rugged canyon, enhancing amenities like food service and anticipating the aesthetic desires of sophisticated visitors eager to view the museum's treasures -- including Mr. Getty's collection of Greek and Roman antiquities -- in a fresher light.

title: Matchmaking: Hot teams and rich sponsors
Nikki Sudden, Punk Rocker, Dies at 49
description: Nikki Sudden, a pioneer of the English rock avant-garde known for his velvet jackets and larger-than-life panache, died on Sunday, a day after performing at the Knitting Factory in Manhattan. He was 49.

description: WASHINGTON, March 28 - At Ben S. Bernanke's first meeting as head of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee, the watchword was no surprises.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSS, CHESTER. MARCH 29, 1917
description: ROSS--Chester. March 29, 1917. Your 89th Birthday. We love you and we miss you everyday. "You do not depart from us". B and D

title: G.M. Will Also Restate Results for Its Finance Unit
description: DETROIT, March 28 - Two weeks after it increased its 2005 loss by $2 billion, General Motors said Tuesday that it would restate several years worth of results for its financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.

title: Along With Stories, a Dish From Nazareth
description: THE name Rawia in Arabic means storyteller. When Rawia Bishara, a Brooklyn chef and restaurateur, talks about food, she tells stories, complete with elaborate gestures as she widens or narrows her striking eyes. There are stories about her mother; about her childhood in Nazareth, the Arab town in northern Israel where she was born; and about the traditional food ways of Palestinian cooks and households.

title: Arrest Is Made in Killing of Veteran Harlem Minister
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with stabbing to death a minister credited with helping to bring a blighted block of Harlem back to life.

title: Bach Collegium Japan Brings Smorgasbord to Zankel Hall
description: When Masaaki Suzuki introduced his Bach Collegium Japan to New York, in a 2003 concert at Carnegie Hall, it was with a stroke of Bachian grandeur, the "St. Matthew Passion." But when he returned on Monday evening, in the more intimate space of Zankel Hall, it was with a program that on the surface was the opposite in every way. In place of a single vast sacred choral work, Mr. Suzuki this time brought a handful of concertos and a suite.

title: Apple vs. Apple in Dispute Over Trademark
description: LONDON, March 29 A The High Court of Britain, accustomed to the sounds of bewigged barristers parsing the fine points of the law, was treated today to a funky playback of the disco anthem "Le Freak" as a lawyer for the Beatles' record company argued that Apple Computer's iTunes digital music store violated a trademark agreement between the companies.

title: Taking the Rough-and-Tumble Approach to Science
description: San Francisco - ALTHOUGH today's solar eclipse will not be visible in North America, science fans will get a chance to see it online. The Exploratorium science museum will transmit a live Webcast of the event from Turkey to www.exploratorium.edu.

title: Olive Oils For Drizzling, Meals for Passover
description: Distinctive varietal olive oils from Israel, the Harrington Trace Israeli Gold collection, are sold in slender 375 milliliter cobalt-blue bottles. A green-gold oil made from barnea olives is earthy and mellow, and manzanilla has a spicy, vegetal scent and a warm, rich flavor with a hint of pepper.

title: Roundup:$23.45 million deal secures Sizemore
Speech due by Chirac on protests
The Knockoff, or the Desert Classic?
description: EMILE HENRY TAGINE

title: Extension of Voting Act Is Likely Despite Criticism
description: ATLANTA, March 27 - Representative Lynn Westmoreland, a former builder who represents a jigsaw of predominantly white areas just south and west of Atlanta, acknowledges that the 1965 Voting Rights Act, a cornerstone achievement of the civil rights movement, was necessary in its day to register blacks and overturn decades of laws preventing them from voting.

title: Safety Stings at Work Sites Will Be Halted
description: Federal officials told immigrant advocates in a letter made public yesterday that government immigration agents would discontinue using undercover sting operations involving health and safety programs to round up illegal immigrants.

title: Brewers Embrace Flower Power
description: "JUST the kiss of the hopsnone of the bitterness," reads the tag line in a 1940's ad for Schlitz. This was a selling point for beer back when mild, chuggable pilsners monopolized the brewing world.

title: Ferreting for clues on a likelihood of bird flu pandemic
New Money Dances With Old Money at the Frick
description: AS roses dripped from the stone urns in the garden court of the Frick Collection and candles illuminated the fountain, some of Manhattan's young boldface names, like Marina Rust Connor, Aerin Lauder Zinterhofer and Vera Wang, adjusted their mantillas and sipped sangras and martinis at the Frick's Young Fellows gala earlier this month. Its theme, tangos and tapas, played off the current Goya show.

title: Invoking Federal Law, Maryland Takes Over Baltimore Schools
description: BALTIMORE, March 29 A Invoking the federal No Child Left Behind Law, the Maryland State school board voted today to take control of four Baltimore high schools with chronically low achievement and strip the city of Baltimore from direct operation of seven more middle schools.

title: Pavano Takes Another Step in Comeback
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 28 - The ball squirted down the first-base line, and Carl Pavano scrambled off the mound in pursuit. Even with a 6-foot-5, 250-pound body, Pavano is the most fragile of Yankees. One batter into his comeback, this looked like disaster.

title: Is It All Loot? Tackling The Antiquities Problem
description: On March 6, at the New School in New York, Michael Kimmelman, The Times's chief art critic, moderated a discussion about antiquities and their provenance. He opened by delving into the topic of the Euphronios krater, a 2,500-year-old Greek bowl that the Metropolitan Museum of Art has recently agreed to return to Italy. Here are excerpts, edited for clarity, from the conversation:

title: Yahoo Japan in Talks With Online Bank
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, March 29 - The Yahoo Japan Corporation, the country's most visited Web portal, said on Wednesday that it was in talks about a possible alliance with Japan Net Bank, an online bank controlled by the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation.

title: French like job climate in Ireland
Teaching the Bible in Georgia's Public Schools
description: ATLANTA, March 28 - Georgia is about to become the first state to approve the use of the Bible as a textbook in public schools.

title: 32 militants, 2 coalition soldiers die in Afghan battle
Nanny Is Hit by Truck While Seeking Help to Save a Choking Baby
description: An Upper East Side nanny trying to save a choking boy was struck by a truck yesterday after she wandered into a busy Manhattan street on her way to the hospital, the police said. When she collapsed from her injuries, strangers and a police officer took the child from her, revived him and took him to the hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, ROBERT C.
description: MEYER--Robert C. Age 58, of NYC, on March 22, 2006. Beloved companion of Carlos Pedreros. Son of Elmer Meyer and the late Margaret (nee Ottiwell). Brother of Lorraine Headrick and Edward Meyer. Funeral service was held on March 25 at St. Michael's Lutheran Church, Amagansett. Interment Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton. Mem'l donations appreciated to St. Michael's Lutheran Church, P.O. Box 695, Amagansett, NY 11930.

title: Fake ID's at the Border Crossings
description: While federal officials have been scrambling to install enough radiation detectors to screen all cargo for dangerous nuclear materials, they have apparently left a glaring hole in this thin and spotty line of defense. Even when detectors signal the presence of a radioactive substance, border guards may be fooled into waving a shipment through based on fraudulent paperwork and glib talk by the drivers.

title: Friday Cocktails, With a Splash of Art
description: EVERY Friday, before the sky goes black, the lights go down in the lobby cafe of the Rubin Museum of Art, which fills the old Barneys building at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street. Keeping with the museum's focus on the culture of the Himalayas, a gong sits on the floor next to a table where the D.J. spins a soothing mix of Eastern-inflected trance rhythms punctuated by soft jazz and bass-heavy world music. Small tables are set with electric candles that flicker a shifting display of turquoise, purple, blue, red and green.

title: I.R.S. Quickly Answers Study on Audits of Rich Americans
description: In a rare disclosure, the Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that it had audited 11,715 -- or 5.2 percent -- of the 225,000 Americans who reported incomes of more than $1 million in 2005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOONE, THOMAS F.
description: NOONE--Thomas F. Age 74, of Sea Bright, NJ and Rio Mar, PR died March 25, 2006. Beloved husband of Mary Jane, beloved father of Caragh Woods (Michael) and Patrick Donnell (Alicia) and grandfather of Helen and Patrick Noone. Proud graduate of Regis High School, Saint Peter's College and Fordham Law School. Retired senior partner Emmet, Marvin and Martin. Funeral Mass on Saturday, April 1, 2006 at 11 AM at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Route 36, Highlands, NJ. There are no calling hours, cremation private and no flowers please. Memorials may be made to Regis High School, 55 East 84th Street, New York, New York 10028.

title: Sotheby's Bets on a Windfall for Today's Chinese Art
description: A $4 million blue and white Yuan dynasty jar is one of the stars of Sotheby's Asian auctions this week. So is a $1 million lacquer dish made for a 15th-century Chinese emperor. But neither object takes center stage in Sotheby's sun-filled 10th-floor galleries.

Nets Rolling at Right Time, and Tempo Is Everything
description: To understand why the Nets seem to be a dangerous team again, it does not necessarily take savvy in X's and O's. But it's helpful to have been a passenger in a car.

At G.M.'s Helm or Going Under?
description: DETROIT, March 28 - In 1992, with General Motors in the worst financial crisis in its storied history, its board ousted top management and brought in a fresh slate of executives with orders to burst through the automaker's turgid culture.

description: LOS ANGELES, March 28 - Can Hollywood make quality movies for both love and money?
