description: The 35th annual New Directors/New Films festival continues its cinematic world tour with selections from such ports of call as Ireland, Russia, the Netherlands and Texas. Today and tomorrow you can also catch encore screenings of "Eleven Men Out," "John & Jane Toll-Free," "Old Joy" and "Iron Island," along with almost half a dozen documentaries that were shown in past festivals. For further information about all these titles and for ticket availability: www.filmlinc.com.

title: Correction
description: An article last Wednesday about the New Orleans chef Ken Smith misidentified the neighborhood for his restaurant, Upperline. (The error also occurred in an article on March 8.) It is in Uptown, not the Garden District.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Barnes Foundation to Get $25 Million
description: The Barnes Foundation will receive a $25 million grant from the State of Pennsylvania for its move from suburban Merion to a new museum on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway in downtown Philadelphia, the office of Gov. Edward G. Rendell announced yesterday. The foundation, home to a world-class collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art, has been at the center of legal battles and financial difficulties for years. In 2004 a Philadelphia judge ruled that the foundation, backed by pledges of $150 million in financial support primarily from three Philadelphia-area foundations, could move downtown, where more people could see the art. The decision went against the charter and bylaws drawn up by the collection's mercurial founder, Albert C. Barnes, left, who famously stipulated that no picture in his collection could be lent, sold or even moved on the walls of the neo-Classical galleries that he had built for it in the mid-1920's. In a statement, Governor Rendell said that the money, which will come from a state fund for capital projects, would be "as important to the continued development of Philadelphia's downtown as any in recent years." But former students who have consistently opposed the move stood firm. "If they'd given us the $25 million in the first place, the Barnes would never have had to move," said Nicholas Tinari, a former Barnes student. CAROL VOGEL

title: Israeli Voters, by Thin Margin, Support Parties Vowing Pullout
description: JERUSALEM, Wednesday, March 29 - Israelis voted Tuesday to bring to power a new centrist party, Kadima, which is committed to a further pullout from the occupied West Bank.

title: New U.N. Draft on Iran Softens Condemnation
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 28 - European and American diplomats circulated a new draft statement to the Security Council on Tuesday evening that weakens language condemning Iran's nuclear program but still calls on Tehran to abandon uranium enrichment activities, which the West believes are intended to make weapons.

title: British Museum Shows Works Michelangelo Wanted to Hide
description: LONDON - The British Museum's acclaimed new show of Michelangelo drawings is an invitation to voyeurism, albeit not, as may be supposed, because of the Florentine master's undisguised worship of the naked male body. Rather, it is because Michelangelo never intended his drawings to be seen by eyes other than his own or those of his family and pupils.

title: Years of Political Service vs. Some Ill-Timed Remarks
description: PATERSON, N.J. - SITTING at the back of a Lebanese restaurant in South Paterson in his crisp gray suit, cellphone incessantly beeping, Sami Merhi cites the Constitution, reflects on family, tells an immigrant's success story, muses ruefully about lessons learned.

title: A Director Whose Eye Is Focused on Change
description: MEETING James Cuno for the first time, a visitor registers the spring in his step, sparkling eyes and not an ounce of stuffiness. Entering his narrow, book-lined office, first impressions are confirmed by a life-size cutout of the Boston Red Sox slugger David Ortiz, alongside his glass-topped desk.

title: Capitalism under fire
New Money Dances With Old Money at the Frick
description: AS roses dripped from the stone urns in the garden court of the Frick Collection and candles illuminated the fountain, some of Manhattan's young boldface names, like Marina Rust Connor, Aerin Lauder Zinterhofer and Vera Wang, adjusted their mantillas and sipped sangras and martinis at the Frick's Young Fellows gala earlier this month. title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the McClatchy Company's offer of 12 Knight Ridder newspapers for sale misidentified the publication that said the Times-Shamrock Company was a logical buyer for The Times Leader, a Knight Ridder paper in Wilkes-Barre, Pa. It was The Citizens' Voice of Wilkes-Barre, not The Times Leader.

title: Four Hot Meals, and Hold the Dazzle, Please
description: I RECENTLY celebrated the first anniversary of my grudge against Caf Gray.

title: 'The New Medicine' on PBS: Doctors Turn to the Mind for Healing
description: Last November, just four months before she died, Dana Reeve, the widow of the paralyzed actor Christopher Reeve, taped the introduction to "The New Medicine," a two-hour PBS documentary that will be shown tonight. Ms. Reeve, who was fighting lung cancer at the time, is an ideal host for this program, which wants to argue that there is more to medicine than mere science, and that a growing number of physicians now accept the role of mental and emotional well-being in health and in recovery. She is warm but not smarmy, upbeat but not spacey, affirmative without getting weird or New Agey.

title: World Briefing: Europe, Asia, Africa and Americas
description: WORLD AWAITS FIRST TOTAL SOLAR ECLIPSE IN YEARS Tourists and scientists were gathering at spots around the world for the first total eclipse in years, a solar show that will sweep northeast from Brazil to Mongolia and blot out the sun across swaths of the world's poorest lands. The last such eclipse, in November 2003, was most visible from Antarctica, said Alex Young, a NASA scientist. The eclipse today will block the sun in highly populated areas, including West Africa. In Togo, the authorities imported hundreds of thousands of pairs of special glasses that consumers cleared rapidly from shelves in the capital, LomA. Villagers in the interior will not have access to the eyewear, and officials called on them to stay home.

title: China Passes Japan in Foreign Exchange Reserves
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, March 29 - China's reserves of dollars and other foreign currencies hit $853.7 billion in February, an official Chinese newspaper said on Wednesday, allowing China to overtake Japan as the world's largest holder of foreign exchange reserves.

Russian Company Moves Closer to Bankruptcy
description: MOSCOW, March 28 - A Moscow court appointed a bankruptcy administrator on Tuesday for Yukos, once Russia's largest private oil company, pushing it closer to insolvency and the probable nationalization of its remaining assets.

title: German strikes come amid signs of rebound
Joshua Brewster Bolten: Longtime Ally, Now a Top Aide
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 - Joshua B. Bolten, the incoming White House chief of staff, would appear to have the insider credentials and ability to soothe Congress that the White House desperately needs.

title: Go for the van Gogh, but Stay for the Smoked Eel With Jalapeo
description: AT the Mitsitam Cafe in the National Museum of the American Indian in Washington, food has become an extension of the collection. Salmon cakes reflect life in the Pacific Northwest, and buffalo burgers echo the diet of the Great Plains Indians. Even its name is educational. Mitsitam means "let's eat" in the language of the Piscataway and the Delaware people.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Critics Say Beer Spots Exploit Loopholes
description: IN a television commercial for Bud Light during the Super Bowl and Olympics, three men climb onto the roofs of their houses, telling their wives that they were going to clean gutters and repair satellite dishes. Instead, the men break out the Bud Light and lawn chairs. One man eventually falls through the roof and into his living room.

title: Text of Fed Statement on Rates
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to raise its benchmark interest rates a quarter-point:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about rallies in support of immigrants referred incorrectly in some copies to demonstrators in Los Angeles, one of them waving a Mexican flag in the foreground. They included farm workers, but their citizenship was unidentified; they were not known to be from Mexico.

title: Comparison shopping makes progress online
Why Lease When You Can Own?
description: After two decades in the same location -- a town house on 57th Street just west of Fifth Avenue -- Ascot Chang, a retailer of custom-made shirts that cost as much as $650, found itself facing an uncertain future. The building had a new owner and the store's $40,000-a-month lease was set to expire in 2007.

title: The Literary Heart of Old Madrid Ponders Its Next Chapter
description: Aurora Nez has grown accustomed to the cabarets and jazz cafes that have moved into her centuries-old Madrid neighborhood near the Prado, a tangle of narrow streets once lined only with fruit vendors, rare-book sellers and antiques dealers. But Ms. Nez, 55, who works for the culture ministry and is a lifelong resident of the literary quarter known as Las Letras, never imagined a trendy onslaught like this would take over.

title: Arts, Briefly; Love, '24' Style
description: Spring is here, and love is in the air on "24." Or the action series's version of love, anyway. In Monday's episode, Jack (Kiefer Sutherland) had to interrogate his beloved ex-girlfriend, Audrey (Kim Raver, below), to find out if she had sold secrets to terrorists. An audience of 14.53 million watched Jack throw Audrey against a wall before determining that she was innocent. (She later forgave him.) Monday's "24" drew its best ratings since its time slot premiere in January. With CBS broadcasting repeats but for a single episode of "The New Adventures of Old Christine" (12.1 million), Fox easily won the night among adults 18 to 49 and placed a close second to CBS among total viewers (12.43 million versus 12.32 million). On WB, "Everwood" returned to the schedule for the first time in more than three months. The acclaimed family drama, which may be a casualty of the merger between UPN and WB, delivered an average of 3.52 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. That was more than UPN's lineup attracted (3.16 million), but the two networks tied in the 18-to-34 demographic the merged network, CW, will aim at next season. KATE AURTHUR

title: U.S. official pushes China on trade gap
U.S. Approves Whirlpool's $1.7 Billion Purchase of Maytag
description: The Justice Department approved Whirlpool's $1.7 billion purchase of the rival appliance maker Maytag this afternoon, saying the combination is "not likely to reduce competition substantially."

title: Judge Rejects Leniency for Officer in Louima Case
description: Nearly a decade after the station house attack on Abner Louima, a redefining act of police brutality that left epic consequences for the city and its police force, a federal judge told a former police officer today that his perjury had prevented a full accounting of the crime.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "We are prepared to compromise, give up parts of our beloved land of Israel, remove, painfully, Jews who live there, to allow you the conditions to achieve your hopes and to live in a state in peace and quiet."

title: Gunmen Kill 8 Workers at Iraqi Shop
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 29 A Gunmen in commando uniforms burst into an electrical supply shop in one of Baghdad's most fashionable neighborhoods today, rounded up all the employees and riddled them with machine gun fire, Iraqi officials said.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Robert W. Miller, 84, Who Studied A-Bomb Effect, Dies
description: Dr. Robert W. Miller, an epidemiologist who led an American team that determined that even fetuses had suffered damage from the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 84.

Several smaller companies provided cable service on Long Island until the late 1990's; Cablevision is not the only one to have served the island.

title: South Carolina Has a Shot to Repeat
description: Every time South Carolina's Renaldo Balkman dunked or grabbed an offensive rebound and deposited the ball into the basket last night, his shoulder-length dreadlocks would twirl and Louisville Coach Rick Pitino's face seemed to twist.

title: Scientists Question Effectiveness of Bird-Flu Vaccine
description: A bird-flu vaccine being stockpiled by the government in preparation for a possible pandemic protects only about half the people who receive it, scientists are reporting. In addition, it must be given in such high doses that if a pandemic were to start soon, manufacturers could not begin to make enough vaccine for all who would need it.

title: Curators Can Curate, But Writers Can Try, Too
description: AS Hilary Spurling delved into the life of Henri Matisse for what would become her prize-winning two-volume biography of him, she had a great idea. Believing that textiles were "the earliest and longest lasting of all the sources that fed and shaped" Matisse's imagination, she proposed to a couple of museum curators an exhibition exploring his relationship with fabrics.

Ms. Walker's authors include Mukhtar Mai, who also offers an insider's view of Muslim life, but not Monica Ali, who writes about a Bangladeshi in London in an arranged marriage; Ms. Ali's editor is Nan Graham.

title: Facts and Folly
description: I was leaving for a trip the other day and scooped up some reading material off my desk for the plane ride. I found myself holding three documents: one was the Bush administration's National Security Strategy for 2006; another was a new study by the Economic Strategy Institute entitled "America's Technology Future at Risk," about how America is falling behind the world in broadband. And the third was "Teaching at Risk," a new report by the Teaching Commission, headed by the former I.B.M. chairman Louis Gerstner Jr., about the urgent need to upgrade the quality and pay of America's K-12 teachers.

description: FRANKFURT, March 28 - With its stock options, Silicon Valley-like image and reputation as Germany's answer to Microsoft, SAP would seem a rather fruitless place to organize a labor movement.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on March 20 about the Bush administration's defense of its Iraq strategy misstated the magnitude of antiwar protests held in cities around the country on the weekend of March 18-19, the third anniversary of the American-led invasion. They were not all relatively small: while some 7,000 people demonstrated in Chicago on March 18 and smaller protests were held in other cities, a larger demonstration took place in Portland, Ore., on March 19, and organizers estimated that at least 10,000 people took part. (Go to Article)

title: Woman Admits She Threw Baby Down Air Shaft
description: JERSEY CITY, March 28 - A teenager admitted in court on Tuesday that she tried to kill her newborn son by throwing him down an air shaft in her West New York apartment building -- and said that two years earlier, her father killed another newborn by tossing her down the same air shaft.

title: Bone Fragments Found on Roof
description: More human remains have been found at the former Deutsche Bank building, a skyscraper adjacent to ground zero, authorities said yesterday.

title: Deal in Albany on Budget Gives New School Aid
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, March 29 - Legislative leaders agreed Tuesday on a $112.4 billion budget that authorized $11.2 billion for school construction in New York City and included a broad tax-cut package that would send property tax rebate checks to homeowners across the state.

title: Looks Can Be Deceiving
description: IT'S only a 0.58-mile drive from the new restaurant Urea to a Home Depot. I know because I did a MapQuest search, which also provided the directions: east on 28th, south on Park, west on 23rd. I eagerly share these with Alex Urea, the restaurant's chef and owner. And I urge him to commandeer a van and head over to the store, or somewhere similar, before it's too late.

title: Snowboarders Take on Rock Star Status
description: Alan Watts has been reintroduced to Led Zeppelin, courtesy of his son Ben, a spindly 12-year-old who is a budding talent in the snowboarding world. When Ben takes a break from his 30-hour practice week and touring schedule that recently included stops in Switzerland and Stratton Mountain, Vt., he retires to his room in Bend, Ore., to strum a few Jimmy Page chords. Lately, Ben has been playing a Gibson Les Paul purchased with a sponsorship check handed out by Burton Snowboards after he won a competition in January.

description: IT'S 10 a.m. on a Saturday and the lobby of the Museum of Modern Art is packed with boisterous children waiting for the weekend family programs to begin. Though the idea of mixing 5-year-olds and modern art may seem daunting, Ben Street, a freelance educator at the museum, is delighted to see how his young charges respond to Matisse, Picasso and Pollock. "We encourage them to be as imaginative as they can in their observations," he said. "If they are convinced a Jackson Pollock is spaghetti, then it is spaghetti."

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Robber Who Posed As Officer Is Sought
description: A man posing as a police officer has stolen people's bags in a series of robberies over the past several months, the police said yesterday. Detectives think the man is responsible for six robberies since October 2005 in commercial buildings, generally on the West Side between 36th and 39th Streets. The robber, described as a well-dressed man in his 30's with bad teeth, stops people inside the buildings, identifies himself as a police officer, tells them they are in a secure area and frisks them, the police said. He then steals their bags.

title: Recalling history's first take
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Charges In Money-Smuggling Scheme
description: Two lawyers, an 81-year-old mortgage banker and several Yemeni men were arraigned in federal court in Brooklyn yesterday on charges that they ran an unlicensed money transferring business that smuggled more than $5 million to Yemen. One of the lawyers, Neil S. Kramer, 58, and four of the Yemeni men were also charged in a loan sharking scheme that prosecutors said preyed on Yemeni immigrants, making loans ranging from $5,000 to $100,000. The borrowers were required to sign judgment papers with the amount, terms and due date of the loan left blank and, in some cases, to surrender leases to their businesses, as well as green cards and passports until the debts were paid. All of the defendants pleaded not guilty before United States Magistrate Judge Joan M. Azrack and all but one, Hamood Zokari, 53, were freed on bond. The arrests were the result of a three-year investigation by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents.

title: U.S. and Europeans Consider Sanctions Against 40 Belarus Aides

title: 'Yang Ban Xi,' a Documentary on Chinese Operas as Propaganda
description: Long before Nixon and Peter Sellars, and long before Made in China branded the world, the Chinese government produced state propaganda of the campiest kind. In the documentary "Yang Ban Xi: The 8 Model Works," the director Yan-Ting Yuen revisits the country's recent past to explore the history and legacy of one of the strangest byproducts of totalitarian madness: the revolutionary spectacular. With the onset of the Cultural Revolution in 1966, the government allowed only about a dozen revolutionary operas, or Yang Ban Xi, to be performed on stage and on screen; the most popular became known as the eight model works. Although filled with dancers lustily singing Mao's praise, these productions look eerily familiar, maybe because, as one performer remembers, it was "as if I were working in a fairy tale like a Hollywood musical."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Court Strikes Down City Tow Rules
description: A federal judge yesterday said that city rules requiring all tow truck operators driving in New York City to obtain a city medallion are an unconstitutional infringement of interstate commerce, city officials said. Judge Richard Owen, of the United States District Court, made the ruling in a lawsuit filed by AAA New York after the city began stopping unlicensed trucks from outside the city in 2004. The enforcement required the club to arrange a series of hand-offs between towing companies at the city line, club officials said. Gabriel Taussig, a lawyer for the city, said the licensing rules allowed the city to perform criminal background checks on tow truck drivers, which helped protect city residents. He said out-of-city companies could obtain medallions to operate in the city. The judge is expected to enter a final decision after a court appearance on April 13, and Mr. Taussig said the city would probably appeal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRARY, STEPHEN TROW BRIDGE
description: CRARY -- Stephen Trow bridge, 93. Died March 23, 2006, in Hanover, N.H. Beloved as husband, father, grandfather, professor, and friend. Born in Warren, PA, he received his undergraduate and doctorate degrees from Yale University and his divinity degree from Union Theological Seminary. He served as an army chaplain in the Pacific in World War II with the 39th General Hospital, composed of Yale doctors and nurses. He was chaplain and professor at Smith College from 1951-1957, then professor and chairman of religious studies at Brown University until 1971. In retirement, he lived in Lyme, N.H.; he and his family also spent many summers in the White Mountains at Randolph, N.H. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Eleanor Collier Crary; five children, Ann C. Evans of New York City, Sarah H. Crary of Amherst, MA, Alexander D. Crary of Washington, D.C., Jonathan K. Crary of New York City, and David H. Crary of Brooklyn, N.Y.; and five grandchildren. He was predeceased by his brothers, Calvert H. Crary and Douglas D. Crary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELTHAM, REGINALD
description: FELTHAM--Reginald. Completed his journey in passing on March 23, 2006. Reg was a world-class swimmer in the 1940's shattering NYC and national breast stroke records throughout his high school and college years. Later, Reg was Director of Special Education for B.O.C.E.S. II on Long Island--selected "Educator of the Year" in 1976. Reggie will be remembered for his devotion to family, his commitment to quality education for everyone, his adventurous spirit, his work hard/play hard mentality and his awesome spoon playing. Reg is survived by his loving wife, Mary, seven adoring children & eighteen cherished grandchildren. Reginald Feltham wanted us all to live, love, laugh and be happy!

Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Tenafly: Councilman Is Indicted
description: An Essex County grand jury has indicted a Tenafly councilman on charges that include drug possession and intent to distribute a controlled substance, the authorities said yesterday. The councilman, Jeffery Romano, was also charged with official misconduct and other crimes, said the Essex County prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. Mr. Romano, 43, was arrested last November after narcotics investigators in Newark found 40 envelopes containing heroin inside his 2006 Corvette, prosecutors said. A call to Mr. Romano's house yesterday was not answered and a message left with his lawyer, Robert Galantucci, was not returned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STUART, DONALD KIRKLEY
description: STUART -- Donald Kirkley. The retired president of Stuart Broadcasting Co. and founder of the National Baseball Network (NBN) died Thursday, March 23 at his home in Darien, CT at age 69. Born September 25, 1936 in Grundy VA to Russell Thorson and Caroline Clark Stuart, he graduated from Brown University in 1960 with a B.A. in English Literature. Prior to the formation of SBC and the NBN, Don was the national sales manager for WPIX-TV, a corporate Vice President of CBS and Broadcast Affairs Vice President for the New York Yankees. Don moved to Darien from New York City in 1977 and was active in the community. He is survived by his sister Lynn Stuart Merrell; a daughter, Michele Stuart; his sister's children and their families. A service was held in memory of Don on Tuesday, March 28 in the Chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church of Darien. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Darien Library Annual Campaign, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT 06820. www. lawrencefuneralhome.com

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (11) THE BEDFORD DIARIES -- "I'm Going to Love College." In this new drama series for very young adults, a handsome young man (Penn Badgley, left) enters Bedford College, a fictional institution in New York City. He is immediately accepted into a prestigious sex seminar (taught by Matthew Modine), as is his older sister (Tiffany Dupont), whose affair with a professor may soon be exposed in the campus newspaper. The show borrows a device from "Sex, Lies & Videotape," having the students use video cameras as confessionals, but that oldie "The Harrad Experiment" also comes to mind. Audra McDonald, as a faculty member, lends some intelligence to the proceedings.

title: Scientists Question Effectiveness of Bird-Flu Vaccine
description: A bird-flu vaccine being stockpiled by the government in preparation for a possible pandemic protects only about half the people who receive it, scientists are reporting. In addition, it must be given in such high doses that if a pandemic were to start soon, manufacturers could not begin to make enough vaccine for all who would need it.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Man Indicted In Killing
description: A man accused of killing his wife and infant daughter was indicted on first-degree murder charges by a grand jury. The authorities said the man, Neil Entwistle, 27, shot his wife, Rachel, and their 9-month-old daughter, Lillian, in January in their home in Hopkinton, Mass. The authorities said Mr. Entwistle fled to his native England hours later. He was arrested in London on Feb. 9 and extradited to Massachusetts. Mr. Entwistle will be arraigned in Middlesex Superior Court in the coming weeks. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: NEC to Spin Off Its Internet Service Provider
description: The NEC Corporation, Japan's largest maker of personal computers, will spin off its Internet service provider, Biglobe, and sell some shares in the unit to five companies, NEC said. The new company, NEC Biglobe, will be created in July and have about 4 billion yen ($34 million) in capital, NEC said. NEC Biglobe, 78 percent owned by NEC, intends to increase its sales to 100 billion yen by the year ending March 2009, from about 60 billion yen in the 12 months ended March 2005.
