How to Rest When You're Expecting
description: To the Editor:

title: Attack on coalition base in Afghanistan leaves 14 dead
U.S. Tightens Fuel Economy Standards for S.U.V.'s
description: BALTIMORE, March 29 A The Transportation Department announced new fuel economy standards today for sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans that will make some of them go farther on a gallon of gasoline than cars are required to do and will cover most of the biggest S.U.V.'s for the first time.

title: Downtown Atmosphere, With Food on the Side
description: ONE afternoon last summer, shortly after Zucco Le French Diner opened on Orchard Street, friends and I took over one of two cafe tables set up on the sidewalk for some midday salads and merguez sandwiches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PHANG, HELEN
description: PHANG--Helen. As someone who had the privilege of working with Helen Phang for 20 years, I want to express my infinite gratitude for the knowledge and assistance she gave me. Helen was one of those rare individuals who was not afraid to speak her mind or do what she believed was the right thing. For all this and more I will always remember her with affection. My deepest condolences to her daughter Peggy and the rest of her family. Mark A. Jofe, MD

title: Trade Truce With China in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 - Two of China's most relentless critics in Congress announced a temporary cease-fire on Tuesday in their long-running attack on China's foreign-exchange practices.

title: Getting Textbooks Cheaper From India
description: Vikas Rajkumar, an engineering student at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., has found a way to save up to $1,000 a year on textbooks. He buys them in India when he visits his home there, or has relatives ship them to him.

title: Enron Prosecutors Drop Some Charges and Rest Case
description: HOUSTON, March 28 - After more than eight weeks and 22 witnesses, the government rested its case on Tuesday against two former Enron chief executives, Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, setting the stage for the defense to begin its bid to keep them out of prison.

title: After Hard Lessons, a New Game Plan for Hurricane Seasons
description: BATON ROUGE, La., March 28  Federal and state emergency officials promised a different approach on Tuesday to the coming hurricane season, saying they would no longer use "last resort" shelters like the Superdome to house displaced residents.

title: Gay movie's success echoes in Seoul's closet
Japan rejects Chinese slave laborers' suit
Critics Raise Concerns Over 9/11 Memorial Exits
description: For two years, planners and architects have worked in the public spotlight on almost every aspect of design for the World Trade Center memorial and its museum: how much of it will be underground, how the waterfalls will work, how the names of victims will be arranged around the sunken pools, how the unidentified remains will be stored.

title: Municipal Workers Strike in Britain, Closing Schools and Offices
description: LONDON, March 28 - Local government workers walked off their jobs across Britain on Tuesday, closing schools, libraries and other community centers in a one-day strike over reductions in pension benefits.

title: Protests in France Over Youth Labor Law Turn Violent
description: PARIS, March 28 - France was racked by strikes and demonstrations that turned violent on Tuesday, the latest act in a nationwide political and social drama aimed at forcing the government to rescind a new youth labor law.

title: U.S. Arrests 7 on Charges of Credit Data Trading
description: The Secret Service yesterday announced seven arrests in five states and the District of Columbia as part of a continuing crackdown on online forums where credit card data and other stolen consumer information is routinely traded.

title: Mexico Pledges to Extradite Drug Traffickers to the U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, March 28 - President Vicente Fox of Mexico said Tuesday that his government would begin suspending trials against suspected drug traffickers wanted in the United States and extradite them for prosecution in American courts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUSNETZ, GERALDINE
description: KUSNETZ--Geraldine. Of Flushing, New York on March 27, 2006. Loving wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of William (Roberta), Martin (Ellen), Nathalie Hillman (Lee). Cherished grandmother of David, Stephen and Rebecca, Meredith, Robin, Felicia, Joshua and Allison. Services at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, at 10:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Myasthenia Gravis Foundation.

title: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sale $3.22 million 2604 Third Avenue (at 140th Street) Mott Haven, Bronx A medical center is to move into this 25,870-square-foot five-story brick warehouse, formerly used by a publishing company to store books. Buyer: Mike Kane Seller: H. W. Wilson Co. Broker: David Simone, Massey Knakal Realty Services

title: How to Rest When You're Expecting (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Lays Off Hundreds of White-Collar Employees
description: DETROIT, March 28 - General Motors laid off several hundred white-collar workers on Tuesday, its latest move in a restructuring plan that is cutting deeply into all ranks of the company.

title: Fake ID at the border
This Year's Highlights
description: Art exhibitions abound all over the country. Here is a selection of the latest offerings.

title: Native Works, Reborn
description: The University of Alaska Museum of the North has a striking design, and its arts and crafts pieces tell a colorful story of the state.

title: Slide Show: Currents
description: Turning objects into objets, it almost wiggles as it walks and more.

title: Slide Show: Personal Shopper
description: Botanicals, pink posies and prairie blossoms make a soft bed for spring naps.

title: Slide Show: Now Showing: Wrists, Shins, Etc.
description: Those on fashion's fringe are cutting suits that appear to have gone through the laundry by mistake.

title: Viewing a Solar Eclipse
description: Schoolchildren in Ghana were among those viewing a solar eclipse sweeping from Brazil northeast to Mongolia.

title: Frances Elite C.E.O. Club May Admit First Woman
description: If they pull off the trans-Atlantic merger they are discussing, Alcatel and Lucent Technologies will have many integration challenges ahead of them. There are potential issues related to national security, customer base and corporate cultures, just to name a few.

title: Slide Show: Gear Test With Cindy Reid
description: Golfers have clung to their outdated cotton polos even as synthetic fabrics that dry fast and wick away sweat have become the norm in other sports.

title: Michael Eisner as Wannabe TV Host
description: Last night, Michael Eisner, the former chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, returned to television with his new CNBC show, Conversations with Michael Eisner. We here at DealBook were a bit unsure what to think: at times, he came across as an unwatchable pompous chief executive, but at other times we were impressed that he seemed to have a sense of humor and might actually be a real live person.

title: Rumors of CBS Bid Lift Univisions Stock
description: Investors pounced on Hispanic television giant Univision  on Tuesday amid rumors that CBS chief Leslie Moonves is searching for a partner to make an offer for the network after claiming earlier that he was an unlikely bidder.

title: Hedge Fund Hopes for a Higher Lexar Bid Fade
description: Shares of Lexar Media slid Tuesday, as the possibility of a higher price for the sale of the flash-memory product maker diminished. Earlier this month, Micron Technology agreed to acquire Lexar in an all-stock deal that valued Lexar at $690 million, a premium of about 19 percent to its stock price at the time.

title: Softbank Taps 11 Banks for Vodafone Buy
description: Softbank is seeking a one-year loan from about 11 banks to help fund its 1.8 trillion yen ($15.3 billion) purchase of Vodafone Groups Japanese mobile-phone unit, bankers involved in the transaction said.

title: Wall Street C.E.O.s: Their Money Is Where Their Stock Is
description: With Wall Street earnings soaring in 2005, by years end Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers, Bear Stearns, Morgan Stanley, Citigroup and J.P. Morgan each saw their stock climb about the same amount they increased their C.E.O.s pay: 25 percent on average.

title: Yahoo Japan in Talks With Online Bank
description: Yahoo Japan Corporation, the countrys most visited Web portal, said on Wednesday that it was in talks about a possible alliance with Japan Net Bank, an online bank controlled by the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation.

title: Private Equity Suitors Gear Up for New ITV Offer
description: The venture capital consortium stalking ITV is planning to present a revised offer  with a cash alternative  to the broadcasters board for approval before the weekend, The Times of London reported. The Apax, Goldman Sachs and Blackstone group is preparing to stitch together a new deal, which requires a further 1.3 billion pounds worth of new ITV shares to be underwritten in case existing shareholders want to sell out en masse.

title: Yale Cuts Ties With Hedge Fund It Helped Found
description: Yale University helped Christopher Hohn build one of Europes most successful and activist hedge funds. Now, Yales $500 million investment and Hohns firm are parting company, according to The Washington Post.

title: Johnnie Cochran Firm Merges With Rival
description: The national Cochran Firm, a plaintiffs firm founded by the late Johnnie Cochran Jr. that started a Miami outpost in 2004, is merging with a Miami plaintiffs firm and increasing its south Florida presence.

title: Linden Lab Offers Toehold in Games Industry Without the Big Pricetag
description: Linden Labs online virtual world Second Life just grabbed an $11 million round of funding from investors including Amazon founder and CEO Jeffrey P. Bezos. But whats the financial appeal to investors? For one, they want to find some way to ride the boom in online games, but without the Hollywood-size cost.

title: Vienna Prosecutor Issues Arrest Warrants in Refco Affair
description: The Vienna public prosecutor issued arrest warrants Tuesday for Phillip Bennett, the former head of the commodities and futures brokerage firm  Refco, and the son of a former president of the bank that loaned Bennett hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Macquarie Joins Consortium Bidding for British Airports Operator
description: Grupo Ferrovial has appointed Macquarie Bank as a joint financial adviser to its consortium which is bidding for British airports operator BAA. The appointment means Macquarie has effectively ruled itself out as a rival bidder for BAA.

title: After BlackBerry, eBay Steps Up to the Patent Plate
description: The lawsuit that nearly shut down the countrys BlackBerry e-mail devices vaulted the normally obscure issue of patents into the national spotlight this winter. But for all the attention that battle received, it pales in significance to a similar case  entitled eBay v. MercExchange  that will be argued at the U.S. Supreme Court on Wednesday.

title: Record Fine Urged in Gemstar Case
description: Henry C. Yuen, former chief executive of Gemstar-TV Guide International, should pay $60.9 million for presiding over an accounting fraud at the company, the Securities and Exchange Commission says in a court filing. The agencys proposed fine includes a $15.7 million civil penalty, which would be the largest S.E.C. fine ever for an individual in an accounting case.

title: European Commission to Sanction Spain Over Blocked Bid
description: The European Unions internal market commissioner said Tuesday that he would propose legal action against Spain for rushing through regulations that would allow its authorities to block a proposed 29.1 billion takeover of the Spanish utility Endesa by E.ON of Germany.

title: Apple Computer Executive to Depart
description: Avadis Tevanian, former head of Apple Computers software business, is leaving the company after nearly a decade to pursue other interests, the company said Tuesday.

title: Cablevision Closer to Big Payout
description: Cablevisions big dividend is moving forward. Three weeks after reviving plans for a $3 billion payout, the Bethpage, N.Y., cable TV operator has tentatively settled a lawsuit that sought to block the companys plans. The settlement requires court approval, but in the meantime the board has asked two independent directors to consider a special one-time dividend.

title: Temasek Wont Take Management Role at Standard Chartered
description: Temasek HoldingsStandard Chartered or other banks it has bought stakes in, an executive said.

title: Intel Defends Business Practices in Europe
description: Intel is confident the way it runs its business is legal, the companys chairman said on Tuesday, commenting on an antitrust investigation by the European Commission.

title: Yukos Is Pushed Closer to Bankruptcy
description: A Moscow court appointed a bankruptcy administrator on Tuesday for Yukos, once Russias largest private oil company, pushing it closer to insolvency and the probable nationalization of its remaining assets.

title: Biovail Shareholders Follow Suit
description: Lawyers for Biovail Corp. shareholders said Tuesday they have launched a $4 billion lawsuit against Bank of America Securities, hedge fund S.A.C. Capital Management LLC, and others for allegedly spreading false information in a short-selling bear attack on the Canadian drug company.

title: Enron Prosecutors Drop Some Charges and Rest Case
description: After more than eight weeks and 22 witnesses, the government rested its case on Tuesday against two former Enron chief executives, Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, setting the stage for the defense to begin its bid to keep them out of prison.

title: Pressure Mounts on G.M. Chief
description: General Motors is reeling and Rick Wagoner, its chairman and chief executive, is under pressure to save the company as well as his job. Whether he can do either is far from certain. G.M.s shaky financial situation has put Mr. Wagoner in a harsh spotlight and woken up G.M.s board, with its newest member, Jerome B. York, who is allied with its biggest investor, demanding that Mr. Wagoner take action.

title: LNK Partners Closes Its Debut Fund
description: LNK Partners, a buyout firm that plans to specialize in consumer retail investments, has closed its debut fund at $400 million, well ahead of the $275 million cap originally set on the fund.

title: Horoscopes of the Rich and Famous
description: Whats your sign? If you are a Virgo, weve got some good news for you. Turns out, more members of the Forbes billionaires list share your zodiac sign than any other. That was the magazines finding after trolling through all the birth dates they have collected on the worlds wealthiest.

title: Burkle Sows More Wild Oats
description: Famed supermarket investor Ron Burkle appears to have wooed Wild Oats Market in his bid to raise his ownership stake in the company. Burkle, through his hedge fund, Yucaipa, increased his stake in the organic foods chain to 15 percent, and the company amended its shareholder rights agreement to allow him to buy up to 20 percent of its stock.

title: TA Associates to Sell Partners on Recent Acquisition
description: TA Associates , which just closed on two funds, has a new sales pitchfor its limited partners. The firm wants its investors to do business with its newest portfolio company, eSecLending, which it has just purchased from Britain-based financial services concern Old Mutual.

title: Intel Creates Brazilian Venture Fund
description: Intel Capital, the venture arm of chipmaker Intel, has created a venture fund that will invest $50 million in Brazilian start-ups, the latest step in an effort to expand its business in emerging nations.

title: Payment Technology Provider I4 Raises $27 Million
description: I4 Commerce  has raised $27.4 million in its latest round of funding to convince more retailers to support its buy now, pay later platform for consumers. The alternative payment technology provider raised its fourth round of capital from an investment group led by New York-based hedge fund Kingdon Capital.

title: Seattle Genetics Plans Share Sale
description: Seattle Genetics plans to sell 7.3 million shares in a follow-on stock offering, it said Tuesday after the markets closed. Additionally, the company plans to sell 1.1 million shares in a private placement to investment funds affiliated with Baker Brothers Investments at a share price equal to that paid by investors in the public share offering.

title: NEC to Spin Off Internet Unit Biglobe
description: NEC  said Tuesday that it would spin off its Internet service provider unit, Biglobe, as a separate company as part of the Japanese electronics makers plans to revive sagging profits.

title: Citigroup Bond Executive Retires
description: Citigroups Chris Fitzmaurice, who helped Salomon Brothers recover from its 1991 Treasury trading scandal and rose to run the United States government bond desk, is retiring after 22 years with the bank and its predecessors.

title: McClatchy Accepts Bids
description: McClatchy on Tuesday accepted offers for 12 newspapers that it does not want to keep after its $4.5 billion takeover of fellow publisher Knight Ridder, kicking off an auction that could last several months.

title: Father Knows Best
description: The political death of Mayor Sharpe James has been greatly exaggerated, according to his son, John James, a South Ward council candidate. Caught outside his fathers office yesterday afternoon, Mr. James  a national guardsman who is listed as J. Sharpe James on the ballot  said that his father should not be counted out just yet.

title: Exxon  Is Seen as Interested in  British Gas Company
description: Exxon Mobils interest in BG Group has not waned, according to traders, who feel BGs interests in Kazakhstan is what Exxon is keen on acquiring. The talk is that Exxon will attempt a knockout bid valuing the company at 900 pence a share, or about 31.6 billion pounds.

title: Moroccan Minimalism
description: The writer Tahir Shah relocated his family from a cramped apartment in London to a 10-bedroom mansion in Casablanca.

title: Bids Due for Pfizers Consumer Unit; Will Colgate Bite?
description: If you were thinking of buying a nearly $4 billion-in-sales consumer healthcare business, it is time to speak up. First-round bids are due on Wednesday for Pfizers collection of over-the-counter products, an array of household brands that includes Listerine, Benadryl, Rogaine and Zantac.

title: The Mind of the Machine
description: A morose, quiet mood prevailed at City Hall and around Newark yesterday, one day after Mayor Sharpe James announced departure.

title: Slide Show: An 'Aha' Moment for Bonnard's Art
description: Pierre Bonnard's art, steeped in memory, registers in the here and now, at the instant it is seen, demanding repeated viewings that then disclose fresh discoveries.

title: Campaign Like Its 1946

description: Selborne Journal: 29 March 1759:  Sowed half a Gallon more, four rows of Marrow-fats, in the lower field-garden: the rows are four feet apart; the former sowing five.

title: Lear to Swap Unit for Stake in Wilbur Ross Venture
description: Wilbur Ross auto-parts rollup is gathering steam.

title: Legroom
description: This spring, there is no such thing as the wrong trousers.

title: A One-Ring Show
description: It is no longer the "greatest show on earth," but the circus at Madison Square Garden is peculiarly satisfying and entertaining.

title: JupiterResearch, Prophet of the Tech Boom, Fetches $10 Million
description: It may be a small deal, but it contains a lot of history of the (still relatively young) Internet era.

title: Scenes from Alcatraz
Debate Flares Over The Israel Lobby
description: A fierce debate is being waged in opinionland over the merits of The Israel Lobby, a working paper by John Mearsheimer, a University of Chicago political scientist, and Stephen Walt, a Harvard government professor. Last week, the paper was published in the London Review of Books. Max Boot of the Los Angeles Times is the latest to weigh in, accusing Mearsheimer and Walt of paranoia, faulty reasoning, and a terminal lack of seriousness.

title: Another Hedge Fund Goes Hollywood
description: Hedge funds in the United States have already warmed to the movie-making industry  witness Dune Capital, the Soros Fund spinoff that plans to invest $325 million in Fox releases  and now the fad has travelled overseas.

title: Taking It to the Streets
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Rethinking Vouchers?
description: Is Cory Booker reconsidering his support for public school vouchers?

title: Time to Think About Education
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans March 29 column, Facts and Folly

title: Oh, What a Feeling
description: Cory Booker (Associated Press)

title: Salmon in Curry Sauce
description: Mark Bittman prepares his recipe for salmon in a cucumber curry sauce.

title: AB Ports Rejects $3.8 Billion Approach From Buyout Group
description: With apologies to The Graduate, we have one word for you: ports.

title: Whirlpool-Maytag Deal Is Approved
description: So much for the wisdom of antitrust lawyers and unnamed sources. After The Wall Street Journal, Reuters, Bloomberg News and The Associated Press all reported that federal regulators were likely to challenge Whirlpools proposed purchase of Maytag, antitrust watchdogs at the Department of Justice have waved through the $1.79 billion deal.

title: Leave the Light Off
description: Shedding Light: Left, Urea on East 28th Street. Right, the Pegu Club on Houston Street in SoHo.(Left, Shannon Greer for The New York Times; right, Marvi Lacar for The New York Times)

title: Check the Strength of Your Cellphone Coverage
description: Today, another e-mail from another cellular rep:

title: Kristof the Crusader
description: People keep calling me a crusader, and they mean it as a compliment. The latest comes from the Dallas Morning News editors:http://dallasmorningviews.beloblog.com/archives/2006/03/kristof_crusade.html

title: Good Medicine for the Heart
description: I had an excellent morning, and Im still feeling the effects of it as I write this at 2200. The sun vaulted off the edge of the earth with a stunning light, mingling with the cool breeze thats been swirling around for the last few days, and whipping the American and Iraqi flags that fly side by side at our brigade headquarters.

title: Concerns Voiced in Europe Over Microsoft's Next Windows
description: BRUSSELS, March 29 - Microsoft and the European Commission once again may be on a collision course over the shape of the company's next-generation computer operating system, Windows Vista.

title: Bush Rejects Idea of Boycotting Meeting in Russia
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 - President Bush said Wednesday that it would be a mistake for the United States to boycott the Group of 8 meeting in Russia this summer.

title: A Nation of Immigrants Faces the Current Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOWLAND, ELIZABETH PHILLIPS
description: HOWLAND--Elizabeth Phillips, 88, of Fairfield, CT and West Chop, MA died March 27, 2006. Wife of the late Silas W. Howland Jr., mother of Libby Howland, Silas W. Howland III, Dolly Campbell, and Jenny Howland. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, April 1, 2006 at 11:00 a.m. at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, CT.

title: New Power Seen for Mexico's Media Giant
description: MEXICO CITY, March 29 - Mexico's largest media company, Grupo Televisa, is at the center of a bitter debate over proposed laws that critics say strengthen the company's dominant position.

title: Otto Schenk, Opera Director, Says 'Don Pasquale' Is His Last Met Production
description: "I'm doing this from the Beyond," said the elderly man in the overcoat.

title: The New Face of an Oil Giant
description: If Rex W. Tillerson has his way, Exxon Mobil will no longer be the oil company that environmentalists love to hate.

title: For the Ravenous Antiquer, 70 Dealers, 5 Days a Week
description: Antiques shows come and go, but for those constantly on the hunt, a permanent market, Center 44, is open at 222 East 44th Street. It has 70 dealers whose wares -- antiques and some reproductions -- range from early Chinese to 17th-century French and midcentury modern. One dealer, the English Looking Glass of London, sells gilt-frame reproduction mirrors (below), as well as reproduction period furniture. Prices for mirrors start at $2,850. Many decorators and designers shop at the center, and the public is welcome. It is open Monday through Friday from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; (212) 450-7988.

title: Russia Says Belarus Must Now Pay Market Price for Gas
description: MOSCOW, March 30 A Russia's state-controlled gas monopoly today announced that it would require Belarus, a Kremlin ally whose economy is subsidized by Russia, to begin paying market prices for natural gas.

title: Film Review: A bank heist managed by twists, turns and talent
Scans Show Different Growth for Intelligent Brains
description: The brains of highly intelligent children develop in a different pattern from those with more average abilities, researchers have found after analyzing a series of imaging scans collected over 17 years.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Supreme Court arguments in the case of Salim Ahmed Hamdan, who is challenging the administration's plans to try him before a military commission, referred incorrectly to Lt. Cmdr. Charles Swift of the Navy and Harry Schneider. They are among Mr. Hamdan's lawyers, but they did not argue (or testify) before the court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WYCKOFF, WILLIAM S.
description: WYCKOFF--William S. The Directors, Officers, Staff, Members and Advisory Board of The Wyckoff House & Association wish to express their deep sorrow on the death of William F. Wyckoff and their deepest condolences to his children, grandchildren and other close family members on their loss. It was through Bill's unselfish devotion, tireless energy, and dogged determination over a 40 year period that the Pieter Claesen Wyckoff House originally built in 1652, was saved from destruction and designated as New York City's first landmark in 1965 and restored and opened to the public in 1982 as a museum dedicated to the City's early Dutch history. 20 years later, Bill was instrumental in the Museum's redevelopment as the Wyckoff Farmhouse Museum and Education Center. Bill served as the Association's First Vice-President from 1957 to 1967 and then as President from 1967 to 1972. From that point, he served as Chairman of the Executive Committee until 1989. Bill was the eighth great-grandson of Pieter Claesen Wyckoff, who arrived in New Amsterdam on March 4, 1637. E. Lisk Wyckoff, Jr. Chairman Naj Wikoff, President Sean Sawyer, Executive Dir

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Turkey: 3 Dead As The Police Battle Kurdish Protesters
description: Three people died, hundreds of others were injured and more than 200 were arrested in two days of clashes between the police and Kurdish protestors in Diyarbakir, in the mainly Kurdish southeast, officials said. The fighting began after funerals for four Kurdish rebels killed by Turkish troops last week. Television news reports showed groups of mostly young people hurling stones and Molotov cocktails at armored police vehicles, as the police used tear gas to disperse the crowds. At least 130 police officers were injured, and the local headquarters of the country's governing Justice and Development Party was ransacked, the Anatolian News Agency reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINHARDT, JEAN STETTHEIMER
description: STEINHARDT--Jean Stettheimer. A consistent and significant contributor to many Santa Barbara charities and organizations, Jean Stettheimer Steinhardt passed away on Saturday, March 25. She was the daughter of the late Florence and Walter Stettheimer of Atherton, CA, the sister of the late Barbara S. Adler and the sister-in-law of the late Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President and General Manager of The New York Times, both of New York City. Mrs. Steinhardt lived her later years at the Casa Dorinda in Montecito, CA. Jean was a quiet force in making public and private gifts with a definite plan and a strong sense that such were her responsibilities. She did not seek public recognition but would have wanted to be remembered as a person who made a positive difference. Jean had a zest for life and leaves a legacy of wisdom, of strong conviction and of resolute character. She always cared and taught by example that life could be a blend of social concern and glamorous fun. She is survived by her daughters Felicia W. Rogan of Charlottesville, VA and Jill W. Cartter of Beverly Hills, CA. She was also the beloved friend and quintessential aunt of Bobbie Adler Katzander of New York City. No services are to be held. In keeping with her great sense of charitable responsibility donations can be made to the Cancer Center of Santa Barbara.

title: Myers Wants Frisbee to Be a Collector's Item
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 29 - There have been many, many players more famous than Mike Myers. But somehow, year after year, Myers winds up on the same field with all the talented guys, delighted to be in on a wonderful joke.

title: Denis Twitchett, 80, Scholar Who Created 'History of China', Is Dead
description: Denis Twitchett, a scholar of imperial China best known for his role in conceiving and creating "The Cambridge History of China," a monumental 15-volume study widely regarded as the most comprehensive history of China in the English language, died on Feb. 24 in Cambridge, England. He was 80.

title: Cost of Celebrations Rises in the N.F.L.
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., March 29 - Forget the situps, using a pylon as a putter, sliding down a goal post or rocking a football to sleep. N.F.L. players are going to have to become more creative -- and maybe more conservative -- after owners voted to limit touchdown celebrations at the league meetings Wednesday.

title: Hamas Cabinet Is Sworn In, Widening Break With the Israelis
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, March 29 - The new Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya, and his cabinet were sworn in Wednesday, formally putting the Islamic movement Hamas in charge of the Palestinian Authority and marking an almost total break in the government's contact with Israel.

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: Ericson and Ziegler's Interventionist Art at M.I.T.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 25 - A favorite fantasy of the art vanguard is the idea of intervention: the artist introduces something into the cultural mainstream that may or may not be recognized as art, but causes those who see it to reconsider and, ideally, to change their relationship to conventional values.

title: Arts, Briefly; An Opera Sampler
description: New York City Opera's annual tasting menu of new works takes on a synthetic character this year, with four pieces in the lineup featuring electronic scores. The house this week released the program for "Vox 2006: Showcasing American Composers," a chance to hear excerpts from new operas performed by City Opera artists. It is being held on May 6 and 7, for the first time at the Skirball Center of New York University. Tickets are free. The electronic-minded composers are Mason Bates, Justine F. Chen, Anne LeBaron and Stephen Andrew Taylor. Also on the bill is "Frau Margot," a new work by Thomas Pasatieri, with a libretto by Frank Corsaro. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: A Nation of Immigrants Faces the Current Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Settling in, Hamas quickly rebukes aid cuts by West
Man Is Arrested in Florida in New Jersey Woman's Death
description: Following a tip, the authorities in Florida arrested a New Jersey man yesterday in connection with the death of a woman found in her garage with a bag over her face and a savage blow to her head.

title: Charges in Swissair's demise
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Tuesday about some polygamists' views of "Big Love," the new HBO series about a fictional polygamous family, referred incorrectly to a disclaimer that notes that the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints renounced polygamy in 1890. It appeared at the start of the first episode; it does not appear with every one.

title: Knicks Let Their Defense Down. So What's New?
description: After 70 games, the Knicks are still working on the basics. And they do not seem any closer to getting them right than they did coming out of training camp.

title: Hamas Cabinet Is Sworn In, Widening Break With the Israelis
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, March 29  The new Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya, and his cabinet were sworn in Wednesday, formally putting the Islamic movement Hamas in charge of the Palestinian Authority and marking an almost total break in the government's contact with Israel.

title: American Reporter Kidnapped in Baghdad Is Released
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 30  Jill Carroll, the American reporter who was kidnapped in Baghdad nearly three months ago, was freed today on a street in western Baghdad and walked into the office of an Islamic political party clutching a letter from her captors asking the party to help her.

title: Russian rocket carries first Brazilian into space
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Automakers Give Drivers the Power They Prefer, and Fuel Efficiency Lags For two decades, automakers have been developing technology that could make vehicles go farther on a gallon of gasoline. But instead, they have chosen pep and size, responding to consumers' preferences by putting that technology into making heavier vehicles accelerate faster. [Page A1.]

title: Soccer: European nobility keeps the arrivistes at bay
For a Parish in the Suburbs, It's Time for a Big New Church
description: PEARL RIVER, N.Y., March 29 - Msgr. John O'Keefe considers himself an effective, engaging priest. But since becoming the pastor of St. Margaret of Antioch Church nearly three years ago, he has heard one persistent complaint from parishioners after weekend Mass.

title: Automakers Use New Technology to Beef Up Muscle, Not Mileage
description: John Elsden relishes the excitement of the mint-condition '65 Mustang convertible he takes out of his garage in eastern Virginia only on sunny days. The sporty coupe with a 289-cubic-inch engine growls, rumbles, vibrates and shakes when he puts his foot on the gas pedal.

title: Senate Considers Competing Immigration Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  Senators plunged into a debate today on how the United States should balance compassion with caution in its treatment of 11 million illegal immigrants in the post-9/11 era.

title: Women in Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Would Speed Challenge to Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, introduced a bill Wednesday that would put lawsuits challenging the National Security Agency's domestic surveillance program on a fast track to the Supreme Court.

title: How useful is a fast watch? In F1, it's all about timing
Scans Show Different Growth for Intelligent Brains
description: The brains of highly intelligent children develop in a different pattern from those with more average abilities, researchers have found after analyzing a series of imaging scans collected over 17 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURNETT, ROBERT D.
description: BURNETT--Robert D. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert D. Burnett, associated with The Times from December 1939 until retiring in October 1974.

title: It's Porkball for Yankees and the Bronx
description: WELL into a City Council hearing this week on the proposal for a new Yankee Stadium, one of the lawmakers recalled why he and his colleagues were there in the first place. "The name of this here issue is not black, not white, it's green," said the councilman, Thomas White Jr. of Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FRIEDMAN, REGINIA, M.D.
description: FRIEDMAN--Reginia, M.D. 1/3/59-3/30/01. You are so sorely missed in this world, Little Sister. Love you always, Esther, Your Schvester

title: Albany Acts on Behalf of Patients Lacking Aid
description: The Legislature agreed yesterday to require hospitals to give discounts to poor patients -- and even some middle-income people -- who have no health insurance.

title: Study Backs Equal Coverage for Mental Ills
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 - Providing insurance coverage for mental illness equal to that for physical illness does not drive up the cost of mental health care as many insurers feared, a new study of health benefits for federal employees says.

title: The Cost of Invading Iraq: Imponderables Meet Uncertainties
description: THE question of whether it was worth invading Iraq is being asked with increasing frequency and fervency.

title: A Feminine Mystique All Her Own
description: Ladue, Mo. - RECENTLY, a biography of Phyllis Schlafly, the Missourian who traveled the country battling the equal rights amendment with a hairdo like a treble clef, arrived to make a case for its subject as one of the most influential figures in modern American political history. Among critics who found this thesis convincing, some faulted the book, saying it failed to reconcile the discrepancies between the antifeminist positions Mrs. Schlafly maintained and the accomplished professional life she has pursued. The book, "Phyllis Schlafly and Grassroots Conservatism: A Woman's Crusade" (Princeton University Press), is a flattering portrayal but also an impersonal one, largely because the author, Donald T. Critchlow, a historian from Mrs. Schlafly's hometown, St. Louis, conducted his research in archives. The two never sat down for a talk, Mrs. Schlafly, now 81, explained in the sunroom of her brick colonial house here in a suburb of St. Louis one afternoon not long ago, even though it would seem there is still much she has to say.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the Emirates Group, the Dubai airline, referred imprecisely to the airplane shown. It was made by Airbus, which has an order from the company for 45 superjumbo A380 aircraft. (Boeing has an order from the line for 63 planes, but its craft were not shown.)

title: It Almost Wiggles As It Walks
description: What happens when Rod Arad, a furniture designer, teams up with the fashion designer Issey Miyake? One result is Mr. Arad's plastic Ripple Chair, above, dressed smartly in a snug, colorful cardigan (otherwise known as a slipcover) created by Mr. Miyake and his collaborator Dai Fujiwara. The chair, to be shown next week at the Salone di Mobile in Milan, resembles a curvaceous woman with ample hips and skinny legs. The chair is $800; the cover, of woven cotton and nylon, is $1,360. The ensemble will be available in the fall at Issey Miyake, at 119 Hudson Street (North Moore Street) in Manhattan; (212) 226-0100.

title: A Lawbreaking Mannequin's Fresh Start
description: DENVER, March 29 - Tillie the mannequin got Greg Pringle in trouble with the law, but her life of crime might have saved her own neck.

title: To Pacify a Quirky Space, The Best Angle Was a Curve
description: Sometimes a loft space needs a little order, a little structure. When Lee Day and Ursula Endlicher approached nArchitects, a New York firm, about the large yet awkward lower floor of their TriBeCa duplex, they were given a simple solution. A curving plywood wall was used to divide but also unify the 1,000-square-foot area, which resembles an obstacle course interrupted by columns, piers and even an unused elevator shaft. The wall, said Eric Bunge, a principal at nArchitects, "maximizes space while providing cohesiveness."

title: Port Operator Rejects Bid
description: Associated British Ports Holdings, one of the biggest operators of ports in Britain, rejected a 2.2 billion ($3.8 billion) takeover bid yesterday from the Goldman Sachs Group, Singapore and a Canadian pension fund.

title: A provocateur's stamp on French film
Russia Says Belarus Must Now Pay Market Price for Gas
description: MOSCOW, March 30 A Russia's state-controlled gas monopoly today announced that it would require Belarus, a Kremlin ally whose economy is subsidized by Russia, to begin paying market prices for natural gas.

title: Seoul office of U.S. fund raided
Starting Over in a Caliph's Castle
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco - SETTING up house in a North African slum is not at the top of many wish lists. But as the writer Tahir Shah explained recently, his family's relocation from a cramped apartment in London to a 10-bedroom mansion in this sprawling coastal city was partly to help his two children escape the cultural insularity of his own youth.

title: Briefly: Court bans marriage for nonresident gays
Review: Rousseau's Dog
Listen to the Testimony: Only the Sleazy Know This Brooklyn
description: It could be argued that one of the most intriguing characters in the trial of Louis J. Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa is not a person, but a place. As absorbing as the witnesses, the lawyers and the two defendants is the borough of Brooklyn, which has arisen in the trial as something like an empire of the ill-fated and often illicitly employed.

title: A long-lasting Asian love affair with 'moving system machines'
A Studio That Refuses to Think Small
description: IN his tiny Upper East Side apartment, with its single, shallow closet, Giuseppe Pica has room for only what he absolutely needs.

title: Democracy in Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Does the Sex of the Surgeon Matter?
description: LAST June, after Jerri Hafizi, a 5-foot-3 construction firm executive, lost 65 pounds, she asked a plastic surgeon to tighten the loose skin around her torso and lift her breasts. But the surgeon seemed not to understand what she wanted. He squeezed Ms. Hafizi's skin in his fists, she said, and told her that the only way to solve her problem was with implants.

title: Italy Grants Asylum to Afghan Christian Convert
description: ROME, March 29 - A man who faced the death penalty in Afghanistan for converting to Christianity was secretly flown to Italy, where he was granted asylum under round-the-clock protection by the government, the Italian prime minister said Wednesday evening.

title: GM announces plan to sell stake in Isuzu
Doubt Cast on Stockpile of a Vaccine for Bird Flu
description: A bird flu vaccine being stockpiled by the government in preparation for a possible pandemic protects only about half the people who receive it, scientists are reporting. In addition, it must be given in such high doses that if a pandemic were to start soon, manufacturers could not begin to make enough vaccine for all who would need it.

title: Maryland Acts to Take Over Failing Baltimore Schools
description: BALTIMORE, March 29  Invoking the federal No Child Left Behind law, the Maryland school board voted today to take control of four Baltimore high schools with chronically low achievement and strip the City of Baltimore from direct operation of seven more middle schools.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Fire Warning Issued For Dry Spring
description: Faced with an exceptionally dry spring, state environmental officials imposed statewide restrictions yesterday in an effort to control the number of forest and brush fires. The environmental protection commissioner, Lisa P. Jackson, placed restrictions on all campfires unless they are contained within a stone or metal fire ring. Ms. Jackson also urged people to be cautious with cigarette butts and machinery that discharges sparks. There have been at least a dozen brush fires in New Jersey in the last month, officials said. JOHN HOLL (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Belarus Plans to Charge Defeated Candidate Who Led Protest
description: MOSCOW, March 29  Prosecutors in Belarus said Wednesday that they would bring criminal charges against a defeated presidential candidate who led an antigovernment march last week, and that they were considering lesser charges against a second candidate who organized a rally.

title: Doris Muscatine, 80, Writer on California Wine and Food, Dies
description: Doris Muscatine, a pioneering chronicler of California's wine and food culture, died Saturday at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 80.

title: Digital music is data, Apple's lawyers say
Patently ridiculous
Paid Notice: Deaths   GUILD, MARIAN STEDMAN
description: GUILD--Marian Stedman. On March 25 at age 104. She was born in Cleveland, OH on September 15, 1901 and lived there and in New York City before moving to Montclair, NJ in 1971. Wife of the late Kenneth H. Guild. Survived by a brother Charles Arthur Stedman; a daughter Nancy Weidner, a son William K. Guild; granddaughters Alyson Harkins and Cynthia Weidner; great granddaughters Courtney and Alexis Bowling, and Grace McInerney. A memorial service will be held at 1PM Saturday, April 1 at St. James Episcopal Church, 581 Valley Rd, Upper Montclair, NJ 07043. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the St. James Memorial Fund.

title: American Dreams, Foreign Flags
description: Pittsburg, Tex. - HUNDREDS of thousands of flag-waving demonstrators took to the streets in Denver, Los Angeles, Phoenix and dozens of other cities in the last week to protest harsh legislation passed by the House that would make felons of the 12 million illegal aliens living in the United States -- along with anyone who provides them with shelter, food or other services. It didn't take long for a bipartisan majority on the Senate Judiciary Committee to get the message and take a softer tack.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the former chief executive of the Raytheon Corporation, Daniel P. Burnham, that will require him to return part of his annual bonus for 2000 included an erroneous example of executives who have faced pressure or agreed to give back bonuses. (The error also appeared in an article on Jan. 12, 2005.) While government regulators are considering requiring the repayment of bonuses from two former top executives at Fannie Mae, they have not yet decided to do so.

title: Marketing humanitarian crises
Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, RUTH
description: BERNSTEIN--Ruth. July 14, 1909-March 29, 2006. Passed away peacefully at 96 years young with a lively spirit, the sharpest of minds, and a gentle wit until her last moments. Known as "Aunt" Ruth by so many, she truly enjoyed life to its fullest-with a rare spark that lit up the room and the hearts of all who knew her. Always exuding elegance, warmth and generosity, Ruth was a dedicated volunteer reader for The Jewish Guild for the Blind for over 50 years. Wife of the late Bernie Bernstein, and a devoted rock in the Brill family, she will be loved and missed by her nieces, nephews and their families: Ed Brill, Micki Levin and Michael Brill of NY; Ellen, Martin and Bonnie Brill of CA; Jeff and Yvonne Brill of NV; and Geert and Leslie Van Brandt-Brill of MD. Adored by all who knew and cared for her Aunt Ruth's vivacious spirit will live on. Contributions may be made to The Jewish Guild for the Blind and Congregation B'nai Jeshurun. A service will be held at 12:30 P.M., Thursday, March 30th at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York City.

title: A Nation of Immigrants Faces the Current Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Raiffeisen net surges 83% after buy-up spree
As Life Returns to New Orleans, So Does Crime
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 29 - The wail of police sirens is back, and gunfire again punctuates the night. As drug dealers move into flood-damaged houses, alarmed residents say that in the last few weeks, they have begun to sense a return to the bad old days before Hurricane Katrina, when crime was an omnipresent straitjacket on life in this city.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Gun Seized In School
description: Two sixth-grade boys were arrested yesterday after they were caught with a loaded .45-caliber automatic pistol in Roy H. Mann Intermediate School in Bergen Beach, said a Department of Education spokesman, Keith Kalb. Mr. Kalb said that one boy had the gun but that the other boy, who had two bullets, admitted taking the gun to school. Detective Theresa Farello, a police spokeswoman, said that the boys were charged with weapons possession. The gun, she said, belonged to Roger Stewart, 47, the boyfriend of the second boy's mother. He was charged with reckless endangerment and weapons possession. ELISSA GOOTMAN (NYT)

title: Immigrants to Be Proud Of
description: Everybody says the Republicans are split on immigration. The law-and-order types want to close the border. The free-market types want plentiful labor. But today I want to talk to the social conservatives, because it's you folks who are really going to swing this debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENRIGHT, JOAN K.
description: ENRIGHT--Joan K. of Bronxville on March 28, 2006. Wife of Joseph M. Enright. Mother of Kerry Ellen Enright and Kelly Enright Schmelter. Grandmother of Keith Patrick and Emily Brooke Schmelter. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 7-9 PM Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, April 1 at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Ursuline Provincialate, New Rochelle, NY 10804.

title: Master of lens turns to masters of ink
Jagr Dog-Ears Page in Record Book
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 28 - Jaromir Jagr has given the Rangers one of the most memorable seasons in their 80-year history. Their fans, though, will have only two more years to cherish the brilliance of the star right wing, who continues to rewrite the club's record book.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Abandoned on the Curb, Resurgent on the Internet
description: The Internet is going to the aid of New Yorkers who scavenge for discarded furniture: garbagescout.com alerts junk fans about where treasures might be found on the street, with photos that can be displayed on a cellphone and the time that has elapsed since the item was sighted. It's all free, but the immediacy of the Web means that scavengers must hurry. "Sometimes things will be gone in five minutes," said Jim Nachlin (above right), a computer programmer and confessed hoarder who started the site in January. For Mr. Nachlin, spreading news about trash treasures helps him control the clutter in his tiny apartment in Manhattan. "Instead of taking stuff home I'm posting pictures of it," he said.

title: Endesa hints it will post bond to halt deal
Roundup: Mitchell is called to look at steroids
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Officer Indicted
description: A police officer who bought electronic goods that prosecutors charge he knew were stolen has been indicted on charges of attempted grand larceny and other crimes, the authorities said yesterday. The officer, Jai Aiken, 39, who has worked for the Police Department since 1994, most recently as a housing officer in the Bronx and Queens, was the target of an undercover investigation by the department's Internal Affairs unit, according to a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney. In December, Officer Aiken bought an iPod for $150 from an undercover officer who told him it was stolen; he was arrested on Feb. 15 after the same officer sold him a flat-screen television, prosecutors said. KAREEM FAHIM (NYT)

title: A Powerful Featherweight in a Class Dominated by Bulk
description: The Gateway NX100 is a departure from the bold, powerful and heavy laptops that now seem to be the rage. It is wafer-thin, and its striking black case could elicit double and triple takes when opened on a long-distance flight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GINSBERG, VICTOR, M.D.
description: GINSBERG--Victor, M.D., 92. Died March 28 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. After a distinguished career in hematology in Brooklyn, Dr. Ginsberg retired to Florida and, at the age of 75, obtained a degree in business administration from Florida Atlantic University. After completing his undergraduate studies at the University of Michigan, Dr. Ginsberg continued his studies at Michigan's Medical School graduating in the class of 1937. He served his country as a Captain in WWII after which, he was the Director of the Blood Bank at Kings County Hospital for over 30 years, Professor of Hematology at Downstate Medical School, Director of Medicine at various Brooklyn hospitals and a pioneer in transfusion methods and leukemia treatment. Active in the International Hematological Society, he had over 50 articles published in the field. He has been a major benefactor to the University of Michigan as well as FAU. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Frances (nee Rossuck), his children, Richard and Gail Ginsberg and Jane and Marvin Brown, his beloved grandchildren, Daniel, Matthew, Rachel, Stephen, and Allison and six great grandchildren. Funeral Services at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI Friday at 12:30.

title: Leniency Request Is Denied for Officer in Louima Case
description: Nearly a decade after the station house attack on Abner Louima, an act of police brutality that had epic consequences for the city and its police force, a federal judge told a former police officer yesterday that his perjury had prevented a full accounting of the crime.

title: West Bank Withdrawal
description: Tuesday's election in Israel was a minor breakthrough. Israeli voters rightfully slammed Likud, the right-wing party of former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, casting their lot instead with Kadima, the infant party created by Ariel Sharon, who remains comatose after a severe stroke.

title: Prosecutors raid Seoul office of U.S. buyout firm
For My Next Trick, I'll Need a Broom Closet
description: TO create the illusion of space in his tiny studio apartment, Giuseppe Pica played tricks with color and scale. Artwork includes a wire whisk big enough for a giant's omelet and a pair of pencils the length of a table, paradoxically suggesting that there is room to spare.

title: Massachusetts Court Limits Same-Sex Marriages
description: BOSTON, March 30 A Massachusetts's highest court ruled today that same-sex couples who live in other states cannot get married in Massachusetts unless gay marriage is legal in their home states.

title: Chirac May Step In to Try to Resolve Crisis Over Jobs Law
description: PARIS, March 29 - President Jacques Chirac announced Wednesday that he would address the nation "in the coming days," in a deepening political crisis over the government's standoff with students and unions over a new jobs law.

title: Spanish Parliament approves greater Catalan autonomy
The International Traveler Q & A: Around the world for less
Journey Back to a Wild and Crazy Time
description: HUMAN memory is a strange mechanism. We think we remember things as if they were recorded for us and we simply play the tape back in our minds. But memory is more a reconstructed assemblage of bits and pieces, snapshots, smells and textures, than anything so linear and easy.

title: Arts, Briefly; Prince's Surprising Debut
description: At the age of 47, more than two dozen albums into his career, Prince, below, has achieved a surprising triumph: his first No. 1 debut. Though several of his albums have reached the top of the Billboard chart, none until "3121" (Universal), released last week, did so on their first week in stores. Prince's success is even more surprising given that "3121" is not available as a download on iTunes (an increasingly important sales engine), and that with 183,000 copies purchased, according to Nielsen SoundScan, it actually sold slightly fewer copies in its first week than his last CD, "Musicology," which opened at No. 3 in 2004. In other debuts this week, the rapper B.G. opened at No. 6 with "The Heart of tha Streetz, Vol. 2: I Am What I Am" (Koch), Ben Harper reached No. 7 with "Both Sides of the Gun" (Virgin) and Teddy Geiger is at No. 8 with "Underage Thinking" (Columbia). The "High School Musical" soundtrack (Disney) is at No. 2 with sales of 152,000 copies, and the British crooner James Blunt sold 111,000 copies of "Back to Bedlam" (Atlantic) to reach No. 3. Barry Manilow's appearance on "American Idol" last week gave his "Greatest Songs of the Fifties" (Arista) a big boost: it jumped 20 spots to No. 4, with 78,000 sales. BEN SISARIO

title: The Bear Behind the Bruins
description: LOS ANGELES, March 28 - U.C.L.A. Coach Ben Howland's smile, rarely seen in practice or on the sideline, has taken on an incandescent quality this week.

title: Liberian Seized to Stand Trial on War Crimes
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 29 - Charles G. Taylor, the warlord who became Liberia's president, was captured Wednesday after a dramatic 24 hours in which he disappeared from the villa in Nigeria where he had lived in exile and then was recognized at a remote outpost as he tried to leave the country.

title: The Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League Open in Dallas
description: The Spring North American Bridge Championships of the American Contract Bridge League begin today in Dallas and run through April 9. These Nationals, as they are commonly known, were last in Dallas nine years ago. Then, the best piece of declarer play came in the Open Swiss Teams. It was perpetrated by the Norwegian superstar Geir Helgemo on the diagramed deal.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on March 13 about "Ring of Fire," at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, misidentified the performer who sang "I Still Miss Someone." She was Beth Malone. (Lari White is another member of the cast.)

description: Following is a timeline of the sexual-assault case roiling Duke University.

title: G.O.P. Risking Hispanic Votes on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 - The battle among Republicans over immigration policy and border security is threatening to undercut a decade-long effort by President Bush and his party to court Hispanic voters, just as both parties are gearing up for the 2006 elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOONE, THOMAS F.
description: NOONE--Thomas F. Age 74, of Sea Bright, NJ and Rio Mar, PR died March 25, 2006. Beloved husband of Mary Jane, beloved father of Caragh Woods (Michael) and Patrick Donnell (Alicia) and grandfather of Helen and Patrick Noone. Proud graduate of Regis High School, Saint Peter's College and Fordham Law School. Retired senior partner Emmet, Marvin and Martin. Funeral Mass on Saturday, April 1, 2006 at 11 AM at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Route 36, Highlands, NJ. There are no calling hours, cremation private and no flowers please. Memorials may be made to Regis High School, 55 East 84th Street, New York, New York 10028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDBERG, DONALD
description: LANDBERG--Donald, of Pisgah Forest, NC, formerly of Neponsit, NY, on March 29, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude. Devoted father of William Landberg (Louise), Laura Berkowitz (Mark), Suzanne Minken and Peter Worth. Loving grandfather of Terrence, Jesse, John, Daniel, Geoffrey, Zachary, Amanda, Peter Jon, Candace, Steven, Kimberly, Mary Beth and Michael. Greatgrandfather of four. Services Thursday, March 30th at 10:30AM, Bernheim - Apter Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Robert Wood Johnson Hospital, Pediatric Unit, c/o Dr. Daniel Notterman.

description: BERLIN, March 30 A A day after the United Nations Security Council approved a heavily compromised statement criticizing the Iranian nuclear program, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice today raised the idea of imposing sanctions on Iran for the first time with the permament members of the council but received a decidedly cool reaction from China and Russia.

title: Joel Osteen's Credo: Eliminate the Negative, Accentuate Prosperity
description: HOUSTON, March 29 - Last Sunday morning, as usual, the ever-smiling preacher, best-selling author and religious broadcaster Joel Osteen took the stage at Lakewood Church, formerly known as the Compaq Center, the 16,000-seat home of the Houston Rockets basketball team.

description: PARIS, March 30 AFrance's Constitutional Council ruled this evening that a disputed labor law that has brought more than a million protesters into the streets was valid, setting the stage for further confrontation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAESS, KEN
description: KAESS--Ken. DDB Worldwide and its staff are deeply saddened by the death of our President and CEO Ken Kaess. Ken was determined to bring diversity to the advertising business, and in 1998 he founded the Bill Bernbach Minority Scholarship Fund (named for one of DDB's founding fathers). The New York Urban League honored Ken in 2004 with the Frederick Douglass award for his role in promoting diversity and opportunity. Former Chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, two-term member of the board of the Ad Council and the American Education Foundation, and two-term chairman for Advertising Week, Ken's presence in our industry will be missed. A man of many talents, Ken was an accomplished pianist who toyed with the idea of becoming a professional musician before landing at Doyle Dane Bernbach in 1976. He was a mentor, a leader, a pioneer, a humanist and a friend. We are grateful to have worked with him. Our thoughts and deepest sympathies are with the Kaess family, Heidi, Courtney and Christopher, his father Dr. Kenneth Richard Kaess Sr., his sister Karen and his brother Karl. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021 or Builders Beyond Borders, 8 Willard Road, Norwalk, CT 06851. Funeral services will be for family and close friends, at 11 A.M. Friday, March 31, at Christ and Holy Trinity Church, 55 Myrtle Avenue, Westport, CT. A memorial service will be held in Manhattan at a date to be announced.

title: Travel Deals
Guidant Withdraws Stents After Discovering Defects
description: The troubled Guidant Corporation announced yesterday that it would scrap Xience heart stents that had been manufactured for sale in Europe and for clinical testing in Japan after discovering that some of them had defects. Guidant said the action would result in a $15 million write-off in the first quarter.

title: Hamas Criticizes Aid Cuts as It Assumes Power
description: JERUSALEM, March 30 A As Hamas government ministers took over their new offices today, the group sharply criticized aid cuts that have been announced or threatened by Western countries.

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about "Sound Digression in Seven Colors," by Tony Oursler, included an erroneous closing date supplied by the Nyehaus Gallery in Manhattan. The exhibition has been extended to April 15; it did not close on Saturday.

title: Some Sequels Really Are Worth the Wait
description: SEQUELS to great games fill me with a mix of excitement, hope and dread. The hope is that they will contain the same wondrous mix of elements that made the original so enthralling. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OCHS, NORMAN M. ''RED''
description: OCHS--Norman M. "Red". Of Syosset (but his heart was always in Rockaway) died Wednesday, March 29 at the age of 79. He is survived by his wife Betty, his children and their spouses; Tom, Peter and Nadine, Carrie and Romeo, Suzanne and Patrick and his two step-children, Elisa and Michael. He also leaves behind his 13 beloved grandchildren: Jack, Marc, Damian, Fallon, Kirk, Bryan, Lucy, Finn, Danny, Declan, Sadie, Ruby and Beck. He is also survived by his loving sister, Ruth Benson and many nieces, nephews and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENTZEL, ALVIN J.
description: MENTZEL--Alvin J. March 27, age 84, after a brief illness. Al served as an officer in the United States Navy in the Pacific theatre during WW II. He joined the firm now known as Price Waterhouse Coopers in 1951, becoming a partner in 1963 until 1984. Upon retirement, he and his wife Hallie moved to Martha's Vineyard. Al served on the Boards of the Vineyard Conservation Society, Hospice of Martha's Vineyard and the Friends of Family Planning of Martha's Vineyard. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Hallie, his children Andrea, Anthony and Nina. Donations to Hospice of Martha's Vineyard or a charitable organization of your choice.

title: Delta Job Cuts Occur Earlier Than Planned
description: Delta Air Lines, in the midst of trying to persuade its pilots to accept pay cuts totaling $305 million a year, said yesterday that it was cutting administrative and management employment by 1,000 positions, or about 20 percent.

title: Nasdaq pulls its offer for London exchange
The Disposable American: Layoffs and Their Consequences
China and India raise Nokia's expectations
Next Stop for Delphi: The Courts
description: DETROIT, March 29 - Delphi, the auto parts maker, and its largest union, the United Automobile Workers, agreed on one critical point on Wednesday: that the company was likely to ask a bankruptcy court judge to let it set aside its labor contracts and impose sharply lower wages and benefits.

title: American reporter freed in Iraq
Shrubs, With Tenderness and Chainsaw
description: OYSTER BAY, N.Y. - RICHARD WEIR III, a horticulturist trained at Cornell University who recently retired from Cornell Cooperative Extension in Nassau County, has taught me everything from how to prune a lilac to digging a proper hole for a bare-root tree. In mid-March, he handed me an old spade and told me to dig.

title: In Dazzling Eclipse, Bashful Sun Allows Glimpse of Its Wild Side
description: KASTELLORIZO, Greece, March 29 - The shadow of the Moon swept across half the globe on Wednesday, blotting the Sun from the sky in a long swath from the tip of Brazil to northern Asia.

title: Senate Debates Competing Immigration Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 A Senators plunged into a debate today on how the United States should balance compassion with caution in its treatment of 11 million illegal immigrants in the post-9/11 era.

title: Automakers Use New Technology to Beef Up Muscle, Not Mileage
description: John Elsden relishes the excitement of the mint-condition '65 Mustang convertible he takes out of his garage in eastern Virginia only on sunny days. The sporty coupe with a 289-cubic-inch engine growls, rumbles, vibrates and shakes when he puts his foot on the gas pedal.

title: Violent Youths Threaten to Hijack Demonstrations in Paris
description: PARIS, March 29  The images are unnerving: hooded, swift-footed youths infiltrating protest rallies in the heart of tourist Paris, smashing shop windows, setting cars on fire, beating and robbing passers-by and throwing all sorts of objects at the riot police.

title: New Money for School Construction but Not Daily Expenses
description: ALBANY, March 29 - The budget accord that lawmakers reached here on Tuesday night will let Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg move forward with what city officials are calling the most ambitious school construction program in the city's history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TENNEY, DANIEL G., JR.
description: TENNEY--Daniel G., Jr. Of Locust Valley, N.Y. died peacefully on March 28, 2006 at age 92. Beloved husband of Constance Franchot Tenney, his wife of 66 years, he was the devoted father of Constance Rafle, Pamela Simpson, Alexandra Potts and Daniel G. Tenney III. Grandfather of nine and great grandfather of four. A graduate of the Choate School (1931), Yale College (1935) and Yale Law School (1938), he had a long and wonderful career at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Boys Club of New York or Trout Unlimited.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARYMONT, JOSEPH
description: MARYMONT - Joseph. March 24, 2006 of Voorhees, NJ, formerly of Teaneck, NJ. Husband of the late Marcia (nee Stettin) Marymont. Survived by many nieces and nephews and many dear friends. Services on Friday beginning at 11 A.M., Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., Cherry Hill, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: A Nation of Immigrants Faces the Current Wave (10 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: As Life Returns to New Orleans, So Does Crime
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 29  The wail of police sirens is back, and gunfire again punctuates the night. As drug dealers move into flood-damaged houses, alarmed residents say that in the last few weeks, they have begun to sense a return to the bad old days before Hurricane Katrina, when crime was an omnipresent straitjacket on life in this city.

title: For Work on the Road, a Digital Touch of Home
description: The ability to carry computer files (or back them up) can make the road-weary traveler feel at home even when using an unfamiliar machine. Verbatim's new versions of its Store 'n' Go line of pocket hard drives can haul either four gigabytes ($129) or eight gigabytes ($199) in a chrome-and-plastic shell slightly larger than a Zippo lighter.

title: The Watchdog Awakes
description: The Federal Election Commission finally did the right thing in ruling that the Internet must not be used as a conduit for unregulated salvos of big-money political advertising. Scolded by a federal judge, the commission reversed its earlier rule that threatened to turn the Web into a giant trough for the six- and seven-figure donations from corporations, unions and fat-cat influence shoppers that Congress banned in the campaign reforms of 2002.

title: New Yorkers May Soon Be Able to Tell a Commuter Van by Its Color
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONNELL, JOHN JOSEPH
description: CONNELL--John Joseph. Of Bogota, NJ, formerly of Manhattan, on Wednesday, March 29, 2006. He was Chairman of Maintenance for the TWU Local 100. Volk Leber Funeral Home 201-836-0202

title: Freelance Journalist Kidnapped in Iraq Is Freed
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 30 A Jill Carroll, the reporter who was kidnapped in Baghdad in early January and whose case generated widespread international attention, was freed today, according to a correspondent for her newspaper, The Christian Science Monitor.

description: WEINBERGER--Caspar W. The Board of the American Friends of The Churchill Museum at the Cabinet War Rooms (London) mourns the loss of our fellow Trustee, Caspar W. Weinberger. We value the passion he devoted to raising awareness of the legacy of Sir Winston S. Churchill through the new museum in London. We extend our sympathy to Mrs. Weinberger and their family. Sir Deryck Maughan, Chair Phil Reed, Director

title: As the East Village Revives, a Church Withers
description: From the outside, the Church of the Nativity hardly evokes feelings of the divine. Its boxy, cinder-block-and-brick aesthetic give it a drab institutional feel. Inside, the church is similarly lacking in flourish: bare white walls, oak pews and little else.

title: Kidnapped American journalist is freed in Iraq
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Extends Rent Rules
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill yesterday that extends the Rent Stabilization Law for three years, to April 1, 2009. The bill, which had overwhelming support from the City Council and Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum, was based on a finding that a public emergency exists in the rental housing market. A survey last year by the Census Bureau and the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development determined that the vacancy rate was 3.09 percent, below the 5 percent rate at which state law requires that rent regulation be discontinued. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: Berlin talks seeking unity on Iran action
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Charity Official Charged In Theft
description: An $80,000-a-year grants administrator for the Rockefeller Foundation was charged yesterday with stealing thousands of dollars from her employer. According to the Manhattan district attorney's office, the administrator, Cheryl McEwan, and her husband, Anthony McEwan, a musician, stole $232,500 in triple-matching grants from the foundation when she made donations to a fake charity called An Urban Alternative, controlled solely by Mr. McEwan. They used the money to pay American Express bills, the down payment on a house and their mortgage, prosecutors said. The McEwans and Frank Melli, director of an environmental charity called Green Sphere, were also charged with stealing $188,500 in Rockefeller money through a similar scheme. A judge ordered Mr. Melli and Ms. McEwan held yesterday in $250,000 cash bail each. Both denied any wrongdoing. Mr. McEwan has not yet been arraigned. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)

title: Inter fights back to defeat Villareal 2-1
Autonomy passes for Catalonia
Drifting Off to Sleep in a Field of Dreams
description: YOU'VE cleaned the closets and vacuumed the dust bunnies, and now it's time to spruce up for spring and rid the house of the winter blahs. Floral bedding may be just the right bedroom accouterment to jump-start the season. After a long winter, tired rooms can be refreshed with sheets and duvet covers sprinkled with bouquets and blossoms, and for those who prefer sleeping in solid-color sheets, a flowery topping can change the whole scene.

title: Domain name gifts: Dot-com boon for charities
Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Is Sweet Music For Fox Once Again
description: "American Idol" massacred everything in its path, and as a result so did Fox, according to Tuesday's Nielsen estimates. On "Idol," the theme was songs from the 21st century. Most of the performers were roundly criticized by the judges -- yes, even by Paula Abdul, the nice judge. An audience of 31.48 million tuned in, and of the 18-to-49-year-olds who watched television between 8 and 9 p.m., 32 percent chose "Idol." Those ratings continued the talent competition's streak of double-digit growth in comparison with last year's telecasts. Fox's "House" also won its hour in dominant fashion, with 21.51 million viewers at 9 p.m. In that slot, the CBS action series "The Unit" brought in 15.9 million viewers, placing second to "House"; it is this season's most-watched new show so far. Also of note, the good news for NBC was that its new sitcom, "Teachers," drew 6.7 million viewers and retained most of the "Scrubs" audience (6.8 million). The bad news was that the combination of the two shows was good enough only for a weak third place for the hour. KATE AURTHUR

title: JetBlue May Be Big, but It Wants Fliers to Think Small
description: IT was Descartes or Plato -- or perhaps Jessica Simpson -- who once advised, "If you can fake sincerity, you've got it made." Now, a low-fare airline, seeking to maintain its upstart persona in the face of ambitious expansion plans, is presenting itself to consumers as the sincerest form of flying.

title: On 'So Notorious,' Tori Spelling Mocks Herself Before You Can
description: How do you solve a problem like Tori Spelling? An irritating symbol of 1990's nepotism, a farcically rich Hollywood airhead, a tabloid target: Ms. Spelling knows what people say about her, and in her new scripted comedy series "So Notorious" on VH1, she is saying it with them.

title: Not With a Bang but a Pop
description: JERUSALEM, March 29  In an election that Israeli leaders hoped would produce "the big bang," creating a strong, stable centrist majority, Israeli voters delivered a small pop, unwilling to give too much power to an untested acting prime minister, Ehud Olmert.

title: Violent Youths Threaten to Hijack Demonstrations in Paris
description: PARIS, March 29 - The images are unnerving: hooded, swift-footed youths infiltrating protest rallies in the heart of tourist Paris, smashing shop windows, setting cars on fire, beating and robbing passers-by and throwing all sorts of objects at the riot police.

title: Twilight of Tax Privacy
description: For most people, the apparently hard-wired human reluctance to pay taxes is overcome by the knowledge that it's illegal not to. The Internal Revenue Service, in turn, is legally bound to keep tax returns private.

title: With Ink Not Yet Dry on Budget, Pataki Aides Assail the Legislature's Plan
description: ALBANY, March 29 - Setting off a fresh round of skirmishing over the budget on Wednesday, Gov. George E. Pataki's staff claimed that the Legislature's new budget understates spending by as much as $2.6 billion and would create deficits totaling at least $10 billion over the next two years.

title: Eugene Landy, Therapist to Beach Boys' Leader, Dies at 71
description: Eugene Landy, the psychotherapist who was variously called a savior and a snake oil salesman for his unorthodox, round-the-clock treatment of Brian Wilson, the famously dissolute leader of the Beach Boys, in the 1970's and 80's, died on March 22 in Honolulu. He was 71.

title: A Clay Britney Stars in the Abortion Debate
description: Britney Spears is probably not the likeliest muse for a work of art promoting an anti-abortion message. Yet hard as it may be to imagine her inspiring such meditations, it is no stretch at all to imagine that a gallery show including a politically tinged likeness of Ms. Spears is apt to draw a bit of attention.

description: OTT--Howard. Cherished husband of Gloria. Beloved father and grandfather. All of his friends from childhood mourn his passing. A standup guy has left us. Middle Village Friends

title: Doctor in India Jailed for Telling Sex of a Fetus
description: NEW DELHI, March 29 - An Indian doctor has been jailed for two years for disclosing the sex of a fetus to its parents. It was the first instance of a physician jailed under legislation intended to stop the abortion of unwanted girls.

description: No, Joe and Marie Hanley decided at first, they would not listen to the 911 tape of their son, Chris, calling for help from Windows on the World.

description: MOSCOW, March 30  Russia's state-controlled gas monopoly today announced that it would require Belarus, a Kremlin ally whose economy is subsidized by Russia, to begin paying market prices for natural gas.

description: BALTIMORE, March 29 - The Transportation Department announced new fuel economy standards Wednesday for sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans that will make some of them go farther on a gallon of gasoline than the average car does, and will apply to many of the biggest S.U.V.'s for the first time.

description: As in football, sometimes the best offense is a good defense when fighting viruses, spyware programs and other malicious software trying to invade your computer.PCdefense from Laplink Software aims to differentiate itself from other security programs by including a disaster-recovery tool.

description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that its technology chief, Marv Adams, was leaving the company effective April 21 to join Citigroup.
