description: MIAMI, March 29 - Jack Abramoff, the former superlobbyist at the center of a major corruption investigation in Washington involving members of Congress, was sentenced on Wednesday to 5 years and 10 months in prison on related fraud changes in Florida.

title: China and Russia Wary of Call for Iran Sanctions
description: BERLIN, March 30 A A day after the United Nations Security Council approved a heavily compromised statement criticizing the Iranian nuclear program, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice today raised the idea of imposing sanctions on Iran for the first time with the permament members of the council but received a decidedly cool reaction from China and Russia.

title: Graves Happy to Make Way for Jagr
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 29 - It has been 12 years since Adam Graves scored 52 goals for the Rangers, setting a franchise record with a Stanley Cup championship team.

title: Massachusetts Court Limits Same-Sex Marriages
description: BOSTON, March 30  Massachusetts's highest court ruled today that same-sex couples who live in other states cannot get married in Massachusetts unless gay marriage is legal in their home states.

description: PARIS, March 29  President Jacques Chirac announced Wednesday that he would address the nation "in the coming days," in a deepening political crisis over the government's standoff with students and unions over a new jobs law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHMERGEL, PAUL
description: SCHMERGEL--Paul. Of Port Washington, NY passed away Friday, March 24 in Miami, Florida. Born in Hungary in 1908, Mr. Schmergel immigrated to America in 1939. A successful real estate developer, Mr. Schmergel was responsible for many notable residential and commercial projects throughout Long Island, as well as Florida. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Patricia, as well as his sons Peter, F. William, John, Paul Jr., his nephew Stephen and 12 grandchildren. Viewing services will be held at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home in Manhasset, New York, on Wednesday, March 29 from 7-9 in the evening and on Thursday, March 30 from 3-5 in the afternoon and again from 7-9 in the evening. Funeral services will take place at 9:30 AM on Friday, March 31 at St. Peter's Church in Port Washington, with burial to immediately follow at Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to St. Francis Hospital, Office of Development, 100 Port Washington Boulevard, Roslyn, New York 11576.

title: Physical Culture: GEAR TEST WITH Cindy Reid, Golf Pro; Stay the Course? Not in These Togs
description: GOLFERS angling for an edge have embraced all sorts of technology: oversize titanium drivers, low-spin balls and even contrast-enhancing contact lenses. Yet they have clung to their outdated cotton polos even as synthetic fabrics that dry fast and wick away sweat have become the norm in other sports. Why the lag?

We love and miss you, and pray you're playing golf with Paul and dancing with your wife, Ruth, in Heaven. Jo Davis Hallingby

It took me about 20 minutes one morning to reach the revolving doors at the entrance. In the end, I would have waited forever. The show is sublime.

title: American Reporter Kidnapped in Baghdad Is Released
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 30 A Jill Carroll, the American reporter who was kidnapped in Baghdad nearly three months ago, was freed today on a street in western Baghdad and walked into the office of an Islamic political party clutching a letter from her captors asking the party to help her.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Work Planned For Lexington Line
description: Downtown express service on one of Manhattan's most congested subway lines --the 4 and 5 trains from 86th Street and 14th Street -- will become more congested for seven weeks beginning on Monday, transit officials said yesterday. New York City Transit said that track work on the line from April 3 to May 22 would require trains to operate over a temporary track at slower than normal speeds. It said the impact would be most pronounced during the morning and evening rush -- from 7 a.m. to 10 a.m. and from 3:30 p.m. to 7 p.m. -- with estimated delays of up to 10 minutes. THOMAS J. LUECK (NYT)

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 11 P.M. (History) THE PLOT TO KILL: RONALD REAGAN -- On the afternoon of March 30, 1981, John Hinckley Jr. shot President Ronald Reagan (left) in the chest in front of the Washington Hilton, where the president had been making a speech. The plot, in this case, seems to have been a one-man operation. This new documentary uses a little of everything -- interviews, eyewitness accounts, archival tape and re-enactments -- to examine the events of that day and Mr. Hinckley's stated purpose: to impress the actress Jodie Foster, then a student at Yale University.

description: GLUKHOVSKAYA--Polina. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Polina Glukhovskaya, beloved mother of Ludmila Kislin, mother-in-law of Semyon Kislin, and grandmother of David and Regina Kislin. The Kislin family's leadership is marked by a deep commitment and boundless generosity that enriches the New York Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Ludmila, Semyon, David, and Regina; and to their entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Man's Sentence Is 23 to Life in Ex-Girlfriend's Murder
description: A Long Island man who stalked and threatened a former girlfriend for at least two years before shooting her to death last June was sentenced yesterday to 23 years to life in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVESTRE, PATRICIA ANN
description: SILVESTRE--Patricia Ann. Born in New York City, NY on June 13, 1936, daughter of Mary Elizabeth Lydon and Alphonse Michael Silvestre. Pat lived in the Bronx with her mom and her first job was a line girl at Horn & Hardart Cafeteria. Knowing this would not suffice, she convinced the family patriarch, her grandfather Nicholas Silvestro, to allow her to join the 1st Sergeants Program for Army Nurses in New York State, so she could attend school. Succeeding in her quest she went to Lenox Hill Hospital School of Nursing and graduated in 1958. Pat's thirst for knowledge never stopped. She received a Bachelor of Science in Nursing from Columbia and a Master's in Hospital Administration from Baylor. Her military education: Army Medical Department Officer Advanced Course, Department of the Army Inspector General Course, (Pat was the 1st female placed on the I.G. team) and the Chief Nurse Orientation Course. Upon retirement, she became an Instructor at the American Red Cross. During her Army career, she held a variety of clinical, administrative and staff positions: Madigan, the 121st Evac. in Seoul, Korea, Fort Gordon, Fort Jay, a tour at the U.S. Army Recruiting Command, the office of the Surgeon General as Assistant Chief for the Army Nurse Corps Procurement, Surgical Hospital, Quang Tri, the 95th Evacuation Hospital Republic of Vietnam, Inspector General U.S. Army Health Services Command, Aberdeen Proving Ground, Fort Campbell, the Army Regional Medical Center in Frankfurt, Germany and Fitzsimmons in Colorado. She was the youngest Colonel in the Army. Pat's army career ended with her retirement on September 25, 1986. However, her new life of retirement in San Antonio, TX began anew with an old life long motto of serving others. She started at the SAMM Shelter volunteering for the night shift in downtown San Antonio. She became an active field worker for the Red Cross and when mobility became a problem she became an instructor. She became a vital member of the St. Vincent de Paul Society, where she used her skills and character for many years to benefit those who needed a helping hand. As a member of her church she served as a CCD instructor, lector, and Parish Council. She remained an active member of Kiwanis, Veteran's of Foreign Wars and the Women's Overseas Service League for as long as her health permitted. Paraphrasing M. Rausch's words about Colonel Silvestre, "What lies behind us and what lies before us are tiny matters compared to what lies within us. You have left a trail of excellence as exhibited by your family, friends, and colleagues and the future holds great promise; however it is what lies within you which has touched 'The Body of Christ."' Alfred Adler, one of the fathers of modern psychiatry, said one of the dominant impulses that every human being is born with is the instinct to get ahead. The problem arises whether one is willing to channel it for good. Christ said that in the Kingdom of God greatness is measured in terms of service. And you my friend have accomplished that level of excellence because you were always ready to the cries of those in need. Your service has cost you through the years to bleed and suffer knowing the price for greatness is long hours and many sleepless nights. There is another quote which puts you in mind. "You Pat, are a very special individual who at all times and every where gave her strength to the weak, her substance to the poor, her sympathy to the suffering, and her heart to God. The endless number of people who have crossed your path will bear witness to this. When a void existed you were ready to step in and serve with honor and humility. It is yourcommitment in ministering to others which has touched us all." Colonel Silvestre's awards and recognitions are too numerous to mention. Colonel Patricia Ann Silvestre passed away at the Army Retirement Community in San Antonio, TX on March 12, 2006. She leaves behind dear friends, colleagues, cousins Nancy Guerin, Dorothy Lyons, Michael Guerin, their families, and her sister, Marietta.

description: Denise Grady answered reader questions about her article "How Serious Is the Risk?" from this week's Science Times.

title: Antiquities Trial in Rome Focuses on a London Dealer
description: ROME, March 29 - The activities of Robin Symes, a London antiquities dealer who has done business with many of the world's top collectors, came into sharp focus on Wednesday at the trial of Marion True, a former curator at the J. Paul Getty Museum, and Robert Hecht, an American dealer.

title: Beleaguered Premier Warns U.S. to Stop Interfering in Iraq's Politics
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 29  Facing growing pressure from the Bush administration to step down, Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari of Iraq vigorously asserted his right to stay in office on Wednesday and warned the Americans against interfering in the country's political process.

title: Noah leaves his dad's shadow
EU and U.S. unite to push China on auto-part tariffs
Off to a Chilly Start
description: Off to a Chilly Start

title: Harlem and Los Angeles
description: A NEW boutique, N, opened last week in Harlem. The store, below, will carry a mix of national brands and work by designers based in the neighborhood.

title: The Magic Numbers and the Elected Take a Trip Back in Time
description: Yesteryear's bubblegum is today's hipster treat. In a sold-out show on Tuesday night at Webster Hall, the Magic Numbers looked and sounded like something from the 1960's. Long-haired and unglamorous, they smiled and harmonized their way through songs backdated to a blithe era of West Coast pop, with unabashed echoes of the early Beach Boys and the Mamas and the Papas.

title: When the Owner Wants to Work Less
description: It had been nearly 15 years since Henri Elfassy boogied the night away at a discothque, but for the last few months, that's exactly what he's been doing. Not for fun, mind you, but for work.

title: Duke Players Practice While Scrutiny Builds
description: DURHAM, N.C., March 29 - While a flier featuring photographs of Duke's lacrosse players began appearing around campus, the university's president, Richard H. Brodhead, urged a group of students Wednesday morning to learn from the controversy surrounding the team.

title: Supreme Court Hears Arguments Over Foreigners' Rights in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 - The question before the Supreme Court on Wednesday was whether an international treaty that protects people embroiled in another country's criminal justice system gives foreign citizens any specific rights they can assert in American courts.

title: In Dazzling Eclipse, Bashful Sun Allows Glimpse of Its Wild Side
description: KASTELLORIZO, Greece, March 29  The shadow of the Moon swept across half the globe on Wednesday, blotting the Sun from the sky in a long swath from the tip of Brazil to northern Asia.

title: Review: The Book About Blanche And Marie
China Is Told of U.S. Impatience on Trade
description: BEIJING, March 29 - The rise of protectionist sentiment in the United States over a $202 billion trade deficit with China could hurt the Chinese economy, Commerce Secretary Carlos Gutierrez said Wednesday.

title: American Is Sentenced to 30 Years in Terror Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  An Arab-American student from Virginia was sentenced Wednesday to 30 years in prison for plotting with operatives of Al Qaeda to assassinate President Bush and hijack airplanes.

title: 'Another day, another euro' for some Germans
On Web, Error Is Uncovered Through Relentless Pursuit
description: Correction Appended

title: Rare timepiece highlights a 'Mozart' among clockmakers
Whose Ukraine?
Doris Muscatine, 80, Writer on California Wine and Food, Dies
description: Doris Muscatine, a pioneering chronicler of California's wine and food culture, died Saturday at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 80.

title: Swiss press fund managers
Catalonia Wins Self-Governing Powers from Spain
description: MADRID, March 30 A After hours of occasionally bitter debate, the lower house of Parliament agreed today to grant broad new powers of self-government to the wealthy northeastern region of Catalonia. The vote was 189 to 154.

title: For Prodi, prudence lights way to victory
You Say You Want a Constitution
description: NEARLY six decades after the state of Israel was founded, members of the newly elected Parliament will try to complete the job of drafting a constitution. Their greatest challenge will be to lend coherence to Israel's dual identity as a state that is both Jewish and democratic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the trip to China by Senators Charles E. Schumer and Lindsey Graham misstated their position on China's handling of its currency, the yuan. They want China to allow the yuan to move higher against the dollar; they do not want it devalued.

title: A Nation of Immigrants Faces the Current Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefly: Glaxo starts testing bird flu vaccines
Loss Doubles at HealthSouth
description: HealthSouth, the nation's largest chain of rehabilitation hospitals, said yesterday that its losses more than doubled in 2005 as it settled lawsuits stemming from a $2.7 billion accounting fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILTON, ARTHUR
description: MILTON--Arthur. The entire Citymeals-on-Wheels family mourns the passing of Arthur Milton, a wise and generous friend to the thousands of homebound elderly we nourish. We send condolences to his beloved wife Phyllis and his entire family. Marcia Stein, Exec. Director, Citymeals-on-Wheels

title: Orpheus Chamber Orchestra at Carnegie Hall Performs Music Inspired by Scotland
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra's program at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening offered music about something other than music. All three pieces could be called Scottish, at least by association. They featured graphic Scotland in Peter Maxwell Davies's "Orkney Wedding, With Sunrise," then theological Scotland in James MacMillan's "Veni, Veni Emmanuel" and finally a German tourist's Scotland in Mendelssohn's Third Symphony ("Scottish").

title: Beleaguered Premier Warns U.S. to Stop Interfering in Iraq's Politics
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 29 - Facing growing pressure from the Bush administration to step down, Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari of Iraq vigorously asserted his right to stay in office on Wednesday and warned the Americans against interfering in the country's political process.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Ferrovial Hires Macquarie Bank as Adviser
description: Grupo Ferrovial of Spain, which is bidding 8.7 billion ($15 billion) for the British airports owner BAA, hired Macquarie Bank of Australia as an adviser and agreed to sell terminals in Sydney and Bristol to a unit of the bank should the offer succeed. The agreement removes a potential counterbidder for BAA, which this month spurned the offer by Ferrovial, a builder based in Madrid. Macquarie said that it had decided against a separate bid because BAA did not meet its investment criteria.

title: Big Belt Plays the Bully in My Closet
description: I learned only recently that my husband was nursing the antiquated notion that a belt is something you put through loops.

title: Now You Can Charge Your Cellphone Anywhere (Even if You're Nowhere)
description: You're walking through East Nowhere and the battery in your cellphone or P.D.A. dies. There's no place to plug in a charger, and besides, you don't have time to hang around while the battery recharges. Cellphone battery boosters have been around for a while, but they have built-in batteries that need periodic recharging as well.

title: Milan leaves Lyon with 0-0 draw
China and Russia Wary of Call for Iran Sanctions
description: BERLIN, March 30  A day after the United Nations Security Council approved a heavily compromised statement criticizing the Iranian nuclear program, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice today raised the idea of imposing sanctions on Iran for the first time with the permament members of the council but received a decidedly cool reaction from China and Russia.

title: Cartoon fans Papua asylum quarrel
City to Adopt Changes in Handling of Abuse Cases
description: Responding to the killing of Nixzmary Brown, a 7-year-old girl beaten to death in January, a city panel yesterday recommended changes to improve coordination between the child welfare agency and the Police and Education Departments, including giving teachers and guidance counselors more leeway to report signs of neglect.

title: Microsoft refutes EU charges with satisfied customers
Paid Notice: Deaths   BERGMANN, THERESE G.
description: BERGMANN--Therese G. Loving wife of the late Paul and devoted mother of Peter, Steven and Ronald, died peacefully at home in her beloved New York City. Born in Graz, Hungary, she was an education activist, consumer and community board advocate, member of Cancer Care and the Council of Jewish Women. She leaves her three sons, daughters-in-law, and six grandchildren, Rachel, David, Maggie, Paul, Caroline and Joseph. She will be missed by her family and friends. Services are Friday, March 31, at 11 AM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to Fort Tryon Jewish Center, 524 Fort Washington Ave, NY NY 10033, or Beth Israel Medical Center, 16th St and 1st Avenue, NY NY 10003.

title: French confidence slips
3 Indicted in Deaths of 2 Firefighters Who Jumped
description: The former owner of a Bronx building and two of his tenants have been indicted in the deaths of two firefighters whose efforts to battle a blaze in the building last year were hampered by a warren of illegally constructed rooms and walls, the authorities said.

title: Symbolic resonance endures
Will Success at Gucci Be Sexy or Safe?
description: Milan - ON a drizzly February morning toward the end of the Italian fall shows, as editors from New York, Shanghai and Moscow were watching models snake down the catwalks, Francesca Tronchetti Provera, a mother of three, was shopping for pants at the Gucci flagship on Via Montenapoleone in Milan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRARY, STEPHEN TROW BRIDGE
description: CRARY -- Stephen Trow bridge, 93. Died March 23, 2006, in Hanover, N.H. Beloved as husband, father, grandfather, professor, and friend. Born in Warren, PA, he received his undergraduate and doctorate degrees from Yale University and his divinity degree from Union Theological Seminary. He served as an army chaplain in the Pacific in World War II with the 39th General Hospital, composed of Yale doctors and nurses. He was chaplain and professor at Smith College from 1951-1957, then professor and chairman of religious studies at Brown University until 1971. In retirement, he lived in Lyme, N.H.; he and his family also spent many summers in the White Mountains at Randolph, N.H. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Eleanor Collier Crary; five children, Ann C. Evans of New York City, Sarah H. Crary of Amherst, MA, Alexander D. Crary of Washington, D.C., Jonathan K. Crary of New York City, and David H. Crary of Brooklyn, N.Y.; and five grandchildren. He was predeceased by his brothers, Calvert H. Crary and Douglas D. Crary.

title: INSIDE
description: An 'Aha' Moment for Bonnard's Art "Pierre Bonnard," at the Muse d'Art Moderne in Paris, reveals a deeper truth about that artist, with works like "The Dining Room, Vernon, 1925-27," which disclose fresh discoveries with repeat viewings.

title: Speakers That Surround You With Sound, Not Wires
description: Hiding speaker wires is always a problem, but it's made worse when you want to install a surround sound system with several satellite speakers. The wires from the front speakers to a computer or home entertainment center can at least blend into the clutter of wires behind a desk or audio-video center. But the long wires feeding the surround-channel speakers that are typically placed to the sides or the back of a room can be visually obtrusive.

title: Belarus Plans to Charge Defeated Candidate Who Led Protest
description: MOSCOW, March 29 - Prosecutors in Belarus said Wednesday that they would bring criminal charges against a defeated presidential candidate who led an antigovernment march last week, and that they were considering lesser charges against a second candidate who organized a rally.

title: Maryland Acts to Take Over Failing Baltimore Schools
description: BALTIMORE, March 29 - Invoking the federal No Child Left Behind law, the Maryland school board voted today to take control of four Baltimore high schools with chronically low achievement and strip the City of Baltimore from direct operation of seven more middle schools.

title: Tongue Twisting Web Sites
description: This week's reader e-mail brought this intriguing comment:

title: British Court Hears Apple v. Apple and 'Le Freak'
description: Correction Appended

title: Executive attacks enemies with 'Locusts'
Arab League futility
U.N. Council Urges Iran to Halt Atom Activity
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 29  The Security Council urged Iran on Wednesday to suspend its uranium-enrichment activities and asked the director of the International Atomic Energy Agency to report back on Iran's compliance within 30 days.

title: Ground Zero Still Lacks an Agreement on Rebuilding
description: An agreement on a major realignment of the rebuilding effort at ground zero continued to elude government officials and the developer Larry A. Silverstein yesterday, even as the Port Authority board planned to meet today to discuss the matter.

title: The Kid Is Now the Man
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 29 - Anderson Hernandez's teammates did a double take when they saw him Wednesday morning, and it was not because they thought he had missed the bus.

title: A Spam Fighter Is Overzealous but Can Learn
description: GOOD thing people don't judge me by my e-mail in-box. If they did, they'd conclude that I'm sickly, overweight and unemployed, that I need a new mortgage, don't know where to buy medicine and can't please my wife.

title: Mexico City in the City
description: A series of pictures in "ABCDF," a mostly photographic dictionary of Mexico City now on exhibit at the Queens Museum of Art, illustrate the word "quinceaera." The quinceaera is the honoree at the coming-of-age party Mexicans throw for their daughters at age 15. The quinceaos is celebrated on a grand scale: the girl often arrives in a rented pumpkin-shaped Cinderella coach, and 250 guests can be present, whether the families can afford it or not.

title: Roots of George Mason's Success Grew in Queens
description: THE phone kept ringing on Jack Curran's desk -- old grads, weeklies from Queens, national talk shows, good friends. They all wanted to talk about Curran's trip to the Final Four this weekend.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Accused of Role in Four Organized Crime Killings
description: A former F.B.I. agent was accused in an indictment today of "acting in concert" with members of organized crime in the murder of four people during the 1980's and early 1990's, according to District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: 'Toro Negro' Examines the Life of a Violent Young Matador in Mexico
description: Be aware that any confrontation with "Toro Negro" ("Black Bull") -- an unflinching look at bullfighting and debasement in the Yucatn Peninsula -- will entail witnessing animal torture and death. And that's not the worst of it. Shot on vivid high-definition video, in backwater districts where the blood sport thrives, this documentary follows 21-year-old Fernando Pacheco, a disturbed matador, as he lurches from contest to contest in an alcoholic stupor, lashing out at beast and man with equal fury.

title: Hastert Hints at Compromise on Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 - Speaker J. Dennis Hastert said Wednesday that he and other House Republicans recognized the need for a guest-worker program, opening the door to a possible compromise with the Senate on fiercely debated immigration legislation.

title: Moussaoui Sentencing Case Goes to the Jury
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 29 - The jurors in the case of Zacarias Moussaoui began deliberating Wednesday whether he is eligible for the death penalty, after prosecutors told them that he had been in the thick of the Sept. 11 plot and his lawyer portrayed him as a feckless "Al Qaeda hanger-on."

title: Old Stuff as Not-So-High Art: Turning Objects Into Objets
description: Fine art is often discovered in attics. But what if you want to make an artwork out of your vintage lunchbox collection? Mark Indursky, an owner of Lost Found Art in Stamford, Conn., creates tabletop or wall displays out of collectibles. "The idea is to turn them into sculpture," said Mr. Indursky, who charges $150 an hour. Lost Found also sells its own finds as separate items or assemblages: a gaggle of old microphones, above, suitable for a media mogul's desk, is $3,500; a shadowbox with 18 tin ray guns, below, is $3,200. For baseball fans, nine little mitts, weathered by time and countless line drives, are displayed in a white box. "I like the scale and the innocence," Mr. Indursky said of the mitts. But "I don't do cookie jars." Information: lostfoundart.com or (203) 595-0575.

title: G.O.P. Chief Backs Ex-Yonkers Mayor for Senate
description: John Spencer, a Republican who hopes to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton this year, yesterday picked up the endorsement of the chairman of the state Republican Party, Stephen J. Minarik III, who just months ago was writing him off as a second-tier candidate.

title: In Jakarta, Blair hears criticism of Iraq war
Bubba Sparxxx's Unlikely Comeback
description: "Let me sell 50 million, then I'll call it quits."

title: Soccer: UEFA Cup quarterfinals
Now It's Easy to Back Up Data on a Network
description: Like most fans of the iTunes Music Store, I'm aware of its one-time download policy. Once I download a song, it's my responsibility and if lost, I will have to buy it again. Like far fewer iTunes aficionados, I finally did what Apple recommends that you do. I backed up my music.

title: Germany may tighten borders for World Cup
Hamas Criticizes Aid Cuts as It Assumes Power
description: JERUSALEM, March 30 A As Hamas government ministers took over their new offices today, the group sharply criticized aid cuts that have been announced or threatened by Western countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALLIS, RYER SCHEINMAN
description: BALLIS--Ryer Scheinman, 95, died March 27, 2006. Hunter College, Phi Beta Kappa, Court Interpreter. Loved by all. Always kind, rarely judging. Survived by daughters, Marcia (Stanley Milberg) and Barbara (Deepak Lal). Grandchildren, Lisa Kate (Marc Wassermann), Judith Aileen, Deepika and Akshay. Great-grandchildren, Gilbert and Marguerite. Caretakers, Carmen, Jackie, Marva. Services Thursday, March 30, 11:30, Kehila Chapel, Bklyn.

title: Corrections
description: The White House Letter column on Monday, about changes made by Laura Bush in her East Wing staff, misstated the title of a book by Christopher Buckley, who commented on the recent departure of the White House pastry chef. It is "No Way to Treat a First Lady" -- not "a Lady."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OCK, MURIEL A.
description: OCK--Muriel A., 98 of Whiting, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, and Maplewood, NJ, for many years on March 21, 2006. A memorial Service will be offered on April 6 at 1pm in St. Paul Lutheran Church, Beachwood, NJ.

title: Literature: Oh, Juliet, to beseech your advice!
Fitness; Upgrading the Road to Nowhere
description: IT'S 5:15 on a Friday afternoon, and while much of Manhattan is heading home or to happy hour, Jodi Cornish, an instructor at the Wall Street branch of Equinox, is leading 10 regulars through a treadmill workout intended to banish boredom and love handles.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the former chief executive of the Raytheon Corporation, Daniel P. Burnham, that will require him to return part of his annual bonus for 2000 included an erroneous example of executives who have faced pressure or agreed to give back bonuses. (The error also appeared in an article on Jan. 12, 2005.) While government regulators are considering requiring the repayment of bonuses from two former top executives at Fannie Mae, they have not yet decided to do so.

title: Poetry Bookshop Changes Hands
description: The Grolier Poetry Book Shop in Harvard Square, the oldest poetry book store in the United States, is about to change hands for the second time in eight decades, Publishers Weekly reported. The influential store, opened in 1927 and a favorite of poets including E. E. Cummings,T. S. Eliot and Marianne Moore, has been sold to Ifeanyi Mentiki, a professor of philosophy at Wellesley College. He is also a poet whose most recent collection,"Of Altai,the BrightLight," was published last year by Earthwinds Editions."The store has meant a lot to so many of us," he said. "I wanted tomake sure it continued." The sale, by Louisa Solano, who owned the store for 31 years, was prompted by her ill health and will become final tomorrow."I'm going to catch up on 30 years of sleep," Ms. Solano said.

title: Concertante Plays Mozart and Shostakovich at Merkin Concert Hall
description: Concertante, a flexible chamber ensemble, made its contribution to the Mozart and Shostakovich anniversary celebrations by splitting its program between them on Tuesday at Merkin Concert Hall. Each was represented by a quintet -- Mozart by the String Quintet in C (K. 515) and Shostakovich by the Piano Quintet in G minor (Op. 57).

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "You can wash the outside of the cup all you want. If the inside is still unclean, you're going to have the same problems."

title: People: Charlie Rose, Prince, Julia Roberts
Paid Notice: Memorials   FOWLER, EDITH
description: FOWLER--Edith. March 30, 2005. With me everyday in everything I know that's beautiful. Clem

title: U.N. Council Urges Iran to Halt Atom Activity
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 29 - The Security Council urged Iran on Wednesday to suspend its uranium-enrichment activities and asked the director of the International Atomic Energy Agency to report back on Iran's compliance within 30 days.

title: Letter from India: Service with a smile brightens India trains
Chelsea Announces Alliance
description: Chelsea, the English Premier League club that is about to win its second straight title, announced an alliance yesterday with the Anschutz Entertainment Group and the Los Angeles Galaxy, one of the four Major League Soccer clubs A.E.G. operates. Under terms of the relationship, Chelsea and A.E.G. will hold a tournament every other year that will include Chelsea and an M.L.S. club; will give Chelsea the first option to sign Galaxy players and enable the English club to loan players to Los Angeles; provide for the exchange of coaching and medical personnel; and create a reality TV show in which the winner will get a professional contract from Chelsea. JACK BELL (NYT)

title: Ex-Prosecutor in Terror Inquiry Is Indicted
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 - A grand jury charged Wednesday that a former federal prosecutor in Detroit who led one of the Justice Department's biggest terrorism investigations concealed critical evidence in an effort to bolster the government's theory that a group of local Muslim men were plotting an attack.

title: Not With a Bang but a Pop
description: JERUSALEM, March 29 - In an election that Israeli leaders hoped would produce "the big bang," creating a strong, stable centrist majority, Israeli voters delivered a small pop, unwilling to give too much power to an untested acting prime minister, Ehud Olmert.

title: Gazprom sets quid pro quo for French participation in pipeline
Tero Saarinen Company From Finland Dances in New York
description: The Tero Saarinen Company from Finland made its New York debut in 1998. It was welcomed warmly, but for whatever reason, it took eight years to return. Its opening at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night was an occasion for some terrific dancing, building happily from strength to strength over the three pieces on the program.

title: Filling a Mall With Art, and a Few Volcanoes
description: "My parents warned me about places where RadioShack closes," said Jacques Vidal, 23, the artist-organizer of a "surrealist county fair" coming to Metro Mall in Middle Village, Queens, an area rich in cemeteries. Harry Houdini's remains are resting down the street.

title: A Nation of Immigrants Faces the Current Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Gas Deal Roils Ukraine and May Have Cut Leader's Vote
description: KIEV, Ukraine, March 29 - The official residence of the managing director of a company now set to control Ukraine's supply of natural gas is a one-story, clapboard house in a tumbledown village bordering a defunct collective farm outside Moscow. A dirty rug covers the floor, a bare light bulb hangs from the ceiling and scraps of plywood plug gaps in the wall.

title: As France Approves Labor Law, Students Block Roads and Rails
description: PARIS, March 30 AFrance's Constitutional Council ruled this evening that a disputed labor law that has brought more than a million protesters into the streets was valid, setting the stage for further confrontation.

title: As France Approves Labor Law, Students Block Roads and Rails
description: PARIS, March 30 France's Constitutional Council ruled this evening that a disputed labor law that has brought more than a million protesters into the streets was valid, setting the stage for further confrontation.

description: AND you thought only your savings were shrinking.

description: March 29, 2006

title: Doubt Cast on Stockpile of a Vaccine for Bird Flu
description: A bird flu vaccine being stockpiled by the government in preparation for a possible pandemic protects only about half the people who receive it, scientists are reporting. In addition, it must be given in such high doses that if a pandemic were to start soon, manufacturers could not begin to make enough vaccine for all who would need it.

title: Hamas Criticizes Aid Cuts as It Assumes Power
description: JERUSALEM, March 30  As Hamas government ministers took over their new offices today, the group sharply criticized aid cuts that have been announced or threatened by Western countries.

title: Other Views: The Age, The Times, Times of India
Corrections
description: A schedule note on Tuesday with a review of the Kronos Quartet and Azerbaijani musicians at Zankel Hall misidentified the instrument played by Wu Man, who is to perform at Zankel on April 6 in the next part of the quartet's "Live Mix" series. It is the pipa, not the koto.

title: Will Success at Gucci Be Sexy or Safe?
description: Milan

title: Cycling: Intending no disrespect, Boonen begins his own Holy Week
A Nation of Immigrants Faces the Current Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: American Is Sentenced to 30 Years in Terror Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 - An Arab-American student from Virginia was sentenced Wednesday to 30 years in prison for plotting with operatives of Al Qaeda to assassinate President Bush and hijack airplanes.

title: Buena Vista
description: The artist Jorge Pardo designs a tropical getaway for a favorite patron.

title: Behind the Green Door
description: A California house demonstrates Roy McMakin's knack for making the familiar slightly unfamiliar.

title: Finding Her Perfect Fit
description: Like many women, the Times's Melanie Warner has wasted many hours trying on ill-fitting clothing. Hoping to put that wasted time behind her forever, she put Fit Logic sizing to the test.

title: Facebooks $2 Billion Trial Balloon
description: More than six million college and high school students have already registered for social-networking Web site Facebook. If each ponied up $333, they could collect more than enough to cover the $2 billion that the company hopes to fetch in a sale, according to Tuesdays article from BusinessWeek Online. (Maybe they can borrow the money from their parents.)

title: The  Goldman Diaries: A Day in the Life of a Wall St. Executive?
description: Whats life like at Goldman Sachs? How bad are the hours? How great is the bonus?

title: Yahoo Japan Buys Web Bank Stake
description: Yahoo Japan will partner with Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group in Internet banking by taking a stake in the lenders online subsidiary, Japan Net Bank, the companies said on Thursday. Yahoo said it would pay 2.5 billion yen ($21.2 million) for an initial 14.9 percent stake in a new holding company for Japan Net Bank.

title: LandAmerica Buys Capital Title
description: LandAmerica Financial, a provider of real estate transaction services, on Wednesday said it agreed to buy Capital Title Group for $251 million in cash and stock to diversify its business mix and expand in title insurance.

title: SanDisk Seen as Potential Rival Bidder for Lexar
description: SanDisk may not be entirely out of the bidding to buy Lexar Media  following its failed offer to acquire the company last year. Thats the conclusion of one Wall Street analyst after a review of the details of a recent Securities and Exchange Commission filing concerning Lexars acquisition plans.

title: British Bank Is Said to Reject $10 Billion Offer
description: British mortgage bank Alliance & Leicester has rejected an informal 5.8 billion pound ($10.1 billion) offer from Frances Credit Agricole, according to The Independent. Alliance & Leicester CEO Richard Pym thought the offer, worth around 1,300 pence a share, did not reflect the banks full value.

title: CBS Brushes Off Talk of Buying Univision
description: CBS brushed off talk of a Univision buy, saying the big Spanish-language radio and TV broadcaster is expensive. Finance chief Fred Reynolds told investors at a Bank of America conference in New York that CBS isnt eager to pony up $12 billion for Univision, likening an acquisition of that size to climbing Mount Everest.

title: Nasdaq Pulls $4.2 Billion Bid For London Stock Exchange
description: Is the London Stock Exchange playing too hard to get?

title: Pfizers Big Sale Not a Sure Thing
description: Drug giant Pfizer looks like a more-than-willing seller. In early February, 2006, the company announced it was exploring the possibility of selling or spinning off its consumer business. The betting was that Pfizers $3.9 billion operation, which includes brands like Listerine and Visine, could be worth more than $10 billion.

title: Hedge Funds Reap Big Gains Betting on Mergers
description: Thanks to a spate of blockbuster deals, hedge funds that bet on mergers are on a tear, making almost as much money in the opening weeks of 2006 as they did in all of 2005. These hedge funds use a strategy known in the business as merger arbitrage or risk arbitrage, meaning they seek to profit from the spread between the current market price of a company being acquired and the price once a deal has gone through.

title: France and Germany Deny Backdoor Alcatel Deal
description: The authorities in France and Germany rushed Wednesday to dispel mounting speculation that their governments were planning to shake up Europes satellite industry as a result of a proposed telecommunications tie-up between Alcatel of France and its U.S. rival, Lucent Technologies.

title: Life Insurance Fund Makes Healthy Profit for Owners
description: Hugh Osmonds Sun Capital Partners and TDR Capital, the private equity firm, have made an estimated profit of 500 million pounds on their 1 billion pound purchase of Pearl, the closed life insurance fund, The Times of London said.

title: RTL Denies It Had ITV Merger Talks
description: Channel Five owner RTL today denied it had held talks with the private equity consortium stalking ITV about a possible merger of the two broadcasters.

title: Morgan Stanley Takes the Knife to Retail Managers
description: The investment bank, Morgan Stanley, cut 15 percent of the managers who oversaw its retail brokerage operations in the New York area yesterday as part of a revamping, according to a memorandum. The cuts affect about 20 to 25 people who worked in the New York City headquarters and in Westchester County.

title: United Biscuits May Be Considering $2 Billion Offering
description: United Biscuits reported a 25 percent surge in full-year profits on Wednesday, fuelling speculation that the maker of McVities biscuits and KP Nuts is preparing for a 2 billion pound London offering.

title: Private Equity Firms Pick Up 2 Hollywood Film Libraries
description: Investors fascination with Hollywood libraries continued Wednesday as Qualia Partners, a private-equity group led by former Artisan CEO Amir Malin and president-COO Ken Schapiro, bought the libraries of Rysher Entertainment and Gaylord for about $100 million.

title: Medical Financial Tool Provider Gets Funding
description: Medical Present Value , which provides financial tools and expert services to manage pay contracts and audit reimbursement for physicians offices, secured $14 million in venture capital. Investors are Rho Ventures, CenterPoint Ventures, Care Capital, Star Ventures and Techxas Ventures.

title: Las Vegas Sands in $3.6 Singapore Casino Bid
description: Las Vegas Sands, one of four bidders for Singapores first casino development, said it is proposing to invest $3.6 billion in the project, which it said would be the most expensive gaming resort worldwide.

title: MapQuest Hopes to Catch Wave with Local Matters I.P.O.
description: MapQuest founder Perry Evans is taking aim at an opportunity in the Internet-search business for local information as he prepares to take Local Matters public. Known for starting up MapQuest  acquired by America Online in 2000 for $1.1 billion  Evans has stayed in the local-information arena with Local Matters.

title: Anti-Wrinkle Maker Gets $50 Million Injection
description: Armed with an injectable product that promises to smooth out facial wrinkles on a permanent basis, Artes Medical has raised a nearly $50.7 million Series E round. While its flagship awaits Food and Drug Administration approval, Artes is putting proceeds from the round to help build its sales, marketing and training staff.

title: Intersouth, In a Hurry, Raises Seventh V.C. Fund
description: Intersouth Partners is attempting to raise $250 million for its seventh venture capital fund, just three years after launching its most recent vehicle, VentureWire reported. The firms marketing timeline is quicker than that of most venture capital firms, which typically wait four to six years between funds.

title: Sourcefire Backers See Bright Side to Thwarted Bid
description: When federal regulators scuttled the planned acquisiton of security software maker Sourcefire by Israeli company Check Point Sofware Technologies last week, it struck a sour note with the venture capital community and analysts. But as far as the venture-backed company and its investors are concerned, the canceled deal has served as a sort of validation.

title: Internet Capital Expands On-Demand Software Holdings
description: Internet Capital Group Inc. expanded its foray into the growing market for on-demand Web-based software, saying yesterday that it had acquired a 36 percent stake in Vcommerce Corp., of Scottsdale, Ariz., for $13 million. The Wayne, Pa.-based technology-investing firm spent years struggling to stay in business after the dot-com bust of the early 2000s.

title: British Court Hears Apple v. Apple
description: The High Court of Britain, accustomed to the sounds of bewigged barristers parsing the fine points of the law, was treated Wednesday to a funky playback of the disco anthem Le Freak as a lawyer for the Beatles record company argued that Apple Computers iTunes digital music store violated a trademark agreement between the companies.

title: Nymex Pit Traders Consider Walkout Over I.P.O.
description: Squeezed by falling trading volumes that are only exacerbated by the skyrocketing price of doing business at the New York Mercantile Exchange, pit traders at the worlds largest energy market are entertaining a walkout to get the attention of exchange leaders.

title: Honeywell Sells Crash Test Dummy Unit to Private Equity Firm
description: Honeywell International  said on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell the crash test dummies unit of newly acquired First Technology for $87.3 million. The sale of the First Technology business to HgCapital, a European sector-focused private equity investor, is expected to close during the first half of the year.

title: Whos Afraid of Microsoft? Not VCs
description: Microsoft used to cast such a pall over startups that venture capitalists would ask them the M question  how does the company plan to coexist with Microsoft? And if the answer was that the startup planned to compete with the software giant, then venture capitalists wouldnt invest.

title: With MySpace Buy, News Corp. Gets a Rare Gem
description: When News Corporation paid $580 million for MySpace, an Internet site for teens and young adults, some people figured that Rupert Murdochs fascination with all things digital had once again led him to overpay for a new-media property.

title: Top Court Asks eBay Hard Questions
description: Supreme Court justices showed little inclination on Wednesday to scale back the rights of patent holders, sharply questioning arguments made by a lawyer representing the online auctioneer eBay.

title: U.S. Start-Ups Look to Britain for Listings
description: American startups are increasingly looking to London exchanges to list their initial public offerings to avoid millions in costs to comply with Sarbanes-Oxley rules.

title: Abramoff Gets Prison Time in Florida Fraud Case
description: Jack Abramoff, the Republican lobbyist at the center of a Washington corruption scandal, was sentenced to five years and 10 months in prison in an unrelated fraud case in Florida. U.S. District Judge Paul Huck in Miami accepted the plea of Abramoffs lawyers for the shortest possible prison time.

title: Caterpillar to Purchase Finning Unit
description: Diesel engine and heavy equipment maker Caterpillar said on Wednesday it has agreed to purchase the rail and remanufacturing business of Caterpillar dealer Finning International. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Verizon Broadband Decision Is Challenged
description: A group representing telephone and Internet companies on Wednesday challenged action by regulators that freed Verizon Communications from rules on its broadband data services for businesses. The Federal Communications Commission exempted Verizon from scores of regulations for its high-capacity data business services

title: Germanys Infineon Said to Be Looking at a  Nasdaq Listing
description: Infineon is leaning more and more toward an initial public offering of its memory chip unit rather than a spin-off, and its chief executive would prefer a listing in the United States, Reuters reported. The unit would be listed on the Nasdaq in that case.

title: Get Ready for More Google
description: A follow-on stock offering by a public company is usually not headline news. Unless that company is Google, the $100 billion-in-market-cap heavyweight of Internet stocks.

title: Mittal to Cut Arcelor Bid if Dividend Is Approved
description: Mittal Steel said it will cut a hostile bid for Arcelor, currently valued at $25.5 billion, if Arcelor investors approve a higher-than-expected dividend at an annual shareholders meeting April 28.

title: New Power Seen for Mexican Giant
description: Mexicos largest media company, Grupo Televisa, is at the center of a bitter debate over proposed laws that critics say strengthen the companys dominant position.

title: Citigroup Starts Internet Bank
description: Citigroup has begun an Internet bank that offers higher interest rates as part of its plan to attract more online customers and reverse a decline in consumer banking profit.

title: G.M. Wants Mitsubishi to Buy Isuzu Stake
description: Mitsubishi Corporation said Thursday that General Motors has asked the Japanese trading house to buy part of its 7.9 percent stake in truck maker Isuzu Motors.

title: Pioneer Closes Gulf of Mexico Asset Sale
description: Pioneer, the oil exploration company, completed the sale of some Gulf of Mexico assets to Marubeni for $1.3 billion in cash. The Dallas-based firm expects to record an after-tax gain on the deal of $425 million to $475 million.

title: Technology Companies Grease  Washingtons  Wheels  With Junkets
description: Las Vegas posh Bellagio resort is home to five bars, seven fine dining restaurants and fountains gushing choreographed displays set to music every evening. It also was home to a cross section of Capitol Hill last year: 13 congressmen, two senators and 65 congressional staffers, plus some spouses and children, got a free trip to the luxury resort, thanks to a technology lobbying group.

title: Biovail Battle Highlights Problems in Wall Street Research
description: While hyping stocks used to be common practice among some Wall Street firms, all that was supposed to change in 2003 thanks to much-needed reforms put in place by securities regulators and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer.

title: Wall Street Chieftains Fight Curb on Foreign Investment
description: Wall Streets most powerful chief executives weighed into the debate over protectionist trade policy in America, claiming that proposed reforms to the rules governing foreign investment in the United States could scare away billions of dollars worth of business.

title: S.E.C. Sues Former StarMedia Executives
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued eight former executives of StarMedia Network  on Wednesday, claiming the Internet portals revenue was improperly inflated by more than $18 million over a two-year period.

title: Greater Clarity Needed for Financial Reports, House Told
description: Greater transparency is necessary to reduce the complexity of corporate financial reports, government and business officials told House lawmakers Wednesday. Scott Taub, the Securities and Exchange Commissions acting chief accountant, told a House Financial Services subcommittee that the agency believes using interactive financial data will heighten access to corporate information and improve the reliability of data.

title: International Investor Turned Away from Russia
description: When it comes to fans of Russia  and in particular the policies of its controversial president, Vladimir Putin  they dont come any more enthusiastic than Bill Browder, the CEO of Hermitage Capital Management.

title: Judge Blocks Microsoft Request for Rivals Documents
description: District Court in California on Wednesday quashed an attempt by Microsoft to force Sun Microsystems and Oracle to provide documents in its battle with the European Commission.

title: Next Stop for Delphi: The Courts
description: Delphi, the auto parts maker, and its largest union, the United Automobile Workers, agreed on one critical point on Wednesday: that the company was likely to ask a bankruptcy court judge to let it set aside its labor contracts and impose sharply lower wages and benefits.

title: Tim Hortons Underwriters Pick Up More Stock
description: Tim Hortons  has confirmed that the financial service firms that led its initial public offering have decided to buy an extra 4.35 million shares of the coffee chain. The underwriters  led by Goldman Sachs in the United States, and RBC Capital Markets in Canada  had the option to buy an extra 4.35 million shares if the first 29 million were all scooped up.

title: Roundup
description: Sharpe James has laid low since dropping out of the mayors race on Monday, skipping out side doors of City Hall, keeping his public schedule blank. But according to his son John James, Mayor James will be out on the trail as early as next week to lobby voters for his slate of Municipal Council candidates. Can the man who called himself The Real Deal in 2002, an effervescent campaigner who rallies troops like a political evangelist, keep Cory Bookers team from completely taking over?

title: Bank of New York Reportedly Close to Big Branch Sale
description: Under pressure to exit the retail banking business, Bank of New York is in advanced talks to sell about 300 branch offices to J.P. Morgan Chase, cable news network CBNC reported Thursday morning. At least one analyst has valued the banks retail arm at $4 billion.

title: Can Iraq Vets Attract Voters?
Sago Mine Survivor Is Released
description: One of the doctors treating Sago Mine survivor Randal McCloy says there are many reasons why Randy may have done better than others. (March 30)

title: Chip-Gear Maker ASM Urged to Consider Break-Up
description: Shares of ASM International rose more than 4 percent in early trading Thursday in New York, amid hopes that shareholders could force a break-up of the Dutch maker of semiconductor equipment. The rise pushed ASMIs market capitalization to nearly $1.1 billion.

title: Left-Right Shuffle Over Immigration
description: The immigration debate continues to make for strange bedfellows; first it was John McCain and Ted Kennedy, now its conservative icon George Will and left-wing flamethrower Robert Scheer. In the Washington Post, Will, always more of an ideologue than a Bush partisan, wont make his friends on the right happy in telling them that:

title: The Get
description: The must haves of the season.

title: Jill Carrolls Out!
description: Any journalist feels the horror when a colleague is kidnapped or killed, and so today were thrilled that Jill Carroll has been released in Baghdad. Richard Bergenheim, the editor of the Christian Science Monitor, also put out a fine statement:

title: The New Collectibles
description: Finds from austere to baroque.

title: Ask Science
description: Denise Grady answered reader questions about her article "How Serious Is the Risk?" from this week's Science Times.

title: Wheres the Answer Sheet?
description: Theres a growing list of questions for Cory Booker from readers over at Newark Speaks. The inquiries, refreshingly, tend to focus on policy rather than process.

title: Great News From Pakistan
description: Callers to the Pakistani Embassy in Washington who cited my columns and asked for help for Aisha Parveen were told that I was lying and that the incident was all false. But in Pakistan, the government has finally acted.

Selborne Journal: 30 March 1759:  Put a brimful Barrow of Dorton-loam into each light of the Cantaleupe-bed. The Hills will require, now the boxes are raised, a barrow & half each at least. Bed comes slowly to its heat; & is very mild yet.

title: Are Immigrants Taking the Blame for Us?
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 30 column, Immigrants to Be Proud Of:

title: Leisure World
description: Relax. These sofas are for every living room.

title: Slide Show: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Tiger by the Tail" and "Mercy on the Doorstep."

title: As Shares Slump, Tribune Hears Calls to Sell
description: Could Tribune be the next Knight Ridder?

title: The Originals
description: These mavericks of design have always done it their way.

title: Artfully Searching for Treasure
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Luxe Modern
description: The luxe of the old meets the shock of the new in a Turin palazzo.

title: Slide Show: Yard Sale
description: Crafty design, historical reference and minimalism have their day in the sun.

title: Asset Swap Considered in Bank of New York Deal
description: It could be slightly misleading to focus on the headline figure of $4 billion in Thursdays reports of a possible sale of Bank of New Yorks branch offices.

title: Whats a Mayor Worth?
description: No question, Cory Booker used to think that the mayors salary was excessive.

title: David Pogue: Windows on an Intel Mac
description: With a lot of patience, you can put Windows XP onto a Mac.

title: $2 Billion for Facebook? News Corp. Says No Way
description: Ross Levinsohn, the Web czar at media conglomerate News Corporation, has good news and bad news about the latest crop of Internet start-ups. The good news: they are cheap (mostly). The bad news: They do not know how to make money. And that, apparently, is where News Corporation and its large sacks of money  earmarked for more Net acquisitions  come in.

title: Check the Calendar
description: Cory Bookers campaign calendar may suggest that Mr. Booker is out hitting the streets every day, in every ward. But when Newark06 called to get a specific location for this afternoons Cafe Con Cory event at a senior building in the North Ward, we were told, Oh wait, thats not actually going on.

title: London Exchange Is Looking Lonely
description: The London Stock Exchange appears increasingly like a wallflower in the consolidation dance that is sweeping exchanges. Soon after Nasdaq Stock Market abruptly withdrew its $4.2 billion offer for the L.S.E., Deutsche Borse, which runs the Frankfurt stock market, announced on Thursday that its board had authorized it to begin formal merger talks with Euronext.

title: Webber and Australian drivers
description: Drivers always face more pressure at their home races, but today in Melbourne, as the teams prepared for the Australian Grand Prix on Sunday, Mark Webber, an Australian driver, said something a little surprising and perhaps revealing, for one of the most intelligent, articulate and fastest drivers.

title: Jimmy Carter: Eradicating Trachoma
description: As part of a Times series on diseases on the brink of eradication, former President Jimmy Carter discusses The Carter Center's work to combat Trachoma in Ethiopia. (Producer: Craig Duff)

title: Colony Capital Makes Bid for Aztar
description: Colony Capital Acquisitions, a real estate investment firm, offered to buy Aztar, the owner of the Tropicana casino hotels, for $1.4 billion.

title: The Voters Speak
description: With the mayoral field settled, and no more speculation about Sharpe Jamess intentions to distract us, we thought it was time to go out into the streets and ask Newarkers what they actually wanted from the next mayor, who will take over on July 1. The voters we talked to at the corner of Market and Broad were chosen at random. Heres what five of them said.

title: Tongue Twisting Web Sites
description: This weeks reader e-mail brought this intriguing comment:

title: Times Square's Sound Sculpture
description: That sound wafting up from a subway grate at 46th Street and Broadway? It's art. Metro reporter Sam Roberts explains. (Producer: Brent McDonald)

title: 'Drawing Restraint 9'
description: Stephen Holden reviews "Drawing Restraint 9," a stately film of few words, conceived and directed by the artist Matthew Barney, who co-stars with his partner, Bjrk.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Brick'
description: Stephen Holden reviews Rian Johnson's "Brick," a hard-boiled noir set at an upscale Southern California high school.

title: The Education of the New Soldier
description: I dont think it is any secret that the Army has a one-year rotation policy when it comes to troop management in Iraq. I cant say when I am leaving, and it doesnt matter  I am still months away. However, now that I see some light at the end of the tunnel I am thinking about how the new troops will feel when they arrive.

title: Shocks Seen in New Math for Pensions
description: The board that writes accounting rules for American business is proposing a new method of reporting pension obligations that is likely to show that many companies have a lot more debt than was obvious before.

title: U.S. and Europe Say Tariff by China Is Discriminatory
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 - The heat on China is not letting up. In a rare coordinated move, the United States and the European Union filed a complaint on Thursday with the World Trade Organization, accusing China of imposing discriminatory tariffs on foreign suppliers of auto parts.

title: Live Action Simpsons
description: This one is amazing, amazing, amazing: It's a *live-action* video of "The Simpsons" opening-credits sequence. (Even the incidental characters standing on the sidewalk are right.) Never let them tell you the Internet is a waste of time.

title: Quakes kill at least 50 in Iran
Eldridge Street Synagogue Holds 'A Lower East Side Passover'
description: From the Desert of Sinai To the Lower East Side

title: Endesa delays bid from rival
Billy Harper Opens the Central Brooklyn Jazz Festival
description: When a group of business owners, community activists and musicians formed the Central Brooklyn Jazz Consortium in 1999, their goal was to preserve a jazz culture deemed to be withering at the grassroots level. The following year, they applied that sense of purpose to the first annual Central Brooklyn Jazz Festival, along with an educational outreach and a Brooklyn Jazz Hall of Fame.

title: Captors Warned Reporter Not to Cooperate With Americans
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 31  Jill Carroll, the abducted American reporter who was released Thursday after three months in captivity, spent today recovering in the heavily fortified heart of Baghdad, where the American Embassy is housed, despite a warning from her captors to avoid the area and not cooperate with American officials.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,317 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Cities That Lead the Way
description: Crippled by soaring corrections costs, states and municipalities are re-examining policies that drive ex-offenders right back to prison by barring them from employment. Locked out of the mainstream, ex-felons become burdens to their families, their communities and the nation as a whole. Three cities -- Boston, Chicago and San Francisco -- have taken groundbreaking steps aimed at de-emphasizing criminal histories for qualified applicants for city jobs, except in law enforcement, education and other sensitive areas where people with convictions are specifically barred by statute.

title: New Directors/New Films Festival Reviews
description: The New Directors/New Films festival concludes its 35th edition with two French and four American films, several fresh from the Sundance Film Festival. Today through Sunday, there are also encore screenings of the selections "Pavee Lackeen," "First on the Moon," "Still World," "Texas" and "Into Great Silence"; also playing today are the documentaries "Witness to War," "The Ties That Bind" and "Who Killed Vincent Chin?" More information, including ticket availability, is at www.filmlinc.com.

title: Briefly: Iranians test missile with multiple warheads
School Aid: Meet the New Math, Same as the Old
description: ALBANY, March 30 - They call it "the formula": an arcane scheme as unknowable as the recipe for Coca-Cola that is supposed to determine with mathematical objectivity how the state divides education aid among 677 school districts.

title: Debate on Release of 911 Tapes Remains Polarized
description: Even as parts of the tapes of 911 calls made on Sept. 11, 2001, were made public today, disagreement persisted on whether the city government should have released them and on whether any parts of the tapes should have been redacted.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Portugal: Law To Increase Number Of Women In Politics
description: Parliament passed legislation requiring that women make up at least a third of the candidates from any political party participating in national or local elections. Supporters of the initiative, led by the Socialist Party of Prime Minister Jos Scrates, said it was needed to correct an underrepresentation of women in Portuguese politics. About 25 percent of seats in Parliament are currently held by women, most from the Socialist Party. Opponents of the measure, which prohibits either gender from making up more than two-thirds of a party's candidates, called it discriminatory. RENWICK McLEAN (NYT)

title: New Directors/New Films Festival Reviews; 13 Tzameti
description: The New Directors/New Films festival concludes its 35th edition with two French and four American films, several fresh from the Sundance Film Festival. Today through Sunday, there are also encore screenings of the selections "Pavee Lackeen," "First on the Moon," "Still World," "Texas" and "Into Great Silence"; also playing today are the documentaries "Witness to War," "The Ties That Bind" and "Who Killed Vincent Chin?" More information, including ticket availability, is at www.filmlinc.com.

title: Gamecocks Repeat a Championship Performance
description: For the first time in more than 60 years, the National Invitation Tournament has a repeat champion -- South Carolina.

title: Dreams, Drugs and Danger in 'Iowa'
description: Opens today in New York Directed by Matt Farnsworth Not rated; 104 minutes

title: Contested French labor law gets green light
Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINHARDT, JEAN STETTHEIMER
description: STEINHARDT--Jean Stettheimer. A consistent and significant contributor to many Santa Barbara charities and organizations, Jean Stettheimer Steinhardt passed away on Saturday, March 25. She was the daughter of the late Florence and Walter Stettheimer of Atherton, CA, the sister of the late Barbara S. Adler and the sister-in-law of the late Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President and General Manager of The New York Times, both of New York City. Mrs. Steinhardt lived her later years at the Casa Dorinda in Montecito, CA. Jean was a quiet force in making public and private gifts with a definite plan and a strong sense that such were her responsibilities. She did not seek public recognition but would have wanted to be remembered as a person who made a positive difference. Jean had a zest for life and leaves a legacy of wisdom, of strong conviction and of resolute character. She always cared and taught by example that life could be a blend of social concern and glamorous fun. She is survived by her daughters Felicia W. Rogan of Charlottesville, VA and Jill W. Cartter of Beverly Hills, CA. She was also the beloved friend and quintessential aunt of Bobbie Adler Katzander of New York City. No services are to be held. In keeping with her great sense of charitable responsibility donations can be made to the Cancer Center of Santa Barbara.

title: Sierra Leone Asks to Move Liberian's Trial
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 30 - The government of Sierra Leone asked the International Criminal Court in the Netherlands to provide a venue for the trial of Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia who was arrested Wednesday on longstanding war crimes charges, officials in the Netherlands said.

description: Tom Wesselmann: The SixtiesL&M Arts45 East 78th Street, ManhattanThrough April 15

title: Searching Margaritaville for the Perfect Key Lime Pie
description: TRAVELERS come to the Florida Keys for the sun, the sand and the scenery of America gone Caribbean. They come for bone-fishing in the morning, margaritas at midday and sunset celebrations at dusk. And before it's time to depart, everybody wants a piece of Key lime pie.

Delphi Asks Bankruptcy Court to Void Union Deals
description: DETROIT, March 31  Delphi, the nation's biggest auto-parts maker, filed a motion in court today that is likely to set off a chain of events that could cost up to 20,000 American auto workers their jobs and leave thousands of others with less than half their wages.

title: S.E.C. Suspends 3 Ex-Managers of KPMG Over Tenet Audit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended three former KPMG managers from performing public company accounting as part of a settlement related to their roles in a 2002 Tenet Healthcare Corporation audit.

description: MITTENS or gloves?

title: Philippine press comes under official heat
Iraq at the 11th Hour
description: The fate of the entire U.S. enterprise in Iraq now hangs in the balance, as the war has entered a dangerous new phase. It is the phase of barbaric identity-card violence between Sunnis and Shiites. In the late 1970's, I covered a similar moment in Lebanon, and the one thing I learned was this: Once this kind of venom gets unleashed -- with members of each community literally beheading each other on the basis of their religious identities -- it poisons everything. You enter a realm that is beyond politics, a realm where fear and revenge dominate everyone's thinking -- and that is where Iraq is heading.

title: Iran Earthquake Kills 70, Destroys 330 Villages
description: TEHRAN, March 31 A A strong earthquake hit Iran's western province of Lorestan this morning killing 70 people and flattening more than 300 villages, state television reported.

title: Calls for Help
description: The following are audio and text excerpts of calls made to 911 on Sept. 11, 2001, introduced by The Times's Jim Dwyer and Kevin Flynn.

description: QUBOR, Venezuela  Julio Borges is an unusual politician among Venezuela's fragmented opposition. He is running for office.

Paid Notice: Deaths   REGAN, ATHENA
description: REGAN--Athena. March 29, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Peter G. Regan. Loving mother of George P.Regan and his wife Eve, Basil P. Regan and Marie P. Tutulis and her husband Peter J. Tutulis. Cherished grandmother of Pamela G. Regan and Anne G. Regan. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday March 31, 2-4 and 79PM. Service Saturday, April 1, 12 noon at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian, 353 East Clinton Ave, Tenafly, NJ. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ.

description: SITTING in the reading room of the Rosenbach Museum & Library in Philadelphia, I was immediately struck by how little the concerns of writers had changed in the last century and a half.

description: Prayers offered by strangers had no effect on the recovery of people who were undergoing heart surgery, a large and long-awaited study has found.

description: ROME, March 30  The room spilled over with foreign reporters curious to see Romano Prodi up close, and one went so far as to refer to him as the "probable" next leader of Italy.

Sharon Stone Returns in 'Basic Instinct 2,' an Older Femme but as Fatale as Ever
description: IT should come as no surprise that "Basic Instinct 2," the long-gestating follow-up to Paul Verhoeven's 1992 blip on the zeitgeist screen, is a disaster of the highest or perhaps lowest order. It is also no surprise that this joyless calculation, which was directed by Michael Caton-Jones and possesses neither the first film's sleek wit nor its madness, is such a prime object lesson in the degradation that can face Hollywood actresses, especially those over 40. Acting always involves a degree of self-abasement, but just watching trash like this is degrading.

title: Corrections

They were from the National Museum of Health and Medicine in Washington. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 30 - Jill Carroll, the American reporter kidnapped in Baghdad nearly three months ago, was freed Thursday, saying she had spent most of her time in a small room but had been well treated by her captors.

description: New Orleans's levees do not meet the standards that the Federal Emergency Management Agency requires for its flood protection program, federal officials said yesterday  and they added that the problem would take as much as $6 billion to fix.

description: President Bush said today that he continued to favor legislation that combines tougher control of the nation's borders with a legal guest worker program to supply labor for sectors of the economy unappealing to most Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALEXANDER, MURIEL WASCH CAMITTA
description: ALEXANDER--Muriel Wasch Camitta. On March 30, 2006 at age 90. Petite, poetic, creative, gracious dynamo. Predeceased by loving husbands, Herbert Camitta and Ralph Alexander. Loving mother of Bruce, Kris and Doug. Beloved mother-in-law of Marsha, John and Louise, grandmother to eleven and great-grandmother to seven. Memorial service at future date. Donations to the Milwaukee Athletes Against Childhood Cancer Fund or The Nature Conservancy or charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DU MOULIN, EDWARD I.
description: du MOULIN--Edward I., age 91, of Port Washington, on March 29, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Eleanor. Loving father of Richard (Ann), and the late Cathy Morea. Dear brother of Julia and Charles. Also survived by seven grandchildren, son-inlaw Jerry, and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held Saturday, April 1 at 10 AM at the Knickerbocker Yacht Club in Port Washington. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Seamen's Church Institute, 241 Water St., NY, NY 10038 or the Herreshoff Marine Museum in Bristol, RI.

title: An American Revolt in London
description: It's not exactly a tea party yet, but the Americans are again revolting against the British over taxation. At issue is the American embassy's refusal since last July to pay a traffic congestion surcharge when its diplomats drive around downtown London, where the embassy is situated. The Americans say the fee is a tax, and add that the Vienna Convention protects diplomats from taxes abroad.

title: Governing coalition winning in Sri Lanka
Extraterrestrials With an Appetite in 'Slither'
description: The slimy little creatures that wiggle into the mouths of the seriously freaked-out characters in the horror film "Slither" are meant to have originated in space. In truth, these delightfully repellent critters, which look like fast-moving leeches, squirmed out of the brainpan of the film's writer and director, James Gunn, a horror savant who has obviously put in some time with the collected works of both George A. Romero and David Cronenberg. Mr. Romero's zombie nation lives in shadow form in "Slither," a film about a fecund extraterrestrial with an insatiable appetite for flesh. But it's Mr. Cronenberg's early career interest in oozing orifices and spiky protuberances that seems to have left the biggest impression on Mr. Gunn.

title: The Listings: March 31 - April 6; DAVID ROBERTSON
description: Labor disputes made for a dissonant prelude to his tenure with the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, but the acrimony has seemingly passed, and Mr. Robertson (above), who began his music directorship in September, has been off to an ambitious, promising start. As part of his Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall, he returns with the orchestra for two programs this weekend, including tonight's performance of "Cassandre" by the noted Swiss composer Michael Jarrell, based on a contemporary reimagining of the ancient myth. (The actress Barbara Sukowa -- of early Fassbinder fame -- declaims the text over a chamber orchestra studded with synthesizers.) Tomorrow, Mr. Robertson, recently decorated for his commitment to American music, will lead John Adams's moving 9/11 memorial piece, "On the Transmigration of Souls." The work was written less than a year after the attack and conceived as a "memory space" that includes lists of victims' names, samples of urban noise and a children's choir. It should be fascinating to see how the piece ages as the national memory of the tragedy itself continues to shift. (At least Mr. Adams's memorial has been realized, unlike most other projects connected to ground zero.) Brahms's "German Requiem" fills out the program on a somber note. (Tonight at 7:30 in Zankel Hall; tomorrow night at 8, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; $30 to $35 tonight; $24 to $82 tomorrow.)

But the House rejected a Democratic proposal to halve the interest rate on student loans.
