title: Artistic Treasures Take Manhattan During Asia Week
description: ASIA WEEK is upon New York, and it is bigger than ever. Two substantial Asian art fairs have taken over the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, at 67th Street, and the Gramercy Park Armory, on Lexington Avenue at 26th Street. And about two dozen special gallery exhibitions are spread around the Upper East Side. Timed to coincide with the fairs and mounted by local and visiting dealers, some are sublime. Quite a few are at a single address -- the Fuller Building at 57th Street and Madison Avenue -- almost making up a third fair, and a very tony one at that.

title: 'Hatshepsut: From Queen to Pharaoh,' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art
description: CAN a queen be a king, too? Consider the case of Hatshepsut, an Egyptian ruler of the 15th century B.C. The eldest daughter of Thutmose I and his principal queen, she married her younger half-brother, Thutmose II. His untimely death left her regent for Thutmose III, his son by another wife. At some point, she decided to govern jointly with the boy and took on the title of king. Later, she assumed the supreme title of pharaoh and ruled Egypt in that powerfully masculine role until her death.

title: French Law Is Affirmed as Protests Snarl Traffic
description: PARIS, March 30  France's Constitutional Council upheld the constitutionality of a fiercely contested new labor law on Thursday, dealing a blow to opposition Socialists who had asked the council to strike it down but extending the crisis now facing the government.

title: ViewPoints: China trade and U.S. wealth
The Listings: March 31 - April 6; ART BRUT
description: The British rockers Arctic Monkeys may be grabbing all the press attention in this country lately with their perky, self-aware grousing. But their countrymen, Art Brut, are just as jumpily funny in their skewering of the rock-star preening among the hip, gallery-crawling set. The gleeful satire "Formed a Band" finds a sweet spot between poseur narcissism and the thrill of genuine musical creation. With a talk-sing delivery over his band's jaunty guitar blurts and swells of bashed bravado, the frontman Eddie Argos (above left, with Jasper Future) boasts a vocal tone more empathetic than the sneer of Johnny Rotten but testier than the party-rallying of the B-52's Fred Schneider. Art Brut's snooty name recalls an outsider art movement, and songs like the mash note "Emily Kane" happily crib from the romantic playbook of the star-crossed but always optimistic outsider artist and hit parade dreamer Jad Fair. "Emily Kane" imagines a world in which the subject of unrequited love might change her fickle mind when she receives the ultimate pop gift: being the central figure in a hit song. Mr. Argos swoons at the thought of such a song, as he promises the choosy Ms. Kane, "schoolkids on buses singing your name." (Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111; $15.)

title: 36 Hours in St. Louis
description: ST. Louis has undergone a remarkable transformation since 1972, when the spectacular demolition of its high-rise Pruitt-Igoe housing project became an indelible symbol of urban decline. Young professionals drawn to new biotech and medical research industries, as well as a new wave of immigrants from places like Bosnia, are bringing new life to neighborhoods that last thrived a century ago. New loft districts, old civic jewels and revitalized night life are making the old refrain of "Meet Me in St. Louis" a welcome phrase again.

title: French Twist
description: Paris - IN Paris, the atmosphere has been morose for weeks: The winter's riots in the poor suburbs have been succeeded by a springtime student revolt. Now it's the middle class's turn to express its discontent -- over a government plan to make it easier for businesses to fire young workers. This season, though, the protests aren't in far-off housing projects, but right under our eyes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IASON, GIRARD (JERRY)
description: IASON--Girard (Jerry). Born November 12, 1918, the son of Lawrence and Sadie Robinson Iason, died on March 29, 2006. Much loved father of Larry, John and Barbara. Devoted father-in-law of Cara, Valorie and Rob. Extraordinary Poppy of Scott, Sara, Lizzie, Jessica and Emily. Loving husband of the late Jeanne Hirsh Iason. Special friend of Edie Finck. Loving care provided by Carol Houser, Carren Serrette and Ann Williams. Jerry was an alumnus of Phillips Exeter Academy (1935) where he was elected captain of the first lacrosse team, and he was also an alumnus of Yale College (1939). Jerry volunteered for military service after Pearl Harbor and became an officer in the U.S. Navy. On D-Day he participated in the Normandy invasion. He also participated in the landings at Sicily, Salerno and Anzio. After the war he worked with his father at N. Erlanger, Blumgart & Co., Inc. where he became president. He enjoyed squash, golf and travel, but his greatest love was his family. He was an extraordinary father and husband who thoroughly enjoyed life and left his children and grandchildren a great legacy through his devotion to each of us. "A man's reach should exceed his grasp or what's a heaven for." Services private. Family receiving Sunday 28pm. Contributions to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital.

She will be remembered for the grace with which she lived and the support she gave unfailingly. Her gentleness and generosity will be missed by all who loved her. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Pregnant Woman Found Dead
description: A 36-year-old pregnant woman was found dead in her apartment late yesterday afternoon, the authorities said, and investigators were trying to determine the cause. . The woman, Marilyn Ginel, was found about 5 p.m. at 1085 Beach Avenue in the Bronxdale Houses development. Her three children were home from school, neighbors said. The family was seen returning from the supermarket about 10 a.m. No arrests have been made, the police said. The woman had planned to have a baby shower this weekend. "She told me the baby was due any day," said Desiree Ferguson, 38, a neighbor. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; No 'Men,' No Joy for CBS
description: At different points during this season, both "Out of Practice" and "Courting Alex" occupied the time slot after the most successful comedy on television, CBS's "Two and a Half Men," broadcast on Mondays. Recently, the two shows were moved to fill the 8 p.m. hour on Wednesdays and to see how they survive without "Men." The results have not been pretty. This Wednesday in Nielsen's estimates, "Practice" drew 6.29 million viewers, and "Alex" attracted 6.35 million, for fourth place in the hour among total viewers and fifth place among adults 18 to 49. First at 8 p.m. was NBC's "Deal or No Deal" with 16.1 million viewers, a lead that was squandered by the newly displaced "Law & Order" (9.4 million) and then the seemingly dead-on-arrival "Heist" (7.36 million). Fox was No. 1 for the night, as the "American Idol" results show brought in 27.27 million viewers at 9 p.m. ABC's "Lost" (16.07 million) continued to suffer at the hand of "Idol," tying its lowest 18-to-49 rating of the season for an original episode. In the same hour, WB's "Bedford Diaries" was a complete washout, with 1.9 million viewers.

title: The Listings: March 31 - April 6; JAMES SEWELL
description: New York choreographers visit Tower Records for music ideas. James Sewell went straight to Home Depot in Minneapolis, where his company is based, and bought a chainsaw and a power drill for his new "Guy Noir: The Ballet" (above, Benjamin Johnson, one of the dancers). "For years I've been wanting to do a ballet with a chainsaw," Mr. Sewell said. Guy Noir is a cigar-chomping radio detective created by Garrison Keillor, who wrote the ballet's script and narrates it on tape. The story involves a deadly dance contest at the ACME Tulle Company, and the plot unfolds to a jazz score that includes music by the Guy's All-Star Shoe Band. (The program also includes "Involution," set to music by Thomas Newman, and "Anagram," an improvisatory ballet set to Schubert.) Mr. Sewell, who trained at the School of American Ballet and performed with Eliot Feld, had wanted to do a Keillor ballet. Then, a few years ago, he got the perfect entree when the writer asked him to choreograph a can-can dance for men in tuxedos and sneakers for a gala for the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra. The kickline included Mr. Keillor. What kind of dancer was he? "He's very tall," Mr. Sewell said. "A great big guy. He had complete commitment." Pause. "He didn't screw up." Mr. Sewell and his wife, Sally Rousse, left New York in 1993, taking their company with them. What has Minneapolis got that New York doesn't? "My 15 years in New York were not replaceable," he said. "But I got to the point where I wanted to do my work with the least resistance. In New York, you need 20 to 50 percent more energy to get to base level, and 70 percent more energy and money to raise a family. And there's a real tradition here of philanthropy and of pushing the boundaries of art forms." (The James Sewell Ballet will perform Tuesday, Wednesday and next Friday at 8 p.m.; Thursday at 7:30 p.m.; April 8 at 2 and 8 p.m.; and April 9 at 2 and 7:30 p.m., at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, www.joyce.org; $40.)

For example, there's pond skimming, the widespread practice of dressing in outrageous costumes, getting up some speed on skis or snowboards and trying to skim across ice-cold bodies of water without sinking. Winners can take home cash and prizes, while losers are rewarded only with a case of the shivers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONNELLY, MARGARET (PEGGY) WARD (NEE HEALY)
description: CONNELLY--Margaret (Peggy) Ward (nee Healy). Of New York City died Tuesday March 28. Peggy was born in Brooklyn, New York and lived in New York City for 52 years. She graduated from Bay Ridge High School. Peggy is survived by her husband Thomas of 25 years and his children, their spouses and her grandchildren. She is also survived by three sisters, Geraldine Hofer of Ann Arbor, Michigan, Joan and her husband Robert Nixon of Port Richey, Florida and Loretta and her husband Jack Looney of Wayne, New Jersey. Also her aunt Celestine Hybil of Sparks, Nevada. Peggy was also a caring aunt to several neices, nephews, greatneices and great-neiphews. Known as Peggy Ward for many years, she was associated with Federated Department Stores for fortyeight years. As the administrator for the New York City headquarters, she was responsible for numerous internal and external operations, including the orginazation of record breaking fund raising by Federated. After retiring as Vice President, she returned as a consultant to the chief executive office of Federated. Among her other activities was soliciting donations for the Make-A-Wish Foundation. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Robert L. Fine Cancer Research Laboratory Foundation, 650 West 168 St, Black Building, 20-05 NY, NY 10032, Which is seeking a cure for Pancreatic Cancer.

title: The Listings: March 31 - April 6; DAN FISCHER: 'STRANGELOVE'
description: For some people, art is a religion: a constantly preoccupying, all-encompassing system of gods, saints, heroes, villains, myths and icons. Dan Fisher, a young New York-based artist, gives expression to that idea in a series of beautiful, small graphite drawings. Each is copied from a photocopy of a magazine or textbook photograph of a well-known artist or artwork. Subjects include Robert Smithson, Sol LeWitt and Piet Mondrian, who poses in his studio in a three-piece suit. The single artwork depicted in this exhibition is Jeff Koons's stainless-steel cast of an inflatable Mylar bunny, a gleaming totem for the postmodern era (above). With the fine grid of pencil lines used in the copying process left visible, these velvety drawings are devotional works of monkish craft. But do we detect an element of satire? Mr. Fischer's pantheon is such orthodox academic fare, you can't help suspecting that he might be partly mocking the cultish worship of certain Modern and contemporary artists and their works. His drawings produce a tantalizing dialogue between idolatry and iconoclasm. (Derek Eller, 615 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-6411, through April 15.)

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (11) SURVIVAL OF THE RICHEST -- Series premiere. Kat, who is the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's daughter, makes enemies right away. And some people don't care for Hunter, the Dutch aristocrat who brags about going to school with Prince William. Seven rich young people, most of whom have never worked a day in their lives (yet have a combined net worth of $3 billion), and seven poor young people, some unemployed and most in considerable debt, live together in a grand reality-show-style mansion and compete for $200,000. For the rich, it's a chance to prove to their families that they aren't completely worthless. For the poor, it's all about the prize money. Everybody's first task is waiting tables at a bustling Medieval Times restaurant.

title: Preventable Disease Blinds Poor in Third World
description: ALEMBER, Ethiopia - Mare Alehegn lay back nervously on the metal operating table, her heart visibly pounding beneath her sackcloth dress, and clenched her fists as the paramedic sliced into her eyelid. Repeated infections had scarred the undersides of her eyelids, causing them to contract and forcing her lashes in on her eyes. For years, each blink felt like thorns raking her eyeballs. She had plucked the hairs with crude tweezers, but the stubble grew back sharper still.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Report Questions Security Of Canadian Trash
description: Customs officials should immediately ban shipments of Canadian trash to dumps in Michigan because border agents were not effectively screening for weapons or other smuggled goods, a bipartisan report by a Senate domestic security subcommittee said. If a ban is not imposed, the customs agency should charge a fee on the more than 100,000 trash shipments a year to pay for more comprehensive inspection, the report said. ERIC LIPTON (NYT)

title: French Law Is Affirmed as Protests Snarl Traffic
description: PARIS, March 30 - France's Constitutional Council upheld the constitutionality of a fiercely contested new labor law on Thursday, dealing a blow to opposition Socialists who had asked the council to strike it down but extending the crisis now facing the government.

title: LIVING HERE | Houses Near Resort Towns; Almost Being There
description: WHO -- Dee Gustafson, 55, an advertising executive from Idaho Falls, shown with her husband, Bob, 59, a structural engineer WHAT -- 4-bedroom house WHERE -- Driggs, Idaho

title: Art in Review; Stanislaw Ignacy Witkiewicz
description: Drawings From the 1930's Ubu Gallery 416 East 59th Street, Manhattan Through April 22

title: No News Is Woods's News
description: In the midst of Ed Bradley's worshipful two-part profile of Tiger Woods on "60 Minutes" last Sunday, I wondered if it was an infomercial or if Woods had paid a fee for these adoring 25 minutes. With nothing new to report -- and not a single tough question in his arsenal -- Bradley chose to join Camp Tiger.

title: Fewer Marshes + More Man-Made Ponds = Increased Wetlands
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 - In the bog of the federal regulatory code, a wetland is defined as a marshy area of saturated soils and plants whose roots spend part of their lives immersed in water. In the Interior Department's periodic national surveys, a wetland is defined, more or less, as wet.

title: Private property? Well, not so much
Law Enforcement Agencies Break 2 Major Drug Rings
description: Two major drug-trafficking rings that smuggled huge amounts of cocaine from Mexico -- some of it concealed in tombstones engraved with the image of the Virgin Mary -- and shipped it to New York were broken up yesterday in multiple raids by federal, state and local law enforcement agencies nationwide, the authorities said.

title:
Digital Divide Closing as 
Blacks Turn to Internet
description: African-Americans are steadily gaining access to and ease with the Internet, signaling a remarkable closing of the "digital divide" that many experts had worried would be a crippling disadvantage in achieving success.

title: The Road to Dubai
description: For now, at least, the immigration issue is mainly hurting the Republican Party, which is divided between those who want to expel immigrants and those who want to exploit them. The only thing the two factions seem to have in common is mean-spiritedness.

title: Water, Water Anywhere
description: THE temperate climate and abundant wildlife were what first drew Daysi and Jorge Morey to the somnolent coastal town of Palm Coast, Fla., a four-and-a-half-hour drive north from their Miami apartment. Now they have another reason for owning a vacation home there: rising property values.

title: At Sept. 11 Trial, Tale of Missteps and Management
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 - Three weeks of testimony and dozens of documents released in the sentencing of Zacarias Moussaoui have offered an eerie parallel view of two organizations, Al Qaeda and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and how they pursued their missions before the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Paul A. Flaherty, a computer engineer who was a pioneer in indexing the World Wide Web, misidentified the state where he was raised. He is from Grand Rapids, Minn., not Michigan.

title: Wal-Mart Shows a Similar Side to Sears
description: THE year was 1993, and Sears, Roebuck & Company wanted to shake off its image as a testosterone-filled department store focused on tools and lawn mowers.

title: New Strain on Duke's Ties With Durham
description: DURHAM, N.C., March 30  Francis Conlin says that he is a pretty sound sleeper, but that his wife is often jarred awake by the raucous noise spilling from one of the frequent and teeming student parties in their neighborhood beside the East Campus of Duke University.

title: World Briefing: Asia and Europe
description: ASIA

title: Reality Bites Back: Some at ESPN Assail Bonds Show
description: A two-day seminar attended by ESPN personnel at an airport hotel in Hartford earlier this week exposed a schism within the network about the wisdom of televising a 10-hour reality series starring Barry Bonds.

title: A New Motivator for Governors Island
description: An accomplished fund-raiser for New York City's public schools has been picked as the president of the corporation devoted to the reinvention of Governors Island, a $1 gift to the city and state whose future has been mulled over for three years with little to show for the effort.

title: Setback for Merrill in a Hiring Dispute
description: James P. Gorman, head of Morgan Stanley's retail brokerage unit, won a reversal yesterday of a court order that had barred him from trying to hire people away from his former employer, Merrill Lynch.

title: Conservatives Stand Firm on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 - Conservative House Republicans bluntly warned their leaders Thursday against any immigration compromise that would allow temporary foreign workers and assailed a Senate proposal that would open the way for illegal immigrants to earn citizenship.

description: OLIVER PLATT caught his first glimpse of Hank Azaria in the drama department at Tufts University in the early 1980's.

title: A Requiem Rich With Reverence and Sober Introspection
description: The Requiem is about as good as Verdi's music gets. Not chained to a silly libretto but instead built on a time-honored sequence of meditations on the afterlife and prayers for the redemption of the dead, it includes sublime choral music, as well as solo vocal lines as dramatic as those in Verdi's operas. But where Verdi's focus on voices in the operas led him to give the orchestra pedestrian music most of the time, the Requiem shows that under the right circumstances, he had a vivid orchestral imagination as well.

title: Senate Debates Resolution to Censure the President
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 A President Bush's once-secret surveillance program sparked a bitter debate today before the Senate Judiciary Committee over what kind of president George W. Bush has become and how he stands in history.

title: In 'Adam & Steve' a Second Chance for Lovers After a Disastrous Striptease the First Time Around
description: Who said mainstream Hollywood has a monopoly on dumb, gross-out farces? The gay, independent comedy "Adam & Steve" is as crude and nonsensical as any number of B-list studio equivalents, with the added disadvantages of a low budget and shaky direction by Craig Chester, who wrote and also stars.

title: Bishops Report Decline in Abuse Accusations
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 - A total of 783 new accusations of priests' sexual abuse were received by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops last year, with about 13 percent of the cases dating from 1990 or later, the bishops reported Thursday.

title: Lobby Reform Lite
description: With the ghost of Jack Abramoff, the recently sentenced rogue lobbyist, wafting above the debate, the Senate has voted for a halfhearted package of reforms that would come nowhere near curing the easy money, quid pro quo culture that now bedevils the Capitol.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, SHELLEY W.
description: STEIN--Shelley W., 90. Formerly of Scarsdale, New York, died peacefully in Pittsburgh, PA on March 29, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Ruth B. Stein. Devoted father of Carol (Michael) Bleier of Mt. Lebanon, PA & Elaine Stein-Cummins (Daniel Cummins) of Chestnut Hill, MA. Brother of Serena Winer of New Orleans, LA, the late Beatrice Gilbert & Denton Stein. Grandfather of Tom (Victoria Frenkel) Bleier, Lisa (Rodney Tanner) Bleier, Mark (Darlene) Bleier and Daniel (Jennifer) Primack. Also survived by eight greatgrandchildren. Graveside service at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, 80 Commerce Street, Hawthorne, New York, 9 AM, Sunday April 2. Contributions may be made to American Heart Association or American Cancer Society. For info Ralph Schugar Chapel, Inc., Pittsburgh, PA (1 - 888 621-8282).

title: INSIDE
description: Bush in Talks on Legalizing Migrants in the U.S. At the Chichn Itz ruins near Cancn, Mexico, President Bush took a break from talks with Canada's prime minister, Stephen Harper, left, and his host, President Vicente Fox. Immigration was the theme. PAGE A8

description: WASHINGTON, March 30  A total of 783 new accusations of priests' sexual abuse were received by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops last year, with about 13 percent of the cases dating from 1990 or later, the bishops reported Thursday.

title: Pataki and Budget Chief Open Up on Legislators' Plan
description: ALBANY, March 30 - Gov. George E. Pataki and his budget director said in interviews on Thursday that they had reservations about the two central initiatives of the Legislature's budget, calling a nearly $1.8 billion property tax cut package unconstitutional and saying a bonding deal for New York City schools would set a bad precedent in the use of state debt.

title: Clothes That Fit the Woman, Not the Store
description: It is a noble pursuit that has long eluded the clothing industry: a standardized sizing system that would allow consumers to navigate the frustrating world of off-the-rack apparel, where size varies from retailer to retailer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDENSTEIN, FERDIN
description: FREUDENSTEIN -- Ferdin and. Higgins Professor of Mechanical Engineering at Columbia University, husband of Lydia, father of David and Joan, brother of Eric, Elsa Michaels, and Greta Wimpfheimer, and grandfather of Sophia and Eliyahu; beloved and revered by the whole family. Services Friday, March 31, 10AM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. Shiva at home of deceased through Wednesday, April 5.

title: Chirac Presses On With Divisive Labor Law
description: PARIS, March 31  Facing down the most united nationwide protests of his presidency, French President Jacques Chirac declared today that he would implement a divisive new labor law and demanded that angry student and trade union leaders begin constructive talks with the government rather than mobilizing more people in the streets.

title: Searching Margaritaville for the Perfect Key Lime Pie
description: TRAVELERS come to the Florida Keys for the sun, the sand and the scenery of America gone Caribbean. They come for bone-fishing in the morning, margaritas at midday and sunset celebrations at dusk. And before it's time to depart, everybody wants a piece of Key lime pie.

title: Retired F.B.I. Agent Is Accused of Role in Killings
description: When R. Lindley DeVecchio, a 65-year-old retired F.B.I. supervisor, stood up in a courtroom in Brooklyn yesterday to face charges that he had helped his prized Mafia informant commit four murders, the tension was clear.

title: Russia Raises Price of Gas for an Ally, Belarus
description: MOSCOW, March 30 - Russia's state-controlled gas monopoly announced Thursday that it would require Belarus, an ally whose economy is subsidized by Russia, to begin paying market prices for natural gas.

It has placed all of the estate, not just the boat, on its list of America's 11 most endangered historic places.

title: Off the Charts: Bear in a bull's costume
Judges Order Release on Bail for Ex-Broker in Enron Case
description: In a surprise move, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in Houston late yesterday ordered that a former Merrill Lynch executive, William Fuhs, be immediately released on bail awaiting final decision on his appeal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAESS, KENNETH R.
description: KAESS--Kenneth R. It was our great good fortune to know Ken Kaess as a friend and colleague over the past 16 years. Ken was so much more than a business partner and confidant, he was a remarkably caring human being who graciously put the needs and concerns of others before his own. In so many ways, he taught us how to live life to the fullest, to take joy in the accomplishments of others, to face the challenges of work and life with an indomitable spirit, and to look even the toughest problem straight in the eye and face it with courage and confidence. His spirit inspired us to the end. We will sorely miss him and fondly remember the joy he brought to our lives. Keith, Rose-Lee, Geoff, Rachel and Lizzie Reinhard

title: Sierra Leone Asks to Move Liberian's Trial
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 30  The government of Sierra Leone asked the International Criminal Court in the Netherlands to provide a venue for the trial of Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia who was arrested Wednesday on longstanding war crimes charges, officials in the Netherlands said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Ex-Detective Sentenced For Rapes
description: A former New York City police detective has been sentenced to five years in state prison for sexually assaulting three girls between the ages of 11 and 13 at a Yonkers hotel last year, the Westchester district attorney, Janet DiFiore, said yesterday. Last month, the former detective, Brian Tuitt, 39, pleaded guilty to raping and abusing the three girls at the hotel, the Royal Regency, in February 2005. The mother of one of the girls had been staying at the hotel on business and asked Mr. Tuitt, a close family friend, to look after them, prosecutors said. Mr. Tuitt, a member of the department's cyberspace patrol team, whose job was to track down pedophiles, has also pleaded guilty to similar charges involving at least five other girls in the Bronx and Orange County. ANAHAD O'CONNOR (NYT)

title: Lawyers for Lacrosse Players Dispute Accusations
description: DURHAM, N.C., March 30 - Lawyers representing players on the Duke lacrosse team attacked the account of the woman who accused the players of raping her, and said Thursday that the players would be acquitted when DNA tests were analyzed and other details of the investigation emerged.

description: ROME, March 30 - The room spilled over with foreign reporters curious to see Romano Prodi up close, and one went so far as to refer to him as the "probable" next leader of Italy.

description: With the consequences of a state law that bars strikes by public employees still resonating after the transit strike in December, labor leaders appeared at City Hall yesterday to condemn the law as unfair to workers and an impediment to collective bargaining.

title: John McGahern, Chronicler of Irish Rural Life, Dies at 71
description: John McGahern, whose stark depiction of love and despair in repressive rural Ireland made him one of his country's most acclaimed fiction writers, died yesterday in Dublin. He was 71.

description: A pregnant woman who was found dead on Thursday night was stabbed to death, possibly by her male companion and his ex-wife after a dispute over money, the police said today.

title: Massachusetts Court Limits Gay Unions
description: BOSTON, March 30 - Massachusetts's highest court, which legalized same-sex marriage here two and a half years ago, ruled Thursday that gay couples who live in states where such marriages are prohibited cannot marry in Massachusetts.

title: Arrow Points to the Jump Ball's Demise
description: The first basketball game ever played began with a jump ball, tossed in the air by James Naismith in 1891. Decades later, when the rules were altered to eliminate the jump ball after every basket, Naismith lamented the change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERGMANN, THERESE G.
description: BERGMANN--Therese G. Loving wife of the late Paul and devoted mother of Peter, Steven and Ronald, died peacefully at home in her beloved New York City. Born in Graz, Hungary, she was an education activist, consumer and community board advocate, member of Cancer Care and the Council of Jewish Women. She leaves her three sons, daughters-in-law, and six grandchildren, Rachel, David, Maggie, Paul, Caroline and Joseph. She will be missed by her family and friends. Services are Friday, March 31, at 11 AM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to Fort Tryon Jewish Center, 524 Fort Washington Ave, NY NY 10033, or Beth Israel Medical Center, 16th St and 1st Avenue, NY NY 10003.

title: Lisa Kron's 'Well' Opens on Broadway, With Mom Keeping Watch
description: FANS of that beleaguered literary form, the memoir, can breathe a little more easily this morning. Lisa Kron's sparkling autobiographical play "Well" has arrived on Broadway, where it opened last night at the Longacre Theater, to restore the honor of a genre that was slipping into disgrace even before Oprah Winfrey ran James Frey through a shredder on national television.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Wednesday showing parishes and schools affected by the reorganization plans of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misidentified one Bronx parish and school scheduled for closing and gave an erroneous identification from archdiocesan officials for a Manhattan parish set to close, with its church officially becoming a chapel. The Bronx parish and school are St. Anthony's at 4505 Richardson Avenue, not St. Anthony's at 1496 Commonwealth Avenue. The church that would be downgraded to a chapel is Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary, at 307 East 33rd Street, not the Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus at 457 West 51st Street. A revised version of the map is linked online at nytimes.com/corrections.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jets To Build New Headquarters
description: The New York Jets have reached an agreement to build its new corporate headquarters and training complex in Florham Park, officials said yesterday. The new complex will be situated on 20 acres of a 420-acre site along Park Avenue. The team's offices are expected to be completed in the summer of 2007. The team agreed to the move in a deal to share a new Meadowlands stadium with the Giants, scheduled to open in 2009. RICHARD G. JONES (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about President Bush's selection of Joshua B. Bolten, his budget director, to succeed Andrew H. Card Jr. as the White House chief of staff referred incorrectly to the aide Mr. Bush was discussing when he said, "He thought it might be time to return to private life." It was Mr. Card, not Mr. Bolten.

title: Bush Reassures Mexico Leader of His Backing for Immigrants
description: CANCN, Mexico, March 30  President Bush, in an effort to reassure Mexicans and to defuse an intense debate in the United States, told President Vicente Fox of Mexico on Thursday that he supported proposals to legalize undocumented workers as long as they were not given any advantages over immigrants who entered the United States legally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OTT, HOWARD
description: OTT--Howard. Died March 28, 2006. Devoted husband and cherished father and grandfather. Adored uncle, nephew and cousin; trusted and admired friend. He leaves behind a beautiful wife Gloria, beloved children, Randi, Glenn and Seth, daughterin-law Kim and grandchildren Andrew, Tracy, Jonathan, Jordan and Ryan. He will always be in our hearts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Fatal Stabbing
description: A 25-year-old man was fatally stabbed in Bedford-Stuyvesant last night around 10 p.m., the police said. The victim was taken from 412 Pulaski Street, where the stabbing occurred, to Woodhull Hospital and pronounced dead on arrival. There have been no arrests. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Ferry Capsizes Off Bahrain; At Least 57 Dead
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Friday, March 31 - A Bahraini ferry boat with about 130 people on board capsized during a dinner cruise near Manama, the island country's capital, late on Thursday night, killing at least 48 people, the Bahraini Interior Ministry said.

title: New H.I.V. Cases Reported to Drop In Southern India
description: In a rare piece of good news about AIDS, the prevalence of new H.I.V. infections has fallen significantly in southern India, the region of that country where the disease has occurred most often, scientists reported yesterday.

title: His Close-Up Here, Larranaga Is All Smiles

Metro Briefing | New York: Child Welfare Computer Breaks Down
description: The computerized case-management system used by the Administration for Children's Services has had several breakdowns, making it difficult or impossible for caseworkers to update or read files on abused and neglected children. The breakdowns, which were reported last night by WNBC-TV, affect a state-run computer system, Connections, that has long had problems. The latest version was installed in October; the breakdowns began in the past week as workers tried to fix problems. "We are doing all we can to get the State of New York to fix the system permanently and to provide New York City with direct access to monitor and manage our own data," said the commissioner of children's services, John B. Mattingly, last night.

title: Duke's Playoff Picture: Don't Write It Off Just Yet
description: The Duke men's lacrosse team has had its season suspended and its national championship hopes put on hold pending a police investigation into allegations of a rape involving members of the team. But the Blue Devils, who lost in the national-title game last season, could still compete for an Atlantic Coast Conference title and an N.C.A.A. championship this spring.

(The errors also appeared in articles about the crash on Friday and Saturday.) Mr. Kovar was 77, not 67, and Mrs. Kovar was 74, not 71.

title: Rice Faces Cancellations and Catcalls on British Visit
description: BLACKBURN, England, March 31 A Jack Straw, the British foreign secretary, invited his friend Condoleezza Rice, the secretary of state, home for the weekend to see a soccer match, in return for his visit last fall to Birmingham, Ala., where he watched a college football game. But just before Ms. Rice arrived, the Blackburn Rovers rescheduled their match for Monday night, to maximize the television audience.

title: A Phone Call From Prison Roils Trial of Ex-Detectives
description: A disembodied voice from Colorado threw the trial of two retired detectives into temporary turmoil yesterday, as the jailed gangster who had once accused them of murder turned about and, their lawyers said, pronounced them innocent of some of the charges.

description: HALPERN - Harry. Three years have flown by. You are at rest, lying next to our son, Joel. Miss you so very much. Sylvia

title: The Worrier
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on March 23 about the conviction of an Army dog handler, Sgt. Michael J. Smith, in connection with abuses at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq referred incorrectly in some copies to the period during which the Army has conducted more than 600 criminal investigations into accusations of detainee abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan. It has been since October 2001 -- not 2002.

title: Panel on Judicial Conduct Decides to Remove Spargo
description: The New York Commission on Judicial Conduct said today that it had decided to remove a New York Supreme Court justice who had solicited tens of thousands of dollars in contributions from lawyers to help pay his legal bills.

title: Gay-Themed Film Gives Closet Door a Tug
description: SEOUL, South Korea  "King and the Clown" lacked a single top star from South Korea's booming film industry, or the other usual ingredients of a surefire blockbuster.

title: Web fakes off market
Digital Divide Closing asBlacks Turn to Internet
description: African-Americans are steadily gaining access to and ease with the Internet, signaling a remarkable closing of the "digital divide" that many experts had worried would be a crippling disadvantage in achieving success.

title: Answering Calls From Inside the Towers
description: The following are selected excerpts from the recordings released today by the New York City officials. The recordings are of 911 operators and Fire Department dispatchers handling emergency calls from people inside the World Trade Center on the morning of Sept. 11. The recordings, from both of the twin towers and at various times across the 102 minutes from the first plane strike to the final building collapse, are only of one side of the conversation.

title: Preventable Disease Blinds Poor in Third World
description: ALEMBER, Ethiopia  Mare Alehegn lay back nervously on the metal operating table, her heart visibly pounding beneath her sackcloth dress, and clenched her fists as the paramedic sliced into her eyelid. Repeated infections had scarred the undersides of her eyelids, causing them to contract and forcing her lashes in on her eyes. For years, each blink felt like thorns raking her eyeballs. She had plucked the hairs with crude tweezers, but the stubble grew back sharper still.

title: Meanwhile: Under the full moon, India defies categories
Alcatel-Thales talks complicate Lucent deal
Phoenix Dance Theater Performs at Montclair State
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 29 - The Phoenix Dance Theater rose from the gray ash of the industrial city of Leeds, England, a quarter of a century ago and quickly became a staple of the British modern-dance scene, building an international repertory. Darshan Singh Bhuller, a young Indian-born dancer with the prestigious London Contemporary Dance Theater, was named its director four years ago. At Montclair, the start of a United States tour, this company of wonderfully lithe and personable young dancers is presenting two pieces by Mr. Bhuller, one by Henry Oguike and one by Robert Cohan, a mentor to Mr. Bhuller and to countless British choreographers and dancers.

title: Spain Moves on Law to Give Broad Powers to Catalonia
description: MADRID, March 30  After hours of occasionally bitter debate, the lower house of Parliament agreed Thursday to grant broad new powers of self-government to the wealthy northeastern region of Catalonia.

title: Conflicts of Interest, or Right for the Job?
description: AT the outset, let's clear up one matter that will have a major impact on the steroid investigation that Commissioner Bud Selig announced yesterday.

title: Women go 'missing,' French labor protests, After Israel's election

BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Prominent Money Manager Loses a Ruling In a Lawsuit Accusing Him of Cheating Backers Mario J. Gabelli's first investor won a crucial round in a long-running legal battle over whether Mr. Gabelli, the money manager, bilked him and another backer out of more than $100 million. A judge filed a summary judgment against Mr. Gabelli, determining that he unfairly prevented the two investors from selling their shares in his private company. [Page C1.]

title: Republicans Go on Attack, but the Target Is Pataki
description: Weak. Moribund. Unprincipled. Corrupt.

title: Japan sees bloom
HAVENS | Desert Hot Springs, Calif.; Near Palm Springs, A Little City Thinks Big
description: AS you head north out of Palm Springs, Calif., late on a sunny afternoon, the rumpled brown foothills a dozen miles away cast long shadows. The houses sprinkled on those hills, part of the rapidly growing city of Desert Hot Springs, look as if they were taking a nap in the folds of a cozy old blanket.

title: Bush Reassures Mexico Leader of His Backing for Immigrants
description: CANCN, Mexico, March 30 - President Bush, in an effort to reassure Mexicans and to defuse an intense debate in the United States, told President Vicente Fox of Mexico on Thursday that he supported proposals to legalize undocumented workers as long as they were not given any advantages over immigrants who entered the United States legally.

title: Goodbye Dolly: Up From Sheep to Cloned Horses
description: Royal Blue Boon was a champion and big money-earner in the equine calf-herding sport known as cutting. Comes now her genetic knock-off: Royal Blue Boon Too, whose birth last month was, her creators say, the start of commercial horse cloning.

title: City Releases Tapes of 911 Calls From Sept. 11 Attack
description: The city released partial recordings today of about 130 telephone calls made to 911 after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, stripped of the voices of the people inside the World Trade Center but still evocative of their invisible struggles for life.

title: Europe and the legend of secularization
Bomber Kills 3 Israelis as Hamas Takes Power
description: JERUSALEM, March 30  A Palestinian suicide bomber, possibly disguised as an observant Jew, blew himself up at a gas station in the West Bank on Thursday evening, turning a car into a fireball and killing three Israelis inside the vehicle, Israeli news reports said.

title: Ferry Capsizes Off Bahrain; 48 Are Killed and 63 Rescued
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Friday, March 31  A Bahraini ferry boat with about 130 people on board capsized during a dinner cruise near Manama, the island country's capital, late on Thursday night, killing at least 48 people, the Bahraini Interior Ministry said.

description: Critics who say the private insurance industry got too big a role in the new Medicare prescription drug program may not know the half of it.

description: THE hedge fund industry has its fair share of complaints about news coverage, but one issue that particularly irks managers and that can be easily remedied is a frequently employed two-word description: lightly regulated.

title: Overfarming African Land Is Worsening Hunger Crisis
description: The degradation of farmland across sub-Saharan Africa has accelerated at an ominous rate over the past decade, deepening a hunger crisis that already afflicts more than 240 million Africans, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Bitterly divided panel debates Bush censure
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Governor Suspends Fund Payments
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine suspended payments yesterday from a multimillion-dollar discretionary fund used by lawmakers after a Cranford lawyer sued, claiming the money was being used improperly. The lawyer, David W. Robinson, filed the suit in State Superior Court saying the state failed to properly administer $128 million in grants that go to businesses and municipalities. Payments of the remaining $20 million have been halted pending a review. RICHARD G. JONES (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a visit by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld to Shanksville, Pa., where passengers of Flight 93 overpowered their hijackers on Sept. 11, 2001, and crashed the airliner into the countryside, referred imprecisely to the plane's intended target in Washington. Although investigations have pointed to the Capitol as the most likely target, no definitive evidence exists to confirm that theory.

title: College Admission Angst Finds a Forum on Web
description: "Help!!!" screamed one of the messages posted by a high school student this week on the Web site www.collegeconfidential.com. Another said: "Desperately need help choosing college!!! Need advice please read!!! Can't sleep!!!" And pennylane01, on her blog, wrote: "Thank you O powerful (and treacherous) college gods for nothing but my current state of depression and anxiousness. I can't thank you enough."

title: Arts, Briefly; Mayor Mike B. Beams On Hip-Hop Gig for 212
description: Despite an effort by Los Angeles to lure it away, VH1 has decided to keep the third annual VH1 Hip Hop Honors in New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, far right, announced yesterday. "Welcome to City Hall, or my crib, as I call it," the mayor said at a morning news conference with Russell Simmons, center right, the hip-hop impresario, and Ice-T, near right, the actor and rap artist who will be the host of the ceremony, in October, . "Hip-hop was born in the South Bronx through artists like Grand Master Flash, and every borough has a hand in the music's development," the mayor said. "From Queens have come groups like Run DMC; from Staten Island, the Wu Tang Clan; from Brooklyn, the Beastie Boys, Mike D; and from Manhattan, well -- you've got me, Mike B." Mr. Simmons endorsed the mayor last year during his campaign for re-election. "He's a good role model for a lot of us," the mayor said. "He is a successful entrepreneur, he is a bold trendsetter, a force in the community, a guy who has real opinions and is willing to fight for them." The third annual VH1 Hip Hop Honors ceremony will be taped on Oct. 7 in the Hammerstein Ballroom at Manhattan Center Studios and will be broadcast on Oct. 17.

title: EU grants Serbia reprieve
New Directors/New Films Festival Reviews; My Country, My Country
description: The New Directors/New Films festival concludes its 35th edition with two French and four American films, several fresh from the Sundance Film Festival. Today through Sunday, there are also encore screenings of the selections "Pavee Lackeen," "First on the Moon," "Still World," "Texas" and "Into Great Silence"; also playing today are the documentaries "Witness to War," "The Ties That Bind" and "Who Killed Vincent Chin?" More information, including ticket availability, is at www.filmlinc.com.

title: Dozens drown in Bahrain boat accident
Steroid Investigation Begins, but Not Without Some Concerns
description: With a new baseball season days away, Commissioner Bud Selig yesterday named George J. Mitchell, the former Senate majority leader, to lead an investigation into what appears to be the sport's long, and troubling, involvement with steroids.

title: U.S. Asks European Union to Be Fair in Microsoft Case
description: BRUSSELS, March 30 - The United States government has intervened in Microsoft's antitrust dispute with the European Commission, urging it and the 25 national governments in the European Union to be fair to the company, American diplomats and European officials said on Thursday.

title: Former DeLay Aide Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 A A onetime top aide to Representative Tom DeLay, the former House Republican majority leader, pleaded guilty to conspiracy today and agreed to cooperate in a widening investigation into lobbying fraud and influence-peddling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRSCH, JOAN GIVEN
description: KIRSCH--Joan Given. Age 84, wife of the late Robert J. Kirsch, died peacefully at Brighton Gardens, assistedliving facility in Middletown, N.J. She was an avid golfer and bridge player in her residences in Westfield, N.J., New Suffolk, L.I., N.Y., and Yarmouthport Cape Cod, MA. She is survived by a daughter Nancy G. Erdman of Middletown, N.J., a son Robert M. Kirsch of Norwell, Ma. She is also survived by five grandchildren: John, Lisa, Kimberly, Tracy and Kristin and two great grandchildren, Jackson and Chase. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to VNA of Central Jersey Hospice Program, 141 Bodman Place, Red Bank, N.J. 07701.

description: NEW ORLEANS, March 30  The F.B.I. office here will look into possible improprieties in the distribution of millions of dollars' worth of Red Cross relief supplies, the bureau's New Orleans chief said Thursday.

title: Police in New Jersey Hunt for Missing College Student
description: Police from southern New Jersey are searching two landfills in Bucks County, Pa., for clues to the disappearance of a 19-year-old college freshman who went missing on Saturday.

title: 4th-Quarter Growth Put at 1.7%
description: Energy costs now take up more than 6 percent of household spending in the United States, up from 4.2 percent just a few years ago, the Commerce Department reported yesterday as it released the final revision of economic growth statistics for the fourth quarter of last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROEDER, GEORGE A. JR.
description: ROEDER--George A. Jr. Retired Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Chase Manhattan Bank, March 28 at the age of 85. He joined the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1947, and was named Vice Chairman in 1969, a position in which he served until his retirement in 1982. He and his late wife, Anne Connor, were married for 54 years. A long time resident of Madison, NJ, he leaves a sister, Virginia, of Sebring, FL, a son Russell of Mechanicsburg, PA, daughter Jane of New York City, and three grandsons, Matthew, Andrew and Evan. Burroughs, Kohr & Dangler Funeral Home, 106 Main Street, Madison, NJ.

title: 36 Hours in St. Louis
description: ST. Louis has undergone a remarkable transformation since 1972, when the spectacular demolition of its high-rise Pruitt-Igoe housing project became an indelible symbol of urban decline. Young professionals drawn to new biotech and medical research industries, as well as a new wave of immigrants from places like Bosnia, are bringing new life to neighborhoods that last thrived a century ago. New loft districts, old civic jewels and revitalized night life are making the old refrain of "Meet Me in St. Louis" a welcome phrase again. LARRY FRIEDMAN

title: Gay-Themed Film Gives Closet Door a Tug
description: SEOUL, South Korea - "King and the Clown" lacked a single top star from South Korea's booming film industry, or the other usual ingredients of a surefire blockbuster.

title: A battle for hearts and mouths
New Strain on Duke's Ties With Durham
description: DURHAM, N.C., March 30 - Francis Conlin says that he is a pretty sound sleeper, but that his wife is often jarred awake by the raucous noise spilling from one of the frequent and teeming student parties in their neighborhood beside the East Campus of Duke University.

title: Care for Juveniles Is Extended 30 Days
description: The city's Department of Juvenile Justice and the New Jersey company that provides medical care to more than 400 troubled children in the agency's custody agreed on Wednesday to a 30-day contract extension, a department spokesman said. The agreement averted a potentially chaotic disruption in medical care, as the company's three-year, $10.5 million contract was set to expire today, with no alternative provider in place.

title: Long-Awaited Medical Study Questions the Power of Prayer
description: Prayers offered by strangers had no effect on the recovery of people who were undergoing heart surgery, a large and long-awaited study has found.

title: New York International Children's Film Festival Goes Year-Round
description: A complete hush settled over the darkened room; even popcorn crunching ceased.

title: Pierre Clostermann Dies at 85; Ace French Pilot in World War II
description: Pierre Clostermann, an ace fighter pilot who flew for de Gaulle's Free French forces in World War II, engaging in fierce combat in the Battle of Britain and over Normandy on D-Day, died March 22 at his home in Montesquieu des Albres in southwestern France. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TENNEY, DANIEL G., JR.
description: TENNEY--Daniel G., Jr. Of Locust Valley, N.Y. died peacefully on March 28, 2006 at age 92. Beloved husband of Constance Franchot Tenney, his wife of 66 years, he was the devoted father of Constance Rafle, Pamela Simpson, Alexandra Potts and Daniel G. Tenney III. Grandfather of nine and great grandfather of four. A graduate of the Choate School (1931), Yale College (1935) and Yale Law School (1938), he had a long and wonderful career at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Boys Club of New York or Trout Unlimited.

title: People: Naomi Campbell, Sir Tom Jones, Matt LeBlanc
Fee Foreseen at 9/11 Museum
description: New York City cannot afford to support the operation of the World Trade Center memorial museum, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday, suggesting that an admission fee would be necessary.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Letter from Indonesia: Hammer isn't enough to buy their mine rights
Levee Plans Fall Short of FEMA Standards
description: New Orleans's levees do not meet the standards that the Federal Emergency Management Agency requires for its flood protection program, federal officials said yesterday -- and they added that the problem would take as much as $6 billion to fix.

title: Gun Battles Follow Killing of Militant in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, March 31  A Palestinian militant was killed today when a bomb destroyed his car in Gaza City, and colleagues of the dead man accused the Palestinian security forces of involvement. The allegation set off gun battles in which three more Palestinians died.

title: Test Day and the Stress of a Ticking Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Slide Show: In Darfur, a History of Violence
description: Since 2003, the systematic killing of civilians in the Darfur region of Sudan has shocked the world's conscience. And yet the people of Darfur have also suffered the world's neglect.

title: On the Market
description: A look at five properties for sale in the New York region.

title: Young Lawyers, Big Salaries
description: After years of stagnating, salaries for associates at law firms are on fire. Every week seems to bring a new report of a firm, or a whole posse of firms, sweetening associates pay in order to, well, keep up with all the other law firms. It is beginning to look a little like the real estate market, except the targets of the bidding wars are heavily indebted law-school graduates instead of colonial-style McMansions.

title: Slide Show: Pulse
description:
As clocks spring ahead,
wardrobes also spring
ahead to warmer climes
and more convivial cuts
and fabrications.

title: Garage Technology Creates New Seed Fund
description: Garage Technology Ventures, a seed- and early-stage venture fund, said Thursday that it had created a new fund, which was led by Thomas Weisel Global Growth Partners. In addition to Weisel, other investors in Palo Alto-based Garage Technology Ventures I include Draper Fisher Jurvetson, Silicon Valley Bank and E-Trade.

title: Consortium Said to Be Near Deal for Enron International Assets
description: A group of private equity and hedge fund managers appear to be near to buying the international assets of Enron for close to $2 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported. The group includes London emerging markets fund manager Ashmore Investment Management Ltd. and American hedge funds D.E. Shaw and Eton Park Capital Management.

title: VNU Shareholders Readying to Reject $10.3 billion Bid
description: Shareholders of VNU are expected to reject a buyout attempt by a private equity consortium, derailing what could have been one of Europes largest-ever leveraged buyouts.

title: Colgate Said to Want Entire Pfizer Unit
description: Colgate-Palmolive may offer to buy Pfizers entire consumer-products unit, not just the Listerine brand, when bidding opens today, Bloomberg reported. Colgate will be among at least four companies making offers for the $3.88 billion-a-year division, which also sells Sudafed cold medicine and Visine eyewash.

title: Striving for Success
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Is Vonage Shopping Itself Around?
description: Can Vonage parlay its increased consumer exposure into a lucrative initial public offering? Or is the company, which is hemorrhaging money, actually trying to shop itself to a larger telecom firm?

title: South Korea Raids Lone Star Office
description: Prosecutors investigating allegations of tax evasion and embezzlement conducted a raid Thursday on the Seoul office of an American investment company, Lone Star Funds, which bought a controlling stake in a Korean bank three years ago.

title: Sale of  GMAC Stake May Not Restore Its Status
description: The financial challenges for General Motors GMAC finance unit may not go away, even if a majority stake in the operation is sold, as is widely expected.

title: Watchmaker Tourneau Puts Itself on the Block
description: Taking advantage of the booming market for luxury watches, timepiece maker Tourneau, which also sells such luxury brands as Cartier and Patek Philippe, has put itself up for sale, The New York Post reported. The New York-based retailer is in talks to be acquired by an unidentified private-equity firm for about $250 million.

title: Goldman Back in Googles Good Graces (And Its Offering)
description: Goldman Sachs, twice snubbed by Google, has now been embraced by the Internet darling. The giant investment bank has won a role as the sole underwriter in Googles latest stock offering, which could raise more than $2 billion in cash for the search engine.

title: Who Is Burger Kings I.P.O. Serving?
description: Burger Kings upcoming I.P.O. looks lucrative for the private-equity firms doing the deal. While they make even more cash, the chains long-term debt could hit $1 billion.

title: Guarding  Citadel: A Hedge Fund Story
description: Kenneth Griffin and Edward Lampert have much in common. Both are Ivy Leaguers who started hedge funds in their 20s, and by the time they neared 40 were two of the worlds wealthiest men.

title: Swatting at the Hedge Fund Locusts
description: In the annals of corporate chieftains who have been brought low, the tale of Werner G. Seifert deserves at least a footnote. Now, thanks to Mr. Seiferts own poison-dipped pen, it is getting a whole book.

title: Ex-Merrill Banker  in Enron Barge Case Freed on Bail
description: In a surprise move, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in Houston late yesterday ordered that a former Merrill Lynch executive, William Fuhs, be immediately released on bail awaiting final decision on his appeal. Mr. Fuhs was one of four former Merrill employees convicted in 2004 on fraud and conspiracy charges involving a 1999 sale by Enron of power generators mounted on barges in Nigeria.

title: Boeing-Lockheed Rocket Merger Said to Be in the Works
description: Military officials and government antitrust regulators are completing an agreement that would clear a planned merger of government-rocket businesses run by Boeing Co. and Lockheed Martin Corp., The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Setback for Merrill in a Hiring Dispute
description: James P. Gorman, head of Morgan Stanleys retail brokerage unit, won a reversal Thursday of a court order that had barred him from trying to hire people away from his former employer, Merrill Lynch. He has hired at least three senior Merrill employees since joining Morgan Stanley last month, prompting Merrill to argue that he had violated a noncompete agreement.

title: Court Rules Against Gabelli in Dispute With Early Backers
description: Mario J. Gabellis first investor won a crucial ruling yesterday in a long-running, bitter legal battle over whether Mr. Gabelli bilked him and another backer out of more than $100 million.

title: Shocks Seen in New Math for Pensions
description: The board that writes accounting rules for American business is proposing a new method of reporting pension obligations that is likely to show that many companies have a lot more debt than was obvious before. In some cases, particularly at old industrial companies like automakers, the newly disclosed obligations are likely to be so large that they will wipe out the net worth of the company.

title: Chiron Shareholders Face Deadline on Novartis Bid
description: Shareholders of the troubled vaccine maker Chiron face a crucial vote in the next few days: Sell out to Novartis, or reject the drug makers merger bid and continue to go it alone.

title: Panels Approve Bills About Ports Issues
description: Two Congressional panels approved measures on Thursday in efforts to stem the furor over the attempted takeover of significant terminal operations at some large American ports by Dubai Ports World.

title: Heat-Technology Startup Hyperion Innovates for Dogs
description: Gus, Duke and Fido will be able to keep their paws and underbellies toasty on long car rides or cold nights at home thanks to what Hyperion Innovations is calling the most technologically advanced pet bed in the world. Hyperion, the maker of the Cold Heat soldering tool, is nearing completion of a $2.75 million financing round that it will use to develop even more heat-based products.

title: Judge Questions Clarity of Prosecutions Tax-Shelter Case
description: A federal judge raised questions yesterday about the prosecution of 16 former KPMG employees over aggressive tax shelters, criticizing prosecutors for what he called murky definitions of fraud and evasion.

title: Apple Defends Its Use of Logo on iTunes Store
description: A lawyer for Apple Computer dismissed as ridiculous on Thursday a long-running trademark infringement claim by another cultural icon, the Apple Corps recording label of the Beatles

title: Shareholder Unloads China Life Shares
description: An existing institutional shareholder has sold $125 million worth of China Life Insurance shares in a move to cash in on the strong share price gains in the past four months. Citigroup acted as sole bookrunner for the deal.

title: Millionaire On the Block
description: Who wants to buy a Millionaire? The owner of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? put the worldwide intellectual property rights and the United Kingdom library of programs for the hit quiz show up for sale on Thursday in what television executives said was the first auction of its kind.

title: Bank of America Cleared to Pursue Parmalat Claims
description: A United States judge ruled that Bank of America  may pursue more than $1 billion of fraud claims against Parmalat, the Italian dairy company that collapsed in 2003.

title: U.S. Asks European Union to Be Fair in Microsoft Case
description: The United States government has intervened in Microsofts antitrust dispute with the European Commission, urging it and the 25 national governments in the European Union to be fair to the company, American diplomats and European officials said on Thursday.

title: Citigroup Sued by Australian Regulator for Insider Trading
description: Citigroup is being sued by Australias securities regulator for insider trading while advising Toll Holdings on a A$4.6 billion ($3.3 billion) hostile bid for Patrick Corporation. Shares in Patrick, Australias biggest port cargo handler, surged 13 percent on Aug. 19, the last business day before Toll made its offer.

title: Lay and Skilling to Get Their Day in Court
description: The opening act is finished in what has been billed as the business trial of the century  the governments case against former Enron chiefs  Ken Lay and Jeffrey Skilling. Monday, Act 2 begins.

title: More Subpoenas in Suit Over Obscenity Law
description: Both the Justice Department and the American Civil Liberties Union confirmed yesterday that they had requested and received information from Internet service providers and software makers in connection with an A.C.L.U. lawsuit challenging an anti-pornography law.

title: Are Banks on a Wild Goose Chase in China?
description: As China gets set to throw open its doors to foreign banks by the end of the year, theres a gold rush among global banks to claim their stake in Chinas fast-growing financial services market. But analysts warn that banks in search of riches may find little more than fools gold in China, given the countrys tempestuous regulatory environment, the high cost of entry and the potential for significant loan losses due to the countrys often unstable lending environment.

title: Accused Hedge Fund Manager Now Faces Criminal Charges
description: Kirk Wright , an Atlanta hedge fund manager under suspicion of defrauding a group of investors that included several NFL players, now faces criminal charges in connection with the collapse of funds that investors believed held up to $180 million.

title: LVMH and Morgan Stanley Back in Court
description: LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton and Morgan Stanley will present their cases in the appeals court here today in LVMHs long-running bias suit against the investment bank.

title: Profit Leaps at A.G. Edwards
description: A.G. Edwards on Thursday reported a 60 percentjump in fiscal fourth-quarter 2006 profit, lifted by growth in asset management and service-fee revenue. Robert Bagby, chairman and chief executive of St. Louis-based A.G. Edwards, said it was the first time for the companys fee-based revenue to exceed commission revenue on an annual basis.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Global Crown of Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday charged securities broker and investment adviser Global Crown Capital LLC with fraudulently hiding from investors the trading losses of hedge fund Cogent Capital Management.

title: British Insurer Prepares for July I.P.O.
description: Standard Life intends to go public in July after members vote on its demutualization plans at the end of May, the insurer announced Thursday. Standard life is expected to be worth between 4 billion pounds and 6 billion pounds, and the offering is likely to propel it into the FTSE 100 index.

title: Rosnefts I.P.O. May Have Pitfalls
description: Rosneft, Russias state-owned oil giant, is preparing to sell up to 49 percent of its shares in an initial public offering worth about $20 billion. But while it looks impressive on paper, Rosneft has some skeletons in its closet that may give investors pause.

title: Political Maneuvering  Hindering Alcatel Deals
description: Alcatels bold bid to clinch a telecoms merger with U.S. rival Lucent and simultaneously pull off a satellites deal with defense electronics group Thales has run into some political obstacles, French newspapers said on Friday. The La Tribune and Les Echos newspapers said President Jacques Chirac was refusing to be hurried into approving a deal between Alcatel and Thales, because he wants European defense group EADS involved in any defense electronics tie-up.

title: Ex-Energy Traders to Be Tried Separately
description: Two former natural gas traders scheduled to go to trial together in April will now be tried separately in May. Former Dynegy trader Michelle Valencia and former El Paso trader Greg Singleton were expected to go to trial April 10 for conspiracy and fraud.

title: Income Trust Fever Sweeping Canadas Blue Chips
description: Some of Canadas largest companies, including General Electric Canada Inc., are considering plans to convert divisions into income trusts, setting the stage for a multibillion-dollar wave of blue-chip trust initial public offerings in a market recovering from political uncertainty.

title: Barclays Capital: The Comeback Kid
description: In 1997, Barclays investment banking unit was so marginal that its centuries-old parent, Barclays, dumped most of its businesses, including equities and mergers and acquisitions. Since then, Barclays President Bob Diamond has turned the once-troubled investment banking unit into a powerhouse.

title: Toronto-Dominion Looks South and Licks Its Lips
description: Troubles in the American banking industry could open up acquisition opportunities south of the border for Toronto-Dominion Banks business in the northeastern United States, its chief executive, Ed Clark, said on Thursday.

title: Liberty Puts Hotel Video Unit on the Block
description: John Malones Liberty Media  put its On Command hotel-video unit up for sale and may raise as much as $500 million, Bloomberg News reported. On Command sells pay-per-view movies and video games in more than 1 million rooms in hotels managed by such chains as Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc. and Four Seasons Hotels Inc.

title: Telefonica Receives 7 Bids for Directories Unit
description: Spanish telecom giant Telefnica said Thursday that it has received seven nonbinding offers for its 60 percent stake in its yellow pages unit, Telefnica Publicidad e Informacion SA. The Madrid-based company wants to sell part or all of its stake, which is valued at 1.8 billion euros ($2.1 billion).

title: American  Contenders Seen for British Nuclear Company
description: American contractors are in pole position to take control of Sellafield, Britains most contaminated nuclear site, after the Government gave the green light to a 1 billion pound sale of British Nuclear Group (BNG), the nuclear clean-up company.

title: Approval of Guidant Deal Expected
description: Shareholders are expected to vote overwhelmingly to approve Boston Scientifics proposed $27 billion takeover of Guidant in separate meetings this morning at their headquarters. No major shareholders have publicly opposed the transaction.

title: Wilbur Ross  in First Gear in Auto Parts
description: Six months after gambling on his hunch that the auto-parts industry is ripe for consolidation,  Wilbur Ross says his acquisition spree has only just begun.

title: Londons Cold Shoulder Froze Nasdaq
description: Nasdaq did not cite a reason for pulling its $4.1 billion bid for the London Stock Exchange off the table, but several executives involved in talks between the exchanges said that the London exchanges stock price had risen too high for Nasdaq, and that London executives had given Nasdaq a very chilly reception.

title: Apax Group Walks Away From ITV After Second Rejection
description: A buyout consortium led by Apax Partners Worldwide  and Blackstone Group  said Friday that it would drop its bid to acquire ITV, Britains second-largest broadcaster. The decision came soon after ITV rejected a second, sweetened takeover offer from the group, calling it too risky and too low. The offer valued the company at 5.37 billion pounds ($9.34 billion).

title: Moussaoui Trial Exposes F.B.I. Weakness
description: Jeffrey A. Taylor at Reason Online provides a noteworthy perspective that cuts through the histrionics of the Zacharias Moussaoui trial, warning that readers should not linger on Moussaouis bizarre suicide-by-testimony or the literal cheerleading for his execution. Neither of these is the real story of this case, Taylor writes. The take-home message is that the F.B.I. uniquely and repeatedly punted carefully gathered evidence of an attack in favor of adherence to bureaucratic hierarchies and power trips. Such criticism in a libertarian publication makes that of partisan Democrats look tame:Instead of an effective anti-terror agency, the Bureau is morphing into a kind of Stasi Lite, keeping tabs on domestic subversives: assorted peaceniks, communists in Texas, and the League of Women Voters in Michigan, who had the gall to invite a critic of the PATRIOT Act to a panel discussion. There is a sort of logic to such surveillance: This what the FBI is good at, so this is what it does. Kinda of like looking for your car keys under a street light because the rest of the street is dark.

title: Delphi Asks Court to Scrap Union Pacts
description: In what has increasingly been seen as the inevitable next step in Delphis tortured labor negotiations, the auto-parts maker said on Friday that it had asked a bankruptcy judge to void its contracts with union workers.

Selborne Journal: 31 March 1759:  Planted groups of Sweet-Williams in the border under the rod-hedge down the Shrubbery. Put half barrow more of loam to each Cantaleupe-Hill. Bed very mild. Finished a bastion, & Haha, fenced with sharpned piles, in the vista from Bakers Hill to the Great mead: & a conical mount, about six feet diameter at top, 7 five high, at the bottom of the great mead. Mount about eight days work; Haha about sixteen. Fierce frost, & vast hoar-frost on the Grass: the ground continued very hard, & icy all day in the shade.

title: Ethanol Makers File For I.P.O.s as Sector Gets Hot
description: Just how hot is ethanol? Consider that two producers of the alternative fuel filed for initial public offerings on the same day Thursday. While the proposed I.P.O.s are small  they hope to raise a maximum of $200 million between them  they reflect the mounting buzz surrounding this plant-derived fuel.

title: In France: A Day of Reckoning
description: When asked in the 1950s what he thought of the French Revolution, Chinese Prime Minister Zhou Enlai famously responded that it was too soon to say.

title: From Lab to Table
description: (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times).

title: Welcome to City Hal
description: (Josh Benson for The New York Times)

title: The Cost of Victory?
description: Cory Booker has been picking up endorsements left and right, both before the mayor dropped out and since. But institutional support, while helpful during a campaign, also comes with a set of demands  especially here in Newark, where patronage and quid pro quo are the ways things are done.

title: Immigration and the American Way
description: Readers respond to Paul Krugmans Mar. 31 column, The Road to Dubai

title: Iraq: Time is of the Essence
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans March 31 column, Iraq at the 11th Hour

title: Odds and Ends
description: Lighting strikes twice: The comments submitted in response to the recent post about lighting reveal sharp differences of opinion about how important lighting is  and about what constitutes good lighting.

title: Analyst Named in Biovail Lawsuit Drops Coverage
description: A research analyst swept up in a legal battle between Biovail and hedge fund giant SAC Capital has withdrawn his coverage of the pharmaceuticals company.

title: Roosevelt Island Luxury
description: The Octagon, a luxury rental building on Roosevelt Island in New York, is slated to open in two weeks. Theres a dizzying list of amenities, from on-site childcare to curved shower rod providing more spacious shower area. The press release also touts this tantalizing high-tech lure: warp-speed Internet access.

title: Cold reaction to freezing engines
description: The Formula One of the post 2007 era is finally taking shape. Friday, the International Automobile Federation announced it had received applications from 22 teams for the championship that begins in 2008, and there are only 12 spots to be filled. That makes it sound like a resounding success.

title: Paulson Melts Snow Talk, and More From Goldman Meeting
description: It was a busy day for Goldman Sachss chief executive, Henry Paulson Jr., who held court at his firms annual meeting Friday in New York.

title: Boffo Box in San Fran
description: Street Fight is still hot  outside of Newark.

title: Some High-Profile REITs
description: In yet another sign that real estate investment trusts are moving further into the investment mainstream, Standard & Poors announced this week that it is adding two REITs to the S&P 500 Index.

title: Newark '06: Booker Woos Churches
description: The Times's Damien Cave takes a look at  mayoral candidate Cory Booker's efforts to win over Newark's churches. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: Bush Plays the Same Old Hand
description: Andrew H. Card Jr. and President Bush yesterday at White House. (Jason Reed/Reuters)

title: The $80 Million Question
description: Cory Booker said today that the next mayor will inherit a city on the verge of financial crisis if the $80 million redevelopment organizations set up a few weeks ago by Mayor Sharpe James and the Municipal Council are not rescinded.

title: Hedge Fund Pay Dirt: Who Earned The Most in 2005?
description: Sports Illustrated has the swimsuit issue, and Trader Monthly has the 100.

title: Kristof: The Courage of Mukhtar Mai
description: Nicholas D. Kristof visits a peasant woman in Pakistan, who, with the help of international donors, has created a haven for women and schoolgirls.

title: Live Action Simpsons
description: This one is amazing, amazing, amazing: Its a *live-action* video of The Simpsons opening-credits sequence. (Even the incidental characters standing on the sidewalk are right.)Never let them tell you the Internet is a waste of time.

title: Police Endorse Booker
description: Cory Bookers transformation from insurgent to establishment figure continues. The Fraternal Order of Police in Newark voted today to endorse Mr. Booker, throwing its weight behind the young upstart even though his opponent, State Senator Ronald L. Rice, is a former officer and Vietnam veteran whose law enforcement experience is among his proudest accomplishments.
